column2: Insurance representatives in lower Manhattan completed yesterday contributions of blood to the Red Cross for the armed forces and local needs, amounting to 1,250 pints in five days.

Volume V of "The Army Air Forces in World War II: The Pacific -- Matterhorn to Nagasaki, June, 1944, to August, 1945" is one of two books published today. The history was prepared under the editorship of Wesley Frank Craven and James Lea Cate by the U. S. A. F. Historical Division of Research Studies.

MOSCOW, Saturday, April 18 -- The Soviet Union has decided to accentuate the positive and in general terms ignore the negative, so far as President Eisenhower's speech is concerned, comment in the Moscow newspapers appeared to indicate.

The often-criticized McCarran Act was praised yesterday -- at least, for its naturalization provisions -- by immigration officials and other experts in the field. They said it had liberalized the means by which aliens residing here can acquire United States citizenship.

MEXICO CITY, April 17 -- The International Olympic Committee went into closed session late today to begin its debate on whether or not to confirm the Australian city of Melbourne as host for the 1956 games.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., April 17 -- Four Burlington City police officers, two New Jersey state troopers and a former county detective chief were named today in indictments charging false swearing before the Burlington County grand jury. The panel ended a fourteen-month inquiry yesterday into charges of official corruption by returning seventeen indictments.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The Treasury got about $5,500,000,000 of subscriptions to the offering this week of a $1,000,000,000 bond issue that will run thirty years an pay 3 1/4 per cent interest.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 17 (UP) -- United States Marines will stage a mock atomic attack by helicopter tomorrow when another top-secret nuclear device is exploded atop a tower at Yucca Flat before dawn.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 17 -- The right hand of Jascha Heifetz, the violinist, was swollen last night after a hooligan had hit him with an iron pipe in Jerusalem in protest against his playing music by Richard Strauss, one-time president of the Nazi Kulturkammer.

The new Administration in Washington is directing its efforts in the maritime industry toward encouraging private capital to put up funds for new construction, Robert B. Murray, Under Secretary of Commerce for Transportation, asserted here yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- H. E. Humphreys Jr. of New York City, president of United States Rubber Company, predicted today that scientists and production men will find a way "sooner than you expect" to make automobile tires that give 100,000 miles of wear.
BERLIN, April 17 -- The Rev. Freidrick Hildebrandt, a Roman Catholic priest of Kirchmoeser, Magdeburg, will soon be brought to trial by an East German Communist court, church sources reported here.
PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -The Washington (D. C.) Evening Star won today the F. Wayland Ayer Cup, highest honor in the twenty-third annual exhibition of newspaper typography.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 17 -The new importance of drive-in theatres in the motion-picture industry was recognized today by a group of major film distributor companies in making an out-of-court settlement with payment of damages in the anti-trust action started in December, 1950, by the Skyline Drive-in Theatre Corporation and the California Drive-in Theatres Corporation.

Drexel Co., which has been on trial two years as one of seventeen defendants in the Government's anti-trust investment banking suit, is held by the Government to have participated in only one of seven practices making up the alleged conspiracy, according to a formal summary of the Government case just filed with Judge Harold R. Medina.
BEAUMONT, Tex., April 17 (UP) -- A three-hour operation on golf star Mrs. George (Babe) Zaharias for a rectal malignancy today apparently went so well that she may be able to play again.

YONKERS, April 17 (AP) -- Long shots finished one-two tonight in the featured Armond Pace at Yonkers Raceway before a crowd of 19,193. The winner by a length was Power Chief, with Watson Junior second.

SINGAPORE, April 17 -- Adlai E. Stevenson said today there was no disposition on the part of Americans to minimize the importance of the struggle against communism in Southeast Asia, although not as many Americans were familiar with the area as might be desirable.

Savings banks of New York State registered a deposit gain of $1,165,669,000 in the twelve months ended on March 31, the largest for any comparable period. Data issued yesterday by the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York showed that deposits in the 130 mutual savings banks of the state amounted to $13,595,469,000.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- Wheat futures were backward today, but corn and oats showed a fairly strong tone. Further long liquidation in wheat stymied efforts to step up a rally, and general demand was slow, reflecting the series of events which have unsettled the market during the week.
A career diplomat with thirty-seven years experience in foreign service, Mr. Wadsworth has been called "the greatest of American diplomatic experts on the Near East."
TUNIS, Tunisia, April 17 -- The Bey of Tunis, Sidi Mohammed el Amin Pasha, is upset about the conduct of the rural elections now in progress throughout his country.
Randalls Island Stadium drew one of its largest and noisiest crowds in years yesterday, but there wasn't a sign of pigskin, baseball or even shuttlecock in the arena.

Slashes by the House appropriations Committee in proposals for Government spending and Washington plans to cut back the defense base and raise rates on guaranteed housing loans did not please the stock market yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 17 -- The closing sessions of the annual meeting of the American College of Physicians offered today a striking example of what a medical leader described as indifference by doctors to economic and social aspects of practicing medicine.

The Giants finally got around to opening the season at the Polo Grounds yesterday but in an unguarded moment they left the gates open too long. For after bringing down the Dodgers, 6 to 3, in the afternoon, a play-off of Thursday's postponement, Leo Durocher's men came a fearful cropper in the regularly scheduled night game.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Dr. Allen V. Astin will continue as director of the National Bureau of Standards until late summer or early fall, Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, announced today, and will then be supplanted by a new director.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Alger Hiss, in a letter made public today, denied he had recommended to the United Nations the employment of Americans who later became public issues because of Communist membership or sympathies.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (UP) -- Alfred H. Morton, head of the Voice of America, has been named a "chief consultant" to the new director of the State Department's overseas information program.

A tie-up is being completed between the British ad agency of Legget, Nicholson Partners and Robert W. Orr Associates, Inc. F. A. Nicholson, managing director of the British concern, will be named a vice president of the American company and Robert W. Orr, president of the agency bearing his name, will join the board of directors of the British outfit.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- A former Government researcher who dug up material for wartime Navy and Air Force secret intelligence reports swore to the House Committee on Un-American Activities today that she was not now a member of the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (UP) -- A Jersey City dock worker testified today that "good, hard-working guys" were fired from a Government job at Claremont Terminal in Jersey City to make room for New York gangsters who went swimming in the nude on company time.

At the very hour when President Eisenhower was broadcasting from Washington his first major foreign policy speech since the death of Stalin, here in New York the member states of the United Nations were casting their first unanimous vote in nearly five years. In one sense the two events were an accidental coincidence.
TOKYO, Saturday, April 18 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,588, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korean time:

CINCINNATI, April 17 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs and the Milwaukee Braves traded hits, runs and the lead freely here today until the Redlegs shattered a 7-all deadlock with a three-run outburst in the eighth inning and then held off th Breaves in the ninth for a 10-9 triumph.

BELGRADE, April 17 -- President Eisenhower's vision of a peaceful world at war only with the forces of poverty and need was ecstatically praised here both for its content and for the belief it engendered among Yugoslav officials that the United States had taken over the initiative in bringing an end to the "cold war."
GENEVA, April 17--President Eisenhower has pledged full United States support for an expanded international program of aiding migrants from overcrowded regions of Europe to resettle overseas.
Prison riots result usually from long developing tensions, and no correctional institution is immune, Dr. Walter B. Martin, warden of Attica State Prison, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled unanimously today that the publishers of The Indiana-polis Star and The Indianapolis News made an illegal labor pact with an independent union twenty months ago.

LONDON, April 17 -- Strength in British Government securities and South African gold shares enlivened an otherwise dull stock market today. British funds had one of the busiest days in weeks and South African gold mining issues recovered all, if not more than yesterday's losses.

PARIS, April 17 -- The three chief military spokesmen of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, General of the Army Omar N. Bradley of the United States Gen. Sir John Harding of Britain and Gen. Charles Lecheres of France, set their final estimates today on the number of combat-ready divisions and air wings the Atlantic alliance countries should raise collectively in the remainder of 1953 and in 1954.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, April 18 (AP) -- United States Seventh Division soldiers, fighting hand-to-hand in their own trenches, today drove off the main force of 200 Chinese Communists who attacked "Porkchop Hill" on the Korean western front for the second straight day.

A discussion of the care of garments made of synthetic fabrics was a highlight of the morning session yesterday of the Electrical Woman's Round Table, New York Chapter Workshop, at the General Electric Auditorium, 570 Lexington Avenue.

Candidates seeking the Republican nomination for Governor in Tuesday's primary are convinced that New Jersey's election this fall will have national significance in providing the first test of Republican popularity since President Eisenhower took office. Traditionally Democratic Virginia is the only other state that will elect a governor this year.

With reference to your editorial on the City's Budget (April 9), it was disappointing to see THE TIMES support the recent suggestion of the Mayor's Management Survey consultants on city finances to charge $100 per year tuition fee at the municipal colleges, but we were shocked at THE TIMES' parenthetical remark that it was "too modest a charge, in our opinion."

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan would neither confirm nor deny yesterday a report that he was investigating the possibility of police involvement in the supplying of unregistered firearms to gun dealers.

ELIZABETH, N. J., April 17 -- An obedient, 15-year-old boy retracted tonight his confession to the slaying of two men in the hold-up of a tavern here last month after his father admitted to the police that he and not his son had fired the murder weapon.

Great opportunities exist for the industrial engineer to broaden his service to a complex society and, in so doing, triple his income over the next five years, Harold F. Smiddy, vice president of the General Electric Company, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated a Chicago manufacturer, Edmund F. Mansure, to head the General Services Administration. This is the "housekeeping" agency that has charge of Government buildings and does a lot of Government buying.

With an exhibition of paintings by Snorre Andersen at the Serigraph Galleries, contemporary Norwegian art takes a foothold on the New York scene. Andersen is a landscapist, mildly realistic, and with a special capacity for balancing large and easy designs.

PARIS, April 17 -- The executive board of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization said today it would not endorse the United States Government's loyalty questionnaire or any questionnaire not its own.

The first of six huge "portable dock" barges being built for the Army by the Consolidated Western Steel division of United States Steel Corporation will be launched today at Orange, Tex. The rest are to be finished at the rate of better than one a month.

NEW DELHI, India, April 17 -- Indian officials circles were stunned tonight beyond all other international considerations by the news of the Cabinet overturn in Pakistan at a moment when prospects were bright for steps toward a better relationship between the adjacent Commonwealth countries who several times have seemed at the point of war.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- The death toll in a fire that destroyed a Habet Corporation factory building yesterday rose to twenty-seven tonight as firemen continued searching for bodies of six persons believed still in the wreckage. Ten bodies were removed today.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, April 17 (AP) -- James L. Wick, leader of seven newspaper and radio executives who recently visited the Soviet Union, said today the Soviets had started a campaign to distort statements made by the group.

The thoughts of American patriots may well turn today to Christ Church on Copp's Hill in Boston, more widely known as the Old North Church, from whose spire, as every school child knows and few grown-ups have forgotten, flashed the light of two lanterns on the night of the eighteenth of April, in Seventy Five.

The Lespete Construction Company, Mary Marcus, president, has purchased for investment the six-story apartment house for fifty-nine families on plot 105 by 65 by 112 by 117 feet at 357 East 201st Street, in the Bronx, from the Concourse Crescent Corporation, Carl H. Woidwode, president.

WASHINGTON, April l7 -- Plans, policies and problems of the Eisenhower Administration in many fields were outlined by Cabinet and sub-Cabinet officers today before the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

Earlier this week the news in fruit was the first-of-the-season arrival of four-pound baby watermelons from Florida. Today the newcomer is a more exotic member of the melon family, the meloglow, an import from Chile.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The State Department disclosed today that through Russian intervention Communist North Korea was "taking measures" of release seven of thirteen American civilians seized at the outbreak of the Korean war in June 1950.

PARIS, April 17 -- The decisive electoral victory in South Africa of massive old Daniel F. Malan's Nationalist party must inevitably be the forerunner of significant changes in the Union's internal and external relationships. It can be assumed as inevitable that either Dr. Malan or his eventual successor as Prime Minister will start the rich Dominion along the road of a gradual step by step walkout from the British Commonwealth.

Plans for a development containing 1,000 homes in the low-price field were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of 200 acres on Jericho Turnpike, in Farmingville, L. I., by A. W. Williams to the Dale Developers Company, builders.
Thugs made off with $5,826 yesterday in three payroll robberies in Brooklyn and Queens.

Your combined editorial and birthday congratulations concerning the eightieth birthday anniversary of John Davis came at an especially excellent and timely moment -- for the same day and month, April 13 -- also marks the birthday of another distinguished American, Thomas Jefferson.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 17 -- Mrs. Fancille Hlavaty, substitute French teacher at New Rochelle High School since November, was dismissed today by Donald K. Phillips, Superintendent of Schools. He said she would not tell whether she had been a Communist prior to 1944 although she denied later affiliation with the party.

The whooping cranes, North America's largest birds, have begun their spring migration northward. The Fish and Wildlife Service of the Interior Department in Washington has received word from its Arkansas National Wildlife Refuge in Texas that the last of the cranes had left their winter home there.

BELGRADE, April 17 -- Messrs. Schine and Cohn, who were here for little more than a day, appear to have caused less excitement than amusement. Yugoslav offficials adopted a strictly "hands off" attitude but privately many Yugoslavs did not repress their merriment.

Boys' apparel buyers have had ample proof this spring that early filling of their seasonal requirements pays off with increased volume, Joseph Isaacson, board chairman of the Boys Apparel and Accessories Manufacturing Association, said yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 17 -- Seventy candidates have been nominated for thirty-two Senate vacancies to be contested May 9. lilt no state have Government and Labor opposition groups the field to themselves.

An old steel plate mill, built during World War I and said to be still the largest in the nation, is rolling out plates for the Navy's first atomic energy- powered submarines and for the giant 60,000-ton aircraft carriers, the U.S.S. Forrestal and the U.S.S. Saratoga, the Lukens Steel Company said yesterday.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, unchanged to 9 points lower than on Thursday.

TRENTON, April 17--Attorney Joseph H. Stamler charged today that an opportunity was offered to his brother, Nelson F. Stamler, former Deputy Attorney General, to avoid the present legislative inquiry into his dismissal from office on condition that he admit he was wrong in his dispute with Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 17 -- Liberalization of Israel's economy, which was marked during the last year by the abolition of price control for most goods, was welcomed by the Manufacturers Association at its national convention here today.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, April 17 -- American boys who in a matter of days will receive their freedom arrived tonight in Kaesong, which is just over a rolling hill from this neutral town.

LONDON, April 17 -- If Senator Joseph McCarthy's two globetrotting investigators come to this country, as it now seems they intend to do, the British can be relied upon to receive them with traditional politeness -- and little else.

Carpets play a variety of roles in room settings -- they can be used as the one patterned object in a room, as a colorful accent or to provide an unpatterned, unobtrusive, and often textured surface underfoot.

As one of the six member agencies of the United Defense Fund, the National Recreation Association was pleased to see the fine coverage THE TIMES gave to the annual meeting of the U. D. F. in Washington April 7. In the list of the agencies of the United Defense Fund, however, the name of the National Recreation Association was inadvertently omitted.
ALBANY, April 18 -- Governor Dewey disclosed today that he soon would appoint a committee to make a thorough study of the "serious financial problems" faced by the privately owned bus companies.
SYRACUSE, April 18 -- A significant link in plotting earth tremors in the St. Lawrence Valley is being constructed on Onondaga Hill, four miles southwest of this city.
Cardinal Spellman opened the thirty-fourth annual fund appeal of the New York Catholic Charities last evening in a half-hour radio and television appearance.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- President Eisenhower's speech to the editors here this week is a reminder that this nation's foreign policy is determined, not by the fixed views of contending political parties, but by its geography, philosophy, history and psychology.

In William C. Fitzgibbon's article "Animal Thinkers" (April 5) he reports an interview with T. C. Schneirla, curator in the Department of Animal Behavior, Museum of Natural History, and there appeared a picture of a Canada goose with the erroneous caption -- "not very bright."

THE Federal budget is a huge document, larger than most metropolitan telephone books, and infinitely bleaker reading. It weighs six pounds, nine ounces, and even those who are forced by the nature of their work to read it have been known to wind up talking to themselves.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 18 -Battle lines are being drawn in the Connecticut General Assembly for a renewal of a twenty-year dispute over whether physicians in this state should be allowed to prescribe contraceptive devices for married women where their health was concerned.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- One of the most ambitious projects in the Missouri River Valley development program is before the Eisenhower Administration in a brand new dress.

CHICAGO -- A new 16mm silent movie projector and two 8mm projectors were introduced here last week at the Master Photo Dealers Finishers Association annual trade show. Eastman Kodak displayed the Kodascope Royal, which has a 2-inch f/1.6 Ektanson projection lens, folding nylon-geared 400foot reel arms and 750-watt lamp and is permanently lubricated.

MANY gardeners shy away from growing herbs because they have a vague idea that a special plot must be relegated to them. Actually herbs can be tucked in anywhere there is room, reasonably good soil and, in most cases, full sun.

Why do so many of us who have no use for communism dislike Senator McCarthy's methods? The Senator's stock defense is that we are Communists or fellow-travelers. The Senator is a man with a mission, and anyone who opposes him per se belongs to the opposition.
Top policy officials of the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., refused yesterday to authorize a strike of 75,000 workers against, the General Electric Company.

The Ethical Culture Schools, an outgrowth of the first free kindergarten in the United States, will open a three-week celebration of their seventy-fifth anniversary with "a birthday dinner" next Saturday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Princeton ended Pennsylvania's three-year sway and won the Childs Cup for the first time since 1949 yesterday with a sweep of all three races in New York's opening rowing regatta on the Harlem, Columbia, with a fine display of oarsmanship, finished a close second in the varsity race and also got home ahead of Penn in the junior varsity event.

TEHERAN, April 18 -- In spite of strenuous parliamentary efforts by both camps this week and two street demonstrations in which a little blood was shed and a lot more might have been, the constitutional controversy over who should control the army, Premier Mossadegh or the Shah, remains deadlocked, just about where it was a month or even a year ago.

A PHOTOGRAPH of the design of the two special stamps, 3-cents black and white and 5c blue, which the United Nations will issue on June 12 as a tribute to the Universal Postal Union, one of the world organization's oldest specialized agencies, was made available last week by Reidar Tvedt, Chief of the U. N. Postal Administration.

LAVISH is the word for Louis A. Brennan's first novel. He has ransacked a fun cupboard to bring us this high-fidelity tale of love and life in a medium-sized Ohio town. As a sweeping, sprawling reportage of civic divertissements and interior pitched battles between sexes, "These Items of Desire" impressively joins Mr. Anderson's "Winesburg, Ohio" and Mr. O'Hara's "A Rage to Live" in a going American tradition.

The fifth annual John H. Finley public lectures on "The Newspaper and Society," presented by City College, will be given at 8:30 P. M. on May 5 and 6 in the faculty room of the college's main building, 139th Street and Convent Avenue, Prof. Edgar Johnson, chairman of the department of English, announced yesterday.

STAMFORD, Conn., April 18 -In a faded red, wooden, weatherbeaten building a stone's throw from Town Hall, a potbellied stove radiates warm contentment in the oldest stove foundry in the United States, but its days are numbered and the doom of a century-old establishment is sealed.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 18 -- The White House announced today a series of five Cabinet speeches, with Secretary of State John Foster Dulles leading off, to support and expand the "peace offensive" launched by President Eisenhower on Thursday.
COLUMBUS, Ga., April 18 (UP) -- Tornadoes, packing winds up to 100 miles an hour, swept across Arkansas, Alabama and into Georgia today killing at least nine persons and injuring possibly 200 more.

CHICAGO -- Stereo and electronic flash were the principal product groups at the twenty-eighth Master Photo Dealers' and Finishers' Association convention held here last week. Offering its biggest and most varied assortment of new products in recent years, the show had items designed and priced for the beginner as well as top-level equipment for the professional.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP) -The American Public Power Association disclosed today that it had asked the Atomic Energy Commission to give it a part in developing electric power from atomic energy. The association is composed of municipal and regional public power organizations from coast to coast.

A major controversy has developed between Mayor Impellitteri and his associates in the Democraticcontrolled administration of New York City, on the one hand, and Governor Dewey and the Republicancontrolled State Legislature, on the other, over the issue of state aid to local governments.

Merchants fighting for the right to set their own store prices struck hard last week in Vermont and California. In Vermont they were undisputed victors over their fair-trade opponents, while in California they delivered the most serious attack on legal retail price-fixing since passage of the McGuire Act.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- Robert L. Johnson, the new head of the State Department's International Information Administration, disclosed today that he was undertaking a full investigation of the information activities.

RICHMOND, April 18 -- Despite the sharply lowered farm prices, indications are that 1953 will still be a relatively good year for Fifth District farmers, the Richmond Reserve Bank reports. Smaller acreage allotments for some crops, including peanuts and flue cured and burley tobaccos, will cause adjustment in planting patterns.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Justice Department, which has been studying for almost nine months Congressional demands for perjury action against Mr. Davies, said tonight that the case was still under "active consideration." A Justice Department spokesman declined to predict when a decision would be made on whether to prosecute.

Under pressure from the scientists of the country Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks has temporarily reinstated Dr. Allen V. Astin as director of the National Bureau of Standards. It may well be that President Eisenhower has intervened, for the Secretary says that the reinstatement was made with "White House approval."

FOR several years sportsmen and conservationists opposed Federal dam projects on the basis of "wildlife conservation," but during the past year these groups seem to have discovered a more potent argument, and one which is receiving the ready support of other agencies -- upstream water control.

Boy Scouts of the Greater New York Councils began yesterday their third annual "good turn" week for the Goodwill Industries, Inc. Their representatives met at the quarters of Engine Company 1 at 142 West Thirty-first Street and received from Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet the first of the 100,000 bags they will distribute to New Yorkers for filling.

AFTER the May festivals come the summer festivals, and the United States, as usual, will have its generous helpings of summer music. There will be music again at Tanglewood, Aspen, Central City, Brevard, Carmel, and most of the other centers where annual festivals have been made going concerns, and most of the large cities will have their outdoor series.

Some intriguing statistics are presented in a new publication just issued by the United Nations Educational and Statistical Organization. Finland, we learn, has the world's highest literacy rate, 99 per cent, while in parts of Africa only 1 per cent of the population can read or write.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 18 -Navy's varsity crew still clung to its championship role as it rowed down the Severn almost in the dusk this evening. The boatload of midshipmen, except for the coxswain, that had swept aside all competition here and abroad last season and capped its performances by winning Olympic laurels, met its first 1953 test against Yale successfully.
BASEBALL can be an art as well as an avocation when properly taught by trained managers, as illustrated in these stories of the Little League.

Whether or not Mr. Clark's statements are justified on the basis of his tests is not as important as the fact that his conclusions certainly merit further investigation. The approach ought to be a positive attempt to see how we can improve our methods of teaching students to think through an even better program.

BUENOS AIRES, April 18 -- Violence broke out in this nervous capital this week as youths, incited by an angry speech by President Juan D. Peron, resorted to arson and left the headquarters buildings of the regime's opponents in smoldering ruins.

Shimer College (Mount Carroll, Ill.), a co-educational institution affiliated with the University of Chicago, has received a grant from the Fund for the Advancement of Education to provide thirty early admission scholarships for the 1953-54 academic year. Students who will be no more than 16 1/2 years old on July 1 and who are recommended by their high schools may apply.

YONKERS, April 18 -- Ford Motor's First closed strongly on the outside in the final quarter to gain a nose victory over the favored Honor Direct in the first division of the White Plains Pacing Stake at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 18 -- The problems that will confront members of the United Nations, and particularly the United States, if there is an armistice in Korea are so numerous and so difficult that the whole process that will be involved in attempting to settle them deserves much more attention than it has received.

FAMAGUSTA, the ancient port of Cyprus, is a city of ruins. The old churches were dismantled by the Turkish invaders and the Gothic cathedral is a Moslem mosque. The stout walls the Crusaders built still stand, but houses and cottages have been built from their stones.

ROME, April 18 -- Roy M. Cohn, chief counsel to Senator McCarthy's Government Operations subcommittee, and Gerard David Schine, subcommittee consultant, were planning tonight to be back in Washington by the middle of next week after their visit to Europe.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., April 18 -- Maximum use of the new 950-bed veterans hospital here may be thrown sharply off schedule if additional funds for operation are not forthcoming soon from the Veterans Administration, it was indicated today. The build-up to capacity operation since the $20,000,000 institution was opened last Oct. 12 has been considerably slower than was planned.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., April 18 -- Cathie Daly of Gladstone, N. J., qualified for the A. S. P. C. A. class in the national fixture by winning the horsemanship trophy event at the northern New Jersey horse show today. Miss Daly's Bright Maid, a brown mare, took the children's hunter blue and placed second in the working hunter hacks test.
The freighter Tyrifjord, the first ship built for the Norwegian America Line in Norway, was introduced to New York last week.

The recent conciliatory gestures of the U. S. S. R. could be the harbinger of an era of relaxation of international tensions and perhaps a more tolerable modus vivendi among many nations presently burdened with anxieties and the demands for the maximum defensive preparations and arrangements.

HEMET, Calif. -- Beginning today, citizens of Hemet and near-by San Jacinto will pay their spectacular annual homage to one of the most enduring legends ever to emerge from the realm of literature. The legend is Helen Hunt Jackson's famous Story, "Ramona," which although published in 1884 still stands as the classic fictional delineation of California life in the romantic days of the Spanish ranchos.

The N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra last night presented on its broadcast from the Belasco Theatre Alexei Haieff's Piano Concerto, the work selected by the New York Music Critics Circle as the best new orchestral composition introduced in this city last year.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Pull out chickweed and other weeds in the perennial border, and remove by hand or raking leaves and other debris. Sprinkle a balanced commercial fertilizer, taking care not to touch new growth. Then cultivate lightly, not disturbing late starters.

IN the competitive search for unhackneyed material to record, the manufacturers of long-playing disks are exploring all of music's branches. How thoroughly they are combing and reproducing the literature for the organ is evidenced by an armful of excellent organ recordings that have been issued in the last few months.
Foreign nations, particularly those of Western Europe, will soon have to look more to private investment and business enterprise to fill their need for American dollars.
TOKYO, April 18 (AP) -- The Japanese Government today authorized American movie companies to remit $2,500,000 to the United States from profits accumulated in Japan during the last seven years.
Man will entertain guests at ithe luncheon and card party for the benefit of the Silver Cross Day Nursery to be given on Tuesday in the St. Regis Roof and Penthouse
THIS week will be occupied chiefly by the final half of the highly successful season of "American Dance," sponsored by the B. de Rothschild Foundation, at the Alvin Theatre.

By this time everybody ought to know that a transistor is a pea-sized bit of germanium, a silvery metal, and that it can supplant the familiar vacuum tube for many purposes. Germanium is a semi-conductor. It can control the flow of electrons just as a vacuum tube does.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 18 -- Four ambassadors, two college presidents and 500 adult and undergraduate specialists in Latin America gave this city back its name this afternoon after a three-day program during which Mayor John A. Lynch had technically changed it to Pan-America, U. S. A.

MEXICO CITY, April 18 (AP) -The announcement today by Otto Mayer of Switzerland, chancellor of the I. O. C. that the Olympic would remain in Melbourne halted speculation that the games might be taken away from the Australians because of insufficient preparations.

At 9 A. M. tomorrow Korean time (7 P. M. tonight Eastern standard time) United Nations officers will escort twenty-five Communist prisoners to a row of tents at one side of the Panmunjom truce clearing; at the same moment, the Communists will deliver twenty-five U. N. prisoners to a row of tents on the opposite side of the clearing.
THIS summer, as every Briton knows, or at any rate as every Briton hopes he knows, Americans will be coming to London in unprecedented numbers for Her Majesty's Coronation.

The foundations of Britain's milliondollar radio telescope, which is expected to double the size of the known universe, are now being built at Jodrell Bank, Cheshire. There is to be a huge maneuverable steel bowl, 330 feet high, 300 tons in weight, and a superstructure to house the electronically controlled telescope.

Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion of Israel, in a message yesterday to Americans in anticipation of the fifth anniversary of his country's independence tomorrow, said the citizens of that state looked to the future in a spirit of hope and confidence.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., April 18 -- An election contest that was discounted last November as the routine gesture of a defeated candidate burgeoned this week into a battle that stirred New Mexico and held the possibility of bolstering the Republican party's skimpy margin in the United States Senate.

NEVER was an old proverb of less accurate modern application than the proverb about the Fool and his Money. You will have heard it said that the Fool and his Money are soon parted. That was true enough for the yokel at the fair, but in this modern city life of ours it is just the other way.

IN his review of "Israel" by Norman Bentwich, Hal Lehrman * * * reproaches Mr. Bentwich for "a surprisingly uncritical acceptance of lavish claims by Israel Bond promoters." One would gather that Professor Bentwich devoted substantial attention to the Israel Bond effort or effects.

NEW DELHI, India, April 18 -India's persistent assertion of neutrality and her preoccupation with colonialism as a live issue in Asia appear to have obscured the strong appeal to this country's passion for conciliation that might otherwise have been seen here in President Eisenhower's speech on Thursday to the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

A suggestion that the synthetic rubber plants owned by the Government be offered for sale "on a bid basis, with negotiations for a definitive contract after opening the bids," was made last week by H. E. Humphreys Jr., president of the United States Rubber Company.
BEAUMONT, Texas, April 18 (AP) -- The Babe "looks wonderful."

EL-AROUSSA, Tunisia, April 16 -- Villagers and peasants of this verdant countryside sixty - five miles southwest of Tunis cast their votes in an election today for the first time in their lives. They had been invited by the Administration to elect one member and one alternate for the rural council that will assist Mokhtar Nalli, Kaid of the region of Medjez-el-Bab.

IT may not make the greatest splash in book and record stores, but it is decidedly worth mentioning anyway: the Archives de la Musique Enregistree has just issued a discography of ethnographical and folk music that is up to the scholarly comprehensiveness of its predecessors.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP) -Several thousand members of the Daughters of the American Revolution poured into town today to register for their sixty-second Continental Congress, which opens Monday, and to participate in traditional pre-Congress activities.
ALTHOUGH it would be hard to imagine any music more un-Mozartean than that of Tchaikovsky, the Russian composer adored Mozart, whom he called "the Christ of music."

OTTAWA, April 18 -- While Canada and the United States continue to be each other's best customers, Canadian exports to and imports from other countries are rising steadily, Commerce Minister C. D. Howe told the House of Commons last night.

IT is possible that Henri Sauguet, a man who in the past has known need and who lives and works with a keen relish for circumstances and people as he finds them, was inwardly amused with the situation in which he finds himself on his first visit to America and to New York.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The very real threat of a year in jail, a sentence that can be meted out for his earlier refusal to talk to Congressional tax investigators, has loosened the tongue of Henry W. (The Dutchman) Grunewald.

THE great consolation about most Presidential campaign speeches is that they die fast. Like old campaign buttons and old love letters, they are usually retained mainly as mementos of our youth and we read them later at our peril.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 -- Industrial centers in this district continue to show moderate increase in employment. Compared with a year ago, employment in the district is up 6 per cent and payrolls 12 per cent. Bankers estimate the annual payroll of industry in the Delaware River Valley approximates $2,000,000,000, a new high record.

Unemployment is on the upgrade in motion picture studios and during the next six weeks appears likely to reach a peak unequalled in recent years. Ironically the very technical developments -- three-dimensional films and assorted varieties of new styles in screen sizes and shapes -which are expected to benefit the boxoffice are in large measure responsible for the increasing shortage of jobs.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 18 -- The award of three championship rosettes tonight capped the Secor Farms Riding Club's twentyfirst anniversary horse show.
The English-Speaking Union of the United States yesterday named eight newspaper men and broadcasters as recipients of its Better Understanding Awards for contributions to international cooperation.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 18 -Navy notched its third straight track and field victory in the triangular meeting with Penn and Yale today. Navy's athletes rolled up 73 points at Thompson Stadium, while Yale had 57 1/2 and Penn 31 1/2.

A FLOWER box at a window, on the porch or terrace, or at the front or back entrance of the house, can be an interesting and colorful "garden" all through the year. This sort of garden may be tailored to fit the space, and only a little advance planning is needed to maintain bloom for three seasons and green during winter.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Congress of the United States is currently indulging in its annual spring exercise of trying to decide whether to permit the resident citizens of the District of Columbia to enjoy the advantages -- or disadvantages -- of daylight saving time.
BOYLE, Ireland, April 18 (AP) -The full skeleton of a Stone Age man has been found on the bed of an Irish lake now being drabbed to reveal secrets of life 5,000 years ago.

Only in a Tru Balance girdle will you know the wonderful, comfortable secret of Natural Control. No other girdle but Tru Balance is designed to follow the natural flow of your body muscles. You look so much better, feel so much freer, are controlled so much more perfectly in a Tru Balance.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 -- A Stanford University biochemist, in reporting that the pituitary gland at the base of the brain was highly important in the development of cancers, suggested today the pituitary hormone ACTH might be a key to the production of some types of malignancy.

TOKYO, Sunday, April 19 -News that the Communists were sending a fourth convoy of sick and wounded United Nations prisoners from a camp near the Yalu River south toward Kaesong disrupted today the United States Fifth Air Force's plans to resume bombing of the supply traffic on the route to Pyongyang, North Korean capital.

Governor Dewey announced yesterday at Albany the appointment of two members of the fiveman New York City transit authority set up by the 1953 Legislature to take over the city's subway, bus and street car lines and run them at a fare sufficient to cover all operating costs.

POSITANO, Italy -- Well, here it is, an hour and a half by car from Naples. You go over and around the Sorrento Peninsula to its south side, on the Gulf of Salerno, driving by a well-paved but rather vertiginous road along rocky ledges above the sea, through orange and lemon groves (this is the pays in "Connais-tu le pays ou fleurit l'oranger?") and then along the spectacular hairpins of the Amalfi drive.

WHEN someone asked me recently why we grew the same well-known annuals every year rather than the more unusual and "exotic" kinds, I found it was not a question that could be answered in a sentence or two.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 18 (AP) -- Dave Schneider's Elixir registered his second straight stakes victory by romping to a fourlength triumph in the $15,000 Hallandale Handicap before 15,355 spectators at Gulfstream Park today.

In his inspiring address to American editors last Thursday President Eisenhewer did much more than delineate specific peace proposals. He did, it is true, call upon the Soviet Union for definite acts and he enumerated some that would be regarded as an earnest of good faith.
TRENTON, April 18 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll reviewed today his seven-year stewardship in New Jersey as he signed his final appropriation bill. He will leave office next January.

THE drop of 13 per cent in department store sales countrywide reported for the week ended on April 11 by the Federal Reserve Board, should not be misinterpreted. Although coming at the time of the Korean "peace scare," the decline chiefly involved comparison of sales in the post-Easter period this year against the final week of Easter trade a year ago.
" NIGHT Youth Paris and the Moon" exclaimed John Collier without even a comma to interrupt his ecstasy, and proceeded to write the most captivating of all trunk-murder stories.

AS anyone who read "We Took to the Woods" knows, Louise Dickinson Rich was enormously happy in the wilderness of northern Maine and she was deeply devoted to her husband. She never anticipated that this idyl might end -- that her husband would die and leave her as the sole custodian, support and guide of two children.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 -Most players go through a lifetime lost in anonymity and get nowhere, but Mickey Mantle, with not even two full seasons in the majors, is to have everlasting recognition in the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N. Y. Sid Keener, curator of the baseball shrine, requested today the ball that the Yankees' ace hit out of Washington's Griffith Stadium yesterday.
Walter Bruchhausen, 60-yearold Brooklyn attorney, was nominated by President Eisenhower yesterday to be a United States District Judge for the Eastern District of New York.

THE phenomenon of the true poetic-scientific mind is, by reason of its rarity, usually attributed to epochs in history which favored the growth of the complete and balanced personality. Yet Goethe lived at a time of fast-increasing specialization which was intensely poetic, intensely scientific and intensely unbalanced.
TOKYO, Sunday, April 19 -- The United Nations Command and the Communist leaders agreed today to resume full-scale negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war.

Empty store windows, streets darkened by power shortage, houses dimly lit by kerosene lamps and people living under the constant shadow of fear characterize life in the once thriving cities of Czechoslovakia, according to travelers recently returned from that country.

FOR those tired of the old fifty-two weeks a year, there is a happier calendar. On it, merchandisers, promoters and beneficent societies have put not weeks but Weeks, and in 1953 there are a record 150 of them. They began in January with the likes of Printing Education Week, Idaho Potato and Onion Week and Take Tea and See Week. They'll go on until the year ends with International Golden Rule Week.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- President Eisenhower's recent invitation to the forty-eight Governors to come to Washington for a conference over mutual problems of statecraft with officials of his Administration has given renewed assurance that he and other Republican spokesmen are really serious about their desire, as expressed in one campaign slogan "to turn government back to the people."

Before the season progresses too far there are a number of questions to be asked. Why does it snow in April, with daffodils at their best and tulips making a display that shouldn't have to be brave, but turns out to be? Why does rhubarb come so early and asparagus so late?

NEWARK, April 18 -- Performing in dismal weather, Manhattan College, kingpin of the indoor and outdoor I. C.-4-A. world, and Georgetown, a power in the distance field, shared the honors today at the seventh annual Seton Hall University Relays at Newark Schools Stadium. Each team won two Eastern crowns as the two-day track program came to an end.

AS inspector of foreign investments, this department is now in a position to report as follows: "Paint Your Wagon" -- bullish; "South Pacific" -- steady; "Call Me Madam" -- collapsing. Among the futures: "Guys and Dolls" -- bound to be oversubscribed. On the whole this is an encouraging bulletin.

THE brand-new home owner with only $25 to $75 to spend on landscaping his grounds the first year might well consider the plant material recommended and listed in the accompanying box. It has been selected for three main reasons: (1) to give some immediate color to the grounds; (2) to form a nucleus of permanent plants to which more will be added each year, and (3) for adaptability to this area.

THE first test of a baseball book is whether it can immobilize those young hopefuls whose cleats cut the carpets on rainy days. These three meet the requirement. "Second-Season Jinx" by Burgess Leonard, chronicles the wobbly ascent to stardom of an earnest young southpaw who throws 'em hot and wild.

" WE are a long way from Marcel Proust." This sentence from Claudel's commentary on "Winds" carried my mind back more than twenty years. I was an undergraduate at Cambridge in 1930 when St. John Perse was introduced to the English public by T. S. Eliot's translation of "Anabasis," a poem which had appeared in French in 1924.

It is discouraging in the extreme to learn from John B. Oakes' article, "Inquiry Into McCarthy's Status" (April 12), that "no member of Congress -- Democrat or Republican -- cares personally to tangle with McCarthy."

LONDON, April 18 (Reuters) -England and Scotland fought to a 2-2 tie for the British international soccer championship in the seventieth game of the series at Wembley Stadium today. Lawrie Reilly, the Scots' center forward from Hibernian, clipped the equalizer over goalkeeper Gil Merrick's head in the last few seconds.

WHILE South Germany and Switzerland have been preoccupied this latter part of the season with Carl Orff's "Trionfi," the news in North Germany has been the first German production of Alban Berg's "Lulu" by the Municipal Opera House of Essen.

THE mastery of understatement, an English native accomplishment or irritant, according to foreign taste, was never more sharply and unexpectedly evidenced than when our soberest daily journal described (in a headline, tool) the casting of the latest screen Juliet as "unusual."

CHICAGO -- An attractively, compactly designed $25 enlarger for the beginner was a popular item at the photographic trade show held here last week. It was the First Enlarger, which is of plastic construction, takes negatives up to 2 1/4x3 1/4 inches, has an f/11 double lens in extra large focusing mount, uses a 50-watt projection lamp and is twenty-eight inches high.

NOTHING but regal treatment will be accorded "Julius Caesar" by MetroGoldwyn-Mayer. Last week it was learned that the studio's adaptation of the Shakespearean drama is headed for the Booth Theatre on West Forty-fifth Street, where it is slated to have its world premiere this summer, possiby in June, and thereafter continue as a reserved-seat, two-a-day attraction.

The rich market for merchandise among the youth of the nation has been a prime target of many business organizations for some years and out of their efforts to tap it has come an interesting story. It concerns Eugene Gilbert, 26-year-old head of the youth research organization bearing his name, whose yearly income is now well up in five figures.

LAWNS in this part of the country show a fine green stand of grass. Many of them look almost like a hayfield, including ragged and uneven growth. It has been almost impossible, especially for commuters who mow their lawns over the week-ends, to find a day when the first cutting could be done.

For the first time a group of students and faculty members from St. John's College, Annapolis, gave a public presentation in New York City of the Great Books program in operation. The St. John's representatives presented afternoon and evening demonstrations last Tuesday at Town Hall showing the educational methods used in the third oldest college in the United States.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 18 -- The United States Embassy announced today that the Shiraz regional Point Four office, sacked by a mob on Wednesday night, is reopening with new equipment that is now being flown in.

A WAG with a culinary pitch once observed that professional baseball is a skillful mixture of plenty of pepper, ham and lots of lettuce (the long green variety) -- with rhubarb, of course, to be added to taste. In any case, there's no question but that it's habit forming, as hundreds of thousands of fans have already started to testify again this week.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 18 -- The campaign for northern Laos progressed toward a climax today, with the French ordering their garrison at Nonget near the Vietnam border to withdraw westward toward their Plaine des Jarres base on the Tranninh Plateau. There the French and Laotians are expected to attempt to halt a strong Communist-led Vietminh drive before it can reach the Thailand border and cut Laos in two.

IN his review of Peter Viereck's "Shame and Glory of the Intellectuals," James Burnham seems obsessed by Mr. Viereck's youth. Professor Viereck is deplorably young at 38. Professor Burnham from the Olympian old age of 48 finds his younger colleague lacking in maturity.

Buddy Combs' Red Bank Polo Club drew even with the New York A. C. trio in the national senior indoor championship struggle by halting the Winged Foot, 13 -- 11, in the second match of the best-of-three series at the Squadron A Armory last night.

A FEW thousand Hopi people, now living on a reservation of two and a half million acres of Arizona desert land, entirely surrounded by the enormous Navajo Indian reservation, have for hundreds of years preserved their dignity, way of life and independence, both spiritual and economic.

PARIS, April 18 -- The executive board of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization has failed to agree on a candidate for Director General, it was announced today, and has postponed the special session of the general conference called for May 19 to approve the board's choice.

FEW Americans realize that high on the crest of the state of Colorado, in the shadow of Pikes Peak, is a gold camp called Cripple Creek whose fantastic wealth altered the nation's history at the turn of the century. This is understandable because for sixty years Cripple Creek has lacked a historian.

AS every parent knows all too well, the young are exerting more and more influence these days on family buying. Living costs are high for children as well as for their mothers and dads. Early this month the Youth Research Institute, a commercial organization set up to study the "tastes, attitudes and opinions" of people under 25, announced findings of a survey on spending habits of 3,000 youngsters, 10 to 18.

The British Government is to be congratulated on having refused to renew the International Wheat Agreement for another three years. Though this refusal sprang from considerations not of principle but of price, it may well put an end to the international price-fixing of wheat.

NOTHING quite comparable to "Zorba the Greek" has appeared on the literary scene for years. This much is true, whether it is a point of merit or not. Mr. Kazantzakis speaks with a voice distinctly different from the familiar diction of the American novel.
Intensive nation-wide research on a curious silvery metal called zirconium is being watched carefully these days by the men who hope to be using atomic power soon in private industry.

IN 79 A. D. Vesuvius erupted. This catastrophe to the inhabitants of Pompeii, Herculaneum and Stabiae, was a boon to art lovers, for it miraculously preserved the art and architecture of a sophisticated civilization. Hidden until the first excavations of 1848, the cities of the Campania are still yielding treasures.

The police, school officials, apartment house superintendents and neighbors are keeping a wary eye on boys walking or playing near the railroad tracks in the Bronx to prevent any more rocks from being hurled at commuters' trains.

SPRING always brings a bumper crop of free pamphlets designed to help in the planning of summer vacations. Here is a random choice among recent publications: "Where to Stay in Nova Scotia," a booklet issued by the Nova Scotia Information Bureau, 247 Park Avenue, lists nearly 600 hotels, lodges, cottage colonies and camps in the province.

A chapter of World War II is coming to a close -- the work of the United States Committee for the Care of European Children. The group came into being to rescue youngsters from the perilous present that was June, 1940; it worked after the war to reclaim them from a tragic past; and it is ending after having given 4,177 a future.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Opponents of the bill to confer on coastal states title to the submerged lands seaward to their historic boundaries blocked efforts today by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican leader of the Senate, to bring the pending measure to a vote next Friday night.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, April 19 (AP) -- United States and European infantrymen smashed a many-pronged Chinese Communist attack along a two-mile front before dawn today.

HARRY CROSBY was one of the rich, Back Bay Boston Harvard men who enlisted in the American Field Service during World War I. After some aimless drifting, he returned to Paris to work in the family firm, Morgan et Cie., and eventually settled down to be a poet.

TRENTON, April 18 -- The four major candidates for the Democratic and Republican nominations for Governor, winding up their campaigns over the week-end, all expressed confidence tonight in ultimate victory in Tuesday's primary.

PURCHASING a tree or a shrub is all too often a spurof-the-moment transaction, especially for the beginning gardener. My first purchase -- a supermarket "special" on lilacs and forsythias -- quickly demonstrated that a buyer should know something of climate and soil requirements before any tree or shrub is purchased.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 18 (AP) -- Two stars of the Olympic games last summer, Darrow Hooper and Thane Baker, shared the thunder with Kansas' famed baton teams in the twenty-eighth running of the Kansas Relays today.
BOWIE, Md., April 18 (AP) -- Post Car, for the stable of Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords, gained a nose decision over Max Kahlbaum's Jampol in the $15,000 added Laurel Handicap here today.

WASHINGTON, April l8 -- Projected hearings before the Senate Small Business Committee on the dismissal of Dr. Allen V. Astin as director of the National Bureau of Standards have been canceled, Senator Edward J. Thye, Republican of Minnesota and committee chairman, announced on the Senate floor today.

BONN, Germany, April 18 -- The Government department charged with planning West Germany's military contribution to the projected European Defense Community is making steady progress toward the completion of preparations for rearmament.
Following is the text of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles' address last night to the American Society of Newspaper Editors in Washington, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
KUWAIT, April 18 (AP) -- The latest oil discovery at the head of the Persian Gulf may put some of the little fellows in the industry right up front with the giants, oil men say.

For the fifth time in fifty years, Barnard College freshmen upset the sophomores yesterday afternoon to win the annual Greek Games by a score of 53 -- 47. Competition was so sharp that early in the afternoon the ancient Greek victory yell of "Nike!" gave way to the American collegiate cry of "Yay!"

The visit of Chancellor Adenauer of West Germany attracted special attention because he is the first German Chancellor to include America is his travels. He is different in other ways from the German Chancellors of the past.
CHIQUITOY, Peru, April 18 -- In this ancient valley we are on a road so old that it may predate the roads Julius Caesar built over the Alps in 57 A. D.
Oscar Levant's deft piano hands were rapped smartly yesterday by James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 18 -The defending champion, Mrs. Lyle Bowman of California, and Miss Edean Anderson of Helena, Mont., shot their way into the final of the Trans-Mississippi golf tournament today and will meet for the championship at thirty-six holes tomorrow.

BONN, Germany, April 18 -- The State Department has ordered the transfer from West Germany of John Patron Davies Jr., career diplomat, who was accused last year of having recommended that the Central Intelligence Agency enlist the advice of persons having "Communist associations and connections."

WASHINGTON, Calif., April 18 --Extravagant claims and optimistic forecasts, perhaps based partly on fiscal sleight-of-hand and wishful thinking, have put prospects of balancing the Federal budget into a state of thorough confusion.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 18 -Howard W. Stepp, swimming coach at Princeton and dean of all active Princeton coaches, was honored tonight at a surprise dinner celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of his arrival at the university.

Barnard College has opened a campaign for $150,000 to develop a drama workshop where girls interested in theatrical careers will be trained through collaboration of professional theatre folk and members of the faculty.

Norodom Sihanouk, King of Cambodia, one of the three Associated States of Indo-China, warned here yesterday that unless the French gave his people more independence "within the next few months" there was real danger that they would rebel against the present regime and become a part of the Communist-led Vietminh movement.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 18 -- The United Nations General Assembly unanimously adopted today -- and will dispatch to both sides in the Korean war -- a resolution expressing hope for a quick armistice.
MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 18 (AP) -- Mrs. J. P. McCormick's Black Fox Run rallied after running a steady second most of the distance today to capture the Middleburg Hunt Cup steeplechase.

THE chances are that hardly any of the travelers who use the airlines for transportation have ever heard of the Cornell-Guggenheim Aviation Safety Center. Yet the Center is important to every airline passenger, since its object is to make flying the safest form of travel.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 17 -- After many months' deliberation the Government has decided to reorganize the National Bank to decentralize it as is being done with other economic institutions. The main purpose will be to provide a freer play of credit and to assure increased independence for branch banks.

COLOR television, which has had its ups and downs for over ten years, took a major step forward last week. The latest color TV showing by the Radio Corporation of America was much the best tinted video yet seen and an exciting augury of the home television of the future.

TOKYO, Sunday, April 19 -- Japanese voters throughout the home islands went to the polls in strength today to elect a new House of Representatives, which in turn will pick a Premier to head a new Government.
BOSTON, April 18 -- New England has money enough to fuel its economic machine; the principal need is a heavier hand on the throttle.
THIS is the warmweather season for vins roses. These are the pink wines that are described with a set of favorite adjectives as "sprightly," "fresh," "lively" and/or "young."

YOU remember the story of Bugle Ann, a fabulous foxhound with a voice of sheerest melody whose like never lived in any time or nation. Her trumpet-cry became a legend around Heaven Creek in the Missouri hills.

Sentiment in financial and business quarters received a lift last week, as leaders in many quarters voiced assurance that both business and future prospects were favorable for months ahead. Good first quarter production and divident reports also removed some of the pessimism that had existed, but the news was not enough to prevent the stock market from dropping into lower territory for the fourth successive week.
The fickle April weather canceled the entire National League schedule yesterday, including the rubber contest of the season's first series between the Giants and the Dodgers at the Polo Grounds.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 18 -A legal wrangle over the custody of American-born Katherine Cecilia Holmes, aged 2 1/2, was developing here today.

PRETORIA, South Africa, April 18 -- The election in South Africa this week was fought by both sides on the principle that it could well be decisive for this generation in South Africa and of major significance for the future of all Africa south of the Sahara.
ELIZABETH, N. J., April 18 -Eugene Monahan, a 44-year-old ex-convict, and his son, Michael, 15, were arraigned here today on charges of murdering two men in the hold-up of a local tavern last month.

MOUNT VERNON, Va. -Early spring at this historic home of George Washington once was a quiet season, given over to a few wealthy visitors who came here for leisurely strolls along the graveled paths beneath the flowering dogwood and pink-budding Judas trees. Many of them made annual stops at Mount Vernon en route north from Florida resorts, or on their way south to visit the gardens of the Carolinas.

" WHAT can we know even of the people one lives with every dry?" sighs a character in a Virginia Woolf novel. And what indeed -- an interviewer may ask -- can one hope to know of a person on short acquaintance?

Three concerts, the weekly recorded one on Wednesday between noon and 2 P. M. and two "live" programs, will be offered this week at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. All will be held in Room 213.

RAIN-DRENCHED soils present difficulties mixed with blessings. The difficulties increase with the amount of clay in the soil's make-up (all soils contain some clay). The blessings are in proportion to the organic or humus content.

LOS ANGELES, April 18 (UP) -Olympic Champion Parry O'Brien made the second longest shot put on record today as the University of Southern California track team downed the Los Angeles Athletic Team 83 2-3 to 52 1-3 in Memorial Coliseum.

A repeat performance of Strauss' "Die Fledermaus" at the City Center yesterday afternoon saw an improvement in balance and singing over what had been heard at the premiere about two weeks ago. Part of this resulted from the presence of several new singers; and, of course, the company had learned much from the previous performance.
The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association will open the season with a one-day tournament for Class A and B players at Green Brook Country Club, West Caldwell, N. J., on Thursday.

Corporate dividends may be paid to shareholders in cash or in property, or partly in each. When paid in any, medium other than money, the property is taxable to the recipient at the fair market value at the time it becomes income to the shareholder (Section 115 [j] of the Internal Revenue code).

THE long and complicated set of variations that Beethoven composed on a trite little theme by Diabelli belongs with the last quartets and several of the last sonatas as a typical example of the composer's otherworld introspection.

" WERE it left to me to decide whether we should have a Government without newspapers or newspapers without a Government," Thomas Jefferson wrote in 1787, "I should not hesitate for a moment to prefer the latter." And after a good deal of experience with a hostile and sometimes scurrilous press he provided a philosophical basis for his preference: "Where the press is free, and every man is able to read, all is safe."

NOW the City Center is appealing to the public for help. It has started a drive for $200,000. Considering that the Center operates -- often with distinction -- in three difficult and costly fields, drama, ballet and opera, it is not asking for a great deal. If you add the fact that the Center has been functioning for ten years without any public campaigns for contributions, it deserves not only indulgence but also support.

WHAT is lacking in an automobile that will make for safety, comfort and driving ease? The question was answered recently by 2,269 motorists in a poll taken on a voting machine by the Automobile Club of New York.

PALERMO, Sicily, April 18 -Americans Budge Patty of Los Angeles and Bernard Bartzen of San Antonio, Tex., continued their sweep of Italian tennis tournaments today by gaining the final of the Palermo tourney.

TOKYO, Sunday, April 19 -- The Allied Prisoner of War Command announced yesterday that a new riot broke out Friday among Communist captives on Yongcho Island, off the south coast of Korea, resulting in the killing of four prisoners and the wounding of forty-five.

MEXICO CITY, April 18 -- Melbourne was confirmed today as the site of the 1956 games and the International Olympic Committee expressed its "utmost confidence" that the Australian city would make a success of them.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said tonight that the State Department's career officers were dedicated to the country, not to any Democratic or Republican Administration.

Frederic C. Stecker, the new president of F. R. Tripler Co., started "reaching" in the retail buisiness at an early age. He got his first job with Tripler when he was 15 years old, and because he was over six feet tall even at that tender age, he was assigned to the collar department.

STRAWBERRIES are undoubtedly the most popular small fruit grown in this region. One of the highlights of the year is June and strawberry shortcake, but not many of us can indulge this appetite to the extent we would like. Perhaps if the ease with which this fruit can be produced were better known, more backyard gardeners would try strawberries.

More than two years have gone since the market for United States Government securities was restored to a free basis at the insistence of the Federal Reserve System and with the acquiescence of the Treasury executives of the Truman Administration.
American girls working in the United States Embassy in Moscow have been impelled to do some mail-order shopping for fashions they have glimpsed in State-side magazines.

PRESIDENT EISENHOWER'S fondness for golf, including practicing iron shots on the White House lawn and last week's outing on the links of the Augusta (Ga.) National Golf Club, is the mild sort of revolt all Presidents stage against the confinement of their job -- now probably the greatest burden placed on any human in the world.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 18 -Calumet Farm's Breeze By was seriously injured in a spill today at Keeneland and "definitely will miss the Kentucky Derby," according to Trainer Ben Jones.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., April 18 -- Doug Ford of Harrison, N. Y., rapidly gaining the reputation of being one of professional golf's most consistent players, made the third round his worst one here today but held on to his three-stroke lead in the $12,500 Virginia Beach open tournament.

HERE is the self-revealing story of an incorrigible but surprisingly urbane nonconformist, through a long life which began in England's Liverpool in 1867 and finds the writer today listed in "Who's Who", as a resident of Port Washington, L. I.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Sunday, April 19 -- Panmunjom is tremulous with excitement today, for the first sick and wounded United Nations prisoners of the Korean war will come down the road from the north tomorrow morning and be free men again. It will be a stirring moment as they are taken from their captors' hands.

FROM the term "geometrical" art most people infer, and correctly, a non-figurative pictorial style made up of circles and rectangles, and in sculpture, one of solids tailored in similar fashion. It is easy enough to argue against considering art and mathematics one and the same thing, but Mondrian and his circle were convinced that they had created an art, equal in stature to art's older avatars, but "unconditioned by subjective feeling."

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Fifty-four women from New York will be among 1,200 Republican women leaders called here for briefings Thursday and Friday "on the progress of the specific objectives of the Eisenhower Administration." President Eisenhower himself will give the final briefing at a luncheon Friday.

WHEN Flaubert began to collect the huge library of notes from which he later composed "Salammbo" he wrote: "The mood, the diction and all the elements which compose my tale must be of a piece, and I shall fail completely unless I give the reader the sensation of being present among the Carthaginians."

" A horse can haul more than he can carry. So can a motor truck." With that slogan the Fruehauf Trailer Company in five years -1915 to 1920 -- pulled its sales from $22,000 to $700,000. The slogan hasn't been in use for the past three decades or so, but the company hasn't stopped growing.

Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri's two major problems in this spring of an election year are so closely intertwined as to be almost indistinguishable. One is his budget; the other is his political future. Last week the Mayor was encountering new difficulties with both.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 17 -Turkey's newly won position of importance in world economy ems likely to undergo some were trials in the coming months spite many external signs of ability. The Government must like crucial decisions in the fields foreign exchange and agricultural policy lest progress achieved nce the inception of United States aid in 1947 be halted.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 5 -- Of the 2,000,000 Americans who passed through Australia on war service, between 1,500 and 2,000 have settled in this country, the great majority of them in the three eastern states of New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland.

THE management of television station WICC-TV, in Bridgeport, Conn., newly operating on Channel 43, has prepared a booklet which it distributes to guests scheduled to make their first appearance before a TV camera on the well-founded belief that the guests will know little or nothing about video techniques.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., April 18 -- King or Smoky Pine, Labrador retriever, owned by Mrs. Reginald G. Lewis of Eastern Maryland and handled by Vance Morris, today was best in a field of forty-eight in the Derby Stake for 2-year-old retrievers, highlight of the second day of competition in the annual spring field trials of the Long Island Retriever Club.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- The Defense Department indentified 194 Korean war casualties today in a new list that included thirty-five killed, 127 wounded, twenty-three missing, four injured, three captured, one dead of wounds and one returned to military control.
The Communists talked of peace last week but brought shooting war into a new country -- the little kingdom of Laos.

THE new gardener is often at a loss when he opens his package of newly purchased plants. Lucky is the one who can drive to a local nursery and have plants freshly dug for him. All kinds of plants, however, are ordered from catalogues and shipped by mail or express.

IS secret police chief Lavrenti P. Beria the real ruler of Russia today? That is the question which is posed before the world by Moscow's recent repudiation of the alleged "medical murder" plot. These charges, made only last January, had seemed clearly aimed at Beria.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The American Society of Newspaper Editors, concluding its three-day annual convention, received reports today of general progress and some setbacks in its fight against suppression of news by public agencies.
THE perennials found in modern gardens are the good old-fashioned kinds that have been close friends of gardeners for generations. They've won their place by reliable performance through the years.

THE prevailing spring weather has already had some influence on this year's plant pests and their control. That is, by means of the dormant spray program, so essential for fruit trees and many other woody plants.

Six lodgers, trapped by fire, were carried by firemen down ladders from top floors of the Catholic Worker House of Hospitality at 221-23 Chrystie Street, on the lower East Side, before dawn yesterday.

This country's constant quest for better methods and products has its minor disadvantages as well as its major advantages. New markets, before there has been a chance to satisfy them, are superseded by newer markets. And the threat of technological advances hangs over stockpile programs.

Physicians could achieve far better results in medical practice if they applied the principles of psychiatry as widely as those of chemistry and physiology, Dr. William C. Menninger, one of the country's eminent psychiatrists, said yesterday.

Topics of The Times for April 12 comments on the plight of those "persons whose school and college records would show three, four, five or more years of study in a foreign language * * * but who today have difficulty in translating the occasional sentences or phrases of that language" that they may come across in their reading of works written in English.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 18 -Pakistan would "welcome opportunities to discuss with the Western powers the immediate restoration of peace in this part of the world, including the Middle East," Mohammed Ali said today in an interview on his first day as Prime Minister of the largest Moslem nation in the world.

President Eisenhower has recommended to Congress that it pass legislation permitting the Federal Government to sell to private interests at "full fair value" all the Government-owned synthetic rubber plants. He has called also for inclusion in such legislation of terms assuring the availability of synthetic rubber for national needs in time of emergency, while pointing out that at present this nation's stockpiling program for this commodity is nearing completion.

" GARDENING is the only unquestionably useful job." However much one may agree or disagree with George Bernard Shaw's assertion, to this extent it is true: during April and May gardening is, unquestionably, a "job."

THE continuous and overly abundant supply of water, coupled with reasonably mild temperatures, can produce more growth on trees and shrubs than is ordinarily realized during a normal season. There will be little or no harmful effects to most plants -- unless the deluge continues.

India with her vast, undeveloped natural resources offers a fertile field for American investment, both on a Governmental and private plane, in the opinion of John F. Gehan, executive vice president of the American Export Lines.

IN the last few years something very sad has happened about city planning and the public. The public seemed to get bored with this problem, giving it little more than lip-service as a remote socio-economic endeavor.

WHAT contemporary American literature needs, and will presently have, is a new birth of humanism. Vitality it has had through most of this century, after having lost it temporarily in the decline from Lewis Mumford's "Golden Age."

As a teacher of social studies in the New York City high school system may I congratulate THE TIMES Magazine on publishing Dr. Benjamin Starr's excellent analysis of Delbert Clark's article, "Danger in What We Don't Know" (March 22).

THIS year being the five hundredth anniversary of the fall of Constantinople, special attention will be given to the Eastern Roman Empire.
