While the debate on why Old Rome fell continues, there will be renewed discussion of why Constantinople, New Rome, was able to hold out nearly a thousand years longer.

AT a few minutes after noon, aircraft 420, a four-engined airliner with twenty-one on board, was cleared out of Honolulu to San Francisco. Many hours later and more than halfway to the California coast the propeller of No. 1 engine tore free and was lost.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- The Chicago White Sox staggered to a 7-6 victory over the Cleveland Indians today in a game marked by twenty-six walks, four short of the major league record of thirty set in 1916 by the Detroit Tigers and Philadelphia Athletics.

THE several books of Maude Hutchins have all been notable for their single-minded. Freudian concentration on the boy-gets-girl relationship. "My Hero" is no more reticent. It follows the career of one Steve from birth to young manhood, "from innocence to carnal knowledge, to ideal love, to reality, to his code of behavior, 'I harm no one, so it's not bad.'"

When Korean peace feelers appeared at the end of last month, the Tokyo Stock Exchange broke sharply. Stories from Tokyo explaining the action were lugubrious over the state of Japan's merchandise foreign trade, still running at a deficit.
TOKYO, Sunday, April 19 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,589 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korean time:

ATLANTIC CITY, April 18 -The Jewish Labor Committee criticized today the plans of the American Jewish Tercentenary Committee for celebration of the 300th anniversary of Jewish settlement in the United States. The labor group stressed the contributions of Jewish trade unionists and of Jewish immigrants from Eastern Europe.

LONDON -- If the coat lapel of the guide who is showing tourists through an historic building or using the loudspeaker on a motor-coach tour sports the red and white official badge of the British Travel and Holidays Association's "Registered Guide," one can expect to receive a high standard of accurate information, courtesy, tact, humor and friendliness.

Wide variations in the sales showings of department stores were reported in this area last week. Stores that put on special promotional drives had increases, out observers estimated the average for the city would show a slight decline under the 1952 week.

A "bill" outlawing discrimination and segregation in Federally aided undertakings was passed yesterday at the final session in the ninth annual Model Congress, arranged by the Hunter College Political Science Club and the political science department.

BUENOS AIRES, April 18 -- The population of this capital's prisons continued to grow today as the Government announced that scores of rumormongers had been arrested. The Government's price-enforcement campaign already had resulted in the jailing of more than 750 merchants.

Setting new production records seems to be becoming a habit with this country's steel industry. Only last January a production mark of almost 10,000,000 tons of steel was recorded. Now comes word that last month the January figure was topped by a production of 10,153,000 tons.

FLORIBUNDA roses with their clusters of large single or double flowers are a husky and hardy group. Bushes planted in spring will be flowering by July at the latest and after the first year bloom constantly from June until November.

PRETORIA, South Africa, April 18 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan broadcast to the South African public tonight a request to the Opposition United party defeated in elections this week to give him the extra twelve or thirteen votes in Parliament necessary to take about 48,000 Cape Mulattoes off the Cape Province common voting roll without a constitutional crisis.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 18 -Nifty relief pitching by Christy Emerson, who retired five straight batters -- three via the strikeout route -- paced Yale to a 7-6 Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League victory over Navy today. The game was played in a drizzle.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 18 -Gen. Anapio Gomes has resigned the presidency of the Bank of Brazil as the result of a misunderstanding between him and Minister of Finance Horacio Lafer over the $300,000,000 loan to Brazil by the United States.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 18 -- Following is the text of the Brazilian resolution on the Korean question, which was approved unanimously today by the United Nations General Assembly:
The Catholic War Veterans meeting last night at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn elected William B. Walzer of 4376 Martha Avenue, the Bronx, as New York State Commander.

The several thousand physicians who attended the thirty-fourth annual meeting of the American College of Physicians here last week were faced with a problem of differential diagnosis that they do not encounter in daily practice. One of the world's largest postgraduate medical assemblies, it offered scores of scientific papers, dozens of clinics and symposia, continuous demonstrations, colored television programs and numerous conferences.
DETROIT, April 18 (UP) -- The Browns took advantage of inept fielding by the Tigers today to sweep both ends of a double-header, 8 -- 7 in the eleven-inning opener, and 3 -- 2 in the finale.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 18 -- A mob of irate students stormed the offices of the Dutch daily De Yrije Pers at Surabaya today, smashing glass windows, wrecking office equipment and damaging composing machines. Several Dutch staff members were molested and a photograph of Queen Juliana was torn up and burned.

A divided world has received great hope following the advent of President Dwight D. Eisenhower and the death of Joseph Stalin, declared the Rev. Dr. Louis L. Mann, rabbi of Temple Sinai, Chicago, in a sermon yesterday morning at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

AN average loss on passenger-train operations of half a billion dollars annually during the last four years is causing much figurative scratching of heads among railroad executives concerned with the financial stability of the industry. Various steps are being considered to eliminate or at least reduce these losses.

IN his brief foreword to "Three Battles," Maj. Gen. Orlando Ward, the Army's Chief of Military History, sums up as the book's purpose the portrayal of "difficulties of small unit commanders and soldiers in executing missions assigned by higher headquarters."

SIXTY, years ago, David Belasco's comedy, "The Girl I Left Behind Me," opened the newly built Empire Theatre. Making her first Broadway appearance before the glittering, white-tied and ermined first-nighters was a blue-eyed slip of an ingenue named Edna Wallace.

Although the number of minor offenses committed by juveniles in New York has remained relatively static, there have been substantial increases in serious law violations, a review of court records shows.

Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia, the Erie Basin hiring boss who was a reluctant witness at the State Crime Commission waterfront hearings, emerged yesterday as champion of a hiring hall for dock workers.

CAMDEN, N. J., April 18 -- Suppose you're the skipper of an oceangoing ship headed up the Delaware to discharge passengers or cargo. You've got a tight schedule. Time at the Philadelphia dock is limited. Or maybe your orders call for anchoring in midstream and not docking at all.

A RAKE is "an implement consisting of a bar with projecting pegs or prongs, set transversely, and used for gathering hay, stirring and spreading earth, etc." Almost any garden supply store nowadays may have as many as seven or eight different types in fully as many different sizes and lengths for lawn and garden use.

CENSUS BUREAU records show Dennis Day as one person, but he is really a trio. On the Jack Benny radio program he's a not overly bright kid of 18, while on his own television show he matures to his real age of 35.

IT LOOKS like a busy spring. Nine days after the close of the season of "American Dance" at the Alvin, the New York City Ballet will begin a six-week engagement at the City Center, from May 4 through June 14.

Through action taken by the City Planning Commission, which is expected to be approved by the Board of Estimate next Thursday, the city is slated to acquire from the Federal Government for $25,000 Mill Rock Island in the East River as an 8.6-acre park.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 18 -- Marines in full battle gear "captured" an atomized "beachhead" by land and helicopter today as the dust settled from one of the biggest nuclear explosions ever set off in the United States.
HARTFORD, Conn., April 18 -The Connecticut General Assembly, after three and a half months of sessions, has been unable to reach an agreement on a state tax program favored by Gov. John Davis Lodge.
With local district golf schedules virtually completed, the Metropolitan Golf Association is expected to have its entire schedule ready for publication within the next few days.

THE Franklinia (Gordonia donia alatamaha) is grad- coming better known and more widely cultivated, and deservedly so. It is a shrub of extraordinary beauty and value, particularly for its early fall flowers. Spring is a good planting time.

THE other day as Walter Slezak approached the Morosco Theatre to begin his transformation into the embezzling seraph of "My 3 Angels," he overheard one elderly lady tell another: "That man Slezak. He's revolting looking." Mr. Slezak braked his burly body. "I am not revolting looking," he told the lady.
" JUST meet the ball," says the man who has hit more home runs than any other active player in baseball today. However, Big Jawn Mize is not urging beginners to swing for

In this newspaper's magazine section today Soviet Secret Police Chief Lavrenti P. Beria is termed the "purger of the purgers." Mr. Beria's right to that title has been reaffirmed once again by the latest events in his native land, the Soviet Caucasian "republic" of Georgia.

BEGINNING May 29, Turkey will observe a ten-day celebration of the 500th anniversary of Turkish rule over Istanbul. Twelve stamps are being issued to commemorate the fall of the city, then Constantinople, to Mohammed II the Conqueror.

THIS spring gardeners in the Northeast have had no excuse to complain of aching muscles. As long ago as January seedsmen in California were plowing and sowing their acres and gardeners were planting rose bushes.

At auctions here this week in the many categories of household and personal adornments will be a collection of English period furniture and decorative accessories. Part of the English group, from the New York residence of the late Mrs. Thomas W. Lamont, will be offered at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, while early American furniture, clocks and decorations will be sold at the Plaza Art Galleries, 9 East Fifty-ninth Street.

BUTLER, Md., April 18 (AP) -War Gold, 11-year-old gelding owned by Mrs. C. W. Williams, won the Grand National Steeplechase over a rain-soaked countryside today after all the pre-race favorites had been scratched.

FOR some decades the advertising industry has cried aloud to be the target of a genuine satirical novel. Beginning with Frederic Wakeman's "The Hucksters," the challenge has not been wanting in takers. But, in the opinion of one diligent reader (with the possible exception of Dorothy Sayers' wonderful "Murder Must Advertice"), the assailants have been turned aside, and what purported to be novels have been, instead, mere farces, or worse, thinly disguised, vengeful polemics.

THAT loan bureau, or "benign pawnshop plan," for new playwrights on which John Golden is toiling -- and on specific orders from the man you are not to call it the Golden plan since he is not interested in personal publicity but in results -- is making encouraging headway.

WE'VE been a long time waiting for a really good novel dealing with the material that wove itself into Western balladry, but here is one at last. It even takes its title from "Goodbye, Old Paint," though it isn't a cowboy story or anything of the kind.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, called on the Soviet Union tonight to accept President Eisenhower's challenge and cooperate in a program of peace that would close "a black chapter of distrust."

THOSE earlier novels, "The Amboy Dukes," "Cry Tough" and "The Big Brokers," were abrasive, rock-hard documentaries of people whose environment and inclinations fitted them poorly for life inside the law.

MOSCOW, April 18 -- The former State Security Minister of the Soviet Republic of Georgia, Gen. N. Rukhadze, and a group of his associates have been arrested for fabricating and prosecuting "cookedup charges" against workers of the Georgia Communist party and the Government of Georgia, it was disclosed here today.

HAMPTON BAYS, L. I. -Following the lead of New York City this little community, which straddles the Shinnecock Canal in eastern Suffolk County, begins next weekend a summer-long celebration of its 300th birthday.

JUST about the most transcendental piece of intelligence these days in the world of hot music, a highly diffuse and riven community at best, is the news that Benny Goodman, the Charlemagne of the clarinet, has put together a new big band (with some old hands) and will take it across the country on a series of high-class gigs, or auditorium dates, beginning this week.

Women are taking over the steering wheels in the sports of yachting and pleasure boating. That's the startling view of Howard Larson who came to New York the other night from Milwaukee, where he heads up sales and surveys for Evinrude motors, to speak to a gathering of the Marine Trades Association of New York.
EDUCATIONAL programs have been planned for this week by three New Jersey garden clubs. Planting techniques, flower arrangements, propagation and conservation are among the subjects to be covered.

PARIS, April 18 -- After a study of the proposed six-power political charter drafted by the Constitutional Assembly of the European Coal and Steel Community, the Council of Europe's General Affairs Committee decided today to urge the governments to hasten adoption of the plan.

Many buyers were in the wholesale market here last week expressing special interest in promotional merchandise for May sales and Mother's Day, according to McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office. Gains on the retail level are expected to continue through the summer.

THE ghosts of modern fiction, says Elizabeth Bowen in her excellent introduction to this collection, "build themselves up out of the neuroses of those who see them -- as though the seers had been selected prey."

LANNY BUDD, hero of Mr. Sinclair's running history of the world since the first World War, has already been the allseeing eye of ten books containing possibly five or six thousand pages. Now Lanny comes back with 555 additional pages, which must bring his wordage close to two million.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -Deems Taylor, composer and music commentator, has given to the Library of Congress a collection of his music manuscripts.

A BIT of an international incident seems to be developing -- or has developed -from the team matches played in this country ten weeks ago between a British women's team, the European women's champions, and three American teams.

WHEN Emlyn Williams opens a three-week season sponsored by S. Hurok, tomorrow night at the Bijou with his rendering of "Bleak House," he will be returning to a New York familiar with his work in reincarnating the drama and comedy of Dickens.

IN 1946 Edwin G. Nourse was absorbed in his economic studies at the Brookings Institution in Washington, when he was abruptly swept into the mainstream of American political development. Public opinion, supported for once by every pressure group and every political faction, called out for continuous analysis of the physiology of our economic life with a view to practicing preventive medicine against the pathological disturbances to which it is vulnerable.

TODAY in Washington, D. C., those who are interested in contemporary homes are being given the opportunity to examine eight varied examples both inside and out. The occasion is the second annual Modern House Tour sponsored by the Sidwell Friends School, the proceeds to benefit that school's scholarship fund.

Mr. Oakes, writing on Senator McCarthy's "status," misses the point altogether. The Senator's status is not determined by what anybody in Washington thinks. What the papers say will not determine his status.

A fight against the new Congressional proposal to halt future public housing -- at a time when the city faces both a housing shortage and a continuing influx of Puerto Rican and other migrants -- was urged repeatedly yesterday at a conference on Puerto Rican problems here attended by 800 persons.

THE hottest news about books -- and it isn't along Publishers' Row yet -- is that Alan Paton's new novel has arrived at Scribner's. A postal clerk with X-ray eyes told us of its arrival and he also told us the title: "Too Late Phalarope."

CHANNEL 7, beginning April 27, is going to do something to vary the old movie diet that is the lot of the late evening television viewer, when it introduces "Talk of the Town," a Monday through Friday series of "live" variety musical programs to fill the hour from 11 o'clock to midnight.

Fifteen members of two rival teen-age gangs and the mother of one of the boys were arrested yesterday in South Jamaica, Queens, as an aftermath of the fatal shooting of a 15-year-old boy and the stabbing of another boy late Friday night.

The overturn of Pakistan's Cabinet has come as a surprise and shock here just as it has in India, and, we presume, in Pakistan itself. The deposed Premier, Mr. Nazimuddin, has indicated his resistance to the action of the Governor General, but his successor, Mohammed Ali, is already assuming the reins.

Young women, including Miss Margot Potter and Miss Jean Read are aiding members of the executive committeein arrangements for the Second anniversary luncheon of the Spence-Chapin Corner Shop Committee to .be given on Wednesday in the Collion Room of the Pierre for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service.

Despite adverse weather conditions over a large part of the main wheat belt, prospects appear good for harvesting another billion-bushel crop this year. Although such a yield would be about 275,000,000 bushels below that of 1952, a harvest of that size would be just about sufficient to take care of domestic needs and anticipated export demand.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 18 -- The Communists of Yugoslavia whose leaders hold the reins of government have been called upon to intensify their "struggle against religious prejudices and superstitions."

The vanguard of more than 1,200 American and Canadian newspaper executives started to arrive in the city yesterday for the sixty-seventh annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association which will open Tuesday at the Waldorf- Astoria Hotel.

Major changes in the methods of teaching citizenship are taking place in the nation's junior and senior high schools as a result of three years of work by the Citizenship Education Project of Teachers College, Columbia University. Last week the Carnegie Corporation, which has financed the program, made an additional grant of $800,000 to enable the work to go on for three years more.

PARIS, April 18 -- President Eisenhower did a great service to his old team, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, when he recaptured the diplomatic initiative for the West on the eve of NATO's critical April meeting.

The total active United States merchant fleet, including private and Government-owned vessels, increased by twenty-one ships as of April 1, it was reported last week in the "Merchant Marine Data Sheet" issued by the Maritime Administration.

PARIS, April 18 -- Lord Ismay, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said today that, on the basis of analyses made to date by the organization, there was no reason to regard the Soviet Union's current peace offensive as anything more than a tactical maneuver or to assume that Moscow's long-range expansionist objectives had in any way altered.

LIKE its Vesuvius, Italy's Anna Magnani smoulders even in repose. Now making her initial visit to these shores for the premiere of her latest vehicle. "Bellissima," the actress can claim an international film reputation as a searing symbol of gutter femininity, and possibly the most awesomely familiar surname since the abdication of Garbo.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- Chicago area's business indexes point to new high marks in operations for many segments of industry. The Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported new February records for steel production, electric power output, air travel, postal receipts, real estate and banking.

Hunter College made a clean sweep of seven matches to retain its women's intercollegiate fencing team championship yesterday on the winner's strips. It was the twenty-fifth annual event. The victorious squad was made up of Louise Knab, who was unbeaten in all seven tests; Grace Milo, 6 and 1, and Beverly Feigelman, 6 and 1.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 18 -Princeton University's undefeated track team won twelve of sixteen events today and downed Columbia, 99 -- 41, in Palmer Stadium.

I see no reason for rejoicing over the recent decision by the Government to advance the general pattern of interest rates by offering 3.25 per cent for long-term Government bonds. The increase in the cost of money -- and this is the meaning of the increase in the interest rate -- obviously would make inflation worse if we were still in a period of inflation.

THE country bumpkin who went to New York a generation ago and shortly acquired the Brooklyn Bridge for his very own was properly recognized as a stock character. He was a hick, a rube, a yokel, a hayseed. But we don't seem to have any name for the stock character who is now coming from the vast and busy cities back into the country to live out his days in bucolic delight.

Gold, a lively topic in any economic discussion, is again receiving attention in connection with the prospect of peace in Korea and its expected deflationary effect. Since inflationary pressures of recent years would have been intensified by any increase in the price of gold, now -- the argument goes -- deflationary tendencies will bring nearer the day when it would be desirable to take such inflationary action.
Premier Georgi M. Malenkov touched off the Soviet "peace" drive in a speech in Moscow on March 15. He said:

President Peron of Argentina is facing his greatest crisis since becoming an unchallenged dictator, in 1945. He is such an obnoxious type of dictator that it is tempting to do some wishful thinking today. However, we know too much now about the technique of modern totalitarianism not to realize that a ruler who retains control of the army and police is virtually unassailable.

The seventy-eighth running of the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs in Louisville will be broadcast by the C. B. S. television and radio networks Saturday, May 2. Until now, the televising of the turf classic had been problematic because of the high broadcasting fee demanded by Churchill Downs officials.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 19 -- With a final outstanding showing in his sailing dinghy Agony, Arthur Knapp today wrapped up and sealed the over-all championship at the Larchmont Yacht Club.
BERLIN, April 19 -- The East German Parliament has sent an appeal to Britain's House of Commons asking it to exert pressure for an immediate conference of the Big Four nations to reunify Germany,

Late romantic music formed the program presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Dimitri Mitropoulos, Saturday night at Carnegie Hall. With one exception, the offerings were Russian, including the most recent of the compositions, Rachmaninoff's Piano-Concerto, No. 3, in which Anna Zydis was the soloist.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- State Department officials said today that the transfer of John Paton Davies Jr. from his post at Bonn, Germany, to the United States Embassy in Lima, Peru, was "routine."
British pound sterling and the Canadian dollar fluctuated narrowly in foreign exchange trading during the past week. Amount of dealings reported were only moderate in volume and mostly routine.

Yugoslav trade-union leaders who criticize the American Federation of Labor for opposing admission of their labor organization into the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions do not understand, or perhaps they ignore, the basis of the A. F. L.'s policy.

PARIS, April 19 -- Maurice Thorez, head of the French Communist party, who has just returned from two years in Moscow, has told his party leaders that the Kremlin's peace offensive dominates everything else in the present situation, according to an article to be published in tomorrow's Le Figaro.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Monday, April 20 -- One hundred United Nations soldiers, including thirty Americans, were freed from Communist captivity today as the opponents in the Korean war began the exchange of sick and wounded prisoners under a recently negotiated agreement.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Walt Masterson shut out his old teammates, the Boston Red Sox, on five hits today and the Washington Senators won their first game of the season, 4 to 0. Jackie Jensen led the Washington attack with a double and a triple.

AMSTERDAM, April 19 -- As the monetary position continues to improve, the Netherlands Government is contemplating permitting imports beyond the present limitation. Another sign of the favorable position is that the Netherlands will repay to the Chase National Bank on May 14 the $15,000,000 loan, part of which was due on June 30 and the remainder on Dec. 31.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Following are the votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-call in Congress during the period April 11 to April 18:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 19 -- Screen Actors Guild Opposition to the so-called "thirty-day" clause in the Taft-Hartley Act governing union membership will be outlined to the Senate Subcommittee on Labor and Public Welfare at a hearing Tuesday in Washington.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce may find that she is traveling to take up her post in Rome at her own expense unless the State Department can convince the Controller General that there is warrant for making the trip on an Italian liner.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The untimely death of Prof. Eduard C. Lindeman is an occasion for profound sorrow to many hundreds of students by whom he was revered as a teacher, both in this country and abroad.
DENVER, April 19 -- One of the most spectacular business mergers in the history of Rocky Mountain financing has been dissolved.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 19 -- In a demarche to the United States, British, French and Turkish Governments, the Israeli Foreign Ministry drew attention today to the steadily deteriorating situation" that has led to more and more serious border incidents culminating Friday in an attack on five Israeli fishing boats.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The Smithsonian Institution is cracking at the seams and it wants Congress to give a million dollars so it can put itself back together again.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, was accused today of using the Fish and Wildlife Service for "political purposes" in his dismissal Friday of Albert M. Day from his post as director.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 19 (AP) -- Straight Face and Correspondent, among the ranking candidates for the Kentucky Derby, appeared today as likely headliners in the $25,000 added Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland Thursday.

BOSTON, April 19 (AP) -- Suffolk Downs will have twelve stakes events, topped by the $50,000 Massachusetts Handicap, during the sixty-day race meeting that opens tomorrow at the seaside track in East Boston.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 166 Korean war casualties in a list that reported thirty killed, 115 wounded, thirteen missing, four injured and four captured. The following were from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

Organized industry struck yesterday at the principal prop supporting organized labor's demands for higher wages this year. The National Association of Manufacturers asserted that the ben efits of increased industrial productivity should be distributed in the form of lower prices for all Americans rather than fatter pay envelopes for workers in unionized industries.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- The people who design and manufacture the packages in which America's multi-billion-dollar output of goods is brought to the consumer will open a four-day meeting on mile-long Navy Pier here tomorrow.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., April 19 -- Ann C. Voorhees of Short Hills won the hunter seat horsemanship championship and Margie Shannon of Montclair took the saddle seat laurels in the third and final day of the Northern New Jersey Horse Show Association fixture at the West Orange Armory today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19 -- Before leaving today for the Paris meeting of the Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Lester B. Pearson, Minister for External Affairs of Canada and President of the General Assembly, dispatched to negotiators at Panmunjom the text of Brazilian resolution, approved on Saturday by the Assembly. The vote was 57 to 0, with no abstentions.

John E. Carton, president of the Police Conference of the State of New York, who also is president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association of the city, sent a telegram to Governor Dewey yesterday, asking him to take steps to legalize off-track betting, bingo and a state lottery.
Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Administrator, made public yesterday two opinions regarding service increases.

Fans of Charles Dickens and of that facile actor, Emlyn Williams, will beat a path tonight to the Bijou. At 8 o'clock, Mr. Williams, attired in the costume of the famous novelist, will unveil his latest gallery of thirty-six portraits from "Bleak House," coincidentally marking the restoration of the Bijou to the legitimate stage after an absence of six years and, according to the Encyclopedia Britannica, the centenary of the book's publication.

The Early Music Foundation completed its season last night with its sixth concert -- a program of sixteenth and seventeenth-century music at Carnegie Recital Hall. Inability to obtain a needed organ played hob with the final group, but Clerambault's cantata, "Orphee," and the madrigals in English had considerable charm.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his letter of April 11 Walter F. Willcox made a good case for a smaller House of Representatives.

ST. LOUIS, April 19 (AP) -- Stan Musial's first home run of the National League season in the fifth inning today enabled the Cardinals to gain a 4-3 victory over the Braves in a game delayed once by a blinding snow.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Monday, April 20 -- The first American prisoner of war to reach here from Panmunjom this morning arrived at 10:07 o'clock [8 P. M. Sunday, Eastern standard time] by helicopter. He was Pfc. Robert C. Stell of Baltimore, who was taken prisoner twenty-eight months ago.
The success of the season of "American Dance" presented by the Rothschild Foundation at the Alvin Theatre continues undisturbed, with even the Sunday matinee a virtual sell-out.

BOSTON, April 19 (AP) -- The strongest foreign delegation in the 57-year history of the Boston A. A. marathon -- thirty-five entries representing six nations -- will be in tomorrow's starting field of 191, which wil get away at suburban Hopkinton for the jaunt of 26 miles 385 yards.
PARIS, April 19 -- That France's foreign trade troubles persist despite the measures that have been taken to stimulate exports and to reduce imports is pointed up by the newest statistics.

Interest charged on short-term loans to business concerns by New York City banks during the first half of March this year averaged 3.25 per cent, unchanged from the postwar high in the first half of last December, according to the quarterly survey of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PARIS, April 19 -- Experts here who have been studying the Far Eastern outlook in the light of President Eisenhower's speech Thursday have found it difficult to avoid the conclusion that a general Asian settlement such as the President urged would entail full recognition of the Communist regime in China.

Colorful designs on glass appear in a new collection of lamps and trays by John Kelly and Robert Vaughn. The objects are available through decorators in the designers' showroom at 127 West Fifty-sixth Street.
The program for today's session of Newspaper Week follows, all the events to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria unless otherwise noted:

David Rockefeller, banker, philanthropist and civic leader, and Senator Herbert H. Lehman received last night the 1953 World Brotherhood Awards of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America in recognition of their contributions to the ideal of human fellowship.

It's a good thing Norman L. Hatch is the head of the Latin Department at Phillips Exeter Academy and not its athletic director. If he were, the chances are that the only sport on the spring curriculum would be lacrosse. And perhaps it would be the only one played during the fall and winter, too.
BONN, April 19 -- A German engineering company of Dortmund has contracted to build in Yugoslavia the most modern oil refinery in all of southeast Europe.

The annual exhibition of work by members of the Sculptors Guild at the American Museum of Natural History is one of the two large art shows being held this week, the other being the seventh National Print Annual, which opens Wednesday at the Brooklyn Museum.

Stephen Spender, poet and critic, who recently has been lecturing at the University of Cincinnati, has a book of non-fiction on Harcourt, Brace's list for June 19 entitled "Learning Laughter." It is an account of his trip last year from Marseilles to Haifa on "a children's boat" and of his tour of Israel, where children from more than thirty countries were living together.

ROME, April 9 -- The Most Rev. Fulton J. Sheen, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, preaching at the American Roman Catholic Church of Santa Susanna, warned his congregation this morning not to put too much faith in Soviet peace overtures and not to "expect to receive peace from above -- from a government or from the United Nations."

ALBANY, April 19 -- Mayor Impellitteri and other New York City employes who served in the armed forces in World War I may have their eventual pension allowances increased under legislation approved today by Governor Dewey.

To the very young the progress of April spells warmth, and warmth means no hats and coats, as well as an end to arguments about whether or not hats and coats should be worn. To the very young April is soon come and gone, a pretty but short pathway to May.
Little girls "grow up" suddenly at about their twelfth birthday and begin to take a keen interest in clothes.

Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy warned his 8,000 department employes yesterday to be on guard against an active attempt by Communists to seize control of their activities through a new union sparked by some of the same persons who were thrown out of the Congress of Industrial Organizations as pro-Communist suspects.

ROME, April 19 -- The campaign for the general election June 7, which will decide the political complexion of the Italian Parliament for the next five years, got under way officially today with an estimated 5,000 meetings all over Italy.

DETROIT, April 19 (AP) -- The league-leading Browns, sparked by Bobby Young's clutch single and daring base running, scored three runs in the eleventh inning today to whip the Tigers, 6 -- 3, for a clean sweep of the three-game series.

The Rev. Donald B. Reitz, associate pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that in these days of special diets many persons found to their sorrow that it was relatively easy to grow outwardly but not spiritually.

The Giants, who suffered more than their share of Sunday idleness this time a year ago, got a little more of the same yesterday when cold weather forced the postponement of the opener of their two-game series with the Phillies at the Polo Grounds. Since rain had canceled Saturday's encounter with the Dodgers, the Giants therefore saw an entire week-end with an expected attendance of 50,000 or more go by the board.

Several young American composers had their music played last night at the museum of Modern art at a concert given by the League of Composers. The offerings ranged from unaccompanied violin to string quartet.
Three Protestant ministers in sermons here yesterday morning appealed to church members to take a forthright stand in opposing crime and other evils in New York City.

The Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, in his sermon yesterday at the Riverside Church, decried the effects of mechanization on the spirituality of this generation and urged that more thought be given to "the value that God has placed on the individual soul."

One man was shot and killed and two others were captured last night when the-three men, suspected of having robbed a Queens motion-picture theatre of $2,800, encountered four detectives who had been trailing them on suspicion, the police reported.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 19 (UP) -- A third Vietminh column invaded Laos today as French Union troops battled strong Communist armies in the northern part of the beleaguered Indo-Chinese kingdom.
BOSTON, April 19 (AP) -- Benny Goodman was placed in an oxygen tent tonight in his room in the Ritz Carlton Hotel after collapsing for the second time within eighteen hours.
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 19 (Reuters) -- Bulldozers flattened the homes of 7,000 Africans today after the natives had been forced but of two shanty-town settlements in the suburbs of Nairobi.

The Isbrandtsen Company has called the attention of the Maritime Administration to a report that one of the Japan-to-the-United States steamship freight conferences is about to institute a dual rate system.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 19 -- As Israel completed her fifth year tonight her first Premier, David Ben-Gurion, told her citizens that 12.6 per cent of all Jews in the world now lived here compared with 5.6 per cent when the republic was established.

RANGOON, Burma, April 19 (AP) -- A Government spokesman today said that William J. Sebald, United States Ambassador, had approached Prime Minister U Nu with a proposal that the Burmese Army halt its campaign against the Chinese Nationalist guerrillas in northeast Burma.

SECAUCUS, N. J., April 19 -- Strong-armed thieves lugged a 300-pound safe from the dining room of a pig farmer's home here last evening to secluded meadowlands two miles away. Then, working leisurely in the tranquil dusk without fear of the prying eyes of the law, they cracked open the safe and made off with $2,000 in cash.

The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis expressed fear yesterday that a large amount of gamma globulin might be expended in non-efficacious use under the allocation program announced last week by the Office of Defense Mobilization. The foundation offered its help to state health officers who may elect to employ community-wide injections in efforts to halt poliomyelitis epidemics.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican leader of the Senate, suggested today that every effort be made to "settle all the questions of the Far East in one bite."
Six students on the New York Times Youth Forum's television program last night agreed that strong nationalism was a vital thing but that there were at least two important exceptions.
" HE'S a good horse," grudgingly admitted Jockey Eric Guerin, speaking with the caution characteristic of all horsemen. They have a holy horror of superlatives.

PITTSBURGH, April 19 -- John Greenleaf Whittier, the noted author of Snowbound, should have been at Forbes Field to write the story of today's ball game between the Dodgers and the Pirates, which the National League champions won by a 12-4 score.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- Perhaps the Yankees ought to demand a saliva test of Alex Kellner, Athletics' southpaw. Here is a pitcher who used to lose to the New Yorkers consistently -- six times last year -- but in the first week of the 1953 season, the world champions already have faced him twice and after eighteen innings they have yet to score a run against him.

Eighteen hundred persons attended a mass meeting yesterday in the Hunter College auditorium, Sixty-eighth Street and Park Avenue, to commemorate the tenth anniversary of the battle of the Warsaw Ghetto. The meeting was under the sponsorship of the New York Chapter of the American Jewish Committee, the Metropolitan Council of B'nai B'rith and the Club of Polish Jews.
As part of a general tightening up of longshore working practices, a "no work, no pay" order with respect to shop stewards on New York's piers was issued yesterday.
Twenty-six educational institutions and agencies received grants totaling $1,890,000 from the Carnegie Corporation of New York in the first three months of the year.

HAMBURG, Germany, April 19 -- The Christian Democratic Union party opened its convention today in an atmosphere that made clear that it hoped to win the forthcoming general elections on the basis of the achievements of its leader, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, in foreign affairs, European integration and the economic recovery of West Germany in the last four years.
Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission, said yesterday that he was not a candidate for Mayor, but added that he would not resist a draft.

SMITHTOWN, L. I., April 19 -- The Rice Farms' black gelding Mount Merrion from Huntington, guided by Frank Rice, won the championship with 14 points at the Smithtown hunter trials on the Glad Acres Farm today. Reserve went to Bourne Breena, a chestnut mare owned and ridden by Mrs. James T. Kelly of Huntington.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 19 -- A feeling of security and being part of a family group was described today as a basic need fin training children to live in a democracy society.

Reporting hopeful prospects for continued good business throughout the country, newspaper executives, here for their annual Newspaper Week, said yesterday that the American people appeared generally to be viewing Soviet "peace" moves with caution.

As part of the celebration of its hundredth anniversary, the Studebaker Corporation announced yesterday release to non-theatrical exhibitors of three half-hour movies telling how the company grew from a blacksmith shop where two brothers shod a horse for two bits.
TOKYO, Monday, April 20 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 381, for Sunday to 6 P. M.:

Although the New York Central Railroad spent a record $140,000,000 last year for new equipment and improvements, William White, president, said in the annual report for 1952 that "there will have to be a tapering off until earnings are more substantial and working capital has increased."
The Roman Catholic Church in this country is threatened from within and without, as it faces a shortage of priests, the Rev. John Schultz of Washington declared here yesterday.
Joy and excitement swept last night through the homes of prisoners of war released from Communist camps in North Korea as their names were made public.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19 -- In the year since administration of the former Japanese-mandated islands in the Pacific was transferred from the Navy to the Department of the Interior, political growth and competence has been demonstrated by the Micronesians, the United States reports in its annual statement to the United Nations on the trust territory.

PARIS, April 19 -- Roy M. Cohn and Gerard David Schine, aides to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, who came to Europe two weeks ago to inquire into matters of "waste, efficiency and loyalty" in the operation of the United States Information Services abroad, were put on the griddle today by British correspondents at a press conference here.

A call to Jews to be "daring" in defense of civil liberties was made last night by Dr. Maurice N. Eisendrath, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, in an address opening the eightieth anniversary biennial convention of the organization of Reform Judaism

James Hall, bass, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. His program contained the final aria from Bach's cantata, "Christ lag in Todesbanden"; other arias by Handel, Lully Haydn and Mozart; the Bramhs "Vier erneste Qesaenge" items by Purcell and Arne and a final group featuring Negro spirituals.

MR. CHAIRMAN, Ladies and Gentlemen: have tried to talk sense to the American people in this campaign. I have sought to present the books and the issues that confront us and will confront our children and our grandchildren -- our issue's issues, so to speak.

LONDON, April 19 -- Naturally a professional playgoer is not expected to enjoy himself in the theatre. But sometimes that is unavoidable. Take, for example, a farce entitled "Dear Charles," in which Yvonne Arnaud is giving a droll performance at the New Theatre.
LONDON, April 19 -- Stock market and business reactions to the budget have been very much as expected.

Strange things are happening. The owner of a television set obtained a leave of absence on Saturday from the Federal Communications Commission and by chance discovered a revolutionary development in the entertainment world. It is called the legitimate theatre.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $73,267,285,411. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Many reservations have been made for the rummage luncheon to be held tomorrow in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Lots for Little Thrift Shop, 1214 Third Avenue. Mrs. Charles Banks Belt is chairman of the luncheon committee and Mrs. Alexander J. McDonnell is president of the shop.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., April 19 (AP) -- Doug Ford of Harrison, N. Y., became professional golf's second leading money winner for 1953 today when he shot his fourth successive sub-par round to win the $12,500 Virginia Beach open tournament.

TOKYO, Monday, April 20 -- The United Nations command prepared today to resume full-scale negotiations with the Communists for an armistice in the Korean war, with the vexed question of repatriation of prisoners still apparently the main obstacle in the path of an agreement.

Sales and leased machinery income of the Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation rose 47 per cent last year over the 1951 figure, and net earnings after taxes advanced from $9,745,779 to $10,701,323. After deducting preferred dividends, the common stock earned $3.41 on each of 2,952,670 shares, against $4.01 on 2,266,647 shares in 1951.

The majority of gas utility companies in the Pacific Northwest suddenly swung their support to a project to pipe natural gas into their area from Canada as hearings before the Federal Power Commission in Washington were recessed last Thursday.

Christians continually fail in their responsibility to become "good shepherds" who should utilize their lives as "staffs" to prod men when they falter and to rescue them when they stray from Christ, the Rev. Dr. James A. Pike, Dean of the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine), declared yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19 -- Through its official observer at the United Nations the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions is prepared to ask the Economic and Social Council tomorrow to take steps to avoid possible economic and financial dislocations that might arise from decreases in the tempo of rearmament.

TRENTON, April 19 -- Managers of major party candidates for nominations for Governor made customary predictions of victory today in the New Jersey primary elections Tuesday. In the state's 3,955 election districts the polls will be open from 7 A. M. to 8 P. M.

MOTORISTS moving up Bronx River Parkway sometimes catch a fleeting glimpse of a Union foot soldier standing right in the Bronx River south of Gunhill Road Bridge and wonder why he was ever put there. It seems the soldier was to have guarded a G. A. R. plot in Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx in 1898 but when he left the sculptor's hands one of his legs broke in transit.

Cotton futures prices followed an even keel last week. At the close of trading on Friday on the New York Cotton Exchange quotations were unchanged to 9 points higher, or 45 cents a bale. This compared with a net change of 30 cents lower to 30 cents higher the week before.
ALBANY, April 19 -- Governor Dewey vetoed today two Sunday Blue Law bills because of widespread uncertainty over their effects.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The news is interesting that Senator McCarthy's group investigating the Government's international information service has unearthed "seventy-five authors established as, or suspected of being, communistic" on the shelves of the United States State Department public libraries throughout the world.

OSCEOLA, Iowa, April 19 (UP) -- A Burlington Railroad passenger train was derailed last night, killing three persons and injuring nineteen. A railroad shop employe was credited with preventing a far worst accident by flagging down another train speeding toward the wreck.
" I have just come into a legacy," said the cute young thing, "and I want to know how to invest it. Have you any suggestions?"
Edward Lindsay of The Decatur (Ill.) Herald and Review was re-elected president of the American Council on Education for Journalism at its annual meeting last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 19 (AP) -- Six holes and almost hopelessly down in the early stages, Edean Anderson of Montana brought herself back into contention and dethroned the defending champion, Mrs. Lyle Bowman of California, in the final of the Trans-Mississippi golf tournament today.

MOSCOW, April 19 -- Leopoldo Bravo, Argentine Ambassador, announced today what he described as a "successfull" conclusion of "the fundamental basis for a trade agreement between the Soviet Union and Argentina."

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 19 -- President Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, bitter rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1952, met as friendly competitors on a golf course today in a state that played a key role in deciding that the right to run for the Presidency would go to General Eisenhower.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., April 19 -- The business community of this Monmouth County shore resort set the stage today for a state-wide revolt against new enforcement of the anti-gambling laws by announcing that it would hold a car raffle Friday despite the threat of prosecution.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Monday, April 20 (AP) -- American soldiers returning today from Communist prison camps told a story of generally good treatment, with many obvious Red shadings. None appeared to have been won over by Communist pressure in the camps.
ABILENE, Tex., April 19 (AP) -- A Tulsa concern today bought $2,300,000 in Texas oil properties from a group including Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 19 -- There's a new stir of activity these days in and around the United Nations headquarters on the East River. Indoors, it's cleaning; outdoors, planting. In a word -- spring.

Shareholders of the North Butte Mining Company, which on Jan. 21 sold all its assets except cash, accounts receivable and causes of action of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company for $2,000,000, are being circularized with an offer to buy their stock for 88 cents a share less stock transfer taxes.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 19 -- The paralysis of Iran's legislative body, caused by the painful problem of whether to hand Premier Mohammed Mossadegh control of the Army, continued today as a boycott by Opposition deputies again prevented a quorum.

Consolidated net income of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company fell to $39,981,610 last year -- 20 per cent below the 1951 figure of $50,216,838, the company reported over the week-end. The earnings were equal to $4.61 a share, compared with $5.79 a share for the previous year.

The story is told about a certain famous headmaster of an English public school who had one of his problem students on the carpet. When the young man was brought into his presence the exasperated educator opened the conference with a question. "Jones," he demanded wrathfully, "did you come here to get an education, or just to learn things?"

The Amphibious Training Command of Little Creek, Norfolk, Va., will conduct a double ceremony today involving an exchange of posts between two of the command's highest ranking officers. Rear Admiral Augustus J. Wellings, U. S. N., commanding the training program, will switch assignments with Rear Admiral Rufus T. Rose, U. S. N.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, April 20 (AP) -- United States Third and Seventh Division troops and Belgian infantrymen hurled back yesterday an attack by 750 Chinese Communists northwest of Kumhwa, on the central Korean front. The foe struck behind a twenty-minute artillery barrage.

As remarkable a collection of German white wines as has traveled to this country in many years arrived at Sherry Wine and Spirits late last week. They came from the Treasure Cellar (Schatz-keller) of the Kesselstatt holdings in the Moselle River region, and were imported by Frank Schoonmaker.

Continuing its concerts of music by contemporary composers of the smaller European nations, the New York Public Library presented a program of Swiss compositions yesterday afternoon. The event was arranged in cooperation with the Swiss Music Library and cinsisted of four chamber-music works.

LONDON, April 15 -- London's stores are gearing themselves for the influx of foreigners expected during the coming months. Already a good number are here and day by day the hotels are getting more crowded.

Richard C. Patterson Jr., retiring United States Minister to Switzerland, arrived yesterday at New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, with glowing praise for the country, where he has been stationed for the last two years.

The first exchange of sick and wounded prisoners in Korea, now happily under way, is recognized as a step toward a Korean truce. This has been emphasized by the agreement to reopen truce negotiations at Panmunjom on Saturday. We welcome the prisoner exchange wholeheartedly. We look to the truce negotiation guardedly.

More than 600 young string players participated in a concert given late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall as the major event, in the second National String Festival and Convention-arranged by the Violin. Viola and Violoncello Teachers Guild.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., April 19 -- More than 1,200 New York State educators wound up a three-day conference here yesterday after hearing a member of the faculty of Columbia University warn them that their profession was in danger of turning out troublemakers and apple polishers in their classrooms instead of fully developed children.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 19 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan, who has won the North and South amateur golf tournament three times, was favored to make it four on the eve of the fifty-third staging of the event opening tomorrow at the Pinehurst Country Club.

LONDON, April 19 -- Queen Elizabeth II has put a stop to this kingdom's most popular form of Royal advertising, but her fiat cannot undo centuries of testimony by the loyal publicans of the realm to their affection for the monarchy.
The annual fund appeal of New York Catholic Charities, which seeks $2,477,138 this year, opened yesterday with pontifical mass offered by Cardinal Spellman in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

ATLANTA, April 19 (AP) -- Spring windstorms, reaching hurricane force in some areas, lashed the South over the week-end, wrecking hundreds of homes and killing at least ten persons. More than 200 persons were injured.
PITTSBURGH, April 19 -- The steel rate for the country last week was unchanged from the week before at 99 per cent of rated capacity. The rate would have been much higher had it not been for:
Striking examples of interfaith cooperation were witnessed yesterday in two communities in the metropolitan area. In both, Roman Catholics had the aid of Protestants and Jews.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Miss Carson, in commenting on Mr. Day's ouster, said that under his direction the Federal management of hunting of migratory birds and of commercial fishing in Alaska had been based upon scientific principles developed by the agency's research program.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 19 -- The Jewish Labor Committee adopted here today a comprehensive program for this year that included greater effort to obtain fair employment legislation in states and cities, as well as intensified activity to achieve drastic revisions of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Monday, April 20 (UP) -- Thirty Americans and seventy other United Nations soldiers gained their freedom from Communist prison camps today in the first exchange under the agreement to repatriate sick and wounded captives in the Korean war.

More than 600 young string players participated in a concert given late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall as the major event, in the second National String Festival and Convention-arranged by the Violin. Viola and Violoncello Teachers Guild.
With a colorful parade up Fifth Avenue and impressive church services, men and women of Greek descent yesterday commemorated the 132d anniversary of Greek independence.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- Wheat futures were hard hit last week by a succession of bearish features which combined to throttle any inclination to buy and hold it. Long liquidation was heavy and at the close of the week prices were near the crop's low levels.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company made a mortgage loan of $1,750,000 at 4 1/2 per cent on the seventeen-story Berkeley Building at 19 to 25 West Forty-fourth Street, extending through to Forty-fifth Street, through the Charles F. Noyes Company, broker. The owner of the building is Berkeley Investors, Inc., Harry J. Takiff vice president, which bought it in 1947 through the Noyes organization.
LONDON, April 19 -- The revised Order of Service for the Coronation, in which the Church of Scotland will participate for the first time, was published tonight.

Mayor Impellitteri, it became known yesterday, has decided upon the two men whom he will name today as members of the five-man New York City transit authority. This is the agency authorized by the 1953 Legislature at Governor Dewey's insistence to take over the municipal transit lines and run them at a fare sufficient to meet all operating charges.

In a deal near Morningside Park, the five-story building containing two stores and eight apartments at 390 Manhattan Avenue, between West 116th and 117th Streets, has been sold by Joan Properties, Inc., to the Trans-New York Corporation, operators, through Balaban, broker. Barry Katzman were the attorneys for the seller.
TOKYO, Monday, April 20 -Premier Shigeru Yoshida ran his Liberal party to a commanding lead in returns today from yesterday's national election for a new House of Representatives.

The increasingly lucrative oceangoing trade between the Great Lakes and ports in Western and Mediterranean Europe via the St. Lawrence River route will be served this year by fifty-one foreign-flag, shallow-draft ships.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay said tonight he believed "wherever possible, the Federal Government should not interfere" with a state or with private enterprise in development of hydroelectric projects.

LONDON, April 19 -- Wild-life conservationists are racing against time in their efforts to pump off water from a flooded area of Suffolk in East Anglia so that one of Britain's rarest birds, the avocet, can lay eggs on dry land.

The soloist on yesterday afternoon's Carnegie Hall concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, was Artur Rubinstein. Mr. Rubinstein chose two works, the seldom Played but ever-welcome Concerto in G minor by Saint-Saens and Franck's Symphonic Variations.
BERLIN, April 19 -- A showdown appeared to be drawing near today between the East German Government and the leadership of the Evangelical Church.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Subversive Activities Control Board today ordered the Communist party of the United States to register with the Department of Justice as a Communist-action organization, "nurtured by the Soviet Union," that seeks to overthrow the Government of the United States and to establish a dictatorship of the proletariat.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- The Kroehler Manufacturing Company of Naperville, Ill., has adapted mass production methods to the manufacture of quality upholstered furniture that will result in a 25 to 35 per cent reduction in retail prices, D. L. Kroehler, president, announced today in company showrooms in the American Furniture Mart.

Judge Harold R. Medina said yesterday that if he should dismiss the anti-trust charges brought against Seventeen investment banking houses, his action would not be related "in the slightest degree" to a wish to avoid spending two or three more years on the trial.

ALBANY, April 20 -- Governor Dewey cleared up the last of the 1,080 bills left on his desk by the 1953 Legislature tonight, only a few hours before the thirty-day period in which he was required to sign or veto the measures expired.

LONDON, April 20 -- The news of an early resumption of truce talks in Korea coupled with second thoughts about the budget gave a fresh impetus to British Government securities on the stock markets here today.

The second day of prisoner-of- war exchange in Korea kept families at home close to their radios hoping for word that their sons and fathers and brothers would be among those passing through Panmunjom into Allied hands again.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Edmund M. Flaherty, a United States foreign-aid consultant in Europe and a thirty-five-year veteran of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., told the du Pont anti-trust trial today in Federal District Court how he invented Duco, the first modern automobile lacquer, as a result of an accidental discovery more than thirty years ago.
FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, April 20 (UP) -- Some Americans coming back from North Korea today said the Reds were still holding Allied prisoners who were in worse condition than those now being freed.
MEXICO CITY, April 20 -- For the third straight year the International Olympic Committee today tabled membership requests from Communist China and East Germany.

If Emlyn Williams continues this business of impersonating Charles Dickens it is going to be as difficult to separate the pair as it is to think of Raymond Massey as any one other than Abraham Lincoln.

BUENOS AIRES, April 20 (UP) -- Argentine authorities today ordered the release of Stephen Jacyna, of the Bronx, New York, who was arrested last week in connection with the bombings that killed six persons.

MOSCOW, April 20 -- Charles E. Bohlen, new United States Ambassador, and Kliment E. Voroshilov, President of the Soviet Union, expressed their hopes today that all questions at issue between the United States and the Soviet Union might be settled amicably.

Fifteen hundred experts in mass production techniques met in two midtown hotels yesterday to discuss how American factories can best get some of the nation's newly designed fast airplanes and guided missiles off the designing boards and intot he air.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 20 -- The White House-constructed "green curtain" was pierced today long enough to disclose that President Eisenhower had broken ninety on the golf course for the first time since he became President. He shot an 86, fourteen over par, in a match yesterday with Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, on the Augusta National Golf Club course.

Laffango, the 3-year-old who bettered Native Dancer's time in winning his section of the Gotham on Saturday, will not compete in the $100,000 added Wood Memorial at Jamaica. Trainer Merritt Buxton had to order the withdrawal of the son of Errard yesterday because of a calcium deposit on the left front ankle.

The Ingalls Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Pascagoula, Miss., was the low bidder for the construction of two refrigerated stores ships for the Navy, it was announced yesterday in Washington by the Maritime Administration, which is acting as construction agent for the vessels.
ALBANY, April 20 -- Governor Dewey signed today a bill altering the method of using state equalization rates in fixing special franchise valuations for railroad and utility properties.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 150 Korean war casualties in a list that included 25 killed, 114 wounded, 5 missing, 5 captured and 1 injured. The following casualties were from New York (none from New Jersey or Connecticut):

Margot Ward, New York soprano, made her New York debut last night at Carnegie Hall in a program that consisted principally of early music. In her first group she accompanied herself on the lute. Later she was accompanied by Virginia Harper on the harpsichord.

The Holland-America Line's flagship Nieuw Amsterdam will arrive this morning under the command of a new master, Capt. Cornelis Visser, who has uscceeded Commodore Pieter H. G. Verhoog on the vessel's bridge. Commodore Verhoog retired under the company's age limit after a 43-year sea career with the ship's last arrival in Rotterdam.

LONDON, April 20 - -Digby Morton, aware of the necessity of offering fresh fashions for the big London season that is about to burst forth in its full vigor, has turned out a pretty collection. His showing took place this afternoon in his smart establishment at 54 Grosvenor Hill, London.

The "massive and magnificent" words of President Eisenhower's address on the Highway of Peace continue to reverberate around the globe, inspiring mankind with new hope that the problems of the world may yet be solved by peaceful means and that there are better things in store for it than atomic war and extinction.

Representative members of the worlds of society, diplomacy and art attended the April in Paris Ball last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, a benefit for various French-American philanthropic organizations here and abroad.
LONDON, April 20 -- Prime Minister Churchill publicly voiced today his desire for an eventual meeting of the leaders of "some of the principal powers" involved in the "cold war."
MUSAN, Korea, Tuesday, April 21 (AP) -- A returned South Korean soldier said today many of his comrades died in North Korean prison camps.
ST. LOUIS, April 20 (UP) -- Steve Bilko's three-run homer paced Joe Presko and the Cardinals to a 9-to-4 victory over the Braves tonight.
The first outspoken opposition by a major importer to proposals now before Congress for a "sliding scale" graduated tariff on lead and zinc was annouced yesterday by American Metal Company, Ltd.

All thawed out following the dreary week-end during which most of them suffered in the cold and rain at the Seton Hall Relays, officials and coaches gathered at Leone's yesterday for the weekly track luncheon. The writers unanimously picked Mal Whitfield, double winner in the Olympic Games last summer, as the outstanding performer of the 1953 indoor track season.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved by a 12 to 1 vote today a bill designed to help Congressional investigating panels force witnesses to answer questions despite refusal to testify on the ground that what they said might incriminate them.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Senator Alexander Wiley of Wisconsin, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said here tonight that one way the Soviet Union could meet President Eisenhower's challenge for sincere good deeds would be to resume diplomatic relations with Israel.

A 15 per cent increase in sales for E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., in the first quarter of 1953 helped to raise earnings to $1.19 a common share, according to the quarterly statement being prepared for mailing to stockholders. This compares with $1.06 for the corresponding period of 1952.

A strike by 1,000 members of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., against the Cities Service Oil Company, operator of sixteen coastwise tankers, which was to have begun this morning, was averted late Friday night, when the oil company and union agreed to terms.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 20 -- The Social Committee of the Economic and Social Council approved today a resolution recommending that the 1926 League of Nations convention on slavery be transferred to the United Nations. The vote was 16 to 0, with Poland and the Soviet Union abstaining.

A program to strengthen liberal Judaism in the United States was submitted last night to the Union of American Hebrew Congregations at the second session of its forty-second biennial five-day convention at the Commodore Hotel.

The Columbia Broadcasting System formally revealed yesterday that it would use the color standards adopted by the National Television System Committee, an all-industry group, for a series of experimental color telecasts to begin next week.

MOSCOW, April 20 -- Seven civilians, headed by Capt. Vyvyan Holt, former British Minister at Seoul, Korea, arrived in Moscow today after an eleven-day journey from North Korea, where they had been interned for nearly three years.

Parents should not try to be pals to their teen-agers by trying to act like teen-agers themselves, Dr. Fred U. Tate said last night at a meeting at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West Sixty-eighth Street. Dr. Tate, who is clinic chief of the Institute for Religion and Psychiatry, discussed changes and disturbances during adolescence at the third in a mental hygiene-and-adolescence film forum series.
JERUSALEM, April 20 (AP) -- Police officials said a young United States woman tourist and her uncle were murdered today in the latter's house where she was visiting.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 20 (AP) -- William C. Campbell, Huntington, W. Va., the 1950 winner, and David (Spec) Goldman of Dallas tied for the medal today with 1-under-par 71's in the North and South amateur golf tournament qualifying round.

Dr. Ordway Tead, who will complete next month his fifteenth consecutive one-year term as chairman of the Board of Higher Education, announced formally last night at a regular monthly meeting of the board that he would not be a candidate for another term.

Asparagus, now a dime a pound cheaper than it was the first of the month, should be even cheaper within a week or so. The current average of about 25 cents a pound probably will be reduced when New Jersey starts shipping here in abundance.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today that the Korean truce negotiations would go ahead on a military basis and that the United States would press for a broader political settlement with the Communists as soon as possible.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- A Federal judge took judicial notice today of Mickey Mantle's long home run here last week and disagreed with sports writers who said the ball was boosted along by a brisk tail wind.
KILDARE, Ireland, April 20 (AP) -- John Carr fairly blistered the Curragh of Kildare golf tournament yesterday with a 52 -- for one hole.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- President Eisenhower proposed today a reorganization of the Department of Justice to make the Deputy Attorney General the second highest officer of the department.

Amidst an appearance of great cordiality on both sides the Argentine Ambassador to Moscow has announced the successful conclusion of "the fundamental basis" for a Soviet-Argentine trade agreement. Argentina is to ship various agricultural products, while it will receive industrial equipment and various types of industrial raw materials.

In answer to a recent letter from Miriam Selss under the heading "Fireproof Race Track Stables," in which she asks whether anybody cares about helpless animals, I would like to call attention to an amendment to the Nassau County fire prevention ordinance now pending.

Six parcels of real estate in Brooklyn and Queens are to be offered at three auction sales by the Board of Transportation of the City of New York. The sales will be held in Room 1310 of the Board of Transportation building at 370 Jay Street in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) -- The movie industry told a Congressional committee today that more than 29 per cent of the nation's motion picture theatres would closes within a year unless the 20 per cent admission tax was repealed.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The Army's Surgeon General estimated today that the military forces would need to draft 12,259 physicians and dentists in the next two years -- almost double the past rate.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York called yesterday for a one-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act in its present form to allow careful study of basic changes in foreign economic policy.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 20 -- There is more than just a one-picture assignment behind the signing by Columbia of Dianne Foster for a featured role in "Scalpel," with Carleton Heston and Lizabeth Scott.

ALTOONA, Pa., April 20 -- Another snow storm of almost blizzard proportions completely discouraged the Pittsburgh management from attempting to play any baseball today. With the game canceled some time before noon the Dodgers boarded a 2 o'clock train for Philadelphia, where they tangle with the Phils in three straight night games.

When Premier Yoshida dissolved the Diet after a close vote of non-confidence and went to the country in a general election he hoped to get an outright majority in Japan's lower house. Similarly, his opponents, especially the rebelling wing of his Liberal party, whose defection had caused his defeat in the Diet, hoped to gain enough seats to unseat the Premier permanently.

Artur Schnabel, who died in December 1951, was a musician whose influence reached out in many directions -- as pianist, teacher, editor and man of wide culture. It is not surprising, therefore, that an Artur Schnabel Memorial Committee has taken form or that it has drawn its strength from among the most distinguished intellectual and artistic circles of the Western world.

Three brothers, successful in the hosiery manufacturing business, have decided to close up shop and take it comparatively easy. Samuel, Martin and Frank Burd, owners and officers of Prestige, Inc., a leading hosiery brand, will dispose of the business and use the proceeds to invest in other companies.

MOBILE, Ala., April 20 -- The Louisville and Nashville Railroad will spend $2,500,000 for new rolling stock, mainly in anticipation of heavy movement of iron ore from Venezuela through this port to Birmingham.

Stock issues with short positions on the New York Stock Exchange rose almost 10 per cent in the month to April 15, but the number of shares carried in short accounts advanced only a little more than 2 per cent, the exchange reported yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, April 21 (AP) -- The mutter of guns along the Korean front faded to a whisper Monday as the Allies and Communists began the war's first exchange of disabled prisoners. Only in the air did the war go on much as usual, and even this activity was curtailed by an overcast and rain.

As Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber upheld yesterday the constitutionality of the projected New York City transit authority, Mayor Impellitteri appointed and swore in two new members of the authority -- William G. Fullen and Ephraim F. Jeffe.

A Brooklyn mother with four sons in tow, the oldest 5 years old, dropped in yesterday at the City Housing Authority at a 2 Frankfort Street to apply for an apartment in a low-rent housing development.

Several hundred longshoremen went on a wildcat strike yesterday at the Army Port of Embarkation in Brooklyn after it had become known that the New York Shipping Association had advised the International Longshoremen's Association that it would no longer pay certain shop stewards who do not perform "assigned services."

The business boom has about run its course and the prospect of peace in Korea will not change the business pattern fundamentally, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Banking and Finance at New York University, said last night.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Herschel Young, 46 years old, was convicted tonight of perjury in testimony to a grand jury that investigated the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in 1951. The trial jury in Federal Court deliberated about five hours.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Tuesday, April 21 (AP) -- The Communists informed the United Nations Command today they would deliver 100 South Koreans to the Allies tomorrow in the third day of the prisoner-of-war exchange.

The National Committee of the Communist party announced here yesterday that it would not follow the order by the Subversive Activities Control Board to turn its records over to the Government as agents of a foreign power, and that its members would not register under the order.
Two radio patrolmen saved yesterday the lives of seven persons who had been overcome by coal-gas fumes in a four-story apartment house at 169 Howard Avenue, in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn.

MONTREAL, April 20 (AP) -- As agreement has been reached to market 1,000,000 tons of iron ore and 150,000 tons of titanium annually for ten years from the Tache Bourget property of Canadian Javelin Foundries and Machine Works, Ltd., on Quebec's Saguenay River.

TRENTON, April 20 -- The C-123B, first of a large number of newly designed assault-transport planes that have been ordered by the Air Force, made its debut this morning at Mercer Airport, just west of here. Buffeted by strong northwest winds, the massive, but graceful, low-bellied craft went through its paces for the benefit of its builders, Air Force officials, photographers and reporters.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 20 (UP) -- Communist-led Vietminh troops today occupied Xiengkhouang -- a fortress town of the Kingdom of Laos -- and swept on toward the Plaines des Jarres.
BOSTON, April 20 (UP) -- Tony DeSpirito returned to the saddle today at Suffolk Downs and helped open a 60-day meeting by riding three winners and finishing in the money with two other mounts.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 20 -- The Danes are holding a general election tomorrow to conform to one of the precepts of their Constitution requiring that amendments be approved by a newly elected lower house of Parliament before being endorsed by the people at large in the form of a plebiscite.

ALBANY, April 20 -- Motorists suspected of drunken driving will be required to submit, to chemical intoxication tests or have their operators' licenses revoked under a bill approved today by Governor Dewey. It will go into effect July 1.

State Rent Commissioner Joseph D. McGoldrick said yesterday that he would institute injunction proceedings if reports proved true that some landlords had started billing all their tenants for 15 per cent more rent starting May 1.
