Alvin Silverman has purchased the six-story apartment house for fifty-four families at 555 West 173d Street from the Goodlink Realty Company, represented by Wien, Lane, Klein Purcell, attorneys. Dwight-Helmsley, Inc., was the broker. The property, on plot 100 by 100 feet at the northwest corner of Audubon Avenue, was acquired for cash above mortgages of $135,000.

Five years have now passed since thirty-seven men and women gathered together in a museum building in Tel Aviv and signed the Proclamation of Independence of the State of Israel. These have been five eventful years for this outpost of democracy in the Middle East, five years of heroic achievement as well as of constant struggle.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 20 -- American churchgoers were called upon here today to face "realistically" the thorny question of land reform in India.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- National conservation organizations looked today for "serious repercussions" in the removal of Albert M. Day as director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.

BOSTON, April 20 (AP) -- Japan's tiny Keizo Yamada, a 25-year-old mining engineer who weighs only 108 pounds, ran the fastest marathon ever recorded with a 2:18.51 performance today against a brilliant international field of 158 in the Boston A. A. race.

Operations at the nation's steel plants were scheduled at an estimated 99.3 per cent of rated capacity this week, indicating production of 2,238,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

George M. Humphrey. Secretary of the Treasury, made his first public address as a member of the Eisenhower Cabinet yesterday before The Associated Press annual luncheon. From its crisp opening sentence -- "There is no reason to fear peace" -- to its close this was a strong and reassuring speech.

Dr. Sigmund Spaeth's letter in your April 14 issue raises an intriguing question -- What if Malenkov should realize that his name could go down in history "as representing the savior of the modern world" if he would only use his power to stop the Korean war, lift the Iron Curtain and join with the United Nations in bringing a real peace, and a possible United States of Europe?

Although leading media are getting more particular about what types of ads they publish or broadcast, there is still much to be done in this direction, according to John R. Buckley, publisher of Good Housekeeping magazine. He referred specifically to misleading and "double-talk" ads.
MEXICO CITY, April 20 -- There is free speech in Mexico but from now on it has to be free speech in Spanish, and good Spanish at that, at least in public.

John Varady, an acting investigator for the Department of Sanitation, was a defense witness yesterday for John E. Gleason Jr., former general inspector in the department. The latter is being tried in General Sessions Court for perjury in denying to the grand jury that he shad taken part in shakedowns of fuel oil installers.

LONDON, April 20 -- The two aides who have been on a whirlwind fact-finding tour of Europe for Senator McCarthy's subcommittee concluded their investigations today with a five-hour visit to London and a verbal pat on the back for Winthrop W. Aldrich, the United States Ambassador here.

Some of the tallest hurdles are still ahead, but the New York City Transit Authority has survived its first court test and becomes a going concern with the appointment of four of its five members. Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber yesterday upheld the constitutionality of the state law establishing the Authority and found no interference with the principle of home rule for New York City.
The text of the address by Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey at the annual luncheon yesterday of members of The Associated Press at the Waldorf-Astoria follows:
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The International Typographical Union, A. F. L., attacked a proposed order of the National Labor Relations Board today as dishonest.

The insurance industry took a look at electronic computers yesterday to see what such machines could do with the maze of names, birth dates, premium amounts, mortality tables and other materials that actuaries wrap up in a life insurance policy.

Aluminium, Ltd., announced yesterday the terms of its offering of 818,657 shares of new capital stock to its shareholders. The offering is to be made to holders of record April 24 on the basis of one new share for each ten shares held. Warrants will be mailed to shareholders about April 25 and will expire on May 15.

Carbonated soft drinks in cans will be introduced in the New York area in mid-May by Cantrell Cochrane Corporation, a subsidiary of National Phoenix Industries, Inc., Walter S. Mack, president of the parent company, announced yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Renee Jeanmaire, the highly regarded French ballerina known to American movie-goers for her appearance with Danny Kaye in the film, "Hans Christian Andersen," and familiar to ballet fans for her work with the Ballet de Paris company, signed contracts yesterday morning to star in "The Girl With Pink Tights."

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The near-filibuster against legislation revoking federal claims to the produce of offshore state lands that is being conducted by what seems to be well less than one-third of the Senate membership has both resemblances and differences to similar delaying actions by minorities in the past.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 20 (AP) -- Ohio State University trustees today dismissed Dr. Byron T. Darling, a physics professor who refused to tell the House Un-American Activities Committee if he was or had been a Communist.
BOSTON, April 20 (AP) -- Dick Gernert today hit in a style resembling that of Boston sluggers of past seasons in leading the Red Sox to two victories over the Senators, 4 -- 2 and 11 -- 4.

Liquidation of the Standard Gas and Electric Company moved nearer yesterday with the approval by the United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., of Step Two of the company's dissolution plan. This step provides for retirement of the utility's $4 preferred stock.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- The Beneficial Saving Fund Society commemorated its one-hundredth anniversary today by giving a "clinic on wheels" to the community for the treatment of needy arthritis and rheumatism sufferers in their homes.

DESPITE bad weather, high water and low temperatures, the opening-day anglers on many of the popular Connecticut streams took quite a number of trout. The size and coloration of some of the fish proved they were not right out of the hatchery.

GLEN COVE, L. I., April 20 -- The prettiest kettle of fish to emerge from Long Island Sound in a long time boiled over in this city today, scalding the Mayor and City Council and furnishing something entirely new in the way of fish stories for the many citizens here who are fond of going out into the Sound in rowboats after a few flounder.

The automobile industry is "going to be getting to the end of the road" one of these days unless sales efforts are stepped up, James J. Nance, president of the Packard Motor Car Company, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting.

WAUKEGAN, Ill., April 20 -- The will of Mrs. Jean Morton Cudahy, widow of Joseph Michael Cudahy, who headed the Cudahy Packing Company, was filed in Probate Court here today. She died April 7 at Palm Beach, Fla., at the age of 69.
Periods ranging from early eighteenth century French to contemporary Danish are represented in new designs for silver.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Former Senator William Benton said today he had heard that "the policy decision has been reached" to pull the Government's worldwide propaganda-information program out of the State Department.

CAIRO, April 20 -- The newly appointed Egyptian Ambassador to the United States, Dr. Ahmed Hussein, said today that his mission in Washington was an effort "to convince the Americans that it is better to have friends in the Middle East than to have a formal but meaningless defense pact."

A special benefit preview showing of "Bellissima," the new Italian drama starring Anna Magnani, will be held at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, on Wednesday, April 29, at 8:45 P. M. Proceeds from tickets, priced at $6 each, will go to the museum's program fund.

RANGOON, Burma, April 20 (AP) -- Nearly 2,500 Chinese Nationalist troops, supported by Karen rebels, have mounted a three-pronged attack on Burmese Army units in the Moulmein area, 350 miles south of their previous area of operations around Kengtung on the China border, War Office sources said today.

LONDON, April 20 -- Peter Thorneycroft, president of the Board of Trade, told the House of Commons today that Britain had informed the United States Government that rejection of a British bid to build the Chief Joseph Dam in Washington State, because the bid, although the lowest, was made by a British rather than an American company, would be considered a bad omen for the future foreign trade policy of the Eisenhower Administration.

HAIFA, Israel, April 20 -- Israel's armed forces marching 10,000 strong along the waterfront, naval units cruising slowly offshore and squadrons of military aircraft roaring overhead combined today to mark by its biggest military display the beginning of the nation's sixth year of independence.
ALBANY, April 20 -- The State Department of Taxation and Finance warned today that truck and trailer owners who had not yet painted weight signs on their vehicles were running the risk of arrest.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 20 -- Rowland R. Hughes, vice president of the National City Bank of New York, today was named Assistant Director of the Budget by President Eisenhower. He will assist Joseph M. Dodge, Director of the Bureau of the Budget.
The humane and emotional American reaction to the initial exchanges of prisoners of war in Korea should not blind us to the ulterior military and political motives of the Communists.

MANILA, April 20 -- The Secretary of Foreign Affairs, Joaquin M Elizalde, declared in an interview today that there had been no official interference by the United States in Philippine election activities. He noted that Ambassador Raymond A. Spruance and his staff were now making every effort to keep Americans out of the heated Presidential contest here.

The $4,715,000 First Avenue tunnel running under First Avenue from Forty-first Street to Forty- eighth Street, which was built to ease traffic congestion in the United Nations site area, was formally opened yesterday.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Tuesday, April 21 -- Another group of weary American prisoners of war found their way to freedom today. Again they were almost silent. There was no evidence on their part of real enthusiasm, but there were thin smiles of thankfulness that spoke more eloquently than words.

The south blockfront on West 235th Street is comprising 27,000 square feet between Oxford and Cambridge Avenues in the Riverdale section of the Bronx has been sold by the Burgundy Construction Cohporation to a builder who will erect a large apartment house there.
TOKYO, Tuesday, April 21 (AP) -- Japan's politicians worked today to stitch together some sort of patchwork Government in the wake of Sunday's national "election that nobody won."

TRENTON, April 20 -- Partisan New Jersey voters will go to the polls in 3,955 election districts tomorrow to pick the Republican and Democratic party standard bearers in the race next November for control of the state government for the next four years.

LONDON, April 20 -- Winding up the debate on the British budget for the Opposition tonight, Aneurin Bevan, leader of the Labor party's left wing, accused R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, and the Conservative Government of using United States aid to underwrite a reduction in the standard rate of the income tax.
DENVER, April 20 (AP) -- The Colorado Supreme Court ruled today that a former Denver university football player was entitled to worker compensation because of football injuries.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 20 -- The executive committees of the African National Congress, the South African Indian National Congress and the Cape Province Mulattos Franchise Action Council issued a joint declaration today to the non-white people of South Africa, calling on them to do everything possible to make the Nationalist Government's policy of apartheid or separation, of races, unworkable.

Members of the New York Committee of the Frontier Nursing Service have arranged a rummage tea in behalf of the organization tomorrow afternoon in the home of Mrs. Archibald Douglas at 834 Fifth Avenue.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., April 20 -- Two New York men were killed and three women injured today when their car overturned on the New Jersey Turnpike two miles north of here. The victims were thrown from the vehicle as it rolled over several times. A sixth passenger was not injured.

PARIS, April 20 -- The chief military leaders of the fourteen member nations gave their final approval behind closed doors in the Palais de Chaillot here today to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's Annual Review, 1952, which establishes in detail each country's defense contribution toward the year-end goal of about sixty divisions and 5,000 jet aircraft.

Stock prices tumbled yesterday to a new low for 1953 and a bottom since last Nov. 17. Then the averages recovered, with steels, motors, oils, chemicals and some of the rails heading for higher ground, and closed with a gain, their first since Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Lewis W. Douglas, former Ambassador to Britain, was named today chairman of a mid-century conference on the evaluation and long-range use of the country's natural resources.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., April 20 -- Local merchants who defied the threat of prosecution yesterday by setting a car raffle for Friday won their point today when J. Victor Carton, Monmouth County Prosecutor, and Police Chief Fred Lembke decided that the raffle would not violate New Jersey anti-gambling laws.
CLEVELAND, April 20 -- Cheers of a colorful and excited audience greeted the world premiere tonight of "Me and Juliet," the Richard Rodgers-Oscar Hammerstein 2d musical, at the Hanna Theatre.

PARIS, April 20 -- The Permanent Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization instructed both its secretariat and its Military Committee today to ascertain whether there was any reason to assume that Moscow's fundamental foreign policy intentions or military plans had changed as a result of the current Soviet "peace offensive."

Although many large packers of frozen foods were absent from the first show of the National Frozen Food Industries Exposition, which opened in Grand Central Palace yesterday, representatives of specialty foods and makers of freezers and equipment whose exhibits filled the main floor expressed themselves as satisfied with the attendance of food store men and the orders they placed.

RICHMOND, Va., April 20 (AP) -- Carl I. Collins, president of Superior Steel Corporation, said today capacity operations coupled with a $7,000,000 expansion program has raised his company's employment to the highest level since World War II.

Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey reminded the nation yesterday that "in peace America grew great," and predicted even better times for all Americans no matter whether there was an armistice in Korea, a real peace or a continued defense build-up.

Citizens of Levittown, L. I., donated 512 pints of blood to the Red Cross last Saturday, when two bloodmobiles spent the day at Levittown Hall, the community center. The contribution exceeded the goal that had been set for the area, the New York Chapter of the Red Cross announced yesterday.

It was with great interest that I read your three articles on the "modern" teaching program of our school system. You are entirely correct that parents have a high stake in our school system and that is why so many parents have been dismayed at the results of the so-called "activity," then "progressive" and now "modern" system.

GENEVA, April 20 -- A new and precise project for settling 17,000 European migrants in "greenbelt" colonies in Brazil is to be presented tomorrow by the Brazilian delegation to the Intergovernmental Committee for Migration from Europe.
John (Johnny) Alu, 34-year-old ex-convict and member of Local 824 of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., known as the Pistol Local, went on trial yesterday for perjury.

The sixth annual Bancroft Prizes for distinguished writings in American history were awarded last night by Columbia University to George Dangerfield for "The Era of Good Feeling" and to Dr. Eric F. Goldman for "Rendezvous With Destiny, A History of Modern American Reform."

GENEVA, April 20 -- Neutral observers who are fully informed on the progress of the secret East- West trade discussions here have concluded provisionally that a wholly new approach has been adopted and is being adhered to by the Russians and their Eastern European colleagues.

After a two months' test, L. Bamberger Co., Newark, is using cellophane for pre-wrapping packages of appropriate merchandise throughout the store, the first department store in the country to do so, according to a joint announcement yesterday by Bamberger's and the Olin Cellophane division of Olin Industries, Inc.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The White House announced tonight that Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower would join the Daughters of the American Revolution, which opened its sixty-second continental congress at Constitution Hall today.
The time has come again for the homemaker to wage war on the clothes moth and she will find in stores a number of new items that may be helpful.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 20 -- President Eisenhower has invited the chairmen of the House and Senate Armed Services Committees and of the Foreign Relations and Foreign Affairs Committees to join the regular Republican Congressional leadership at a conference with him at the White House Thursday morning.
The report made yesterday by the board of directors of The Associated Press at the annual meeting of the news service follows:...

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 20 -- Sir Gladwyn Jebb, British representative in the United Nations, declared today the Chinese Nationalist Government must stop supplying arms and ammunition to 12,000 Nationalist troops in Burma and tell them to stop fighting.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican leader of the Senate, threatened tonight to force a vote on closure or a limiting of debate, on the bill before the Senate to give coastal states title to oil-rich lands under the marginal seas within their historic boundaries.

NEWARK, April 20 -- A conference between representatives of 7,000 striking telephone workers and the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company ended abruptly at 5:15 P. M. today when John J. Curtin, president of the Telephone Workers Union, independent, walked out angrily and said he would "not be back tomorrow."

Three hundred persons, who said their aim was to rid the city of machine politics by offering a coalition candidate for Mayor, held an organizational meeting last night at the Commodore Hotel. Many of them were associates of the late Fiorello H. La Guardia.

" The Kremlin vs. the People," an examination of the Soviet Union by Robert Magidoff, will be issued June 4 by Doubleday. Among the subjects discussed by the author are the revival of nationalism and religion during World War II, the Russification of minorities, anti-Semitism, the condition of peasants and the workers and the bureaucracy.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 20 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, charged here today that the nation was about to witness "another great oil scandal that would far surpass the infamous Teapot Dome scandal."
William Rivlin, the last of fifteen gamblers described by the District Attorney's office as collegiate basketball fixers, surrendered yesterday. He had been sought since February, 1951.
TOKYO, Tuesday, April 21 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 382, for Monday:

In an effort to dissuade Congress from accepting the recommendations of the House Appropriations Committee for a deep cut in Federal housing allocations, Mayor Impellitteri telegraphed members of the city's Congressional delegation yesterday that such a slash would "cut the heart out of the city's efforts to clear slums."

The management of Webster-Chicago Corporation received assurance of support yesterday from representatives of sixteen of its distributors in twenty cities. The group, known as the Customer-Shareholder Committee, meeting in the New Weston Hotel, endorsed the management side in a forthcoming proxy fight.

HAMBURG, Germany, April 20 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer launched the West German election campaign today with the contention that the United States Government would not accept any proposal on Germany that would be carried out at the expense of the German people.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 20 -- Following a six-day tour of investigation, Gert Jan Van Heuven Goedhart, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said today he would return to Geneva tomorrow with a good impression of the double-barreled refugee situation here.
Almost all day long yesterday it was just like the old New England weather proverb -- if you didn't like the weather the way it was all you had to do was wait around a few minutes.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) -- Congress was told today that the Soviet Union was dumping potash on the American market in a move that could hurt United States fertilizer makers and farm production in an emergency.

Longshoremen of the American Federation of Labor are expected to return to work today at the Brooklyn Army Base and at Pier 61, Hudson River, after one-day work stoppages that stemmed from disputes involving union shop stewards and foremen.

THE best of all Arnold Bennett stories, the story of his life, has now been written by Reginald Pound in "Arnold Bennett: A Biography."* This is an extraordinary story of an extraordinary man -- at once the Babbitt and the Sinclair Lewis of modern English literature.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Price trends in grain futures were irregular today, wheat continuing to drag lower while corn and rye showed considerable strength at times. Oats were about steady, and soybeans held in a moderate range. Bullish wheat conditions in the Southwest over the weekend failed to spur buying, although there were reports of high winds, dust storms, hail storms and low temperatures.

Mr. Hughes has been for some years a member of the Committee on Federal Tax Policy, formerly the Committee on Postwar Tax Policy, a private New York study group. In 1951 this committee urged a $10,000,000,000 cut in the Truman Administration estimates for the fiscal year of 1952.
The following United Nations prisoners were received in the exchanges of sick and wounded prisoners with the Communists in Korea:

The Cornell University A Capella Chorus, which was founded six years ago by its director, Roberr Hull, gave its first New York concert last night at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A. The event was for the benefit of the Federation Scholarship Fund and the Georgia Laura White Memorial Fund.

Allie Reynolds will be Manager Casey Stengel's choice to start against the Red Sox at the Stadium today, when the teams open a three-game set, with Marv Grissom going for Lou Boudreau's out-ift. It will be Allie's second outing of the season, following a route-going 4-1 victory over the Athletics. Stengel plans to use Johnny Sain and Vic Raschi in the other two contests.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The State Department's security officer disclosed today the "separation" of nineteen department employes from the payroll on homosexual charges since he took office March 3.

A substantial growth in clientele and services was reported yesterday at the opening session of The United Press annual executives' meeting at 220 East Forty-second Street. Hugh Baillie, president, presided.

RICHMOND, Calif., April 20 -- Sixteen residents of public housing projects here today challenged the constitutionality of a loyalty oath requirements for persons living in housing accommodations built with Federal aid.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Col. Robert M. Guggenheim, industrialist and a director of the Daniel Guggenheim Foundation, is expected to be named soon as United States Ambassador to Portugal.
Who has not wished, while listening to a long speech deliberately spoken, that the speaker would hurry up just a little and get on to those beautiful words, "* * * and in conclusion * * *"?

NEW DELHI, India, April 20 -- A political fast in the Gandhian style, undertaken by an advocate of a Kanarese-speaking linguistic state in southern India, caused a large-scale riot with possibly important consequences yesterday in the town of Hubli in southern Bombay State.

With three shillelaghs tucked under his arm -- one for his uncle, one for his aunt and one for himself -- young Michael O'Reilly jauntily walked down the gangplank of the British liner Georgic yesterday to head for Brooklyn and a new life in this country either as a policeman or a lawyer.

MUNSAN, Korea, Tuesday, April 21 -- The contrast between the Communist and the American prisoners of war passing through the exchange point at Panmunjom yesterday was so great that it was difficult to believe they were the victims of the same war. The Communists gave the appearance of being beaten and broken physically, while the majority of the Americans appeared dazed and beaten mentally.
YONKERS, April 20 (AP) -- Black I Win, the favorite, just had enough to withstand the stretch rush of Doctor Vic tonight in the Valhall Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

Activity was light on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday. Prices closed generally lower with coffee, cottonseed oil, cocoa, zinc, lead, rubber and tin showing declines. Hides were higher and soybean oil, sugar, wool and potatoes ended mixed.
Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, unchanged to 10 points lower than on last Friday.
DILLON, S. C., Tuesday, April 21 -- The Atlantic Coast Line's East Coast Miami to New York passenger train, the Champion, piled up near here last night.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 21 (UP) -- United States B-29 Superforts resumed the attack today near the routes taken by Communist convoys carrying Allied prisoners from northwest Korea to Panmunjom for repatriation.

PELHAM, N. Y., April 20 -- With helicopters now gliding overhead every morning to deliver mail to near-by communities, Pelham Township and its incorporated villages of Pelham, Pelham Manor and North Pelham believed today they should receive at least a full-fledged post office.
Ten thousand persons trekked to the tenth floor of Gimbels yesterday, many of them ready to put cash on the line to buy an apartment sight unseen in a project not yet under construction.

The United States is a great country, and we rarely do things by halves. Certainly the proponents of the program to give away our national resources are moving on a grand scale. A complete pattern for transferring to private ownership our national heritage of oil, gas, minerals and publicly owned power resources is now emerging into full view.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 21 -- A second group of 100 sick and wounded Allied prisoners of the Korean war, including thirty-five Americans, were returned to freedom this morning in the second day of the exchange for Communist captives in the neutral zone at Panmunjom, between the battle lines.

SAN FRANCISCO, Tuesday, April 21 (AP) -- A Western Air Lines DC6B -- one of the largest type passenger planes -- crashed in San Francisco Bay last night just after stopping at the San Francisco Airport on a flight from Los Angeles to Oakland, across the bay.

A curve that hung, high and inviting, broke up a tense pitching duel between Larry Jansen and Robin Roberts yesterday at the Polo Ground With two out in the ninth, the score tied and none aboard, Jansen threw the curve, Granny Hamner slammed it on a high line into the upper leftfield seats and the Phillies had a stirring 2-1 victory over the Giants.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- General of the Army George C. Marshall, former Secretary of Defense, said today he signed a series of budget assumptions on Sept. 27, 1950, including one that combat operations in Korea would be finished by June 30, 1951, on the recommendation of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, submitted over the signature of General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, chairman.

A great deal of good could be accomplished in the field of early sex education if more opportunity were offered for open discussion by parents themselves on this subject. Such training is essentially their responsibility and not that of clergymen, physicians or teachers, Dr. Milton I. Levine declared last night.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 20 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh agreed last night to hold elections for the vacant seats in the Majlis [lower house of Parliament] in the hope of overcoming the opposition boycott that was preventing a vote on the proposal to divest Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of his powers of control over the military and civil affairs of Iran.

Israel's fifth anniversary as a nation was celebrated yesterday with colorful ceremonies throughout the city. The birthday came at a time when the young state was attempting to consolidate its economic structure and seeking a permanent peace with the surrounding Arab states.

Northwest Airlines is staking $21,800,000 -- and fourteen banks are backing it with a 4 per cent loan to that amount -- that peace in Korea will bring it new business on its northern transcontinental line and that to the Orient through Alaska.
Four additional colleges will launch their rowing season Saturday and Navy and Princeton are matched in the big race of the week.

SUMMIT, N. J., April 20 -- The end of the racial segregation in the Young Men's Christian Association here will be marked on May 15, 1953, when the Lincoln Y. M. C. A. will officially close its doors and the Summer Y. M. C. A. will expand its services to the entire community.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, said today Congress should look into the possibility of exempting building trades unions and the construction industry from the Taft-Hartley Law. He made the statement during testimony before the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee by Richard J. Gray, president of the building trades department of the American Federation of Labor.

Presentation of testimony ended yesterday in the perjury trial of John E. Gleason Jr., former general inspector in the Department of Sanitation, who is accused of having denied falsely to a grand jury that he took part in shakedowns of fuel oil installers.

ALBANY, April 21 -- If New York State is to avoid a post-Korea recession, business men must stimulate an increase in private consumption through aggressive sales promotion, more effective and efficient distribution, and the development of new products, the State Commerce Department warned today.

The Union of American Hebrew Congregations, embracing 465 Reform congregations in this country and Canada, sharply condemned yesterday as "un-American and dangerous" certain methods used in Congressional investigations to uproot communism.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- Chairman Styles Bridges said today that the Senate Appropriations Committee will call Acting Secretary of State Walter Bedell Smith to give "all available information" on alleged mistreatment of Allied war prisoners in Korea.

Sales in the first quarter of 1953 hold the promise of a banner year for the knitted outerwear industry, according to Sidney S. Korzenik, executive director and counsel of the National Knitted Outerwear Association.

About 125 Civil Defense volunteers took part last night in an hour-long drill in West Fifty-fourth Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. The exercise, which began at 7:45 P. M., was based on the assumption that an atom bomb had been dropped over Ward's Island by enemy bombers and that the rest of the city had been attacked with high explosives and incendiary bombs.

The stock market found recovery tendencies difficult to maintain yesterday. Volume was light on early morning strength and remained so during the afternoon. Even a batch of excellent first quarter earnings reports couldn't prevent early gains from being pared down or replaced by moderate losses in afternoon dealings. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange contracted to 1,250,000 shares, making the session the slowest since Feb. 10.

Today's new film is "Sombrero." a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama in Technicolor, with Ricardo Montalban, Pier Angeli, Vittorio Gassman, Yvonne de Carlo and Cyd Charisse, at Loew's State. Norman Foster directed and Jack Cummings produced from a screen play by Josefina Niggli and Mr. Foster, based on Miss Niggli's novel, "A Mexican Village." Rick Jason, Nina Foch, Kurt Kasznar and Walter Hampden head the supporting cast.

BERLIN, April 21 -- Seven Lutheran Bishops from both East and West Germany cast off today the diplomatic language with which they had criticized the East German Government in the past. They charged the Soviet-sponsored regime with the "inhumane" treatment of young church members and said the wrath of God would fall on those responsible.

The Subversive Activities Control Board has finally ruled that the Communist party must register under the Internal Security Act of 1950. It could have sensibly come to no other conclusion. After hearings that dragged on for more than a year and filled 15,000 pages, a panel of the board held last October that the Communist party of the United States was "a foreign-dominated revolutionary movement," and now the entire board fully confirms that finding.

It seems to be necessary, every so often these days, for someone to point out a fact that used to be a matter of common knowledge and accepted as such. That is the fact that, until "national emergencies" became the rule rather than the exception, this country's economy had, for 150 years, been based on the free price system.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Wednesday, April 22 -- The Conservative-Agrarian liberal coalition Government, led by the Agrarian leader, Erik Eriksen, has resigned over the outcome of yesterday's general election, it was announced at 3 o'clock, local time, this morning.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 21 -- For the first time in almost three years, a representative of the Soviet Union paid an official visit today to the Secretary General of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Justice Department filed a civil suit here today to break up an alleged international petroleum cartel in which it charged that five major United States oil companies had participated.

"Camembert," says Larousse, "is a fat cheese, very esteemed, made at Camembert (Orne) and its environs." This is indeed true. Camembert is a soft rennet cheese (rennet being an extract from the stomachs of young calves, pigs or goats) made from cow's milk.

The costs of putting a television station on the air, plus the high costs of the individual show, which have stopped all but ten or a dozen of the biggest advertisers from putting on a full hour program, turned downward yesterday.

Miniature bell buoys attached to "Walk" and "Don't Walk" signs to warn pedestrians of changes in traffic tides were suggested yesterday by the Thirty-fourth Street-Midtown Association. One to make ready, two to go and three remain moored to the curb, was a stroke pattern offered by the organization.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, outlined in a statement issued today the rigid controls that would be imposed on the Communist party if the order issued yesterday by the Subversive Activities Control Board requiring the party to register and file fiscal records was not set aside by the courts.

PARIS, April 21 -- The current spate of purging and unpurging in the Soviet Union has unearthed one curious indirect admission by the Moscow Government -- namely, that secret policemen are employed in high positions abroad by the Soviet diplomatic service.

More than one-fourth of the so-called "savings" reported by the House Appriations Committee in the Independent Offices Bill comes under the heading "reduction in public housing units." What the committee proposes is to halt the federal public housing program by forbidding further loans, annual contributions or authorizations to start construction.

MOSCOW, April 21 -- The Central Committee of the Communist party in a list of forty-seven slogans issued tonight for the annual May Day celebration placed the chief emphasis upon a declaration that "there is not a single difficult or disputed question that cannot be solved by the peaceful means of mutual agreement of interested countries."
Three faculty members at New York University knew yesterday that they had made their debuts on television. But instead of Ricky and Lucy, they love "Ralph" and "Celia."

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 21 -- Of two Sarah Lawrence College faculty members who recently were questioned by the Senate Internal Security subcommittee, one has resigned and the other has been cleared by the board of trustees, the college announced today.
A fabric and color forecast for the fall was presented yesterday by the New York Fashion Group in connection with a display at a luncheon in the Astor Hotel.

Alfred Aidala, a sturdy member of the photographic corps who has photographed visiting and resident celebrities for years here, gave up his usually firm grip on his camera yesterday and had his picture taken.

Events tonight: "La Cenerentola," City Center, 8:15 o'clock; Walter Gieseking, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; "The Coronation of Poppea," American Chamber Opera Society, Town Hall 8:40; Arkadie kouguell, pianist-composer, Lexington Avenue "Y," 8:40; "Die Fledermaus," Finch Junior College, 52 East Seventy-eighth Street, 8:30.

LONDON, April 21 -- British Government securities went on to new strength in the stock markets today. After initial hesitancy prices advanced afresh and made gains ranging up to five-sixteenth of 1 per cent.
ST. LOUIS, April 21 (AP) -- The Redlegs surged to a five-run lead and then hung on tonight to beat the Cardinals, 5 -- 4, in a battle of home runs that broke the Redbirds' three-game winning streak.

The new administration in Washington was warned in a friendly fashion yesterday that American Indians and their friends would keep a keen eye on how the Republicans come through with some of the campaign promises made by General Eisenhower in Indian territory last fall.

Briday dresses that varied from informal to formal were presented yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Arnold Constable. Pale colors as well as traditional white were suggested for summer weddings in the fashions designed by Murray Hamburger.

The performance of Bach's B Minor Mass presented last evening in Town Hall by the Concert Choir, under the direction of Margaret Hillis, was one with which almost no fault could be found. Nothing had been left to chance; the event showed the results of long and careful preparation; choristers and soloists knew their music perfectly.

WARD MOREHOUSE, whose absorbing excursion down memory lane, "Just the Other Day,"* is up for discussion this morning, has been a Broadway habitue for a good many years. To be precise, his metropolitan debut occurred in the fall of 1919, when he joined the staff of The New York Tribune as a reporter; it has continued without real intermission since through more than one city room.

Having become the cynosure of a loyal band of supporters as a result of his witty ad-libs on radio and video, the bespectacled Steve Allen will make his Broadway stage debut at 8 o'clock tonight in "The Pink Elephant" at the Playhouse.

BERLIN, April 21 -- Western officials here studied today the possible implications of Moscow's decision to summon home Ambassador Vladimir S. Semyenov who, many believe, is one of the chief architects of Soviet policy in Germany.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Marion Clawson accused Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, of "political consideration" today in removing him as director of the Bureau of Land Management and in the displacement of Albert M. Day as chief of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.

An elevator carrying sixteen persons plunged six floors out of control in a downtown loft building yesterday afternoon and crashed at the bottom of its shaft. All the passengers were injured and five were hospitalized with possible fractures.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 21 -- A broadcast from the Latvian capital of Riga announced tonight a sweeping Cabinet shake-up in which Russians have replaced eight Latvian Ministers in that Soviet Republic.

DESPITE a delayed attack of winter last week, when several inches of snow blanketed parts of northern Maine, the ice is leaving the lakes rapidly, and, according to late reports, the fishing on several of the lakes there has never been better.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 21 -- Columbia's Jim King yielded only four hits and tripled home the winning run as the Lions edged Princeton, 3 -- 1, on University Field today.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Chuck Stobbs registered his first victory for Washington tonight, holding the Athletics to five hits as the Senators capitalized on the wildness of Charley Bishop and Bobo Newsom to post 5-1 triumph.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 21 -- Mexico, with the support of most of the Asian, African and Latin-American countries, introduced today a resolution deploring the presence of "foreign forces" in Burma and calling on all states, when requested by Burma, to provide all the assistance in their power in facilitating their peaceful evacuation.
Six trans-Atlantic liners debarked 4,903 passengers on New York's waterfront yesterday to make it the second busiest day in passenger travel here this year.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The likelihood of early peace in Korea has left business here unperturbed, Government and business leaders agreed here today. Referring to a report by his department that commercial activity continued at a high rate through the early part of this month. Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks said the facts shown prove that business men are not worried by the so-called "peace scare."
Great Britain has never possessed an unofficial ambassadoress of goodwill with more twinkling good natured charm than Lady Clark.

DILLON, S. C., April 21 (AP) -- Rescue workers hunted through the shattered hulls of the Atlantic Coast Line's derailed streamlined all-coach train here tonight on the possibility that more dead or injured persons might be inside.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- United States District Judge Alexander Holtzoff ruled today that Negroes might legally be barred from Federally aided housing projects if equal facilities were available.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -- Russ Meyer's debut against his former team-mates at Connie Mack Stadium tonight was a failure. The Phils knocked Meyer out in the fifth inning and won the game, 7 -- 1, behind the five-hit pitching of Curt Simmons.

HOUSTON, April 21 (UP) -- All seeded stars moved up in the men's singles division of the River Crest invitation tennis tournament today, but the fourth-seeded Dick Savitt had trouble with young Bobby Wertheimer of Southern Methodist before winning 6 -- 1, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 2.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 21 -- "The Prize of Gold," a novel by Max Catto, has been purchased by Warwick Productions, the independent company headed by Irving Allen. R. C. Sherriff will write the screen adaptation and Mark Robson will be the director.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Four woman members of Congress accepted today an invitation from the American Home Laundry Manufacturers Association to hear two woman experts denouncing the excise tax on dryers and ironers as sex discrimination.
Mayor Impellitteri denied yesterday that the city was "on the verge of bankruptcy," as was charged Monday night at a meeting of the Citizens Nonpartisan Committee at the Commodore Hotel.

PITTSBURGH, April 21 -- The Giants tonight made their first inspection of Pittsburgh as an "Eastern" city in the National League and, as far as Manager Leo Durocher is concerned, you can loss the entire project back into Boston Harbor.

The Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre, once known to its faculty and students as "the peripatetic school," celebrated last night its twenty-fifth anniversary with a play commissioned for the school and played in its own theatre with a cast of students.

The Seventh Symphony of Sergei Prokofieff, who died March 4 of this year in Moscow, was played for the first time in New York last night in Carnegie Hall by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting.
A revolutionary type of propeller that may have far-reaching influence upon future tugboat design was demonstrated to the shipping industry on the Hudson River.
MILWAUKEE, April 21 (UP) -- Larry Watson upset Danny Nardico in a ten-round bout at the Milwaukee Arena tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- An all-out campaign by the Daughters of the American Revolution for the Bricker "treaty - limiting" Amendment and against continued United States participation in the United Nations was presaged by tonight's national defense meeting of the Sixty-second Continental Congress.

The Yankees still aren't hitting enough to satisfy Manager Casey Stengel. Fortunately, the attack is a comparatively minor detail when Allie Reynolds is pitching for the Bombers. A fifth-inning homer by Joe Collins gave the Chief all the edge he needed to subdue the Red Sox, 1 -- 0, before 7,193 chilled on-lookers at the Stadium yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Cox yesterday dismissed a suit for $200,000 brought against the city by Mrs. Olga Trapani Rocco, who had charged she was not properly protected against her estranged husband, Alphonse Rocco.

HAMBURG, Germany, April 21 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, was acclaimed forty times tonight when he delivered a speech backing the European Defense Community, the political unity of Western Europe, and absolute identification of the German people with the foreign policy of the United States. Dr. Adenauer was addressing the congress of his party, the Christian Democratic Union.
The American Standards Association has completed and published its minimum performance standards for rayon and acetate fabrics in men's, women's and children's apparel, it was announced yesterday.

The North Atlantic Council, the supreme authority in charge of defense of the Western World, meets in Paris tomorrow in the midst of President Eisenhower's "true peace offensive," to determine how far its fourteen members are willing and able to back up peace with strength.

Paul L. Troast, chairman of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority, won the Republican nomination for Governor of New Jersey in yesterday's primary election, defeating State Senator Malcolm S. Forbes, his nearest rival in a field of seven, by better than 47,000 votes.

Behind the steady pitching of Vince Lupica, senior right-hander, Bill McCarthy's New York University nine scored its first Metropolitan Collegiate Conference victory in three states and snapped a five-game losing streak by beating Manhattan College, 4 -- 2, at Ohio Field yesterday.

Modernization of India's economy will require private capital investment many times that which could be accumulated domestically or provided through such institutions as the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, according to E. A. G. Manton, president of the American International Underwriters Corporation.

The address delivered Monday by Secretary of the Treasury George Humphrey to The Associated Press could serve as the keynote speech for the conference of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. This meeting, which opens tomorrow in Paris, brings together the principal Ministers of fourteen governments, the so-called Atlantic Council.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Americans for Democratic Action called on the Freedom of Information Committee of the American Society of Newspaper Editors today to "make a thorough investigation of political press reporting."

An indication of how agile traders and arbitrageurs take advantage of differentials in stock prices is shown in the big jump during the past month or so in the short position of the common stock of Merck Co., Inc. The New York Stock Exchange reported earlier this week that the short position in Merck had soared to 56,900 shares on April 15, from 14,075 shares in mid-March.

SCHENECTADY, April 21 -- More than 2,200 stockholders of the General Electric company attended the sixty-first annual meeting here today and heard that first quarter sales and earnings broke all previous company records.

LONDON, April 21 -- "Today is the Queen's birthday; we offer Her Majesty our humble and loyal greetings." This message over the British Broadcasting Corporation's programs greeted London early today for Queen Elizabeth II's twenty-seventh birthday.

HANOI, April 21 (AP) -- In pressing the nine-day-old invasion of Laos, one Vietminh division, stabbing westward from the Vietnam province of Annam, took over the town of Xiengkhouang after it was exacuated by French and Laotian forces. Xiengkhouang, on Colonial Route 7, lies ninety miles southeast of Luang Prabang, the capital of the ailing Laotian King Sisavang Vong.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 21 -- A prominent Protestant theologian declared here today that President Eisenhower's recent foreign policy speech constituted as grave a challenge to the people of the United States as it did to the Kremlin.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, April 21 -- Details of a forced march lasting forty-five to fifty days, on which 101 Allied soldiers in Communist captivity died, came to light today in interviews with survivors who were returned to United Nations custody.

Arturo Toscanini has agreed to continue next fall as conductor of the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra's radio concerts in Carnegie Hall. The 86-year-old conductor will direct his customary fourteen concerts during the 1953-54 season, beginning Nov. 7. Eight other concerts will be conducted by Guido Cantelli.

One Count beat the weight and then beat an objection in winning the Naturalist Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. The dark brown colt owned by Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords, making his first local start as a 4-year-old, captured the mile-anda-sixteenth feature event by a length and three-quarters, satisfying the greater part of the crowd of 23,150 fans who made him favorite.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 21 -- Hofstra College's fourth annual tribute to William Shakespeare opened here this afternoon with a matinee performance of "Macbeth."

Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council, disclosed yesterday that he had issued a demand to four city departments to meet "within the week" to draw up a program to pave the way for a new building code that would permit theatres to be constructed in apartment houses and office buildings.
NEWARK, April 21 -- Main Street, U. S. A., is being projected into the age of modern aviation at the $8,500,000 passenger terminal building that is nearing completion at Newark Airport.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Twenty-five Senators, twenty-two of them Democrats, asked President Eisenhower today to define the extent of the underseas land grant to the states he considers is contemplated in the bill under debate in the Senuate.

The New York City Housing Authority borrowed $4,000,000 yesterday for eight months at an interest rate of 1.72 per cent for the temporary financing of Bay View Houses, a city-aided, non-cash-subsidy, low-rent project in Brooklyn. An issue of notes for this amount was sold to Salomon Bros. Hutzler.
NEW DELHI, April 21 -- The Indian Government announced today a comprehensive plan to develop new markets for hand-loom products in Middle Eastern and Southeast Asian countries.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 21 -- The head of the political arm of the American Federation of Labor charged today that a large number of members of the House and Senate serve primarily as "agents of the National Association of Manufacturers."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 21 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines quoted to the United Nations Economic and Social Council today a passage from last week's speech by President Eisenhower to bolster his own endorsement of a recommendation that at least thirty countries voluntarily pledge a minimum of $250,000,000 for aid to underdeveloped areas.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The police had two ambulances waiting at Union Station here tonight for any passengers aboard the survivors' train who might require emergency medical attention. They were not needed, however. Many passengers stayed on the special train to continue the trip to Baltimore and New York.

Officials and founders of the Sheltering Arms Children's Service came in for their share of praise at its 130th anniversary dinner last night. But the guests of honor at the Henry Hudson Hotel were the foster parents of the children in the agency's care.
MALONE, N. Y., April 21 -- An early spring blizzard overnight deposited eight inches to a foot heavy wet snow throughout Franklin County and parts of Clinton and Essex Counties.

TRENTON, April 21 -- Paul L. Troast looks like a successful business man or administrator. He is both. President of the Mahony-Troast Company, probably the best-known construction concern in Passaic County, he headed the three-man board that planned, financed. built and is now operating the New Jersey Turnpike.

THE Cleveland Browns of the National Football League have just triumphantly announced the signing of George Ratterman for the second straight year as the second-string quarterback. It's nice work if you can get it. No salary terms were revealed but the general estimate is that the nice-looking blond youngster from Notre Dame will receive something like $20,000 for the season, assuming that he's getting the same as he did in 1952.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars told its members today "the fight is on" and the time had come "to stand up and be counted" against what it called Congressional efforts to reduce veterans' benefits.
TEHERAN, Iran, April 21 -- Brig. Gen. Mahmud Afshartous, chief of the nation's police, was the object of a widespread search today after his failure to return from a mysterious rendezvous last night.
Contributions to the American Red Cross blood donor program amounted to 1,409 pints of blood in the metropolitan area on Monday, officials reported yesterday.

Surely it would be difficult to find an important link in New York City's public transportation system that has as much wrong with it as the Times Square-Grand Central subway shuttle. Col. Sidney H. Bingham, chairman of the Board of Transportation, has been working on the problem, along with the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the Stephens-Adamson Manufacturing Company.

ST. LOUIS, April 21 (AP) -- The head of the patient is placed directly over the "window" of an atomic reactor in an experimental treatment for a deadly brain cancer described today by the American Radium Society. The results thus far, based on tests on ten patients, indicate there were no harmful side-reactions.

Delicacies from Norway -- flat bread, shrimp, sardines and cheeses -- certainly are familiar here. But for the first time a wide variety of Norwegian foods has been assembled in an exhibit at Norway House, 290 Madison Avenue. The display, to which twelve importers have contributed, will be open to the public Thursday and Friday.

The Worthington Corporation, manufacturer of pumps and heavy industrial equipment, has signed a lease for the first space to be rented in the twenty-six-story office building being built by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company at 99 Park Avenue, southeast corner of East Fortieth Street.
LANDSTUHL, Germany, April 21 (UP) -- The United States Air Force played host today to thirty-six members of the famed German "Richthofen Squadrons," who fought American airmen in two world wars.

The sixty-seventh annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association opened here yesterday. The principal problems discussed were rising production costs and competition from television. Most solutions proposed were based on constantly striving to publish better papers, promoting them in every conceivable way, and using "good housekeeping" methods to keep down costs even in small matters.

Peace returned to two spots along the city's waterfront yesterday when longshoremen at the Brooklyn Army Base, First Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, and at the West Side Chelsea piers of the United States Lines reported for work after one-day stoppages.

Customs collectors have been alerted to watch for illegal importation of German-made toiletries bearing a "4711" trade-mark, John Roosevelt, president of "4711," Limited, informed a state sales meeting of the company yesterday. In addition, he said, the company's legal department has been instructed to proceed against any person or organization selling or distributing toiletries products under the trade-mark which do not originate with his company.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, left by plane today for a strategy meeting of Western nations with a warning against any retreat in defense planning and a prediction that the "growing strength of the free world" might enforce a true policy of peace by the Soviet Union.

Every well-wisher of the United Nations will heartily support your appreciation of the work of Trygve Lie, and your good wishes as he leaves his thankless post. The American public has the general idea that he has done a real job. He never sank the man in the office.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- A Government lawyer told House of Representatives investigators today that the Federal Maritime Board twisted the law "out of shape" in granting nearly $7,000,000 in subsidies to the American Export Lines.
DETROIT, April 21 (UP) -- Southpaw Billy Pierce gained his second victory of the season today as the White Sox downed the Tigers, 7 -- 5, before 2,742 fans at Briggs Stadium.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Arthur A. Kimball today was named acting deputy administrator of the State Department's overseas information and educational exchange program.
The annual report of the International News Service, made public yesterday, stressed two developments in high-speed transmission of news photos.

WASHINGTON, April 21--Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, has recommended a new Director of the Bureau of Mines, and John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, has given the White House notice he will fight Mr. McKay's selection.

Eva Le Gallienne's autobiographic story, "With a Quiet Life," will be published by Viking on Friday. It is a "behind-the-scene" chronicle of her struggles as manager, producer, director, actress, translator and "gadfly extraordinary" in the cause of good drama.

PARIS, April 21 -- In a small collection of simple wearable mid-summer models, Patou abandons low waistlines. Suits of fine gray-and-white check woolens revert to the classical as collars, nipped waistlines and short, clinging peplums.

BEERSHEBA, Israel, April 21 -- Water began to flow this week from Israel's deepest well to the town of Beersheba and twenty-one new farming settlements will be added to the existing fifty in the Negev.
HANOI, Vietnam, April 21 -Vietminh forces today arrived within five miles of the French military base on the Plaine des Jarres in Laos.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- A resolution to add the words "under God" to the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag of the United States has been introduced in the House of Representatives by Representative Louis C. Rabaut, Democrat of Michigan.

Newspapers received $526,058,000 for advertising last year, according to a compilation released yesterday by Media Records. Groceries advertising was the leading classification with $120,825,000, but this included $29,634,000 for advertising of laundry soaps and cleansers and $1,110,000 for disinfectants and exterminators.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- The age of the Government's charges against the du Ponts was stressed today at the anti-trust trial in Federal District Court when a du Pont attorney told of extreme difficulty in finding witnesses and documentary evidence to aid in the defense.
I leave my breakfast table morning after morning with the intention of telling the editors of THE NEW YORK TIMES what a solid bulwark of information their paper provides daily.

NEW ORLEANS, April 21 -- James F. Crist, president of the Southern Association of Science and Industry, said today that the industrial development rate in the South "means that at least 100 new major waste-disposal problems must be solved in the region each year."
The cotton futures market here closed barely steady yesterday and final prices were 16 points lower to 2 higher than on Monday.
Joseph M. Friedlander, financial vice president of Jewel Tea Company, Inc., has been elected a director of Signode Steel Strapping Company.

"Bait and switch" advertising is widely prevalent in the sewing machine and vacuum cleaner fields, in addition to such practices in the sales of other appliances such as radios and television sets, long subject to a campaign by Better Business Bureaus.

More than twenty outstanding newspaper and magazine photographers have contributed some of their best prints to the Overseas Press Club of America, which will put them on public exhibition from May 1 through May 9 in the lounge of the Time-Life Building, 9 Rockefeller Plaza.

A substantial increase in sales and operating revenues, and a modest boost in net income, were reported yesterday by the Aluminum Company of America for the first quarter this year, compared with a year ago. Sales and operating revenues were $170,322,877 compared with $139,650,841.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, April 21 -- Easy laughter burst from the throats of the newly freed American soldiers for the first time here this morning while they were talking to members of the press. As soon as the first prisoners were helped or carried into the interview tent, it was obvious that much of yesterday's tension and uncertainty had lifted.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 21 -- A conference of commonwealth and state veterinary officers and experts on stock diseases from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization at Canberra unanimously recommended today that there be no relaxation of the quarantine laws for horses participating in 1956 Olympic Games.

Republican leaders said last night they would welcome the help of good government forces in an effort fort to change administrations at City Hall, but they made it clear they expected any coalition to be led by their party.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The State Department decided today to resume making dollar-exchange contracts with American newspaper, magazine and book publishers who wished to sell their publications abroad.

MOSCOW, April 21 -- According to reports of the Tiflis newspaper Zarya Vostoka (Dawn of the East), a special plenary session of the Georgian Trade Union Council has been held at which the decision that had excluded Ivlian Samsonovich Zodelava from the Trade Union plenun was reversed.

Pleas for integration of economic as well as defense and foreign policy in Europe were made here yesterday by leading citizens of five countries, the United States, Britain, France, Canada and the Netherlands.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 21 -- The Delaware Park race track today announced the completion of a $100,000 bunk-house project aimed at getting all grooms out of its stables into living quarters where there will be less of a fire hazard.

There is no question that New York City could stand much in the way of civic beautification and improvement in general appearance. Our dirty streets have long been a source of shame, and the fact that they have remained messy and unseemly to look at has done nothing to stimulate property owners to keep their houses painted and lawns trimmed.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 21 (AP) -- The co-medalists, Bill Campbell of Huntington, W. Va., and Spec Goldman of Dallas, and the defending champion, Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, each squeezed through to a 1-up victory today in the opening round of the North and South amateur golf tournament's match-play competition.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- A possible merger of Western Union Telegraph, R. C. A. Communications, Inc., and American Cable and Radio Corporation is under study by the three companies, it was disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, today recommended a two-year extension of the physicians' draft law, "with a minimum of tampering."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 21 -- With the present high rate of divorce, there is a tendency to overlook the fact that many of these marriage failures originated in dating and courtship, Dr. Henry A. Bowman of Stephens College, Columbia, Mo., said here today.

The city is quietly planning to keep open until late June the time within which final action may be taken on the $1,528,812,795 budget for 1953-54. Local legislation to this end will be introduced at a special meeting of the City Council tomorrow.

Judge Harold R. Medina conferred yesterday with lawyers in the investment banking anti-trust trial with a view to streamlining the case's current phase -- the oral arguments of defense lawyers supporting motions to dismiss the charges.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 22 -- The United Nations and Communist commands completed the exchange of the third group of sick and wounded prisoners of the Korean war today while former captives of both sides made charges of having suffered ill treatment while in internment.

New York is the most "disgustingly filthy" city in the world, Edna Ferber declared here yesterday shortly before debarking from the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth after a ten-week vacation in Western Europe.

Sidney H. Bingham, chairman of the Board of Transportation, said yesterday that an endless-belt conveyor to replace the Grand Central - Times Square subway shuttle could be built at a cost of $3,800,000.
TOKYO, Wednesday, April 22 (AP) -- United Nations Command Communique 1,592, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korean Time:

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 21 -- The Bergen County special grand jury, which has been investigating gambling and corruption for the last year, declared today that the alliance between "a new type of criminal" and "weak officials" was primarily responsible for failure to enforce the anti-gambling laws here.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- House investigators turned up testimony today that the Army spent $45,000,000 for overcoats too heavy and gadget-loaded to use.

TRENTON, April 21 -- A libel suit seeking $4,500,000 from Frank Hague Eggers, former Mayor of Jersey City, and an equal amount from Walter Scott, trading as the Scott Printing Company of Jersey City, was filed in Superior Court here today by nine Hudson County lawyers.

HARTFORD, April 21 -- The Connecticut General Assembly adopted a bill today to prohibit the public sale of fireworks in this state after Oct. 1. The measure goes to Gov. John Davis Lodge for his signature, which is assured.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- A Republican drive to halt the public housing program stirred one of the sharpest controversies of the session today as the House of Representatives began debate on the year's first regular appropriations bill.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Senate investigators looked again into Congressional committees today for signs of Communist infiltration among staff members who had advised legislators during wartime.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 21 -- The last technicality standing in the way of United Nations General Assembly approval of an impartial inquiry into the Communist charges that the United States used germ weapons in Korea was removed today.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- Grain futures started with fractional gains today but reacted sharply, demand fading soon after the opening. However, the setbacks in wheat and other grains appeared to meet support on resting orders rather than running into liquidating pressure. Much of the selling was for local account, professionals apparently trying to start another run of liquidation.

The Fisher Cadillac Corporation has leased the one and two story building containing about 25,000 square feet at 380-82 Central Avenue in Newark, N. J., from the Jayaness Corporation. The lease also includes a plot of 10,000 square feet at Morris Avenue and New Street which will be used for the open storage of cars.

MODERN fire laws don't permit recording companies such as Columbia and R. C. A. Victor to build wooden studios, which are best for making records, so company engineers in New York keep looking for existing structures that have mellow interiors they can adapt for the purpose.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Henry W. Grunewald testified today that he had received a $25,000 fee in 1949 from a New York attorney who later got speedy handling of a half million dollar corporation tax refund.

LONDON, April 21 (AP) -- A sharp increase in British exports to Red China -- seventeen bigger in January and February than in the first two months of 1952 -- was disclosed today. A British Government spokesman said only non-strategic goods were being sold.
For the first time in 15,000 criminal cases, Benjamin Schmier, Legal Aid Society attorney, pleaded yesterday in Federal Court that a defendant be sent to prison.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Powerful Republicans in Congress would like President Eisenhower to appoint at once a new stand-by military high command to put under critical review, even before taking office formally, all the strategic decisions of the present Joint Chiefs of Staff.

BERLIN, April 21 -- Six Britons and an Irish missionary returned to the Western world here today after almost three years' internment by the North Koreans. They were sunburned from lounging about their camp near the Yalu River, but visibly worn by their experience.

Commodity prices closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee, lead, zinc and hides showed sizable volume. Lead, zinc and soybean oil were higher and cocoa, coffee, sugar and tin ended lower. Hides, wool, potatoes, cottonseed oil and rubber closed mixed.

President Eisenhower has called "the financial crisis facing the nation's seventy-nine medical schools" a "dangerous threat to the national welfare which must be met." His declaration is contained in a letter to S. Sloan Colt, president of the National Fund for Medical Education, which is seeking $10,000,000 in a campaign directed primarily at industry and the medical profession, to help the medical schools overcome deficits threatening their teaching and research programs.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- Zenith Radio Corporation said here today that it had asked the United States Court of appeals in Washington to set aside the recent Federal Communications Commission dismissal of Zenith's application for permission to operate a commercial television station on Channel 2 in Chicago.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 21 -- The Soviet Union's delegation to the United Nations took some campus buffeting from the Harvard Crimson today in the form of a "peace dove" offering that the Russians accepted, and then discovered that all they got was the bird, known venerably as the razzberry.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that Americans owe $82,000,000,000 on mortgages, installment purchases and other short-term debts.

PARIS, April 21 -- Military experts of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization plan to present to the full ministerial conference opening here Thursday statistics estimating the present Soviet front line air strength at a minimum of 4,000 modern jet-propelled combat planes and the Soviet ground forces at 175 combat-ready divisions.

The Lucy Stone League urged yesterday in a telegram to the John Peter Zenger Foundation that a way be found, "even at this late date," to honor Anna Zenger equally with her husband in the John Peter Zenger Memorial Room to be opened tomorrow in Federal Hall, the old Sub-Treasury Building at Nassau and Wall Streets.

The Grumman Cougar, latest of the long line of "cat" fighters produced by Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation at Bethpage, L. I., is a swept-wing Navy fighter that can take off from the deck of a carrier and outperform the Russian MIG "in range, speed, climb and maneuverability."

Roy M. Cohn and Gerard David Schine, aides to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's Permanent Investigations subcommittee, returned here yesterday from their eighteen-day tour of seven European nations where they had investigated the United States Information Service.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 21 -- The oil-slicked waters of San Francisco Bay were searched for bodies today while a four-point investigation got under way into the crash of a passenger airliner in which eight persons apparently died shortly before last midnight.

Mayor Impellitteri virtually repudiated yesterday the action of the Police Department in issuing a permit to the left-wing United Labor and People's May Day Committee to hold its annual May Day parade on Eighth Avenue.

NEW DELHI, India, April 21 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and the new Prime Minister of Pakistan, Mohammed Ali, have exchanged cordial messages raising hope again for an adjustment of long-standing problems that have seriously impeded the economic progress of both countries and have caused apprehensions both here and abroad.

Being young and a former model herself. Helene Scott has designed maternity fashions that have a liberal amount of youthful dash. Shown yesterday at Lane Bryant, they featured a version of the currently popular box jacket with a variety of slim-in-line but adjustable skirts.

SEOUL, Wednesday, April 22 (AP) -- Action lagged on the ground in Korea yesterday but United States carrier planes staged a surprise party for the Communists with smashing raids on the central and eastern fronts.

Mayor Impellitteri said yesterday that the New York City Transit Authority members, including the two he had named, were "on their own" in working out the agreement for taking over the city's deficit-ridden transit system. State law requires them to reach such an agreement with the Board of Estimate by June.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- President Eisenhower flew back to the capital late today after an eventful nine-day Georgia vacation during which he began a drive to regain for the United States the initiative in the world "peace offensive," won a brief bout with food poisoning, and finally got his golf score under 90 for the first time since he became President.

The letter from B. A. Garside appearing in your columns on April 15 entitled "Our Korean Policy" is an articulate expression of a viewpoint regarding American Far Eastern policy which merits thoughtful reflection.

A dozen pairs or new shoes came ashore yesterday on the feet of a family from Holland. After noting the appearance of Lambertus de Brouwer, 46 years old, his wife and ten children with footwear of fine leather, coats of sturdy tweed on the men and furs on the women, one wondered why they had left their prosperous dairy farm in St. Dedenrode for an unpredictable future in Canada.

CAIRO, April 21 -- Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, chief British military delegate to the forthcoming talks with Egypt on the withdrawal of British forces from the Suez Canal zone, refused today to answer questions as to whether London's agreement to begin the talks Monday indicated acceptance of the Egyptian demands for the unconditional evacuation of the zone.
The bond market continued its readjustment yesterday to the Treasury's borrowing of upward of $1,000,000,000 on long-term 3 1/4 per cent bonds.
Two soldiers were injured, one of them critically, when the propelling charge of an anti-aircraft shell exploded at 2:10 P. M. yesterday at an anti-aircraft battery near Flushing Airport, Queens.

BONN, Germany, April 21 -- The Social Democratic party, second largest in West Germany, would welcome a Soviet proposal of free and secret all-German elections as the first step toward this country's reunification.

MOSCOW, April 21 -- D. I. Chesnokov, who has been listed as chief editor of the Communist party Central Committee's principal organ Communist since November of last year, is not listed in that post in the issue of Communist appearing on sale today.

CLEVELAND, April 21 (AP) -- Bob Lemon scored his second straight victory today as the Indians snapped the Browns' four-game winning streak, 4 -- 3. A crowd of 1,772 saw the affair. The loss dropped St. Louis into a first-place tie with the Yankees.
JERSEY CITY, April 21 -- Bingo is legal here.

ALBANY, April 21 -- The State Workmen's Compensation Board announced today that it would not be necessary this year for carriers who provide disability benefits insurance to pay an assessment into the special disability benefits fund. Miss Mary Donlon, chairman of the board which administers the disability program, said the high level of employment had resulted in fewer claims against the special fund.

PARIS, April 22 -- Political and military leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty nations will open here tomorrow their eleventh conference to discuss the vital need for collective security, despite the recent Soviet peace gestures.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -The Senators rallied for four runs with two out in the ninth inning off Harry Byrd tonight, but Carl Scheib came out of the bullpen to preserve a 7-4 victory for the Athletics.

BALTIMORE, April 22 (AP) -Orlando Zulueta of Cuba and Joey Brown of New Orleans, two aspiring young lightweights trying to advance their title ambitions, failed in the attempt tonight as they battled to a tame 10-round draw in the Coliseum here. Zulueta weighed 133 3/4, and Brown 135.

Gasoline stocks in the nation declined 3,265,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were listed as 157,942,000 barrels, compared with 161,207,000 a week earlier and 157,392,000 a year ago.
PANMUNJOM, Thursday, April 23 (AP) -- Following is the official list of United Nations sick and wounded prisoners here today:

Purchases of life insurance in the United States during March totaled $3,337,000,000, a record figure and 34 per cent greater than in the corresponding period of last year. Purchases of ordinary life insurance in March, it was reported yesterday by the Life Insurance Agency Management Association, totaled $2,169,000,000, a new high and a gain of 26 per cent above March, 1952.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -Karl Drews, the deliberate righthander, pitched the Phils to a 5-4 victory over the Dodgers that dropped the losers from first place and practically ruined Jake Pitler's fifty-ninth birthday party, which was tossed for the Brooklyn coach after the game.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- In attacking the problem, as it soon must, of what to do about the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the Administration will face a highly complex situation

The Welcome Wagon, an international organization that has made a business of greeting newcomers to a community, celebrating birthdays, taking gifts to brides and new parents, celebrated its own twenty-fifth birthday yesterday with a gathering of 2,000 hostesses at the Park Sheraton Hotel.
