LONDON, April 22 -- A welcoming crowd sang the hymm "Praise God From Whom All Blessings Flow" as six British civilians and an Irish priest returned home today from internment in North Korea.
The time has come to strip representation rights from unions found to be subversive agencies posing as labor organizations, A. H. Raskin, labor reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES, said yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, April 22 -- A third attempt will be made at 2 P. M. tomorrow to determine the position thirteen city commission candidates will have on May 12 on the voting machines in the municipal election here. But members of the warring factions expressed their fears openly this afternoon that they probably would wind up in court again, just as they did after the first two attempts.

A special jury returned a verdict of guilty last night against John E. Gleason Jr., former general inspector in the Department of Sanitation, who was charged with having perjured himself before a grand jury investigating shakedowns of fuel-oil installers.
LONDON, April 22 -- Twice in the House of Commons today Prime Minister Churchill asserted his and Britain's independence from the United States.

CAIRO, April 23 -- Proposals for the establishment of an effective defense organization of the Arab states on a regional basis without links to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization were reported to have been the subject of conversations here today between Egypt's Premier Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, and President Camille Chamoun of Lebanon.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Senate Rules Committee approved today a proposal intended to make it easier to apply closure, or a "gag," on filibusters, which are time-killing actions aimed at preventing a vote on any resisted measure.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 22 -- A telephone operator who played the part of a practical midwife by remote control was nominated here today for a national award by officials of the New York Telephone Company.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 23 -The Communists promised today to return more than the 605 United Nations and South Korean prisoners of the Korean war originally scheduled for transfer as sick and wounded under the terms of the Geneva Convention. Fourteen United States soldiers were among fifty of the Allied forces returned today.

Varied divertissements have been planned for the annual Spring Festival of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, to be held today and tomorrow in the Parish House of the church at 31 East Seventy-first Street. Mrs. Charles Ingalls Morton is chairman of the executive committee, Mrs. Richard S. Meredith, vice chairman; George Emlen Roosevelt, treasurer; and Mrs. John Gerdes, assistant treasurer.

The industrial property at the southwest corner of Flushing Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street in Maspeth, Queens, has been sold by Charles Gleason, president of the Gleason-Tiebout Company, to the S. S. Corrugated Paper Machinery Company in a transaction negotiated by the Charles F. Noyes Company as broker.

Work stoppages yesterday morning on four Brooklyn piers -- the result of a "no work, no pay" order last week to dockworkers' shop stewards -- led to what appeared last night to be the resolution of the problem that caused a series of halts this week.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -The Army counter-attacked on the overcoat front today with a statement that it knew full well what had happened to $45,000,000 worth of coats ordered in 1946.
The Joint Chiefs of Staff, the nation's four top-ranking military men, were the focus of debate in Washington yesterday.

A continued adverse effect on attendance at college football games during 1952 was caused by live television, it was disclosed yesterday by the National Collegiate Athletic Association Television Committee.
LOS ANGELES, April 22 -- Scientists have just condemned 1,000 white mice to lives entirely in "smog" to see if it can cause lung cancer.

LOS ANGELES, April 22 -- Alleged threats by Brig. Gen. Joseph Stanley Holtoner, commanding officer of the Edwards Air Force Base, to bomb her resort ranch were related to Federal Judge James M. Carter today by Miss Florence Pancho Barnes, also known as a flier. She asks $300,000 damages for injury to her resort business.

Dr. Buell Gallagher, president of City College, made a special appeal for blood donors yesterday to meet the needs of the troops still fighting in Korea as students at that institution started a three-day effort to provide 1,000 pints of blood to the Red Cross units.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 23 (AP) -- A new story of a death march across North Korea's frozen wastes, of prisoners clubbed, bayoneted and pushed over embankments when they faltered, was added today to the grim history of Allied captives in Communist hands.

The United States, as the leader of the free nations, cannot afford the existence of any bigoted attitudes here and "any amount of bigotry is too expensive," Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, said last night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 22 -- William Wellman will continue his alliance with Wayne-Fellows, independent producing unit, by directing its adaption of Ernest Gann's new novel, "The High and the Mighty." John Wayne will star in this one himself and it is scheduled to go before the cameras sometime in the summer.

Defense counsel for Blyth Co., Inc., one of the seventeen defendants in the anti-trust investment banking suit, cited yesterday the company's trade record in public sealed bidding deals in an effort to show that there was no basis for the Government charge that Blyth had conspired to prevent the adoption of compulsory competitive bidding for the purchase of certain types of securities and to circumvent the practice after it was adopted.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, described to the Senate today what he termed "the discipline" meted out by the Truman Administration to a Federal tax official for accepting favors from a taxpayer in trouble with the Government. He said the official received two pay rises, a promotion and a cash bonus.

Ignatz Mezei of Buffalo, 56 years old, expert cabinet maker and man without a country, walked from Manhattan Island onto an Ellis Island ferryboat at 3:45 P. M. yesterday for possible confinement the rest of his life.

Alexander P. Cannon and Thomas J. Rafter, who formerly operated the firm of Cannon Rafter, specializing in the acquisition of gasoline station sites, have joined a new department formed by William A. White Sons for the acquisition of such sites.

John D. Rockefeller Jr., who in December bought the eighteen-story apartment building at 740 Park Avenue, northwest corner of Seventy-first Street, where he lives, has resold it to the tenants for operation on a cooperative basis.

PRETORIA, South Africa, April 22 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan, whose Nationalist party was victorious in last week's elections, returned in triumph to the South African capital today under circumstances that emphasized to the maximum that it was the victory of a nation -- a Boer nation -rather than a political party.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 22 -- Following a report that Queen Juliana of the Netherlands was disappointed by the White House's chilly reception of her recent personal appeal to President Eisenhower on the refugee problem, a personal letter from the President to the Queen has arrived here.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 22 -- The Mutual Security Agency mission here recommended today that Washington approve the Netherlands Government's proposal to earmark for defense expenditures one-third of the 900,000,000-guilder ($237,000,000) counterpart fund and to devote part of the remaining two-thirds to flood relief. Funds not earmarked for either of these purposes would finance normal budget expenditures.
Columbia University mineralogists reported yesterday the isolation of a heretofore unknown mineral rich in uranium, a radioactive element used in the production of atomic energy.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) -The Department of Defense reported today that United States battle casualties in Korea now total 133,787, an increase of 324 over last week's report.

New York University has completed arrangements to acquire the Holley Chambers property at 33 Washington Square West, southwest corner of Washington Place, Chancellor Henry T. Heald announced yesterday. The property consists of the sixteen-story Holley Chambers and two adjoining eight-story buildings known as the Holley Hotel.

On Aug. 4, 1735, John Peter Zenger, printer and publisher, was acquitted by a jury, out for only ten minutes, of a charge that his newspaper published false, malicious and seditious discussions "tending to alienate the affections of the people of this province from His Majesty's Government."

ATLANTIC CITY, April 22 -The United States could be a greater leader of the world if its people would stress our material wealth less and our spiritual and intellectual side more, the Hotel and Restaurant Employes and Bartenders International Union, A. F. L., heard today.

The running of the $30,100 Correction Handicap at Jamaica yesterday provided a close-order finish in which Joe W. Brown's Parading Lady, after a between-horses charge in the stretch, won with half a length to spare in the role of $9.10-for-$2 third choice.
TOKYO, Thursday, April 23 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 384, for Wednesday to 6 P. M.:

A meeting protesting the admittance to this country of Walter Gieseking, German pianist, was held last night at Seventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, near the entrance to Carnegie Hall, where the musician was performing before an audience of 2,700.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 22 -Dr. Reuben Hill of the University of North Carolina today criticized family research for what he called its concentration on mother and child relationships and a tendency to slight other relationships in the family circle.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Tracy S. Voorhees of the Long Island Transit Authority told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that tax concession provisions in the plan for reorganizing the Long Island Rail Road offered the best hope for improved commuter service.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 22 (UP) -- Straight Face and Correspondent, equal third choices in the Kentucky Derby winter book at 4 to 1, meet for the first time tomorrow in the twenty-ninth running of the $25,000-added Blue Grass Stakes.
Charley Dietlin, Fordham's unbeaten junior righthander, twirled a one-hitter for his third success as the Rams topped City College, 6 -- 1, yesterday at Fordham Field.

The outstanding draft indebtedness of Brazil rose an additional $3,100,000 last month to a new peak of $205,100,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The data are based on reports supplied by fifteen banks which participate in the Federal Reserve's monthly survey of Latin American export credit.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 -New capital totaling $30,000,000,000 must be found by business men of the eleven western states if jobs are to be provided for those needing them by 1960, it was estimated today by Charles R. Sligh Jr. of Grand Rapids, Mich., president of the National Association of Manufacturers.

A hand-size fire extinguisher made by the Pyrene Manufacturing Company won the grand prize last night at the eighth annual home safety awards dinner, arranged by Lewis Conger, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Robert B. Meyner, 44-year-old Phillipsburg lawyer, emerged yesterday as the winner of the Democratic nomination for Governor of New Jersey in Tuesday's close primary race, but his victory was challenged immediately by Elmer H. Wene, Vineland chick breeder, who demanded a partial recount.

An almost unanimous vote to authorize strike action by 1,200 installers of heavy equipment at telephone exchanges in New York, Westchester and Long Island was cast last night in a closed session of Local 10,169 of the Communications Workers of America, C.I.O.

Three new contemporary fabric patterns, correlated in colorings so they might be used in the same room, are available through the decorating department of Altman's. Designed by Vera for F. Schumacher, the motifs are printed on a light-weight denim that is washable and pre-shrunk. The fabric comes in thirty-sixinch width.

Bathing-suit sales, representing a substantial portion of all the knitted outerwear volume, can be increased by an educational campaign among store buyers and merchandise men, according to William Burston, manager of the merchandising division, National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The estimated revenue for all newspaper advertising in 1952 was $2,309,000,000 compared with $2,111,000,000 in 1951, it was said yesterday by Stuart M. Chambers, chairman of the board of directors of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

HOUSTON, April 22 (AP) -- Hal Burrows, the nation's nineteenth ranked amateur, ended Dick Savitt's brief return to tournament tennis today as two other seeded players made narrow escapes in the fourth round of the River Oaks Invitation.

A startling inconsistency is evident between President Eisenhower's recent pledge to work for "the highest possible level of [international] trade" and the Defense Department's rejection of a low British bid to supply certain electrical equipment for no visible reason other than that it was British.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) -Oscar L. Chapman, former Secretary of the Interior, confirmed today that he had considered discharging Marion Clawson as Director of the Bureau of Land Management "a long time ago" because he had not been "loyal" to Mr. Chapman.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Every formula that as yet has been devised to remove from or keep out of Government service all persons who might, in large or small degree, endanger the security of the United States has encountered constructive criticism as well as the other kind.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Dr. Earl J. McGrath, Commissioner of Education, resigned today in a letter to President Eisenhower as a protest against a new $8,448,391 cut in the proposed $88,876,370 budget for the Office of Education in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare for the 1954 fiscal year beginning July 1.
Ways of modernizing a kitchen were discussed yesterday at the fourth annual Automatic Gas Range Conference held at the Ambassador Hotel by the Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association.

MUNSAN, Korea, Thursday, April 23 -- The Communists returned to United Nations hands today prisoners who obviously were seriously ill. Their faces were chalk white and some seemed to be in pain as they were lifted from ambulances.

Spring, which according to the meteorologists arrived a month ago, became official in these parts yesterday as the recurrent rain, wind and chilly weather that has marked April thus far relaxed under the benign influence of sunshine and temperatures above 60 degrees.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, April 28 (AP) -- South Korean raiders slashed into Chinese Communist trenches near Panmunjom at daybreak today, under cover of tanks and a thunderous two-hour artillery barrage.

PARIS, April 22 -- In view of the worsening situation in Indo-China, and in Laos in particular, the French Cabinet decided today to call on the United States for increased aid in Indo-China and on the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for priority in dealing with the Indo-China problem.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -The White House said today President Eisenhower's illness last week resulted merely from eating something that disagreed with him -- no case of food poisoning was involved.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Treasury announced today that offers to buy its $1,000,000,000 issue of 3 1/4 per cent thirty-year bonds had totaled about $6,000,000,000 and that, after weeding out excessive and speculative subscriptions, awards of $1,080,000,000 of the securities had been made.

BILLY PIERCE of the White Sox spun a gaudy one-hitter the other day to score a 1-0 victory over Harry Brecheen of the Browns, who spun a handsome two-hitter himself. This feat inspired some of the younger parishioners to write in and ask: Was there ever a double no-hitter pitched in the major leagues? There sure was, buster.

BOSTON, April 22 -- Incorporation papers were filed today at the Massachusetts State House for the Northern Textile Association, an organization of New England manufacturers working for a prosperous textile industry in this area.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Shane," a Western drama in Technicolor, produced and directed by George Stevens for Paramount with Alan Ladd, Jean Arthur, Van Heflin and Brandon de Wilde heading the cast, is at the Radio City Music Hall.

We observed a recent report in THE NEW YORK TIMES describing a letter sent to Lester B. Pearson, President, United Nations General Assembly, by the New York branch of the Federation of Greek Maritime Unions in which the latter protested regarding the agreement effected between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Greek shipowners here in New York.

LONDON, April 22 -- British Government securities continued to dominate the stock markets today. Buying of the funds broadened to embrace most undated and longer term stocks which made another fairly general advance of about 114 per cent. South African gold shares also improved, especially those of the scheduled uranium producers.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, April 22 -- Growing alarm is being expressed in New Zealand at the United States' big stockpile of surplus dairy produce. New Zealand is among the world's largest dairy exporters and officials declare there is danger that American disposal of its surplus would have a disastrous effect on the world market.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 22 -- Dag Hammarskjold, the Swedish economist and diplomat who so unexpectedly became Secretary General of the United Nations twelve days ago, made his first solo public appearance this afternoon when he accepted a $6,000,000 contribution from the United States for the organization's technical assistance program.

Several dinner parties will be given in advance of the recital by Anna Russell, singing comedienne, to be held tonight at Town Hall for the benefit of the Third Street Music School Settlement. Mrs. John L. Tonnele is chairman and Mrs. Cyrus McCormick, co-chairman, of the benefit committee.

PARIS, April 22 -- Settlement of the question of whether the United States or Britain is to be in command of the naval sector known as "Iberland," including the Atlantic approaches to the Western Mediterranean through Gibraltar, has been postponed indefinitely owing to a difference on interpretation of an agreement made at Rome during the North Atlantic Treaty Organization meeting in November, 1951, Allied circles indicated today.

The French pianist-composer Arkadie Kouguell appeared at the Kaufmann Auditorium of the Lexington Y. M. and Y. W. H. A. last night in a program of his own compositions. It was an evening of music that demonstrated the range and versatility of Mr. Kouguell's talent.

BERLIN, April 22 -- The third session of the Big Four talks on air safety over Germany was held here today to consider proposals offered by both the East and the West. Allied sources said definite progress had been made.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- In many ways the shift from a defensestimulated economy to one based more on civilian demands has been highly encouraging thus far, M. S. Szymczak said today. Mr. Szymczak, acting vice chairman of the Federal Reserve System, addressed the annual stockholders' meeting of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Chicago.
CHICAGO, April 22 (UP) -- Ed Mathews smashed two home runs and a double today to drive in six runs as the Braves blasted the Cubs, 15 to 6, before 9,920 ladies' day fans in Wrigley Field.

Although next season may appear to be a long way off, Maurice Evans and George Schaefer already have laid out their plans for their production of "The Teahouse of the August Moon," the John Patrick comedy based on the novel by Vern Sneider.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 22 -- A scale model of an early Elizabethan playhouse will be unveiled tomorrow in the Yale Library by Charles R. Prouty, Professor of English and an Elizabethan specialist. The event will mark the 389th anniversary of the birth of William Shakespeare.
Newspaper publishers were counseled yesterday to keep an alert eye" on United Nations activities that "ostensibly' aimed at worldwide freedom of communication but might be used to restrict the press.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., April 22 -- Approval of the General Electric Company's plans for building a national administrative office center on a 315-acre tract at Valhalla, overlooking Kensico Reservoir, was recommended today by the Mount Pleasant Town Planning Board in a report to the Town Council.
Denmark has arranged to increase the amount of funds to be made available for the retirement of dollar bond obligations this year from $9,600,000 to $14,400,000, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, recommended to President Eisenhower today the appointment of Marvin C. Nichols of Fort Worth, Tex., a consulting engineer, as Commissioner of the Bureau of Reclamation.

THE HAGUE, April 22 -- During March, the first month of Government operation of the mines on Bamka Island, principal source of Indonesian tin, Indonesia's production of tin in concentrates was 2,342 tons, compared with 2,886 in the same month last year, the International Tin Study Group reported here today.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 2 points higher to 3 points lower than on Tuesday.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 22 -- Princeton lost its second baseball game in as many days today as Herb Bittlingmaier pitched four-hit ball to help New York University gain a 9-4 victory at University Field. The contest was called at the end of eight innings because of darkness.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- President Eisenhower is now engaged in one of the most ambitious experiments of his long career. He is trying to use the game of golf as a solace to the anguish of his job, and as an instrument for unifying the Republican party.

Miss Edna Ferber was in a caustic humor when she got off the boat after a ten-week vacation in Europe. New York was the most "disgustingly filthy" city in the world. The streets were covered with garbage, and she didn't mean dirt. Apartment windows couldn't be opened because of dust and soot.

MOSCOW, April 22 -- Two more Soviet republics -- Azerbaijan and Armenia -- have carried out reorganizations of their local governments to bring them into line with consolidations of the Central Government Ministries carried out in March.

All of the rain of March and April has done one thing at least, if no more. There have been a lot of little things too, of course. For example, it has increased the revenue of sump pump manufacturers and of plumbers, and it has made additional work for the weary repairers of roads.

LONDON, April 22 (AP) -- The International Wheat Council announced tonight that twenty-sevn governments had signed the international wheat agreement concluded in Washington April 13. Britain was not listed.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 22 -- Chinese Nationalist troops who have been operating on Burmese soil were called upon today by fifty-eight members of the United Nations -- including all the Western powers and the Soviet bloc -- to put aside their arms and leave the country or march into internment camps.

CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- Prices of hogs reached $23.80 a hundred pounds today, the highest since Aug. 4. A very active trade, including fair demand from outside order buyers, sent values 50 to 65 cents higher on all weights and classes. Cattle stood steady to 50 cents lower, but sheep were steady to 50 cents higher.

His forty years rest lightly on the broad shoulders of Big John Mize when he stands up at the plate with a bat in his hands. Summoned from the bench with the bases full in the eighth inning, the venerable slugger came through with a pinch single that produced the decisive run of a 6-2 Yankee victory over the Red Sox at the Stadium yesterday.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 22 -Strong Vietminh forces opened a mortar attack tonight on French and Laotian troops entrenched on the broad Plaine des Jarres. This may be the first phase of an allout assault. The French high command hoped it was.

ROME, April 22 -- The new United States Ambassador to Italy, Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce received a tumultuous welcome from a large crowd of American and Italian officials, newspaper men of several nationalities and friends and wellwishers on her arrival in Naples today aboard the Italian liner Andrea Doria.

Webb Knapp, Inc., announced yesterday that it had acquired full control of the twenty-eight-story office building at 2 Park Avenue through purchase of outstanding stock of holders, represented by Joseph Rabinovich.

Namm Loeser's Summer Story of Fashion was previewed for the press yesterday. The fashion show, which will be presented to the public today at 6 P M., featured imaginative but inexpensive dresses, suits and sportswear.

The Sacramento, Calif., City Unified School District sold yesterday $3,750,000 of bonds due from 1957 to 1976 to a banking syndicate headed by First National Bank of Chicago and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. The winning bid was 100.06 for interest of 5 per cent, 2 per cent and 2 1/4 per cent, an interest cost of 2.3255 per cent.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., April 22 -- Chuck's Rip Joy, owned by the Mount Joy Kennels of Davenport; Iowa, won the open all-age stake and Native Shore Pink Lady, owned and handled by George W. Carmony of Westhampton Beach, the amateur stake in the specialty field trial of the American Chesapeake Club today. The event was in the East for the first time in several years.

MANILA, April 22 -- An official "Committee of Fifteen" has prepared a new set of recommendations here in support of the Philippine Government's move to seek a revision of the 1946 agreement regulating the present trade relations between the United States and the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) -Representative Harold H. Velde, Republican of Illinois and chairman of the House Un-American Activities Committee, agreed today after a private meeting with Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam to consider ways to prevent "unjust accusations against any innocent person."

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended April 15:

When the House of Representatives just before the close of trading yesterday, voted 2 to 1 to stop the Government's public housing program after July 1, a wave of selling hit the New York Stock Exchange. Standard issues came out in large blocks, volume picked up and prices continued to decline until the close, which was only a fraction of a point above the low for the year registered on Monday.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- All grains were strong in the early part of the session but later heavy realizing by longs in the coarse grains proved too much for the demand, and sharp recessions resulted. Wheat reversed its weak trend of late yesterday but was unable to maintain all the price gains.

Representatives of the French diplomatic corps joined members of the French and American military establishments last night in an inspection tour of the Seventh Regiment Armory, 643 Park Avenue, at Sixty-sixth Street. The inspection, which included both the armory and training and equipment, was preceded by a reception and dinner.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) The Presidential yacht Williamsburg started her brief career as a cruise ship for wounded service men today. Forty-four Korea war veterans from Washington area hospitals were aboard when the Williamsburg sailed down the Potomac from the naval gun factory at 1 P. M.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The State Department will curtail sharply its international information program by dropping 830 persons and eliminating several foreignlanguage programs of the Voice of America. Moreover, the program will be taken out of the State Department and formed into a new agency.

New issues of public utility and railroad securities aggregating $21,800,000 will be offered to investors today by investment banking syndicates. The money raised will be used to retire bank loans and preferred stock for the utility enterprises and to further the dieselization of a Western railroad.
ST. LOUIS, April 22 (AP) -- Vinegar Bend Mizell needed help only to get the last out, and the steady beat of an extra-base hitting attack by the Cardinals defeated Cincinnati tonight, 8 -- 3.

The American Chamber Opera's performance of Monteverdi's "L'Incoronazione di Poppea," which had been heard earlier in the season at a New Friends of Music concert, was again put on view last night in Town Hall. Although there were several changes, the cast was substantially the same, and, as before, the Chester Kallman translation was used.
DENVER, April 22 (AP) -- A Colorado mining official said today that there soon will be no domestic production of lead and zinc unless Congress grants the industry tariff relief at once.

LONDON, April 22 (Reuters) -- Great Britain has formally protested to Washington against any civil proceedings involving British oil companies for alleged violations of the United States anti-trust laws.

Stockholders of Delta Air Lines in Atlanta and those of Chicago and Southern Air Lines in Memphis voted yesterday to merge into what will be the nation's fifth largest airline system in point of revenue passenger-miles flown. It will be known as Delta-C. S. Air Lines.

Felix Grodzki and his horse were busy with spring plowing yesterday behind his home at 1325 Flushing Avenue, Ridgewood, in the midst of a dirty, congested factory district just inside Brooklyn on the Brooklyn-Queens boundary line.

PITTSBURGH, April 22 -- It was just about four years ago that the eminent Casey Stengel of the Yankees, largely through necessity, suddenly stumbled upon the wonders of the two-platoon system. Something of the sort may have happened tonight to Leo Durocher, whose leanings have invariably been in that direction anyway.

BAYONNE, N. J., April 22 -- A mahogany plaque, bearing a goldinscribed message of friendship, was presented today to Capt. Georges Bourrague of the French aircraft carrier Dixmude by Capt. Hugh C. Haynsworth Jr. of the Naval Supply Depot here.

The seventy-family apartment house at 2018-22 Monterey Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Jack M. Vure and others of the An-Kay Management Company to M. C. Pely, Inc. It is assessed at $182,000. Rely-on Real Estate, Inc., was the broker, and Emanuel Goldberg, lawyer, represents the sellers.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Under pressure largely from Southern Democrats, Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican Senate leader, abruptly put off until Monday the test vote he had planned for tonight on the long-debated offshore oil bill.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The admission of 240,000 immigrants above quotas was proposed by President Eisenhower today for the relief of refugee and population problems in Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Sixty-second Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution overwhelmingly approved today a series of resolutions urging the curbing of the powers of the United Nations.
The Pennsylvania Railroad Company held a tight rein over operating expenses in the first quarter of this year, its income statement, issued yesterday, indicated.

John G. Fuller, a playwright hitherto unknown to Broadway, has written a farce which he calls "The Pink Elephant." It was acted at The Playhouse last night and, along with the weather, may be recorded as one of this spring's latest aberrations.

The annual safe driving campaign conducted by newspapers had the best record last year in its twelve-year history -- 2.05 accidents in 100,000 vehicle miles. This was announced yesterday by Cranston Williams, general manager of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, at the association's annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Apparently automobile drivers are keeping their cars in somewhat better condition than they were a year ago. This may be the result of compulsory periodic inspection in a score of states -- a measure which regrettably failed of adoption in New York this year -and in part, it may be hoped, of realization by the motorist of the importance of continued vigilance on his own part.

A group of low-priced houses is planned by the Montauk Beach Company at its Soundview Estates development to help ease the housing situation for the 400 or more employes at the new Montauk plant of the Goble Aircraft Specialties Corporation, a subsidiary of the Republic Aviation Corporation of Farmingdale.

NEW ORLEANS, April 22 -- Dr. A. P. Black, head of the chemistry department at the University of Florida and a past president of the American Water Works Association, was elected president of the Southern Association of Science and Industry today for a one-year term.
Americans wish to build and operate their own hospitals, rather than depend only on Government facilities, Dr. Alan Gregg, vice president of the Rockefeller Foundation, asserted last night.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -The Commodity Credit Corporation has raised the interest rate on price-support loans to farmers from 3 1/2 to 4 per cent.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 22 -- The crisis resulting from the decision of the Cabinet of Agrarian Premier Erik Eriksen to resign over a minor setback to the Conservative partners in the Government coalition in yesterday's general election has led to a request to the Social Democratic Laborites by King Frederik to form a new Government.

John J. Totten is a walking history of the last fifty years of New York's musical life. He has picked it up during a half century's continuous service at Carnegie Hall, and his backstage view of the world's famous includes not only musicians but also men and women of the greatest prominence in statesmanship, politics and other fields.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will put on public exhibition tomorrow in a special setting one of the loveliest and most important classical objects ever to be acquired. It is a marble statue of Aphrodite that rivals in beauty and significance such renowned statues of the Greek goddess of love as the Medici Venus in the Uffizi and the Venus of Milo in the Louvre.

Events today: Betty Louise Lumby, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 12 noon; Chamber music program, Townsend Harris Auditorium, 1 P. M.; "Der Rosenkavalier," City Center, 8:15; Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Nathan Milstein soloist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, said today that he had been assured by officials of the State and Defense Departments that evidence was being gathered for use in any war crimes trials that might grow out of the Korean war. He said that reports of atrocities committed against United Nations personnel by Communist troops were "sadly and unfortunately correct."

Reynolds Metals Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries cleared $4,636,263, equal to $2.75 a share, in the first quarter this year, R. S. Reynolds Jr., president, told the annual meeting yesterday in Richmond, Va. This compared with $3,352,979, or $1.97 a share, a year ago

THE late Gertrude Stein would have found inspiration in the latest bulletin of the International Game Fish Association concerning the problems involving the classification of Allison, Yellowfin and Big-Eyed tuna, and the suggestions for telling one from t'other.

MUNSAN, Korea, April 22 -- Expressions of Anguish, suffering and want have become so commonplace on Korean civilian faces during nearly three years of war that these same expressions on the faces of the 100 captive Republic of Korea soldiers returned by the Communists yesterday seemed almost natural.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- After declining for three months, the Consumers' Price Index rebounded two-tenths of 1 per cent between mid-February and mid-March, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Crown Prince Akihito, heir apparent to the throne of Japan, passed five hours in New York yesterday on his way from Canada to England, where he will be a guest at the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II.

A statesman came out secondbest yesterday at the opening of a two-day auction of abandoned, unclaimed and seized merchandise sold publicly by the Customs Service at the United States Appraiser's Stores, 201 Varick Street.

Hair for summer will be shorter, with a complete absence of any set look, according to such style-setters as Michel of Helena Rubinstein, Elizabeth Arden and the Charles of the Ritz salon. The effect is soft and, though carefully calculated, looks loose and easy, with more little fringes and less actual curl than last season's mode.

You have to figure it down pretty fine, but there is one thing you can buy now that in some ways is cheaper than it was in 1933, it was reported here yesterday at the national aeronautical meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

A two-year-old conspiracy indictment against two former policemen -- one an inspector -accused of taking graft from Harry Gross was dismissed yesterday in Kings County Court by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz at the request of the District Attorney's office.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -Republican leaders of the House of Representatives agreed today on a substitute bill extending rent controls on some five and a half million housing units in thirty-two states to July 31.

TEL AVIV, Thursday, April 23 -- In a two-hour battle along the entire two-mile border in Jerusalem yesterday four men were killed and five injured on the Jordanian side of the armistice line and four Israelis were injured, an official spokesman for the Israeli Army said early today.

An order tightening regulations governing maintenance of building elevators such as recently were involved in two accidents causing injuries to twenty-nine persons was issued yesterday by Bernard J. Gillroy, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings.
Clay casts of two finely modeled stucco heads that were found recently beneath a Mayan temple at Palenque, Mexico, will be on exhibition today at the American Museum of Natural History.
YONKERS, April 22 (AP) -- A daily double payoff of $8.40, the lowest in the history of Yonkers Raceway, was recorded tonight, on the combination of two odds-on favorites.
DETROIT, April 22 (UP) -- Sherm Lollar, Sam Mele and Vern Stephens lined home runs today as the White Sox handed the Tigers their fifth straight setback, 9 -- 7, before 2,345 fans at Briggs Stadium.

TRENTON, April 22 -- Robert B. Meyner is a successful lawyer with a wide practice. Born in Easton, Pa., July 3, 1908, he was educated in the public schools of Phillipsburg, N. J., and was graduated from Lafayette College and Columbia University Law School.

Women in business are not a "challenge" to men, Mrs. Mary G. Roebling, president and chairman of the board, Trenton Trust Company, New Jersey, declared yesterday. Speaking at a meeting of the women's forum of the New York Chapter, American Institute of Banking, she explained that "rather, women are an effective part of a team, which can form an unbeatable combination."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 22 -Professors Martin and Amdur have previously given a complete report of their activities to representatives of the institute, the school disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -The Senate Commerce Committee approved today the nomination of Frederick Billings Lee as administrator of the Civil Aeronautics Administration. Mr. Lee, a pilot and lawyer, has been deputy administrator of the C. A. A. since 1947 and has served with the agency since World War II, when he was a Navy test pilot and instructor.

The Metropolitan Museum is to be congratulated on the acquisition announced in our news columns today -the marble statue of the Greek goddess of love, Aphrodite, surprised by an intruder while bathing. This ancient variant of a Greek statue originally executed about 300 B. C. by a follower of Praxiteles enriches the museum's already important classical collection and rivals similar statues abroad.

Jimmy Carter, lightweight champion, and Tommy Collins were warned by the joint board of the National Boxing Association and the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday that the winner of their title fight tomorrow night must meet George Araujo in a championship bout within sixty days.

The Japanese tea ceremony in which guests kneel in tribute to a simple vase of flowers before they bow to their hostess was performed according to centuries-old ritual for the opening yesterday of the Gramercy Park Association's annual flower show.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Subversive Activities Control Board was asked today by Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, to order twelve groups to register with the Department of Justice as Communist-front organizations.

Sales and net earnings of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, the nation's largest domestic producer, were higher in the first quarter this year than in the same 1952 period, the company reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The House of Representatives voted today to prohibit further expansion of the low-rent public housing program despite the Eisenhower Administration's request for authority to start an additional 35,000 dwelling units.

A movement for the nomination of Representative Jacob K. Javitz for Mayor will be started at a dinner for him at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on May 17. Announcement of the dinner was made yesterday by Assemblyman Samuel Roman, secretary of the dinner committee. Mr. Javits, a Republiean, has announced that he will run for Mayor if called upon to do so by the good government forces of the city.

Coffee was traded in sizable volume and hides were moderately active yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Prices closed generally lower in light trading. Coffee, cocoa, lead, zinc and tin were lower. Soybean oil, sugar, wool and potatoes ended mixed and cottonseed oil, hides and rubber closed higher.

Denmark has just had one of those slight electoral shake-ups which have been so characteristic of her politics over the last few decades. The Social Democrat party, which had fifty-nine of the 149 seats in the Folketing, or lower chamber, won two more seats; the previous coalition Government of the Moderate-Liberal (Agrarian) and Conservative parties came out with the same combined total of fifty-nine which they had before.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) -President Eisenhower today scheduled two top-level policy meetings with Republican Congressional leaders tomorrow and may give them a look at his military and foreign aid spending plans.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A university professor, who said he had been a member of the Communist party from 1938 to 1944, testified today that he had won "clearance" after he left the party to work on the atomic bomb. He advised on materials for the bomb.

All members of Congress from New York City were urged last night by Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council, to "rise to to reverse this latest defeat" for housing, embodied in a vote of the House of Representatives yesterday for an appropriations bill that would curb the long-range housing program. He said the vote was "a step back to the economic dark ages."

A crew member of the United States Lines' flagship United States and a harbormaster employed by the same company were held yesterday in $50,000 bail each for grand jury action after being arraigned before a United States Commissioner on a charge of illegal possession of narcotics.

A movement for the nomination of Representative Jacob K. Javitz for Mayor will be started at a dinner for him at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on May 17. Announcement of the dinner was made yesterday by Assemblyman Samuel Roman, secretary of the dinner committee. Mr. Javits, a Republiean, has announced that he will run for Mayor if called upon to do so by the good government forces of the city.

Coffee was traded in sizable volume and hides were moderately active yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Prices closed generally lower in light trading. Coffee, cocoa, lead, zinc and tin were lower. Soybean oil, sugar, wool and potatoes ended mixed and cottonseed oil, hides and rubber closed higher.

Denmark has just had one of those slight electoral shake-ups which have been so characteristic of her politics over the last few decades. The Social Democrat party, which had fifty-nine of the 149 seats in the Folketing, or lower chamber, won two more seats; the previous coalition Government of the Moderate-Liberal (Agrarian) and Conservative parties came out with the same combined total of fifty-nine which they had before.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) -President Eisenhower today scheduled two top-level policy meetings with Republican Congressional leaders tomorrow and may give them a look at his military and foreign aid spending plans.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A university professor, who said he had been a member of the Communist party from 1938 to 1944, testified today that he had won "clearance" after he left the party to work on the atomic bomb. He advised on materials for the bomb.

All members of Congress from New York City were urged last night by Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council, to "rise to to reverse this latest defeat" for housing, embodied in a vote of the House of Representatives yesterday for an appropriations bill that would curb the long-range housing program. He said the vote was "a step back to the economic dark ages."

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, April 22 (UP) -- Nicholas Zographos, the fabulous gambler who would risk a fortune on the turn of a card, died here last Friday of cancer in a hospital. He was 68 years old. Mr. Zographos had been treated for cancer for the last six months by Switzerland's top specialists.

The present hearings in Congress on the ammunition shortage could very easily be misleading to the public. Questions of consumption rates, desirable stock levels at home and abroad, deterioration, available covered storage space, obsolescence and general reserves are some of the factors that must be considered. The picture is further confused by much military testimony which, rather than being factual, is based on false loyalties, often mandatory.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 -- A Federal court opinion holding that the Coast Guard in its program of screening "bad security risks" off the waterfront must give defendants details of the evidence against them was looked upon in some maritime quarters today as possibly presaging a revision of the screening process.

Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth largest steel producer, can now obtain 1,400,000 net tons of iron ore each year -- or about 20 per cent of its needs at full operations -- from its Benson Mines at Star Lake in northern New York State, C. L. Austin, president, said yesterday.
The program for today's closing sessions of Newspaper Week follows, all meetings to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel unless otherwise noted:

PINEHURST, N. C., April 22 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan, the defending champion, lost a 1-up match in the third round today to Frank Strafaci, Woodhaven, N. Y., in the North and South Amateur Golf Tournament. A year ago, Stranahan defeated Strafaci, 8 and 7, in the final.

" Recollections of Andre Gide," by the late author's close friend, Martin du Gard, has been scheduled for May 11 publication by Viking Press. M. du Gard has compiled a candid, often humorous report from his journal, assembling his comments on thirty years of meetings with Gide.

LONDON, April 22 -- A "very quiet" man, John Reginald Halliday Christie, who could pass in any crowd for exactly what he was -- an unemployed 55-year-old clerk -- went on trial here today accused of murdering his wife and three other women.

HARTFORD, April 22 -- The constitutionality of attaching statewide referendum riders to bills in the General Assembly was challenged today by Senator Samuel J. Tedesco of Bridgeport, Democratic Minority Leader in the State Senate.

BONN, Germany, April 22 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, apparently at the apex of his personal popularity and political power, received a stirring welcome when he arrived in the West German capital this afternoon.

PARIS, April 22 -- John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, said on his arrival from Washington today that he and his colleagues "have the greatest faith in NATO and we want to help it succeed." Then he added that "we have some new ideas about making it succeed that we shall want to talk over with our allies."

OXFORD, Pa., April 22 -- Plans were announced today for changing Lincoln University, the first institution in the world to give collegiate degrees to Negroes, into a completely interracial university.

The joy with which the Western World has greeted the exchange of sick and wounded prisoners in Korea has been darkened by two disclosures brought back by liberated Allied captives. One consists of the mounting tales of horrors which these men report as having seen and experienced during their captivity -- tales of massacres, death marches, starvation and other brutalities which within their knowledge have cost many lives.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -Senator John Sherman Cooper (Republican of Kentucky) said today the Eisenhower Administration must be prepared to risk adverse public opinion and make limited concessions in exchange for real peace with the Communists in Asia.

MUNSAN, Korea, April 22 -Half of the 600 Allied sick and wounded prisoners being repatriated have now been received in Allied hands here and most of them have agreed that in recent times they had been receiving at least passably good treatment at the hands of their Communist captors.

Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain, stung by Edna Ferber's remark on Tuesday that this is the most "disgustingly filthy" city in the world, challenged the novelist yesterday to tour the city with him and see if she could prove her charge that the streets are covered with garbage.

" THE CARDBOARD CROWN,"* by Martin Boyd, is a rueful, cheerfully savage novel of changing generations under Australian and English skies. Although Mr. Boyd's style has been dutifully compared with the styles of Henry James, E. M. Forster, John Galsworthy and Hugh Walpole -- what a diminuendo! -- the traces of their influence are not spectacularly apparent.

Mayor Impellitteri set in motion yesterday the machinery designed to produce today, by action of the Estimate, a local law giving the Board of Estimate the power to modify between June 11 and 13 the 1953-54 budget it must adopt not later than next Monday. This action was taken to provide for the possibility that agreement with the new transit authority may not be reached by June 1.
FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, April 23 (UP) -- A United States Marine corpsman related today how his Communist captors turned exercise periods into propaganda sessions.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 22 -- The nation's farm officials, responsible for 7,500,000 acres of corn, the largest tillage devoted to this product in Europe, have decided to give hybrid corn a chance.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission told the Boston and Maine Railroad today to proceed with a securities modification plan approved in 1951. The plan, designed to eliminate more than $75,000,000 in dividend arrearages, would simplify the capital structure of the road by reducing the number of stock issues from eight to two.
PARIS, April 22 -- The meeting of the North Atlantic Council to begin here tomorrow will mark an offfiical and general sanction of a leveling-off of the rate and the cost of Western rearmament.

Books and articles that provide sound information on child development and help to develop a reasonable point of view can be very useful to parents, a group of specialists in parent-child relations agreed Tuesday night. They held, however, that reading material that ladled out advice that was too specific and allowed no room for individual differences in children and families could cause harmful confusion and anxiety among parents.

Your April 6 issue carried an interesting article about the ruinous erosion problem in Central Park and other parks in New York City. The tenor of the article indicated that this problem is due to occasional severe rainfalls and the custom people have of walking on the grass, and seemed rather at a loss regarding solution to it.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -The United States Court of Appeals today upheld the dismissal of a contempt of Congress indictment against William L. Patterson, leader of the left-wing Civil Rights Congress.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Friday, April 24 (AP) -- The latest United States sick and wounded soldiers to be exchanged -- only recently captured in battle -- told yesterday of better Communist treatment, but from South Korean prisoners came reiterations of wholesale brutality and neglect.

LONDON, April 23 -- One of the seven repatriated Britons from Korea spoke out today about the cruelties to which he and his fellow captives were subjected in a 9-day forced march of 150 miles on which ninety-six men and women, many of them aged, died.

WESTPORT, Conn., April 23 -- A father who apparently nursed a hatred for the doctor who was attending his daughter when she died of asthma in the Norwalk Hospital more than fifteen months ago summoned the physician to an empty house here today on a ruse, and welcomed him into the living room with the muzzle of a loaded .32-caliber automatic.

A 21-year-old mother and two of her three children died yesterday of poison she had mixed into a rice soup and served for dinner Wednesday evening. The third child was in critical condition last night.

The board of directors of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City challenged dissident council members yesterday to vote them out if they did not like the decision barring a planned parenthood group from membership.
Collection of 1,440 pints of blood on Wednesday were reported yesterday by Red Cross officials, who appealed for additional donations to meet the needs of the armed forces in Korea.
TOKYO, April 23 (AP) -- United Nations Command Communique 1,593, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korean time:

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The Athletics overcame a 4-0 deficit to turn back the Senators today and give Bobby Shantz his first victory of the year. Home runs by Gus Zernial and Eddie Joost helped the A's in their uphill fight to win 6 -- 4.
Abstract art, in which the artist arbitrarily translates his first perceptions into his own pictorial language, dominates four of this week's exhibitions.

NEW DELHI, India, April 23 -The underdeveloped countries of South and Southeast Asia have welded an active common front in the war against poverty, ignorance and other economic and social ills that afflict them alike, a report released today of the Colombo Plan's second year of operation has revealed.

Commodity prices closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges with coffe, hides and world sugar fairly active. Coffee, sugar, hides, lead, zinc, tin and rubber ended higher. Potatoes were mixed and cocoa, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and wool closed lower.
The 1952 George Foster Peabody radio and television awards covering nine categories of programming were revealed yesterday. The winners were:

For the first time since late February, when domestic copper prices rose as much as 9 cents a pound as a result of price decontrol, custom smelters sold refined metal yesterday at quotations lower than those of the big copper mine companies.

It is the well educated and conscientious young mother, all too often, who feels overwhelmed and frightened by child-care responsibilities, and traditional educational methods may be responsible for this situation, Dr. Benjamin Spock said Wednesday night.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended April 18, 1953, were 751,628 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 30,489 cars, or 4.2 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 16,559, or 2.3 per cent, more than a year ago and 58,394, or 7.2 per cent, fewer than two years ago.

Patti Page, the song stylist whose current recording, "Doggie in the Window," is hi the top spot on the sundry music charts, has shown considerable improvement in her television show (8:30 P. M. on alternate Wednesdays) over N. B. C., but her program still is not all it could be.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Dimitri Mitropoulos began its final week of the season at Carnegie Hall last night, and no doubt to make sure that contentment would reign among the subscribers the program began with Bach and ended with Beethoven.

The City Council and the Board of Estimate unanimously approved yesterday a local law giving the city the power to amend its 1953-54 budget after June 1 if the Board of Estimate and the state-authorized transit authority have not reached by that date an agreement on the transfer of the municipal transit lines to the new agency.

NORTH CALDWELL, N. J., April 23 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair won low gross honors in the opening one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association over the Green Brook Country Club today. Hitting the ball well, Mrs. Cudone, the New Jersey Association medal play champion, turned in nines of 39, 43 -- 82 to lead her nearest rivals by two strokes.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, April 24 (AP) -- South Korean patrols slashed their way into Communist trenches in four demolition raids yesterday, killing an estimated sixty-eight Communists and wounding thirtythree more in savage hand-to-hand fighting.

LONDON, April 23 -- A completely mobile newspaper plant that in an emergency could produce 12,000 eight-page tabloid papers an hour has been built for The Times of London. It will be exhibited for the first time at the British Industries Fair opening here on Monday.

Eight sales executives of major concerns departed on a flying trip to Europe yesterday to attend meetings for exchange of sales ideas and to outline factors involved in the success of the American economic system. The visit, sponsored by the National Sales Executives, Inc., of New York, is known as Operation Enterprise IV.

Although prices twice attempted to rally and generally gave ground stubbornly, the stock market was forced to retreat on a broad front yesterday. When the smoke blew away it revealed a new bottom for the year or for any time since Nov. 6. The close was the lowest since Oct. 31.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Eisenhower asserted today, that he opposed the removal of any public servant merely for the sake of change or political patronage. In so doing, he reaffirmed his faith that his Cabinet members were well-intentioned and were seeking key subordinates who would be willing to accept Administration policies.

PARIS, April 23 -- The United States armed forces in Europe will begin Tuesday in Oberammergau, Germany, the first of a series of indoctrination courses in atomic warfare for senior officers of North Atlantic Treaty forces.

Anglo-American relations in the future can develop "no possible deviation" from the enduring principle of a permanent alliance between Britain and America, working together in the large area of common interests, Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, declared last night.

HARTFORD, April 23 -- A bill legalizing raffles and bazaars in Connecticut, one of the most controversial issues before the current session of the General Assembly, was approved by the State Senate today by an overwhelming voice vote.

If successful, the marketing of the Maine Turnpike extension bonds may be the signal for the grooming of other major public revenue bond offerings within the near future. Prominent among the scheduled deals is an issue of $100,000,000 of Delaware River Port Authority's bonds early next month.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, said today that livestock feeders were being caught in a "real pinch" between declining animal prices and high feed grain prices held at inflexible levels by Federal price supports.

The Union of American Hebrew Congregations, the oldest national Jewish religious association in the United States, went on record yesterday in a condemnation of "irresponsible attacks on our public school system by exaggerating the small number of subversive teachers out of all proportion to the true facts."
TEHERAN, Iran, April 23 -- Hussein Ala, Court Minister, Iran's stanchest defender of royal prerogatives against Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, quietly resigned tonight.

Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter reserved decision yesterday on the demand of two civic groups that the Police Department revoke a permit for a left-wing May Day parade -- after Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan insisted that the permit had never been issued.

TRENTON, April 23 -- Evidence that Harold J. Adonis was in a position to destroy complaints of gambling and other illicit activities directed to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll while Adonis was employed in the Governor's office was given here today at a public hearing of the legislative committee investigating the dismissal of Nelson F. Stamler as deputy attorney general.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board announced a revision of its consumer credit estimates today which raises the estimated indebtedness of individuals by nearly $2,000,000,000.

PRETORIA, South Africa, April 23 -- The danger of South African disintegration -- of an Afrikaans -- British apartheid -- is beginning to be recognized by the victorious Nationalist Afrikaaner leadership, gathered here for the Cabinet's first meeting since the recent elections, as the most immediately pressing problem.
LONDON, April 23 -- President Eisenhower's speech of last week proposing a five-point disarmament plan was acclaimed in Parliament today as one that would rank with Lincoln's Gettysburg address.

The morning session of the Board of Estimate yesterday ended in a verbal melee that included such charges as "doublecross," "you go on television just to put on a show" and "you've brought property owners in here just to give them a hearing and hang them."

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 23 -By an overwhelming majority of its members present, the Scarsdale Town Club approved tonight a committee report that the Scarsdale school system was free of organized Communist infiltration. The vote was 251 for the committee's findings and nine opposing.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were active yesterday and closing prices were 7 to 16 points net higher than on Wednesday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 25 -- Ernest A. Gross, for almost four years one of the United States' top diplomats at the microphones and behind the scenes of the United Nations, made his last appearance today on the rostrum of the General Assembly.
PITTSBURGH, April 23 -- The Giants finally got around to catching their first glimpse of the Pirates in broad daylight today, but unhappily they caught nothing else.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -Henry W. Grunewald, self-styled investigator and successful horse bettor, added the name of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt today to the list of clients who allegedly had patronized his investigating business.
Three pioneers in modern adult education were honored last night by the New York Adult Education Council at its twentieth anniversary dinner in the Roosevelt Hotel.
PARIS, April 23 (AP) -- Following is the text of a message sent to the North Atlantic Council by President Eisenhower:

The American Association of Advertising Agencies announced election of officers following closed sessions of its board of directors yesterday at the thirty-four annual convention in the Greenbrier Hotel, White Sulphur Springs, W. Va.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon last night reviewed the accomplishments of the Eisenhower Administration in its first 100 days, to be completed next week, and declared they were aimed at the protection of freedom at home and abroad as the key to world peace.

WITH only reasonable cooperation from the Weather Man, those who are planning a trip to the Catskill trout streams this week-end face the brighest prospects of the season, for most of the popular streams are running clear and water temperatures have risen from 5 to 12 degrees.

Today's new film is "Angel Face," an R. K. O. melodrama with Robert Mitchum, Jean Simmons, Mona Freeman and Herbert Marshall, at the Mayfair Theatre. Otto Preminger directed and produced from a screen play by Frank S. Nugent and Oscar Millard and a story by Chester Erskine.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Senate heeded strong leadership advice today in voting, 61 to 21, to reject a motion to set aside debate on the offshore oil bill long enough to approve an extension of rent control and other economic measures related to the nation's defense.

NEWARK, April 23 -- The margin of Robert B. Meyner's victory in Tuesday's primary election for the Democratic nomination for Governor was reduced today to 1,865 as Elmer H. Wene, his defeated opponent, pressed demands for a three-county recount.

The American Bosch Corporation announced yesterday that it had restored operations to a profitable basis in the first quarter of this year, when net income was $322,000, equal to 19 cents a share on the common stock. But that news was not enough to prevent the management from receiving a considerable amount of criticism at the annual meeting because, on consolidated sales of $90,539,243, the company sustained a deficit of $509,708 in 1952.

The Government Research Foundation, Inc., which is to be headed by Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore, will be devoted to advancing and improving the science of government and the administration of public affairs, according to an announcement yesterday by Nelson A. Rockefeller.

NEW DELHI, India, April 23 -Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told the Council of States, or upper house, of Parliament today that India had to invite United State engineers to assist in construction of gigantic multi-purpose projects because there were very few other countries in the world with experience in building high dams.
They called him Tatanka Yatanka, Sitting Bull. A sixfoot, deep-chested Indian who walked with a slight limp. He had a prominent nose, calm eyes and a deliberate manner.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 23 (UP) -- Correspondent, a bundle of speed from the West Coast, smashed Keeneland's track record for a mile and an eighth today to score a five-length victory over five other Kentucky Derby candidates in the $25,000 added Blue Grass Stakes.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Demand from manufacturers of civilian products has more than kept pace with the marked drop in defense orders in the last six weeks, trustees of the National Tool and Die Manufacturers Association reported at their annual meeting here today.

PRAYING mantis eggs are paying for a Ph. D. for Sidney A. Schwartz, a Government biologist studying at New York University in his spare time. He runs a praying mantis farm on Long Island; sells the eggs to farmers and to gardeners.

ALBANY, April 23 -- The Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that the pro-Communist activities of the International Workers Order "undoubtedly" gave the State Superintendent of Insurance authority to liquidate the multi- million-dollar organization.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Nathan Milstein soloist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; "La Boheme," City Center, 8:15; jazz concert, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 and midnight; Equitable Life Assurance Society Choral Concert, Town Hall, 8:30; Stephen Hero, violinist, Kosciuszko Foundation, 15 East Sixty-fifth Street, 8:30; Queens College String Quartet, Queens College Auditorium, 8:30.

CLINTON, Conn., April 23 -Some 300 New Englanders gathered tonight at Town Hall to celebrate "Allen W. Jones Day" in honor of the doughty 87-year-old man who has been editor of The Clinton Recorder since it was founded in 1895.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with his remarks in indirect discourse as required by White House rules:
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 23 -- Assurance that his Government would encourage foreign investments was given today by Pakistan's new Prime Minister, Mohammed Ali, at his first formal press conference.

Seasonal influences cut New York bank loans to business $54,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. The decline, fourth in five weeks, compares with a reduction of $113,000,000 in the similar week of 1952 and brought the total decrease since the start of this year to $110,000,000, against a reduction of $224,000,000 a year ago.
DETROIT, April 23 (UP) -- Southpaw Billy Hoeft hurled a five-hitter today as the Tigers defeated the White Sox, 8 -- 4, to snap Detroit's five-game losing streak before 3,567 fans at Briggs Stadium.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- If Stout Steve O'Neill wants to needle the Dodgers he certainly is in a position to do so. Tonight, behind Robin Roberts, his Phils completed a sweep of the three-game series, 6 -- 1, and now occupy first place exclusively, with the Dodgers in third place with a .500 record.

Back in the days when the city's northern boundary was Thirty-fourth Street and everything beyond was considered the suburbs, four members of a young Roman Catholic teaching order, the Brothers of the Christian Schools, founded the Academy of the Holy Infancy for the purpose of broadening the "intellectual horizons" of qualified young men.

Pakistan's formal request for a million tons of wheat from this country should receive a prompt and favorable answer. Moreover, since we have wheat in surplus the assistance to this friendly state should be in the form of a grant, not a loan. Pakistan's need is critical.

The first meeting of the North Atlantic Council since the establishment of the Eisenhower Administration and the death of Stalin got under way in Paris yesterday amid warnings that this is no time to relax our defense efforts. In a message to Paris President Eisenhower declared that our first task must still be to develop enough strength to deter aggression until genuine peace permits diversion of armament costs to more constructive purposes.

Through no fault of its own the Boston Maine Railroad is already in arrears on dividends on its new $5 preferred stock to be issued pursuant to the stock modification plan which the Interstate Commerce Commission ordered into effect earlier this week.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 23 -Lieut. Gen. William E. Riley, United States Marines, Chief Staff of the United Nations truce supervision organization for Palestine, effected a truce today between Jordanian and Israeli forces at an extraordinary meeting of the Mixed Armistice Commission following last night's two-hour battle along a two-mile front in Jerusalem.

St. John's University gained its first victory in four starts in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference yesterday by beating Manhattan College, 6 -- 0, at Van Cortlandt Park. The loss, their fourth in league play, left the Jaspers in sole possession of last place.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- During the week ended April 22, member bank reserves decreased $456,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Just thirteen months ago this newspaper warmly endorsed President Truman's proposal to admit an additional 100,000 immigrants from Europe during each of the next three years as "a humane and practical program to deal with one of the most urgent of all the problems that have been plaguing Western Europe since the end of the war."

It was eminently fitting that the International Society for Contemporaneous Music, with the assistance of faculty and student artists of the Juilliard School of Music and members of the New York City ballet, should honor the contemporaneous French composer, Henri Sauguet, with a strikingly varied and contrasted program of his compositions last night in the Museum of Modern Art.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 23 -- Following is the text of the Mexican resolution on Burma's complaint against the presence of Chinese Nationalist troops, approved today at the final meeting of the seventh session of the United Nations General Assembly:

The five-story apartment house accommodating forty-one families at 309-313 Sixth Street in Union City, N. J., has been sold by the Barnet Holding Corporation to the Bradley Holding Corporation. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker. The building contains 153 rooms in suites of three and four rooms.

Swoop, owned by the High Tide Stable and ridden by Charley O'Brien, was the winner of the feature race at the Jamaica track yesterday. Going into the lead early in the mile-and-a-sixteenth event, called the Ridgewood, Swoop beat off a challenge by the odds-on Kiss Me Kate, to score by a half length.

Hugh Baillie, president of The United Press, announced yesterday the election of Lyle C. Wilson, Washington manager and chief political writer of the news service, as a vice president of the agency. Mr. Wilson will continue as chief of The United Press operations in Washington, where he heads a staff of seventy- five.

TOKYO, Friday, April 24 -- Pfc. Raymond H. Medina of the Bronx told a press conference today that he had witnessed no atrocities by his Chinese Communist captors during more than two years and four months of imprisonment.

A new memorial, at once recalling a basic battle for freedom of the press and evocatively commanding the same crusade for all time, was turned over to the nation yesterday. It was the John Peter Zenger Memorial, occupying a vaulted marble chamber in the Federal Hall, national historic site at Wall and Nassau Streets.

A veteran policeman accidentally shot and wounded a young girl seriously late yesterday in Brooklyn with a bullet he had fired at a stray dog. The police said the girl, Virginia Carley, 13 years old, of 412 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, stepped out of a garage unexpectedly while the policeman was shooting.

Maintenance of a large and effective Air Force can be accomplished at the lowest cost if top-Level planning can be done on a Long-range basis, the president of the Republic Aviation Corporation suggested here last night at the annual dinner of the National Aeronautic Meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

Repeated broadcasts from the Communist Vietminh in Indo-China are rapidly clarifying the basis and objectives of the assault upon the Associated State of Laos. The target is manifestly not the small French Union force in the state. The target, at this stage, is not even primarily military.

CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- Another big rise in hog prices, amounting to 75 cents to $1 or more, sent the top to $24.60 highest since Aug. 31, 1950. Cattle were steady to 50 cents lower again but lambs were 25 to 50 cents higher. Ewes were weak to 50 cents lower.
The first official group of French educators to study home economics programs in this country has just completed a two-month tour of educational institutions.

Bethlehem Steel Corporation has started a program of offering financial aid to about forty-five privately endowed colleges and universities in proportion to the number of their graduates selected by the company for its own graduate training course.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- A mathematics professor who was a Communist for nine years told the House of Representatives' Un-American Activities Committee today that Congress, by changing investigative tactics, could encourage more members of the Communist party to quit and get more former members to answer questions.

LONDON, April 23 -- Today was St. George's Day, the feast day of the patron saint of England and the most famous living Englishman, Prime Minister Churchill, was the speaker tonight when the Honorable Artillery Company, the oldest serving English regiment, celebrated the occasion.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Department store sales in the week ended on April 18 were 8 per cent above those of a year ago. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1952:
I was particularly interested in the article entitled "French Eye Voting in Tunisia Warily" appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES on April 16.

Record sales of $447,861,616 were attained by the Federated Department Stores, Inc., and subsidiaries in the fifty-two weeks ended on Jan. 31, according to the annual report released yesterday by Fred Lazarus Jr., president.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- The announcement that 150,000 bushels of red winter wheat had been sold out of Chicago to exporters and that more was wanted led to a late spurt in wheat prices on the Board of Trade today. This caused a quick recovery in other grains, but in coarse grains offerings increased and the close was rather heavy.

Six hundred and fifty-nine sales of real estate were made in Manhattan during the first quarter of this year for considerations that amounted to $79,171,215, according to data contained in a market analysis released yesterday by the Real Estate Board of New York.

With "High Noon" so lately among us, it scarcely seems possible that the screen should so soon again come up with another great Western film. Yet that is substantially what has happened in the case of George Stevens' "Shane," which made a magnificent appearance at the Music Hall yesterday.

BOSTON, April 23 (AP) -- Confident and relaxed, Jimmy Carter, lightweight boxing champion, who has been made the 3-2 betting favorite, today completed preparations for his fifteen-round title defense against Boston's Tommy Collins tomorrow night at the Boston Garden.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Reuben Thorson, resident managing partner of Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, has been nominated as chairman of the board of governors of the Midwest Stock Exchange for a one-year term. The annual election will be held June 1. Nomination is tantamount to election.

An improved program of teacher training designed to attract persons into the profession was outlined yesterday by Joseph G. Cohen, dean of teacher education for New York's four municipal colleges. Hunter, City, Brooklyn and Queens Colleges conduct the largest teachertraining program in the United States at an annual cost of $7,000,000, of which $5,000,000 is underwritten by the state.

A barrage of adverse reviews left no doubt about the longevity of "The Pink Elephant," which had its premiere Wednesday night at the Playhouse and will close after its fifth performance tomorrow night. Written by John G. Fuller, who made his bow as a playwright, the political farce was presented by a trio of newcomers to the managerial fraternity -- Eugene Paul, William I. Kaufman and Blair Walliser.

Retailers can increase sales by putting more effort into promotion of formal wear, Sam Rudofker of S. Rudofker's Sons, Inc., said yesterday before a graduate class of the School of Retailing of New York University. The men's formal wear field, he said, is virtually untapped and should be an easy market to reach.

Louis T..and Rose Albrrtini have purchased the 'six-farnfiy apartment house at 9-08 Thirtyfourth Avenue' in Long Island City, Queens, fr0rh Josephine S avaiese. The sale was negotiated by'. Wil liam A. Krahe Son, Inc:,? as broker.
