A gaunt Frank Costello, thirty pounds lighter than when he began his prison term eight months ago, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal Court to an income tax evasion indictment.
Sales of small apartment properties to investors formed the bulk of realty deals reported yesterday in Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The Government announced today that it was closing five of its six magnesium plants.

The work done by Supreme Court Justice Felix Frankfurter and former Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman James L. Landis, both at that time Harvard law professors, in helping to draft the securities legislation of 1933 and 1934 was recalled by defense counsel in the investment banking suit yesterday in an effort to show that no one imagined then that the present syndicate system infringed the Sherman Act, as the Government now charges.

Charles H. Tuttle, president of the National Republican Club, said last night that New York City, like the Augean stable of Greek myth, needed a cleaning out and that election of a fusion city ticket was the way to do the job.

Mickey Mantle set no distance records with his second home run of the season yesterday. He just broke up a ball game with it. With the score tied, two on and two out in the ninth the muscular young Oklahoman unloaded on Ellis Kinder's first pitch.

What with all the furor going on concerning the city's financial plight, it seems a wonder to me why the men in high places do not concentrate more on cutting unnecessary costs and less on cutting essential services and new ways to tax the populace.

" The Book of Health," an anthology that "covers the entire subject of health for the layman," will be published by Elsevier Press on Sept. 15. Containing articles by 250 medical authorities in the United States, the volume is edited by R. Lee Clark Jr., M. D., director of the M. D. Anderson Hospital for Cancer Research, Houston, Tex., and Russell W. Cumley, director, editorial department, the University of Texas M. D. Anderson Hospital.

The action of the House of Representatives on Wednesday in barring further expansion of the low- rent public housing program was criticized by city officials yesterday at the opening session of the annual conference of the Mid- Atlantic Regional Council, National Association of Housing Officials, in the McAlpin Hotel.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Four Administration leaders put new steam behind President Eisenhower's "peace offensive" today in speeches before a two-day conference of 1,400 Republican women.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The National Trust for Historic Preservation held a press preview today of improvements at Woodlawn Plantation, built as the home of George Washington's adopted daughter, Nelly Custis, and her husband, Lawrence Lewis, Washington's nephew.

RICHMOND, Va., April 23 -- Dr. James Stevens Simmons, Dean of the Harvard University School of Public Health and an outstanding medical authority, today called upon the medical profession of the Western world "to re-examine with a critical eye the manner in which it is meeting its obligation to the people."
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Eisenhower took steps today to prevent any of his high officials from getting terminal leave pay checks when they ended their government service.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 23 (AP) -The Federal Government was reported tonight to be investigating scandals involving millions of dollars worth of exported wheat at the ports of Houston and New Orleans.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -William G. Barr, Acting Director of Rent Stabilization, today announcesd the dismissal of three officials who, he said, had "instigated, participated in and approved" a plan for collection of annual leave cash payments.

The Rockefeller Foundation announced yesterday that it had made grants totaling slightly more than $3,700,000 for the first quarter of this year. Grants by the General Education Board amounted to about $340,000, Dean Rusk, foundation president, disclosed.

Members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association were told yesterday the threat of labor monopoly resulting from nationwide bargaining demands of the International Typographical Union had been "arrested," but they were warned that constant vigilance against this danger was essential to the preservation of a free press.
CHICAGO, April 23 (UP) -- The Cubs broke loose for two runs in the sixth inning today to pull ahead and defeat the Milwaukee Braves, 6 to 2, before 6,860 Wrigley Field fans.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today laid down ground rules for food purchase plans promoting sales of home freezers.

Leasing of Pier 3 in Hoboken, N. J., to the Boise-Griffin Steamship Company, Inc., was announced here yesterday by Joseph M. Byrne Jr., vice chairman of the Port of New York Authority. The pier has been idle since last October.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 23 (AP) -- Former champions William C. Campbell of Huntington, W. Va., and Mal Galletta of St. Albans, L. I., led the way to the semi- finals of the fifty-third North and South amateur golf tournament today.

If New York City goes through with its proposed "decimation" of the Department of Health's day care unit, it will -- for a saving of only $7,000 -- "jeopardize health standards for 20,000 children in private and public-supported nursery schools," the Citizens Committee on Children of New York said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives proposed major cuts in outlays for Federal power projects today under a new policy of providing funds only for functions "which private enterprise cannot or will not undertake."
Ulysses S. Grant may have been pictured by most historians as a whisky-drinking, hard-fighting soldier of the old school, but he had deep religious convictions that the public knew little about.

Peck Peck planned an imaginary vacation flight to Paris with a wardrobe of Carolyn Schnurer designs in a showing yesterday at its executive office at 260 Fourth Avenue. At take-off a stalk-straight duster of black pique with cardigan neckline and short sleeves was suggested.

After long delay and many false starts, spring really got into the groove yesterday and produced the warmest day of the year so far. Another fine day was forecast for today, the third in a row. However, showers, are likely tomorrow.

PARIS, April 23 -- An effort to define the conditions under which the Western powers might meet the Soviet Union in a four-power conference was made today by Georges Bidault, Foreign Minister, in a carefully prepared speech he delivered at a luncheon for the foreign ministers and other diplomats attending the North Atlantic Council meeting here.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered today an investigation of whether the airlines operating in Alaska should be merged, possibly into two systems.

Israel Investors, Inc, in 16 E 52d St; Key Sales Associates, manufacturers representatives, in 14 E 39th St through Carstens Linnekin, Inc; D. H. Weiss Associates, builders, in 50 E 42d St -Cushman Wakefield, Inc, brokers.
HANOI, Vietnam, April 23 (AP) -French Union forces today halted a rebel Vietminh invasion spearhead driving south toward Luang Prabang, the royal capital of Laos.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution voted today to permit Mrs. Philip R. Peck, as spokesman for the dissident Glens Falls, N. Y., chapter, present that group's position on the United Nations.

ELMONT, L. I., April 23 -- Oscar Heeger, 58 years old, saw his wife through a window lying dead on the kitchen floor of their recently purchased home here today and rushed into the gas-filled room with a lighted cigar in his mouth, setting off an explosion that critically injured him.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 28 -- A strong appeal for organized labor "to stand up and be counted" among the friends of the United Nations was made here today by the Hotel and Restaurant Employes and Bartenders International Union -- fourth largest in the American Federation of Labor.

CAIRO, April 23 --- The editor of a leading Cairo news magazine has been cited to appear before a disciplinary court for his authorship of articles calling most of the Egyptian press inaccurate, corrupt and spineless.

Fourteen original letters written by Florence Nightingale were presented yesterday to the School of Nursing of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center for its collection of materials on the founder of modern nursing. The donor of the gift is the Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing, and the presentation marked the end of an agreement, under which Mount Sinai students had received experience in obstetric nursing for fifty-five years at the Presbyterian Medical Center.

HOUSTON, April 23 (AP) -- Fifth-seeded Billy Talbert beat off alive-set challenge from Hal Burrows to join the big three -- Gardnar Mulloy, Vic Seixas and Art Larsen -- in the semi-finals of the River Oaks tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The House of Representatives, accepting a last-minute compromise to avert a new disagreement with President Eisenhower, voted today to extend Federal rent controls for three months beyond the present expiration date of April 30.

ALBANY, April 23 -- Frank C. Moore announced today his resignation as Lieutenant Governor, effective in September, to accept the presidency of a new nonprofit organization, the Government Research Foundation, Inc., being set up by Nelson A. Rockefeller to study and improve governmental administration.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- John (OK) Da Grosa, a member of the Pennsylvania Athletic Commission and a television sports commentator, died today in his home at the age of 51. He had been ill for a few months.

Your timely articles entitled "Bulgaria Decrees Death for Emigres," published on March 28, and "More Heed Urged for East Refugees," published on April 3, deserve the thanks of all refugees from communism -- particularly Bulgarians.

The new foreign economic policy now being developed by the Eisenhower Administration -- affecting the export-import trade, foreign investment and free-world military strength -- must be one that will have a wide measure of public support, members of the National Council of American Importers were told yesterday.
YONKERS, April 23 (AP) -- Taking the lead at the half mile, Noble Dean went on to capture the featured Queens Pace by two lengths at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Eisenhower placed before Republican Congressional leaders today a series of proposals designed to strengthen the civilan control of the Defense Department, unify all foreign assistance programs under Harold E. Stassen in the Mutual Security Agency, and take the State Department out of the propaganda business.
The Chicago Great Western Railway declined to borrow $6,000,000 yesterday on twenty-five-year collateral trust bonds at an interest cost of 5.9 per cent.
The State of Connecticut borrowed $10,000,000 yesterday in the public market on bonds maturing over twenty years at an interest cost of about 1.9 per cent.

BUENOS AIRES, April 23 -- Five United States business men were being held under "house arrest" in the city of Resistencia today despite efforts of the United States Embassy to obtain their release, Ambassador Albert F. Nufer reported today. He said he had made "preliminary representations" to the Foreign Office this morning and hoped to talk to the Foreign Minister later.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Eisenhower advocated today United States participation with Canada in the construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway.

The active membership of the Overseas Press Club of America last night elected J. Clifford Stark, former London Bureau chief of The Associated Press, as president to succeed William P. Gray. Mr. Stark was unopposed.
Justin P. Quinn has been appointed director of sales of the Park Sheraton Hotel.

LONDON, April 23 -- Japan was reported here today to have shown a cooperative attitude toward the British blockade against sales of Iranian oil, the ownership of which is still in dispute between Britain and Iran.

Cotton dresses by Kay Windsor were presented yesterday in a fashion show at Franklin Simon. Broadcloth, chintz, tiny flower prints, woven stripes and sheer chambrays were featured in a variety of designs by Grace Norman.

DURHAM, N. H., April 23 -- Gov. John S. Fine of Pennsylvania asserted here today that there was a growing need for "extensive" free public education above the high school level to train potential leaders for whom the present costs of higher education were too great.

The April 22 issue of THE TIMES carries a statement by Edna Ferber calling New York City "the filthiest in the world." After an aerial trip around the world in which in the course of my work I visited the capitals and a number of important cities in other countries, I would endorse that statement.

Net profit of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and wholly owned domestic subsidiaries in the year ended on Jan. 31, last, increased 22 per cent compared with the previous fiscal year, Bernard F. Gimbel, president, stated in the annual report yesterday.

Long Island's commuters faced yesterday the prospect of an average fare increase of 25 per cent, ranging from 22.1 per cent for those riding to Pennsylvania Station to 28.7 per cent for riders to Brooklyn.

A jury in Brooklyn Supreme Court absolved the city and a Brooklyn patrolman yesterday of liability in a $250,000 damage suit stemming from the fatal shooting in 1951 of a 26-year-old man by the policeman.
" I'll be abeam of Ambrose Lightship at 1 P. M., Thursday, and dock at 3 P. M.," said Capt. Pierre Chupin when he left Le Havre breakwater April 17 with the French liner Flandre.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Eisenhower declared today that the West's rearmament must go forward on a sort of plateau of long sustained effort, avoiding alike the peaks and valleys of exertion and ignoring supposed performance deadlines in terms of this or that possible crisis year.

QUEBEC, April 23 (AP) -- The bodies of four children, their heads smashed with an axe, were found in their parents' three-room apartment late today. Solicitor General Antoine Rivard said the father, a Quebec laborer, "has made statements to the police."

BONN, Germany, April 23 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's complete identification with United States foreign policy at the Hamburg conference of his Christian Democratic Union, which ended yesterday, appears to have eliminated any basis for a compromise with the Social Democratic Opposition.

Sharply improved sales and earnings were reported by the Nash Kelvinator Corporation for the six months and quarter ended on March 31, 1953. Unit sales of automobiles were 70 per cent larger than a year ago, when output was affected by a strike in the plant of an important supplier and a long shutdown for model change-over.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Eisenhower reaffirmed today his belief that there could be no real peace in Korea if the broader problems of the Far East were ignored. He said he viewed with a heavy heart the stories of atrocious treatment that have been coming from the returned United Nations prisoners of the Communists.

The three-story six-family apartment house at 234 Cook Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Geoffrey W. Pelletier to Clearwater Securities, Inc., represented by Hyman R. Shapiro, attorney. The Wilmort Service Corporation was the broker.

The United Nations General Assembly has made the right gesture in calling upon the Chinese Nationalists in Burma to put down their arms and leave the country. These troops have served no useful purpose to the Nationalist cause, and they have been a source of intense irritation and even danger to the Burmese.

TOKYO, Friday, April 24 -- The United Nations Command informed the Communists today that it would repatriate additional Chinese and North Korean sick and wounded prisoners of the Korean war beyond the 5,800 scheduled to be returned during the current exchange at Panmunjom.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 23 -- The appointment of George J. Cooke Jr., a member of Princeton University's administrative staff for the last seven years, as executive director of the Princeton University Fund was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.

LONDON, April 23 -- British Government securities quieted down today after the continuous advance of the last few days. However, the undertone remained firm and prices of undated and longer term stocks closed unchanged, apart from a few scattered falls of about one-sixteenth of 1 per cent.

Elephants, clowns, acrobats and other performers disported themselves under the window of Bellevue Hospital yesterday as the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey circus put on its annual show for the hospital's patient for the fifty-first time.

PHILADEPHIA, April 23 (UP) -Michigan's mighty milers and Manhattan's scampering sprinters were the best bets today in the fiftyninth annual Penn Relays, which begin a two-day whirl at Franklin Field tomorrow.

IT seems a shame that Lindy Remigino of Manhattan College will not be able to compete in the Penn Relays today and tomorrow. Little Lindy's luck has been uniformly bad since he returned from Europe last Summer. That's when his luck was uniformly good. Dat ol' debbil, the law of averages, is something no man in sports ever can elude.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Eisenhower made it clear today that any changes in American foreign economic policy to liberalize world trade and payments must await the report of an Executive and legislative commission yet to be appointed.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The Defense Department today opened up promotion prospects for all but one of the 11,521 Americans reported to be prisoners or missing in Korea.
What do great chefs eat when they dine together? An interesting answer may be found in the menu of the spring dinner of Les Amis d' Escoffier that took place earlier this week at the Pierre Hotel.

An issue of $75,000,000 revenue bonds of the Main Turnpike Authority will be placed on the market today by a syndicate of 237 underwriting houses headed by Tripp Co., Inc., and Stifel, Nicolaus Co., Inc.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 23 -- The United Nations General Assembly wound up its agenda today by adopting resolutions calling for an impartial investigation of Communist charges that the United States had used germ warfare in Korea and for the withdrawal or internment of Chinese Nationalist troops operating in Burma.

New York City can congratulate itself on the good fortune of having one of its ablest citizens appointed as Postmaster. Harold Riegelman will take over on May 1, with the word "acting" in front of his title for the time being, a qualification that is not inappropriate.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- When the Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles, a few days ago told a Senate Judiciary subcommittee why he no longer fears abuse of the treaty-making power, as he did in April, 1952, his presentation was that of a highly skilled lawyer and diplomat.

Pork prices are sharply higher this week-end. Midwest livestock markets, according to The Associated Press, report that it appears likely hogs will soon sell higher than cattle for the first time since 1947. Live hogs already have reached the highest price levels since last August, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.

BALTIMORE, April 23 (AP) -- The Maryland Racing Commission today heard testimony that Larry MacPhail had used profanity to three horse owners, and it refused to let him back in at Bowie race track for the time being at least.

LONDON, April 23 -- At least for the time being, Gracie Fields has rescued the Palladium from the Yanks. Generally, some American is bawling away in the last number of London's most illustrious music hall. Johnny Ray, the blubbering balladeer, washed out the theatre a few weeks ago, and Tennessee Ernie, the groaning hillbilly, has just done his stuff and moved on.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- A leaflet entitled "The Shortage of Young Women Workers" was issued today by the Women's Bureau, Department of Labor.
ALBANY, April 23 -- Utilities subject to the jurisdiction of the Public Service Commission were granted rate increases estimated at $44,679,500 during 1952, the commission disclosed today.

TOKYO, Friday, April 24 -- Japanese voters returned to the polls today for the second time in a week, this time to fill half the seats in the House of Councilors, the virtually powerless upper chamber in the Diet (parliament).

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 23 (UP) -- Leaving the favored Sam Snead to flounder far afield, Lew Worsham of Oakmont, Pa., and Earl Stewart Jr of Dallas took the lead in the $35,000 Tournament of Champions today with four-under- par 68's.

Many parties were given at the entertainment, known as the, Skyline Dinner Dance, held last night in the St. Regis Roof for the benefit of Kips Bay Boys Club. Mrs. A. Schuyler Clark and Mrs. Reginald V. Hiscoe were co-chairmen of the benefit committee, and Mrs. Colley E. Williams was in charge of the arrangements for the fete.
BUFFALO, April 23 (AP) -- United States District Judge John Knight decided in effect today that Arthur J. Glover of Buffalo still was president of the Switchmen's Union, A. F. L.

MUNSAN, Korea, April 23 -- As Operation Little Switch, the exchange of sick and injured prisoners of the Korean war, continued to move forward smoothly today the United Nations waged an adroit and successful campaign to increase the number of prisoners being repatriated by the Communists.

PARIS, April 23 -- The fourteen allies of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreed today that there was no reason for assuming any change in the basic policy of the Soviet Union despite such gestures as Moscow has made during the post-Stalin "peace offensive."

Higher sales and an improved profit margin on merchandise raised net income of the Allied Stores Corporation for the year ended last Jan. 31 to surpass the previous year's results by 47 per cent, according to the annual report released yesterday.

The budget situation that faces New York City is of more than local interest. It should concern and will concern all neighboring counties very soon. Essentially, there is no great difference legally between Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester Counties and the city.

Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said last night that it would take the Department of Justice the rest of this year to rid itself of "odd characters, log rollers and misfits" inherited from the Truman Administration.

A McCarthy is not a McCarthy is not a McCarthy is not a McCarthy. That was what Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman of the city's private transit industry, learned yesterday when he finished arbitrating what had looked like a routine dispute between the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and the New York City Omnibus Corporation.

Eight members of the city's Board of Higher Education toured the City College uptown campus yesterday and several concurred in the view that the college's library facilities were inadequate and that more funds were necessary for proper maintenance of the buildings.

On April 21 THE TIMES printed a letter from Maurice P. Davidson under the title "'Looting' of National Assets" citing a recent address by Herbert Hoover at the Case Institute at Cleveland on April 11. Obviously Mr. Davidson never read Mr. Hoover's address, for he states:
The machine tool industry reported yesterday that demand from producers of civilian goods was more than offsetting a steady decline in orders for defense items.

Using the same purse-on-a- string tactics that embarrassed the youthful Red Sox, the Yankees tripped the hopeful Senators, 4 -- 1, before 8,528 spectators at the Stadium yesterday, thus entrenching themselves more firmly in first place.

The Department of State is moving through diplomatic channels to arrange for the acceptance of Ignatz Mezei, 56-year-old cabinet-maker of Buffalo, N. Y., into a foreign country, it became known last night.

MUNSAN, Korea, April 24 -- United States prisoners exchanged by the Communists today agreed that many captives had died during their long marches north. One man said that 400 of about 1,200 had died along the road.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, April 24 -In predominantly Roman Catholic Croatia, of which this city is the capital, Government-approved efforts to create priests' associations, which have been condemned by the Vatican and the church hierarchy, appear to have slowed down.
BERLIN, April 24 (Reuters) -- A West Berlin Court ruled today that tape recorders could infringe on copyrights.

PARIS, April 24 -- Leading ministers of the Western Big Three powers will meet here tomorrow in response to a French suggestion that reflected mainly the eagerness of Georges Bidault French Foreign Minister, to discuss the possibility of a conference with the Soviet Union.

The anti-trust theorizing behind the Government's complaint against certain investment banking houses would, if extended to merchandising, require swanky Madison Avenue stores to compete for customers by grabbing them on the sidewalk, William D. Whitney, defense lawyer, asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The future of the economic and social system in the United States is "dependent upon the success of the United Nations in averting world war and bankruptcy," the Women's Supreme Council of B'nai B'rith was told today.
Frozen rock lobster tails, especially those from Cuba, were subject for discussion when a representative from this department recently visited the Atalanta Trading Corporation, 77 Hudson Street.

LONDON, Saturday, April 25 (AP) -- The Moscow radio charged today that stories of Communist atrocities in Korea were designed either to complicate the prisoner exchange or shield the United Nations Command's own handling of prisoners.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, called before his Senate Investigations sub-committee today for closed door questioning James A. Wechsler, editor of The New York Post, who often has denounced Mr. McCarthy.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Government's decision to take over Port Newark for shipments under the Mutual Defense Aid Program forced the handlers of equipment for the Morocean air bases to operate out of Claremont Terminal, between Jersey City and Bayonne, and put them into the hands of the worst type of waterfront racketeering, it was testified here today.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The appointment of J. Walter Yeagley as first assistant to Warren Olney 3d, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Criminal Division of the Department of Justice, was announced today by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. Mr. Yeagley will relinquish the post of associate general counsel of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, which he has held since 1951.

NEWARK, April 24 -- Campaign managers for Robert B. Meyner, Phillipsburg lawyer who won the Democratic nomination for Governor in Tuesday's primary election by a narrow margin, said today they were prepared to institute recount proceedings in four south Jersey counties if the impending three-county recount by Elmer H. Wene, his defeated opponent, changed the results.

TRENTON, April 24 -- A former state police official took the stand today at a public hearing of the legislative committee investigating the ouster of Nelson F. Stamler as deputy attorney general and accused Mr. Stamler of being "mentally confused" and of lying while under oath. He also charged Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons, who dismissed Mr. Stamler for insubordination, with giving untruths in his testimony before the committee.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Joe Adonis, gambler and racketeer, has something new to look forward to when he gets out of New Jersey State Prison as a result of his indictment on perjury charges by a Federal grand jury here today.

The greater use of air conditioning in American homes may have a marked effect on their design, architect Richard Neutra said here this week. Mr. Neutra came to New York from his home in Los Angeles to serve on the jury for an architectural competition being held by the Carrier Corporation, makers of a "Weathermaker" unit designed to air condition the entire house.

A record of recent advances in exploring the mechanics and mysteries of the human brain will be issued Monday by Norton entitled "The Living Brain." The author is W. Grey Walter, a physiologist who has pioneered many developments in electroencephalography in Great Britain in the last eighteen years.

LONDON, April 24 -- Kneeling before Queen Elizabeth II in one of the drawing rooms of Windsor Castle tonight, Winston Churchill was dubbed knight and invested with the insignia of the Garter, the highest and oldest order of knighthood within the gift of the sovereign.

Representative Jacob K. Javits, who certainly must be reckoned among the most eligible possibilities for Mayor, gave the people of New York yesterday a well-rounded program for restoring the city's political health, financial stability and position of respect in the eyes of the world.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The National Council of the League of Women Voters, completing its fourteenth biennial session here today, declared for a campaign to combat "unfounded attacks on the United Nations" in communities in the United States.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- The Government took in more taxes last year than ever before in history -- $68,500,000,000, or about $425 for every man, woman and child in the United States.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- President Eisenhower declared today that no miraculous overnight accomplishment could be expected to solve all the nation's foreign-policy problems and bring lasting peace.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use to the homemaker:

The Greater New York Hospital Association elected Dr. Ambrose P. Merrill, superintendent of St. Barnabas Hospital, as its president yesterday at a meeting at the American Institute of Banking, 233 Broadway.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, April 25 (AP) -- United States Third Infantry Division soldiers, fighting hand-to-hand in their own trenches, smashed back a 500 to 750 man Chinese Red attack on the central Korean front before dawn today. An Eighth Army staff officer said the American defenders killed and wounded 190 Reds in the fierce, close-quarter action.

It was trouble, trouble and still more trouble for Mrs. Lee Maggio, whom Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh yesterday dubbed with the unenviable title of "the most serious scofflaw that ever has come into Traffic Court."

ST. LOUIS, April 4 (AP) -- The police thwarted an attempted bank robbery with tear gas and bullets today while fifty employes and customers trapped inside the bank with the bandits looked on in terror.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- A Cabinet Subcommittee was formed today by President Eisenhower to prepare promptly recommendations for United States participation in the construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway.

HONOLULU, April 24 -- Former President Harry S. Truman urged students at the University of Hawaii today to accept the responsibility for world peace "so that when this island bastion of the Pacific becomes a great state in a great Union of states, you may contribute to the peace of a united world in the coming atomic age -- the greatest age in history."

Under the title "A Victory for Evil" your editorial comment of April 17 on the outcome of the general election in the Union of South Africa expressed "the dismay and the sense of shame that all civilized persons must feel at this victory."

PELHAM, N. Y., April 24 -- The Pelham Men's Club six-man team outspelled three rival groups on the stage of the Memorial High School auditorium before an audience of 600 tonight and regained possession of a silver trophy cup the club members had not seen since 1936, when they placed it in competition.

Wild ducks splashed in the reflection of cherry blossoms yesterday in the lake of the Japanese Garden at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. "These ducks must not be so wild, because they come back every year to visit like friends," Frank Okamura, gardener of the Japanese area, said.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- Three Republican Senators joined today in introducing legislation to carry out President Eisenhower's plan to admit 240,000 additional immigrants, above present quotas, to the United States in the next two years.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 24 -- Battle lines are being drawn in Laos in the valley of the Mekong River and the French and Laotians are conducting extensive preparations to defend the capital of Luang Prabang.

BERLIN, April 24 -- Fifty Protestant church officials and lay workers have been arrested in the growing East German drive against the church, according to a report issued here today by the office of the United States High Commissioner.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 24 (UP) -- Mal Galletta of St. Albans, L. I., the 1944 titleholder, came from behind to win the last two holes today and defeat Bob Cochran of St. Louis, 1 up, to enter the final of the North and South amateur golf tournament along with William Campbell of Huntington, W. Va.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 24 -- An unusual legal complication, resultant from the divestiture of theatres by motion picture producing companies in compliance with a consent decree judgment, was introduced today in United States District Court in Los Angeles over the closing of the Belmont Theatre.

Taxed by a heavy backlog of tentative underwriting commitments, investment banking syndicates are sensitive to the course of stock prices in the immediate future and concerned over how much further basic bond yields will rise before new resistance is established.
Thomas C. Smith has been appointed vice president in charge of engineering of the Daystrom Electric Corporation, Poughkeepsie.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Following are the test of the letter of April 13 by Senator Harry F. Byrd and the replying letter of April 19 by General of the Army Douglas MacArthur in relation to the current Senate investigation of reported ammunition shortage in Korea:

SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 24 -- More than 2,500,000 Californians, including thousands of war veterans and 60,000 corporations, would have to sign a loyalty oath in filing their state income tax returns next year if a proposed bill is enacted into law, state officials said today.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., chief United States delegate to the United Nations, testified today that all American employes of the United Nations who had refused to answer a Senate subcommittee's loyalty questions had been discharged.

The Government's twenty-six-month investigation into the illegal diversion of gold into the European black market ended yesterday when a Federal grand jury returned fifteen indictments naming twenty-two persons.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 (UP) -- Jim Konstanty, a relief pitcher undertaking a starter's role for the first time this season, tamed the Pirates with two hits tonight to give the Phillies a 5-3 victory that kept them entrenched in first place in the National League.

First quarter net profit for the New York Stock Exchange was $162,719, against $72,775 in the comparable 1952 period, Keith Funston, president of the market place, reported yesterday. Aggregate income rose $419,267 and expenses before depreciation and taxes $221,786.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., April 24 -- Six Air Force men lost their lives here early this evening in a midair collision between an F-84 Thunderjet and a B-29 Superfortress.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 24 -- Complying with Congressional committee requests, the Tennessee Valley Authority is deferring all action on its scheduled headquarters transfer from Knoxville to Muscle Shoals, Ala.

PARIS, April 24 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, told the North Atlantic Council this afternoon that his existing armed forces were insufficient to face a possible Soviet attack.

BUENOS AIRES, April 24 -- The National Council of the Democratic party announced today that it had ordered its provincial legislators and municipal councilors to abandon their posts because of an "absolute lack of any guarantees of freedom to the opposition within the provincial and municipal bodies."

CHICAGO, April 24 -- Decreases in loans and discounts, total deposits, cash resources and Government bond holdings were reported by Chicago national banks today in responding to a call by the Controller of the Currency for statements of condition as of April 20. Savings deposits gained slightly.

Great strides in cutting down in recent years the pollution of tidal waters in the metropolitan area were described yesterday by state and city officials at the annual convention of the New York State Society of Professional Engineers, meeting at the New Yorker Hotel.

LONDON, April 24 -- The fashions for the women who will watch the Coronation procession from the stands on the streets must be serviceable. Their wearers will be exposed to the elements, to long hours of sitting on hard and narrow seats and to the onslaughts of hunger and thirst.

BUENOS AIRES, April 24 -- Five United States business men who had been held by Argentine authorities since their arrest Monday night in Resistencia were released tonight. High officials of the Ministry of Interior ordered their release after persistent representations by Kenneth Yearns, United States Consul General.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The campaign of influential Republicans in Congress for the appointment of a new stand-by military high command to review all the strategy decisions of the present Joint Chiefs of Staff apparently has made some headway at the White House.

The departmental trials of the eleven public school employes who have been suspended for refusing to answer questions about alleged Communist party membership will begin May 15 at 10 A. M. All are charged by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, with insubordination and conduct unbecoming members of the school system.

It is already evident that NATO meets a different mood from that prevailing in previous conferences. The study of Soviet intentions made during the past few weeks has led to a unanimous conclusion that there is no change in basic policy and that the nations represented in the conference in Paris have no choice but to continue to strengthen their arms program.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, who doesn't really need the money but nevertheless has the proper regard for it, will be shooting for $107,000 in a nine-furlong horse race at Jamaica today. The race is the Wood Memorial for 3-year-olds, which has been increased in added value from $50,000 to $100,000 this year, and two of the seven entrants will fly the Vanderbilt silks.

Billings and net profit of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company in the first three months of 1953 dropped 5 per cent and 8 per cent, respectively, below the levels of the 1952 quarter, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Following is the official White House transcript of President Eisenhower's talk today at a conference here of of Republican women:

PRETORIA, South Africa, April 24 -Johannes G. Strydom, Minister of Lands, who is regarded here as the most outspoken Republican and Nationalist in the Government just reelected to power, gave a promise last night amounting to a guarantee that American investments in uranium production in this country will not be damaged by the retention of power by the Nationalists.

LOS ANGELES, April 24 (AP) -- Marion Davies today contended that she agreed to furnish only the house for the fabulous party given last fall to honor newlyweds Marilyn Morrison and Johnny Ray, singer.

BONN, Germany, April 24 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's hopes of winning the complete approval of West Germany's legislature for the Allied-German treaties were set back today when the Bundesrat, by a two-vote margin, refused to take action on the pacts.

The first regular theatre demonstration of Twentieth Century-Fox' CinemaScope, a wide-screen motion picture projection system supplemented by "stereophonic" (or directional) sound, was put on yesterday morning at the Roxy Theatre at a private screening for the trade and press.

LONDON, April 24 -- The vitamin called B-6, or Pyridoxin, is not only effective against radiation sickness caused by exposure to atomic rays, but it also sobers up inebriates in two or three minutes, according to a note on the subject in today's issue of the British Medical Journal.

" Papa Joe" Leibstein, probably New York City's oldest waiter, sat down at his table yesterday and let others do the serving at a party in honor of his eighty-eighth birthday. The party took place at the New Campus Restaurant, 106 West Thirty-second Street, where Papa Joe has been a waiter for the last thirty-five years.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 24 -- Seven Kikuyu were sentenced to death by the Supreme Court today for the murder of the Ruck family on a North Kingangop farm Jan. 24. Two others were acquitted, but then rearrested. Three others, who possibly were under the age of 18 at the time of the murder also were convicted and ordered to be detained during the Governor's pleasure.

MOSCOW, Saturday, April 25 -- Soviet leadership, Pravda said today, is prepared for a businesslike discussion of international questions, either directly or through the United Nations, but finds no evidence in President Eisenhower's April 16 speech of an American desire to take upon itself a fair contribution toward international peace.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- The Defense Department disclosed today that it would ask soon for a system of scholarships for medical students and subsidies for medical schools to provide more physicians for the military services.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- An Army Signal Corps educational film technician testified today that motion pictures and texts "detrimental to the best interests of the United States" had been introduced into an in-service training course for New York school teachers in 1947.

Retail pressure will not force unwilling carpet makers to produce synthetic carpets, James G. Law, chairman of the board of trustees of the Carpet Institute, Inc., asserted yesterday. He spoke at the institute's spring meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The text of President Eisenhower's letter to Senator Anderson follows:

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 24 -- A severe earthquake, centered about eighty miles southwest of the Rabaul-Kokopo area, shook the island of New Britain for several hours from 2:30 A. M. today. Kokopo lies fifteen miles southeast of Rabaul across Blanche Bay.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The Defense Department gave to the Air Force today permission to begin early construction of a disputed two-wing bomber base at Plattsburg, N. Y. The action was made public by the office of Representative Clarence E. Kilburn, Republican of upstate New York.
BOSTON, April 24 (UP) -- The New York Knickerbockers tonight obtained Wally Dukes, the nation's No. 1 college player, in the 1953 National Basketball Association draft.
Five events were decided in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union swimming championships for women in the Brooklyn Technical High School pool last night.
CHICAGO, April 24 (UP) -- Chicago and several other Illinois cities were targets of a mock air assault today.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- The nation's 4,916 national banks had profits of $562,000,000 last year before dividends, Controller of the Currency Ray M. Gidney announced today. This was an increase of $55,000,000 over 1951.

MOSCOW, April 24 -- An important change in the Communist party organization in Leningrad, which gives major responsibilities to Nikolai G. Ignatov who served as one of the secretaries of the Central Committee of the Communist party from last Oct. 17 to March 7, has been announced by the newspaper Leningrad Pravda.

The annual spring review of the Knickerbocker Greys was tendered yesterday to Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, Commanding General of the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division, Five hundred parents, relatives and friends of the cadets attended the review, which took place in the Seventh Regiment Armory, 643 Park Avenue, at Sixty-sixth Street.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., April 24 -- Comus of Timber Town, a 2-year-old Labrador owned by the Timber Town Kennels of Bryn Mawr, Pa., won the derby stake that began three days of competition in the spring trials of the Labrador Retriever Club today.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 24 -- The Westchester Federation of Women's Clubs recommended to the County Board of Supervisors today that it "take the necessary steps to accept the Institute of Applied Arts and Sciences at White Plains as the permanent community college" of the county.

THE northern fishing seems to be improving every day, and reports from Maine, New Brunswick, and even Nova Scotia indicate that this may prove to be one of the best trout and salmon seasons in many years.

Four policemen, including Deputy Inspector Daniel A. Mooney, were found guilty yesterday of failing to suppress open bookmaking in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. Five others, who stood departmental trial with the four before Aaron Frank, Third Deputy Police Commissioner, from April 10 through April 17, were found not guilty.

Directors of Imperial Oil, Ltd., Canada's largest refiner and distributor of petroleum, elected John R. White president yesterday at a board meeting in Toronto following the annual stockholders' meeting.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 24 (AP) -- Willys-Overland Motors stockholders voted today to sell their stock to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation for $62,300,000 -- a deal making K-F the world's fourth largest automobile producer.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 25 -- The sixth day of the exchange of sick and wounded prisoners of the Korean war passed off smoothly today, with more United Nations captives sent back than originally had been expected.

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., April 24 -- Police Chief George E. Keating aid today he would welcome a chance to go before the special legislative committee to answer accusations of "uncooperativeness" made by Col. Charles H. Schoeffel, former State Police Superintendent.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- Sewell L. Avery, 79-year-old chairman of the board, today "ran the show" at the annual stockholders' meeting of Montgomery Ward Co., as he has for many years. He repeated his previous assertions that the country is in a bad plight financially and the thing for a company to do is to maintain a strong liquid position.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- Rains in the northern and central Great Plains areas, and the Southwest took the edge off demand for wheat today. Prices receded sharply, the weather news dissipating the effect of export business in red winter wheat in Chicago, estimated at around 600,000 bushels.

Sixteen American steamship companies have been appointed agents for fifty retired merchant ships being called to duty as grain storage bins, the National Shipping Authority of the Maritime Administration announced here yesterday.

A forty-woman fact-finding committee from the lower East Side will "march" on Washington next Tuesday by bus. Members of the Educational Alliance's mothers' clubs, they have two objectives: sight-seeing and inquiring into the high cost of living.

THE writing of biographies about medaled commanders in World War II has reached the "Call Me Mister" stage, influenced, possibly, by a recent Presidential campaign. At any rate, Quentin Reynolds' excellent informal biography of Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle, perhaps the most picturesque Air Force officer in an age of picturesque Air Force officers, is called "The Amazing Mr. Doolittle."*

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur believes that a warning to the Kremlin of the power of the United States to destroy the industrial base of Communist China and cut its armies off from Soviet supplies might bring not only a settlement of the Korean war but of "all other pending global issues."

Representative Jacob K. Javits, aspirant for a Republican-fusion nomination for Mayor, proposed yesterday a four-point program upon which he believes the Republican, Liberal and City Fusion parties and the civic groups seeking a better city administration can unite.

MEXICO CITY, April 24 -- Ben Hogan arrived by plane today unwilling to talk about the criticism leveled against him by fellow professional golf stars and determined only "to play a good game" in the Pan-American tournament starting here Thursday.

Political and community action will be discussed by women of many faiths who will attend annual fellowship meetings next Friday under the auspices of state and community councils of church women and the General Department of United Church Women of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

MUNSAN, Korea, April 24 -- For five days now, sick and injured prisoners of the Korean war have been coming home to freedom and, if one thought in all their minds could be put into a single statement, it would be:

PARIS, April. 25 -- Lanvin Castillo's midseason opening confirms subtle ease above and below the natural waistline. Often it is produced by two unsewn and unpressed darts in front and back. On a frock of blue green shantung a half-sash spans the space between the two front darts.

LONDON, April 24 -- The securities market was again quiet and dull today. Most prices drifted lower except those of British Governments. Gilt-edge issues were slightly stronger and more active. South African gold-mining shares, too, ended with some modest rises after initial declines.
Sophomore Tony Palladino clouted three doubles and a homer to lead Columbia to a 9-6 victory over Army in a free-hitting Eastern Intercollegiate League game at Baker Field yesterday.

Construction of reinforced concrete barriers to protect pedestrians and bench-sitters from traffic hazards at the intersections of Broadway and crosstown streets between West Sixtieth and 167th Streets has been started by the Department of Parks.

LONDON, April 24 (Reuters) -- Lord Brabazon of Tara, "father" of British civil aviation, chided the United States today for delaying approval of British Comets and other jetliners as airworthy for operation in the United States.
An increase in the amount of the municipal automobile-use tax, as advocated in a letter published by you, conceivably might prove considerably less lucrative than your correspondent supposes.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine workers, proposed today that Congress restore the labor laws of the country to their pre-New Deal state.
The dedication of Manhattan College's new $1,500,000 Hayden Science Hall will be a highlight of the ceremonies today as the college marks its 100th anniversary.

It is an exceptional home that does not have an accumulation of odds and ends which have outlived their usefulness. Most of us have tucked away in the obscure corners of our attics, closets and cellars such items as broken toasters, irons, toys or lamps. Perhaps there are chairs, tables and other furniture that have had their day.

Before 26,334 cheering witnesses at Ebbets Field last night the Dodgers snapped their losing streak at three games, with their Harlem neighbors, the Giants, supplying full cooperation. The Dodgers won, 12 -- 4, and with no pressure after the fourth inning, although outhit, 12 to 9.

Anna Magnani, the distinguished Italian film actress, was guest of honor yesterday at a private luncheon at Leone's Restaurant, West Forty-eighth Street, tendered The New York Film Critics, representing the metropolitan newspapers, by Italian Film Export, sponsors of the star's first visit to this country.

SDE BOKER, Israel, April 24 -This is the settlement deepest into the heart of the Negev, fifty miles due South from Beersheba, where wide empty plains cleft by canyons stretch far into the distance to flat-topped yellow mountains. Here, where only four to six inches of rain falls in most years and less than two inches fell last winter, fourteen men, four girls and five dogs are running the Negev's first sheep ranch.

A holder of the Root-Tilden Scholarship at New York University's School of Law has been named editor in chief of its Law Review. Daniel G. Collins, 23-year-old second-year law student of Floral Park, L. I., will head the editorial board for 1953-54.

The contribution a children's museum can make to the lives of young people was analyzed yesterday by an educator, an anthropologist and a museum official at the annual luncheon of the Friends of Children's Museum at the Towers Hotel in Brooklyn.
LONDON, April 24 (AP) -- The Order of the Garter, the foremost of Britain's eight orders of knighthood, was formed in the middle of the Fourteenth Century, when English chivalry was at a high point.

There was heavy trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and closing prices for active months were very steady and unchanged to 58 points higher than on Thursday, led by the strength in May.
The next important foreign legisaltion to be submitted to Congress will be the Customs Simplifiaction Bill, and it should be ready for introduction soon, trade sources here said yesterday.

CLEVELAND, April 24 (AP) -- Mike Garcia, the Indians' twenty- two-game winner last season, won his first 1953 game tonight, a nine-hit 4-1 defeat of the Tigers. Only 9,283 watched the first night game of the year here, which started in rain.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Alleghany Corporation, largest holder of Missouri Pacific Railroad common stock, today filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission suggested changes in the plan of reorganization for Mopac approved by the commission in 1949. The changes are based on economic developments since that time.
MUNSAN, Korea, Saturday, April 25 (AP) -- The official list of United Nations non-Korean prisoners of war returned by the Communists today:

The annual spring drive for blood donations at the National Board of Fire Underwriters, 85 John Street, and City College uptown and downtown campuses ended yesterday with a total of 3,609 pints of blood collected. A Red Cross official said the two-week drive at the National Board of Underwriters brought 2,361 pints and the three-day collection at City College campuses netted 1,248 pints.
TOKYO, April 24 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,594, covering Thursday's operations:
Two plumbers emerged as heroes yesterday when they hurried to the rescue of an elderly man and a middle-aged woman who were trapped in a burning tenement at 205 West Sixty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- President Eisenhower, moving to avert a strike scheduled for tomorrow, created today an emergency board to handle a dispute between the Nickel Plate Railroad and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen.

NEW DELHI, India, April 24 -- The new United States Ambassador-designate to India, George V. Allen, faced candidly the first challenge of his job here a few minutes after he stepped from a plane at Delhi's international airport this evening.
A 15-year-old girl, returning to her home in Brooklyn yesterday with a pair of black ballet shoes she had just bought, found $520 in cash on a sidewalk near her home.

A couple of times in the course of every academic year there is something set down on the schedule as a Teachers' Conference. This means that the academicians of the region get together for the purpose of listening to addresses, exchanging views and perhaps reviving the enthusiasm needed to carry them through the rest of the term.

Since 1943, when the very necessary rent control became law in the State of New York, there have been changes in the landlords' financial balance with their tenants. Some costs have gone up, of course, but occupancy has reached 100 per cent contrasted with the half vacancy of ten years ago.

PARIS, April 24 -- Giving emphasis to its new "stretch - out" philosophy of preparing Europe's defenses for an unpredictably long period of time, the fourteen North Atlantic Treaty allies agreed today to the joint financing of a three-year military construction program in Western Europe.

The weight of the $12,400,000 offering of Central Southwest Corporation new common stock, gingerly cradled by underwriters since right before the big market break, finally reached the market unaided by stabilization purchases yesterday, with the result that the shares sold off 5/8 of a point to close at 20.

PARIS, April 24 -- Under the sponsorship of the Museum of Modern Art in New York and the Museum of Modern Art here, a special exhibition of modern American painting was opened today in the presence of Douglas Dillon, United States Ambassador.

RICHMOND, Va., April 24 -- Dr. Edward L. Bortz, past president of the American Medical Association, told a large gathering of distinguished physicians and surgeons from the United States, Canada, and nineteen Latin-American countries here tonight that "if all the data now available for preserving life would be utilized in planning individual and family life, many of our citizens would attain the century mark."
The annual period of confusion known as Daylight Saving Time will begin tomorrow morning when 2 A. M. becomes 3 A. M. for some 60,000,000 Americans.

At a moment when an increasing number of sick and wounded prisoners are being liberated in Korea, when even the Communist regimes are beginning to proclaim amnesties for "minor offenders," the thoughts of freedom-loving peoples turn with mounting anger to the continued detention of prisoners of the "cold war," and especially to the most notable of these -- William Oatis.

Anent Florence L. C. Kitchelt's letter to THE TIMES on April 14 in connection with "equal rights" for women, it is understandable that women should want to be appreciated for the intelligent and capable beings that they are, but, in my opinion, the issue is being carried too far.
ALBANY, April 24 -- In the face of growing speculation that he plans to seek re-election for a fourth term, Governor Dewey continued to deny today that he had any political plans.
Two late spring entries, "Masquerade" and "An Evening With Will Shakespear," have decided, both for independent reasons of their own, not to brave the New York boards.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Fred Barton, who appeared in "Mr. Roberts,'' received this week Patent No. 2,635,373, for which he applied just four years ago. His invention is the Teleprompter, which coaches television actors into letter-perfect delivery of their lines and permits news commentators to simulate prodigious feats of memory.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., April 24 -- Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of Glen Oaks opened the Women's Long Island Cross-Country Golf Association season by capturing the low-gross honors at Wheatley Hills today. The association's medal-play champion carded a 39, 37 -- 76, two over women's par.
A year-long fight between contracting stevedores and freight forwarders over allegedly illegal control of steamship cargo has been settled.
JERSEY CITY, April 24 -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested a ship captain today on his arrival at Port Newark and charged him with manslaughter on the high seas.

How much does it cost a railroad to sound its locomotive whistles? The "Southern Pacific Bulletin" has the answer for the 265-mile Southern Pacific line between Houston and Dallas. Every day, it says, locomotives on that line of the road must whistle 6,268 times.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 24 -- Publicizing and encouraging the cultural accomplishments of America, as well as the material, was urged here today by Dr. Vergil D. Reed, a vice president of the J. Walter Thompson Company.

LONDON, April 24 -- Renewal of a fisheries agreement between Britain and the Soviet Union is believed to have been among the subjects discussed between Sir Alvary Gascoigne, British Ambassador to Moscow, and Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, in the Soviet capital yesterday.

BOSTON, April 24 (AP) -- Jockey Tony DeSpirito today drew a ten-day suspension at Suffolk Downs -- beginning Monday -- for careless riding aboard Lil's Joy in the third race yesterday. The ban will start Monday.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., April 24 -- The three speakers on the plastic arts panel this afternoon at the Smith College symposium on art and morals declared that art and morality were inseparable. The speakers were Ben Shahn, painter; Philip Johnson, architect, and Edgar Wind, Professor of Art and Philosophy at Smith College.

JERSEY CITY, April 24 -- The position of candidates' names on the voting machines for the May 12 City Commission election here was finally decided today, on the fourth try, but not without another attempt to have the results set aside in court.

BOSTON April 24 (UP) -- Southpaw Alex Kellner, giving promise of regaining the form that made/ him a 20-game winner as a rookie, turned in a masterful mound performance today to notch his third straight victory as the Athletics defeated the Red Sox, 7 to 2.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 24 -- Pakistanis went to the polls in Karachi today, with unrestrained campaigners contending for their ballots in an election to fill eighty-two seats of the Municipal Corporation, or city council. Voting was open to all who could impress a thumbprint on a ballot.

Determined support for a few rail issues changed the tone of yesterday's stock market. After they had drifted downward to make new lows for the year, prices were pushed upward in the final hour to end the session with a net gain. Some of the rubbers, chemicals and aircrafts joined the advance but the oils, motors and steels lagged.
The national secretary of the Progresive Party yesterday "demanded'' that President Eisenhower order the withdrawal of proceedings to force twelve groups to register as Communist-front organizations.
The savage nature of the Jimmy Carter-Tommy Collins lightweight title fight in Boston last night aroused television viewers throughout the nation to register protests.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Indications increased here today that the Administration had adopted, with some modifications, the concept of a "broad defense mobilization base" built up since the start of the Korean war to give the country an industrial production reserve.

A redefinition of what constitutes wool manufacturing was requested yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers at a supplemental hearing before the Department of Labor in Washington on minimum wages under the Walsh-Healey Act.

American business men should use market research to increase efficiency of marketing and advertising and to cut costs. This advice was given yesterday by F. K. Leisch, executive vice president of A. C. Neilsen Company. He spoke at the first annual sales and advertising conference of the University of Notre Dame at South Bend, Ind. Mr. Leisch believes the interests of the man in the street should be considered by advertisers and marketers.

Four men, said to be members of a huge narcotics ring that sold $250,000 worth of pure heroin in the last six months and had 100 to 175 pounds of narcotics cached in the city, were held in high bail in Federal Court yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24 -- Accusing longshoremen of a "slowdown" in loading lumber at Coos Bay, Ore., the Oliver J. Olson Company here announced today the withdrawal of its seven schooners from the coastal lumber trade.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 24--The action of the Connecticut State Senate in approving a bill legalizing raffles and bazaars was condemned today by fifty members of the clergy and laymen of the Protestant Diocese of Connecticut as an effort to "legalize gambling."
The next "revolution" in self-service food merchandising will be pre-packaging of fresh meats. This was predicted yesterday by Jim Nash, long-time specialist in package designs for food products.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- House of Representatives investigators sought today to link Henry W. Grunewald to a darkly mysterious story of an alleged attempt to extort $500,000 from a man having tax troubles.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- The Controller General, Lindsay C. Warren, said today that $830,000,000 "illegally or erroneously" paid out by the Government had been recovered during the twelve years he has headed the General Accounting Office.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -Working on the theory that more business men would benefit from technical publications of the Department of Commerce if the documents were couched in layman's language, the Federal agency has begun a review of its 2,600 publications.

DURHAM, N. H., April 24 -- Mrs. Ivy Baker Priest, Treasurer of the United States, called today on college students to avoid becoming the victim of "those who spread the false doctrine of gloom," and to rely instead on their birthright of unbounded optimism to meet the challenge of complex society.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 24 -- The course of official Dutch-United States relations ran erratically again today as United States Ambassador Selden Chapin called on the Foreign Ministry here to present a personal letter from President Eisenhower to Queen Juliana. The letter was the President's reply to the Queen's personal appeal that he take the lead in a world-wide program to help refugees.
Prices of most commodity futures on the local exchanges were irregular yesterday.
Four of this week's exhibitions of painting deal, more or less straightforwardly, with that old-fashioned subject, landscape.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 24 (UP) -- Gene Bearden, a former member of the St. Louis Browns, shackled his old team-mates tonight with a three-hitter to give the Chicago White Sox a 3-0 victory.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., April 24 -- Five factors determine whether home televiewing has any serious effect on the child at school, according to Helen E. Rees, director of the Smith College Day School here. If parents can answer "yes" to the following questions, Miss Rees declared this week, their youngsters' school work will not suffer:

WASHINGTON, Saturday, April 25 -- President Eisenhower took a hand in the prolonged fight over the offshore oil bill yesterday with a public plea for "prompt" passage of the measure, which the Senate has been debating since April 1.

A new X-ray unit said to offer new diagnostic possibilities in the field of medicine will be demonstrated on the "American Inventory'' program tomorrow from 2 to 2:30 P. M. over the N. B. C. television network. Dr. Williams S. Love, professor of cardiology at the University of Maryland, will demonstrate how the unit can be used in diagnosing different forms of heart disease or detecting ulcer conditions.

TULLAHOMA, Tenn., April 24 -- The gates were opened here today for the first public showing of the super secret and highly controversial Arnold engineering development of the United States Air Force -- a $170,000,000 test station to try out jet airplane engines without flying them.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 24 (Reuters) -- The Kenya Government, in two moves to curb Mau Mau terrorism, rounded up 6,000 Africans in a mud-and-stick village on the outskirts of Nairobi today and gave security forces orders to shoot any suspect who failed to halt when challenged.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- There were two developments of major consequence this afternoon as the fifty-ninth annual Penn relays opened at Franklin Field. The first was a victory by Michigan in the college distance medley relay championship.

Colonia, Inc., United States distributor of toiletries for the German house of "4711," disputed through its attorneys yesterday the claims made to use of the "4711" trademark by the domestic toiletries concern, "4711," Ltd. The attorneys, Katz Sommerich, declared that the assertion of the domestic concern were unjustified.

TAKORADI, Gold Coast, April 24 (Reuters) -- Freighters calling at this booming colony's main deep-water port here will no longer have to lie at anchor for days offshore waiting for wharf space to take on cargo.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today a plan under which farmers may obtain a one-year extension of Commodity Credit Corporation loans on 1952-crop corn.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield today gave the National Capital some of the postal service it lost along with the rest of the country in 1950.
An attempt will be made to stage a left-wing May Day parade next Friday despite a State Supreme Court ruling yesterday prohibiting such a march.

Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, told delegates to the annual conference of the Mid-Atlantic region of the National Association of Housing Officials, at the McAlpin Hotel yesterday, that the recent Congressional curtailment of low-rent housing would interfere with current programs to lessen the future deterioration in large cities.
Excerpts from the speech of Representative Jacob K. Javits at a luncheon of the Young Men and Young Women's Young Republican Clubs of New York follow:

DES MOINES, April 24 (AP) -- A threatened tornado, of which spectators were warned, failed to develop, but Kansas' Wes Santee and Georgetown's four-mile relay team provided some lively action on a rain-drenched track in today's opening session of the forty-fourth Drake Relays.

Gen. James A. Van Fleet, retired commander of United Nations ground troops in Korea, called for "a smashing military victory" over communism there when he received official honors from the city at a City Hall reception yesterday.

Whatever the merits of the dispute between County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz and District Attorney Hogan on the former's charge that some officials have waited for the State Crime Commission to drop evidence in their laps before springing into action, it is clear that undue delay in the next chapter of the Commission's work may be fatal to early reforms of waterfront evils.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, wearing a light brown lace dress with a white orchid pinned at the waistline, received today the pages state regents and national officers of the Daughters of the American Revolution, of which she had just become a member.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- Officers of the Pennsylvania Welfare Conference took under consideration today the action of Roman Catholic members in boycotting the group's forty-third annual meeting because of a planned parenthood exhibit.

BOSTON, April 24 -- In one of the most reprehensible mismatches in modern ring history, Jimmy Carter of the Bronx successfully defended his lightweight championship of the world tonight. He knocked out Tommy Collins, local idol, in 2 minutes 28 seconds of the fourth round of a scheduled fifteen-round contest.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 24 -- Lieut. Gen. William E. Riley has resigned his post as chief of the United Nations team that has been supervising the keeping of the truce agreements between Israel and Arab states.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 24 (UP) -- Lew Worsham, the money player from Oakmont, Pa., clung tenaciously to the leadership at the end of the second round of the $35,000 Tournament of Champions today as he added a one-under-par 71 to his first-round score for a 139.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -The Department of Commerce said today that retail sales had eased off slightly in March, by comparison with February, but still had run well ahead of volume a year ago.

Prevented by smoke and flames from using the stairs, 100 persons climbed down fire escapes and rescue ladders at 4:45 A. M. yesterday from a six-story tenement at 207 East Eigthy-fifth Street, between First and Second Avenues.

ONLY a short time ago, Dubby and Dubbah, two fully grown Syrian bears, residents of Jerusalem, sent the United Nations into action and made international headlines. The pricele couple broke out of their steel cage in the Holy City's Biblical Zoo, which is a collection of animals mentioned in the Testaments.

THE WORD has gone out to the studios to tone down physical violence in films lest the world become convinced that barbarity is the order of the day in America. Oddly enough, people overseas, who take in stride a much more realistic exposition of sex on the screen than is condoned in this country, are protesting and criticizing the displays of brutality in many pictures coming out of Hollywood.

BUSINESS and industry continue to ride the crest of the boom, according to all available statistics, although the decline last week in stock prices to new lows for the year did not contribute to optimistic business sentiment.

THE wilderness trails that Federalist Tom Hazard rode between his frontier Tennessee country and Spanish New Orleans were tangled and dangerous. Even more tangled and dangerous was the Separatist intrigue that in 1788 threatened to "march the frontier out of the Union."

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Senate crowned a new speaking champion today as Senator Wayne Morse, Independent of Oregon, completed a demonstration against the pending offshore oil bill that kept him on his feet for a record twenty-two hours and twenty-six minutes.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- while President Eisenhower is mocking golf balls around the White House lawn, Vice President Richard M. Nixon is whanging them by the bucketful on a public driving range.

The development of asepsis in surgery, knowledge of the hormones of the glands of internal secretion, the relationship between contaminated food and infant mortality and the introduction of psychoanalytic techniques into psychiatry were listed here last week by a number of leading medical authorities as among the major advances of medical progress in the last seventy-five years.

A 1O-YEAR-OLD consultant reported that "The Good Ship Spider Queen" was a lot of fun, but, she complained, it didn't seem as real as the book she had been reading be fore. Investigation revealed that "the book she had been reading before" was "Huckleberry Finn" -- admittedly a tough act to follow -- but she is right about the Crists' story.

The net of legal restriction closed a little tighter around the Communist party last week. The Subversive Activities Control Board formally ruled that the party was a "Communist-action" organization operating under Soviet direction to overthrow the United States Government.

IN the best cloak-and-dagger tradition, this tale starts one night in a remote English coastal village with the fury of wind and rain lashing in from the sea. An injured, weather- beaten Norwegian stumbles to the house where young Dick Cudden and his uncle, Major Dawson, live and proves to be an agent with whom Major Dawson once worked in the underground movement.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 25 -- Woodrow Wilson Fellowships, reserved for undergraduates who show marked promise for the teaching profession, were awarded today to 101 young men and women from colleges and universities in the United States and Canade.
Eddie Arcaro, jockey who has ridden a long list of winning mounts, was unhappy about his saddle, so he suggested to his friend, Dan Allison, a saddler, what he thought it should be like.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 25 -- The Communist-controlled Indonesian estate workers' union, Sarbupri, has launched its first big wage offensive since the start of the Korean war and presented several stiff wage and social security demands to the central government and private estates.
Prospective home buyers are cautioned against overlooking the cost of upkeep and maintenance of a home in the family budget.

PARIS, April 25 -- United States Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said tonight that there was "absolutely" no difference between his and President Eisenhower's attitude toward the Soviet Union, as the Moscow newspaper Pravda had contended in an article broadcast earlier today that contrasted the recent speeches of the two.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Senator Allen J. Ellender, Democrat of Louisiana, tonight chided some of the Senate liberals who were opposed to filibusters, charging that they were filibustering themselves.

EZIO PINZA'S new television show, originally announced as a "light, colorful, romantic drama," with a setting in Tahiti, has undergone a radical change in its progress toward actuality. The Pinza vehicle now is described as a situation comedy, with Mr. Pinza cast as a concert singer and the father of eight children.

THE annual Cherry Blossom Festival, which opened Friday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, continues through May 10. The collection of single and double-flowering cherry trees, considered one of the finest in this hemisphere, includes more than thirty species and varieties.

A reduction in the cost of clay tile work for homes as well as for commercial and industrial buildings is promised by leading clay-floor and wall-tile manufacturers who have just given approval to an improved installation method.
Brother Cormac Philip dismisses the practical value of foreign language study with the facile assertion that "very few students ever have the opportunity to speak the language."

MOSCOW, April 25 -- M. D. Bagirov, for many years secretary of the Communist party of Azerbaijan, has relinquished this post in connection with his assumption of the Premiership of the Azerbaijani Republic, it has been announced.
While the first steps toward a possible truce were being taken last week in Korea -- for two years and ten months a field of battle -- these questions were being increasingly asked:

President Eisenhower's magnificent speech of April 16 spurred the hopes and imaginations of men and women throughout the world with its vision of what could be done by a war against poverty and disease if the fear of war among nations could be lifted. The President also pointed to the steps that must be taken on concrete problems if that fear were actually to be ended.

In his "Judiciary's 'Wild Bill'" (April 19) Alfred Steinberg observes of Senator William Langer that, "Liberals who loved him * * * for opposing the McCarran Internal Security Act shivered * * * at his efforts to halt deportations of admitted Nazi aliens."

Economy-minded homeowners, seeking ways to keep within their budgets, may find some of the following booklets and pamphlets useful in planning, building, decorating and repairing their homes. Most of the literature is free; some booklets cost 10 or 25 cents.

The new Soviet regime is now engaged in the biggest trade offensive since the time of the International Economic Conference in Moscow early last year, Government observers have concluded on the basis of reports from many parts of the world.

TRENTON, April 25 -- When the Republican and Democratic State Committees meet here on Thursday to reorganize, they will be faced with the task of resolving a multitude of problems arising not only from the results of last Tuesday's primary elections but also from intra-party squabbles.

THE world could do with less hatred. Certainly the world of music should manage without it. Music, at its best, should lift up the heart and should make us feel that all things are possible, even getting along with one another as individuals and peoples.
Hope of hatching the first rare Darwin rheas in this country was shattered for the Bronx Zoo late Friday night when vandals sneaked into the home of the placid birds in the Ostrich House.
