The air-conditioned age is at hand. This year makers of air-conditioning equipment are confident that $2,000,000,000 worth of their products will be sold to home owners determined to disprove the old saw about everybody talking about the weather and doing nothing about it.

Portable cooking equipment has developed fast since the war. Once confined to toasters and waffle-irons, the pieces now include deep-fat fryers, electric barbecuers, table roasters. So rapid has been the growth of this equipment, and so ingenious its many forms, that it dominates the field of what might be called the "small kitchen trappings."

Keith Funston, chairman of the 1953 fund-raising campaign of the Greater New York Fund, has just visited five typical agencies among 423 the Fund helps support to see for himself what he is going to ask New Yorkers to contribute $9,000,000 for tomorrow.

An emergency short-term campaign to raise a minimum of $25,000,000 in cash by having contributors convert pledges into cash will be started by the United Jewish Appeal on Friday. Edward M. M. Warburg, general chairman of the organization, which is conducting a national year-long drive for $144,524,250, announced that Joseph Holtzman of Detroit, a national chairman of the over-all campaign, would be chairman of the short-term effort.
BOSTON, April 25 (UP) -- Tony DeSpirito, granted a one-day grace period before starting another suspension, rode two winners and finished in the money with five other mounts today at Suffolk Downs.

BOSTON, April 25 (UP) -- Mel Parnell became the first Red Sox pitcher to hurl a full game this season as he led his mates to a 4-3 victory over Philadelphia today in a game that ended the Athletics' three-game winning streak.

WITH the coming of May the 1952-53 New York music season will taper to a close. Its imminent ending raises the question: how did it compare with previous seasons? The opinion of the concert hall managers and a count of the events coincide with the verdict that it was slightly heavier than last season.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The vigorous, new leadership which the President promised in the 1952 campaign to give the nation has begun to emerge after a slow start as General Eisenhower nears the completion of his first hundred days. But thus far it is primarily in the area of foreign affairs, and for this there are two principal reasons.

The first and second acts of Richard Strauss' "Der Rosenkavalier" were given yesterday afternoon by the N. B. C. Television Opera Theatre, as the first part of the presentation of the whole opera. The last act will be given next Saturday afternoon, and will complete the most ambitious undertaking of the four-year-old series of N. B. C.-TV opera productions.

For three and a half weeks and well over a million words of heavy speechmaking, liberal Democrats in the U. S. Senate have been trying to "educate the public" on the "evils" of the Administration's offshore oil bill.

Year-round central air-conditioning unit enthusiasts may be right in their contentions that these installations are headed for dominance in the home field, but this year the more familiar room air-conditioner, either fixed to the window or to the floor, will be the prime target of home owner purchasing.
Cornell University has added another bulletin to the growing literature on the kitchen -- probably the most written-about room in the whole house.

MEXICO CITY, Sunday, April 26 (AP) -- Thirty men were killed tonight in a silver mine cave-in and fire. From fifty to sixty others were trapped. Hope for them faded at midnight as smoke poured from the mouth of the mine.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -Majority members of a Senate Appropriations subcommittee called on the State Department today to supply evidence that some of the international meetings its delegates attended were not simply "wining and dining" affairs.

Makers of industrial instruments, who have been enjoying a double peak of defense and civilian demand for the last two years or so, see nothing ahead but more of the same. By the time defense demand levels off, they believe, the increasing need for precision in modern manufacture will have replaced it with commercial orders.

Anybody who wants an argument has only to walk into a Wall Street brokerage house and whisper something about a "peace scare," Peace, he will be told in the hoarse accents of those who do much of their talking on subways and Stock Exchange floors, is always bullish.

Commitments for Government pensions should be minimized in view of the possible adverse effects of large-scale pensioning on the country's economy, according to Henry W. Steinhaus, research assistant of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. Pensions now are fairly adequate in supporting minimum needs of the aged, he holds.
Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Native Dancer, bet down to 1 to 10, had an $87,000 frolic in the $123,750 Wood Memorial at Jamaica yesterday.

IN line with Hollywood's supposed "satisfied back slapping" as regards Academy Awards, it is a bit distressing, if not slightly ludicrous, that you and your New York confreres once more have seen fit to fill valuable column-inches with disparaging remarks aimed at the men and women of the motion-picture industry.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, asked today for immediate passage of a law to grant immunity to witnesses appearing before Congressional committees. He said this was needed to aid in exposing "a great many new facts of the Communist conspiracy."

WHEN economists shuck off all the cant of their calling and produce a book without one reference to the nature of rent, marginal utility or the limiting factors of want gratification, the event should have the same effect in academic halls as the seven trumpets of rams' horns before Jericho.

Those who are about to move this spring may be interested in some information on how to do your own moving. Walter L. Jacobs of the Hertz Truck Rental System said in a recent report that more and more persons rented trucks for this purpose every year. He offered the following suggestions to help make the transfer job simpler.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Senator Price Daniel, Democrat of Texas, pitched into the controversy over Administration treaty-making powers tonight with a suggested compromise constitutional amendment.

Before becoming involved in a freezer-frozen food plan, prospective buyers would do well to examine the proposition carefully. The idea of purchasing on an installment basis a freezer plus four to six months' supply of frozen foods has many appealing features.

The city executive committee of the Affiliated Young Democrats decided yesterday at a meeting in the Piccadilly Hotel to ask the Democratic Assembly district leaders of the city to call meetings of their county committee members and election district captains to determine whom they want as a candidate for Mayor.
PROKOFIEFF'S Seventh Symphony, played for the first time in New York last Tuesday night by Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra, was heard with mixed feelings by the audience.

REFLECTING the growing interest among serious amateurs in the technical aspects of photography, seven books have recently come off the presses. The most exciting is a "first" in the field, Robert C. Cleveland's "Architectural Photography of Houses" (New York: F. W. Dodge Corp. $7.50), a successful West Coast professional's comprehensive, instructive, readable manual on "how to take good pictures of exteriors and interiors."

Top leaders of American parent-teacher, school board, school administration and teachers' organizations, as well as civic authorities, are scheduled to attend the fifty-seventh annual convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers, May 18-20, in Oklahoma City.

Plastics have become almost as prevalent in the home as the air its occupants breathe. From the fillings in her teeth, her eyeglass frames and the clothes she wears (nylon, Orlon and other synthetic fibers) to the countless items she uses and handles during the day, plastics are aiding the housewife.

A GOOD many home-grown carrots look like gnarled tree roots -- short, lumpy, and often pronged. As a result, some gardeners prefer to buy rather than to raise their own. It is possible, however, to pull smooth, long, symmetrical carrots most soils in this area.

American college and university students are taking the demands of the Korean conflict in their stride. They have adjusted to the Selective Service deferment policy and are prepared to serve their two or three years, whatever the case may be, upon leaving the campus.

GILUHDA -- the Hairy Killer -- was what the Indian called the tusked and trunked monster. His description of the mammoth and the tale of how it was threatening the existence of the Twilight People brought young Sam Ward deep into Cherokee country for the greatest hunt of his life.

BONN, Germany, April 25 -- The West German Finance Minister, Fritz Schaeffer, announced today that an agreement had been reached with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization powers in Paris under which West Germany would contribute 950,000,000 Deutsche marks ($226.190,000) a month to Western defense from the time the European Defense Community takes effect until the end of June, 1954.

THE conventions of World War II fiction are hardening. Following them, the novelists assemble a group of self-conscious types meant to represent a cross-section of America's regional, racial and social problems. The war novelists continue to show us the types in civilian settings, emphasizing the social data.

A FOUR-SQUARE program in the home garden includes vegetables, flowers, fruits and herbs. None of them need be neglected if the property is approximately 5,000 square feet (50 by 100 feet), for there is ample room to produce a satisfactory crop of each.

FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, Sunday, April 26 (AP) -- A United States Air Force captain said today he and The Associated Press photographer, Frank Noel, escaped from their Communist captors in August, 1951, but were recaptured three days later.

Coordinated patterned materials, designed to give a bright look to kitchens that, furnished with white equipment, may look somewhat "clinical," have been introduced recently by Youngstown Kitchens, makers of steel kitchen equipment.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Eisenhower talked with three visitors to the White House this morning, conferred with his press secretary James C. Hagerty over the latter's announcement regarding the Pravda "negotiation" editorial and left for his Saturday golf game at the Burning Tree Club at 10:10 A. M.
MOST of the strong rubber-game games in New York are played in the clubs, but during the last three weeks there has been a series of "home games" that at least matched any of them.

A home air-conditioning unit that easily converts any forced warm-air heating system into an all-year indoor weather-control plant is being offered by the United States Air Conditioning System in compact form.

CONTRARY to popular conception, most native American birds do not use birdhouses for nesting sites. The majority build every spring on the ground, in open fields that support dense vegetation, under cliffs, at the ends of burrows excavated in steep banks and in shrubs and trees.

At last, at long last, there are signs that the conscience and common sense of the American people may be stirring themselves to impose a brake upon the orgy of "investigations" which have been squandering public funds, diverting Congressmen from their major responsibilities, pre-empting a disproportionate attention in the press, intimidating innocent and unimpeachably loyal citizens, and slowly permeating the national consciousness with habits of suspicion and distrust.

Hot-water radiation systems are readily convertible to all-year air conditioning generally without major structural changes in the home, according to David E. Feinberg, vice president of the United States Air Conditioning Corporation, who says the change-over can be made in existing dwellings by installing room unit air coolers.

KNOWN principally as an English editor and publisher, John Lehmann appears in a new dimension in this volume. "The Age of the Dragon" is made from four previously published books and represents what he considers his best poems from 1930-51. His foreword tells what he had tried to do.

THIS column has never failed to give Frank O'Rourke top billing for his Westerns. Two of his older books were reread before attempting a review of the latest, CONCANNON (Ballantine, $1.50). What accounts for the excellency of Mr. O'Rourke's stories?

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Eisenhower has pledged himself to use every "useful measure, private and public" to create stable economic conditions in the United States and to foster a rising standard of living for the American people.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The American nurse in Korea will be symbolically honored as "Woman of the Year" at the Women's National Press Club's annual dinner and party next Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- There was a four-way split of high school honors in the fifty-ninth annual Penn Relays, with St. Augustine's of Brooklyn and Cardozo of Washington entering the winner's circle today at Franklin Field.
TOKYO, Sunday, April 26 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,596, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korean time:

The home electric fan, perhaps the first motor-driven household appliance to appear on the market and normally used only for helping to cool a house, can serve for a variety of other purposes, according to D. L. McFarland, manager of the Small Appliances Division of the General Electric Company.
PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- Philadelphia's home - run power came to the aid of a shaky Curt Simmons today to enable the Phillies to defeat the Pirates, 7 -- 6, for their sixth straight victory.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Eisenhower Administration's dollar-and-cents thinking is now in full view and almost fully in operation. No family, job, or business can escape its effects.

THE waning season is proving particularly hospitable to sculpture. With the Whitney annual recently opened and a survey of American sculpture of the last half century at the Sculpture Center, last week brought in the annual exhibition by the Sculptors Guild at the American Museum of Natural History, metal pieces by Herbert Ferber at the Betty Parsons Gallery and work chiefly in plastic by Naum Gabo at Pierre Matisse's Gallery.

IT is several years too early to measure the full significance of what the B. de Rothschild Foundation for the Arts and Sciences has accomplished by its sponsorship of the season of "American Dance," which closes at the Alvin Theatre with two performances today.
MORRISTOWN, N. J., April 25 -A campaign for $350,000 for a new building will be opened next Friday by Neighborhood House, a settlement house serving an interracial area here.
TOKYO, Sunday, April 26 -- United Nations and Communist delegations resumed today their negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war, after a lapse since last Oct. 8.

HELLEVOETSLUIS, The Netherlands. IN the terrible days after last winter's floods this port, so aptly named "Sluice at the Foot of Hell," served as the debarkation point for hundreds of families fleeing from inundated farms on the island of Goeree-Overflakkee. Blank-eyed and numb, they stumbled off barges, ferries and tugboats to be put on buses and sped to inland refuges.

QUIETLY and very naturally, like someone talking in a Persian courtyard where no voice should be raised above the murmur of the fountain, Najmeh Najafi tells of her native Persia She belongs to the minor nobility, her father having been an adviser to the Kadjar Emperor, Ahmed Shah, who was deposed by Reza Shah in 1921.

NO one has yet developed a timetable that an air traveler can read as easily as he can the price on his ticket. However, the harassed passenger whose confusion used to increase each year during the Daylight Saving Time season, can challenge the dreaded schedules today with more confidence.

LOS ANGELES, April 25 -- Although the precise factors involved in the runaway growth that characterizes cancer are still an enigma, scientists are assembling an impressive mass of information on details of the aberration.

AFTER the New York City Ballet finished its first City Center season, in the fall of 1948, a few legitimate doubts were raised by objective onlookers. To those who had no axe to grind it was a moot point whether the project was worth continuing.

IN his autobiography of several years ago, the late novelist Edgar Wallace signed off about this way: "I wonder what happens next. No matter, it is certain to be interesting." And he was right about it; he died at about the time the book came out.

DOES the United States have the kind of economy that can stand peace? The Communists say that depressions are inevitable under capitalism and that sooner or later one of these depressions will destroy capitalism. But they have also said that the armament program has been staving off depression in the United States.

WHILE daffodils and tulips are improving the spring landscape, foresighted gardeners are making their selections from the bulbs, corms, tubers and rhizomes which are noted for their summer bloom. The popularity of gladiolus and dahlias is attested to by innumerable shows planned for these two flowers alone every year from July to October.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 25 -- Al Besselink of Grossinger, N. Y., carded his second 68 in a row today to add to a first round 72, and moved into the lead with a 54-hole score of 208 in the $35,000 tournament of champions.

The Italian Line's second new 30,000-gross-ton liner, now nearing completion at Genoa, Italy, will be named the Cristoforo Colombo at her launching on May 10, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Giuseppe Ali, general representative of the company here.

Virtually all public and voluntary psychiatric clinics here are so severely overcrowded that persons needing psychiatric attention must wait three to six months -- sometimes even a year -- for appointments.

John Janzen, a student at the Charles E. Gorton High School in Yonkers, won the first prize yesterday in a state-wide school health poster contest for which the women's auxiliary of the Medical Society of the State of New York was sponsor.

SALONIKA, Greece, April 25 (AP) -- Newspaper photographs of three women shocked Greek church and Government officials today. They were snapped on Mount Athos, where women and all female animals have been banned for 1,O00 years.

SPORTSMEN'S groups from several parts of the country see no "threat to conservation" or "dangerous political maneuvering" in the appointment of John L. Farley of Seattle as Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, and many see in this move a closer cooperation between state and Federal fish and game agencies that should be of real benefit to conservation.

CLEVELAND, April 25 (AP) -- The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, heeding a court order, canceled today a strike of 2,300 members against the Nickel Plate road and its Wheeling and Lake Erie division. It was the second cancelation in a month in a dispute since July over time claims, working rules changes and other issues.

Gladiolus may be planted any time now. That is, as soon as the soil dries out from the excessive rainfalls we've been experiencing this spring. And, of course, plantings may be continued, at the convenience of the gardener and to spread the season of bloom, through the first week of July.

The aircraft carrier Franklin D. Roosevelt, one of the three largest in the United States Navy, docked in New York yesterday after maneuvers in southern waters. Her crew of 3,000 will get a week-end in the city before sailing on a Mediterranean cruise.

ANSON PHELPS STOKES, reviewing "American Education and Religion," edited by F. Ernest Johnson, uses the opportunity to exploit his own opinions, not to review the book. He speaks of the "growing awareness of need for emphasis on religion."

MOSCOW, April 25 -- The Soviet Union's statement, printed today, that it stands ready to discuss and resolve pressing international issues with the United States either through direct negotiations or within the framework of the United Nations was termed by an experienced Western diplomat a strong affirmation of Soviet preparedness to proceed to the examination of specific disputed international issues.

HAMMERFEST, Norway -The world's most northerly gas stations have been doing a brisk business here since the post-war opening of Norway's Arctic Highway, servicing the big, bumbling Nord Norge Bussen and a wide assortment of every conceivable type of car driven eagerly north by British, French, American, German and other visitors.

NEW ORLEANS, April 25 (AP) -- Action by Congress to limit imports of foreign oil was called for today by Russell B. Brown, general counsel for the Independent Petroleum Association of Americe. He said oil companies had failed to achieve cooperation in limiting imports and Congressional action was the only alternative.

THE urge is on to go out and buy those seeds and plants. Unfortunately the available space nowadays is often small. And in my garden each year the addition of a couple more "must" roses cramps what room is left for the few favorite vegetables and flowers that are really indispensable to my scheme.

LONDON, April 25 -- The Russian response to President Eisenhower's speech of April 16, published by Pravda and Izvestia today, can be counted on to stimulate demands from the Opposition that the Conservative Government take early steps toward new high-level talks directed at a general settlement of differences between East and West.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 25 -- Navy's Olympic invincibles rowed away from Princeton on Carnegie Lake today to win by four boat lengths.

IN the Navy they say "There is a wrong way of doing things and a right way of doing things and the Navy way of doing things." The matter of framing pictures is not so simple. There are many wrong ways and many right ways.

THE refugee migrations to America between 1933 and 1941 were unusual in the number of intellectuals involved. Of not much more than 100,000 newcomers from Germany and Austria in those years, well over 7 per cent were persons of high skill and professional training.

The high-level political and military "brass" of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization -- fourteen nations joined together in one of the greatest military coalitions in history -- met in Paris last week for stock-taking and future planning.
APRIL is one of the two best times of year for setting out evergreens. Whether shrubs or trees, they should be chosen and planted with care.

EDITH ADAMS. a 26-year-old blonde from Kingston, Pa., has only been on Broadway since Feb. 25. But since Miss Adams happens to be in "Wonderful Town." with Rosalind Russell and others, she is likely to continue at the Winter Garden for a long time; going into its third month this week, the musical version of "My Sister Eileen" shows no signs at all of ceasing to be a smash.

Under the auspices of the Renaissance of Italian Youth Foundation, the Renaissance Enchantment Dinner and Ball will be held on the night of May 22 in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of Boys Towns of Italy, Inc. Miss Rosetta Valenti, director of the foundation, heads the benefit committee. Among her aides are Mrs. James F. Fitzsimmons and Mrs. Emily Barret Blanchard.

The modern, efficient chain food store occupies three times the area of its 1940 predecessor -- but it costs twelve times as much. This is the conclusion from thirteen years' experience in supermarket construction by Safeway Stores and its building subsidiary, Franklin Design.

THE Peabody Awards in radio and television were announced last week and the excitement was something less than tremendous. The sheer number of prizes in broadcasting inevitably has detracted from the interest in any one set of blue ribbons and this year the Peabody group hardly covered itself with imaginative distinction.
Everyone's trying to save the housewife work these days, and the home sewer is coming in for her share of the attention, too. There are new sewing accessories to suit a wide range of pocketbooks.

ST. LOUIS, April 25 -- Contract awards of $9,905,777 by the State Highway Department of Missouri last week brought the total for the fiscal year to date to $43,167,700, which with pending projects will amount to more than $50,000,000 by June 30.
CLEVELAND, April 25 -- Al Rosen singled across the winning run in the eighth inning today as the Indians defeated the Tigers, 4 -- 3, for their third straight victory.
BAINBRIDGE, Md., April 25 (AP) -- The Army marched off with the major laurels tonight in the first world boxing championship among the armed forces, taking six of the ten titles.

ALGECIRAS, Spain -- A minimum of time and money will buy for the tourist in Spain a trip to another continent (Africa) and another world. This side trip is not only an exotic experience for the traveler in Europe but may pay for itself if one wishes to take advantage of the free money market in Tangier.

Enlarging on his comment Friday night following the Boston fight between Lightweight Champion Jimmy Carter of the Bronx and Tommy Collins, Robert K. Christenberry, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, declared yesterday that "it is probably the most deplorable thing I've ever seen."

Permit me to suggest that Lord Kilbracken ("Pardon My Coronet, April 19) straighten his a bit. Summing up the ducal situation, he says that the eldest son of a Duke is a Marquis. Generally speaking, he is correct, but there is an exception.
Cardinal Spellman announced last week that Pope Pius XII had elevated thirteen priests of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

A group of American rubber manufacturers will attempt to put down the concept of natural rubber as a "buffer" or cushion stock while synthetic rubber remains free at the annual meeting of the International Rubber Study Group to be held in Copenhagen, Denmark, from May 11 to 15.

PARIS, April 25 -- Democracy's grand alliance, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, concluded its eleventh ministerial council meeting this afternoon with a commitment to raise six more divisions this year to bolster the defenses of the free world against any threat of Soviet attack.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- A new Pentagon security order apparently can keep top military public relations officials in ignorance of some Defense Department developments, even though they have been "cleared" to handle secrets.
Both in refrigerators and freezers the trend in 1953, as for the last two years, is toward appliances requiring a minimum of floor space yet providing maximum storage capacity.

GENIUS is not enough. For greatness of the magnitude of Orozco, circumstances of time, place and culture must conspire. Mexico in the first half of this century provided the right setting: a revolution offering symbols of revolt against oppression and a public tolerant enough to honor an artist who reserved virulent passages for the sins committed in the name of their revolution.

Important books, as well as furniture and decorations, are in the limelight of this week's sales at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. The auctioning of French, Biedermeier and English period furniture and accessories on Thursday, Friday and Saturday will be preceded by two book sales.

Instead of a depression, a stronger economy based on sounder fundamental conditions than we have known for years can be the outcome of peace in Korea. This was the gist of a reassuring speech given last week by George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury,. and it temporarily stemmed a decline in the stock market.

CAIRO, April 25 -- Egyptian and British negotiating teams for the forthcoming discussions on the future of the British-controlled Suez Canal zone base held separate consultations today to define the positions they will put forth when they meet on Monday.

Gene Woodling blasted a home run into the rightfield bullpen with two Yankee team-mates on base in the ninth inning yesterday to beat the Senators, 4 -- 2. Thus the delayed-fuse Bronx Bombers put on another thrilling finish for the edification of a Ladies Day crowd of 24,636 (18,121 paid) at the Stadium.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 25 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, United States Commander in the Pacific, who arrived here this evening, took a sober view of the Indo-China military situation tonight as Communist-led Vietminh units thrust from two directions to within sixty miles of Luang Prabang. Luang Prabang, where elderly ailing King Sisavang Vong holds court, is the capital of Laos.

The homemaker can get more than her money's worth from home appliances -- if she use her intelligence. Home economists in industry (employed by equipment manufacturers) and in education (teaching young women the skills of homemaking) are continually emphasizing the fact that good as a machine is, it can be even better if the woman using it thinks about the job she is doing.

FIRST, the father, then the son. The architect Eliel Saarinen died in 1950 at the age of 76, so renowned that his native Finland gave him an official state funeral and he was mourned internationally. Eero Saarinen is today 42 and is already the most widely known and respected architect of his generation.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 25 -- The fury of an atomic explosion wrenched a radio-guided plane from its course today as it attempted the first flight through the center of a nuclear blast and sent it crashing to earth as troops crouched in foxholes near by.

Twenty-five years ago one Thomas Winston Briggs, a 38-year-old advertising man, head of his own agency in Memphis, Tenn., thought he might be able to serve his clients a little better by greeting new arrivals in the city and perhaps making customers out of them.

DESPITE rumors about the film future of "Oklahoma!" which has been setting all kinds of records in the theatre for the past ten years, it begins to look as though the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical finally will be made into a movie.

More than the usual attention will be focused on steel during the coming week because of three scheduled events which may throw some welcome light on a widely discussed question: When and how much are steel prices going up?

Speculative home builders all over the country are climbing on the year-round air-conditioning bandwagon. This year for the first time they are asserting publicly that a new house without complete air conditioning built in may become a drug on the market soon.
In the mere six years that have passed since television sets became generally available to the American consumer, a minor revolution has taken place in the living rooms of homes all over the country.

NO one is grumbling about the service at the Old Vic just now. Robert Donat is acting there in a masterly production of T. S. Eliot's "Murder in the Cathedral" and the Old Vic is itself again. From every point of view this is an exalting occasion.

PARIS, April 25 -- The extent to which Moscow responds to the West's diplomatic initiative is ultimately related to the internal political course set by Premier Malenkov. This was not immediately made apparent by the Soviet's reply to President Eisenhower today -- an answer which left wide open the door for eventual negotiations, but deliberately kept vague on the basic issues.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 25 -- Tennessee's Limited Constitutionali Convention with its organizationI completed, will turn Tuesday to ;the d. -ng of up to six amend-I [ment to the state's elghty-three-! year-old charter.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Contrary to reports from some sources within the Department of Agriculture, most top officials there and Senators and Representatives from farm areas have not detected any great pressure building up to try to force Congress to act against high, rigid farm price supports before they expire at the end of 1954.

The history and development of wallpaper will be traced in a free art lecture at 6:15 P. M. Tuesday at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The lecturer, B. H. Hellman, editor of Wallpaper magazine, is a specialist in the home furnishings field.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 25 -- Qualifying selections for next November's National Horse Show equitation finals at Madison Square Garden were made today at the Boulder Brook Club during the opening-day program of the annual two-day spring fixture.

MUCH ink has been spilled over Elgar's Enigma Variations, a work so titled by the composer. Why "Enigma?" Well, there's a "hidden" theme, unheard and never stated, that counterpoints with the main theme.

Charlie Dietlin, Fordham's unbeaten right-hander, pitched a one-hitter to give the Rams a 2-0 victory over Wagner yesterday at Fordham Field. The lone single, a line drive to center by pinch-hitter Sal Vindigni, came with two outs in the ninth.

One of the picturesque garden tours of the spring season in New York is that of the City Garden Club which will be held on the afternoons of May 5 and May 12. The tour will include six gardens and penthouse terraces on each afternoon, the gardens being open from 2:30 o'clock until 6.
Upon rereading several Dickens novels recently, it occurred to me that the motion picture industry is missing an opportunity to combine business with pleasure.

Estimates by trade observers put department store volume in the area at about even with the corresponding 1952 week. While the weather turned mild, helping sales during the latter part of the week, the low temperatures checked expansion of spring buying on Monday and Tuesday.

YONKERS, April 25 -- Mr. and Mrs. Stanley F. Dancer's Volo Chief, driven by Dancer, scored in 2:04 3-5 to win the $9,000 Larchmont Pacing Stake tonight at Yonkers Raceway before a crowd of 31,540, a national record for night pari-mutuel tracks.

MILWAUKEE, April 25 (UP) -The Milwaukee Braves flexed their muscles in their new ball park today with Ed Mathews hitting two homers as the Braves overpowered the Cincinnati Redlegs, 8 to 4, before 14,492 fans.

The Hotpoint Company, kitchen and laundry equipment division of General Electric, expects to-increase its business about 25 per cent this year over 1952, and looks for sales on a number of appliances to rise to six times their current levels by 1960, John C. Sharp, president of the division, said yesterday.

THE Encyclopaedia Britannica lists six Barringtons: a viscount, a barrister, an admiral, a Bishop, a Chancellor of the Exchequer and a picaroon. The picaroon gets about twice as much space as any of the reputable Barringtons and he is the subject of the first historical novel by Ernest Dudley, a British actor and crime writer.

READERS remembering Reginald Arkell's "Old Herbaceous," the story of a ruggedly individualistic English gardener, may be rather surprised to find Mr. Arkell leaving the shaded garden paths for the glittering byways of the stage.

Small fabricators of aluminum can increase integration of their operations by adopting methods of continuous casting and processing, according to Frank R. Nichols, president of the Nichols Wire and Aluminum Company of Davenport, Iowa. He said the method involved a relatively low capital outlay.

ON the day that an atomic blast was touched off at Yucca Flat, Oregon's State Senate debated a bill to forbid installation of television sets in automobiles. We debated it long and strenuously, and finally the bill was passed by a vote of 23 to 7.

THE season of the whirling blades and flying grass clippings has returned. Whether a hand or a power mower is used, it undoubtedly needs some attention, and a great deal of timely advice is being offered by manufacturers of such equipment.

ALONG with the switch to Daylight Saving Time, a readjustment of schedules on all railroads goes into effect today, a situation bound to perplex some train riders for the next few days. As an example, the New York Central announces that from now on the Twentieth Century will leave the city at 6 P. M. eastern daylight and arrive in Chicago at 9 A. M. central daylight, "a half-hour earlier than at present."

PINEHURST, N. C., April 25 -- Bill Campbell of Huntington, W. Va., defeated Mal Galletta of St. Albans, L. I., today, 2 and 1, in the thirty-six-hole final of the North and South amateur golf tournament.

SKEPTICS who like to hold that specialists in the study of child behavior have "learned nothing really" about child rearing that grandmother or, more likely now, great-grandmother didn't know, like to point as proof of their statements to several diametrically opposed theories propounded within the past half century.

A WEEK from tomorrow Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, will announce the winners of Pulitzer Prizes for 1953. There already has been some speculation concerning the decision that the Pulitzer board may reach in the field of drama.

ANYONE strolling along Fourteenth Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues in the year 1953 will search in vain for any trace of a theatre there. It (Civic Repertory Theatre) has gone the way of most dreams, but it still exists in the mind and heart of Eva Le Gallienne.

LESS than 100 picture theatres for some 30,000,000 people hardly suggests a population of film fans, but although the financial yield may not be great Hollywood must take credit, or responsibility, for a not inconsiderable influence on the social life of West Africa.

An overwhelming majority of students attending an Intercollegiate Conference on Academic Freedom resolved here last night that teachers had the right to teach what they believed and express their own point of view, so long as they permitted discussion of contrary views.
LONDON, April 25 -- The British press provided its readers with a good deal of fun and entertainment at the expense of Senator McCarthy's two young investigators, Gerard David Schine and Roy M. Cohn.

I have read the comment by Philip B. Perlman on the marginal oil lands. It is, of course, true that the Supreme Court, by a 4 to 3 vote, decided in 1947 that the State of California had no right to offshore lands, and that in 1950, by a 4 to 3 vote, a similar decision was rendered against the states of Texas and Louisiana.

A bullet-punctuated 90-mile-an-hour chase through the midtown section at dawn yesterday ended when forty policemen in twenty radio cars closed in on a stolen automobile and captured one of two men suspected of having held up a West Side garage attendant.

CHICAGO, April 25 (UP) -- The Chicago Cubs collected fifteen hits off six St. Louis Cardinal pitchers today and swamped the Redbirds, 10 -- 6. They had an eight-run fourth inning in which eight players got hits.

A 23-year-old student of Leyden University in Holland, Meika Meurs, who arrives tomorrow aboard the liner Westerdam, will share honors with a Hunter College junior, Jill Oplinger, in being designated "Miss 300th Anniversary."

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., April 25 -- A full schedule of art shows has been announced for the Moran Woodhouse Galleries at Guild Hall by Mrs. Edmund T. Delaney, art committee chairman, and Mrs. Warren Whipple, director of the hall.

Sixty million Americans lost an hour during the night as Daylight Saving Time went into effect at 2 A. M. today in New York and ten other states: California, Massachusetts, New Jersey, New Hampshire, Vermont, Rhode Island, Connecticut, Maine, Nevada and Delaware.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., April 25 -- The body of one of the crew members of the B-29 that crashed with an F-84 Thunderjet here yesterday afternoon was recovered from the waters of Great Peconic Bay.

FROM the make-up of the Down Town Glee Club one would hardly suspect the harmonious power which has placed the group among the city's formidable amateur choral societies. The club has appeared for twenty-five years in Carnegie Hall and will sing its fiftieth concert there next Friday.

As much a part of the season as daffodils and dandelions are the garden tours and teas sponsored each year by horticultural societies and garden clubs. Among the first to be held locally this year is the annual spring showing of New York City gardens and penthouse terraces on May 5 and May 12, from 2:30 to 6 P. M.

The United States has long been considered by both learned Europeans and Americans to be a nation of neurotics. Our hysteria when it comes to thoughts of economic depression as reflected in the writings in our periodicals, in the pronouncements of prominent citizens and in the sentiments of the populace seems to give added credence to this allegation.
Chaim Gross, New York sculptor regarded as one of the foremost artists in his field, will be honored Wednesday evening by art students, fellow artists and civic leaders.

EIGHT days after Guatemala resigned on April 7 as a member of the five-nation Organization of Central American States, one of the four remaining republics, Nicaragua, issued a series of stamps to commemorate the group's founding in 1951, and one of the postal designs includes a portrait of Guatemala's President Arbenz Guzman, the man who authorized his country's withdrawal.

The Old Guard of the City of New York, resplendent and perhaps a bit warm in their giant bearskin shakos and ornate high-collared uniforms, paraded in City Hall Plaza yesterday afternoon at the 127-year-old organization's annual review and swearing in of military officers.
A softball match between teams representing the City Councils of Chicago and New York was rapidly shaping up yesterday as the New York Councilmen prepared to accept a Chicago challenge.

JERSEY CITY, April 25 -- The political forces of Mayor John V. Kenny and his immediate predecessor, Frank Hague Eggers, are girding for their ninth battle at the polls since May 10, 1949, when Mr. Kenny defeated Mr. Eggers. The election will be held May 12.

ONLY two persons in Britain -- Lieutenant Commander Barrett of the destroyer Scimitar and an acidulous newspaper man named Crockford -- have the wit to see that a naval review at Spithead, with its attendant luminaries, might be too much of a temptation for a canny enemy to overlook.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Sunday, April 26 -- The Communists proposed today that final disposition of prisoners of war who refused repatriation be decided at the high-level political conference called for in the draft armistice agreement.

MUNSAN, Korea, April 25 -About 150 American prisoners of the Korean war have come back this week from Communist camps. From their first stories, told as they arrived at Freedom Village, a dismal picture has emerged of the life they lived behind the barbed wire -- life that thousands of other Allied captives are presumably still living.

George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, expressed skepticism last night regarding the Soviet peace offensive of recent weeks but added that the United States should have a workable domestic program ready in case international conditions improved and defense spending was cut sharply.

A TITLE of the flatness of "Books in General," and the fact that it covers "thirty-four studies of books and writers, both classic and contemporary,'' might suggest that here is something for readers in general to pass by. They would be misled.

Industrial business this month, normally a period of seasonal pickup, is holding previous gains, and there has been a slight increase in new orders and production. Prices are holding steady, with a more pronounced trend to a buyers' market. Foreign offerings are having a depressing effect on several basic commodities.

Who rules Russia today? The simple truth is that no non-Communist knows with certainty the answer to this seemingly simple question. The highest diplomatic and intelligence officials of the Western world are engaged in an unprecedented guessing contest, trying to put together the scanty available clues in order to come up with the most likely answer.

In summertime, rooms can take on a cool, trim look with the use of some of the window coverings that utilize, among other materials, bamboo, cord or wood slats. Such draperies or window shades permit privacy and they also allow a soft light to filter into the room. Practical and easy to keep clean, curtains of this kind are suitable for town or country.

UNLESS my audits are awry I've played Hamlet 777 times. I've impersonated the brooding Prince at London's Old Vic; on an open-air stage in the Jungle Training Area, Hawaii; in West Forty-fourth Street; in towns and theatres strewn all the way from Boston to San Diego.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 25 -- The United States need have no fear of peace if its business men would face up to the facts about what was needed for the change-over, it was emphasized here today by a Government official and a newspaper publisher.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 25 -- On what he described as "a sad and sorrowful day," Sir Alexander Hood, the Governor, bade god-speed today to the last troops of the British garrison, which is closing after more than 250 years' association with Bermuda. A few

Tips on using the clothes drier, the newest addition to home laundry equipment, have resulted from research at Ohio State University. Dr. Elaine Knowles Weaver, Associate Professor at the university, reported that fabrices, especially loosely woven ones, dried in such an appliance had a tendency to shrink more than those dried on the clothesline.

Now that the Eisenhower Administration is getting around to appointing a new executive personnel set-up for the Securities and Exchange Commission there is good prospect that the experimental and overlapping securities laws passed by Congress in the Nineteen Thirties and thereafter administered "not wisely but too well" will come in for long overdue revision.

Prof. Hugh W. Puckett, executive officer of the German Department at Barnard College, and Prof. Frederic G. Hoffherr, executive officer of the Barnard French Department, will retire at the end of the current academic year, Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of the college, announced yesterday.

GIOVANNI VERGA -- who was born in a Sicilian village in 1840, and died at the age of 82 -- is a figure not uncommon in literature: the great writer who, a classic in his country, is much neglected abroad. (An American, Henry Adams, who was Verga's contemporary almost to the year, happens to be in a similar plight.)

A REALISTIC story, steeped in wisdom, this has the gentle humor of peasant folklore. The Krog family is the poorest and loneliest in their Swedish village. When a bear cub strays into their yard, the children are overjoyed but Papa says they are too poor to feed a pet -- if Grumms were sold, he would bring food and money.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Representative George H. Bender, Republican of Ohio, charged -- and Immigration Service officials conceded -- today that newly naturalized citizens still were receiving a congratulatory full-page letter signed by former President Harry S. Truman.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, called on the Eisenhower Administration today to exercise "strong" influence on Congress for maintenance of taxes at present levels as the only way to assure a balanced budget.

BOWIE, Md., April 25 (AP) -Royal Vale, imported from England by Mrs. E. du Pont Weir, turned in an outstanding effort in winning the $20,000-added Bowie Handicap here today, running the mile and a sixteenth only three-fifths of a second off the track record.

The use of wall-coverings may be considered one of the easiest means of imprinting one's individuality on a home. Thousands of new designs appear every year on wallpapers, displaying a range of motifs for every taste. And there are numbers of other coverings to choose from: plastic fabrics or tiles, grass cloth, textured papers from Japan.

COOPERSTOWN -- The opening of the big league baseball season always heightens interest in the National Baseball Hall of Fame, one of the three museums in this upstate New York Village on Lake Otsego, 200 miles northwest of midtown Manhattan. The first week of the present baseball season added another fillip when Mickey Mantle hit a 565-foot home run over the wall of Washington's Griffith Stadium.

RAVEL'S compositional style and precision, his distinctive harmonic idiom and his orchestrational brilliance made him the next important impressionist to Debussy. "The Swiss watchmaker" (Stravinsky's name for Ravel) was no wonder-child in whom,' according to the cynical definition, the wonder disappears and the child remains.

French forces in Indo-China are depending heavily on a hastily constructed defense perimeter in the high, grassy Traninh Plateau to check the fast-moving Vietminh invasion of Laos. From positions constructed around an airfield on the Plaine des Jarres the French obviously hope to rebuff Vietminh attacks and then to lash out in counter-drives aimed at disrupting the lines of Vietminh advance.

Norman Thomas, chairman of the public affairs committee of the Socialist party, said that the denial of a right for left-wingers to stage a May Day parade Friday was an "invitation to future mob violence."

Thomas E. Murray, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, warned yesterday that the American public must face the facts of atomic life or face disaster. We cannot retreat into comfortable ignorance when the possibility looms that this century might be "closing time" for the human race, he said.

Barnard College has launched a campaign to raise $150,000 to create on its campus the Minor Latham Drama Workshop. This is to be a professional theatre in which Broadway figures will cooperate with the college faculty in presenting an unusual program of training for Barnard students interested in the theatre.

THERE are two kinds of novels, those that you exhaust at a sitting and those you will sit with again. Mr. Zilahy's kaleidoscopic novel of his native Hungary (an angry angel himself, he now lives in New York) belongs in the latter category.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- A White House spokesman said officially today that the latest Soviet profession of readiness to negotiate a solution of East-West problems might be "a first step toward something concrete." If it should prove to be the forerunner of a real peace move it would find the United States and allied nations ready "to work unceasingly for peace," the spokesman asserted.

WE, from the secure haven of the dawning twenty-first century, can see what was less obvious at the time: that the Nineteen Fifties saw the beginning of the new trend which has transformed the world. There were certain problems of which at that time foresighted people were conscious.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., April 25 -- The Jersey Central's No. 1555 steamed into the station here twenty-six minutes late this afternoon, but nobody cared. It was "Old Friendly's" last passenger run between Somerville and Flemington after eighty-nine years of service.

SINCE the widespread popularity of television barely spans six years, there have been few stories which give young people a behind-the-camera look at the industry. The delay was worth while if books as complete in scope and detail as this are to be the result.

WHEN Walt Whitman thought he could live with the animals because they do not sweat and whine about their condition he was being particularly human. He was displaying his capacity for discontent, a talent unique in man.

NO doubt about it; religious art has had a hard time for many years now. From the very top, from occasional disapproval of Rouault and the French clergy thundering against Matisse's chapel at Vence, right down to the non-figurative painter who pathetically entitles his insignificant forms "St. John of the Cross," painters who seek to express the inexpressible have had very few kind words for their efforts.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- A bill extending Federal rent controls to July 31 awaited President Eisenhower's signature at the White House today.

COGNAC, France -- Cognac, the golden brandy, is known in every civilized land and language in the world. But the small French town which "invented" the drink remains unknown even to thoroughly traveled tourists.

Retail business continued at a better rate than activity in the wholesale market here last week, according to Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Retail stocks were in good shape and stores were taking advantage of the excellent buys available. All types of summer goods were in demand.

CERTAINLY the best available account of Soviet Russia during the Korean War that this reviewer has seen is Frank Rounds' "A Window on Red Square." Mr. Rounds entered the country by train on Jan. 10, 1951, and left on the LeningradLondon boat on June 5, 1952.

FIVE new accessories for the 35mm Kodak Retina cameras are announced by Eastman Kodak. The Kodak Retina Sports Finder, an open-frame finder which fits in the accessory clip of the camera, has parallax adjustment, is collapsible and comes with a carrying case at $6.50.

Preliminary verbal assaults in what may become a full-fledged battle over the issue of more or less liberal tariff-trade policies for this country are scheduled to get under way in Washington tomorrow. The occasion will be the opening of hearings before the House Ways and Means Committee on extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, which is due to expire on June 12.
Color-conscious home owners and builders are placing more emphasis on the lighter shades and tints since the advent of air conditioning.

A stained glass memorial window honoring Francis Lewis, one or the signers of the Declaration of Independence, was dedicated yesterday by the Right Rev. James P. DeWolfe, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, at a special service in Grace Church, Fourteenth Road and Clintonville Street, Whitestone, Queens.

An unexpected and inexplicable development in trans-Atlantic travel has major North Atlantic passenger steamship companies offering accommodations during the peak summer travel season, it was revealed yesterday.
THE full-length opera recordings which have appeared so profusely in recent months are, nine times out of ten, transferred to LP from masters made in Europe. It is cheaper that way.

CLEVELAND, April 25 -- Approval of a $60,000,000 addition to the Ford Motor Company plant in suburban Brook Park will double the motor company's engine and foundry plants in this area. The new building will close one street in the 100-acre tract and will bring $360,000 a year in tax revenue to the suburb.

The direction of the Communist Vietminh attack in Laos, most westerly of the Associated States of Indo-China, suggests that a major target is the Mekong River. It is already quite clear that the Communists have a specific political goal, the establishment of a puppet state in this northwestern region and its proclamation as an area of "liberation."

Young matrons are furthering the sale of tickets for the performance of Cinerama on May 5 at the Broadway Theatre for the benefit of the Washington Square Home for Friendless Girls. Mrs. Richard C. Bondy Jr. is chairman of the benefit committee, whose members have been holding meetings recently at the Pierre to advance plans for the event.

BUENOS AIRES, April 25 -- Downtown sections of this capital were rocked by bombs early today for a second time in a fortnight. The bombs, set off at the exclusive Military Club, social headquarters of the Argentine Army's officialdom, appeared to be an open manifestation of unrest in sectors of the nation's political front.

Methods of cleaning marble, which appears in many forms in homes today, are outlined in an article in a recent issue of Apartment Life Magazine. Marble is used in objects ranging from ash trays to the United Nations building.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- Varieties of fine alloy steel, long scarce here on account of last summer's steel strike, are now in adequate supply. But nickel is still short. Price advances in some parts of the list have been accepted without much complaint.

The recipes appearing here today deal with preparing cooked meat for a second appearance on the dining table. This subject more often is referred to as "the problem of leftover." That they need' be no problem is shown by these tempting recipes which come from fine chefs in leading New York restaurants.

The Bay Ridge branch of the Lincoln Savings Bank at Fifth Avenue and Seventy-fifth Street, Brooklyn, retained its record among savings banks as a leading Red Cross blood donor, with 352 pints collected yesterday from emloyes and residents of that area.

This is the moment, that moment which may last for a day or a week, depending on the wind and weather. It is the time when tree-green trembles between wary bud and opening leaf, when a few hours of concentrated sunlight could almost change the face of the land.

For many years concern has been growing over the tremendous loss in working years and wealth suffered by business and industry and by individuals through the inroads of cancer, second greatest killer of Americans.

Repenting of sins rather than boasting of greatness was suggested for nations as a step toward international disarmament yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Jacob Kohn in a sermon at Temple Ansche Chesed, 100th Street and West End Avenue.

GIBRALTAR, an emblem of British power, has become a key point of passage for tourists on the increasingly popular southern approach to Europe. While most people are still moving in the old grooves to Southampton, Le Havre and the other northern ports, more and more travelers are using the Mediterranean route to Spain, Africa, and Italy.

ITHACA, N. Y., April 25 -- Bob Davis, a sophomore righthander from Great Neck, L. I., pitched a no-hitter as Yale defeated Cornell, 3 -- 0, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game on Hoy Field today.

IT'S too early to make a final accounting on the recorded versions of all of Broadway's musical offerings for this season (Cole Porter's "Can-Can" and the Rodgers and Hammerstein "Me and Juliet" are still waiting in the wings), but it will be a rare season indeed if any of the scores still to come can match the gaiety and inventiveness of Wonderful Town as it has been transferred to a twelve-inch LP by Decca.

Three out of every five new homes being built today make use of gas for heating, and industry officials believe that this ratio will rise considerably in the next few years as pipeline systems bring more natural gas into various parts of the country, including the Northeast.
Science and industry have joined forces to bring a new era of comfort and convenience to modern home life.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a union certified as the exclusive bargaining representative of employes could not charge nonmembers a fee for processing their grievances.

SHORTLY before June 2 the resplendent objects shown here, constituting the chief items of the Regalia of England will be removed in great secrecy from the Tower of London and taken to Westminster Abbey where they will appear in the solemn Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II.
SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, April 26 (AP) -- The war quieted today after an angry Saturday on the central front, where United States troops mowed down 190 of possibly 750 attacking Chinese.

COLUMBIA, Mo., April 25 (AP) -- The Washington Star and six individuals will receive medals of honor for distinguished service in journalism next Friday from the University of Missouri School of Journalism.

Vitamin C, found in citrus fruits, is regarded chiefly as a preventive of scurvy. Now comes a team of five scientists under the leadership of Prof. Charles Glen King, Professor of Chemistry at Columbia and director of the Nutrition Foundation, with the discovery that vitamin C is much more than an anti-scorbutic.

Dried beef, otherwise known as jerked beef, is nothing new to soldiers and explorers, but eating it has never been considered a gastronomic delight. As the result of experiments conducted at the University of California it may be that "freeze-drying" of raw meat will take the place of the old method.

SHEFFIELD, Mass -- Romantic motorists who are of the opinion that what this country needs is more covered bridges, should head, one of these fine spring days, for the upper reaches of the Housatonic River where, within a space of forty miles along scenic U. S. 7, there are three of the colorful, barnlike structures, one of which is brand new.

IN this remarkable novel Edith Simon proves that she can write as well about the intricate emotions of the human heart in modern times as she did, rather loftily, about fourteenth-century England in "The Golden Hand." Here Miss Simon has faithfully caught the atmosphere of the uncomfortable period of postwar reconstruction in Britain.

Prof. Paul F. Kerr and Gerald P. Brophy, both of Columbia University, have discovered in samples of the black, flaky mineral from the Freedom Two uranium mine at Marysvale, Utah, a new species of uranium they call "umohoite." This umohoite contains molybdenum and water in addition to uranium, so that chemists would call it a hydrous uranium molybdate.

Spring cleaning, the annual commotion that rages in households all over the land, has begun. This year many a delighted housewife and her grateful husband are finding the situation much less odious than formerly. Modern air- conditioning units have cut the work of the distaff side in half and lessened the disturbance of the husband's state of mind.
BERLIN, April 25 -- East Germany, which in recent months has appealed to the French to resist West German rearmament, has in the past few days singled out Britain for special attention.

THE difference between baseball's knothole gang and Happy Felton's television version is that the youngsters have been brought from the wrong side of the fence straight to the diamond. This small miracle could hardly have failed to attract viewers.

As a companion piece to "Evil to him who evil thinks" one could suggest, "Honor to him who honor deserves." Queen Elizabeth could not have chosen a more fitting person for the accolade of Knight of the Order of the Garter than Winston Churchill. He had refused the honor previously because of a political overtone that has since, happily, been removed.

ACCORDING to historical novelist John Brick, the "most important single event" of the American Revolution may have been a shot fired by an Irishman named Timothy Murphy. It happened at the Battle of Saratoga. Murphy, a real but half - forgotten Revolutionary hero, fired his "impossible" 200- yard sniper shot at British General Fraser, around whom disorganized royalist troops were rallying.

During this week the new Administration in Washington will have completed its "first hundred days." It is perhaps too early to make a balanced appraisal of its accomplishments, or to pass a judgment on each of the things that has been done or left undone. Some issues that have been raised have been controversial and there has been the expected and, we believe, healthy controversy.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 25 -- Harvard's varsity crew received surprising opposition from Rutgers, but the Crimson responded with mid-season form to gain a three-quarter-length victory over the Scarlet in the season's first collegiate crew race on the Charles today.

A loom is a loom is a loom. . . . Paraphrasing Gertrude Stein's soliloquy on a rose, textile manufacturers in the United States are facing the realization that the pressure of foreign competition can be applied against them in an area previously held inviolate -that of supplying the armed forces.

Billy Kelly, who guarantees four, winners at the race track -- and produces them (after the races are run) was arrested yesterday on charges of violating Section 421 of the Penal Law, which covers misleading advertising.

IN Dana Thomas' "Crusaders for God" a ship's captain says to Father Damien, "I can understand how a man can cheat, fall in love, even give his life for another on the battlefield. But what is beyond me is why a young man will leave his home and travel nineteen thousand miles to live on an island with a bunch of half-civilized Kanakas!"

CHARLES GATES DAWES of Chicago was one of the first men of his generation in public and business life. Between 1897 and 1932 he held a series of major public offices, from Comptroller of the Currency to Vice President; in Chicago, both as banker and as citizen, he became a civic institution.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 25 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy, the defending champion, turned back Art Larsen in four sets today in the semi-finals of the nineteenth River Oaks tennis tournament.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- Manhattan College stepped down from its sprint throne today and Morgan State stepped right up to fill the vacancy as the fifty-ninth Penn Relays came to a roaring finish before 32,000 fans at Franklin Field.

Americans have been told by some Europeans and others with primitive home-heating devices that central heating leads to enervation. The people of this country are not sold on that proposition. They demand more and more improvements in their central heating systems, long the most efficient in the world.

OROZCO was content to submit to his innate compulsion to picture deep-seated feelings; to paint the private ferment concealed by a thoughtfully inexpressive exterior. Though his major pictorial themes, drawn from the life and death of whole races and classes, were often repeated -- they were grand enough, surely, for reaffirmation -- exciting ideas raced through his mind and leaped from his paint-brush to the day of his death.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The United States and the Soviet Union have been outdoing each other for a month now in protesting their willingness to negotiate a general settlement of all differences, but both sides seem to want the settlement on the same familiar terms.

A chimney placed on the inside of a house offers certain fuel economies as compared with at chimney on the outside of a house. Thus in planning a new house, a builder may wish to provide for an inside chimney if possible, say the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau.

A single by Alvin Dark that slithered through a drawn-in infield with the bases full and the score tied in the eighth inning enabled the Giants to overcome one Flatbush jinx at Ebbets Field yesterday while still preserving one of their own.

THE subject of this frequently raffish memoir out-Hearsted Hearst in lurid journalism, out-Barnumed Barnum in showmanship, and his eccentricities make Lord Timothy Dexter, Newburyport's eccentric of long ago, seem in comparison as staid as the late George Apley.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 25 -- Abolghassem Amini assumed the duties of court minister today, according to a palace communique. Mr. Amini replaces Hossein Ala, who resigned Thursday after Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi once more had failed to support Mr. Ala's defense of royal prerogative against the Government.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Spring rains have made spraying imperative for fruit trees of all ages and sizes. Spray apple and pear trees just before blossoms open and again when they fall, and peaches again as soon as petals fall. Recommendations are available from state experiment stations. Start weekly spraying for roses and plants susceptible to disease.
I LIKED everything about Anthony Boucher's review of my book, "The Big Heat," except this line: "Philadelphia * * * a city for which McGivern has a vivid contempt."

LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, April 25 -- Government leaders appeared today to have swung suddenly into a new attack on the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church, whom they denounced for refusing to cooperate in a Government plan for the "settlement" of relations with the churches.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. declared today that his recent criticism of the Truman Administration's loyalty program had been directed not at those responsible for carrying it out but at "basic flaws" in the procedure.

FOR many a day the men who make up the quiz programs, as well as the public at large, have wanted a book containing the facts of American history arranged for ready reference. The American sections in Langer's "Encyclopedia of World History' are excellent, to be sure, but something more comprehensive was needed. Now we have it.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 25 (AP) -- Darrow Hooper, 220-pound shot-putter from Texas A. and M., shattered a 19-year-old meet record and Illinois took team laurels as the forty-fourth Drake Relays ended today in rain-sprinkled Drake Stadium.

A 1932 Yale man who used to clear the way on the gridiron for Albie Booth is now running interference in a different league -- this time for Secretary of State John Foster Dulles with whom he flew Last week to the NATO Council meeting in Paris.

Before next Friday about 17,000 food retailers throughout the country will receive a novel gift from an unusual company. The gift will take the form of a May basket (a basket holding a gift, such as spring flowers, left at the door of a favored person on May Day).

PERHAPS a comment on the play which virtually began the current season may appear stale, but I was in Europe when "The Time of the Cuckoo" opened, and thus missed all of the local reviews of it -- except for those fragmentary echoes in the advertisements for the production.

PARIS, April 25 -- When the United States has a Presidential year everyone seems to know about it. This is Presidential year in France and though the news does not seem to have reached the public yet it is already exerting its influence in every phase of French politics.

Public officials, civic leaders and educators joined last night in recognition of the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Ethical Culture Schools at a dinner meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The anniversary will be celebrated for three weeks.

BONN, April 25 -- As the Russians are well aware, any serious and outwardly sincere proposal by the Soviet Union on the reunification of Germany will provoke a major political row in the Federal Republic and begin a period of strain in the relationships between West Germany, on the one hand, and the United States, Britain and France, on the other.

DURING the first week of May at Victoria, on Canada's Pacific coast, eight theatre groups from all parts of the Dominion will vie for first place in Canada's theatrical world. The Dominion Drama Festival in the Royal Theatre at Victoria, from May 4 to May 9, culminates another year of the Canadian theatre, which has taken a new lease on life, especially in the smaller towns and cities of the country.
Sixty years ago Manchester was a dying English city thirty-five miles inland from the Irish Sea. It could not accommodate any vessels larger than small barges.

Many United States soldiers who saw Buchenwald in 1945 came away with a new seriousness, a new anger, a new, inescapable sense of guilt and responsibility. Mr. Weiss' arresting first novel (the first winner of the Frieder Literary Award for books in English on Jewish themes) is the story of such a soldier, David Hutchinson, and of Saul Swoboda, the young Jewish Czech D. P he met at Buchenwald and later knew in New York.

THE literature of piracy is large and varied. Pirates are depicted as bloodthirsty villains, careless of life and property, as glamour boys of the seas; sometimes, by romantic writers, as men of heroic mold. In this book by a historian on the faculty of Bucknell University they appear as business men, or perhaps it is better to say as seagoing racketeers and hijackers with the right connections on shore.
ST. LOUIS, April 25 (UP) -- The Chicago White Sox defeated the St. Louis Browns, 6 -- 4, today on the five-hit pitching of Tommy Byrne and Harry Dorish.

THIS essentially simple tale of the struggle of two women for the possession of a man is bone-clean. without one superfluous detail. The setting is the dateless Brittany of quaint custom and pagan spiritism, of the belief in omens, curses and the expiatory capacity of a "divine victim," the Brittany of today as well as of five centuries ago.

Double-pane insulating glass, first introduced to enable homeowners to have large picture windows and window-walls without excessive heat loss during the winter months, now premises to became just as important in the home air- conditioning picture by keeping summer heat outside of the house, in the opinion of architects and builders.

The Astin-Weeks affair has focused the attention of millions of automobile owners on what they call battery "dopes" but what the National Bureau of Standards more ceremoniously calls "additives." It is the purpose of these "dopes" or "additives" to lengthen the life of a dying storage-battery cell. If they did what is claimed for them automobile owners would save millions every year.

Installation of an electronic heating control system that literally "anticipates" changes in the weather will be one of the major features of each of twenty-eight colonial and ranch-type homes in the $2,000,000 Todd Estates development to be opened to the public next month in Glen Head, L. I.
PARIS, April 25 (AP) -- Following is the text of the final communique of the North Atlantic Treaty Council's meeting, translated from French:

Washday can be easier and faster if an ice cube tray and a home freezer are used. This advice comes from Mrs. Jessie Cartwright, laundering expert and director of the Norge Home Institute. She has devised a method for freezing liquid starch in ice cube trays.
LONDON, April 25 (Reuters) -- Results of today's British football games:

There is a striking contrast between the attitudes toward the United Nations expressed during the past week by two influential women's organizations. The Daughters of the American Revolution, in addresses and resolutions, revealed a high degree of mistrust and outright hostility.

LONDON, April 25 -- Much gossip over the tea cups was devoted today to Sir Winston Churchill's new title. Opinion seems divided between those who hold that no title can enhance the splendor he has won for his own name and those who think that if he had to have a title it should have been nothing less than a dukedom.

LOGAN, Utah -- Eastern motorists studying maps in preparation for transcontinental trips next summer can, with a little planning, add considerable interest to the long cross-country drive. Already serious-minded sight-seers have begun to seek out historic sites as well as scenery in the regions athwart the Continental Divide, searching for the original crossing points used by the mountain men and pioneer emigrant trains of a hundred years ago.

LOGAN, Utah -- Eastern motorists studying maps in preparation for transcontinental trips next summer can, with a little planning, add considerable interest to the long cross-country drive. Already serious-minded sight-seers have begun to seek out historic sites as well as scenery in the regions athwart the Continental Divide, searching for the original crossing points used by the mountain men and pioneer emigrant trains of a hundred years ago.

What constitutes "a reasonable allowance for salaries," for income tax purposes, is purely a question of fact. Since it is the function of the United States Tax Court to pass upon questions of fact, the higher courts do not ordinarily disturb their findings on this issue unless the higher court determines that the Tax Court's findings are clearly erroneous.

THIS column generally has no business scratching around United Nations business, but a bone has been thrown our way and we have hungrily snatched it up. A lady we know in the U. N. told us a little about the new Secretary General's literary amours and a lot more about how handsome he was.

IN his review of the "Holmes-Laski Letters," A. A. Berle Jr. states that "in 1924, Laski had been juryman in an English libel action by a British general falsely accused of Indian atrocities." I regret to point out that this allusion is incorrect.

Infallible signs of spring in the city are the sudden eruption of glee club concerts in our local concert halls. A pleasant event of this kind was offered yesterday afternoon in Town Hall by the Centenary Singers of Centenary Junior College, Hackettstown, N. J., and the Lafayette College Choir of Easton, Pa.

At a conference organized by the New York Academy of Sciences, Dr. Raymond M. Hainer, on behalf of himself and Dr. Alfred G. Emslie and Miss Ada Jacobson, all of the Arthur D. Little Laboratories, Cambridge, Mass., told last week how reports of physiologists, psychologists and others were studied to find out how well people can smell.

Radiant heating and homes without basements are relatively new to the Northeastern United States and other areas with cold winters. They have long been accepted in California and other places with mild climate.

NOTICEABLE in interior design and architecture in this country today is the Japanese influence. Most obvious results are the translations of the modular geometric panels of Japanese sliding shoji screens to screens and walls of American homes. Five examples are pic tured here along with a photograph of an authentic Japanese interior in a contemporary Tokyo house executed in the traditional style from which these designs are derived.

TELEVISION had its official all-electronic coming-out fourteen years ago next Thursday at the formal opening of the New York World's Fair. Since then some of its peculiar lingo has permeated the American language with garish or devastating aptness.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- An increase in the volume of imports is in the national interest and should be encouraged even if some domestic industries suffer, according a proposed statement of policy drawn today for the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

THE Willamette Valley in Oregon is the source of some of the highest quality pansy seed in America. For the soil is rich, and the mild climate well suited to raising vigorous plants. But the varieties grown there are a far cry from those grandmother knew and used to call by their nicknames of heart's ease and ladies' delight.

TULSA, Okla., April 25 (AP) -- The $100,000,000 international petroleum exposition opening here on May 14 for a ten-day run is billed by its sponsors without challenge as the "world's fair of the oil industry."
The melancholy Jacques, walking in the Forest of Arden, encountered Touchstone basking in the sun. The "motley fool" drew a sundial from his pocket, as Jacques later reported --
The attitude of Louis M. Hacker, "The New Challenge to Adult Education" (April 5), causes me to fear that some of our educators in the "cultural" centers of America are misleading our people. * * *

TOKYO, April 25 -- Japan's voters registered their intention this week to continue their reliance on conservative political forces for the direction of the nation's business. By their votes they reduced the likelihood that Japan would in the near future adopt courses in domestic policy and foreign relations very different from those it has pursued in recent years.

UP and down New England they are taking out the clumsy, friendly old-fashioned telephone with its individualistic hand-crank for the local "central." In its place is coming the new-fangled, highly impersonal dial system. In Vermont, Dorset and Rutland have already "gone dial."
