For almost the first time in twenty years, the average small investor is being obliged to brush up his recollection of what is meant by "the market effect of a narrowing spread between stock and bond yields." Since the November election, bond yields have risen so sharply -- from 2.04 to 2.64 per cent on municipals -- that the man with a $10,000 taxable income may find tax-exempt bonds a better bargain than common stocks.

IF you were asked to guess the name of the performer who has been identified longest with "Porgy and Bess," you might stab at the answer by recalling Todd Duncan and Anne Brown, who played the title roles in the 1935 premiere and in the revival six years later.

When the nation's first "Do-It-Yourself Show" finished a week's run at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory in New York City last month, more than 53,000 persons -- one-third of them women -- had examined the hundreds of products on display.
Cornell's varsity crew overcame Columbia's early lead and won by half a length in their mile and three-quarter test on the Harlem yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy charged today that the State Department was spending millions to subsidize German newspapers. The Senator asserted that many of the papers had been highly critical of President Eisenhower, John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, and himself.

DURHAM, N. H., April 25 - Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Under Secretary of State, warned today that despite recent implications of a change of Soviet policies the United States should wait for clearer signs of a willingness to negotiate for peace in good faith.
Wider use of glass has served to bring striking changes in home designs and room layouts and has proved to be a bonanza to manufacturers of this material.

WITH the summer touring season just over the horizon and many thousands looking forward to burn-up the country's pavements, the Rubber Manufacturers Association comes forward with suggestions for coaxing extra service out of automobile tires.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Albert M. Cole, new head of all Federal housing, urged Senators today to kill a House-approved order to halt all new public housing. He also asked that many drastic cuts in housing funds be restored and restrictions removed.

SEOUL, Korea, April 25 (UP) -- An American jet pilot blacked out during a bombing mission over North Korea today, but a radioman on the ground directed him to drop his bombs and come in to a safe landing.

NEWARK, April 25 -- Veteran politicians in this city were surprisingly sparing today in their predictions on the outcome of the municipal elections May 12, in which twenty-six candidates are competing for the five commissionerships.
Clarence C. (Buddy) Combs, ten-goaler, led the Red Bank Polo Club to the national senior championship at the Squadron A armory last night.

NOW that we've had the opportunity to take a good polarized look at three-dimensional movies, from the sample essays of Stereo-Techniques to the all-out bombardment of the senses of the Warners "House of Wax," it is possible to do some speculating on what's in this 3-D stuff for us -- "us" being the movie-going public -- in the way of potential sights and sounds.

The shirt industry faces troubled times as retail prices edge higher, reflecting increased production costs, manufacturers said last week. The new fall lines already opened generally show price increases and the many lines that will open in the next two weeks are struggling with the price problem.

A new roof-framing method which permits the use of the upper story of a one and a half story house while dispensing with load-bearing partitions on the lower floor has been developed for the Housing and Home Finance Agency by the Small Homes Council of the University of Illinois, according to the Housing and Home Finance Agency.

A SOLID and able work on minority groups, this volume deals mainly with the Negro and the Jew in American society today. In it the authors -- professors of sociology at Oberlin College -- bring together in a manageable form numerous specialized studies

Homeowners and apartment dwellers can expect a veritable bombardment of advertisements in every media on air conditioning. Manufacturers and dealers have moved out of the infant stage in promotion as well as product.

THERE was the same barbaric callousness to it that the Roman Emperors showed during gladiatorial combat or during the feeding of the early martyrs to the lions. The Emperor Caligula could not have been more indifferent to human suffering than was Referee Tommy Rawson in Boston the other night during the "fight" between Jimmy Carter, the lightweight champion, and Tommy Collins, whose only qualification was that he was a local idol.

WADI RAMON, Israel, April 23 -- The almost unpopulated southern third of Israel is being opened up by a new road through the middle of the central and southern Negev. It has now reached into and across the gorge Wadi Ramon, sixty miles south of Beersheba, and according to present plans will reach Elath on the Gulf of Aqaba of the Red Sea in a few years.

YOUTH, it has been said, is a blunder, manhood a struggle and old age a regret. Presumably in every man's life (this reviewer is not yet old enough to know) there comes a time when he finds himself standing on this threshold of regret.

LONDON, April 25 (AP) -- Following is the text of the statement published today in Pravda and Izvestia on President Eisenhower's April 16 speech. The statement was broadcast from Moscow. ( The quotations ascribed to President Eisenhower are approximate as a result of retranslation from the Soviet newspapers.)

The trend to appliance-equipped houses gained momentum with the recent announcement that Gunnison Homes, subsidiary of United States Steel, would make all-electric kitchen and laundry facilities available to purchasers of the new models of these prefabricated steel dwellings.

THE painful approach of a birthday has led me into reminiscences of my youth and some of the girls I knew who gave color and character to the Twenties. For that period will always live in our memories as a giddy montage of their short skirts, bobbed hair, long cigarette holders and rolled stockings.

NEW CITY, N. Y., April 25 -- An "all-out" civil defense test in Rockland County, starting at 8:20 A. M. today, brought charges by William Brophy, county director of civil defense, that only twenty- eight of the forty-two civil defense districts were fully alerted to meet the simulated "attack."

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany Hall, said yesterday that 2,500 persons had called at the rent information center established last Tuesday at Tammany headquarters at 331 Madison Avenue. He said that additional thousands had visited local Democratic clubs, where similar centers have been established.

Popular approval of up-to-date equipment, labor and step-saving devices and space arrangements in new dwellings has made older-type houses harder to sell in today's competitive market, according to Mrs. Helen Bauer, head of the Banner Homes Realty Company of Teaneck. N. J.

The prospects for an extension of the International Wheat Agreement have turned decidedly dim with the formal announcement of its withdrawal by the United Kingdom from this enterprise. There were forty-two "importing" countries and four "exporting" countries in the original four-year agreement, scheduled to expire at the end of July, but the United Kingdom accounted for, roughly, one-third of their combined purchases.

ONE of the most rewarding summer-flowering bulbs is an old favorite of mine -- the dahlia. It is not extraordinary for a single plant to produce over a hundred blooms during one season. Since dahlias are subtropical natives, tubers are not planted until the weather becomes settled and warm.

GENEVA, April 25 -- East-West trade consultations here have "opened up possibilities for change in the trend in East-West trade relations" and have made a "good start toward progressive normalization of trade relations between countries of Eastern and Western Europe," a United Nations official said today.

PARIS, April 25 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi of Italy stated today that if he were returned to office next June 7 in Italy's national elections, the "first major task in the field of foreign-policy" he would assign to his new Government would be the ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty, which provides for the rearming of Western Germany in a supranational army.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 25 -- Taking first place in 13 out of 16 events, the Yale track team outclassed Dartmouth, 103 -- 37, today.

HARTFORD, April 25 -- Abraham A. Ribicoff of Hartford, former United States Representative who ran 100,000 votes ahead of his ticket in his losing bid for the United States Senate in 1952, has emerged as the leading possibility for the Democratic nomination for Governor in Connecticut in 1954.

BURSTING with color, this novel is a brilliant period piece of sixteenth - century France. The reader is introduced briefly to Fontainebleau under Francis I, and among real historical characters to Queen Eleanore, Henri, Dauphin of France; his mistress, Diane de Poitiers, and Captain Cartier, the explorer, all of whom lend a kind of authenticity to the story.

Hodding Carter in "Segregation's Way in One Town" (April 5) quite properly and pridefully records the steady progress in race relations in his home city of Greenville, Miss.. and elsewhere in the Deep South.

HANDEL did not number his own works, but there are seven groups of them which bear opus numbers notwithstanding. The numbers were put on them by publishers. Op. 1, the earliest group to be so numbered, was published in 1724 when Handel was 39.

An odd salvage case involving a burning tanker and a tug that was wrecked and lost trying to save the tanker was determined in a decision handed down last week by Judge Edward Weinfeld in the Southern District of Federal Court.

While admission to practice before the United States Supreme Court tomorrow marks a pinnacle of success for thirty Queens lawyers, it will be an especially stirring moment for Joseph Lonardo, who will enter the marble building in the nation's capital with vivid memories of his entry into the United States as a stowaway in March, 1904.
Japan is continuing her efforts to increase her merchant fleet to 4,000,000 gross tons by 1957 so her vessels can carry 50 per cent of the nation's imports, according to information from abroad.
While men today fear war, they also fear peace, John Haynes Holmes, Minister Emeritus of Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, said yesterday in his sermon there.

WASHINGTON, April 26--The Government's drive to rid the country of alien and naturalized racketeers, subversives and other undesirable persons has brought proceedings against thirty-eight individuals since it began last October, according to records tabulated today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- If negotiations for a truce and peace in Korea fail, Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, said today he favored a three-step program to bring the fighting to an end.

PARIS, April 26 -- The official report of the European Payments Union for March shows a trend toward balance in the payments of the member nations, which is considered a favorable sign for the future of this organization.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 26 (AP) -- Al Besselink of Grossinger, N. Y., confronted with the richest putt of his life on the eighteenth green, sank it safely and took the $10,000 first prize in the $35,000 Tournament of Champions here today.

The American Radio Association, C. I. O., told its membership yesterday that the question of shipboard radiotelephone would be the major hurdle in getting a new contract to follow the present two-year agreement that expires June 15.

Motifs from the American past inspired some fresh-looking patterns for a new collection of fabrics and matching wallpapers designed by Virginia Hammill. The materials, executed in spring-like colorings, are available through decorators at the S. M. Hexter showroom, 509 Madison Avenue.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 26 -- Brig. Gen. Mahmud Afshartous, chief of Iran's police, who disappeared last Monday night, was found dead of strangulation today. A number of retired Army generals and politicians opposed to Premier Mohammed Mossadegh have been implicated in the crime.
Two Detroit tool companies announced over the week-end the creation of a third company to design and build machinery and tools to reduce costs in automatic manufacturing.
NEW ORLEANS, April 26 (AP) -- A woman here is living with glands of a guinea pig transplanted into her body, a surgeon disclosed today.

The New York waterfront and Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., were defended yesterday as longshoremen, checkers and other workers assembled in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for their fourth annual communion breakfast.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Diplomatic officials were not encouraged by summaries reaching here today of the Communists' six-point counter-proposal for exchanging war prisoners in Korea. They will, of course, take a long look at official reports, when they arrive, in the hope that study may suggest some new opening for a solution not apparent at first glance.
The opening today in Egypt of the Anglo-Egyptian discussions about the British bases and garrisons in the Suez Canal zone marks the beginning of a new chapter in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- President Eisenhower, in high good humor, today helped 600 "fellow Texans" to celebrate San Jacinto Day with animadversions at the Senate speeches by foes of the offshore oil bill and observations on the after-dinner speech.

An increase in the number of cases of juvenile delinquency handled by the Children's Court in recent years was caused in part by the heavy migration to New York from Puerto Rico, Presiding Justice John Warren Hill of the Court of Domestic Relations declared yesterday in the twentieth annual report of that tribunal.

The Liberal party intends to run its own candidate for Mayor in the city campaign this fall and does not expect to endorse either the Democratic or the Republican nominee, Adolf A. Berle Jr., State Chairman, declared yesterday.

Maurice Evans brought his short version of "Hamlet" to television yesterday afternoon over the N. B. C. network, and it made for memorable and exciting viewing. Edited down to slightly more than an hour and a half, the tragedy was played for its sheer dramatic value and proved superbly arresting theatre.

The church and the nation, "nurtured in the same cradle" since their founding, have been on a long pilgrimage to find "the peace and righteousness which is ineradicable in men's hearts," the Rev. Dr. Hermann N. Morse, Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A., declared yesterday.

The Government's new Consumer Price ("cost of living") Index showed a slight upturn in the month ended on March 15, according to the monthly news release of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. There is no reason to suppose, however, that this minor change of direction will restore the 1950-1952 popularity among labor leaders of the
ALBANY, April 26 -- State Comptroller J. Raymond McGovern announced today that an issue of $125,000,000 state guaranteed Thruway bonds, the first of its kind, will be sold May 5.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, reported today an "upsurge" of 8.2 per cent in major crimes in 1952.

The interim fares now being charged on the private bus lines operating under city franchises will be extended today by the Board of Estimate until midnight June 30. These fares--12 cents on buses of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and 10 cents on all other lines--otherwise would lapse at midnight Thursday.

PARIS, April 26 -- The possibility of eventual differences between the Soviet Union and Communist China over Chinese economic development, territorial problems, leadership in Asia and doctrinal questions was examined by the fourteen nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization at the council meeting that terminated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- G. Bromley Oxnam, Methodist Bishop, and Representative Donald J. Jackson met in debate today as to whether criticism of the Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives was justified.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 26 -- The Government published today a revised draft of the law on freedom of religion, stressing that it was based on recommendations of leaders of the Serbian Orthodox Church and the Islam religious community.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, April 26 -- The Communist proposal for a truce spelled out at the conference tabe this afternoon has serious deficiencies from the point of view of the United Nations Command. It will probably have to be modified radically.

WASHINGTON, April 26--Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota is turning out to be the "surprise" of the Eisenhower team. As Director of the Mutual Security Agency, in charge of the Administration's foreign aid programs, he is on the rise again after a long stretch on the political skids.

A plea for a national maritime policy that will include greater consideration for the unsubsidized segment of this country's merchant fleet, particularly 200 tramping vessels, was made yesterday by F. Riker Clark, president of the American Tramp Shipowners Association.
I read with much interest the article you had in your April 22 issue concerning Edna Ferber's statement that this city is the filthiest in the world and I most heartily agree with her.

From the Travelers Insurance Company's latest annual study of traffic accidents we learn that 37,600 persons were killed in 1952 on our streets and highways -- the third consecutive year in which there was an increase in the traffic death toll. For the first time in history we had more than two million traffic casualties.

LONDON, April 26 -- Since the budget, the stock markets have moved erratically. Market men and investors generally have been busy endeavoring to work out the implications of the budget as it affects individual companies and groups of companies.

Although the sun shone only part of the time at Ebbets Field yesterday, it still was more brilliant than the two teams who played there for nearly three hours, with the Dodgers outscoring the Giants in their "rubber" game, 8 -- 4.

I am in complete agreement with Edna Ferber's statement about the disgusting filth in New York, my native city. I, too, spent many weeks in Europe last summer and when I returned home I had exactly the same reaction as did Miss Ferber. I felt ashamed of my city.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified ninety-two Korean war casualties in a new list that reported twenty-one killed, fifty-one wounded, five missing, five injured and ten captured. The following casualties were from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

The four young singers who appeared under the banner of "Aristo Artists" late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall not only upheld the standards of Aristos of other years, but, if anything, raised those standards a little higher. All four were exceptionally talented.

A campaign that should enlist wide support is the annual drive of the Greater New York Fund, which opens today. The 423 voluntary hospitals and health and welfare agencies in New York that participate in the fund will need this year the sizable sum of $223,000,000 to provide their various essential services.

Peace must be fought for with the same courage and devotion that soldiers exhibit on the battlefield, Lieut. Col. George W. L. Townsend told Australians and New Zealanders here yesterday at Anzac Day ceremonies in the Anzac Garden atop the British Building in Rockefeller Center.

Louis Hollander, president of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations, observed a triple anniversary yesterday with announcement of his election for an eleventh two-year term as manager of the New York joint board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America.

Our editorial position has been made clear and has been stated more than once. We believe that in the debate over the return of the oil tidelands to the states the Senate minority is in the right and the presumptive majority in the wrong. We have urged the defeat of the measure and would support its veto if and when it were passed.

De Leuw and Brill, machinede-I signers, floor in 227 E 44th St, / through Ruland ' and Benjamin,' agents; Small Shop, gifts, throughl Julian Gordon, agent, store in 1034J Madison Ave -- Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc, brokers.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today that labor unions were "not disturbed" by the wage cuts they were taking under escalator contracts based on the cost of living.

There is more than special interest in the recent experience of this country's tool and die industry, as recounted recently in Washington. A month and a half ago 80 per cent of this fundamental industry's business represented defense orders. Here surely, one would suppose, is a case in which any drop in military orders would represent catastrophe.

BRESCIA, Italy, April 26 (AP) -- A French driver and a boy were killed and twelve others were injured in accidents today in the running of Italy's Mille Miglia (thousand mile) auto race, won by Italy's Giannino Marzotto in a Ferrari.

A long-pending dispute over the membership application of a former Vienna speech specialist, Dr. Godfrey Edward Arnold, is expected to break loose tonight at the regular monthly meeting of the Medical Society of the County of New York.

The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers called on the new Transit Authority yesterday to free the municipal subway system from control by a "scandalous alliance of politicians representing certain machine organizations and a certain coterie of reactionary union leaders."

This week's art program is dominated by the large exhibition, "Sculpture of the Twentieth Century," which opens at the Museum of Modern Art on Wednesday. More than ninety pieces of sculpture by outstanding American and European artists are included and many of them will be shown in the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden, which has been redesigned.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 26 -- The trial of two trees versus some of the citizens of Connecticut will open tomorrow night in the Town Hall Meeting Room. The case will be tried before Joseph A. Dietrich, tree warden of Greenwich, who will be both judge and jury.

Six high school students and Fannie Hurst, the novelist, explored the subject of what constitutes good manners and whether today's young people are mannerly enough, on the New York Times Youth Forum on television last night.

A note in the news colums reporting the departure for London of this city's No. 1 counter of horn toots, Ernest H. Peabody -- who says that on an average day he can count a horn blaring unnecessarily every second and a half on Fifth Avenue -- has moved a scout to look into the business of automobile horns and how they grew.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 26 -- The customary Sunday calm at the Statler Hotel in Los Angeles gave way to noisy hustle and bustle today as committee members of the Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers completed arrangements to accommodate more than 1,000 scientists, engineers and technicians, a record number, who are registering for a week's conference, beginning tomorrow.

BONN, April 26 -- Sources close to the German Federal Government defended tonight the right of the German press to hold divergent views on all subjects. These sources were replying to Senator Joseph E. McCarthy's assertions that the United States State Department was helping finance some newspapers that were highly critical of President Eisenhower, John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, and the Wisconsin Republican Senator himself.

Congratulations upon your timely editorial, "Crisis in Pakistan," appearing in the issue of April 19. The closing sentence, "Pakistan will weather this storm, but Pakistan may need help and it should be given," has particular meaning to the voluntary American agencies working in Pakistan as one of the channels for people-to-people help.

CHICAGO, April 26 (UP) -- Bill Serena smashed a two-run homer in the seventh inning today to enable the Cubs to gain a 7-to-5 victory over the Cardinals before 6,692 fans who shivered in 42-degree weather.

ITHACA, N. Y., April 26 -- The small communities of New York are in a process of transition, it was agreed at several meetings concerned with small towns and villages at the recent Cornell Farm and Home Week here.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 26 -- Explaining his resignation as chief of staff of the United Nations group supervising the truce in the Arab-Israeli war, Lieut. Gen. William E. Riley, United States Marine Corps (retired), said today: "The time has come for me to get back to the States and take a rest. This kind of job is not easy on the nerves, you know."

It happens every spring. As soon as the snow disappears, out come bats, balls and other baseball gear. It may be a biting, cold day in March or a blustery one in early April, still, on campuses -- or sandlots for that matter -- youngsters may be found getting in spring training under conditions more conducive to pneumonia.

The vogue successfully initiated by "Don Juan in Hell" as a dramatic reading program was bound to spread eventually into the musical field. In a song and dance bill tentatively named "An Evening With Victor Herbert," the entertainment will utilize the services of Lionel Barrymore, it was announced yesterday by the newly formed Triumph Productions, consisting of Anna Sosenko, Jay Lurye and Kenneth Allen.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Friend and foe of the proposal to recognize state claims to offshore oil hoped tonight that a break in Senate debate would result from a test vote scheduled for tomorrow -- the nineteenth day of argument.
BONN, Germany, April 26 -- The Free Democratic party, the second party in Chancellor Adenauer's Government coalition, has embarked on a purge of Nazis in its ranks.
Ground was broken yesterday afternoon at Gold and Nassau Streets, Brooklyn, for an edifice for the interdenominational Church of the Open Door. The site adjoins that of the Farragut Housing project.

Seven members of a family, all of whom had emergency treatment at Knickerbocker Hospital for poisoning Saturday night, rushed back to the same hospital yesterday to clear up a second case of collective poisoning. The police traced the trouble last night to a leaky line in a gas refrigerator.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The load of work on the Government's investigating agencies has seriously delayed the selection of President Eisenhower's own slate of United States Ambassadors and diplomatic chiefs around the world.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- The Senate Democratic leader, Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, said today that the legislative record of the Eisenhower Administration so far was "scarcely a record of accomplishment."

ST. LOUIS, April 26 (AP) -- The White Sox, held to two hits for eight innings, broke loose with four hits in the ninth for a 3-0 second game victory over St. Louis today after the Browns had taken the opener, 7 -- 2.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 26 (AP) -- The Kentucky Derby, which will be run at Churchill Downs for the seventy-ninth time on Saturday, shaped up today as a two-horse race, although as many as twelve 3-year-olds may answer the call to Boots and Saddles for the $100,000-added mile-and-a-quarter classic.
TOKYO, Monday, April 27 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,597, for the twenty-four hours to 6. A. M., Monday, Korean time:

TUNIS, Tunisia, April 24 -- The rural elections in Tunisia ended yesterday to the advantage of the Government and the French residency. The nationalists of the Neo-Destour party and of the Tunisian Trade Union Federation suffered a setback.

The feast day of St. George -- England's patron saint -- was celebrated yesterday at the New York Cathedral (Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine) with a colorful parade and evensong service dedicated to "affirming our ancient ties with the British Commonwealth."

The labor committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York recommended yesterday that the Taft-Hartley Act be changed to give states the right to enforce laws of their own dealing with picketing, jurisdictional strikes, enforcement of collective bargaining agreements and a broad range of other labor issues.

TOKYO, Monday, April 27 (AP) -- A top United Nations Public Information Office spokesman said today the first American sick and wounded prisoners of war released in the Panmunjom exchange would be flown to the United States "this week for sure and probably within the next couple of days."

The thirty-five-voice Cappella Russian Male Chorus, which gave its first New York concert in December, 1949, was heard in a program Saturday night at Town Hall, which was attended by 1,000 persons. Nicholas V. Borodulia conducted.

MILAN, April 26 -- For the fifth year in succession the Milan Trade Fair, greatest merchandising organization in Europe, has established a new record for the number of exhibitors, 11,270 participating, against 10,393 in 1952.

According to the records, Conrad Marrero, the roly-poly right-hander of the Senators, will be 36 years old on Thursday. Casey Stengel, who, along with 21,759 fans at the Stadium yesterday, saw the Cuban-born "junkman" snap the Yankees' five-game winning streak with a 5-4 decision, insists that somewhere along the line Marrero neglected to count nine years.

TOKYO, Monday, April 27 -- The United Nations told the Chinese and North Korean Communists at a fifty-two-minute session today. that their six-point plan for settling the dispute over prisoners of war -- the last issue holding up an armistice in Korea -- was "unreasonable and obstructive."

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Withdrawal of the blanket endorsement of United Nations' action in Korea and its replacement by a demand that every member nation furnish military forces and other aid "proportionate to its ability" was recommended to the Chamber of Commerce of the United States by its policy committee.

A sudden increase in textile buying helped to pull the cotton futures market out of a developing slump last week. Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange ended the five-day trading period with net gains of 20 cents to $2.50 a bale. Most of the gains were made on Friday.
Acts of vandalism against the New York Central System, which have been plaguing the railroad since the advent of spring, broke out anew yesterday in the Bronx.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, April 27 (AP) -- United States infantrymen early today smashed a company-sized North Korean Communist assault on the east-central front and beat off four smaller Red thrusts elsewhere.

The first of three evenings of modern music, presented under the auspices of Rosalyn Tureck, was heard Saturday in the North Room of the Town Hall Club. The program was an extension of the evenings of modern music that Miss Tureck held in her home last year.

CLEVELAND, April 26 (AP) -- Bob Feller and Bob Lemon hurled victories over the Tigers today, 2 -- 1 and 12 -- 2, to extend the Indians' winner streak to five games. The triumphs put Cleveland into the league lead by 28 percentage points, although the Indians trail the Yanks by a half game in the won and lost columns.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 26 -- Trygve Lie, who retired recently as Secretary General of them United Nations, predicted today that there would be no settlement in Korea except in relation to other issues involving the Far East, and then only if Communist China was a party to it.

BUENOS AIRES, April 26 (UP) -- The arrest in Salta of Jose L. Nougues, former Governor of Tucuman Province, today increased to eighty-five the number of critics of the Argentine Government known to have been jailed in recent weeks.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 26 -- French-officered Laotian troops have evacuated the post of Banse, fifty-seven miles northeast of Luang Prabang in the midst of the continuing Vietminh advance on the royal Laotian capital, a French military spokesman announced tonight.

The fifty-sixth annual dinner of the Citizens Union of New York City will be held tonight in the Henry Hudson Room of the Roosevelt. Proceeds will be used to pay the administrative expenses of the organization, a volunteer, non-partisan representative of the public's interests in city and state government.
The Seagram-Distillers Corporation announced yesterday that its retail prices of whiskies here would go up 5 to 10 cents a bottle on July 1.

PARIS, Monday, April 27 -- A show of Communist voting strength and evident losses by the followers of Gen. Charles de Gaulle to former Premier Antoine Pinay's Independents and to the Radical group featured the early returns from municipal elections throughout France yesterday.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 26 (AP) -- Top-ranked Gardnar Mulloy successfully defended his River Oaks tennis honors today against second-ranked Vic Seixas.

Dr. James M. O'Neill, speaking to 600 members of the Catholic Institute of the Press at their ninth annual communion breakfast yesterday, cautioned against "the false cries of censorship" that, he said, have confused recent public controversies.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 (UP) -- The Phillies, with Robin Roberts winning, 7 -- 5, and Karl Drews triumphing, 8 -- 1, swept both ends of a double-header with the Pirates today to run their winning streak to eight straight -- the Phils' longest victory string in five seasons.

THE Metropolitan Opera House, gone dark with its seventieth season just ended, is no more melancholy than Miss Mathilde Weber, who has held one of her family's three opera seats since the Met opened in 1883. She says, "I live in fear that it may never open again."
Nine films, including importations from Britain and Italy, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. They follow:

BONN, Germany, April 26 -- Confident that there will soon be a chance to reunite Germany through talks with the Soviet Union, the German Socialists will wage a last-ditch fight against any foreign policy commitments by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer affecting the future of a government of a unified Germany.

Pan American World Airways, Inc., had net earnings of $6,673,000 in 1952, after provision of $4,420,000 for Federal income taxes, according to the annual report of Juan T. Trippe, the airline's president, mailed to stockholders over the week-end. The 1952 earnings, which equaled $1.09 a share on the common stock, compared with $6,546,000, or $1.07, for 1951.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony concluded its 1952-53 season yesterday afternoon with a concert at Carnegie Hall that brought its total to 125 this season and a grand total of 5,180 concerts in 111 seasons.

It is possible, of course, that the Communists really want a truce in Korea. The initial exchange of views, however, as the truce talks were resumed at Panmunjom, does not warrant any high optimism. The United Nations suggestion that Switzerland might properly serve as a designated neutral to have temporary custody of prisoners who refused repatriation was promptly rejected by the Communists.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:So that the public can properly appraise the work of the Dewey State Crime Commission, one item among many might be borne in mind. The "super-colossal" and dramatic explorations by Judge Proskauer's Commission have most fortuitously led the public to the possible matrix of the waterfront problem, commonly known as the "shape-up."

LONDON, April 26 -- The future of Britain's ship tonnage is "being endangered by the impossibility of setting aside enough money to provide for the heavy cost of replacement," the Cunard Steamship Company's chairman, Frederic Alan Bates, declared today in his annual statement.

Four thousand persons saw Cardinal Spellman dedicate yesterday the new School of the Visitation, a parochial elementary school, at West 239th Street and Putnam Avenue in the Marble Hill section of the Bronx.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., April 26 -- A full-scale Senate investigation into last November's electoral contest between Senator Dennis Chavez, Democrat, and Maj. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley, Republican, will begin tomorrow with the arrangement, at a public session here, of the mechanics for a recount of more than 200,000 votes cast.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., April 26 -- Mrs. Junius Morgan of Glen Cove had the winner of the Labrador Retriever Club's open all-age stake in Woodcroft Inga's Bonus today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 26 -- Following is a summary of major decisions taken at the seventh session of the United Nations General Assembly, which concluded action on its agenda last Thursday and recessed:

On March 19 President Eisenhower announced the designation of Lewis W. Douglas as head of a study group to re-examine the nation's foreign economic policy and to recommend changes required to strengthen the free world.

Last night's Carnegie Hall piano recital by Vytautas Bacevicius was his sixth in that auditorium. Mr. Bacevicius had one of his own sonatas on the program, as well as more standard works by Bach-Buelow, Scarlatti, Chopin, Liszt, Ravel and Debussy.

PARIS, April 26 -- Immediate assistance for the defense of Laos in the form of additional American transport planes for moving troops and further material aid for the war in Indo-China in the coming fiscal year seemed certain after a two-hour conference today between two members of the United States Cabinet and three French Ministers.

SOME novels are born historical. These are generally the costumed affairs of swords and poses. Some have an air of being historical unmercifully thrust upon them. These are the victims of changing fashions. Some achieve historical eminence. These are rarer. They are the novels that break fresh ground, inaugurate unmistakable styles, open new ways of telling the grave and comic story of man's existence, his squalor and his gallantry.

Ninety-five educational and cultural institutions in thirty-three foreign countries have begun preparations to celebrate with Columbia University next year the theme of its bicentennial, "Man's Right to Knowledge and the Free Use Thereof," it was announced yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia.

Two persons were killed and a third seriously injured yesterday at 6:35 A. M., when their automobile skidded on a wet road, mounted a dividing island on the Henry Hudson Parkway, between Seventy - seventh and Seventy-eighth Streets, and knocked down two electric light poles, the police reported.

" Report on Mao's China," by Frank Moraes, has been scheduled for May 26 publication by Macmillan. Mr. Moraes, a barrister-at-law of Lincoln's Inn and editor of The Times of India, a 114-year-old newspaper, was one of a group of Indians who were invited last year by Mao Tse-tung on a five-week tour of the country.

MEXICO CITY, April 25 -- The long-predicted crisis in the Mexican mining industry has overtaken the new government of President Ruiz Cortines, which has just announced that it was preparing a long-range plan to revive the industry, including immediate relief through lower taxes.

Every year we have one or two new books called "The Development of Economic Thought" or "A History of Economic Thought."* This is encouraging. It shows that, despite current evidence to the contrary, there are still people in this country willing respectfully to consider the ideas of others.

The City of New York publishes today its "Official Directory," popularly known as "The Little Green Book," a pocket-sized volume of 704 pages, listing key officials of the city, as well as state and Federal agencies, their qualifications, who appoints them, their length of term, date of expiration of term, how they may be removed, and how vacancies are filled.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on roll calls in Congress during the period April 18 to April 24 are given in the appended tabulation.

Owning several festive-looking tops and skirts and interchanging them in unexpected ways will previde the answer to a problem facing the young matrons or debutantes who can only afford one good evening dress a year but who want to appear in a new dress at many summer parties.

President Eisenhower, in deciding to send his brother Dr. Milton Eisenhower as a special envoy to study United States relations with Latin America, has demonstrated his awareness of a situation that has worried some United States diplomats for many months.

The vacant plot at 128-30 Hicks Street, near Clark Street, in Brooklyn, has been purchased by Jacob Mark and Sons for improvement with a new apartment building. This is one of the few available apartment sites in the Borough Hall section.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- The grain markets appeared to be going through a leveling-off process last week, bearish influences having been discounted by recent price declines. At the end of the period price changes were small.

Charles W. Halloran, president of the Buffalo Federation of Labor, charged here yesterday that "irresponsible" leadership of some unions had caused "more tyranny and chaos" in the American labor movement today than ever before in its history.

The blue and orange banners that deck flagstaffs all over the city today are there to remind you that the appeal of the Greater New York Fund is under way. The flags symbolize the opening of the biggest annual local, non-sectarian campaign.

AT least a hundred times since the start of this new baseball season the base runner on second base ran half way to third while a fly ball was being lofted to the enemy outfield. Then he scampered back to the bag while the outfielder made the catch just as expected. Why does the runner always advance half way to the next base? It's as purposeless and as senseless a maneuver as anyone could imagine.

LONDON, April 26 -- A five-year domestic political program calling for still more socialism in business was adopted today by the National Executive Committee of the British Labor party which during its post-war term of office nationalized the coal, steel, railroad, trucking and power industries among others.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 26 -- The Boulder Brook Club awarded nine championship ribbons this afternoon and tonight to cap its annual spring horse show, a two-day affair that drew a record crowd of over 1,000 to the arena on Old Mamaroneck Road.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Residents of New York State pay more state taxes for every man, woman and child than do their nightbors in New Jersey and Connecticut.
After twenty-eight years at 1457 Broadway, Arthur S. and Irwin Thomases, brokers and garage property specialists, will move their offices on Friday to 1790 Broadway.

BONN, April 26 (AP) -- The State Department has recalled one of the top officials of the United States High Commission in Germany for questioning by Senator McCarthy's Senate Investigation Committee, American officials said today.

A series of ten letters exchanged by Pope Pius XII and former President Harry S. Truman has been privately printed in book form by Myron C. Taylor, personal representative to the Vatican from 1940 to 1950 for both Mr. Truman and Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

Joseph Cole, baritone, who made his debut here five years ago, gave his second New York recital last night at Town Hall. Accompanied by William Browning, he sang a Purcell group. Brahm "Vier Ernste Gessenge"; Faure's "L'Horizon Chimerique" and spirituals arranged by himself.

New Yorkers enjoyed yesterday the warmest day so far this year, with a bright sun breaking through cloudy skies after more than a half inch of early morning rain and sending afternoon temperatures up to 74 degrees.

Two identical installation ceremonies were conducted yesterday at the True Light Chinese Lutheran Church, 195 Worth Street, when the Rev. Paul Chang was made an assistant to the pastor, the Rev. Louis T. Buchheimer.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- A Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee said today that recent Russian peace moves might furnish a cloak for increased spy activity in the United States and other free countries.

PARIS, April 25 -- The story of Nina Ricci's midsummer showing centers around cottons and the way they are combined with silk chiffon or organdy, wool jersey or felt. For instance, black wool jersey making a camisole bodice is repeated as a border on the hemline of a swirling cotton skirt that is a photographic print of an old-fashioned patchwork quilt of many colors.

EDMONTON, April 26 (Canadian Press)--Edgar Dame of Revere, Mass., set his third record last night at the 1953 North American indoor speed-skating championships to win the senior men's title. Nineteen records were shattered in the three-day meet.
BAKERSFIELD, Calif., April 26 (UP) -- Louise Suggs of Atlanta defeated Patty Berg of St. Andrews, Ill., in a sudden-death play-off today for the top purse in Bakersfield's invitation golf tournament.
City Council President Rudolph Halley called yesterday for a rejection of the 1953-1954 budget in its entirety, terming it "the joint product of Dewey arrogance and Impellitteri incompetence."

The spring publishing season for cookbooks is off to a good start with the appearance this week of Hazel Meyer's "The Complete Book of Home Freezing," (Lippincott, 456 pp., $4.95). Miss Meyer has written such a complete book, in fact, that one is almost overwhelmed by her range of reference and her inclusion of countless details.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Monday, April 27 (AP) -- Following is the official text of the Communist proposal yesterday to settle the dispute over prisoners of war in Korea:

CHICAGO, April 26 -- The International City Managers Association reported here today that seventy cities established off-street parking lots for the first time in 1952. It was declared to be part of a steady trend in municipalities to meet the increasing demand for parking space.

Foreign exchange market passed through one of the dullest trading sessions in some time during the past week. Rates moved within a limited range and the amount of business reported was relatively light.
PITTSBURGH, April 26 -- With the first month of the second quarter about gone there is no sign of a slackening in steel demand. Steel production has not kept pace with the flow of new orders.

CRISTOBAL, C. Z., April 26 -- Nine hundred officers and enlisted men of First Battalion Combat Team, Fourth Regiment, Eighty-second Airborne Division, will reach France Field near here tomorrow for a month of training in jungle warfare under the tutelage of Canal Zone troops.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 26 -- Dr. Hadley C. Cantril, a leading social psychologist, has been named chairman of Princeton University's Department of Psychology, it was reported today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the University. Professor Cantril, director of the Office of Public Opinion Research, succeeds Dr. Carroll C. Pratt.

President Eisenhower has been asked by Mayor Impellitteri to exercise his influence to prevent termination of the Federal public housing program on July 1 with resultant damage to the city's slum clearance program and its construction industry.

THE NETHERLANDS, April 26 -- Early introduction of Royal Dutch Petroleum Company shares on Wall Street has become uncertain, according to the Amsterdam Daily Telegraaf. The main reason given is that New York authorities seem to consider the Royal Dutch debenture loan as an obstacle, because of previous unfavorable experiences with holding companies having such loans -- especially public utilities.
ALBANY, April 26 (AP) -- Senator Thomas C. Desmond, who is 65 years old, contended tonight that the age of 70 was "more accurately the beginning of old age" than the generally accepted 65.
TOKYO, Monday, April 27 (AP) -- An American soldier said yesterday that of one group of 165 Americans in a North Korean prison camp, Seventeen openly took to communism.

MILFORD, Conn., April. 26 -- The calm of this 300-year-old community at the mouth of the Housatonic River is being ruffled by controversy between the forces of business bustle and those residents who would preserve Milford's pastoral charms.

CAIRO, April 26 -- Two diplomats and two soldiers will meet here tomorrow in an effort to reconcile Egypt's demands for the immediate departure of British military forces from the Suez Canal zone with the reluctance of Britain and her allies to surrender all interest in the base that has formed the kingpin of Middle East defense strategy.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) -- Senator J. William Fulbright said today that the Administration should go slow in "uprooting" the overseas information programs from the State Department and putting them under a new agency.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- A high tariff supporter testified today that an increase in sale of foreign goods here -- as urged by United States allies and some Administration leaders -- would bring "disaster" to the American economy.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- O. R. Strackbein, a witness before a Congressional committee, today accused some segment of the press of distorting news in favor of a freer trade policy.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today, in effect, rejected a petition of the railroads that they be allowed to make permanent a 15 per cent increase in freight rates, granted in April, 1952, to expire on Feb. 28, 1954.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee said today it had uncovered a story of wartime Communist espionage in a General Motors plant in Detroit involving a cook, a dishwasher's assistant and others.

LONDON, April 27 -- The stock market here began the week on a dull note today with demand concentrated in tobacco, brewery, aircraft and colliery shares, which had minor gains. Nearly all other groups lost ground.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 27 -- Harold J. Adonis, former executive clerk to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, testified today before an Amsterdam court examining new evidence supporting a request by the United States for his extradition.

The Shelvon Aircraft Products Corporation, of Great Neck, L. I, offered $100,000 to the Maritime Administration yesterday for the Government - owned refrigerated cargo ship Gommet Reefer that grounded and split in two off Leghorn, Italy, last December.

The American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Academy, dedicated to the task of raising funds for the establishment of a Shakespearean center in Connecticut, is planning to send out next season two full-length Shakespearean productions, possibly "Hamlet" and "Macbeth," and its bill of highlights from the Bard's works, "An Evening with Will Shakespeare."

Prices of United States Government securities sustained their biggest setback yesterday since the Federal Reserve System stopped supporting the price of the Treasury's longer-term bonds at 100 in March, 1951.

PARIS, April 27 -- Fashions outstanding in Jacques Griffes' mid-season collection were his summer cottons, many in floral designs on pique, some striped in gray and white. The presentation, which took place yesterday afternoon, showed a pleasing feeling for youthfulness of style. There was grace of movement in the skirts, which were circular, gored or pleated and flaring to a wide hem. Generally they were smooth at the waist and hips.

WASHINGTON, April 27 - President Eisenhower has asked a Congressional study of possible "serious and inequitable restrictions" in the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act, including that section the Justice Department has interpreted as barring Communists from admission to the United States but admitting Nazis and Fascists.

The Kelvinator division of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation has cut back production of its Kelvinator and Leonard refrigerators, a division spokesman revealed yesterday. He did not disclose the extent of the cutback except to say that 400 employes at the refrigerator and electric range plant in Grand Rapids, Mich., had been laid off.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 27 (AP) -- Top-seeded Gardner Mulloy of Miami, Fla., and second-seeded Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., led the victory parade of the favorites today in the opening round of the San Antonio Country Club invitational tennis tournament.
Three hundred and sixty-eight unprepared Boy Scouts turned a would-be triumphal march into a near-fiasco yesterday afternoon at the opening of the Greater New York Fund campaign.

One need feel no sympathy with the politics of those May Day marchers who are seeking to protect their license to march (or, if Mr. Monaghan is correct, the right to obtain one) to support them against the Commissioner.

Steve Weinstein, a lefthander, pitched the finest game of his career yesterday as he led City College to a 3-to-2 victory over Wagner in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference affair at McCombs Dam Park. The loss was Wagner's first of the season in league play after three victories.

Col. Arthur Edwin Young, Commissioner of the City of London Police, predicted yesterday that the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II on June 2 would give the police there the greatest crowd-control problem they ever faced.

BONN, Germany, April 27 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has been forced to decide to send the Allied-West German treaties back to the Bundestag, or lower house of Parliament, and to ask that body if it will join the Bundesrat, or upper house, in seeking an advisory opinion from the Federal Constitutional Court on the pacts' constitutionality

MOSCOW, Tuesday, April 28 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov told the Soviet-supported peace-partisan organization that Russia favored its appeal for a five-power peace pact, Soviet newspapers said today.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- A Senate Appropriations subcommittee decided to summon Lincoln White, State Department press officer, for questioning tomorrow concerning his account of Charles W. Thayer's resignation as consul general at Munich.

PARIS, April 27 -- It is apparent that the Cominform, which administers foreign Communist parties for the Kremlin, is tending to show some effects of the new international political atmosphere resulting from recent Soviet gestures.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The opponents of state control of offshore lands received a 56-to-33 setback today as the Senate voted on their chief counter proposal in the four-week debate.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- A brisk upturn in May wheat carried other deliveries up to a less extent, and there were also fractional upturns in the feed grains. In all pits, buyers were chary of pressing the rallies, and from the top levels the market receded moderately.

Secretary of State Dulles has been able to tell French Cabinet officials that President Eisenhower will shortly send to Congress recommendations for increased help in Indo-China. At the moment the most urgent military need is transport, and especially transport planes.

LONDON, April 27 (UP) -- Prime Minister Churchill's Conservative Government won final passage tonight of the bill to denationalize transport after invoking the "guillotine" to cut off debate in the House of Commons.

BUENOS AIRES, April 27 -- Shortly after the Radical party ended its convention today the police arrested Dr. Santiago H. El Castillo, chairman of the party's National Executive Committee, and Dr. Luis R. MacKay, the party's secretary.

CHICAGO, April 27 (AP) -- Presidents of four major college athletic conferences tonight asked the North Central Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools to "immediately suspend its proposed enforcement procedures."

The Suez Canal set a new traffic record last year when 86,137,000 net register tons of shipping, or 4,300,000 tons more than during the previous peak year of 1950, passed through it. The canal links the Mediterranean with the Red Sea.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Public tests of three-dimensional television were authorized today by the Federal Communications Commission.
NEWARK, April 27 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court did a legalistic strip-tease today that reduced burlesque to its fundamentals.

There was a reminiscent return to the era of stately living at the Jamaica race track yesterday when the fiftieth anniversary of that popular oval was observed with a program that was headed by the Blackstock Handicap. This handicap was named after William C. Whitney's winner of the first Excelsior Handicap, run on April 27, 1903.

O. K., there has been a great deal of rain. During the month of March the officially recorded downfall in New York was surpassed only by the Biblically recorded floating of the Ark. The first part of April also followed in line, and while it is not yet possible to speak of records for the month, the ground certainly is not parched.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Eisenhower Cabinet team returned today from its first meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to report to the President and the Congress its conviction that the Western defense organization now would be run "with greater firmness, greater strength and greater economy."
LONDON, April 27 -- Another quarrel over relations with the United States is brewing in the British Parliament.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call by which the Senate, 56 to 33, voted today to table the combined Anderson and Hill amendments to the offshore oil lands bill. The Anderson amendment would have eliminated sections establishing state title to the lands and would have substituted Federal control.

In refusing coalition with the Republicans regardless of their candidate in the Mayoral election this year the Liberal party has chosen a course that is illiberal, autocratic, detrimental to the best interests of the people of New York and, if persisted in, virtually certain to guarantee the re-election of our present incompetent Mayor.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., April 27 -- Three-dimensional motion pictures hold the possibility of both revealing and helping to correct unsuspected vision difficulties among as many as 15 per cent of the American public, the Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers was told today.

THE Soviets are still camping out in the looted palaces of the Czars. They talk brightly about the future and live darkly behind the battlements of the past. This is a main impression one gets from reading Frank Rounds Jr.'s new book, "A Window on Red Square."*

Emotional and physical problems resulting from the rapid growth of teen-agers were discussed last night by Dr. Lawrence I. Kaplan, a neuro-psychiatrist, who is director of the neurological service at the Hospital of Joint Diseases. He gave particular emphasis to emotional problems.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Senator John W. Bricker, Republican of Ohio, said today that officials of the American Bar Association had been called in to help rewrite his proposed Constitutional Amendment to limit treaty-making powers.
Edward T. Hile and Harry H. Yeater have been elected directors of Harbison-Walker Refractories Company. Preston C. Mitchell has been elected vice president in charge of mining operations.

Harry E. Yerkes, passenger traffic manager of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, announced yesterday that, effective May 28, higher fares would be charged for commuters traveling solely in New Jersey on that road and the New York and Long Branch Railroad, which it operates.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, disconcerted an overflow luncheon gathering of delegates of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States here today by telling them bluntly that their organization's "cash" plan for balancing the budget and cutting taxes was not feasible.
Harvie Ward, the defending champion, and Frank Stranahan, a two-time winner, head a twenty-nine man United States delegation entered in the British amateur golf tournament at Hoylake, May 25-30.

Sears, Roebuck Co. expects no over-all retail price cuts this year, Robert E. Wood, chairman, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting. He added that the company expects prices in the fall catalogue to be around last year's levels.

Dressed in a red, white and blue "Miss Liberty" gown, Mrs. Robert A. Vogeler yesterday received the crown she is to wear Saturday in the sixth annual Loyalty Day parade. The "coronation" took place at the New Yorker Hotel, with John D. Tracy, parade chairman, and Clendenin J. Ryan, honorary chairman, officiating.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- In brief orders issued today the Supreme Court disbarred Alger Hiss from practice before it, and rejected his latest appeal for a new trial. The high tribunal in 1951 refused to review his conviction.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Supreme Court upheld today a lower court dismissal of a 101-count indictment against James J. Carroll, formerly a nationally known betting commisioner of St. Louis

LONDON, April 27 -- Two warnings of the threat to Britain from foreign business competition were given today at the opening of the annual British Industries Fair, a varied display of the product of British factories by more than 2,000 exhibitors.

The music students and faculty of Teachers College of Columbia University presented a program last night at Town Hall in which choral music predominated. Norval L. Church, Jack L. Lyall and Harry R. Wilson were the conductors.

The four members of the newly constituted New York City Transit Authority appointed by Governor Dewey and Mayor Impellitteri met yesterday in a session described as "harmonious" to select a fifth member.

Burglars who apparently figured that "the impossible takes a little longer" achieved something akin to it over the week-end, in stealing $80,000 worth of mink skins from Eastwood Holt, fur brokers, at 275 Seventh Avenue, the police revealed yesterday.

TOKYO, April 27 -- The United States Far East Command has offered $50,000 and political asylum to any Communist pilot who delivers a MIG jet fighter or other modern Soviet jet to the United Nations forces in Korea.

A new attempt to get clearance for a May Day parade next Friday was made yesterday by Leon Straus, chairman of the United Labor and People's Committee for May Day. Mr. Straus appeared before Second Deputy Police Commissioner John J. O'Connor with three suggestions for alternate routes to take the place of Eighth Avenue, traditional May Day parade street that has been closed for paraders this year by a State Supreme Court decision.

Apparently, as one of the first results of their excursion to Europe, Senator McCarthy's two juvenile detectives have turned up the dreadful information that some German newspapers are critical of President Eisenhower, Secretary Dulles and even of Mr. McCarthy himself.
Edna Ferber proffered the olive branch to offended city officials yesterday, but declined the metaphorical broom they had offered her in the city's forthcoming cleanup campaign.

CAIRO, April 27 -- The man accused of having instigated and directed the disastrous anti-British riots in Cairo on Jan. 26 1952, was granted amnesty today by a decision of the Egyptian court that left the question of his guilt or innocence undetermined.

Against powerful opposition from misguided nationalists, as well as Communists and Peronistas -- those who think along the same lines as President Juan Peron of Argentina -- inter-American cooperation for defense is making concrete progress.

The Monday Evening Recreation Club for Older Men and Women staged its annual show last night in Pilgrim Hall of the Broadway Tabernacle Church ( Congregational) at Fifty-sixth Street. Youngsters of 60 vied with oldsters of 80 and more in presenting skits, solos, monologues and dialogues that would have warmed the hearts of many old-time Palace vaudevillians.

Commodity prices closed generally higher in light volume yesterday on the New York exchanges. Potatoes showed more activity but remained below normal levels. Cottonseed oil trading increased considerably, bringing it up to average volume. Wool, soybean oil, lead, tin, rubber, hides and cocoa were higher.

Ceramics in the home was the subject of several talks yesterday afternoon at the first session of the design division program of the fifty-fifth annual meeting of the American Ceramic Society at the Statler Hotel.
TOKYO, Tuesday, April 28 -- Five students were killed and sixty were injured yesterday when Mount Aso volcano, on Japan's southernmost island of Kyushu, erupted during a high school sightseeing tour.

The United States Steel Corporation is expected to decide within the next two weeks whether it will become a television sponsor next fall. Its advertising agency has recommended an hour drama series to be televised on alternate weeks and produced by the Theatre Guild, which currently produces the corporation's radio program.

Today's new feature is "Bright Road," a Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer drama at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. Dorothy Dandridge, Harry Belafonte, Robert Horton and Philip Hepburn head the cast. The screen play, adopted from a magazine story by Mary Elizabeth Vroman was written by Emmet Lavery. Gerald Mayer directed and Sol Baer Fielding produced.
EAGLE PASS, TEX., April 27. (UP) -- Six men outfitted an expedition today to search for the grave of Sequoyah, famed Indian chief and scholar, in the Mexican wilderness south of Eagle Pass.

The First National Bank of Chicago, Ill., reported as of April 20, 1953, total deposits of $2,366,340,985, and total assets of $2,601,035,620, compared, respectively, with $2,607,302,751 and $2,828,620,633 on Dec. 31, 1952. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $606,468,153 against $741,776,708; holdings of United States Government securities to $659,726,867 against $707,652,757; and loans and discounts to $1,170,290,601 against $1,224,074,254.

The average market price of all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined from $42.56 at the end of February to $41.94 on March 31, the exchange reported yesterday. This was a drop of 1.5 per cent, against one of 1.8 per cent for THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average.

The President could have made an even more compelling and unanswerable plea for a sane world order than the excellent one contained in his address to the editors had he called for the elimination, instead of the limitation, of national armaments and armed forces, the purpose of which is to wage war, as distinguished from police forces and coast guards, the purpose of which is to enforce law.

Pending Federal legislation which would ban dangerously flammable fabrics from trade channels should provide for a mandatory guarantee by the textile producer that his fabrics comply with the law, the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers declared yesterday in a brief filed with the House Committee on Interstate Commerce.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The two largest unions in the American Federation of Labor, the Teamsters and the Machinists, bitter foes at times, have made a pact to divide the garage and service station industry between them in a country-wide cooperative organizing campaign.

Fairly common in South America, cherimoyas are a luxury during the brief season when they are offered here. That season has just begun. Martin's Fruit Shop, 1042 Madison Avenue, which has received its initial shipment, reported that the first-of-the-year specimens of this exotic relative of the custard apple were $1 apiece.

We cannot be reminded too often that Latin-American nationalism, with its accompaniment of anti-Yankeeism, is a powerful force. The two articles which Sam Pope Brewer has just written for this newspaper give a picture of the South American continent that is important because it is typical.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Lloyd's of London, traditional insurers against the perils of the sea, lost in the Supreme Court today a suit in which a point at issue had been "restraints and detainments of all kings, princes and people."
John Dioguardi, regional director of the United Automobile Workers, A. F. L., was named yesterday in a two-count criminal information that charged him with state tax evasions in 1950 and 1951.

Robert L. Troast, Republican nominee for Governor of New Jersey, issued a statement yesterday suggesting a state-wide referendum on the legalization of bingo and was promptly accused by Robert B. Meyner, his Democratic opponent, of "stealing another plank in the Democratic platform."

The 37-year-old Mannes School of Music at 157 East Seventy-fourth Street has received a charter from the New York State Board of Regents, giving the school academic status. Henceforth, it will be known as the Mannes College of Music.

New York bade Trygve Lie a formal farewell yesterday in a ceremony at City Hall where the former United Nations Secretary-General received the city's Medal of Honor for "distinguished and exceptional public service."

Asserting that Mayor Impellitteri had made a mess of his administration, Milton M. Bergerman, chairman of the Citizens Union, said last night that it would take the combined efforts of the good people in the city, regardless of party, to bring about a change.
Funded debt of the Union Pacific Railroad Company dropped below $200,000,000 last year for the first time since the road emerged from reorganization in 1897.

Baseball Commissioner Ford Frick, taking official cognizance of clubhouse games for high stakes, issued a stern warning to all sixteen major league clubs today against gambling and association with gamblers.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Studies shedding light on the origin of behavior cycles in man and animals, cycles accentuated in mental patients but observed also in individuals presumably normal, were reported here today at the annual spring meeting of the National Academy of Sciences.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 27 -- A verdict of acquittal was returned here tonight in the trial of two towering sugar maple trees charged with having threatened the lives of countless men, women and children in the Riverside district.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, figured prominently in two Congressional committee hearings today although he did not appear personally at either.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A reorganization plan for National Republican Headquarters was placed before President Eisenhower today by Leonard W. Hall of New York, the newly elected Republican National Chairman.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 27 -- The United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, whose future will be decided on soon, gave an account today of its six-year effort to feed and care for needy children in all parts of the world.

Prospects for French ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty have improved as a result of the current municipal elections, in which national and international issues overshadow purely local questions. The results will not be complete until the run-off elections next Sunday, but the main trends are evident.

At one of the most heavily attended meetings in its history, the Medical Society of the County of New York rejected overwhelmingly last night the membership application of Dr. Godfrey Edward Arnold, speech and voice specialist formerly of Vienna.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 27 (AP) -- Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., opened her second tennis tournament in England today with an easy victory. She needed only twenty minutes to defeat Angela Buxton, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 0, in the first round of the British Hard Courts tournament.

The driver of a crowded bus in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn collapsed and died of a heart attack in the morning rush hour yesterday. The bus crashed into an uncoming automobile and came to rest against an old trolley pole. Fourteen passengers suffered minor injuries.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 27 (AP) -- Television football fans will see a greater number of games -- but no more than one a week -- under the plan of continued controls proposed today by the TV committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

In a move to circumvent the "delaying tactics" of Park Commissoner Robert Moses, the Washington Square Park Committee has urged Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley to close the road the park by designating it through as a play street.

Large commercial banks in New York and other important money centers raised the "prime" rate on business loans to 3 1/4 per cent yesterday. The advance from 3 per cent was the first increase since December, 1951, when it was lifted from 2 3/4 per cent, and brings the rate to its highest level since the early Thirties.

Many more brides will walk down the aisle this summer in full-length gowns with trains than in shorter frocks. A recent survey of bridal departments shows that the vast majority of women, though they may be crisply modern in other respects, cling to all that is traditional for their wedding.

LUANG PRABANG, Laos, April 27 -- Despite the disturbing drone of military transports and the hour-by-hour arrival of more Moroccan troops the atmosphere is one of calm in this royal Laotian capital. Sixty-eight-year-old King Sisavang Vong is abed with gout, but the protective statue of Luang Prabang, the celebrated Buddha, stands erect on the royal altar and the crimson Laotian flag with its embossed white elephants flies serenely from the palace.

PARIS, April 27 -- Although official statistics were not expected to be complete until tomorrow, unofficial returns late tonight in the French municipal elections permitted the conclusions that the Gaullists had suffered serious losses and the Communists had maintained their strength in industrial centers.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 27 -- Royal Dutch Shell, which has vast oil holdings in Sumatra and Borneo, has completed plans to increase its capital investment in Indonesia by $400,000,000 during the next ten years, provided Indonesia is prepared to give three important guarantees.
CHICAGO, April 27 (AP) -- A meat industry official told a group of meat cutters and packinghouse workers today that more and more customers were turning to self-service meats.

Although the nation's steel-makers have scheduled their operations at a slightly slower rate this week than last, those operations were expected to remain a shade above the industry's theoretical capacity a second week in a row. The steel plants will operate at an estimated 100.3 per cent of rated potential, equal to production of 2,262,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The city's assistant commissioner of health in charge of maternal and child health services, Dr. Leona Baumgartner, is resigning to become executive director of the New York Foundation after sixteen years in the Department of Health.
Contributions of 644 pints of blood on Saturday were reported yesterday by the Red Cross.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of an April 6 letter from President Eisenhower to Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, proposing a Senate inquiry into operations of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act:

Unadvertised private brands and so-called "exclusive merchandise," while furnishing a satisfactory gross profit, actually are expensive for paper wholesalers, in the opinion of Emanuel Katz, president of Doeskin Products, Inc., maker of tissues.

Last year the bandbox theatre called Circle in the Square, down in Greenwich Village, made its mark with an impressive revival of Tennessee Williams' "Summer and Smoke." Last night the same organization gained fresh prestige when it presented a thoughtful and tender new production of Truman Capote's "The Grass Harp."

MEXICO CITY, April 27 -- A number of brief newspaper items in the press of Mexico City recently have provided fresh evidence that President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines' reform campaign is more than the usual broom-sweeping normally accompanying the advent of a new Mexican administration.

Trading in the stock of Amurex Oil Development Company featured the American Stock Exchange tape yesterday on the basis of a tip put on the air by a commentator. The shares, which had closed Friday at 14 7/8, were in such demand at the opening that the initial sale was for 26,400 shares at 20 7/8.

AFTER stumbling along at a sixth-place gait for the first half of the 1952 season, the Phillies regained their equilibrium under the gentle guidance of Steve O'Neill and whirled through the second half at a giddy first-place pace. The erstwhile Whiz Kids were well pleased with both themselves and their new skipper by the time they had played their final game.

Forty British, French, Belgian and German war brides, with their fifty-five children and two lone husbands, left New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday for a three-month reunion with parents and relatives in "the old country."

Twenty per cent of the steel work on the 1.61-mile South Street Elevated Highway, which is to run from Jackson Street, along the waterfront, to the Battery Underpass, has been completed, Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of lianhattan reported yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 27 -- The Yugoslav Army will change the style of its uniforms, it became known today. The shoulder boards will be eliminated and officers' ranks will be designated on shoulder loops, while non-commissioned officer grades will be designated on sleeves.
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 27 -- Proposals for a treaty of friendship between the United States and Pakistan will be "explored" within five to six weeks, Prime Minister Mohammed Ali disclosed today.

BERLIN, April 27 -- The East German Government brought its campaign against Protestant youth groups to a climax by declaring them illegal today and threatening legal action against members. A statement to this effect by the Ministry of Interior indicated that these groups, known as Junge Gemeinden, or Young Communities, would be suppressed by Government action.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, today rejected Marion Clawson's request for reinstatement as Director of the Bureau of Land Management.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of an Executive Order by President Eisenhower today on security requirements for Government employment:

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Supreme Court ruled today, in a 7 to 2 decision, that a Portsmouth N. H., member of the Jehovah's Witnesses sect had a right to make a speech in a city park, but held that he should have sought legal remedies before speaking without a license.

New York, which has been celebrating its tercentenary, has finally acquired a Miss 300th Anniversary. In fact, it acquired two yesterday morning when the Holland - America liner Westerdam docked at Hoboken, N. J., after a nine-day trip from Holland.

A record city budget of $1,528,814,950, just $2,155 higher than the executive budget submitted last April 7 by Mayor Impellitteri, was adopted yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The vote was 13 to 3. The three negative votes were cast by City Council President Rudolph Halley.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 27 -- Although combat air power of the North Atlantic Treaty forces still is seriously weak, recommendations to reorganize and strengthen it that Gen. Matthew B.
