Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander, made more than two months ago, have not yet been acted on by his Allied superiors.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Roger M. Kyes, Deputy Secretary of Defense, charged the military services today with reckless overstatement of their needs during the post-Korean build-up and promised a new era of sound management and effective civilian control in the Department of Defense.

LONDON, April 27 -- Prime Minister Churchill, who was knighted last Friday, gave a jovial assurance in the House of Commons today that he did not intend to take a higher title and retire to the House of Lords.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Post Office Department is "now studying the need for the resumption of a second delivery" daily in city residential areas, Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield said today in an interview. He expressed the hope, however, that such action would be found unnecessary.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 27 -- The Derby Trial, a one-mile race that sometimes points out the Kentucky Derby winner (but usually doesn't) will be run at the Churchill Downs race track on the morrow.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 9 points higher to 13 points lower than on last Friday.
The Soviet Union can indicate its sincerity for peace in one way by a genuine repudiation of its recent anti-Semitic campaign, Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland said last night.

BONN, Germany, April 27 -- The Government coalition parties are preparing to rush through a bill permitting the recartelization of West German industry before the present Parliament is dissolved June 6.
GENEVA, April 27 -- The discussion on the future of United Nations action on behalf of refugees opened here today.
A number of elections and appointments were announced by the American Ceramic Society, which began its fifty-fifth annual meeting yesterday at the Statler Hotel.

After thirty-one years in the city's service, all of them in the Department of Finance, City Treasurer Spencer C. Young announced yesterday that on next Sept. 1 he would put in his retirement papers, effective Dec. 31.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 27 -- Two policy-making members of the United States Senate warned business men today that the Russian peace moves were designed to throw this country off guard and carried no promise of any change in the long-range Communist plans for world domination.

The transplanted Braves, in their new role of a Western club from Milwaukee, face the Giants at the Polo Grounds tonight and the Redlegs meet the Dodgers at Ebbets Field as the National League invasion of the East by the Western clubs gets under way.

TRENTON, April 27 -- A subdued but affable Joe Adonis, alias Joseph Doto, notorious racketeer and alumnus of Murder, Inc., stepped nonchalantly into the colorful reception room of the aging State Prison here this morning. Shuffling across the room, he took a seat at the end of a long mahogany conference table.
CHICAGO, April 27 -- New light has been shed on the Cause of sudden death from severe allergic reactions, two professors of the Harvard University Medical School reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Elisha Hanson, general counsel for the American Newspaper Publishers Association, urged today that Congress keep in the Taft-Hartley Act a ban against closed-shop unionism.

The election of Arthur F. Douglas and Dr. Charles A. R. Connor to the board of directors of the New York Heart Association was announced yesterday by Carl Whitmore, chairman of the board. Dr. Connor is a New York physician and Mr. Douglas is president of the Hotels Statler Company, Inc.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee today called as a witness the twenty-sixth of American citizen employes of United Nations organizations in its investigation into alleged Communist infiltration of the United Nations.

The first annual report for general distribution by W. R. Grace Co. and subsidiaries showed yesterday a record sales and operating revenues volume of $284,148,190 for 1952, compared with $264,982,359 in 1951.

Mothers of the lower East Side who formed a human traffic barrier last Wednesday and blocked traffic for three days at Avenue D and Eighth Street, protesting "hazardous conditions" there, have been summoned to appear in Lower Manhattan Court today on disorderly conduct charges.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Eisenhower Administration today announced a new, stricter security program for Federal employes, discarding the dual Truman system that had made a distinction between loyalty and security.
BEAUMONT, Tex., April 27 (AP) -- Newsmen saw and talked to Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias today for the first time since her operation on April 17 and found her smiling and cheerful.
YONKERS, April 27 (AP) -- Coming along fast on the far turn, the favored Harvey Pointer took command and went on to win the Staten Island Pace by two lengths over Wind Up at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- Defense and Government attorneys in the du Pont anti-trust trial in Federal District Court today disclosed plans to wind up presentation of evidence by early July and to present final arguments in the fall.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 27 -- Broadway's Joshua Logan and Leland Hayward have teamed with Hollywood's James Stewart and Alfred Hitchcock to produce a picture independently with Paramount Pictures playing the role of financial agent and distributor.

CLEVELAND, April 27 -- The settlement of the threatened strike by the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen on the Nickel Plate Railroad resulted late today in cancellation of plans for the appointment of an emergency board to look into the dispute.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Robert D. Murphy, retiring Ambassador to Japan and prospective Assistant Secretary of State, will be named a special adviser to Gen. Mark W. Clark on Korean truce problems. The announcement is expected tomorrow in response to a reported request by General Clark, United Nations commander in Korea.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 27 -- Broadway's Joshua Logan and Leland Hayward have teamed with Hollywood's James Stewart and Alfred Hitchcock to produce a picture independently with Paramount Pictures playing the role of financial agent and distributor.

CLEVELAND, April 27 -- The settlement of the threatened strike by the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen on the Nickel Plate Railroad resulted late today in cancellation of plans for the appointment of an emergency board to look into the dispute.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Robert D. Murphy, retiring Ambassador to Japan and prospective Assistant Secretary of State, will be named a special adviser to Gen. Mark W. Clark on Korean truce problems. The announcement is expected tomorrow in response to a reported request by General Clark, United Nations commander in Korea.

While world attention has been focused upon the well-publicized moves which have constituted the current Soviet peace offensive, life has been going on in the rest of the Communist empire, and, in particular, the 1953 budgets of both Poland and Czechoslovakia have been made public.
Honolulu, Hawaii, announced yesterday that it will receive bids on May 7 on $3,000,000 of bonds dated July 1, 1953, and due from July 1, 1958 to 1983.

The National Foreign Trade Council, regarded as the top or ganization in its field, announced yesterday its opposition to the extreme tariff-protectionist Simpson bill for extension of' the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.

THE average hunter who shoots over a spaniel has been inclined to avoid participation in field trials. However, the initiation of the "field dog stakes" by the American Spaniel Club, held in conjunction with regular AKC trials, is giving the spaniel owner a chance to stretch his sport out well beyond the regular hunting season.

Plans are being advanced rapidly at frequent meetings for the concert to be given for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service on May 7 at Carnegie Hall by the New York Pops Orchestra, composed of seventy members of the Philharmonic-Symphony with Marie Braggiotti, pianist, as soloist.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) -- William H. Taft 3d said today that as Ambassador to Ireland he would claim the privilege of tutoring only one man in diplomacy -- his father, Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 28 -- The United Nations Command told the Communists today to produce a "constructive" proposal for an armistice in the Korean war or face a new recess in the resumed negotiations at Panmunjom.

The general principle of academic freedom has been sufficiently expounded, though it is as yet by no means understood by the general public. The more immediate question is the relation of this principle to the Congressional committees of investigation.
TOKYO, Tuesday, April 28 (AP) -- United Nations headquarters communique 1,598 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

" Foreign Policy Without Fear," a new book by Vera Micheles Dean, has been scheduled for publication next Tuesday by McGraw-Hill. The book combines an assessment of American foreign policy since the last war with an evaluation of how the policy can be rewritten into a "positive, consistent, long-range" instrument of democracy.

MARTINSBURG, W. Va., April 27 -- Mass picketing in support of a strike against the Perfection Garment Company's plants in this city and at Ranson, fifteen miles away, came under Circuit Court ban here this morning following the arrest of sixteen pickets earlier in the day.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- James A. Wechsler, editor of The New York Post, asked today that the Senate Investigations subcommittee make public the testimony he gave before it Friday at a closed-door meeting.

LONDON, April 27 -- Five Government science departments are combining their resources in an effort to save one of Britain's historic monuments, the 187-year- old hulk of Nelson's flagship Victory, which is being eaten to pieces by a tiny wood-boring beetle.

SEOUL, Tuesday, April 28 (AP) -- Fighting on the ground in the Korean war was generally light yesterday while United States Sabre jets dive-bombed Communist troops and targets along the front on their first close-support mission.

For a time in early stock market trading yesterday, virtually the entire list, save the public utilities and machine manufacturers, appeared to be marching away from the lows of the year established on Friday. As the day wore on, however, only the steels and motors held their opening gains, rails and chemicals shaded their advances and American Telephone and Telegraph -- not usually a market leader -- was definitely soft.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby held her first press conference today as Secretary of the new Department of Health, Education and Welfare and promised "a good hard look at our basic laws" on welfare.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 27 -- Members of the Independent Petroleum Association of America meeting here today unanimously adopted a resolution calling upon Congress to limit the importation of foreign petroleum products.
ST. LOUIS, April 27 (AP) -- European countries will increase their consumption of zinc by at least 43,000 tons this year, the American Zinc Institute was told here today.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 27 -- The Case of the Frisky Squirrel left this community virtually without train service this morning.

More than one-half of the eighty-five clubs comprising the second district of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State are contributing to the district's effort to save Sunken Forest, a fifty-acre woodland tract on Fire Island, Mrs. C. Turner Richardson of Douglaston, Queens, said yesterday.

VIENNA, April 27 -- In reply to President Eisenhower's speech last week in which he outlined United States peace objectives, the Hungarian Communist party organ Szabad Nep declared today that the Hungarian people had chosen without American help the form of government that seemed best to them.

Forty years is a short time as history goes but a considerable span in the life of the individual. It is the progress in the life of the average wage-earner that the Labor Department takes as its yardstick for a report -- "The Workers' Story, 1913-1953" -- which presents an interesting series of contrasts and conclusions over the period since the department was established.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 27 -- The international executive board of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., took the first step today in a drive to win higher wages for 1,250,000 workers in steel-producing and fabricating plants. The outcome of the drive will have a significant influence on the 1953 wage-price pattern in most basic industries.

PARIS, April 27 -- In long talks over the week-end among ministers of the United States, Britain and France it was agreed that the three powers would exchange views regarding any concrete Soviet proposal that might be made and it was expected they would act together in replying to it.

The formal agreement on a special Export-Import Bank loan to Brazil to help that country liquidate its heavy backlog of commercial dollar debts will be signed in Washington on Thursday, according to an announcement yesterday by an official of the Brazilian Treasury Delegation here.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 27 -- Smoldering political strife in Iran appeared to have been buried today along with Brig. Gen. Mahmud Afshartous, national police chief, who was assassinated after his abduction last Monday night.

Here in Venezuela we do not yet know what reactions have occurred in connection with proposed law H. R. 4294, presented in Congress by Representative Simpson of Pennsylvania, which, if approved, would limit the importations of crude petroleum and its derivatives to 10 per cent of the domestic consumption of the previous year and would limit to 5 per cent the imports of fuel oil.

An important change in the setup of the United States record industry will take place in September. Columbia Records and British Columbia, its affiliate in Britain, it was learned yesterday, have not renewed their contract, which expired last Dec. 31.
A young father on a fire-escape swung his son and niece into the arms of rescuers on a near-by roof yesterday as eleven panicky residents of a frame apartment house in Brooklyn fled from a fire.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., April 27 -- Lieut. Sheppard Carl Thierman, 30 years old, of Brooklyn, a medical officer, went on trial in an Army court-martial here today on charges that he obtained his commission fraudulently, that he committed perjury and failed to cooperate with the Senate Internal Security subcommittee.

CAIRO, April 27 -- British and Egyptian negotiators began today examination of the thorny problems raised by Egyptian demands for immediate withdrawal of British troops from the Suez Canal zone and establishment of Egyptian control over the important military base there.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Government officials were generally unimpressed tonight with the news from Moscow that Foreign Minister Molotov had declared the Soviet Union ready to join discussions intended to lead to a five-power peace pact. The statement was viewed as "old stuff."

GENEVA, April 27 -- Even the slight improvement in the terms under which Communist Europe is prepared to trade with non-Communist Europe has further weakened the already loose cohesion of the Atlantic group of nations in matters of trade and economic policy.

An array of silver pieces, with special emphasis on tea sets, of which there are 200, is on display at Altman's. There are contemporary and traditional patterns from this country and new designs from England, France and Denmark.

YONKERS, April 28 (AP) -- Stanley Dancer drove four winners at Yonkers Raceway tonight. In the fifth race he finished second, thus missing the opportunity to tie his five-for-five record established in 1951.

ROME, April 28 -- The new United States Ambassador, Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, presented a copy of her credentials today to Dr. Alcide de Gasperi in his double capacity as Premier and Foreign Minister. As a result of this action, the Italian Government considers that Mrs. Luce has taken over as of today her official duties as head of the United States diplomatic mission in Rome.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The old question whether the country needed intensive soil conservation at a time when surpluses plagued the economy popped up today before the Agriculture Committee of the House of Representatives.

Lieut Gov. Frank C. Moore told the Women's National Republican Club yesterday that Governor Dewey's proposed solution of New York City's financial problems had his wholehearted support, "without reservations or qualifications." The key feature of the Governor's program is the transfer of the deficit-plagued city transit lines to a new authority responsible for keeping operating costs within operating revenues.

St. John's defeated New York University, 2 -- 1, at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday in a pitching duel between the Violet's Vinnie Lupica and Dick Eichorn of the Redmen. The victory was the second in five Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference starts for St. John's and marked N. Y. U.'s third league defeat in four contests.

Eight women who last week led a baby-buggy blockade of Avenue D in a demonstration for traffic lights appeared yesterday in Lower Manhattan Court on disorderly conduct summonses and won both their case and their objective.

Hear ye! Hear ye! All persons having business in the Hall of Records, who have risked life and limb riding the ancient and decrepit elevators to do business with the Surrogates, the Sheriff, Register or search old city records, be of good cheer, for yesterday Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen promised that these hazards would disappear with 450 days.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges closed irregularly higher yesterday. Volume continued light but zinc was active. Coffee, cocoa, wool, lead and tin closed higher. Zinc, soybean oil, cottonseed oil, sugar and rubber were mixed and potatoes declined.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- President Eisenhower was told today by the Emergency Committee on Natural Resources that Federal Government career men should not be removed for political reasons and that they should have an opportunity to carry out the concepts and policies of a new Administration.

LONDON, April 28 -- A transportable home that is known as the "house on skis," is the most novel exhibit in its class at this year's British Industries Fair, which has for the first time devoted a section to prefabricated houses.
HANOVER, N. H., April 28 (UP) -- Dartmouth College today expelled two students, suspended a third and disciplined five others for getting an 8-year-old Hanover boy drunk.

GEDERA, Israel, April 28 (AP) -- Moshe Rosner, 50 years of age, uncle of the two young Austrian Jewish orphans allegedly smuggled from France to Spain by Roman Catholics, promised today "freedom of religious choice" for the boys if they are handed over to his wife Hedwig.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 28 -- Ground was broken near here today for a new $1,250,000 regional office building of the Allstate Insurance Company, a subsidiary of Sears Roebuck Co. The nine-acre site, facing Westchester Avenue in Harrison, is part of the old Whitelaw Reid estate.
The trial of John (Johnny) Alu, ex-convict and waterfront figure, on charges of lying to the New York State Crime Commission, ended at 12:45 A. M. today in a hung jury.
TEHERAN, Iran, April 28 -- A prominent Opposition deputy was officially, if somewhat vaguely, linked today to the abduction and assassination of Brig. Gen. Mahmud Afshartous, national police chief.

LOS ANGELES, April 28 -- Application will be made to the Federal Communications Commission some time this year for permission to introduce "pay-as-you-see" television, it was stated today at the national convention of the Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers.

Rudolph Halley, the City Council President, and Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan are busily writing a political record against the time when it might be needed at the polls. Mr. Halley cast his three Board of Estimate votes against the Mayor's executive budget, chiefly because the budget is built on the premise of city acceptance of authority operation of transit.

TRENTON, April 28 -- John J. Dickerson, Republican State Chairman, disclosed here today that an admitted friend and associate of racketeers and gamblers had lent $25,000 to the Republican State Committee in the 1949 Governorship campaign and that records of cash contributions had been destroyed.

PRINCETON, N. J., Wednesday, April 29 -- One thousand Princeton University undergraduates ran wild for three hours here last night in a riot that kept virtually the whole town in an uproar and exhausted the resources of its twenty-one-man police force.

European shipyards are filled with new construction and have orders ahead "as far as they can see," but their production is slow because of materials shortages, according to Walter L. Green, president and chairman of the American Bureau of Shipping.
Val Peterson, Federal Civil Defense Administrator, urged industrial leaders last night to cooperate fully with a new program to protect plants and workers against atomic bombs and other new weapons.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (UP) -- A Senate committee reported today that big military contractors farm out the "lion's share" of their subcontracts to other large companies.

NEW HAVEN, April 28 -- If the Eisenhower Administration's new security program for Federal employes is poorly administered it could discourage vitally needed scientists and other skilled personnel from accepting Government employment, the Scientists Committee on Loyalty and Security declared in a statement issued tonight.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, April 28 -- A British wedding cake created by internationally known Ronny Rock, various coronation cakes and a small sculpture of Queen Elizabeth, crown and all, stole the show at the first International Pastry and Confectionery Trade fair currently being held here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 28 -- Motion-picture personalities have a keener awareness of Communist machinations and are not being as easily duped today as in the past, the American Legion has concluded after a year of close association with industry executives in dealing with Communist problems.

An elaborate project is being fostered by Billy Rose. In October or November he promises to introduce on Broadway an English version of "Orpheus in the Underworld," Offenbach's popular operetta of 1858.
BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 28 (UP) -- Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., and Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, advanced to the third found of the British hard courts tennis championships today.

DOVER FURNACE, N. Y., April 28 -- The trout fisherman, confronted with unusual and unseasonable success, is inclined to be rather apprehensive, for superstition takes over when the fly goes on the leader, so we are not neglecting an occasional glance over the left shoulder after today's experience.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Army tolerated some waste and gangsterism at the Claremont Terminal in Jersey City because it felt that a steady flow of materials for overseas air base construction should not be jeopardized by possible strikes of longshoremen, Col. Charles T. Tench, who had been in charge of the shipping center, testified today.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 28 -- Dark Star, flying the blue-and-white-blocked silks of the Cain Hoy Stable, qualified rather handsomely for a starting berth in next Saturday's Kentucky Derby when he won the $15,300 Derby Trial in fast time at Churchill Downs today.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Spokesmen for eight widely varying industries told Congress today their businesses faced injury or destruction unless more protection was provided against imports of cheaper foreign goods.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 27 -- The Yugoslav Government is engaged in a thorough reassessment of foreign reaction to the Soviet "peace" moves.

The shipping slump that hit the waterfronts of the world late last year sharply increased the number of beached seamen who sought lodgings at the Seamen's Church Institute of New York while waiting to ship out.

Nine Jewish organizations joined yesterday in denouncing the national origins quota system for immigration and proposed as a substitute a flexible law that would allocate admission without regard for the "accident of place of birth."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 28 -- A home builder and an inspector for the Veterans Administration were indicted here today by a holdover Middlesex County grand jury for conspiracy to defraud the agency and the Federal Government in the construction of houses in Middlesex Borough.
George T. Elser has been elected vice president in charge of production of The Valspar Corporation.

Ted Ashley Associates, theatrical agents and producers of radio and television shows, have leased the penthouse in the fifteen-story office building under construction at 579 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Forty-seventh Street, one of two structures being built by Ivor B. Clark on a U-shaped plot comprising the north and south corners of the east blockfront on Fifth Avenue between Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth Streets.

Net earnings of the Texas Company and subsidiaries for the opening quarter of 1953 were estimated at $42,681,806, equal to $1.55 a common share, compared with $42,815,926, or $1.56 a share, for the same period a year ago. The report was made yesterday by J. S. Leach, chairman of the board, at the annual meeting of stockholders.

Col. Candler Cobb, New York City Director of Selective Service, declared yesterday that the organization had "nothing to do with a man's politics" and judged only on a sociological or economic basis whether a man was eligible to report for induction into the armed forces.

I wish to register my objection to your editorial captioned "Housing Vote." Public housing has degenerated into such a racket that it threatens the confiscation of properties of many thousands of our thrifty citizens who have invested their life savings in a little piece of real estate to call "home, sweet home."
The City of Cincinnati, Ohio, borrowed $17,228,000 in the public market yesterday on bonds maturing serially from 1954 to 1990 at an interest cost of 2.3747 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Waving a copy of a speech by Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Under Secretary of State, that criticized pending legislation limiting the treaty-making powers of the President, Senator John W. Bricker, sponsor of the legislation, told an audience here today:

Ethel and Albert, two of the most real and warmly humorous character creations on the air, have made the transition to television in their own half-hour show at 7:30 P. M. Saturdays over N. B. C. After a successful tryout last year on the Kate Smith video program, the Arbuckles obviously are ready for promotion, but for the moment their many friends must keep their fingers crossed.
BOWIE, Md., April 28 (UP) -- Iswas, with Bobby Mitchell aboard, equaled a track record that had stood for twenty-four years at Bowie today as he galloped to an easy victory in the Embassy purse.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 28 -- Dan Throop Smith, assistant to Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey, cautioned underdeveloped countries today against expecting any "tremendous outflow" of American capital for foreign investment regardless of inducements offered in the form of tax remissions.

James Fleetwood, who led the Philadelphia Choral Ensemble here in 1948 and 1949, last night conducted the Fleetwood Singers at Carnegie Recital Hall in a program devoted to Medieval and Renaissance Music. It had much freshness and charm.

HONOLULU, April 28 -- Thirty-five sick or wounded United States military men freed last week from Communist prison camps in Korea returned to American soil here today as their big hospital plane touched down at Hickam Air Force base after a flight from Tokyo.

The performance of the stock market yesterday was cheering to the so-called "tape technicians." While prices eased moderately in the early hours, the pressure of offerings was light. It continued so into midafternoon without further loss of ground until about the final half hour, when news of an increase to 50 cents from 45 cents in the quarterly dividend of Jones Laughlin sparked interest in the entire list.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Russell B. Chatham, who once directed lie-detector examinations at the Oak Ridge atomic plant, said today that 600 employes or prospective employes there had admitted during the tests that they had withheld from the Government information on such things as major crimes or membership in "un-American" organizations.

CLEVELAND, April 28 (AP) -- Bobby Shantz pitched and batted the Athletic to a 3-2 victory tonight over the Indians, whose winning streak was snapped at five games. The undersized southpaw drove in two runs with a pair of singles and held the Tribe to eight hits, including a last-inning homer by Bob Kennedy.

The body of M. Frank Reid Jr., 25-year-old second-year student at the Union Theological Seminary, was found in the courtyard beside the tower of Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, at 11:35 A. M. yesterday. The police said Mr. Reid had jumped or fallen from the observation tower twenty-one stories above.

President Eisenhower has taken the first step -- and only the first step -- toward redeeming the pledge made during his campaign to "repeal the unfair provisions" of the McCarran anti-immigration act. In a letter written early in the month but released only this week he has listed ten features of the law which may operate "with unwarranted harshness."
PITTSBURGH, April 28 (AP) -- Price increases on some products were disclosed today by Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation as it reported gains in both sales and earnings for the first quarter of 1953.
Two soldiers were burned to death early yesterday morning and two others were injured when a fire swept their tent in a Brooklyn anti-aircraft unit.

Today's adult whose childhood coincided with, or perhaps preceded by a few years, the early success of the Model T may catch himself occasionally fighting off, as he reads current newspapers and magazines, a feeling of unreality.

Milton M. Bergerman, chairman of the Citizens Union, made a written demand yesterday on Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, for the ouster of five Tammany district leaders who had figured in the State Crime Commission's investigation.

The New Symphony Orchestra of New York, under the direction of its founder-conductor, Maurice Bonney, played its second and final concert of the season last evening at the Central High School of Needle Trades Auditorium.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 28 (AP) -- Eight new counts of perjury were lodged today against a New York City lawyer arrested on a Superior Court bench warrant here April 10 for allegedly contriving false testimony in an uncontested divorce case.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 28 -- Undaunted by steel company assertions that no wage increase was warranted this year, the Wage Policy Committee of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., served notice on the industry today that it intended to win higher wages for its 1,250,000 members in steel producing and fabricating plants.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., April 28 (AP) -- A bill introduced today in the State Legislature might force the University of Illinois out of the Big Ten and the N. C. A. A., says Athletic Director Doug Mills.
Three new films, including an Italian importation, open at first run theatres today.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, and Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College, have protested to President Eisenhower the recent action by the House of Representatives in eliminating scheduled appropriations for low-rent housing projects.

PARIS, April 28 -- When Gen. Mark W. Clark openly offered $100,000 to the first Communist pilot in Korea or China who would fly a Soviet-built jet plane to an Allied base he publicized a form of enticement that the United States had been practicing quietly for some time.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- A Polish-born former Communist who admitted he had been a wartime spy in American industrial plants for the Soviet Union told the Senate Internal Security subcommittee at a televised hearing today how he stole and passed on to other party agents almost 100 military diesel engine blueprints and a chemical formula that he believed to be "top secret" matter.

MOSCOW, April 28 -- May Day portraits of ten Government leaders headed by Premier Georgi M. Malenkov were posted on important buildings in Moscow's center today as part of the traditional decoration of the city for the holiday.

A mid-spring burst of art activities in the vicinity of Greenwich Village includes work in various media by four artists at the Village Art Center and by three others at the Pen and Brush Club. An exhibition at the RoKo Gallery contrasts sharply with a show uptown at the Rehn Gallery.

As the City Council received yesterday the record city budget of $1,528,814,950, Majority Leader Joseph T. Sharkey, Brooklyn Democrat, declared that the city's ills would not be cured "until we get a new Governor and elect as many Democrats as possible to the Legislature."

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, with the reported backing of Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, the Majority Leader, proposed today freeing of the powerful building trades unions of the American Federation of Labor from all provisions of the Taft-Hartley Law.

The one-hour limit on parking in unmetered and unrestricted sections of the city will be wiped out late next month, when the first phase of the huge parking meter program is completed, Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley made known yesterday.

Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld has cleared the air by expunging from the record a federal grand jury's presentment accusing certain union officers of filing false non-Communist affidavits under the Taft-Hartley Act. He made it clear that such accusations should not be made without evidence sufficient to warrant indictment.

QUITO, Ecuador, April 28 (AP) -- Policemen hurled tear gas today to break up demonstrations touched off by the Government's closing of two newspapers -- La Nacion and La Hora of Guayaquil -- and the jailing of five executives. Five persons were arrested.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board said today its index of industrial production rose two points in March to a level 10 per cent higher than that of a year ago and 20 per cent above production in mid-1950.

As a further move in their latest "peace offensive" the Soviets have revived a project whose real purpose is actually to advance their ultimate and still unchanged objective of a Communist world controlled from Moscow. This project, advanced many times in recent years and just as often rejected by the West, calls for a "peace pact" between the Big Five Powers, Soviet Russia, the United States, Britain, France and -- Communist China.

In one of his last public appearances before his return to Norway, Trygve Lie, first Secretary General of the United Nations, restated his faith in the world organization yesterday at ceremonies dedicating the new sculpture garden of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- Grain futures lacked any sustained buying power today, and while there was a period of firmness early in the session the market reacted later in the absence of any aggressive support.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., April 28 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of the Cherry Valley Club scored 43, 41 -- 84 and then won a drawing from four rivals to take the low gross award during the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament at the Rockville Club today.

The design of ceramic objects was discussed by several speakers yesterday at the afternoon session of the fifty-fifth annual meeting of the American Ceramic Society, now in progress at the Statler Hotel.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 28 -- French headquarters announced today that the post of Pakseng, forty-three miles northeast of Luang Prabang, the royal capital of Laos, had fallen to attacking Communist-led Vietminh forces. Pakseng, which lies on the Namsuong River, had been defended by troops of the National Laotian Army.
LONDON, April 28 (Reuters) -- Britain today took a first step toward freeing her atomic energy program from bureaucratic control and speeding its development through free enterprise methods.

An investment banking syndicate headed by the First, Boston Corporation will place on the market today a new issue of $40,000,000 of Detroit Edison Company's thirty-five-year general and refunding mortgage bonds at a price of 102.425 to yield about 3 3/4 per cent.

The King Ranch's Islay Mist, a 4-year-old filly with lots of zip, ran away with the mile-and-a-sixteenth Trance Handicap at Jamaica yesterday afternoon. The race was a prep for next Tuesday's Firenze Handicap for fillies and mares 3 years old and upward, and eight eligible for that test went to the post.
DETROIT, April 28 (UP) -- Southpaw Mickey McDermott fired a three-hitter today to pitch the Red Sox to a 2-0 victory over the Tigers before 3,059 fans at Briggs Stadium.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 28 -- The squirrel tribe was absolved today of all blame for the power failure yesterday that tied up train service between this point and Stamford, an official of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad announced.
PITTSBURGH, April 28 (AP) -- Preston Ward and Randy Jackson belted across four runs with two booming home runs to lead the Cubs to a 5-3 victory tonight over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

LONDON, April 28 -- A spokesman of the Pan American Airways said here today that there was "no change" in the status of the company's order for British Comet jet airliners, which some Britons fear the company may cancel unless the Comet soon receives a United States certificate of airworthiness.

PARIS, April 28 -- There was exuberance in the collection of Serge Kogan when it was presented yesterday afternoon. This young designer, one of the most recent to take his place in the couture, has novel ideas, which he shows with a light touch.

The last time a Milwaukee team played a major league baseball game in this city it lost to the Providence Grays, 4 -- 1. That was in 1878, seventy-five years ago. Last night the transplanted Braves, now representing the Wisconsin metropolis, reversed that defeat by the same score, the Giants being their victims on this occasion.

ATHENS, April 28 -- The Greek Government has drafted a law primarily designed to bring under the Greek flag nearly 7,000,000 tons of Greek shipping that during the post-war years has been registered abroad, thus rendering no profit to the home country.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Democratic Congressional leaders will reject a proposed 1954 mid-term party convention. They contend such a meeting would divide, not unite, the party.

The suspended look, a motif that has been very popular in the last two years for its decorative quality, has received functional meaning in a new collection of Danish furniture introduced here yesterday and available through decorators from Swedish Modern, 675 Fifth Avenue.

NOW that the hot-weather pitchers have shaken off the icicles, now that a seat behind third base (or even at a TV screen), a scorecard and a beaker of Ballantine andor Schaefer are paradise enow for any fan, it's a pleasure to applaud Henry Wiggen as he begins his first long walk from the bullpen. Henry is both the hero and the narrator of Mark Harris' excellent baseball novel, "The Southpaw."*

ST. LOUIS, April 28 (AP) -- The Independent Petroleum Association of America was told today that "oil is high on the list" of basic American industries slated for Federal control by the "zealots who would destroy free enterprise in its entirety."

A family ownership of forty-six years has been terminated in the same by Mrs. Belle Natt of the two-story dwelling at 43 Sherman Street, Brooklyn, to Thomas E. Conlon. The Harry M. Lewis Company was the broker. Built in 1907 by the late Senator William H. Calder, the house originally was planned for two-family occupancy but was altered for one-family use.

BONN, Germany, April 28 -- The political crisis involving the Allied-German treaties was complicated further tonight when parliamentary leaders of the three Government parties pressed President Theodor Heuss to sign the pacts in violation of his pledge to the Social Democratic Opposition.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Appointment of Gen. Nathan F. Twining as new Chief of Staff of the Air Force is widely forecast in defense circles. General Twining, now second in command, would succeed Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, who is scheduled to retire on completion of his tour of duty. June 30.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Jewish War Veterans offered the State Department today a plan for immediate establishment of a Middle East defense organization as a means of establishing peace in that area and of building another strong anti-Communist force.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., April 28 -- Television station WRGB announced today that it had offered five hours of air time weekly to educators in its coverage area and would pay $2,500 annually toward the salary of a person to produce educational programs.
LONDON, April 28 (Reuters) -- The foundations of a new self-governing domination within the British Commonwealth -- a British West Indian Federation -- were laid in London today.

TOKYO, April 28 -- Robert D. Murphy, retiring United States Ambassador to Japan, confirmed tonight that he had been appointed a member of the United Nations Korean armistice team to serve in the capacity of political adviser to his old friend, Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations Commander.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 29 -- The Communist truce negotiators at Panmunjom indicated today that they might name an "Asian nation" to serve as custodian for prisoners of the Korean war who refused to accept repatriation after an armistice.
Guards at Sing Sing Prison have been unionized by the American Federation of State, County and Muncipal Employes, A. F. L., the organization announced yesterday.

Recent release of tin by the Government to dyers led to a warning yesterday by the International Silk Association that, according to the rules of the Federal Trade Commission, weighted silk and products made from it must be clearly labeled.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Harry A. McDonald, retiring Administrator of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, made a plea today for its continuance as an "essential source of credit for small business and small communities."

The American system of mass production and mass distribution would largely disappear if installment credit were to be drastically restricted, Arthur O. Dietz, president of the C. I. T. Financial Corporation, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting.

The textile industry is in the hands of its salesmen, J. Spencer Love, chairman of the board of the Burlington Mills Corporation, said yesterday at a meeting of the Textile Salesmen's Association at the Astor Hotel. Production has outstripped consumption, he explained, and the work of the salesmen will determine the industry's future.

A tract of twenty acres and 146 additional lots in Oceanside, L. I., have been purchased by Murray Glicksman Assoc. for improvement with 168 dwellings. William R. Gibson Jr., president of the Eveready Construction Corporation, was the seller.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Grand jury proceedings against major United States oil companies for alleged participation in an international cartel were quashed today on motion of the Department of Justice, which began the inquiry last September.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The United States Court of Appeals held the West Texas Utilities Company in contempt today for failure to obey an order to bargain with a union. In a rare decision the court ordered the company to cease paying a wage increase of 18 cents an hour that it had negotiated more than a year ago with an uncertified employe representative.

The Barnard College award of the George Welwood Murray Fellowship, providing a year of graduate study in the humanities, was made yesterday to Miss Harriet Brundage, a blind student from Newburgh, N. Y., for showing "most promise of distinction" in her field. Miss Brundage, who plans to extend her religion major into Union Theological Seminary next year, received her award at the third annual honors assembly in Barnard Hall, Broadway and 117th Street.

Redbook magazine, which had a monthly circulation of 250,000 in 1914 and averaged 2,040,369 in the second half of last year, marks its fiftieth anniversary of continuous publication with the May issue on sale today.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 28 -- The way is now open for Turkey to take a more active role in organizing the Middle East defense by using her increasing influence to win Arab support for military collaboration with the West.

Plans for altering the five-story building at 346 West Eighty-seventh Street into small apartments were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property by the Agatha H. Hadley Estate to a group of builders. The sale was the first involving the house in more than fifty years and was negotiated by Earle Calhoun-Slawson Hobbs, brokers.

The operations of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) for the three months ended last March 31 resulted in an estimated net profit of $126,000,000, equal to $2.08 a share, it was announced yesterday.

TAIPEI, Formosa, April 28 -- President Chiang Kai-shek declared in a lengthy speech released today that in the event of a conclusion of the Korean war the Chinese Communists could take one tenth or one fifth of the forces fighting in Korea and conquer most of Southeast Asia.

Young matrons, including Mrs. Robert W. Sarnoff and Mrs. Bruce A. Gimbel, are furthering the sale of tickets for the performance of "Can-Can," a new musical, on the night of May 19 at the Shubert Theatre for the benefit of Irvington House in Irvington-on-Hudson, N. Y. They have been holding luncheon meetings recently at the Savoy-Plaza to advance plans for the event.
A gay and unusual collection of sportswear designs from Europe was shown yesterday at Gimbels by Elizabeth Appenzellar of that store.

Few professed nature lovers have ever set foot in it, but deep in the heart of New York there is a broad area where mourning doves gather in the spring, where pheasants roam undisturbed, where azaleas bloom and graceful golden willows stand in neat rows.

Evidently two of the Iron Curtain nations -- Poland and Czechoslovakia -- do not see eye to eye on the subject of servicing debts owed to the capitalist creditors of the American dollar world. The Polish People's Republic yesterday took time out to issue a press release emphasizing the fact that it has made a payment of $317,406 on principal and $40,039 on interest on its 1946 loan from the Export-Import Bank.
PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- The directors of the Girard Trust Corn Exchange Bank and the National Bank of Germantown and Trust Company approved today a plan for merger.
A claimant to the title of world's champion wheat grower arrived here yesterday morning on the liner Queen Mary for his first visit to the United States.

Record first-quarter sales and increased net earnings compared with both the previous quarter and the year-ago period were reported yesterday by United States Steel Corporation, the nation's biggest steel producer, following a board of directors' meeting here.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The State Department informally rejected today a proposal by Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, for a five-power peace agreement among the Big Four powers and Communist China.
When and if the time comes to throw Mayor Impellitteri's hat into the ring as a candidate to succeed himself in next fall's city election, Mr. Impellitteri will be the man to throw it.

Directors of the P. Lorillard Company have appointed a new chief executive officer and elected a president and an executive vice president, it was announced yesterday. Herbert A. Kent, chairman of the board of directors and a former president, was designated chief executive officer. William J. Halley was elected president and Frank Hopewell executive vice president.

Edmond J. Moran, president of the Moran Towing and Transportation Company, was re-elected president and chairman of the board of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York at the organization's annual meeting yesterday at 80 Broad Street.

RANGOON, Burma, April 28 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic candidate for the Presidency in 1952, speaking to local and foreign reporters at the United States Ambassador's residence here yesterday, said Southeast Asia was standing up well to Communist disruptive campaigns.

Manager Chuck Dressen was a much happier person last night as he watched the venerable Preacher Roe make his 1953 mound debut by subduing the Redlegs, 5 to 1, before 8,637 chilled customers at Ebbets Field.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 28 -- President Eisenhower is expected to issue a directive soon outlining new machinery for judging the political fitness of United States citizens employed by the United Nations.

LOUISVILLE, April 28 -- A gray horse won the first race at Churchill Downs this gray, overcast afternoon and the superstitious hardboots in this land of the mint juleps and the blue grass promptly pounced on it as just another omen for Saturday's Kentucky Derby. This may be the week for the grays and Native Dancer, the overwhelming favorite, is a gray.

Mayor Impellitteri, his Transit Advisory Commission and the Board of Estimate were accused yesterday of trying to "influence an arbitration panel in the dispute between eight private bus companies and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.

EVEN New York's old rags and other household discards are precious in their way. Large amounts of them finance the $1,000 Kate Butler Memorial Scholarship at Columbia University. They also yield cash gifts up to $150 for undergraduates temporarily in distress, with Columbia's deans quietly passing the funds. Repayment is not demanded.

PARIS, April 28 -- The French Cabinet will discuss tomorrow the crucial military situation in Laos and whether to appeal to the United Nations to condemn the aggression against this Indo-Chinese state by the Communist-led nationalist Vietminh from the adjoining Indo-Chinese state of Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The National Academy of Sciences, top scientific society in the country, joined other important scientific groups today in support of Dr. Allen V. Astin, director of the National Bureau of Standards, who had been summarily dismissed by the Secretary of Commerce, Sinclair Weeks.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, gave the House Foreign Affairs Committee an estimate today that the over-all combat effectiveness of Allied forces in Western Europe would be increased about 30 per cent as a result of plans adopted at the recent Paris meeting of the North Atlantic Council.
LONDON, April 28 (AP) -- Dr. Ernst Kisch, Methodist medical missionary in Korea, died from undernourishment in June, 1951, while a prisoner of the North Koreans, a repatriated Briton said tonight.
Following is the text of the statement by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan denying a parade application by the United Labor and People's Committee for May Day to march this Friday:

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The White House is hesitating about nominating John W. Edelman of the Congress of Industrial Organizations for Assistant Secretary of Labor, but, since his competence is not challenged, the C. I. O. will not withdraw him.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The top policy planners of the nation's Reserve forces debated a plan today to raise the status of the civilian and military officials responsible for administering Reserve affairs.

Frozen foods have limited tolerance to temperature fluctuations likely to occur on their route from producer to consumer. Early mishandling renders the products extremely sensitive to any later adversity.
Prices of cotton futures were irregular on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closed 18 points higher to 10 points lower than on Monday.

BOSTON, April 28 (UP) -- Featherweight Tommy Collins indicated today he might "pull outa Boston just like the Braves" -- but would resume his ring career within sixty days despite his beating last Friday by Jimmy Carter, lightweight champion.
CAMDEN, N. J., April 28 (UP) -- Indian Land, a stretch-running colt from the Alfred Vanderbilt stable, dashed to a neck victory over Hyphasis today in the $20,000 added handicap at Garden State Park.

DES MOINES, April 28 (UP) -- Dr. Louis H. Bauer, president of the American Medical Association, outlined a six-point program today including expansion of volunteer medical insurance as a means of preventing socialized medicine.

The Greater New York Fund is the "united charity where the unfortunate of every creed is aided by the generosity of all creeds," District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Kings County said yesterday at a luncheon opening the fund's $800,000 Brooklyn drive.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 29 (UP) -- United States Navy planes from the carriers Princeton and Valley Forge flattened two Communist build-up areas in northeast Korea yesterday and made roaring bonfires of the wreckage.

CAIRO, April 28 -- Egyptian and British negotiators seeking to define a new status for the Suez Canal zone still were skirmishing around the edges of the problem today without reaching a discussion of the main issue -- the Egyptian demand for withdrawal of the British forces.

An American edition of "Lost Trails, Lost Cities," by Col. P. H. Fawcett, edited by his son, Brian Fawcett, has been scheduled for May 14 publication by Funk Wagnalls. It is an account of Colonel Fawcett's seven explorations into the heart of the Amazon Basin.

Those who would wash the city clean of all its dust and dirt are agreed that keeping New York clean is a jumbo job. To dramatize the need of civic cleanliness, the new Greater New York Citizens Clean-Up, Paint-Up, Fix-Up Committee sought yesterday a pair of elephants to strike the keynote of its spring program.
GLOVERSVILLE, N. Y., April 28 -- Thomas J. Curran, Secretary of State, asserted today that the Republican party had gained strength this year in both the state and the nation.

Many representative members of society attended the Ciro Ball, the annual spring dinner dance for the benefit of the New York Infirmary, last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Thomas M. Bancroft and Mrs. Eugene W. Ong, trustees of the beneficiary, were in charge of arrangements.
An exhibit of eighty-four Dutch paintings and etchings lent by private collectors and museums opened last night at the Sara Delano Roosevelt Memorial House, 47 East Sixty-fifth Street.

A child's religious affiliation cannot be changed unless both parents consent, Justice Jacob Panken ruled yesterday in the Children's Court Division of the Domestic Relations Court. He said that until this year the law stipulated that even a child's name could not be changed unless both parents agreed. "The question of religion is much more important than a change of name," he said, adding that he thus considered his finding a matter of law.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 28 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century won the top honors in the opening Westchester division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class A one-day tournament today. Playing over the well-groomed Knollwood Country Club course.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income, after all taxes and other charges, of $47,623,654, or $2.81 a common share, in the twelve months to March 31. This compared with $40,389,298, or $2.33 a share, in the preceding twelve months.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- A threat by Senate leaders to keep the chamber in continuous session broke the four-week debate against state ownership of offshore lands today.

BALTIMORE, April 28 -- The 1952 "Champion of Human Rights" award, inaugurated this year and to be conferred annually by the Baltimore chapter of the American Jewish Congress, was presented tonight to Philip B. Perlman of Baltimore, former United States Solicitor General and chairman of the Truman Commission on Immigration and Naturalization.

PARIS, April 28 -- Former Premier Antoine Pinay, leader of the Independents, the winning group in Sunday's municipal elections, issued an appeal today for union among the Right and Center parties to consolidate the election victory.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Following is the vote by which the Senate, 58 to 26, today defeated an amendment by Senators Paul H. Douglas of Illinois and Clinton P. Anderson of New Mexico, both Democrats, to establish Federal ownership of submerged offshore lands beyond the three-mile limit.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Republican economy lines held fast in all tests today as the House of Representatives approved major cuts in outlays for public power and other activities of the Interior Department.

Sidney A. Swensrud, president of the Gulf Oil Corporation since 1948, was elected chairman of the board of directors yesterday. William K. Whiteford, formerly executive vice president, was elected president and will be chief administrative officer of the company.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Theodore Kaghan, a State Department Foreign Service officer, faced Senate investigators today in a secret, closed-door session.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Defense Department announced tonight that a "small group" of exchanged American soldiers had shown indications of "having succumbed to Communist indoctrination" while they were captive in North Korea, and would be given medical and mental treatment.

LONDON, April 28 -- The stock markets continued slightly dull today after having opened firmer on yesterday's Wall Street rally. Doubts over the outcome of Korean truce talks kept buyers away and it was this lack of support rather than any marked selling that produced more small declines.
Mayor Impellitteri reaffirmed yesterday his faith in his assistant, Frank J. Sampson, and made it clear that he had given no thought to dismissal.

CHICAGO, April 28, (AP) -- The White Sox today summoned Harry Dorish to the rescue for the sixth time this season and the right-hander checked a ninth rally to enable the Sox to gain a 5-4 victory over the Senators.

An increase in the admission ages to kindergarten and first-grade classes has been recommended by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, and approved by the Board of Education's committee on instructional affairs. The changes are expected to be approved officially at tomorrow's board meeting, when the necessary revisions in the by-laws will be made.
Martha Graham and her company of dancers will give a season of seven performances at the Alvin Theatre beginning Sunday. May 17, and closing the following Saturday evening, with no matinees.
PARIS, April 28 -- A strike by about 700 officers of the French Line threatened tonight to delay the sailing of the liner Ile de France, scheduled to leave Le Havre for New York at 2 P. M. tomorrow.

ST. LOUIS, April 28 -- free-for-all fight that saw punches flying on the diamond and bottles from the stands marred tonight's 7-6 overtime victory by the Yankees over the Browns. The battle royal around second base in the bottom of the tenth inning caused a seventeen-minute delay before order finally was restored.

Four changes in its general advertising policy were announced yesterday by the Ladies' Home Journal, which reported that with the May issue it has exceeded 5,000,000 circulation for the fifth consecutive issue. The magazine will increase its circulation base rate and its advertising rates, and introduce a new schedule of discounts and new advertising space units.

Negotiations have been opened between the Long Island Transit Authority and the Pennsylvania Railroad looking to the formulation of a mutually acceptable plan for terminating the Long Island Rail Road Company's bankruptcy and restoring it to private operation.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 28 (AP) -- Three of ten horsemen faced with a showdown over racing terms have agreed to participate in the Hollywood Park meeting starting on May 12, James D. Stewart, general manager, said today.

GENEVA, April 28 -- Emil Arnold, member of the Swiss Parliament and a leader of Switzerland's small Labor (Communist) party, was sentenced today to eight months in prison and two years' loss of civil rights by the Federal court in Basle for "endangering the security of the state" by a speech made in Budapest in 1951.

At the Board of Estimate hearing on the school share of the proposed executive budget for 1953-54 Superintendent Jansen called attention to an important footnote. Besides eliminating $15.2 millions of the Board of Education's request the proposed budget carries a statement that before Sept. 1, 1953, the Board of Education will submit a list of specific reductions in the professional staff to effect "savings" totaling another $2 millions.

James A. Wechsler, editor of The New York Post, released yesterday a telegram he sent to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, agreeing to name people he knew as young Communists years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (UP) -- Al Brazle and Jerry Staley stopped rallies by the Phillies in the eighth and ninth innings as the Cardinals scored a 6-5 victory and snapped the Phils' streak at eight straight, their longest string since 1950.

David W. Peck, Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division, First Department, declared last night that the use of juries in civil cases was cumbersome, slow and inordinately expensive. He urged that the practice be ended.

In the week since Miss Edna Ferber got off the boat from Europe and pronounced New York the dirtiest city in the world this newspaper has received more than a score of letters from readers, all irate at the condition of New York's streets. Not one thus far received comes to the defense of the Sanitation Department, except to suggest occasionally that citizens littering the streets are also to blame.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan refused yesterday to allow what he called a Communist-front May Day group to parade down any city streets this Friday, on the ground that anti-Communist feelings of other citizens "would create a potential riot-laden situation."

Susan Elaine Eisenhower, President and Mrs. Eisenhower's youngest grandchild, posed for her portrait recently, and the result will be on exhibition today at Portraits, Inc., 137 East Fifty-seventh Street, in the gallery's annual "Portraits in Review" show, which continues through May 18.
WALDEN, N. Y., April 28 -- Mrs. Jane M. Johnston, Mayor of this Orange County village, died late last night after taking an overdose of sleeping, tablets. She was 57 years old.
TOKYO, Wednesday, April 29 (AP) -- United Nations Command Headquarter communique 1,599 for the twenty-four hours to Wednesday 6 A. M.:
The sun emerged from behind clouds early yesterday afternoon just long enough to warm a chilled May Queen at her coronation amidst pink and white cherry blossoms in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

BERLIN, April 28 -- Bishop Otto Dibelius, head of the Evangelical Church in both East and West Germany, in effect defied the East German Government today by telling church youth groups in the Soviet zone to continue functioning.

When the expected period of "tough selling" in all fields arrives, request for funds from top management for advertising, research and other sales aids may encounter considerable resistance, James J. Nance, president of the Packard Motor Car Company, gave this warning yesterday at a luncheon in the Roosevelt Hotel of the Sales Executives Club of New York,

ATLANTIC CITY, April 28 -- The nation's knitwear manufacturers now have an opportunity to bring their machinery up to date without the prolonged delays usual in a period of armament build-up, according to textile machine builders exhibiting their products at the biennial Knitting Arts Exposition.
LONDON, April 28 (AP) -- Viscountess Astor said today that women just seem to get dumber and dumber.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 29 -- In the workshops of the United Nations a young American artist has been busily copying the coats-of-arms of each member government in brilliant blues, reds and gold, to form a vivid backdrop for the speakers' platform in the General Assembly chamber.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Farm prices declined 2 percent between mid-march and mid-April, the Deaprtment of Agriculture reported today. In the preceeding month prices had gone up two levels of 1 per cent to halt temporarily a long down turn.

John Carter Vincent, a State Department adviser on China policy in the Truman Administration and central figure in a celebrated loyalty case, returned to the United States yesterday with the status of a retired career diplomat, and he immediately voiced his disagreement with the reasons assigned by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles for his dismissal.

STAMFORD, Conn., April 29 -- Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, told a group of Fairfield County newspaper executives and Dartmouth alumni tonight that freedom of the press was given to the public and not to the publishers.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- The Philadelphia National Bank observed its sesquicentennial tonight as host at an anniversary dinner attended by representatives of forty-three Philadelphia concerns as old or older than itself.

The principal change which President Eisenhower's new security plan for federal employes makes in the Truman program is that it lumps together disloyalty and lack of security as grounds on which any employe can be discharged. The practical effect of this change is that henceforth an employe dismissed from federal service under the security program does not necessarily bear the onus of disloyalty to his country.
Executives have been changing jobs more rapidly than ever before.

NEWMARKET, England, April 29 (AP) -- Bill Humble's Nearula, a 13-to-5 favorite, won the 2,000 Guineas by four lengths today as Queen Elizabeth's colt, Aureole, ran fifth in the first of the British classic races for 3-year-olds.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Spokesmen for ten of the country's smaller industries appealed to Congress today for protection against what they termed unfair and damaging competition from foreign imports.

This port's longshoremen will be permanently barred from supporting the strikes of others through secondary boycotting should an agreement reached yesterday be formalized by the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., its New York District Council and the New York Shipping Association.

PARIS, April 29 -- The United States' revision of its foreign aid philosophy, by stipulating that assistance must be based solely upon tangible achievements in the realm of Western defense, poses a problem with regard to Spain.

LONDON, April 29 (Reuters) -- The first wool futures market over held in Britain opened today in a newly-built trading ring in London's commodity trading center. The floor was crowded with many British, United States, Commonwealth and European representatives.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- Brunswick - Balke - Collender Company, Inc., reported today a loss of $391,498 in the three months ended March 31, compared with a loss of $270,184 in the corresponding period of 1952. The figures include the Canadian subsidiary.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey announced today that individuals, partnerships and personal trust accounts had bought more of the new thirty-year Treasury bonds than any other investor class.

The establishment of a research group to investigate the causes and prevention of pre-birth injuries and malformations was urged yesterday by Dr. Josef Warkany, Professor of Pediatric Research at the University of Cincinnati.

As Coney Island came forward yesterday with an offer to "train down" the City's Council's softball team into proper competition weights and training form, the Council's committee on indoor sports notified the Chicago City Council that New York stood ready to accept the Windy City's "brazen" challenge.

Sound financing principles for unemployment insurance have not been established by the states, with the result that control over benefits is being undermined and greater dependence upon the Federal Government is developing.

Volumes improved on cottonseed oil, soybean oil and hides on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday, while rubber and zinc continued active. Prices closed irregular with zinc, lead, rubber, coffee and sugar showing increases. Hides, cocoa, soybean oil, cottonseed oil, potatoes and tin were lower and wool ended mixed.
The cotton futures market here closed irregular yesterday, 15 points lower to 7 points higher than on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- American ports are not secure against possible sabotage and other threats to the national safety, Rear Admiral Raymond J. Mauerman, Coast Guard chief of operations, told a Senate Commerce subcommittee today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 29 -- Dag Hammarskjold, in his first official communication with a United Nations organ since becoming Secretary General, said today that he would defer action on proposals by Trygve Lie, his predecessor, for reorganizing the Secretariat.

TRAVIS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., April 29 -- A 7,000-mile journey from Communist prison camps to a midday dinner of thick steaks and strawberry shortcake on the United States main land ended today for thirty-five United States fighting men.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 29 (AP) -- C. R. Smith, president of American Airlines, Inc., said today the turbo-propeller engine basically was more suitable than the turbo-jet engine for air transportation requirements.

Knowing the interest of Americans in the unification of a free Europe, I feel that I must write to tell you how relieved we all were to hear the words of President Eisenhower and Secretary Dulles when they stated as one of the fundamental problems of peace the liberation and integration of the peoples now under Soviet domination.

WASHINGTON, April (AP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organization said today it was protesting against what it called "the announced program of turning atomic energy development over to the big monopolistic corporations."
LOS ANGELES, Calif., April 29 -- "Three dimensional" television was broadcast for the first time here today in a special test.

ALBANY, April 29 -- Lewis A. Wilson, State Education Commissioner, said today that, while the schools of the state were still faced with such serious problems as inflationary costs, building needs and teacher shortages, progress had been made during the last year along many lines.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 29 -- As expenditures on defense begin to lose their direct influence on economic growth, it will be vital to insure that gaps left by contractions in investment on armaments are filled by alternative expenditures as quickly as they materialize, David H. Morse, director general of the International Labor Organization, stated in his annual report, released today.

TORONTO, April 29 (AP) -- The International Nickel Company of Canada supplied more than 75 per cent of the nickel used in the free world last year, for the third successive year, stockholders were told at the concern's annual meeting here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 29 -- Mrs. Alva Myrdal, internationally known Swedish sociologist, was refused official permission to enter the United States as a visitor on United Nations business when she arrived here March 19 and was admitted only after she had signed an agreement putting her on parole for the duration of her three-week stay.
TRENTON, April 29 (AP) -- The New Jersey Public Utilities Commission today ordered railroads operating within the state to adopt stronger safety measures before Nov. 1.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, warned the Parliaments of Western Europe tonight that delay in their approval of the European Army was holding back the only "good solution" to the problem of creating a strong and peaceful Europe.

DETROIT, April 29 (UP) -- Chuck Davey, blood streaming from his right eye for the last seven rounds, scored a technical knockout over young Sammy Giuliani of Stamford, Conn., tonight in the last round of their scheduled ten-round bout at Olympia.
For the fourth successive day stock prices rose yesterday, clambering slowly but steadily for most of the session but losing some ground near the close.

LONDON, April 29 -- Labor Members of Parliament protested today against including the former German Gen. Hans Speidel, once Chief of Staff to Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, among the guests at military demonstrations in Brittain next week. They said the visit was unwise and premature and an affront to those who had fought against Marshal Rommel in Africa.

Five Methodist missionaries who have been captives in North Korea since June 25, 1950, are to return home, the Rev. Dr. Thoburn T. Brumbaugh, administrative secretary for Korea of the Methodist Board of Missions, 150 Fifth Avenue, said yesterday.
TOKYO, Thursday, April 30 (AP) -- Released United States prisoners, back in the sunshine of freedom more than a week, told new stories yesterday of Red terror.

Gasoline stocks in the nation amounted to 157,990,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This represented an increase of 48,000 barrels from the week-ago level and compared with 155,367,000 barrels a year ago.

PARIS, April 29 -- The French Line delayed the sailing of its 43,000-ton liner Ile de France today when a strike by officers of the company in Le Havre prevented her departure for New York with 755 passengers.

LONDON, April 29 -- By the electrical manipulation of hundreds of valves and circulits, the largest electronic calculating machine at the University of Cambridge here has been "taught" a conditioned reflex action like that of a trained dog.
Army experts on airborne troops -- entranced after World War II by the vision of a great airborne army -- are, like the armored leaders, greatly disappointed at the limited progress of postwar years.

A community rally to protest vandalism in the Bronx will be held next Sunday night in the Pilgrim Congregational Church, 1800 Grand Concourse, as the result of three acts of vandalism committed against the church in the last Lenten season.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 29 -- "Gentlemen Marry Brunettes," from the pen of Anita Loos, who created "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," will be produced independently in Europe this summer by Richard Sale under the banner of Film Locations, Ltd., a British company in which Montague Marks and Mike Frankovich are associated.

One reason New York is sometimes called the "Wonder City" is that its engineers have found answers to such questions as "I wonder how we could build a water-supply system to provide for 8,000,000 persons?" or "I wonder how we could build a safe railway under ground?"

NEW DELHI, India, April 29 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali of Pakistan has made an official personal approach to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India for a meeting of the two leaders on Kashmir and other disputes existing between their two countries.

MEXICO, CITY, April 29 (AP) -- Ben Hogan, center of a controversy involving a reported bonus to play here, shot a 69, three under par, today in the pro-amateur preliminary to the Pan-American open golf championship, beginning tomorrow.

The retirement of Miss Anna Eva McLin as director of the Child Education Foundation, 535 East Eighty-fourth Street, was announced yesterday by the organization's board of trustees. The retirement will become effective on June 30.

Louis I. Kaplan, who had just completed the Government's twenty-six-month investigation of the illegal sale of gold on the black market that resulted in the indictment of twenty-two persons, tendered his resignation yesterday as an assistant United States attorney, effective tomorrow.

The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's biggest steel-maker, announced yesterday that it was raising the prices of some steel products, effective today, "for the most part through adjustments in 'extras.' "

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP) -- Harold T. Woerner, a Yale graduate who now sells oil burners, refused to tell House of Representatives investigators today whether he belonged to a Red "youth cell" while in college.
CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- A vicious spring storm that hit Texas with death-dealing twisters, cloud-bursts and lightning, moved eastward across Louisiana and Mississippi today.
LONDON, April 29 (Reuters) -- The Glasgow Rangers defeated Aberdeen, 1 -- 0, in a hard-fought game at Glasgow today to win the Scottish soccer cup final.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 30 -- The United Nations today branded as "undesirable" a Communist proposal that prisoners of the Korean war who refuse to return behind the Iron Curtain be turned over to an "Asian nation" while their eventual fate is settled in an international political conference.

TRENTON, April 29 -- Republican State Chairman John J. Dickerson testified under oath here today that he had helped elect Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City, a Democrat, in May, 1949, in return for which Mr. Kenny assured the election of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll the following November by keeping to a record minimum the Democratic vote in Hudson County.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 29 -- Four more Princeton students were arrested tonight and charged with disorderly conduct as the result of a new incident in this normally peaceful college town, tense after last night's student roistering.

NEWARK, April 29 -- A majority of' the striking members of the Telephone Workers Union, independent, have voted to accept an agreement between the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company and union negotiators, John J. Curtis, president of the union, announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The following is the text of President Eisenhower's speech tonight before a dinner meeting of the United States Chamber of Commerce:

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A new radio telescope that can penetrate to a distance of six billon light years into space, three times farther than the 200-inch Hale Telescope of the Mount Palomar Observatory in California, the world's largest optical telescope, was described here today at the annual meeting of the National Academy of Sciences.

BONN, Germany, April 29 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer ran into more parliamentary difficulty today when he submitted the London debt agreement for ratification in the Bundestag, lower house of the Federal Parliament.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 22, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The demand for high-styled leisure-wear shirts has increased, moving them from the luxury to the necessity category, Alfred Shapiro. president of Alfred of New York, makers of sports shirts, declared yesterday. A sports shirt is no longer just a dress shirt with an open collar, but it has become an important style item, he said.
