DUBLIN, April 29 (AP) -- Former Agriculture Minister James Dillon told Parliament tonight that "if Ireland is neutral between Moscow and Washington, then it is damned."
The city moved ahead yesterday with its new program for developing revenue-producing parking lots when the Public Works Department opened bids for the first lot to be built under the project.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, wired James A. Wechsler, editor of The New York Post, today that the did not regard editors as "immune" to investigation.

LOUISVILLE, April 29 -- The early morning mists were still steaming up from the grass when Ben Jones vaulted into the saddle of his palomino pony to lead a set of his Calumet horses out on the track for their works.
CANNES, France, April 29 (AP) -- Shirley Booth, American actress, tonight was named the world's best actress for her performance in "Come Back, Little Sheba."

The New York Foundling Hospital and television station WPIX will cooperate in presenting a new weekly prgram entitled "A New Home for a Child" beginning Sunday from 12:15 to 12:30 P. M. Supervised by Msgr. John E. Reilly, directing head of the institution, the program will give case histories of children for potential adoption or placement in foster homes.

American Jews have given $416,000,000 to help the people of Israel in that nation's five-year history, Rudolf G. Sonneborn, national chairman of the United Israel Appeal, announced yesterday in a report to the agency's board of directors.

The price of lead was advanced a half cent a pound to 12 1/2 cents yesterday by a leading mine producer, and other sellers quickly matched the new quotation. This brought the price up to the level in effect between April 15 and April 20.

Mrs. Inocenio Medina, whose son, Pfc. Raymond H. Medina, was the second New York area prisoner returned by the Chinese, received a picture of him yesterday taken by the Far Eastern Division of the Red Cross at a Tokyo hospital.
The State of South Carolina announced yesterday that it will receive bids on May 19 on an issue of $15,000,000 school bonds dated May 1 and due on the same date from 1954 to 1968.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Senate foreign policy leaders declared today that important military supplies originally intended for Europe would be diverted by the United States to Indo-China to help the hard-pressed French against the Communist-led rebels.

BONN, Germany, April 29 -- The West German Government will make a new attempt next month to push the Allied-German treaties through the Bundesrat or upper house of the Federal Parliament, Government sources said today.

City College defeated Manhattan. 16 -- 3, for the second time this season in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game at Van Cortlandt Park, Bronx, yesterday and took over first place in the league standings with a mark of six and two.
Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. shook hands last night with Andrei Y. Vishinsky. Mr. Lodge refused to shake hands with Mr. Vishinsky earlier this year when their paths first crossed at the United Nations.

Declaring that a police permit to demonstrate tomorrow in Union Square was a "partial victory," the United Labor and People's Committee for May Day bowed yesterday to Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan's order barring it from parading on any city streets.

PITTSBURGH, April 29 (AP) -- Pete Castiglione blasted a two-run single in the eighth inning and the Pirates snapped a five-game losing streak with 4-3 victory tonight over the Cubs. Cal Abrams hit a homer for the Pirates to start the three-run eighth inning rally.

THE TIMES of April 26 tells of the plan that has been approved by the North Atlantic Treaty council. According to this plan, "sound national economies" are to be developed concurrently with the "increase of military forces."

FARMINGDALE, L. I., April 29 -- Two successive explosion-like blasts caused by a jet plane that was diving at speeds faster than sound over Long Island alarmed residents of the South Shore at 12:30 P. M. today. Their anxious inquiries flooded police and newspaper switchboards.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., April 29 -- Radioactive chemicals, or radioisotopes, "have no place in cosmetics because of the danger associated with their use," W. B. Rankin of the Federal Food and Drug Administration declared at the Oak Ridge Institute of Nuclear Studies here.

YONKERS, April 29 (AP) -- Dick Thomas, driving the supposedly weaker part of the Henry Thomas entry, Blitzen Up, scored a two-length victory tonight in the featured Westchester Trot before 20,637 at Yonkers Raceway.

LONDON, April 29 -- There were signs of slight improvement in the stock markets here today after a weak opening. Prices for foreign bonds and base metal shares rallied in the afternoon to close with small net gains. South African gold mining issues were a weak exception and relapsed afresh in late dealings.

Joe Adcock hit a ball into the center-field bleachers of the Polo Grounds -- the first time this feat has been achieved in a major league contest -- as the slump-shackled Giants dropped a second straight decision to the Braves, 3 -- 2, yesterday.

CHICACO, April 29 -- Heavy liquidating pressure combined with indifferent demand caused declines in all grains today, but pressure was greatest on the May deliveries. Large deleveries on May contracts of wheat, corn and rye are looked for, with possibly substantial deliveries on oats also. As a result, traders were inclined to mark time pending the effort of such deliveries on the markets.

Notice that the Liberal party was not committed to any candidate, policy or pattern of action affecting the city election in November was sent yesterday to all party clubs and county organizations by Ben Davidson, executive director.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican leader of the Senate, warned against Senate acceptance of any "half-baked proposition" as proposals were pressed today to use revenues from offshore oil to reduce the $265,000,000,000 national debt.

Ethel Barrymore, the actress, and Harper Bros., publisher, were named co-defendants yesterday in Supreme Court in a suit filed by Hermitage House, Inc., another publishing concern, which charged that Miss Barrymore had broken an agreement to write her memoirs for it.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio today assailed Harry Bridges, leader of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, and charged him with "misrepresentation in practically every statement" Bridges made to the Senate Labor Committee.
The Standard Fruit and Steamship Company announced yesterday that it would operate a series of twelve-day cruises this summer from New York to La Ceiba, Honduras.

Younger members of society, including Miss Nancy Moreland and Miss Marguerite Stehli, are active in the plans for the entertainment known as the Moonlight Mist Ball, to be held tonight under the auspices of the New York City Cancer Committee of the American Cancer Society, Inc., in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the organization.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- Directors of the Inland Steel Company, Chicago, elected Clarence B. Randall as chairman and Joseph L. Block as president today. Mr. Randall, who was president, will continue as chief executive officer. Mr. Block was executive vice president.
Your editorial on the position of the Liberal party seems to me wholly inaccurate and misleading. In addition, it misreads the plain facts of New York City politics.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- Dr. Bret Ratner, Professor of Clinical Pediatrics at New York Medical College, New York City, said today in a press conference that under certain conditions kisses from a man with a mustache could be dangerous to food sensitive persons.

Today's new film is "Double Confession," a British-made melodrama with Derek Farr, Joan Hopkins, Kathleen Harrison, Peter Lorre and William Hartnell, at the Little Carnegie. Ken Annakin directed and Harry Reynolds produced the Stratford Pictures release, which has a screen play by William Templeton, as adapted by Ralph Keene from John Garden's novel, "All on a Summer's Day."

PITTSBURGH, April 29 -- In the Western Pennsylvania School for the Blind visually handicapped boys and girls are learning to do home-making chores such as baking pies and cakes, cooking meals and doing the wash.

For many years -- about 300, say -- the name of Claudio Monteverdi was one that occupied more space in the musical history books than in the repertoire. Lately, the musicians and public have been becoming aware of his stature, and last night's performance in Carnegie Hall by the Dessoff Choirs of the "Vespers and Magnificat in Honor of the Blessed Virgin" is but another indication of the composer's growing popularity.

There was no lack of charm in the summer fashions shown yesterday at the Pierre Hotel by Claire McCardell and available at Lord Taylor. In addition to their usual casual effect, there was softness and femininity not previously associated with this fashion creator's work.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29 -- It now appears that there will be eleven or twelve starters in Saturday's seventy-ninth running of the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs, with Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's unbeaten Native Dancer the favorite at something like 1 to 2.

That some boys and girls in New York will grow up to be farmers is as certain as the fact that carrots soon will sprout from the plots seeded by the children yesterday on the grounds of the Rockefeller Institute, York Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

CHICAGO, April 29 (UP) -- Right-hander Bob Porterfield shackled the White Sox with five hits today and won his own game with a third-inning single as the Senators downed the Pale Hose, 3 to 0, before 2,879.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- John W. Ford, State Department security officer, said today that a survey of department personnel files had revealed at least 4,300 cases in which employes had been inadequately investigated or not investigated at all.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- President Eisenhower will make an announcement tomorrow afternoon on the momentous subject of defense policy of the United States and the related security of the free world.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Theodore Kaghan, American Foreign Service officer in Germany who recently denounced two McCarthy subcommittee investigators as "junketeering gumshoes" in Europe, told that panel today that a decade of fighting communism had qualified him to direct counter-propaganda and psychological warfare against the Soviet Union.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 29 -- The real battle on the Brazilian-United States military aid pact began today, after the Senate approved a motion of urgency on the issue.

Sales and net income of the Republic Steel Corporation in the first quarter of 1953 increased 12 per cent and 17 per cent, respectively, above those recorded in the first quarter of 1952, it was announced yesterday.

There were many who looked with regret at the bulldozers that moved in last summer to uproot the linden trees from the Museum of Modern Art's Fifty-fourth Street garden. Official reassurances that a new garden was being planned were small comfort to those who had enjoyed one of the city's few green oases.

PARIS, April 29 -- After a stormy discussion the French Cabinet split today over the question of "internationalizing" the Indo-China conflict by an appeal to the United Nations on the aggression against Laos. The Cabinet put off a solution of this issue and a number of others connected with the war in Indo-China until May 8, just before the National Assembly returns from the election recess.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 29 (AP) -- B-29 bomber simulating combat caught fire and crashed six miles south of its home base today, killing ten fliers. Five parachuted to safety.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- At the suggestion of Fred M. Vinson, Chief Justice of the United States, President Eisenhower today called a conference for the purpose of reducing delays, expense and volume of records in the quasi-judicial and other rule-making agencies of the Government. The object is relief and expedition for the citizen in contact with the agencies.

Honored by the Advertising Club of New York as "Our Television Man of the Year," Bishop Fulton J. Sheen advocated yesterday the cooperation of all in the field of communications for the attainment of truth.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 29 (UP) -- Top-seeded Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., and second seeded Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, virtually walked into the singles quarter-finals of the British hard courts lawn tennis championships today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 29 (AP) -- Expanding Brazil, hopeful of creating its own national automobile industry, is considering a stiff new series of regulations on the importation of cars.

An oil painting of one of the most popular and profitable vessels of the American clipper ship era has been placed on display at the Seamen's Bank for Savings on Wall Street, marking the hundredth anniversary today of the launching of the ship at the yard of William H. Webb, between Fifth and Seventh Streets, East River.
Dividend-paying habits of New York Stock Exchange common stocks have come under the scrutiny of The Exchange, magazine published by the New York Stock Exchange.
Original dress designs were presented by fashion students yesterday morning at the Pratt Institute to representatives of the fashion industry and the press.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 29 -- Three hundred and fifty Vietnamese recruits were kidnapped from a French-sponsored training center late last night in a bold raid staged by the Communist-led Vietminh troops in the lower Red River Delta.
Following is the text of an address by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles on the recently concluded North Atlantic Treaty Organization conferences as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
OTTAWA, April 29 -- Austin E. Dewar, Liberal Member of Parliament for Qu'Appelle, Saskatchewan, announced his resignation in the House of Commons this morning and his intention to seek re-election.
Horse racing, which used to be called the sport of kings, is threatening to become the king of sports.
THE wet weather has been providing difficulties for the trout fisherman and, at the same time, stimulating the growth of the grass that adds to the "spotting" problems of the varmint shooter.

SECAUCUS, N. J., April 29 -- Elmer H. Wene of Vineland gained 117 votes here today as the official recounting of votes cast in the Democratic primary in Jersey City's 312 election districts was completed. Mr. Wene was defeated April 21 by former State Senator Robert B. Meyner for the Democratic nomination for Governor by 1,683 votes, the official total being 107,752 votes for Mr. Meyner and 106,069 votes for Mr. Wene.
CLEVELAND, April 29 (AP) -- Early Wynn limited Philadelphia to four hits today as the Indians trimmed the Athletics, 2 -- 1, and moved to within one game of the front-running Yankees, who were idle.

SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., April 29 -- Two San Bernardino mining prospectors were emitting radioactivity from their bodies eighty hours after having come into contact with an atomic dust cloud on the Nevada desert, it was announced today by physicians and scientists who examined them.
I am referring to your recent editorial, "The Astin Case."

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP) -- Dr. John R. Heller, director of the National Cancer Institute, says any connection between heavy smoking and lung cancer has not been definitely established "to our satisfaction,"
TOKYO, April 29 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 390 for period ended at 6 P. M. Wednesday, Korean time:

The Consolidated Gas Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore reported yesterday a net income of $3,694,047 for the three months ended March 31, equal to 68 cents a share on the common stock. This compared with $3,050,289 or 56 cents a share in the like 1952 quarter.

ON TUESDAY nights alert and sensible persons in these latitudes like to be near a radio at 9:45. They set their dials or their channel readings for WQXR. At that moment the Oxford-man-from-Glasgow voice of Gilbert Highet goes on the air. What does he talk about? He talks about people (not persons, please).
Progress in employment opportunities for Negroes on a higher level than in the past was reported yesterday by Lester B. Granger, executive director of the National Urban League.

Representatives of eleven national organizations dealing with mental illness have agreed that the nursing professions should assume leadership and responsibility for training of all nursing personnel caring for psychiatric patients, the American Nurses Association and the National League for Nursing announced yesterday.
WINNIPEG, Man., April 29 (Canadian Press) -- Low April rainfall on the praires has increased the odds against an average grain crop this year.

A course in family life education, requested and outlined by students, is described by Mrs. Payton Kennedy, dean of girls at Thomas Jefferson High School, San Antonio, Tex., in the current issue of The Journal of Social Hygiene.

MANILA, Thursday, April 30 -- President Elpidio Quirino's Secretary of Justice resigned from the Cabinet yesterday under fire from the Opposition in the Philippine Senate. It was the third Cabinet resignation since March 1 in the rough and tumble political warfare incident to next November's Presidential election.

The Dodgers received a "gift" triumph at Ebbets Field yesterday. With the bases loaded and two out in the ninth, Carl Furillo dashed home from third on a passed ball as the National League champions accepted a 6-5 decision over the Redlegs.

Hal Price Headley's Revolt won the forty-first running of the Youthful yesterday. As 21,920 fans looked on at Jamaica, the son of Revoked registered by two lengths over C. V. Whitney's Catspaw while Terrebonne, owned by Fortune P. Ryan, ran third.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 29 -- Reporting on the first 100 days' achievements of the Eisenhower Administration, Mrs. Ivy Baker Priest, Treasurer of the United States, told 300 Republican women here this afternoon that national confidence in the Government had been restored, the international integrity of the nation had improved and many millions of dollars of tax money had been saved.

J. M. Scott, author of "The Will and the Way," a mountain climbing adventure story, has turned to the sea for the plot of his new novel. Entitled "Heather Mary," the story deals with the skipper of a small yacht of the same name. It was named for the skipper's dead wife, to whom the four members of the crew were devoted.

Business men and city officials banded together yesterday to form the Committee to Abolish Bowery Conditions. The committee was formed at a luncheon-meeting at the Dry Dock Savings Bank, 341 Bowery, at which Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh placed blame for the conditions at City Hall, where, he said, "Mayor Impellitteri isn't interested in this or any other social problems that confront the courts."
ST. LOUIS, April 29 -- The return bout between the Yankees and the Browns was rained out today.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Broad national interests rather than the welfare of a single industry should be the controlling factor in deciding whether a tariff rate should be increased, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States asserted today.
SEOUL, Thursday, April 30 (AP) -- Rains pelted the inactive Korean battle front yesterday as ground fighting dropped to a low ebb and most Allied war planes were grounded.

Recent reports from Washington point to the probability that a general overhaul of its methods is under way on the part of the Federal Trade Commission, the agency charged with enforcing the provisions of the Anti-Trust Act and the Federal Trade Commission Act.

There is reason for alarm and regret over recent developments in Ecuador. The alarm comes from the arbitrary attacks on freedom of the press by President Velasco Ibarra. Two newspapers of Guayaquil -- La Hora and La Nacion -- were shut down last week and their editors arrested because they were critical of the Government and, according to the President, were inciting the army to revolt.

GENEVA, April 29 -- Nobody seems to want to take the responsibility for the Chinese refugees in Hong Kong. This was the only clear conclusion emerging from the debate today in the advisory council of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees on what to do about the unfortunate Chinese stranded in the British colony on the edge of the Chinese mainland.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. added sixty two organizations today to the list of groups classified by the Department of Justice as totalitarian, Fascist, Communist or subversive. He redesignated 192 organizations already on the list.

QUITO, Ecuador, April 29 (AP) -- The Government today released Jorge Mantilla, Quito news executive who was arrested with five others yesterday for protesting the Government closing of two Opposition newspapers.

" Men of Distinction," a first comedy by Richard Condon, makes its Broadway debut tonight at 8:05 o'clock at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre under the auspices of Chandler Cowles and Martin Gabel. Robert Preston, seen here in revivals of "Twentieth Century" and more recently in "The Male Animal," is starred in the cast that includes David Burns, Martin Ritt, Orson Bean, Mr. Cowles, Jean Carson, Ralph Bunker and Diana Herbert.

The Netherlands Music Committee and the Hunter College Music Department will hold a musicale at 4 P. M. today in Roosevelt House, 47 East Sixty-fifth Street, as part of the college's two-week "Salute to the Dutch Founders of Our City" and to New York's 300th anniversary as a municipality.

Our own inclination would have been to let the Communists and their sympathizers parade on May Day. In that way they would have proved once more how few they are, measured against the millions of New Yorkers who despise communism. We think, but cannot prove, that Police Commissioner Monaghan has exaggerated the dangers of violence and public disturbance in refusing to permit the parade.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of upstate New York, said today that the House of Representatives Judiciary subcommittee, of which he is chairman, would ask Francis P. Whitehair, Under Secretary of the Navy in the Truman Administration, to explain his intercession with the Department of Justice on behalf of an indicted bond dealer.

The 1952 Albert Lasker Medical Journalism Awards for outstanding reporting on medical research and public health were presented to Miss Cathy Covert of The Syracuse (N. Y.) Herald-Journal and John Lear of Collier's magazine at a luncheon yesterday in the Sherry-Netherland Hotel.

Although it could not be confirmed here officially, a rift has developed between American Actors Equity and British Equity stemming from a deadlock in extended negotiations between the two groups to ease restrictions affecting employment of alien performers in both countries.

Today marks the one hundred and fiftieth anniversary of a real estate transaction which in both size and political importance has never been surpassed. At the astonishing rate of about four cents an acre the United States increased by 140 per cent the territory under the jurisdiction of the Constitution adopted only sixteen years before this remarkable purchase was negotiated in 1803.

Basic, though informal, agreement on objectives of the main countries of the free world is needed for international stability and prosperity, Robert Marjolin, secretary general of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, said last night.

Events today: Gilda Muhlbauer, violinist, Vocational High School, 11 A. M.; "Die Fledermaus," City Center, 8:15 P. M.; Drusilla Huffmaster, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; All-Rachmaninoff Concert, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Lynna Phillips, soprano, Mannes Music School, 8:30; Bronx House Music School benefit concert, Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., 8:40.

Net sales of General Motors Corporation climbed to a new high of $2,546,854,722 in the first quarter this year, with both civilian and military volume up sharply, Harlow H. Curtice, president, and Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman, reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 (AP) -- An eleventh-inning double Billy Johnson coupled with an error gave the Cardinals a 1-0 triumph over the first-place Phillies tonight, despite a three-hitter by Curt Simmons, the losing pitcher.

Producers and merchandisers who do not recognize major changes taking place in population patterns may find themselves "off the beam," Henry Bach Associates, Inc., warns in its latest issue of "The Bach Letter," out today.

Child Health Day will be observed tomorrow, and fast on its heels will come the city's fourth annual Nutrition Week beginning Monday under the general sponsorship of the municipal Welfare and Health Council. "Food comes first" is the slogan, and there will be particular emphasis on fruits and vegetables.
Sidney J. Weinberg, a director of Sears Roebuck Co. and the B. F. Goodrich Company, must resign either post or both posts, Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld ruled yesterday.

CAIRO, April 29 -- The British and Egyptian representatives discussing Cairo's demands for the withdrawal of British forces from the Suez Canal zone recessed today until Saturday and drew tighter the blanket of secrecy around their negotiations.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Army is planning to "beef up" the infantry regiment to give the basic fighting unit, the squad, more men and more firepower. Other changes also are contemplated.

The Fund for the Advancement of Education, 575 Madison Avenue, announced yesterday the granting of 252 one-year fellowships to college faculty members in this country, Hawaii and Puerto Rico. The grants, which are for the 1953-54 academic year, exceed $1,400,000.

The old aphorism "boys will be boys" often has considerable merit when used by parents to explain the mysterious and mischievous acts of their charges. Fortunately for our sanity boys will not always remain boys -- they will progress through various stages of development until maturity is achieved and become fine young men. That is, most of them will.

The Eisenhower Administration may not be able to reverse the twenty-year trend in farm legislation and aid, but appears ready to turn "the relief type programs" closer to "the middle of the road," William M. Blair, a member of the Washington staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The United States will have on hand by the start of this summer about 13,000 medium tanks, still far short of the estimated 40,000 of all types generally credited to the Soviet Union.

The Greek Government of Premier Papagos has embarked on an enterprise which goes to the crux of the whole European problem and which, if successful, could set a pattern that would do more to put Europe on its economic feet than any other single measure.
The Trio Concertante, comprised of Frances Blaisdell, flutist, Lucien Kirsch Laporte, 'cellist, and Lucille Burnham, pianist, made its debut appearance in Town Hall last evening.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- New members added to the rolls of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. in 1952 totaled 114,607, making a net gain of 43,924 members and bringing the aggregate to 2,526,172, the office of the General Assembly of the denomination reported here today.
LONDON, April 29 -- Samuel Goldwyn held a press conference here yesterday with some unexpected results.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- A nine-man committee of scientists began a study today of the National Bureau of Standards at the request of Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks, who asked a "thorough, objective and impartial" examination of its operations.

LONDON, April 29 (Reuters) -- Marshal Kliment E. Voroshilov, Soviet President, said today that Russia's armed forces "do not threaten anyone and have no intention of attacking any foreign country," the Moscow radio reported.

I am impelled to write of my astonishment at your editorial of April 28 and at its deviation from the usually fair and objective approach by THE TIMES to matters of public interest. Your editorial entitled "A Reckless Liberal Party" is so completely self-contradictory as to serve to add to the already widespread confusion about the New York political scene.

CHATTANOOGA, April 29 -- The National Cotton Council declared today that unless the American farm economy was backed by an adequate agricultural research program, "there can never be any farm program that makes real sense."

DETROIT, April 29 (UP) -- The Red Sox pounded out seventeen hits and pushed across eight runs in the first three innings today as they coasted to a 10-4 victory over the last-place Tigers before 1,767 fans at Briggs Stadium.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Eisenhower Administration was putting the finishing touches today on a $5,800,000,000 Mutual Security Program for the fiscal year 1954. The President plans to outline the program at a news conference tomorrow as part of a much larger global defense commitment.
The shipyards of the world were less busy on March 31 than they were three months earlier, Lloyds' Register of Shipping has reported here.

Serious fire hazards exist in many woodland areas of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut as a result of fallen trees and broken limbs caused by wind and ice storms since the fall of 1950, foresters and fire-control officials reported yesterday.
COLOGNE, Germany, April 29 -- A German state court awakened echoes of the tumultuous early days of National Socialism today when it ordered the restoration of German citizenship to Dr. Otto Strasser.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., April 29 -- Lieut. Sheppard Carl Thierman, 30 years old, of Brooklyn, a medical officer, pleaded innocent today to a charge that he obtained his Army commission fraudulently while a member of the Communist party.
While their children attend school in classrooms near by, parents will donate blood this afternoon at two Bronx schools.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman attacked last night what he called "the growing disease of McCarthyism and Jenneritis" as abridging the Bill of Rights by indirection, innuendo, smear and attack. He spoke at the annual $100-a-plate dinner of the Democratic State Committee in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Private Juan Osorio-Melendez, 22-year-old Puerto Rican veteran wounded in Korea and recently released after nine months in a Communist prisoner-of-war camp, got his first look at New York yesterday and, using his newly acquired English, flinched and said, "I want to go home and be alone with my family."

A night club musician, identified last week in court as the man who staged two hold-ups in the Jackson Heights, Queens, branch office of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, was cleared yesterday by the confession of a man to whom he bears a striking resemblance.

BERLIN, April 30 -- Soviet-occupied East Germany announced today its gross production in the first quarter of this year had fallen 3.8 per cent short of the goals of the five-year plan and conceded that the supply of fish, butter and sugar was even lower than a year ago.

GENEVA, April 30 -- As a matter of practical government and business planning Western Europe now is operating on the assumption that the Eisenhower Administration's foreign economic policy will be "aid, not trade" for a long time to come.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Eisenhower redefined, military policy today, proposing a sustained level of strength in the era of crisis, a reduction of $8,500,000,000 in the national budget for the fiscal year 1954, starting July 1, and the improvement of civilian control of the armed forces.

LONDON, April 30 (AP) -- Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill, resplendent in his new knightly trappings, tilted at "super-original forms of art" before the Royal Academy tonight. The Prime Minister is an honorary member extraordinary of the Academy by virtue of his own painting talents.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Emphasizing war readiness with economy, President Eisenhower issued today his detailed plan for an efficient and "ever-prepared" defense establishment.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today Chinese Communists were at least part owners of some ships hauling goods to Red China under pledged protection of the British Navy.

Neither Svengali, Machiavelli nor all the backroom plotters for the thrones of Shakespeare's kings had anything on the characters who inhabit Richard Condon's "Men of Distinction," which made its appearance at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre last night.
BOWIE, Md., April 30 (UP) -- Nick Shuk went on another riding rampage at Bowie today as he piloted four winners and finished in the money with two other mounts.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The dairy, beef cattle and pottery industries put in pleas today for amendments giving greater tariff protection in an extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Law.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- House leaders began clearing the way today for a proposed investigation of boxing.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republic of Wisconsin and the editor of The New York Post, James A. Wechsler, exchanged more telegrams today, with Mr. McCarthy agreeing to make public Wednesday testimony the editor gave his Senate investigations subcommittee last Friday behind closed doors.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Resolutions were introduced in both Houses of Congress today "authorizing recognition" by the Government and people of the United States of the 200th anniversary of the founding of Columbia University to be celebrated next year.
PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (AP) -- The Phillies and the Cardinals played a five-inning 1-1 stalemate tonight. The game, ended by rain, will have to be replayed as a new contest at a later date.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 30 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has decided not to renew the appointment of J. Donald Kingsley as head of the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Four Yankees and two Browns were fined today for their parts in last Tuesday night's free-for-all fight at Busch Stadium. President Will Harridge of the American League, after reviewing reports of the umpires, assessed Clint Courtney, the St. Louis catcher, the highest amount, $250.

With 800,000 housing units in the city scheduled for rent increases today under the equalization adjustment voted at the recent session of the Legislature, a large number of tenants and landlords with unresolved problems concerning their May rent bills applied for assistance yesterday at the six local rent offices.

TENAFLY, N. J., April 30 -- At the Carnes' residenece and bird sanctuary here, a cedar waxwing situation is developing, possibly with complications of a triangular nature, and just when Mrs. Betty Carnes has a highly scientific paper to finish.
A giant electric beacon was lighted in Times Square at 1:30 P. M. yesterday, marking the start of a nation-wide campaign to raise $7,500,000 for aid to victims of cerebral palsy.

HARTFORD, April 30 -- Gov. John Davis Lodge sent to the General Assembly late today the nominations of seven Superior and Common Pleas Court Judges. The nominations completed the Governor's slate of eleven high court nominations, four of which had been submitted in the past few days.

Congressional inquiries into subversive influences in education pose "at least by indirection" a national threat to academic integrity, Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, asserted last night. He made it clear, however, that colleges should not retain on their faculties "those whose sense of loyalty to a democratic society is confused and in doubt."

An unusual article appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES recently describing the work of ninety French priests in factory jobs in France. This is only one manifestation of a spiritual renaissance taking place in France.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated within a narrow range all day yesterday and closed somewhat irregular, 14 points higher to 5 points lower than on Wednesday.
HARTFORD, April 30 -- The State House of Representatives, in a surprise vote, defeated late today a bill that would legalize raffles and bazaars in Connecticut. The vote was 127 to 120.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Representative William S. Hill, Republican of Colorado, said yesterday he plans to give the House Ways and Means Committee a full report on how lead and zinc price drops have affected domestic mining.

RICHMOND, Va., April 30 (AP) -- An employe-stockholder charged today that the management of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway had taken its shareholders "down the river" by signing a closed-shop contract with eleven non-operating unions.

OTTAWA, April 30 (Canadian Press) -- A new type of wheat, resistant to Race 15-B rust, has been developed and likely will be available for distribution at the end of the next growing season, James Gardiner, Canada's Minister of Agriculture, said today in the House of Commons.

PARIS, April 30 -- The strike movement of officers of the French merchant marine that began at Le Havre Tuesday spread today to the ports of Marseille, Rouen and Nantes with a decision to halt the departure of all French ships. The strike will begin in Marseille Tuesday.

Brig. Gen. and Mrs. John Williams Morgan gave a reception, garden party and tea yesterday afternoon in their home at 39 West Eleventh Street for Dr. Eleanor Anderson Campbell, founder and general director of the Judson Health Center, and for Henry Jones Clay, recently elected president of the organization, and Mrs. Clay.
TOKYO, Friday, May 1 -- The United Nations proposed Sweden today as a neutral nation competent to take custody of prisoners of the Korean war who refuse repatriation.

New insurance policies that become effective today for the Cunard liners Queen Elizabeth and Queen Mary cover each ship for over $500,000 more than the expiring contract. The policy for the Queen Mary is well over twice what it was when she entered service eighteen years ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 30 -- Completion of the $4,600,000 motion picture, "The Robe," from the best-seller by Lloyd C. Douglas after ten years of preparation and shootings was announced today bl Twentieth Century-Fox production chief Darryl F. Zanuck and producer Frank Ross.

Another magazine with a good circulation record is halting publication due to increased costs and insufficient ad support. It is Park East, the Magazine of New York, which suspends with its May issue. Circulation during its lifetime rose from 8,000 to more than 70,000 net paid.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 30 -- Mohammed Ali, the Prime Minister of Pakistan, returned to this capital city this morning after two days of an extensive national "get acquainted" tour. During the trip he pleaded for unity among a people who perhaps knew less about him than many United States Congressmen and State Department officials with whom he associated as his country's Ambassador in Wahington for the last two years.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- During the week ended April 29, member bank reserves increased $13,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Eisenhower's reference today to the "paper divisions and cardboard wings" with which he had been familiar as chief of North Atlantic Treaty forces in Western Europe recalled his efforts a year ago to prevent heavy cuts in the Mutual Security program to finance their equipment.

LONDON, April 30 -- British Government securities were outstandingly strong in otherwise dull stock markets today. Gilt-edge issues gained over a wide front by about one-eighth per cent. Elsewhere, interest remained small and prices continued to sag until near the close, when industrial shares rallied and cut losses to a few pence.

Except for good music on several stations there's not been too much reason of late for the radio and television set owner to stay up very long past 11 o'clock at night. The radio oracles in the restaurants seem to have pretty much run their course with their midnight editorials and the late movie shows on TV rather desperately need some good new films.

Fashions for career girls were presented yesterday by Lord Taylor on the second floor of its store at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street. Cool, light-weight summer town dress, casual sun dresses, practical travel clothes and informal party dresses were included in the thirty-minute noonday show.

JERSEY CITY, April 30 -- With his political future depending on a victory in the May 12 local municipal election, Mayor John V. Kenny, Hudson County Democratic leader, today found himself the target of attacks on several fronts.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A cut of more than 22 per cent in funds asked by the Truman Administration for the State, Justice and Commerce Departments during the coming fiscal year was proposed in a bill reported to the House of Representatives today for action next week.

MEXICO CITY, April 30 (UP) -- A 35-year-old Mexican caddie stole the show from Ben Hogan today as he tied for the lead with Dave Douglas in the first round of the $17,500 Pan American golf tournament.

Another step has been taken in the long, slow process of creating a British Caribbean Federation. Yesterday five of Britain's West Indies possessions -- Jamaica, Trinidad and Tobago, Barbados and the Windward and Leeward Islands -- signed a proposal for a federal union with its capital in the lovely little island of Grenada, one of the Windward group.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- By vote of 59 to 22, the Senate rejected an amendment to the offshore oil bill today to keep submerged lands and their resources, seaward of the three-mile limit, in the hands of the Federal Government and to devote revenues they produce to reduction of the national debt.

Despite achievement of a record $160,000,000 in Italian exports to the United States, there is need to increase the volume to offset the recent annual average of $400,000,000 of United States exports to Italy, Marcello Egidi, Italian commercial attache in New York, said yesterday.

Two craftsmen from California, each of whom seems to have achieved a particularly individual type of work in the crowded field of modern ceramic making, are represented in a new exhibit at the Willow, 182 West Fourth Street. Both ceramists, the Misses Polia Pillin of Sun Valley and Virginia Davidson of Woodside, have shown their work previously at this shop.

Twenty-eight laymen were the recipients yesterday of Christopher Awards for creative works that "reflect the power for good that can be exerted, with God's help, by one individual in the literary and entertainment fields."

PRETORIA, South Africa, April 30 -- According to information obtained here today, Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Nationalist regime is firmly opposed to the proposal that it realize the Nationalist party's official intention to establish a republic by creating a federal state and permitting the British east coast area to form a canton retaining the suzerainty of the British crown.
The fifth annual presentation of George Polk Memorial Awards for distinguished contributions to journalism was made yesterday at a luncheon in the Roosevelt Hotel.
YONKERS, April 30 (AP) -- One favorite had it, and the other didn't in the two sections of the Greyhound Trot tonight at Yonkers Raceway.
TRENTON, April 30 (AP) -- The New Jersey Parole Board today announced it had denied parole to Frank Erickson, reputed head of a nation-wide gambling combine.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Brazil received two loans totaling $303,000,000 from the United States Export-Import Bank and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development today.

A patrolman was accused yesterday by the Police Department of having lied to a superior officer when he denied any association with Communist or subversive groups. He will stand trial on the charge next Thursday and a department spokesman said he believed it to be the first police case involving subversive activity.

Five new fur-bearing natives of this city made their first appearances before the press photographers yesterday. In Brooklyn, there were two bears, Jerry and Susie. In the basement of Madison Square Garden, there were three leopard kittens, Chuck, male, and Alice and Muff, female.

The largest retirement of railroad bonds so far this year lifted the total of bonds called for payment in April before maturity to $28,423,000 from $18,438,000 in the preceding month. The month's total was the heaviest since January and for an April since 1951. It compared with $17,036,000 in April, 1952 and $134,523,000 two years ago.

The four members of the City Transit Authority who were appointed by Governor Dewey and Mayor Impellitteri have failed to agree on the fifth member of the agency, but will make a final effort to do so today, the deadline set by the law creating the Authority.

LONDON, April 30 (AP) -- Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister, gave Japan's Crown Prince Akihito a stag lunch at 10 Downing Street today and invited some of Britain's leading figures to meet him.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, the Majority Leader, said tonight he would do "anything I possibly can" to secure passage of a bill to authorize United States participation in the St. Lawrence Seaway project.

LONDON, April 30 (UP) -- Earl Jowitt, former Lord High Chancellor of Britain, said in a book published today that the conviction of Alger Hiss on perjury charges had left him with doubts that justice was done.

LONDON, April 30 -- Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister, offered no comfort today to those in Britain who had been crying out against Gen. Mark W. Clark's offer to pay $100,000 to the first Communist pilot who surrendered a Soviet MIG-15 jet fighter plane in Korea.
TOKYO, Friday, May 1 (AP) -- The tentative list of men in the second phase of the Freedom Airlift included these from the New York area:
BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 30 (AP) -- Doris Hart and Shirley Fry, United States tennis stars, coasted into the semi-finals of the British hard-court championship tournament today.

Stanley E. Davis Jr., 34-year-old suspended patrolman convicted last Feb. 27 of manslaughter in the first degree, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court to an eight-to-fifteen year term in Sing Sing Prison.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 30 -- The Motion Picture Industry Council today pledged its "fullest cooperation" in helping to advance the effectiveness of the motion-picture phase of the State Department Overseas Information program. The organization, which embraces all segments of

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 30 -- Dr. Lewis W. Jones, president of Rutgers University, announced today he had filed formal charges against Abraham Glasser, assistant professor of law, Rutgers Law School, Newark, for refusing to tell the House Committe on Un-American Activities whether or not he was a Communist.

The April 19 edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES carried an article by Murray Illson on the relationship of reading disability to juvenile delinquency. Justice John Warren Hill, presiding justice of the city's Domestic Relations Court, was quoted as follows:

MOSCOW, Friday, May 1 -- Pravda declared today that if an armistice were possible in the "hot war in Korea," then an armistice in the "cold war," which it said was "ruining all people," should follow and peace itself should be possible.

With parading floats, flying colors and playing bands, the Sanitation Department will open an annual clean-up drive Monday when Mayor Impellitteri, in a City Hall ceremony at noon, proclaims the period from Monday through May 16 as "Spring Clean-up Weeks."

Bethlehem Steel Corporation's production and shipments set new high records in the first quarter this year, but net income rose to $30,961,033 from $18,926,045 a year ago, Eugene Grace, chairman, reported yesterday.
Capt. Harry Manning, 56-year-old commodore of the United States Lines, will retire today to devote his time to writing and lecturing.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Republicans in Congress were pleased today by President Eisenhower's preview of his policy on Government spending, but the Democrats were somewhat skeptical.

OF all the top-drawer short-story writers appearing regularly in The New Yorker John Cheever has always seemed to this reviewer to epitomize the New Yorker manner -- to represent the brilliant, bitter essence of that magazine as perfectly, say, as Col. Matt Wynn once represented the Kentucky Derby or Lucius Beebe has stood these many years as a synonym for Twenty-One.

The Curtiss-Wright Corporation board of directors reported yesterday that for the three-month period ending March 31 consolidated net profits were $2,445,642, compared with $1,766,244 for the same period of 1952.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 30 -- A Government spokesman declared today that Yugoslavia would be ready to negotiate directly with the Vatican on church-state differences in this country.

Merger of Merck Co., Inc., and Sharp Dohme, Inc., was approved by stockholders of both companies yesterday at separate special meetings, according to George W. Merck and John S. Zinsser, chairman of the boards of the respective companies.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The country ended its second venture within a decade into the realm of general price controls here tonight with the formal passing of the Office of Price Stabilization.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Joseph P. Ryan, indicted president of the International Longshoremen's Association, told a Senate Commerce subcommittee today that he had not "purged" his union of racketeering officials nor made other reforms demanded by the American Federation of Labor's executive council.

The home has been the scapegoat for juvenile delinquency too long, Leonard W. Mayo said yesterday, for "the standards of the community as a whole -- specifically government, business and industrial morality -- are also highly important in influencing young people's behavior."

TRENTON, April 30 -- A demand that Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City be read out of the Democratic party was made here today as party leaders opened their quadrennial convention. Meanwhile Republican leaders, also in convention, praised their state chairman, John J. Dickerson, for his part in a deal which, he disclosed yesterday, had been conceived by himself and Mr. Kenny.

BONN, Germany, April 30 -- East Germany's Communist rulers are uneasy and frightened as a result of the Soviet Union's motions toward a negotiated settlement with the West and are considering various measures for bolstering the Communist party's position in the event of all-German elections.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A nuclear physicist estimated today that a 300,000-kilowatt power plant now burning 5,000,000 pounds of coal daily would consume less than two and one-half pounds of nuclear fuel daily if security, engineering and cost problems could be solved to make possible economic private production of power.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 30 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, told members of a Southern regional political strategy conference tonight that "we steadfast Democrats should keep the door wide open for those who strayed from the house of their father in last year's Presidential election."

The amnesty for delinquent traffic violators came to an end yesterday and Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh deemed the experiment a success. He reported that fines collected in April had totaled more than $250,000 over the average for previous months.

Drusilla Huffmaster, a young pianist from Texas, made her recital debut last night in Town Hall. She is no stranger to the local scene, however, and one remembers her agile playing of the Rubinstein D minor Concerto some years ago with a local orchestra.

WHEN a man bites a dog or a bullhead fisherman lands a thirty-pound muskie in a Catskill lake late in April, the incident is news, but unfortunately for Jack Avery of Rock Hill, the law says no muskies may be legally possessed before July 1, and the big fish was returned to the water.
Cottons, translated into summer designs by Adele Simpson, were presented yesterday by Saks Fifth Avenue at luncheon time at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Martin P. Durkin, Secretary of Labor, said today that charging Mexican contract farm workers for "twistems," which are paper covered wires used in tying bunches of carrots, was not a proper charge under terms of the international migrant agreement with Mexico, except in cases where the workers wilfully destroyed or negligently failed to return unused wires.

CHARLESTON, S. C., April 30 -- Representatives of four private waterfront terminals, the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and the state and Federal conciliation services met today in an attempt to iron out a labor dispute that has closed this port to shipping. No announcement of progress was immediately forth-coming.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- For the twenty-fifth year, May Day is Child Health Day by proclamation of the President.
Trading on most of the New York commodity exchanges was dull and featureless yesterday Only cottonseed oil showed sizable volume.
The time has come for this nation to reconsider its long-range policy in regard to a subsidized merchant marine.

THE NEW YORK TIMES has performed a public service in spotlighting the decline in morale of the nation's civil servants. This morale problem, however, is neither new nor basic. It has existed for some time, fed by inflation, Congressional investigations, the growth of Government and inadequate personnel administration for more than two million federal employes.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Through overindulgence in food and drink and underindulgence in foods that supply vitamins, minerals and good quality proteins, 20,000,000 or more Americans are shortening their lives, handicapping their health and running the risk of contracting destructive diseases, Dr. Charles Glen King of New York said today.

Plans for the merger of Pacific Public Service Company with Pacific Gas and Electric Company were made known yesterday in connection with the proposed purchase by Blyth Co., Inc., investment banking concern, of a majority interest in Pacific Public Service from Standard Oil Company of California.

On a recent day which must have been distressing to the Federal Government, although pleasant elsewhere, an income tax refund check came into the house. It was not addressed to the head of the house, of course, for all parties to the contract understand that he never gets anything back and, indeed, usually is found to owe more than he sends.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- The nation's radio and television stations and networks did an $809,400,000 business last year, 8 per cent higher than in 1951, the Federal Communications Commission reported today.

The highlights of the mixed bag of new acquisitions that go on view today at The Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East Thirty-sixth Street, are a mid-ninth century French illuminated gospel book, the only example in America of a manuscript from the Franco-Saxon School at this period, a Dutch fifteenth century Book of Hours and a drawing by the French seventeenth-century artist Jacques Bellange.
The New York Stock Exchange had a 1,140,000-share day yesterday, the smallest in six months, and prices drifted downward until the final hour, when a modest rally cut losses.

NEW DELHI, India, April 30 --One elephant is equivalent in work capacity to twenty to thirty men, a Government spokesman told the Lower Hbuse of Parliament today. J. L. Hathi, Deputy Minister for Planning and Irrigation and Power, revealed thai; the Asn Stat Government, using eleohants in road building, had

CHICAGO, April 30 -- New York nudged out Chicago as No. 1 killer among American cities with more than 1,000,000 population in an analysis of automobile fatalities issued today by the National Safety Council. It is the first time since last May that Chicago has not had the highest death rate in ratio to its automobile registration.

In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES April 25 H. M. Moolman, director of the South African Government Information Office, refers to "the views freely held and freely expressed by the majority of voters" in the recent South African elections. He fails to state that at least 80 per cent of the people -- South Africa's nearly ten million African and colored people -- are almost completely disfranchised.
The White Motor Company has named as directors J. Nevin Bauman, vice president of sales; V. W. Fries, vice president of manufacturing; and Edward S. Reddig, vice president of finance.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Discussing regulations regarding the United States soldiers now being return from captivity in Korea, a Pentagon spokesman explained tonight that time in captivity was counted as service time.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The bevatron, world's most powerful atom smasher, designed to hurl atomic projectiles with energies of six billion volts, is less than a year from completion at the University of California radiation laboratories.

LONDON, April 30 -- Representatives of British West Indian colonies formally announced today that they had agreed upon the formation of a British Caribbean Federation which is intended to become eventually a new self-governing unit in the British Commonwealth.
BALTIMORE, April 30 (AP) -- Larry MacPhail was found guilty today of conduct detrimental to horse racing during his short and stormy career as president of the Bowie track.

Women, headed by Mrs. Edward A. Pommer, assisted by members of a junior committee of which Mrs. Myron Kahn is chairman, are aiding in the plans for the annual luncheon and fashion show or the benefit of Camp Nyda, the summer camp of the New York Diabetes Association, to be held on May 6 at the Plaza.

President Eisenhower announced yesterday a broad program which calls for more governmental reorganization together with substantial reductions in the $78,600,000,000 budget submitted by his predecessor.

Fifteen bookmakers, including John (Johnny Dee) and Alexander (Pope) Dalessio, reputed gambling and racket bosses of Staten Island, and eight present or former policemen were indicted yesterday by a special Richmond County grand jury on charges of conspiracy in maintaining a multi-million-dollar bookmaking operation.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., April 30 -- Mrs. Mary Stallcup Markward, a former undercover agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, identified a Government exhibit today as the Communist membership application card of Lieut. Sheppard Carl Thierman of Brooklyn, a medical officer attached to the base hospital here.

WARNER ROBINS, Ga., April 30 (AP) -- A twilight tornado killed thirteen persons here today and left another 300 injured. Of the injured, sixteen were in critical condition at Robins Air Force Base Hospital. The air base was heavily damaged, but only three or four airmen suffered minor injuries.

The annual report of the Socony-Vacuum Company, Inc., for 1952 was so pleasing to one of the company's stockholders for its compactness that it prompted him to write George V. Holton, chairman, of that $1,500,000,000 corporation the following: "Thank you for sending me the annual report. After reading it, everything appears simple.

Aristocratic Kitchens, Inc., manufacturer of kitchen cabinets, has taken a long-term lease on a new factory built by Charles Follini at 1425 East Bay Avenue, the Bronx. The building contains 12,000 square feet of floor space and occupies a plot 100 by 130 feet. The Joseph G. Platzner Company was broker in the transaction.

Your editorial on Senator Wayne Morse's marathon talk is not quite fair. As I recall, the minority group fighting the oil giveaway offered to halt the debate about two weeks ago to permit the Senate to pass legislation against filibustering. This Senator Taft refused to do.

NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., April 30 (AP) -- Taking advantage of brisk winds, Richard Rheem's 98-foot ketch Morning Star moved into an early lead today as a fleet of 149 vessels got under way in the sixth annual Newport Harbor international yacht race to Ensenada, Mexico.

The possibility of another large apartment development in the vicinity of Manhattan House, which occupies the old carbarn site at Third Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, was seen yesterday with the announcement that Jack Resnick and associates had purchased a three-acre property bounded by Second and Third Avenues, Sixty-eighth and Sixty-ninth Streets.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Grain and soybeans showed early declines today, with further local selling and scattered long liquidation. Oats were relatively steady in contrast to wheat and rye, all futures of which made new low marks for the season. Deliveries on May contracts were not as heavy as many expected, but there was not much buying for outside account.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 30 (UP) -- John C. Garand, inventor of the rifle used by millions of American soldiers in World War II and the Korean war, was honored tonight on the eve of his retirement at the age of 65.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's press conference statement today on the budget and defense:

The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income of $34,660,667 for the twelve months to March 31. This was equal to $2.29 a share of common stock, and compares with $28,664,949, or $2.03 a share, in the preceding twelve months. Gross revenues were $311,229,772, against $286,247,430.

The Board of Education elected by unanimous vote yesterday Miss Florence S. Beaumont and Edmund J. Gannon to be associate superintendents. Miss Beaumont has been an assistant superintendent and Mr. Gannon a member of the Board of Examiners.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Frank Raboski, 49 years old, of suburban Northlake, civic leader and treasurer of the Northlake Crime Commission, was exposed today as an ex-convict and a fugitive from prison since 1938.
PITTSBURGH, April 30 (AP) -- Outfielder Frank Thomas blasted a two-run homer over the left field score board in the ninth inning to give the Pirates a 4-2 victory over the Cubs today.

Press photographers have made an important contribution to world understanding, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, director of the Department of Trusteeship of the United Nations, said yesterday at a press preview of a photographic exhibit arranged by the Overseas Press Club of America at 9 Rockefeller Plaza.
Both bond and stock financing here in April declined from the levels of a year ago. Stock flotations, at the smallest monthly figure since December, were the lowest for an April since 1948.
LOS ANGELES, April 30 -- Television audiences were promised a new deal, visually speaking, in TV motion pictures and film-recorded programs by the electronics industry today.

In his broadcast on the latest NATO meeting Secretary of State Dulles referred to direct American aid to Europe as a "crutch," necessary in an emergency but to be thrown away when economic health is restored. He suggested that there are many ways of putting relations between us and our partners in the Atlantic Community on a new basis, "dignified and self-respecting for all concerned."
ST. LOUIS, April 30 (AP) -- "I'd say Mantle today is the greatest player in either league," said Manager Marry Marion of the Browns.

LUXEMBOURG, April 30 -- The nine members of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community gathered today at the Belval Steel Works in Esch near here to witness the release of a gleaming sputtering molten stream that it had been decided to call the first "European" steel to be cast.

HONOLULU, April 30 (AP) -- Forty-one United States soldiers freed from Communist prison camps and hospitals in Korea last week landed at Hickam Air Force base today, the second group to reach Hawaii on the way back to the United States.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in April declined from the preceding month but was the largest for any April since 1950. Sales were above the million share mark in every session, the largest of which was 3,046,810 shares on April 6 and the smallest in six months was on the last day of April on 1,138,150 shares.

Confidence in Great Britain's ability to achieve a new expansion of its sales to world markets was expressed yesterday by Sir Frank Lee, Permanent Secretary of the British Board of Trade. Sir Frank spoke at a luncheon given in his honor by the British Commonwealth Chamber of Commerce at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
President Eisenhower's speech at a Republican State Committee dinner here on Thursday, will be broadcast and televised.

Accommodations for 123 families are to be provided in a new home colony at Deer Park Avenue and Old Country Road in Deer Park, L. I., where the builders, Henry Lefkowitz and Jack Silverstein, have completed a display model. The development is to be known as Deer Park Greens. The houses will be in ranch style with three bedrooms and are to be priced at $10,990.

LOUISVILLE, April 30 -- Rain sluiced onto this theatre of turf operations during the night, and the track was muddy at Churchill Downs today. Consequently, there was much talk, all through the gray afternoon, of the weather prospects for Saturday, when the Kentucky Derby will be run for the seventy-ninth time.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Arguments began today in the Supreme Court in a Case brought to test the right of restaurants in the District of Columbia to refuse to serve Negroes. They will continue tomorrow.
ST. LOUIS, April 30 (UP) -- Bob Elliott's seventh-inning home run with two men on proved decisive tonight as Virgil Trucks pitched a three-hitter to give the Browns a 3-1 victory over the Senators.

New borrowings by public utilities and sales finance companies largely offset seasonal repayments of New York bank loans to business last week. As a result, despite reductions in credit requirements of food and tobacco industries, commodity dealers, textile factors and metal interests, the decline during the week ended on Wednesday was held at $8,000,000.

There were no record-shattering home runs at the Polo Grounds yesterday. However, there was one circuit clout and though it didn't even clear 300 feet it was easily the most heartening sight our harassed Giants had looked upon in days on end.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 30 -- One student was dismissed and nine others were suspended from Princeton University today for their parts in an undergraduate rampage through this town Tuesday night.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 30 (UP) -- Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, said tonight there was no justification for a cutback in military spending and that the Korean war probably would have been averted had the arms budget been "realistic" five years ago.
TOKYO, Friday, May 1 (AP) -- The United Nations Command headquarters communique for Thursday's action:

New York University's governing council voted yesterday to dismiss from the faculty Dr. Edwin Berry Burgum, an Associate Professor of English in the Washington Square College of Arts and Sciences, who was suspended last Oct. 13 after his refusal to tell the Senate Internal Security subcommittee whether he ever had been a member of the Communist party.

A study of the political ideas that guided and sustained the rise of liberty in Colonial and Revolutionary America will be published next Friday by Harcourt, Brace under the title "Seedtime of the Republic." The author is Clinton Rossiter, president of the New York State Political Science Association, who is on the staff of the Department of Government at Cornell University.

Lamb and pork prices show sharp advances this week-end. Spring lamb, which is in light receipt, is up from 6 to 10 cents a pound, the city Department of Markets reported yesterday. Another 6 cents a pound has been added to the cost of pork loins, which are continuing their increase in price.
Western Union offered yesterday to sell private weather forecasts up to six months in advance for fees ranging from $20 to $120 a month.
MOSCOW, Friday, May 1 (AP) -- Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Defense Minister, greeted the Soviet armed forces this May Day with one of the briefest and mildest orders of the day in many years.

BUFFALO, N. Y., April 30 (AP) -- Arthur J. Glover, president of the Switchmen's Union of North America, A. F. L., won a vote of confidence at a special international convention today. The convention, by a vote of 191 to 96, backed Mr. Glover's dismissal of four international executive board members who had challenged his rule. Delegates from thirty-eight states and parts of Canada are here for the convention.
CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- Harold Weiner and John Quinzi of Rochester, N. Y., rolled 1,319 to gain seventh place in the doubles event the American Bowling Congress tournament today.

BIRKDALE, England, April 30 (AP) -- Phillip Scrutton, 29-year-old stevedore, blasted his way into the quarter-final round of the English amateur golf championship today -- and virtually onto Britain's Walker Cup team, which will meet the United States next September.

LOUISVILLE, April 30 -- The Dancer is about to do the fanciest stepping of his career. He has been waltzing to victory up to now but the band will speed the tempo in the Kentucky Derby on Saturday and Native Dancer will have to keep time to the music.

A vast assortment of mix and match summer sportswear separates, highlighting the opening of the Sun Shop yesterday at Ohrbach's, featured cottons of almost every description as well as some synthetics.

Adhering faithfully to their 1952 pennant-winning pattern of making merry at the expense of second-division opposition, the Dodgers yesterday breezed to a 7-4 triumph over the last-place Redlegs before 3,410 chilled spectators at Ebbets Field.

Next January's National Motor Boat Show was signed, sealed and all but delivered at some special committee meetings ending yesterday at the National Association of Engine and Boat Manufacturers, sponsors.

WHITE PLAINS, April 30 -- Garden type apartment construction costs can be cut 10 per cent in communities that adopt a proposed state multiple dwelling code as an alternative to local codes and the state multiple residence law, Edward J. McGrew Jr., chairman of the State Building Code Commission, estimated today after a hearing at the County Center.

The nation's state-chartered and state-supervised banks increased their holdings of the time deposits of individuals, partnerships and corporations 7.3 per cent last year to $40,164,353,000, according to an annual study of the assets, liabilities, earnings and expenses of these institutions just completed.

MOSCOW, April 30 -- A group of fourteen French citizens who had been interned in North Korea arrived in Moscow today en route back to France after spending in most instances nearly three years in camps in the vicinity of the Yalu River.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Department store sales in the week ended April 25 were 1 per cent under sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

More than sixty manufacturers in diversified fields have asked the American Fair Trade Council in the last two months for help in placing their products under fair trade. This was disclosed yesterday by Frank Masterson, assistant to the president, who said this constituted a record number of new fair-traders in so short a period.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, April 30 (Reuters) -- The near-Communist People's Progressive party won a landslide victory in British Guiana's first election under her new Constitution.

SALZBURG, Austria, April 30 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe; Lieut. Gen. Charles Lawrence Bolte, Commander in Chief of the United States Army in Europe and a number of other high officers of Allied forces attended a farewell review of United States Forces in Austria here in Salzburg today in honor of their retiring commander, Lieut. Gen. George P. Hays.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Senate Labor and Welfare Committee held today its last scheduled hearing on Taft-Hartley Law revisions and Senator James E. Murray, Democrat of Montana, complained that the hearings had been "incomplete and inadequate" because no Administration spokesman had been heard.

A group of doctors headed by Dr. Arnold Gottesman has purchased the Lexington Hospital at the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street in a deal negotiated by William Bialek, brokers.

Austin Taylor Graves today assumes the presidency of John Wanamaker, New York, according to an announcement yesterday by John E. Raasch, chairman. Mr. Graves formerly was vice president and assistant general manager of Marshall Field Co.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Conjunctivitis kept Gene Woodling on the bench today, but Bill Renna, the replacement for the Yankees' leading hitter, made certain Woodling's .436 average was not missed. The solidly-constructed Renna, a 226-pound former Santa Clara fullback, slammed a homer, triple and single, accounting for three runs, as Casey Stengel's Bombers turned back the White Sox, 6 -- 1.

PARIS, April 30 -- The French Government is consulting with the United States and other Governments regarding a possible appeal to the United Nations over the Vietminh aggression in Laos, it was stated in authorized circles tonight. There will be no decision, it was said, until the subject has been thoroughly explored.

TOKYO, Friday, May 1 (UP) -- The United States battleship New Jersey hurled a thunderous May Day bombardment from its sixteen-inch guns today at Communist coastal batteries at Wonsan on Korea's east coast.

NEW DELHI, India, April 30 -- If India were asked to be the Asian nation demanded by the Communist side as the neutral custodian of prisoners in Korea who refuse repatriation, she would accept the job -- but only with the utmost reluctance.

Back in 1897, when the red brick school building at 60 West Thirteenth Street was already half a century old, a plaque was put up on the outside wall noting that the Thomas Hunter Association of Grammar School No. 35 had been founded there on Nov. 30 of that year.

DELHI, India, April 30 -- Developments in the Far Eastern struggle against communism are encouraging on the whole, although new Red invasion of Laos, one of the Associated States of Indo-China, is an alarming development, Adlai E. Stevenson said today. The former Democratic Presidential candidate arrived here from Calcutta.

Milspal, a filly owned by Willy Schwab and ridden by Willie Lester, scored an upset at Jamaica yesterday by winning the feature race. The event, a mile-and-a-sixteenth test called the Herodias, attracted some pretty strong performers, on form, but Milspal, the sole filly, was accorded little chance in the field of ten 3-year-olds.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Republicans at the Capitol voiced approval today at the rate of turnover in policy-making and other personnel at the Department of State since President Eisenhower took office.

This is a good time, in view of the increasing shipments of spring vegetables, to consider those foods as first courses. A variety of them, raw and cooked, arranged on a huge platter or on one of those lazy Susans that again have become popular, attracts the eye, enlivens the appetite, benefits the waistline and, not the least important, blesses the cook.
The city's cement and concrete interests were accused yesterday by Councilman Hugh Quinn, Queens Democrat, of being "so hungry, they are afraid they are going to lose the sale of one bag of cement."

The new board of directors of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad at an organizational meeting yesterday elected Morgan B. Brainard chairman. He is president of the Aetna Life Insurance Company and is senior member of the New Haven's board. He has been associated with the railroad and its subsidiaries more than twenty years.

First-quarter earnings of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., are estimated at $44,000,000, or $1.26 a share on 34,982,068 shares of common stock, B. Brewster Jennings, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday. Net earnings for the first three months of 1952 were $41,000,000, or $1.29 each on 31,801,880 shares.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 30 AP) -- Fred Kovaleski of Washington and Canada's Lorne Main gained the semi-final round of the Coral Beach tennis tournament today.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Following are the texts of President Eisenhower's Defense Department reorganization plan and of his message concerning it:
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- Aluminum producers warned the Government today there might not be enough aluminum to meet all military and civilian requirements during the July-September period.

LUANG PRABANG, April 30 (Reuters) -- Women with mud-streaked faces joined their men today in digging trenches to defend this royal capital of Laos from the Communist-led invaders. Children, too, helped to dig, string barbed wire and carry logs for barricades outside the ancient town of pagodas and tree-lined avenues.

Independent jewelry store sales in the first quarter of the year showed an increase of 9 per cent over a year ago, while the chains chalked up a 7 per cent gain, according to the National Jewelers Association yesterday. Sales subject to the Federal excise tax registered a 7 per cent rise for independents and 3 per cent for the chains.

The Bower Roller Bearing Company expects to show a slight rise in net profits on a 28 per cent increase in sales for the first quarter of this year compared with 1952, S. A. Strickland, president, announced at the annual meeting yesterday.

Apparently Shirley Booth, who has been showered with all sorts of awards lately, is reconsidering her statement at last month's meeting of the Drama Desk, the organization of Broadway Boswells, that she would spend the summer on vacation after "The Time of the Cuckoo" closed May 30.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- E. Merl Young, who once had ready access to the White House in the Truman Administration, was sentenced today to serve four months to two years in prison for perjury arising out of a Senate committee investigation of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Questions involving esthetics, the interpretation of history and the right to remove from a public building a work of art that is offensive to special groups were raised at hearings held today before a Public Works subcommittee of the House of Representatives.

A writ of habeas corpus, the goal of which is to obtain a reduction of bail for John (Johnny Dee) Dalessio and his brother, Alexander (Pope) Dalessio, alleged kingpins of Staten Island gambling, was signed late yesterday by Justice William B. Carswell of the Appellate Division.

MOSCOW, May 1 -- The United States embassy staff bade farewell today to the May Day celebration on Mokhovaya Street across from Red Square with unusual scenes of "fraternization" with Moscow's May Day paraders.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Senator Wayne Morse, Independent of Oregon, charged today that the offshore oil bill marked the mere beginning of "a raid on the public domain" engineered by political powers that controlled the Eisenhower Administration.
