PHILADELPHIA, May l -- Pennsylvania defeated Harvard, 10 -- 7, on River Field today to top the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League standing with a 3-0 record.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- James C. Dunn, United States Ambassador to Spain, is due to arrive here over the week-end for high-level discussions of the Madrid Government's latest proposals for the exchange of United States economic and military aid for the use of Spanish military facilities.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- American clock and watch manufactures told Congress today they could not meet demands for military time fuses because their industry had been injured by a flood of imported foreign goods.

When a team is in a slump, form flies out the window. Even with Dave Koslo, who rarely loses to the Cardinals, pitching against Gerry Staley, who beat the Giants only once in seven 1952 tries, the New Yorkers bowed to St. Louis, 3 -- 2, at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

TRENTON, May 1 -- Evidence that New Jersey officials had definite proof of syndicate gambling in Bergen County as early as August, 1948, but did nothing about it until October, 1950, was presented today at the legislative committee hearing here.

DETROIT, May 1 -- David L. Cole, outgoing Director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, tonight urged President Eisenhower to support a new approach to the problem of national emergency labor disputes.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, chairman of the Joint Committee on Reduction of Non-essential Federal Expenditures, reported today that March had shown the largest drop in Federal employment of civilians since the start of the Korean war, a net decrease of 20,135.

The National Academy of Sciences has now joined other important scientific groups in support of Dr. Allen V. Astin, director of the National Bureau of Standards. Dr. Astin, recently dismissed from this post by Secretary of Commerce Weeks, has been reinstated by that official, significantly "with White House approval."

A twelve-count grand larceny indictment was returned yesterday against a textile salesman on charges that he swindled two businessmen of $188,989 in an intricate dress goods deal. The grand jury also brought charges against a suspected bookmaker who obtained $20,000 from the salesman as the latter vainly attempted to recoup his losses.
The city's plan to close down the Richmond County Jail and lodge its inmates in the Brooklyn city prison as an economy measure was assailed yesterday by the April King's County grand jury.

Women gardeners may find it helpful to wear boots made of soft, stretchable green latex. They cover the ankles and are easy to pull on, having no snaps or zippers to fasten. Waterproof and mudproof, they are washable inside and out. The boots are available at Lewis Conger.

MADRID, May 1 -- The State Department decision to call Ambassador James C. Dunn and the heads of the special military and economic missions here to Washington for consultation was said to have been made after John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, had made his report to President Eisenhower on the meeting of the North Atlantic Council in Paris last week.
JERSEY CITY, May 1 -- This city's Mayoralty campaign, already heated, virtually boiled over tonight when a shower of eggs greeted Frank Hague Eggers' invasion of Mayor John V. Kenny's home bailiwick.

MEXICO CITY, May 1 (AP) -- Art Wall, a former Duke University star who has scored twenty-nine holes-in-one, fired a two-under-par 70 today to share the halfway lead with Dave Douglas in the $15,000 Pan American open golf tournament.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 1 (AP) -- President Victor Paz Estenssoro disclosed today that the Government and the Patino mines -- nationalized a year ago -- had reached an agreement with the General Services Administration in the United States for the export of wolfram.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 1 -- Turkey will export 200,000 metric tons of her bumper 1952 wheat crop to Spain in return for $19,000,000 in currency and Spanish manufactured goods.

Gross revenues of the Southern Pacific Transportation System were at a record high in the first quarter this year and net income was at the best level for the period since 1943, the company announced yesterday.

May Day in Union Square yesterday was a soggy affair, dominated by a platform painting of President Eisenhower and Soviet Premier Georgi Malenkov shaking hands. The legend was "Let's Make It Happen Again," splashed on in yellow over the word "Peace" in red letters six feet high.

PITTSBURGH, May 1 (UP) -- Nine men who battled thirty-foot flames and exploding ammunition to rescue a pilot from his crashed jet plane were among twenty-two persons cited today by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission for outstanding acts of bravery.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 1 -- Greer Garson has her mind set on making her American stage debut next season on Broadway, but she won't know until next week at the earliest whether Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will share her enthusiasm.

THE TIMES' editorial of April 27 on Senator Morse's twenty-four-hour speech on the tidelands oil question deserves the commendation of those who believe that a filibuster, regardless of the issue which prompts it, is a fundamental evil in a democratic society. The American Civil Liberties Union has long opposed this practice in the United States Senate.
The New York Civil Liberties Union urged Police Commissioner George E. Monaghan yesterday to appoint two new deputy commissioners to deal with charges of police brutality.

ITHACA, N. Y., May 1 -- Attacks on public school education and ways to "take the counter-offensive" were discussed during the twenty-seventh annual institute for parent-teacher leaders held this week at Cornell University.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- An hour or so before game time tonight, the Yankees were dodging hailstones during a rainstorm. Then the contest with the White Sox started and, as long as Johnny Sain lasted, the Bombers were in danger of being crowned by flying baseballs.
PARIS, May 1 -- May Day was observed today by the French workers in an atmosphere of growing labor unrest, which has taken the form of work stoppages and agitation in important industries.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 -- A fifteen-gun salute at Treasure Island marked the retirement today of Vice Admiral John L. Hall after a distinguished Navy career spanning forty-four years.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- High income taxes are making the traditional money incentives less effective in drawing bright young men into managerial ranks, Crawford H. Greenewalt, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., said today.

MACON, Ga., May 1 (UP) -- Two more victims died today in tornado-ravaged middle Georgia, raising the death total to nineteen as the Government rushed aid to stricken families and officials estimated damage at upward of $15,000,000.
Ralph (Tiger) Jones, Yonkers middleweight, evened the score with Jimmy Herring of Ozone Park, L. I., in the main ten-round bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 -- A spokesman for the State Senate Un-American Activities Committee charged today that Communists had "infiltrated" the San Francisco public school system.

A group of importers of rare woods, together with converters, cabinetmakers and workworking and furniture craftsmen, has banded together to put on a campaign to educate users on the difference between fine wood construction and falsely represented substitutes.

Furnishings that give a somewhat softened look to the straight and simple lines of a contemporary three-bedroom house have been employed by Ward Bennett in decorating one of the three model homes that will open to the public tomorrow in North Freeport, L. I.

CLEVELAND, May 1 (AP) -- Standard Oil Company of Ohio announced today development of tiny, nitrogen-filled plastic balls it hopes will save the petroleum industry millions of dollars annually in crude oil evaporation from storage tanks.

The New York City Federation of Women's Clubs elected as its president yesterday Mrs. Lyonel Robinson of the Forest Hills Women's Club, and in three resolutions called for no real estate tax increase, a council-manager form of city government, speedier mail and more courteous bus service.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Two former Government economists, who held high posts in wartime, refused to tell the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today whether they were engaged in espionage now, whether they had been during the war, or whether they had been members of a Communist ring that allegedly passed out official secrets, as had been stated in an intelligence report.

SINGAPORE, May 1 -- One of the Malayan Communist party's top leaders has been murdered by his own bodyguards in Negri, Sembilan State, it was officially announced in Kuala Lumpur tonight. He was Ah (Shorty) Kuk, a member of the Central Committee of the party who had a price of $66,000 on his head under the old rewards system abolished this year.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub team matches, with more than six hundred contestants braving the cold and rain, were launched yesterday with the defending champions starting out well in two of the three districts, but not in Long Island.

A Senate resolution that would permit the sale of eight American-flag vessels to the two Filipino concerns now operating them under chapter from this country has been introduced by Senator Charles E. Potter, Republican of Michigan.

EL PASO, Tex., May 1 -- The Boston Symphony Orchestra, making its first coast-to-coast tour in its seventy-three-year history, played for the first time in this colorful section of the Southwest tonight.

TRAVIS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., May 1 -- A plane returning twenty-two United States prisoners of war from Korea, designated by the Air Force as "victims of Communist propaganda," landed here today under military secrecy, refueled and took off again.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 1 -- A Westchester County grand jury, in a presentment handed up today, said that the town clerk of Greenburgh, N. Y., wrongfully had taken $885 in fees from the town with the cooperation of an attorney acting as "dummy," but that no indictments were warranted.

LOUISVILLE, May 1 -- The color chart on Kentucky Derby winners lists thirty-six bays, twenty-seven chestnuts, eleven browns and four blacks. Nary a gray has made the grade in seventy-eight runnings of the Julep Belt's big horse race. The chief reason, of course, is that the grays are outnumbered by the others, and few have tried to do any grade-making in the Derby.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- The United States Court of Appeals today upset the hopes that have been held for fourteen months by owners of $10,000,000 of 1929 Chicago Board of Education tax warrants, that they might eventually collect on the warrants.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Leonard W. Hall of New York, the Republican National Chairman, sharply criticized what he termed the inefficiency of party headquarters here today and announced a sweeping reorganization plan that envisaged the dismissal of about forty employes and a saving of $100,000 a year in operating expenses.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Senator Milton R. Young, Republican of North Dakota, said today that Cargill, Inc., "broke the market" in oats last year and two Government officials said they believed the company was trying to manipulate prices again by illegal trading.
BUENOS AIRES, May 1 (AP) -- The Government's central bank announced it would grant exchange permits for the import of 2,200,000,000 pesos worth of essential goods this year.

A 9-year-old girl, crowned "Little Miss Clean-up of 1953," proposed yesterday that the school children of this city issue informal summonses to adult "litterbugs" whom they discover throwing rubbish in the wrong places.

Commodities closec{ irregularri iyeSterday on the New York ex, !.changes in light and feature les itradin. Cottonseed oil, soybezn] 0il and potatoes were most active...] Potatoes, cottoffseed oil, coffee[ !lead and zinc closed lower. Sugar,[ wool, cocoa and rubber were higher and soybean oil, hides and tin ended mixed.

March and April rains seem to have abetted the work of ever-present vandals in damaging the city's parks. More than $1,000,000, nearly one-fifth of the Park Department's budget, will be spent this year to save the city's earth and greenery from being washed down sewers.

Increases ranging from 1 to 15 per cent appeared yesterday on the May rent bills of about 800,000 New York City tenants as equalization adjustment, voted at the recent session of the Legislature, went into effect.

People hunting for antiques will have one show to comb that had not been anticipated earlier this season -- the New York Antiques Exposition that opens today at Grand central Palace and continues through May 10 from 1 to 11 P. M. daily.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The possibility of selling a 125,000,000-pound stockpile of surplus wool to Japan was disclosed today at a Senate Agriculture Committee hearing.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 1 -- A move by the administration of Gov. John Davis Lodge to reform the minor court system in Connecticut has been rejected by the joint Judiciary Committee of the General Assembly.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 1 (AP) -- Doris Hart and Shirley Fry, America's touring tennis stars, encountered unexpected trouble from English players today in the semi-final round of the British hard courts championship, but recovered to win.

Lieut. Francis Zek Jarecki, Polish airman who flew one of the latest-type Russian MIG's into Denmark recently, ,arrived at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday from London. He was cheered by travelers in the airport terminal as well as by seventy-five representatives of Polish American Organizations.

Sir Alexander Fleming, the British discoverer of penicillin, said here yesterday the drug was being used indiscriminately throughout the world. He said that had become evident from the number of persons who had become sensitive to the antibiotic, but not because penicillin-resistant strains of microorganisms were developing, reports of which he discounted.
King Norodom Sihanoug reaffirmed his position in a letter received by THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday.

THE big problems confronting the anglers now fishing the blue waters off Bimini is how to keep from catching white marlin, and most of them seem to have shifted to light tackle and are taking advantage of the unusual run.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- T. B. King, Joan guaranty officer of the Veterans Administration, said today there was "very great probability of early action" on proposals to increase the interest rate on G.I. home loans.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., May 1 -- Mrs. Mary Stallcup Markward, a former undercover agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, asserted today it would "not be even remotely possible" for her to have processed the Communist party application card of Lieut. Sheppard Carl Thierman without his already having been accepted as a member.
Sales of housing properties in Harlem featured realty deals reported in Manhattan yesterday.

The extinction of "Men of Distinction" takes place tonight after the fourth performance at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. The New York reviewers, to a man, found Richard Condon's first play about the unsavory doings of cafe society characters too unpalatable for their tastes.

Two contracts lay side by side on the desk of John I. Snyder Jr., chairman and president of the Pressed Steel Car Company, this week. They demonstrated what the company's product diversification of the past few years has accomplished.
A smoky barbecue sauce, crisp dilled onion rings, and strawberry preserves from Prince Edward Island are among the new foods in Gimbels main-floor epicure department.

LONDON, May 1 -- During the Coronation season in London next month a historic meeting of the British Commonwealth Prime Ministers will take place. Problems of foreign policy, which are uppermost in the minds of world statesmen at the moment, will be high on the agenda.

Greater emphasis upon guidance to enable high school students to meet their personal and social problems was urged yesterday by Dr. Edwin R. Van Kleeck, assistant state education commissioner. He decried the lack of adequate counseling services in most schools and said the situation would grow progressively worse as student enrollment increased.
Sixty waiters, bartenders and kitchen workers, members of the Hotel and Restaurant Employes Union, A. F. L., went on strike yesterday against Gallagher's Steak House, 228 West Fiftysecond Street.

Another step toward the ultimate goal of a United States of Europe has been taken with the expansion of the European Coal and Steel Community to the full scope contemplated under the Schuman Plan. Having established a single free market for coal last February in an area comprising six Continental nations with a combined population approximating that of the United States, the Community's High Authority has now instituted a like market for steel.

Six million newspapers were bought in the city yesterday, and if Joe Cantalupo, whose carting company cleans up fragrant Fulton Fish Market every day is right, one of every twenty papers landed in the streets after being read and absorbed.
SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, May 2 (AP) -- Fifty United States Sabre jets in their deadly new role as live-bombers hurled destruction yesterday on the North Korean capital at Pyongyang.

NEW DELHI, India, May 1 -- Negotiations between New Delhi and Washington on India's longstanding proposal to amend the existing civil aviation pact between India and the United States so as to limit the number of passengers that can be carried in and out of India by United States airlines are to be resumed here May 11.

CLEVELAND, May 1 (AP) -- The Red Sox ran their victory string to four games tonight by handing Cleveland's Bob Lemon his first defeat of the season, 8 -- 1. They scored seven of their runs off Lemon who had won three straight.

The possibility of a nation-wide strike by 100,000 shop workers against all Class One railroads except the Pennsylvania developed here yesterday at an emergency meeting of general chairmen of the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen, A. F. L.
HANOI, Vietnam, May 1 -- Advance Vietminh units were reported tonight to be nearing the bend of the Mekong River at two points within twelve miles of Luang Prabang, the royal capital of Laos.
TOKYO, May 1 -- Extraordinary police precautions and careful planning by the leaders of non-Communist unions combined to give Japan a May Day free from anticipated violence today.

A new A. B. C. television network project destined for a fall season run is a dramatic series that will star Menasha Skulnik in the role of a "private eye." The program is a creation of the fertile brain of George Jessel, who will write and produce the scripts with the assistance of Sam Carlton.
LONDON, May 1 (Reuters) -- London's favored Arsenal defeated Burnley by 3-2 today to win the first division championship in the English League with a superior goal average.
The French Line has made "great progess" in the dispersal of passengers booked for the liner Ile de France, now strikebound in Havre, a spokesman said yesterday.

Hundreds of stores, in 150 key American cities, have made plans for special sales promoting British goods in connection with the Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II on June 2, it was reported yesterday by H. J. O. Letcher, president of the British Commonwealth Chamber of Commerce.

Two American prisoners of war from Korea will help to dramatize the fight against communism when they ride in the van of the sixth annual Loyalty Parade down Fifth Avenue this afternoon under the sponsorship of the Veterans of Foreign Wars.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- A Justice Department lawyer told House of Representative investigators today it was still his "honest opinion" the Government could not have won a $185,000 mail-fraud case against Roy E. Crummer and associates.

After five successive weekly declines the stock market ended the week yesterday with a net gain. It was not an impressive performance, however. Prices drifted lower most of the day and were pushed to the plus side by a minor rally in oils.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 1 -- Natal's powerful Torch Commando war veterans, which raised a threat of secession from the South African Union last year at the time of the constitutional crisis, seems to be swinging toward the demand for dissolution of the Union and for Federal reorganization.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 1 (UP) -- Foreign Minister Aureliano Otanez said today that the five-year-old Grancolombiana merchant fleet may be dissolved because of the "unfriendly attitude" toward V nezuela by Colombia and Ecuador.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- John Taber, Republican of upstate New York, said today next year's foreign aid request might be set finally at less than $4,000,000,000 by cutting off unused funds from past years.

Tom Sawyer and Huckleberry Finn probably would have been the first to concede that school days have changed since their time, had they seen seventh and eighth grade pupils from Public School 6 happily helping yesterday morning to move their classrooms from Eighty-fifth to Eighty-first Street on Madison Avenue.

A quarter of a century ago Prof. John von Neumann of the Institute for Higher Learning and Dr. Oskar Morgenstern of Princeton published a book on the "Theory of Games and Economic Behavior." So important has this work become that in the University of Wisconsin poker is being played by advanced students who bluff, cheat, scheme and do about everything but assault one another.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Henry Edward Schultz, vice chairman of the Board of Higher Education of New York City, declared in a speech prepared for delivery here tonight that "communism is the enemy" in this country and not "our great liberal and democratic institutions," which, he said, have been "under attack."

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The leading designers of the atomic and hydrogen bomb, attending the annual Washington meeting of the American Physical Society, were urged tonight to help solve what was described as one of the most fundamental problems facing the United States and the free world -- the lack of defensive measures against atomic attack comparable with the growing power of the atom as an offensive weapon.

The device of setting up large stocks in warehouses throughout the country can be of great help to shoe retailers who, as independents, cannot compete equally with retail stores owned by manufacturers, it was asserted yesterday by William Manowitz, president of the Hussco Shoe Company of Honesdale, Pa., and this city.

DETROIT, May 1 (UP) -- Ned Garver, tagged for two home runs in the first two innings, settled down to pitch a six-hitter today and end a six-game losing streak by the Tigers with a 7-3 victory over the Athletics.

MOSCOW, May 1 -- The Foreign Ministry has informed diplomats in Moscow that Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov now has four deputy ministers, headed by Andrei Y. Vishinsky and Andrei A. Gromyko, both of whom are first deputy foreign ministers, Mr. Vishinsky serving as a permanent representative to the United Nations and Mr. Gromyko as chief deputy in Moscow.
TOKYO, Saturday, May 2 (AP)--United Nations Command Communique 1,602, covering Friday's operations:...

The one-story renovated industrial building at 39 Clay Street in Brooklyn has been leased by the William Fierro Company from the Silfen Paper Company and will be used for the manufacture of women's handbags and pocketbook frames.

Compulsory retirement of men at 65 years old. and women at 60 is forcing many aging workers tobecome ''runaways.'' Mrs. Georgel Hamlin Shaw. president of the INational Travelers Aid Association, said yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, May 1 -- President Juan Peron, opening Congress today on a May Day marred by a series of bomb explosions, charged that three United States news agencies were openly engaging in an "infamous campaign of lies against Argentina."
PARIS, May 1 (AP) -- The heads of American and European boxing commissions agreed today to set up a four-man committee to iron out perennial disputes over rightful claimants to world championships.
CLEVELAND, May 1 (AP) -- A scrap steel broker said today Argeatina has been buying scrap steel from the French Government and then reselling it to Russia.

LONDON, May 1 -- Work on the new plutonium-producing atomic reactor to be built in the; northwest hill district of Cumberland will start next week, it was revealed last night in the House of Commons by Supply Minister Duncan Sandys.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Cornelius Pytsch, 49 years old, alias Frank Raboski, a civic leader of suburban Northlake and treasurer of its Crime Commission, began a fight today to avoid serving old prison sentences in New York and California.

GUATEMALA, May 1 -- Approximately 70,000 May Day demonstrators marched through the main streets of the city for five hours today, ending the parade at the National Palace. President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman, accompanied by members of his Cabinet and other officials, watched the parade from a palace balcony.

The pamphlet report of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., and wholly owned subsidiaries, issued yesterday for the three months ended on March 31 showed sharp increases in net sales, taxes and net income, although dividends received from General Motors Corporation were the same as those received in the first quarter of 1952.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 1 -- Because science succeeded where nature failed, 5-year-old Mei-Da Ann Pang will fly for her Honolulu home from La Guardia Airport tomorrow with the use of "arms" she did not have at birth.

Anyone with a strong hankering to touch Texas soil could do it easily in Times Square yesterday afternoon. A light sprinkling of early afternoon rain carried down with it reddish, sandy dirt that weather men said probably came from drought-stricken areas of the Southwest.

A 49 - year - old hospital electrician, described by the Government as Moscow's top-ranking representative among the Communist youth of the Western Hemisphere, was arrested last night and taken to Ellis Island for deportation proceedings.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, said today he feared Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby intended "to build a record of economy at the expense of the school children of this country."

POTTSTOWN, Pa., May 1 (AP) -- Walter John Bookman Jr., 33 years old, of 108-29 160th Street, Jamaica, Queens, died today in Pottstown Hospital half an hour after his light plane had crashed and burned near Flowing Springs, a tiny community near here.

ALBANY, May 1 -- The Democratic leaders of the Legislature criticized Governor Dewey today for his approval of the 1953 Residential Rent Control Law and said that their party was proclaiming today, when rent increase provisions go into effect, as "Landlord's Day."

The average market value of New York Stock Exchange bonds on March 31 was the lowest since Nov. 30, 1942, the exchange reported yesterday. The average on the recent date was $96.57, a 58 cent decline from $97.15 at the end of February.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -- Senator Henry M. Jackson asked Congress today to pledge the United States to divert much of its present defense spending to a peaceful attack on world poverty if the Soviet Union would accept strict armament controls.

The battle for Korea would have been "lost in two weeks" had it not been for the prompt application of sea power, Vice Admiral John J. Ballentine, Commander of the Air Force of the Atlantic Fleet, told members of the Naval Order of the United States last night at the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 1 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold assured employes of the United Nations today that under his administration "the principles on which the independence of our Secretariat is founded will be stanchly defended and firmly applied."

Addressing a group of American editors at SHAPE last year General Eisenhower said in substance many of the things he said on Thursday in his statement on the budget and defense. In his capacity as Supreme Commander of the NATO forces he was naturally concerned that Congressional appropriations should not be cut below the sum needed to fulfill the commitments we had already made for the Mutual Security Program.
Robert E. Tyriver has been appointed general sales manager of Cantrell Cochrane Corp., a subsidiary of National Phoenix Industries, Inc., carbonated beverages.

A committee of fifteen prominent Connecticut judges and lawyers has asked the two United States Senators and the six Representatives from Connecticut to support legislation that would provide a $10,000 increase in the salaries of all Federal judges.
Marin County, Calif., plans to sell $2,000,000 of water district bonds, due from Feb. 1, 1956 to 1980, on May 18. Interest may not exceed 5 per cent.

PARIS, May 1 -- The French municipal elections last Sunday showed that the principal change a loss of 15 per cent in the Gaullist strength and that these losses went to swell the votes of nearly all the other parties.

Brooklyn is back in first place in the National League. It took a mighty effort, but the Dodgers were equal to the occasion last night. They trailed by three runs at Ebbets Field as they came to bat in the eighth inning and rushed -- four tallies across in short order to defeat the Cubs, 6 -- 5, and thereby replace the Phillies as the loop's leader.

LOS ANGELES, May 1 -- Recognition of television as a news medium entitled to the same access as the press and radio in the coverage of public affairs was urged today by the National Association of Radio and Television Broadcasters.

Gradual adoption of a policy of free trade by the United States would prove beneficial to this country and to the world economy, Kenneth Parker, chairman of the board of the Parker Pen Company, said yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 1 -- A proposal for a special meeting between representatives of Israel and Jordan to work out means of avoiding frontier incidents, such as the outburst of shooting in Jerusalem nine days ago, was made early this week by the British Ambassadors in Amman and Tel Aviv.

There's a horse race in New York's own yard today that will not go unnoticed by the citizenry in this area, despite the millions of words that have been siphoned in the direction of Louisville and the Kentucy Derby. The event in question is the Gallant Fox Handicap, a mile and three-sixteenth test for 3-year-olds and upward, at the Jamaica track.
No single style dominates the five of this week's exhibitions of paintings under consideration, though they are all, to varying degrees, romantic in character.

The Atlas Tile and Marble Works has purchased the one-story industrial building at 41-17 Crescent Street, Long Island City, Queens, from Marie B. Cochran, Yvonne B. Mills and Jules C. Brulatour. The Advance Realty Company was the broker.
One of the things for which copy clinics chide national advertisers is that they do not tell the price of their goods in advertising. Only a few advertisers have paid any heed to the criticism.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Pakistan has indicated her willingness to serve as the neutral custodian of prisoners of the Korean war who do not want to return to their Communist homelands, and the United States, it is understood, would accept the Karachi Government for that role.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 1 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that he hoped current negotiations between the United States and the United Nations would settle "once and for all" questions on the right of access to the organization's headquarters here.

PARIS, May 1 -- The French reply to a recent declaration by King Norodom Sihanouk of the French Associated State of Cambodia that unless France gave his people independence "within the next three months," they might join the Communist-led Vietminh movement, has been to resume the conversations long delayed for reform of relations with the Cambodian Government.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A double topcoat that a man can expand to enfold his girl friend is among the inventions patented this week. The garment is expected to be especially useful at sports events. When a storm strikes the bleachers, for instance, the owner pulls his arm out of one sleeve, unsnaps the folded panels at front and back, and invites the young lady inside.

LONDON, May 1 -- The stock markets ended the week today as they began it -- quietly dull A little routine selling was sufficient to bring falls in most markets except in British Government securities, foreign bonds and the oils.

The Broollyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday, anet income of $1,651,629 after all expenses, taxes and other charges in/ the first three months of this year./ This was equal to 99 cents a share! on the utility's outstanding common stock, and compares with a] net of $2,071',380 or $1.31 a shareI in the first quarter of 1952.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 1 -- Southern Democratic leaders attending a regional political strategy conference today assailed the economic and fiscal policies of the Eisenhower Administration and declared "the people are too enlightened to be fooled by such goings-on."

A spokesman for The Saturday Review said last night that he did not know whether Mr. Fitzgerald would review more books for the magazine. He said the book reviewer had started working for the publication three years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves brought their big bats into Connie Mack Stadium for the first time tonight and scored a 5 --2 victory over the slumping Phillies, with Joe Adcock, Jim Wilson and Andy Pafko contributing homers.

TORONTO, May 1 -- Confident that a sustained publicity campaign in the United States will bear fruit officials of the Canadian International Trade Fair expect to attract 2,000 American buyers, or double last year's figure.

Pfc. Joseph Picerno, the first New Yorker among repatriated prisoners of the Korean war to return to this city, arrived at La Guardia Airport, Queens, yesterday and began a thirty-day furlough, during which he plans "to make up for lost time" with members of his family.

OMAHA, Neb., May 1 -- The Council of Bishops of the Methodist Church expressed concern today that "in a period when its witness is so sorely needed, the church has been persistently and falsely accused in many quarters and her world-wide leaderhip therefore jeopardized."

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Department of Agriculture and the Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced in a joint statement today the suspension of rodent and insect grain contamination control by means of seizing carload lots of grain at terminals.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Mrs. Truxton Beale held a small reception today at her famous old home, Decatur House on Lafayette Square, to announce her intention of bequeathing the house, part of its contents and an endowment for its preservation to the National Trust for Historic Preservation.

PRETORIA, South Africa, May 1 -- The Nationalist Cabinet apparently has decided on a policy of imposing news censorship at the source on the newspapers that oppose the Nationalists in their editorial columns. In South Africa this amounts in effect to the whole English-language press.
ST. LOUIS, May 1 (UP) -- Sonny Dixon came in to pitch in the ninth inning tonight to choke off a rally by the Browns and give the Senators a 6-5 victory.

The Deck Scow Captains Union, negotiating new contracts with two employer groups in New York Harbor, reportedly has accepted tentatively an offer from one but has rejected an identical offer from the other. The result: confusion.
PITTSBURGH, May 1 (AP) -- Castiglione belted two homers, drove in three runs and did some sensational fielding despite an error to give the Pirates an 8-3 victory over the Redlegs tonight.

The man whose fortune or misfortune it is to possess a garden will be easy to recognize for the next several Monday mornings. He has been led to believe that the recent heavy rains have made the ground soft and workable, and accordingly has been busy bringing order out of the chaos left by winter.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Public Health Service doctors reported today that preliminary evaluation had shown that bicillin, a form of penicillin, was an effective one-injection cure for syphilis in its early stages.

MOSCOW, May 1 -- Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Defense Minister, speaking from atop the Mausoleum in Red Square, declared today that in the absence of any sign of a lessening arms race or a diminution of the network of military bases close to the Soviet frontiers, Russia must strengthen her armed forces.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Senator Wayne Morse challenged United States scientists today to make clear that their colleagues in Government jobs must be "clear of political pressure." He added that the Senate should investigate the dismissal of Dr. Allen V. Astin from the Bureau of Standards.

BERLIN, May 1 -- East Germany displayed the extent of its preparations for rearmament today in a grandiose May Day parade through the Soviet sector of Berlin, but the dampening influence of the current Soviet "peace offensive" was much in evidence.
Special programs will be conducted this week-end in Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish congregations to emphasize ideal family life. The coming week will be National Family Week.
TOKYO, May 1 (UP) -- A United States sergeant told today how the Communists faked propaganda pictures of Allied war prisoners being treated handsomely on the march and in North Korean camps.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- William C. Bullitt, former Ambassador to Russia and France, called today for a complete sea blockade of Red China and a coordinated attack, without additional United States ground troops, in Korea, the Chinese mainland, and Indo-China.
The sixteenth annual Three Choir Festival held under the auspices of Congregation Emanu-El opened yesterday afternoon with a concert at the assembly hall of Temple Emanu-El.

Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, declined yesterday to serve as the fifth member of the New York City Transit Authority after the four members appointed by Governor Dewey and Mayor Impellitteri were unable to meet the deadline for their designation of the fifth member required by the law creating the new agency.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Supreme Court took under advisement today, after listening to four hours of arguments, the question of whether laws enacted eighty years ago to prevent racial discrimination in restaurants in the District of Columbia were still valid and constitutional.

Permanent financing totaling $2,747,600 has been arranged by J. Halperin Co., brokers, for the third and last section of the Beech Hills cooperative apartment development under construction at 245th Street and Sixtieth Avenue in Douglaston, Queens.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals has ruled that the Federal Power Commission was "without power" to order Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company to enlarge its facilities and provide all the gas it contracted to serve customers.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Senate Republican leader, today expressed "agreement in principle" with a proposal to exempt the building trades unions and local public utilities from the Taft-Hartley Labor Act.

TOKYO, Saturday, May 2 -- The Communist delegation at Panmunjom named India, Pakistan, Burma and Indonesia today as Asian nations considered neutral in the Korean war, but refused to nominate any one at this time as the potential custodian for prisoners refusing repatriation.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Three staff sergeants in the Yugoslav Air Force announced today that they had, deserted because citizens had no rights in their Communist country, and asked asylum in the United States. They have been studying jet propulsion in the United States Air Force base in Amarillo, Tex.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Dallas S. Townsend of Montclair, N. J., was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be an Assistant Attorney General. If confirmed by the Senate, he would become chief of the Alien Property Office, succeeding Harold I. Baynton, who has resigned.

The debate should be welcomed concerning the justification of the United States Information Service in spending $3 millions a year to operate the Neue Zeitung in Germany and to assist other German papers, even though some of them do not support United States policy or are critical of some political aspects of it.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, May 1 -- The latest information on the atomic weapons tests in the United States has now been furnished to Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, and is being used by his staff as a basis for an important study to determine the forces that the North Atlantic Treaty allies should have under arms by the end of 1956.

When Elizabeth MacKintosh died in London last year, five days before publication of "The Daughter of Time," it was believed that was her last detective story written under her pen name of Josephine Tey. Since then the manuscript of a new Inspector Grant story has been found and Macmillan will issue the book May 12.

Charles H. Silver will soon be rounding out a year of service as a member of the New York City Board of Education. He took office, by appointment of Mayor Impellitteri, in a backwash of public resentment over the Mayor's failure to reappoint the veteran member James Marshall. We were among those who condemned the dropping of Mr. Marshall,

A 73-year-old Ramsey, N. J., heiress sailed with her lawyer yesterday for Colombia to claim an estate of $300,000 bequeathed to her in that country by her brother, but she plans to give all the money to Colombian charities.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 1 -- The recount in the contested Democratic primary election for Governor was extended to two more counties here today and the possibility of a state-wide check of all ballots was projected.

To those of us who are concerned about the rising tide of juvenile delinquency, the action of the House of Representatives in prohibiting the further expansion of the low-rent public housing program was most disheartening. It is now generally recognized that slum areas, with their crowded living quarters, their lack of adequate sanitary facilities, are fertile soil for the growth of antisocial behavior among young people.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Department of Defense made public today the full study that resulted in the plan for reorganization of the Pentagon placed before Congress yesterday by President Eisenhower.

To call attention to the "antiquity" of the present annual personal registration in New York City, ten members of the League of Women Voters rode yesterday in a 1922 Model T Ford truck from East Ninety-fourth Street and First Avenue to the Board of Elections, 400 Broome Street, with six of them registering centrally for the November election.
Sales of Manhattan and Brooklyn department stores declined 3 per cent in April, compared with the same month last year, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
The Cotton futures market here was moderately active yesterday, and closing prices were 2 to 19 points net higher than on Thursday.

Chairman Smith of the Senate Labor Committee has offered a bill which would exclude from the Taft-Hartley Act jurisdiction over several million employes. He would free the building trade employes from the act entirely. Then he would exempt employers of less than ten persons, as well as "local" public utilities such as streetcar and local bus lines.
AMMAN, Jordan, May 1 -- Two cousins, both British-educated, will be installed as Kings of Jordan and Iraq tomorrow, their eighteenth birthday.

VIENNA, May 1 -- The feature of May Day in the Soviet satellite states today was a speech by Antonin Zapotocky, President of Czechoslovakia, calling for the cooperation of the Big Five -- the Soviet Union, the United States, Britain, France and Communist China -- for peace and endorsing an Austrian treaty.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 1 -- At a May Day pageant in Tel Aviv Stadium, 10,000 workers were called upon to pledge loyalty to the "ancient socialism," which was identified with "Love Thy Neighbor as Thyself."

CHICAGO, May 1 -- The grain market was full of speculative cross currents today. Futures held in a moderate range but with extremely choppy fluctuations. Shorts took profits on quite a heavy scale but there were periods of further long liquidation which made it easy to cover sales.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 1 -- There was good news in taxes in this town tonight when the Board of Finance approved a new and lower rate which, it was explained, came about through prudent municipal housekeeping.

Your leading editorial of April 29 lists the issues, stated by President Eisenhower on April 16, which must be settled if a just peace is to be achieved. Allow us to supplement your list by the following excerpts from the President's address:

The collection of 27,717 pints of blood in April in the regional blood program of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross indicates that its over-all defense quota for the fiscal year ending next month will be assured, T. Morgan Williams, chairman of the program, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today authorized construction by three natural gas pipeline companies to make available an additional 300,000,000 cubic feet of gas daily to the Northern Natural Gas Company of Omaha.

James O'Shea, supervisor of the State Employment Service camp placement unit at 1 East Nineteenth Street, reported yesterday that there were excellent job prospects, with salaries higher than in former years, for college men and women interested in working as counselors in summer camps.

KINGS POINT, L. I., May 2 -- The baseball game between City College of New York and the United States Merchant Marine Academy today was canceled due to wet grounds, but a tennis match, two dual track meets, sailing and a rifle tournament were held.
ST. LOUIS, May 2 (UP) -- Mickey Vernon's first home run of the year gave the Senators and Frank (Spec) Shea a 5-4 victory over the Browns today.
WEST POINT, N. Y., May 2 -- Manhattan defeated Army's track team in a soggy setting on The Plains today, 80 1-3 to 59 2-3.

THE latest of Myron Brinig's many stories belongs to an old and useful tradition, in its way a great tradition. Novels were once the great purveyors of aristocracy to the middle class, serving the wives of the aspiring as etiquette books and reveries.

LOUISVTLLE, May 2 -- Native Dancer, under solid whipping for the first time in his career, reached the end of the winning trail in the $118,100 Kentucky Derby before 100,000 more than mildly surprised onlookers at old Churchill Downs today.

THE New York City Ballet opens its twelfth season at the City Center on Tuesday. Its chief dancers will be Maria Tallchief, Andre Eglevsky, Janet Reed, Diana Adams, Patricia Wilde, Yvonne Mounsey, Nicholas Magallanes, Francisco Moncion, Herbert Bliss Hugh Laing, Todd Bolender, Frank Hobi, Michael Maule, Roy Tobias and the newly returned Marie-Jeanne. The schedule for the season follows:

BWANA video, it seems, is on the way. In a careless moment last week the Federal Communications Commission authorized the American Broadcasting Company to offer an experimental 3-D telecast on the West Coast.

LOS ANGELES, May 2 -- The television broadcasting industry has made great progress in the last year in applying its code of good taste governing program material, but still has some way to go, an industry spokesman reported this week.

ARLINGTON, Va., April 29 -- Capt. Richard Helsden Phillips, U.S.N., and Mrs. Phillips have announced the engagement of Mrs. Phillips' daughter, Miss Suzanne Johnson, to Lieut. (j.g.) Daniel David Milne Willard, U. S. N., son of Mrs. De Blieux S. Willard of Grande Ecore, Natchitoches, La., and of David Milne Willard of Natick, Mass.

RECENTLY the gourd has come up in the world. From its lowly station as a drinking cup beside the "old oaken bucket," or as a nest egg in the barn to coax the hens to lay, it rose a little when it found itself in mother's darning basket.

THE Coronation will help the traveler in Britain. It will put more things out into the open and some things into Technicolor: the country will be on display. But whatever happens, England remains the mild, quiet, half-tone country of every-man's-home-his-castle, of high hedges and garden walls for privacy.

MEMPHIS, Tenn. -- A week from next Tuesday, May 12, the Cotton Carnival will get under way here. Memphis' spring celebration, which is also called "The Nation's Party In the Land of Cotton," dates back to 1931 and, true to its billing, annually attracts thousands of spectators from all parts of the country.
This was the balance sheet last week on the grounds for hope and the grounds for doubt about the sincerity of the Communist "peace offensive":

MYRTLE BEACH, S. C. -- This quiet, dreamy resort on the South Carolina coast, 652 miles out of New York, seems too good to be true. It affords quiet, twenty miles of sandy beach creamed by sleep-producing surf night and day, and good meals and accommodations at modest prices.
ITHACA, N. Y., May 2 -- Cornell's sweep-swingers rowed to their second victory of the season today, beating Syracuse by a length and a half in a two-mile race on choppy Cayuga Lake.

CONNOISSEURS of legal ingenuity and dramatic fireworks wait eagerly and sometimes a bit impatiently for the moment in a Perry Mason novel when Erie Stanley Gardner finally arrives at a trial. The rest of the book is usually fine in its way, but nothing else quite equals Mason at work in a courtroom.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- President Eisenhower, discussing his budget with the reporters on Thursday, looked and sounded remarkably like almost any other American discussing the family budget these days.

RICHMOND, Va. -- For more than eight months a group of Virginia aviation enthusiasts has been planning an aviation exhibit for Richmond's Richard E. Byrd Field on May 16 and 17. More than 300 airplanes, military and civilian, conventional and jet, will take part in the event.
SYRACUSE, May 2 -- Danny (Bang Bang) Womber of Chicago outpointed Cuba's Kid Gavilan, the world welterweight champion, in a ten-round non-title fight tonight.

PAULINE VINSON brings a novel treatment to the perennial subject of a child's first day at school by making the new student an attractive mouse. In a brief, light-hearted picture book we follow Willie from his matter-of-fact examination by the school nurse through his introduction to such activities as painting, block building, story-telling, rest hour and play time.
STAMFORD, Conn., May 2 -- This city was busy today preening its fiscal feathers.

OUR town's independent firm sweepstakes will get an added starter tomorrow when "Go, Man, Go" goes into production at the Fox Movie-tone studio. This, it was learned the other day, not only will be the initial movie venture of Alfred Palca Enterprises Productions but also will serve to introduce ace cinematographer James Wong Howe to the directorial ranks.

Some Gateway to the West! -- that enormous metal wicket with which St. Louisans mean to deface their entire neck of the woods. At the same site they ought also to re-erect the World's Fair perisphere and trylon in the usual layout so that guffawing Cyclopes could play croquet.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, said today an analysis by the Library of Congress had shown "some wide open loopholes" in the laws to safeguard the nation against treason, espionage, sabotage and sedition.

JOHN J. TOTTEN, a calm, efficient man, was the guest of honor at a testimonial dinner on the stage of Carnegie Hall last week. This was the first time in the sixty-two-year history, of the hall that there had been a dinner on the stage, although heaven knows that there have been occasions when the musical ideals to which the place is dedicated have been diverted much more seriously.

Competing at the distance for the first time, Herb Hinman, Theodore Roosevelt High senior, turned in a fine showing in capturing the open half-mile run at the sixth annual Brooklyn College interscholastic track and field games conducted on the Kingsmen's field yesterday.

George May's recent article, "The Total Fear of the Red Terror" inside the Soviet satellites, should be a reminder that we are facing a similar fate. We needed this reminder that no dictatorship ever gained power or maintained it save after having created fear of liquidation in the minds of its mass victims.
Remedies for the traffic congestion caused by hundreds of illegally parked trucks and for the practice of ignoring traffic summonses were outlined last week by the Twenty-third Street Association.

THE so-called "revolution" in retailing, connoting self-service, super-markets, night openings, branch stores and huge suburban shopping centers, is also developing a phase that might be regarded as new, but is nevertheless as old as retailing itself.

VARIETY comedy is television's spectacular and troublesome paradox. It is lucrative programming fare which always has led to bountiful ratings and presumably contented sponsors. Fresh evidence on this point has been provided in the last few weeks in the wake of the $25,000,000 merger of the United Paramount Theatres and the American Broadcasting Company.

A MIDDLE-AGED Hindu of superior if slightly tarnished caste, Margayya is the money-lender of Malgudi, and the mortal enemy of the Central Cooperative Land Mortgage Bank. Opposite this institution and directly below a banyan tree, he distributes to the poor the small sums which enable them perpetually to float loans from the bank -- and remain perpetually in debt.

CALCUTTA, India, Sunday, May 3 -- A Comet jet airliner with three Americans and a party of rubber and tin operators from Malaya reported aboard crashed in a violent storm late yesterday within minutes after a take-off from Calcutta.

ON the rolling, equatorial uplands of Kenya, white and black people alike live today in a state of constant fear and tension. Through a great area of this British East African crown colony no one can tell where or on what night gangs of secret Mau Mau terrorists will strike, murdering men, women and children with hatchets and machete-like panga knives.

So many misleading statements have recently appeared in the press concerning the Institute of Pacific Relations that the general public is in danger of forming an erroneous conception of it. Therefore, I ask your permission to summarize the main facts.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to name a bipartisan commission to make "a broad-gauge study into the question of what our foreign economic policy should be."

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The House un-American Activities Committee will go to New York tomorrow for an investigation of Communist infiltration into educational and entertainment fields and "sensitive" Federal installations of the area.

TO ride in a real train and hear the whistle blow up into the sky was something 6-year-old Stephen had always wanted. His first trip was as much fun as expected, with some surprises thrown in. Other Stephens keep turning up all over the train: the conductor, the engineer and even another little boy named Stephen to play with.

WHERE is the distinction of real ease and pleasure that should be found at least somewhere in serious writings about the arts? Atrophied by puritanism and by all sorts of current insecurities, you conclude.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- That lampooning newspaper, The Washington Short Change, made its sole appearance tonight at the annual dinner and stunt party of the Women's National Press Club. President and Mrs. Eisenhower were the honor guests at the event.

One million adults and children will be under hospital care for serious mental disorders this year, Dr. George S. Stevenson, medical director of the National Association for Mental Health, predicted yesterday.

Drill teams from nineteen Eastern colleges and universities met here yesterday in an all-day competition for the annual prize of the National Society of Pershing Rifles, an organization of honor members of the Reserve Officers Training Corps.

PARIS, May 2 -- William Shakespeare, who was not a political warrior, observed, "'Tis a kind of good deed to say well: and yet words are no deeds." Such may be described as the West's attitude toward the Soviet peace offensive.

IN the Northeast May is a month unparalleled for its bloom on trees and shrubs. It is ushered in by crabapples and spireas, flowering almond and shadbush. Before many days have passed dogwood and apple trees as well as lilacs will be in full flower, and on their heels will come the viburnums, azaleas and rhododendron.

ROBERT PAYNE makes two statements about our translation of Liu Shaw-tong's "Out of Red China" which we would like to answer. He accuses Mr. Liu of saying little about "the life of the people" and then writes of us "It is no service to supply free embellishments when we want the naked truth."

About twenty years ago the late Sir Arthur Eddington assured astronomers and cosmologists that, in accordance with the calculations of Abbe G. Lemaitre, the universe is doubling its radius every 1,400 million years or so and that the age of the earth, as determined by the spontaneous transmutation of uranium into several kinds of radium and finally into lead, must be about 3,500 million years.

Three major studies for improving nursing and alleviating the country's critical shortage of nurses are under way at the new Institute of Research and Service in Nursing Education at Columbia University's Teachers College.

FIRST the entire crew of the destroyer Melroy loses its heart to the stray, flop-eared puppy; then the Old Man, who banned all animals and thought he meant it, follows suit. Let the reader who boasts an indifference to dogs beware, for a similar fate awaits him when he gets to know Bosun.

IN another six weeks the cruise season will open on the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence River. These trips are a delightful way to escape from summer heat waves, catch a few days' rest and at the same time view some fascinating scenery.

THE Eisenhower Administration has been experiencing unexpected difficulties in recruiting the manpower to fill out its policy-making team. Not the dozen or so very top places, for there are many aspects of the highest public posts which appeal even to men who must make heavy sacrifices to accept them.

OMAHA, May 2 (AP) -- Mrs. Warren C. Hunter of Portland, Ore., is the new president of the National Council of Camp Fire Girls. Mrs. Hunter, formerly a vice president and director, was elected at the conclusion of a two-day meeting on Thursday of the National Council in Omaha.

CARLISLE, Pa. -- Never more than twenty miles in width and flanked by scenic ridges of the Appalachian chain, which contains some of Pennsylvania's finest forest and park areas, the picturesque and historic Cumberland Valley extends for approximately one hundred miles in a southwesterly direction from the Susquehanna River in Harrisburg to the Potomac River.
DERBY, Conn., May 2 -- A strong 150-pound Princeton crew defeated Yale and Harvard today to win the twenty-eighth annual Goldthwaite Cup race on the Housatonic River.

CLEVELAND, May 2 (AP) -- Boston's Red Sox won their fifth straight game today, a 5-1 victory over the Indians, as Hector (Skinny) Brown's bid for his first major league shutout was ruined by Dale Mitchell's homer with two out in the ninth.

COMPOSED by a psychiatrist and a professor of law, "Psychiatry and the Law" seems to herald an end to a century-old struggle between lawyers and psychiatrists. The introductory essay, "The Place of Psychiatry in the Law," declares that the contributions of psychiatry must be made "within the framework of existing legal principles." The dog, then, must wag the tail.

Debate on foreign-trade policies got off to a good start in Washington last week. By contrast, current developments in the actual business of exporting and importing indicated there would be less foreign trade for the United States this year.

BOSTON, May 2 (UP) -- Tommy Collins was back home today after passing successfully the physical examination ordered by the State Boxing Commission following his widely publicized defeat in a title bout with the lightweight champion, Jimmy Carter.

TRAVIS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., May 2 -- Forty beaming American service men, just released from Communist prison camps, arrived here by plane today from Tokyo. Their happy mood was in remarkable contrast to the exhaustion and indifference shown by most of the first planeload three days ago, although later they soberly reported the deaths of thousands of their former fellow soldiers in Chinese and North Korean prisons.

President Eisenhower's statements during the past week show some shift in emphasis in the thinking about defense and budgetary problems. In most of the time since we faced the necessity of rearmament, specific targets have been proposed both for ourselves and for our allies.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 2 -- Gov. John Davis Lodge is being attacked by the state leadership of the Congress of Industrial Organizations for his choice in appointing the C. I. O. representative on the State Board of Mediation and Arbitration.
ATLANTA, May 2 (UP) -- The estimate of tornado damage approached $20,000,000, as new storm bulletins were broadcast throughout this area.

TOKYO, Sunday, May 3 -- The United Nations Command again called on the Communists yesterday to return additional sick and wounded prisoners of the Korean war who, according to repatriated captives, still are held in barbed-wire stockades north of the Thirty-eighth Parallel.

The quotation from Jefferson concerning the press which forms the opening paragraph of Henry Steele Comanger's article on John Peter Zenger. ("A Fighting Printer -- and a Free Press," April 19), would be counterbalanced by one Jefferson wrote to John Norvell of Danville, Va., on June 11, 1807:

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- Cornell won eleven events and tied for first in one to swamp Pennsylvania's track team, 94 -- 46, in a dual meet on Franklin Field today. The Ithacans captured eight of the nine running tests.

THE Model 220 Lumax 1953, a $49.95 electronic flash unit that weighs three pounds with batteries, powered by D-type dry-cell batteries and equipped with the General Electric FT-218 flash-tube, is announced by Lumax Manufacturing Company, 489 Sixth Avenue.

THE oriental crabapples are fast becoming the most popular group of flowering trees in America. They can be grown anywhere apples are, and this includes about 75 per cent of the gardening area of the United States.

A break with the past has just been made in the advertising of issues of securities for sale to the public. The occasion for the innovation was the marketing of a $75,000,000 issue of public revenue bonds to finance extension of the Maine Turnpike from Portland to Augusta and to consolidate the Turnpike Authority's outstanding debt into the new bond issue.
Defalcation! The word makes bankers shudder, especially since bank embezzlements have been rising during recent years.

CHARLOTTE TURGEON, reviewing the two cookbooks "Stars in Your Kitchen" and "Our Favorite Dish," writes: "Raising money through cookbooks is a time-honored and ecclesiastically approved custom, but this is the first time to my knowledge that it has reached the stellar theatrical world."

It did not astonish the experts on cybernetics to learn last week from this newspaper's scientific correspondent in London that in the mathematical laboratory of the University of Cambridge there is a machine that can profit by experience. In this respect the machine surpasses many a human being.

PARIS, May 2 (AP) -- European and American ring officials formed the International Committee for Professional Boxing today to regulate the recognition of world championships -- and two minutes later the war of words was on over the middleweight title.

Almost everyone has had the exasperating experience of spilling catsup -- if not all over the table, at least dumping far too much on a plate. Usually this was because air had dried up part of the bottle's contents, forcing the user to strike the bottom in order to eject the amount desired.

IN his first novel Albert Johnston describes the heartaches and disillusionments of a Mexican family who leave their village home and come to New York. It is the story of Miguel Gaivados, who worked in a Brooklyn shipyard during World War II, and wanted his loved ones to share the opportunities and wonders of the great Americano city where a man like Paddy Hogan, Miguel's boss, called him "Mike" and treated him as a friend.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The 1954 Congressional elections, although distant, are throwing a long and unusually early shadow over the Eighty-third Congress, and the Eisenhower "honeymoon" has now ended. In the first place, the present Republican control is a desperately close thing -- by a single seat in the Senate and by ten seats in the House. Second, there is the fact that in non-Presidential years the party in power commonly suffers some net loss.

AMONG the prophets of British socialism, R. H. Tawney occupies a special place. If (to oversimplify greatly) the Webbs gave the Labor party its theory of public administration, and Harold Laski gave it a theory of politics, and G. D. H. Cole a theory of economics, then Tawney, more than any other intellectual, understood and developed its ethical impulse.

" MAY, with alle thy floures and thy grene," Chaucer put it. A nice celebration by the poet -- and we can celebrate books this month too, without any queasiness. There are a number of potentially outstanding books of fiction and, curiously, their titles catch the spirit of Chaucer's sentiment.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the text of United States District Judge Luther W. Youngdahl's decision today throwing out four charges against Owen Lattimore but ordering him to trial Oct. 6 on three counts of perjury:

Their scheduled contest with the Cubs having been called off yesterday because of rain and generally unpleasant weather, the Dodgers rested comfortably in first place awaiting today's arrival at Ebbets Field of the Milwaukee Braves.

In a book entitled "Das Marsprojekt," published in Germany, Dr. Werner yon Braun develops a plan for a journey to Mars which he has presented frequently in lectures and in popular magazines of large circulation here. He is convinced that it is technically possible to organize and send out an expedition of seventy to Mars.

A calendar of events to beautify the city during the next two weeks has been worked out by city leaders, and Mayor Impellitteri has officially proclaimed Spring Clean-up Weeks tomorrow through May 16.

The expected intensive development of the eastern section of the Bronx in the next few years has made essential the drafting of a careful zoning pattern for that area, John J. Bennett, chairman of the City Planning Commission, said yesterday.

A PIECE of advice currently circulated by the men of Suburbia is: "Don't ever give your wife an electric floor polisher! My wife got one a while ago and I've been going around the house on ice creepers ever since. I bet she runs the thing three times a day."

BEFORE we all are absorbed in the ballet again, as we shall begin being on Tuesday, there is still time to jot down a few of the highlights of the recent season of "American Dance," which the new B. de Rothschild Foundation brought so valiantly into being.

THE question of how the theatre owner feels about the various technical developments which are expected to benefit business, but meanwhile have slowed down the Hollywood studios, was answered rather pungently the other day by Mitchell Wolfson at the convention of the Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers.
Nationality groups from lands behind the Iron Curtain dominated the sixth annual Loyalty Parade down Fifth Avenue yesterday, with banners and placards demanding freedom for their homelands.
Americans who plan to travel abroad this summer were called upon yesterday to cast themselves in the role of "ambassadors of goodwill" rather than as wealthy visitors with too much money to spend.

IT was in October, 1926, that the Civic Repertory Theatre opened its doors on Fourteenth Street, an attempt to provide the people of New York with popular priced classical repertory similar to that in Europe. It played five straight seasons there, and then, after a year off, worked another before the events of a slightly later autumn pinched shut the purses of its backers.

Twelve directors-at-large were elected last week to the board of the Empire State Foundation of Independent Liberal Arts Colleges, at the foundation's first annual meeting, held at the Biltmore Hotel.

ALBANY, May 2 -- Recent heavy rains in the Adirondack area have reduced the prospects of any serious fires in the state's forest preserve to the lowest level in a number of years, the State Conservation Department reported today.

RYE, N. Y., May 2 -- Questions concerning the projected state Thruway that have been puzzling many Westchester officials and property owners will be answered on the night of May 19 by Bertram D. Tallamy, State Superintendent of Public Works and chairman of the State Thruway Authority.
Armed Forces Week, May 11-17, will include a parade down Fifth Avenue from Ninety-fifth to Sixty-third Street on the afternoon of May 16, a Saturday.
NATURE'S springtime sea menace -- the iceberg -- is on the move again. Since early April, huge chunks of these frozen masses have been sloughing off into the Polar seas.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 2 -- That "Big Business" should assume some of the bills that Uncle Sam has been paying for projects relating to public welfare seems to be a theory emanating from Washington. Already it has met with a generous response from industry in the Delaware River Port.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 2 -- Princeton's varsity crew won the Compton Cup race over a mile and three quarters of choppy water on the Charles River this afternoon, beating Harvard and M. I. T.

As Congress hacked away at reducing appropriations for the coming fiscal year, reports last week that President Eisenhower would recommend a substantial cut in defense and foreign aid spending had a sobering effect on financial markets.

BONN, Germany, May 2 -- With the Free Democratic party in the lead, the conservative parties of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Government are purging their ranks of right-wing extremists in preparation for this year's national election.

PHOENIXVILLE, Pa., May 2 -- An Army spokesman said today many freed American prisoners of war flown here secretly were "burned up" because of publicity given the possibility that they had succumbed to Communist propaganda in Korean prison camps.

On Nov. 4, 1951, during the battle for "Old Baldy" hill in Korea, Private First Class Joseph Picerno, 21, of Queens, N. Y., was hit by shrapnel and captured by the Communists. For eighteen months he lived in a prison camp near the Yalu River. Last Wednesday at 11:30 A. M. a C-47 transport put down at Travis Field, Calif.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 2 -- Taking the lead shortly after the break, Brookfield Farm's is Proud won the second running of the $20,000-added Betsy Ross stakes by three-quarters of a length at Garden State Park today.
Whereas landlubbers "install officers" after their elections, the fraternity of yachtsmen with its nautical lingo prefers to describe its equivalent ceremony as "changing the watch."

TIME is the most potent weapon in the Soviet arsenal -- time to build up Russia's own military preparedness, time to sow defeatism in the free countries of Europe, Asia and Africa and, most important of all, time to let us grow weary of the huge cost of armaments and relax our defenses to a point that will give the Kremlin a clear road to world domination.

ON the radio the Chakkari Kid shoots his way out of an ambush. From the music shops come the soulful notes of "Ekibasha" ("Stage Coach"). Nine-year-old "boyas" read translations of the latest installment of "Straight Arrow."

THIS ersatz Fitzgerald item is concerned principally with a Princeton '27 narrator, whose beautiful wife Barbara has got herself into jail The next seven years are extraordinarily busy ones for Webb, brooding about Bar, trying to maintain the proper Princeton poise, quoting Pascal at the proper occasion, glooming about the "alien and night-enshrouded era" in which he has to live, and enjoying to the full a career of carnality.

Civic groups in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn joined yesterday in contributing 228 pints of blood in response to the special appeal made for the Brooklyn Chapter of the American Red Cross by the Flatbush Savings Bank branch at 1550 Flatbush Avenue.

SLEDGE BESTON bursts into this story with the violence of a hurricane; by Page 5 he has outwitted one boy and licked another. Sledge is smart, often too smart for his own good, but he enlists our sympathy and constant interest as he plunges from one misadventure to another.

A 30-year-old practical nurse was booked last night on a charge of possessing narcotics as an aftermath of a police investigation into the death of a 17-year-old boy, whose body was found in an areaway of an apartment building in the Bronx yesterday morning.

IN regard to the question posed by my old friend Chris Morley in his review of Somerset Maugham's "The Vagrant Mood," as to whether maids ever wore streamers indoors, may I say that maids did apparently wear streamered caps all the time in Victorian days.

AS the season moves along, more and more gardens will be opening their gates to the public for tours scheduled by garden clubs and horticultural societies. The City Gardens Club of New York, for example, announces that its annual spring tours of city gardens and penthouse terraces will take place this Tuesday and May 12.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 -- Twenty tough, newly arrived inmates of Alcatraz prison in San Francisco Bay rioted Wednesday and Thursday, setting fires in their cells and corridors, it was disclosed today.

CAIRO, May 2 -- Negotiations which opened here this week between Egypt and Britain on the future status of the Suez Canal represent essentially an attempt to resolve a conflict between national pride and international "cold war" strategy.

The Williston Basin, so much in the news two years ago as the new bottomless font of crude oil, "plods along" quietly now yielding some 20,000 barrels of petroleum a day -- just about enough to fill a single oil barge.

Argentina's dictator, President Juan Peron, was acting strictly in character when he celebrated May Day and the opening of his Congress with a diatribe against United States news agencies and a demand for their investigation and punishment. The principle of loyalty to a free press is not understood by dictators.

ALBANY, May 2 -- Governor Dewey announced today that he would meet with members of the State Crime Commission, leaders of the Legislature, district attorneys and other state and local officials on Monday, May 11, to discuss a new program of anti-crime legislation.

Illustrating Barbara Ward's "''The Spell He Cast Is the Spell of Life'" (April 19) you show an extremely pretty balcony which is labeled Juliet's. It is romantic enough, but I fear not the one which legend has associated with that young lady.

The prospective softball game between members of New York's City Council and those of Chicago's City Council broadened last week to include the likelihood of a three-city round-robin tourney. Cleveland sent word it definitely wanted to be included in the competition.

ALBANY, May 2 -- The State Bar Association dedicated as its permanent headquarters today a 154-year-old Albany building that served as the state's executive mansion in the early Eighteen Hundreds. It is the first permanent home the association has had since its founding in 1875. Several hundred members of the bar group came to Albany for the occasion.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 2 -- King Faisal II assumed the throne of Iraq today on his eighteenth birthday, bringing to an end the fourteen-year Regency of Emir Abdul Illah, his maternal uncle.
BOWIE, Md., May 2 (UP) -- Brookfield Farms' unbeaten 2-year-old, I Appeal, dashed through the rain at Bowie today to win the $10,000 Kindergarten Stakes by two lengths over favored Right Bit.

AN innovation in flower shows in this city will open to the public tomorrow at Macy's, Herald Square, and may be seen through Saturday. Within the last twenty-four hours truckloads of flowers from East Coast nurseries, gardens and greenhouses and from California and Hawaii have been unpacked and fashioned by more than 100 men and women into a special version of spring.

IT has always been standard airline procedure not to make specific seat reservations, but to sell enough tickets to fill a plane and let the first passengers aboard take their pick of where to sit. Now National Airlines is experimenting with advance seat reservations.

LONDON, May 2 (AP) -- Blackpool scored two goals in the last five minutes today to defeat the Bolton Wanderers, 4 -- 3, and win the Football Association Cup for the first time before a crowd of 100,000 soccer fans in Wembley Stadium.

THE sea is the consolation of our day, as it has been the consolation of the centuries. It is the companion and the receiver of men. It has moods for them to fill the storehouse of the mind, perils for trial, or even for an ending, and calms for the good emblem of death.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- Yale won the Blackwell Cup and finished first in all three races in its rowing regatta with Columbia and Pennsylvania on the Schuylkill today. Traversing the Henley course of a mile and five-sixteenths in the fast time of 6:10.5, with the help of a brisk tail wind, Jim Rathschmidt's varsity eight got home ahead of Columbia by three-quarters of a length.

CANADIAN TV audiences are now seeing American network shows over their own Canadian stations. Following a four months stalemate over rates to be paid American TV networks, the government's Canadian Broadcasting Corporation reached an agreement with United States networks.

The bond market is still on the defensive. Although the basic structure of investment yields has risen drastically in recent weeks and, in certain instances, may even have been overdone, there is nothing visible in the current play of investment supply and demand to suggest any imminent respite from the ordeal which the market is going through.

BEIT YERAH, Israel, April 13 -- Excavation of a Byzantine church, probably built in the second half of the fifth century A.D., has been completed here on the southern shore of the Sea of Galilee by Prof. Pinhas Pierre Delougaz of the Oriental Institute of of the University of Chicago.
The Department of Health will offer free blood tests on neighborhood street corners in a two-month campaign starting tomorrow to find and treat unreported cases of syphilis.

The cost of acquiring an education, whether academic or professional, is not a deductible expense for income tax purposes. While the cost of acquiring a professional education may be said to be a capital outlay, income from the practice of a profession is fully taxable as ordinary income.
