No income tax deduction is allowed on account of such an investment.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 2 -- The second year's competition for the Rockefeller public service awards, designed to establish incentives for public service by civilians in the executive branch of the Federal Government, was opened this week by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University.

The sixteenth Three Choir Festival at Temple Emanu-El ended yesterday. The last of the three programs, following the traditional pattern, was integrated into the regular morning sabbath service in the temple's main auditorium.
IN rubber bridge an overtrick more or less is said to be unimportant. The first thought is to make the contract, or to try the safest possible play for it.
THIS month and next, fluid milk will be at its annual peak in supply throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Interest rates permitted on private home loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration and those guaranteed by the Veterans Administration were increased to 4 1/2 per cent by order of the Government today.

SOMETIMES a boy -- like David, for instance -- will try harder to meet a stranger's approval than that of his own family. Mother's reminding 9-year-old David of his unfinished chores has less effect than David's wanting a new farm-friend, Henry, not to think him a sissy.

Daily in a crude wooden hut at Panmunjom last week, two men -- Lieut. Gen. William K. Harrison and Gen. Nam Il -- addressed one another in low and even tones across a green baize table. On their words hung the chances for a Korean truce. But the substance of those words did not originate in Panmunjom.

JEFFERSON'S celebrated phrase, chosen as the title for these lectures delivered at the University of Michigan in 1952, is, as Howard Mumford Jones says at the outset, "as fundamental, as baffling, as confused, and as interesting an idea as ever appeared in a state paper." Americans have always agreed that "happiness" is the aim and end of their religion, their political institutions, their educational theory and practice.
William Bocca, 23-year-old Bronx victim of hemophilia, has been given another chance of survival through the joint efforts of Fordham University, the Red Cross and the New York Hemophilia Foundation.

The board of trustees of Barnard College has elected Mrs. Gavin Keith MacBain of Chappaqua, N. Y., to a two-year term on the board. She will fill the unexpired term of Winthrop W. Aldrich, who resigned when he was named United States Ambassador to England.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., May 2 -- Historians of Westchester County will join with church leaders here tomorrow morning in dedicating a plaque at Zion Protestant Episcopal Church in memory of two sons of Alexander Hamilton, first Federal Secretary of the Treasury.
The third act of "Rosenkavalier" was presented yesterday afternoon on the concluding portion of a two-part performance of the Strauss opera by the N. B. C. Television Opera Theatre.

The low-fat diet often prescribed for persons with coronary artery disease must also be low in plant fat, says Dr. Charles W. Crumpton, director of the heart research laboratory at the University of Wisconsin's Medical School. The role of cholesterol is unknown in coronary artery disease at the present time, though some animal experiments indicate that high cholesterol diets and high cholesterol blood levels may be at least partly at fault.

Royal Vale, a 5-year-old English-bred horse owned by Mrs. Esther du Pont Weir, won the Gallant Fox Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. Opposing such strong campaigners as Crafty Admiral, One Count and Cold Command in the $71,400 race, Royal Vale surprised the crowd of 30,623 by scoring in convincing style.

Far from all the millions who marched in May Day parades last Friday were Communists, but the largest such fetes and the most politically significant took place in Moscow, Peiping and East Berlin. The other capitals in the Soviet orbit, naturally, stayed in line.

Volume in the area's department stores was judged by trade observers to be about even with the 1952 week, with the possibility of a slight decline. The weather was not especially favorable. Some stores fell behind, but the average was brought up by promotional events, chiefly in home furnishings and small appliances, in several big stores.

ALTHOUGH Miss Frances Winwar's packed volume about the sallow Corsican, whose plans to unite Europe with his sword kept that Continent in turmoil for two decades, is offered as a historical novel, it would be just as accurate and perhaps fairer to judge it as a romantic biography.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 2 -- Funds being made available by the Rockefeller family will enable immediate construction of lodge and tourist facilities for nearly 5,000 vacationists on Jackson Lake, Wyoming, in the Grand Teton National Park. Total cost of the project, which will be partially open for the 1954 tourist season and completely operative by 1955, is expected to reach $6,000,000.

WARRENTON, Va., May 2 (AP) -- Rayquick today won Virginia's Gold Cup steeplechase and gave his owner, C. M. Greer Jr., permanent possession of the glittering urn that once belonged to Catherine the Great.

VIENNA, May 2 -- Austria's hopes for freedom, which were so definitely dashed by Russia's refusal last September to discuss the short form of state treaty proposed by the West in a last despairing effort, have been as suddenly revived by Moscow's new gestures of appeasement.

Significant changes are taking place in the management consultant field. Instead of restricting attention to quite a large and complex industrial or business enterprise or a great city, the consultant now assists managements heading operations of all sizes and types.
DETROIT, May 2 (AP) -- The nation's automobile industry will produce an estimated $12,000,000,000 worth of civilian cars and trucks and replacement parts this year.

HAVANA, May 2 (AP) -- A Government spokesman says Cuba has been officially informed that Mexican authorities have arrested a group of former Cuban officials and seized "information disclosing an intent to attack the Cuban coast."

The hot summers and the open winters of recent years in some parts of the country, the abnormal amount of rain that has fallen in the East in March and April, the sudden changes in weather are attributed by thousands to the explosions of atomic bombs. Some atomic explosions in the past were certainly followed by torrents of rain, high winds, lightning and thunder.

Fair activity was noted on ready-to-wear items in the wholesale markets here last week, according to McGreevey, Werring Howell, resident buying office. Stress was placed on bridal, bridesmaid and mother-of-the-bride dresses and formals.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 (UP) -- Louise Suggs of Atlanta carded even women's par, 37, 37 -- 74, today to take the first-round lead in the third leg of the Weathervane cross-country golf tournament.

NEWARK, May 2 -- Stained-glass windows from Germany, Botticino and Carrara marble from Italy and limestone blocks from Indiana were being uncrated here this week by scores of craftsmen engaged in the final phase of interior construction of the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Sacred Heart.

HANOI, May 2 -- The Vietminh invasion of Laos, northwestern-most of the three Associated States of Indo-China, has created a new and more difficult problem for the West. Although the invasion has brought the Indo-China war close to the borders of Thailand and Burma, it has not altered the protracted nature of the conflict that has been going on here since 1946.

TROY, N. Y., May 2 (AP) -- Bishop Frederick B. Newell of New York told delegates to the Troy Methodist Conference today that churchmen should "put conviction before caution, the individual before the institution and make the people the center of life."

The first decisive labor-management negotiations since the voters installed a "business men's government" in Washington will get under way this month in steel, traditional setter of wage-price patterns for the national economy.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Following is the text of the letter sent by President Eisenhower to Vice President Nixon and House Speaker Martin:
LONDON, May 2 -- British authorities believe they know better than their United States counterpart how to exorcise Communist sympathies from soldiers home from Korean imprisonment.

ALAMEDA, Calif., May 2 (AP) -- Ensign Peter Vought's Panther jet fighter went dead 24,000 feet in the night sky this week and the 24-year-old son of the late chance Vought, pioneer aircraft builder, headed into a steep glide toward the naval air field here to touch down finally at 280 miles an hour, nearly twice the plane's normal landing speed.

THE battle of the dimensions notwithstanding, consider these oldies: "The Loves of Sunya," with Gloria Swanson, John Boles, Raymond Hackett; "The Trespasser," also with Miss Swanson; "The Thin Man," with William Powell, Myrna Loy, Maureen O'Sullivan, Minna Gombell; "Top Hat," with Fred Astaire, Ginger Rogers.

Thank William C. FitzGibbon for, in his quiz "Who's Whom" (April 26), giving "cannot help but" its long-deserved comeuppance; too late, I fear, as it has been rearing its ugly head in some of the most respectable places.

Borough President John Cashmore will hold an old-fashioned "town meeting" at 8:30 next Thursday night in Brooklyn Borough Hall to permit Brooklyn residents to discuss the controversial Class S district zoning amendment pending before the Board of Estimate.

PITTSBURGH, May 2 (AP) -- Carlos Bernier, rookie outfielder, hit three triples and Ralph Kiner and Danny O'Connell belted two-run homers to lead the Pirates to a 12-4 victory over the Redlegs today. The triumph extended Pittsburgh's winning streak to four straight -- longest in almost two years.

NORTH of Trinidad is a group of islands -- Grenada, St. Lucia, St. Vincent, Dominica and the tiny Grenadines -- that are the Caribbean's gems. They are known as the Beewee Islands (for British West Indies). The unit of currency is the British West Indian dollar, worth only 60 United States cents.

AUSTRALIA will commemorate in September the sesquicentennial of the settlement of Tasmania by English Army colonels named Collins and Paterson, each of whom became Lieutenant Governor. Their portraits will be on adjoining 3-pence stamps in the same sheet.

Pete MacKinnon, Dartmouth right-hander, held Columbia to six hits as his mates pounded Jim King for eleven to defeat the Lions, 7 -- 2, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game at Baker Field yesterday.

GIANT for a day! That's what Tommy was. Usually he was a little boy, but one morning he woke up a Giant. He was so tall he could push clouds away from the sun. He was so strong he could move boats from place to place in the ocean. Airplanes could land on his big shoulders.

THE coastal fishing should open up for the season within the next two weeks, and reports on some of the migrants that serve as the major lure of salt water angling indicate that these species will be on time or early.

A NEW voice in philately is being raised by Flatbush, that area in the heart of Brooklyn which is home to thousands of Brooklyn Dodger fans. Flatbush wants a commemorative stamp all its own, the denomination to be 1/2-cent, and it has asked its Congressional Representative, Mrs. Edna F. Kelly, to see that Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield is influenced by the Senate and House Postal Committees to give his approval some time this year.

TUNIS, Tunisia, May 2 -- Chadly Kastalli, Vice President of the Tunis City Council and prominent newspaper publisher, was assassinated in a busy street of the Medina (old town) here this morning, presumably a victim of nationalist terrorism.
LOCK HAVEN, Pa., May 2 (AP) -- A small private plane clipped the top of a barn soon after take-off today, then crashed in flames, killing the pilot and four others, two of them small children.

WHEN he was American consul in Liverpool Nathaniel Hawthorne complained more than once, in his stern New England way, that the English were insufferably consequential. He was quite right: the consequent Englishman has been the bread and butter of the English comic novelists.
THOSE who love Handel will cheer the news that Julius Caesar, long absent from the world's opera houses, is available on records.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Dr. Allen V. Astin, director of the National Bureau of Standards, who was dismissed and then reinstated on a temporary basis by the Secretary of Commerce after protests from American scientists, outlined the aims and purposes of the bureau and the importance of its operations to the national welfare and security today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 21 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies is confronted by heavy odds in his campaign for the election of thirty-two Senators May 9. This is the first occasion on which Australia has elected Senators without simultaneously electing a new House of Representatives -- and it is a vital election for the Government.

ITALIAN instrumental music of the baroque period has a curious combination of grandeur and sprightliness, two qualities which we are now apt to think irreconcilable. It also has another apparent paradox: long flowing melodies that are deeply human and yet somehow impersonal.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- Looking west from City Hall, hub of the midtown business-shopping district, Philadelphia today presents blocks of barren land to all except planners, who envision a development rivaling New York's Rockefeller Center.

MEXICO CITY, May 2 -- Ben Hogan hurtled from a tie for fourth to first place in today's third round of the $15,000 Pan American open golf tournament with a blistering four-under par 68 -- his best round of the meet.
A young man with a bicycle that has already borne him 11,000 miles, including a crossing of the Bolivian Andes, said here yesterday he hoped to start pedaling for Canada and Alaska tomorrow.

Two of the three "missing" policemen indicted last Thursday by the special grand jury investigating official graft and corruption on Staten Island have been located by aides of Special Prosecutor William B. Herlands, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- State Department officials neither accepted nor rejected today any particular Asian country as a neutral caretaker of prisoners who refuse to return to their Communist homelands.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 2 -- Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., won the British hard-courts tennis title for the third successive year today with another victory over Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, this time by scores of 6 -- 3, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4.

Seven hundred and fifty guests attended the 101st annual meeting and "homecoming day" of the City College Alumni Association yesterday afternoon in the Academy Building on the college's recently acquired Manhattanville campus, 133d Street and Convent Avenue.

HAMDEN, Conn., May 2 (AP) -- A Princeton student was fatally injured by a falling rock today and thirty other mountain-climbing enthusiasts from Princeton and Yale were preparing to climb the precipitous face of a sprawling range known as the Sleeping Giant.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 2 -- A plan by the Connecticut Park and Forest Commission to buy 5,000 acres of land in the northwest corner of the state, owned mostly by New York State residents, has started a major controversy in the state.

SOMETIMES, around about the age of 8 months, an infant who has previously "had a smile for everyone" may begin to show the earmarks of a little misanthrope. Friends of the family, accepted socially before, are now viewed with what appears to be suspicion, often accompanied by tears.
President Eisenhower sent to Congress last week a plan to reorganize the biggest business of the Government -- defense.

DALLAS, Tex., May 2 -- Southern Methodist University presented seven awards for distinguished service in journalism today at the closing session of the first annual Southwest Journalism Forum, sponsored by the university and the Press Club of Dallas.

ATLANTA, May 2 -- Farm income in the Southeast declined $34,693,000 in the first two months this year, the Atlanta regional office of the Department of Commerce reported this week. The income loss by States ranged from $2,688,000 in Alabama to $18,564,000 in Georgia.

THE conclusion of the New York Philharmonic - Symphony Society's 111th season, and the number of programs, the number of conductors, the number of compositions new and old which it gave in that period, are emphatic of several things.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 2 -- By pressing a button Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies today launched at the Woomera rocket range in South Australia, 230 miles northwest of Adelaide, a pilotless aircraft designed and built by Australians and powered by a jet engine from Britain.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 2 -- The Chief of Staff of the United Nations truce supervision organization, Lieut. Gen. William E. Riley, said today he had advised Brig. Gen. Bennet de Ridder of Belgium, chairman of the Israeli-Jordanian Mixed Armistice Commission, not to enter Israeli territory "for about a week" after the April 22 shooting affray in Jerusalem.

" I AM that queer monster, the artist, an obstinate finality, an inexhaustible sensibility." says one of Henry James' characters. James might have been speaking of himself, as he often did in various fictional disguises.

ALBANY -- A brand-new set of driving laws, covering such details as drunken-driving tests, hand signals and slowpokes, has been signed into law by Governor Dewey in time to confront spring and summer motorists.

ONE of the most entertaining activities in the art world is crystal-ball-gazing into changes of taste. What will be fashionable ten years from now? Which prices will be soaring in twenty? Will collectors of the next decade parallel those of the last, leaving about a forty to fifty year time-lag between creation of art and its top prices? If so, then the fauves are on their way, the cubists are not far behind.
YONKERS, May 2 -- H. T. King's Red Sails, handled by Gene Riegle, scored an upset to win the $9,450 Billy Direct Pacing Stake in 2:06 before 22,228 at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

At his news conference Thursday President Eisenhower remarked that a great deal of his waking moments are given over to the problem of the budget. From the outset of his Administration it has been obvious to Washington observers that a central question for the new Republican regime is this:
WASHINGTON, May 2 (UP) -- Government leaders paid tribute to the military services today in a series of statements in connection with Armed Forces Day May 16.
The shipping industry is expected to make an all-out effort this weak to win broadened Government subsidies as the House Merchant Marine Committee begins open hearings on Wednesday in Washington.

The construction of a new $4,880,000 cooperative housing project in Long Island City, Queens, was approved last week by the City Planning Commission at a special meeting in its offices in the Municipal Building.
TOKYO, Sunday, May 3 (AP) -- United Nations Command Headquarters communique 1,603, for Saturday's operations:

ROME, May 2 -- More than seventy different parties have registered throughout Italy for the general elections to be held on June 7. By far the greater part of them, however, have not the slightest prospect of electing even one single member of Parliament.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 2 -- Ambassador George C. McGhee, whose resignation effective June 20 was accepted yesterday by President Eisenhower, said today that he would resume direction of hic business interests as "an independent producer of oil in Texas, Louisiana and Pennsylvania" on his return. He also gives up his post as chief of the United States aid mission here.

COMPOSER, critic and head of the Composition Department at the University of Southern California, Halsey Stevens has written the first full-length study of Bela Bartok to be published in English. Bartok presents an absorbing task for any biographer.

WHEN Amy marries Dickie, the only man in her best friend's life, Esther begins a familiar emotional battle. First, she goes away and gets herself engaged to show she no longer cares, but when Amy dies in childbirth, Esther breaks off her engagement and comes back.
Messages from leading Americans, headed by President Eisenhower, will be broadcast to Poles behind the Iron Curtain today on the 162d anniversary of the Polish Constitution.
The first city-wide civil defense training exercise of 1953, in which 33,000 civil defense workers will take part, will be held Tuesday
RAHWAY, N. J., May 2 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey declared today that American scientists overestimated the significance of "irritants" that limit their freedom of inquiry.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Continue planting and sowing of all but the tender plants. Finish moving or setting out shrubs, evergreens, roses and trees as soon as possible. Do not transplant tomatoes outdoors or sow sweet corn, cucumber, zinnia, marigold and other warm-weather crops for ten days or so. Sow bush beans.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., May 2 -- How business and industry, cooperating with higher education, can help solve the serious financial problems now confronting American colleges and universities is exemplified here at Carnegie Institute of Technology. Without the vastly increased support of industry, the institution would be in a dangerous financial situation.

THE creatures of this attractive and interesting book are remarkable for either habits or structure -- remarkable enough to have been written about in the monthly magazine of the American Museum of Natural History, from which the editor of that journal has gathered their stories.
ASHEVILLE, N. C., May 2 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, said tonight that the South could be sure of a full voice in the present rebuilding of the national party organization.
AMMAN, Jordan, May 2 (AP) -- King Hussein I swore the royal oath of office before a crowd in Parliament today and began his reign.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Administration's efforts to turn over to the states the rich offshore oil reserves have raised the bigger question of whether such action would be the first step in a "giveaway" of the country's Western public-land wealth.

TWO circumstances have contributed to the decline of portraiture in the twentieth century. One is, of course, the camera: the other is the leveling spirit of the age which sets comparatively little value on the uniqueness of personality.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 2 -- Princeton's trackmen, who last year won their first dual meet with Yale in a decade, showed they were determined to continue on the winning path this afternoon as they registered a 72-68 triumph over the Elis in the forty-eighth meeting between the schools.

COLUMBUS, Ga., May 2 -- New tornadoes struck tonight in storm battered central Alabama and Georgia, where twenty-eight persons have died and hundreds have been injured in three days of high winds and twisters. Property damage in the storms has been estimated at millions of dollars.

The most intensive campaign yet undertaken to recruit college students for training in the field of social work will get under way within the next few weeks. Sponsored by the recently formed Council on Social Work Education, the recruitment drive will be launched on a nation-wide scale in an effort to relieve the critical shortage of social workers.

" HE goes to sea to fish, he plays tennis, he watches birds, he is by no means an unsociable neighbor, and he entertains frequently. He is unhappy in London, which he associates with concert-giving and visits to the dentist, with meetings and being rung up on the telephone, with auditions and having to see people on business -- with anything, in fact, except composing."

DALLAS, May 2 -- Department store sales in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District set a record during March, it was reported this week. Sales were 26 per cent above February and 12 per cent higher than in March a year ago. Widespread rains have improved agricultural conditions, but more moisture is needed in the western parts of the district.

NEWARK, May 2 (AP) -- Bayonne High School won the Group 4 mile event in the Newark Board of Education invitation track meet today even though its ace miler, Johnny Kopil, was sidelined with an injury.

THE onward and outward expansion of the wide screen was noted here last week in two events of large importance -- at least, in the present state of things. One was the formal presentation of George Stevens' fine new western, "Shane," on a screen of enlarged and slightly altered proportions at the Music Hall.

Commercial banks 6; savings banks 3; savings and loan associations 4; miscellaneous 4 -- that's the score for New York State banking laws approved this year. During the session just com pleted, the Albany legislators considered fifty proposals, with one, the savings banks branch office bill, defeated after the bitterest intra-industry struggle of recent years.

PARIS, May 2 -- A national conciliation board has been called to meet Monday in an attempt to end the strike of officers of the French merchant marine that has paralyzed the operations of the French Line and other shipping companies.

TRENTON, N. J. -- Despite the fact that New Jersey shore and mountain resorts will not observe their formal openings until May 30, those who venture across the Hudson even as early as this week will not be disappointed. As a matter of fact, they will find a number of events staged especially for their entertainment, and some of these are at least unusual.

THE forest in the title refers to virgin territory in the interior of Brazil, but the author, before she is through, explains that it also stands for the wilderness of emotions through which she progressed before she found contentment.

In an address entitled "The Reply of the Mayor to the Critics," Mayor Impellitteri denounced yesterday what he termed the so-called intelligentsia, society wisecrackers, sour professional faultfinders and imports from the Mudvilles and Gopher Prairies for slandering the City of New York.

Last winter nature's wind and ice took their toll of trees in New York and surrounding states, and as the dry season approaches there looms another and worse hazard for our woodlands -- fire. Winter storm damage has provided much ready fuel. We could not prevent the ravages by storms, but we can prevent fires.

IN a preface to "The Wild Honey," Victoria Lincoln writes: '"There are always occasions when we must go apart to the wilderness for a little to question ourselves, but in times like ours we try to make it snappy and wipe the locusts and wild honey off our mouths before we come back."

BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., May 2 (UP) -- Meyer Lansky of New York, linked by the Senate Crime Investigating Committee with the Murder, Inc. mob and an interstate gambling syndicate, was sentenced to serve three months in prison and fined $2,500 today for gambling operations at Saratoga Springs.

FEW hopeful voices have been raised in the discussion about the future of the West since Hitler's rise to power, when the inescapable waves of the future from the East threatened to submerge the "obsolete" West.
Topcoat weather dampened the spirits of New Yorkers as the merry month of May's first weekend opened yesterday.
PARIS, April 18 -- A bill providing for revision of eleven articles in the new French Constitution will be submitted with a demand for urgent action when the National Assembly meets May 12.

PARIS, May 2 -- Former Premier Antoine Pinay's Independent party headquarters protested today against the official figures on last Sunday's municipal elections, claiming a 14 per cent gain instead of the 5 per cent that was officially assigned. The Independents said they won 1,759 instead of 866 seats.

NEWARK, May 2 -- The adoption of a program for the next two years will be the major concern of delegates to the thirtieth convention of the League of Women Voters of New Jersey Monday and Tuesday at the Berkeley-Carteret Hotel, Asbury Park.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- Business activity in Chicago hit a faster pace in the first quarter this year than in the corresponding period of last year, a new business barometer of the Chicago Federal Reserve Bank showed. The Bank is making a monthly survey of bank debits in the Seventh District that eliminates time, U. S. Government and interbank account debits, leaving only debts to demand deposits of individuals, business, state and local governments.

Much of Bertrand Russell's writing I have most cordially disliked. How he delights me with his account of the great pact in "Looking Backward -- to the Nineteen Fifties" (April 26). Let us stress more and more that many aims of the extreme right and of the extreme left are in essence identical.

It may be a man's world, but women are going to have more to say on how men will look in it. Last week Mme. Elsa Schiaparelli, an outstanding designer of women's apparel, agreed to cre ate a line of robes, sport shirts and swimwear for Peerless] Robes and Sportswear, a men's wear manufacturer.

THE anti-Soviet novel, of which Peter Julian's book is a competent example, has evolved into a species of political Western. In it the Iron Curtain steppes substitute for the Arizona badlands. The villain identifies himself by N. K. V. D. card rather than black mask.

DETROIT, May 2 (UP) -- Southpaw Morrie Martin scattered three hits and Allie Clark cracked a three-run homer today as the Athletics downed the last-place Tigers, 4 -- 1, before 4,629 fans at Briggs Stadium.
Five major New York breweries, charging they had been plagued by a series of costly slowdowns, told their 5,000 workers yesterday not to report for work until further notice and closed their plants.
OF all flowers, the lilac is perhaps most admired in its wild form. And its improved modern forms are the least understood, least known and least seen.

BUENOS AIRES, May 2 (AP) -- Dr. Ricardo Balbin, Radical party candidate for President in 1951, was arrested last night on charges that he had been disrespectful to a traffic policeman in the town of Eva Peron, formerly known as La Plata.

LOOKING downward, Ivah Green gives a new perspective to nature study, one which ought to appeal to any child who has ever tried to catch a chipmunk or collected cicada shells. Here are described the habits and habitats of seventeen animals, insects and birds which live underground -- and the useful earthworm too.

The much-heralded air conditioning boom of 1953 is beginning to roll a full month ahead of schedule. Stores all over the country reported last week substantial sales of room units to customers determined not to be left out in the heat when the torrid weather finally strikes.

The early flowers are bright in meadow and woodland, violets and bluets and the very last of the hepaticas. Anemones are tossing in the wind, and yellow rocket is coming to flower. Shadbush blooms along the rivers. But the overwhelming beauty just now is in the new leaves on the trees and bushes.

A GROWING interest in group activity among amateur photographers is reflected in queries recently received by this department on what it takes to start a camera club. If it is understood that a club is primarily a group of persons with a mutual interest in, and enthusiasm for, photography, then the answer is simple: get a few congenial people together, meet in someone's home and talk, show and discuss pictures.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 2 -- The twenty-fifth anniversary exhibition of the Hudson Valley Art Association will open with a reception and tea at the Westchester County Center at 3 P. M. tomorrow. Winners in the oil, water color and sculpture groups were announced following a judging today.

" BIDDABLE" was the word for Lilly Waller. Like the little yellow cat she sat fondling the day she heard her drunken mother and the lodger quarreling about leaving "the kid" behind, she was small on this earth.

UNDER its French title, "Servitude et Grandeur Militaires," this little book has long been familiar to students of French. It is the prose masterpiece of Vigny and one of the minor classics of the last century.

A $118,000 gift from the Louis W. and Maud Hill Family Foundation of St. Paul has made possible the establishment of a Center for Philosophy and Science at the University of Minnesota. The center will work for better cooperation between scientists and philosophers to coordinate research being carried on in many areas and promote better communication among scientists in different fields by organizing a common terminology.
Capt. Folkert Hendrik Dobbinga has been named commodore of the Holland-America Line's fleet, Frederick R. Wierdsma, general manager of the company here, announced yesterday.

The Roman Catholic Parish of the Immaculate Conception of the Blessed Virgin Mary, Melrose Avenue and 150th Street, the Bronx, will observe its 100th anniversary with a solemn pontifical mass at 10:30 A. M. today.

Eighteenth and early nineteenth century American and English furniture will be up at auction on Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, property in part, of the late Margaret Haskell Waring of New York.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 -- California's Democrats, looking ahead to the 1954 election for the Senate and for Governor, are hopeful that the selection of a new chairman of the Republican State Central Committee will cause sharp disunity in their rivals' ranks.

IN March, 1952, this department printed a paragraph of mine concerning the merits of theatre-in-the-round. It was then my contention that central staging would not achieve real stature until playwrights dedicated original material to the medium.

A speed-up in the inspection of incoming ship and air passenger baggage, even if it means a less intensive examination, will become effective on May 15 by order of Francis B. Laughlin, acting Collector of Customs in New York.

THE story of the Foreign Legion needs a book four times this long. Howard Swiggett has had to select and compress until, in places, a few lines must suffice for a whole battle. And he has not satisfied the reader who wants to know something of how the Legionnaire fights his battles, how he attacks and defends, and how he has used the weapons of yesterday and today.

SIGNED original photographs by a group of press photographers, most of them well-known members of the Overseas Press Club of America, are being offered for sale at $25 each for the benefit of the Correspondents' Memorial Building, the new home of the club at 35 East Thirty-ninth Street.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Lobby spending in Washington, as it is reported to Congress under Federal law, fell to a low point of $4,823,981 in 1952.

TOKYO, Sunday, May 3 (UP) -- A Communist battalion hit Allied positions on the main line of resistance along the western Korean front early today, but was hurled back after heavy hand-to-hand fighting in the trenches.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., May 2 -- The annual $100 Glascock poetry prize at Mount Holyoke College was won by Richard C. Sewell of Liberty. Me., an 18-year-old freshman at Bard College, Professor Marianne Brock announced today. The judges were W. H. Auden, Pulitzer-prize poetry winner, Louise Bogan, critic for The New Yorker, and Leonard Stevens, teacher at Philips Exeter Academy.

YAKIMA CANUTT, which sounds at first glance like a man in the throes of a body-bending sneeze, is actually the name of a bronzed, rugged, bristle-haired Californian who paused overnight in New York the other day on his troubleshooting way to England.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- President Eisenhower by Executive Order today made Philip Young, Civil Service Commissioner, his adviser on Government personnel matters and by the same order abolished the liaison Office for Personnel Management.

Without any fanfare the United States Bureau of Engraving and Printing recently completed its ninetieth year of operation while its 6,000 employes went about the routine of turning out the currency notes, stamps, bonds and other printed material used in this country.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 2 -- Princeton University has received $75,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation for the continuance of a study of human behavior seeking a greater understanding of the "how" and "why" of man's experience, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, announced today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 2 -- Orland K. Armstrong, newly appointed Director of Public Affairs for the State Department, predicted tonight that one of the major moves in the Eisenhower Administration's new "cold war" policy would be "the immediate release of all our Korean prisoners of war, and all Chinese prisoners, who desire to fight for the United Nations."

HERBERT J. STACK, director of the center of safety, New York University, points out that regardless of how well built the roads or how efficient the law enforcement system, "unless we can reach the man behind the wheel no great good can be accomplished."

MR. MIRVISH has approached a difficult subject with a generous and sympathetic eye. Though much of "A House of Her Own" reads like a scenario, the protagonist, Margo, top prostitute at the Hotel Internacional, does come alive.
The six local rent offices of the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission were besieged yesterday by landlords and tenants seeking information on the effects of the new state rent law.

LONDON, May 2 -- Roger Bannister ran the world's tenth fastest mile today with a clocking of 4 minutes 3.6 seconds. He had a lead of 40 yards as he crossed the finish. The present world record is 4:01.4, set by Gunder Haegg of Sweden in 1945.

ON the first day of May, 1945, a group of officers and correspondents, waiting for the end in Germany, speculated on what had happened to Hitler. The greater question was posed by a Military Government officer.

IT is time now when iris bloom to review beds and borders and decide on something new and interesting for next year. There has been much interest shown in recent years in dwarfs, spurias and other species. But nothing except neglect has been meted out to another section which, for want of a better name, is called Table iris.
CHICAGO, May 2 (AP) -- Bob Stout of the Philadelphia Turners won the all-around title in the National A. A. U. gymnastics meet that ended tonight at the University of Illinois, Navy Pier.

ROME, May 2 -- In a May Day speech he delivered to 4,000 workers gathered in the Vatican from many parts of Italy, the Pope endorsed the celebration of the day as a Christian holiday for labor. The text of the Pope's speech was made public only today, with a translation into English.

THIS spring has brought not only flowers and plenty of rain, but many complaints concerning the appearance of both broad and narrow-leaved evergreens. There are several causes, one dating back to 1952.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 2 -- Rutgers University will conduct summer programs here, in Newark, Ocean City and Trenton, it was announced this week by Dr. Charles H. Stevens, the director of Summer Session.

WHAT has happened to the Jewish and Christian religions as a result of unbiased scholarly inquiry into the books of the Bible? The Bible presents the historian more fascinating puzzles and the challenge of fewer clues than any detective story.
HANOI, Vietnam, May 2 -- The military situation around Luang Prabang, royal capital of Laos, remained static today as heavy rains slowed up the fighting activity throughout northern Indo-China.

BERLIN, May 2 -- Pastor Martin Niemoeller, president of the Evangelical Church in Hesse, has asked Archbishop Boris of the Russian Orthodox Church to aid the Evangelical clergy in its difficulties with the East German Government, according to the West German news agency D. P. A.
The choice of the fifth and last member of the New York City Transit Authority became limited yesterday to two of the four members of the Port of New York Authority who are residents of the city.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Federal District Judge Luther W. Youngdahl dismissed today four counts of a seven-count perjury indictment against Owen Lattimore, Johns Hopkins lecturer and an expert on Far Eastern affairs.

The complexities of modern times as reflected by artists will be outlined in a lecture, "Art as Communication," on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. in the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The speaker, Prof. Stefan Hirsch, is a painter and Chairman of the Division of Art, Music, Drama and Dance at Bard College.
ALBUQUERQUE, May 2 (AP) -- Flocks of geese are replacing hundreds of imported laborers in New Mexico cotton fields -- and the trend is spreading to other states.

Two new programs designed to improve the quality of teaching in both high schools and colleges have been awarded substantial sums by the Ford Foundation's Fund for the Advancement of Teaching. Vanderbilt University and the George Peabody College for Teachers together will receive $100,000 a year for three years to carry out a joint graduate school program to provide better training for high school teachers.

HANOI, May 2 (AP) -- Heavy rains stymied French fighters and bombers that have been straffing and bombing Vietminh troop concentrations. But despite the bad weather, French transport planes poured still more troops and war supplies into Luang Prabang from Hanoi, 275 miles to the northeast.

The bill introduced by Senator Smith of New Jersey (S. 1785), with the reported approval of Senator Taft, has extraordinary and serious implications. It exempts the construction industry, most public utilities, and "small" employers from the Taft act.
PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- A union-management dispute over submitting an $80 pay grievance to the usual settlement machinery halted the movement of all dry cargo in the Port of Philadelphia today.

LANGHORNE, Pa., May 2 -- A smooth fox terrier, Champion Downsbragh Two o'Clock Fox, owned by Mr. and Mrs. William Brainard Jr. of Far Hills, N. J., was the best-in-show winner today at the Bucks County Kennel Club's annual all-breed show.
Columbia's junior varsity and freshman lightweight crews defeated a New York athletic club combination eight and a junior boat, respectively, on the windswept Harlem River yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- In designating the Georgia counties of Muscogee and Macon as major disaster areas today, President Eisenhower acted in response to a request by Gov. Herman Talmadge.

Under the auspices of the Sunday School of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, a performance of an original play, "Peter Rabbit's Dream," written by Miss Diane Fryburg, one of the school's teachers, will be presented Friday night in the Parish House of the church at 316 East Eighty-eighth Street.

Why shouldn't all seats in the even-numbered rows of the orchestra -- the second, fourth, sixth, and so on -- be held at the box office for direct sale to the public instead of being allotted to brokers? Tickets in the odd rows could be allotted for sale through agencies.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- The State Department asked Congress today to halt action on a bill by fourteen Western Senators intended to curb the increasing flow of foreign agricultural imports, particularly wool.

WHEN the child in the fairy tale, unlike his eiders, unbemused, flatly announced that the emperor was naked, he made one of those imperishable remarks that never lose their point and need, under varying circumstances, to be repeated over and over again.

THE highly favorable reaction by most observers to the recent color television demonstration by the Radio Corporation of America in Princeton, N. J., has put new zest into behind-the-scenes activities to bring tinted video to the public. Aside from the engineering and electronic aspects still under development, tricky problems and new methods loom for producers of color programs.

Of the various special weeks held during the year to focus public attention on health problems, there is none that is more significant in terms of both cost and the number of persons affected as Mental Health Week, which starts today.

Foreign capital, mostly American, flowed rapidly into Japan last year, almost tripling the post-war aggregate to the end of 1951. The figure at the close of 1952 was $58,346,000, of which $24,982,000 represented stock and proprietary interests and $33,285,000 "claimable assets arising from loans."

The poor post-college or post-school retention of foreign language deplored, and rightly so, in Topics of The Times for April 12 has long concerned language teachers. The fact that disuse also causes students of physics, English, mathematics and other subjects to forget them in later life does not prove that those studies are a waste of time.

ONE night recently when the electronic carillon in Los Angeles' City Hall tower accidentally started up and flooded the downtown area with music at midnight, few citizens evinced surprise. The populace was thoroughly acclimated to music, in manifold and variegated forms, engendered under the auspices of a music-minded city Government.

DONALD DAY specializes in making consecutive the random remarks of certain personages. He has compiled "autobiographies" from the personal sayings of Woodrow Wilson, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Will Rogers.

In Eric Johnston's excellent "Take an Axe to the Budget -- But Where?" (April 19), he refers to the standard of efficiency provided private industry by the necessity of selling its product, and goes on to state, "* * * there is no comparable way in the Government to measure efficiency or the relative value to be placed on services provided."

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today that the United States had already acted to hasten the delivery of "critically needed" military supplies to the forces defending Laos from Communist attack.

MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., May 2 (UP) -- A banker here mortally wounded today two lawyers he believed were responsible for his maze of court troubles and killed himself with a second gun after one of his dying victims had disarmed him.

The Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys in Millington, N. J., will be the beneficiary of the Coronation Bridge Benefit, to be held on its campus on the afternoons of May 18, 19 and 20. Mrs. Reeve Schley and Mrs. Paul F. Switz are co-chairmen of the committee for the event.

BLEEDING hearts have always had a romantic appeal for gardeners. No old-fashioned garden was complete without them, and today even with the wealth of "improved" perennials available, none is more handsome or colorful in May and June than this tall, old favorite, which has just started to bloom.

EARLY this season Broadway was visited by the National Theatre of Greece, with Alexis Minotis and Katina Paxinou, and by Madeleine Renaud and Jean-Louis Barrault and their French company. Both organizations, it will be recalled, offered repertory programs in their native languages.

TOKYO, May 2 -- The Kremlin was calling the signals this week as the Communist and United Nations delegations plodded back to Panmunjom for a new round of negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war.

KEARNY, N. J., May 2 -- A young patrolman was jailed here today, charged with setting seven fires on his beat since last Sept. 18 so he could be the first to turn in an alarm and be commended as a "hero."

IRRESPECTIVE of political party, conservationists throughout America have been alarmed by Secretary of the Interior McKay's unceremonious firing of Albert M. Day as director of the Fish and Wildlife Service. Mr. Day is a career officer, having started out as a biologist in the predecessor agency to the Fish and Wildlife Service thirty-five years ago.

Beaten in ten of their fifteen games to date and further weighed down by their second Saturday home postponement of the young season, the Giants yesterday cast something of a forlorn figure as the second game of their series with the Cardinals at the Polo Grounds was wiped off the calendar by cold, damp and generally miserable weather.

Young women, including the Misses Joan Derby Benkard, Mary Stone and Paulette Cohen, are assisting members of the executive committee in advancing plans for the performance of the new musical, "Can-Can," on the night of May 21 at the Shubert Theatre for the benefit of the Child Education Foundation.

DURING the last six weeks Philadelphia has been the City of Brotherly Love and "Can-Can." Its citizens have been aware of the new Cole Porter-Abe Burrows musical of Montmartre in the Nineties as they have been aware of few other shows that have tried out here on their way to Broadway.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- Speaking of upsets, as they must have been doing at Louisville just a few minutes earlier, the White Sox came through with a powerful stretch run of their own, scored four runs in the ninth inning and bowled over the Yankees, 8 -- 7, today at Comiskey Park.
HOW is a chrysanthemum border started? Are plants purchased, and if so where? When is the best time of year to begin such a border? These are questions frequently asked by gardeners.
MODIFICATION o the musical schedules of two radio stations will give after-midnight listeners a new diversity of programming beginning tomorrow night.

Two New York lawyers, Walter W. Land and Edward K. Mosenthal examine and reject the legal arguments against the fluoridation of water supplies in the Journal of the American Water Works Association. There have been public referendums on fluoridation in Seattle, Wash., and San Francisco, Calif.

ALBANY, May 2 -- Governor Dewey's office denied tonight published reports that the New York City Transit Authority might become legally stymied if members of the Port of New York Authority were unable to agree on the selection of an eligible member of that body as the fifth member of the transit group.

ON the Blue Bus to Warwick the other day a jovial puffing housewife with an armful of bundles greeted a friend who was already safely seated: "Did you hear the one o'clock news? There'll be frosts everywhere tonight," she announced.

Two major instruments of Western policy in Europe are the European Defense Community treaty and the Bonn Contractual Agreement -- both of which are still unratified by a single European country. It has long been apparent that ratification hinges on a series of major forces -- among them Soviet policy, U. S. policy, European nationalism.

ROME -- Before we started our forty-fifth wedding-anniversary tour of Europe last fall, our principal concern was the mode of travel to adopt after arriving on the Continent. Since clothing for eight or nine months and three seasons had to accompany us, flying was out of the question.

THE current Soviet peace gestures and President Eisenhower's answer to them impel us to look at the factors underlying Soviet policy. Among the most important of these is the mentality of the Soviet people.

SAN FRANCISCO -- This city's Golden Gate Park, carved out of a thousand acres of sand dunes on which a few scrub oaks and willows once struggled for life, has a new attraction or two for its summer visitors.

DAWSON CREEK, B. C. -- For 265 miles the new Hart Highway cuts through a vast British Columbia wilderness and affords the motorist in his automobile the same sense of penetrating the unknown which must have been the lot in other times of the frontiersmen who came by pack string, by canoe or merely on their own two feet shod in beaded moccasins.

Despite Soviet Russia's official disavowal of an open policy of anti-Semitism, no evidence exists of any improvement of conditions for Jews or other religious and ethnic minorities behind the Iron Curtain, Jacob Blaustein, president of the American Jewish Committee, asserted last night.

THE orchestras for all the musical plays -- the good as well as the bad -- play much too loudly. Rather than enjoying the music -- as I do when I hear it on records or over the radio -- I cringe from it and sometimes leave the theatre with a headache because of it.
ALBANY, May 2 -- The State Education Department cleared the way today for the first vote on centralization of school districts ever to be held in Nassau County.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Governors of forty-five states, one commonwealth, three territories and an island possession will be welcomed to Washington Monday morning by President Eisenhower for a two-day conference on national and international affairs to which they were invited by the President April 11.

LONDON, May 3 -- The subdued condition of the stock markets that followed shortly after the initial outburst of enthusiasm and buoyancy created by the budget became more pronounced last week. This was not because of any revision of opinion concerning the favorable and helpful nature of the budget proposals but sprung from other and shorter-term factors and considerations.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 3 (UP) -The tornado threat that has hung over the South for five days was lifted today and the authorities counted forty-one dead and estimated the damage at $20,000,000 from twisters that struck from Texas to Georgia.

MAHWAH, N. J., May 3 -- The estranged wife of a former Rutgers University football star killed her four children by carbon monoxide poisoning in the family station wagon here early today and then tried desperately to save them when it was too late.

Forty-one members of the Police Department who performed outstanding acts of bravery in 1952 were cited yesterday for the annual medal awards that will be presented later this month or early in June at a City Hall ceremony.

LOS ANGELES, May 3 -- The Boston Symphony Orchestra, traveling in a special train on its first transcontinental tour, arrived here this afternoon and played in nearby Pasadena tonight under the direction of Pierre Monteux.

The fiftieth anniversary of the laying of the cornerstone of Broadway Tabernacle Church (Congregational) at Fifty-sixth Street, was marked there yesterday. The morning service included hymns and prayers used at the ceremony half a century ago.

The citizens' group we represent is grateful to THE NEW YOEK TIMES for its continued championship of UNICEF (the United Nations Children's Fund). While we believe our own children have a claim on priority of consideration, we believe that it is not only callous but unenlightened to withhold concern for the other, far less privileged, children in the world.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 3 -The National Labor Relations Board has ordered a national bargaining election among writers working in network television to settle a six-month-old jurisdictional claim by the Television Writers of America, an independent union, against the Screen Writers Guild and the Authors League of America.

A 33-year-old registered nurse wag held in $10,000 bail by Magistrate Samuel J. Ohringer yesterday as the police investigated the death of a 17-year-old youth whose friends said he consumed a large quantity of "yellow capsules."

A memorandum supposedly written by David Greenglass, confessed atomic spy, was featured yesterday as new "evidence" at a rally on behalf of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, convicted and under death sentence as his fellow conspirators.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., May 3 -Mrs. James Kelly's chestnut mare Bournebreena from Lloyd Harbor scored fifteen points today to win the working hunter championship during the annual Rice Farms spring horse show for the benefit of the St. Charles Hospital for crippled children of Port Jefferson.

The Advertising Council is supporting the National Blood Donor Program with aids to national advertisers in all media. Albert Carroll, advertising manager of Merck Co., is the voluntary coordinator of the campaign and its voluntary agency is Cunningham Walsh, Inc., for all media except newspapers, for which Ted Bates Co. serves.

PITTSBURGH, May 3 -- Over-simplified, steel "extras" mean charges for "custom-making" steel. Physical and chemical requirements over and beyond so-called base characteristics carry charges which are in addition to base steel prices. These extra charges featured steel price news last week.
HANOI, Vietnam, May 3 -- French paratroopers clashed with invading Communist-led Vietminh troops only nine miles from the royal capital of Laos, a French Army communique reported today.

" It is not mind alone, but mind and spirit that lead us to the truth of God," the Rev. Dr. James Hutchison Cockburn, chaplain to Queen Elizabeth II, declared yesterday in a sermon at Rutgers Presbyterian Church, 236 West Seventy-third Street.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on major roll-calls in Congress during the period of April 25 to May 1 are given in the appended tabulation:
A spry, 99-year-old former cantor of the Bialystoker Synagogue at 7 Willett Street was honored last night at the celebration of the house of worship's seventy-fifth anniversary.

SOMERSET MAUGHAM and Gilbert Highet have recently been discussing the perils and pleasures of murder. Both have sharply critical things to say about the seedy way sudden death is dealt with in contemporary literature. Their views, though formally centered upon modern detective stories, illuminate the whole darkly popular field of vicarious violence.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Congressional leaders expressed deep concern today over military developments in Indo-China, but differed over the ultimate role of the United States in meeting the latest challenge of Communist aggression.

CHICAGO, May 3 (UP) -- The Athletics swept a double-header with the White Sox, 4 to 2 and 10 to 6, today behind standout pitching by Southpaws Bobby Shantz and Alex Kellner to knock Chicago into fifth place in the American League.

There is a neighborhood restaurant in Yorkville that has a steady following among those who like sound cooking in the Hungarian style at low prices. It is called the Budapest, and it has just moved from cramped quarters at 1503 Second Avenue to a larger place a couple of blocks south at No. 1481.

TRENTON, N. J., May 3 -- A 4-year-old bright red smooth dachshund, Ch. Hardway Welcome Stranger, completed a big day for his owner. Mrs. John W. Cross Jr. of Wilton, Conn., by taking best in show at the twenty-fourth Trenton Kennel Club event today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 3 -A deal for Betty Grable to star in "The Pleasure Is All Mine" was set yesterday between Jerry Wald, Columbia's executive producer, and Darryl F. Zanuck, chief of Twentieth Century-Fox. This marks the first time since Miss Grable attained stardom in 1939 that Fox has agreed to permit her to work for another studio.

LONDON, May 3 -- Now that the seats for spectators along the route of Queen Elizabeth's coronation procession are nearly completed, some once familiar sections of London are beginning to resemble the Yankee Stadium.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 3 -- The announcement of Oliver Lyttelton, British Colonial Secretary, that he is coming to Kenya for a second time is expected here to usher in a constructive phase of the struggle to overcome the rebellion of the Mau Mau secret society.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Eisenhower Administration looked ahead tonight to a major test as it put finishing touches to the arguments it will present to Congress on the twin problems of world trade and aid.

Details of a special port-wide referendum to be held Friday by thirty-five International Longshoremen's Association locals on the controversial shape-up system of hiring longshore labor were announced here yesterday by the Honest Ballot Association.

This week at Macy's it will be difficult to see the customers for the trees -- and the snapdragons, the tuberous begonias, the roses, orchids and other blossoms that have burgeoned overnight in the store's first spring flower show. The unusual show, featuring more than "two million blooms," opened last evening at a press preview in the Broadway store.

It was a well known British economist, Sir Arthur Salter, who, in the early Thirties, summed up better than most of its critics at home the essential character -- or lack of character -- of the New Deal. Sir Arthur plainly regarded it as an unprovoked attack on the English language to refer to the latter as a "program."

Group exhibitions and one-man shows in a wide variety make up the art program of the week. Among the former is the exhibition of eighteenth century English paintings to open tomorrow at Knoedler's in connection with the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II.

No wonder the free world views the invasion of Laos with grave concern. In the first place it marks a distinct advance in the Communist effort to add all of Southeast Asia to its conquests. A glance at the map reveals that the little kingdom occupies the narrowest part of the Indo-Chinese peninsula, abuts on Burma in the north and in the south encloses a good part of the neighboring country of Thailand, or Siam.

Protestant, Jewish and Roman Catholic clergymen will lead members of their congregations in a mass blood donation at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, today at 1:30 P. M.
MEXICO CITY, May 3 (AP) -- Ben Hogan today won the $15,000 Pan American open with a two-under-par 286. It meant $2,600 in prize money for the Palm Springs (Calif.) golf star.

One fine day about now the lady of the house, standing in the living room and looking out toward the yard, will observe that one scarcely can see through the windows. After a pause it will be added that winter certainly seems to have made the windows dirty.

If the Christian Church abandoned the "Trinitarian approach in the interests of a supposed simplicity" there would be "a vitamin deficiency in the spiritual experience of Christians of future generations," the Rev. James A. Pike declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the New York Cathdral (Cathedral of St. John the Divine).

The 1953 season of free outdoor concerts by the Goldman Band will begin in Central Park Friday night, June 19, and will continue through August 16. It will be the thirty-sixth season of the Guggenheim Memorial Concerts, a gift to the people of this city by the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- A new proposal for the use of limited amounts of United States funds in the rural economic development of other countries has been circulated here in recent weeks. It has the support of several influential members of Congress on the eve of their consideration of foreign aid appropriations.
The demands that the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., will submit soon to East and Gulf Coast steamship operators can be summed up in one word -- "more."
Officers and directors of Willys Motors, Inc., formed last week when Kaiser Manufacturing Corporation bought the physical assets of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., were named over the weekend.
With a performance of Rossini's "La Cenerentola" last night at the City Center, the New York City Opera Company brought to an end its nineteenth season.

The Italian liner Vulcania, fresh from a three-month lay-up during which she was extensively repaired and refurbished, will arrive in New York on May 25. W. H. McConnell, vice president in charge of passenger traffic of the American Export Lines, agents for the Italian concern, announced here over the week-end.
GENEVA, May 3 -- There has been an "extraordinary" drop in mortality from tuberculosis of the respiratory system since the end of World War II, the World Health Orgonization reported today.

The new Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Australia, formerly the French Line's De Grasse, will arrive on this side of the Atlantic for the first time under her new name on Wednesday when she berths at Montreal.

The Hakoah-Brooklyn Hispano selected squad defeated a picked eleven from the New York Americans and Brookhattan-Galicia, by 5 -- 3 at Sterling Oval, the Bronx, yesterday, in the first of two practice games for the match at Triboro Stadium on May 17, when an American Soccer League All-Star team will meet the Liverpool Club of England.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -Roy M. Cohn, Chief Investigator for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, tonight accused "certain elements within the State Department over in Germany'' of putting "a tail" on him during his recent trip to Europe.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- Big-scale long liquidation with not much news to stimulate buying to cushion the selling caused a big drop in prices last week. Selling was induced by the bearish supply and demand situation ahead and in a measure by the Administration's reported opposition to the present system of supports, although the law will be operative through the 1954 crop year.

ALBANY, May 3 -- A reproduction in miniature of the parade that will feature the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II in London next month will go on display officially tomorrow in the rotunda of the State Education Building here.

The dainty femininity that pervades a Hannah Troy collection reflects the woman who is its guiding spirit. She is petite, vivacious and quick of motion. Her dark hair, combed back from a broad white forehead, her deep brown eyes and fineness of feature frequently cause her to be taken for an Italian.

President Eisenhower and Governor Dewey have sent messages to the 500 leaders in the field of practical nursing from all parts of the United States who will attend the annum convention of the National Association for Practical Nurse Education opening today in the Park-Sheraton Hotel.
I have had an opportunity to read here in La Paz your editorial, dated April 9, entitled "Anniversary in Bolivia."

Criticism of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act, which enunciates United States immigration policy, and other aspects of our national life was contained in reports made yesterday by two Jewish groups and one Negro association.

Fairly active business in textiles continued to support cotton futures prices last week. Near-by future contracts traded on the New York Cotton Exchange gained as much as $1.55 a bale for the five-day trading session, while losses were confined to the more distant deliveries.

A six-foot eucalyptus sapling flown here from Israel was planted yesterday afternoon in the Music Grove of Prospect Park, Brooklyn, at ceremonies observing the fifth anniversary of Israel's independence. The tree was presented by Leo Marder, president of the Brooklyn Jewish Community Council, sponsor of the observance, and was accepted by Borough President John Cashmore.

A shortage of mechanical and electrical engineers will make it impossible for New York to complete the $100,000,000 first phase of its pollution-control program by the end of this year, it was made known yesterday by Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works.

Mrs. Ralph H. Boots will give a luncheon Wednesday in the Colony Club for more than a hundred women who are actively interested in the plans for a series of three benefits to aid member hospitals of the United Hospital Fund.

PARIS, Monday, May 4 -- Runoff balloting in the municipal elections of 18,000 smaller communities in France was marked today by gains for former Premier Antoine Pinay's moderates or their center coalition and by spirited contests in many districts between the Communists and Socialists.

A good child who is excessively submissive to authority may be potentially as great a problem to himself and society as a delinquent child, according to Bertram M. Beck, director of the Juvenile Delinquency Project of the United States Children's Bureau.
WAVERLY, Ohio, May 3 -- An Atomic "gold rush" is rapidly changing the face of Pike County - a region of scrub farms, tumbledown barns and tar-paper shanties in the hills of southern Ohio.

ZURICH, May 3 -- At the annual meeting on April 30 of Ciba, Ltd., of Basle, largest concern in the Swiss chemical industry, Dr. R. Kaeppeli, managing director, gave shareholders a survey of business conditions in all parts of the world where Ciba operates.

LYNDHURST, N. J., May 3 -Fifteen miles from its usual outdoor site on the edge of the Hudson River just north of the George Washington Bridge, the annual fish fry of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints was held in the Adoniram (Masonic) Temple here today.

SEOUL, Korea, May 3 -- President Syngman Rhee said today that the South Korean Army would fight any peace agreement made by the United Nations that did not unite all Korea. Regardless of any agreement, South Korea will continue to fight and, if necessary, invade North Korea to reunify the country, he asserted.

A significant role in improving the lot of the seafaring man has been played for many years by the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, 25 South Street, New York 4. Historically, the Institute was active in helping to end the practice of crimping and shanghaiing that prevailed in New York as well as in many other United States port cities during the last century.

ROME, May 3 -- Scores of Communist and left-wing intellectuals gathered today in the Museum of Modern Art here for a preview of what is said to be the largest and most comprehensive exhibition of Pablo Picasso's work ever held.

With Communist troops on the perimeter of Luang Prabang, capital of Laos, this sector of the war in the Far East has become the most critical at the moment. Thailand is justifiably alarmed, has rounded up some Communists and alerted the frontier with Laos.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- The American Political Science Association announced a plan today to educate the people on the affairs of Congress.

HANOVER, N. H., May 3 -- The Dartmouth College map library has acquired highly specialized ethnographical and administrative maps of Eastern Europe that were made for Adolf Hitler when he was dreaming of a Nazi super-state.

Carmine G. De Sapio, leader of Tammany, has rejected overtures seeking his support for the nomination of Mayor Impellitteri by the Democratic party, on the ground that Mr. Impellitteri's record is such that he cannot be re-elected.
TOKYO, Monday, May 4 (UP) -- The Peiping radio said today that the North Koreans had turned over six United States missionaries and a merchant to the Russians for return home.

LONDON, April 25 -- At this point London is a bit reserved when it comes to using the coronation as a promotional fashion theme. Anything that has to do with Queen Elizabeth, her gowns or robes for the coronation, is completely hush-hush.

George Bernard Shaw's "Arms and the Man" was presented on television yesterday afternoon as the season's concluding installment of "Omnibus" over the C. B. S. video network. Unhappily, the result was too much like "The Chocolate Soldier" without a score.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- President Eisenhower placed a wreath today at the statue of John Witherspoon, only clergyman to sign the Declaration of Independence, before attending services in the National Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was arranged by the St. Andrews Society of Washington as a prelude to the annual "Kirkin' o' the Tartans," in which the various clan tartans are dedicated and blessed.

COLOGNE, Germany, May 3 -- Germany returned to international broadcasting today when President Theodor Heuss opened "The German Wave," a short-wave radio transmitter that will broadcast to North and South America, Africa and the Near and Middle East.

Rollin A. Sawyer will retire today after thirty-eight years of work in a place he calls "very much alive" -- the New York Public Library -- where he has been chief of the economics division since 1921. Friends and members of the library staff will honor him this afternoon at a reception in Room 206 of the library's Fifth Avenue building.

Eugene F. Moran, 81 years old, a member of the Port of New York Authority since 1942, was chosen yesterday as the fifth member of the five-man New York City Transit Authority. This is the body created by the 1953 Legislature to take over the debt-ridden municipal transit lines and run them at a fare sufficient to meet all operating expenses.

Foreign exchange trading during the past week was centered mainly in the British pound sterling and the Canadian dollar. Business was reported as only moderately active and price fluctuations were confined to a limited range.

AMAGANSETT, L. I., May 3 -- Twenty Suffolk County farmers, their barns piled high with 300,000 bushels of "late" potatoes, for which there is no market, today offered them to any hospital or public institution that would carry them away.

LOUISVILLE, May 3 -- It's a dreadful and blighting experience to fall madly and blindly in love with a race horse. But that's what happened to this tourist to the blue grass belt. The unashamed admission must be made that he fell in love with Native Dancer. But he was not alone in becoming enamored of the big gray. Almost half of the press box tenants at Churchill Downs yesterday also were ga-ga over him.
One of the world's largest producers of the atomic age metals titanium and zirconium is an old-line company which started out in 1891 as a maker of white lead pigments for paint.

Today, with a parade and a public ceremony, the Greater New York Citizens Clean-Up, Paint-Up, Fix-Up Committee launches its spring drive to "dramatize the need for civic cleanliness." The Sanitation, Commerce and Fire Departments, the Mayor and a host of chambers of commerce, trade associations and civic groups will participate.

Mayor Impellitteri, who for some time has been busily defending his financial program, and more recently also attacking critics of the city's moral and physical condition, switched his emphasis yesterday to his efforts against communism.

PITTSBURGH, May 3 (AP) -Johnny Lindell, 36-year-old Pirate knuckleball specialist, stopped the Cardinals, 8 -- 2, on four hits today for his first National League victory. The triumph extended the Pirates' winning streak to five games.
TUNIS, Tunisia, May 3 -- An atmosphere of crisis prevailed here today following the assassination yesterday of Chadly Kastalli, vice president of the Tunis City Council.

There are days when it is quiet on the Housatonic River in Connecticut. This wasn't one of them. A glance disclosed eight eight-oared shells, a scull, a wherry, two launches and a pair of outboards. Indeed, it seemed a miniature navy was in operation. The fact is that the Kent School's oarsmen were going through a routine workout.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The membership of the Planning Board of the revamped National Security Council has just been completed by the selection of Robert Bowie, chief of the Policy Planning Staff of the State Department.

BERLIN, May 3 -- Western Germany leads the Western European continental countries today in the extraction of coal, production of steel, chemicals, electrical equipment, machine tools and machines, shipbuilding and housing construction.

INDIANTOWN GAP, Pa., May 2 -- Bridges of goodwill have been built by the Army at the military reservation here to close the gap between recruits and the civilian life they recently left. Soldier homesickness and civilian neighborliness have been merged during the last four months in a program that may become as common to Army recruits as tiring marches.

TOKYO, Monday, May 4 (UP) -- Dispatches from the front indicated today that Chinese casualties were heavy as Canadian and British troops smashed back a 1,000-man Chinese assault northeast of Panmunjom yesterday in the heaviest fighting since the Korean truce talks resumed.
Nine new films, including importations from England, France and Russia, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 (UP) -The Phillies used Robin Roberts and Curt Simmons against the Cubs today to sweep a double-header, 5 -- 1 and 2 -- 0. The victories, the first of which snapped a three-game losing streak, moved the Phils into a tie for first with the Dodgers.

Brazil in some ways reminds her friends of France. Just when we are ready to throw up our hands in despair and decide that a situation is hopeless, the Brazilians do the right thing, usually in the nick of time.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The National Geographic Society said today that a sky survey, now under way to aid in mapping the universe, would provide astronomers "with enough new material for a century of study."
The New York State Crime Commission has recommended strengthening the removal powers of the Governor as a means of helping to eliminate the links between organized crime and local public officials.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 -Former President Harry S. Truman, returning with his family today aboard the President Cleveland after a month's Hawaiian vacation, said he was more convinced than ever. Hawaii should receive statehood.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- A Judiciary subcommittee of the House of Representatives will begin hearings Monday on bills to permit the use of evidence obtained by wiretapping in Federal cases involving the national security and defense.

SEOUL, Korea, May 3 -- Lieut. Gen. Glenn O. Barcus, 49-year-old commanding general of the Fifth Air Force, has flown more than a dozen missions over North Korea in a marked Sabre jet plane and has told the Communists by radio who he was and why he was flying, it was disclosed today.

Some of the scientific "wonders-in-progress" that have made headline news since 1945 are the subject matter of a book by Waldemar Kaempffert, science and engineering editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, scheduled for publication by Viking May 18.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 13 -- Capt. Eugene Brown landed a one-engine biplane at Hadley Field near here this afternoon and delivered a fifty-pound sack of mail to the same postal official who had greeted him exactly twenty-five years ago at the end of the first mail flight from Atlanta, Ga.

ROME, May 3 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi revealed in an election campaign speech in Florence today that in 1945 he was willing to undertake to keep Italy out of any coalition of powers if the Soviet Union abandoned its intention of imposing a punitive peace treaty upon his country.

Times have changed in America since the depression of 1929-32, when one out of four workers suffered total loss of income and the others took substantial cuts. Since then, the well-to-do and the rich have become the economy's "forgotten men."

SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 (AP) -Louise Suggs, posting rounds of 74, 75 -- 149, won the San Francisco leg of the cross-country Weathervane tournament for women golf professionals today. The victory netted her $750.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., May 3 -- A pushing, shouting group of about sixty relatives and friends greeted today the first exchanged war prisoner from Nassau County to reach home: Marine Pfc. George F. Hart Jr. of Wantagh, L. I.

ST. LOUIS, May 3 (AP) -- The winning streak of the Red Sox was stopped at six today as the Browns rallied twice for a 6-5 second-game victory after falling before a seventeen-hit attack, 14 -- 5, in the opener.

PARIS, May 3 -- At a time when French policies in Indo-China are said to be meeting many criticisms as the Vietminh offensive develops in Laos, official figures have been issued here to show that the first results have been obtained in the economic field in the three associated states under the recovery program that was started by Marshal Jean de Lattre de Tassigny.

Leo Durocher's well-nurtured plans for lifting the Giants out of the dank depths of seventh place in the National League were forced to remain in abeyance for another twenty-four hours when rain washed out yesterday's Polo Grounds double-header that was to have ushered in a four-game series with Rogers Hornsby's Redlegs.
