CLEVELAND, May 3 (UP) -- Behind the strong pitching of Early Wynn and Mike Garcia, the Indians defeated the Senators in a double-header, 7 -- 0 and 4 -- 3, today before 17,160.

PHOENIXVILLE, Pa., May 3 -- Ten former prisoners of war, released by the Communists in Korea after confinement up to two and a-half years, protested today at any implication that they or their fellows had succumbed to Communist indoctrination.

James Marshall, former president of the Board of Education, said last night that the failure of the American teaching profession to root out Communists from its ranks had made possible the use of objectionable methods by Congressional committees.

Five major New York breweries, which had announced they would suspend operations today, called off their threatened shutdown last night after obtaining what they interpreted as assurances from their employes' union that there would be no future slowdowns.
Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh declared yesterday that the time had come for the voters of this city to insist on the election of a nonpolitical candidate for Mayor.

I don't share the enthusiasm for Senator Morse's record-setting filibuster. Yet, while I am no admirer of the talkative Oregonian, I feel that it was cruel to insist that he stay on his feet throughout his twenty-two-hour talk, described as "the longest continuous speech in the history of the Senate."
That high wind last week had nothing to do with meteorology. It was caused by thousands of ancestors of the New England textile industry, spinning in their Providence and Boston graves.

AFTER luxury - apartment agents had combed the town's Gold Coast last week for a proper suite for Dag Hammarskjold, the new Secretary General of the United Nations, he and they had to drop the idea of a straight rental and settle for a cooperative at Park Avenue and Seventy-third Street.

I am sure that the Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES requires no defense of his merited criticism of the Liberal party. The letter written by Adolf A. Berle Jr., state chairman of the Liberal party, published April 30, in reply to your editorial, was entirely unconvincing.
The wealth held by consumers in this country has risen more than 50 per cent since the end of World War II and now exceeds three-quarters of a trillion dollars.

PARIS. May 3 (UP) -- American boxing officials achieved a major triumph today when the European Boxing Union refused to recognize as a world middleweight championship fight the June 9 bout in London between Randy Turpin of England and Charles Humez of France.

A 35-year-old Yaphank, L. I., physician, Dr. Winton Steinfield, and his wife, 27, continued to be the object of a Coast Guard search yesterday in lower Delaware Bay. The couple had left Georgetown, Md., on April 25 for Long Island Sound via the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal aboard the thirty-two-foot sloop Allegro II.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Ranking leaders of B'nai B'rith, the 110-year-old Jewish service organization and oldest of its kind in the country, declared here today that unless the McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Law was sharply revised American foreign relations would be seriously impaired.

Public officials, civic and religious organizations and private companies mobilized over the week-end, intent on giving New York a thorough scrubbing behind the cars when the annual two-week clean-up campaign starts today.

Love for God and man is a good foundation on which to build a life, the Right Rev. Bo Giertz, Bishop of Gothenburg, Sweden, said yesterday in a sermon at Gustavus Adolphus Lutheran Church, 153 East Twenty-Second Street.

The Hoover Administration introduced, in 1932, a program of soak-the-rich tax legislation. The Roosevelt and Truman Administrations successively increased higher-bracket surtaxes nearly to the point of confiscation.

CALCUTTA, India, May 3 -- All thirty-seven passengers and the six crew members of the British Overseas Airways Corporation Comet jet liner that fell in a storm thirty air miles from Calcutta yesterday are believed dead. Eighteen bodies had been recovered today but none had been identified.

YONKERS, May 3 -- Austin Scott of the Bronx, representing the New York Pioneer Club, won the Metropolitan senior A. A. U. ten-mile run sponsored by the Pacoy Club and the Yonkers Recreation Commission at Glen Park today.

AMSTERDAM, May 3 -- The favorable development of Dutch balance payments -- especially the dollar balance -- has brought the time nearer when the Netherlands in concert with other European countries and the United States may be prepared to devise measures that may lead to restricted restoration of convertibility, Dr. Marius W. Holtrop, president of the Netherlands Bank, said in his annual report this week.

Net earnings of the National Dairy Products Corporation were $6,793,785, equal to $1.03 a share, in the first three months of this year, compared with $5,605,590, or 87 cents a share, in the same period of 1952.

Under existing legislation the Philippines will begin next year to pay a progressively increasing part of the United States tariff on such major export products as sugar, coconuts and fabricated hemp. Quota allocations will remain in force, as will the provision that United States citizens are to enjoy, for twenty years, parity with Filipinos in the development of natural resources.

DETROIT, May 3 -- The Yankees took advantage of an error, a passed ball and a wild pitch to count four times in the ninth and beat the Tigers, 6 -- 5, today at Briggs Stadium. Somewhere in between these totally unexpected but thoroughly acceptable gifts, Irv Noren punched a pinch-hit single, good for two runs and a tie.
PARIS, May 3 -- Police lines were broken at Le Bourget Airfield here tonight by a crowd that gave a tearful and excited welcome to fourteen interned French civilians who had been captured in Korea.

A solemn pontifical mass of thanksgiving, at which Cardinal Spellman presided, was sung yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception, Melrose Avenue and East 150th Street, the Bronx, to commemorate the one hundredth anniversary of the parish.

Milton M. Bergerman, chairman of the Citizens Union, took issue yesterday with Mayor Impellitteri's "Reply to the Critics," made on Saturday at a luncheon of the Queensboro Federation of Mothers Clubs, by accusing the Mayor of sidestepping city issues.
High levels of sales and earnings will be maintained during the last half of 1953, according to a majority of business executives interviewed recently by Dun Bradstreet, the credit reporting agency.

LOUISVILLE, May 3 (AP) -- One of the loudest Kentucky Derby post mortems in many a year was spinning about mint julep town today after Dark Star ended Native Dancer's unbeaten streak in the seventy-ninth edition of the Run for the Roses.

The building containing fifty-eight apartments and eleven stores at 1229 Franklin Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased for investment by Leo A. Bercow and Walter Berger from Chobel Navone, operators, in a deal negotiated by Stanley Russell Associates, Inc., broker.

Two current Broadway attractions announced closing dates yesterday. Tennessee Williams' controversial play, "Camino Real," will end its run at the National Theatre on Saturday night. "An Evening With Beatrice Lillie," the program of songs and sketches at the Booth, will have its final performance on May 30.

How a United States private enterprise helped a less developed country improve its economic and social conditions while bringing in a profit to its stockholders is outlined in a study of Sears, Roebuck Co. operations in Mexico, released over the week-end by the National Planning Association.
LUXEMBOURG, May 1 -- With a single market for coal and steel inaugurated as of today, the next big step by the European Coal and Steel Community will be to make the single market also a free market.
Young people in this country today present "a new dimension in the over-all national economic balance," according to Lester Rand, president of the Youth Research Institute.
TOKYO, Monday, May 4 (AP) -United Nation Command communique 1,604, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Monday, Korean time:

By holding the Braves to three hits and one earned run, Billy Loes became the Dodgers' "winningest" pitcher as the Brooks defeated Milwaukee, 4 -- 3, yesterday at Ebbets Amid, for their sixth straight triumph. The victory was the Astoria Kid's third against one loss and by far his best performance to date.

When Brig. Gen. Harold R. Harris took over as president and chief executive officer of Northwest Airlines last New Year's Day, he passed the word to all personnel that he intended to build the "best international and domestic airline under the American flag."

Robert Shaw completed his "Choral Masterwork Series" last night with a performance of Haydn's "The Creation" at Carnegie Hall. His assisting forces were the Collegiate Chorale and the R. C. A. Victor Symphony Orchestra, the same groups that participated in the two previous concerts of the series.

TOKYO, Monday, May 4 -- The United Nations Command nominated Pakistan today as the neutral nation to take custody of war prisoners who refuse to return to their homelands after the start of a Korean armistice.

For the second time within eleven days, New York University has announced the purchase of property on the west side of Washington Square. Its holdings now total 80 per cent of the property on the square.

Plans to construct a $5,000,000 College of Pharmacy and Drug Research Institute on the campus of Columbia University were announced last night at a dinner of the Alumni Association of the Columbia University College of Pharmacy.

VICTORVILLE, Calif., May 3 (UP) -- Forty Air Force men parachuted safely from a burning C-119 transport 5,000 feet above rugged Southern California desert country today moments before the pilot landed the crippled ship at George Air Force Base near here.

HOBOKEN, N. J., May 4 -- The United States Steel Corporation is well equipped to face the increased competition expected in the closing months of this year, Benjamin Fairless, chairman, said today at the annual meeting here.

The Independent Grocers Alliance of America is again exploring the possibility of entering the New York market, where the credit standing of the average small food store has hitherto made it impossible for the alliance to find wholesalers willing to meet its franchise terms.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -The Supreme Court heard arguments today on the validity of the 1950 perjury conviction against Harry Bridges, West Coast labor leader. The International Longshoremen's president was a spectator.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., May 4 -- The Westchester County P. G. A. held its first pro-amateur best-ball one-day tournament of the season at the Leewood Country Club today. The event was in honor of Alex Watson of Leewood, who just returned home after a serious operation.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 4 -- A diet rich in proteins and high in calories would enable a healthy blood donor to give plasma at the rate of five pints a week, or more than seventy times the rate now regarded as safe, according to studies reported here today.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP) -- The Marine Corps announced today the names of sixty-nine marines believed held by the Communists as Korean war prisoners. It said, however, that the sixty-nine still will be listed officially as missing because of lack of accurate information.

May one remind the thirty-seven presidents of American universities who issued a recent statement on academic freedom that history pops up awkwardly? They make the point that a proper professor is loyal "to the country and to its form of government." This proves too much.

NEW DELHI, India, May 4 -- India's fight to raise her living standards without the sacrifice of individual liberties was cited today by George V. Allen, United States Ambassador, as the most significant development in the Orient" at the moment.

With more aggressiveness than he usually shows, unfortunately, in attacking the city's major problems, Mayor Impellitteri has made a "reply to the critics" of New York, using the occasion of the city's celebration of its 300th anniversary of incorporation. He defended the city as having "much to celebrate, much to be grateful for, much to be proud of" -- an unchallengeable fact.
Today's column deals with reader letters, among them two that raise the question of substituting one food for another in a recipe.
A lull in the cotton textile market has given mills an opportunity to take stock after a fortnight of heavy selling.
The State of Washington announced yesterday that it would receive bids June 3 on $20,000,000 of school construction bonds dated June 1, 1953, and due June 1, 1955 to 1963.

Every so often the debate is revived as to whether Britain should try to restore the pound sterling to the status of a convertible currency, and if so what form such convertibility should take. Thus far, however, these debates have not proceeded beyond the discussion stage.

Sworn in yesterday as Acting Postmaster of the New York Post Office, the largest in the world, Harold R. Riegelman promised to reward merit and faithful service without regard for "political or partisan" considerations.

Billy Rose, who has given much consideration lately to the prospect of producing "The Immoralist," the new play by Ruth and Augustus Geotz, has made up his mind to go ahead with the project. The producer signed contracts with Leah Salisbury, agent for the authors, stipulating a Broadway production for the work "on or before Dec. 1."

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 -- The Rev. Dennis J. Comey, permanent arbitrator of waterfront trouble here, used his "unlimited authority" today to end a labor-management dispute that had halted the movement of all dry cargo in the Port of Philadelphia for two days.

Ten clergymen of the Protestant, Jewish and Catholic faiths and groups from twelve churches and synagogues made blood donations yesterday in the parish house of the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

PARIS, May 4 -- Reviewing the outcome of the second ballot yesterday, held as a run-off in the small communities of France, Charles Brune, Minister of the Interior, decalred today that the results confirmed the main indications of the municipal elections April 26.

Award of $40,000 in eight grants for medical X-ray studies at nine universities throughout the world was announced here yesterday by Harold E. Stassen, Director for Mutual Security and president of the James Picker Foundation of New York City.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday and closed 3 to 28 points net higher on active months, with the strength in old crop months.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 5 -- United Nations delegates at Panmunjom rejected today a Communist proposal to transport to a neutral nation prisoners of the Korean war who refused to return to their former homes after the start of an armistice.

On improved but still moderate volume, prices on the New York Stock Exchange made the widest gains yesterday since March 24 and ended at the highest levels since April 17. Volume, the best in more than a week, was 1,520,000 shares, against 1,200,000 on Friday.
A free trade policy as a method of obtaining economic health in the free world was advocated yesterday by John E. Raasch, chairman of the board of the John Wanamaker stores.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 4 -- The Ludonesian Government rejected today the Communist suggestion it might supervise the detention of Korean prisoners opposing repatriation. ~ official spokesman said Indonesia would also refuse to serve as a host country for recalcitrant war prisoners.

BUENOS AIRES, May 4 (Reuters) -- The police said tonight they had arrested a 34-year-old society woman, two doctors and two other public figures planting the bombs that have shaken Buenos Aires in the past few weeks.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 4 -- John N. Popham, Southern regional correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was named tonight as the South's "outstanding newsman of 1952" by the Atlanta professional chapter of Sigma Delta Chi.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- Purchase of United States Rubber Company stock by a syndicate including many members of the du Pont family in 1927 was motivated by a desire to get the ear of the management and help the company out of a bad financial condition, Irenee du Pont testified today at the du Pont anti-trust trial before Judge Walter J. Labuy.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- Unfavorable reports on the winter wheat outlook in the Southwest caused more active buying of wheat today. Straight investment buying was indicated, and shorts were also taking profits on a substantial basis.

Diplomatic observers said yesterday that the Soviet Government's decision to send a team of chess masters here next month for a match against this country's best players was a significant move in the Kremlin's current "peace offensive" as well as an effort to dispel United States belief in Soviet anti-Semitism.

Amid justified and angry protests from the victims of the Phoenixville fiasco the truth is emerging. The whole thing seems to have been some sort of technical mistake in classification of the flight and in description of the hospital to which the veterans were returned.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 4 -- The quality show for American antiques, the Eastern States Antiques Fair, which takes up its stand at the Westchester County Center here, spring and fall, opened today with collections of 120 dealers above the usual high average.

Artie shaw, nationally known band leader, with tears welling to his eyes told the House Un-American Activities Committee here yesterday that the Communists had made him a "dupe" by using his name on front lists. He said he had refused to join the party after four exploratory "cloak and dagger" meetings in 1946 because he wanted free speech.

TRENTON, May 4 -- Superior Court Judge Ralph J. Smalley declared here today that bingo, the fund-raising game popularized over the last few years primarily by religious, charitable and fraternal organizations, was illegal and must be stamped out.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The White House announced today that Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent of Canada would be a guest of the United States Government during his visit here from Thursday to Saturday.

Large crowds swamped the six local offices of the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission yesterday. Officials estimate that 15,000 visited the offices during the day. Tenants only outnumbered landlords, but all wanted information about the rent increases that went into effect last Friday.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Administration's $5,800,000,000 Mutual Security Program goes before the combined foreign policy committees of the Senate and the House of Representatives tomorrow without benefit of a Presidential Message to prepare the way.
Navy's champion Olympic crew returns to action this week in the Adams Cup Regatta at Annapolis.

LONDON, May 4 (AP) -- Duncan Sandys, who as Minister of Supply is in charge of Britain's atomic energy program, gave the House of Commons today a thumbnail description of the work done in the country's atomic stations.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- A bipartisan group of pro-civil rights Senators headed by Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, will attempt tomorrow a new approach in the old effort to outlaw racial or religious discrimination against workers.
The renewed haggling in the truce talks in Korea combined with the swift advances of the Communist-led Vietminh through the jungles of Laos poses a major threat to anti-Communist forces in Asia.

Large department stores are being encouraged by Norcross, Inc., to set up separate self-service shops for the sale this year of Christmas cards, gift wrappings and related items. The company has a portfolio of blueprints, showing not only how to set up such shops but also the type of fixtures that can be used most effectively.

Greater efforts-to rehabilitate the tuberculosis patient should be made by providing more medically supervised workshops that will serve as "a bridge" between sanitarium life and economic self-sufficiency, Dr. Louis I. Dublin said here yesterday.
MONTREAL, May 4 (AP) -- Gordie Howe of the Detroit Red Wings today was named the winner for the second consecutive year of the Hart Trophy as the most valuable player in the National Hockey League.

LONDON, May 4 -- Doubt about the Far Eastern situation was reflected in the cautious attitude of investors on the stock markets here today. With buyers holding off, small selling pressure brought dullness to most sections.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, May 5 (AP) -- Six United States warships ripped Communist lines with heavy shell fire yesterday around the Korean east coast towns of Koje and Kosong. The heavy action smashed enemy guns, buildings and bridges.

HACKENSACK, N. J., May 4 -- Mrs. Carol Tiedeman MacDonald was arraigned before County Judge Herman Vanderwart this morning on four counts of murder in the deaths yesterday of her four children, who were found dead in their Mahwah home of carbon monoxide gas poisoning.

Trading in United States Government bonds in the dealers' market came to a virtual standstill yesterday and prices again receded to new low levels. The secondary market for corporate obligations was weak, too, on light turnover.
TOKYO, Tuesday, May 5 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,605, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, supported by George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, asked Congress today for a "standstill" of one year on tariff legislation to give the Eisenhower Administration time to evolve a national foreign trade policy consonant with current world conditions.

Everyone at Ebbets Field was happy last night when Roy Campanella belted a three-run homer in the first inning to give the Dodgers a one-run lead over the Braves, but an hour or so later gloom enveloped the 13,474 fans.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- A manufacturer testified today he had made 110,000 airplane gun heaters that burned out readily because the Air Force would not let him make better ones.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- An excellent example was provided today how a Congressional committee of inquiry, operating within the limits of its proper function, can help the Executive to formulate national security policies without invading the Executive province.
The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York has sent notices to its members announcing that a 20 per cent increase in rates will be charged to most subscribers after July 1.

ROME, April 29 -- An effective anti-Communist exhibition is on tour through Italy. Three replicas of the exhibition, sponsored by private organizations in almost all the North Atlantic Treaty countries, are being transported in trucks and it is expected that millions of voters will have seen the exhibit before the general elections on June 7.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Indonesia has urged the United States to manage any disposition of its Government-owned synthetic rubber plants so as not to upset the natural rubber industry, on which the Asian republic depends for a living.
ST. LOUIS, May 4 (AP) -- Fred M. Saigh, former St. Louis Cardinals owner, surrendered today to a United States Deputy Marshal to begin a fifteen-month prison term for income tax evasion.

Direct consumer credit constitutes the largest single factor in the current contraseasonal bank loan expansion, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. At the same time, the bank observes in its monthly review, issued today, the failure of business loans so far to develop the expected volume of seasonal net repayments has contributed to the growth in bank loans.

HONOLULU, May 4 (AP) -- A C-54 military transport carrying nineteen liberated United States war prisoners from Korea landed at nearby Hickam Air Base at 7:29 P. M. today [1:29 A. M., Tuesday, Eastern daylight time].

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -Senator George D. Aiken said today he had evidence that four subsidized American ship lines "have been violating the law by buying most of their supplies in South America and Australia."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 4 -- Leaders of the Westchester Board of Supervisors moved today to have the county take over operation of the Institute of Applied Arts and Sciences here when the state relinquishes the responsibility on Aug. 31.

BONN, Germany, May 4 (AP) -- The United States High Commissioner's office denied today a charge that it had had investigators for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's Senate Investigation subcommittee trailed during their recent visit to Germany.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- A Defense Department spokesman endorsed today a bill by Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of upstate New York, to legalize wiretapping in cases involving national security.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -The National Geographic Society reported today that its entire mapmaking program -- 10,000,000 maps a year -- had been threatened by a pigeon intent on motherhood.

Today's new film at a first-run theatre, "The Juggler," a drama of post-war Israel from the Stanley Kramer Company, opens at the Victoria. Heading the cast is Kirk Douglas and Milly Vitale, supported by Paul Stewart, Joey Walsh, Alf Kjellin, Beverly Washburn and Charles Lane.

There is an industrial and scientific wonderland within a 400-square-mile area in New Jersey that is just a stone's throw from New York Harbor. Situated north of the Raritan River and west of the Hudson, this territory probably has the greatest concentration and diversification of industry of any area of comparable size in the world.

Net sales and net profit of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and subsidiaries for the quarter ended on March 31 increased 8 per cent and 53 per cent, respectively, above volumes recorded in the first three months of 1952, it was announced yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, May 4 (AP) -- Wilmer (Vinegar Bend) Mizell, 22-year-old Cardinal southpaw, hurled a two-hitter tonight to beat Pittsburgh, 5 -- 0, and stop the Pirates' winning streak at five games. Solly Hemus hit a homer for the Cards in the seventh. Ray Jablonski had two singles and a triple and scored two Cardinal runs.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 4 -- A fear of "a clash of interests on racial lines" between white and black miners in Northern Rhodesia, leaving "a legacy of bitterness," is the reason given by copper mine owners for the move to abolish race discrimination.

The International Commission of Jurists urged American lawyers last night to join it in "perhaps one of the most bitter crusades in history, the crusade against systematic injustice and the denial of human rights behind the Iron Curtain."

The C. B. S. television network has changed its policy of presenting 'Wry Friend Irma," starring Marie Wilson, as a "live" performance and now will use kinescope film recordings. The change reportedly was made to avoid any fluffs that might occur in a "live" performance.

Fifteen persons, including representatives of business organizations, social service and civic groups, and private home owners took part yesterday in arguments before the City Planning Commission for and against proposals for rezoning the Bronx.
BERLIN, May 4 -- Chemnitz, a leading industrial center in Saxony, was renamed Karl Marx Stadt today by the East German Government.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 4 (AP) -- Housewives in a hoarding panic against a threatened food shortage today swept bare the shelves of most meat and bakery stores throughout the country.
Bonwit Teller keyed a showing of summer fashions by a group of top name designers yesterday to the look of youthful prettiness that American women like.

Carl (Bobo) Olson of San Francisco and Honolulu and Paddy Young of New York finally were matched yesterday for an American middleweight title bout at Madison Square Garden on June 19. Promoter Jim Norris of the International Boxing Club closed the deal after a telephone conversation with Sid Flaherty, Olson's manager. The fight will be over the fifteen-round route.
NEW DELHI, India, May 4 -- The Indian Government is trying to get back from the United Kingdom the famed Kohinoor diamond, which adorns the British Crown.

LOS ANGELES, May 4 -- The 28-year-old son of a famous father will join the Metropolitan Opera next fall. He is Robert Herman, who will assume a newly created post of assistant stage director and assistant stage manager. His father goes under the formal name of Floyd Caves Herman, but followers of baseball in general and of the Brooklyn Dodgers in particular know him better as Babe Herman.

THOSE who refused to be discouraged by forbidding weather, but made the trek to the Beaverkill anyway, were rewarded by the best dry fly fishing of the season over the past week-end, although the hatches were of short duration.

Prof. Albert Einstein criticized Senatorial committees for inhibiting nonconformist thinking yesterday when he received one of five $1,000 awards from Miss Dorothy Shaver, president of Lord Taylor, at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- A series of resolutions, one demanding more effective state laws to eliminate racial and religious discrimination in education, employment, housing and public accommodations, was submitted today to the twentieth triennial convention of B'nai B'rith, the oldest and largest Jewish service organization in the country.
Sketches of the winners of Pulitzer Prizes and citations follow:
HANOVER, N. H., May 4 -- James B. Reynolds Foreign Scholarships have been awarded to two members of the Dartmouth College senior class and two men who were graduated from Dartmouth in 1948.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 4 (UP) -- Gen. Gonzales de Linares, the French Commander in Northern Indo-China, said the threat had eased to the point where "I am beginning to breathe again." But even as he spoke a Communist column by-passed the main French defenses in Laos, knifed southward through the jungle, over-ran a French outpost and headed for the border city of Paksane, fifty miles away.
Commodity prices closed higher yesterday on the New York Exchanges with potatoes and sugar ending mixed. Volume was light and trading was generally featureless.

Kuhn, Loeb Co., one of the seventeen defendants in the investment banking anti-trust suit, has competed actively for business in recent years, although at one time it did business on the "show window" or "playing hard to get" theory, defense counsel said yesterday at the trial in Federal Court here.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- George W. Stoddard, president of the University of Illinois, said today that educational television must succeed despite charges against it of "creeping socialism." Addressing the first National Conference on Educational Television, he ascribed the charges to "mass neurosis."

DETROIT May 4 -- It has been asserted that the Tigers are the weakest club in the American League. Even at this early stage in the race, the last-place Bengals are so far behind they need binoculars to see the leaders.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 4 -- "Casey at the Bat" was written by Ernest L. Thayer around 1888. It is, for the benefit of those in Outer Mongolia who somehow have missed connections with it, a narrative poem in hiccuping iambic septameter couplets describing, as Milton could, the immortal strike out (with two out in the ninth).

Retail prices for shoes will be decided this week as buyers shop and place fall and winter orders at the Popular-Priced Shoe Show of America, which opened Sunday at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels. Activity was slow the first two days.

MEXICO CITY, May 4 -- While Mexican authorities remained silent on the affair of "the Cuban plotters," the Mexico City press attacked its Government today for wavering from the country's traditionally generous policy of granting political asylum.

For the first time amalgamating in a large exhibition three categories of sculpture -- architectural design, small sculptures and bas-reliefs -- the National Sculpture Society has made a grandiosely comprehensive affair of its annual this year.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Tuesday, May 5 -- Violence involving local long-shore leaders erupted here for the second time within two years late last night when the hiring boss of troublesome Pier 3 was shot dead on the sidewalk near his home.

The departmental trial of Nat Holman, former basketball coach at City College, and two other faculty members was adjourned yesterday until May 25. Gustave G. Rosenberg, chairman of the three-man trial committee appointed by the Board of Higher Education, said that the adjournment was granted at the request of Mr. Holman's attorney, who was busy with other commitments.

GREAT NECK, L. I., May 4 -- The Long Island Professional Golfers Association opened another season with an amateur-pro tournament at the Fresh Meadow Country Club today. A hundred teams took part in the first event shortly after Al Ciuci teed up the first ball to make it official.
Plans are being advanced at frequent meetings for the annual autumn fashion show and card party to be held for the benefit of St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases on Sept. 29 at the Plaza.

Robert F. Wagner, whose illness forced him to retire in 1949 as Democratic Senator of New York after serving in that post for almost twenty-three years, died here early last evening at the home of his son, Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan. He would have been 76 years old next month.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Federal Court of Appeals ruled today, in effect, that the Civil Aeronautics Board, in setting mail subsidy payments, must take into account all income of an air carrier. It handed down two rulings on substantially the same point.

John V. Lyon, chairman of the New York Shipping Association, announced yesterday that the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and that union's Local 333, made up of tugboat workers, had rejected a proposed settlement of an unfair labor practice charge filed by the association in connection with the tugboat strike last February.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- In a test case involving the issue of immunity of the Federal Government from taxation by a state, the United States and the Esso Standard Oil Company lost a $4,000,000 tax suit in the Supreme Court today.

Three hold-up men, two of them brandishing pistols, took $2,375 from Loew's Valencia Theatre in Jamaica. Queens, yesterday and left the assistant manager, Henry Shamp of 212-08 Seventy-fifth Street, Bayside, Queens, tied up with twine on the floor of his office.

The city's annual spring clean-up drive got off to an unusually timely start yesterday, as Mayor Impellitteri urged the public to spruce up the area, and the Department of Sanitation staged a parade carrying the same message to throngs throughout Manhattan.

MILWAUKEE, May 4 (UP) -- Heavyweight Dan Bucceroni of Philadelphia went into the ring win a 17-pound weight advantage and scored a technical knockout over Wes Bascom, St. Loius light-heavyweight, in the Milwaukee arena tonight.

Your recent editorial indicates most New Yorkers agree that their city is the filthiest in the world. No useful purpose can be served by further discussion of whether Miss Ferber's indictment is true or false. However, if New York is not as clean as we would all like it to be, an examination into some of the important factors involved in the city's sanitation problems is in order.

The route of the Fourteenth Street crosstown bus line of the New York City Omnibus Corporation was changed yesterday to include Clinton Street. Buses had been banned on Clinton Street since last November. Merchant protests and complaints by parents brought the route shift.

A small collection of new fabric designs which, in their cheerful colorings or airy patterns might be useful in adding a summer touch to rooms, is available through decorators at Knoll Associates, 575 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Eisenhower's plan for economizing in defense expenditures is expected to materialize later this week with recommendations for reducing the armed forces by about 200,000 men, and for a saving roughly estimated tonight at $2,400,000,000, in the fiscal year 1954, beginning July 1.

Two of Northern Rhodesia's leading copper mines have asked the all-white Northern Rhodesia Copper Miners Union to lift its color bar, a step expected to have far-reaching consequences on race relations in Central and South Africa.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 4 -- Trygve Lie, former Secretary General of the United Nations, announced today that he would return here in September to attend the early weeks of the General Assembly in a private capacity, and that he would afterward give twenty-five lectures on the organization and on the world situation in different parts of the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Eisenhower told the new Egyptian Ambassador today that the efforts of the Government of Premier Mohammed Naguib to meet the domestic and foreign problems of that country had made "a deep impression on the American people."

It will be "absolutely necessary" to increase the transit fare to more than 15 cents before July 30 if the city's system is to be operated on a self-sustaining basis under the existing provisions of the New York City Transit Authority Law, Controller Lazarus Joseph charged yesterday.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May (AP) -- Harvie Ward and Frank Stranaham -- top threats to carry Britain's biggest amateur golf title back to the United States -- are in the sharpest bracket for the British amateur tournament and could meet in the fourth round.
ROME, May 4 (AP) -- Invaders from the West began taking charge of the Italian international tennis tournament at the start today.

A brother and sister, missing from their Brooklyn home since last Friday, were found asleep last night on a starway at 783 Ninth Avenue, but the boy had disappeared again before the police arrived there.

Leopold Ingber, 36 years old who had been convicted in the shooting on Oct. 22 of his former business partner, was sentenced yesterday to fifteen to twenty years in state prison on the rare charge of attempted murder in first degree.

PARIS, May 4 -- The Government attempted today to end a strike of merchant marine officers by conciliation, but with no immediate result. Shipowners rejected a demand for a forty-hour work wek and proposed a slight modification of present system of annual leaves, which would lengthen them for some of the personnel.

The nation's steel mills have scheduled operations for this week at 100.3 per cent of theoretical capacity, matching last week's actual production rate, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. Thus, this week's output is expected to equal last week's 2,262,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings.

Two Department of Agriculture inspectors and nineteen persons engaged in the egg industry were indicted yesterday on charges of conspiracy to defraud the Federal Government, it was announced by United States Attorney J. Edward Lumbard.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The supporters of state claims to ownership of offshore oil lands attacked the charge that they were proposing a multi-billion dollar "giveaway" today.

EGON FRIEDELL called Hans Christian Andersen "a poet so profound that children could understand him." In something of that spirit Friedell wrote his own singing chronicle of man and his lost paradises, "A Cultural History of the Modern Age,"* whose first volume Knopf has just reissued with a superb introduction by Alfred Polgar.

WASHINGTON, May 4(UP) -- Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey said today that the Government would impose an extra duty on wool tops imported from Uruguay. The amount and other details will be announced in a few days.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Forty-six local housing authorities will call for bids for $123,000,000 of new housing authority bonds on May 26 at 2 P. M. (Eastern daylight time).

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- When President Eisenhower flies to New York Thursday night to make two political speeches, he is going to use a commercial plane instead of the Presidential transport, the Columbine.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Secretary of Labor Martin P. Durkin upheld today the right of Korean war prisoners to their old civilian jobs even though their total absence exceeded the four-year limitation in the Universal Service Law.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 4 -- Outright elimination of motion pictures produced by the Federal Government for propaganda purposes in foreign countries at a saving of millions of dollars was urged today by Eugene W. Castle, founder and first president of Castle Films, who is now an investment banker in New York.

The Propeller Club urged President Eisenhower yesterday to appoint a shipping official to a proposed commission that would study all existing legislation -- and the regulations and administrative procedures stemming from it -- that bears on this country's foreign economic relations.

The governing boards of both. the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies and the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York voted yesterday to support a slate of eleven opposition candidates for membership on the board of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City.

LOS ANGELES, May 4 -- American scientific progress is in serious danger today because of fear-inspired rumors, unjust accusations and ill-advised investigations growing out of the tensions of the "cold war," Dr. D. Ewen Cameron, president of the American Psychiatric Association, warned today.

Skitch Henderson, band leader, pianist and radio personality, entered a new field last night when he led seventy members of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony in the first of a series of five Pops concerts at Carnegie Hall.

YONKERS, May 4 (AP) -- The largest daily double of the Yonkers Raceway meeting, $521.70, came up tonight with the combination of Beau Maplecroft and Freddy Chief in the first and second races. Beau Maplecroft returned $20.50 and Freddy Chief $45.90 for $2.
Of the 423 voluntary agencies helped by the Greater New York Fund, seventeen maintain infor mation and referred services to which anyone may go for guidance.

The first general public appeal in New York City for funds to support voluntary services for mental health is under way. National, state and local organizations have joined forces in a campaign to raise money through the Mental Health Fund to fight one of the most terrible illnesses of man.

Public offering of 1,000,000 shares of new common stock of Tennessee Gas Transmission Company will be made today by an underwriting syndicate of 115 investment houses headed by Stone Webster Securities Corporation and White, Weld Co. The stock is priced at $22.75 a share.

BOMBAY, India, May 4 (AP) -- A policeman foiled an attempt to assassinate Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today when he picked up a live bomb from a railway track in the locomotive headlight glare of the Indian leader's own onrushing train.
HOLLYWOOD, May 4 (AP) -- Wives of sports people are usually regarded as remote accessories to the sports picture.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The United States was reported tonight to be in favor of reopening diplomatic conversations with the Soviet Union, Britain and France in the near future on the question of a state treaty for Austria.

An agreement providing for wage increases ranging from 5 to 13 cents an hour for 16,500 Western Electric Company employes in forty-three states was announced here yesterday. A spokesman for the company said the settlement had been reached after six weeks of negotiation between Western Electric officials and District 10 of the Communications Workers of America, C. I. O.

Swoop of the Hide Tide Stable registered a debated victory in the King Saxon, the classified handicap that served as the feature race at Jamaica yesterday. The 4-year-old son of Sky Raider had a lead of two and a half lengths over Ogden Phipps' Ancestor at the finish of the mile-and-a-furlong event, and Adele L. Rand's Anchor Man was third, almost a length in back of Ancestor.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 4 (AP) -- A leading political opponent of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh ducked into the sanctuary of Parliament today after his nephew had been charged with having led the plot that ended in the murder of Gen. Mahmood Afshartus, Teheran's Chief of Police.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Eisenhower and other high Administration officials gave a secret briefing on foreign policy moves to forty-four state and five territorial Governors today and asked their advice on future action.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, through their unity subcommittees, have agreed to give up raiding each other's unions, and the C. I. O. announced it was revamping its field set-up to put more emphasis on organizing the unorganized.

Albert I. Rosenquist has been elected president of the Wilson Jones Company (Canada), Ltd., Toronto subsidiary of the Amencan record-keeping equipment concern. He was formerly with Mont-! gomery Ward and /vrandel Brothers of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved five nominations including Walter Bruchhausen to be Federal District Judge for Eastern New York and John O. Henderson to be United States Attorney for Western New York.

AMAGANSETT, L. I., May 4 -- The offer of free potatoes to non-profit institutions, made by a group of twenty Suffolk County farmers who have 300,000 surplus bushels that are subject to spoiling soon, was met today with eager response from at least fifty institutions in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Howard S. Cullman made public yesterday a letter sent to Mayor Impellitteri in support of proposals to permit construction of theatres in apartment and commercial buildings to replace "rookeries."

A compatible, three-dimensional color television system is being developed by the Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., Dr. Alien B. Du Mont, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

Net income of the Consolidated Natural Gas Company dipped to $8,828,565, or $2.40 a share on its 3,683,285 shares of common stock outstanding, in the first three months of this year. In the like 1952 period net was $10,347,753, or $3.16 a share on the 3,274,031 shares then outstanding.
A high official of the State Communist party declared yesterday that the party no longer maintained membership lists or rosters "that stool pigeons could use to prosecute members."

AS later events unfortunately were to prove, the discussion was merely academic without any immediate pertinence. But the conversation is worth repeating because it can be filed away for future use and because it supplies a fundamentally sound slant on that ever-perplexing question of greatness.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 4 -- An armed force of 200 to 300 terrorists of the Mau Mau secret society wiped out one of the strongholds of the home guard of their fellow Kikuyu tribesmen last night. At least nineteen guardsmen of the unit, which was under the command of Chief Stefano, one of the most prominent of Kikuyu leaders loyal to the Kenya Government, were killed.

The city's two-month city-wide program of free blood tests to discover unreported cases of syphilis opened yesterday morning on the edge of Chinatown. Business at the four sidewalk clinics was anything but brisk.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 4 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has decided to play the field in regard to new screen techniques. A flexible production policy calling for the making of thirty-four features during the next eighteen months was defined today by Dore Schary, vice president in charge of studio operations, at the end of four days of meetings with home office executives from New York.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Government announced today a contract with the Molybdenite Corporation of Canada, Ltd., Montreal, under which it has an option to buy up to 6,000,000 pounds of molybdenite during the next five years.

France's municipal elections have again provided a major political swing. The previous local elections in 1947 saw the newly formed Rally of the French People, which was General De Gaulle's political organization, shoot up like a rocket. The elections for local Councilors held last Sunday and the Sunday before saw that rocket plummet downward.
CHICAGO, May 4 (AP) -- The International Harvester Company today announced price reductions of $87 to $152 on its R-line model trucks.

Ernest Hemingway, a major novelist since the Nineteen Twenties, and William Inge, whose first play on Broadway was produced only three years ago, won the 1953 Pulitzer Prize for fiction and drama -- for "The Old Man and the Sea" and "Picnic," respectively -- it was announced at Columbia University yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The National Milk Producers Federation conceded today that foreign nations must sell to America, but insisted that imports should not add to surpluses in this country.

BALTIMORE, May 4 (AP) -- Jockey Nick Shuk, Maryland hottest rider, gained his third winner on Pimlico's opening-day program today by guiding Mrs. Samuel M. Pistorio's Brazen Brat to victory over Sweet Vermouth.

LONDON, May 4 -- A spokesman for the British Government rejected proposals in the House of Commons today that some other member of the United Nations, in addition to the United States, should be represented at the Korean armistice talks, and that the negotiations should be put in the hands of high-ranking politicians.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on the constitutionality of the 1946 Federal Lobbying Registration Law, which was designed to help Congress evaluate the arguments of so-called "pressure groups."

Mrs. John Powers has had so many children in the last twenty-seven years that she wasn't quite sure of the number until an official of the Children's Aid Society, honoring her yesterday as Foster Mother of the Year, told her. It was fifteen, not fourteen, as Mrs. Powers had thought.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Supreme Court held today that the "Jaybird primary," which has been held regularly in Fort Bend County, Tex., since 1889, was a device to bar Negroes from voting and dodge the guarantee of the Fifteenth Amendment that the right of citizens to vote shall not be denied or abridged because of race.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today ordered resentencing of Harold R. Christoffel, former Milwaukee labor leader convicted of lying when he denied Communist party affiliation.

ROME, May 4 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce presented to President Luigi Einaudi at noon today the credentials that accredit her as the new United States Ambassador and the first woman to represent any foreign country in Italy as head of a diplomatic mission.
The first four months of 1953 would have found Noah just about in his element.

RYE, N. Y., May 4 -- The Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association opened its 1953 season under sunny skies and with a field of eighty-six contestants today over the south course of the Westchester Country Club.

The Giants and the Redlegs spent the better part of five hours belting each other all over the Polo Grounds yesterday only to wind up right where they started, in seventh and eighth places, respectively.

Warren Neuberger, the league's leading hurler, unfurled a two-hit shutout yesterday as City College toppled Brooklyn College, 8 to 0, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game at Macombs Dam Park in the Bronx. The victory brought C. C. N. Y.'s record to 7 and 2 in loop play and solidified its hold on first place.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 4 -- Four hundred thousand disabled persons in New York, New Jersey, Delaware and Pennsylvania could return to work if sufficient funds were available to provide vocational rehabilitation for them, it was reported here today at the opening of the Region 2 conference of the National Rehabilitation Association.

TROY, N. Y., May 4 -- Departmental trials of four New York City public school teachers who were suspended for refusing to answer official questions concerning alleged Communist activities were delayed today by a court order handed down here.

The fourth annual entertainment known at Le Bal Blanc was held last night in the Carnaval Room of the Sherry-Netherland. Proceeds will be used to purchase new equipment and materials to further the vocational program of the House of Free Russia, Inc., 349 West Eighty-sixth Street, which was founded by the Russian-American Union to educate and shelter displaced refugees.

Worried over the slim attendance thus far this season, the National League club owners met at an informal session yesterday at the Hotel Commodore to discuss the advisability of beginning the 1954 season a week later.

LUANG PRABANG, Laos, May 4 -- Vietminh forces held off their expected assault against Luang Prabang today and suddenly sent a spearhead driving southward toward Vientiane, the Government seat of this Indo-Chinese Kingdom of Laos.

The Pulitzer awards are always interesting, and this year is no exception to the rule. We at THE TIMES are naturally pleased over the recognition accorded the Sunday Review of the Week section of this newspaper. The Review of the Week represents an effort to give as objectively as possible the background of the news in order to help the reader understand its meaning.

" Winston Churchill -- The Era and the Man," a new book by Virginia Cowles. will be published by Harper on May 27. It is an account of the Prime Minister's early days, of the influences "brought to bear" upon him as a young man and of his "prodigious career.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 (AP) -- Del Ennis blasted a homer and a three-run double to lead the Phillies to an 8-4 victory over the Cubs tonight for a sweep of the three-game series. Willie Jones also contributed a homer. The triumph put the Phils in undisputed possession of first place in the league race.

This is the first Tuesday of May, and tonight the schoolhouse lights in many non-metropolitan communities will burn both long and brightly. For tonight is the time of the Annual Meeting, that occasion when taxpayers of school districts come together to consider some of the unpleasant phases of education.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, angrily shut off the testimony of a State Department official today and abruptly terminated a public hearing of the Senate Investigations subcommittee. The Senator charged, in effect, that the witness opposed moves to halt all sea traffic to Red China and Soviet bloc ports by vessels owned by Allied shipowners.

The Greatest Show on Earth and the greatest audience on earth met yesterday morning at Madison Square Garden and the result was a deafening two-hour mutual admiration session. Fifteen thousand youngsters from hospitals and social agencies packed the Garden for the circus' special children's performance.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 4 -- Selecting the $10.50-a-gallon Federal excise tax as their chief target, speakers at the opening day's sessions of the National Conference of State Liquor Administrators opened a drive for lower liquor taxes today.
PHILADELPHIA, May 4 -- The three judges of Philadelphia's Common Pleas Court No. 6 unanimously upheld the constitutionality of Pennsylvania's Loyalty Oath Act today, but said they did so reluctantly.
Letters received here yesterday by airmail from Cairo were prepaid with Egyptian stamps overprinted with three black bars that almost obliterate the features of former King Farouk I.

TUNIS, Tunisia, May 4 -- Despite the silence still enveloping the police inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the assassination Saturday of Chadley Kastalli, Vice President of the Tunis Municipal Council, there were persistent rumors today to the effect that a highly ramified terrorist organization was being taken apart, piece by piece.

LONDON, May 4 -- A local census among breeders of the famous Manx, or tailless cats on the Isle of Man in the Irish Sea, has shown that they are dwindling in numbers and may be in danger of extinction.

President Eisenhower has sought to avert or at least postpone a struggle within the Republican party by requesting an extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act for another year as an "interim measure" while a bipartisan commission undertakes a broad study of our foreign economic policy.

Would it not be proper to remind Carmine DeSapio, whose "sweetness and light" letter appeared in the April 30 issue of THE TIMES, that the position of your newspaper in the forthcoming Mayoralty election is probably based, in the main, upon the history of the party he heads?

Net profits of New York's state-chartered banks and trust companies last year exceeded those of every year since 1946, increasing by almost one-half over the 1948 low-point, according to data issued yesterday by William A. Lyon, Superintendent of Banks.

PARIS, May 5 -- The strike of French merchant marine officers spread to Marseilles-today, as had been expected. The stoppage, which began at Le Havre a week ago, has thus grown to a point where it is bottling up the major part of France's merchant fleet in Atlantic and Mediterranean ports.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 5 -- A Thai military representative said here today his Government in Bangkok was starting to evacuate all male Vietnamese nationals of military age from sensitive border positions inside Thailand along the frontier separating Thailand from Vietminh-invaded Laos.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 5 -- Turkey will produce from $7,500,000 to $8,000,000 worth of artillery shells for the North Atlantic Treaty forces under the first offshore procurement contract to be concluded between Washington and Ankara.

Investors have purchased the five-story apartment house for sixteen families on lot 40 by 62 feet at 1291-93 Madison Avenue, southeast corner of Ninety-second Street, from David S. Weister, who bought the property recently. There are three stores in the property, which is assessed at $100,000.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 6 (AP) -- The 4,190-ton British steamer Duke of York and the United States freighter Haiti Victory collided just before dawn in the North Sea today and first reports indicated that the British vessel was sinking.

United States Attorney J. Edward Lumbard called on a Federal Court jury yesterday to find Gerhard A. Puff, 38-year-old bank robber, guilty of the "premeditated and wanton" killing of a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UP) -- An Indiana electric company has become the first Rural Electrification Administration borrower serving only farmers to pay back its debt in full, the Department of Agriculture announced today.

Saul K. Padover, biographer of Thomas Jefferson and editor of "The Complete Jefferson," has a new work on Harper's list that deals with another famous figure in American history, James Madison. Entitled "The Complete Madison," the volume presents a collection of the writings of our fourth President with emphasis on Madison's concern with political and social issues.
City officials and civic leaders joined yesterday in supporting the improvement of the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx as a picturesque park and a center of research in the scientific field.

As the Welfare and Health Council of New York City approached its election tomorrow with partisans of the Planned Parenthood Committee of Mothers Health Centers seeking to reverse the council's exclusion of that group by electing their own slate of directors, two incidents pointing up the controversy occurred yesterday.

Several influential Democrats are urging the nomination of Associate Judge Charles W. Froessel for chief judge of the Court of Appeals as a means of helping local Democratic candidates for municipal offices in New York, Buffalo and other cities.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 5 -- A new disease entity, manifested by a lack or severe shortage of gamma gloubulin, the fraction in blood plasma essential for the production of immunity agents against bacterial and virus infections, was described here today at the annual meeting of the Association of American Physicians.
GENEVA, May 5 -- The United States steel industry has been paid a high tribute from a quarter that may somewhat surprise its leaders.
IT REALLY looked like a comedy act. Al Schacht wouldn't have done a better job of burlesque than Sam Calderone did on that one embarrassing day in Phoenix. However, it was entirely unintentional.

Italo Scortichini, 154 3/4 pounds, Rome, scored an upset in outpointing Jerry Dreyer, 149 3/4, Pretoria, South Africa, the British Empire welterweight champion, in the main bout of ten rounds last night at Ridgewood Grove, Brooklyn. The setback was the second in thirty-five bouts for Dreyer.

Your editorial of April 22 disparaging the decision of the Subversive Activities Control Board in the case of the Communist party and belittling the resultant controls gives further circulation to misconceptions unfortunately already too widely current as to the work of the board and the provisions of the Internal Security Act under which it operates.

LOUISVILLE, May 5 (UP) -- Jockey Al Popara tonight expressed disappointment at Eric Guerin's attitude toward the bumping of Native Dancer in Saturday's Kentucky Derby. Popara blamed the incident on "racing luck."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 5 -- Somewhere on Lexington Avenue, in the Forties, there is a grocery store whose back room has a small place in the history of the Republic of Indonesia.

PARIS, May 5 -- The tramp steamer, with its salt-caked smokestack, butting through the seas of the Orient, has been a subject of literary romance well garnished by Masefield, Kipling, Maugham and Conrad.
The ban on new public housing voted by the House of Representatives would be a "calamity" for New York, costing it 24,000 apartments now planned. Mayor Impellitteri said yesterday.

Higher interest rates in this market are being reflected in the decreasing premium of the Canadian dollar over the United States dollar. After reaching a high point on Aug. 13 last year, when the premium was 4 11/32 cents, the Canadian currency has dropped so that yesterday's decline of half a cent brought it to a half-cent premium.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., May 5 -- Mrs. James R. Dunne was starting to take four of her five children to school this morning when John Shelley, a neighbor, came running up to the car. "My wife, Barbara, is giving birth prematurely," he said. "Can you help her?"

William Spier, who produced "Omnibus" during its first season on television, has left the program to produce a new drama series entitled "Medallion Theatre," which will begin over the C. B. S. television network July 11, from 10 to 10:30 P.M.

The bond market floundered again yesterday to lower levels. Government securities sank in the early trading to new lows for the present movement but rallied later, and high-grade corporate debt issues, both undistributed new issues as well as seasoned obligations in the secondary market, were weak again.

Determination of policies on trade is now the most basic problem faced by the free nations, it was asserted yesterday by Warren Lee Pierson, chairman of Trans World Airlines and of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 203 Korean war casualties in a list that included thirty-one killed, 157 wounded, nine missing and six injured. The following were from New Jersey and Connecticut (none from New York):

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, Speaker of the House of Representatives, said tonight there would be "no meat-axe approach" in the cutting of the Federal budget. He emphasized that the reduction of waste in no way implied the slashing of the Federal budget below "that minimum consistent with our national security and with our basic foreign and domestic obligations."

The Radio Corporation of America put on one of its best shows yesterday in the country's largest single television studio at Radio City. Occupying Studio 8-H of its subsidiary, the National Broadcasting Company, R. C. A. held its annual meeting of stockholders before a near-capacity audience of more than 700.

ROME, May 5 (UP) -- Maureen (Little Mo) Connolly, the 18-year-old Californian who holds the Wimbledon, American and Australian tennis titles, made her first Continental singles appearance today and defeated Maria Maura Veronesi of Italy, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 0, in the second round at the Italian championships.

The salesman who dislikes, distrusts or ignores advertising of his product suffers a self-imposed handicap, according to the latest issue of "Sales Reminders," published by National Sales Executives. Advertising, says the publication, actually is salesmanship in print, and is a definite help both in preparing the ground for the salesman's canvass and in backing up his efforts.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UP) -- Federal Housing Administrator Albert M. Cole said today that he might ask Congress to make it easier to buy a Government-insured home. He could do this by lowering down payment requirements on F. H. A.-insured houses and by raising maximum mortgage insurance on these houses.

It is possible that no lawyer scoring a brilliant victory in his calling ever received quite the measure of praise that the talented artists' group of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York earned yesterday at the opening of its annual art exhibition.

STRASBOURG, France, May 5 -- Meeting here for the first time in more than a year, the Committee of ministers of the fifteen-nation Council of Europe will be confronted once again tomorrow with the problem of making progress toward the unification of Europe.

" Gunsmoke" is a radio program that has been called the "High Noon" of broadcasting. The analogy is overstretched a bit but it is not too far wide of the mark. Certainly as Westerns go on the air, be they on radio or television, "Gunsmoke" is different.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 5 (AP) -- R. P. Levy's Hueso won the Jersey Trial by five lengths today at Garden State Park before a crowd of 19,946. Better Goods was second in the mile-and-a-sixteenth prep for Saturday's $30,000 added Jersey Stakes.

REPORTS from the salt water front seem to be improving each day, for the mackerel are definitely arriving in increasing numbers off Brielle, N. J., pollock are off Block Island in good numbers, and a few weakfish were reported from Peconic Bay yesterday.

New issues of public utility and industrial securities valued at more than $62,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The offerings include two issues of debentures totaling $38,000,000, and two new issues of common stock. Money raised by the issuing companies will be used to finance expansion. The offerings are as follows:

Seven men were held yesterday as material witnesses in the latest flare-up of violence along the turbulent Hudson County waterfront. This was the slaying of a 45-year-old pier hiring boss, John Francis Kelly, near his home at 131 Park Avenue, Hoboken, late Monday night.

United States Lines Company and consolidated subsidiaries, owners and operators of two luxury passenger liners and 46 dry cargo carriers, cleared a consolidated net profit of $10,511,423, equal to $6.95 a common share in 1952, according to the annual report released yesterday by John M. Franklin, president.

The Berg Collection at the New York Public Library is offering something unique in exhibitions. For the first time it has put on view the work of a living author and devoted an entire exhibition to one volume only. The author to be so honored is John Masefield, poet laureate of England since 1930, and the book is his collection of "Salt-Water Ballads."
F. S. Rall has been appointed manager of the appliance department of the Westignhouse Electric International Company.

The World Health Organization in a statement from Geneva says that it has announced "one of the most sensational developments ever recorded in the field of public health." This is the fact that deaths from pulmonary tuberculosis in twenty-one countries have been reduced in twelve years by 50 per cent.

Seven city gardens, deep down in shadows of apartment house walls, or high on windy rooftops, went on exhibit yesterday for a spring tour arranged by the City Gardens Club. Within the small confines of back yard or terrace, early blooms flowered against green backgrounds of shrubs hardy enough to withstand a city's seasons, in designs either rustic or formal.

THE unsuccessful artist or writer who faces up to life in his maturity, admits that youthful enthusiasm and art are not exactly synonyms and turns into a successful business man is a common phenomenon in our culture. The successful business man who closes his factory door when profits are still rolling in, sits down at a brand-new typewriter and becomes a successful novelist is a somewhat rarer specimen.

The President has recently proposed and a group of Republican Senators has introduced emergency legislation to permit 240,000 refugees, most of whom are now crowded in free territory in Europe, to enter the United States during the next two years outside the quota system.

A one-story taxpayer building on plot 110 by 115 feet at 40-46 North Franklin Street, Hempstead, L. I., was purchased by a syndicate of investors from the builders in a deal negotiated by Samuel Simms and Jerome C. Mayer, brokers.

CHICAGO, May 5 (AP) -- The hog market climbed higher today in a continuation of yesterday's activity but uneven trade. Slaughter steers and yearlings were uneven. Slaughter lambs were fairly active. Department of Agriculture reports on today's trading here:
President Eisenhower will speak tomorrow night to 4,000 Republicans at twin $100-a-plate dinners at the Astor and Waldorf-Astoria Hotels under the auspices of the New York State Republican Committee.
TOKYO; Wednesday, May 6 (AP) -- United Nations Headquarters communique 1,606, for Tuesday:
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was barely steady yesterday and closing prices on active months were 12 to 25 points net lower than on Monday.

Two hundred acres of land near Mahwah, N. J., in northwestern Bergen County hard by the New York-New Jersey state line, have been acquired quietly in the last two weeks at what are locally said to be record prices for industrial plant site purposes.

TENAFLY, N. J., May 5 -- Police Lieut. Joseph Faley was cruising in his prowl car in East Railroad Avenue at 3 A. M. today when his headlights suddenly revealed a teen-age boy striding purposefully in the direction of near-by Closter.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 4 -- A decision to divide the collective settlement of Ein Harod between members of the Mapai and Mapam parties was announced tonight after nine months of deliberation by a nine-man secretariat of the Histadrut, or Federation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The newest member of the National Labor Relations Board said today it was time for a change in the board's policy of permitting a stable, plant-wide bargaining unit to be carved into small craft units.

BOSTON, May 5 -- A $4,100,000 addition to the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston building will be dedicated tomorrow night at exercises to be attended by George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, and other national, state and city officials.

In the opinion of its discoverer, the development of penicillin demonstrated divine providence acting in human affairs. Sir Alexander Fleming said last night that, several times after he discovered the mold in 1929, scientists had begun to study it, but for one reason or other had "chucked" the idea.

According to Pravda, official organ of the Kremlin, the Central and Eastern European nations have obtained their present form of government at the cost of a heroic fight. The truth is that when they were rid of nazism these people had to fight Russian infiltration and Communist terror.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Shippers will pay a charge of 10 cents a hundred pounds to the railroads operating in the East for the delivery or pick-up of less-than-carload freight, if the railroads make use of the authority granted today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, today proposed amending the Taft-Hartley Act to prevent discrimination by an employer or labor union against any worker because of race, religion, color, national origin or ancestry.

All interested parties were eying each other warily here yesterday, waiting for certain definition of the battle lines and issues in what promises to be one of the greatest interstate disputes about garbage ever aired in public.

DETROIT, May 5 (UP) -- Bob Porterfield supplemented ragged pitching with a grand-slam home run today as he paced the Senators to a 14-4 victory over the last-place Tigers before 2,605 fans at Briggs Stadium.
Robert F. Wagner exemplified throughout his long career of public service the high qualities which so many immigrants have contributed like thank offerings to their adopted country.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- State and territorial Governors concluded today a two-day review of the grave international situation with leaders of the Eisenhower Administration.

PARIS, May 5 -- Paquin's summer collection has achieved a pleasing union of American and French expression. This is due to the work of Alan Graham, young American designer whose name is known in New York because of his previous association with Seventh Avenue houses.
PASADENA, Calif., May 5 (UP) -- Bob Richards, 1952 Olympic pole vault champion, amassed 6,740 points today to win the John Muir Junior College open decathlon event.

BONN, Germany, May 5 -- Dr. Werner Naumann and his henchmen, who are held on charges of conspiracy to destroy the West German Republic, represented "an acute danger" to German democracy, Dr. Thomas Dehler, Minister of Justice in West Germany, declared today.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 5 -- The pastor of the National Baptist Memorial Church in Washington, the Rev. Dr. Edward B. Willingham, declared today the Roman Catholic Church was "a major threat to religious liberty as we know the principle in this country."

After waiting patiently to get going with "The Little Hut," John C. Wilson now is wondering whether Equity's new policy affecting the employment of alien actors will block his presentation. Yesterday he said he would obtain an interpretation from the union regarding the status of the five-character Andre Roussin-Nancy Mitford farce, which has been regaling Londoners since Aug. 23, 1950.
CHICAGO, May 5 (UP) -- Southpaw Mel Parnell stopped the White Sox with five hits tonight as the Red Sox reached Saul Rogovin for eight hits and a 5-1 victory before 11,144 fans.

Assailing McCarthyism as an evil influence, Averell Harriman former Director for Mutual Security, urged the Democratic party yesterday to take a forthright stand on the matter and make it an issue in the Congressional campaigns next year.
LONDON, May 5 (Reuters) -- The world's most antiquated merchant navy is owned by Spain, with Russia a close second, according to a report of a survey by Lloyd's Register of Shipping.

The executive committees of two Customs Service associations adopted resolutions at separate meetings last night urging the Secretary of the Treasury and high Bureau of Customs officials to rescind an order made public Sunday that would permit less intensive examinations of the baggage of arriving ship and air passengers.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UP) -- Federal Judge Matthew F. McGuire ruled today that the Federal Government held joint responsibility with Eastern Air Lines for an air collission that cost fifty-five lives here Nov. 1, 1949.

If the investment banking anti-trust suit had come to court prior to enactment of the 1933 banking and securities legislation, the business record of the time might have shown Sherman Act violations, but not necessarily a general conspiracy such as is now alleged by the Government, Judge Harold R. Medina, presiding at the trial, commented in Federal Court here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The House of Representatives, reversing a previous tentative vote, refused today to give the Attorney General, Secretary of State and Secretary of Commerce blanket and unconditional authority to discharge employes.

LOS ANGELES, May 5 -- Conflicting views concerning the personality effects of brain surgery to relieve the emotional tensions of psychotic patients were expressed here today at the 109th annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Senate ended nearly three months of studying the offshore oil issue and a month of debating it today by voting, 56 to 35, to give the coastal states title to any submerged lands within their historic boundaries to sea.

DEAL, N. J., May 5 -- A 2,800-ton freighter, the Sandra, of Panamanian registry, ran ashore here tonight and was grounded for nearly three hours on the Municipal Bathing Beach at Phillips Avenue. The ship was able to float herself free in the rising tide.

BONN, Germany, May 5 (Reuters) -- The West German Bundestag today approved a bill designed to defend German steel producers against allegedly discriminatory "turnover" taxes in other coal-steel pool countries.
YONKERS, May 5 (AP) -- Cash Kirk, the even-money favorite, won the featured Mount Kisco Purse tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

Several of the materials now most popular for home furnishings are used together in a new collection of pieces introduced here yesterday by Grosfeld House, 215 East Fifty-eighth Street, and available there through decorators. The group, designed by William Breger and Stanley Salzman, architects, combines walnut cases, brass bases, travertine table tops, can insets and glass fronts.

A number of imaginative designs give a fresh look to the twenty-first annual exhibition of work by students and instructors of the Craft Students League of the Young Women's Christian Association, opening today in the Art Gallery of the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel, 106 Central Park South.

Nothing irritates children more than to be scrutinized by an adult -- any adult, kin or friend of the family -- and to hear a voice saying, "My, how you've grown!" with the exclamation point quivering almost visibly in the air.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 5 (AP) -- The Hollywood Turf Club was supported today by the Los Angeles Central Labor Council in the track's controversy with the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 5 -- Three journalists were acquitted today of charges of sedition and fomenting class hatred that were based on a cartoon and articles published in the newspaper The Evening Times of Karachi. Judge Z. H. Lari set aside the charges and drew a clear distinction between politically fair and seditious comment.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- How a sharp drop in the price of rubber nearly upset the 1927 investment of members of the du Pont family and associates in stock of the United States Rubber Company was told today at the du Pont anti-trust trial before Judge Walter J. LaBuy in Federal District Court here.

Netty Simons, composer from New City, N. Y., presented a program of her own compositions last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. They were brief and a little fragmentary, but they revealed a deft and imaginative talent.
