Eric Guerin, rider of Native Dancer, the 7-10 favorite that was beaten by a head in the Kentucky Derby at Louisville last Saturday, lashed back yesterday at criticism directed at him for his failure to win with Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's 3-year-old.

A three-family brick dwelling at 2120 Bay Ridge Parkway in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn was sold by Mollie Waldman to Philip Wishner for cash over a mortgage of $11,000 in a deal negotiated by A. Prince and Irving Prince, brokers.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Two more high officials of the Eisenhower Administration urged Congress today to extend the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act for one year without basic change pending a commission study of foreign economic policy.
ST. LOUIS, May 5 (UP) -- Virgil Trucks pitched an eight-hitter tonight as the Browns scored a 2-1 victory over the Athletics.

TRENTON, May 5 -- Vincent A. G. O'Connor, assistant district attorney of New York County, told a legislative committee here today that syndicate gambling as it existed in Bergen County until 1950 must have had political protection to survive.
Derby Co (Metals Minerals), Inc. British export-import company; Ralph C. Wilson Agency, insurance, in the Fred F. French Building 551 Fifth Ave from the Fred F. Management Co.

MOSCOW, May 5 -- Important simplification of Government apparatus in the Soviet provinces to eliminate "superfluous" intermediate governmental bodies is now under way, according to the provincial press.

NEWARK, May 5 -- A couple of things like a twenty-seventh birthday and preparations for receiving his third Silver Star award, for gallantry and heroism in Korea, threw Louis A. Gaybrant's routine as a taxi driver completely off schedule today.
LONDON, May 5 (Reuters) -- Middlesex and Northamptonshire today ended their match in an exact tie -- only the fourteenth tie in first class cricket during the thirty-five years since World War I.
Warren Giles, president of the National League, said yesterday television might force major league baseball from under the lights back into the daylight.

In the crude village of Nieuw Amsterdam on the tip of Manhattan (circa 1692) a thin Scot, John Baldoon Spratt, brother - in - law of Mayor Abraham DePeyster, walked the poorer parts of the town, "bestowing alms where he thought they were needed."

Fog, accompanied by intermittent showers, delayed harbor traffic here for several hours yesterday morning and caused the cancellation of some flights at LaGuardia Airport and the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

The Dupmag Realty Corporation bought for investment from Harold Litwin and Herman Epstein the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building for sixty-two families on plot 83 by 102 feet at 171 West Seventy-ninth Street and insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Wednesday, May 6 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. William K. Harrison Jr. said that the neutral custodian would be given full details of the arrangements for control of nonrepatriated captives for its approval. He then asked the Communist delegates if, under the terms he had proposed, they would agree to Pakistan as the neutral.

TUNIS, Tunisia, April 29 -- French officials responsible for economic planning in Tunisia are wrestling with the problem of how to make production catch up with a runaway birth rate. They confess to a certain amount of anxiety.

LOS ANGELES, May 5 -- Live entertainment has a future. Even in this community, film capital of the nation, there was excitement last night when three major attractions played at the same time. Los Angeles' own Civic Light Opera opened its sixteenth season with a revival of "Carousel."

With beef in plentiful supply at invitingly lowered prices, this seems the time to satisfy the taste, which most of us share, for steaks. For special occasions there are porterhouse and sirloin, but for everyday fare the less tender cuts -- round, flank and chuck -- can be succulently satisfying.

BONN, Germany, May 5 -- The West German Government has submittal to all member states of the Council of Europe a memorandum complaining about the "unbearable conditions" in the Saar and has charged the Saar Government with violating the United Nations Convention on Human Rights, it was announced officially today.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- The National Boxing Association today considered shuffling its weight alignments to give more fighters a chance at the in-between weight championships.

Jerome Robbins, who created the dances for "The King and I" and other Broadway hit shows, testified here yesterday that he had been a Communist from 1944 until disillusioned in 1947. He named eight other then party members, including Jerome and Edward Chodorov, playwrights.
A slim young man in a gray ensemble that included gloves to match took $7,000 in cash from two women employes of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company yesterday at pistol point and escaped.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 5 -- A new village in which all the men are more than 65 years old and the women more than 60 was dedicated today in a former British Royal Air Force camp in the plain before the Hills of Ephraim, midway between Tel Aviv and Haifa.

LONDON, April 20 -- Smart Englishwomen are selecting a "different" and very chic type of costume for Ascot and the early garden parties. They no longer fancy the trailing chiffon with huge picture hat. Instead their taste runs to the modish dress or costume of silk or sheer.

Assistant District Attorney Julius Helfand, community appeal chairman for the Brooklyn Chapter of the American Red Cross, announced last night that three communities had exceeded their quotas and that ten others had passed the three-quarter mark in the drive for funds.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May 5 (UP) -- Negro church delegates turned to Miami's Negro section for lodgings today after a move to turn over to them an ocean front hotel in an all-white area had been canceled because of telephoned threats to the management.
Mrs. Margaret Noordzy, mother of four and grandmother of three, was named Foster Mother of the Year yesterday by the city's Department of Welfare.

CLEVELAND, May 5 -- Winning the "big" one has been for years a habit of the Yankees. That's how they have won four straight pennants and world championships, and that's how they hope to achieve five in a row -- by beating the club they believe must be beaten.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The following presents in summary form the Administration's foreign aid program for the fiscal year to begin July 1, calling for authorizations totaling $5,828,732,500, a cut of $1,771,267,500 from the $7,600,000,000 estimated for the period by President Truman.

Leo Durocher's plans for lifting the Giants out of their present lowly station of seventh place in the National League received another setback yesterday when rain washed out the concluding test of a listed four-game set with the last-place Redlegs at the Polo Grounds.

The biggest hurdle for the woman lawyer is not passing the bar examinations but getting a job, Miss Alice Sofis said Monday night at a forum on employment problems facing the newly admitted woman lawyer.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 5 -- Although there is little activity around movie studios at present, plans for future productions are going forward as indicated by the acquisition today of three new story properties.
LONDON, May 5 -- With a list of exhibitors taken from the pages of "Who's Who" and "Debrett's," the second "Painting Is a Pleasure" exhibition opened at the Trafford Gallery today.

BERLIN, May 5 -- The Roman Catholic hierarchy in Germany and the heads of Protestant churches in East Germany have taken parallel actions to resist the attempts of the Communist Government to undermine and disorganize their institutions.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 5 -- Stockholders of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation cast their ballots today at a stormy special meeting in the Du Pont Hotel here on the question of whether to retain the system of cumulative voting used in electing the ten-man board of directors.

A proposed local law extending the 3 per cent sales tax to include commercial services will be presented to the City Council within the next two weeks, Lee Thompson Smith, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- James A. Wechsler, editor of The New York Post, turned over to the Senate Investigations subcommittee today a list of names of about sixty persons he said he had known to be Communists between 1934 and 1937 after he had joined the Young Communist League at the age of 18 years.

LONDON, May 5 -- News of improvement in gold and dollar reserves last month helped impart a slightly better feeling to the stock markets today, although there was no accompanying increase in business.
LONDON, May 5 -- A flying ace of World War I hired a small plane today and flew it under fifteen of the eighteen bridges that span the winding river Thames between Blackfriars and Kew.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Following are the texts of President Eisenhower's Message to Congress today asking approximately $5,800,000,000 in foreign aid appropriations, and of the supporting statement by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, before a joint session of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives:

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today postponed until May 26 new hearings in an investigation of Otis Co., Cleveland investment bankers. The inquiry grew out of a collapse of a 10,000,000 stock offering by the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation in 1948.

The New York State Thruway Authority borrowed $125,000,000 in the public market yesterday on bonds maturing serially from 1958 to 1984 at an interest cost of 2.63827 per cent. The transaction marked the first long-term financing by the Authority, which is authorized to bond the state to the extent of $500,000,000 to finance construction of the 427-mile expressway being built to connect Buffalo with New York City.
WASHINGTON, May 5(UP) -- William Olson, New York University instructor of English, refused to tell Senate investigators today whether he recruited students or faculty members for the Communist party.
Hides, wool, zinc, coffee and cottonseed oil showed increased activity yesterday on New York commodity exchanges.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Sloane-Blabon Corporation, hard surface floor coverings division of Alexander Smith, Inc., Yonkers carpet and rug producers, is up for sale, it was revealed here today in applications filed by the Smith company with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

SEOUL, Wednesday, May 6 (AP) -- The battleship New Jersey and three other United States warships bombarded the rubbled port of Wonsan yesterday, crumpling gun positions and touching off tremendous explosions.

Nine contributors of $25,000 or more were inducted as founders of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University at a reception attended by community leaders yesterday at the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street.

CAIRO, May 5 -- Egypt's constitution drafters voted unanimously tonight to offer this country a republican form of government to replace the monarchy that went into eclipse with the exile of King Farouk last July.

Kiss Me Kate carried the top weight of 126 pounds easily in the Firenze Handicap for fillies and mares at Jamaica yesterday, and won the $35,200 event by three lengths. Installed the favorite by the 20,956 fans, Kiss Me Kate showed steady speed through the entire mile and a furlong, and there was no denying her victory once the field headed into the stretch. Her straight price was $6.20 for $2.
CANBERRA, Australia, May 5 -- Australia has decided to call for bids immediately in Australia, Britain, Europe and North America for the second stage of the Snowy Mountains hydroelectric project.

In a letter to Governor Dewey, Mayor Impellitteri demanded yesterday that the expected special session of the Legislature correct the "unfair and onerous" parts of the fiscal program for New York City adopted by the 1953 regular session.
BALTIMORE, May 5 (UP) -- Again II, a 5-year-old invader from Argentina, scored his first victory in this country by leading home five distance runners today in the Pleasant Hills purse at Pimlico.

Twenty-four permanent residents of the Park Sheraton Hotel, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, went to Mid-Manhattan Court yesterday with a summons charging the hotel with harassing them by depriving them of services they had enjoyed formerly. At the hotel's request, the case was adjourned until May 14.

Nothing could be more trite, obvious -- and true -- than to say that the distinguished Canadians who arrive in Washington tomorrow are most welcome. Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent, Lester B. Pearson, Secretary of State for External Affairs (an old friend), and J. W. Pickersgill, Secretary to the Cabinet, will spend three days in Washington attending the first top-level conference between Ottawa and the Eisenhower Administration.

The stock market encountered sufficient selling yesterday afternoon to erase the best part of the gains achieved in early trading. At the close THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average of fifty stocks stood at 184.01, up 0.20 on the day, but below the season's high of 185.09.

The New York City Ballet last night opened its twelfth season at the City Center, and though there was nothing new on the program, there was the incomparable novelty of realizing once again just what a good company this is. Whatever its weaknesses may be, and it has them, its strengths lie in its beautiful style, its respect for craftsmanship, not only choreographic but also musical and mechanical, and its artistic vitality as a whole.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Eisenhower urged support today for a South Korean relief and rehabilitation fund and asserted that United States troops in Korea had been contributing more for this purpose than the people at home.

In this age of conformity we like the idea of awarding prizes for nonconformity. The men who dared to sail westward on an ocean that was flat were nonconformists, and they discovered a new world. The men who fled their homelands to settle that world were nonconformists, and they founded a new civilization.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- O. K. Armstrong, former Republican Representative from Missouri, who received billing in Atlantic City last week-end as the newly appointed Director of Public Affairs for the Stare Department, has not been named to that post. Nor, it appeared today, is he likely to be.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 5 (Reuters) -- William Alexander Bustamente, "strong man" of Jamaican labor, was appointed Chief Minister today under a new constitution which takes the 1,500,000 African, Indian and European people of the colony a step nearer self-government.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 5 -- Elections for local school board officials were held today in Westchester County.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Representative Louis B. Heller, Democrat of Brooklyn, introduced in the House today a bill that would make it lawful for a newspaper man to refuse to divulge his sources of information in Federal Court trials, in Federal grand jury inquiries, and in investigations by Congressional committees. A somewhat similar bill he introduced in 1951 never was reported by the Judiciary Committee.

Sixteen local housing authorities with assistance contracts with the Public Housing Administration borrowed $132,502,000 in the public market yesterday on temporary loan notes at interest costs ranging from 1.65 per cent to 1.84 per cent.

MANILA, Wednesday, May 6 -- The Philippine Foreign Office announced yesterday that it had transmitted through the United States Embassy here specific proposals for a revision of the basic trade agreement between the United States and Philippine Governments.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 6 -- The Communists rejected today a United Nations proposal that all Korean war prisoners be released immediately after an armistice and allowed to settle wherever they chose on the peninsula. Lieut. Gen. William K. Harrison Jr. told correspondents that progress at the tenth session of the renewed truce talks was "zero."
The Duke of Windsor, Bob Hope and many other notable will take part in the pro-celebrity tourney slated for the Meadow Brook Club, Westbury, L. I., next Wednesday.

TORONTO, May 5 (Canadian Press) -- The Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd., Brazil's major public utility, had net profit in 1952 of $42,169,630 (U. S.), about 19 per cent above the $35,233,677 in 1951.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- The pressure of liquidation appears to have subsided in the grain markets, but buying is far from aggressive, investors showing reluctance to follow rallies. The general tone was firm early in the session, with May wheat relatively strong on indications that the many weeks of light country selling is beginning to tell.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 5 (AP) -- Reinforced Vietminh troops continued today their effort to knock out two stoutly defended French-Laotian outposts holding up strong enemy units attempting to join the threatened Communist siege of Luang Prabang, the royal Laotian capital.

Residents of upper Manhattan heard the "Voice of Cleanliness" yesterday, as the Department of Sanitation pursued its spring custom of reminding people to tidy up the town. The appeal for public cooperation goes on all through the year -- with 1,000,000 pieces of literature in English, Spanish, German and Yiddish.

BOSTON, May 5 (AP) -- A State Representative charged today that officials in the Tommy Collins-Jimmy Carter fight were either "in collusion or incompetent." but a legislative committee rejected his recommendations for changes in the state boxing law.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Eisenhower urged Congress today to authorize $5,828,000,000 for new military, economic and technical foreign aid in the fiscal year 1954 through a Mutual Security Program based on "the long-term security of the United States living in the shadow of the Soviet threat."

The situation in Asia has changed as a result of the new offensive in Laos. Not only does this invasion throw doubt on the sincerity of the truce negotiations in Korea. The action of the Communist-led forces in by-passing the royal capital of Luang Prabang and making a dash toward the border of Thailand shows that the little kingdom of Laos is only a route to larger conquests.
The text of the letter from Mayor Impellitteri to Governor Dewey, made public yesterday, follows:

LANGLEY FIELD, Va., May 5 -- A weird collection of giant multi-million dollar "tools" for solving the baffling problems created by the development of 800-mile-and-hour, and faster, airplanes and for studying the flight of long-range guided missiles at speeds of up to 6,840 miles an hour -- nine times the speed of sound -- was exhibited here today.

HONOLULU, May 5 (UP) -- The airlift for sick and wounded former war prisoners neared an end tonight with fifty more men on their way to United States homes or hospitals. Only two of the 149 Americans exchanged with the Communists remain in Tokyo.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 5 -- An 80 per cent premium on industrial exports will be introduced here this month, a delegation representing the manufacturers association was told in Jerusalem today by Finance Minister Levi Eshkol and Commerce Minister Peretz Bernstein.

NEW DELHI, India, May 5 -- Short of nationalizing the industries of the country, the Central Government has been empowered to control effectively all means of production and distribution and regulate prices of commodities.

Older persons need recognition from the community and a change in the prevailing attitudes toward age in this youth-oriented country, Albert J. Abrams, director of the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Problems of the Aging, declared here yesterday.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 5 -- Police surrounded the Karieka market, a large trading center for natives, in suburban Nairobi today and questioned 776 Africans. All but twenty were held as suspected members of the Mau Mau terrorist society.

NORTH BABYLON, L. I., May 5 -- After Dr. James H. Northrup, principal of the public school here, had been charged with "conduct unbecoming a teacher," taxpayers of this school district tonight declared that the accusations against the educator were "biased and unjustified" and demanded suspension action pending against him be dropped.

While the other Dodger regulars went about their personal pursuits yesterday morning as soon as the word was flashed that Brooklyn's game with the Braves had been postponed because of rain and wet grounds, Gil Hodges worked out at Ebbets Field in a determined effort to snap his batting slump.
Thomas Torazo Nishio, 53-year-old Japanese, became an American citizen yesterday in the Brooklyn Federal Court in a class of 270 men and women representing thirty-two nationalities.

Purchases of textiles for the Armed Services have been exceptionally heavy in the last three months, but procurement for the fiscal year ending June 30 will be well below that in the previous fiscal year, it was learned yesterday.

Little likelihood of higher retail prices in popular-priced shoes appeared yesterday. Retailers and manufacturers are each absorbing part of the increased production costs, according to a survey of activity at the Popular Price Shoe Show of America at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels.
Victor Sedor, 10 years old was back with his family in Brooklyn yesterday, enjoying the comforts of home and convinced, as he put it, that "crime doesn't pay."

At a new showcase called the Harlem Musical Theatre, 11 West 125th Street, an energetic all-Negro company is appearing in a revue called "The Year Round." The production opened on April 28 but, at the request of the management, the press was not represented until last night.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Trouble Along the Way," a Warner Brothers comedy-drama with John Wayne, Donna Reed and Charles Coburn, is at the Roxy. Michael Curtiz directed, from a screen play by Meville Shavelson and Jack Rose.

HARTFORD, May 5 -- Connecticut Democrats appealed to the State Superior Court today to declare unconstitutional a law recently passed by the Republican-controlled General Assembly changing the boundary lines of the thirty-six State Senate districts.
NEW DELHI, India, May 6 -- It is all a mistake. Britain can keep the Kohinoor diamond as India does not regard the fabulous stone as an art object.
The Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth sailed early yesterday afternoon, completing her quickest turnaround in this port.
Now that he's seen all the other American League teams, Manager Casey Stengel is convinced that the Yankees will have no easy path to their fifth straight pennant.
CHICAGO, May 6 (UP) -- Southpaw Billy Pierce held the Red Sox to six hits today as the White Sox scored their first victory in four games, 6 -- 2.

Your editorial "No May Day Parade" evokes many regrets in the minds of those who had observed these parades for over fifty years. They remember no disturbing incidents, even when the Left Wingers took part in the parades on the same day with the conservative unions.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 6 (AP) -- A union spokesman said tonight about 450 service employes would go on strike against Yale University at 6 A. M. Daylight saving time, Thursday.
BONN, Germany, May 6 (AP) -- The United States High Commis sion said today that a trimming of occupation functions by July 1 will have cut more than 2,400 Americans and Germans from its payroll.

American exporters were urged yesterday to exercise caution in future business dealings with Brazil after that country clears up its heavy commercial debt with the help of a $300,000,000 loan recently granted by the Export-Import Bank.

ALBANY, May 6 -- Governor Dewey ordered today an immediate study of the request by Mayor Impellitteri and Controller Lazarus Joseph for a special legislative session to revise portions of the city fiscal and transit program adopted by the 1953 Legislature.

LONDON, May 6 -- Within a day or two the three major Western powers will have reached full agreement on the terms of their approach to the Soviet Union and an invitation will be issued for another four-power meeting on the Austrian treaty, according to expectations here.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange was the slowest in six months yesterday in a colorless session. There was a net loss on the day but it was only because four of the stocks in THE NEW YORK TIMES industrial average -- Eastman Kodak, Bethlehem Steel Standard Oil of New Jersey and Westinghouse Electric -- were selling ex-dividend.

The West Indies island of Jamaica has just embarked on a new constitutional status which is worth noting. In the first place, any new development in the Caribbean area is important to us and to the rest of the hemisphere. In the second place, this is an advance toward national independence and democracy in a colonial territory with a nonwhite population.

ROSAMOND LEHMANN'S new novel, "The Echoing Grove,"* is the story of a male Camille and some of the women who loved him. It is bound to be one of the most talked-about books of the year. There has not been such a ruthless exploitation of the fundamental pangs-of-love plot since Dumas and Verdi had done with it a long time ago.

The sixth annual William D. Richardson memorial tourney, sponsored by the Long Island Golf Association, will get under way today at the Seawane Harbor Club, Hewlett Harbor, L. I., with a qualifying round. The tournament is named in honor of the late golf writer of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 6 -- Miss Gertrude L. Warren of Washington, who recently resigned from the United States Department of Agriculture, for which agency she had guided the development of 4-H Clubs, was re-elected president of the Women's National Farm and Garden Association today.

News that the Soviet Chess Federation has accepted an invitation from its American counterpart and will send to this country a top-flight team, headed by world champion Mikhail Botvinnik, is a matter whose interest goes beyond the usual chess competition. The near monopoly of victories gained by the Soviet Union in post-war chess tourneys has been a source of prestige for Moscow.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -- American battle casualties in Korea rose by 395 last week to a new total of 134,805, the Defense Department reported today.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 6 -- A mechanical coughing machine, which automatically coughs up life - endangering secretions accumulating in the lungs and bronchial tubes in a number of serious diseases involving the respiratory tract, was described here today at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the Association of American Physicians.

In spite of the fact that thousands of tenants in New York must pay 15 per cent more residential rent from now on under the new state control law, the regulations in effect in New York are still the most stringent in the country, according to Robert S. Fougner, realty lawyer.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- An effort to have the Senate pass without debate a bill to allow Congressional committees to give their witnesses a blanket immunity from prosecution in exchange for information was blocked today.

The news story carried by THE TIMES on April 2 about the death of Mrs. Leo Arnstein reflected something of the work done by that gallant lady with the young people of New York. Yet a brief news item could not give the full effect of her life story nor its future implications.
BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., May 6 (AP) -- A State Supreme Court jury early today acquitted Victor J. Urquhart, 56 years old, of charges that he ran a horseroom and dice table in Saratoga Springs.

LONDON, May 6 -- Four passengers are believed to have lost their lives when a British passenger ship was sliced in two in a collision with an American freighter in the North Sea early today. Two persons are known to be dead and at least two others of the 500 passengers and crewmen of the British ship were unaccounted for tonight.

GENEVA, May 6 -- A twist has been given to Europe's gloom about the strength of high tariff interests in the United States Congress by evidence that during the last few months some of the most promising results have been registered in the long drive to increase western Europe's dollar earnings from trade.
Motion pictures made by Group 3 Ltd., an experimental production unit sponsored by the British government, will be released in this company by Arthur Mayer-Edward Kingsley, Inc.
LONDON, May 6 -- Business remained slack in the stock markets today. Only South African gold mining and oil shares were a little more active and higher.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein granted a motion yesterday to dismiss the complaint in a damage suit brought by James L. Lenahan, former president of the McClure Newspaper Syndicate, for "unlawful sale of his stock in the syndicate, and to enjoin and restrict the sale, transfer and other disposal of the corporate stock."

Tammany will start tomorrow the circulation of petitions demanding that Governor Dewey call a special session of the Legislature to repeal the 15 per cent rent-increase law, Carmine G. DeSapio, leader, announced yesterday.

The Senators who voted for the offshore oil bill have a heavy responsibility on their shoulders. They have voted to give certain states a great natural resource, of vital importance to the national defense, which has always belonged to the Federal Government. They have rejected the proposal to use this enormous wealth for the benefit of all the children of our nation, through federal aid to education.

A two -story one-family dwelling at 2080 Brown Street in Brooklyn has been sold by the Matsen Lake Garage and Restaurant, Inc., to Fannie Scarpelli. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

MOSCOW, May 6 -- The Communist party's leading theoretical organ, Kommunist, declared today that the Soviet policy of seeking a relaxation of tense relations with the West was a long-term proposition and furthermore emphasized that the Soviet Union would not abandon its "moral and political support" of colonial "liberation" movements.

The Simpson bill, if approved, will be the first milestone of the present Administration on the road toward economic isolation. The mining interests supporting this legislation are quite confident. They have made no attempt to becloud the issue by the use of such hackneyed phrases as "to protect infant industries" or "in defense of American labor."

Herbert Bittlingmaier shut out Hofstra College of Hempstead, L. I., with six hits as New York University gained a 5-0 victory yesterday in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference Baseball game at Ohio Field. The triumph enabled the Violets to take third place in the circuit with a record of four victories and three defeats.

The bond market scored its first substantial recovery in more than a week yesterday. United States Government obligations snapped back 1/16 to 3/8 of a point and bids for high-grade corporate bonds in market supply improved by about 1/4 point.

A delayed action bomb, described by the police as the homemade product of a "publicity-seeking jerk," exploded in a parcel and luggage locker at Grand Central Terminal shortly before 5 P. M. yesterday. No one was injured.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Continued advances in payrolls of private industry accounted for most of a $1,500,000,000 increase in personal income in March, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce reported today.
Vietminh forces are spreading across Laos, one of the three Associated States of Indo-China, and Luang Prabang, its capital, has already been surrounded.

NEW DELHI, May 6 -- Russian peace overtures took a social form that was both moist and "cultural" last night when correspondents from Western countries and their wives were invited to the Soviet Embassy for the first time in nearly four years and were asked to share in a vodka toast to United States-Soviet friendship.

Tin and rubber production in Malaya is now but little affected by Communist guerrilla depredations; rail and road communications are on the whole secure and Communist terrorists are harried even deep in the jungles and are decreasing in numbers.

BOSTON, May 6 (AP) -- William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, said tonight the past two years have seen "the almost ideal economic situation" -- with a remarkable degree of economic stability at record levels of employment and production.

BALTIMORE, May 6, (AP) -- Despite two days of recurring showers which left the track thoroughly water-logged, William H. Foales' Just Sidney won the Reisterstown purse at Pimlico today in time only two-fifths of a second slower than the track record.

LOS ANGELES, May 6 -- Claude McCue, West Coast secretary of the American Federation of Radio and Television Artists, A. F. L., said today that a scheduled appearance of Cecil B. De Mille on a national television show had been disapproved by the union because of the film producer's continued opposition to union fiscal policies.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -- Baseball's top brass asked Congress today to help regulate major league television and radio broadcasts before they destroy the entire game.

The Planned Parenthood Federation of America charged the Roman Catholic Church in this country yesterday with "pressure tactics" designed to obstruct the Planned Parenthood program throughout the nation.

The Eisenhower Administration "will not approve a Tennessee Valley Authority for any of our great river basins," Luther A. Huston, a member of the Washington staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES, predicted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- High Administration officials were reported today as ready to recommend the cancellation of the fatherhood draft deferment of men who had previously obtained deferment as students.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- Irenee du Pont's doubts about the future of the tire business were stressed by his attorney today at the du Pont anti-trust trial as the 76-year-old retired chief of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., concluded three days of defense testimony before Judge Walter J. LaBuy in Federal District Court.

HOBOKEN, N. J., May 6 -- Michael McNamara, a material witness in the killing on Monday night of John Francis Kelly, hiring boss of turbulent Pier 3 here, was named today to replace the slain man. He and two assistants, also witnesses in the killing, will supervise the shape-up when the pier reopens tomorrow morning.

TOKYO, Thursday, May 7 -- In the earlier stages of the truce talks, United Nations representatives had shown little enthusiasm for any sort of multi-national control of captives unwilling to be repatriated.

An intensified campaign against local firearms dealers who have been suspected of handling unlicensed weapons has resulted in a drop in their number from 127 to 51 since Jan. 1, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday.
Man accosted two young ladles in Central Park the other day. He said to them: "There's a pair of gnat-catchers over by the Schiller statue."

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Opponents of the Eisenhower Administration's offshore oil bill, passed yesterday by the Senate, remained on the attack today although legislative machinery was readied for completing of Congressional action on the measure by the House of Representatives.

Definite patterns as well as the more expected textured effects are included in a new collection of V'Soske rugs introduced here yesterday at Lord Adams, 43 West Fifty-fourth Street, where they are available through decorators.

Acquisition of land for a section of the Cross Bronx Expressway between Anthony and Longfellow Avenues, the Bronx, was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission. After a heated public hearing on April 23, the Board of Estimate failed to approve the route, but the board is expected to act affirmatively on it at its next meeting, May 14.

After jockey-of-the-day honors had been won by the old maestro, Eddie Arcaro, who scored with his first four mounts, horse-of-the-day honors went to Mrs. Samuel M. Pistorio's Maryland-bred Tuscany yesterday as beauteous Belmont Park opened its spring race meeting with 21,910 winner-hunters in attendance.

A committee to plan a celebration of the 100th anniversary of the founding of Central Park in the week of July 21 was appointed by the Park Association yesterday at its annual meeting at 70 Pine Street.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower will spend the week-end in Central Pennsylvania at the home of his brother, Dr. Milton Eisenhower, president of the Pennsylvania State College.

Demonstrating the "staying" power of ads in printed media, N. W. Ayer Son, Philadelphia, reported yesterday that a recent survey showed school and college ads in directory sections of newspapers and magazines often bring in new students several years after publication.
YONKERS, May 6 (AP) -- Thunderation collared the pace-setting Emerson Hanover on the backstretch and came home a one-length victor tonight in the Yorktown Trot at Yonkers Raceway.

On April 8, last, the Treasury announced its plans for marketing a thirty-year issue of 3 1/4 per cent bonds. Five days later, it may be recalled, a group of nine United States Senators, most of them long identified with the cause of perpetually easy money, issued a joint statement protesting this plan for restoring the free market in the field of Government finance.

The National Labor Relations Board, opening the first formal action of its kind against dock workers of this port, began taking testimony yesterday in its case against the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L. on a complaint of secondary boycott.
MOSCOW, May 6 (AP) -- A young woman student at the Government Motion Picture Institute charged Soviet script writers today with underestimating the power of love.

Gasoline stocks in the nation declined 391,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were reported at 157,599,000 barrels, against 157,990,000 a week earlier.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 6 -- By a vote of 13 to 0, with two abstentions, the Fiscal Commission of the United Nations this afternoon adopted a resolution submitted by Pakistan, recommending that highly developed countries give "sympathetic consideration" to the possibility of relieving its private investors in foreign countries from the burdens involved in double taxation.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- Grains followed an irregular trend yesterday, but met free selling on the hard spots, declining sharply in the late trade. Weakness in wheat influenced the sale of other cereals as well as soybeans. Reports of further deterioration in the west end of the winter wheat belt were bullish but little buying developed.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today the following principal changes for the week ended April 29:

Leaders in the home-building industry predicted yesterday that the higher interest rates now in effect for G. I. home loans and F. H. A.-insured mortgages would free large sums of money for new residential buying and building.

BUFFALO, N. Y., May 6 (AP) -- The House of Delegates of the Medical Society of the state of New York announced its opposition today to "any agreement that might lead to the establishment of a clinic in a tax-supported public housing project."

A thousand policemen, uniformed men and detectives, will augment Federal security agents in guarding President Eisenhower on his three-hour visit to New York tonight. This will be his first trip here since taking office. He is coming to speak at the two $100-a-plate dinners of the Republican State Committee at the Astor Hotel and the Waldorf-Astoria.

NEWARK, May 6 -- Because heads of utility concerns are apt to think of their home-service specialists as "cup-cake experts" and therefore do not place them in key positions, the specialists often do not "get ideas over to women," Miss Clara H. Zillessen, Philadelphia utility consultant, said here today.

CAIRO, May 6 -- Britain and Egypt suspended today negotiations on Egyptian demands for the withdrawal of British forces from the Suez Canal zone after six meetings in the last ten days had produced no progress toward agreement on a basic approach to the problem.

The Third Street Music School Settlement presented a student concert in Town Hall last evening. Major works heard on the program were Purcell's Chaconne, played by the Junior Orchestra under Ralph Shapey's direction; Robert King's "Seven Conversation Pieces," played by a brass ensemble conducted by Simon Karasick, and excerpts from Handel's "Acis and Galatea" performed under the direction of Emanuel Balaban.

A 23-year-old Greek exchange student, who spent his early teens pasting up anti-Nazi slogans in Athens while a member of his country's underground, has turned his talents to putting up posters in his one-man campaign for mass blood donations at Long Island University next Monday.

PARIS, May 6 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle announced today that his party, the Reunion of the French People, henceforth would put up no candidates at elections and would cease to act as a group in parliamentary maneuvers.

PRESQUE ISLE, Me., May 6 -- Aroostook County is "knee deep" in unmarketed potatoes, according to farming sources in this capital of the spud empire, but most folks expect to wade out of them in time to plant just about as many again this year.

BOSTON, May 6 -- Mu Triton Chapter of Phi Sigma Kappa fraternity at Boston University has been suspended by the national board of officers for initiating a Negro among its group of twenty-one spring candidates, officials of the chapter said today.
PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (UP) -- Rain washed out the Phillies-Redlegs game tonight with the Phillies leading, 2 -- 0, in the bottom half of the third inning.

New issues of public utility and finance company securities totaling $23,000,000 will be placed on the market today by underwriting syndicates. The money raised will be used for the most part to retire bank loans. The offerings are:

The Tuberculosis Preventorium for Children at Farmingdale, N. J., will be the beneficiary of the performance of the new musical "Can-Can," Wednesday night at the Shubert Theatre. Miss Jessie Mann heads the benefit committee.

James A. Farley, former Democratic State and National chairman, warned last night that there was grave danger that the Democratic party might become minority party in this state with little influence. He declared that a slow disintegration of the party's power in the state was going on as the result of absentee leadership.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -- Charley Riley, 132 pounds, scored a seventh-round technical knockout tonight over Dave Gallardo, 128 1/2, the top featherweight contender, in a scheduled ten-round bout at Turner's Arena.

MINEOLA, L. I., Thursday, May 7 -- An all-male jury that had deliberated since yesterday morning on forgery and conspiracy charges against William H. Abel, former president of the Central National Bank of Mineola, was dismissed early today in the Nassau County Court after reporting a hopeless deadlock.

A banking syndicate headed jointly by Phelps, Fenn Co. and John Nuveen Co. bought yesterday issues of $6,200,000 of bonds of Pima County, Ariz., school districts. The bid was 100 for interest rates of 3 3/4 per cent, 3 per cent and 3 1/4 per cent, an interest cost of 3.163 per cent.

The annual Olga Samroff Memorial Concert was held last night in the auditorium of the Museum of Modern Art. Three premieres honored the occasion. Richard Franko Goldman's Violin Sonata, in its first pubic performance, was played by the able Joseph Fuchs, with Joseph Bloch, the equally dependable pianist.
PARIS, May 6 -- The French Government is ready to requisition all ships on the Indo-China run if the strike of merchant marine officers, now in its second week, continues much longer.

BERLIN, May 6 -- The Communist Government of East Germany has decided to raise the production norms of industrial workers in an effort to prevent a repetition of the failure to meet the quotas of the Five-Year Plan in the principal branches of industry during the first quarter of 1953.

In the foreign exchange market here the Canadian dollar, which has outranked the United States dollar in value for more than a year, sank to its lowest level in thirteen months. The bottom quotation was 5/16 of a cent above par, the lowest, premium since March 24, 1952.

BOSTON, May 6 -- Dr. Seymour E. Harris, Harvard University economist, said today that the New England Governors Textile Committee, of which he was chairman, had recommended that the six states of the region spend $50,000 to establish a permanent organization to undertake a continuing study of the industry.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- The purchasing job for the once mighty remount section of the armed services has simmered down to one man -- and he is pretty well reduced to buying dogs.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- T. Lamar Caudle, a former Assistant Attorney General, told a House Judiciary subcommittee today that he had recommended dismissal in 1946 of indictments for mail fraud because he and his legal associates became convinced the Government had made a mistake in bringing the action and would be unable to obtain a conviction in court.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 6 (AP) -- Alfred N. Steele, president of the Pepsi-Cola Company, said today his concern had not lent money to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 6 (AP) -- Mrs. Alfred Roberts' Eatontown whirled to a two-length triumph today over a sloppy track at Garden State Park before a crowd of 19,588 in the Frankford Purse.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, said today that changes in the Taft-Hartley Act probably would be held up if an anti-discrimination proposal was made part of. the revision bill.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 6 -- Charitable bequests exceeding $240,000 were left by Mrs. Lulu Flora Tuller of this city, whose will was filed for probate today. Mrs. Tuller, who died on April 28, was the widow of W. Lee Tuller, publisher of the former White Plains Reporter.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- What may be history's first known doodle has been unearthed in ancient Mycenae. It is a figure of a slant-eyed dancing girl scratched on the back of a clay tablet, presumably by a preoccupied Greek business man of the Bronze Age.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Spyros Markezinis, Greek Minister of Economic Coordination here with top Greek economic advisers, completed a full day of conferences with Government officials today by attending a dinner in his honor given by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State. Tomorrow Mr. Markezinis is scheduled to meet President Eisenhower at 11:30 in the morning and again meet with Secretary Dulles in the afternoon.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a vountary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children 8 to 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- President Eisenhower has authorized the accumulation of "substantial stockpiles" of food and fuel and some industrial materials in West Berlin as a precaution against possible renewed blockade of the area, John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today.

One hundred and ten Customs employes in the New York area have been notified they will be dismissed from their jobs on June 30, if a general nation-wide cut proposed by Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey becomes effective.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Administrator, was reported yesterday to be considering changes in the administrative set-up of his organization to handle the flood of inquiries that has poured into the six local rent offices since the new residential rent control law went into effect on May 1.

A coffee shop patterned after the venerable and well-known Caffe Grego in Rome opened recently at 43 West Fifty-sixth Street. It is Orsini's, an establishment with marble-topped tables, red velvet walls and candlelight. Served there are food and drink typical of the Roman coffee hour and modest lunches also in the Italian manner.

Riverdale scored 54 1/2 points to win the fourth annual Van Cortlandt pentagonal track and field championships at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium, the Bronx, yesterday. Horace Mann, the defending champion, was second, with 31 points.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Industries complaining of competitive imports were assured by two members of President Eisenhower's Cabinet today that their petitions for tariff protection by administrative action henceforth would be handled more sympathetically.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 6 -- Dr. Henry H. Kessler, director of the Kessler Institute of Rehabilitation, West Orange, N. J., said here today that social attitudes and legal limitations were seriously handicapping the disabled in an effort to earn a livelihood.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Two witnesses who until recently were top officials of important steamship companies admitted publicly today at a Senate Commerce sub-committee hearing that they had received "goodwill" payments totaling $27,800 from the Jarka Corporation of New York, which held stevedoring contracts with their lines.

A good - natured and boisterous group of Columbia undergraduates besieged the dormitory of their sister institution last night in what they hope would be recorded as the second annual Panty Raid of Morningside Heights.

A favored area for the operation of the sky-writing plane is over Central Park, where many people go for rest but do not find it. The droning noise of the motor, kept up for hours at a time, is an intolerable nuisance.

A syndicate of investors has purchased the sixteen-story office and showroom building at 244 Madison Avenue, southeast corner of East Thirty-eighth Street, from J. Chr. Hupfel, it was announced yesterday by Spear Co., the brokers in the transaction.

Thor Heyerdahl, who recorded his 4,300-mile voyage by raft across the south Pacific in "Kon-Tiki," has a new work on Rand McNally's list tentatively scheduled for June 1. Enttiled "American Indians in the Pacific," the book presents Mr. Heyerdahl's reasons for believing that the peoples living in the far-flung islands of Polynesia all had their origins, centuries ago, in the Americas.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, May 7 (AP) -- Navy dive bombers, flying about 100 miles from Siberia, hurled a mighty blow at an important Communist mining center near North Korea's east coast yesterday and left flaming destruction in their wake.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A Senate Appropriations subcommittee voted today to restore funds for 35,000 public housing units to a 1954 money bill for twenty-three independent agencies. But it sustained many cuts made by an economy-minded House of Representatives.

PANMUNJOM, Korea. Thursday, May 7 (AP) -- General, Harrison, observing that the Allies were seeking a fair armistice based on the principle that no prisoner shall be forced to go home, said: "The Communists admitted that the prisoners shall not be physically removed from Korea.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- The Soviet Union has advised the United States that seven American civilians released from detention in Korea will arrive in Moscow Monday.

TOKYO, Thursday, May 7 -- The Communists backed down today from their demand that all prisoners of the Korean war unwilling to go home be shipped to a neutral country but proposed that a five-nation commission take custody of them in Korea.

General Public Utilities Corporation plans to offer 568,665 additional shares of its common stock to shareholders in June, according to a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The offer will be on the basis of 1 new share for each 15 held on June 2, and the subscription price will be determined just prior to the offering.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6 (UP) -- Dr. Wallace E. Howell, rainmaker of the 1950 New York drought, today offered another product -- sunshine.
HARWICH, England, May 6 (AP) -- Scores of Americans were among the survivors who told dramatic stories of the terror in this potential tragedy of the sea. They said there was no panic.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The United States is ready to study Philippine proposals for a revision of the basic trade agreement between the two countries, but not to commit itself at this time to any particular course of action, officials said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 6 -- Western delegates reported today that although there had been some informal talks, no formal dis cussions had yet taken place here regarding an appeal to the United Nations against the Communist-led threat to Laos.

The fact that there is increasingly little difference today in furnishing a period style house and one that is identified as modern is demonstrated in three model homes scheduled to open Sunday in Hicksville, L. I. The houses, at Broadway and Bethpage Road, were built by Walter G. Stackler and Leonard L. Frank and furnished by Abraham Straus.
ST. LOUIS, May 6 (AP) -- Alva (Bobo) Holloman pitched his way into the record books tonight by hurling a no-hitter for the Browns in his first major league start to beat the Athletics, 6 -- 0.

Net income of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company in the first quarter this year was down $630,000, compared with the like 1952 period, W. A. Mather, president, said at the annual meeting yesterday in Montreal. He attributed the decline partly to a 4.8 per cent decline in traffic volume and partly to higher wage rates not compensated for until March, when a 7 per cent increase in freight rates became effective.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 6 -- The French announced tonight that Communist-led Vietminh forces were withdrawing northward through Laos in a sudden move that may mean their invasion of the kingdom is being abandoned.

Richard H. Balch, Democratic State Chairman, called yesterday on Governor Dewey to demand that the Department of Agriculture hold a hearing for the purpose of including Northern New Jersey in the New York milk marketing area.
CHICAGO, May 6 (AP) -- Butter will sell at bargain prices in five Midwestern states for six weeks starting on May 18.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 6 -- Since 1929 the world's iron and steel industry has expanded consistently, reaching a peak in 1951 of an estimated 285,000,000 metric tons of metal, according to the May issue of the United Nations Monthly Bulletin of Statistics, issued today.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today blamed excessive speed for the rear-end collision of an Atlantic Coastline passenger train with a freight at Fleming, Ga., last Jan. 17.

HANOI, May 6 -- Six United States C-119 "Flying Boxcars," each capable of carrying forty-two fully equipped soldiers or eight tons of cargo, have arrived here from Japan to help the French Air Force carry out its airlift operations in support of the scattered

Laden and enriched, respectively, by out-of-town critical honors and profitable box-office receipts, "Can- Can," the elaborate Feuer and Martin musical presentation, takes up residence this evening at the Shubert Theatre. The first-night curtain will rise at the unusually early hour of 7:30 P. M.

GUSSIE BUSCH tossed a get-acquainted luncheon yesterday at Toots Shor's. Gussie is a new boy on the block. He is August A. Busch Jr., the president of the St. Louis Cardinals, and the wonders of his new post give him a perpetual look of starry-eyed excitement. So the baseball folks gathered to welcome him into the lodge, naturally letting him pick up the tab.

The National Institute of Arts and Letters announced yesterday the election of four distinguished foreigners as honorary associates. They are Bertrand Russell, British philosopher and winner of the Nobel award for literature in 1950; Gian-Carlo Menotti, Italian composer; Charles Le Corbusier, French architect, and Sidonie Gabrielle Claudine Colette, French writer.

FEW people attain greater anonymity than the average professional fly-tier, whose craft reaches its peak only by the perfection of imitation, and whose product is measured in quality by its very lack of originality.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today that the United States had consulted with other governments on possible United Nations actions for meeting the Communist invasion of Laos.

Plans for a $6,485,000 housing development to be known as Coney Island Houses were approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission. The multi-building project, to accommodate 420 families near the southernmost tip of Brooklyn's shore, will be put under construction early next year.
Dean Spain has been elected president of the Standard Diary Company, and Lester Madans sales manager.

The Joint Finance Committee of the Connecticut General Assembly has recommended passage of the LeMaire-Cowles Bill authorizing the issuance of public revenue bonds to finance the expressway proposed to extend from the New York State line near Port Chester to the Rhode Island line near Killingly.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -- A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee said today that United States aid to Pakistan and India "cannot be effective" until the two countries "reach a settlement of the problems between them."

Because of the demand for information about the New York season of the Sadler's Wells Ballet, which is to open at the Metropolitan Opera House on Sept. 13, S. Hurok, impresario of the company's American tour, has announced the complete repertory of the local engagement four months in advance.

Pink figured importantly in the Bonwit Teller showing of summer fashions yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Teamed with white in prints or used alone, it was glimpsed in a whole bevy of crisp, full-skirted cotton frocks with pretty scoop necks, as well as stalk-slim sheaths.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 6 (AP) -- All the favorites, led by second-seeded Don McNeill, gained the quarter-final round of the Bermuda invitation tennis tournament today.
ALBANY, May 6 -- More than 60 per cent of the New York State income tax is paid by only 6 per cent of the taxpayers, the State Tax Commission reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 -- As a privately owned and operated steamship company for the first time in fourteen years, the American President Lines released its annual report today for the fiscal year ended on Dec. 31, 1952.

DACCA, Pakistan, May 6 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali will face his first test of political strength tomorrow when he is scheduled to arrive here from Karachi for a series of meetings with the powerful Moslem League party leaders of East Bengal Province.

The National Board of the Young Women's Christian Association has named Mrs. Savilla Millis Simons of Washington as general secretary, effective Sept. 1, Mrs. Edward W. Macy, president of Y. W. C. A. of the United States, announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the board, 600 Lexington Avenue.

TRENTON, May 6 -- Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons warned all of New Jersey's twenty-one county prosecutors today that it was their duty to stamp out bingo games and all types of raffles now being conducted in this state.

The National Labor Relations Board has made a three-to-one ruling which we believe will tend to unstabilize existing labor relationships and encourage further the tendency of some unions to carve out so-called craft units from existing larger employer or industrial units.

BOUND BROOK, N. J., May 6 -- Three new plants, described as the largest single expansion program in the history of the plastics industry, are to be built by the Bakelite Company, a division of Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation. Texas is to have two and California the third.

A six-acre tract off Midland Avenue and near the Susquehanna Railroad in Saddle River, N. J., has been purchased by Robert Gilson from Mr. and Mrs. Janos Bobrenko. The parcel is part of an assemblage which will be improved with small industrial plants.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Charles Kramer, now a research economist for the Progressive party, refused to tell Senators today whether he was now a Communist or whether he belonged to a Soviet spy network while working for the Government.

Tooting a hooter at the round-about while driving a saloon on the verge will be quite all right for New York motorists who visit London for the Coronation ceremonies. However, it will be well to watch out for a road diversion or dual carriageway, particularly if there is a caravan in the offing
DETROIT, May 6 (AP) -- Ned Garver, working with a sore knee, belted a two-run homer and scattered ten hits to lead the Tigers to an 8-4 victory over the Senators today.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The White House is considering granting greater patronage authority to the new chairman of the Republican National Committee, Leonard W. Hall of New York, in response to widespread Republican grumbling that Administration bottlenecks are slowing down the placement of faithful party workers in important Federal jobs.

It was the ageless and inexhaustible "Swan Lake" that once again stole the show in the New York City Ballet's second performance of the season at the City Center last night. George Balanchine's full and lively version of the old piece, and Cecil Beaton's handsome mounting of it, make for genuine enjoyment in themselves, but on this occasion Maria Tallchief's performance topped them both.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 6 -- "I cannot eat in peace when I know there are citizens hungry for bread," Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion declared in the Knesset (Parliament) today. He was referring to Israel's unemployed, now estimated at more than 20,000, and the immediate need to raise about 10,000,000, Israel ($10,000,000) to put them to work.

Members of the Turf and Field Club and their guests arrived early yesterday for luncheon parties in the circular dining room of the old Manice House at Belmont Park before the opening-day program of the thirty-seven-day meeting of the Westchester Racing Association at the famous oval track.
PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP) -- A railroad official today described as "picayunish" a $1,000,000 public relations fee when paid by a $40,000,000,000 industry.

LONDON, May 6 -- Once again it was proposed in the House of Commons today that political representatives should be assigned to the Korean truce talks in Panmunjom and again Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister declined to take up the proposal with the United States.

Members of the Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York held their annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the York Club. The Right Rev. Charles F. Boynton, Suffragan Bishop here, was guest of honor.

A complete pulp and paper mill project will be constructed in Portugal under the terms of a "private Point Four program" announced recently by Parsons Whittemore, pulp and paper machinery organization.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- B'nai B'rith, the Jewish service organization, ended its five-day triennial convention today with an appeal to the Eisenhower Administration to persuade the Arab nations to end all economic boycotts and blockades against Israel.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, announced today that an additional duty of 18 per cent would be put on Uruguayan wool tops about June 15. There is already a duty of 27 3/4 cents per pound and 6 1/4 per cent on wool tops.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, today directed a former member of the Communist party to compile for the Senate Investigations subcommittee a list of Communists who had infiltrated into news media fields in New York City.

The run that put Brooklyn in front to stay scored on a protested play last night as the Dodgers turned back the Cardinals, 7 -- 3, in the first 1953 meeting of the clubs before 18,178 spectators at Ebbets Field.

LOS ANGELES, May 6 -- The prolonged absence of fathers during wartime may lead to the development of effeminacy in their sons and is responsible for much of the increase in juvenile delinquency, an internationally known psychiatrist said here today.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The statistical exposure by the Senate Investigations subcommittee of the brisk and lucrative trade with Red China in which Western merchant ships were still engaged in 1952, two years after the Chinese Communist forces entered the Korean war, has a clear and meritorious purpose.

ROME, May 6 (AP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, United States Davis Cup captain, led the way into the quarter-final round of the Italian international tennis tournament today with a 6-3, 6-0, 6-3 victory over Ferrante Cavriani of Italy.

Yorkshire pudding, Sir Winston Churchill's cigars and copies of the flags of the Knights of the Garter are but a few of the items, indigenous to the British Isles, being scrutinized by New Yorkers at the British Exposition at Wanamaker's.

LONDON, May 6 -- The British-Egyptian talks on the future of the Suez Canal military base hit today the very snag that the British negotiators were trying to avoid -- a fundamental disagreement on procedure.
The New York Post Office will set up a new speed system for the mails, beginning next Monday, with the introduction of "sack racks" in the lobbies of principal office buildings.
Commodity prices closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges with tin showing the most active day of the year and soybean oil the largest volume since Jan. 9.

Operations of the B. F. Goodrich Company, manufacturer of tires and rubber products, in the first three months of 1953 resulted in an estimated net income of $8,105,712, equal to $1.94 a common share, it was announced yesterday by John L. Collyer, chairman and president.

In a voluble appearance before the House Un-American Activities Committee, Lionel Stander, actor, swore here yesterday that he was not now a Communist, but refused to repeat under oath his former frequent denials that he ever had been one.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Representative W. Sterling Cole, Republican of upstate New York, said today that projects to develop atomic-powered aircraft and airplane carriers might be cut down but definitely would not be scrapped.

ROME, May 6 -- Four Communist deputies have asked the public prosecutor to start legal proceedings against Msgr. Giacomo Cannonero, Bishop of Asti, for having urged Roman Catholics not to vote for the Communists and their allies but to vote instead for parties that undertook to defend Catholic principles.

Burying the hatchet for the day, warring factions of the Welfare and Health Council of New York met yesterday to discuss problems they have in common, on the opening day of a two-day annual conference.

DEARBORN, Mich., May 6 -- The private papers of Henry Ford, who scorned history as "more or less the bunk," will be dedicated tomorrow afternoon to the scholarly task of filling the gaps in the story of his life and times.
PHILADELPHIA, May 6 -- Judge Thomas J. Clary of the United States District Court ruled today that income tax investigators could not seize records of suspected tax evaders.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 6 -- Jack L. Warner, vice president and studio head of Warner Brothers, was the source of Hollywood's "big" news today. In a lengthy statement expressing optimism about the future he announced the following:
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 6 (AP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson, retired world middleweight champion, said today he would go back into the ring if the crown left America.

Three contiguous developments and an industrial tract in southeastern Georgia, originally assembled in 1925 by the late Henry Ford, have been sold by the International Paper Company to Gilbert Verney, textile industrialist.
TANGIER, May 6 (Reuters) -- A United States Appeals Court here today reduced the sentences imposed last year on Sidney J. Paley, convicted of organizing a pirate raid in the Mediterranean.

OTTAWA, May 6 (Canadian Press) -- The combined opposition in the Canadian House of Commons today pressed for immediate announcement of a $1.65-a-bushel initial wheat price, but Governmen members defeated the demand.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 6 -- Suppression of moonshining, rather than raising of revenue, should be the prime consideration of the Government in fixing the level of liquor taxes, Thomas J. Donovan, vice president of Licensed Beverages Industries, Inc., asserted today.

NORTH BABYLON, L. I., May 6 -- Dr. James H. Northrup, principal of the public school here, who has been accused of beating a pupil and conduct unbecoming a teacher, was suspended effective at midnight tonight pending a hearing May 22.

Tree peonies have refused to open this spring on Long Island and in Westchester County because of the weather, but tree peony blooms may nevertheless be seen this week at Macy's flower show. Fully open flowers flown in from California ornament the cerebral palsy booth near the main entrance of Macy's Broadway Building.
TOKYO, Wednesday, May 7 (AP) -- United Nations Command headquarters communique 1,607 for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. today:
NEW HAVEN, May 6 (UP) -- A middle-aged blind couple served as volunteer civil defense spotters here today and proved they could do a better job than some who can see.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A number of regulations intended to effect an orderly transition from the Controlled Materials Plan governing the production and distribution of steel, copper and aluminum, which ends on June 30, to the Defense Materials System, which replaces it on July 1, were issued by the National Production Authority today.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat irregular yesterday, closing 16 points lower to 14 points higher than on Tuesday, with old crop months showing the most weakness.

General de Gaulle's announcement that the R. P. F. (Reunion of the French People) will no longer function as an organized party, leaving his followers free to vote as they please, is a recognition of a fail accompli. The Gaullists are already badly split in the National Assembly and their losses in the recent municipal elections indicate that the party is on the decline.

Intensified education and preventive psychiatry should be major factors in coping with the universal need for mental health, Dr. Rodolph L. Coigny, local official of the World Health Organization, declared yesterday at a conference of the New York State Society for Mental Health.
NEW HAVEN, May 6 -- C. Hamilton Sanford, business manager of Yale University, issued a statement tonight that said in part:

OTTAWA, May 6 -- On the eve of his official visit to President Eisenhewer, Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent received today unanimous instruction for the House of Commons to press for the removal of United States restrictions on Canadian agricultural products.

Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Casey, retired, one of Governor Dewey's appointees, was elected yesterday as chairman of the New York City Transit Authority as the new agency held its first meeting since its membership was completed with the selection of Eugene F. Moran as its fifth member.

BONN, Germany, May 6 -- United States and French officials are vigorously assailing a Bundestag bill authorizing the Government to double the turnover tax on coal and steel as an example of German economic nationalism striking at the foundations of the European Coal and Steel Community.

Shelling six pitchers for fifteen safeties in a barrage that included a seven-hit, six-run fifth inning, the Giants replaced the Cubs in the sixth spot in the National League by scoring an 8-to-5 victory over Phil Cavarretta's Chicagoans in the opener of a two-game set at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

CLEVELAND, May 6 -- A four-point program to make equity investment both feasible and attractive was advocated today by John J. Mann, chairman of the board of the American Stock Exchange, in an address before the twentieth annual conference of the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The American Automobile Association has withdrawn from the National Highway Users Conference, which it helped to organize in 1932 to promote the interests of highway transportation.

MILWAUKEE, May 6 (AP) -- Ted Jamieson, Milwaukee Boxing Referee who was jeered Monday night after stopping a bout between Dan Bucceroni and Wes Bascom, turned in his license today to the State Athletic Commission.

Two physicians who are brothers have been dropped from the staff of Creedmoor State Hospital Queens Village, Queens, for refusal to sign an Army loyalty oath. What is more, the men are to be inducted into the service as privates, according to Dr. Newton J. T. Bigelow, State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, who approved the ouster effective April 30.

LOS ANGELES, May 7 -- The most dangerous time for a person with suicidal tendencies is the period when he seems to be recovering from an emotional crises, the 109th annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association was told today.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- President Eisenhower called a special meeting of State and Defense Department advisers at the White House today to discuss the Communists' latest proposal for a truce in the Korean war.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 7 -- Gangs of Mau Mau terrorists, organized in the forests north of Nairobi, are beginning to show an increasing capacity to act as military units and to fight, if not pitched battles, at least regulation skirmishes, acting apparently under orders and with a military purpose.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told Congress today that "the possibility of war is still with us." He said the Soviet Union's "atomic capability is rapidly improving" and there was no basis in military intelligence for supposing a change of heart in the Kremlin.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- All deliveries of wheat dropped today to new low price levels for the season. The decline prompted some short profit taking and a little buying by commission houses on resting orders. Other grains were affected by the wheat weakness, and in all pits there was a moderate amount of ear]y selling on the brighter prospects for a Korean truce.
LONDON, Friday, May 8 -- The Labor party made extensive gains at the expense of Conservatives and independents in yesterday's municipal elections held throughout England and Wales.

Eleven-year-old Paul Weiss, a school safety patrolman who saved the life of a little girl last November, was congratulated yesterday by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan before leaving for Washington where he will receive a gold medal today from Vice President Richard M. Nixon.

JERSEY CITY, May 7 -- Mayor John V. Kenny's "Monster Labor Parade and Rally" in honor of the Mayor and his fellow candidates for re-election was held here tonight. The parade lasted an hour and a half, and was only a third as long as a similar demonstration in the 1949 campaign.

ST. LOUIS, May 7 (UP) -- Marty Marion, manager of the Browns, promised today to Bobo Holloman, no-hit pitcher against the Athletics last night, another chance against the same club next Tuesday night.

The assembly-line system of industrial production in which Henry Ford pioneered is being used by Columbia University to produce a two-volume history of the Ford Motor Company from the 5,000,000 documents and 25,000 photographs in the private and corporate papers of Mr. Ford.
Indications of a downward trend in United States exports were reported yesterday by the Export Managers Club in partial results of a recent survey.

After stalling the resumed armistice negotiations in Korea to the point of new deadlock, the Communists have now come up with a new "compromise" proposal which bows to the United Nations standpoint on another vital issue but still contains enough dubious conditions that its ultimate significance must still be determined.
ALBANY, May 7 -- Low bids totaling nearly $20,000,000 for four Thruway projects were announced today by the State Public Works Department.

President Eisenhower told audiences at Republican fund-raising dinners here last night that any peace in Korea must be fair to the Korean people and must also be fair to those who were our enemies but who now seek political asylum in free countries.

The new New York City Transit Authority, created to take over operation of the deficit-plagued municipal transit system from the Board of Transportation, split three to two again yes terday, this time on the selection of counsel to advise it in negotiations with the City Administration for the transfer of the lines.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 7 -- This was D (for destruction) Day at the Paramount Studio. Sixteen cooperative elephants, responding on cue like the experienced actors most of them are, began throwing their weight against the sprawling Ceylon plantation house that is destroyed by an aroused herd at the climax of "Elephant Walk."

The end of the shape-up system of hiring longshoremen on the New York waterfront will be recommended in the fourth and final report of the New York State Crime Commission, Joseph M. Proskauer, chairman of the commission, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson has asked Canadian officials to cut down on oat exports to the United States.

Having qualified as one of the fashionable summer emporiums, the Westport (Conn.) Country Playhouse is drawing up blueprints for its new season, opening June 15. Activities will commence with modernized conception of Sheridan's 1777-comedy, "The School for Scandal," possibly with June Havoc interpreting Lady Sneer-well with tongue in cheek.

Motions for dismissal of anti-trusts charges against the investment banking houses of Smith, Barney Co., and Drexal Co., were supported yesterday by the oral argument of defense lawyers in the trial before Judge Harold R. Medina in Federal Court, here, yesterday.
When stickball on the asphalt and cobblestone "fields" of the Lower East Side takes its toll on the shoes of future big leaguers, their mothers hurry off to a building at 334 Madison Street.

A statement of the position of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York and the Catholic Charities of Brooklyn, filed yesterday at the meeting of the delegate body of the Welfare and Health Council by Thomas F. Keogh, follows:

Planned Parenthood groups over the country should continue to seek membership in their community welfare and health associations despite possible opposition from groups against planned parenthood, a panel discussing community relations concluded yesterday at the annual meeting of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America.

BOSTON, May 7 -- Fourteen Bostonians, most of them with religious or educational affiliations, asserted tolay that present Congressional investigations into Communist activities in this country were "undermining the entire constitution and our democratic system.''

A little more than a year ago Arthur Levitt was appointed by Mayor Impellitteri to the Board of Education to fill the unexpired term of Maximilian Moss, who was elected a justice of the New York State Supreme Court.
