During this period Mr. Levitt has demonstrated ability of a high order in dealing with educational and administrative problems.
Postponed matches in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub competition were played in the three districts yesterday.

The Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, Inc., reported a net profit of $1,220,000, equal to $1.18 a common share, yesterday for the three months ended on March 31. This compared with $196,350, or 15 cents a share, for the corresponding three months of 1952.

General motors Acceptance Corporation is negotiating with Morgan Stanley Co. for the public marketing of an issue of debentures of "relatively short maturity," John J. Schuman, president of the company, said yesterday. Registration of the issue with the Securities and Exchange Commission is likely within a couple of weeks if the negotiations are concluded satisfactorily.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 7 -- The Dutch have made little concrete headway in attempts to get United States support for their territorial defense program.

ATHENS, May 7 -- A Government-sponsored bill designed to combine loose strands of intelligence in at least eight separate services into one effective, all-powerful central intelligence agency was enacted tonight by Parliament. Hostile criticism came from many who interpreted the bill as an authoritarian measure inconsistent with democracy.
LAGOS, Nigeria, May 7 (Reuters) -- Sharp Nationalist demands for freedom from British rule and "self-government by 1956" challenged Nigeria's fifteen-month-old constitutional Administration today.

Order-taking improved in the final two days of the Popular Price Shoe Show of America, and producers reported yesterday at the close of the five-day event that bookings had been better than expected. Manufacturers that maintained their fall price levels had excellent business, while those that absorbed most, though not all, of the recent increases in production costs said retailers had placed sizable orders at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels.

BONN, Germany, May 7 -- The basic policies of the Soviet Union in Europe and Germany are unchanged, despite Moscow's peace offensive, and vigilance in defense is as necessary as ever, Dr. James B. Conant, United States High Commissioner, warned today.

The need for stepped-up efforts in the field of international advertising was stressed yesterday by speakers at the fifth international convention of the Export Advertising Association, Inc., in the Plaza Hotel. American producers were said to be facing considerable competition from British, Japanese and German manufacturers now able to make many products for mass consumption.

Since the new musical show at the Shubert is called "Can-Can," no one should be surprised to discover that the dancing is the best thing in it. Cole Porter has written the music and the lyrics. Abe Burrows has written the book and also attended to the direction.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- New York steamship companies that either receive subsidies from the Government or charter its vessels are now being investigated by the Maritime Administration to determine whether the taxpayers are being defrauded through shakedown payoffs and padded payrolls listed by the lines as operating expenses.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 7 -- The second United Nations commemorative stamp of 1953, honoring the Universal Postal Union will be issued Friday, June 12, the United Nations Postal Administration announced today.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

OSLO, Norway, May 7 (Reuters) -- Housewives in Norway and all other buyers of consumer goods soon may have their own organization to act as a watchdog over the quality and durability of goods offered for sale and to advise on what to buy and how much to pay for it.
Residents of Brooklyn Heights trooped to the Borough Hall last night to battle for their point of view -- a particularly scenic one that includes the Statue of Liberty.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 7 -- The latest Communist offer regarding Korean prisoners of war found a warm welcome at the United Nations today. A number of delegates pointed out that it was similar to the Indian resolution, which was adopted by the General Assembly last December and was then rejected by Communist China and North Korea.

A noble form of giving is to share one's crust of bread or canteen of water directly with another. Poets and philosophers have sung about this impulsive gesture in famine area, battlefield and prison camp. Another form of giving tests the inner flame and faith of mankind. It is the quiet, anonymous bestowal of salinething valued upon someone unknown.

A plan to demolish two antiquated lower Manhattan elementary schools and replace them with a new, modern structure was adopted yesterday by the Committee on Buildings and Sites of the Board of Education.

More than fifty detectives and policemen from West Side precincts were rushed aboard the superliner United States last night to search for a "bomb" that an anonymous caller said had been hidden on the big ship.

ALBANY, May 7 (AP) -- High water and strong currents continued to stymie traffic on the south-! era end of the State Barge Canal'si Champlain section today. The Public Works Department said it expected conditions to improve enaugh to permit "limited operation'' between Waterford and Fortl Edwa2d. Heavy rains had swollen the waters and washed away many buoys.
The son-in-law of Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City was indicted yesterday on a charge of "false swearing."
Roy Flint has been named an assistant national sales of Schenley Distributors, Inc.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "The Desert Rats," a Twentieth Century-Fox drama of World War II featuring Richard Burton and Robert Newton, is at the Mayfair, Robert L. Jacks produced and Robert Wise directed from a screen play by Richard Murphy. Robert Douglas, Torin Thatcher, Chips Rafferty and Charles Tingwell are among the supporting players.

Record quarterly sales, a sharp increase in net earnings and the promotion of five vice presidents and a comptroller were announced yesterday by the Chrysler Corporation and its wholly-owned subsidiaries.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Over the strenuous protest of Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, the Senate followed the lead of the House of Representatives today in passing a bill allowing the Export-Import Bank to issue war risk insurance up to $100,000,000.

Ramon Fuentes, Los Angeles welterweight, is favored to make a successful Eastern debut tonight when he meets Al (Sugar) Wilson of Englewood, N. J., in the feature ten-round bout at St. Nicholas Arena.
The 125th anniversary of the birth of Henri Dunant, Swiss founder of the Red Cross, will be observed today by Red Cross societies all over the world.

There are more ways to prepare potato salad than most cooks imagine, and now, apparently, is the time to learn them. For what is probably the most often eaten vegetable, at least in the North, is in such heavy supply that prices recently dropped to the lowest retail levels in almost three years.

Perverse weather, which is just about making a shambles of the major league baseball campaigns this spring, cracked down on the metropolitan area again yesterday as both the Giants-Cubs flame at the Polo Grounds and the Dodgers-Cardinals encounter in Ebbets Field were rained out.

MEXICO CITY, May 7 -- A sharp drop in the flow of United States tourists to Mexico during the last three months has aroused some panicky fears here and has led to plans for complete reorganization of the Mexican tourist industry.

After an ownership of about a month, the five-story building containing eight apartments and occupying a lot 19 by 100 feet at 70 East Seventy-ninth Street, between Park and Madison Avenues, was resold by Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, to a buyer who was represented by Joseph Hidalgo Sons, brokers. The tax valuation is $60,000.

Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, said last night that one of the major issues confronting education was "whether a man should be permitted to pay for the education of his son, or must he be compelled in the interest of democracy to take what the state provides?"

Leading theatre representatives and spokesmen for civic and industrial groups urged yesterday the passage of proposed amendments to the city building code that would encourage the construction of new legitimate playhouses on Broadway.

PARIS, May 7 -- French officials expressed tonight the hope that their reluctance to bring the invasion of Laos before the United Nations might be justified by the withdrawal of the invading force. Latest reports told of the retreat of this force away from the capital toward which it had appeared to be headed.

Federal Judge John J. Parker asserted last night that a proposed Constitutional amendment to limit the treaty-making powers of the Executive Branch of the United States Government "would hamper and impede this country in its efforts to establish world order through the United Nations as well as in exercising effective world leadership."

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, president of Pennsylvania State College, told a centennial convocation at Beaver College today that modern life demanded that education go all-out to develop a 'wholeness' of mind and character and not merely narrow specialists.

If historic trends are a proper guide, it is reasonable to predict that there will be less specialization in the ad agency business in the future, except in the highly technical fields. James M. Cecil, president of Cecil Presbrey, Inc., made this assertion last night at a meeting of the League of Advertising Agencies, Inc., in the Ad Club.

Consumers took care of last week's sharp price advances on pork. They cut their purchases to the extent that pork loins came down 6 cents a pound, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday. Sliced bacon, however, which was not boycotted, moved up to the highest price since October, 1948.
SAN BRUNO, Calif., May 7 (AP) -- Willie Shoemaker won five straight races at Tanforan today and the fifth was the big one of the day -- the $7,500 Solano County Fair Purse.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- A story of tax-fixing attempts in California, with cash as a reward and murder as a threatened penalty, was reported today by the Senate Investigations subcommittee headed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

The schedule for the State Republican Committee's dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel called for the arrival of President Eisenhower in the ballroom at 10:20 P.M. When at exactly that moment Attorney General Herbert Brownell ended his speech with the words, "our great President Eisenhower," this was the cue for the diners to rise for a cheering welcome to the President.
Stock market volume duplicated the Wednesday level of 1,110,000 shares, lowest since Oct. 1; and prices slipped moderately yesterday in the third successive decline.

LONDON, May 7 -- Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister, affirmed today that the British Government would give "most careful attention" to the Communists' new eight-point plan for disposing of the Korean war prisoners.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 7 -- Making what some members called a final offer whose rejection would cause bitterness in Bermuda, the Assembly yesterday unanimously approved a recommendation that an offer of 750,000 ($2,100,000) be made to the United Kingdom Government for its surplus property in Bermuda, totaling probably 800 acres and including installations such as the former British dockyard and garrison at Prospect, closed last month when the last British troops departed.

ALBANY, May 7 (AP) -The Public Service Commission today ordered the Erie Railway to continue Train 27 westbound daily between Port Jervis and Binghamton, but approved discontinuance of eastbound Train 28 between Binghamton and Jersey City.

The United States Chess Federation suggested yesterday the proposed United States-Soviet Union chess match in this country begin July 27. Harold M. Phillips, president of the United States organization, disclosed.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 7 -- The Communist-led Vietminh invaders of Laos appeared tonight to be continuing their withdrawal northward from Luang Prabang, the royal capital, and from the area of Plaine des Jarres, about eighty-five miles southeast of King Sisavang Vong's Buddhist city.

Sea Legs profited by the early pace set by his entry-mate to win the fifty-sixth running of the International Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The event, the first of the jump handicaps listed for the meeting, attracted a field of seven, with Sea Legs and Hot running as the favored pair, saddled by R. G. Woolfe.

LONDON, May 7 -- The Communists' eight point plan for a Korean truce prompted buying of British Government securities on the stock markets today. Prices of gilt edged securities rose steadily and gained up to nearly one-half of 1 per cent. Chinese and Japanese loans also made prominent rises.

THERE'S something poignantly characteristic of this town and its citizenry in the fact that Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Casey, new head of the city's Transit Authority, and Eugene F. Moran, fellow authority member, have been neighbors in the same apartment house at 120 East End Avenue for almost, two years but never met until they got together at a meeting of the Authority two days ago.

TRENTON, May 7 -- Chief Justice Arthur T. Vanderbilt of the New Jersey Supreme Court announced today that the trial of Walter G. Winne, superseded prosecutor of Bergen County, on an indictment alleging nonfeasance in office would begin June 1 in the courthouse at Hackensack.
HARTFORD, May 7 -- The Joint Labor Committee of the Connecticut General Assembly voted favorable reports today on two bills increasing workmen's and unemployment compensation benefits.

Plans to issue 50,000 shares of $100 par value cumulative preferred stock, to increase authorized common stock from 750,000 shares to 1,000,000 shares and to revamp the long-term debt structure were approved by stockholders of the Pittston Company at the annual meeting yesterday.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 7 (AP) -- Shelley Mayfield, one of the youthful brigade, stole a march at the start of the seventy-two-hole Greenbrier open today, but three old pro golfers were only a stroke behind.

An earlier mail delivery in residential areas is "in the offing," Harold Riegelman, who last Tuesday was sworn in as Acting Postmaster of the New York Post Office, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Young Republican Club.
PARIS, May 7 -- The Jacques Heim collection shows originality and spirit in its beach and sports wear and a genuine feeling for haute couture in its more conservative daytime and formal gowns.
GREAT NECK, May 7 -- An ex- marine, lately returned from Korea, won the metropolitan intercollegiate golf championship today as the team honors went to Princeton for the third successive year.

GENEVA, May 7 -- An international election of more than routine interest and importance to the United States will take place here next week. It will determine who is to be Secretary General of the International Telecommunications Union, the body that sits at the center of the long international wrangle over the highly sensitive question of who is to use what radio frequencies, and for what purposes.

Dr. Ermenti Torregrossa of the Shore Road Hospital in Brooklyn gasped after two policemen had rushed him in their radio car last night to the foot of Ninety-third Street where they had found a woman's body in the Narrows a few feet offshore.
TOKYO, Friday, May 8 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,608 for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. today, Korean time:

Behind 100 roaring motorcycles, President Eisenhower drove through Times Square twice last night and the police estimated that 150,000 persons had seen him in the course of the motorcade route between Pennsylvania Station and the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, via the Astor Hotel.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 6 -- The United Nations is in the field for sculpture to embellish the buildings and gardens of the world capital. However, the statuary must be of high artistic value, and it must be free -- either a gift from a government or some generous private donor.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (UP) -- George Preston Marshall, president of the Washington Redskins professional football team, said today the Justice Department's anti-trust operations "will destroy all sports" unless Congress curbs them.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- The House Merchant Marine Committee was told today that proposed amendments to the Merchant Marine Act would disrupt American shipping service.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. today announced the arrest for deportation of Israel Blankenstein, described as a charter member of the Communist party in this country who has long operated underground.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of the testimony of James A. Wechsler, editor of The New York Post, which was released today by the Senate Investigations subcommittee headed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin:

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent of Canada served notice today that Canada was "not bluffing" about its determination to construct the St. Lawrence Seaway alone if the United States failed to become a partner.

Many tickets have been purchased for the performance of "Can-Can" next Thursday night at the Shubert Theatre for the benefit of the Jacob A. Riis Settlement. Mrs. Henry P. Davison Jr. is chairman and Mrs. August Zinsser Jr., co-chairman. Among their aides are Mrs. J. Stanley Davis and Mrs. Robert Colgate.

HEWLETT, L. I., May 7 -- Medalist honors remained undecided today in the sixth annual William D. Richardson Memorial Tournament sponsored by the Long Island Golf Association as the long-hitting 23-year-old Tim Holland and Jack Sabine, 37, shared the lead in the qualifying round with 74's.

THE weather may be foul, the streams high and discolored and the temperature of both air and water low over the coming week-end, but for those trout fishermen willing to risk it, there should be fair fly fishing on most of the Catskill streams.

A pilot plant in Lowell, Mass., operated by the Compo Shoe Machinery Corporation of that city and Boston, turned out yesterday 240 pairs of women's shoes on machinery that has just been brought to this country from Germany.

TOKYO, Friday, May 8 -- The United Nations Command gave detailed study today to a new Communist plan for repatriation of prisoners of the Korean war, after the start of an armistice. The plan agreed that the captives should be held on the peninsula pending final determination of their fate and conferred custodial powers on a "neutral nations repatriation commission," including two members of the Soviet bloc.

The first move has now been made in the Senate to restore funds for the public housing program which the House eliminated two weeks ago. A Senate subcommittee has voted an appropriation for this purpose that would maintain the present rate, with starts annually of 35,000 family units

Hosiery shipments in March were 14,348,411 dozen pairs, compared with 13,921,997 dozen pairs in March of 1952, it was announced yesterday by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. Women's full-fashioned shipments amounted to 4,905,395 dozen pairs, against 4,834,437 dozen pairs in the corresponding month last year.

The Church of the House of Prayer for All People, an organization reported to have about 500,000 adherents in 130 branches along the Atlantic seaboard, has purchased the thirty-three-story Eldorado Apartments at 300 Central Park West. The deal was made by Charles M. Grace, as trustee for the group, and was negotiated by Joseph H. Lopin Co. and Edward M. Rogall, brokers.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was slightly easier yesterday, and closing prices were 3 to 13 points net lower than the preceding day on active months.
On the recommendation of J. Paul Getty, important West Coast oil man, directors of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company elected David T. Staples president of that $429,000,000 company yesterday.

In the first formal charge of communism against a member of the Police Department, Patrolman Meyer E. Rubenstein of the Simpson Street Station, the Bronx, was identified by a professed former Communist yesterday as having been an active member of the party a one time.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- During the week ended May 6, member bank reserves increased $322,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The Jewish Theological Seminary, which for several years has offered the excellent "Eternal Light" series on radio, has kept abreast of the television medium with some rewarding experiments in the field of religious drama. Thanks in large measure to the sensitive pen of Morton Wishengrad, the seminary's plays usually have had a simplicity and beauty with a meaning for people of all faiths.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 7 -- A report released today by the Food and Agriculture Organization showed that silk's place among fibers and in the world economy has been declining during the last twenty-five years. The drop was attributed to the increasing supply of man-made fibers -- notably rayon and nylon -- which have made "great inroads" into silk's market for apparel and decoration.

HENRY JAMES, in the opinion of Leon Edel, has always been a misunderstood novelist. To his admirers he is a writer of the first rank, the apotheosis of perceptive elegance, a kind of international Proust. To less-initiated readers he is a garden-grown American snob, an anemic straddler between Back Bay and Mayfair, a concocter of neoGothic conceits doomed to be widely ignored.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The proclamation by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey recognizing the seventieth anniversary of the signing of the first Civil Service Law in this state was a fine and fitting tribute to that great event. The law reminds of the anxiety of forward looking men and women of previous decades concerning the character of personnel in government.

INGLEWOOD Calif., May 7 (AP) -- Representatives of the Hollywood Turf Club and the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association held an executive session today, trying to settle their differences over purse distribution money for the approaching meeting.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 7 -- Lessing J. Rosenwald, president of the American Council for Judaism, charged tonight that Zionist activities on behalf of Israel and Israeli legislation had combined to place American citizens of Jewish faith, "without their volition," in a "quasi-legal" position different from that of Americans of other religious beliefs.

DEARBORN, Mich., May 7 -- Fair Lane, the baronial home of the late Henry Ford on the north bank of the River Rouge, was dedicated today as a research center for scholars tracing out the history of mass production in America.

The publishers of Collier's, sold as a weekly since its founding sixty-five years ago, announced yesterday that the magazine would be published every other week in a move made necessary by television's inroads on the reading audience.

The City of Miami, Fla., announced yesterday that May 27 had been set as the date for receiving bids one $16,000,000 of sewage disposal bonds, due serially from 1957 to 1993 and on $11,100,000 of sewer revenue term obligations due on Jan. 1, 1993. The sale is to take the place of that recently canceled.

WASHINGTON, May. 7 -- A definition of a small business in the wholesaling field was proposed by the Small Defense Plants Administration today as any concern doing less than $1,000,000 worth of business annually. The agency proposed its definition in sending a questionnaire to enterprises in the distributing, jobbing and converting fields.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Department of the Interior today ordered a cut of not less than 1,000 employes by June 30 in the staff of the Bureau of Reclamation.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was disturbed to read the letter by Joseph Goldsmith in the April 29 TIMES on public housing.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- An official of the Sun Oil Company charged the Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission today with creating gasoline monopolies by granting exclusive rights to a single supplier on various sections of the superhighway.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Eisenhower Administration submitted to Congress today a defense budget calling for $5,244,000,000 less in new appropriations and about $2,300,000,000 less in actual spending than had been requested by President Truman in his budget message to Congress last January.

Five youths accused of having kidnapped a midtown parking lot attendant here in a 1948 sedan they were alleged to have stolen from the lot at 3 A. M. yesterday were arrested two hours later by the New Jersey State Police near New Brunswick, N. J.
A 19-year-old package thief was shot dead at 2:30 P. M. yesterday while fleeing from detectives across Tenth Avenue at Thirty-eighth Street.
BERLIN, May 7 -- A trade agreement signed in Moscow April 27 by the East German Communist Government has accelerated the process of integrating East Germany with the Soviet economic bloc.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Predictions that the national school lunch program would not survive the $8,367,491 cut recommended for the 1954 fiscal year by the Budget Bureau were made before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee today by spokesmen for school food services and child health, welfare, and education groups.

Ed Sullivan canceled plans yesterday to do a biography of Cecil B. De Mille on his "Toast of the Town" television program. He said that the movie producer had refused to appear unless he could serve as narrator, a role that was barred to him by the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, A. F. L., with which Mr. De Mille is not in good standing.

Seasonal repayments by commodity dealers and food and tobacco manufacturers offset new borrowings by public utilities and metal, petroleum and chemical interests in the week ended on Wednesday, holding the net change in business borrowings from New York City banks to zero. There had been a reduction of $19,000,000 in such credits in the similar week of 1952.

" Design for the home has social significance because it has social consequences," Miss Elizabeth Gordon, editor of House Beautiful Magazine, told a luncheon meeting of the Home Fashions League here yesterday.
POTTSVILLE, Pa., May 7 (AP) -- The anthracite industry, through John L. Lewis, expressed concern today over production of coal in nonunion mines.

Painters and sculptors from both sides of the Atlantic participate in five of the current art exhibitions. For its first exhibition the new Artisans Gallery, 32 West Fifty-eighth Street, is showing work by eighteen artists, each of whom has won an award in the Audubon Artists Annual Exhibition or in that of the Brooklyn Society of Artists.

FRANKFURT, May 7 (AP) -- Hans Wallenberg, editor of the United States State Department's newspaper in Germany, denied today that he was a Communist or that he hired "card-carrying Communists" for the paper's staff.

BOSTON, May 7 -- Dr. Philip Morrison of Cornell University, a physicist, testified today that he had been a Communist before he had been "sought out" to work on the atomic bomb project in World War II.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- President Eisenhower, in his first move toward forming within the next few months an almost completely new Joint Chiefs of Staff, named Gen. Nathan F. Twining today as Chief of Staff of the Air Force to succeed Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- President Eisenhower was reported today to have approved a reorganization plan that would re-establish the Council of Economic Advisers as a three-man agency with more power and a higher salary for its chairman.
The murder of a Hoboken pier hiring foreman is a vivid reminder that crime continues on the Port of New York's sprawling waterfront.
NEW HAVEN, May 7 (AP) -- Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, Yale president, said tonight he did not see how the demands of about 450 striking university service employes could be met.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Walter Pitkin Jr., vice president of Bantam Books, Inc., in his letter published April 15 attempts to link up and indict all groups combating indecent literature as being a threat to freedom of the press."

Columbia University and the Jewish Theological Seminary signed an agreement yesterday allowing students in both institutions to earn bachelor's degrees in liberal arts and in Jewish studies through a combined course of study.
LONDON, May 7 (AP) -- Eleven American debutantes were presented today to Queen Elizabeth II and met the Duke of Edinburgh in the white and gold state ballroom at Buckingham Palace.

TUCSON, Ariz., May 7 -- A challenge for colleges to produce "well rounded men and women for business and government" was issued today by Edward T. McCormick, president of the American Stock Exchange, at the dedication of a $900,000 building for the College of Busness and Public Administration at the University of Arizona.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, May 7 (AP) -- Following is the eight-point proposal submitted by the Communists today for settling the prisoner exchange issue and reaching an armistice in Korea:

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Senator John W. Bricker, Republican of Ohio, accused State Department officials today of making "false and misleading" arguments to the Senate in their support of a pending treaty to define the legal rights of members of United States armed forces serving abroad.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, May 8 (AP) -- Scores of bomb-laden United States Navy planes and three warships hurled new blows at two Communist port areas yesterday in mounting attacks on the northeast coast of Korea.

LONDON, May 7 -- Four bodies, three of them believed to be those of American women tourists, were removed today from the British passenger ship Duke of York, which was in a collision with the United States merchant vessel Haiti Victory in the North Sea yesterday.

PARIS, May 7 -- It is twenty-four days since a well organized Vietminh army rushed across the borders of the little Indo-Chinese Kingdom of Laos. Now, as the first of the monsoon rains are showering down, this curious offensive seems -- at least for the moment -- to be petering out, with those Communist-led troops that were closest to Luang Prabang, the royal capital, withdrawing.

PARIS, May 7 -- With negotiations between the French shipping companies and striking officers deadlocked, the French Line decided this evening to lay up the 49,000-ton liner Liberte, originally scheduled to leave tomorrow, afternoon for New York.

A funeral service yesterday morning for former Senator Robert F. Wagner at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street, was attended by Mayor Impellitteri, members of the Board of Estimate, delegations from the State Senate and Assembly, members of the judiciary and labor leaders.

Opposition to the proposed establishment of two State University dental schools was expressed yesterday by deans of the three dental schools in this state. The officials, who represented Columbia University, New York University and the University of Buffalo, said that if additional dentists were needed the problem could best be met by increasing the facilities of existing schools, rather than by establishing competing public institutions.

CAIRO, May 7 -- Egyptian leaders received a new message from the British Government tonight, forwarded in an apparent effort to get the stalled negotiations between the two countries on the future of the Suez Canal zone under way again
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The United States indicated today that French opposition did not end the possibility of seeking United Nations action against the Communist-led invasion of Laos.

The suspension of the Anglo-Egyptian negotiations on the Suez Canal is a grave development. For this reason, and because the potentialities are so explosive, it must be hoped that the talks can be resumed with better advance preparations. Britain's new note to Egypt, delivered last night, is a sign that some efforts at least are being made in that direction.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's top United Nations representatives have launched a series of hard-hitting speeches designed to offset what they call a "smear campaign" against the world organization.

City College invited one of its most distinguished alumni, Bernard M. Baruch, to make the Charter Day address yesterday, and the alumnus showed that in the sixty-four years since he was graduated his mind has gone on growing.

MIAMI, Fla., May 7 (AP) -- Russell Tongay was arrested today for investigation in the death of his 5-year-old daughter, Kathy, swimming star, but was released tonight in custody of his attorney to appear at a hearing at noon tomorrow.

A fifteen-story office building will be erected on a plot of 65,000 square feet on the south side of Queens Boulevard at Eighty-third Avenue in Forest Hills, Queens, which has been assembled during the past two years by the Lefrak Organization, Samuel J. Lefrak, president, announced yesterday. The land was acquired from eighteen individual owners through the Louis Hammerschlag Agency, broker.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (UP) -- The Subversive Activities Control Board announced today that it would hold hearings May 13-14 for organizations listed by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr., as being Communist fronts.

SHAWNEE - ON - DELAWARE, Pa., May 7 (AP) -- Pete Arand, 20- year-old University of Virginia student from Allenhurst, N. J., and Ellis Taylor, former Delaware champion from Wilmington, today tied for the medal with one-over-par 73's in the thirtieth annual Shawnee invitation golf tourney.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 7 -- Fear that the move to abolish the color bar in Northern Rhodesia copper mines might foreshadow a similar move on the South African gold mines was expressed today by Die Transvaler, Johannesburg mouthpiece of the Nationalist Government.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that it had $3,065,000,000 invested in surplus farm products at the end of March, or about $18 worth for each citizen. This compared with $1,730,000,000 a year ago and a record of nearly $4,300,000,000 shortly before the war started in Korea.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (UP) -- The Government had $3,065,643,000 tied up in price-support operations as of March 31, about $18 for each person in the United States, the Agriculture Department reported today.

A syndicate headed by Union Securities Corporation, Kidder, Peabody Co and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane will make a public offering today of 70,000 shares of $4.84 dividend preferred stock of Texas Power and Light Company at $99.79 a share to yield 4.85 per cent.

Robert Rossen, writer, director and producer of the 1949 Academy Award film "All the King's Men," publicly repented yesterday his 1951 refusal to tell all he knew about the Communist party. He said he had been a member of the party from 1937 to 1947 and had contributed $40,000 to party causes in that time. He also named fifty-seven persons he had known in Hollywood as party members at the time.

The opposition slate of directors of the Welfare and Health Council was elected last night by a vote of 317 to 259, after a tedious roll-call vote held despite an earlier effort to postpone the election.

TRENTON, May 7 -- The validity of the bribery indictment against Harold J. Adonis, former executive clerk in the office of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, was seriously questioned today by the testimony of two high state police officials.

STRASBOURG, France, May 7 -- The foreign ministers of Western Europe decided today in favor of Strasbourg and the Council of Europe as the center for the coordination of all their activities in the interests of unification.

Irving Charles Velson, who refused to tell the House of Representatives Un-American Activities Committee Wednesday whether he had ever been a Communist, has been barred from the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers "for life," John J. Grogan, national president of the union, said yesterday.

The annual report of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York for 1952 shows that the organization attained last year a new record of membership with 47,019 Scouts and 13,036 adult volunteers. More than 6,000 women and men volunteers took training courses for group leadership, program skills and functional courses.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Three of the country's big farm organizations split today over President Eisenhower's request for a one-year extension without basic change of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.

Representative Harold H. Velde, Republican of Illinois and chairman of the Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives, yesterday assailed "distortions" of the committee's work and said he would investigate Communists wherever he could find them, even among the clergy.

Prices of United States Government bonds improved further yesterday, imparting firmness to the market for high grade corporate obligations. However, there was little doing in the secondary market for corporate liens.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 4 -- Political refugees who escape to Turkey from behind the Iron Curtain may be able to support themselves economically while they await resettlement abroad if a self-help experiment being sponsored by United States officials here proves a success.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Francis P. Whitehair, former Under Secretary of the Navy, and James L. Fly, former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, told a House Judiciary subcommittee today that they saw Tom C. Clark, then Attorney General, once for ten minutes in 1945 when they were seeking dismissal of fraud indictments against a client of theirs. The indictments were dismissed eight months later.
This country is ill-equipped to meet the challenge of current Soviet "peace" maneuvers, Bernard M. Baruch declared yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- Jefferson Medical College Hospital reported today what it believed to be the first successful use of a mechanical heart and lung apparatus to save the life of a patient.

CLEVELAND, May 7 -- Courtesy and friendliness in letters to customers and prospects is a lost art, Ray W. Johnson, credit manager of the Boston Store, Fort Dodge, Iowa, told delegates to the twentieth annual conference of the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association today.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 7 -- The Boston Symphony Orchestra appeared in this city tonight for the first time in thirty-eight years, but the sentimental hero of the occasion was 78-year-old Pierre Monteux, who was returning to a place that had been his happy hunting grounds for seventeen years.

The new one-story trucking terminal at 37-27 Ninth Street in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by the Raystyne Corporation to Morris Leon of the Anzio Trucking Company. Baumeister Baumeister were the brokers.
TORONTO, May 7 Canadian Press) -- Howard S. Mark, vice president of the Robert Simpson Company, said today newspaper advertising has no substitute for effectiveness.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 7 -- The Lloyd Brasileiro steamship line is negotiating the purchase of eighteen new ships including one passenger and two refrigerator ships, it was announced here today by Admiral Lemos Basto, head of the Government-owned steamship line.

ATHENS, May 7 (Reuters) -- Somerset Maugham, one of the world's most popular authors, announced here today that he had put down his sardonic pen for good at the age of 79 and was taking one last fling before he dies.
CLEVELAND, May 7 (AP) -- Johnny Bratton of Chicago, gunning for a welterweight title bout, won a unanimous decision from Livio Minelli of Italy tonight in a ten- round bout in the Arena.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., May (AP) -- Five Negroes have won City Council seats in North Carolina municipalities, and four of them were the first of their race to be elected since reconstruction days. Dr. William Hampton of Greensboro won his second term.

DACCA, Pakistan, May 7 -- Mohammed Ali, Prime Minister of Pakistan, arrived at this capital of East Bengal Province this morning for his first test of political strength with older Moslem League party leaders and won the first round before he left the airport.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 7 -- Harold Stonier, New York executive vice president of the American Bankers Association, today advised the nation's bankers to adopt a more cautious policy on installment credit.

The Federal Government has changed its attitude toward the Reciprocal Trade Act under the new Administration, according to Representative Richard M. Simpson, Republican of Pennsylvania. Closer adherence to the intention of the act, he said, is aiding American industry.

Volume improved yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchanges with tin showing double the activity of any other day this year and cottonseed oil registering the highest volume since March 3. Prices were generally lower, reflecting improvement in the Far Eastern situation.

Trygve Lie sailed for his native Norway yesterday after asking the United Nations officials and the eight diplomats who had come to see him off to give their active support to Dag Hammarskjold, his successor as Secretary General of the United Nations.

A program designed to obtain the nomination of highly qualified candidates for the bench by the major political parties was announced yesterday by leaders of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and the New York County Lawyers Association

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The story of five hours of clashes between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, and James A. Wechsler, editor of The New York Post, was spread upon the public record today.

ARDMORE, Okla., May 7 (UP) -- Ed (Porky) Oliver sank a 6-foot birdie putt on the final green today to share the first-round lead of the rich Ardmore open golf tournament with Earl Stewart Jr. of Dallas.
The long siege of London weather that has gripped New York for ten weeks continued yesterday.
ROME, May 7 (AP) -- Unseeded European players surprised touring American and Australian tennis stars today as a wave of upsets swept through the international tournament.
The following is a round-up of household hints that may be of interest to homemakers:

MUNSAN, Korea, May 8 -- Representatives of the United Nations Command and members of the press took advantage of a one-day recess in the Korean truce talks to fight it out on a crudely marked diamond for the Panmunjom softball championship.

Where did Henry Ford get the idea of an assembly line? There seems to be some confusion between the version of his grandson Henry Ford II, president of the company, and that of the Ford advertising department. On a television program this week Mr. Ford said he did not think his grandfather personally would ever take credit for originating the assembly line idea.

GREENSBORO, N. C., May 8 (AP) -- Seven colleges pulled out of the seventeen-member Southern Conference today and arranged to meet on June 14, in Raleigh to make plans for establishment of their own conference.
The wild swans that have lived on Long Island's fresh ponds and brackish inlets from Valley Stream to Montauk for the last sixty years have never had it so good.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 8 (AP) -- The Hollywood Turf Club won a point in a side issue today in its controversy with the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association, but was still deadlocked on the main problem -- the H. B. P. A. demand for more purse money.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- The University of Chicago has decided virtually to abandon the plan of abbreviated education that for more than a decade has had a part in making it a center of controversy in the educational world.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -The House Education and Labor Committee ended three months of hearings on proposed revision of the Taft-Hartley Act today with a burst of criticism of the National Labor Relations Board.

ROME, May 8 (AP) -- Doubles competition took over today in the Rome international tennis tournament but Mrs. Dorothy Head Knode of Alameda, Calif., and Australia's Lewis Hoad squeezed in a couple of important singles victories.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- Associate Justice Felix Frankfurter of the United States Supreme Court was among six leaders of the American legal profession honored today at the fiftieth anniversary of the University of Chicago Law School.

The 7,773-gross-ton Moore-McCormack Line cargo ship Mormacsun has been sold to the Pacific Transport Line for operation in the latter company's Pacific Coast-Orient service, it was announced here yesterday by William T. Moore, president of the Moore-McCormack Line.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 8 -- The American Book Publishers Council was told today that Columbia University planned no move to screen its teaching staff for Communists.

PARIS, May 8 (AP) -- Shipowners today turned down counter-proposals of striking merchant marine officers and sailors whose demands for higher wages and fewer hours of work have paralyzed French coastal and oceanic shipping.

The Marymount College Glee Club sang a concert at Town Hall last evening under the direction of Hugh Ross, offering as the principal work of the evening "Le miroir de Jesus," an oratorio for women's voices and soloists by Andre Caplet.

GENEVA, May 8 -- Messages of congratulation and support for the Red Cross and its work poured into Geneva today on the 125th anniversary of the birth of the founder of the world organization, Henri Dunant of Geneva.

Events today: Member of New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Skitch Henderson conducting, John Corigliano, violinist; Faye Emerson, narrator, Carnegie Hall, 11 A. M.; Jewish People's Chorus, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Program of contemporary chamber music, North Room, Town Hall, 8:30; Galaxy of Stars Concert, Town Hall, 8:30; Eroica Winter, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
The Welfare and Health Council of New York resumed business as usual yesterday, marking time until its twelve newly elected directors assume office.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- John E. Barton, chairman of the New York Power Authority, issued a statement here today attacking charges by Senator Herbert H. Lehman and Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., both Democrats of New York, that his organization intends to turn over the development of hydroelectric power of the Niagara River to private enterprise.

Evening Out made a most fitting debut for a 2-year-old filly yesterday. Competing in the fifty-fifth running of the Fashion against others of her own age and sex over the four-and-a-half-furlong Widener course at Belmont Park, Evening Out moved to a convincing triumph over Wolf Gal, with the heavily-favored Sitting Duck third.
The managing editor of The Naugatuck, Conn., News killed a "scoop" last night to save the life of one of his town's civil servants, the police of the West Thirtieth Street station reported.

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., May 8 -The county prosecutor's office said today it had begun an inquiry into drainage conditions at Colonia Village here after a 2-year-old child had been pulled from a water-filled area in the rear of his home.

DETROIT, Mich., May 9 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., failed today to regain control of the union's largest bargaining unit, Ford Local 600, which represents some 60,000 workers of the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge plant.
KANSAS CITY, May 8 (AP) -Former President Harry S. Truman spent his sixty-ninth birthday anniversary today working, reminiscing and reading greetings from young and old.

The Texas Power and Light Company's issue of 70,000 shares of its $4.80 preferred has been oversubscribed, it was announced yesterday by Union Securities Corporation, Kidder Peabody Co. and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane.

GOLDENS BRIDGE, N. Y., May 8 -- Satilla Samson, a black and white pointer belonging to Joseph Ciaidi of New Haven, displayed particular promise for higher competition today in winning the open derby that began the twenty-sixth spring trials of the Southern New York Field Trial Club.

CINCINNATI, May 8 (AP) -- Warren Giles, president of the National League, today disaallowed a protest by St. Louis Manager Eddie Stankey over a disputed play in the 7-3 victory by the Dodgers over the Cards at Brooklyn Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) -President Eisenhower assured Representative James T. Paterson, Republican of Connecticut, today that local draft boards had authority to continue deferring individual farm youths from military service as long as a deferment was in "the national interest."

John P. McGrath, former Corporation Counsel, announced last night that his law firm had declined to serve as counsel to the City Transit Authority because its selection was not the unanimous choice of the new five-member agency, a condition it regarded as essential to constructive attorney-client relations.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 8 -- Paul L. Troast, Republican candidate for Governor in New Jersey, promised here today to appoint a woman to his cabinet if he is elected in November.

ALBANY, May 8 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today the names of 432 persons who passed the examination for admission to the bar held on March 5 and 6. A total of 1,206 applicants took the test.

Lehualani (Flower of Heaven) will go back to keeping house in Jackson Heights, Queens, when Macy's flower show closes tonight, but thousands of New Yorkers who watched her making leis will remember a sarong-garbed maiden in a tropical setting.

Last night's program by the New York City Ballet at the City Center consisted of four aspects of George Balanchine's art as a choreographer in as many ballets. For a man with as marked a style as his, he can manage a notable variety.

LONDON, May 8 -- Garry Davis, former United States bomber pilot, and self-styled "World Citizen," was taken to a London hospital for observation today after he tried to force his way into Buckingham Palace to petition the Queen.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- With high officials locked in conferences for the second day, the United States, it was understood, asked today for guidance from the United Nations command in Korea on a possible basis for a counter-offer to the Communist eight-point proposals for handling prisoners of war.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A three-member division of the Interstate Commerce Commission approved today the setting up of a transcontinental motor bus system which, it said, would make possible more effective competition with the Greyhound Bus System.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, told Congress today that the cost of national defense and foreign aid made it impossible to balance the Federal budget in the fiscal year 1954 starting July 1 and that the present legal limit of $275,000,000,000 on the national debt might have to be increased.

President Eisenhower, without actually alluding to the specific terms of the latest Communist truce proposal, put his finger squarely on its most significant defect when he spoke in New York on Thursday evening. He stressed the idea that we must be "fair." This he set up as an attribute of strength when he said:
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- President Eisenhower was guest of honor tonight at a stag dinner given in the Hotel Statler by the White House Correspondents' Assocation.
MIAMI, Fla., May 8 (AP) -- Russell Tongay went to Tarpon Springs today for the burial of his swimming-star daughter, Kathy, 5 years old, after denying that he had given her a fatal beating.

LOS ANGELES, May 8 -- The lack of formal examinations to test the mental and emotional state of key witnesses may often lead to unjust verdicts in court trials, a leading authority in legal medicine said today at the 109th annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association.

Commodity prices closed generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was light with only potatoes showing improvement over the activity earlier in the week. Cocoa, soybean oil, hides, lead, rubber and tin ended lower.

Loretta Young will be the narrator and star of a weekly series of filmed dramas to be televised over the N. B. C. network beginning Sunday, Aug. 23, from 10 to 10:30 P. M. Entitled "A Letter to Loretta," the program will be produced by Tom Lewis, Miss Young's husband, under the sponsorship of the Proctor and Gamble Company.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Average primary market prices were unchanged at 11.0 for the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

BOSTON, May 8 -- Billy Goodman, the second sacker of the Red Sox, is a pretty fair batter, but his name never bobs up in conversations about long-ball hitters. Still, it was an eleventh-inning homer by Goodman that ended tonight's marathon between the Yankees and Red Sox in favor of the home side, 2 -- 1.
A class of physically handicapped youngsters in Public School 109, 215 East Ninety-ninth Street, is winding up its school year with gains in weight, height and food appreciation.

PARIS, May 8 -- The Mayer Cabinet agreed today on a series of measures designed to balance president and future budgets and to reinforce the Executive power, which has been notoriously weak in France.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -The Senate approved today creation of thirty-nine more Federal judgeships. It did so by voice vote after adopting an amendment by Senator Olin H. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, to add one district judge for Puerto Rico.

One of the first thoughts of the founders of New York was for the afflicted. "Soon after their arrival upon Manhattan Island the Dutch burghers established a hospital within the Fort for the aid and comfort of the sick," wrote Mrs. John King Van Rensselaer in "The Social Ladder" (Henry Holt, 1924).

NEW DELHI, India, Saturday, May 9 (AP) -- An Air India passenger plane crashed in a ball of fire today, killing eighteen persons, including two Americans, in India's second air disaster within a week.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 8 (AP) -- Sam Snead, the 1952 winner, went ahead of the field on his own course by shooting his second straight 67 today to lead Ben Hogan by one stroke at the halfway stage of the seventy-two-hole Greenbrier open tournament.
BALTIMORE, May 8 -- Under a pension plan put into effect during his own tenure, Roy B. White will retire as president of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad and will become chairman of the board.

New York and New Jersey pier workers voted yesterday to keep the shape-up method of dock hiring and thereby increased the likelihood that their union, the International Longshoremen's Association, would be expelled from the American Federation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The American Federation of Labor was warned today that Federal legislation would be enacted to clean up the International Longshoremen's Association unless the A. F. L. acted itself to purge its racketeer-dominated dock union affiliate.

A brief, heavy thunderstorm, which drenched pedestrians, sent bench sitters in the parks scurrying for shelter and rained out baseball games at the Polo Grounds and Ebbets Field, pushed the mercury suddenly downward last night.
BERLIN, May 8 -- The supply position in West Berlin improved substantially last month as a result of the relaxation of border controls by Soviet authorities.

The only books published today are a pictorial presentation of Italy and an architectural volume on Philadelphia. "Italy," by Martin Hurlimann (Studio-Crowell, $7.50), contains 225 pictures in photogravure with an introductory essay and historical notes by Mr. Hurlimann. "Philadelphia Architecture in the Nineteenth Century," edited by Theo B. White, is published by the University of Pennsylvania Press for the Philadelphia Art Alliance. It sells for $3.50.
The Amerada Petroleum Corporation had a gross operating income of $21,697,418 in the first quarter this year, an increase from $19,560,279 a year ago, the company reported yesterday.

A record 1,661 full - fashioned hosiery machines were scrapped in 1952, according to the annual report of the Textile Machine Works of Reading, Pa. Some were replaced. The report revealed that at the end of 1952 there were 9,469 full-fashioned machines in place as compared with 10,945 machines at the beginning of the year.

STRASBOURG, France, May 8 -- In a message delivered to the Consultative Assembly by Paul Van Zeeland, Belgian Foreign Minister, the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe urged today that the Soviet peace proposals should not be allowed to retard progress toward the council's goal.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Following is the text of the joint communique issued today by President Eisenhower and Louis St. Laurent, Canadian Prime Minister, after they conferred at the White House together with other officials:

Representative Jacob K. Javits, candidate for the Republican nomination for Mayor, outlined last night a plan by which, he said, the people of the city could bring about a good-government coalition for the November election. He called on the Republican party to take vigorous leadership of the good-government forces.

LONDON, May 8 -- The "great eye" of the Palomar 200-inch telescope soon will be able to peer at a point in space where it is possible that stars no longer rush outward at an ever-increasing velocity, Dr. Edwin P. Hubble of the Mount Wilson and Palomar observatories said here tonight.

The Johns-Manville Corporation may be "faced with a further squeeze on profits as competition for the sales dollar becomes more intense," L. M. Cassidy, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) -The Department of Agriculture estimated today in a season-end report that the last year's cotton crop amounted to 15,136,000 bales, valued at about $2,617,000,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 8 -- There are a good many children in institutions for the feeble-minded who aren't feeble-minded, the American Pediatric Society was told at its sixty-third annual meeting, which ended today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 8 -- Greece accused Bulgaria today of occupying a "no man's land" island in the Evros River [cross on map] and called for an immediate United Nations on-the-spot investigation.

Since there was no cooperation by the weather man at Ebbets Field last night the Phils and the Dodgers will stage one of those day-night programs for separate admissions today, with all holders of last night's ticket stubs welcome back tonight.

QUITO, Ecuador, May 8 -- A Presidential decree based on recommendations of the National Economic Council will increase operating costs for both domestic and international air lines in Ecuador. Object of the decree is to provide service on a $4,000,000 loan from the Export-Import Bank for improvement of airports at this city and at Guayaquil.

MEXICO CITY, May 8 -- A country priest of pure Spanish blood who fought the church and his homeland to make Mexico a nation was born 200 years ago today in the village of Corralejo, State of Guanajuato.

Drug stores can keep their sales volume high by featuring new departments associated with their professional nature, according to Richard N. Shaw, sales director of the drug-pharmaceutical division of Becton Dickinson Co., Rutherford, N. J., medical surgical instruments maker.

HARWICH, England, May 8 (AP) -- Police announced today the identification of three United States women and one German killed on the British steamer Duke of York during a North Sea collision Wednesday. Another American -- an Air Force lieutenant -is missing and believed drowned.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture set out on a myth-debunking expedition today. It was prompted by the fact that within a few days the countryisde in many Eastern states will be ringing with an incessant chorus of drumming and whirring insects.

The French Line announced yesterday that with the aid of travel agencies it had succeeded in placing on ships and planes of other companies about 700 of the 1,150 passengers who were unable to sail on the Ile de France last Thursday because of the strike of French merchant marine officers and seamen.

Both unions and big business were satirized at Hunter College yesterday as 140 seniors won first place in Sing, the college's thirtyseventh annual interclass song competition, for their interpretation of "Facts of Factory Life." They were led by Joan Gellinoff Masket, the first married Sing leader.

State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman charged yesterday that the House of Delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York had adopted a resolution opposing the Mount Sinai Hospital Carver Houses clinic plan after hearing only one side of the argument.

THE spring migration of waterfowl to the great nesting and rearing grounds of the Canadian prairie provinces is more impressive than last year in many areas, and the birds have spread out even in the more northerly regions, where spring thaws have barely started, according to a survey by Ducks Unlimited.

Additional demands including carfare allowances, longer vacations and shorter work days were presented yesterday by the Deck Scow Captains Union and immediately rejected by the Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York, operators of 400 deck scows in New York Harbor, on the Hudson River and along Long Island Sound.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The lack of a quorum alone prevented Senate passage today of a bill to permit Congressional investigators to compel a man, under a grant of immunity, to testify-against himself on pain of punishment for contempt. A readiness to approve it had been plainly indicated by those present.

The establishment of a permanent Eduard C. Lindeman Professorial Chair to preserve the philosophy and teachings of the late Dr. Lindeman, educator and social worker, was announced yesterday by the New York School of Social Work, Columbia University.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 8 -President Eisenhower today won the full endorsement of top business leaders in his demands that a balanced budget precede any reductions in taxes. Members of the Business Advisory Council, called together to advise the Secretary of Commerce on economic affairs, conceded t hat even the excess profits tax, due to expire June 30, should be kept in force until other sources of revenue sufficient to meet Government costs were uncovered.

BUENOS AIRES, May 8 (UP)--The Ministry of Communications advised The United Press today that it was cutting off the transmission of United Press service to client newspapers in the interior of the Argentine effective May 16.

A borrowing by the city of Baltimore will be the biggest bond issue coming to market next week. The Maryland municipality will take bids on Tuesday on $25,479,000 of various obligations. Kansas City, Mo., will receive bids the same day on $8,500,000 of water revenue bonds.

GENEVA, May 8 -- The Swiss Government said today it knew nothing about possible Swiss participation in a commission to control the unrepatriated prisoners of the Korean war except what it had read in the papers. The United States Legation in Bern was no better informed.

A "slow track" for slow learners, which may make it possible for some youngsters who have difficulty with the elementary school program to study seven years instead of the present six, is being considered by school officials.
Last summer I wrote to you commending the apparently increasing interest of both public and private owners in preserving New York's architectural landmarks. I spoke too soon.

CINCINNATI, May 8 (AP) -- The Cardinals made quick use of four Cincinnati errors tonight to send the Redlegs crashing to their eleventh defeat in fourteen games by a 5-3 score. All the Cincinnati runs came on homers, including the fifth each for Gus Bell and Ted Kluszewski and the first major league distance drive by Rookie Bob Marquis.
Ramon Fuentes, a hard punching welterweight from Los Angeles, made his first appearance in the East at the St. Nicholas Arena last night, and it was a triumphant one.
TOKYO Saturday, May 9 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,609 for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M., today, Korea time:

NEW DELHI, India, May 8 -The Communist proposal for a five-nation commission to administer Korean war prisoners refusing repatriation is as far as Communist China will go, according to Indian diplomatic information. Its acceptance will be urgently supported by New Delhi.

ARDMORE, Okla., May 8 (UP) -Earl Stewart Jr., the little redhead from Dallas, carved out another sub-par round over the hillsides of Dornick Hills Country Club course today to forge to the front by a stroke in the Ardmore open golf tournament.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 8 -- The United Nations is doing business -- and intends to keep doing business -- with an American manufacturer who recently charged that the organization was becoming a harbor for spies and saboteurs.

DEARBORN, Mich., May 8 -- The University of Michigan received today a grant of $1,000,000 from the Ford Motor Company Fund for construction on the Ann Arbor campus of a nuclear reactor to be used in nonmilitary research.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 9 -- The executive director of the Baptist Joint Committee on Public Affairs voiced a belief here tonight that the movement to send an American Ambassador to the Vatican City "is past resurrection in this Administration."

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, said today he "has to assume" that former President Harry S. Truman was responsible for what he called a virtual "slowdown" order on military purchases for the Korean war in September, 1950.
BOSTON, May 8 -- A second university professor told Congressional investigators today that he had been hired on the atomic-bomb project after having been a member of the Communist party.
NEWPORT, R. I., May 8 -- The United States Naval War College concluded today its fifth annual round table global strategy discussions, now a recurrent feature of each scholastic year.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) -The State Department announced today that the United States will send a nineteen-man mission to Copenhagen to attend a meeting on the international rubber situation.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 8 -The Colombian Government published today a series of proposed Constitutional reforms that would greatly increase Presidential powers, declare the press "a public service" and proscribe political parties that do not conform to "fundamental principles of Christian democracy."

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 8 -The Thai Government, as well as the people, have not been worrying much about the developments in Laos, mainly because they believe the United Nations would aid, if necessary, since Thailand was one of the first nations to send troops to Korea.

LONDON, May 8 -- The securities markets here ended the week today with prices still falling in nearly all sections except British Government issues. Lower profit statements by several large industrial companies, Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler's reference to British-American trade, and Labor gains in municipal elections induced some scattered selling.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, appointed Frederick H. Schmidt today to the new post of security officer of her department. He had been serving as a supervisor of the investigative division, Federal Bureau of Investigation.

The Giants, who last played on Wednesday, went to the post last night against the Pirates, which represented progress of a sort. But after one and a half scoreless innings, the inevitable rain closed in on the Polo Grounds. The upshot was the season's eighth postponement for the water-logged New Yorkers

LONDON, May 8 -- Britain has informed the Egyptian Government that the terms of reference it has proposed for the negotiations on the future of the British military base, the Suez Canal Zone, in Egypt are not acceptable to this country.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 (AP) -The Senators whipped the Athletics by 10 -- 7 tonight, teeing off against Bobby Shantz and Charley Bishop for five runs in the eighth and taking advantage of four walks and a fly ball to register two more runs in the ninth.
MILWAUKEE, May 8 (UP) -Johnny Antonelli hurled a four-hit shutout tonight as the Braves edged the Cubs, 2 to 0, Chicago suffering its eighth straight defeat.

SHAWNEE - ON - DELAWARE, Pa., May 8 (AP) -- Co-medalist Ellis Taylor of Wlimington, Del., battled through 25 holes today to defeat Frank Allen of Pittston, Pa., 1-up, and advance to the semi-finals of the thirtieth annual Shawnee invitation golf tournament.

TRENTON, May 8 -- A picture of appalling conditions in a county prosecutor's office, widespread gambling and an apathetic public that resented any interference in either was presented here today to the legislative committee investigating the dismissal in January of Deputy Attorney General Nelson F. Stamler.

Stocks ended the second successive week with a gain yesterday and found themselves almost exactly where they had been four weeks earlier, on April 10. Prices drifted lower early in the day but recovered enough in the final ninety minutes to show a rise.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., May 8 -The New York Conference of the Methodist Church, meeting here today for its 154th annual session, recommended that Negro bishops be granted full membership in the church's Council of Bishops.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 8 -Joan Crawford has entered into a profit participation deal with Republic Pictures to play the lead in "Johnny Guitar," a Roy Chanslor story with a Western background.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., the United States representative to the United Nations, promised a House Judiciary subcommittee today that all United States nationals employed in the Secretariat would be "cleaned up" by next October.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The whole weight of the Eisenhower Administration was thrown today into support of the St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project, with the aim of winning Congressional approval.

The world was a vastly different place on the mild, sunny Monday in May when Andrew Weggenman first went to work with an architectural concern. President Theodore Roosevelt was in California, critically examining some trees. Up on West Ninety-third Street an overhead train made such noises that the four horses drawing a banker's carriage bolted, and two of them jumped over a wall into Central Park.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 8 (AP) -- President Spyros P. Skouras scored a resounding victory today in his battle to retain control of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- Astonished Senators heard a meat packer complain today that the Army rejected several thousand dollars worth of canned hamburgers because they were packed "horizontally instead of vertically."

The Ridgewood Country Club turned back last year's New Jersey champions from Montclair, 11 to 4, as the third week of play in the women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub team matches concluded yesterday.

Two exhibitions of sculpture are among the art events currently taking place in New York galleries. That at the Sculpture Center is devoted to work by two artists -- Julian Martin and Henry di Spirito -- who have little in common.

CHICAGO, May 8 (UP) -- Joe Dobson scored his seventh straight victory over the Tigers tonight, giving up only five hits as Chico Carrasquel drove in four runs, for a 7-2 White Sox triumph before 25,491 fans.

DACCA, Pakistan, May 8 -- A leader of the Moslem opposition to the Pakistan Moslem League, tonight challenged Prime Minister Mohammed Ali to produce on his promises of a democratic form of government in this young nation by calling legislative elections here in East Bengal.

The free rescue and towing service operated for motorists on the West Side Highway has been doomed by the city's desperate financial situation. The service, hailed as an important factor in speeding traffic on the hazardous highway, will be discontinued on July 1.

JERSEY CITY, May 8 -- The voters of this Hudson County community, who traditionally prefer politics to baseball or television, will go to the polls on Tuesday to decide whether they want a nephew of former Mayor Frank Hague, or one of his former lieutenants, as they next Mayor.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -Six terror - stricken youngsters got awards for heroism today from Vice President Richard M. Nixon, who told them that meeting him was "part of the cost of the medal."

CHICAGO, May 8 -- A Government attempt to obtain a vast new collection of company records for use in the du Font anti-trust trial today drew bitter protests from defense attorneys who termed the action a "dragnet" which would prolong the case indefinitely.

A citizen, past middle age, whose dress would have won approval from an up-to-date Polonius, stood on the sidewalk staring across the way where the stone walls that marked a period piece of the early years of this century were being stripped from a building, leaving only the steel skeleton naked against the sky.
LONDON, May 8 (Reuters) -The touring Australians defeated powerful Yorkshire by an innings and 94 runs in a first-class English cricket match which ended today.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday and closing prices were 3 to 15 points higher on the active months than on Thursday.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., May 8 -- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Conroy of New York, injured in an automobile collision about ten miles north of here Wednesday afternoon, remained in "fair" condition at St. Mary's Hospital today.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 8 -- An official French military spokesman said tonight that the immediate threat to Luang Prabang, the royal capital of Laos, had been lifted. He said that airlifting of-French Union reinforcements to that Buddhist city had "saved the day" there.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 8 -Charges brought by Uppsala University theologians that the election last October of the Lutheran Bishop of Strangnas, Dr. Dick Helander, was achieved by undue influence on the electorate through anonymous letters attacking his rivals are being investigated by the police.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A "burglar trap" patented this week is designed to enable a cashier, without moving a finger, to knock a bandit off his feet and hold him until the guards or the police arrive. With one knee, the cashier releases a spring-operated "striking bar" that wallops the robber at about calf level.
Seven years of "borrowed" freedom ended yesterday for an escaped German prisoner of war whose prospective mother-in-law discovered his true identity through a magazine article.
HARTFORD, May 8 -- A four-year controversy over the tenure of Municipal Court judges in seventy Connecticut cities and towns was settled today by the General Assembly.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 8 -- One of the most powerful atomic bombs tested in this country was dropped today on simulated military installations and sent flames through a mock forest on the barren desert of the Nevada proving ground.

CARTERET, N. J., May 8 -Police Chief George F. Sheridan said today that he would not follow the recommendations of the Borough Attorney concerning the legality of "queri," a game similar to the bingo banned throughout the state by an Attorney General's decision.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 -- Dr. Monroe E. Deutsch, vice president and provost-emeritus of the University of California, asserted here today that because of the financial aid this country had given to Israel, the Washington Government had the right to make certain demands on the young state.

When so much attention is being paid to the current Communist "peace offensive" of words and gestures, it may be of interest to consider how this tactical change relates to the timetable of atomic development.

Surrogate William T. Collins upheld yesterday the validity of a will drawn by a young woman's great-grandfather who had stipulated that should any of his descendants marry outside the Jewish faith they would have to forfeit their rights to an inheritance.

ROME, May 8 -- The Italian general elections, now less than one month ahead, have caused the Moscow radio to multiply its broadcasts in the Italian language beamed on Italy. They have easily outstripped those of the Voice of America.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 8 -- The heaviest fighting of the Mau Mau rebellion took place early today at a police center at Othaya in the Nyeri area west of Mount Kenya. A Mau Mau force carried out a military attack on the barbed-wire protected police camp.

CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- Bolton Sullivan, president of the Skil Corporation, Chicago said today "an independent directors amended plan of reorganization" for the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company had been filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington.

The nation's expanding aluminum industry set a new monthly production record in March and a new quarterly record in the first three months this year, the Aluminum Association reported yesterday. Daily average production also was at a new high in March.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The National Labor Relations Board issued a broad order today requiring the International Typographical Union, A.F.L., to bargain in good faith and saying, in effect, it would not accept the union's promise to obey the law without such an order.

A three-character play about a bank embezzler, "Run Thief Run," written by James P. Davis, New York newspaper man, has been acquired for Broadway production by the new team of Don Hershey and Peter Glenn. The script, formerly labeled "A Bag of Dreams," once held the interest of Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse.

Red Cross officials announced yesterday that 1,194 pints of blood had been collected on Thursday. The largest collections came from residents of Huntington, L. I., who gave 228 pints; employes of the United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., at 1412 Broadway, who donated 213 pints, and employes of the Royal Insurance Company, 150 William Street, who gave 159 pints.

Ten prominent American Protestant clergymen will travel to Great Britain this summer as exchange pastors under a program set up by the National Council of Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. An equal number of British clergymen will fill pulpits in this country.
DANBURY, Conn., Italy 8 -What does one do about an alderman who does not want his job, and cannot resign because he never took office? That thorny question confronted Danbury's Common council today.

With three performers seeking to retain double crowns and six out to repeat single victories of last year, the twentieth annual Metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships will be held at Triborough Stadium today. Strongly favored to win their fourth straight team title will be the Jaspers of Manhattan College.

The weather at any point on the calendar is an alternation of regression and anticipation. Of course, when January isn't around, January is thought of as a snowy-white crystalline time. When February isn't with us, February is one long blizzard and subzero freeze. March uneven and fickle.
CHICAGO, May 8 (UP) -- Rocky Marciano and Jersey Joe Walcott were warned officially today that foul tactics could cause the loss of next Friday's heavyweight title fight.
