The annual meeting of the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad in St. Louis was recessed yesterday until 10 A. M. today to permit additional time for counting the ballots in the election of directors. The delay is the result of a proxy fight, in which seven directorships on the twenty-one-member board are at stake.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. announced today that he had submitted to the Senate and the House of Representatives a bill to legalize the use of evidence obtained by wiretapping in Federal criminal cases involving national security or defense.

Carl Byoir, public relations counsel, charged yesterday that Pennsylvania truckers were using testimony taken in pre-trial hearings in their anti-trust suit against major Eastern railroads to "smear" his firm.

HOBOKEN, N. J., May 8 -- Authorities revealed today that they were seeking a woman bus rider who reported seeing an automobile with a New York license near the scene where a waterfront hiring boss was shot to death last Monday night.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 8 -- The Delaware River Port Authority voted here today to offer, at public sale on May 20, issues of serial and term bonds totaling $100,000,000 to finance construction of a bridge to connect Philadelphia with Gloucester, N. J.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- A group of publishers of English-language Jewish newspapers declared today that some avowed foes of communism were as dangerous as the Reds themselves "because of their conterapt and disregard for our treasured civil liberties."
The armed forces were accused yesterday of being too arbitrary in exempting from local taxation properties over the country that they have designated for exclusive use by the Federal Government.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- Corn futures displayed considerable buoyancy here today, with the May contract especially strong, influenced by the tight cash market. In other pits, however, there was not much buying except for some short profit-taking.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 8 (AP) -Two speakers looked at the United States economy today and disagreed about what they saw.

Two importations comprise today's new features. At the Normandie is "Landfall," a British drama starring Michael Denison and Patricia Plunkett. In supporting roles are Edith Sharpe, Margaret Barton, Charles Victor, Kathleen Harrison and Denis O'Dea.
Nearly one-fifth of the House of Representatives, accompanied by wives (or husbands) and children, came from Capitol Hill to City Hall yesterday for a strictly non-political week-end.

Physicians treating children who are victims of rheumatic fever can change their emphasis from imposing strictly limited physical activity on the youngsters to a positive program of preventing the conditions that lead to a re-attack of the disease, medical men said yesterday.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 8 -- Andor Foldes, American pianist, gave his first concert on his African tou r here last night to probably the best armed audience any American pianist has faced. The Kenya National Theatre was sold out.

Your recent editorial on the position of the Liberal party was a dandy. The response of Adolf A. Berle Jr., state chairman of the Liberal party, is a disappointment. It is a reaffirmation of an inconsistency which your editorial so brilliantly exposed. In a municipal election, all elements in our city seeking good government must combine if the Democrats are to be ousted.

The health and welfare of children in the United States -- as well as in the rest of the world -- require immediate assistance from the United Nations Children's Emergency Fund, the executive committee of the Child Welfare League of America said yesterday.

The New York Telephone Company, largest operating subsidiary in the Bell System, reported yesterday that net income for the first quarter of this year, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, was $15,850,893. This compared with $13,953,265 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- President Eisenhower and Canadian Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent asserted in a joint statement today that the new act of aggression in Laos, one of the French Associated States of Indo-China, cast doubt on Communist intentions and might have serious consequences throughout Southeast Asia.

BONN, Germany, May 8 -- A Government stratagem to win ratification of the Allied-German treaties by the Bundesrat, upper house of Parliament, was frustrated today when Waldemar Kraft, leader of the All-German bloc, announced he would not pull his party out of the coalition government of the State of Lower Saxony.

LONDON, May 8 -- An assurance of British support for France in Indo-China and an appeal for United States aid in solving Europe's dollar problem were coupled today in a speech by R. A. Butler, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer.

LAWRENCE, L. I., May 8 -- Rock Hall, a spacious and dignified eighteenth-century mansion here, has been painstakingly restored and furnished in keeping with its period. It will be opened to the public tomorrow as the Town of Hempstead Museum.
MacLennan Farrell, fiction editor of Collier's magazine, was dismissed from his job yesterday, three weeks after the dismissal of Bucklin Moon as associate fiction editor.
Zinc shipments from domestic smelters last month were the largest in five months at 86,156 tons, which compared with 77,285 tons in March the American Zinc Institute reported yesterday.

CAIRO, May 8 -- The foreign ministers of the seven Arab nations were busy here today compiling a thick dossier of complaints and aspirations to pour into the ear of United States Secretary of State John Foster Dulles during his visit to the Middle East, beginning in Cairo on Monday.

MOSCOW, May 8 -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov wished the German people success today in their struggle for national unity and for creation of a peace-loving democratic and independent Germany. He asked for quck conclusion of a German peace treaty "answering to the basic interests of the German people and all peace-loving peoples."

A bill that would require virtually all American deep-sea shipping to carry aboard a device that would receive radio calls automatically or to employ a second radio officer has been referred to the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce.

Considerable public interest has been focused on the early meetings of the New York City Transit Authority because of what they may portend as to policy, the chances of success in reaching an agreement with the city, and the attitudes of the various members.

TOKYO, Saturday, May 9 -- The United Nations delegates at Panmunjom demurred today at a new Communist proposal to achieve an armistice in Korea by the transfer of war prisoners to the custody of a five-nation neutral commission and by an international conference to settle their fate.

ST. LOUIS, May 8 (AP) -- The Indians capped an uphill fight tonight with a 4-run rally in the ninth inning, including Dale Mitchell's second homer of the season, to defeat the Browns, 7 -- 4. The Indians had tied twice earlier only to have the Brown's pull back into the lead.

A nation-wide shortage of trained social workers threatens to grow worse. Recent estimates place the number of social workers needed within the next decade at 150,000. This is a formidable figure, considering that there are today only 75,000 practicing social workers employed in public and private agencies throughout the country.

HEWLETT, L. I., May 8 -- A sensational streak of putting carried Frank Strafaci of Garden City, winner of the tourney last year, to the semi-final round of the William D. Richardson Memorial golf tournament at the Seawane Harbor Club today.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, May 9 (AP) -- United States Sabre jets shot down two Soviet-built MIG jets in a low-level clash today deep in northwest Korea, only a few miles from the big jet air base at Antung, Manchuria.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The free world and the Communist bloc of countries are exchanging about $3 billion worth of business annually despite their political and economic differences and the attempted embargo on strategic items.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- President Eisenhower has promised a group of Senators and Representatives from Western States that the Administration will consult with them on matters affecting the Bureau of Land Management, which a reorganization committee has discussed transferring to the Department of Agriculture.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., May 9 -- President Eisenhower golfed and fished for brown trout today with his brother, Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, whom he is sending to Latin America late next month as his personal emissary to strengthen political and economic relations with the countries of that area.

A RETAINING wall of stone or a brick wall for any purpose may sometimes need to be softened with plants in order to blend it into the garden or property. Generally self-clinging vines such as Boston or English ivy, climbing hydrangea or euonymus are used. Or, where space permits, tall-growing shrubs are planted along the base of the wall to cover as much of the surface as possible.

CLEVELAND, May 9 -- Three building projects aggregating close to $2,000,000 announced this week by Robert F. Black, president of the White Motor Company, brings to $20,000,000 the capital expenditures, exclusive of patterns and dies, since 1941. Mr. Black said the company plans to spend $1,000,000 on an addition to the coach plant here and $350,000 on a branch sales and service plant in Regina, Sask.

THE design of the leg in today's furniture is becoming increasingly important. Traditionally, the shape and details of the leg have served to identify the era and country in which the piece of furniture was made. Sketches below show the varied lines this element of furniture has been given over a period of three thousand years. Though each design is distinctive, changes have been gradual.

IT may come as a shock to the admirers of Lion Feuchtwanger, but the sad truth is that the author of "This Is the Hour" and "Proud Destiny" has failed this time to reach the goal he set himself. At first glance, Jean-Jacques Rousseau seems the perfect subject for a fictionalized biography.

Brother Cormac Philip's letter in the April 19 issue of THE TIMES, Professor Pei's of April 26, and, apparently, Topics of The Times for April 12, all argue the question of whether or not foreign language study in our schools and colleges is a waste of time and effort in the light of the practical results achieved.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., May 9 -- A Paris-born Middlebury College professor contends that "Government informers" such as Louis Budenz, who renounced communism, may still be serving the interests of the Soviet Union.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. -- Soon the Rocky Mountains will swarm with refugees from the heat of eastern summer, writing home paeans of praise for this crisp, high land where day temperatures stay in the seventies and people sleep under blankets at night.

Plans are under way for promoting the sale of titckets for the performance of the Sadler's Wells Ballet Company on the night of Sept. 22 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over for the benefit of the Institution of World Affairs.

CHICAGO, May 9 (UP) -- The White Sox scored ten runs in the fourth inning, the largest single inning total of the American League season, to rout the Tigers, 12 to 3, before 8,700 fans today.

TUNIS, Tunisia, May 9 -- Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin, commander of Allied ground forces in Central Europe, pledged last night that France would "keep her word" in Tunisia by leading the protectorate toward a "peaceful free destiny." But he warned that violence and intimidation would not be tolerated.
NEW DELHI, India, May 9 (UP) -- An American school teacher kept her appointment with death early today in the flaming wreckage of an Indian transport plane along with seventeen others.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 9 -Philadelphus Antonio of Dah-Lyn, imported Pekingese owned and handled by John B. Royce of Chestnut Hill, Mass., gained the main award in the Springfield Kennel Club's show today. George H. Hartman judged. The American-bred honors went to a Great Dane, Ch. Dion of Kent, owned by Mrs. Marion Rankin and shown by Lina Basquette.

Promotions for Mother's Day resulted in excellent volume and stores were filling stocks in the wholesale markets here last week, according to Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Fall activity began with many lines being shown.

THE American Recording Society which, with the aid of the Alice M. Ditson Fund of Columbia University, has labored untiringly to make the works of American composers available on records, this week offers music by Aaron Copland and Samuel Barber.

Gen. Karl F. Hausauer, commanding general of the Guard, announced today.

ST. PETERSBURG -- Florida's west coast is looking for another record-breaking summer season, with reduced rates already prevailing. They will continue reduced until the start of the winter trade in early December. This means that for the most part prices are slashed in half.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- There are 116,743 separate Government units in the United States, many of which directly affect daily living. These governmental units direct such operations as the education of children and the protection of homes from fire and of individuals from criminals.

PARIS, May 9 -- United States foreign policy, as applied in Europe, is entering a new and difficult phase. Divisive signs are commencing to appear like tiny cracks in the wall of Western harmony. There is ample time to mend them. But if they are not heeded, trouble can be foreseen.

Secretary of State Dulles is on his way to Cairo to begin a survey that will take him all the way to New Delhi. India. He is the first American Secretary of State to make this journey, and he is doing it at a critical time.

The N. B. C. Summer Symphony played a concert yesterday afternoon at the Belasco Theatre, with Frank Brieff conducting. Mr. Brieff, a member of the viola section of the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra, also is conductor of the Bach Aria Group and the New Haven Symphony.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., May 9 -- A thousand visitors viewed the gardens of Planting Fields, the 400-acre estate of Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe off Chicken Valley Road, here. It was a benefit showing for the maintenance and expansion of the arboretum when the estate, by the will of Mr. Coe, will come into possession of the Long Island Agricultural and Technical Institute of the New York State University, at Farmingdale.

Surgical history was made the other day in Philadelphia when, with the aid of a machine devised by Dr. John H. Gibbon Jr., a pioneer in such matters, an 18-year-old girl had a hole closed in the wall that separated the right from the left chamber of her heart. For twenty-six minutes Dr. Gibbon's machine served both as a heart and as a lung.

Cardinal Spellman was honored at Governors Island yesterday with a citation from the American Legion commending him for his leadership in fostering Americanism and for his interest in the welfare of American service men as exemplified by his visits to the front in Korea.
Seaboard and Western Airlines, an all-freight trans-Atlantic carrier, will complete six years of ovre-ocean operation today with its 1,931st crossing of the Atlantic.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 9 (UP) -Royal Bay Gem staged a typical stretch run today as he led home ten 3-year-olds, including several candidates for the Preakness, in the $36,300 Jersey Stakes at Garden State Park.

A new program in nursing education for graduate nurses, leading to the Bachelor of Science in Education degree with a major in Nursing will be offered at Hunter College in September, Prof. Claire Favreau, director of the college's Division of Nursing Education, announced yesterday.
An air of confusion and uneasiness hung over the New York-New Jersey waterfront yesterday following Friday's vote by longshoremen to retain the shape-up hiring system on the docks.

TOKYO, Sunday, May 10 -- The Communist delegation at Panmunjom indicated today that no veto power would be demanded in the neutral nations commission proposed to hold prisoners of the Korean war unwilling to return behind the Iron Curtain after an armistice.

IN the recent Congressional hearings on proposals to repeal the 20 per cent U. S. tax on movie admissions, spokesmen for the industry provided a statistical Gethsemane in a twenty-five-page statement of exhibitors' woes.

IT is a valuable thing to have our major musical organizations tour the country. One needs to travel with such an ensemble only for a little while to realize how useful such an undertaking can be. It is not only the communities visited that are benefitted, but the traveling groups themselves.
MILWAUKEE, May 9 (UP) -- The Cubs snapped an eight-game losing streak today as Right-Hander Bob Rush shut out the Braves on three hits, 2 to 0.
A facing up to reality rather than escape should be the aim of modern religion, Rabbi Louis I. Newman said yesterday in his sermon at Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.
WEST POINT, May 9 -- Army's track and field team had too much depth for Pennsylvania today, routing the Quakers, 91 -- 49, on a soggy track. It was the first dual meet held between the schools.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 9 -Business will continue to boom along through the rest of 1953, with sales volume exceeding the previous year's totals, the Business Advisory Council informed the Secretary of Commerce, Sinclair Weeks, today.

TIME was when a stockbroker simply bought and sold shares on order, arranged transfers, collected dividends and performed other such dull and mechanical chores. Occasionally he might tip off a few good customers, say, that Old Pirate Rum was about to clinch a deal with the British Navy and would shortly zoom upward on the market.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 9 -- The University of Notre Dame's College of Arts and Letters will dedicate May 15 and 16 its new home, the $2,300,000 I. A. O'Shaughnessy Hall of Liberal and Fine Arts. Six persons will receive awards of honorary degrees at a special convocation.

ENTRIES are invited for the 1953 International Exhibition of Photography sponsored by the Photographic Society of America in connection with its 1953 convention, which is to be held Aug. 3-8 inclusive at the Biltmore Hotel, Los Angeles.

Piling up points in wholesale fashion, George Eastment's Manhattan College squad captured the team title for the fourth straight year in the twentieth annual metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.
ALBANY, May 9 (AP) -- The Empire State Federation of Teachers Unions asserted today that educational recommendations of a tax payers' group were "irresponsible and unsound."

Michigan State College, in cooperation with the University of Chicago, is planning a nation-wide research project designed to determine the existing relations between public education and the press and radio. The Michigan Department of Journalism will coordinate this extensive study of education-press-radio cooperation. The Midwest Administration of Chicago will collaborate.

Three centuries of New York's maritime history, from Dutch sailing craft to today's superliners, are depicted in the special marine exhibition, "The Sea and the City," which will open Thursday at the Museum of the City of New York,

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 -- A popularized version of the city government's annual report, explaining what the Administration did in 1952 and what it plans for the future, will be made available to all families in the Philadelphia area tomorrow.

Nine new meet records were established as Poly Prep took the title for the eighth straight year in the ninth annual Ivy Prep Schools League track and field championships yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium.

MOTHER'S DAY, variously known as "a real part of American life" and "an opportunity to offset the poor business of an early Easter" (by the day's official promoters and a newspaper financial writer, respectively), is celebrated today for the fortieth time. Officially, that is.

WHAT with the center of attraction being largely new techniques these last few weeks, the mere subject matter of movies has somewhat escaped considerate view -at least, in this critical corner, which is mainly maintained for such pursuit. So let us herewith resume the franchise with some briskly inclusive reviews.

LONDON, May 9 -- If Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill was toying with the idea of calling another general election this summer in the hope of increasing the slight majority of the Conservatives in the House of Commons, this week's municipal and borough elections are likely to make him think again.

MIAMI BEACH -- Late spring and summer visitors to the east coast of Florida will have a greater choice of accommodations than they have ever had before. At Miami Beach alone about 90 per cent of the 375 hotels and 1,800 apartment buildings will remain open, providing around 25,000 hotel rooms and 17,000 apartment units.
Regarding Henry Steele Commager's "A Fighting Printer -- And a Free Press" (April 19) I think your readers would like to know of an interesting sidelight on the Zenger case.

WASHINGTON -- Those "taxpayers' playgrounds," the large and small National Parks and other areas maintained by the National Park Service are already attracting visitors in such numbers that the service is predicting "phenomenal" increases in this summer's attendance.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Loans and inventories of the Federal farm price support program totaled $3,065,643,000 for the first nine months of the 1953 fiscal year that ends June 30, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

THE nation's railroads are preparing to move the usual flow of vacationists to resort areas this summer, and while they offer no new fare inducements there are a number of new services already in effect and in the offing which should be pleasing to travelers.

ANYONE who remembers the Soviet-sponsored Waldorf-Astoria peace conference a few years back will remember the novelist Fadayev, who is general secretary of the Union of Soviet Writers. He headed up the visiting Soviet cultural contingent.
RICHMOND, Va. -- Having broken all previous travel records in 1952, the states of the Midsouth are prepared for what officials optimistically predict will be another banner year for tourism.

The trend toward feminine control of family expenditures will manifest itself in the Barnard College curriculum next fall with the introduction of an economics department course in "Personal Finance." The course will consider installment buying and other credit problems, insurance, annuities, Social Security, investment for security and income, and the effects of taxation and inflation on a personal budget.
BALTIMORE, May 9 (AP) -- Royal Vale beat favorite Crafty Admiral for the second time in a week today to win the fifty-second running of the Dixie Handicap at Pimlico.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Following is a statement read by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, at a news conference today reviewing the Administration's actions relating to recent developments in Laos and Thailand:

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UP) -The Congress of Industrial Organizations announced today that former President Truman and twelve other prominent persons had agreed to serve as advisers to the $1,000,000 foundation set up in honor of the late Philip Murray, C. I. O. president.

The New York Pops concerts at Carnegie Hall came to an end yesterday morning with a fifth program, designed for children and billed as a "Lollypops." Prokofieff's "Peter and the Wolf," with Faye Emerson as narrator, was the big attraction.

Negotiations have been completed between the Luckenbach Steamship Company, Inc., and the Port of New York Authority for a seven and a half-year lease of Cargo Terminal Building 140 at Port Newark, Joseph M. Byrne Jr., vice-chairman of the bi-state agency, announced yesterday.

DELPHINIUM is one of the perennials which is rewarding but not easy to grow in many parts of the country, particularly in the East. Plants may give excellent bloom the first year, but to maintain the display some renewal is necessary at frequent intervals.

Norwegian-American groups will commemorate Norwegian Constitution Day with a parade next Sunday in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. On May 17, 1814, Norwegian delegates, meeting at Eidsvold, adopted a Constitution patterned along American lines which granted them their own legislative assembly.

DISCOVERY of the United States 10-cent air-letter sheet printed in a chocolate-brown color, instead of the bright red in which it has been normally appearing since its release in 1947, was disclosed here last week.

" COW business is damn fine for men and mules, but it's hell on horses and women." Substitute any Western state for "cow business" and dogs for "mules" and you have the ancient quip which Mrs. Marriott has paraphrased to obtain her title.

Eleven young American women, several of them from New York and the metropolitan district, were presented at the Court of St. James on Thursday, the second presentation party of the year, and several others will be presented at the Queen Charlotte Bali on Tuesday in London.

ROAD improvements during the last year will make the way much easier this season for vacationists planning motor trips throughout the country. Several additional projects, still in progress, are expected to be completed before the annual summer motoring rush gets into full swing.

An Immigration Service ruling that all persons are "aliens" when they enter the United States, whether they be foreigners or American nationals or citizens, has been declared invalid by the United States District Court.

PORTLAND, Ore. -- Although the Pacific Northwest contains far more scenic attractions than the average tourist could see in many years of wandering, man actually has succeeded in augmenting nature's marvels in this far-flung region of the nation.

TULIPS bid fare to over-shadow all other spring bloom this week and next. Dogwood, lilacs and apple blossoms will claim their share of the limelight, but the flamboyant tulips are likely to steal the show.

MONTREAL -- Canada from Montreal to the Atlantic might be divided into six vacation areas -- the Laurentians, Laurentide National Park, the Gaspe, New Brunswick, Prince Edward Island and Nova Scotia with Cape Breton.

WHEN Martha Graham and her company open a week of repertory at the Alvin Theatre next Sunday evening, there will be a new work under the title of "Theatre for a Voyage." (Like so many of Miss Graham's titles, this one will probably explain itself upon fuller acquaintance.)
Do modern electronic devices actually speed up checking account operations and improve service sufficiently to justify their installation?

LIMA, Peru, May 5 -- The recently announced plan of a United States capitalist for colonizing a vast area in the Amazon basin of Peru is meeting a mixed reaction here. The plan, sponsored by Robert G. LeTourneau of Longview, Tex., a manufacturer af heavy machinery, includes a concession in jungle country to be developed agriculturally, mainly by Peruvian colonists.

FOR all our republican condescension, most Americans dearly love a queen. From a safe distance we can observe all the pomp and glitter of her existence -- satisfying a left-over craving from "The Red Fairy Book" days -- without taking on any responsibility.
SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, May 10 (AP) -- An American Starfire night fighter pilot today reported the first victory for that new type jet over a Red MIG-15 in the Korean war.
TOKYO, May 9 -- Britain's Anglo-Iranian Oil Company extended to Japan today its fight to prevent foreign purchases of Iranian petroleum products, which, the company asserts is still its property.

In November, 1929, Mr. Heartman bought at a sale in the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., New York, a copy of Thomas Hariot's sixteenth century work on "the new found land of Virginia" for $7,300. Six years later, in the same place, he paid $10,400 for a nearly complete set of "Jesuit Relations," reports on America of early Jesuit missionaries.
ITHACA, N. Y., May 9 -- Three meet records were broken as Cornell defeated Princeton, 77 to 63, in a track meet today.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of the new Department of Health, Education and Welfare, said today it was her "personal philosophy" that adequate medical care for all Americans could be achieved by "expanding and perfecting the system of voluntary, non-profit, privately operated health-insurance programs."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 9 -With Dick Emery, a right-hander, allowing only one hit, the Princeton baseball team blanked Yale in an Eastern Intercollegiate League clash today, 5 to 0. The result was a disappointment to the followers of the Bulldogs, particularly since the squad showed to such good advantage yesterday in beating Holy Cross.

OTTAWA, May 9 -- Prime Minister Louis S. Laurent told the Canadian Parliament within an hour of his return from Washington this afternoon that his visit had been "most interesting and very pleasant" and that there was good reason to believe it may bear fruit.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 9 -Yale scored a 2-stroke victory over Nenn State today to win the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association's team title. 599 -- 601, on the Springdale golf course.

Auction buyers making the rounds of the galleries this week will find, beside a plentiful supply of furniture and room accessories, an unusual quantity of paintings, from old masters to contemporary works.

BETWEEN 1934 and "February Hill" and 1953 and "The Wild Honey" there has come from the pen of Victoria Lincoln a nice display of novels, long and short, and stories, short and long. These are simply the published products of the pen, however, and they constitute considerably less than the half of it.

The rainy season of 1953 may not become as famous as the blizzard of '88, but it certainly is destined to be more than a Weather Bureau statistic. Home gardeners throughout the East and particularly in the suburbs of New York City have found it almost impossible this spring to mow their lawns, and have watched in vain for April-sown seeds to sprout.
RYE, N. Y., May 9 -- The New Rochelle High School Huguenots won the sixth annual Rye invitation track and field championships on the local high school track today, scoring 25 points.
Two tankers that have been serving as storage vessels at Terrebonne Bay, La., are now on a 4,500-mile journey that will end under the ship-breakers' hammers in the United Kingdom.
While the pressure for more power increases, fossil fuel resources are dwindling. Even at the present rate of consumption coal and oil will be scarce in some areas in the next fifty years.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 -- Retail sales continue ahead of a year ago, largely due to aggressive promotions stressing price reductions. In the aggregate, since a year ago consumer installment buying is up roughly one-third, of which a large slice consists of automobile sales credit.

SEOUL, Korea, May 9 -- One thousand disabled veterans of the Army of the Republic of Korea marched through the main streets of this city at noon today to hold the latest demonstrations in a series of protests against any peace without unification of the country.

THE story behind the broadcast of "Adventure" began more than three years ago when those of us in news and public affairs at C. B. S. Television became curious about the ways and means by which television could provide the most usefull educational service ("Adventure" makes its debut at 5 P. M. today).

WILLIAMSBURG, Va. -- Historic Williamsburg will be at its scenic and sentimental best during the next few weeks. An uncommonly generous spring has brought the old town's gardens to an almost unparalleled peak of radiance.
DACCA, Pakistan, May 9 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali won the support today of an opposition group whose efforts had threatened earlier to break the young Pakistani nation in two.
DURING the past few years groups of so-called "exceptional children" in our population have been attracting ever-increasing attention as various organizations seek aid for their particular problems.

The word "finch" reaches far back to Anglo-Saxon origins, its original meaning lost, though it probably applied to some small bird. It has been taken, however, by the ornithologists as the family name for one of our largest groups of seed-eating birds. But add the word "gold" to "finch" and you rouse a stirring sight or memory in anyone who knows a handful of birds by name. The goldfinch is Mr. Spring.

CHILDREN and adults who enjoyed reading together Herbert Zim's "What's Inside of Me?" and "What's Inside of Plants?" will welcome these new explorations. Like the first volumes, these are set in two sizes of type, the larger to be read by children, the smaller for the use of parents or teachers who are sharing in the reading.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today that there was general agreement between the United States and its allies in the Korean war on the need for clarifying or modifying certain points of the new Communist truce proposals.

THE fluted, white, trumpet-shaped walls of Morning Glory Pool, one of the loveliest sights in Yellowstone National Park, hold crystal-pure water that mirrors the blue of the sky; the surface sparkles, wisps of steam drift above it and shades of red and rust tint its borders.
There are errors in Barbara Ward's essay on Shakespeare, "'The Spell He Casts Is the Spell of Life'" (April 19) * * *

THE eighteenth century in England makes a good case for itself in its own staid way in two of the group exhibitions which have recently opened. One, assembled at the Knoedler Galleries in honor of the approaching coronation of Queen Elizabeth II, includes important loans from public and private collections with portraits by Gainsborough, Reynolds, Raeburn, Hoppner and Lawrence, and Constable's "Weymouth Bay" from the Boston Museum.

From the days of the French voyageurs the St. Lawrence-Great Lakes System has been a recognized highway to the heart of the North American Continent. In more recent years the St. Lawrence has been an underdeveloped source of hydroelectric power. The project to open some or all of the Great Lakes to sea-going vessels of adequate tonnage is inextricably linked with the project to develop the river's latent power.

Discrimination in coverage, long a fundamental weakness in our social security program, is still one of the major defects that must be corrected to insure a sound program of old age benefits, E. J. Eberling, Professor of Economics, of Vanderbilt University, told the National Social Security Conference in Chicago recently.

THE sinner turned saint is a common enough figure in Christian history but few since Mary Magdalene have caught the imagination like the French hermit-priest Charles de Foucauld (1858-1916). Father de Foucauld's life story is shot through with paradox and contradiction. An ardent, almost chauvinistic Frenchman, he lived a life of self-imposed exile among the Targui warriors of Algeria.
Efforts to avert a strike threatened on the Hudson Manhattan Railroad for 7 A. M. tomorrow ended without progress yesterday, and no plans were made for additional negotiations today.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 9 -- Much of the commotion generated by the Vietminh invasion of Laos, north-westernmost of the Associated States of Indo-China, has died down now that the Communist-led insurgents have pulled back some of their forces from the areas they originally threatened.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: The prevailing weather brings not only rain but mildew to roses and grapes, botrytis to lilies, delphinium and many other plants. Dust roses with sulfur or fermate to prevent gray coating of foliage; spray grapes with fermate or karbam. To halt spotting and rot of leaves on plants afflicted with botrytis, weed around them to improve air circulation and spray with bordeaux mixture.

ALBANY, May 9 -- A steadily larger percentage of the state's employed population is contributing toward the expense of running the state government through paying income taxes, a five-year survey by the State Tax Commission showed today.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 9 -- Farmers of the nation's Corn Belt had more beef cattle in their fattening pens this week than at any other time in recent years, and, if they adhere to plans filed with the Department of Agriculture, they will place nearly half on the market before July 1.
WEST POINT, N. Y., May 9 -Pennsylvania remained at the top of the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League with a 5-to-4 victory over Army at Doubleday Field today.

Every week-end for the rest of this month will see going-intocommission days for near-by yacht clubs. The pattern is familiar. Somehow or other, amid rushing and excitement, clubhouses, lounges, porches, runways, floats and flag poles get painted.

HONOLULU -- One of the biggest issues in Hawaii at the moment involves new hotels at Waikiki for tourists. No one denies that additional hotel accommodations are needed to care for the increasing number of vacationists who come -- or want to come -- to these tropical islands.
CAIRO, May 9 -- Egypt won support today from the representatives of seven other Arab nations in her demands for the unconditional withdrawal of British military forces from the Suez Canal zone.

TO paraphrase a comment once made by James Branch Cabell. Jean Stafford seems to have dedicated herself to writing beautifully about unbeautiful matters. The smell of the sickroom hovers like an incubus over these sad and unforgettable short stories.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Nations of the free world are making multi-million-dollar wagers on the price of wheat. The United States Government is the biggest bettor -- and a sure loser.

KYLIE TENNANT writes with unflagging gusto about any phase of Australian life she chooses to treat. Taking her six earlier novels and this, her latest, together, one feels no reluctance whatever to assert that she is one of the most interesting novelists in the Commonwealth today and the one of her generation most likely to write, sooner or later, a great story of Australian life.
NAIROBI, Kenya, May 9 -- A British report on European farming in the Kenya highlands came out this week, urging more and faster immigration from Europe.

ROME, May 9 (UP) -- Maureen (Little Mo) Connolly of San Diego, Calif., and Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., charged into the women's finals of the Rome international tennis championships today -- but the last two men from the United States playing in the tournament were eliminated in the quarter finals.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said today that he had written a letter to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, giving his views on trade with Communist countries.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 9 -- Dr. Charles F. McKhann, Professor of Pediatrics at Jefferson Medical College, Philadelphia, spoke out today against a proposed cut of $65,000,000 in the United States Public Health Service, as recommended to Congress by Secretary Oveta Culp Hobby's Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
DETROIT, May 9 (AP) -- This decade may well go into automotive history as the "accessory age."

THE Caribbean, general impression to the contrary notwithstanding, is not reserved for millionaires. To prove this, two young tourists with a sharp eye for the economical alternatives, recently spent twenty days on an island vacation for just under $400, or about $10 a day each, plus airline fare.

VIENNA, May 9 -- The Czechoslovak Government, which has deported tens of thousands of middle-class families from the cities in the past two years, has decided to strike another blow against them by reducing or canceling their pensions.

BOGY or battle-cry, Pan-Slavism has been in some degree an issue in every major European war or revolution over the past hundred years. In World War I Pan-German plans for Mitteleuropa stimulated a counter-reaction of Slav resentment and Slav solidarity, tempered, however, by the primary reliance of the Poles, Czechs and Yugoslavs on Western aid.

Proper display of the 1953 city $5 and $10 auto use tax stamps on private passenger cars is likely to prove a guessing game with many motorists, N. Peter McLean, executive secretary of the Thirty-fourth Street-Midtown Association, said yesterday.

Uncle Sam is a silent partner of several eastern discount houses that are tapping a big Middle Western market, but he is deriving no profit from the association. His postmasters in several important Indiana cities have been snowed under by a storm of mailorder flyers from the discount houses offering goods to Hoosiers at substantial discounts.
A reduction in electric service rates will become effective on June 1 for most residents of Staten Island, the State Public Service Commission announced yesterday.

THE espalier fruit tree is ideal for the small garden where space does not permit trees of standard or even dwarf size. The espaliered type of tree can be grown along paths, against the side of buildings or a background material for a flower border. The branches of an espalier are trained so that they will form a flat tree, rather than the ordinary spreading bushy type.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UP) -- Government mediators cautiously reported "hopeful" signs today for industrial-labor peace this summer. The mildly optimistic forecast was made despite the opening of nation-wide wage negotiations in key industries and previous reports the industrial outlook could be black.
BUENOS AIRES, May 9 (AP) -Dispatches of The Associated Press, United Press and International News Service all but disappeared from the pages of newspapers.
ABEE, symbolizing industry, and two medals, superimposed on a shield containing a beehive, illustrate an Italian 25-lire violet stamp received by Pierson Ostrow.
OUT of the welter of executive huddles and deliberations concerning the fate of "Your Show of Shows" for next season, these results have evolved:

The members of the Soviet Cabinet heading the ministries that direct the Soviet Union's economics have had their powers and freedom of action greatly increased as part of the post-Stalin reorganization of the Soviet Government, Pravda, Communist party newspaper, has disclosed.

The Seaboard Finance Company went right ahead and marketed $5,000,000 of 5.75 per cent sinking fund preferred stock last week, although some economists were shaking their heads over the rising volume of consumer credit -- $25,700,000,000, according to latest Federal Reserve Board estimates.

Ways in which art education can benefit the "Sunday painter" and the person who is "just interested" in art, as well as the serious student, will be discussed on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. by Simon Lissim in the eighth of a series of ten free art lectures at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

CHICAGO, May 9 --Steel mills in the Chicago area produced a record daily average of steel in April, 59,600 tons, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. Output for the month amounted to 1,798,100 tons, under the record 1,833,500 ton monthly output set in March due to a one-day shorter working period in April.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 9 -Five hundred parents of Princeton University freshmen will participate in the university's fifth annual Freshman Parents Day program next Saturday on the campus.

A NUMBER of attempts have been made to translate Sholom Aleichem into English, all of them disappointing. This is unfortunate, as his world reputation among Jews as a writer and humorist is fully justified.

BONN, May 9 -- Peace has its victories no less renowned than those of war, and German democracy won one this week when it recognized, located and vigorously attacked the plot of Dr. Werner Naumann's Nazis against parliamentary democracy in the Federal Republic.

SALT LAKE CITY -- The wide open spaces have finally realized that what they can best sell to the tourist is wide open spaces. Short on big cities, formalized entertainment and formal resorts, folks in the Intermountain West, from the western slopes of the Rockies to the eastern ridges of the Sierras, and from the Canadian to the Mexican borders, are nevertheless ready to lure many tourists.

OF all the fifty-two weeks of the year, the proverbial two weeks when the average vacationist takes his vacation are probably the most crucial. You know how it is. You dream of them for weeks and months ahead. You consider the dates when the kids will get out and have to be back for school once again.

HOBOKEN, May 9 -- This mile-square city of 50,000 residents and 26,200 registered voters will close the most active municipal campaign in its history on Tuesday with the election of a Mayor-Council administration to replace the present commission form of government.

MOTHERS are no less popular than before. At any rate, Mother's Day business in New York and Brooklyn department stores this year went ahead of last year's by a small margin, despite poor weather at the beginning of the week.

AS the reminiscences and critical essays in this volume abundantly show, Thomas Wolfe was obsessed by the idea of time. The Twenties, when Wolfe was serving his literary apprenticeship was, as a matter of fact, the great period of the "time" novels, of Proust's "Remembrance of Things Past" and Joyce's "Ulysses," of Fitzgerald's "The Great Gatsby." Faulkner's "The Sound and the Fury" and Virginia Woolf's "To the Lighthouse."

TRENTON, May 9 -- When the legislative committee that was selected to investigate the dismissal of Nelson F. Stamler as deputy attorney general chose Augustus C. Studer as its counsel, a lot of eyebrows were raised. The slightly built, soft-spoken and dignified corporation lawyer did not seem to fit the role.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May -- When the counting of votes in the Senate election ceased tonight, the indications were that Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies would retain control of the upper house by a majority of two instead of the majority of four he now has in the sixty-member body.

THE Mamiyaflex Automatic, a twin-lens reflex camera taking twelve 2 1/4x2 1/4-inch pictures on 120 film, is one of three new Japanese camera imports recently introduce by the Mamiya Camera Company of America, Inc., 82 Wall Street.

" THE Negev will be cut off (by the Arabs) because it is indefensible," a friendly British diplomat assured Jewish Agency representative David Horowitz just before the partition of Palestine. "Galilee will only hold out a few days.
Dr. Frederick J. Moffitt, the state's associate commissioner of education, received Long Island University's annual award last night for "distinguished service in education."

TRAVEL aboard the country's domestic and overseas airlines is expected to be the heaviest in history this summer but the schedules now being put into effect are planned with a view to taking care of the big load adequately.

LOS ANGELES, May 9 -- Illegal immigration from Mexico into the southwestern United States, on the increase ever since World War II, has reached a peak of such overwhelming proportions that officers of the United States Immigration Service admit candidly, if unofficially, that there is nothing to stop the whole nation of Mexico moving into the United States if it wants to.

THERE is a magnificent impatience about Frank Tilsley's work which sweeps us into vicarious experience before the first page is finished."The Fortunate Man" is as lusty and vigorous as its predecessor ("Champion Road") and set to as lively a tempo, though it delves deeper into the complexity of human relationships.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 9 -- Big business should assume the burden of some of the bills Uncle Sam has been bearing by himself on projects relating to public welfare.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- A Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee recommended today another year's trial for State Department Operation of the Overseas Information Program, including the Voice of America.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Defense sources indicated today that at least three more training divisions of the Army would soon be closed out and their operations consolidated into the six such units remaining.

Although the 53,330-gross-ton super-liner United States was in service for only six months last year, the fastest commercial ship in the world carried 36,044 passengers on twenty-three trans-Atlantic crossings, or more than half of the 68,354 travelers accommodated on United States Lines vessels in 1952.

SAN FRANCISCO -- With rates at about the level that prevailed last summer, northern California resorts on the coast, in the national parks, on the major lakes and in the mountains are preparing to ring up one of the best tourist years in history on their cash registers.

The Navy had to work out a method of repairing a broken pipe under emergency condiitons without using heat or flame. Out of that pressing need has come a method for making repairs that apparently has inexhaustible industrial applications. Word of the method, which makes use of a special property of a thermosetting resin, has filtered out to industrial engineers and large numbers of inquiries have been coming in.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 9 -The Greenwich Republican Town Committee will select a new chairman Wednesday. It will act on a recommendation of the party's executive committee that Charles H. Tuthill, businessman, civic leader and a key member of the Representative Town Meeting, be named.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 9 -- North African nationalist leaders denounced the invasion of the kingdom of Laos as unprovoked aggression by "Communist imperialists" today and urged Asian countries to bring the case to the United Nations.

ONE of the delights of every vacation is the special foods that are to be enjoyed as part of it. Those who trek to Maine, for example, delight in its fresh lobsters. Folks who vacation in the Adirondacks think there's nothing finer than a dinner of succulent brook trout.

BOSTON -- New England vacation resort operators, fully aware of the attractions of foreign travel this year, report themselves pleasantly surprised by the volume of advance reservations and inquiries about the six-state region.

More than 1,000 business executives from fifty countries will assemble in Vienna May 17 to attend the fourteenth annual congress of the International Chamber of Commerce. Those present will include a large delegation from the United States, representatives of the specialized and regional agencies of the United Nations, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund and the president of the International Bank.

THE reconciliation of a nonrepresentational style with humane subject-matter would seem to be the chief present problem for advance guard New York painters. It is a dilemma, but de Niro, whose paintings are at the Egan Gallery, demonstrates that it is not an insoluble one.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Complaints that the Virgin Islands is rapidly becoming a divorce mill for mainland residents seeking quick and easy-to-get decrees have been reaching members of Congress during the last few months, along with demands for remedial action.

TRENTON, May 9 -- The state committees of the Republican and Democratic parties released today the texts of their proposed 1953 platforms, which will be submitted for approval by the respective party conventions when they convene here on Thursday.

Four brothers-in-law opened their 100th shoe store on Thirty-fourth Street across the street from Macy's last Thursday. The store is the most elaborate link in the country's largest independent retail shoe chain, National Shoe Stores, Inc.

SEOUL, Korea, May 9 -- A settlement similar in purpose to Boys Town, Neb., a community for homeless youngsters, will begin operation with American aid on an island near here in the Han River in July, according to present plans.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- A young postal worker in an eastern city approaches a veteran employe.

A school in which 400 students withdraw an average of 500 books a day from the library, in which the students asked that their sixteen-hour week of classes be increased to twenty without extra credit, in which the professors meet regularly to plan their individual classes -- this describes to some extent the success of the Boston University College of General Education, now in its sixth year.

THEIR home town will be honored when the Garden Club of Flatbush holds its third annual show on Wednesday. The theme, "Our Borough in Spring," will be carried out in eleven arrangement classes interpreting such well-known Brooklyn landmarks as the Academy of Music, Prospect Park, Ebbetts Field and the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

THESE harried days, the travel posters tell us, our best escape is by sea: and the next best, the book charts indicate, is a vicarious sea voyage -- a walking or swimming tour of its depths, fighting on it or under, or simply fighting it.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -South Dakotans who slipped into North Dakota and transferred the remains of Sitting Bull had news today from the head of the North Dakota State Historical Society.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 9 -- The award of scholarships to 268 young men and women representing every county in New Jersey was announced this week by Rutgers University.

The first major change in the program of the Army's Reserve Officers Training Corps since its inception in 1916 has been adopted. A new program, known as General Military Science, was introduced experimentally last September in fifty-four of the 260 colleges and universities that offer R. O. T. C. courses.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 9 (UP) -- A man who was declared dead fifteen years ago pressed a claim today for a share in a $750,000 tract of land left by his father, a onetime slave.

LATE spring is an in-between time as far as travel goes, which means that travel goes just about anywhere. This is the season when the Caribbean and Florida become attractively inexpensive while, at the same time, the resorts in Europe and more temperate parts of the United States may not yet have hit their summer rates.
PHILADELPHIA, May 9 (UP) -Walt Masterson tossed a two-hitter today while the Senators reached Alex Kellner for ten blows as Washington toppled the Athletics to their fourth straight loss, 6 -- 0.

DALLAS, May 9 -- Southwestern business held a steady pace during the last week. Department store sales held to about the same volume as the previous week and in some instances a little better. Merchants reported moderately good response to Mother's Day promotions and spring clearances.

Every contributor of a space-travel tale to a science-fiction magazine takes it for granted that among the thousand million stars and more that can be photographed there are solar systems and hence habitable planets. Is there any basis for the assumption? An examination of recent astronomical literature indicates that there is.

IN the last years of Queen Victoria, a brash American boy made a trip to Europe without funds of any kind, supporting himself by what we now would call hitch-hiking. He wrote an account of his adventures and told how he refused to be impressed by the Diamond Jubilee. "We have jubilees every four years," he said, "only we call them Presidential elections."

A DEAD oriole fell to the hearth. He gazed abstractly at the black and golden feathers and touched the soft body with the fire tongs. A bright apple leat was caught under one wing. He picked the bird up carefully with a piece of newspaper and put it in a box which he found on the shelf of his closet.

The Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute is about to test a new method of detecting icebergs from the air when fog or clouds obscure aerial observations. An airborne radiation thermometer will measure the temperature of the sea surface. The instrument measures the long-wave radiation (heat) from the sea and compares it with the radiation from a water sample of known temperature in the instrument itself.

DERBY, Conn., May 9 -- The Big Red crews of Cornell staged a triumphant procession down the Housatonic River this warm summer afternoon and won the Carnegie Cup as they made a sweep of their third successive regatta.
HARTFORD, May 9 -- Efforts are under way in Connecticut to heal a Republican party split that has been growing since Gov. John Davis Lodge took office in January, 1950.

Every morning outside New York's piers, longshoremen form a semicircle and the pier "hiring boss" picks those who are to work cargo that day. The bosses, many of whom have criminal backgrounds, have arbitrary power. This hiring system, known as the "shape-up," has been the root cause of the evils besetting the docks for years -- kick-backs, loan-sharking, cargo pillaging, and the gang wars to control these lucrative rackets.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 9 -The position of the Roman Catholic Church in Colombia has been greatly strengthened in the Conservative Government's proposed constitutional reforms to be submitted to the Constituent Assembly scheduled to start deliberations on June 15.

Folsom man, so called because of the place where his relics were found, was not the first inhabitant of this continent, Prof. Alexander D. Krieger told a joint meeting of the Society for American Archeology and the Central States Anthropological Society at the University of Illinois last week. He said that man had been in America for more than 15,000 years.

ALBANY, May 9 -- Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, who was military aide to former President Truman, predicted tonight that current investigations in the fields of foreign policy and defense by Congressional committees would have "tragic consequences."

ONE of the more puzzling and little-noticed developments in television has been the qualitative decline in the discussion of current issues on the air. Only too often the discussion program has been turned into a sort of vaudeville free-for-all that generates more emotion than enlightenment.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9 -Sloan fellowships have been awarded to thirty-four industrial executives showing unusual promise for leadership, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology announced today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 9 -Harvard's sweepswingers gave Navy quite a surprise today as they turned in a sparkling, all-out performance before bowing to the world champion midshipmen in the 27th edition of the Adams Cup regatta.

THIS collection of stories about the Bell family, and their farm in a valley of the Ozarks, has a mellow warmness laced with bubbling humor. Jean Bell Mosley, writing of her childhood escapades, of her secrets shared with Grandpa and Grandma, of the peculiarity and kindness of their neighbors, gives us some fresh and lighthearted reading.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 9 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles' tour of the Middle East capitals next week is viewed by Israeli Government authorities as part of a supreme effort by the United States to bring about peace between the Israelis and the Arabs.

Vacations here used to mean luxury, travel for persons with long winter vacations and enough money to travel leisurely. Summer in the United States was off season down here because most travelers headed across the Atlantic.

Floyd Philpott brought back home with him is beginning to wear off for Hogansville and at a somewhat faster pace than the "Philpott boy" can adjust himself to the reality of being back in his home town. Her manners must be natural, but appropriate to her ceremonial duties; she has to be both dignified and informal at the same time.

BOSTON, May 9 -- Columbia's crew easily defeated M. I. T. and Boston University on the Charles River today. The Lions, rebounding from defeats from Princeton, Cornell and Yale, were never in any danger after the half-way mark. M. I. T. was judged second by two officials and thus pushed the Terriers back to third.

Wagner College successfully defended its title yesterday in the second annual College Girls' track and field championships, sponsored by the Metropolitan A. A. U., at Macombs Dam Park, the Bronx. Six colleges participated in the meet.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UP) -Robert A. Taft, Senate Majority Leader, startled some of his Republican colleagues today by a statement that Administration budget estimates now indicated a deficit of about $11,000,000,000 for the fiscal year 1954.

A BOOK that has urgently required writing for many years has appeared at last. It is excellent. Only those who for religious reasons condemn the very idea of divorce are likely to find major fault with this work.

It is believed they will be out in full force again by Labor Day.

George M. Houser's letter was of great interest, but I do feel it is necessary to point out that the so-called "election" in South Africa did not represent the popular vote. The clever manipulation of constituencies made sure of a Nationalist majority.
Mount St. Michael High took the team title yesterday in the third annual Fordham Prep relay carnival at Macombs Dam Park, Bronx. Seventeen schools took part in the meet.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 10 -- Gerald Fehr of Yale defeated Ted Cooney, the medalist, of Harvard, 5 and 3, today to lead the field into the semi-finals of the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association's individual championship tournament on the Springdale course.
With Mother's Day behind us, thoughts focus now on the man of the family, as Father's Day falls on June 21.
Mayor Impellitteri said yesterday at a luncheon of the Citizens Committee for New York City's 300th Anniversary Celebration that "what we need in this town is a few boosters and less knockers."

During the hearings before the Senate Permanent Investigating Subcommittee charges have been made against Theodore Kaghan, deputy director of the Office of Public Affairs in the Office of the United States High Commissioner for Germany, and Hans Wallenberg, editor of Die Neue Zeitung, the official United States newspaper published in the German language in Frankfurt and Berlin.
After trying in vain all spring to piece together two victories the Giants yesterday finally got around not only to achieving this lofty accomplishment but actually going it one better.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, May 11 (AP) -- Spring rains drenched the bleak Korean battlefront early today, hampering air and ground action, but one United States patrol reported killing or wounding fifty-one Chinese Communists in a sharp fight.

UNTIL recently my ignorance was so great that I imagined that women were people, half the human race, and not just the oppressed victims of masculine prejudice. Wasn't the battle for women's rights won long ago? Didn't women have the vote? Didn't they wear trousers and even shorts? Didn't they hold jobs in every imaginable human activity?

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Twenty Democrats in Congress proposed today that the Federal Reserve Board go back to the practice, abandoned more than two years ago, of supporting Government bonds at their par value.
No soul can be "born to heaven" except through the "supernatural motherhood of the Roman Catholic Church," the Rev. James P. Griffin of St. Patrick's Cathedral staff declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- H. E. Cook, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporations, reported today that income of the nation's 13,439 insured commercial banks reached a record in 1952 of $5,076,000,000, or about 11 per cent over 1951.

Production in the men's clothing industry increased during the first quarter of this year compared with 1952, according to Harry A. Cobrin, executive secretary of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. Output, however, continued to trail the 1951 highs.

Among the more important art exhibitions this week are the sixty-first annual exhibition of the National Association of Woman Artists, opening Friday at the National Academy of Design; a second selection of work from the collections of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, opening Wednesday, and the seventeenth biennial exhibition of water-colors at the Brooklyn Museum.
Plans for the summer were announced yesterday by operators of eleven strawhat theatres. The following opening bills were listed:
Nine new films, including importations from England, France and Italy, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

Business of the Great Western Sugar Company expanded in the year ended on Feb. 28, and consolidated net income was $4,273,356, or $1.79 for a common share after preferred requirements, against $4,301,867, or $1.81 in the preceding fiscal year.

ARDMORE, Okla., May 10 (UP) -- Earl Stewart Jr. won $6,900 top money in the Ardmore open golf tournament today with a 2-over-par 282. The victory made him the top money winner of the year among the pros.

A fellow named Roy Campanella is threatening the legendary prestige of Paul Bunyan and Fin McCool, not to mention Superman. That, at least, is the conviction shared by the 23,843 fans and the allegedly blase members of the press who were at Ebbets Field yesterday when the Dodgers beat the Phils, 5 -- 0, and took over the National League lead.

The latest news from Argentina bears out the theory that there is a sort of natural law to which dictators and dictatorships are subject. A dictator of the modern sort, whether in Italy, Germany, Russia, Spain, China or elsewhere, always pretends to be a friend of the common man and always outpromises himself.

MANHASSET, L. I., May 10 -- Fred Blum's gray gelding, On Leave, ridden by Johnny Bell, scored 11 points to win the jumper championship for the North Shore Hospital Trophy during the Oaks Hunt Horse Show, staged as part of the annual spring festival for the benefit of the North Shore Hospital fund on the Greentree Estate today.
PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 10 -- Iona College of New Rochelle captured two events here today in a regatta held on the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island course.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 10 -- Single women who have hopes of being picked by the United Nations new chief, a bachelor, to help him preside at official parties are out of luck. Any hostess selected by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold must be married, and her husband should be present to signify his consent and approval.

HEBRON, Neb., May 10 (AP) -- A tornado raked this town last night, damaging or destroying two-thirds of the buildings and injuring at least sixty-nine persons. At least eighteen were said to be hurt seriously. There were no known deaths.

CLAY, W. Va., May 10 (AP) -- Forty-eight men were charged with murder today because, the prosecutor said, none would individually admit firing the shots that killed a 29-year-old non-striking coal miner.

Allen B. Du Mont, veteran in electronics and in the new art of television, has taken a look at an older advertising medium -- newspapers -- and decided they and television can live happily and prosperously together. He made public yesterday results of his studies of the recent convention proceedings of the American Newspaper Publishers Association and some late figures on television.

ROME, May 10 -- The 30,000-ton turboliner Cristoforo Colombo glided majestically this morning down the slipway of the Ansaldo yards in Sestri Ponente near Genoa. She is scheduled to join her sister ship, the Andrea Doria, on the North Atlantic run in 1954.

ZURICH, May 10 -- Authoritative quarters in Switzerland have felt relieved since John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, revealed in his radio address on April 30 that at NATO council meeting in Paris on Western defense "we put our emphasis upon getting greater military strength by less costly methods * * *.

PARIS, May 10 -- French exports to foreign countries in April reached their highest point since June, 1951, official statistics showed today. They totaled 79,700,000,000 francs, as compared with 72,900,000,000 francs in March, 73,400,000,000 francs in February, and 68,800,000,000 francs in January.

The family as "a place where children can learn democracy" and where, as a result, the parents can afford to disagree, was the ideal presented by Mrs. Sidonie Matsner Gruenberg, writer on parent-children relationships, last night.

While the Rev. Laurance I. Neale sat in a back pew with his wife, five laymen -- a news commentator, a retired actor, a salesman, a lawyer and a life insurance executive -- took charge of yesterday's service at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

LONDON, May 10 -- A modest revival in public interest and some mildly stimulating events have lifted the stock markets in the last few days a little out of the rut of dullness into which they had recently fallen. Chief among those incidents have been good gold and dollar reserves figures for the last month and a change for the better in the prospects for ending the Korean war.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 10 (UP) -- Sam Snead captured his third straight Greenbrier open golf championship today, firing a two-under-par 68 for a 72-hole total of 268.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 10 -- Jeffrey Munson of Sparkill, N. Y., broke seventy-five straight targets in a shoot-off to win the distance handicap today as the forty-fourth annual national amateur trapshooting championships ended at the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island traps.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $76,381,680,971. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 10 -- Two sharp engagements between Kenya security forces and Mau Mau armed bands took place last night and today. A Kikuyu home guard camp at Iriani was destroyed and at Kanderedu the secondary school buildings were burned to the ground.

Columbia University has decided to withdraw recognition by Oct. 1, 1960, from all campus organizations -- except religious groups -- that deny membership because of an applicant's race, color or religion.
Examples of the use of cotton through the ages and over the world are shown in an exhibit that will open at the New York Botanical Garden with a special ceremony Tuesday at 3:30 P. M.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 10 -- The appointment of Carlisle H. Humelsine, former deputy under secretary of state, as executive vice president of Colonial Williamsburg, Inc., and Williamsburg, Restoration, Inc., was announced today.

A taxpayer building containing a food supermarket and three other stores at Power House Road and Roslyn Road, in East Park, L. I., near Roslyn Heights, has been sold by the Levitt interests to Jack Brause, investor, in a deal negotiated by James Felt Co., the J. Clarence Davies Realty Company and Max Gruber Associates, brokers.
Cotton futures prices were irregular last week, finally closing 10 points lower to 4 points higher, or down 50 cents to up 20 cents a bale, on the New York Cotton Exchange.
TOKYO, Monday, May 11 (AP)) -- United Nations Command communique 1,611, for Sunday's operations:

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 (AP) -- The Senators swept a four-game week-end series with the Athletics by taking both ends of a double-header today. They scored an 8-0 triumph behind Bob Porterfield's one-hit hurling in the first part of the twin bill, while home runs by Jim Busby and Jackie Jensen helped take the second, 6 -- 2.

The State Education Department of the University of the State of New York and WCBS-TV have completed plans for a series of educational programs to begin Saturday, May 16, over Channel 2, at 2 P. M. The series of forty-five-minute programs will be known as "Camera Three."

SAN FRANCISCO, May 10 -- In a strong attack on the Zionist movement's policies in the United States tonight, Rabbi Elmer Berger, executive director of the American Council for Judaism, denounced what he termed the Zionist concept that anyone not friendly to Israel was anti-Semitic.

" Life in New York," a series of television programs designed to acquaint New Yorkers with their own city, made its debut at 3 P. M. yesterday over WNBT. The premiere was perhaps the most incredibly awkward bit of video journalism yet seen. On future weeks there is not much the program can do but get a little better.

PARIS, May 10 -- The United States has promised Greece and Turkey, the two easternmost allies of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the immediate support of strategic and tactical atomic weapons in the event of a war involving NATO.

The Freedom of Information Committee of the American Society of Newspaper Editors has been instructed to study "all of the relevant material" in the recent questioning of James A. Wechsler, editor of The New York Post, by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Agriculture Department reported today that farmers were being more careful about taking loans and credit, and interpreted this as a sign of lower farm incomes ahead.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 10 -- Fred MacMurray has joined the all-star cast for Stanley Kramer's Columbia production of "The Caine Mutiny." He will play the role of Keefer.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 10 -- Miss Boston, a bay mare owned by Maj. Donald Mitchell of Cornwall-on-Hudson, took the jumper championship at the second annual Junior Essex Troop Horse Show today. Collecting 9 points, the mare, ridden by Fred Edwards of Tompkins Cove, beat out Manina, owned and shown by Peter Briggs of Short Hills, N. J., by one point.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., May 10 The Greenburgh Town Planning Board has been asked to grant a zoning variance to permit development of a regional shopping center on part of the old Felix Warburg estate near Central Park Avenue here. Part of the land extends into White Plains but rezoning there is not needed.

This month the Secretary General of the United Nations, after receiving a recommendation from an advisory committee, will choose a new agent general for the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency. This agency originally was not to function until the Korean war ended, but the war has dragged on and an agreement was reached whereby it could undertake certain rehabilitation projects during the period of hostilities.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 10 (AP) -- Members of the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association tonight voted overwhelmingly at a mass meeting to continue their boycott of the Hollywood Park race meeting which opens Tuesday.

JERUSALEM, May 10 -- Publication of "The Jerusalem Bible," which was edited by Prof. Umberto Cassuto and is the first revision of the Hebrew text of the Old Testament by a Jewish scholar printed in Jerusalem, was announced today by Sir Leon Simon, chairman of Hebrew University's Magnes Press.

Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States delegate to the United Nations, playing host yesterday to eighty Representatives, criticized the Department of Defense for having made "a mistake in decision" that prevented our allies from sending more troops to Korea.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- President Eisenhower flew back tonight to the capital with his preoccupation over the problems of peace or was backed by the fervent prayer of a Pennsylvania State College congregation that divine aid would grant him "the skill and valor" to lead the world to freedom and security.

EAST ALTON, Ill., May 10 (UP) -- A young woman bank clerk who was locked for nine hours in a vault was ordered to bed for several days today to recover from exhaustion and nervousness. "It was awful, I thought I'd never get out," Miss Ann Linkogle said after workmen had broken through a concrete and steel wall to free her last night.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 5 -- Australia is grateful for the diversity of the services that former United States servicemen are rendering the country.

MANHASSET, L. I., May 10 -- North Shore Long Islanders turned out by the thousands today to frolic in behalf of a worthy cause as summer sun and skies smiled on the final day of a two-day festival held for the benefit of the new North Shore Hospital.

ROCHESTER, May 10 -- The first winner of the new Edward B. Benjamin Composition Award of $500 was announced this afternoon, on Founders Day, at the concluding concert of the twenty-third Eastman School Festival of Music.

When New York's German-American groups decide to have a "day," they pull out all the stops. And it was full organ yesterday when they got together before 22,609 spectators at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island to celebrate the thirtieth anniversary of the German - American Soccer League.

Taking advantage of yesterday's bright sunshine and balmy weather, the congregation of Holy Trinity Lutheran Church of Flatbush, Avenue R and Hendrickson Street, Brooklyn, participated in an open-air Mother's Day service and heard the Rev. Norman W. Ross, the pastor, praise Christian mothers for their good example.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Learned Hand, the distinguished New York jurist, turned up today as a ballad singer in a new record album of folk music just released by the Library of Congress.
THE town's street sweepers, still hurt by Miss Edna Ferber's jibe about Manhattan's untidiness, are ready to tell any listener about difficulties they come up against in their job.

LONDON, May 10 -- The ancient carriages that will move through London on June 2 in the coronation procession were unlimbered today and pulled from Buckingham Palace to Westminster Abbey and back again in a rehearsal that drew thousands of spectators from their Sunday morning sleep.

YONKERS, May 10 -- Faced with the possibility of a strike by a committee of the Standardbred Owners Association, William H. Cane, president of Yonkers Raceway, today disclosed that he had again increased purses for the two weeks of Grand Circuit racing starting tomorrow night.

A bill designed to encourage private investment in shipbuilding and to bring tax relief to shipowners by setting a fixed rate of depreciation of their ships and letting them write them off at a faster rate, if they choose, has been introduced in Congress.
NEW DELHI, India, April 19 -- With her teeming population increasing at the rate of 4,000,000 a year, India is rushing to embark on a $1,300,000 birth-control program ahead of schedule.

Going into the producing business are William Hammerstein, son of Oscar Hammerstein 2d, and Robert Keith, well-known stage and screen actor. For their first venture they have chosen "The Adams in Eden," a play by William Joyce Cowen and Lenore Coffee, a husband and wife team of Hollywood writers who were last represented on the Broadway stage with "Family Portrait" in 1939.

Magazines, newspapers, and television and radio programs presenting distorted information on foreign countries endanger the prestige of the United States abroad, the Rev. Louis O'Meara declared yesterday at the tenth annual communion breakfast of the Catholic Guild of the Department of Health, held at the Commodore Hotel.

IT'S indeed comforting to know that Hughie Devore has latched on as assistant coach of the Green Bay Packers because there just isn't a nicer guy in the football business than this modest, soft-spoken and extremely competent young man who had his New York University football team whisked out from under him. The Packers provide another detour for Hughie, who still hasn't found the main highway.

BOSTON, May 10 -- The West German reparations agreement will enable Israel to obtain the heavy material necessary for the reorganization of her transportation and communications systems, Dr. Nahum Goldmann of New York said today.
