Israel, entering its sixth year of independence, is operating on the basis of a balanced budget, Pinhas Lavon, minister without portfolio, told a national Labor Zionist Conference here yesterday.

BOWER CAVE, Calif., May 10 (AP) -- Jon Lindbergh, scientific-minded son of the famed flier Charles A. Lindbergh, swam about 200 feet under water in inky darkness yesterday, to discover in the Sierra what is described as one of the largest submerged caverns in the West.
CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- The White Sox rebounded to win the nightcap, 10 -- 5, after losing the first game of a double-header with the Tigers, 8 -- 6, before a crowd of 20,770 today.

NAZARETH, Israel, May 10 -- The first symphony concert given in Nazareth was performed last night by the Haifa Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Jacques Singer of the United States. The leading Arab citizens of Nazareth showed themselves unsympathetic when first consulted about the Haifa Orchestra's plan to bring symphonic music to outlying districts.

An exposition of the abstract qualities involved in design is on view in the gallery of America House. Arranged by the American Craftsmen's Educational Council, the exhibition, called "A Visual Definition of the Elements of Design," consists of ten panels on which text is combined with photographs and objects to illustrate the theme.

P. W. Litchfield, chairman of the board of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, said yesterday that the rubber industry should formulate a program to prevent an interruption in the supply of synthetic rubber during the transfer of the Government's plants to private ownership.

Had T. K. Quinn written thirty or forty years earlier when there was no radio or television to preempt people's attention, his "Giant Business: Threat to Democracy"* might have become a Bible for young men and older men with still-flexible minds.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Monday, May 11 (AP) -- The United Nations command charged the Communists today with failure to explain satisfactorily their eight-point proposal on the issue of Korean war prisoners.

The ancient rite of Rogation Day, an observance dating back to the fifth century, was celebrated yesterday at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine) with the traditional chanting of the Litany in a procession through the cathedral grounds and the annual tree presentation to the Very Rev. James A. Pike, dean.

The Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee, which has been investigating the Voice of America and other activities of the International Information Administration for several months, will hold its first public hearings in New York, starting today at 10 A. M.

Copper from the rich mines of Northern Rhodesia threatens to invade the United States market on an important competitive basis this summer for the first time since the great African "Copperbelt" was developed in the late 1920's.

JERSEY CITY, May 10 -- Mayor John V. Kenny and former Mayor Frank Hague Eggers, in final rallies tonight in the bitterly fought City Commission campaign, each predicted victory for his slate by a wide margin.

FRANKFURT, Germany, May 10 -- West Germany's Social Democratic party, largest Socialist organization on the Continent, pledged today its support for negotiations with the Soviet Union on reunification of Germany and its opposition to the policy of Western European integration that the United States is said to be forcing on the German people.

ST. LOUIS, May 10 (AP) -- Four home runs by the Indians, including a grand slam blast by Ray Boone, accounted for ten runs today as Cleveland smothered the Browns under a barrage of sixteen hits, 12 -- 3. All the victors' runs were scored in the last two innings.

CINCINNATI, May 10 (UP) -- The Redlegs backed strong pitching by Bubba Church and Ken Raffensberger with four home runs and five double plays today to defeat the Cardinals, 4 -- 2 and 5 -- 2, before a crowd of 14,525.

ROME, May 10 (AP) -- Maureen Connolly, the United States singles champion, teamed with Julia Sampson to upset the American and Wimbledon doubles titleholders, Shirley Fry and Doris Hart for the title in Italy's international tennis tournament today.

The final stage of reconstruction of the twenty-five-year-old Northern State Parkway in Nassau County is being rushed to completion under a round-the-clock schedule, the Long Island State Park Commission announced yesterday.
A glass of wine with a meal promotes digestion, makes food taste better, advances friendliness and is generally part of the good life, Charles Quincy said the other day.

STRASBOURG, France, May 10 -- Even the most ardent federalists conceded tonight that, unless the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe endorsed tomorrow the draft treaty for a European political community, the chances were that plans for supranational political union of six European countries would be indefinitely sidetracked.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Monday, May 11 -- Miss Joanne Leonberg, 19 years old, of near-by Medford, died at 12:20 A. M. today in the Burlington County Hospital after her brother, Stanley Leonberg Jr., a medical student, had massaged her heart for nearly six hours after she had collapsed.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 10 -- For the first time since the Union of South Africa was formed forty-three years ago a crack has developed in the solid front that the ruling whites, now totaling 2,600,000, have invariably presented toward the non-white majority, now numbering 10,000,000.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on major roll-calls in Congress during the period of May 2 to May 8 are given in the appended tabulation:
NEWARK, May 10 -- Taking cognizance of reports that record sums would be spent on poll workers in Tuesday's City Commission election here. Essex County Prosecutor Edward Gaulkin said today:
The New York City Transit Authority will make a new effort to select counsel at a meeting at 10:30 A. M. today at the Board of Transportation Building, 370 Jay Street, Brooklyn.

BOSTON, May 10 -- Exclusive rights to rhubarbs on the diamond do not belong to the Yankees. Ever since L'Affaire Courtney at St. Louis, fingers have been pointed accusingly toward Casey Stengel's men, who today at Fenway Park rallied to defeat the Red Sox, 7 -- 4.
Frank S. Hogan, District Attorney of New York County, is definitely interested in running for Mayor, it was learned yesterday on good authority.

GOLDENS BRIDGE, N. Y., May 10 -- Buenavista Trigger, a 3 1/2-year-old white and liver pointer owned and handled by John J. Smith of Valhalla, N. Y., was the winner of the "Top" Turnure Trophy in the amateur gun-dog stake that ended the three-day trials of the Southern New York Field Trial Club today.

Nine new recommendations for strengthening law enforcement are contained in the State Crime Commission's third report, made public here yesterday on the eve of a conference that Governor Dewey is holding with legislative leaders and others concerned with crime problems.

Between 1950 and 1952 the number of Protestant missionaries from this country serving overseas increased from nearly 15,000 to more than 18,000, according to a report issued yesterday by the Missionary Research Library. The library is operated by the Division of Foreign Missions of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. and Union Theological Seminary.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 10 (AP) -- The first session of the Iranian Parliament since early March broke up in wild disorder today within five minutes of being called to order.

A communique issued in Paris states that a series of protocols has been completed that will assure to the Associated State of Cambodia, in Indo-China, "full sovereignty" in military, judicial and economic matters. This is presumably another step in the French program of moving toward self-government in the hitherto dependent areas and at the same time preserving the integrity of the French Union.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- Failure of the wheat market to attract substantial buying on recent declines discouraged holders, and there was another wave of liquidation by longs which broke the market to a succession of new lows for the crop year. The weakness in the bread grain unsettled other grains also, but corn was conspicuous for its relative strength.

New Yorkers finally stopped talking about the weather yesterday and did something about it. By the hundreds of thousands they fled apartment and pavement for fresh air and sunshine on the warmest day of the year.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 10 -- The application to Turkey of the Eisenhower Administration's doctrine that further United States foreign and should be restricted almost exclusively to defense procurement and small technical assistance projects is being received with misgivings by qualified American experts here.

Twenty-five thousand persons participating in an annual World Sodality Day ceremony at Fordham University were told yesterday they should be "restless until every colored child of God is certain that his color will not prevent him from mingling with us on our own block, in our own club, in our own business."

For its first week-end at the City Center this season, the New York City Ballet busied itself with getting more numbers from its fairly extensive repertoire into action. No less than eight of them, as a matter of fact, had their first presentations of the spring engagement at the four performances on Saturday and Sunday.

BUENOS AIRES, May 10 -- Describing 200 persons arrested under suspicion of having been engaged in the recent bombings in this city as members of a "gigantic mafia" Government newspapers reported today that the police appeared near the end of the trail in their search for the terrorists.

The Soviet "peace campaign" descended on Henry Street on Manhattan's lower East Side yesterday as two Russian United Nations delegates spent more than an hour at a gathering of social workers, sipping tea and listening.

Spring tornadoes, by far the year's most destructive, whirled a deadly path through large sections of the Midwest yesterday. At least nine persons were killed and upward of 100 injured with the casualty list still incomplete. Property damage is expected to run into the millions of dollars.
Carlos Montoya, guitarist, was heard in a recital of unusual interest Saturday evening at the Theresa L. Kaufmann Auditorium of the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.

MILWAUKEE, May 10 (AP) -- Little Don Liddie hurled a two-hitter in his major league debut today, beating the Cubs 4 -- 1 in the second game of a double-header after the Braves had won the opener, 6 -- 2, behind Max Surkont, before 33,721 fans in the County Stadium.

A different Mother's Day story unfolded yesterday in Felony Court when a 38-year-old woman was charged with having caused her daughter, one of eight children, to steal a purse containing $20.98 in Lord Taylor's department store Saturday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (UP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that 7,105,000 persons work for the Federal, state and local governments.

As the city's 1953-54 budget approaches adoption by the City Council many New Yorkers may find something to be thankful for in the fact that the budget contains a departure from past practice and presents for the first time an official "program" form of budget for three departments.
Summer lingerie designs follow closely the trends in dress fashion, offering styles for both the slim and full silhouettes.

Weakness in the Canadian dollar and British pound sterling were the main points of interest in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Amount of business transacted was reported to be fairly heavy at each daily session.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 7 -- A bitter intraparty struggle among Colombia's ruling Conservatives has flared into the open, overshadowing the Conservative-Liberal poiltical feud that has torn the country apart in the last five years.

Among the anniversaries of this month is the celebration of the establishment of the first photo news service, fifty-five years ago. It started with Dewey. Not with Dewey the Governor, for all this happened four years before Thomas Dewey was born.

For five days, beginning today and ending Friday, relatives or friends will be able to send free radio messages to any member of the armed services anywhere in the world through the courtesy of the Army Signal Corps and a group of cooperating radio amateurs.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- A joint Canadian-United States expedition is seeking, on bleak and desolate Ellesmere Island in the Arctic Ocean, the source of the great floating ice islands like the one used during the last two years as an Arctic weather base observatory.

More than 500 members of the Society of the Silurians, an organization of newspaper men who Worked in New York at least twenty-five years ago, gathered last night at the Statler Hotel to honor James A. Hagerty of THE NEW YORK TIMES and his son, James C. Hagerty, White House press secretary.

The work of contemporary Portuguese silver and goldsmiths is represented in a collection of jewelry and accessories for the home that will go on view today in the Portuguese Consul General's office at 630 Fifth Avenue. The exhibit will be open on week days from 2 to 5 P. M. through May 29.
HOLLAND, Mich., May 11 (UP) -- Rocky Marciano, a slow starter, will shadow-box in his dressing room for the first time Friday night to prevent being floored early by Jersey Joe Walcott.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 11 -- Lieut. Gen. William E. Riley, who resigned last month as chief of the United Nations truce supervision organization in the Middle East, has warned the Security Council of worsening Israeli-Jordan relations, and advised high-level talks to ease the mounting tension.

Boys' suits for fall of 1953 have advanced 5 to 7 per cent in price at the wholesale level, it was learned yesterday at the combined showing of the Boys Apparel and Accessories Manufacturers Association in the New Yorker Hotel. The price advance reflects a wage increase to clothing workers in the men's and boys' field.

Headed by Manager Don Welsh, sixteen members of the Liverpool Football Club of England's First Division arrived here yesterday aboard the Cunard liner Queen Mary. Liverpool begins a ten-game soccer tour of this country and Canada against the Irish Internationals at Ebbets Field Thursday night.
MEXICO CITY, May 11 -- A heavy increase of wetbacks, illegal Mexican immigrants making their way across the Rio Grande in search of agricultural jobs, has been noted since the beginning of the year.
Investment banking syndicates bidding on $14,000,000 of new public utility bonds yesterday appraised the going market yield of A-rated utility obligations at slightly less than a 4 per cent basis.

The availability of tremendous amounts of energy in existing uranium deposits is one of the most significant aspects of the future utilization of atomic energy as a source of commercial power, Dr. Karl Cohen, vice president of the Walter Kidde Laboratories, said last night.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (UP) -- President Eisenhower said today "Americans of all parties" had accepted the "moral obligation" of providing "decent housing for those now compelled to live in slums."

Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson promised the farmers of the United States last night that he would do "all in my power" to develop and maintain a sound economy for agriculture. At the same time, however, he warned against "undue dependence on public assistance," over-centralization of power, and "governmental adventures in business."

Dr. Leo Lowenthal, chief of the evaluation staff of the Voice of America, estimated yesterday that Voice programs were being heard "fairly regularly" by 50 per cent of the population owning radios behind the Iron Curtain.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 11 -- Six companies of French Union troops, including three paratroop companies, moved out from their position on the Plaine des Jarres in Laos today and fought two engagements with elements of the Vietminh 304th division.

A concert in memory of Dinu Lipatti, given for the benefit of the Rumanian Welfare, at which the widow of the composer appeared as soloist in the performance of Lipatti's "Concertino in Classic Style," was given last night in Town Hall. On this occasion the Rumanian conductor, Remus Tzincoca, conducted an orchestra of fifty Philharmonic - Symphony players in a program that contained two of Lipatti's compositions, prefaced by works of Beethoven and Faure.

Customs collections in the Port of New York in April amounted to $28,150,230, or 30 per cent more than the $21,519,066 recorded in April, 1952, Francis B. Laughlin, acting Collector, said here yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- All grains futures showed a strong tone early in the session, but when demand faded later, prices reacted sharply. In wheat the feature was the relative strength in the May delivery, which sold at a small premium over the July.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Some very sharp and experienced eyes have been turned on the President's plan to reorganize the Defense Department since he submitted it to Congress April 20. Among those who seriously question many of the most important provisions, and what they think are the implied results thereof, are two men who in different capacities won high authority to speak on the subject.
The off-again, on-again Communist invasion of Laos has emphasized the weaknesses -- and the strengths -- of the French in Indo-China.

VIENNA, May 11 -- The invitation to the Soviet Union to send a delegate to the meeting of Foreign Ministers' deputies to be held in London May 27 to discuss an Austrian treaty made no mention of the short treaty draft, hitherto the bone of contention between East and West, it was reported in Austrian circles today.

Boys High School won the team honors in the thirteenth annual Brooklyn Automotive interscholastic track and field meet at McCarren Park, Brooklyn, yesterday. The Red and Black athletes scored 16 points in the ten open events.

Sixteen years ago Mrs. Juliette M. Palmer found an old clock in a thrift shop and, woman-like, took it home as a sort of antique. The next Saturday was sultry and, man-like, her husband, Brooks -- an insurance man -- passed the time of day by taking the clock apart.

A house described by Chief Assistant District Attorney Edward S. Silver of Brooklyn as "worse than a Tennessee share-cropper's shack" was inspected by the prosecutor and his staff yesterday as part of a campaign to eliminate firetraps in the borough.

Continued expansion of consumer credit is a sure way of maintaining mass production and high employment, Edward A. Lifson, president of the National Retail Furniture Association, declared yesterday. He took issue with some bankers, politicians and economists who urge curtailment of consumer credit.
Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, will speak at a dinner to be given at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in his honor on May 21 by the American Council on Nato, Inc.

YONKERS, May 11 (AP) -- Victor Scott turned on the speed in the stretch to beat Casanova by a nose tonight in the Salem Pace, the feature of the first night of Grand Circuit racing at Yonkers Raceway.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Senator Charles W. Tobey of New Hampshire, Republican chairman of the Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, issued a statement today giving assurance that none of the 242 channel assignments for educational television would expire on June 2.

STRASBOURG, France, May 11 -- By a vote of 76 to 7 with 18 abstentions the fifteen-nation Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe passed tonight a resolution calling on the foreign ministers of six European countries to take a speedy decision on the draft treaty for six-power European political community which had been submitted for the Assembly's opinion.

After almost forty-seven years of service, William P. Koehler has retired from active duty as a vice president of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation, in charge of its derrick and inland salvage department. He will continue to serve the company as a consultant.

Among the various superstitions having to do with fate is one that says to put shoes on a table is to bring bad luck. Far too many superstitions seem to stress bad luck rather than good, but perhaps that is neither here nor there. Sufficient for the moment is the fact that to put shoes on a table will immediately bring a slash in pay, a night of insomnia or a crumpled fender.

CAIRO, May 11 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, arriving here as the dispute between Britain and Egypt over the Suez Canal zone reached a crisis, issued a statement tonight in dicating support for the British view that the canal zone base must remain on an efficient footing for future use by the forces of the free world.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Representative Emanuel Celler of Brooklyn, ranking Democrat and former chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, announced today that he would introduce legislation to put all investigations of subversive activities under the sole jurisdiction of a single joint Congressional committee.

PARIS, May 11 -- The latest issue of the Cominform journal, For a Lasting Peace, for a People's Democracy, to reach Paris, published May 8 in Bucharest, Rumania, and commemorating VE-Day, stresses for the first time the current Soviet "peace offensive."

In accordance with regulations of the Federal Communications Commission, an emergency method of keeping radio stations on the air during air-raid alerts will take effect here on Friday, Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday.

ATLANTA, May 11 -- The Public Health Service's Communicable Disease Center announced today that two of its researchers had adapted to growth in experimental mice the Brunhilde strain of polio virus, the type believed to be the cause of most cases of poliomyelitis in human beings.

TRENTON, May 11 -- The legislative committee investigating the ouster of Deputy Attorney General Nelson F. Stamler today heard testimony from a state policeman that the Moretti murder case was bungled from the beginning and that officials don't yet know who killed the notorious gambler or why.

Thirty-four prominent religious pacifists, representing the "peace blocs" within eighteen Protestant denominations, issued a statement yesterday calling upon all Christians to "break with modern absolutized war."

Columbia University has moved in the right direction in its decision to withdraw university recognition from any organization that is obliged by its national regulations to discriminate in its membership on a racial or religious basis. The deadline for this action, set at 1960, certainly allows ample time for a revision of the national constitutions of the organizations that would be affected by the ban.

In its first show of unanimity on a major question, the five-man New York City Transit Authority agreed yesterday on a choice of counsel who, between now and June 1, will undertake to draft and negotiate an agreement with the city for the acquisition of the municipality's transit network.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 11 (AP) -- Confronted with an all-out boycott by horsemen and jockeys, the Hollywood Turf Club late today called off its opening program tomorrow. The announcement was made by the track board of directors.

They staged a home-run hitting contest before last night's exhibition game between the Giants and the Red Sox at the Polo Grounds, but someone apparently overlooked Dusty Rhodes. The pull-hitting outfielder proved he should have been in on the act when he subsequently clouted two circuit drives to lead the New York team to a 7-to-3 triumph.
In line with the city's need to "scramble for every dime," Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley has asked the Board of Estimate to speed approval of 15,000 additional parking meters.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today to recommend passage of a bill to increase the salaries of members of Congress and of the Federal judiciary by $10,000 and to raise the salaries of United States Attorneys and other law officers.

Felix Jackson, who formerly supervised the "Four Star Playhouse" and produced the "Schlitz Playhouse of Stars." has been hired by the Columbia Broadcasting System to produce the "Studio One" television program, beginning next fall.

It required the combined strength of three policemen to pull a 30-year-old woman weighing 210 pounds to safety last night from a fifth-story window ledge on which she was perched for fifteen minutes at a West Side hotel.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 11 -- The editor of the Communist daily Kol Haam was arrested this morning on a charge of defaming Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, and was released a few hours later upon signing a 500 Israeli bond at Police Headquarters.

PARIS, May 11 -- While officials were chary of comment tonight on the speech in the House of Commons of Sir Winston Churchill, British Prime Minister, other observers here considered he had sought to break through the preliminary conditions that the United States had attached to a conference with Soviet leaders.

The familiar triple-tailed configuration of Lockheed Constellations, seen at major commercial and military airports all over the world, may be in view for years to come. Speaking at the annual stockholders' meeting held recently, Robert E. Gross, president of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, Burbank, Calif., said that the four-engined "Connie" was far from finished.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Chester Bowles made a final report to President Eisenhower today on his assignment as Ambassador to India and said later he believed the fight against communism in Asia was going better from a military standpoint than it was a year ago.

Advances in the detection of minute traces of metal in oil and of oil in water were reported yesterday at a meeting of the refining division of the American Petroleum Institute in the Commodore Hotel.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary of the Air Force in the Truman Administration, today attacked President Eisenhower's proposed reorganization of the Defense Department.

BALTIMORE, May 11 (AP) -- Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin said tonight that he was "distressed and shocked" to learn that Maryland's official Red-hunters had checked on a rally last night sponsored by the United World Federalists.
Navy's world champion eight heads the seedings for the sprint regatta of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges, to be held Saturday on the Potomac at Washington.

LONDON, May 11 -- Invitations were issued today for a meeting of the deputies of the Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union to resume negotiations on an Austrian treaty.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 11 -- Republican support given to John M. Reiber, Elmsford roadhouse proprietor, for appointment as Governor of the Virgin Islands was defended in a 1,200-word statement here today by Herbert C. Gerlach, Westchester Republican chairman and County Executive.
The cotton futures market eased lightly yesterday and active months closed unchanged to 13 points net lower than on Friday.

The B. F. Goodrich Company of Akron, Ohio, filed suit against the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, also of Akron, in Federal District Court in Cleveland yesterday, charging Firestone with infringing Goodrich patents in the manufacture and sale of tubeless tires for motor vehicles and aircraft.

A week-long observance of the fiftieth anniversary of Cathedral College, 555 West End Avenue, minor seminary of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, opened yesterday morning with the celebration of a solemn pontifical mass of thanksgiving at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., May 11 -- Claude Harmon of Winged Foot carried off the individual prize of $1,000 in the annual pro-amateur tournament staged today at the Piping Rock Club for the benefit of the North Country Community Hospital.

A French theory that two horns are better than one to reduce automobile accident potential is being studied by traffic safety experts here. The aim is to eliminate raucous blasts in city streets that fray nerves and shatter sleep.

Declaration of a 16 per cent cash dividend out of 1952 earnings will be proposed to shareholders of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company at the next general meeting, directors announced yesterday. A 13 per cent dividend was declared last year out of 1951 earnings and the company in addition paid a stock dividend of 2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UP) -- A Texas broadcaster, Gordon McLendon, said today that the future of baseball was threatened by "a few selfish, monopolistic" club owners and not by unlimited radio and television broadcasts.

Despair over the inroads made by television in children's reading time is a wasted emotion, Mrs. Frances Lander Spain, new Superintendent of Work with Children for the New York Public Library, commented yesterday. Mrs. Spain, a grandmother, will take over her duties at the library on Aug. 1.

GENEVA, May 11 -- The United Nations Commission on Human Rights agreed today to grant time for discussions of new United States proposals for action by the United Nations in the field of human rights.
LONDON, May 11 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from Prime Minister Churchill's foreign policy speech today in the House of Commons:

A Federal credit union, operating under a charter issued by the Federal Security Agency, has been established at Manhattan College, John A. Cossa, dean of student personnel, announced yesterday. The organization aims to encourage thrift among the members and to make loans to them, at low interest rates, for any provident or productive purpose.

A refreshing beverage for those with a taste for tartness is "weisse mit schuss," the summertime favorite in Berlin. The "weisse" is a markedly sharp beer brewed from malted wheat rather than the customary barley. The "schuss" is a natural heavy raspberry syrup.

THE best week-end weather wise since the opening of the trout season put a lot of pressure on most of the popular trout streams, and the Long Island bays attracted a large crowd of salt-water enthusiasts. The reports from both fresh and salt fronts indicated that the results were not very exciting.

ROME, May 11 (AP) -- Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., scored one of the year's biggest tennis upsets today when she defeated Maureen Connolly, America's triple crown holder, in an exhausting three-set match for Rome's international championship.

Rosalind Russell, the Hollywood actress who made good on Broadway, spoke yesterday of events leading up to her acceptance of the starring role in "Wonderful Town," and of her reaction to the public and critical superlatives that followed.

The scale weight of 126 pounds meant very little to Ben F. Whitaker's Tahitian King in the Swift at Belmont Park yesteray. The dozen 3-year-olds that competed in the $25,750 stakes over the seven-furlong distance each carried the same weight, but it was a real burden to all except the son of Polynesian.

The significance of the "Power for Peace" theme of Armed Forces Day was stressed by Mayor Impellitteri yesterday as he proclaimed Saturday as Armed Forces Day in the city. The Mayor issued his proclamation at City Hall, in a brief ceremony attended by four men and four women, representing the Army, Marine Corps, Navy and Air Force.

Officials of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad who had been seeking, with the aid of a Federal mediator, to settle a strike that cut off normal service for 70,000 commuters who usually use the Hudson Tubes said at 12:45 A. M. today that they were "going home for the night."

All but one of the major domestic distillers filed with the State Liquor Authority yesterday a schedule of advanced retail prices for package stores in the New York State market. The schedules, filed to become effective under the law on July 1, provide for increases of 5 to 10 cents a bottle to the consumer, according to size and grade, with nearly all of the rise going to the hard-pressed proprietors of the liquor stores.

TUNIS, Tunisia, May 11 -- Final returns published by the French Residency today showed that 14,108 Tunisians, or 40 per cent of the registered Tunisian electorate in twenty-five towns, had voted in the second series of municipal elections yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Tuesday, May 12 -- In another outbreak of campus restlessness, 2,000 Yale University undergraduates staged a two-hour riot here late last night before they were brought under control early today by more than 100 policemen.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- President Eisenhower told leaders of the nation's savings banks today that the sharp upturn in American savings is "a most heartening and helpful factor in our battle against inflation."

BOSTON, May 11 -- Dr. Sumner H. Slichter, Harvard University economist, outlined today a thorough revision of the Taft-Hartley Labor Act to correct what he called some of the "crudities and faults" that had become apparent in its six years of operation.

While a group of youngsters played sidewalk checkers with bottle caps on the corner, and another group not far away engaged in a game of stickball, twenty- seven boys and girls gathered in a classroom at Washington Irving High School, Sixteenth Street and Irving Place, yesterday afternoon to take part in a poetry contest.

Although Canadians contend that autumn is the best time to paint, Irving Mendelson of the Plaza Paint Supply shop here says the 80-degree temperatures of the last week-end were "just right" for the amateur painter in this city. Many of his customers, he says, do their painting between now and July, then relax in the summer and finish up if necessary in the fall.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 11 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold, speaking in French, opened this afternoon an international conference on opium in which various non-member countries of the United Nations are participating, but which includes no representative from the Soviet Union or any of its satellites.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense, told appropriations leaders in Congress today that the Administration's new defense budget would maintain the combat forces at safe levels and continue their modernization despite reduced spending, less manpower and a cut in draft calls.

FOR racetrack scholars, The Morning Telegraph is required reading, and many of the scholars, in the course of their studies en route to Belmont Park yesterday, must have noticed The Telegraph's two-column headline, "Torrid Pace in Riding Race Being Set by W. Shoemaker."

ATLANTIC CITY, May 11 -- A new Committee for Decent Trade Unionism today called upon delegates to the convention of the International Jewelry Workers Union, A.F.L., to act to clean up the union, often criticized for tolerating racketeers and corruption.

ALBANY, May 11 -- The temporary State Crime Commission's proposal for establishment of a permanent commission of investigation was attacked today by District Attorneys from New York City and upstate at a hearing called by Governor Dewey.

The supply of rhinestone jewelry will be tight by late fall, exhibitors said yesterday at the first semi-annual market week sponsored by the Costume Jewelry Manufacturers Association of New York at the Martinique Hotel. The supply at the present time is adequate, producers said, but replacements are difficult to obtain.

Television spot films on Advertising Council campaigns will not be subject to the new policies of the Screen Actors Guild imposed by the 1953 Producer-Screen Actors Guild Contract for Filmed Commercials. Policy in regard to public service films will remain as in the past.
About $34,000,000 a year is now required to cover the annual pension roll of the old police and fire forces.

The land at 460 Park Avenue, northwest corner of Fifty-seventh Street, has been leased by the Tishmam Realty Construction Company from the Davies Building Corporation for improvement with a twenty-two-story office structure to be known as the Davies Building.

Anthony Anastasia, Brooklyn waterfront leader, said yesterday he would call a meeting soon of Brooklyn's 7,000 longshoremen to discuss methods of eliminating the shape-up system of hiring dock workers here.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 12 -- Lieut. Gen. William K. Harrison Jr., chief of the United Nations delegation negotiating an armistice in Korea, branded today as "simply not workable" a Communist plan to permit an international political conference to settle the fate of prisoners who refuse to return to their former homes behind the Iron Curtain.

VALLEY COTTAGE, N. Y., May 11 -- Chessboards have been put away for a while and a taffy ball of a cat sleeps under a portrait of Tolstoy. But the smell of paint and the hammering on nails testify that new purposes are abroad at Reed Farm, the Resettlement Center of the Tolstoy Foundation here in Rockland County.

The "strange position" of the lead and zinc mining industry, whose metal prices are depressed in the face of a "boom" in consumption, was described yesterday by Clinton H. Crane, chairman of the St. Joseph Lead Company.
TOKYO, Tuesday, May 12 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,612, for Monday's operations:
SEOUL, May 11 -- The Voice of America, which has maintained coverage of the Korean war since the outbreak of hostilities, is discontinuing its radio reports from this country.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The Eisenhower Administration undertook a move in Congress today to increase foreign trade by simplifying a maze of United States customs regulations and procedures.

ROME, May 11 -- The Communists have so far filed suit against three Archbishops and two Bishops for reminding the faithful that to vote for the extreme left-wing parties is "a grave sin" and are threatening to take similar action against others.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 11 -- Liquor by the drink returned to Oregon today for the first time since the advent of Prohibition in 1916, but the rush to bars was something less than spectacular.
A protest against growing American protective barriers was made by the Chilean Ambassador, Anibal Jara, at a luncheon given in his honor yesterday by the Pan American Society of the United States.

LONDON, May 12 (AP) -- Contemporary British composers, who often complain that making music in Britain is a frustrating business, are getting their big chance at the Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II on June 2. Every note played or sung during the solemn service in Westminister Abbey will be British, with nearly half of the music the work of modern composers.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The National Federation of American Shipping reported today that a fleet of 119 privately owned American ships was devoting all its time to carrying military cargoes for the Navy's Military Sea Transport Service.

Steel operations are scheduled this week at 100.5 per cent of capacity, indicating production of 2,266,000 net tons of raw steel, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The actual rate last week was 100.2 per cent and production was 2,259,000 tons.

WACO, Tex., Tuesday, May 12 -- At least thirty-four persons were killed and more than 400 injured late yesterday when a pair of tornadoes crashed with deadly fury on this city and on San Angelo, 200 miles to the west.

Four jumping frogs from Britain and South Africa arrived at New York International airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 10:30 o'clock last night on their way to the Jumping Frog Jubilee to be held Friday at Angeles Camp, Calaveras County, California.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 11 -- In a surprise development late today, Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer announced that its pending $5,000,000 damage suit against Mario Lanza had been "settled by mutual agreement," with the singer having given the studio the right to use his recording of the Sigmund Romberg songs in "The Student Prince."

In the great contest for world power in which the most important trumps are space, population, industry and raw materials, Soviet Russia has already achieved a dangerous and almost decisive lead: 32 per cent of the world's population and 24 per cent of its area are already under Communist domination.

I WILL probably never forget the Saturday afternoon when I was about 12 that I saw for the first time one of those miracles of Chinese ivory carving, a hollow ball carved into an intricate fretwork with other hollow balls with different patterns inside it. The largest was as big as a baseball, the smallest the size of a pea. My first thought was that it was beautiful and a marvel of laborious craftsmanship.

PORT ARTHUR, Ont., May 11 (UP) -- A Great Lakes freighter launched in disaster and trailed by bad luck for fifty-two years was dashed by high winds into "The Rock of Ages" in Lake Superior today and sent to the bottom.

The Kollsman property known as the Mill River Farm in Upper Brookville, L. I., has been purchased for personal investment by Joseph K. Alliger and Hyman Ratner of the Sterling Investing Corporation. The property, comprising 160 acres with frontages on Mill River and Pine Hollow Roads, will be sub-divided for houses in the $50,000 to $60,000 price class.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, May 12 (AP) -- The mighty United States First Marine Division has been pulled out of the Korean battle-line to rest after thirty-three months of war, it was announced today. The famed division was relieved a week ago by the rested United States Twenty-fifth Infantry Division, which got into action immediately.

LONDON, May 11 (AP) -- Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister, digressed from his foreign policy speech today to read Parliament a telegram he sent to Stalin in the "grand alliance" days of World War II.

The election of Hollister Sturges Jr. as president of the board of trustees of the Child Education Foundation, 535 East Eighty-fourth Street, was announced yesterday. He succeeds Paxton Blair, who was head of the board since 1933.

In the quietest market since October, prices on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday were little changed. Although THE NEW YORK TIMES' combined average dropped 0.19 point on the day, this was almost entirely because General Motors and Norfolk and Western were selling ex-dividend.

LONDON, May 11 -- Prices drifted lower in nearly all sections of the stock market here today. The drying up of buying was attributed to the rupture of the Suez negotiations and the United Kingdom's adverse overseas trade balance.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 8 -- By an ironic twist of history, Dr. Mariano Ospina Perez has, in his bid for leadership of the ruling Conservative party, been made a victim of the same dictatorial decrees he initiated to help crush the Liberals of Colombia.

Plans were filed with the Department of Housing and Buildings yesterday for the twenty-two-story commercial building to be erected at 1424-32 Broadway, southeast corner of Fortieth Street, on the site now occupied by the Empire Theatre. The cost is estimated at $4,200,000.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Theodore Kaghan, a current target of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's investigating subcommittee for alleged past pro-Communist tendencies, has resigned as Deputy Director of the Public Affairs Division for the United States High Commissioner's Office in Germany.

The decision of Traffic Commissioner Wiley to eliminate the present one-hour parking restriction, as reported in THE TIMES for April 29, is bad news for the occupants of private homes in residential areas of this city.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 11 -- Pakistani Government officials are returning here in a mood of celebration after five days of efforts to tighten the knot of national unity with East Bengal Province, which is coextensive with East Pakistan.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The International Monetary Fund announced tonight the establishment of the initial par value for the Japanese yen at 360 a United States dollar.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 11 (AP) -- A royal decree announced today the transfer of the Shah's privately held estates to the Government of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh. The move was another victory for Dr. Mossadegh in his campaign to bring the royal court under complete Government domination.

The recent "referendum" on hiring practices canvassed by the International Longshoremen's Association was for a number of reasons confusing and inconclusive. The idea was to ascertain the reaction of the longshoremen to the shape-up system, under which men line up at piers and are selected daily by a hiring boss.
A proposal for selling common stocks on the installment plan may soon be adopted by the New York Stock Exchange.

NEWARK, May 11 -- Federal Judge Thomas J. Meaney today sentenced Leo Link, convicted bookmaker of Teaneck, to three years in the Federal penitentiary and imposed a fine of $10,000. Link, who conducted his national horse-betting business over Western Union telegraph wires, had pleaded no defense to charges of evading payment of $135,543 in income taxes for 1946 through 1949.
Plans for exporting Israel-made automobile tires to the United States were announced yesterday by Arthur Taubman, president of the Alliance Tire and Rubber Company, Ltd.
The opening of the new kennel shop at Mark Cross was the occasion for a showing of dog fashions and luggage yesterday at luncheon in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel.

The New York State Crime Commission, headed by Joseph M. Proskauer, was set up by Executive Order of Governor Dewey on March 29, 1951. Its first report, on Jan. 23, 1953, recounted the salient and sordid findings of hearings held in Ogdensburg, on Staten Island and in the city of Hudson. The major recommendation of that report was for the establishment of a permanent state Commission of Investigation.

CLEVELAND, May 11 (AP) -- An eighth-inning double by Chico Carrasquel settled a pitching duel between Billy Pierce and Bob Lemon tonight and gave the White Sox a 2-1 victory over the Indians. The defeat knocked Cleveland out of first place in the American League.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey announced today that his department would issue a new series of Treasury savings notes on Friday with a shorter...
The Appellate Division affirmed by a 3 to 2 majority yesterday a $300,000 verdict awarded Duane Jones Company, Inc., advertising agency, for the alleged "pirating of agency accounts and personnel."
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Improved prospects for winter wheat pointed today toward Government restrictions on next year's crop to keep the surplus within bounds.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- President Eisenhower accepted "with great regret" today, the resignation, effective June 30, of William H. Draper Jr., of New York, as the United States Special Representative in Europe.
Gil Turner had too many gloves and landed them too many times last night to suit Johnny Lombardo in the main bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn.

SINGAPORE, May 11 -- A joint committee under Britain's Commissioner General for Southeast Asia, Malcolm MacDonald, was set up tonight in what informed circles in Singapore described as the first step toward the unification of the Federation of Malaya and the colony of Singapore.

In behalf of the New York City Hospital Visiting Committee, a tea, cocktail party and fashion show will be given on Thursday in the ballroom of the Pierre. The organization was founded in 1872. Its members visit thirty-one municipal hospitals to provide welfare aid for charity patients.

When Sir Winston Churchill speaks on foreign affairs we hear what is probably the most qualified and is certainly one of the wisest voices on the subject in the free world. This is not in any sense a derogation of those who speak on this side of the ocean, nor is it a blanket endorsement of whatever the Prime Minister says.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Some of the Eisenhower budget cuts in "categorical health programs," such as those pertaining to cancer, mental health and the heart, have been restored in closed sessions of the House Appropriations subcommittee handling the requests of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The United States Government took no position today on Sir Winston Churchill's proposal for a conference among the leading nations at the "highest levels."

A new departure in motion picture sound projection, developed by Earl I. Sponable, director of research of Twentieth Century-Fox, and his staff, was announced yesterday by Spyros P. Skouras, president of the company.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., May 11 -- A fifteen-foot putt by Jack Patroni of Apawamis on the eighteenth green took top honors today for Patroni and Frank Donahue, his amateur partner, in the opening pro-amateur best-ball tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association.

Commodity prices were weaker yesterday in light volume on the New York exchanges. Tin, however, continued active, registering its highest volume of the year for the third time in four trading days. Tin, coffee, zinc, lead and rubber closed lower. Soybean oil, cottonseed oil, sugar, wool, potatoes, cocoa and hides ended mixed.

Patrolman Meyer E. Rubenstein of the New York Police Department admitted yesterday that he had at one time been a member of the Community party. The admission was made at a departmental hearing held at Police Headquarters where Rubenstein was under trial on a charge of having lied to superiors when he denied Communist affiliations earlier this year.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 11 -- Laos joined Vietnam today in protesting French devaluation of the piaster. Vietnamese sources predicted that the French action would result in a 30 to 40 per cent price increase and cause grave internal difficulties in the Indo-Chinese states associated in the French Union, which are beleaguered as a result of Communist warfare.

Seven pianists who have not appeared previously with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony have been engaged to play with the orchestra next season. Three of them are young Americans who will perform in contemporary works under the direction of Dimitri Mitropoulos.

Emanuel Berson, 38-year-old former plainclothes man, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Louis Goldstein in Kings County Court to thirty days in jail and fined $250 on a summary contempt charge. He ordered that Berson serve an additional thirty days if the fine was not paid.

LONDON, May 11 -- Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister, declared his belief today that the time was ripe again for a conference of the heads of state of the leading powers to try to settle at least some of the differences between the East and the West.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Department of Agriculture informed the Senate Agriculture Committee today that it was working on amendments to a bipartisan bill designed to give greater control of Federal farm credit operations to the farmers themselves.
The Arabs can have peace if they want to negotiate, Abba S. Eban, Israeli Ambassador to the United States and representative at the United Nations, said last night.

Operations of the Caterpillar Tractor Company for the twelve months ended on March 31 produced a net income of $22,509,085, it was announced yesterday. This compared with $15,203,935 reported for the corresponding twelve months a year earlier.

The Haire Publishing Company, publisher of business magazines and merchandising trade papers, whose offices have been at 1170 Broadway for the last thirty-seven years, will soon move downtown to the thirteen-story building at 111 Fourth Avenue, where it has leased two floors.

The sixteen Sunday afternoon dates at Town Hall, formerly taken by the New Friends of Music, will be filled next season by programs to be presented by a new nonprofit corporation known as the Concert Society of New York.
Richard M. Crooks was chosen chairman of the board of governors for the third time yesterday at the New York Stock Exchange's 137th annual election.

" Few Are Chosen," an autobiographical account of four years spent in a convent by Norma Downey Ferraro, will be issued tomorrow by Harper. The author left an orphanage in Newfoundland to enter an American convent at the age of 15 and left it when she was 19, after having taken her first vows.

Philippa Schuyler began making news at the age of 2 1/2 when reporters discovered she could spell some enormous words with unfailing accuracy. At 4 she began winning piano tournaments. Three years later she revealed gifts as a composer and at 14 she was a soloist at the Lewisohn Stadium. Last night at Town Hall she entered a new phase of her career, for she gave her first formal recital here as an adult artist.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Department of Defense today identified 73 Korean war casualties in a new list that included 10 killed, 47 wounded, four missing, eight captured and four injured. The following names were listed for New York and Connecticut (none from New Jersey):

MANILA, May 12 -- Although firm political information is at a premium here, there are unmistakable signs that there is a boom in the making for the nomination of Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo as President of the Philippines on the Liberal party ticket to oppose the former Defense Secretary Ramon Magsaysay.

From better starting of automobile engines in cold weather to a demand for the redesign of electric motors for permanent lubrication, the thousand engineers and chemists attending yesterday's session of the American Petroleum Institute at the Commodore Hotel, heard of scores of advances in the industry's processes.

BOSTON, May 12 (UP) -- Tony DeSpirito returned to action today at Suffolk Downs after a fifteen-day absence, but a rival jockey, Richard McLaughlin, stole the show by turning in three winners on the nine-race program.

TRENTON, May 12 -- Evidence that the dismissal of Nelson F. Stamler as Deputy Attorney General may not have been justified and that there definitely has been bungling in the investigation of the murder of Willie Moretti, the gambler, was presented here today to the legislative committee inquiring into the causes of the ouster of Mr. Stamler.
NEWARK, May 12 -- Two of the five incumbents seeking re-election to the City Commission, including Mayor Ralph A. Villani, lost their seats to independent candidates in today's municipal voting here.

HOBOKEN, May 12 -- City Commissioner John J. Grogan, national president of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., was elected Mayor of this city tonight, unseating Mayor Fred M. De Sapio.

Events tonight: Immaculata Singers, Town Hall, 8:30 o'clock; National Arts Club Orchestra and Chorus, National Arts-Club, 15 Gramercy Park, 8:30; School of Education Chamber Orchestra and Band, New York University School of Education Auditorium, 8:15.

Homer Bigart of The New York Herald Tribune became last night the first person from a single publication to win two of the annual awards of the Overseas Press Club. He was cited for best press reporting from abroad of foreign affairs and was the recipient of the George Polk Memorial Award for courage, integrity and enterprise above and beyond the call of duty.

Cheers are in order this morning for the Robert Montgomery production of "Appointment in Samarra," which was seen on Monday evening over N. B. C. television. The adaptation of John O'Hara's bitter and hard tragedy was a superb work of enlightened craftsmanship, a drama of integrity and maturity.

FOR more than eighteen months now midtowners have been puzzled by two white images that stare sadly into the honky-tonk area from ninth-floor windows of the Brill Building branch of Tin Pan Alley on Broadway at Forty-ninth Street.

The two-day strike on the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad was settled at 11:20 o'clock last night and the 70,000 commuters who rely on the Hudson Tubes to get them to and from their jobs in New York and New Jersey were assured that normal service would be available this morning.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 12 -- A high-ranking official of the General Federation of Women's Clubs warned here tonight that the group would not remain the largest association of organized women's clubs in the world if its various state federations failed to adjust themselves to changes.

Aesthete won the Elpis Handicap, the mile race for fillies and mares that featured yesterday's program at Belmont Park. Hal Price Headley's 4-year-old filly triumphed with something to spare in 1:38 3/5 and paid $10.20 for $2 to those among the 21,347 fans who backed her.

Stung by recent reports of increasing student rowdyism and ill manners on buses, the pupils of the Hunter College Elementary School presented yesterday a graphic lesson on how to behave while traveling to and from school.
Israel's first trans-Atlantic passenger liner, the 10,000-gross-ton Jerusalem, is due to arrive here next Monday on her first visit to the United States under the Israeli flag.

With conferences in Washington today on continental defense problems, Ernani do Amaral Peixoto, Governor of the State of Rio de Janeiro and son-in-law of President Getulio Vargas of Brazil, will complete a three-week mission in the United States on behalf of the President.

Sidewalk superintendents in the United Nations Plaza, now being built, are getting a grandstand view these pleasant days of an interesting salvage operation in the East River just off the elevated promenade where East Forty-sixth Street used to be.

NEW DELHI, India, May 12 -- The efficiency of the Indian Government under immense physical handicaps and the scope of inchoate attempts toward achieving mass welfare for this vast young republic's 357,000,000 inhabitants were highly praised by Paul H. Appleby, dean of the School of Public Administration, Syracuse University, in a 30,000-word report submitted to Parliament today by Finance Minister Sir Chintaman Deshmukh.
CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- The directors of the General American Transportation Corporation raised the company's common dividend rate today and announced plans to split the stock on a two-for-one basis.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 12 -- Speakers at the fifth annual Labor-Management Conference at Rutgers University here emphasized today the importance of psychological considerations as well as financial factors in developing retirement programs.
Dr. Edward T. Wentworth, president of the Medical Society of the State of New York, spoke out last night against extending hospital services into housing developments.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Justice Department and a radio man, Gordon McLendon, got a rough going over today as hearings ended on a bill Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat of Colorado, says is needed to save baseball.

HANOI, Indo - China, May 12 (UP) -- French headquarters said tonight the Vietminh Communists had withdrawn almost half their invasion forces from the kingdom of Laos and were massing northwest of Hanoi -- apparently for a new campaign.
The City of Baltimore borrowed $25,479,000 in the public market yesterday on serial bonds maturing from 1956 to 1982 at an interest cost of 2.5123 per cent.
BOSTON, May 12 (AP) -- Dom DiMaggio, Red Sox center fielder and the last of the three DiMaggio brothers in major league baseball, announced his retirement tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The House of Representatives took steps today to insure that Federal claims to the right to develop oil and other natural resources of the outer Continental Shelf were not forgotten the moment state title to submerged lands within historic offshore boundaries was recognized.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, May 13 -- The Communist party organ Pravda published today a summary of the foreign policy speech of Sir Winston Churchill, British Prime Minister, and asked whether the British Government intended to "continue a policy of militarization of Western Germany and the policy of a split of Germany."

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Early response to the bearish crop estimate on winter wheat was a lowering of grain futures values. On the setback, however, there was fairly active commission buying especially in the May deliveries, and for a time the market was strong.

Issues of new securities valued at more than $45,000,000 will be offered to investors today. They include mortgage bonds and common stock of public utility companies, equipment trust obligations of an Eastern railroad, and convertible preferred stock of a Southwestern natural gas enterprise. The offerings are:
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Democrats flung a roadblock today in front of the Republican plan to give presumably Republican Hawaii statehood while denying it to presumably Democratic Alaska.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- W. Randolph Burgess, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, told savings bankers here today, in effect, that the Treasury and the Federal Reserve have an eye cocked on the possibility of economic recession and will take measures to prevent it.

In the May 3 issue of your paper you have a story about the break in the Anglo-Egyptian negotiations, and an editorial The story, sent by one of your correspondents in London, and your editorial both require certain clarifications in order to give your readers a fair and accurate picture of the situation.

The popular Show-of-the-Month Club has gone out of existence. This was regretfully confirmed yesterday by Sylvia Siegler, head of the organization, at her office, 136 West Forty-fourth Street. She blamed her difficulties on the Shuberts, who barred her recently from obtaining tickets to choice attractions in their houses.

WACO, Texas, May 12 -- Thunder boomed as grim-faced armed soldiers guarded storm-mauled Waco tonight in the face of a warning there might be more of the tornadoes that had killed eighty-seven in Texas.

STRASBOURG, France, May 12 -- That Europe could attain convertibility of currencies with the help of the United States was the theme of the economic debate that opened today in the Council of Europe's Consultative Assembly. Currencies are considered convertible when one can be bought with another without restriction or limit.

Sales of leading mail-order and chain-store companies in April showed a rise of 2.7 per cent over volume in the corresponding month last year, according to a compilation of forty-three companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Victor Perlo, long accused of having headed a wartime Communist espionage ring while serving in important Government posts, refused today to answer that charge before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee.

ROME, May 12 -- The proposal of Sir Winston Churchill, British Prime Minister, for top-level parleys to seek an East-West agreement was endorsed by Pope Pius XII today in a speech at the Vatican to about 100 members of the Foreign Press Association here.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Texas tornadoes that took a heavy toll of lives added weight today to pleas to Congress by the Secretary of Commerce, Sinclair Weeks, against any slash in his proposed budget of $26,700,000 for maintenance of Weather Bureau services.

A first meeting between counsel for the New York City Transit Authority and Corporation Counsel Denis M. Hurley to get acquainted and for preliminary discussion of terms for a possible transfer of city-owned lines to the new authority has been arranged for today.

MONTREAL, May 12 (AP) -- Aluminium, Ltd., today reported net profit of $3,070,506 for the first quarter of 1953, compared with $5,106,306 for the corresponding period last year. This amounted to 38 cents a share, against 62 cents a share in 1952.

Special Deputy Attorney General William B. Herlands, chief prosecutor in the investigation of organized gambling and official corruption on Staten Island, got his first conviction last night when Alphonso A. Amato, a recalcitrant witness, was convicted of contempt in the Court of Special Sessions at St. George.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Department of the Interior received another proposal today by private power companies to market power produced at Federal dams. The latest proposal came from twelve electric companies operating in Arkansas, Louisiana and Missouri which outlined a plan for a thirty-year cooperative agreement between the private utilities and the Federal Government.

The annual dinner dance under the auspices of the New York Chapter of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation will be held tomorrow night in the St. Regis Roof for the benefit of the foundation. Mrs. W. Palmer Dixon is chairman of the committee in charge of plans for the fete, and Mrs. Russell C. Cecil is co-chairman.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 12 -- Lieut. Gen. John B. Coulter has been appointed head of the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency, it was announced here today by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold. He succeeds J. Donald Kingsley whose two-year term as agent general expired earlier this month.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The State of New York's Power Authority obtained preliminary permission from the Federal Government today for the construction and operation of its share of the $600,000,000 proposed hydroelectric project in the International Rapids section of the St. Lawrence River.

Commenting on the continuing tight money market situation yesterday, financial observers noted that the Federal Reserve's policy had advanced through neutrality, to mild restraint, to severe restraint. Present indications, they said are that money market pressure probably will be kept about as is, neither tighter nor easier.

Unless a presently unexpected change takes place before then, the Board of Estimate will on May 14 approve a zoning proposal which could destroy the finest public view in New York City -- that of the harbor and the downtown Manhattan skyline as seen from the Brooklyn Heights Esplanade.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- If restaurant owners make the most of their opportunities to increase business, the industry can become the second largest in this country, J. Fred Vollmer of Philadelphia, president of the National Restaurant Association, declared today at the group's thirty-fourth annual convention and exposition at Navy Pier.
LONDON, May 12 -- Dullness pervaded the principal sections of the London stock market today as yesterday's downward price trend continued. Declines, however, were rarely more than a few pence.

JERSEY CITY, May 12 -- The three of five candidates for the City Commission on Mayor John V. Kenny's slate who won tonight in the bitter municipal elections are expected to vote on Tuesday to continue Mr. Kenny as Mayor. The vote will take place at an organization meeting of the five-member commission.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A spokesman for Pan American World Airways contended today that a proposed 45 per cent reduction in trans-Atlantic cargo rates would bring about a "substantial development" in overseas freight business for scheduled airlines.

An interior color scheme that is related to that of the exterior is an interesting feature of a model house opening to the public this Sunday. Decorated by Beatrice West, interior designer, the model of seven rooms and two baths, built by Haskel Gordon and Max Fichtenbaum, is situated on Hillside Lane South, Syosset, L. I.

Andrew G. Clauson Jr., president of the Board of Education, was elected for the sixth time yesterday at the annual meeting of the board held at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn. The vote was unanimous.

THE last of the ice is disappearing from the shadowy fringes of Maine's northern lakes, and fishing is wide open throughout the entire state, with flies hatching on many of the streams and the land-locked salmon gulping streamers and smelt baits on the late-opening lakes.

The Association for the Relief of Respectable, Aged, Indigent Females will be the beneficiary of the annual bazaar and garden party, arranged by well-known women, to be held next Tuesday afternoon and evening at the association home, 891 Amsterdam Avenue.

LONDON, May 12 -- Leading the Labor Opposition in today's continued debate on British foreign policy, Clement Attlee found little to criticize in the summary of Britain's aims and aspirations abroad as expressed by Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister, yesterday, but much to find fault with in the United States Constitution, its effect on political and economic affairs and United States policy in general.
TOKYO, Wednesday, May 13 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,613, for Tuesday's operations:

We hope that the members of Congress will not get cold feet as they consider a pending proposal to increase their own salaries as well as the salaries of federal judges and attorneys. The hesitancy of legislators to vote themselves adequate pay because of fear of political repercussions is notorious.
SALT LAKE CITY, May 12 (AP) -- Union Pacific Railroad stockholders elected fifteen directors at their annual meeting today.

LONDON, May 12 -- A movement of British commando forces in the Mediterranean was reported tonight after it had been disclosed in the House of Commons that something like thirty attacks had been made on British personnel and installations in Egypt in recent weeks.

An unwholesome tendency among administrators of welfare funds to consider aid to dependent children as "relief" threatens to destroy the basic purpose of such programs, Joseph H. Reid, new executive director of the Child Welfare League of America, 24 West Fortieth Street, said yesterday.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 12 (UP) -- Hollywood Park today called off the first four days of its race meeting and warned horsemen embroiled in a dispute with the track over purses that if the Saturday program fails to fill, the track may be compelled to cancel its entire meeting.

The problem in Laos and Indo-China is essentially the same as in other parts of Asia and Africa, where the rising tide of nationalism makes them no longer willing to submit to Western domination. Military action, as in Korea, causes death and destruction to all sides without solving the problem.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Leaders of one segment of the powerful farm bloc in Congress assailed President Eisenhower's plan for reorganization of the Department of Agriculture today and obliquely warned Republicans they were again courting election defeat at the hands of farmers in advocating the Administration proposal.
As a preliminary to the Palm Beach round-robin golf tournament that begins tomorrow at the Meadow Brook Club course, Westbury, L. I., a pro-celebrity event will be staged there today.
The cotton futures market was slow yesterday and closing prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 15 points lower on May and 5 points lower to 2 points higher on other months than on Monday.

Plans were disclosed last night for a strategy conference early next week of three of the men most prominently identified with the American Federation of Labor's drive to stamp out union racketeering on the New York waterfront.

ST. LOUIS, May 12 (AP) -- A tense 1-1 pitching duel for eight innings erupted into a wild ninth tonight as the Phillies wrested the National League lead from the Dodgers by defeating the Cardinals, 6 -- 5.

Boys will follow a style leader in much the same way that men and, particularly, women do, according to a study conducted by the Boys' Apparel Buyers Association. The sales significance of this finding was discussed last night by a panel of buyers, psychologists and manufacturers at a boys' wear industry meeting called by the association at the Astor Hotel.

GENEVA, May 12 -- From Europe's viewpoint both sides in the debate over United States tariff policy now taking place in the United States seem to be missing a major point -- and some trade experts would say the major point -- about trade in the non-Communist world during the next few years.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- George M. Humphrey, the Secretary of the Treasury, said today that the Administration would be ready next week to give Congress its recommendations on tax reduction proposals along with detailed estimates of prospects for balancing the budget.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 12 -- Turkey's largest hydroelectric project moved a step nearer to realization today with ceremonies marking the opening of a pilot tunnel at the Sariyar dam site, in the northwest.

VIENNA, May 12 -- The United States mission for economic cooperation has notified the Austrian Government that unless it launches before June 30 a program for increasing productivity it will lose $10,000,000 of American aid.

LONDON, May 12 (UP) -- Don Cockell, blood streaming from cuts above both of his nearly-closed eyes, won both the British and Empire heavyweight championships tonight by scoring an upset, fifteen-round decision over Johnny Williams at Harringay Arena.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, May 13 (AP) -- The heaviest fighting in ten days erupted yesterday on the Korean central front. About 1,000 Chinese Communists attacked five South Korean outposts and were repulsed with severe losses.

The City Council's committee on rules, privileges and elections was authorized by the full Council yesterday to investigate "charges of unwarranted use of force and abuse of authority" by the Police Department. The vote was twenty-two in favor and one abstention.

" Tales of the City," the new drama series to be written and co-produced by Ben Hecht, will make its debut over the C. B. S. television network on June 25 and will be presented on alternate Thursdays from 8:30 to 9 P. M. Robert Stevens will be the director and a co-producer.

A team of ten United States amateur boxers, five of them National Amateur Athletic Union champions, is scheduled to leave here May 22 for a two-weeks' tour of Argentina, the A. A. U. revealed yesterday.
Frozen calves' liver, well cleaned, skinned and deveined so preparation time is cut to a minimum, is a new product of Excelsior Quick Frozen Meat Products, Inc.

The book "The Strange Case of Alger Hiss," by Lord Jowitt, former Lord Chancellor of Britain, will be published in this country late in the summer after the elimination of "a serious inadvertent factual error," Doubleday Co., publishers, announced last night.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Bureau today adopted a new policy aimed to cut down the year-after-year haggling with business men over their depreciation claims.

Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., large manufacturer of linoleum and other smooth surface floor and wall coverings, announced yesterday the purchase of the Sloane-Blabon Corporation for a price "not to exceed $10,250,000."
BALTIMORE, May 12 (AP) -- A jury today found Sonja Henie and her ice show corporation were not to blame when the stands collapsed just before she opened an appearance here in March 1952.

Because "practically everything" Goldman, Sachs Co. touched in the period following World War I went up, the investment banking firm had no reason to join a conspiracy to monopolize the securities market as charged by the Government, Arthur Dean, defense lawyer, asserted in Federal Court here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- Officials of the Department of Agriculture are facing pressure to put international trade in three important crops on a contract and quota basis.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The United States Government has purchased an estimated 10,000 tons of jet airplane fuel that a Finnish tanker was trying to haul to Communist China.
ST. LOUIS, May 12 (AP) -- Stockholders in the Missouri Pacific Railroad today elected 15 members to the board of directors during their annual meeting.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 12 -- The State Department has "drafted" into service in its motion picture truth campaign against communism twenty-eight Hollywood directors to guide the making of a series of two, three and four-reel films.

PARIS, May 12 -- Jacques Fath's mid-season collection is prophetic of fall. The designer has purposely revealed his feeling for the trends to come because of the many foreigners who will be in Paris this summer before and after the Coronation.

The scratchiest kind of scratch hit by his pitching rival, Early Wynn, deprived Eddie Ford of a no-hitter last night as the brilliant young southpaw of the Yankees shut out the Indians. 7 -- 0, at the Stadium before baseball's biggest crowd of the 1953 season.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations is quietly checking reputed evidence that communism has penetrated one of its affiliates, the United Packinghouse Workers.

For its first premiere of the season at the City Center, the New York City Ballet last night elected to revive Lew Christensen's light-hearted "Filling Station," which dates back to 1938. It was, accord-cording to a curtain speech by Lincoln Kirsten, the first work to be commissioned completely -- score, decor and choreography -- by the Ballet Caravan, an ancestor of the present company, and it has certain sentimental connotations as a consequence.

ALTHOUGH Thomas Hinde's first novel, "Mr. Nicholas,"* is comparatively short, reading it is a nerve-racking experience. Not since Samuel Butler took fiendish revenge upon his own father in "The Way of All Flesh" has a pater familias been portrayed so mercilessly in fiction. "It is frighteningly funny," says the English novelist Henry Green of "Mr. Nicholas."

MILWAUKEE, May 12 -- Cheered by a crowd of 29,967 roaring Milwaukeeans who appeared deliriously unmindful of a biting cold that had cracked down on this metropolis along with the setting sun, Bob Buhl, a rookie right-hander making his first major-league start, spun an eye-filling two-hitter tonight as the Braves downed the Giants, 8 to 1, in the opener of a two-game series.

A former assistant purchasing agent at Syracuse University and two former War Assets Administration employes who conspired to purchase fraudulently surplus drugs from the Government received prison sentences yesterday from Judge Irving R. Kaufman of the United States District Court.

BOSTON, May 12 (AP) -- Ferris Fain doubled for two runs with the bases loaded in the tenth inning tonight to provide the White Sox with a 9-7 victory over the Red Sox. The game-winning hit was stroked against Bill Kennedy, a former team-mate. The resulting runs were at the expense of Ellis Kinder, who had beaten the White Sox on all seventeen previous appearances against them.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 12 (UP) -- Robert A. Hall, a strong advocate of controlled and limited television of college football, resigned today as athletic director of Yale University to enter private industry. His resignation becomes effective July 1.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Coal industry spokesmen and their Congressional supporters testified today that foreign residual oils were being "dumped" on American markets with disastrous effects on coal, railroads and related industries.

The cocktail and evening designs by Filcol, shown yesterday by Arnold Constable at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, were of airy chiffon and silk organdy, with twirling full skirts and decolletages draped for the maximum flattery.

Operators of ships plying the Pacific from Japan to the United States have cut freight rates by as much as 70 per cent in the battle for cargoes that has ensued since two Pacific conferences suspended all regulations on tariffs in mid-March.

Dr. Luther H. Gulick, executive director of the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey, said yesterday a city administration based on an organization plan of 1900 was the cause of the present municipal "mess" and it was not "necessarily the fault of the men in office now."
