A strongly worded attack on the "spurious patriotism whose main intent seems to be to investigate anyone who does not fit into their pattern of narrow-minded outlook" was made yesterday by the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York.

Burt Helgeson slammed a home run over the right-field fence with none out in the fourteenth inning to enable Wagner College to gain a 2-1 Metropolitan Conference victory over New York University yesterday at Grymes Hills, Staten Island.

Details concerning the format of "Highlights of the Empire" program were released yesterday. The farewell tribute to the Empire Theatre, which is to be torn down after May 30, will be given there under the auspices of the American National Theatre and Academy on Sunday night, May 24.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The four military leaders figuring in defense promotions today have had long and varied careers in their respective departments. The following sketches recall some highlights of their lives and service:

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 12 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion's office in the foreign ministry worked feverishly today preparing for Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and Harold E. Stassen, Mutual Security Administrator, memoranda, charts and reports in quantities considerably greater than they or their party can possibly read during the twenty-eight hours they will spend in Israel.

TOKYO, May 12 (AP) -- United States Air Force headquarters said four American Thunderjet fighter-bombers jettisoned their bombs at almost the exact place and time an unidentified ship was reported to have exploded and sunk today.
With only one match to be played in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub series, the Century Country Club is assured the Westchester district title.

CAIRO, Wednesday, May 13 -- An official Egyptian source said early today at the close of conferences with Secretary Dulles that the British-Egyptian dispute over control of the Suez Canal zone remained deadlocked with no signs that negotiations would be resumed in the near future.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Eisenhower has not satisfied all the Republicans who nominated him or the Republicans who opposed him at Chicago, but he is doing his level best to avoid a break with either group.
PARIS, May 12 -- The French merchant marine strike ended its second week today with no settlement in sight and with a growing number of ships laid up in Atlantic and Mediterranean ports.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 12 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that at first glance "I see considerable difficulties" in reconciling the United Nations Charter with a bill introduced by Senator Pat McCarran of Nevada, which would require a security certification by the Attorney General of all Americans employed by the United Nations.

The point in Prime Minister Churchill's speech that has aroused the keenest interest throughout the world is undoubtedly his suggestion for another Big-Power conference "on the highest level" and "without long delay." This suggestion, which he has made many times before, has been seized upon in some quarters as indicating a major difference in policy between the United States and Britain.

Decrying the decision of the State Department to end the Thai and Malayan language broadcasts of the Voice of America, John A. Nalley, acting chief of the East Asia section of the radio propaganda agency, declared yesterday that the decision had "accomplished more in one short month than international communism has been able to accomplish in ten years."

Stocks retreated again yesterday on small offerings. A long list of issues selling ex-dividend had an unfavorable effect on average prices, but the bulk of the list eased independently of this factor. Of the 1,125 issues traded 560 finished with minus signs, 271 advanced and 294 remained unchanged.

Repeal of the 20 per cent Federal excise tax on cosmetics and other toiletries was urged yesterday by Davis Factor, president of the organization's eighteenth annual convention in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

HOBOKEN, N. J., May 12 -- Assistant Prosecutor Abraham Sepenuk said today that the arrest of Michael (Moon Mullins) O'Connor was "the best break so far" toward solution of the murder eight days ago of John Francis Kelly, hiring boss of Pier 3.

TOKYO, May 12 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations commander, conferred privately for an hour today with South Korean President Syngman Rhee, who recently has been voicing outspoken opposition to a cease-fire in the Korean war.

ROME, May 12 -- Only a few hours after arriving in Apulia, the heel of Italy, today to see what land reform has done and is doing for that region Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce figured in the conversion of a Communist.

BONN, Germany, May 12 -- Theodore Kaghan asserted tonight that he had resigned as Deputy Director of the Public Affairs Division of the United States High Commissioner's office here because it was obvious that the State Department "would not back anyone involved" with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

The Census Bureau reports that 7,100,000 persons are now governmental workers in this country, employed by the federal, state and local governments. Measured against our labor force, this figure means that roughly one out of every nine workers in this country is now a government employe.

Sixteen firemen, including two lieutenants, were overcome by smoke or injured last night while fighting a blaze in the upper floors of a three-store store and office building at 709-715 Eighth Avenue, on the southwest corner of Forty-fifth Street. Both lieutenants and one fireman required hospital treatment.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet and advocate of a blockade of Red China, was nominated by President Eisenhower today to succeed General of the Army Omar N. Bradley as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

WHEN Jersey Joe Walcott tackles Rocky Marciano in Chicago on Friday night, it might be advisable for the ageless challenger's seconds to have a comptometer as part of the standard equipment in his corner. Jersey Joe is confident of winning, and winning by a knockout.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- President Eisenhower returned to the White House tonight from Shangri-la, the Presidential cabin in the Catoctin Mountains near Thurmont, Md.

BUENOS AIRES, May 12 -- Anticipating the findings of a Congressional committee named to investigate the activities of three United States news agencies, the Ministry of Communications suspended today the agencies' communications licenses for reception of news dispatches from abroad.

PARIS, May 12 -- The appointment today of Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther as Supreme Allied Commander in Europe is heartening to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, worried by the slackening pace of Western defense.

By agreeing to compromise the effective date of a proposed wage increase the disputants in the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad strike took a sensible course. It is a pity that this could not have been done before the strike of eighty signalmen, towermen and clerks began on Monday, inconveniencing 70,000 commuters daily before it was settled last night.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., May 12 -- Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the Studebaker Corporation and former Economic Cooperation Administration chief, tonight called for the lowering of all types of trade barriers in order to rebuild world markets and strengthen the free world in its struggle with the Kremlin.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 12 -- Egypt told a nineteen-nation committee studying the problem of membership in the United Nations today that the best available solution was the Soviet-backed proposal for mass admission of fourteen countries.

John P. Crane, former president of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, who was dismissed from the Fire Department Jan. 29, 1951, when he refused to waive immunity before giving testimony to a grand jury, was ordered restored to his job yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Benedict D. Dineen.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- Senator Robert S. Kerr, Democrat of Oklahoma, said in a Senate speech today that the new higher interest rates of the Government are "calculated to lead to a recession." He said, "He who produces and he who borrows is the forgotten man of this Administration."
TOLEDO, Ohio, May 12 (UP) -- Ezzard Charles, former heavyweight champion of the world, rallied in the last five rounds tonight to win a unanimous ten-round decision over Bill Gilliam.
Dramatic upsets occurred in the Jersey City Commission election yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, May 12 -- The United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., submitted "profit and loss" figures to its members today to convince them that the eight-week strike of 550,000 workers in the basic steel industry last year had paid dividends to the union rank-and-file.

The recent city budget fight in which allocations for day care were saved by quick and concerted action of interested groups has "won the day-care fight for all time," Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy told members of the Day Care Council yesterday.

LONDON, May 12 -- A warning that differences may arise between the United States and Britain in their reactions to the new conciliatory attitude of the Soviet Union was given today in a joint report of two groups of prominent Americans and Britons that have made a special study of problems in British-American cooperation.

When the wards are quiet in the hospitals, when the last bustling nurse has gone for a snack, there are little sounds that make themselves heard over the normal hospital sounds and the dim clatter from the streets. A little whimper here and there, and, worst of all, a long sigh. The sigh of utter loneliness starts nervous fingers picking at bed coverings.

Bright sun colors keynoted the Ken Barr collection of separates shown yesterday at Russeks. Cotton shirts, shorts, skirts and pants were shown in color combinations chosen to stand out against sand, sky and water.

BONN, Germany, May 12 -- The West German Government received with considerable coolness the proposals of Sir Winston Churchill, British Prime Minister, on the means for easing world tensions as set forth in the British House of Commons yesterday.

James Ramsey Ullman, mountain-climbing author of "The White Tower" and other novels, has a collection of his short stories scheduled for June 10 publication by Lippincott. Entitled "Island of the Blue Macaws," the volume has seventeen stories culled from the forty or more he has written.

The Department of Health announced yesterday its plan for distributing its share of the "sharply limited" national supply of gamma globulin to reduce as much as possible the impact of poliomyelitis or infantile paralysis on the city's children this summer.

James Ramsey Ullman, mountain-climbing author of "The White Tower" and other novels, has a collection of his short stories scheduled for June 10 publication by Lippincott. Entitled "Island of the Blue Macaws," the volume has seventeen stories culled from the forty or more he has written.

The Department of Health announced yesterday its plan for distributing its share of the "sharply limited" national supply of gamma globulin to reduce as much as possible the impact of poliomyelitis or infantile paralysis on the city's children this summer.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense, today called the Administration's reduced defense budget the "best compromise" the Joint Chiefs of Staff could work out and declared that build-up goals for the Armed Services would no longer be set.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Senators made it five in a row tonight, raking Ned Garver for ten runs in less than six innings and coasting to a 10-to-1 victory over the foundering Tigers. Conrado Marrero pitched his second victory, stopping Detroit with six hits.

The question of what is wrong with advertising that is used as point-of-sale or dealer-help material by retailers was debated with vigor yesterday at a luncheon of the Sales Executives Club at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Today's new feature is "The Magnetic Monster," at the Globe. The Ivan Tors presentation stars Richard Carlson, King Donovan and Jean Byron. Harry Ellerbe, Leo Britt, Leonard Mudie and Byron Foulger head the supporting cast.

Only one place remained unfilled last night in the eighteen-member special committee that Governor Dewey has asked to try to reconcile differences between the State Crime Commission and local officials over the commission's proposals for legislation to tighten law enforcement in the state.

The St. Lawrence Seaway has received the endorsement of every President of the United States since Woodrow Wilson. Surely they cannot all be wrong in holding that a navigation and power improvement adding strength to the nation as a whole will benefit every part.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- The Senate Republican leader, Robert A. Taft of Ohio, said today he "always" had believed that Congressmen deserved pay increases but that he was "dubious" whether this was the time to grant them.

In an atmosphere charged with city election-year politics, Mayor Impellitteri yesterday swore ir Assemblyman Edward T. Galloway of the Bronx and the reappointed AleXander Del Giorno of Queens for ten-year terms as city magistrates.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 (AP) -- The Browns' no-hit rookie hurler Bobo Holloman, retired after one and one-third innings with a pitching-finger blister, but the Browns pounded Bobby Shantz for twelve of their fourteen safeties for a 7-to-3 victory over the Athletics tonight.

The enthusiastic reception accorded to the foreign policy speech of Prime Minister Churchill was as important as the speech itself. The proposal of an "unconditional" meeting on the highest level of the leading Powers expressed not only English but European popular sentiment.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- All last year Ben Wade allowed only one home run on the road and that one was hit at Wrigley Field by Dee Fondy. Today Ben was whacked for his second road homer of this season and Fondy hit it in the eleventh inning to give the Cubs a 6-4 triumph before a Ladies' Day gathering of 13,524 (8,077 paid).
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., May 12 -- Former President Harry S. Truman urged the nation today to get behind President Eisenhower's foreign policy "so we can keep the peace of the world."
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The American Red Cross allocated $200,000 today to aid victims of the twin Texas tornadoes, which the agency described as "among the most deadly" in its history.

Volume continued light yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges with only hides, tin and sugar showing moderate activity. Prices closed irregular with coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, cocoa and zinc increased. Hides, potatoes, lead and rubber were lower and tin, sugar and wool ended mixed.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 12 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that the Communist proposals regarding Korean prisoners of war obviously represented "a rather considerable step forward" but added that "we could not for a moment forget that there is still a very long way to go."
Domestic steel mills produced 9,545,000 net tons of raw steel last month, the highest output ever attained in April, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

A sudden and unexpected rush of water, after three days of unexplained clogging, into a sprinkler system serving three Harlem' houses resulted last night in plans by the Fire Department for a quick cancellation of a vacate order that would have driven seventy-five persons out of the three houses within ten days.

The articles on Colombia from Sydney Gruson which this newspaper has been printing give a sober picture of a disturbing situation. Colombia is a country of considerable importance in the hemisphere, and no North American has a right to discuss her without acknowledging that she is a friendly country, very cooperative in trade relations and in United Nations affairs.

Ward 1 of the City Home on Welfare Island closed down yesterday after the last twenty-five elderly patients walked slowly out of the drab old building, climbed into a bus and were helped a few minutes later into wheelchairs at the new Bird S. Coler Memorial Hospital and Home on the north end of the island.

Most gardeners long since have put their spring seed catalogues aside as bending, squatting and crawling on all fours in the garden have replaced armchair horticulture. Those seeds ordered in the dark months now are in the ground and the warm light and the soil are helping to perform their annual miracles.

MEXICO CITY, May 12 -- Mexico has made diplomatic representations to the American State Department complaining anxiously about serious effects that the Simpson bill would have on the ailing Mexican mining industry.

In a never-never land of fish that float in air and other monstrous creations, painters and sculptors on Friday evening at the Astor Hotel will crown the queen of the annual Spring Fantasia Ball of Artists Equity Association.

TOKYO, Wednesday. May 13 -- The United Nations delegation at Panmunjom handed the Communists today a new plan for the disposal of prisoners of the Korean war unwilling to return behind the Iron Curtain after an armistice. The proposal sharply modified the Chinese-North Korean plan for the establishment of a neutral nations repatriation commission and an international political conference.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 12 (AP) -- Mrs. A. Roberts' 7-year-old Eatontown raced within one-fifth of a second of the track standard in accounting for the Collingswood Purse at Garden State Park today. Eatontown covered the six furlongs in 1:09 4-5 over a fast track for his second consecutive victory before 20,454 fans.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 -- Walter S. Franklin, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, told stockholders at today's annual meeting that the carrier's gross revenue last month was the greatest for any April in its history. On revenue of $88,830,000 the railroad had net income of $4,057,000 in April, compared with earnings of $1,226,000 on aggregate revenue of $84,778,000 in the same month of 1952.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., May 13 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Republic Steel Corporation, at their annual meeting here today, approved an increase in the authorized common stock to 20,750,000 shares from the present 10,000,000.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A Long Island physicist who had been cited publicly as a Communist was urged by Government scientists in 1943 to participate in experiments that produced the atomic bomb, according to testimony disclosed today. However, he refused.

Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain presented prizes last night to three girls who had written the best essays of those submitted by thousands of East Side schoolchildren on a subject close to his heart: "How We Can Get Cleaner Streets."

Picketing of piers by members of the tugboatmen's union during their strike last February was defended yesterday morning at a National Labor Relations Board hearing on an unfair labor practice charge. The hearing before Arthur Leff, trial examiner, is being held at the board's regional headquarters, 2 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Senator Prescott Bush, Republican of Connecticut, told the Senate today it was irrelevant whether President Eisenhower wanted the stand-by authority to freeze prices, wages and rents for ninety days in grave national emergency, such as would be provided by a pending bill.

Chrysler and International Silver sold ex-dividend and Firestone dropped 3/4 point in stock market trading yesterday. These three developments were almost entirely responsible for the downward trend in THE YORK NEW TIMES industrial averages, which showed a 1.14-point decline.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Commissioner Charles W. Crawford announced today that the Food and Drug Administration would start enforcement immediately of the ban on polyosethylene monosterate softeners in bread.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -Two editors who helped to license the first newspapers allowed to operate in Germany in the early postwar days announced today they had refused today to tell Senate investigators whether they were Communists at the time.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 13 -- A good deal of golf, humor and autographing were packed into the pro-celebrity competition, a forerunner to the Palm Beach tournament, at the Meadow Brook Club today.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Office of Defense Mobilization announced today it had issued $118,346,403 worth of certificates of necessity for accelerated tax amortization covering 202 new or expanded defense facilities in the period from April 23 through May 6.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A dairy industry advisory group called today for the use of flexible price supports on farm commodities at the end of the current marketing year. This was the first action of an advisory group to cut current high-price crops.

The National Association of Women Artists will open their annual exhibition with a preview tonight in the galleries of the National Academy. Beginning tomorrow the event will be open to the public through the month.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The State Department denied today that it had chosen twenty-eight Hollywood directors to assist in the production of films for the International Information Administration.

A recent dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES by Drew Middleton states that an increase in the strength of the Christian Democratic and Social Democratic parties, expected as a result of the purge of Right-Wing extremists from among the ranks of two of the present Bonn coalition parties, "would set the stage for a coalition of the Christian Democrats and Social Democrats, so ardently desired by some Allied officials."

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The latest session of House of Representatives investigators with Henry W. Grunewald, the Washington "mystery man," ended abruptly this afternoon on the witness' complaint of "illness" after he had testified he had no recollection at all of what a "trading" company he had formed three years ago did specifically.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 (UP) -- The defending champion, Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., and second-seeded Tony Trabert of Cincinnati easily gained the third round of the fifty-third annual California state tennis championships today as each breezed past his first two opponents.

Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican of Iowa, said yesterday he would seek an immediate conference in Washington with officials of the State Department and the International Information Administration to see whether the decision to eliminate Voice of America broadcasting to Latin America could be reconsidered.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Hearings that may open the way for relief to millions of taxpayers who for years have been complaining of various inequities in Federal revenue laws were announced today by Representative Daniel A. Reed, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 13 -- Screen rights to "Zarak Khan," a novel written by A. J. Bevan and published in England in 1949, have been acquired by Warwick Productions, the independent company headed by Irving Allen.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (UP) -Under Secretary of Agriculture True D. Morse said today the Administration is giving increased attention to foreign trade in farm products.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

A warning that this year could mark a turning point in the world arms race in which Russia "may again start to forge ahead" was sounded yesterday by Hanson W. Baldwin, military analyst of THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Cotton trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was quiet, and final prices were 1 to 8 points net higher than on Tuesday.

MOSCOW, May 13 -- United States Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen announced today he had his first business meeting with So viet Foreign Minister Molotov -- a conference of about twenty minutes late Tuesday afternoon.

An arbitrator awarded a wage increase of $5 a week yesterday to 58,000 workers in the women's coat and suit industry in the metropolitan area. It represented the first pay rise for the garment workers since they got an identical increase in November, 1950.
HANOI, Vietnam, May 13 (UP) -The French announced today that paratroopers had wiped out a company of Communist-led Vietminh troops in savage fighting for a jungle canyon deep in Laos.

Stanley C. Allyn and Walter H. J. Behm have been elected directors of the Mead Corporation, Dayton, Ohio, paperboard manufacturer Mr. Allyn is president of the National Cash Register Company and Mr. Behm is president of the Winters National Bank and Trust Company, Dayton.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 (AP) -Eddie Joost's eighth-inning homer with none on gave the Athletics a 2-1 victory over the Browns tonight and broke the A's seven-game losing streak. Big Alex Kellner went the distance and received credit for his fifth triumph against two defeats.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- Rocky Marciano was whisked into town today. With his training session at Holland, Mich., completed, the heavyweight champion of the world moved to Chicago to await his fifteen-round title defense against Jersey Joe Walcott at the Chicago Stadium the night after tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -The American Bankers Association urged Congress today to eliminate Government subsidies from the farm credit system.

The 150 members of the Women's Christian Temperance Union of Springfield, Mass., protested yesterday to the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad against two new tavern cars that have been attached to New YorkSpringfield and New York-New Haven coach trains in the past six weeks.
YONKERS, May 13 (AP) -- Projectile, a mudder, closed fast in the last eighth of a mile to win the Buchanan Trot at the Yonkers Raceway's Grand Circuit meeting tonight.

Landing agents of most of the New York steamship lines -- more commonly known as the "troubleshooters" of the passenger trade -- will gather at Falstaff's Restaurant on South William Street tonight to honor Peter Devine on his twenty-fifth anniversary with the Cunard Line landing department.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Faced with the prospect of a shortage of storage facilities for grain crops, the Department of Agriculture has started to move steel and aluminum bins from nine states into Kansas, the country's biggest wheat producer.

A plea for increased cooperation by the maritime industry with the city's Department of Air Pollution Control was made yesterday by Dr. Leonard Greenburg, Commissioner, at a meeting of the Marine Smoke Control Group in the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street.

THE bluefish schools seem to be moving this way, and reports from several New Jersey fishing resorts from Cape May north indicate larger catches during the past few days. Some boats have brought in up to thirty-five fish, plus good catches of mackerel.

LONDON, May 13 -- The International Press Institute, which is holding its second general assembly here with editor-members from twenty-three countries, today heard interim reports in its research project, a survey of the international flow of news.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -Aides of Dr. Robert L. Johnson, chief of the State Department's International Information Administration, said tonight he had sent a team of experts to Germany to survey the operations of the administration there.

Fifty-nine prizes were awarded yesterday to winners of the annual contest of the Art Directors Club of New York for the best examples of advertising and editorial art. The awards were presented by Roy W. Tillotson, retiring president of the club, at a luncheon attended by 600 persons in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The nation's gasoline stock declined 262,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were reported at 157,337,000 barrels, against 157,599,000 a week earlier.

MOSCOW, Thursday, May 14 -Pravda, Izvestia and other Soviet newspapers today published a nearly full page report of the British foreign policy debate in the House of Commons, including a half page report of Prime Minister Churchill's statement.
BERLIN, May 13 -- West Berlin postal authorities reported today that East Berlin authorities had cut all but three telephone cables connecting the Soviet and Allied sectors of the city.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 6, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

Max Littwitz, Inc. linens and laces, store and two floors in 801 Madison Avenue: Murray Klein Studios, commercial artists, in 114 E 54 St: Spencer Wire Corp, Louis A. Voltter, investments, Frederick Stafford, member of the New York Stock Exchange, Barbour E. Weil, music publisher, in the Squibb Building, 745 5th Ave--Culver, Hollyday Co. brokers.
WACO, Tex., May 13 (AP) -- The number of dead picked from Waco's tornado ruins rose to 100 late today and searchers said they were sure to find more bodies in the twisted steel and rubble.
New men with new methods, a new organization and a revised budget will direct armed forces modified in size and concept during the Eisenhower Administration.

Further information is now available on the so-called "pay-as-you-go" merchandising plan of the New York Stock Exchange, which is under study. In its present form, the plan does not involve the use of credit. Investors will pay their installments without actually owning any stock until enough money has been accumulated to make a commitment feasible.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -The Congressional budget-cutting campaign struck a snag today when the House Appropriations Committee reported that it could trim only 3 1/2 per cent from funds of the Treasury and Post Office Departments in former President Hairy S. Truman's budget, for the 1954 fiscal year beginning July 1.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Britain's proposal for a meeting of the top leaders of the major powers was politely but firmly deferred by the Eisenhower Administration today, pending some token of Soviet sincerity, and British leaders were furiously denounced in the Senate over the Korean peace issue.

UNIONDALE, L. I., May 13 -- William C. De Koning, czar of American Federation of Labor construction unions on Long Island for twenty years, quit today and announced that he would move to Hollywood, Fla. Mr. De Koning's activities had been under investigation by the New York City Anti-Crime Committee for several months.
With Don Bollweg leading a spirited charge from four runs behind, the Yankees cut down the Indians, 9 -- 4, before 14,038 paying spectators at the Stadium yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -Dr. Robert J. Anderson of the Federal Public Health Service told Senators today that the new anti-tuberculosis drug, isoniazid, had "not come up to the high hopes many once held for it."

LOS ANGELES, May 13 -- A spokesman for Cecil B. DeMille, film director and producer, took issue today with union assertions that Mr. DeMille was delinquent in his payment of dues to the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.

The Spanish liner Guadalupe, the first new Spanish ship to call at the Port of New York in twenty-five years, berthed at Pier 1, Hoboken, N. J., yesterday morning, completing the first leg of her maiden voyage.

A recount of the vote for all candidates in Jersey City's election, which could upset the 3-to-2 commission majority of Mayor John V. Kenny, will begin at 10 A. M. today on the order of Superior Court Judge Haydn Proctor.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A little-known group of eighteen lawyers, economists and statisticians are giving their well-worn codebooks, indices and slide rules a workout at the Capitol these days, as usual, in a continuing task that affects the pocketbook of every taxpayer in the country.

Today's new feature is "Cinderella,'' art Italian importation at; the Little Carnegie. The adaptation of the opera "Cenerentola," by Rossini, has a cast headed by Lori Randi, Gino Del Signore, Afro Poli and Vito De Taranto with the voices of Fedoraarbieri and Fernanda Cadoni featured.

INGLEWOOD, Calf., May 13 (AP) -- Chairman Dwight Murphy of the California Horse Racing Board said today he would attempt to settle the deadlock between the Hollywood Turf Club and the boycotting horsemen tomorrow on the basis of a 4-3-2.7 formula under which the track would distribute in purses 4 per cent of the first $10,000,000 pari-mutuel handle, 3 per cent of the second $10,000,000 and 2.7 per cent of the excess.

MEDITATION is good for the soul. A fellow who unexpectedly finds himself delayed on his way to Chicago for the Marciano-Walcott fistic frolic can't help but let his mind wander and ponder while waiting for swift fever to subside. He thinks back to a long-distance telephone call he received not long ago.

Deposits held by New York's mutual savings banks rose $75,848,000 last month. The increase, according to data issued yesterday by Charles R. Diebold, president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, compares with a gain of $56,583,000 in April, 1952, and brought the twelve months' advance to $1,188,000,000, as against $776,000,000 in the comparable 1951-52 period.

A first magnitude political controversy has developed between State Senator Pliny W. Williamson, Republican of Westchester, who heads the special Joint Legislative Committee on Reapportionment, and John R. Crews, Republican leader of Kings County, over the rearranging of State Senatorial district lines in Brooklyn.

ROME, May 13 -- The appointment of Admiral Arthur W. Radford to the chairmanship of Joint Chiefs of Staff is widely regarded in Italy as a victory of the "Asia first" school of thought and fear is expressed in some quarters that it may herald important changes also in emphasis of the foreign policy of the United States as it affects Europe.

Net income of the Cerro de Pasco Corporation plunged 90 per cent in the first quarter, as compared with the same period last year, and sales were off 37 per cent, Robert P. Koenig, president, reported at the annual meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Eisenhower Administration apparently has decided to carry its fight for the President's Department of Agriculture reorganization plan all the way without concessions to growing opposition.

CAIRO, May 13 -- Secretary of State Dulles left Cairo today after two days of conferences with Egyptian leaders that produced no commitments from either side except an implied one to continue to seek a peaceful solution of the British-Egyptian dispute over the Suez Canal zone.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- All new crop wheat deliveries reached new lows for the season today, the outstanding feature being the indifference of outside buyers to the low prices. The weakness in wheat helped depress other grains.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 13 -Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, Harold E. Stassen, Mutual Security Administrator, and their party arrived today for two-day conversations with leaders here on troubled Israeli-Arab relations. It is understood the Americans were startled by the gravity of the British-Egyptian conflict over the Suez Canal issue, which they had discussed for three days in Cairo.

The ever-growing critical shortage of teachers has provoked statements of concern from the State Education Department, the New York State School Boards Association, State Teachers Colleges and parents' and citizens' groups.
TAIPEI, Formosa, May 13 -George K. C. Yeh, Nationalist, Foreign Minister, put Nationalist China on the record today as opposing any big power conference to settle the existing world problems.

New York's Finest -- feminine phalanx -- have been absorbing more than criminal lore in their daily rounds, and this they will demonstrate at a musical show they will put on tomorrow evening at the Commodore Hotel.

Beginning next Monday, exporters to Colombia must provide separate certificates of origin with shipping documents presented for legalization to that country's Consulate General, it was announced yesterday through the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

A wide variety of beautiful cottons and linens and such detailing as tuckings, pipings, applique trims and insets of lace distinguished Gunther Jaeckel's collection of Benham Originals for summer, shown yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

SEOUL Korea, Thursday, May 14 (AP) -- About 200 United States fighter-bombers attacked a big Communist troop and Supply center under the nose of the Red air force Wednesday, and not a MIG challenged them.
MELBOURNE, Australia, May 13 -- Japan has agreed that her pearl fleet off northern Australia will not enter territorial waters except in the emergencies recognized by international law.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The State Department said today Charles E. Bohlen, United States Ambassador in Moscow, had asked permission for Russian wives of American citizens to leave the Soviet Union and join their husbands abroad.

Domestic shipments of rayon and acetate yarn and staple by United States producers in April were 102,400,000 pounds, off slightly from March, acording to a report issued yesterday by the Textile Organon, statistical bulletin of the Textile Economic Bureau, Inc.

On the heels of his projected reorganization of the Pentagon President Eisenhower has now chosen an entirely new high command for our armed forces and nominated a new supreme commander for the North Atlantic Alliance forces in Europe. The new men, who between them will bear primary military responsibility for the defense of the free world, will take command some months from now.

Lyn Austin and Thomas Noyes, who are undertaking no mean assignment next season in starting their producing careers with the presentation of two new plays by two new authors, are well advanced in their managerial scheme of things.

LONDON, May 13 -- protest was voiced in the House of Lords today against "slanderous statements" about British shipowners that were said to have been made in Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's Senate subcommittee in the United States.

Seven American civilians, captured in the Communist invasion of South Korea and interned nearly three years, came home yesterday. Joyously greeted by friends and relatives at Idlewild Airport, the four men and three women smiled happily and chatted gaily.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 13 -Gen. Sir Gerald Templer, High Commissioner of Malaya, said tonight that "communism had no chance of succeeding" on the southeastern Asia peninsula. It lies between Indonesia and the mainland of Asia, an area that last week Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said was of "grave concern'' to the United States.

State Housing Commissioner Herman Stichman blamed "inadequate and inefficient enforcement" of fire, health and building laws for the spreading of slums as he led municipal and religious leaders on a tour of dank, dark and rotting buildings in Brooklyn yesterday.

Secretary of the Treasury Humphrey promises that the Administration will be ready next week to lay before Congress its recommendations on tax proposals, along with detailed estimates for the prospect of balancing the budget.

A conditional agreement between the City of New York and the new Transit Authority may be attempted to meet the June 1 deadline fixed by law for the transfer of the city-owned transit lines from the Board of Transportation to the authority.

Letters and plays by the Irish poet-dramatist, W. B. Yeats, will be published June 1 by two concerns. McMullen Books will issue a hitherto unpublished and forgotten collection of Yeats' letters under the title "The Letters of W. B. Yeats to Katharine Tynan."

Record production of 1,002,000 tons of primary grades of paper in the three months ended on March 31 enabled the International Paper Company and subsidiaries to earn a net profit of $13,795,977 in the period, John H. Hinman, president, reported at the annual meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (UP) -A Texas grain company paid more than $150,000 to Houston and New Orleans port officials for help in exporting some 1,000,000 bushels of "unfit" wheat, Senators were told today.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Chester Bowles, former United States Ambassador to India, said today he thought this Government would "have to go along" with demands for Communist China's admission to the United Nations if such a move were made a condition of peace in Asia.

BERLIN, May 13 -- Symptomatic of West Germany's powerful economic resurgence on world markets is the announcement by Dr. Hermann von Siemens, chairman of the board of Siemens Halske, that his company and a Swiss associate have been awarded a contract by Venezuela to install a modern telephone system in Caracas and environs.
Hamilton Allen has been appointed director of manufacturing of Oneida, Ltd., manufacturer of silverware.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -The International Monetary Fund thinks foreign countries should let their citizens spend freely in the United States all the hard-to-get dollars they earn -- or none at all.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 13 -- Nine persons were arrested today during demonstrations protesting the death sentence imposed by a military court Monday on Maulana Abul Ala Maududi, chief of the Jamaat Islami and an alleged leader of the recent anti-Ahmadiya riots in Lahore.

Referring to your editorial of May 7 entitled "The Oil Given Away," Senators Hendrickson and Smith have been requested by the Economic and Planning Development Council of the State of New Jersey to vote for the so-called "tidelands bill." The council by law is charged with the preservation and development of our tidelands and coastal shoreline.

TOKYO, Thursday, May 14 -- The Communist High Command formally rejected today the new United Nations proposal to reach an armistice in the Korean war by permitting a neutral commission to settle the fate of 14,000 Chinese prisoners unwilling to return to their former allegiance after a cease-fire.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today set May 25 as the last date upon which interested persons may request a hearing on the common stock financing program of the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company of Detroit.

The General Public Utilities Corporation reported yesterday that net earnings of its domestic subsidiaries for the first three months of this year amounted to $4,568,543. This was equal to 54 cents a share on the common stock and compared with $4,144,440, or 52 cents a share, in the March quarter a year ago.

LONDON, May 13-- Beginning early next week the British, French and United States delegates to the Austrian treaty talks will hold a series of meetings in London to discuss and coordinate their tactics before sitting down May 27 with the Soviet representative.

" The Sea and the City," a special marine exhibition that continues the story that has been unfolding of New York's tercentenary, opened yesterday at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, in cooperation with the Marine Museum of New York.

CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- Reduced runs bolstered most livestock classes today. Hogs were steady to 25 cents higher. Cattle were steady to 50 cents up, except for bulls which were steady to 25 cents off. Sheep were steady. Department of Agriculture reports on the livestock market here today:

TRENTON, May 13 -- A proposal that the Democratic and Republican parties in New Jersey become joint sponsors of legislation permitting a bingo referendum this year was made today by Robert B. Meyner, Democratic nominee for Governor of the state.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, asked General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, today for all memoranda emanating from that organization in which any specific date for the end of the Korean war had been predicted.

Under some all-out, left-handed whipping by the distinguished Edward Arcaro, C. V. Whitney's Catspaw managed to run down Christopher T. Chenery's Permian in the final yards and win the seventy-seventh running of the Juvenile Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday.

The Irish Internationals and Liverpool of England's First Division, who open separate soccer tours of the United States and Canada by playing against each other at Ebbets Field tonight, were officially welcomed at City Hall yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 13 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold left yesterday for four or five weeks of touring European capitals, attending official United Nations conferences and talking with diplomats -- but no mountain climbing.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, May 13 (AP) -- Following is the text of a proposal submitted by the United Nations Command today for settling the Korean prisoner-of-war exchange issue:

The Sunray Oil Corporation disclosed yesterday that it was negotiating with a group of investment bankers for the underwriting of "several millions of dollars of capital" to finance two new manufacturing division projects. These are a 6,000-to-9,000-barrel-a-day coking unit to be built in connection with the company's catalytic cracking refinery at Duncan, Okla., and a pipeline from the Sunray refinery to a water transportation terminal on the Mississippi.
Television viewers can expect to see more college and professional football teams in action next fall than they did last season, according to separate announcements issued yesterday.

Historians are beginning to comprehend the importance of mass production through big business and big research, Dr. Allan Nevins, Professor of History at Columbia University, declared at a dinner of the American Petroleum Institute at the Commodore Hotel last night.

The management of Hearn's department stores in Manhattan and the Bronx discharged 800 employes yesterday, but rescinded the order a few hours later after Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer directed the workers "to perform their normal services in a peaceful manner."

BERLIN, May 13 -- Five former Soviet officers, who deserted the Soviet army, said yesterday the West should regard the Soviet army as a potential ally in the liberation of the Soviet Union from Bolshevik domination.

Stockholders of the Bachmann Uxbridge Worsted Corporation voted approval yesterday at the! annual meeting of an amendment to the by-laws changing the date of the meeting from the second Tuesday in May to the fourth Tuesday in April.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- President Eisenhower today nominated Leonard Page Moore, New York City lawyer, to be United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York. If confirmed by the Senate he would succeed Frank J. Parker, who resigned recently.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, announced today the national C. I. O. had approved a proposed merger of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, C. I. O., and the unaffiliated Distributive, Processing and Office Workers of America.

Announcement was made yesterday of the winner of the Tina Leser award in the fourth national Japanese fashion award contest. Miss Michiko Ronishi received the award for not one but two design. When the votes, cast by fashion writers, were counted at 42 East Fifty-seventh Street, it was discovered that the two entries tying for the award were by Miss Ronishi.

VIENNA, May 13 -- Czechoslovak heavy industry seems to be going from one emergency to another. The management and Communist party organization of the Klement Gottwald iron and steelworks in Vitkovice, which manufactures 80 per cent of the crude iron and 66 per cent of the steel produced in Czechoslovakia today appealed for more coal to keep its furnaces going.
SEIGNIORY CLUB, Que., May 13 (Canadian Press) -- An American authority on retailing said today that Canada was beginning a long period of prosperity, with its best business years still ahead.
An improved technique in the refinement of sulphur, cutting costs and eliminating a danger from blasting, was reported yesterday, following two years of testing.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Farm programs may require easing of anti-trust laws to permit farmers, processors and distributors to work together to hold farm prices stable in the opinion of John H. Davis, president of the Agriculture Department's $6,700,000,000 Commodity Credit Corporation.
DANBURY, May 13 -- Policemen and firemen had the upper hand here today in an argument over which of two city government boards should set their salary.

PARIS, May 13 -- At a somewhat indignant meeting today, the French Cabinet decided to instruct the French Ambassador in London to express to the British Government the irritation caused here by two aspects of the speech delivered to the House of Commons Monday by Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister.

BUENOS AIRES, May 13 -- The joint Congressional committee named to investigate the activities of three United States news agencies here, which have been charged with disseminating malicious stories about Argentina, chose Senator Carlos Juarez of Santiago del Estero as its chairman today. Dr. Oscar Albrieu, a Congressman from La Rioja, was named secretary.

Mayor Impellitteri will issue a proclamation today setting aside next week as Amateur Athletic Union Week, when the Metropolitan Association of the union will ask the people of New York to contribute funds for support of the A. A. U.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The Department of Defense announced today United States battle casualties in Korea had reached 134,958, an increase of 153 since last week. This was the smallest weekly increase Since last March 126, 1952, when a rise of 123 was announced.

Kansas City, Mo., received bids yesterday on $8,500,000 of water revenue bonds maturing from 1963 to 1978. The best bid, representing an interest cost of 2.7215 per cent, was submitted by a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Lehman Brothers.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- What is wrong with President Eisenhower's golf game?
LONDON, May 13 -- The deteriorating Anglo-Egyptian situation had the effect of further depressing the stock markets here today. Prices declined in nearly every section.
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I, May 13 -- The Women's Long Island Golf Association opened its season today at the Piping Rock Club and two of the top golfers in the district tied for low gross honors.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 13 -- J. Donald Kingsley, retiring head of the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency, warned today that unless the non-Communist countries helped support a capital investment program for Korea of at least $1,250,000,000, Korea would fall into the Red orbit or continue to be a dependency.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad emerged from bankruptcy reorganization more than five years ago but the Delaware and Hudson Company, as holder of 10,000 shares of a former New Haven subsidiary, announced yesterday that it had petitioned the Federal District Court at New Haven to reopen the New Haven reorganization proceedings.

CAIRO, May 13 -- The Egyptian Government charged tonight that British forces in the Suez Canal zone had killed eight Egyptians and wounded seventeen others in forty-three acts of aggression committed since April 3.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 -- An overhauling of the Interstate Commerce Commission in the interest of efficiency wah urged today by Anthony F. Arpaia, who is ending his tenth month as a Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- A parade of witnesses before the House of Representatives Ways and Means Committee argued today that a proposed curb on oil imports would lead to shortages and higher fuel costs for United States consumers.

Sales and net income of the United Aircraft Corporation and domestic subsidiaries for the first three months of 1953 were 40 per cent and 58 per cent above those of the three months ended on March 31, 1952, it was announced yesterday.

A superseding indictment was returned yesterday against Michael Clemente, asserted overlord of the East River docks, alleging he made false statements to the Bureau of Internal Revenue, it was announced by United States Attorny J. Edward Lumbard.

CLEVELAND, May 13 -- Construction of the Aluminum Company of America's $40,000,000 Government-owned press plant, which has been stymied for months by refusal of Cuyahoga Heights officials to issue a building permit, got the go-ahead signal tonight from Mayor William R. Gerdon of that suburb.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 13 -- The Soviet Union has been making substantial purchases at wool sales in Melbourne and Perth this week at prices indicating her buyers have ample financial resources. Wools being bought are among the best-quality merinos suitable to manufacture utility-type clothing and blankets, rather than first-class wearing apparel.

The City Planning Commission approved yesterday plans of Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. to lay out two new park areas in Greenwich Village. The Board of Estimate is scheduled to act on the plans today.

Judge Harold R. Medina said yesterday that the concept of "satisfactory banking relations" in the current investment banking anti-trust suit "is the craziest thing to hang a case on that I ever heard of."
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -President Eisenhower today nominated Leonard G. Hagner of Wilmington, Del., to be United States Attorney for the District of Delaware.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The House of Representatives gave final Congressional approval today to a bill that enables President Eisenhower to honor a campaign promise to give coastal states title to submerged lands under the marginal sea out to their historic boundaries.
Mary E. Hurlbutt, Professor of Social Work at the New York School of Social Work, will retire next month after twenty - three years on the faculty.

Les beignets souffles are what the French call a dessert that is the unusual daily specialty of a relatively new restaurant at 48 West Fifty-fifth Street, somewhat unfortunately called the French Shack.

Last night's program by the New York City Ballet at the City Center served to give the season's first presentations of Frederick Ashton's "Illuminations" and George Balanchine's "Metamorphoses," along with repetitions of Todd Bolender's "Mother Goose Suite" and Balanchine's "Four Temperaments."
MILWAUKEE, May 13 -- This baseball-happy metropolis was still in the grip of winter today and so were the Giants.

Young Women, including the Misses Jacqueline De Voe and[ Madelon De Voe, are aiding in theI plans for the Renaissance Enchant-I merit Ball to be held May-22 in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of Boys' Towns of Italy, Inc.
A small collection of child-size chairs, chests and desks -- the exact counterparts of large pieces -is available through decorators at the Bristol Antique Company, 319 East Sixty-second Street.

Bill Hanrahan, Fordham's undefeated sophomore right-hander, had little trouble posting his fourth victory as he baffled Columbia 9 -- 0, with four hits at Baker Field yesterday in the Lions' last home game of the season.

The St. Lawrence River power project and its even more important adjunct, the Seaway, moved close to fulfillment on Tuesday. The step then taken, belatedly, was a ruling by the presiding examiner of the Federal Power Commission recommending the issuance of a license to the New York State Power Authority to go ahead with the American share of the hydroelectric plan.

Many arguments have been advanced against admitting to the Union Hawaii and Alaska -- two territories that are entirely ready for statehood and fully deserve statehood. But all the arguments have been answered time and time again, and still the doors are closed to Hawaii and Alaska. Why?

HANOI, May 12 -- Small units of regular Vietminh troops were reported today to be infiltrating down from the Plaine des Jarres area toward the central Mekong valley as the French Union command continued to strengthen its defense positions at Vientiane, administrative capital of Laos, and the small town of Paksane on the Mekong River.

ALBANY, May 13 -- Most of the high schools principals in the state believe that low intelligence and falling behind in studies are the most important reasons for pupils' dropping out of high school before they have completed their course, a State Education Department survey showed today.

LONDON, Thursday, May 14 The Conservative party won a Parliamentary seat from Labor yesterday in a by-election at Sunderland South, an industrial constituency in northwest England. It was the first constituency to change representation in the seventeen by-elections that have taken place since the October, 1951, general election.

After looking at old newspapers through the medium of a projected microfilm image for any length of time, a fantastic aura begins to surround the viewer and his machine -- especially if the viewer is a newspaper man.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 13 -- Egypt's unyielding position on the Suez Canal issue and renewed evidence of Arab unwillingness to participate in a Middle East defense organization have greatly increased Turkey's importance to the West in this area of the world, in the opinion of highly qualified diplomatists here.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -A House of Representatives committee was told today that unless the Government helped American tramp ships meet foreign competition they soon might be driven from the seas.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 13 -Dr. Louis L. Madsen, ousted as president of Utah State Agricultural College by its board of trustees, was removed at the behest of Gov. J. Bracken Lee, an investigation committee was told today by State Representative S. J. Postma, an alumnus of the institution.

Richard H Balch, Democratic Sate Chairman, charged yesterday that the Republican State Power Authority intended to turn over to private public utility companies of the state the electric power to be produced by the projected development of the Niagara and St. Lawrence Rivers.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Subversive Activities Control Board heard oral arguments today on motions filed by three alleged Communist front organizations that seek to avoid registration with the Attorney General required of all Fascist, Communist and other subversive groups under the Internal Security Act.
TOKYO, Thursday, May 14 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,614, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M., Thursday, Korean time:

New issues of securities totaling more than $60,000,000 will be offered to investors today. Among the offerings are public utility mortgage bonds and preferred stock, new common stock of a natural gas company, debentures and convertible preferred stock of an oil enterprise, and equipment trust certificates of major railroads.
BOSTON, May 13 (AP) -- Right-handed veteran Mary Grissom avenged a loss to his former Chicago team-mates by limiting the White Sox to four hits today as he hurled the Red Sox to a 3-0 victory.
Legal penalties for reckless or careless pedestrians who are responsible for traffic accidents were urged yesterday by William Greene, director of the Connecticut Safety Commission.

FORT WORTH, May 13 (AP) -Willie Pep of Hartford, Conn., out-pointed young, tough and willing Jacky Blair of Dallas tonight in a nationally televised ten-round fight. Pep was too fast for the Dallas youngster, who found the former world featherweight champion an elusive target.

PARIS, May 13 -- The foreign ministers of the six nations in the European Coal and Steel Community decided at a meeting here today to study further the draft treaty for a political union before taking any action to carry it out.

The celebrated pioneer in modern architecture, Frank Lloyd Wright, has been selected by the National Institute of Arts and Letters as the recipient of one of two gold medals that the institute awards annually for achievement in the arts.

Commodity prices closed higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume continued light except in tin, which continued at the high levels started last week, and sugar, tin, coffee, zinc, wool, hides, rubber, lead and cocoa closed higher.

LONDON, May 13 -- The storm of controversy aroused here at the end of April by the offer from the United Nations command in Korea of $100,000 to the first enemy pilot to desert with a MIG jet fighter has continued hotly in the letter columns of the daily press.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- An extensive speaking program, including appearances by former Vice President Alben W. Barkley, six Senators and other party leaders, was announced today by the Democratic National Committee.

Two of the day's leading health questions -- the relation between tobacco and cancer of the lung and the role in cancer of exhaust fumes from gasoline, oil and coal engines -- are being investigated at the Institute of Industrial Medicine of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, it was reported yesterday.
BOSTON, May 13 (AP) -- Public control over development of atomic power was advocated today by the atomic power policy committee of the American Public Power Association.

National Luggage Week will begin Saturday and will be observed by retailers all over the country. It is sponsored by the Luggage and Leather Goods Manufacturers of America, Inc., and has been timed for the onset of what is predicted to be the greatest travel period in the history of the industry.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 13 -- Seventeen Mau Mau anti-white terrorists were sentenced to death today at Githunguri, formerly the headquarters of Jomo Kenyatta, who is said to have been the ideological father of the Mau Mau movement in the Kikuyu tribe.

Representatives of the United Jewish Appeal and of the city took part in a ceremony temporarily renaming Times Square "U. J. A. Square" yesterday morning. The organization, having designated May as U. J. A. Month in the city, seeks $10,500,000 to help meet emergency needs caused by anti-Semitic measures in Soviet-dominated eastern Europe and by a crop failure in Israel.

LOS ANGELES, May 13 -- More modern viewpoints and greatly expanded research in the field of mental deficiency, which occurs in one out of every 100 children, were urged today as the Association of Mental Deficiency opened its seventy-seventh annual meeting here.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Eisenhower Administration, after nearly four months in office, is still unable to make a workable adjustment in the labor field.

That the Police Department will crack down on members with Communist ties was strongly indicated yesterday after Commissioner George P. Monaghan announced that "two or three members of the department" were being investigated.
A three-story dwelling at 58 Fort Greene Place, in Brooklyn has been sold by the estate of Charles Reynels to Charles A. Kolligian in a deal negotiated by Paul A. Bogossian Son, brokers.
CHICAGO, May 13 -- To conform to the player-limit restrictions, which become effective at midnight tonight, the Dodgers today dropped two players and restored another to active service.

Capt. Vincent H. McGovern, Air Force pilot who took part in the first trans-Atlantic helicopter flight last July, received the Aviators' Valor Medal from Aviators Post 743 of the American Legion last night.

MOSCOW, May 12 -- The Tiflis newspaper Zarya Vostoka has linked former Deputy Minister of State Security Ryumin with a case that Gen. N. Rukhadze, Georgian State Security Minister, has been accused of having fabricated against a group of leading Georgian Communist party and Government leaders.

NEW DELHI, India, May 13 -Adlai E. Stevenson summed up India's foreign policy today as "not so much neutral" as one of "Noninvolvement -- an anxiety to keep the free from any conflict that affects the world, hot or cold."

The American Museum of Natural History has put its resources at the disposal of television in an hour-long program series called "Adventure" at 5 P. M. Sundays over C. B. S. network. It is a move that thoughtful viewers will welcome heartily because both the country's museums and TV can benefit enormously from a close working liaison.

LONDON, May 14 -- British spokesmen, it seemed to observers today, are trying to keep down the temperature of the quarrel between Britain and Egypt in the hope of avoiding a renewal of fighting in the Suez Canal Zone.

JERUSALEM, May 14 -- Israeli officials asked Harold E. Stassen, Mutual Security Administrator, today to help them raise a $75,000,000 long term loan in the United States to convert Israel's short-term debts into long-term obligations.

BOSTON, May 14 -- George M. Moore, newly appointed Republican member of the Civil Service Commission, estimated today that about 12,500 Federal jobs would be classified as policy-making or confidential and be removed from the merit system regulations.

LONDON, May 14 -- President Eisenhower's failure to respond with the same enthusiasm as manifested here to the proposal of Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister, for early big power talks on the highest level has aroused disappointment in London.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- Shirley Temple, the former screen actress, and her daughter, Linda Susan, 5 years old, visited President Eisenhower at the White House today and found it all "very thrilling."

A varied collection of summer fashions was presented yesterday by John Wanamaker's on the third floor of the store. Clothes for every hour of the day were shown in sizes that ranged from junior and misses to proportioned groups.

LONDON, May 14 -- The market for British Government securities was again the only really firm section on the stock markets today. A cut in interest rates for industrial and agricultural loans stimulated buying of gilt-edge issues, which rose nearly one-half per cent and closed at the top.
PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (UP) -Harry Byrd, righting himself after three successive losses, pitched the Athletics to a 5-3 victory over the Tigers tonight for his second complete game of the year.
Early action by Congress to repeal the "Buy American" Act, which severely limits Government buying from foreign sources, was urged yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.
A cool atmosphere pervades a new model home, decorated by John Abbate, which will open on Sunday in the Sherwood Gardens development of houses in Westbury, L. I.

The waning of the metropolitan art season is customarily heralded by a flurry of group shows that feature highlights from winter exhibitions of paintings and sculpture. Two of these shows now are being held. That at the ACA Gallery is entitled "Artist's Favorites," which means that each artist has sent to this group a canvas of his choice.

LOS ANGELES, May 14 -- A representative of the Mexican Government has lodged a formal protest with Gov. Earl Warren against a charge by a State Crime Commission that Mexico was tacitly encouraging the illicit international traffic in heroin, an opium derivative.

United States Attorney J. Edward Lumbard, summing up yesterday to a Federal Court jury, urged that they find Gerhard Puff, 38-year-old bank robber, guilty of first-degree murder without a recommendation for mercy for shooting to death a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent. The death sentence is mandatory after such a verdict.

Now that the bill giving to the states all the offshore oil out to their so-called historic boundaries has passed Congress and is awaiting the President's signature, it is more necessary than ever that the Federal Government be granted specific power to develop the vast undersea mineral resources still left in its control.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Arguments were concluded before the Subversive Activities Control Board today on requests by five alleged Communist-front organizations for more time to answer the petitions of the Department of Justice that they be ordered to register with the Attorney General under the Internal Security Act.

A consolidated net income of $1,801,175, equal to 13 cents a common share, was reported yesterday by the Greyhound Corporation for the three months ended on March 31. This compares with $1,361,788 or 10 cents a share in the corresponding three months of 1952.

Only seven speakers appeared yesterday at a hearing before the City Council Finance Committee on the record 1953-54 expense budget of $1,528,814,950, and most of them seemed to entertain little hope that their pleas for cuts would be effective.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with his remarks in indirect discourse, as required by White House rules:

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Edwin Witte, Economics Professor at the University of Wisconsin, who helped draft the Social Security Act, asserted today that the "universal-coverage. Social Security plan proposed by the United States Chamber of Commerce would scuttle old age and survivors insurance.
PITTSBURGH, May 14 -- The most crucial labor-management negotiations since the Eisenhower Administration came to power began in this steel capital today.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 14 -- In a statement to his own Nationalist party press today Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan said that in the national elections the people had empowered him to "place the sovereignty of Parliament beyond all doubt" and that this would be done.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 14 -- The New Jersey State Federation of Women's Club urged today that the Legislature enact laws to control the sale in the state of "filthy literature," which, it said, was flooding the nation's newsstands.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Eisenhower said today that he had completely turned over the membership of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the nation's highest military planning body, as proof of his Administration's new approach to problems and its riddance of links with the past.

The French, we hear, were so busy yesterday resenting the references to France in Prime Minister Churchill's speech that they failed to take a stand on the big question he raised. Not only did he offend Gallic sensibilities by suggesting that France raise the period of compulsory military service from eighteen months to two years and send conscripts to Indo-China.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 14 -- Rumania and Yugoslavia have reached an agreement on rules for the administration of the Iron Gate sector of the Danube River where the boundaries of the two nations meet.

ALBANY, May 14 -- The State Education Department announced today the names of 1,654 high school students who had won state scholarships that entitle each to $1,400 for four years at any college in the state approved by the Board of Regents.

Rosano Sons are opening their Coronet Homes colony tomorrow on Bellmore Avenue, north of Southern State Parkway Exit 25, in East Meadow, L. I., where they plan to construct sixty dwellings in ranch and split-level design. Each model has three bedrooms, two baths and basements.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (UP) -- The Defense Department said today it intended to order $1,500,000,000 worth of arms from overseas factories for United States allies in the 1954 fiscal year starting July 1.

A dispute involving the introduction of the self-service system, with consequent reduction of staff, into the two Hearn department stores at Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth Street, Manhattan, and 149th Street and Third Avenue, the Bronx, flared into a strike at noon yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Eisenhower said today that individual states have no special claims to submerged lands in the Continental Shelf area seaward of their historic boundaries.

SAN-FRANCISCO, May 15 -- The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, unaffiliated, began negotiations with the Pacific Maritime Association today on wages and hours as the three-year coastwise contract expiring June 15, 1954, was opened.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (UP) -The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that a Swiss concern has won a $3,553,700 contract for heavy duty electrical equipment at the $1,200,000,000 atomic explosives plant being built in Pike County, Ohio.

An additional supply of A-positive blood is needed to assure the recovery of Joseph Crespo, 30-year-old accountant, who was operated on for a liver ailment last month in St. Vincent's Hospital, the American Red Cross announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Eisenhower expressed his willingness today to sit down with Sir Winston Churchill, British Prime Minister, Georgi M. Malenkov, Soviet Premier, and other world leaders to explore the possibilities of peace, but said first he wanted some concrete evidence of good faith from Moscow.

A man accused of having gone berserk in a Lenox Avenue subway train of the I. R. T. division early today was shot and wounded fatally on the platform of the 135th Street station by an off-duty patrolman who had sought to quiet him.
State Housing Commissioner Herman Stichman's inspection tour of substandard housing in Brooklyn resulted yesterday in some action by State Rent Administrator Joseph D. McGoldrick.

Two prospective candidates for the Democratic Mayoralty nomination, Mayor Impellitteri and Controller Lazarus Joseph, were speakers last night at the thirty-ninth annual dinner of the Bronx County Democratic Committee.

Assistant Corporation Council Victor J. Herwitz filed a motion in Supreme Court yesterday to reopen the case of John P. Crane, former president of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, who was dismissed from the Fire Department by former Fire Commissioner George P. Monaghan on Jan. 29, 1951. The motion is returnable next Monday.
The Cantata Singers, under the direction of Arthur Mendel, presented an uncut performance of Bach's B Minor Mass last evening at St. Michael's Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-ninth Street.

CAIRO, May 14 -- Egypt tightened the economic screws today on the British forces she wants to drive out of the Suez Canal zone as new bitterness boiled up in the old dispute over control of the strategic East-West waterway.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 14 -- A rare sixty-five-acre remnant of the vast forests that once covered most of the Eastern Seaboard has just become the subject of an ardent rescue effort by a group of scientists of Rutgers University and other institutions.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 14 -- The people of this Lehigh Valley steel town seldom refer to the annual festival of the Bach Choir of Bethlehem by its full name. To them it's simply "Bach," and tonight Bach came to Bethlehem for the forty-sixth time.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday the nomination of five principals as assistant superintendents. They were selected from among thirty candidates on the basis of a new program -- designed to obtain the highest order of administrative talent.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -The Department of Commerce said today that publicly reported cash dividend payments by corporations in the first four months of the year amounted to $2,542,000,000. This was 4.5 per cent more than such payments in the first four months of 1952.
May I heartily congratulate you for your editorial of May 8 "Hope for Housing." At best, our housing program for a nation like ours has always been a modest one.
TOKYO, Friday, May 15 -- Allied and Communist delegates argued their way through another session at Panmunjom today with no indication of a closer approach to an armistice in the Korean war.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Eisenhower declined today to be drawn into a controversy over the guaranteed annual wage, a union demand that might figure in current steel wage negotiations.

CHESTER, Conn., May 14 -- The sleepy country calm of the railroad siding here, which has not seen a scheduled passenger train go through in twenty-five years, was disturbed for an hour late this afternoon on the arrival of a politicians' junket from Hartford.

A nation-wide emergency plan for unifying the broadcasts of all standard radio stations in case of an air alert will go into effect today. It was set up through the joint efforts of the Federal Communications Commission, civil defense authorities and broadcasters.

The fifty-six "housekeeping" employes of the Metropolitan Club were on an appropriately discreet and decorous sit-down strike yesterday, seriously curtailing operations of the large clubhouse at Fifth Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

A settlement with respect to the first mortgage 4 per cent thirty-year sinking fund gold bonds of the Philippine Railway Company was reached yesterday by the Philippine Bondholders' Committee, the Philippine government and the Rehabilitation Finance Corporation, a Philippine government agency, as well as the receiver for the properties.
Many and devious are the ways that children learn, workers for the Music Research Foundation have discovered in eight months of special work with third-graders in two Bronx public schools.
Four new films open today in first-run theatres. At the Rialto is "Four Sided Triangle," a British-made melodrama starring Bar

Casey Stengel's revised opinion that the White Sox, rather than the Indians, are the team his Yankees will have to beat to win their fifth straight American League pennant took on an authoritative ring in the light of yesterday's developments at the Stadium, where the Chicagoans defeated the New Yorkers, 7 -- 5.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 14 -The deadlock in the Panmunjom negotiations has depressed United Nations delegates, who recessed the General Assembly only three weeks ago in the confident expectation that there would be an armistice, and that the Assembly would reconvene early in the summer to make arrangements for the political conference to be held after an armistice.

At the closing session of the refining division of the American Petroleum Institute at the Commodore Hotel yesterday reports were made on the superior economy of the Diesel engine in buses over those driven by gasoline or liquid petroleum gas, as shown in a two-year test at Harrisburg, Pa.
A 13-year-old girl plunged into the Harlem River yesterday to rescue her 9-year-old brother, who had been swept past his depth, but the sister and brother both drowned in the swift current.

PARIS, May 14 -- The Government warned French shipowners and striking officers and seamen today that if they did not reach an agreement on the issue of vacation time among themselves it would settle the issue by decree.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- William H. Vander Poel, a wealthy Long Islander, testified today he had paid $50,000 or $60,000 in cash to Henry W. (The Dutchman) Grunewald for help in obtain ing a very favorable settlement of a big tax case.
MILWAUKEE, May 14 (AP) -- Pickets marched in front of all six Milwaukee's famed breweries -- Schlitz, Pabst, Blatz, Miller, Gettelman and Independent. They represented 7,500 production workers.
LONDON, May 14 (AP) -- A British flight expert said today that flights of jet planes of the near future would cave in windows, unroof houses and shatter the eardrums.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -The House today approved a bill authorizing the Federal Reserve System to spend $20,000,000 on six new buildings and ten additions.

The demand for Bibles is now the greatest in the history of Christendom, it was reported yesterday at the 137th annual meeting of the American Bible Society. At the same time, it was noted that the Scriptures had been translated into languages that 90 per cent of the world's population could understand.
