BALTIMORE, May 14 (AP) -Eddie Arcaro, the master jockey, today was in the unusual spot, for him, of being forced to switch horses for the Preakness on May 23.

Nylon carpeting now available at Altman's may be ordered hand-carved with designs that look somewhat like sculptured stone. Woven of du Pont nylon by the Nye-Wait Company, this carpeting has a velvet appearance and is called Corique.

Judge Harold R. Medina, who is trying the Government's investment banking suit in Federal Court here, turned his attention yesterday to arguments put forward by defense counsel in support of a motion to dismiss charges against Eastman, Dillon Co., one of the seventeen defendants.
The weather was warm here yesterday, but to an enthusiastic group of men and women from every part of this country's snow-belt and from Canada there was skiing in the air.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., May 14 -The Race Point fishing season was officially but accidentally opened last night. The first striped bass of the season was taken by a local angler while fishing for pollock at one of the two "rips" near the lighthouse at the tip of Cape Cod.

Although fire losses in the United States for the second year reached a new high in 1952 of $815,134,000, up 11.6 per cent over 1951, the National Board of Fire Underwriters was assured yesterday that the outlook was not as "somber as the stark figures indicate."

Rhubarb, the vegetable valued as the first "fruit" of spring since early Colonial days, is in abundant supply from near-by areas. Because of its high quality and reasonable price -- less than 2 cents a serving -- now is the time to take advantage of its tart fresh flavor to perk up tired menus.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- When it appeared the other day that the Secretary of the Treasury, George M. Humphrey, had abandoned any effort to balance the federal budget before, at the earliest, the span of the fiscal year 1954-55 (all fiscal years begin on July 1) a great many people were shocked and disappointed, and among them were prominent Republicans in Congress.

SECAUCUS, N. J., May 15 -- Not a single vote affecting the slim margin by which Mayor John V. Kenny retained control of the Jersey City Commission in Tuesday's municipal election was changed by a recount today.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Department store sales in the week ended May 9 were 9 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

After waiting since 1948 to get "Howe Hummel" on the boards, Howard Teichmann, a patient author, may experience a windfall. Instead of being concerned with only one production of his adaptation next season, Mr. Teichmann is apt to have two running simultaneously -- one in London and the other on Broadway.

UNITED NATIONS. N. Y., May 14 -- Former President Herbert Hoover has urged the United States Government to give its "morale and material support" to the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.
Jerome Robbins' version of the "Afternoon of a Faun" had its premiere by the New York City Ballet last night at the City Center.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -The National Production Authority ordered the steel industry today to set aside for military and atomic orders, after July 1, iron and steel products in quantities which will be fixed from month to month.
The cotton futures market was quiet but steady yesterday and closing prices were 11 to 17 points higher on active months than on Wednesday.
Baltimore County, Md., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on May 27 on $23,000,000 of bond issues. Dated June 1, the bonds will come due June 1, 1956 to 1993.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -Frederick M. Alger Jr. of Grosse Point, Mich., was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be Ambassador to Belgium. He would succeed Myron Cowan, whose resignation is being accepted.

A request by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley for $723,000 to purchase 15,000 new parking meters was sent by the Board of Estimate yesterday to Budget Director Abraham D. Beame for a report. The step was taken after Jack Pearlman, sitting for Council President Rudolph Halley, asked why a generally similar request by Mr. Halley last January never had been honored.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 14 -- Gen. Raoul Salan, the outgoing French Commander in Chief in Indo-China, explained his conduct of the Laos campaign today in the face of criticism abroad that the French command had not shown sufficient aggressiveness in hitting the Communist-led Vietminh insurgents when they invaded that state last month.

CHICAGO, May 14 -- The first sensatory perception to impress a deplaning passenger at the Chicago Airport today was olfactory. A cold and angry wind wafted an ungentle fragrance from the stockyards. However, this was not accepted as a rap at the Marciano-Walcott fight. This city just isn't that interested in it to express such emphatic disapproval. It's a much more attractive affair than that anyway.

Shipments of copper to domestic consumers increased last month to the best level so far this year, and producers' stocks of refined metal dwindled to the lowest point since July, 1950, the Copper Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Department of Justice took to the United States Court of Appeals today the ruling of Federal Judge Luther W. Youngdahl that four of the seven counts on which Owen Lattimore of Johns Hopkins University had been indicted for perjury were invalid.
TOKYO, Friday, May 15 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,615, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:
WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 14 -The Women's New Jersey Golf Association opened its 1953 season with a record of ninety-one contestants at the Essex County Country Club today.

The Turner Construction Company has been awarded the contract for a new home office building planned by the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company on a tract of 268 acres in Bloomfield, Conn., about five miles from the company's present headquarters in Hartford.
WACO, Tex., May 14 (AP) -- Toiling men late today dragged rubble off the 112th person crushed to death in Waco's explosive tornado and searching was ordered halted at nightfall.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 11--The struggle for control of Colombia's ruling Conservative party, and the governmental power that goes with it, will probably be decided by the Army. And the chances are that the Army will stick to its cherished tradition of remaining aloof from politics.

This has been a bad season for manuscripts. At least two writers in New York have discovered recently that there is something worse than seeing a manuscript returned accompanied by a rejection slip; it is much worse to lose a manuscript altogether.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 14 -- Fred Lazard of the Cherry Valley Club won the medal in the annual Walter J. Travis Memorial invitation golf tournament today after a draw with John J. Humm of Rockville and A. F. Kroeger of the home club.

Rejecting New York City's request for a special session of the Legislature to reconsider the fiscal program imposed on the city, the Dewey administration has in effect told officials here to quit finding reasons why the program won't work and start finding ways to make it work.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- A spokesman for Eastern oil and gas distributors warned today that a proposed curb on oil imports probably would lead to Government rationing. Harry B. Hilts, secretary of the Atlantic coast oil conference of New York City, testified before the House Ways and Means Committee the import curb also would bring higher prices on a wide variety of fuels.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, said today he intended to refer to the Federal Attorney allegedly conflicting testimony given under oath by Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and Frank Kenney, an "insurgent" longshoreman.

Brig. Gen. Carlos Romulo has made countless friends among Americans here and in the Philippines by his career as a courageous journalist, by the brave part he played during the Second World War, by his excellent work here as Ambassador and U. N. representative for his country, and by his singularly prepossessing personality.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- During the week ended May 13, member bank reserves increased $101,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Oedipus, Mrs. Ogden Phipps' champion steeplechaser of 1952, withstood a strong challenge by the Brookmeade Stable's His Boots and captured the Charles L. Appleton Memorial Stake at Belmont Park yesterday. The $7,500 added thirty-second running of the chase was worth $6,200 to the winning owner. Oedipus, the second choice, returned $5.80 for $2.

Advisers to Governor Dewey rejected yesterday the demand by Mayor Impellitteri and Controller Lazarus Joseph for modification of the powers and functions of the New York City Transit Authority at a special session of the Legislature.

AMMAN. Jordan, May 14 (AP) -Secretary of State John Foster Dulles refused to associate himself today with Arab criticism of the Truman Administration's aid to Israel. He arrived here after a twenty-four-hour visit to Israel and paid a courtesy call on Jordan's young King Hussein I.
Richard H. Kirete, president of TACA International Airways, has been elected chairman of the Security Banknote Company. He succeeds Shepard H. Spies, who was temporary chairman.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, introduced an amendment to the Taft-Hartley Act today that would make it an unfair labor practice for employers and for labor unions to discriminate on the basis of race, creed or national origin.

A display of student work completed during the school year at the Parsons School of Design, 136 East Fifty-seventh Street, will be open to the public today and tomorrow, from 10 A. M. to 5:30 P. M., on Sunday from 1 to 6 P. M. and on Monday from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M.

Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, was elected chairman of the board of trustees of the American Heritage Foundation yesterday and announced that it would take over this year's program of the Crusade for Freedom.

The Treasury's new 3 1/4 per cent bond was quoted at par at the close yesterday following a third successive day of firmness for the Government's long-term bond issues. The closing bid was 99 29/32, with 100 1/32 designated on the offering side. Gains of 1/16 of a point were registered for all other issues maturing in 1962 and later.

Although confined to a wheel chair because of arthritis, Jack Fleischer has been working as a volunteer at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx for ten years. Yesterday he received a citation from the United Hospital Fund at its thirteenth annual awards meeting in the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court asserted in an address tonight that it was imperative the West reach an understanding with Asia. A "manifest destiny," he said, was pulling the world closer together and demanding a "real world community."

Cannonball Billy Liddell led Liverpool's soccer team to a 4-0 victory over the Irish International eleven before 10,072 spectators at Ebbets Field last night. It was the opening game of separate North American tours for both clubs.

ALBANY, May 14 -- The following statement on the memoranda submitted recently by the Mayor and Controller of the City of New York asking for a special session of the Legislature was released today by Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore, State Controller J. Raymond McGovern, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

A syndicate headed by Henry Goelet, realty investor and builder, has purchased the two eleven-story buildings called the "Rockefeller Apartments" at 17 to 23 West Fifty-fourth Street and 24 to 36 West Fifty-fifth Street. The property runs through the block between Fifth and Sixth Avenues and was sold by the Waldorf Astor Estate, represented by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, trustee.
On May 7 you published a letter from G. F. Shaughnessy opposing the lead-zinc section of the Simpson bill.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Two editors of the weekly news magazine, The National Guardian, refused under Constitutional protection against self-incrimination today to tell the Senate Investigations subcommittee whether they were now Communists or had been when they helped license United States-financed newspapers in Germany early in the post-war period.

TRENTON, N. J., May 14 (AP) -New Jersey Chief Justice Arthur T. Vanderbilt today appointed six public members to the board of directors of the Prudential Life Insurance Company in line with a new state law.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 14 -- The Screen Directors Guild of American called today on Secretary of State John Foster Dulles for "immediate clarification" of the State Department's "inexplicable repudiation" yesterday of a request to the guild for the services of Hollywood directors in the making of a series of movies for the International Information Administration.

LONDON, May 14 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of West Germany, here as a guest of the British Government, told the International Press Institute today that he hoped the day was not far off when the Soviet Union would realize that its policy "had brought no advantage to Russia" and that her prosperity and security could better be attained "by an honest policy of adjustment."

SEOUL, Korea, May 14 -- In the strongest statement relative to the armistice talks issued so far by a South Korean Government official, Foreign Minister Pyun Yun Tai said tonight that his nation's armed forces would continue to fight if a truce agreement were signed by the United Nations at Panmunjom.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The United States imported $67,340,000 worth of goods from the Communist world in 1952, according to the Department of Commerce. That was about seven of one-thousandths of the nation's eleven-billion-dollar total imports in 1952.

John E. Gleason Jr., former general inspector in the Department of Sanitation, was sentenced yesterday to three and one-half to seven years in state prison for perjuring himself before a grand jury investigating a fuel oil extortion racket in the Fire Department.

One of the leading old Bolsheviks purged in the era of the great purges of the nineteen thirties has been rehabilitated and awarded a government decoration. The move is interpreted by diplomatic observers as another important step in the new Soviet regime's efforts to conciliate the people and gain backing for its rule.

ROBERT W. DOWLING, president of City Investing Company, ran into austerity headwinds at Heathrow Airport near London last week when he landed, after a quick flight from New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, with a 160-pound gift cake for Sir Alexander Korda.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -The Office of Defense Mobilization (O. D. M.) has agreed to grant extra liberal Federal tax benefits to companies which build new defense plants in cities beset by chronic unemployment, it was learned today.

A funeral service for Louis (Wireless Louie) Zeltner, a former Alderman and founder of the New York League of Locality Mayors, was held yesterday in Riverside Chapel, 1 Ocean Parkway at Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn. Rabbi Samuel Soskin of Temple Beth, Emeth officiated.

MILWAUKEE, May 14 (UP) -Jack Dittmer lined a sharp single with the bases filled in the ninth inning to give the Braves a 3-to-2 victory over the Pirates tonight before a chilled crowd of 15,438 and move Milwaukee into a first-place tie with Philadelphia.

SINGAPORE, May 14 -- The Finnish tanker Wiima left Malayan waters today bound for Constanta, the Rumanian port where early this year she picked up 10,000 tons of jet fuel that made her a center of international controversy.
CINCINNATI, May 14 -- Foul weather was still camping on the trail of the Giants today as rain washed out tonight's encounter with the Redlegs.

BOSTON, May 14 (UP) -- Jim Piersall slashed a sharp single to left today to drive home the winning run as the Red Sox defeated the Indians by 5-4 in an eleven-inning game before 4,428 fans at Fenway Park.

ST. LOUIS, May 14 -- Carl Erskine's three-year mastery of the Cardinals was shattered in the first inning tonight when he got nobody out as the Red Birds scored four times and went on to an 8-3 victory over the Dodgers at Busch Stadium.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -Amos Heacock of Seattle, Wash., former head of an association of non-scheduled airlines, today swore that he had never been a member of the Communist party.

Herman A. Acker of New York has been appointed by the National Association of Real Estate Boards official delegate to the International Conference of Real Estate Counsellors to be held in Amsterdam, Holland, on May 26 to 31. Representatives of real estate interests in thirteen countries will attend the meeting.

TROY, N. Y., May 14 -- The impact of modern chemistry on this nation and the world at large will be discussed tomorrow and Saturday during a two-day convocation of teachers, authors, publishers and business representatives at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.

Trading continued light on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday with only potatoes, coffee and cocoa showing gains over the volume of the previous day. Even on these items action was light. Prices closed higher for cocoa, coffee, sugar, cottonseed oil, lead, wool and tin.

ON THE KOREAN FRONT, May 14 -- As the armistice talks at Panmunjom go on, so does the Korean war. A soldier here still sits and sleeps in a cramped, low-ceilinged bunker. He looks out at a stone-littered stretch of lowland tangled with barbed wire in front of the first enemy outposts.

CHICAGO, May 14 -- International Harvester Company stockholders were told at the annual meeting today that estimated sales of $674,700,000 in the six months ended on April 30 were the highest in company history for a six-month period.

AFTER a spring vacation spent motoring nearly 4,000 miles from Fairfield County to New Orleans and back I find the shock of resuming a working schedule somewhat softened by the view outside my study window, a Connecticut hillside foaming with dogwood blossoms. Although the rites of spring were being celebrated everywhere we went, nothing we saw

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Mid-western Senate Republicans, led by Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin, attacked Britain today with threats of economic reprisals, but an answering Republican voice declared that it was time for some Senatorial self-criticism as well.

The time has come when the city "should stop building subway cars like battleships" that can run "practically forever" and should substitute up-to-date twenty-year-life models, in the opinion of Sidney H. Bingham, chairman of the Board of Transportation.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 14 (UP) -- The Illinois Parole Board today refused to free Nathan Leopold, millionaire's son who killed 14-year-old Bobby Franks in a 1924 "thrill slaying."

CLEVELAND, May 14 -- Continuous mining machines are the answer to soaring coal prices, Harold B. Wickey, vice president of the Pennsylvania Coal and Coke Corporation, Cresson, Pa., told delegates to the 1953 coal show of the American Mining Congress today.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -Spec Shea survived a ninth-inning threat to post his second victory without defeat at the expense of the Browns, 2 -- 1, tonight as the Senators gained their sixth straight victory.

Both President Eisenhower and the State Department, speaking with his specific approval, have issued statements deprecating the idea that there are any great differences between the Western nations and seeking to restore the essential Western unity on which Western strength depends.

LONDON, May 14 (AP) -- The head of Britain's Trades Union Congress declared today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was "a greater gift to communism than Judas Iscariot was to the high priests and Pharisees."

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The appointment of Prof. Robert R. Bowie, of the Harvard Law School, to succeed Paul H. Nitze as director of the State Department's policy planning staff was expected in the near future, aides of the Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles, said today.

The Board of Estimate, in a wrangle yesterday after weeks of indecision, finally approved, by ten votes to six, the originally mapped but controversial section of the $86,000,000 Cross Bronx Expressway between Longfellow and Anthony Avenues.

BUFFALO, N. Y., May 14 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, retired, declared tonight that college presidents should discharge any faculty member who refused to answer questions on his loyalty posed by official investigating committees.

MANILA, May 14 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo resigned tonight as Philippine Ambassador to the United States and as permanent delegate to the United Nations. President Elpidio Quirino immediately accepted his resignations.
A Brooklyn delegation with the blessing of shipping men here will go to Washington today to try to talk Congress into deepening the borough's major inland waterway, the Gowanus Creek Channel.

Sales of diamonds at retail will increase about 10 per cent this fall over the 1952 period, Alexander E. Arnstein, senior partner of Arnstein Brothers Co., diamond importer, said yesterday. Spring sales lagged about 5 per cent behind last year's but the fall increase will return 1953 slightly better than a "normal" year, he said.

There are few more disheartening developments on the international scene than the breakdown of the Suez Canal negotiations and the frightening preparations for what Premier Naguib has imprudently called "a big battle. It was revealed on Wednesday that there were a number of incidents, with deaths on both sides, in the last six weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Eisenhower announced today that he would address the nation by radio next Tuesday night to explain in precise terms the Administration's budget and tax policies, with special emphasis on their relationship to national security.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 14 -- Jack Lemmon, who appeared in the recent stage revival of the comedy "Room Service" in New York, has been placed under contract by Columbia and will be introduced as Judy Holliday's leading man in "A Name for Herself."
Sales finance company refinancing through security issues was a major influence in the reduction of business loans from New York banks last week.

FRANKFURT, Germany, May 14 (AP) -- A former United States soldier who tried to settle "an affair of love and honor" by the ancient rules of chivalry was fined $500 today for having challenged his rival to a duel with .38-caliber pistols.

YONKERS, May 14 (AP) -- Nancy Song, winner of seventeen in a row last year, and Royal Pastime, the odds-on choice, won the two divisions of the Rye Trot tonight before 20,666 Grand Circuit fans at Yonkers Raceway.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (UP) -The Air Force disclosed today that planned construction work at fourteen air bases had been canceled because of budget and manpower cutbacks.

A 10 per cent reduction in taxes would more than counteract the effect of any proposed reduction in defense expenditures, according to Henry H. Heimann, executive vice president of the National Association of Credit Men. A tax reduction, he said yesterday in the association's monthly review, would add to purchasing power, reduce the cost of civilian goods, encourage thrift, stimulate production and investment.

LONDON, May 14 -- The two largest ships to be built this year in British shipyards, the Orient liner Orsova and the Peninsular and Oriental liner Arcadia, both of 28,000 tons, were launched at Barrow-in-Furness and at Clydebank, respectively, today.

All 280 Ford dealers in New England have banded for a promotion program designed to encourage tourist and vacation travel in those six states. Within the next six months the dealers will spend more than $250,000 on the campaign, with measurable costs covering national and local advertising, literature and sales promotion.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 14 -- A newcomer to the event, 35-year-old Dave Douglas of Wilmington, Del., assumed a substantial lead in the opening of the Palm Beach round-robin tourney at the Meadow Brook Club today with a record-equaling score of 66.

SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, May 13 -- Through heavy outlays of money and special political considerations, Yugoslavia's Communist regime appears to be defeating efforts of the Cominform to weaken Yugoslavia's hold on the allegiance of 1,300,000 Macedonians whose capital is this ancient Turko-Slav city.

The wonder sparrow, Perriette has rounded out an even decade of occupancy of a flower pot on the fire escape of a Bronx apartment house. Despite her advanced years and air of perpetual fatigue, she has even succeeded in producing another brood of nestlings.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Eisenhower expressed the view today that a bill to grant statehood to Hawaii should be handled alone and on its merits and not attached to the issue of statehood for Alaska.

CHICAGO, May 14 -- Grain futures showed a steadier tone today, but it was still evident that the broader buying was more to cover short lines than indicative of any great increase in the outside investment demand.

The eleventh session of the Berkshire Music Center will open at Tanglewood, Mass., on July 5. Charles Munch, musical director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, is director of the school, Aaron Copland is assistant director and Ralph Berkowitz is dean.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, May 15 (AP) -Two thousand Chinese Reds slammed at key Allied western front outposts today in their biggest attack since the Korean armistice talks were resumed nearly three weeks ago -- and were hurled back by Turkish troops in short, furious fights.

ABOARD PRESS YACHT TARA II, Accompanying President Eisenhower, May 14 -- President Eisenhower relaxed aboard the Presidential yacht Williamsburg tonight en route to Williamsburg, Va., for a speech at William and Mary College tomorrow.
ATLANTA, May 14 -- For the first time since Reconstruction days a Negro won nomination to Atlanta's Board of Education in yesterday's city-wide primary.

BALTIMORE, May 14 -- The executive council of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., repudiated its New York membership today and ordered locals in the Port of New York to abolish the shape-up system of dock hiring in their next contract "on pain of drastic discipline."

Fifty-two persons in twenty states and six United States territories will receive opportunity fellowships of the John Hay Whitney Foundation. The awards, which total $100,000, are designed to furnish opportunity to Americans to advance their education and to develop their special talents in order that they can make their maximum contribution to society.

PARIS, May 14 -- No decision on the ultimate status of the territory of the Saar was reached here during the talks just held between Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and French Premier Rene Mayer and Foreign Minister Georges Bidault.

CHICAGO, May 14 -- Jersey Joe Valcott will make another attempt in the heavyweight championship of the world tomorrow night. The ancient warrior from Camden, N. J., will seek to lift the most valuable individual title in the realm of sports from Rocky Mariano in a bout scheduled for fifteen rounds at the Chicago Stadium.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Military affairs members of the House of Representatives have set up a full-scale investigation of what are said to be widespread complaints that the Pentagon is mishandling the Reserve programs of the armed services.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 14 (UP) -- Harvard announced tonight that it did not intend to be bound by the National Collegiate Athletic Association's football television policy for 1953.

The 15,000-ton liner Rosa of the Lauro Lines of Naples will arrive here early tomorrow on her maiden voyage, establishing a new type of service between New York and Palermo, Naples and Genoa and a rare system of managerial operation as well.

Liberal supplies of beef and a scarcity of pork, noted yesterday by the City Department of Markets, have not affected prices. At the retail level they remain the same as a week ago on all meats as well as poultry.
The trustees of Columbia University announced yesterday three appointments to the advisory board of the American Press Institute, a cooperative study project for newspaper men.

A patrolman on school traffic duty at Madison Avenue and Eighty-first Street joined in chasing a burglar yesterday and a few moments later had cornered a suspect loaded down with $750 worth of cameras and photography equipment that had vanished shortly before from a room occupied by Thanat Khomal, acting United Nations representative of Thailand.

A first-hand account of conditions in Korea and the Near East, a new work by Pat Frank, will be issued July 8 by Lippincott under the title "The Long Way Round," Mr. Frank describes his experiences and observations in Seoul, Panmunjom, Hong Kong, Bangkok and Turkey.

To all our fellow-citizens whose faith in the American idea and the classical American way has been shaken, alike by fears of the foreign foe and feats of the domestic demagogue exploiting these fears, your editorial entitled "Freedom and Fear" must bring reassurance and heartening.

There is no nobler service afforded the afflicted than that of the visiting nurse. With quiet competence she brightens the lives of many in all parts of the city, even though her work entails trudging on dingy streets and climbing dark stairways.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Eisenhower defended the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization today but said he intended to inquire into the criticism made of that agency by some groups in this country.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on May 9, 1953, were 765,411 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 16,088 cars, or 2.1 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 45,552 cars, or 6.3 per cent more than for the corresponding week of last year and 42,716 cars. or per 5.3 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

NEWARK, May 14 -- Commissioner Leo P. Carlin, Director of Public Works, who was re-elected Tuesday as one of Newark's five City Commissioners. is expected to be elected to the office of Mayor, it was believed in City Hall circles today.

Two six-story buildings, each containing sixteen apartments, at 58 and 60 Moore Street in Brooklyn have been sold by Josephine Abeglia to the Paul Realty Corporation. Samuel S. Isaacs was attorney for the buyer and C. Anthony DeLucia acted for the seller.

TAIPEI, Formosa, May 14 -- The Chinese Nationalist Government informed the United States Government today that it objected to a "number of points" in the counter-proposal on the prisoner exchange issue made by Gen. Mark W. Clark in Panmunjom.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., May 14 -- Over the objections of three of its ten members, the State Council of Parks adopted today a resolution calling for state control of power development of the Niagara River rather than turning it over to private utility interests, as proposed in legislation pending in Congress.
Interest rates seem low now to those who recall the 5 to 5 1/2 per cent rates of years ago, Frederic W. Ecker, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, pointed out yesterday.

ROME, May 14 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi, campaigning for re-election, invaded one of the principal Opposition citadels today when he drew a large cheering crowd in Bologna, which the Communists and their allies consider just about as "safe" for themselves as any place in Italy.

LOS ANGELES, May 14 (AP) -The Hollywood Turf Club and boycotting horsemen reached a settlement today in their purse money row and racing is scheduled to start Saturday after a four-day shutdown of the big Inglewood plant.

The New York City Transit Authority directed its engineering consultants yesterday to estimate the effect of fare increases of varying amounts on the number of passengers carried on the city-owned transit lines and also to estimate the savings that could be achieved by immediate and long-range operating economies.

Railroad, rail equipment and electrical equipment shares led a stock market advance yesterday. The gain in THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average was the widest in more than a month but it was accompanied by no significant rise in volume. Turnover was only 1,210,000 shares, against 1,120,000 on Wednesday.

Director William Greene of the Connecticut Safety Commission comes out in favor of legal penalties for reckless or careless pedestrians. "For too many years," he declares, "the pedestrian has been allowed to get away with the impression that his undeniable 'right' to cross the street, as against the motorist's 'permit,' justifies taking chances often resulting in his death."

Warren Neuberger, City College's ace right-hander and the league's leading hurler, went the distance yesterday for the eighth straight time, but failed to register his record-breaking victory as New York University, behind the pitching of Vince Lupica, defeated C. C. N. Y., 2 to 0, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game at McCombs Dam Park.
Dapper, 78-year-old Willie Conklin, known to postoffice inspectors as "King of Forgers," returned to old haunts yesterday, but he felt quite unhappy in doing so.

BOSTON, May 14 -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, said tonight that it would be "grave policy error" to turn back Federal power systems to private enterprise, and that he had "no intention of being a party" to such action.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Eisenhower said today he favored giving to Senators and Representatives a salary rise of $10,000 a year.

Commodity prices closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges on light volume. Only hides, tin, world sugar and coffee approached average trading activity. Tin, coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, wool, lead and rubber were higher.

I was out of the country on a business trip recently, and on April 23 I purchased my airmail edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES of that same day. An editorial appearing in that issue, "Buy American," seemed to tie in with a certain problem I encountered on this trip.

John M. Cabot, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, warned yesterday that demands for tariff protection by special groups could cause serious damage to the nation's vital interests.
BOSTON, May 15 -- The first of two intricate operations to create new hip joints for Arthur Godfrey was performed today at Massachusetts General Hospital.

The Port Washington Shopping Center in Port Washington, L. I., has been purchased by Samson Rosenblatt and his son, Joseph B. Rosenblatt, from Henry M. Weitzner and a syndicate headed by Abraham Dreier of the Dreier Structural Steel Company.
The New York City Ballet last night gave season's premieres to two more works from its repertoire at the City Center. These were George Balanchine's "Valse Fantaisie" and Ruthanna Boris' "Cakewalk."

Net profit after provision for dividends on the preferred stock of the Northern States Power Company (Minnesota) and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31 amounted to $13,229,526, it was announced yesterday. This compares with $10,178,821 for previous twelve months.

PITTSBURGH, May 15 (AP) -- The United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., finished telling the United States Steel Corporation today why it wanted a wage increase. The company asked for time to draw up an answer.

ROME, May 15 -- An extensive plan of French Foreign Minister Georges Bidault to create a special international body, in which North Atlantic Treaty Organization powers would participate, to carry on psychological warfare against Russia and communism began to take shape in Rome today.

YONKERS, May 15 (AP) -- Hi-Lo's Forbes came charging through the fog at Yonkers Raceway tonight to score a one-length victory in the first grand circuit free-for-all pace of the season here. The fog was so heavy that it was impossible for the 20,419 fans to see the horses on the backstretch.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., May 15 -- Surfcasters of this generation, having missed the "good old days" of song and story when striped bass and blue fish were plentiful and large, rarely have an opportunity to equal the sport provided by the pollock fishing at Race Point on the tip of Cape Cod.

More than 6,000 persons have been ousted from tenements on the lower East Side to make room for Federal-supported public housing projects which may never materialize because of Congressional opposition to low-rent construction programs.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn. May 15 -- Howard Coonley, a manufacturer, moved out of his apartment at 1112 Park Avenue, New York, today and drove with Mrs. Coonley to this village to take possession of a two-story residence and twenty-acre estate he had purchased for his new home yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 15 -- The Institute of Applied Arts and Science here would be operated by Westchester County after the state relinquishes control Sept. 1 under a recommendation made today by the budget and appropriations committee of the County Board of Supervisors.

LONDON, May 15 -- A further rise in British Government securities was the only exception to falling prices on the stock markets here today. Gilt-edge issues made good gains ranging up to one-quarter of one per cent.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 15 -- A huge and eloquent monument to the trials of this resurgent port city, in the very heart of the area destroyed by German bombers just thirteen years ago, was inaugurated today by Mayor Gerard E. van Waisum.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 15 (AP) -- Following are texts of President Eisenhower's addresses here today at the College of William and Mary and in the Colonial House of Burgesses:

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 15 -- Robert W. Knowles of the Palmetto nated the medal winner, Fred Lazard of Cherry Valley, 1 up, in the second round of the annual Walter J. Travis Memorial invitation tournament at the Garden City Golf Club today.
HANOI, Indo-China, May 15 (UP) -- The French Air Force today broke up Communist attempts to seize newly harvested rice crops in the rich Hanoi delta by bombing a concentration of 2,000 rebels.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -- Miss Marianne Craig Moore, Pulitzer-prize winning poet, received tonight the $5,000 M. Carey Thomas Award of Bryn Mawr College. The presentation was made by Miss Katharine E. McBride, president of the college, before about 700 guests in Goodhart Hall on the campus.
TOKYO, Saturday, May 18 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 406, for Friday to 6 P. M.:...

LONDON, May 15 -- Broad hints are being dropped in British Government circles that Sir Winston Churchill's proposal for new talks with the Soviet Union did not come as a complete surprise to President Eisenhower.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady, up 7 to 18 points yesterday, led by the strength in old July.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., May 15 (AP) -- Stockholders of Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation met here today to approve a shift in command of the company which employes 50,000 in California and Texas.

LONDON, May 15 -- Oliver Messel has recently broken away from the stage designing with which his name is so closely associated, to take a little fling in the fashion world. He has turned his versatile talents to the designing of fabrics that will take their place in the Coronation pageant.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- They never do things halfway in Chicago. It's either too long or too short. Or so it would appear. In the same city where Gene Tunney and Jack Dempsey fought their famous Battle of the Long Count, Rocky Marciano and Jersey Joe Walcott fought the battle of the short count tonight.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 15 -- An attractive eighth grade school teacher, stabbed nine times in the back yesterday by one of her Cos Cob School students, was reported in fair condition today at the Greenwich Hospital.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 15 (AP) -- The Raritan Stable's Bakersfield upset Philip Godfrey's Elias G. at Garden State Park today, scoring by a length. Third in the dash was Brookmeade Stable's Safety.

BALTIMORE, May 15 -- The crime-infested International Longshoremen's Association, fighting to stay in the American Federation of Labor, promised today to clean house but sidestepped an order to throw out officers with criminal records unless the huge federation adopted such a rule covering all its affiliates.

The following excerpt from Clement Attlee's speech in the House of Commons Tuesday, from a text provided by the British Information Service in New York, covers Mr. Attlee's remarks about the Government and policies of the United States, which aroused sharp controversy in the United States Senate:...

We believe that the State Department owes an explanation of why it summarily forced the resignation of Theodore Kaghan as deputy director of the Public Affairs Division of the United States High Commissioner's office in Germany.
PARIS, May 15 -- Agreements revising the conventions between France and the Saar and providing greater independence for the Saar were initialed here today and will be signed at a ceremony Wednesday.

Harry Girth, the German prisoner of war who had lived as Henry Kolmar for seven years after his escape from Fort Dix, N. J., in 1946, was freed from Ellis Island yesterday on condition that he leave the country within forty-five days.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Army engineers have started buying land around many of the nation's major cities to be used as launching sites for the new antiaircraft guided missile, the Nike.

Our window watcher has been taking note these many seasons of operations of a neighbor who does his farming not in Long Island or New Jersey or Westchester but on a rooftop in the middle of Manhattan.

Events today: Concert Artists Guild, Steinway Hall, 3 P. M.; St. Cecelia Glee Club, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; Composers' Concert, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 5:30; Jan Kiepura, tenor, and Martha Eggert, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30; Eastern Choral Guild, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Benefit Concert under auspices of Jewish Labor Committee, Central High School of Needle Trades, 8:15.

Average market value of all the stocks on the New York Stock Exchange fell in April to the lowest month-end figure since June 30, 1951, the Exchange reported yesterday. The figure of $40.44 a share compared with $41.94 at the end of March and with $38.73 on the 1951 date.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- Grain futures showed little capacity for holding rallies today, the markets losing much of yesterday's price improvement. Short covering appeared to be the main source of support in wheat, and bears were encouraged on the selling side by the inability of the market to maintain gains.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Virgil Trucks snapped Washington's six-game winning streak and pitched his fourth victory with an eight-hitter tonight as the Browns defeated the Senators, 4 -- 0.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 (AP) -- Three homers -- including the first ever hit in major league competition by Pitcher Art Houtteman -- produced all the Detroit runs tonight as the Tigers' whipped the Athletics, 7 -- 6.

The Department of Commerce, the National Bureau of Economic Research, Inc., and the National Industrial Conference Board have published figures on the structure of our economy which deserve special mention at home and abroad as a dramatic justification of the American free-enterprise system.

A mission institute, said to be the first of its kind in this country, will be conducted this summer at Fordham University for Roman Catholic priests, seminarians, brothers, sisters, and lay missionaries.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Syros Markezinis, Greek Minister of Coordination, announced today the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development would send a mission to Greece next month to study the possibility of a loan to the Athens Government.

HARTFORD, May 15 -- A sweeping reorganization of Connecticut's public education system, which involves the elimination of present state administration agencies, was approved today by the Joint Education Committee of the General Assembly.
A quiet-looking young man who grew up in Elizabeth, N. J., and went to Princeton was the host yesterday at a "Maine" clambake on the fourth floor of the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.

Helping emotionally disturbed children is one of the most pressing obligations on this community and many other communities over the country, Justice Justine Wise Polier of the Domestic Relations Court declared here yesterday.

The way to fight is "to fight and not go off begging" was the comment yesterday of City Council President Rudolph Halley on the state administration's rejection of the request of Mayor Impellitteri and Controller Lazarus Joseph for a special session of the Legislature.

Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer directed Local 1250 of the Distributive, Processing and Office Workers of America, C. I. O., which is on strike against the two Hearn department stores, to show cause why it should not be punished for contempt for violating a previous order barring it from interfering with Hearn customers.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- A plan to shorten the working day for Niagara Falls, historic goal of honeymooners, was agreed upon today by a Joint American-Canadian Commission.
LONDON, May 15 (Reuters) -- The Soviet news agency Tass, in reporting the pardoning of William N. Oatis today, said it had come in connection with the recent Czechoslovak amnesty.

CHICAGO, May 15 (AP) -- Arthur Keating, chairman and president of Nesco, Inc., said today that certain directors and other large stockholders had sold approximately 120,000 shares to New York Shipbuilding Corporation.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 15 -- President Eisenhower, accepting an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from the College of William and Mary, declared today that the nation's colleges must produce better defenders of freedom than those who would limit their contribution to the struggle to not more than 15 per cent of their income.

ST. LOUIS, May 15 -- Preacher Roe suffered the same fate this afternoon that overtook Carl Erskine last night when the Cardinals beat Roe for the first time since Aug. 28, 1950, after he had compiled a ten-game winning streak against them. Erskine had a similar streak snapped at seven games.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 15 -- The Netherlands Government rejected today a United States request for the extradition of Harold J. Adonis, former executive clerk to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, who is under indictment on bribery charges.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- A Justice Department source said today that no new credible evidence had been presented that warranted action in the cases of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the atomic spies who are under sentence of death in Sing Sing prison.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The House Appropriations Committee today recommended a cut of $289,199,730 in the current annual spending rate of six agencies. The committee proposed a total of $1,965,581,570 for the fiscal year beginning next July 1.
With car thefts reported on the upswing throughout the country increased vigilance in touring unfamiliar areas was urged yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 15 -- The United States cast the single abstaining vote today on a recommendation to extend the life of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.
CHICAGO, May 15 (AP) -- An official of the Department of Agriculture said today prices paid to farmers have been declining because "other things have not been equal."

Boxing had its "Battle of the Long Count" in 1927, when Gene Tunney retained the crown against Jack Dempsey, and now it has its "Battle-of the Fast Count," according to television viewers of last night's heavyweight title bout between Rocky Marciano and Joe Walcott.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., May 15 -- George F. Kennan, long-time diplomat and former Ambassador to Russia, declared tonight that "there are forces at large in our society" that "march, in one way or another, under the banner of an alarmed and exercised anti-communism."
Dwellings dominated the trading in Long Island areas in transaction reported yesterday.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 15 -- A cocoa colored imported miniature poodle that had figured in the event a year ago took best of breed today in the nineteenth specialty of the Poodle Club of America. She was Mr. and Mrs. A. Hastings Fiske's Ch. Braeval Babbling Brook. The poodle will be 3 years old tomorrow.

LONDON, May 15 -- Speaking at the final session of the three-day General Assembly of the International Press Institute heretoday, Sir Benegal Narsing Rau, Judge of the International Court of Justice at The Hague and former Indian delegate to the United Nations, estimated that 3 per cent of the world's yearly armament expenditure would be enough to implement President Eisenhower's suggested program of aid for all the underdeveloped areas of the world.

A 38-year-old ex-convict and jail breaker, arrested here for allegedly defrauding two Guttenberg, N. J., sisters of $20,000, was questioned late yesterday about the murder of a Hoboken pier hiring boss, John Francis (Strong Man) Kelly.

May is the "peak month" of the 1953 fund campaign of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York, whose headquarters are at 220 West Fifty-eighth Street, New York City 19. In this critical month of its drive the appeal is trying to raise $10,500,000, representing $500,000 for each of the twenty-one working days of the month.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 15 -- Oliver Lyttelton, British Secretary of State for the Colonies, started today a series of talks with officials and representatives of various interests here to draft the outlines of a possible solution for Kenya's immediate problem -- the Mau Mau native terror.
MADRID, May 15 -- Gen. Francisco Craveiro Lopes, President of Portugal, arrived here today to return the visit Generalissimo Francisco Franco made to Lisbon in 1949.

Two bandits disarmed two guards and relieved them of a $10,000 payroll they were carrying from an armored car into an electric fixture factory in the Bush Terminal district of Brooklyn yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- A bill to bring Alaska into the Union was approved today, 12 to 5, by a subcommittee of the Interior and Insular Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives.
The Bronx Zoo will open this morning the Farm-in-the-Zoo, a new casting pool and a new 327-car parking field.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- Three companies jointly announced today the formation of a new company, Rubarite, Inc., to manufacture and sell synthetic rubber powders for use in asphalt for roads and in other asphalt materials. Headquarters of the company will be in the Board of Trade Building in Chicago.

" Britain's Perfect Secretary," a pretty 22-year-old, auburn-haired Londoner, who won her title by writing an essay setting forth the qualifications of a perfect secretary, arrived in New York yesterday for the eighteen-day trip across the United States she won as her prize.
J. P. McCarthy has been named district sales manager in New York for the Graybar Electric Company.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Two bills aimed at helping small business meet its credit needs through the private banking system were offered to the Senate here today by senator John Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 15 -- California Packing Corporation has reported earnings for the fiscal year ended on Feb. 28 of $5,653,026, or 2.62 per cent of sales, compared with $7,115,855, or 3.55 per cent for the preceding year. Earnings per share were $2.93 compared with $3.69.

CINCINNATI, May 15 -- Feeling that the hour had arrived when he had to do something drastic, Leo Durocher, despite yesterday's avowed denials to the contrary, gave his Giants a violent shaking up today. Then the Polo Grounders stepped out and thumped Rogers Hornsby's Redlegs, 7 to 3, in eleven innings to make a clean "sweep" of the only game of the series played here.

TROY, N. Y., May 15 -- The Industrial Council, meeting at Renssalaer Polytechnic Institute with the avowed purpose of "illuminating the economic and social significance of the chemical industry" started its two-day session this afternoon with 550 teachers from all the states and 200 chemical industrialists in attendance.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 15 (AP) -- "I still can't believe it," exclaimed Mrs. William N. Oatis when the United States State department called her tonight with the confirmation she had been breathlessly awaiting that her husband has been pardoned.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 15 -- The prospects for the next coffee crop are good, Marchelino Martins, president of the Rio de Janeiro Coffee Exchange, decided today.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- John E. Burton, chairman of the Power Authority of New York State said today legislation proposing development of more hydroelectric power at Niagara Falls, N. Y., by private enterprise would be "trust building."
Today's new film is "Bellissima," an Italian importation starring Anna Magnani, winner of Italy's "Silver Ribbon" award for 1952, at the Sixtieth Street Trans-Lux.

A drive to organize unorganized workers in retail and wholesale merchandising as part of a program for merging unions in those fields was announced yesterday by Irving Simon, president of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Workers Union, C. I. O., and Arthur Osman, president of the Distributive, Processing and Office Workers of America, C. I. O.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The State Department announced tonight that William N. Oatis, Associated Press correspondence, charged with espionage by the Czechoslovak Government, had been granted a pardon.

Two economists voiced optimistic predictions for the second half of the year at the annual business meeting of members of the New York chapter of the American Statistical Association last night at Remington Rand Hall, 315 Fourth Avenue.

The Distributive, Processing and Office Workers Union, independent, has convinced the Congress of Industrial Organizations that its top officers no longer support the Communist party line. As a result the union has been admitted into the C. I. O. and plans are being made for a merger with the C. I. O.'s department store affiliate in October.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 15 -- United States Army procurement officers are about to place a contract in Yugoslavia for at least $5,000,000 worth of ammunition.

PARIS, May 15 -- Communist propaganda is having a happy time these days exploiting the transatlantic debate between United States and British leaders. It has not yet got around to citing this as typical of what the Stalinist theory called the inherent differences among the capitalist states, but almost certainly one can expect such recollections if nothing is done to smooth out the arguments.
HARTFORD, May 15 -- Gov. John Davis Lodge sent to the General Assembly late today his nominations for Municipal Court judgeships in sixty-five Connecticut cities and towns.

" My desire," Job said, "is that mine adversary had written a book." And since quoting out of context is fashionable in life's echoing grove at the moment, let us see how Job's celebrated wish is being observed. Our adversaries in the last war are certainly obliging. They are turning out now-it-can-be-tolds at an awesome rate.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Dr. Emerson P. Schmidt, director of economic research for the United States Chamber of Commerce, issued a denial today to charges made yesterday by a "Citizens Conference on Social Security" that the Chamber's proposed social security plan would scuttle old age and survivors insurance.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, introduced a bill today to permit the immigration of 240,000 more aliens during a period of two years.
ST. LOUIS, May 15 (AP) -- Nine American Federation of Labor union officers were arrested today on indictments returned in a continuing Federal grand jury investigation of alleged labor racketeering.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Labor committees of Congress are scheduled to start work next week on revising the Taft-Hartley Law and the Senate group may have in hand by then a comprehensive new bill written by Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, the Majority Leader and co-author of the present law.

DAMASCUS, Syria, May 15 (UP) -- The Premier of Jordan told United States Secretary of State John Foster Dulles today there could be no talk of Middle Eastern defense until the individual problems of the Arab states were resolved.

At its high point yesterday THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average was at its best level since May 5 but the stock market was spotty and highly selective, with unimportant volume, and most of the gains were wiped out by the close. By the barest of margins, prices stayed above the close for the previous Friday and the week became the third in a row to end with a net gain.

Judge Harold R. Medina told lawyers in the investment banking anti-trust suit yesterday that they should not take too seriously the running comments he is making about the evidence and courtroom argument as it unfolds.

Archbishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn has designated tomorrow as Catholic Charities Sunday. At masses in the four counties of Long Island, pastors and priests in the 300 parishes of the diocese will voice an appeal to their constituents to support with prayer and sacrificial giving the social welfare program of their church.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration said today it would sharply restrict "discount practices" in the financing of G. I. home loans by lenders and builders now that the permissible interest rate has been raised.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 15 -- Disintegration of the Torch Commando veterans' organization, expanded to 250,000 white members last year and dedicated to safeguarding democracy in South Africa, began today with the resignation of a patron, N. J. de Wet, former Chief Justice and former Acting Governor General of the Union of South Africa.

It came as a shock yesterday to lead in the newspapers that the Danube River is still on the map of Europe. One had almost forgotten that fact, which is surely one of the most striking evidences of what a mad world we live in these days.

HONG KONG, May 15 (AP) -- A Hong Kong shipping executive whose company drew the fire of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, for allegedly trading with Communist China, said today Mr. McCarthy was "uttering words without knowledge."
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Average primary market prices remained unchanged in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The bond market ended the trading week yesterday with another show of quiet firmness. There was little activity in either the market for Treasury obligations or other parts of the high-grade investment market, but what there was reflected a persistence of the better tone which returned to the market early in the week.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Department of Justice announced today that a grand jury would begin on May 27 an investigation into the handling of the office payroll of Representative Ernest K. Bramblett, Republican of California.
The following is a round-up of new products that may interest the homemaker.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. announced today the indictment of Nicholas A. Rattenni of Yonkers, N. Y., described as an associate of Frank Costello, gambler, on tax charges.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Spokesmen for lead and zinc mining companies told Congress today that once-thriving mining communities were being converted into ghost towns by the "dumping" of foreign metal.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Brooklyn political and business leaders joined with members of Congress from the area today in urging the appropriation of $400,000 in federal funds to eliminate a major bottleneck in the Port of New York.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 15 -- The Federal Executive Council adopted today a draft law on religion for ultimate passage by Parliament, which is due to meet May 20.

CHICAGO, May 15 (UP) -- Gardner Cowles, president of The Des Moines Register and Tribune, called today for a "Marshall Plan for Americans" to lower trade barriers and assure a "complete and consistent foreign policy."

Japan must export in order to live, Eikichi Araki, Japanese Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday before the International Trade Section of the New York Board of Trade, Inc., in Town Hall. This year she expects to buy $450,000,000 of food, accounting for 20 per cent of all her food requirements and 25 per cent of her imports.

Production delays in the printing of 1,500,000 $5 and $10 automobile use tax stamps for 1953-54 have postponed from next Monday to May 25 the beginning of the sale of the stickers, City Treasurer Spencer C. Young announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Edward T. Wailes of Brooklyn, a career Foreign Service officer, was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be Assistant Secretary of State for Administration.

ESSEX, Conn., May 15 -- The beautiful Connecticut River, dotted with yacht basins and alive with all kinds of pleasure and commercial craft, makes a shining frame for this old New England town. A magnet for visitors, it will vie for attention next week with river bank homes which will be open for public tour.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Although four of twelve alleged Communist - front organizations that Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, asked the Subversive Activities Control Board to order to register under the Internal Security Act did not participate in oral arguments before the panel this week, they will not be considered in default, Thomas J. Herbert, chairman of the board, said today.

HARTFORD, May 15 -- A legislative investigating committee reported to the Connecticut General Assembly today that there was no justification to "implications and imputations against the integrity" of the State Legislature in connection with recent passage of a bill banning the public sale of fireworks in the state after Oct. 1.

Although the high-customer interest in the New York and London productions of "Dial M for Murder" continues unabated, the national company of Frederick Knott's melodrama will ring down its final curtain tonight at Chicago's Harris Theatre because of lack of business.

The ill-timed sputtering on both sides of the Atlantic shows how easy it is to inflate small differences into great issues. A little hot air, and the cloud no bigger than a man's hand can be blown into a tempest of bad feeling. A speaker in the House of Commons can raise a cheer any time by blaming the United States for almost anything that goes wrong in the world.

Armed Forces Day will be celebrated today with a parade of 25,000 persons down Fifth Avenue, open house at military establishments in the area and public visits to the Army's new atomic cannon and warships moored along the waterfront.
TUNIS, May 15 -- The beginning of the Moslem holy month of Ramadan was marred here last night by a brief but turbulent outbreak of anti-Semitism.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Dr. Robert L. Johnson, administrator of the International Information Administration, moved today to clarify his agency's request for the services of Hollywood directors in the production of a series of movies for the Information program.

CHICAGO, May 15 (AP) -- A bitter, bewildered Joe Walcott, counted out in the first round of his heavyweight championship fight with Rocky Marciano, sputtered tonight that his knockout "was ridiculous."

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The United States, standing firm on the paramount principle of its truce terms, said tonight that it was always ready to end the Korean war "on an honorable basis" but not at the cost of "indefinite captivity" of prisoners of war.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Senator John Marshall Butler, Republican of Maryland, called on the Administration today to rid its ranks of what he called "crypto-Socialists." He charged that in the last twenty years such persons had dug into jobs where they could influence policies of the Federal Government.

KINGSTON, R. I., May 15 -- Six educators and scientists received honorary degrees at the University of Rhode Island today at the start of a two-day meeting that will include the dedication of the new Pastore Chemical Laboratory on the campus.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., May 15 -- William L. Pfeiffer, Republican State Chairman, hinted strongly tonight that he would support Governor Dewey for a fourth term.

QUITO, Ecuador, May 14 -- President Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra said today that his Government would allow the reopening of La Nacion and La Hora of Guayaquil if the owner of those newspapers, now in jail with four members of the papers' staffs, promised in a written statement that the publications would "obey the laws of Ecuador."

JERSEY CITY, May 15 -- Its term extended for an additional twelve weeks, the special Hudson County grand jury investigating waterfront crime and racketeering in cooperation with the New Jersey State Attorney General's office will turn its attention to the Hoboken waterfront next week, it was announced today.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches were completed yesterday despite fog and rain and two new district champions emerged for 1953. The outcome of yesterday's contests also set the stage for a new Metropolitan champion to be crowned next week.

NEW DELHI, India, May 15 -- A Government report detailing the results achieved during the first two years of India's five-year economic plan indicated today the dim financial outlook for the future without foreign aid.

Some pleasant contemporary patterns, predominantly floral, that might be used to give a cool look to a room are presented in a new collection of wallpapers and a new group of decorative fabrics. The papers, hand-screened, are available through decorators at Gene McDonald, 601 Madison Avenue, and the fabrics may be ordered through decorators at Jofa, 45 East Fifty-third Street.

PARIS, May 15 -- The end of the merchant marine strike that has crippled French shipping for more than two weeks appeared in sight tonight when shipowners and strikers both agreed to submit to arbitration by Premier Rene Mayer.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 15 -- Lord Ismay, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty organization, said here tonight he had offered the Turkish Government the services of fourteen technical experts on his international staff to assist in the construction of airfields, communication lines, pipelines and other elements of the program of military installations laid down for this country by the Atlantic Council.

The election of Frederick Lewis Allen, historian and editor, and James F. Brownlee, a partner in J. H. Whitney Co., investment bankers, as trustees of The Ford Foundation was announced here yesterday by Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the board, after its two-day meeting.

LOS ANGELES, May 15 (AP) -- Mal Whitfield, the Olympic champion, launched the thirteenth annual Coliseum relays tonight with an easy victory in the 880-yard run in the time of 1:49.6 before a crowd of 35,979.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, May 16 (AP) -- Thousands of Chinese Communists attacked United States and South Korean positions on the central Korea war front early today and were hurled back after heavy hand-to-hand fighting, with losses of at least 1,100 killed and wounded.

MILWAUKEE, May 15 (AP) -- Sid Gordon slapped a 330-foot home run over the left field fence with Eddie Mathews on base in the eighth inning today to give Milwaukee a 4-3 victory over Pittsburgh and keep the Braves tied for first place in the National League.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The principal Republican foreign policy spokesman of the Senate repudiated today the violent attacks made on British leaders by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin and other members of the party.
Mrs. Martha Coughlin's orderly Brooklyn household was disrupted yesterday by a small, striped alley cat, which might have been suffering from the delusion that it was a ferocious tiger.

Manufacturers who sell fair-traded products to so-called "club plans" are considering abandoning this kind of merchandising, fair-trade attorneys reported yesterday. They said the reason was the legal setback to Landers, Frary Clark early this week in New York Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, declaring that he knew of no letup in Soviet military preparations, appealed today for a constant defense program that would not place economy ahead of the national security.

A syndicate of investors headed by Benjamin Rosenzweig has purchased the fifteen-story apartment house for ninety-five families on plot 101 by 154 feet at 670 West End Avenue, southeast corner of Ninety-third Street, from the Equitable Life Assurance Society.

TRENTON, May 15 -- The refusal of the Netherlands Government to grant the extradition to New Jersey of Harold J. Adonis and his release from an Amsterdam prison was received with silence by most state officials today. However, it was indicated that the news caused little surprise in view of the testimony presented at public hearings of the legislative committee investigating the ouster of former Deputy Attorney General Nelson F. Stamler.

LONDON, May 15 -- Evidence from the new 200-inch telescope at Mount Palomar Observatory near San Diego, Calif., supporting the theory that the universe is expanding, was presented here tonight by Dr. Edwin Hubble, astronomer of Mount Wilson Observatory at Pasadena, Calif., to members of the Royal Institution.

NEW DELHI, India, May 15 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru supported the Chinese Communists' eight-point proposal on the Korean prisoner issue today as a "basis for discussion." He also said he "would earnestly commend" Sir Winston Churchill's suggestion for an informal big-power conference.

LONDON, May 15 -- Clement Attlee's speech Tuesday in the foreign policy debate has become a subject of controversy that may have overshadowed the proposal of Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister, for a new big power meeting of the heads of state, all because some remarks about the political system in the United States and its application to current events struck sharply discordant notes on opposite sides of the Atlantic.

PORTLAND, Me., May 15 (AP) -- American Power and Light Company, a utilities holding concern with extensive Pacific Coast properties, was dissolved today under provisions of the 1935 Utilities "Death Sentence" Act.

Top management's unaided judgment is not a reliable guide when writing to reach the masses, in the opinion of Langley Carlton Keyes, vice president of the Boston advertising agency of Hoag Provendie, Inc. His observation is contained in an article, "Advertising Copy -- Hit or Miss?" in the Harvard Business Review.

ISMALIA, Egypt, May 15 -- The vanguard of a Royal Marine commando brigade arrived at the Suez Canal Zone from Malta today to help defend the huge British military base here against further hostile actions by the Egyptians.
Your editorial of May 12 "Crime and the State" unhappily leaves unresolved whether good citizens should support the suggestion of the State Crime Commission for a permanent investigatory body.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 15 -- The Indian delegation has been getting in touch with diplomats from Europe and Asia to express pointed dissatisfaction with the truce proposals of the United Nations command in Korea.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- Rocky Marciano, the Brockton boxer who holds the heavyweight championship of the world, knocked out Jersey Joe Walcott in one round tonight. Reaching the 39 - year - old challenger with a left and a right to the jaw, Rocky put Walcott down for the full count after only 2 minutes and 25 seconds of fighting.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 15 -- The extent to which the annual Bach Festival is a collaboration between performers and auditors was demonstrated today by the change that occurred when the regular audience arrived to take their places in the pews of the Packer Chapel of Lehigh University for the two sessions of the second day of the forty-sixth Festival of the Bach Choir of Bethlehem.
Because the conflict in Korea is not an officially declared war the Federal Employes Compensation Act of 1916 becomes effective.

A new "Sacred Service for Sabbath Eve" by Isadore Freed had its first performance last evening at the Park Avenue Synagogue. Cantor David J. Putterman and the Synagogue choir were heard under the direction of Max Helfman.

In a move which formally commits Germany to the Western community of nations the Bonn Parliament has now completed ratification of the new European treaty system. This system is designed to establish official peace between Germany and the Western Allies and to create a European Defense Community with an integrated European. Army of 2,000,000 men that will include 500,000 Germans.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 15 -- Spencer Tracy will be off to New York next week on the start of a vacation trip to Europe unless Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer permits him to go on loan-out to Columbia to star in "Frontier," based on Frank Harris' classic story of western Americana, "Reminiscences of a Cowboy."

The first direct helicopter mail flight from New York to Washington was made yesterday when one of the Army's rotary-wing craft left Mitchel Air Force Base, L. I., for the capital carrying a sack full of letters.

Mayor Impellitteri was in a magnanimous and forgiving mood at the Bronx County Democratic dinner. His praise for the Bronx leader, Edward J. Flynn, was warm as only an aspirant for fall endorsement can make it. Mr. Flynn is back, said the Mayor, just in time "to give us the benefit of his wise leadership in the challenging months ahead in this Mayoralty election year."

Gerhard Arthur Puff, 38-year-old bank robber, was found guilty yesterday in Federal Court of first degree murder and became the first person in this area to be sentenced to death for killing a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Following is the text of the State Department's statement of the basic United States position on Korean truce questions:

BERLIN, May 15 -- Belief was expressed in Berlin today that the expulsion of Franz Dahlem, 61 years old, a member of the politburo of the Socialist Unity (Communist) party from all his positions would be followed by a purge of all his followers in party and Government services.

TOKYO, Saturday, May 16 -- The United Nations delegation called today for a three-day recess in the negotiations at Panmunjom for an armistice in the Korean war after a sixty-seven -minute session at which both sides repeated the arguments used yesterday on the disposal of prisoners unwilling to return to communism.

PANAMA, May 15 -- The Inter-American Press Association is considering a report by the chairman of its Freedom of the Press Committee recommending that the Panama Doctrine be invoked in the closing of the Guayaquil newspapers La Nacion and La Hora by the Ecuadorian Government.
BONN, Germany, May 15 -- The Allied-German treaties completed today their long journey through the West German Legislature.
CHICAGO, May 15 (AP) -- Earl Torgeson's one-out double in the ninth and Gran Hamner's single gave the Phillies' Robin Roberts the only run he needed to defeat the Cubs, 1 -- 0, before 6,531 today.
BROCKTON, Mass., May 15 (AP) -- Rocky Marciano's home town took the heavyweight champion's one-round knockout of Jersey Joe Walcott quietly tonight.

LOS ANGELES, May 15 -- Many individuals among the 1,500,000 classified as "mental defectives" in the nation were not so much lacking in intelligence as they were burdened with a failure complex, the Association on Mental Deficiency was told today.

Cedric H. Belfrage, 48-year-old British-born editor who twice refused to tell Congressional investigators whether he was a Communist, was arrested in his New York office yesterday and taken to Ellis Island to await deportation proceedings.

The stepped-up baggage clearance program, under which inspectors will examine only one or two pieces rather than all the luggage of a ship or plane passenger, went into effect yesterday, and Customs officials said it worked well and reduced passenger delays on the piers.
Perhaps there'll be a nickel-on-the-dollar favorite in the seventy-eighth running of the Withers Stakes for 3-year-olds at Belmont Park today.

VIENNA, May 15 -- The Soviet representative at today's meeting of the Allied Council demanded that "Austria liquidate her representation at the European Coal and Steel Community and recall her representative from the Council of Europe.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Shipping and union spokesmen divided today over a bill of Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, intended to prevent alien seamen from being signed on American-flag ships in foreign ports in so far as practicable.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 15 (AP) -- Chet Miller, a competitor in sixteen 500-mile auto races here, was killed today in a crack-up during a practice run on the Indianapolis motor speedway on the eve of the first time trials.

YANGYANG, Korea, May 15 -- Another step forward in the forging of the powerful Republic of Korea Army was taken today when two newly activated Korean divisions received their colors from President Syngman Rhee.

HEPPENHEIM, Germany, May 15 (AP) -- A United States F-84 Thunderjet ripped into a formation of eighteen C-119 Flying Boxcars tonight and killed several United States fliers in the triple collision. Two of the big transports and the jet went down in flames.

WESTBURY, L. L. May 15 -- At the end of one of the most unusual scoring days in the twelve years of the palm Beach round-robin golf tourney, the leader at the conclusion of fifty-four holes of play was Cary Middlecoff, former United States open champion, with a score of plus 25.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Spectacles that see in the dark were among the inventions patented this week. They are equipped with a pair of miniature flashlights, which are set on the ends of the bows at the sides of the frame and are beamed forward.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- James P. McGranery testified today he had been "bypassed" in three important cases that normally would have come to him while serving as Assistant Attorney General under Tom C. Clark in the late Nineteen Forties.

THE Psalmist's exhortation to "worship the Lord in the beauty of holiness" was taken literally and earnestly by the ancients. Throughout the ages in places of worship of all faiths, there was always that quest for "beauty in holiness." When secular melodies were brought into the religious service, the clerics condoned this practice by saying "why should Satan possess all the beautiful tune?"

Mrs. Charles A. Blackwell of 417 Park Avenue and Brookville, Long Island, is chairman of the executive committee for the Belmont Ball on June 12 at the Turf and Field Club at Belmont Park, which this year will benefit the New York Heart Association.

THE notion that the coming of Spring marks the end of the broadcasting season has been rather rudely and encouragingly upset on several different fronts in the last ten days. Especially on TV, there have been a number of interesting and welcome developments.
