MAY, traditionally, is the month when families give time and thought to the appearance of their cemetery plots. The care of a lawn and other plants was the responsibility of the owner until recent years. This custom, however, has been replaced quite generally by staff care for the season or in perpetuity.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- Senator Harley M. Kilgore said today that the Dean of the Harvard Law School warned that a bill to grant immunity to balky Congressional witnesses "seems clearly subject to abuse."
Four first-prize winners were named yesterday for the forty-third semiannual Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit that opened last Thursday and will continue through June 14.
BOSTON, May 16 (AP) -- Derrick Wilde of the host Union Boat Club gained the American Rowing Association's singles sculling title today during its fiftieth regatta on the Charles River.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 16 -- Cary Middlecoff, the erstwhile dentist from Memphis, clung to the lead in the Palm Beach golf tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today by the slim margin of one point.
After reading scenarist Kleiner's "apologia" for "Salome" on the screen I frankly don't believe Mr. Kleiner when he says nothing makes for good barter like a screen writer's head.

MARGARET WISE BROWN'S too-early death last November deprived the children's book field of one of its most original and prolific writers. Of her more than seventy published books for very young children some were, inevitably, tenuous and some were repetitious, but at her best she was inimitable.

THIS book is about pietism in Harlem and, of the three sorts of novel (string, wind and percussion), it belongs to the first. It does not produce its story as an accumulation of shocks (as most novels of Negro life do), or by puffing into a rigid metaphysical system (as most novels about religion do): it makes its utterance by tension and friction.

FIRST novels are, in one sense or another, so generally autobiographical that the reflective reader begins to feel the compulsion to write must be largely therapeutic. Certainly, the first novelist often gives the impression that his ego and its formative influences are absorbingly unique -- not only to himself but to everyone.

IT was many years ago that I visited for the first time the highlands of Calabria Our car proceeded along the Sila plateau, between fallow, uninhabited fields, overgrown as far as the eye could see with long-stemmed, snake-like verbascum and bordered in the distance by dark woods, sacred to boars and to the cult of bandits and brigands I asked who was the owner of this Godforsaken land, and "Baron Barracco" was my companion's reply.

BOOKS about the art of Maurice Ravel in English are few. No writer in English on this subject has done very much that is new or profound as regards the art and the psychology of a unique figure in French music of the twentieth century.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- A possible compromise on the issue of New York State vs. Federal development of new hydroelectric power facilities at Niagara Falls was suggested to Governor Dewey today by Senator Herbert H. Lehman and Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. of Manhattan.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 16 -- Princeton's lacrosse team remained in the running for national championship honors with a 9-to-7 victory over previously unbeaten Army before approximately 2,000 on the Plain today.

AT this time brave gardeners turn to one of the most beautiful and exasperating of all plants -- the tree peony. In spite of its name the tree peony is not a tree but a shrub. Ordinarily it grows about three feet high and as much across, but occasionally plants twenty or thirty years old will reach five or six feet in height and eight or ten feet in diameter.

EVERYBODY who is concerned with the importance of preserving dance compositions in written form, comparable to that in which musical compositions are preserved, will be heartened by a grant recently made by the Rockefeller Foundation which will speed the process immeasurably.

Double taxation permeates Federal income tax laws. Whether double taxation stems from the operation of statutes or results from a mistaken treatment of income, it is prejudicial to the taxpayer and has the effect of a penalty tax.

As the result of a seven-year rally, the wages of United States seamen, ship labor costs have increased 250 per cent and such current costs on United States-flag vessels are four times those on comparable ships of Great Britain and other leading maritime nations.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 16 -- According to Yugoslav military authorities, recent troop movements and other activities in the Soviet satellites, particularly along their borders with Yugoslavia, imply an increased rather than a decreased threat to peace in this part of Europe.
PARIS, May 16 -- It is a fortunate thing that Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, who has been named commander of Allied forces in Europe, is a man particularly renowned for his diplomatic capabilities.

LOUIS DE ROCHEMONT, whose film interests are extensive and varied, is about to return to his "first love," the producer revealed last week. Mr. de Rochemont, who wanted it known that he is not forsaking his other picture projects, is busily preparing to launch a series of new featurettes in color under the general title, "Our Times," and bearing a subtitle -- "Of men, ideas and events which distinguish today from yesterday and tomorrow."

Dr. Frederic Ernst, deputy superintendent of schools who will retire in June, was honored yesterday at a testimonial luncheon at which eight leaders of teacher groups here, including Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, paid tribute to his fifty-year career in the public school system.

THE DALLES, Ore., May 16 -- A new type of Indian warfare will be carried into a Senate subcommittee hearing Monday when members of the Yakima Tribe press efforts to force relocation of The Dalles Dam, being built on the Columbia River by the Army Corps of Engineers.

HANOI, May 16 -- The French Government's decision to devalue the piaster by 40 per cent has disturbed the artificial economic balance that previously existed here and affected virtually all aspects of the Indo-China war.

LONDON, May 16 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer returned home today confident that he and Sir Winston Churchill, the British Prime Minister, saw eye to eye on the future of Western Germany. At a parting press conference the German Chancellor revealed that he and Sir Winston discussed yesterday the implications of the Prime Minister's suggestion of a new treaty in the spirit of the Locarno Pact.

THE strange paradox to be noted by the visitor to Hollywood these days is the surface aspect of nothing doing around the studios. After all the New York talk of turmoil over three - dimensional films and wide screens, it is startling to find the Hollywood workshops as quiet as on a Sunday afternoon.

DETROIT, May 16 -- Averell Harriman, former Director for Mutual Security, sharply criticized tonight both Clement Attlee, the leader of the British Labor party, and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, for their recent trans-Atlantic exchange of unpleasantries.

AT the beginning of this chronicle of a senior year in high school, Petra Stewart is such an ugly duckling one wonders how she will ever become a swan by the end. The answer is, she doesn't. Her hair remains wild, her features plain. Her clothes improve only slightly.

Drew Middleton should be applauded for his honest and sober report, "The Hitler Youth Eight Years After" (May 3). But may I point out just a few small errors. Junyvolk should be translated as "young folks."
The yachtlike Roma, Italy's first steamship to bid for the growing Atlantic tourist-class trade, arrived here yesterday on her maiden call.

Only formal approval by the Federal Power Commission of an examiner's report recommending the designation of the New York State Power Authority as the United States agency to develop the hydro-electric potential of the International Rapids Section of the St. Lawrence River is needed now to permit a start on physical construction of the long-discussed St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- Adolf Hitler assured Polish officials personally only eight months before Germany and the Soviet Union attacked Poland in 1939 that he wanted to maintain a strong nationalist Poland, captured Nazi documents showed today.

The International Longshoremen's Association (A. F. L.) was experiencing the initial fevers of reform last week. So explosive are the questions involved and so high are the tensions within the union and, in fact, within the whole waterfront community of New York, that it appears certain that the long-disturbed dockside areas face a period of upheaval,

TEL AVIV -- The morale of tourists of all nationalities in Israel has soared since the introduction in mid-April of a new tourists' rate of exchange of 1.80 Israeli pounds to the dollar instead of the previous rate of 1 pound to the dollar.

Karl T. Compton's excellent plea, "The Case for National Security Training" (May 3), has completely changed my mind. Looking at my three small sons, aged 7, 4 and 1, I realize this will be best for them later on.

SPRING flowering in the woodland garden comes to its climax in May. Already the ferny mounds of Dutchman's breeches (Dicentra cucullaria) are withering away and seed pods hang like small jade pendants along the flower stems.

GENEVA, May 15 -- Prospects for further moves toward creation of fewer market barriers in Europe, or "economic integration" as it was known in now-distant days of the Marshall Plan, have been considerably marked down by contemplation elsewhere on this Continent of the difficulties of Benelux.

NORFOLK, Va., May 16 -- President Eisenhower will enact one of his major campaign promises into law Monday when he signs the controversial measure giving to the states title to the offshore oil resources within the limits of their historic boundaries.
CHICAGO, May 16 (UP) -- George Metkovich's pinch-hit homer with a man on in the seventh inning sparked the Pirates and Murray Dickson to a 3-to-2 triumph over the Cubs today before 9,728 fans.
Women all over the country stepped into furniture and department stores last week and bought Mengel furniture. Their husbands paid the bills.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 16 -- A winning par 3 at the final hole enabled Robert W. Knowles of the Palmetto Golf Club, Aiken, S. C., to retain his title in the annual Walter J. Travis Memorial invitation tournament with a 1-up victory over Gordon Stott of the Nassau Country Club today at the Garden City Golf Club.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 16 (AP) -- The Hollywood Turf Club finally got its meeting started today, four days late, and 44,500 racing fans flocked to the track to see Ali's Gem win the featured $25,000 Golden State Breeders Handicap.

ST. LOUIS, May 16 -- Manager Leo Durocher trotted out the second half of his newly founded two-platoon system as the Giants opened a three-game series against Eddie Stanky's Cardinals tonight before 13,187 highly interested spectators.

* * * Calling a book "badly flawed" because one doesn't care for its writer's social nonconformity reaches a new low in jingoism. If there is any "lack of maturity" in this instance, it is on the part of the reviewer and not the author of "The Southpaw."
WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- The number of American Indians increased by 106,214 in the years between 1900 and 1950, the Commerce Department reported today.

BUSINESS appears to be about ready to settle into a groove for the summer, free of any outstanding concern that can disturb it greatly other than the Korean peace negotiations. President Eisenhower, wrestling with a budget of around $75,000,000,000, of which more than 75 per cent is for direct and indirect defense spending, has succeeded in whittling off several billions for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1954.
DETROIT, May 16 (AP) -- With possibly one or two exceptions the nation's auto makers will introduce few major styling and engineering changes in 1954-model cars.

CAIRO, May 16 -- Through the Middle East the tensions of half a dozen minor "cold wars" obscure the issues of the big one and impede construction of defense for the vital land bridge between Europe and Africa and Asia.

SAVANNAH, Ga., May 16 (UP) -- Six persons, including three Republican party officials, were arrested today on Federal indictments charging attempted selling and buying of postal jobs in the south Georgia area. All six were arraigned and released in $1,000 bond.

A CAMPAIGN is under way by the Metropolitan Motion Picture Club, the largest group of amateur moviemakers in the country, to make the club "a truly representative cross-section of New York City film makers."

Re the article by C. B. Palmer, "Women in Love -- With Modern Gadgets" (May 3): Indeed women, with the free time provided by laborsaving "gadgets" can not only spend more time with their children (husbands, too) while the dishwasher does the dishes or the automatic washer the laundry, but they can be active in their community.

BACH: Unaccompanied 'Cello Suites Nos. 4 and 5; Lillian Fuchs, violist (Decca). Miss Fuchs performs these works by playing them an octave higher than they are written, but they remain deeply impressive, for she is one of America's finest artists. Excellent recording.

THE second selection of painting and sculpture from the collection of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, which has just been placed on view in the galleries of the museum at 1071 Fifth Avenue, effectively carries forward the program outlined by James Johnson Sweeney when he became director.

WHETHER the young girl emigrant forsakes an English village for London (or it might be Columbus, Ohio, for New York), the mother-she-left-behind-her is going to react in pretty much the same way -- with many remonstrances and apprehensions about big-city pitfalls.

TWO years ago the good gray councilors of the pretty city of Stratford (on Avon, of course, and 100 miles southwest of this metropolis) listened indulgently to an enthusiastic young man and then offered him a grant of $50 toward his idea of staging a Shakespearean festival.

THE term "art director" belongs to our time and has a very specific meaning. There were "art advisers" in the past, men like Cranach with the Electors of Saxony and Cellini with Francis I, who presided over all the esthetic and artistic affairs of their patrons.

TREE peonies seem to thrive best in an open sunny location, free from the competition of near-by shrubs or other plants. But some shade is not fatal and, in fact, certain varieties must be shaded from the hot midday sun not only for good growth but also to protect the blossoms.
TULSA, Okla., May 16 -- The Turner Turnpike, one of the West's first nonstop toll highways, was dedicated this afternoon and opened to traffic between Tulsa and Oklahoma City.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, May 17 -- United States jet pilots shot down eleven MIG planes yesterday as savage battles marked fighting in the air and on the ground in Korea. Six enemy jets were damaged. The score was the highest since Sept. 4, 1952, when thirteen MIG's were destroyed and four damaged.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Soviet leaders "past and present" have pinned their hopes of splitting the unity of the free world on economic disagreements between the Western allies, Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said today.

The cry in the Rubaiyat, "I often wonder what the vintners buy, one-half so precious as the stuff they sell," has become a sort of cry of desperation in the vintners trade today. It is, of course, more accurately the liquor trade here.
Mechanical adjustment of 2,500 subway turnstiles is not expected to be an obstacle to a higher transit fare on July 30 if the New York City Transit Authority decides a fare increase is necessary.

OTTAWA, May 16 -- The Canadian Department of External Affairs sought in a statement today to clarify the situation that is reported to have arisen between Canada and the United States over the proposals put forward by the Korean truce negotiators at Panmunjom.

TROY, N. Y., May 16 -- A proposal that the United States prepare for intensive gas warfare was made here tonight by Gen. Brehon Somervell, wartime head of Army supply, in the closing address before the Second Industrial Council at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. General Somervell is president of the Koppers Company of Pittsburgh.

Fordham University is offering an honors plan and a junior year in Paris for its superior undergraduates. This program is designed to give those students who show ability to carry additional work an opportunity to concentrate in the field of their interests on an individual basis.

GUILDFORD, England, May 16 (UP) -- Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., scored her fourth consecutive victory in Europe when she defeated Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, 13 -- 11, 6 -- 1, to win the women's singles title today in the Guildford lawn tennis tournament.

THE history of musical research is studded with good stories, and one of the most fascinating is that of Cecil Sharp, the English musicologist whose interest in British ballads brought him to this country where, to his astonishment, he found the old ballads were better preserved in the Appalachian highlands than they were in Great Britain.

IN a dahlia world which sees the introduction of 100 or more new seedling varieties each year, a new white, straight cactus dahlia, named Florence Chadwick, won more awards in 1952 than any dahlia ever before on record.

JASCHA HEIFETZ'S return visit to Israel brought two sensations. The one, widely but not quiet correctly publicized, concerned the artist's playing of the Richard Strauss sonata in his Haifa and Jerusalem recitals.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- A new directory of labor unions issued by the Department of Labor today estimated membership of United States unions at 16,500,000 to 17,000,000, with nearly 800,000 of the membership in Canada.

GENEVA, May 16 -- The first great debate in more than twenty years over United States tariff policy has an audience in Europe as attentive if not more so than the one at home. It is a pretty wide audience, too. The last time the Republican party controlled the United States Government the Hawley-Smoot tariff of 1930 was presented to the world as the fruits of Congressional labors in this field.
LOUISVILLE, May 16 (AP) -- The field for next Saturday's Preakness at Pimlico probably picked up another starter at rain-splattered Churchill Downs this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- An appeal to communities in this country to check their own juvenile delinquency facts in comparison with those for the nation as a whole was made today by Dr. Martha M. Eliot, chief of the Children's Bureau.

LOS ANGELES -- Anyone headed for this part of the country can work, for the asking, a bonanza lode of maps and detailed tourist information that will take him step by step across the country, tell him where to eat and sleep en route and lead him finally to exactly the abandoned mine or movie studio he wants to see or a specific hill or bay in Lower California where antelope roam or crabs crawl.

Some of the discussion of the proposed revision of the basic trade act in respect to the Philippines has put the emphasis in the wrong place. It has been pointed out that the imposition of American tariffs on Philippine goods, scheduled to begin on a progressive basis next year, will be damaging to the young Philippine economy.

THE heroine of the first story in this generous collection is happily spinning platters and dead-panning commercials in a tiny radio station in Fox, Wyo., when a singing cowboy named Lonesome Rhodes turns up, looking for a job.

In your issue of May 3 Dr. George Sarton, Professor Emeritus of Science at Harvard, presents the case for the Institute of Pacific Relations. He overlooks the fact that in addition to the "rumors" and "malicious reports" of which he speaks there is a 226-page report of the United States Senate Internal Security Committee, which report was unanimously adopted by the four Democrats and three Republicans of that committee.

UP and down the length of the Rockies, nestled here and there in a lake basin or canyon bottom are small resort towns with purely local reputation. Their charm lies chiefly in the fact that, unlike such resorts as Aspen, Colo., or Jackson Hole, Wyo., they are much less commercialized, less expensive, less regimented and more remote from the hectic rush of modern life.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Navy is planning research to determine if it is possible to prepare teeth for filling by using "silent sound waves" instead of a dental drill. Some "preliminary" experiments with two dogs have proved promising, naval dental officials said today.

After President Eisenhower's weekly meeting with his Congressional leaders last Tuesday, Senate Majority Leader Robert A. Taft said to reporters: "The Administration is going to have to decide what they want. I haven't been able to get even a hint of what they will recommend."

WITH each succeeding season color's growing domination of the American amateur photographic scene would appear to be gradually justifying earlier predictions that color photography would one day supplant black-and-white. In the coming months color will take over in a big way to lend further support to this theory.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Perhaps the dominant fact of national political life this week has been the still-rising power and influence of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio. All the week's political implications flow from this circumstance.

ANYONE curious about the life and mores of Jupiterians? Some fascinating -- if not scientific -- information is offered over the Du Mont television network each Saturday at 7:30 P. M. in a program entitled "Johnny Jupiter." For the most part a satirical fantasy, the show features "live actors as earthlings and hand puppets as Jupiterians.

IN a foreword to this absorbing story, Mr. Richter thanks his large public for understanding his over-all purpose -- which, he says, is "not to write historical novels but to give an authentic sensation of life in early America." The present episode (it is really no more than that) is an illustration of the author's method at its best.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- While undergraduate schools of the nation have made long strides in eliminating discrimination against applicants because of race or creed, professional schools have not kept pace in destroying discriminatory barriers. Dr. Andrew C. Ivy, vice president of the University of Illinois on leave of absence, told a meeting today of the national executive committee of the Anti- Defamation League of B'nai B'Rith.

Carnegie Institute of Technology has established a School of Printing Management, to offer the bachelor's degree. To open in July, this school is believed to be the only one of its kind. The course is designed to prepare young men for positions of administrative responsibility in production, design and general management in the graphic arts fields and allied industries.

INTERNATIONAL intrigue for espionage reasons, with murder but a necessary evil, marks the suspense novel. In the classic espionage stories there was a feeling of detachment for the reader as he watched the game of spy, counter-spy and turned-spy played out with deftness and suavity by both sides.

Liverpool's powerful soccer team, with a string of twenty-two straight victories during three visits to this country, will seek to extend its unbeaten streak today at Triborough Stadium at the expense of the American League All-Stars.

ROBERT MONTGOMERY, as he did last year, will use a limited "summer-stock" company as the hot weather replacement for his Monday-night- at-9:30 dramatic shows over N. B. C. television. Mr. Montgomery plans to use four regular performers on the summer schedule of eight shows which starts on July 6. Only one, his daughter, Elizabeth, has as yet been selected.

More pearls were bought last year than any other jewelry component, according to a survey conducted by the Imperial Pearl Syndicate, importers of cultured pearls. Retail jewelry sales last year were more than $1,200,000,000, with necklaces, rings, bracelets, earrings, pins and charms accounting for most of the volume, and many of these items incorporated cultured or simulated pearls, the company said.

CLEVELAND, May 16 -- Despite a decline in demand for electric power, caused by the national cut-back in magnesium production ordered by the Government, production of electric energy in this area this week is continuing level with last week's rate of 8.3 per cent greater than a year ago.

The recent decision by the Treasury Department to increase duties on imports of wool tops from Uruguary, because that country's multiple currency exchange rates are considered a subsidy device, has drawn criticism from foreign traders here.
Three Britons and two Americans now living in Britain have been appointed overseas representatives of the King George VI Memorial Fund of the English-Speaking Union, it was announced here yesterday.

A great shortage of executives is in the making. While there is a large supply of would-be executives -- persons with a hankering for large desks, paneled offices and three-hour lunches -- there are far too few with executive ability and training.

BUENOS AIRES, May 16 -- A plot to assassinate President Juan Peron last Wednesday morning was frustrated as a result of the police arrests of suspected terrorists, Dr. Miguel Vignola, national judge in charge of the investigation of the recent acts of violence, announced today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 16 -- The candidacy of James Daniel Hopkins of Armonk for County Executive of Westchester, the top political job in a county that exceeds many states in wealth and governmental activities, will move a step. forward Thursday.

There are more showy flowers, and there are many flowers more numerous; but of all the wild flowers to be searched out in this general area few are more perfect examples of rare floral beauty than the showy orchis, orchis spectabilis, as the botanists know it.
A timely auction of terrace and garden furniture, sculptures and other decorative outdoor objects is scheduled for Friday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- House of Representatives farm and economy blocs will collide next week in a test on 1954 appropriations, and the agriculture group today claimed victory in advance.

HARTFORD, May 16 -- The first step toward a State Supreme Court test of the constitutionality of a law that changes the boundary lines of the thirty-six State Senate districts has been taken by Connecticut Democrats.

One of the nation's first superpower electric distribution systems is being made ready for operation in the territory served by the huge American Gas and Electric Company. This $870,000,000 utility system operates in Ohio, Indiana, Michigan, Virginia, West Virginia, Kentucky and Tennessee.

THE twenty chapters of this book are as lively as they are instructive, and whoever reads the first will go on through the last. The substance of the book was originally published in THE NEW YORK TIMES and elsewhere, but the author has revised and amplified his material and submitted his revisions to expert critics.

Harvey Breit, in "About Boxers, Beauty -- and Brutality" (May 10) is right when he says boxing is here to stay, brutality or nay. He omitted an obvious solution to the phenomenon of punch - drunk fighters -- namely, compulsory headgear during training and the bout.

THE previous publication of the Holmes - Laski correspondence makes somewhat anticlimactic the appearance of this biography of Harold Laski. It is an extremely sympathetic portrait by a close friend who shared almost all of Laski's political views and prejudices.

Not since the North Korean armies crossed the Thirty-eighth Parallel nearly three years ago have the United Nations and the Communists approached closer to a settlement of the Korean conflict than they did last week. Nevertheless, U. N. truce delegates at Panmunjom were not optimistic. There was reason to believe that the gap still remaining between the Communist and U. N. positions, although narrow, was deep.

One of the most striking things about education in America is the amount of disagreement surrounding it.
