Newsom, associate commissioner of the New York State Education Department, has written a form reminder to a group of educational institutions, including the city colleges, that an oath to support the Federal and State Constitutions is required oy law of those who teach in institutions "whose real property, in whole or in part, is exempt from taxation."

On April 23, 1951, William N. Oatis, Associated Press correspondent in Prague, was putting his car into a garage when three Czech secret agents arrested him. For the next seventy-two days he was held incommunicado in the grey Pankrac Prison. Then he was put on trial on charges of espionage.

WESTERN European railway fares, which are almost uniformly about 3 cents a mile in first class, cheap by United States standards, are even cheaper than that for tourists who take advantage of the special cut-rate tickets which can be bought on this side of the Atlantic before boarding ship or airplane.

OSSINING, N. Y., May 16 -- Historically minded residents of Westchester and western Connecticut remedied today a sixty-four-year oversight by placing a bronze marker on the pauper's grave of "the Leather Man" in Sparta Cemetery on Albany Post Road between this village and Briarcliff Manor.
CHICAGO, May 16 -- Al Weill, manager of Rocky Marciano, said today that he would be satisfied to send the champion against Roland La Starza or Ezzard Charles in September.

THINGS will be humming at the Columbia studio throughout the summer, it was made evident the other day by Harry Cohn, president, and Jerry Wald, executive producer. Some $14,000,000 has been earmarked for the production of eleven first-line pictures between May 25, when the Judy Holliday comedy.

WITH the publication yesterday of the 1953-54 Hotel Red Book. the country's oldest travel directory, the American Hotel Association began the observance of the "Maytime Is Travel Planning Time" promotional program during which hotels throughout the nation will invite the public to become acquainted with the "back of the house" operations.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Senator Prescott Bush, Republican of Connecticut, protested to the Defense Department today against a proposed determination that men between 17 and 18 1/2 need no longer receive deferment from the draft so that they can enlist in the National Guard.
TOKYO, Sunday, May 17 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,616, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Saturday, Korean time:

SHORT histories of France are not lacking on our market -- but the fascination of the subject is inexhaustible. Nor is our interest purely romantic. Europe is not through. We cannot settle world affairs without or against the old Continent.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- Edmund F. Mansure said today that nobody had to have "contacts" to see him about doing business with the Government. The 52-year-old Chicago civil leader and industrialist laid that down as a principle he aimed to follow as head of the General Services Administration.

ST. LOUIS, May 16 (AP) -- Secretary of the Air Force Harold E. Talbott said here today that there appeared to be no prospect of a change in world conditions "that will permit us to eliminate the heavy cost of national defense in our future plans."
MILWAUKEE, May 16 (AP) -- Gen. Nathan F. Twining declared today that if America ever had to act against atomic warfare the defense would begin with long-range bombing of "Communist bases."

PRIMARILY this is the love story of a young English war-widow of Protestant faith who contemplates marriage with a Papist. The widow, Elizabeth, is sensitive and in love with the poetry of living, the Papist a romantic, intelligent die-hard.

The role of photography in the cultural and social life of the community, as well as its value as a hobby, will be the subject of the ninth in a series of ten free art lectures at 6:15 P. M. on Tuesday at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

The New York Community Trust reported yesterday that community trusts in the United States and Canada had resources of $116,167,030, compared with $110,091,128 a year ago. Returns from seventy-six trusts showed that separate charitable funds in their keeping had increased from 972 to 1,062, each with an average value of $109,385.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., May 16 -- Bunching four of its eight hits in a four-run outbreak in the seventh, the Lawrenceville school halted its time-honored foe, the Hill School, 5 to 2, in the feature attraction of the Alumni week-end sports program today.

There were 57,628 cases of poliomyelitis in the nation last year. In the last week, 110 cases already had been reported, an increase of 20 per cent over the same week the year before. No one can predict what the rest of 1953 will bring.

THE "Bug Out" is how the fleeing G. I.'s referred angrily, sometimes fearfully, to their hell-on-wheels retreat down Korea's peninsula when the Chinese Communists rose suddenly out of the northern hills late in 1950 and sent our soldiers and their allies racing for their lives.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Varying and sometimes contradictory appraisals by Cabinet members and others in the last week or so have given Congress and the public a perplexing picture of the Federal budget and tax outlook.

BONN, Germany, May 16 -- Direct negotiations between the German Federal Republic and the Soviet Union to abolish the economic barriers separating West Germany from East and Southeast Europe were proposed today by Dr. Hermann Ehlers, President of the Bundestag and vice chairman of the Christian Democratic Union, West Germany's largest political party.

A program aimed at serving librarians now working in special libraries as either administrators or assistants and persons interested in preparing for positions in special libraries has been approved by the Queens College School of General Studies.

A TOURING reporter picks up diverse items of news and human interest, which do not add up to a tight-knit Sunday article. With the instinct of the squirrel, he hoards them anyhow. Here, then, are some unrelated notes on musical affairs in California and on the Boston Symphony's conductors on tour:

The Navy with its traditional welcome, "Glad to have you aboard," held open house for visitors yesterday on ten ships of the fighting fleet tied up at piers in the metropolitan area for the observance of Armed Forces Day.

A SPECIALIZED national group of amateur photographers who are reputed to shoot fifteen flash lamps underground for every one fired above ground by other amateurs, met at the Camera Club last week to compare notes and swap experiences.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- The Senate Republican leader, Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, said today that the United States had not received its money's worth for the billions thus far appropriated for air power.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Thirty-two new United States District Attorneys have been selected by Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, since he took office on Jan. 20, inquiries at the Department of Justice disclosed today. Some already have taken office and nominations of others are awaiting confirmation by the Senate.

HOUSTON, Texas, May 16 -- The dismissal of two faculty members and the placing on probation of two others has brought into sharp focus the campus discord that poses a threat to the future of Texas Southern University here and to the state's educational segregation policy.
This year's celebration of World Trade Week, which begins nationally today and locally tomorrow, will be held against a background of renewed controversy over this country's foreign economic policy.

ALBANY, May 16 -- The multitude of varied exports and imports that pass through the state's ports each year benefit directly or indirectly virtually every segment of New York's commerce and industry, Harold Keller, State Commerce Commissioner, said today.

ONE of the pleasures of a spring walk in the country this week-end might well be the finding of foamflower (Tiarella cordifolia) in bloom. In spite of the fairylike quality of the flowers, plants are sturdy. It is not necessary to go far afield to enjoy this wild flower, and it also may be grown without difficulty in the home garden by meeting a few requirements.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Business in the Chicago area is maintaining a fast tempo compared with last year, the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago said. But the trend so far is downward, with the exception of March's high production and profits.

FEW stories in the annals of the conquest of the American West can match the dramatic struggle of the Nez Perce Indians to retain their hold on the lovely Wallowa Valley of Oregon. They lost it -- indeed, they never really had a chance to hold it once Ulysses S. Grant signed the eviction order -- but they went down with courage and dignity.
The mushrooming power of atomic weapons is indicated by these comparisons:
FORT WORTH, May 16 (AP) -- The Southwest Conference today spurned Texas Tech and Oklahoma as members, voting to operate under the same membership it has had for twenty-eight years.

No railroad ever had to conform to a more rigid time table than the newly, created New York City Transit Authority. It must meet four crucial deadlines in the next ten weeks if it is to get started on its assigned task of talking over the debt-mired municipal transit system and running it at a fare high enough to pay all operating expenses.

STOCKHOLM -- Tourists who want to find out more about a place than is to be learned on the well worn circuit of palaces, museums and historic sites will find a new sight in Stockholm this summer. This is the city's new subway line, another link in a slowly expanding rapid-transit system.

Before Japanese common stocks can appeal to the broad mass of American investors there must be changes in Japanese laws, said Jacob Bleibtreu on his return last week from a five-week visit to Japan. Before American investors can feel secure about the fate of their investments in Japan, he added, the regulations of the Tokyo Stock Exchange should be tightened.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- When old friends squabble, it is usually wiser to pay attention to the underlying reasons for the spat than to concentrate on the things said in the heat of the argument.

THE warm season conducive to cold cuts is upon us. These savory meats prompt rejoicing on two counts: they lighten the burden of cooking on a hot day and they furnish tastes and textures that charm the gourmet with their wide variety.

FEWER shy youngsters are to be found these days than in the years when childish virtue hinged on being seen but not heard. The child who does suffer shyness, however, suffers acutely. His problem may not be obvious. Indeed, his parents and teachers may delight in his quiet ways.

I WAS much disturbed by the reference of Peter Blake to two of my books in his over-all review of a number of travel books. I am sure that Mr. Blake had kindly intentions, but the only comment he makes about my travel books is based on an outright mistake.

The award of a contract for the installation of a sprinkler and standpipe system at the Port Authority piers in Hoboken, as part of the $8,276,000, project for the initial stage of their construction and rehabilitation, was announced last week after the monthly meeting of the bistate agency's board of commissioners.

In reference to "Goodbye, Central" by Malvine Cole (April 26): Once on a long trip from Syracuse. N. Y., to western Nebraska, my wife and I were nearing our destination and at Bridgeport, Neb., my wife placed a call to the ranch where we were going.
A complete restudy of the nation's military program will be one of the major tasks of the new members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff appointed by President Eisenhower last week.

JONES BEACH, L. I. -- The biggest and most popular state-owned playground in the world is coming out of winter hibernation and preparing to swing into full operation. All indications point to a year bettering the 1952 attendance record of 8,000,000 at Jones Beach.

ISTANBUL, Turkey's "Magic City," will turn back history's pages five centuries on May 29 and begin a ten-day celebration of its seizure by the Ottoman troops of Mohammed II the Conqueror. One feature of the observance will be issuance of twelve commemorative stamps with "Istanbulun Fethi" (Conquest of Istanbul) and the dates 1453 and 1953 inscribed on each.
PABLO PICASSO has variously confounded the public. For example, his lightning changes of style have left connoisseurs startled.

The strike of Local 1250, Distributive, Processing and Office Workers, C. I. O., against the two Hearn's department stores continued yesterday with each side giving different pictures of its effectiveness.

HANOVER, N. H., May 16 -- Robert L. Allen has been appointed to a new position as assistant secretary of Dartmouth College, working on public relations, John Sloan Dickey, president of the college announced today.

Conservation of natural resources, generally considered as a proper subject only for people in rural areas, was brought up to date yesterday from an urban point of view by speakers at an all-day conference held by the Staten Island Museum at St. George.

If poliomyelitis is not yet controlled it is partly because of time-consuming laboratory methods of research and almost prohibitive expense. Last week the United States Public Health Service announced that polio research would henceforth proceed rapidly because Drs. C. P. Li and Morris Sehaeffer of its Virus and Rickettsia Laboratories in Montgomery, Ala., had succeeded in adapting the third of the three known strains of polio virus to mice.

Plans are being advanced for the first-night performance of the Sadler's Wells Ballet on the night of Sept. 29 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over to raise funds for the English-Speaking Union. Mrs. Lewis W. Douglas, wife of the former United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James, is chairman of the benefit committee, and Mrs. Landon K. Thorne Jr. is vice chairman.

Drew Middleton pays tribute in "The Hitler Youth Eight Years After" (May 3) to the Hitler Youth's "antique [fighting] valor." As an interrogation officer of the First United States Army during the last unpleasantness, I want to put the record straight as far as Mr. Middleton's otherwise superb article is concerned. * * *

MANY phases of bridge skill cannot be learned from books, but the technique of handling any particular suit holding can be The situations are not few, but they are few enough so that a player who is sufficiently interested and studious can learn and remember them all.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The United States Government has taken initial steps toward vesting about $56,000,000 in blocked assets of the Soviet Union and three satellite nations to make them available for the settlement of private claims against the respective Communist regime.

MILWAUKEE, May 16 -- Curt Simmons pitched perfect baseball for the final eight innings today as he shut out the Braves, 3 to 0, on only one hit to boost the Phils into undisputed posses sion of first place. Lead-off man Billy Bruton hit the first ball Simmons pitched for a single but Curt set down the Braves in one-two-three order the rest of the way.
The position of American agriculture needs basic reviewing. No realistic appraisal of the current situation has recently appeared.

Attempts by the financial community to educate the investing community -- actual or potential -- have been becoming more frequent of late. Already there are films on the operations of the New York Stock Exchange, on investment banking and on odd lots.

THREE students of the School of Industrial Art took one-half the New York (city and state) prizes in the 1953 Scholastic - Ansco Photography Awards, sponsored jointly by Scholastic Magazines and Ansco, Binghamton. They are Larry Silverstein and Stuart Umin, seniors, and Sidney Kaplan, a junior.

CASH and merchandise prizes worth $12,000 are offered in the 1953 Ansco Color Snapshot Contest, just announced by William Balch, Ansco's general sales manager. The contest opens June 15, deadline Sept. 30. In addition to the grand prize of a new Ford automobile for the best Ansco Color transparency in the show, there will be fifty prizes in each of two classes, scenics and human interest groups.

LOS ANGELES, May 14 -- New York racketeers are using Southern California as a country retreat in which to obtain a degree of social acceptance while plotting new maneuvers in the realms of crime and politics, the California State Crime Commission reported this week.

The Earhart Plant Research Laboratory of the California Institute of Technology has made a discovery that holds out hope for the cultivation of food plants in the dry and semi-arid zones of the earth.

HARTFORD, May 16 -- Sounding a warning against overemphasis on specialization in education, Dr. Albert C. Jacobs became president of Trinity College today, the fourteenth since the liberal arts institution was established 130 years ago.

MADRID, May 16 -- United States circles said today that Ambassador James C. Dunn had informed Spanish Foreign Minister Alberto Martin Artajo that the executive branch of the United States Government had decided to recommend the Congress reallocate $125,000,000 already earmarked for aid to Spain, in addition to an unspecified sum for the 1954 fiscal year, to implement agreements now being negotiated.

THE return to yesterday -- though a yesterday that is not now and perhaps never will be wholly free of the imprint made by the twenty years of Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman -- is now well advanced in bureaucratic Washington.
CINCINNATI, May 16 -- Rabbi Albert A. Goldman of Yonkers, N. Y., has been chosen to serve as a spiritual leader of Isaac M. Wise Temple Congregation.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., May 16 -- The State Association of Young Republican Clubs gave its support today to the movement calling upon Governor Dewey to run for a fourth term in 1954.

A Contributor to your Sunday section, Arthur Maynard, offers rather controversial an observation concerning the recent Academy Award tendered Shirley Booth. Because the role of Lola Delaney initially was a stage creation of Miss Booth's, the contention is made that her work should have been ruled ineligible for the "Oscar" competition.

THE death of Claude McKay five years ago created, I am now inclined to believe, a vacuum. McKay was a man who didn't hesitate to fight for justice and for his Negro people and who yet possessed a gentleness that makes him seem all the more rare in these days of dogmatic hatred and egocentric bitterness.

O NLY the day before Mr. Hemingway won the Pulitzer award we tried to get hold of him down in Cuba. The message came back that he was on a two-week trip. so that Hem was not "at home" for any celebrations.
BOSTON, May 16 -- Boston is looking at New Orleans for a solution to the problem of revitalizing its port.
WHEN I got back from my second voyage around South America I found my brother waiting at the pier with a two-ton-truck. He had correctly anticipated the extent of my collection of "souvenirs."

Business is turning stronger in department stores in the district, and volume for the week is estimated at 5 per cent above the 1952 period. The undercurrent of good business that had been apparent between Jan. 1 and March 15 has reappeared and merchandisers are cheerful on the outlook for further gains.

ERWIN ROMMEL, one of the great masters of mobile warfare in World War II, never achieved the ultimate success his talents seemed to merit. But the German field marshal did win in Germany and abroad "such glamour as can wear sheer triumph out" and a military reputation which seems as secure as any on the German side.

THE question every right-thinking American who visits England during the Coronation season will be asking himself is this: How can I further Anglo - American relations while, at the same time, remaining one up (a) on the British, (b) on my fellow travelers?

An increasing number of school systems in the United States are changing their report cards or seeking other ways to report pupil progress to parents. Some reasons for this trend were offered last week by two Professors of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University.

The memoirs of former President Harry S. Truman, covering the eventful years between 1945 and 1953 when he was responsible for carrying World War II to a successful conclusion and for framing the policies by which the United States sought general peace and security, will be published serially in THE NEW YORK TIMES, it was announced yesterday.

Last week the American Graphological Society installed as its president Dr. Malford W. Thewlis, eminent geriatrician and founder and secretary of the American Geriatrics Society. Dr. Thewlis is probably the first medical doctor to be elected to the presidency of any graphological society.

THROUGH the years Susan Ertz has provided us with excellent entertainment; competent pictures of the English scene in peace or war a kindly estimate of human nature, a due regard for convention and the nuances of class.
LANCASTER, Pa., May 16 (AP) -- Joe Walker, star sprinter, sparked LaSalle College to a successful defense of its Middle Atlantic collegiate track and field crown today.

I SEE where Harry Sylvester reviewing my book "The Southpaw," says at the end that the book is "flawed" by certain remarks concerning the war against Korea. He says prob ably I will think different after I am "finished growing up."

Hearings have begun in Washington on President Eisenhower's proposal to reorganize the Department of Agriculture. This is the second of six reorganization plans this Administration has sent to Congress and it is the first that is controversial. If political or self-serving opposition does not succeed in blocking the plan it will take effect early next month.

YONKERS, May 16 -- R. L. Craig's favored Wilmington's Star, driven by Jimmy Cruise, put on a stirring stretch rush tonight to win the featured pace of the Grand Circuit program at Yonkers Raceway. Dwight Wilcox' Dandy Dick, handled by Dick Wilcox and the fastest finisher of all, came on the outside for second money.

An estimated 1,250,000 New Yorkers got an impressive capsule demonstration of the might of American armed forces yesterday when 25,000 marchers swept down Fifth Avenue in the fourth annual Armed Forces Day Parade.

MEDIA, Pa., May 16 (AP) -- Arthur E. Pew Jr.'s Irish Double notched his eleventh triumph of the season today in capturing the Rose Tree Plate, a two-mile run over brush, at the Rose Tree Fox Hunting Club's spring race meeting.
Despite its increasing military strength, the Republic of Korea Army will not be able to defend itself alone against communism for a long time to come, its Chief of Staff declared yesterday.

Retailers continued to be optimistic about the coming months and placed orders in the wholesale market here last week, according to McGreevey, Werring Howell, resident buying office. Fall activity was good in infants' girls' and boys' lines.

A tornado has been tracked from its formation for fifty miles with a radar-movie camera by Glenn E. Stout, senior meteorologist for the Illinois State Water Survey At a recent meeting of the American Meteorological Society he displayed a series of photographs of the radarscope tornado pictures.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 16 -- Ch. Hardway Welcome Stranger, a bright red 4-year-old smooth dachshund owned and handled by Mrs. John W. Cross Jr. of Wilton, Conn., became best in show today in the Ladles' Kennel Association of America event that opened the all-breed season in the metropolitan area.
PHILADELPHIA, May 16 (UP) -- The Tigers today defeated the Athletics, 6 -- 3, for their longest winning streak of the season -- two games -- and their first series victory of the year.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- Africa is going on exhibition shortly at Bulawayo in Southern Rhodesia, in the biggest thing of its kind that this continent has ever seen. The exhibitors will be the seventeen countries, colonies and protectorates of the subcontinent, roughly Africa south of the equator.
The future of the International Longshoremen's Association as an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor rests now in the hands of the A. F. L.'s powerful executive council.

UTICA, N. Y., May 16 (AP) -- The Northern New York Methodist Conference criticized today what it called "the extreme and unfair methods" of the McCarthy and Velde Congressional investigating committees.
PHILADELPHIA, May 16 -- Pennsylvania's athletic director. Francis T. Murray, who squabbled with the football coach. George Munger, over schedule-making several weeks ago, was discharged today.

IN the year 1839, fifty-four free Africans. including three female children, kidnapped in their own country and sold as slaves to Portuguese and Spanish pirate traders, revolted against their oppressors on board the Spanish schooner La Amistad off the coast of Cuba.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 16 -- Yale placed first in only three of sixteen events and tied in a fourth but was able to register a rousing triumph as the nineteenth edition of the Heptagonal Games was held at DeWitt Cuyler Field today. It was balance that tilted the scales for the Elis, who tallied points in twelve of the events.

New York University's School of Law announced yesterday the national winners of the twenty Elihu Root-Samuel J. Tilden Scholarships, valued at $6,600 each. The scholarships are awarded annually to two outstanding college men from each of the ten Federal judicial circuits.

WASHINGTON. May 16 -- The staff of the Senate Armed Services Committee was directed today to investigate what Senator John W. Bricker, Republican of Ohio, had assailed as "secret" and "illegal" agreements permitting the trial in foreign courts of United States service personnel stationed abroad.

A VISITOR to the local Fox Movietone Studios last week would have found a scene strongly suggesting a movie within a movie. Vivified below a semi-circle of baby spotlights, a makeshift section of a bedroom in a corner of Stage 1 was enclosed by a small battery of technicians, prior to a final "take."

The combination of higher freight rates, economies resulting from the use of large amounts of new cost-saving equipment and a much less severe winter than in 1952 helped raise earnings of the nation's Class 1 railroads -- those with revenues of $1,000,000 or more annually -- to a peacetime record of $186,000,000 in the first quarter of 1953.

HIS voice was powerful. Sitting in an anchored boat he could make it carry across the water to a large crowd standing on the beach. This was his customary teaching voice -- the cases where he found it necessary to raise it to a higher pitch are noted.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 16 -- The Tunisian Nationalist spokesman at the United Nations said today that the movement was not anti-Jewish, and challenged the French to permit an international investigating body to see whether "our Jewish brothers" were being attacked.

ALTHOUGH ballet dancing has long been regarded as one of the essential elements of the big Broadway musical, Michael Kidd has carried it one step further in "Can-Can." His swift and tumultuous ballets dramatize the work more vividly than the score or the book.

MEXICO CITY -- Ambitious plans for complete revamping of the Mexican tourist industry are now in preparation. The main objectives are to lower prices and to improve services. Worried by the drop in the number of visitors during the first three months of this year, the Government has appointed a new director of tourism, Gustavo Ortiz Hernan, and has given him authority to reorganize the whole industry.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, moved today for possible perjury charges as a result of conflicting testimony given by Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City and Anthony M. (Tony Cheese) Marchitto, waterfront union leader.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- In the wake of the Government's action this week in taking the Lattimore case to the United States Court of Appeals, speculation arose here as to the future course and prospects of the perjury case against the Johns Hopkins University professor.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- Representative John L. McMillan, Democrat of South Carolina, was cleared today by a Federal judge of charges of violating Federal law in leasing land from the Department of the Interior. Judge T. Blake Kennedy commented that Mr. McMillan had been advised by "able and skilled counsel" that he was not violating the law.

Religious leaders were called upon yesterday to assume the initiative in "vigorously opposing all those pessimistic forces that deny the possibility of achieving human solidarity through the United Nations."

CAMDEN, N. J., May 16 -- The Belair Stud's Golden Gloves and Joseph Gavegnano's Joey Boy thrilled a crowd of 32,366 at Garden State Park today when they finished a nose apart in the twelfth running of the $20,000 added Valley Forge Handicap.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 16 -- The twentieth anniversary of the Tennessee Valley Authority Act will be celebrated throughout the seven states of the T. V. A. region for a week, beginning Monday.

MOODUS, Conn. -- Within the past few years the state of Connecticut, once dependent upon its beaches, inland hotels and scenic highways to attract summer visitors, has found that a relatively new vacation facility, the adult vacation camp, is responsible for the presence of an increasing number of sojourners.

PARIS, May 16 -- Striking merchant marine officers and sailors in Marseilles. France's largest port, voted tonight to resume work tomorrow morning. However, in the Atlantic port of Le Havre, where the strike began nineteen days ago, the seamen still held out.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 16 -- The Turkish Government is drafting basic legislation, with the help of an American petroleum consultant, to guarantee equality of treatment to foreign companies that undertake to develop this country's petroleum resources.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- It was a most unsatisfactory fight from every standpoint and everyone was bilked in one way or another -- Rocky Marciano, Jersey Joe Walcott, the paying customers, the non-paying television customers, the television sponsors and the promoting International Boxing Club. It wasn't a fraud, mind you, but it might just as well have been.

The annual tulip festival at St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church in-the-Bouwerie, as folksy as a church social in Struthers, Ohio, home town of its rector, drew hundreds of its lower East Side neighbors to the church yard yesterday.

A few years ago Drs. Gordon Marsh and H. W. Beams of State University, Iowa City, Iowa, succeeded in producing two-headed flatworms. The doctors cut off the head and tail and then passed a light electrical current through the regenerating pieces in agar gel.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., May 16 -- Former President Truman called on the nation today to remember that the United States had taken a position as leader in the free world's struggle for peace and that this position could be continued only if this nation maintained an armed force strong enough to back up its policies.
Three persons were injured yesterday morning when a truck hit three parked cars after a collision with another car in West Street, near Morton, the police of the Charles Street Station reported.

TODAY is Lilac Sunday at the Arnold Arboretum, Jamaica Plain, Mass. The grounds will be open from sunrise to sunset so that the public may see the lilacs as well as other ornamental shrubs and trees at the height of their bloom.
While I agree with Dr. Sumner H. Slichter in "We Can Have Peace and Prosperity" (April 26) that the United States can have both these things, I would like to point out a fallacy in his argument.
TULSA, Okla., May 16 (AP) -- A new electric hand with fingers that indicate how to draw more oil from the earth was shown today to the International Petroleum Exposition.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Navy's invincible eight retained the sprint championship of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges today in the first major regatta held on the Potomac.

The moviegoing public, perhaps unconsciously sharing the film industry's own grim-lipped concern about the future of the cinema theatre vis-a-vis television, has rallied nobly to the siren call of 3-D.

OYSTER BAY, L. I -- This peaceful North Shore hamlet is more than the shrine and burial place of Theodore Roosevelt, and without detracting a whit from the reverence in which his name is held, townspeople will prove the point during Oyster Bay's 300th birthday celebration next month.

RAIN and more rain has been as much a cause of concern for the peony lover as for gardeners in general. Still, what looked like an extremely late and miserable peony season as recently as May 1 now begins to look like a normal one.
THE brooding, enigmatic and mystic world of Sibelius is admirably evoked in a new recording of that composer's Lemminkainen Suite by Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra (Columbia).

TWO aspects of Chaim Gross' art -- sculpture and watercolor -- are represented in a current exhibition at the Jewish Museum. The former are energetic figure groups, writhing, in wood and in stone, totems dedicated to natural forces.

MARTYN GREEN will take over the role of Mr. Tarleton in "Misalliance" tomorrow night from Barry Jones, who is off to make a movie in Hollywood. Yes, that's right -- the bouncing underwear manufacturer in Bernard Shaw's comedy will be played henceforth by the operatic Mr. Green who for thirty years has been charming the little tomtits out of the willows with his singing of Gilbert and Sullivan.

EDMUND WILSON'S literary intelligence is no longer a matter we need question. By degrees over the past thirty years we have come to recognize it as one of the five or six finest to appear in this country in modern times, and one of the last to remain oriented in the great tradition of the humanist man of letters, the line of Boileau, Sainte-Beuve, and Taine.

SEATTLE, Wash., May 16 -- one of the nation's most prolonged conservation controversies has just been put under study by a committee appointed by Gov. Arthur B. Langlie of Washington. It involves the size and use of Olympic National Park, a wilderness area somewhat larger than Rhode Island on the Olympic Peninsula to the west of this city.

OPPORTUNITIES to hang photographs, the goal of most serious photographers, have been increasing steadily in this city. Currently and within the next two to three weeks, about a dozen shows will be on display in various parts of town.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 16 -- The Rutgers varsity track team defeated New York University, 84 -- 54, in the stadium today.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Seven employes of the Department of Agriculture will receive on Tuesday Distinguished Service Awards for research and administrative leadership.
CLIO, the Muse of History, will be found dead tomorrow morning at the foot of Mount Olympus, and Richard Armour killed her.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 11 -- No matter what it is called -- "banditry" by the Conservative Government, or "guerrilla defense" by the Liberal Opposition -- the fighting in Colombia in the last five years adds up to a civil war of heavy casualties and unbelievable eruelty.

The men's jewelry industry faces a difficult transition period if Government contracts taper off and civilian buying continues at present levels, according to Toby Stern, president of Jacques Kreisler Corporation, North Bergen, N. J., maker of watch bracelets, tie bars and cuff links.

CAIRO, May 16 -- The "strong man" of Egypt's revolutionary regime said tonight negotiations for settlement of the dispute over the Suez Canal zone had broken down because Britain sought to impose terms that would have continued the British occupation under a new guise.
May I add a few precisions to the explanation of your "indomitable archivist" concerning, the French film with the strange title, "Fanfan La Tulipe," which is now being shown.

AT the end of H. E. Jacob's interesting report on German letters, he asks why German publishers shun the works of Emil Ludwig and suggests that it might be because he told "his former compatriots too many bitter truths."

A DISTINGUISHED biochemist who believes in trespassing, Roger .J. Williams, has already stepped outside the broad boundaries of his own field in a previous book, "The Human Frontier," and in the present volume he does so again to examine what he calls "the uniformity idea."

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- House investigators reported today that the European defenses of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization would be "inadequate" until European nations "believe in and are willing to organize and finance adequate logistic support."

Stuyvesant Community Center, in Albany Houses. Brooklyn, is relatively new as an inter faith community organization, yet it received four awards in the last year because of work done with neighborhood gangs.
SEATTLE, May 16 (UP) -- Washington's varsity crew stroked to a seven-length victory over California's eight to give the Huskies a sweep on Lake Washington today.
YOUR analysis of the status of discussion on TV in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday, brings to light a point of view which has long needed airing.

COINCIDENTAL with the first burst of real sunshine in recent days news arrived from the southlands concerning those outdoor historical dramas which have taken to dotting the landscape lately. Although one of them, Kermit Hunter's "Forever This Land," dealing with the life of young Abe Lincoln, and presented at New Salem State Park, Ill., has been discontinued, the other five major ventures will be in business again.

The N. B. C. Summer Symphony Orchestra gave another in its series of concerts at the Belasco Theatre yesterday afternoon under the direction of Frank Brieff, conductor of the Bach Aria Group and of the New Haven Symphony.

THE death last year of Josephine Tey was quite possibly the most serious loss which the mystery field has suffered since the abrupt interruption of "The Mystery of Edwin Drood." Most of the deceased masters died well after the period of their best work, while Miss Tey was in the prime of her production.

The Fordham baseball team overwhelmed Manhattan, 11 -- 2, yesterday at Fordham Field. The Rams collected their twelfth triumph in fourteen starts while it was Manhattan's twelfth loss against four victories.

MILFORD, Pa. -- A new service for the week-end canoeist has been instituted here at the end of the Milford-Montague bridge which carries U. S. 206 across the Delaware. Modern metal canoes are available for the run through the Water Gap, with a pick-up service at the end of the route to return canoe and canoeists to the Milford base.

It is a well known fact that during the airlines' two-decade history the industry has made steady, almost interruption free, improvements in its equipment, speed routes, airports, flight personnel, frequencies of schedules and many other factors vital to the huge business of flying passengers, mail, air express and varied tonnages of air freight.

EPH WHEELER'S mistake was to wander down one of New Bedford's dark streets. The next thing the farm boy knew he had been shanghaied aboard a full-rigged sailing vessel with a full head of canvas set for a whaling expedition in the South Atlantic.

LONDON -- The Coronation visitor who intends to drive a car in London this season will do well to approach the matter in the spirit of adventure. For the sprawling capital on the Thames presents problems to the motoring visitor under the best of conditions, and what it will be like in the crowded Coronation period is anyone's guess.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The State Department declared today that the release of William N. Oatis after about two years of imprisonment had removed "one of the obstacles" to better United States-Czechoslovak relations. It promised to consider lifting certain commercial and diplomatic sanctions against the Prague Government.

THE Jen SuperStrobe 110-watt-second Portable Electronic Flash, with a daylight color guide number of 55, Super XX guide number 350, is announced by Jen Products Sales Company, 419 West Forty-second Street. Powered by two 225-volt dry cell batteries with a capacity of 3,000 flashes, the unit charges in three to five seconds and is enclosed in a hip case.

Brooklyn College, behind the six-hit pitching of Bill Anderson, defeated Hofstra, 6 -- 0, at the Flatbush diamond yesterday. The victory was the fourth for the Kings-men against three losses in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference. Hofstra is 6 -- 4.

Higher taxes, serious strikes and Government controls over production, prices and distribution presented the nation's manufacturers with major problems and clamped rather sereve res traints on their operations and profits last year.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., May 16 -- Cranford High captured only two open events, but scored 30 points on its team depth to win the seventh annual invitation interscholastic track and field meet at Winton J. White Stadium today. Thomas Jefferson High of Elizabeth, N. J., the defender, did not compete.

WHEN Pierre Monteux conducts Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande" at the Metropolitan Opera next season the leading parts probably will be sung by Nadine Conner and Theodor Uppman. The production will be a milestone in the career of each singer.

ALL at once come three recordings of Mahler's Symphony No. 1 -- from Vox, with the Pro Musica Symphony of Vienna under Jascha Horenstein; from Vanguard, with the Symphony Orchestra of Radio Berlin under Ernest Borsamski; and from Urania, with the same orchestra and conductor.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 16 (UP) -- The French High Command announced tonight that Communist-led Vietminh forces had launched a "massive" new assault against a French bastion less than thirty miles south of here.

Until recently scientists assumed that we see things around us in three dimensions because we have two eyes separated by just the right distance, which is two and a half inches. The two different images are combined by the brain. According to Dr. T. R. Murroughs, writing in the Journal of the American Optometric Association, binocular vision is now considered merely a check on other cues.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 16 -- The Bach Choir of Bethlehem was the first chorus in America to present a complete rendition of Bach's Mass in B Minor. Its initial performance was at its first festival in 1900. Today, at its forty-sixth, it repeated that work, whose fame it has helped to establish in this country.

The past seven days have been Armed Forces Week and yesterday, throughout the country, young men and women paraded in celebration of Armed Forces Day. The designation of this occasion was made originally to replace the various celebrations, such as Army Day and Navy Day, and to emphasize the essential unity of our forces.
An accredited flower show will be a new feature for the twenty-eighth annual meeting of the Garden Club of New Jersey on Wednesday and Thursday. The place this year is The Inn, Buck Hill Falls, Pa.

Fortunate is the company whose operations provide it with a reliable barometer of its own business prospects for a year or more ahead. The Raymond Concrete Pile Company, a fifty-six-year-old construction concern with projects around the world, has such a barometer and last week it was forecasting good times to come.

Milk, meat, albumen, bacteria, viruses, lungs, hearts -- all are protein. Wherever there is life there is protein. Protein is of fairly recent origin, considering the hot state of the earth in the beginning. How the proteins and therefore life originated has puzzled biologists and chemists for generations.

Stock prices kept marking time last week as Government spokesmen sought to lay the groundwork for possible by-passing of any tax reduction until the budget is balanced. And the Administration will try this week to clarify its position on these matters.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Charles E. Wilson reviewed today his first Armed Forces Day parade as Secretary of Defense and General of the Army Omar N. Bradley reviewed his last as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- President Eisenhower was reported today to be ready to crack down on officials who might resist the $5,000,000,000 cut proposed last week in Air Force funds. Con gressional leaders who have talked to the President say they expect him to devote part of his radio report to the nation Tuesday night to his Administration's program for the Air Force.

A NUMBER of sportsmen's groups, especially in the densely populated Eastern states, are showing an increased interest in landowner-sportsman programs, and the next few months will see considerable pressure applied to the conservation agencies of the states that have been lax in the initiation of a "workable" program.

" We have had three Eighth Armies in Korea," Lieut. Gen. Anthony C. McAuliffe said here last night, "the one that went in originally, another that replaced it starting in April, 1951, and the one that is there now."

With the approach of summer, when the so-called fad of going hatless really takes on the appearance of a general practice among the males of this country, this would seem to be no time for a story about a hat manufacturer.
MODESTO, Calif., May 16 (AP) -- Georgetown University's great relay team won the distance medley event in the California Relays tonight in 10:03.5 -- the fastest time in the country this year.

NUREMBERG, Germany, May 16 -- Thin and pale, William Nathan Oatis, Associated Press correspondent, returned to the free world today from Czechoslovakia's Pankrac Prison, where for two years he was so cut off from outside news that "I did not even know Stalin had died."

MANILA, May 15 -- Opposed by all the resources of a strong and ruthless political machine, supporters of Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo for the Presidential nomination on the Liberal party ticket realized today they have a tough, uphill battle to win the nomination from President Elpidio Quirino at the party convention May 24.

One of the many ships open to visitors on Armed Forces Day yesterday had an especially warm welcome for children, and many of its crew gave up precious liberty in the city to remain aboard and show children around their destroyer escort, the George E. Davis.

Azaleas are one of the flowering shrubs which are widely grown in both the North and the South. May is the big month for bloom in this part of the country and those who do not have any in their garden may still see the native kind, pinxter flower or wild honeysuckle, just starting to open along the parkways and country roads.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 16 -- With perfect weather prevailing, twenty-three skippers enjoyed their first good breeze of the pre-Y. R. A. season off Larchmont Yacht Club breakwater today. Six Classes sailed the five and a half mile course in a fine southeast wind.

The National Ski Association of America yesterday concluded its forty-fifth convention -- the first ever held in this city -- at the Prince George Hotel Today representatives from 469 ski clubs are leaving for their homes with the belief that skiing in the United States will continue to boom and America will make a fine showing in the-world championships in Sweden next winter.

SINCE his European hegira began John Huston has so arranged his professional life that it has certainly been active and varied, to say nothing of its resounding commercial success. From London he dived deep into the adventurous tropical locations of "The African Queen" and before the film was out he was nosing around Montmartre, engrossed in his task of bringing the half-world of Toulouse-Lautrec to the screen in "Moulin Rouge."
Dr. William Jansen, who was recently elected to his second six-year term as Superintendent of Schools, will be honored Monday evening, May 25, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The fates that seem to protect little boys in serious falls enabled four to survive in an unusual series of high tumbles here yesterday.

THE changing facade and interiors of the American home are illustrated by the pictures on these pages. They show a farmhouse built in 1745, restored in 1921 (and accidentally destroyed in 1942), and a contemporary house built on the same site and foundations within the past year.

IN his review of the new edition of Giovanni Verga's novel, "The House by the Medlar Tree." Paolo Milano re marks that "the American reader has been invited to discover Verga at least twice." May I call the attention of Mr. Milano and the American reader to a third invitation.
A FRUIT tree fit for any garden plot is the fig tree, best planted in May. Highly prolific, from August until frost, it yields a fruit which enriches the dinner table for weeks.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 16 -- Princeton's 150-pound varsity crew captured the Joseph Wright Trophy, emblematic of the national lightweight rowing championship, in record time on Carnegie Lake today.

IN his earlier book, "World Communism Today," Martin Ebon demonstrated his special knowledge in this general field. In his new volume he has written considerably less than a full biography but something more than a biographical sketch of Malenkov.

BOSTON, May 16 (AP) -- Johnny Gonsalves, 138 1/2 pounds, of Oakland, Calif., received an unpopular split decision over Paddy DeMarco, 135 1/4, of Brooklyn in their ten-round lightweight bout tonight at Mechanics Building. DeMarco was the aggressor from start to finish but only one of the judges voted in his favor.

In as handsome a performance as any horse-park aficionado could ask for, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Native Dancer yesterday won the $32,150 Withers Mile at Belmont Park. It was a fluid-drive operation in which the gray colt scored with four lengths to spare as he clicked off the eight furlongs in a brisk 1:36 1/5.

WHY "this book," as the author over and over described it in his hopeful "Advertisement to the Reader," never became an actual book until now one cannot imagine. And it is agreeable at last to see this liveliest of all French colonial chronicles taken, by hand of Richebourg Gaillard McWilliams, out of the glass case where it has been shut up for two and a quarter centuries.
WHITE HOUSE and Pentagon, Congress and the public once again are struggling with the riddle of our times: What kind of defense in the Atomic Age?

One may disagree with the specifics of Clement Attlee's criticism of the American Constitution (TIMES editorial, May 14) and at the same time admit that the present working arrangements between the Executive and the Congress in the field of foreign affairs leave a great deal to be desired.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Department of the Interior is seekink to tighten the administration of a provision in the Reclamation Law that, according to the new Republican leadership, has been abused to foster a public power monopoly and impose the Federal Government's will on local organizations and communities.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- Helped by five unearned runs in the first inning, Bob Porterfield pitched the Senators to a 6-0 victory over the Browns today for his second straight shutout and his fourth triumph in a row.

An experimental program that sends employment consultants to four city high schools to advise job-hunting seniors will be completed this year well ahead of June graduations, Anthony Fantaci consultant in the employment division of the State Department of Labor, has announced.

AN irate member of the Automobile Club of New York has up and written the club to complain of the terrible things passengers do to drivers. The letter-writer complains, first of all, of drivers who use the rearview mirror to look at themselves instead of the road behind.

TOKYO, May 16 -- A test of the Communists' intentions to back their growing "peace offensive" with deeds as well as words ended this week in Korea without decisive results. The prospects were not encouraging.
National Maritime Day, which will be celebrated Friday, will emphasize this year the importance of the American merchant marine as the fourth arm of defense.
The Yankees yesterday found new reason to respect the White Sox and considerable cause for feeling disgusted with themselves.
Joseph Stalin, in his last important policy pronouncement, assured the Communist world five months before his death:

HARDLY a day goes by in the course of investigations into subversive activity, organized crime, political skulduggery and whatnot but that a witness refuses to answer questions on the ground that he may incriminate himself. The mere claim of the privilege may spot him on the front page.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 -- A passed ball in the last half of the ninth inning gave Pennsylvania's baseball team a 2-1 victory over Columbia today. The triumph enabled the Quakers to take first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League race.

The Spence-Chapin Adoption Service will be the beneficiary of two previews of the new motion picture, "The Story of Gilbert and Sullivan," on Wednesday night and the night of May 25 at the Bijou Theatre.

TOKYO, Sunday, May 17 -- There was speculation here today that the three-day interval in the Korean truce negotiations granted at the request of the United Nations Command was intended to permit further consultation among representatives of the United Nations powers in the United States and at the Tokyo headquarters of Gen. Mark W. Clark, the United Nations commander.

WATER appeals to everyone, young and old. The small fry spend hours trying to catch the unfortunate polliwogs that breed there and in other aquatic activities usually disapproved of by their elders. But these same elders derive just as much pleasure from water, although in a different way.

No one ever went aloft in an airplane just to count bows, sterns and decks of the metropolitan pleasure boat fleet. But if this were done the amazing area on one of Barnegat Bay's tributaries known as Forked River would be found to have the largest concentration of power cruisers and inboard utilities of any of the nearby harbors and anchorages.
ANDOVER, Mass., May 16 -- Moses Brown ended Andover's supremacy by pacing a field of twelve prep schools in the fourteenth annual New England interscholastic track meet today.

CINCINNATI, May 16 -- The benching of Gil Hodges, a possibility for several days, became a fact today. Manager Chuck Dressen, after today's game with the Redlegs had been rained out, announced that the big first baseman, in a woeful batting slump, would not start in either game of tomorrow's double-header.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Salary and wage incomes are spread more evenly among American workers now than they were in 1939.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- Twenty-two Senators urged the Administration today to set forth the Government's views on problems left unsettled by the offshore oil lands bill.

THE author of "The Conservative Mind" is as relentless as his enemies, Karl Marx and Harold Laski, considerably more temperate and scholarly, and in passages of this very readable book, brilliant and even eloquent. All American thought, whether religious, political, literary, or ethical, should now be preoccupied with the recent intellectual blunder of this learned nation: the mistake in judging the nature and intentions of the present Russian Government.

MANY Southerners and produce dealers would have us believe there are two forms of sweet potatoes -- yams and the regular kinds. Yams are supposed to have a soft moist texture when cooked, while sweet potatoes cook dry. Actually, all are sweet potatoes.

HARTFORD, May 16 -- The Right Rev. Walter H. Gray, Bishop of Connecticut, will inform the Protestant Episcopal diocesan convention here on Tuesda ythat the $1,000,000 development program launched a year ago has yielded in cash pledges more than $787,000.

RECENTLY I was given a present that was very much appreciated -- a tree peony. I had wanted one for years, perhaps because they are so scarce. I have not seen many of them in my life -- not more than a dozen or so. There are two in the town of Durham, N. H. and I have seen one in Dover and, perhaps, a half-dozen in the Arnold Arboretum in Boston.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Though Clement Attlee, the leader of the British Labor party, said some truthful things about the limiting effect of the Constitution of the United States on Executive power to make firm international commitments, his criticisms of the national charter produced the result usual in the circumstances. This is, that while American politicians and lawyers can and often have found fault with the Constitution, they resent it when foreign politicians do so.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Moisture (rain or humidity) and warmth bring out insects. Spray broadleaved evergreens with DDT or lindane to control lacebug; spray basal stems of lilac and rhododendron and foliage of bearded iris with DDT for borers; crabapples with fermate for cedar apple rust. Apply nicotine sulfate to any tip growth and leaves with aphids.

BUENOS AIRES, May 16 -- The bellwether of Argentine policy -- the peronista press -- gave unmistakable evidence this week that all hopes of the United States-Argentine honeymoon developing into a solid marriage have been abandoned. With customary unanimity, the press catigated United States news agencies, which at the same time found themselves a target of official condemnation.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- Unless there is a widespread drought in the next three years, Department of Agriculture officials believe the nation's ranges and pastures will be able to take care of the expanding cattle population -- expected to set a new record by 1955.

A DAMP location often presents discouraging problems to the home owner who is anxious to establish trees on his property. The dampness that accompanies spring rains is a temporary problem but there are, of course, some locations that are almost constantly moist.

GREAT NECK, L. I., May 16 -- Ralph J. Bunche, director of the Department of Trusteeship of the United Nations, will address the students of Great Neck High School in the school auditorium on Monday at 9:15 A. M. His subject will be "The United Nations and World Crisis."

GREAT NECK, L. I., May 16 -- Ralph J. Bunche, director of the Department of Trusteeship of the United Nations, will address the students of Great Neck High School in the school auditorium on Monday at 9:15 A. M. His subject will be "The United Nations and World Crisis."

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith reported last week that a survey of discrimination against Jews in Florida resorts disclosed a pattern, outside the Miami area, making Florida "the most undemocratic state in the nation" in that respect.

This breakwater, built of Florida coral stone, stands looking toward Biscayne Bay on the eastern side of Vizcaya. Dade County Art Museum, the home of the late James Deering, near Miami. The two great dolphins which terminate the ends are by A. Stirling Calder; stone pyramids, fountains and cascades decorate the barge.

BALTIMORE, May 16 (AP) -- Alan T. Clarke's Senator Joe won the $15,000 - added Baltimore Spring Handicap at Pimlico today following the disqualification of Mrs. Jan Burke's Squared Away, who set a new track record in the five and one-half furlong event while scoring by eight lengths.

BOSTON, May 16 -- George Kell, leading batsman in the American League, belted a home run high into the left-field screen today to give the Red Sox a 1-0 victory over Cleveland and move his mates into third place in the standings.

City College's baseball team clinched a tie for the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference title yesterday with a 4 to 1 victory over St. John's University at Macombs Dam Park. The Beavers finished their league schedule with a 9 to 3 mark.

IN the theatre this is the time of prizes and awards. The less theatre we have, the more prizes are awarded Perhaps that is our way of compensating through honor and esteem what we cannot supply in substance. It is certain that among devoted playgoers, the prizes for acting -- even more than those for plays -- create jubilation, discussion, even dispute.

One annual exhibition and a considerable number of group and one-man shows that are opening this week indicate that the art season by no means has ended. The annual is the spring showing beginning tomorrow, of work by the American Abstract Artists at the Hacker Gallery.

CINCINNATI, May 17 -- A bunt single by Gus Bell in the sixth inning of today's second game prevented Carl Erskine from hurling the second no-hit game of his career. As it was, the little Hoosier's one-hitter was a classic of its kind, since only one ball was hit out of the infield.

VIENNA, May 17 -- Reports of Congressional hearings on the Simpson bill to restrict the President's power to negotiate changes in the United States tariff have "created considerable concern abroad," Warren Lee Pierson, head of the United States delegation to the International Chamber of Commerce Congress that opens here tomorrow, said tonight.

CORNWALL - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., May 17 -- Little David, a chestnut gelding owned by the Brook Run Stable of Port Chester, N. Y., won the jumper championship with 19 points in the two-day seventh annual New York Military Academy horse show that ended in the school's arena today.

Arguments will boil around "Effects of Taxation: Investments by Individuals,"* just published by the Harvard Business School. Battles are built into the book because the authors -- J. Keith Butters, Lawrence E. Thompson and Lynn L. Bollinger -- have pranced with hobnailed boots on some of the tenderest seedlings in the garden of finance.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Administration forces looked tonight for a review of the European situation by Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway to help check sentiment in the Congress for a cut in foreign aid below the $5,800,000,000 level set by President Eisenhower.

PARIS, May 17 -- Readers of the French press this week-end might imagine that the great debate started in the British House of Commons last week dealt mainly with France's weakness in Indo-China. Readers of some United States Senators' speeches might imagine that the debate dealt chiefly with the United States Constitution or General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's strategy or Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's influence.
Two tons of scouting equipment -- everything from pots and pans to full uniforms -- were deposited yesterday aboard the Saturnia of the Italian Line for distribution to Italian Boy Scouts.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 17 -- Amid the fighting in Laos, the Vietminh attack on Yenvi, in Vietnam. marked the first time the Communist-led forces had attempted a concentrated blow upon an area of the Tonkin Delta that was strongly fortified by the late Marshal Jean de Lattre de Tassigny.

In their first change of ownership in more than 25 years, three buildings in the Bronx have been sold by the Ebling Company to a syndicate headed by Geisinger Rau, operators. The properties were sold for cash, the deal closing out the realty holdings of the seller.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 17 -- Two young men were under arrest and a third was seriously injured today after a party of picnicking New York University students at Jones Beach was raided by twenty-four young hoodlums.

The annual three-day Adult Education Conference, under the sponsorship of the State Education Department and the University of the State of New York, will open at 9:30 A. M. today at the Statler Hotel.

President Eisenhower has accepted the resignation of George C. McGhee as United States Ambassador to Turkey. In this post Mr. McGhee has performed a useful service. The fact that twenty-five combat-ready divisions today stand guard on NATO's southeastern flank is at least in part a tribute to his entreaties on behalf of Greece and Turkey.

For many years it was the more or less generally established practice among writers of American history to ignore, or pay little attention to, the American industrial revolution as an economic achievement per se. Rather, it was the fashion to treat that phenomenon as a sort of by-product of predatory activities of a group customarily referred to as the industrial robber barons (or, in more magniloquent flights, as the Lords of Creation).

New York Typographical Union 6 (Big Six) held a memorial service yesterday afternoon for 209 of its members who died in the last year and for the thousands who had been members of it in its more than a century of existence.

BONN, Germany, May 17 -- A plan for the reunification of Germany in four steps was advanced today by a prominent politician of the Government coalition as both Government and Opposition spokesmen stressed the importance of unity to Germany and to the peace of Europe.
The young seaman explained to the librarian why he wanted a good book on underwater salvage work.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (UP) -- The Indians scored eight runs in the tenth inning of the second game to rout the Athletics, 9 -- 1, and complete a double-header sweep. They won the first game, 7 -- 3, to snap a five-game losing streak and moved from fourth to third place over the idle Red Sox.

George Cotton, 69 years old, of 347 West 141st Street, was killed when he was struck by a car shortly after midnight as he crossed 141st Street near Amsterdam Avenue. The police said the car was driven by Miss Lena Jones of 344 Beverly Road, Douglaston, Queens.

Twenty years ago this summer the Tennessee River was flowing from its headwaters and tributaries to its junction with the Ohio with only minor artificial impediments. There were five dams along the way. The biggest of these, at Muscle Shoals, could supply water for a dozen big generators, but only two were turning -- and those not all the time.

Bless their hearts, the sports writers still think they can make a boxing match out of a television program. First it was Chuck Davey and Chico Vejar, and then Tommy Collins and Jimmie Carter. Now it is Jersey Joe Walcott and Rocky Marciano. Somehow you've got to admire the scribes' raw courage in the face of such odds.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- Irregular price moves marked pit operations on the Chicago Board of Trade last week, but trade sentiment has been bearish -- and rallies have not been convincing. All wheat deliveries dropped to new crop lows before showing any disposition to recover.

Retail prices have been maintained throughout the Jayson and Excello fall lines of shirts, sports shirts and pajamas, according to Monroe L. Mayer, vice president and general manager of F. Jacobson Sons, Inc. Despite increases in costs the Jayson line has reintroduced a white broadcloth shirt at $2.95.

CHICAGO, May 17 (UP) -- Johnny Klippstein and Warren Hacker held Pittsburgh to four hits in a seven-inning nightcap today as the Cubs blasted the Pirates, 6 -- 2 and 7 -- 3, to sweep a double-header and move into sixth place.
BONN, Germany, May 17 -- Western Germany has established "direct official contacts" with the Soviet Union with the intention of resuming trade relations for the first time in twelve years.
WARSAW, Poland, May 17 -- In this People's Democracy money buys little. The Government now runs all but a few little shops. It knows how to make a fast zloty.

A plot of land containing 94,000 square feet on the west side of Central Avenue, between Marion and Healy Avenues, in Hartsdale, N. Y., has been purchased by David S. Meister from the Healy-Central Construction Company.The land fronts 455 feet on the avenue, in an area zoned for garden apartments, and was sold in a deal negotiated by Ellis Ellis, brokers.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP) -- The seventh annual national materials handing exposition, giant show requiring 170,000 square feet of floor space and costing an estimated $4,000,000 for a five-day run, opens tomorrow in Convention Hall.

" The Secret History of Stalin's Crimes," an inside story of a little- known part of Stalin's life, is planned for fall publication by Random House. The author is Alexander Orlov, a member of the Communist party's inner circle from 1917 to 1938 who had held important posts in the Soviet regime.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The nation's output of goods and services of the "gross national product" rose to another new high annual rate of $361,000,000,000 in the first quarter of this year, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce reported today.

In her recent letter of resignation as Assistant Commissioner of the city's Department of Health Dr. Leona Baumgartner, who had served in city employ for sixteen years, made two points that deserve more emphasis than they have received. One is that the rank and file of city employes in the various departments deserve more credit than they receive from the public, which is always critical of government.

GEORGI MAXIMILIANOVICH MALENKOV, says Martin Ebon in his "Malenkov: Stalin's Successor,"* is a "terrorist-technocrat" with "extraordinary organizational ability" and a past master of slippery intrigue. His rise to his present position of sinister eminence is the result of his single-minded application to the deadly game of Soviet politics, where a wrong guess about the realities of power, a careless word or an honest mistake may mean death.

ZURICH, Switzerland, May 17 -- In a message sent to Parliament last week the Swiss Federal Council explained its reasons for recommending that the unused part of the credit authorized by Parliament on June 18, 1952, to carry out European Payments Union monthly settlements in the year ending next June 30, should be made available for the same purpose in the year ending June 30, 1954.

There is no special need to reduce the volume of bank-held debt, since business activity and the price structure have caught up with the supply of deposits created during the war, according to a study, "Refunding the Public Debt," by New York University's Institute of International Finance. The study was issued by Dean G. Rowland Collins, director of the institute, and Dr. Marcus Nadler, research director.
Local foreign trade men generally like the customs simplification bill introduced last week by Representative Thomas A. Jenkins, Republican of Ohio, and will support it. The measure is H. R. 5106.

Two Governors, a United States Senator, the Republican state chairman and the New York County chairmen of the Republican and Liberal parties joined last night in paying tribute to Representative Jacob K. Javits at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ROME, May 17 -- Hungary beat Italy, 3 to 0, today in a match between their respective national football (soccer) teams, wherewith Rome's new Olympic Stadium was dedicated. The Hungarians had control of the ball most of the time.

MILWAUKEE, May 17 (UP) -- The National Boxing Association today urged that television sponsors cooperate with the N. B. A. in staging fights "to eliminate the disastrous effect of TV on the future of boxing."

INDIANAPOLIS, May 17 (AP) -- Bill Vukovich of Fresno, Calif., raced a rainstorm today and won the pole position for the 500-mile Memorial Day auto race in the second fastest qualifying speed in Indianapolis Motor Speedway history.
It is the responsibility of Christians "to bear witness to our Saviour" by works as well as by words, the Rev. Harry J. Wolff of St. Patrick's Cathedral staff declared at solemn mass yesterday.

Rates for the principal foreign exchanges set an erratic pattern in the daily trading sessions during the past week. British pound sterling finally recovered some of its loss of the previous week and the Canadian dollar moved narrowly in a market that was only moderately active.
Mayor Impellitteri declared here yesterday that "New York is the finest, the most decent and the cleanest city in the entire world."

PITTSBURGH, May 17 -- For some time now interest in steel will be focused on labor negotiations. What happens there will have a marked effect upon steel inventories, cost of manufacture and tightness of the steel market. Here is the current state of the steel market as negotiations for a wage increase get under way:

The New York Shipping Association, in a memorandum to the Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare, protested yesterday against the inclusion of longshore operations in a bill recently introduced by Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington. The measure would legalize maritime hiring halls through amendment of the Taft-Hartley Act.
LOS ANGELES, May 17 -- Jeweled shoes for milady with silver embroidery and rhinestones surrounding a large opal.

Many domestic differences could be avoided if Mrs. Doe handled household finances as Mr. Doe does at the office, David Ford, president of the Savings Association League of New York State, told the Larchmont Rotary Club last week.

LONDON, May 17 -- In the last week the stock markets managed to steer a fairly satisfactory course through rather bewildering and disturbing events. That these happenings on the whole were of a character to depress rather than to strengthen the markets was evident from the outstanding firmness of the gilt-edge stocks into which investment funds invariably drift at times of uncertainty and apprehension.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 17 -- The board of Colonial Williamsburg, Inc., has elected Dr. Harvie Branscomb a trustee. Dr. Branscomb is chancellor of Vanderbilt University. Colonial Williamsburg is a non-profit corporation carrying forward the work of restoration and historic interpretation in the Eighteenth Century area here.

BERLIN, May 17 -- Official statistics indicate that West Germany may once again possess the greatest industrial reserve power in the Western world after the United States in terms of used and unused capacity to produce machine tools and basic industrial equipment.

Caging two goals in each half, the touring Liverpool football club of England's first division extended its victory skein to twenty-three games in three trips to this Country by halting a selected eleven from the American Soccer League at Triborough Stadium.

Six Jesuit priests and six seminarians received mandates yesterday sending them to mission work in the Philippines and the Caroline and Marshall Islands in the Pacific. The ceremony was held in St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street, at a mass presided over by Cardinal Spellman.

A proposal to redevelop the waterfront at South Beach, S. I., along the general plan that "has proved successful at Rockaway Beach" was submitted yesterday by Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, and Edward G. Baker, Borough President of Richmond.

RENO, May 17 (AP) -- Patty Berg of St. Andrews, Ill., sank an eight-foot putt on the fourth hole of a sudden-death play-off today and captured $875 first money in the first Nevada women's professional golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UP) -- Stephen A. Mitchell, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, predicted today that the Democrats would win control of the House of Representatives next year and said he hoped they would do the same in the Senate despite an uphill fight.

AIR FORCE men who manned the ninety-nine-foot globe-girdling B-50 bomber Lady Lucky II last week, when it lay stripped of its enormous wings at the east curb of Duffy Square beside Father Duffy's statue, pulled out of town last Friday with peculiar notions about some New Yorkers.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- A letter of Governor Dewey of New York warning of "the gravity of the danger involved in the power to grant immunity" was made public today by Senator Harley M. Kilgore, Democrat of West Virginia.

CAIRO, May 17 (AP) -- Egypt charged today that British troops had attacked a railway station in the Suez Canal Zone and kidnapped the station master and his assistants. A communique said the Egyptian Government would protest "this unlawful, unprovoked aggression."

A bathing suit was once all the equipment required for a day at the shore. Nowadays, beach fashions include not only swim suits but also a wide variety of play designs to don after coming out of the surf.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Sir Roger Makins, the British Ambassador, touching on matters that recently have been in dispute between United States and British political figures, said today that the two countries might differ on methods but never on "basic political" objectives.

Burglars broke into the Rego Park Post Office, 86-12 Eliot Avenue, Queens, late Saturday or early yesterday and made off with stamps, blank money orders, savings bonds and postal savings certificates with a possible value of $46,320.

MADRID, May 17 -- The Vatican has just informed the Spanish Government that it does not approve what Spaniards here term "the latest snub" of Generalissimo Francisco Franco by Pedro Cardinal Segura y Saenz, it was disclosed today by prominent Roman Catholic source.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UP) -- Alger Hiss, now serving a five-year prison term for perjury in reference to his Communist connections, will be eligible for retirement benefits from the Government at 62 years of age, under present Civil Service regulations.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 17 -- Oliver Lyttelton, British Colonial Secretary, conferred at length today in one of the Kikuyu tribal centers with chiefs and headmen who are leading the fight against the Mau Mau, the secret society of Kikuyu tribesmen dedicated to curbing white influence in Kenya.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- The surging White Sox pounded three Washington pitchers for twelve hits, including a two-run homer by Sam Mele, and defeated the Senators, 7 -- 3, today. Saul Rogovin yielded eleven hits but went the route to post his second victory.
The Right Rev. Quentin K. Y. Huang, Anglican Bishop of the Diocese of Kunming, also known as the Diocese of Southwest China, told yesterday of his imprisonment in Communist China and his escape.

PARIS, May 17 -- Premier Rene Mayer will stake his Cabinet in one or perhaps several votes of confidence he will request in the course of the three-day debate on his financial program that is opening in the National Assembly tomorrow night.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- American Indians are on the move again -- this time leaving reservations under a voluntary relocation program of the Federal Bureau of Indian Affairs.

A manufacturer of textiles has purchased the twelve-story mercantile building on plot 111 by 100 feet at 54 to 62 West Twenty-first Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, from the Minerals Insulation Company Williams Company were the brokers in the sale of the building, part of which will be occupied by the new owner.

Representative Jacob K. Javits called yesterday on the Arab states to resettle 600,000 to 800,000 Palestine-Arab refugees, holding that such a move was a necessary prelude to Arab-Israeli peace and to the establishment of a defense organization in the Middle East.

Officially it was darkness that prevented the Yankees and Browns from completing their scheduled double-header yesterday at the Stadium. Actually it was the 3 hours 33 minutes consumed in the exciting ten-inning curtain-raiser, won by the Yankees, 6 -- 5, that led to the nightcap being called after three and a half scoreless innings.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- In a major move to protect New York garment manufacturers against destructive competition from manufacturers in other areas, the general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A.
