F. L., called tonight for a ban on the signing by any union local of contracts that failed to provide a basic thirty-five-hour work week.
BOGOTA, Colombia, May 12 -- The wonder of the Colombian situation is that the country's economy has never been better despite five years of civil war and political unrest.

THERE was a disbelieving look on Dos DiMaggio's face as he trotted to the dugout from the outfield one day late last season. "When base runners start to take that extra base on the old man," he said bitterly, "it can only mean that I'm really an old man. In the past no one would have dared take such liberties with my arm.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 17 -- The rarity of a Newfoundland winning best in show occurred today in the fifty-first event of the Long Island Kennel Club on a polo field of the Meadow Brook Club.

A "cowboy" between 2 and 3 years old with blond hair, blue eyes and a big smile was found yesterday wandering alone off the parental range in the zoo area of Central Park, and the police said no one had claimed him.

TOKYO, Monday, May 18 -- The United Nations chief delegate at the negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war, Lieut. Gen. William K. Harrison Jr., flew to Tokyo yesterday for consultations with the United Nations commander, Gen. Mark W. Clark.

ST. LOUIS, May 17 -- Threading their way through a maze of managerial maneuvers that seemed to spring from both dugouts in equal proportions, the Giants outscrambled the Cardinals today, 9 to 6. The result, which scarcely met with the approval of 19,177 onlookers, squared the current series at a victory apiece.
LONDON, May 17 -- Apart from some minor criticism, George Axelrod's "The Seven Year Itch, which opened at the Aldwych Theatre Thursday night, generally was well received by the chief aisle-sitters.

G. L. Mehta, India's Ambassador to the United States, cited yesterday the increasing cultural, economic and political contacts between the United States and his country to show that "internationalism is more than an aspiration."

Marta Eggerth, soprano, and Jan Kiepura, tenor, were heard in a joint recital at Town Hall on Saturday evening. The event marked the first New York appearance of the two artists, who are husband and wife, in five years, during which they have sung operettas and recitals and made three films in Europe.

SMITHTOWN, L. I., May 17 -- Long Island's Sport Car Association is an informal organization of men and women who have great fun making things hard for themselves, in fiendishly formal "rallies." Their best days -- and this was one of them -- are spent flashing about the countryside in small, swift automobiles, following as best they can confusing routes and directions prepared by the most devilishly clever plotters among them.

PARIS, May 17 -- Communist and Roman Catholic unions of the striking Merchant Marine officers who have tied up French shipping for three weeks announced today that the strike had been abandoned, with the exception of the port of Le Havre.

The Secretary of State heard the echoes of the British-American squabble in Damascus and Baghdad, two ancient cities that have seen more of the ups and downs of history than the capitals of the Atlantic world. They are not so romantic as the names sound. The glamor of the Arabian Nights is gone.

It is assumed that after the current three-day recess the United Nations negotiators will go back to Panmunjom tomorrow night (New York time) with some suggested grounds for modification of the twenty-four-point proposal that has been so bitterly rejected by the Communists.

Controller Lazarus Joseph re-emphasized yesterday his dissatisfaction with the New York City Transit Authority. In a new memorandum to Governor Dewey, the Controller appealed again for a six-month delay in any fare increase while economies were studied and asked for revision of the state law creating the authority.

Each season has its perils for the young, each has its little traps for the unwary. One tries to do one's duty by warning the young of slippery ice in winter, of sun that blisters in summer, of climbing too high after the apples of early autumn, of poison ivy in the spring.
Seven new films, including an import from Italy, will arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., May 17 -- Two music scholarships of $1,000 each have been awarded to seniors at Mount Holyoke and Radcliffe Colleges by the board of directors of Reid Hall, Inc., an educational center and residence for university women in Paris.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 17 -Cary Middlecoff remembered today that the last shall be first as he won the twelfth Palm Beach golf tournament by 7 points after some of the best scoring of his career.
May I crave your indulgence for space to call attention to the decision of the .American Government to close, on the grounds of economy, the American consulate in Bradford, Yorkshire.

SAVANNAH, Ga., May 17 (UP) -- Action by the Eisenhower Administration against alleged political corruption set off a squabble among Georgia Republicans today and the Republican National Chairman served notice that unethical acts by party members would not be tolerated.

A vigorous attack on the "un-Americanism of the Un-American Activities Committee" and the "abuse by Congressmen of the Congressional investigatory powers" was made in a sermon yesterday by the Very Rev. James A Pike, Dean of the New York Cathedral (Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine).

LYNN, Mass., May 17 (AP) -- Striking draftsmen and technicians at the General Electric Company voted today to end their walkout after a union committee recommended a "temporary truce." A union spokesman said work would be resumed at a time to be determined at a meeting of the locals tomorrow morning.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- The Republican National Chairman, Leonard W. Hall, will make five speeches next month on a coast-to-coast trip, part of which will parallel a tour by President Eisenhower.

Sales and net income of the Philco Corporation in the three months ended on March 31 increased 54 per cent and 45 per cent, respectively, compared with a year ago, according to the report released for publication today by William Balderston, president.

I have read with interest the story. published May 6 reviewing the report of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe in respect to the introduction and spread of the continuous-strip steel mills in the United States. Your correspondent reports that the commission hails the "courage" and "foresight" of those American companies that pushed this great invention forward.
MARSHALL, Tex., May 17 -- A Delta-Chicago and Southern Air Lines plane struck a pine tree today while making a landing approach, crashed and exploded, killing nineteen of the twenty persons aboard.

YONKERS, May 17 -- Karl Gosta Leandersson, six-time national distance champion, of Sweden, captured the American national marathon title today in 2 hours 48 minutes 12.5 seconds. Leandersson led John P. Lafferty of the Boston A. A., home by 600 yards.

Eighteen thousand New Yorkers who trace their ancestry to Norway paraded yesterday afternoon in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn to commemorate Norway's Constitution Day. The police estimated the spectators along the mile-and-a-half route at 50,000.

From the home cook's point of view, one of the most useful of the new food packages exhibited at the recent National Packaging Exposition in Chicago was a drip-proof container for molasses, syrups and salad oils. This innovation of the American Can Company, certainly much needed, was designed to eliminate the dripping that makes conventional tins and bottles such a nuisance to use.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- James A. Wechsler, editor of The New York Post, tonight termed his recent questioning by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy as a pointless inquisition aimed at frightening other editors into softening their criticism of the Wisconsin Republican.
MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., May 17 -- A fluctuating cloud ceiling stymied a scheduled air show for the 80,000 persons at the fourth annual Armed Forces Day celebration here today.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 17 -- Long Island Sound skippers today had their last opportunity to tune up their sloops for the Yacht Racing Association championship season which begins next week-end, and 29 of them took advantage of the occasion.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, May 18 (AP) -- United States F-86 Sabre jet pilots blasted nine Red MIG's out of the northwest Korean skies today and probably destroyed a tenth in air battles that produced history's first triple jet ace.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 10 -- Turkey will soon be able to make year-round shipments of her high-quality coking coal to other members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. This important addition to the West's industrial strength has been made possible by the virtual completion of United States-supported harbor development at the rich Zonguldak coal basin on Turkey's Black Sea coast.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 17 -- The movie companies will have twenty-two pictures before the cameras this week, either shooting in studios here or on locations in this country and abroad.

A new trend in farm family earnings is described by Dr. Virginia Britton in the May issue of the Journal of Home Economics. Dr. Britton, an economist in the Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics, United States Department of Agriculture, says that in April, 1951, more than a third of the families living on farms received more cash earnings from non-farm sources than in 1950 and a sixth received no earnings whatsoever from farming.

By electing Dr. Rufus E. Clement to the Board of Education the citizens of Atlanta, Ga., have taken a noteworthy step. Dr. Clement, president of Atlanta University, is the first Negro to be elected to public office in that Southern city since Reconstruction days.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 17 -- Two of last year's winners will be among ten students from New York high schools who are to receive cash awards Thursday from Mayor Imepllitteri in the annual national examination contest on the United Nations.
The Navy's "open house" display of eleven ships here over the weekend as part of the celebration of Armed Forces Week drew an estimated 34,000 visitors in two days.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 17 -- President Eisenhower worshiped today with the Brigade of Midshipmen at the United States Naval Academy and later told them they were to be congratu lated on dedicating their lives to the United States "in these troublous times." o'clock this morning getting into final shape the report on tax, budget and national security requirements that he will deliver to the nation by radio at 10:30 P. M. Tuesday.

A new comedy has been found for Josephine Hull, the idol of theatregoers. Announcement was made yesterday by Max Gordon, who hasn't had a show on the boards since 1951, that she is to be starred by him next season in the Howard Teichmann-George S. Kaufman collaboration bearing the glittering title of "The Solid Gold Cadillac."

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UP) -- The Government told the nation's 1,000,000 high school seniors today that their chances of finding a job this spring were good and gave them some fatherly advice on how to impress the future boss.
VIENNA, May 17 -- The Hungarian people went to the polls today to "elect," or in other words to rubber-stamp, their present form of Communist dictatorship for another five years.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 17 -- The masquerade ended today for Angel Peter Parga, a paroled convict and whilom Long Island Rail Road ticket collector who decided to go into business for himself -- on the Long Island Rail Road.

LOS ANGELES, May 17 -- Ken's fashion buyers from over the nation today received a preview showing of next fall's California stylings for men at the annual fall market week of the Men's Apparel Guild in California and the Boys Apparel Guild in California.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 17 (AP) -- The Lebanese Parliament's Foreign Affairs Committee told Secretary of State John Foster Dulles today that the United States must "remove from its mind any possibility of [Arab] peace with Israel."

WHIPPANY, N. J., May 17 -- Adventure, travel and the promise he might keep his dog, all came at once today to a 13-year-old boy who ran away from home for the first time. To the police, however, the episode brought considerable embarrassment.
Six panelists of high-school age agreed yesterday on the New York Times Youth Forum that a reconstituted Germany would eventually take its place as a full partner in the community of western nations.

Sales-tax collections soared to a total of $210,058,584 between July 1, 1952, and last April 30 and led city officials yesterday to conclude that business in New York had been prosperous. The collections exceeded by $9,681,485 those in the equivalent 1951-52 ten-month period.

LONDON, May 17 -- About 500,000 early rising Londoners had a preview today of the Coronation procession. They filled the stands along the Mall and stood five and six deep on the Embankment to watch the scarlet and gold royal coach and other carriages with their escorts and footmen journey around the royal route.

LONDON, May 17 -- The Actors' Equity Associations of Great Britain and the United States have abandoned negotiations on reciprocal alien employment practices for the theatre in the two countries, and each organization will apply its own rules to trans-Atlantic actors, Felix Aylmer, president of British Equity, told members today at their annual meeting.

If we should reflect for a moment on the ticking of the hallway clock, we may better understand New York's traffic safety drive. When twenty-four seconds have passed a person somewhere in the United States has been injured in an automobile accident. At the end of fourteen minutes somebody has been killed by a motor vehicle.

FRANKFURT, Germany, May 17 -- William N. Oatis, Associated Press correspondent released yesterday after twenty-five months' imprisonment in Czechoslovakia, left here tonight by plane for New York, where his wife, Laurabelle, awaited him.

SLAVONSKI BROD, Yugoslavia, May 17 --President Tito endorsed today Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill's proposal for intimate East-West talks by the big powers. He made the one reservation that they be informational in character and involve no decisions.

Sara McCaulley, executive director of Colony House at 297 Dean Street, Brooklyn, observed some years ago that groups of old persons gathered daily in the Long Island Rail Road station in Brooklyn. She learned they were there "just for companionship, having no other place to go."

The New York City secondary school division, with 300,000 students in the junior, academic and vocational schools, has embarked upon a major revision of its curriculum. Almost every subject, from English to biology, is being revised and brought up to date.

Martha Graham opened her seven-performance series of dance programs last night at the Alvin Theatre, where only recently the "American Dance" season closed its two-week engagement to crowded houses. On this occasion, the theatre once again was packed to the doors, which would seem to indicate that there is a far more lively and numerous audience for the modern dance than is commonly supposed.

Your recent editorial entitled "The Crime of Genocide," which brilliantly describes the application of the Genocide Convention to the tragic events behind the Iron Curtain, is most significant. Unfortunately, world opinion, which is justly preoccupied with the problem of war, tends to overlook genocide, which is even more detrimental to our civilization than war itself.

In Williamsport, Pa., on Saturday, Willard H. Campbell of Rolf Shockey Associates, Inc., told the Interstate Advertising Managers Association of thousands of lines of local advertising, the solicitation of which is being neglected by newspapers.

A three-year study will be made of the peoples, countries and resources of Africa and of the economic, social and political problems involved in their development, the Twentieth Century Fund has announced.
A light and whimsical approach to the craft of ceramic making is exhibited in many of the new collections that have gone on view in the last ten days.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 17 -- A new round is in prospect in "The Battle of the Redwoods," a contest that is stirring conservationists throughout the country.
Cotton futures prices strengthened last week after a silky start, and closed with net gains of 20 to 28 points, or $1 to $1.40 a bale, on the New York Cotton Exchange.

CHICAGO, May 17 (UP) -- Jersey Joe Walcott's handlers planned a hullaballo tomorrow, but it appeared that none of their antics could gain their fighter the prize he lost in the ring Friday night when he was knocked out in the first round by Heavyweight Titleholder Rocky Marciano.

Calvin Marsh, baritone, was heard in his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. This appearance was the gifted young artist's prize as winner of the sixth annual award of the American Theatre Wing.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today seventy-five Korean war casualties in a new list that included eleven killed, thirty-eight wounded, four missing, twenty-one captured and one injured.

Kermit Bloomgarden, who was uncertain about the Broadway closing date of "The Children's Hour" last week when he announced plans to tour the revival next fall, disclosed yesterday that the Lillian Hellman drama would end its engagement at the Coronet Theatre on May 30.

Because construction costs have more than doubled since 1939, with resulting changes in the values of standing buildings, the corporate insurance manager must review the insurable values of his company's properties from time to time.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- Senator Lehman said tonight that he had "not received any communication" from Governor Dewey on the Niagara power meeting. He added that he would be glad to meet with Messrs. Dewey, Burton and Ives at a mutually acceptable date.

Regarding a recent article entitled "Flags of '62 Given to the Antietam," in your paper, it is mentioned that the flags carried by New York City's "Fighting Sixty-ninth" Regiment were presented to the commanding officer of the Antietam. It might be of interest to your readers to know that New Yorkers played a prominent part in the U. S. S. Antietam's only combat tour.

Net earnings of the Creole Petroleum Corporation approximated $52,300,000 in the first quarter of this year, A. T. Proudfit, presilent, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday. In the same period last year Creole cleared $56,500,000.

BONN, Germany, May 18 -Chanecilor Konrad Adenauer said today that it might be necessary to negotiate a working agreement with the Soviet Union on the issue of Germany's eastern frontier. His statement symbolized a gradual almost imperceptible, change of attitude in West Germany toward the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -The Army told the Senate today that it could not maintain an "adequate medical service" without authority to draft physicians and dentists.

Stanley and Marvin Barnett have sold the one-story factory at 23-69 Thirty-eighth Street in Long Island City, Queens, to an investment syndicate headed by David E. Meltzer. The sale was negotiated by Queens Industrials through Harry D. Cole of Mount Vernon, N. Y. Rubinton Coleman were attorneys for the sellers and Paul R. Silverstein acted for the purchasing group.

Investors and traders stayed on the sidelines yesterday awaiting President Eisenhower's address tonight on budget, tax and security problems. On the diminished volume, prices eased moderately. A late rally in rails pushed THE NEW YORK TIMES average of twenty-five issues to 68.52, up 0.23 on the day.

LOS ANGELES, May 18 -- While tuberculosis' toll in lives, invalidism and money is still formidable, the campaign against it has reached the point where the nation should consider raising its sights from control of the disease to elimination of it, the National Tuberculosis Association was told today.

ALBANY, May 18 -- Governor Dewey agreed tonight to confer with Senator Herbert H. Lehman and Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. on the development of the hydro-electric power resources of the Niagara River.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, May 18 (AP) -- A woman who will look down on most of Britain's coronation guests arrived today. She is her majesty, Queen Salote, 6-foot 3-inch monarch of the peaceful Polynesian island kingdom of Tonga in the South Pacific.
Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Director, said yesterday that the new rent law gave New York City the opportunity to do "the biggest face-lifting job ever imagined" on its housing.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 18 -- Leaders of the Torch Commando veterans organization in Natal Province, the most British of South Africa's four provinces, said this week-end that Natal would secede if Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Afrikaner Nationalist party turned South Africa into a Boer republic.

For a union to confess failure in any of its endeavors is somewhat unusual. It comes close to the man-bites-dog definition of news. We are stirred to this reflection by the current report of the officers to the International Ladies Garment Workers Union convention admitting that the union's venture into radio broadcasting via three frequency modulation stations was a failure to the tune of nearly $1,500,000.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 18 -The tripartite treaty of friendship and alliance among Turkey, Greece and Yugoslavia entered into force today when the Grand National Assembly of Turkey ratified the accord by unanimous vote. Both the Greek and Yugoslav Parliaments had ratified the pact on March 23.
TOKYO, Tuesday, May 19 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,619 for twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:
West Side neighbors came out yesterday for the formal opening at 36 West 106th Street of the "Town House" of Children's Village, which undertakes to rehabilitate problem boys at Dobbs Ferry, N. Y.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to hear a test case involving the effect of the Federal Power Act on water rights validly existing under state law.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., May 18 -- The Huntington Crescent team of Ray Frisby and Lenny Peters won the Long Island Professional Golfers Association's weekly pro-amateur tournament today at the Brookville Country Club.

The Alumni Association of Columbia College last night elected as its president Thomas V. Barber, executive vice president of L. Bamberger Co. of Newark. Mr. Barber, a member of the class of '23, succeeded James Madison Blackwell.

Although it was able to get in only two commercials -- opening and closing -- at the Marciano-Walcott fight, the Gillette Safety Razor Company, sponsor of the affair to the tune of $300,000, didn't fare too badly. This is the consensus of seasoned ad and publicity men, expressed yesterday.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., May 18 -- Jacqueline Cochran, one of the nation's leading fliers, has become the first woman in history to fly faster than the speed of sound. She also set a new international speed record for the 100-kilometer closed course of 652 miles an hour today.
OKLAHOMA CITY, May 18 -More than 2,000 members, officers and friends of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers met here today for their fifty-seventh annual three-day convention.

Miss Helen Ridley, executive in a leading advertising agency, returning from a month in France, wore a red straw hat, a beige suit and a very happy smile. She said French cooking was as good as she had been writing that it was for the last ten years.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 18 -- Fernando Lamas, whose stock has risen markedly since "The Merry Widow," and June Allyson will be teamed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in "Honeymoon," a romantic comedy by Anatole de Grunwald, British scenarist-producer.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -The Senate today put off until Wednesday consideration of a $457,000,000 appropriation measure after an inconclusive debate on whether to add funds to speed up the handling of television station applications.

The Government's charge that defendants in the investment banking anti-trust suit followed price practices through conspiratorial action was denounced as groundless yesterday by Mathias F. Correa, attorney for Dillon, Read Co., one of the seventeen defendants.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway warned Congress today against cutting President Eisenhower's request for $5,828,000,000 in military and economic aid to America's allies. He said any curtailment of weapons shipments abroad would have "an adverse effect on United States defense."

Four chamber orchestras will be heard during the first season of the Concert Society of New York, which will present sixteen Sunday concerts at 5:30 P. M. at Town Hall during 1953-54. The ensembles are the Stuttgart Chamber Orchestra, under Karl Muenchinger: the Szymon Goldberg String Ensemble, the Saidenberg Little Symphony and the Virtuosi di Roma.

The State of New York still was trying doggedly yesterday to collect on the $50,000-fine imposed twenty-one years ago against Russell T. Sherwood, financial agent for the late Mayor James J. Walker. The fine was for contempt and stemmed from Sherwood's failure to appear before the Seabury inquiry to shed light on the tangled finances of the former Mayor, with whom he had shared a safety deposit box.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today set up a tighter policy for its money-lending activities to bring them "in tune with present-day" economic conditions -- peak production, employment and income.

France and the Government of Vietnam should welcome greater American participation in policy-making on Indo-China if the United States is to bear more of the burden of the conflict there, Adlai E. Stevenson said in a statement published today.

By-passing the special 122-man detail constituted as recently as March 27 by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan to enforce the gambling and vice laws throughout Brooklyn, Supervising Assistant Chief Inspector James R. Kennedy, head of the Commissioner's confidential squad, yesterday conducted a major gambling raid in the Williamsburg section.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 18 -- A further demonstration of the probable shape of things to come in the way of a "new look" for motion pictures was given here today by studio heads and technicians of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. In the first press showing of its developments with wide-screen and three-dimension films, the studio revealed samples of some of its forthcoming films in a variety of aspect ratios and then took a long glance ahead.

With a municipal election rapidly approaching, we find many individuals and some newspapers falling into an easy acceptance of the belief that the Democratic party cannot be relied upon to make honest and economical government available to our city.

ST. LOUIS, May 18 -- The power of the home run once again proved superior to the mind today as a pair of robust circuit clouts enabled the Giants to defeat the Cardinals, 8 to 6. The Polo Grounders took the odd encounter of the three-game series before a Ladies Day crowd of 8,244.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -Chico Marrero halted the White Sox with five-hit pitching, striking out nine as the Senators defeated Chicago, 3 -- 0, tonight. The shutout was the sixth by a Washington pitcher in the Senators' fifteen victories.

PARIS, May 18 -- At the outset of the debate in the National Assembly on his financial program tonight, Premier Rene Mayer encountered difficulties, both technical and political, that indicated a severe battle would take place before he won the special powers he sought to effect budgetary economies.

Cayuga Lake at Ithaca will be the scene of the only heavyweight rowing regatta of the week in the meeting between Cornell and Penn on Saturday. At the same time the lightweight crews of the two schools will row on the Schuylkill at Philadelphia.

The two six-story store and apartment buildings on a corner plot 74 by 105 feet at 57-59 Perry Street and 270-72 West Fourth Street, in the Greenwich Village section, have been sold by Timan Klein, real estate operators, to an investing client of Michael Goldberg, attorney.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Treasury proposed today to refund $5,688,000,000 of maturing obligations with a new issue of one-year certificates bearing an interest rate of 2 5/8 per cent. It was the highest short-term rate since the bank holiday in 1933, when a nine-month certificate was offered at 4 1/4.

Although the highlights of the one-round Rocky Marciano-Jersey Joe Walcott heavyweight championship battle in Chicago Stadium Friday night will be discussed for some time to come, the three-dimension film coverage of that brief event is hardly controversial.

An orchestra of septuagenarians, featuring a spry 82-year-old flutist, played lively airs as 400 of New York's "senior citizens" assembled yesterday to lay foundations for a city-wide council of men and women who, despite their age, want to go on being useful members of their communities.

JERSEY CITY, May 18 -- The new five-man Jersey City Commission agreed in private session today to let Mayor John V. Kenny succeed himself in the city's top political post. But dissension cropped up immediately when the two minority members, former Mayor Frank Hague Eggers and Joshua Ringle, complained that the city departments over which they received jurisdiction had been stripped of some of their former functions.

A recommendation that the city terminate any outstanding contracts with the Riche Fuel Company of 1725 Richmond Terrace, West New Brighton, S. I., was made yesterday by Investigation Commissioner James H. Sheils. Mr. Sheils, it was learned, charged falsifications in railroad freight bills as to the grade and source of coal for use on Staten Island.

THE store-front church on Lenox Avenue in Harlem was called the Temple of the Fire Baptized There the saints gathered sure in the knowledge that those who had been converted and saved were among the Lord's anointed There they listened to fiery Sermons rich with the ornate rhythms of the Old Testament.
TOKYO, Tuesday, May 19 (AP) -Far East Naval Forces summary for Monday:
The cotton futures market was quiet on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closing prices for actual months were 3 points lower to 2 points higher than on last Friday.

TOKYO, May 18 -- Shigeru Yoshida, Japan's conservative pro-Western Government leader since 1948, suffered his first defeat in Japan's newly elected House of Representatives today as Opposition political forces combined to elect the Speaker and Vice Speaker.

The Radio Corporation of America will present a special color television demonstration today for members of the Federal Communications Commission, who have accepted an invitation to witness the song and dance program at the R. C. A. Laboratories in Princeton, N. J.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Arthur Gardner, investment banker and manufacturer, was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be Ambassador to Cuba.

By unanimous vote the New York City Transit Authority decided yesterday to ask for a lease instead of an outright gift of the city-owned transit system, provided it can reach a satisfactory lease-agreement with the Board of Estimate.

The bridge about to be built over the Delaware River from Philadelphia to Gloucester City will bring "considerable relief" to present congestion, but another river crossing will be needed "within comparatively few years," Joseph K. Costello, executive director of the Delaware River Port Authority, said here yesterday.

Letting others fight it out as they made the pace, Harry La Montagne's Valadium moved up the fastest at the finish to take the Housemaid Handicap, a classified race of six furlongs at Belmont Park yesterday. There were 25,008 fans on hand, and few among these gave Valadium any chance against the five fillies and mares that opposed her.

MEXICO CITY, May 18 -- Gen. Hermenegildo Carrillo, commander of Mexico's Forty-second Division, was held by the police today as an accomplice in the plot to blow up a Mexican airliner with a time bomb and to collect $100,000 in double indemnity accident insurance on a passenger.

Former Postmaster General James A. Farley, addressing the annual meeting and luncheon of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce yesterday, urged that local and sectional barriers be broken down in planning for the future.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- President Eisenhower is running into a problem that has bothered many of his predecessors as a result of an off-the-cuff answer to a question at his last news conference.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The shortage of "brain power," with its weakening effect on national welfare and security, was brought to President Eisenhower's attention today by the National Manpower Council. The Council submitted a fourteen-point program for easing the problem and keeping a continuing watch over it.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Representative W. Sterling Cole, Republican of upstate New York and chairman of the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee, said today that proposed outlays in that field had been cut about 30 per cent from the totals asked by President Truman in the budget estimates he sent to Congress.

Net income of the Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation and subsidiaries for the three months ended on March 31 amounted to $2,742,721, equal to 86 cents a common share, it was announced yesterday. This compares with $2,653,966 or 94 cents a share for the corresponding three months of 1952.

Stockholders of the world's largest electric and gas utility, the $1,700,000,000 Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., were told at their annual meeting yesterday that the company expected to spend more than $95,000,000 this year for expansion of faciliites.

BERLIN, May 18 -- United States officials said today that the Czechoslovak C-47 airliner that was flown to the Rhine-Main Airfield, near Frankfurt, on March 23 by an air crew escaping to the West would be returned tomorrow to Czechoslovak representatives at Tempelhof Airfield.

WASHINGTON, May 18 --Senator Robert C. Hendrickson, Republican of New Jersey, suggested today that Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Army Chief of Staff designate, be asked to testify on the state of ammunition supplies in Western Europe, where he has been Commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces.
A model of the coach in which Queen Elizabeth II will ride to her coronation two weeks from today went on display yesterday in the area usually occupied by the skating rink in Rockefeller Plaza.

Capacity operations at the nation's steel mills are continuing. The industry's operating rate this week is scheduled at 100.2 per cent of theoretical capacity, indicating production of 2,259,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

In a letter published elsewhere on this page there is the comment that the immensity of the Korean relief problem has not been sufficiently stressed. This is unquestionably true. The problem is an immense and complex one and it is growing in size and gravity. If and when the northern part of Korea is also open for assistance a further enormous field for needed help will be opened.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- Selling pressure continued heavy on the deferred wheat futures today, while May was relatively firm on short covering. New low prices for the crop were registered in July, September and December wheat futures.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., May 18 -- For the second week in a row Jack Patroni of Apawamis won top honors in a weekly one-day pro-amateur best-ball tournament, this time over the Vernon Hills Country Club. With Joe Risoli of Harrison as his amateur partner, Patroni took the Westchester Professional Golfers Association event with an 8-under-par 31, 32 -- 63 in a field of 103 teams.

The New York City Omnibus Corporation and the Fifth Avenue Coach Company accused the Board of Estimate yesterday of repudiating promises and assurances given by the city last winter to bring an end to the bus strike that had tied up nine privately operated bus companies from New Year's Day until Jan. 29.

I have just completed a term of service as a juror in the Brooklyn Municipal Court. Since this was my first such service, I was previously unaware of the dynamics by which jurors arrive at verdicts. Now, shockingly aware, I would like to add my voice in support of the recent suggestion of Judge Peck that the use of juries be discarded in small civil cases.

LONDON, May 18 -- Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister, indicating that he had fully informed Washington of his views on the Communist proposals for the repatriation of Korean war prisoners, said today that Britain should not "go on nagging" the United States.

THERE is no intention here to keep flogging a dead horse. However, the one angry refrain that a returning traveller has been hearing is this: "Walcott took the $250,000 and quit like a dog at the first opportunity." Somehow or other this reporter can't buy it. In the first place it's contradictory to the Old Gentleman's character. In the second place the abrupt ending was too implausible to have been staged.
TRENTON, May 18 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today as invalid a Jersey City ordinance levying taxes on the gross receipts of local merchants and on factory payrolls.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., called today for the ouster of all "racketeers, gangsters and convicted criminals" from the ranks of organized labor.

Three members of the National Association of Women Artists displayed their virtuosity yesterday at the National Academy of Design by their swift portraitures of two men and a woman to whom medals were being awarded. The exhibition was for the benefit of the United Cerebral Palsy Fund.

John Paton Davies Jr., former deputy director of political affairs in the office of the High Commissioner in Germany, arrived at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday from Frankfurt on his way to his new post at Lima, Peru, to serve as Counselor of the United States Embassy.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 18 (UP) -- French Union forces under personal command of Gen. Raoul Salan recaptured today the key communications town of Xiengkhouang, abandoned to the Communist-led Vietminh in the early stages of the invasion of Laos.
PARIS, May 18 (Reuters) -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, newly designated as Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, said here today he firmly believed there would be no third world war.

ROME, May 18 -- Palmiro Togliatti, Communist leader, said yesterday that early in 1951 eminent personalities in the Vatican approached the Italian Communist party through a go-between who declared the Vatican was disposed to abandon its policy of "indiscriminate support of American initiatives" if the Soviet Union and its satellite states would open negotiations on "religious questions and on peace."
The 11,015-gross-ton Jerusalem, the first Israeli-flag passenger vessel ever to call at the Port of New York, docked yesterday morning at Pier 32, North River, at Morton Street.

Lead and zinc were fairly active yesterday in generally light trading on the New York Commodity exchanges. Prices closed irregular with wool, zinc, sugar, soybean oil, coffee and tin ending mixed. Lead and cocoa were higher and cotton seed oil, potatoes, hides and rubber closed lower.

A full-length portrait of Queen Elizabeth II by the late Douglas Chandor, which arrived here from England on May 4, was shown yesterday at a preview at the Wildenstein Gallery, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, and will be on public exhibition there through June 6.
LAGOS, Nigeria, May 18 -- The death toll in political rioting at Kano, Northern Nigeria, rose to thirty-two tonight.

William N. Oatis, former Associated Press correspondent in Prague, said on his return here yesterday that he "certainly" had violated the espionage laws of Czechoslovakia. However, Mr. Oatis, who was pardoned last Friday after having served twenty-two months of a ten-year sentence on charges of espionage, declared that any correspondent operating under United States standards of journalism inevitably would have risked the same violations and the same penalty.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The State Department moved forward today in its program of cutting 830 individuals from the payroll of its International Information Administration, including the Voice of America.

LOS ANGELES, May 18 -- A subcommittee of the House of Representatives Committee on Government Operations interrogated a number of public workers behind closed doors today as a preliminary to the opening tomorrow of public hearings on Los Angeles' controversial $100,000,000 Federally sponsored public housing project.

CHICAGO, May 18 (AP) -- The Illinois Athletic Commission, voicing disappointment of Jersey Joe Walcott's showing against Rocky Marciano and urging his retirement, today rejected a protest of the fight by the ex-champion's manager.

The establishment of a Harry Emerson Fosdick Visiting Professorship at the Union Theological Seminary was announced here last night by Dr. Henry P. Van Dusen, seminary president, at the annual alumni dinner at the seminary, Broadway and 120th Street.

President Tito's outrageous attack on Premier De Gasperi of Italy and his immoderate language about Trieste will make a bad situation that much worse. It would be hard to imagine anything less statesmanlike than the Marshal's wild defiance of Italy, a defiance that probably was also aimed at the United States, for Tito knows where American sympathies lie.

PARIS, May 18 -- John C. Hughes, a New York business man, is being considered by President Eisenhower as the next permanent representative of the United States to the North Atlantic Treaty Council, it was reported today by responsible authorities here.

Adult education must prove its worth by improving the social and economic life of a community, Dr. Paul Essert, executive officer of the Institute of Adult Education, Teachers College, Columbia University, said yesterday. He was a luncheon speaker at the annual conference of the New York State Adult Education Association at the Statler Hotel, attended by more than 500 adult education directors.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- A California program of cooperation between colleges and state and Congressional investigating groups to keep Communists out of faculties or weed them out was cited by Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, today as a possible model for other states and areas.

MOSCOW, May 18 -- Diplomatic amenities between the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia, more honored in the breach than in the observance in the last four years, appear to have taken a trend toward normalcy in Moscow.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- The scope of the dispute over the Government's efforts to obtain thousands of new documents from company files widened today at the du Pont anti-trust trial in Federal District Court. Judge Walter J. LaBuy, who earlier had told both sides to get together, deferred ruling in the disagreement.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Secretary of Labor Martin P. Durkin said today that he expected the Eisenhower Administration to take a definite position on amendments to the Taft-Hartley Law and that he would testify before the labor committees of Congress.

PARIS, May 13 -- Straw is a decorative accessory in Paris for summer. It is seen in the boutiques that dot the smart shopping districts. Leading couturiers use it in their collections in belts, bags, collars and gloves and as an ornamentation in scrolled or flowered patterns on many of their cotton dresses.

This city's vocational school system is badly neglected. Most of the fifty-two buildings where 42,000 boys and girls take vocational training are old, former elementary schools, entirely unsuited for vocational work. Frequently the equipment is poor or outmoded.

HEADQUARTERS, Fifth Air Force, May 18 -- United Nations Sabre jets knocked twelve MIG's from the North Korean skies today as they continued their spectacularly successful sallies over enemy territory. In the ideal spring-like weather of the last six days, thirty-six MIG's have been destroyed, three probably destroyed and fifteen others damaged.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The White House announced today that President Eisenhower had decided to delay until later in the week his signing of the bill granting the states title to the oil deposits within their historic coastal boundaries.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 19 -- The Chinese Communists counted today on foreign support to force concessions from the United Nations delegation, scheduled to return to Panmunjom tomorrow to resume discussions on an armistice in the Korean war.

ATHENS, May 18 -- An article in the Government draft law "On Investment and Protection of Foreign Capital," especially designed to attract the mass of Greek shipping to the Greek flag away from foreign registry and thus bring in sizable revenue to the homeland, appears to have the general support of Greek shipowners, economically Greece's most powerful business group.

BOSTON, May 18 (AP) -- Twelve Boston ministers have apologized to Clement Attlee, British Labor party leader, to the Queen, the Prime Minister and the people of Britain "for the language and ill will" of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

Joseph B. Cavallaro, a 49-year-old Brooklyn lawyer and an outspoken advocate of Congressional investigations into communism in the schools, was elected last night for a one-year term as chairman of the Board of Higher Education. He has served on the board since 1946, when he was appointed by former Mayor William O'Dwyer.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Supreme Court refused to hear an appeal today by William Vanderwyde of New York on a death sentence imposed for the murder of his friend, Benjamin Dietz, on a Greenwich Village street on May 18, 1951.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 19 -- The United Nations Command announced today that the recess in the Korean armistice talks had been extended until next Monday. The negotiations had been scheduled to resume tomorrow after a three-day recess.

CAIRO, May 18 -- The Egyptian Government protested to Britain today against alleged aggressions carried out by British forces in the Suez Canal zone. A Government spokesman denied, however, that Egypt had set up a blockade to deny food supplies to British garrisons in the zone.

CINCINNATI, May 18 -- Bud Podbielan, a former Dodger right-handed pitcher, registered his first triumph of the season tonight in one of the most fantastic pitching performances on record. Ted Kluszewski clouted a one-one pitch off Preacher Roe with one out in the tenth inning to gain a 2-1 victory for the Redlegs over the Dodgers.
LONDON, May 18 (UP) -- Great Britain has no intention of imposing a total embargo on nonstrategic trade with Communist China, the House of Commons was told today.

SINGAPORE, May 18 -- Fighting units of surrendered terrorists are to be sent into the jungle against their former comrades, the Federation Government in Kuala Lumpur announced tonight. A unit will consist of about 180 volunteers selected from hundreds of surrendered terrorists who offered to serve.

PARIS, May 18 -- An indication of the character of the new single market for steel in Western Europe, formally opened May 1, came today when French steel producers announced that their prices in France and the Saar would now rise by an average of 3.3 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -Two major business groups told Congress today that any move to restrict foreign trade now would be a major setback to the United States and its Allies in the "cold war" against communism.

The former rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church in Scarsdale, N. Y., whose assistant resigned a year ago to become a Roman Catholic, announced yesterday that he also had been converted to Catholicism.
DEROIT, May 18 -- The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., and the General Motors Corporation exchanged preliminary volleys today as they prepaid to resume contract negotiations tomorrow afternoon

LONDON, May 18 -- Drastic measures to reduce the amount of money spent on doctors' prescriptions that are now costing the British Health Service about 60,000,000 ($168,000,000) a year were announced today by the Minister of Health, Iain Macleod.

MILWAUKEE, May 18 (AP) -- Del Crandall cracked a 400-foot home run and a bases-loaded single tonight to drive in three runs as the Braves beat the Phillies, 4 -- 0, and moved back into a tie with the Phils for the National League lead.

BALTIMORE, May 18 (AP) -Dark Star was upset today at Pimlico in the Preakness Prep by Royal Bay Gem. The Kentucky Derby winner was outraced in a bristling stretch drive. The race was a final tune-up for Saturday's $100,000 added Preakness Stakes.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 18 (UP) -- The Hedgcroft Hospital, which started twenty-five years ago in a one-room cabin, opened the doors of its new $1,000,000 building today. The hospital is the realization of a dream by a woman who began her service career in the late Nineteen Twenties by helping the polio-crippled child of a friend.

A Democratic party district leader and a City Councilman have mustered forty election district workers to get out the vote in a Parent Teachers Association election of officers in an effort to prevent a left-wing element from gaining control of the P. T. A. unit at Public School 125 on the upper West Side.

The installation of Mrs. Jesse Asinof as president of the New York (Manhattan) division of the Greater New York Women's Division of the National Jewish Hospital at Denver took place yesterday at a luncheon at the Pierre Hotel.

Consumers are too easily influenced by packaging and alluring fragrances when choosing cosmetic products, Dr. Donald H. Powers, director of Hudnut research for Warner-Hudnut, Inc., said last night at a meeting of the Lackawanna subsection of the American Chemical Society in Summit, N. J.
TOKYO (Tuesday), May 19 (AP) -- Yoshio Shirai, world flyweight champion, came out of a barrage of Filipino fists last night the winner by a slim margin over Tanny Campo of Manila.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -The Federal Communications Commission refused today to reconsider its February ruling that Paramount Pictures Corporation held a degree of control over the Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, which operate the Du Mont TV network.
RICHMOND, Va., May 18 (UP) -- A note from President Eisenhower got a 14-year-old school girl out of trouble with her school today.

For the second program of her week at the Alvin Theatre, Martha Graham last night revived "Dark Meadow" for the first time in a number of seasons, and presented "Errand into the Maze" and "Canticle for Innocent Comedians" along with it to make up a strong and varied evening.

Nylza Maria Drummond, a Brazilian soprano with a pretty voice and a good deal of charm, gave her first New York program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. It began most informally, for she was twenty minutes late for her own concert and then had to start with her final group because she had forgotten to bring most of her music.

Several telephone inquiries were made last night about the little blond, blue-eyed "cowboy" who was picked up by the police in Central Park Sunday afternoon and placed in the Children's Center at 105th Street and Fifth Avenue, but the happy youngster is still unclaimed.
Operations of the Aluminum Company of Canada, Ltd., and subsidiaries for the three months ended on March 31 produced a net profit of $3,555,265. This compares with $4,839,450 a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -The Federal Communications Commission today ordered Western Union Telegraph Company, Tropical Radio Telegraph Company and Globe Wireless, Ltd., to end their agreements for joint handling of overseas messages to and from Central America and some Pacific areas.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 18 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet representative to the United Nations, gave a reception tonight at his home near Glen Cove, Long Island, for Other permanent delegates. A moving picture was shown later.

To bring the elegance and comfort of the indoor living room onto the outdoor terrace, patio or porch appears to be the aim of manufacturers of summer furniture this season. Supporting this theory is the finished look of several newly introduced collections, all of which contain as large a variety of matching or related pieces as do more formal collections designed to be used only indoors.

TRENTON, May 18 -- Bingo occupied the spotlight here today as the New Jersey State Legislature reconvened after a five-week recess, but no immediate action was taken toward legalizing this and other minor forms of gambling. However, a referendum to accomplish this is expected to be approved eventually and submitted to the voters at the November election.

A state law requiring licenses for paid solicitors for religious charities is needed, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein said yesterday, to cope with sidewalk collectors here who pass on a minimum share of the contributions to the charities named on their jingling coin-boxes.

BOSTON, May 18 (AP) -- Right-hander Ned Garver hurled the Tigers to their third straight victory with a five-hit, 5-2 decision, but the Red Sox bounced back for an 8-5 triumph in the second game of a double-header today before a crowd of 6,591.

HARTFORD, May 18 -- The Joint Finance Committee of the Connecticut General Assembly, which is controlled overwhelmingly by Republicans, voted a favorable report today on a $41,900,000 tax increase program to balance the state's budget for the two-year period to begin July 1.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 18 -Harvard University announced today the retirement of eight faculty members at the end of the academic year. They are in addition to Dr. James Bryant Conant, now United States High Commissioner for Germany, who becomes president-emeritus Sept. 1, and Dr. Willard L. Sperry, dean of the Divinity School, whose retirements had been announced previously.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -Child custody awards made in one state are subject to possible modification in another state, the Supreme Court ruled, 5 to 3, today. Justice Jackson, one of the dissenters, voiced fear from the bench that the decision might prompt the losing parent in divorce cases to resort to "kidnapping."

As the New York City Transit Authority moves toward a decision on the amount of a fare rise necessary after July 30 it may be useful to review some of the facts. The last three completed fiscal years have brought operating deficits as follows: 1949-50, $1,206,043; 1950-51, $3,067,520; 1951-52, $24,773,883.
BERLIN, May 18 -- Between 35 and 40 per cent of West Berlin's great industrial capacity is available for the production of goods essential to Western defense.

New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants has forwarded to Congress seventy-six recommendations for changes in the Federal tax code, it was announced yesterday. The proposals, sent to the Senate Finance Committe, the House Committee on Ways and Means and the Joint Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation, are designed to eliminate inequities and improve administration of the code, it was said.

How long is "just a minute"? It is not less than a minute, certainly; it may, but not often, be a minute; it may be two or three minutes, or even five. But where is the end of the extension of time that is asked by "just a minute"?

A revised uniform price estimate of $3.57 a hundredweight for milk deliveries during May was issued yesterday by Dr. C. J. Blanford, Market Administrator of the New York Metropolitan Milk Marketing area. An earlier forecast had estimated the price at $3.65 a hundredweight, eight cents higher than that issued today.

We were greatly interested in your presentation of the challenge of Korean rehabilitation in the editorial of May 11, "U. N. K. R. A.'s Opportunity." The American voluntary agencies have conducted active programs of relief and rehabilitation in that stricken country and THE TIMES has generously noted these programs in its news and editorial columns.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Ezra Taft Benson, the Secretary of Agriculture, appealed to Congress today for approval of the Eisenhower Administration's plan for reorganization of the Department of Agriculture but added that he did not have a blueprint of how he would use added powers.
John W. Miller has been named manager of the export department of the Creole Petroleum Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -Employment declined slightly from March to April but remained higher than a year ago, the Commerce Department said today. The department's monthly report on employment included these details:

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- Prime Minister Sidney G. Holland of New Zealand said today after a White House luncheon that he had come to the United States "to cement British-American relations, not to ferment our differences."

Rain gets the blame for washing away sales of used cars in the last two months in this state to an estimated 16 per cent below the same period in 1952. This slump was reported yesterday after a country-wide survey by the National Used Car Dealers Association.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, May 19 (AP) -- The Communist Air Force hurled 800 to 900 MIG fighters at United States Sabre jets along the Korean border in six days of stepped-up aerial war through Monday and was knocked back with shattering losses.

A motion-picture camera described as employing "singly or in combination the best features of three dimensions and wide-screen WarnerScope," has been perfected by Warner Brothers, Jack L. Warner, production chief, revealed yesterday.

After enjoying an off-day yesterday, the world champion Yankees will be out to gain a firmer hold on the American League lead tonight when they meet the last-place Tigers in the first of a two-game set at the Stadium.

Arthur Persley, hard-punching lightweight from New Orleans, registered his fourteenth successive victory last night when he gained a unanimous ten-round decision over Percy Bassett of Philadelphia at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., May 18 (UP) -- The DC-7, a new transport plane described by the Douglas Aircraft Co., Inc., as the fastest piston-powered commercial airliner in the world, made its maiden flight here today. A company spokesman said four major domestic airlines had ordered a total of fifty-eight new DC-7's and expected to place them in service next year.
An air-sea rescue search was ordered early today for a private twin-engine plane that disappeared yesterday with three persons aboard on a flight from Princeton, N. J., to Westerly, R. I.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 -- The fifth annual National Material Handling Exposition, described as the country's largest industrial show of the year, opened in Convention Hall today with more than $10,000,000 worth of equipment on display.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 18 -- The United States, which holds the unified command of United Nations forces in Korea, has decided to modify its counter-proposal at Panmunjom to make the provision concerning the ultimate fate of prisoners of war more in comformity with the resolution adopted by the General Assembly last December.

City College of New York, while defeating Queens, 20 -- 18, in a non-league game yesterday, backed into the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference championship when St. John's eliminated Brooklyn College, the last school with a chance for the crown.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks today supported, and the nation's bankers opposed, legislation to give the Government permanent authority to make direct loans to small business.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 18 -- Dr. Henry B. Decker of Camden, newly installed president of the Medical Society of New Jersey, said here tonight the growing industrialization of the Delaware Valley, with its accompanying population increase, would bring a concomitant demand for medical services.

New York World Trade Week was formally opened yesterday with performance of a historical pageant commemorating "Port of Friendship Day." This first special event in the city's observation of the "week" took place at noon in Jeannette Park, Coenties Slip, adjacent to the Seamen's Church Institute, 25 Souht Street.
LAGOS, Nigeria, May 18 -- Intimations that trouble was expected came early Saturday when the Kano Native Administration withdrew a permit issued to the Action Group to hold a meeting at Sabon Gari.

LONDON, May 18 -- In subdued trading, most sections of the stock market here finished with small declines. However, several selected industrial groups withstood the trend while British Government securities and South African gold mining issues closed better.

The eighth volume of Rear Admiral Samuel Eliot Morison's "History of United States Naval Operations in World War II" will be published June 25 by Atlantic-Little, Brown. Titled "New Guinea and the Marianas, March 1944-August 1944," the volume describes the patrols, carrier strikes and amphibious operations and the part they played in the grand strategy of the United States in the Pacific.
VIENNA, May 18 -- On the theme "World Trade Is Everybody's Business" the International Chamber of Commerce opened its fourteenth and largest congress here today.
Following is the text of the interim report submitted yesterday to Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan by the Police Advisory Committee on Human Relations:
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Following is a summary of recommendation to President Eisenhower today by the National Manpower Council:

If there is one thing that stands out in the challenging report made by the National Manpower Council to President Eisenhower it is that we have scarcely begun to explore the problem of how to insure adequate resources of scientific and professional manpower for the nation.

THOSE who have been worried concerning the bluefish prospects can shift the pessimistic outlook to some other fish, for the reports from North Carolina indicate one of the largest bluefish runs in the memory of the oldest "banker," and they don't consider a man "grown" down there until he's sixty.

NEW ORLEANS, May 18 (UP) -- A storm moving along the Gulf Coast today killed at least four persons, isolated the central Louisiana city of Alexandria, and hit Galveston, Tex., with winds of eighty-four miles an hour.

Police captains of this city will return to Police Academy classrooms, starting Monday, to learn to get along better with people, especially members of minority groups. The back-to-school movement is to be extended until eventually all 19,000 policemen will have had refresher courses in human relations.
A young G. I., stationed in New Jersey and under orders for Japan and Korea, haunted a settlement house in Brook1yn recently. He seemed depressed.
Six carloads of patrolmen swooped down last night on 300 to 400 youths who had squared off to settle an affair of honor over the affections of one girl.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 18 -- Yugoslav sources are speculating whether the Soviet Union will send an ambassador following the change of personnel in Moscow's Embassy here. Anatoli Lavrentiev, the last Russian Ambassador, left Belgrade in the summer of 1949 and was never succeeded.
LONDON, May 18 (UP) -- Britain defeated Norway today to complete the second round of the European zone of the Davis Cup tennis tournament and set up the quarter-finals.
PARIS, May 18 -- Ship movements were back to normal today in all French ports with the exception of Le Havre, where the strike of merchant marine officers was dying hard.

William N. Oatis, three days out of a Prague jail, wasn't ready with a complete story when he faced the other newspaper men, his brothers in an exacting craft, at Idlewild Airport yesterday afternoon. He didn't know the complete story as it had been published in this country. He had been cut off from the world.
YONKERS, May 18 (AP) -- Four horses went across the wire almost as one in the Mohegan Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight and the photo gave the edge to Power Chief by a nose over Watson Junior.
Investment banking syndicates competed at public sealed bidding yesterday for the underwriting of $77,220,000 of new issues of public utility securities.

NEWARK, May 18 -- Scheduled to organize in Newark City Hall tomorrow at noon, members of the new Newark City Commission, elected last Tuesday, named their cabinets and other departmental appointees today.

James D. Norris, head of the International Boxing Club, discussed yesterday with Al Weill, manager of Rocky Marciano, the possibility of an outdoor title fight between the heavyweight champion and either Roland La Starza or Ezzard Charles in a New York ball park in September.

THE American Export liner Constitution, due at 9 o'clock this morning from a 10,000-mile Mediterranean cruise, will bring to Pier 84, North River, in addition to 569 other passengers, a stowaway listed as "AU-43-FAC-544."

Frank Lloyd Wright, the architect, was the subject last Sunday of the latest installment in the National Broadcasting Company's fine series of televised conversations with elder leaders of our day. He made an engrossing and stimulating figure on the screen as he quietly and good-humoredly discussed his work and explained his philosophy on life in general.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., May 19 -- Playing exceptionally accurate golf from tee to green, Mr. and Mrs. Reinert Torgerson of Cherry Valley swept off with the chief honors in the Long Island Golf Association's husband-and-wife tournament today at The Creek course.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Eisenhower, in asking for a six-month extension of the excess-profits tax, today handed Republican leaders of the House of Representatives their toughest assignment of the session.

A body found in Long Island Sound near the wreckage of a private plane was identified last night as that of Mrs. Bernard Peyton Sr., who had left Princeton, N. J., airport on Monday morning in the plane with her son, Bernard Jr., and Arthur Muhs of Pennington, N. J., a pilot.

PARIS, May 19 -- In the opinion of certain French and American observers, the recent unsuccessful Communist-led invasion of Laos effectively demonstrated to the peoples of Asia that the revolutionary Vietminh is not, as it says, a nationalist Vietnamese "liberation force" but a tool of the Chinese Communist Government on which it depends for weapons, munitions, military advice and political commands.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Official sources suggested tonight that the United States would not consider taking part in a top-level Allied meeting with the Soviet Union that did not include France.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- Evening up of May contracts in the different pits on the Board of Trade made up much of the trade volume today, with the current deliveries showing relative strength. At the same time, there was local pressure and some long liquidation in deferred wheat positions, which resulted in all the new crop months making new crop lows.

PARIS, May 19 -- French merchant marine officers at Le Havre, the last to hold out in the three-week shipping strike, voted today to go back to work. The French Line, whose North Atlantic service had been halted by the stoppage, immediately announced that its sailings would be resumed, starting with the Ile de France, which will leave for New York tomorrow.

ALBANY, May 19 -- John E. Burton, chairman of the State Power Authority, told the chairman of the House Public Works Committee today that a bill embodying the authority's plan for developing the power potential of the Niagara River would be introduced in Congress "shortly."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were quiet most of yesterday and closing prices were 10 points higher to 6 points lower than on Monday.
YONKERS, May 19 (AP) -- Ranger Hanover scored his eighth straight victory tonight by winning the Farragut Pace by two lengths on the Grand Circuit program at Yonkers Raceway.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway assured Congress today North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations, working together, were entirely capable of creating and maintain ing the minimum military strength required to meet any Russian aggression in Western Europe.

New issues of corporate securities totaling more than $109,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The offerings represent new issues of public utility and natural gas line mortgage bonds and capital stock of an electrical instrument manufacturer. In another transaction, more than $2,800,000 of outstanding stock of the Meredith Publishing Company, publisher of garden and home magazines, will be placed on the market.

There was an inaugural race at Belmont Park yesterday. It was the Joe H. Palmer Handicap, named for the prose stylist who covered turf activities for The New York Herald Tribune until his death last October.
BALTIMORE, May 19 (AP) -- Native Dancer arrived at Pimlico today to find one of his favorite pacesetters ready to spur him on in Saturday's Preakness.

SEOUL, Wednesday, May 20 (AP) -- The Chinese Red Air Force, which suffered heavy losses in six days of blazing air battles, refused combat yesterday and its MIG jets fled to Manchuria when United States Sabre jets approached.

THE "spring" salmon have almost run their course on the Miramichi in the Province of New Brunswick, but reports indicate there are quite a number of fresh-run fish in the lower tidewater stretches as well as some bright fish in the pools. Anglers can begin taking the fresh-run fish on Monday.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The State Department said today that 5,207 persons claiming American citizenship were being held in Communist-ruled countries.
LONDON, May 19 -- Prices continued to drift lower today in idle stock markets but losses were mostly small and were relieved by individual gains.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense, told a Senate Appropriations subcommittee today that the American people should be reassured by Soviet concentration on fighter aircraft production as a sign that the Russians intended to build an Air Force of principally defensive capability.

Philip Sporn, president of the $870,000,000 American Gas and Electric Company seven-state power system, took issue yesterday with the world's largest electric and gas utility, the $1,700,000,000 Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.

The third week of the New York City Ballet at the City Center opened last night with the third premiere of the season. Todd Belender's "The Filly," to a specially commissioned score by John Colman and with scenery and costumes by Peter Larkin.

Encouraging rail and oil field developments and reports of tougher Washington tax policies virtualy canceled each other in New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday. Volume remained low -- only 1,120,000 shares, compared with 1,080,000 on Monday -- and last-hour rally still left the market with a net loss.
NEW ORLEANS, May 19 (UP) -- A tornadic front moved into Georgia tonight, but floods in its wake ruined $100,000,000 worth of Louisiana crops and forced thousands to abandon bayou villages.

Representatives of thirty-two national organizations interested in aiding refugees from Communist-controlled countries and in relieving overcrowded conditions in free Europe, pledged their support yesterday to emergency legislation, now before Congress, that would permit the entry into this country of 240,000 such persons.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- In 1949, when Mrs. Horton was president of Wellesley, she told a graduating class that the House Un-American Activities Committee had asked to examine the college's social science textbooks. She said she was concerned that committee members "fear that you have been exposed to dangerous ideas."
Bronx Vocational scored eight firsts in the twelve-event program to win the Manhattan-Bronx vocational high school track and field championships at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, yesterday.
BARNEGAT, N. J., May 19 -- A grandfather and two grandsons drowned late yesterday when their fifteen-foot outboard motorboat capsized in Barnegat Bay near Waretown, three miles north of here.
The reputed leader of a huge narcotics ring, Jean Laget, known as the Silver Fox, is wanted in France for the 1937 murder of a banker, it was disclosed yesterday in Federal Court.

A new generation climbed to management heights in one of the country's oldest and largest department store organizations yesterday. Immediately following the annual stockholders meeting of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., directors elected Bruce A. Gimbel, 39-year-old vice president of Gimbel-owned Saks Fifth Avenue as president.

BONN, Germany, May 19 -- A proposal by Dr. Robert Lehr, Minister of the Interior, that West Germany's border police force be transformed into a virtual army of 50,000 men, is being studied by German politicians eager to discover new approaches to West German rearmament.

LONDON, May 19 -- Members of the House of Commons cheered today when Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister, announced that in the future the United States would get quicker and more complete reports of British foreign policy pronouncements.
Ralph (Tiger) Jones, 154 pounds, Yonkers, won a unanimous decision over Joe Tomasello, 158, Elizabeth, N. J., in the ten-round main bout before 2,500 fans at Ridgewood Grove, Brooklyn, last night.

A MONTH after Pearl Harbor, when Leon Uris was 17 years old and a high school senior in Baltimore, he enlisted in the United States Marines. In the Second Marine Division he fought on Guadalcanal and Tarawa. Now, ten years and more after those bloody and glorious battles, Mr. Uris is the author of a novel based upon his experience, "Battle Cry."*

ORLANDO, Fla., May 19 (AP) -- A little brown dog brought water and a pet black snake watched while Herbert Jones endured five days of thirst and pain last week. The 63-year-old farmer lay paralyzed in his pecan grove near Umatilla, after he broke his back in a fall from a pruning ladder last Tuesday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 19 -- The Corporation of Harvard University announced today that it had found three faculty members guilty of misconduct for invoking their constitutional rights against self-incrimination to avoid answering questions of Congressional committees.

NEW DELHI, India, May 15 -- Hoping to adapt India's intensive drive against rural poverty to a fight against similar conditions in Kenya that have been a factor behind the Mau Mau trouble in that British Crown Colony, Joseph Murumbi, Secretary of the Kenya African Union, has been studying this country's widespread community projects program undertaken with United States aid.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 19 -- John Ireland and Jack Palance are hoping to get into independent film production this summer and have their minds set on "Dark of the Moon" for the initial venture. The actors, both busy in pictures here at the moment, are negotiating for acquisition of the Howard Richardson-William Berney play through Rebecca Brownstein, New York attorney.

VIENNA, May 19 -- The Austrian Government announced today, greatly to the surprise of the United States High Commissioner's office here, that the United States had assured Government. the Austrian Ambassador in Washington it was prepared turn over the United States "Red, White, Red" radio network to the Austrian Government.

A representative gathering of industrialists, business leaders and educators met yesterday to form a Greater New York committee of the National Fund for Medical Education, which is seeking to raise $10,000,000 a year to meet a grave financial crisis in the nation's medical schools.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., renewed his demand on the New York City Transit Authority yesterday for an immediate meeting to discuss labor relations on the transit system in the event the authority takes over the lines from the Board of Transportation.

Thorley House of Flowers, Inc., now in the Carlyle Hotel, Madison Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, has sold the six-story building it formerly occupied at 4 West Fifty-sixth Street, near Fifth Avenue, to Fontana, Inc., in a deal negotiated by the Cross Brown Company.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- The American Federation of Labor will not accept the reform promises given to it by the racket-infested International Longshoremen's Association as adequate compliance with the parent organization's order to the dock union to clean house or face expulsion from the federtion.

Visitors at the annual women's recreation exhibit of articles made by the blind at The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, had only one major disappointment yesterday. Nothing was for sale. They were, however, allowed to look longingly at the bright hooked rugs, flowery spring hats and other handsome handicraft products made by the 225 exhibitors.

Grand Central Palace is being taken over by the Bureau of Internal Revenue; no more hemming and hawing about it. The big shows formerly held in the Palace are to move uptown in October to the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx. There they will hold forth until the Columbus Circle Coliseum is completed in 1956.

JERSEY CITY, May 19 -- This city's new administration took office today in a two-and-a-half-hour meeting that was bedlam from start to finish. The police described the crowd in the Assembly Chamber as the largest and most unruly in the City Hall's history.

To add a gracious note to one of the more convivial and leisurely activities of the day, the service of coffee after dinner, designers in Europe and this country have produced a variety of new patterns for the demi-tasse cup. Such a small item might make a suitable hostess gift, or, assembled in a group of matched or different designs, a present for a June bride.
The merger of Lee Simmons, Inc., and the McAllister Lighterage Line, Inc., two of the oldest and largest marine transportation and towing concerens on the East Coast, was announced yesterday.

The Public Education Association, 20 West Fortieth Street, said yesterday it was "shocked" at the statements made Monday night by Joseph Cavallaro, after his election as chairman of the Board of Higher Education.

A continuing high level of business in photography supplies as well as a moderate over-all increase in sales of the Tennessee Eastman division enabled the Eastman Kodak Company and subsidiaries in the United States to increase earnings for the twelve weeks ended on March 22, it was announced yesterday by Thomas J. Hargrave and Albert K. Chapman, chairman and president, respectively.

A sense of urgency apparently pervades the congress of the International Chamber of Commerce in Vienna. One speaker warned that the next few months may perhaps be the Western nations' last opportunity to create a trading system in which private traders can operate, while another, a distinguished American economist, foresaw the possibility of a major international payments crisis in the near future.

By a narrow margin of 46 to 37, the delegates of the National Health Council have rejected a recommendation of their board of directors that the council terminate ith activities because of insufficient operating funds, the unit reported yesterday.
