WEST POINT, N. Y. May 19 -- A four-run drive in the first and a three-run uprising in the ninth enabled New York University to score a 7 -- 4 victory over Army's baseball team at Doubleday Field today.
Prizes for the best annual reports submitted by Junior Achievement companies were presented in the board room of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday by Keith Funston, president of the institution.

Licensed Beverage Industries, Inc., public relations organization of the liquor industry, at its annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, elected R. E. Joyce of the National Distillers Products Corporation to be president for the coming year.

CINCINNATI, May 19 (AP) -- Right-hander Robin Roberts chalked up his sixth victory for the Phillies tonight as he stopped the last-place Redlegs on five hits for a 6-3 triumph. Homers were hit by Ted Kluszewski and Willard Marshall of Cincinnati and by Richie Ashburn and Willie Jones of the Phils.

WINNIPEG, May 19 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Wheat Board today increased the price of wheat in Canada almost 20 cents a bushel, and leading baking officials said the price of flour and bread is also expected to jump.

President Eisenhower has commended the nation-wide observance of "Know Your America Week," to be held June 8-14 under the sponsorship of the All-American Conference to Combat Communism. In a letter to the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, president and editor of The Christian Herald and chairman of the conference, President Eisenhower wrote in part:

Hank Bauer broke up a tight pitching duel between Johnny Sair and Ted Gray last night by blasting a homer into the left-field seats at the Stadium in the eleventh inning with Mickey Mantle on base. This wallop gave the first-place Yankees a 4-2 triumph over the last-place Tigers.

Since Stalin died there have been persistent reports of a possible reconciliation between Russia and Yugoslavia. These stories are based in the main on the interviews of the Soviet Foreign Minister with the Yugoslav Charge d'Affaires in Moscow, the first since the break four years ago, presumably held for the purpose of "normalizing" diplomatic relations.

VIENNA, May 19 -- Business leaders from all over the world were told today not to despair of getting a squarer deal in the American market. The advice came from United States business leaders speaking in the congress of the International Chamber of Commerce meeting here today.

A record volume of 3,000 tons of zinc was traded yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange. With new commission house buying against light commission house profit-taking and trade selling, zinc closed 10 to 17 points higher on 100 contracts.

With all the aplomb of a steeple jack or bridge painter, Mayor Ernst Jungen of Goteborg, Sweden's second largest city and her biggest port, climbed wind-swept catwalks yesterday to the upper reaches of the New York tower of the George Washington Bridge, 635 feet above the Hudson River.

May an Englishman whose business it is to teach American history in an English university and whose politics are conservative make some comments upon the controversy over Mr. Attlee's recent speech in the House of Commons?

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 19 -- Oliver Lyttelton, the British Colonial Secretary, at a press conference here today said that both he and the Governor of Kenya, Sir Evelyn Baring, felt that the "phase of decision" in the campaign to crush the Mau Mau terrorists had been reached and that there now was a chance of achieving speedy results.
Your May 15 editorial in defense of the pedestrian gives cheer and much needed hope to a group which is all too rapidly supplanting the American Indian as the so-called "vanishing Americans."

An announcement last night by the New York Counties Registered Nurses Association authorizing increases in fees effective July 1 for private - duty and general - staff nurses in New York hospitals was greeted coolly by a spokesman for the Greater New York Hospital Association.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America and former Economic Stabilizer under President Harry S. Truman, pleaded with Congress members today not to restrict international trade now.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Association for Childhood Education International, in a two-year plan of action now being sent to its 600 branches, has made strong and specific recommendations for a drive for more school construction in nursery schools, kindergartens and elementary grades.
TOKYO, Wednesday, May 20 -- The Chinese Communists formulated four points today that must be settled when negotiations for an armistice in Korea resume next week.

Former Gov. Walter E. Edge of New Jersey returned from a three-month tour of Europe and the Middle East yesterday with the opinion that Secretary of State John Foster Dulles "will find confusion in the seven Arab states."

The first flan rings made in this country are to be offered in the kitchen equipment departments of several stores here this week. Previously the small supply available was from abroad, where the utensils are used extensively for baking tarts or open pies.

If there were persons who had expected President Eisenhower to pull a fiscal rabbit out of a hat, as it were, in last night's radio address on the budget, they must have found his words somewhat disappointing. We doubt if there were many such persons. Most Americans, we suspect, have learned over the past twenty years that rabbits of this kind, intriguing creatures though they may be, come high.

TRENTON, May 19 -- Testimony that Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons was well aware of the impending publication and probable substance of an article on Bergen County corruption long before it actually appeared in The Saturday Evening Post was presented here today to the legislative committee investigating the ouster of Nelson F. Stamler.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Board of Governors of the American Bar Association visited President Eisenhower today and joined him in his endorsement of a $10,000 salary increase for members of Congress and for Federal judges.

A record $1,274,444,000 was spent in the United States and Canada last year for daily and Sunday newspapers, the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday. This includes $1,208,905,000 for the United States and $65,539,000 for Canada.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 19 -- Gen. Henri-Eugene Navarre arrived in Indo-China today to assume command of French Union forces here in the midst of a complicated picture marked by spotty military conditions in North Vietnam and Laos, a fluid political situation throughout the country and concrete signs that the French public is getting increasingly fed-up with the Indo-China war.

The failure of the Soviet Government to publish any comprehensive data to date on the state of its industrial and agricultural production in 1953 has created additional difficulties for Western analysts seeking to ascertain Soviet strength as a basis for recommendations concerning the needed level of defense preparations by the United States and its Allies.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, announced today that the staff of the Senate Investigations subcommittee, of which he is chairman, was "gathering material" that "indicated waste, incompetence and subversion" in the educational exchange program of the Government's international information and counter-propaganda system.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 19 -- Yugoslav Government sources insisted today they still had no evidence of a change in Moscow's attitude toward President Tito's regime.

Major changes have taken place in the New York City junior high school program within the last ten years. As is true in the elementary division, a more "permissive" atmosphere is now found in the ninety-two schools that have an enrollment of 110,000 pupils in the seventh, eighth and ninth grades.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Complete endorsement of the validity, prime security and tax-exempt status of new housing authority bonds was given to President Eisenhower today by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr.

Six women, charging "discrimination" against Negroes in the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's Parkchester housing development in the Bronx, chained themselves to chairs in the company's main office last night. At 3 o'clock this morning the women unlocked themselves and agreed to leave.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 19 -- Before Trygve Lie left for his native Norway, the United Nations paid $20,000 to its departing former Secretary General. Mr. Lie will receive a tax exempt pension of $10,000 a year for life.

Your editorial "A Soviet Opportunity," suggesting in the name of humanity that Russian-born wives of American citizens be permitted to join their husbands in this country, is very powerful and deserves the applause of decent men everywhere.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Conservative Republicans joined with a small group of Southern and border state Democrats today to restrict so sharply as virtually to defeat a proposal in the Senate to give President Eisenhower authority to impose a ninety-day freeze on prices and wages in the event of grave national emergency.

The first phase of the anti-trust trial of seventeen investment banking houses ended before Judge Harold R. Medina at the Federal court, here, yesterday afternoon, about two and one-half years after the trial's start.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee today approved the nomination of Dallas S. Townsend, 64-year-old New York lawyer, to be Assistant Attorney General in charge of alien property. The nomination now goes to the full committee.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today that business had continued strong and rising throughout the first quarter of this year.
Fashion designs that included those of ten students of the Parsons School of Design, who have won the Gold Thimble Awards were shown yesterday afternoon and evening at the Plaza Hotel.

BERLIN, May 19 -- The Czechoslovak C-47 airplane in which a three-man crew and one passenger escaped to West Germany March 23, was returned this morning to representatives of the Prague Government at Tempelhof Airfield.

"Where Main Street Meets the River," Hodding Carter's personal testament of his beliefs, ideals and goals, will be published Thursday by Rinehart. The author, a Nieman Fellow and winner of a Pulitzer Prize and a Guggenheim Fellowship, tells the story of his newspaper career from the editorship of The Hammond, La., Courier in the early Thirties to the present as editor of The Delta Democrat-Times.

Mrs. Mildred McAfee Horton, former president of Wellesley College and wartime head of the Waves, said yesterday the State Department had invited her to serve as United States delegate to the United Nations Economic and Social Commission, but had withheld the appointment.

Surging masses of dense smoke from a three-alarm $250,000 fire in an Eighth Avenue cafeteria opposite Madison Square Garden swept through the Broadway area up to Columbus Circle last night, disrupting vehicular traffic, delaying theatre patrons and forcing many passers-by to cover their faces against the choking fumes.
SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., May 19 -- Officials of a number of northern California universities and colleges denied today they had hired undercover agents to weed out subversive teachers.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations today backed the Eisenhower Administration's request for a one-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreement Act without limiting amendments.

The fourth encampment of the Children's International Summer Villages, which will be held in 1954, will be just outside this city. Several offers for a camping site to be decided upon later were made at the meeting of the organization Monday night, when preliminary plans were discussed and a planning committee formed.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Miss Bertha Adkins said tonight that she had "expressed regret" to Mrs. Horton over Mrs. Horton's failure to be named United States representative on the United Nations Economic and Social Commission.

BOSTON, May 19 -- A permanent neutral arbitrator for the Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., and the American Woolen Company denied today a company request for a 20 per cent wage cut for 16,000 employes in sixteen Northern mills.

The Korean armistice negotiations have been recessed again, until Monday, while the United Nations prepares what might prove to be a final compromise offer on the prisoner-of-war issue. This offer is now being discussed among the Governments having United Nations troops in Korea and will be framed in the light of some of the doubts and objections voiced by our allies regarding the previous proposal.

The Young Women's Republican Club of New York withdrew yesterday as a co-sponsor with the New York Young Republican Club of a luncheon meeting today at which James Wechsler, editor of The New York Post, will be the features speaker.

A New York University physics instructor and an interne at Kings County Hospital testified yesterday at the Federal Court perjury trial of William Perl that they had attended Communist meetings with Julius Rosenberg and Morton Sobell, convicted atom spies, and Perl in the Nineten Thirties when all were students at City College.

LOS ANGELES, May 19 -- People who are left with a total of less than one lung after surgery for tuberculosis often can still play golf and give birth to babies. This was asserted by surgical specialists at the annual convention of the National Tuberculosis Association here.

MELBOURNE, May 19 -- A rise in prices at Brisbane and Adelaide wool sales this week has been largely due to the activity of buyers believed to be acting for Central European countries behind the Iron Curtain, possibly also for Russia.
Ten persons were injured and thousands delayed yesterday morning in a mishap on the IND subway just north of the 145th Street station at St. Nicholas Avenue.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 19 (UP) -- An atomic device was exploded in a test today, showering radioactive particles on communities 100 miles away and forcing 5,000 persons to take shelter for three hours.

MILWAUKEE, May 19 -- Walter O'Malley, president of the Dodgers, is "not happy" about the sorry showing the Brooks have made on this first western trip and is "prepared to take steps," he told newspaper men this afternoon in a press conference initiated by him.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's radio report to the nation last night as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

PARIS, May 19 (AP) -- Vic Seixas, America's second-ranking tennis player, had no trouble today winning his opening match in the French tennis tournament, the first international competition of the year for the Philadelphian.

Teachers of adults must be prepared not only to meet the interests of individuals enrolled in their classes, but to tackle the needs of the communities where they live, speakers told the second day's conference yesterday of the New York State Adult Education Association at the Statler Hotel.

NEW HAVEN, May 19 -- James T. Babb, librarian of Yale University, announced today the presentation to the university of more than a dozen of what he described as the rarest and most valuable books ever printed in English, the gift of five alumni and a New York philanthropist.
Mayor Impellitteri issued a proclamation yesterday designating Friday as Maritime Day, on which the city will pay its annual tribute, to the United States Merchant Marine.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Michigan-Wisconsin Pipe Line Company of Detroit applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to sell $20,000,000 worth of 3 1/4 per cent notes due July 1, 1954. The company wants to exchange the notes with three banks for a like principal amount of outstanding 3 per cent notes of the company due on July 1 of this year.

HARTFORD, May 19 -- The Connecticut State Senate, by an overwhelming margin, approved today a bill authorizing construction of the Fairfield County Thruway, to connect with the New York State Thruway at Greenwich, and its extension across eastern Connecticut to the town of Killingly at the Rhode Island border.

Despite demands by City Council President Rudolph Halley and Minority Leader Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan Republican - Liberal, that the proposed $1,528,814,950 budget for 1953-54 be rejected, the Council approved it yesterday by twenty-two ayes, two nays and one not voting.
The State of South Carolina borrowed $15,000,000 in the public market yesterday on school bonds maturing from 1954 to 1968 at an interest rate of 2.2 per cent.

The Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans, covering hospitalization and doctors' fees, respectively, are ready to expand and improve their benefit programs as the subscribing public may require the American Management Association's national insurance conference was told yesterday at the Statler Hotel.

Fifty detectives and policewomen were searching Central Park and pressing a painstaking hunt of rooming houses around the park yesterday for a woman who had kidnapped a 2-year-old boy and his year-old baby sister from a Washington couple last Friday night.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 19 (AP) -- The Iranian Government today ordered the expulsion of Marc Purdue, Associated Press correspondent, for having sent abroad what it called "false and provocative news against the interests of Iran."

ATHENS, May 19 -- Local press inferences that French Foreign Minister Georges Bidault, in Greece for a four-day official visit, had had as his purpose the aligning of this country with France and Britain in a "third force" opposed equally to the Soviet Union and the United States were negated today by M. Bidault himself on the eve of his departure.

Raymond Swing, radio commentator who for two years has been the principal political analyst for the Voice of America, resigned yesterday, saying the agency "has been crippled, perhaps beyond recovery, by slanderous attacks on its integrity."

A Supreme Court jury sitting before Justice J. Brady voted 10 to 2 yesterday to dismiss forty-six suits seeking $2,000,000 damages from the American Ice Company because of the collapse of a wall of an unused ice plant six years ago.

ROME, May 19 -- A letter from the Christian Democratic Deputy who tried in 1951 to explore the possibilities of a religious truce between the Vatican and the Kremlin indicated today his efforts had come to nothing because Moscow's reply could be interpreted only as an attempt on the late Premier Stalin's part to have a little joke at the Pope's expense.

Performances of the Sadler's Wells Ballet, which will open on the night of Sept. 13 at the Metropolitan Opera House, have been taken over to raise funds for various philanthropies. The second performance, on the night of Sept. 15, will aid The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind.

The question of whether we should legislate high or low tariff rates is one of simple arithmetic and standards of living. It is not whether the United States is generous enough to give money to foreign friends in order that those friends may buy our products. That is good business if it does not increase taxes too much.

JONES BEACH, L. I., May 19 -- The Long Island State Park Commission issued an order today for a 1 A. M. curfew at Jones Beach Park, as the result of an attack by hoodlums on a college students' picnic here last Saturday night.
NEWARK, May 19 -- The five City Commissioners took their oaths of office today and, in an organization meeting almost free of conflict, approved departmental assignments previously agreed upon.

HARTFORD, May 19 -- Gov. John Davis Lodge took to the people of Connecticut tonight his opposition to a $41,900,000 tax increase program advocated by the Joint Finance Committee of the General Assembly.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 19 -- While the Delaware River Port Authority prepared to offer $100,000,000 worth of bonds for sale tomorrow, with which to build a new bridge linking Philadelphia and Gloucester, N. J., Representative Charles A. Wolverton, Republican of Camden, continued his battle to prevent a rise in tolls on the present stand.

In order to understand the problem which William N. Oatis faced as Associated Press correspondent in Prague (and this would apply to all American correspondents except Communists) it is important to know the press law under which he was condemned.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Powerful Republican Senators were vexed today at the decision of the United States to soften its terms for a Korean truce, and Senatorial displeasure was being directed in private at the Eisenhower Administration.

An amusing, colorful boutique, the Capri Shop, has just opened at Bloomingdale's. It is in the Downstairs Store. Bright separates and accessories, many of which were imported, are featured and nothing in the shop is priced over $10.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- More than 100 representatives of thirty Protestant and Eastern Orthodox communions were told tonight by Lieut. Col.. John I. Rhea of New York, deputy chaplain of First Army Headquarters, that "an alarming shortage" of chaplains now threatens the country's military forces.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 -- Attendance at the fifth National Material Handling Exposition in Convention Hall, where 340 concerns are displaying equipment valued at $10,000,000, rose to 15,000 this afternoon. The two-day registration included top-level industrialists from this and other countries.

IT begins to look as if boxing's confusion already has spread to the race tracks. The script called for Native Dancer, the uncrowned 3-year-old champion, to knock the block off Dark Star, the pretender for the title, in the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday. But someone already has beaten the Dancer to the punch.

There was a possibility that, because of a scheduled July 1 increase in rates, the 70,000 to 80,000 city employes now covered by the Health Insurance Plan would be withdrawn from the plan. Officials estimate that city employes now make up about two-thirds of the total number of the group's subscribers.

By the election of his fellow board members, Joseph B. Cavallaro, Brooklyn lawyer, succeeds Ordway Tead as chairman of the Board of Higher Education. He was an O'Dwyer appointee of 1946. In an interview after his election he said he was in favor of "strong measures in dealing with Communist teachers" and in trying to root them out of the city's colleges.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York obtained a twenty-year blanket first mortgage loan of $550,000 from the Empire City Savings Bank on the fifteen-story Bar Building at 36 West Forty-fourth Street, and the adjoining five-story New York Bar Association Building at No. 42.

CAIRO, May 19 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Egypt's Premier, said tonight that German military experts attached to the Egyptian Army had brought about improvements in the nation's armed forces that the British military mission had been unable, or unwilling, to accomplish in ten years.

CINCINNATI, May 19 (AP) -- The Redlegs announced today that they would begin receiving applications after Saturday for reserved seat tickets for the major league all-star game to be played here July 14.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Bureau of Prisons has closed on a stand-by basis two of six camps activated a year ago for quartering subversive agents in time of national emergency. The camps are at the wartime relocation center at Tule Lake, Calif., and at a former air base at Wickenberg, Ariz.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Following is the 45-to-41 vote by which the Senate today approved a controls bill amendment by Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, that would require a declaration of war or a concurrent resolution by Congress before the President could impose a stand-by ninety-day freeze on prices, wages land rents:

On the eve of the seventy-fifth birthday of the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, which arrives next Sunday, Union Theological Seminary announces the establishment of a visiting professorship to bear his name, endowed by a $250,000 gift from John D. Rockefeller 3d.
Bond men who thought they had "seen everything" in the way of marketing deals rubbed their eyes yesterday at the newest suspense piece in the corporate bond market.
ST. LOUIS, May 19 (AP) -- Stan Musial's double in the seventh inning drove in the second of two unearned runs and enabled the Cardinals to defeat Johnny Lindell and the Pirates, 2 -- 1, tonight.

CAIRO, May 19 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Egypt's Premier, said tonight that German military experts attached to the Egyptian Army had brought about improvements in the nation's armed forces that the British military mission had been unable, or unwilling, to accomplish in ten years.

CINCINNATI, May 19 (AP) -- The Redlegs announced today that they would begin receiving applications after Saturday for reserved seat tickets for the major league all-star game to be played here July 14.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Bureau of Prisons has closed on a stand-by basis two of six camps activated a year ago for quartering subversive agents in time of national emergency. The camps are at the wartime relocation center at Tule Lake, Calif., and at a former air base at Wickenberg, Ariz.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Following is the 45-to-41 vote by which the Senate today approved a controls bill amendment by Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, that would require a declaration of war or a concurrent resolution by Congress before the President could impose a stand-by ninety-day freeze on prices, wages land rents:

On the eve of the seventy-fifth birthday of the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, which arrives next Sunday, Union Theological Seminary announces the establishment of a visiting professorship to bear his name, endowed by a $250,000 gift from John D. Rockefeller 3d.
Bond men who thought they had "seen everything" in the way of marketing deals rubbed their eyes yesterday at the newest suspense piece in the corporate bond market.
ST. LOUIS, May 19 (AP) -- Stan Musial's double in the seventh inning drove in the second of two unearned runs and enabled the Cardinals to defeat Johnny Lindell and the Pirates, 2 -- 1, tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Owen Clarke of Yakima, Wash., was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission. If confirmed by the Senate he will serve until Dec. 31, 1959.
BOSTON, May 19 (UP) -- Milt Bolling rapped a single off Satchel Paige in the eighth inning today to give the Red Sox a 4-3 victory over the Browns before 3,733 at Tenway Park.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- International intrigue in World War I again became a feature of the du Pont anti-trust trial in Federal District Court today when Sir William Wiseman, who headed British intelligence in the United States in that conflict, said he had investigated rumors about Kuhn, Loeb Co.'s being pro-German and found them to be false.

MILWAUKEE, May 19 -- Home runs by George Shuba and Duke Snider and the seven-hit pitching of Russ (Mad Monk) Meyer gave the Dodgers a 4-1 triumph over the Braves tonight and rudely jolted the idols of Milwaukee out of their first-place tie with the Phils.

The sanguinary rioting in Nigeria will disappoint all who are working and hoping for the progress of democracy in Africa. It will give comfort and determination to those like Prime Minister Malan and the Nationalists in South Africa or some of the settlers in Kenya and Central Africa who have been saying that the African is not ready or able to rule himself.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Eisenhower said today that there was no place in this country for "second-class citizens."

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., May 19 -- An application by the General Electric Company for the rezoning of 315 acres at Valhalla, an unincorporated hamlet whose governmental seat is this village, was unanimously approved tonight by the Mount Pleasant Town Board.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 -- J. Harry LaBrum, president of the Chamber of Commerce of Greater Philadelphia predicted today that a forty-foot Delaware River Channel to Trenton would one day make this port the largest in the nation.

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 19 -- More than 1,000 members of parent-teacher organizations from all over the United States heard themselves described as ignorant, inept, naive and blundering by an educator at their annual national banquet tonight.
CHICAGO, May 19 -- The Giants brought misery to 8,135 Cub sympathizers today as they defeated Phil Cavarretta's Bruins in ten innings, 6 to 4, in the opener of a two-game series.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 19 -- Dispatches from Macassar reported today that Lieut. Col. Warouw, acting commander of the Seventh Indonesian Military Territory, which stretches from Celebes to the shores of western New Guinea, had emphatically denied official Dutch statements that they had repulsed an armed Indonesian infiltration into Vogelkop last week.
TOKYO, Wednesday, May 20 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,620, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korean time:

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Dr. Allen V. Astin, temporarily reinstated as head of the National Bureau of Standards, and Craig R. Scheaffer, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, popularly credited with prompting Dr. Astin's ouster, which was later rescinded, shared a speaker's platform here today -- but neither referred directly to their differences.

BUENOS AIRES, May 19 (AP) -- The Argentine Government opened the way tonight for United States news agencies to distribute news in this country again, after having banned incoming news through these agencies since May 12.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- Ellery W. Stone, president of the American Cable and Radio Corporation, said today his company was "interested" in acquiring Western Union's cable system, either by itself or in conjunction with R. C. A. Communications, Inc.

MEXICO CITY, May 16 -- The spirit of Pan-American cooperation has been frittered away to nothing since the end of World War II, and only bold new United States initiative can restore good hemisphere relations, according to Ezequiel Padilla, Mexico's wartime Foreign Minister.
NEW DELHI, India, May 19 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles, the United States Secretary of State, arrived here today by plane for a two-day visit and his first meeting with Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Warning that freedom still was in danger from the Soviet Union's aggressive designs, President Eisenhower called on the American people tonight to continue to bear the current tax burden and even to forgo two tax reductions due next year.

The management of the General Aniline and Film Corporation won a larger voice in the direction of the company yesterday as James Forrestal, John C. Franklin and Franklin A. Gibbons, vice presidents, were among the nine new directors elected.

CHATSWORTH, N. J., May 19 -- State Highway Commissioner Ransford J. Abbott was seriously injured here early today when the automobile he was driving plowed into the side of a Jersey Central Lines freight locomotive.
TOKYO, May 19 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida, who led Japan to independence, won the right this afternoon to form his fifth postwar administration.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (AP) -- Harry Byrd, the American League rookie of the year in 1952, gave only two singles tonight as he pitched the Athletics to a 2-1 victory over the White Sox. Joe DeMaestri hit a homer as Philadelphia's lead-off batter in the first inning.

The TV-Radio Workshop of the Ford Foundation will produce a second television program, beginning in September, intended primarily for young persons in the 8 to 16 group. Entitled "Junior Omnibus," it will be presented over the N. B. C. network on Sundays from 3:30 to 4 P. M.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, today announced Morris U. Cohen of Brooklyn, a physicist and chemist, was "one of the worst men as a security risk" ever to appear before the Senate Internal Security subcommitte in its investigation of communism.

BERLIN, May 19 -- Soviet authorities today handed over to liaison officials of the United States Berlin command two privates who were seized by East zone police last November 26 on the boundary between the United States sector of Berlin and the Soviet Zone. They were returned at Karlshorst, Soviet headquarters.

ORANGEBURG, S. C., May 19 -- Dr. Lewis K. McMillan, Professor of History at South Carolina's only state-supported college for Negroes here, who recently published a book evaluating and criticizing Negro higher education in the state, has been dismissed from the faculty, effective with the expiration of his contract June 30.

Through the purchase of the dwelling at 216 Berkeley Place, Brooklyn, from Mrs. Eleanor Banghte, Jacob Mark Sons have completed the assemblage of a site of 9,500 square feet for improvement with an eight-story apartment house to contain sixty-four suites.
ALBANY, May 19 -- The State Department of Public Works announced today that it would no longer issue any permits for motor vehicle races on the State highways.

Unable to resist a long-felt ambition to become a producer, Michael Abbott, who has had plenty of backstage experience, feels he is headed in the right direction this time. He has acquired Rosemary Casey's comedy, "Late Love," which received a favorable send-off when tested in March by Margo Jones' band of torchbearers in Dallas.

PARIS, May 19 -- Premier Rene Mayer, facing a hostile Assembly tonight, demanded a vote of confidence on the article in his financial bill that would grant him special powers to effect economies in the budget and to reform the present Administration.

LONDON, May 19 (AP) -- A British concern has won an order for electric power cables from Seattle's light department with a bid of $103,600. The W. T. Henley Telegraph Works Company of London said it had received the contract in competition with United States concerns "undoubtedly because of the very favorable price and delivery date quoted."

ST. LOUIS, May 20 (AP) -- Red-Schoendienst, with a two-run homer and a three-run double among his four hits, led a seventeen-hit Cardinal attack tonight as the Red Birds defeated the Pirates, 11 -- 6. The Bucs got fourteen safeties, including a pair of run-scoring doubles by Ralph Kiner.

Those selling goods and services to industry will find more of their potential concentrated in New York City's five counties than in any comparable market, it was said yesterday by Sales Management Magazine. The statement is based on a recent survey by the publication, which showed that the city ranks first in manufacture with $7,038,000,000 value added (selling price less cost of material) last year and with 998,300 persons employed in industrial production.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities, shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended May 13:

Events today: Gordon Jones, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 12 noon; Beatrice Brown, pianist, Steinway Hall, 8 P. M.; Excerpts from "Madame Butterfly," Mannes College of Music, 8:30; program of operatic excerpts, Turtle Bay Music School, 8:30; Ruby Yoshino, soprano, and Marc d'Albert, pianist, Community Church of New York, 8:30.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 20 -- Mrs. Margaret Chew Welch of Syosset told a Nassau County Court jury today that she resented being referred to as the complaining witness in the case against her girlhood friend, Mrs. Ethel Carhart Jones Taylor, who is accused of stealing $10,000 worth of jewels from her home in April, 1951.
OSLO, Norway, May 20 -- Norway seems to be gradually overcoming her objections to letting in foreign military personnel to man some of the country's North Atlantic Treaty Organization bases.

The journalist, however distinguished and experienced, is not necessarily or uniquely qualified to determine the scope of the First Amendment's guarantee of freedom of the press. Arthur Krock's column on Senator McCarthy's examination of James Wechsler, editor of The New York Post, is based on a dangerous misconception of the nature of law in general and the Constitution in particular.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Columbia University's plans for its two hundredth anniversary were laid before a House judiciary subcommittee today in support of a resolution authorizing governmental recognition and participation in the event.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- President Eisenhower told the makers of Ford automobiles tonight how he had souped up a "Model T" he and his wife had bought about 1920.

The Reid Foundation yesterday approved continuation of a program under which six American newspaper men and women will receive fellowships of $5,000 each for study abroad in 1954. Candidates must have had at least five years of newspaper experience and must be sponsored by newspaper executives.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Wayne A. Johnston, president of the Illinois Central Railroad, told stockholders today that he expects the remainder of 1953 to be a fairly satisfactory year. "With the Illinois Central's net income being somewhere near that of 1952" when it was $23,203,516.

A crane operator played his part yesterday in building a bridge. He manipulated levers to swing gently into place five steel girders, each fifty-four feet long and each weighing from fifteen to twenty-two and one-half tons. The pink-hued girders rested finally on sand-smoothed ledges between a concrete abutment and pier.

PARIS, May 20 -- Frequent cuts in electric power and the lowering of gas pressure disrupted activity in home and industry throughout France and Algeria today as gas and electrical workers staged a 24-hour strike in support of wage demands.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., called today for establishment of a Federal advisory council to make a continuing study of Communist subversion in this country and to cooperate with legislative, law enforcing and investigative agencies in combating it.

HARTFORD, May 20 -- The House of Representatives in the General Assembly tonight approved and sent to the Senate a bill for a sweeping reorganization of Connecticut's administration of public education.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 20 -- Joe Castle pitched a seven-hitter today as Princeton downed Fordham, 1 -- 0, in baseball at University Field. The shut-out was the Tigers' seventh and their ninth triumph against five setbacks and one tie.

Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's sales at $158,286,000 for the first quarter of 1953 were larger than for any entire year from 1946 through 1949, President Robert E. Gross reported yesterday in Burbank, Calif. Gross earnings were $10,921,000 and net $3,501,000 after providing $7,420,000 for taxes.

MARIETTA, Ohio, May 20 -- One of the world's largest plants for producing the alloying ingredients vital to modern special-purpose steels is approaching completion near here on 750 acres of former farmland on the Ohio River.

Tied, 38 -- 38, with Haaren going into the final event, Stuyvesant placed first, third, and tied for fourth in the high jump to win the annual Public Schools Athletic League track and field championship of Manhattan at Van Cortlandt Park, Bronx, yesterday.

After protesting again and again that he did not tell lies, William Perl was confronted on cross-examination at his Federal court perjury trial yesterday with false and conflicting statements he had made, sometimes under oath.

To nobody's surprise the City Council has approved Mayor Impellitteri's $1,528,814,950 expense budget for 1953-1954. The Council may reduce or omit any item in the budget as adopted by the Board of Estimate, except certain fixed charges. But it made no changes, as usual.

" Sweeney Agonistes," the musical setting by Richard Winslow of the unfinished poem by T. S. Eliot, had its first performance in this city last evening at the Brander Matthews Theatre of Columbia University.

The aggregate short interest in stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose 18,393 shares between April 15 and May 15, the exchange reported yesterday. The figure on the latter date was 1,853,266 shares, against 1,834,873 shares a month earlier.

An original play, "The Chess Game," by Robert Howard Lindsay, which attracted attention last February when it was done by the Kraft Television Theatre over the National Broadcasting Company network, is headed for the Broadway stage.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, May 20 -- The Screen Writers Guild reported today that fifty-six television film producers had "voluntarily" subscribed to the terms of the minimum basis agreement negotiated by the Guild last February with the thirteen member companies of the Alliance of Television Film Producers.

The State of New York and the Province of Ontario agreed yesterday on joint action aimed at destroying a racket in Canadian "moose pasture" securities that has drained an estimated $500,000,000 from unwary American investors in the last decade.

FORT WORTH, Tex., May 20 (AP) -- The Air Force today disclosed the first jet airplane flight over the North Pole, the first nonstop flight of six jet B-47 bombers across the Atlantic and the breaking of all distance and endurance records for jet planes by a B-47.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- The National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. today appointed a committee of fifteen, headed by the Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, presiding bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church to watch developments in Congress and elsewhere that "threaten the freedom of the people and institutions of the United States."

HURON, S. D., May 20 -- States of the Missouri River Basin are expected to require three times as much electrical power within the next eighteen years as they do now and these needs can be met only by a closer understanding and cooperation between Federal and private power producers, a report public today asserted.

Plans for a ten-story office and warehouse building on West Thirty-fourth Street to be occupied in its entirety by Robert Hall Clothes, Inc., were announced yesterday by Simon Brothers, builders, who have owned the site adjoining Manhattan Center since 1945.

For no immediately apparent reason the stock market suddenly burst into activity in the noon hour yesterday, shoved sales to the best level since April 24 and closed with the best day's gain since March 24 for THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average.

Cash awards have been presented by eight leading Manhattan department stores to Long Island University retailing students for outstanding work in their senior year, Prof. Howard K. Rice, chairman of the Department of Retailing, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- A sharp drop in May wheat prices started another wave of selling in other wheat futures, and also helped unsettle other grains. Corn and oats were relatively steady in the early trading, but May liquidation was too much for the demand and prices receded in the late trade.
YONKERS, May 20 (AP) -- Singing Sword, an eligible for the Hambletonian, scored an impressive victory tonight in a $5,000 trot for 3-year-olds at the Grand Circuit meeting at Yonkers Raceway.

TOKYO, May 20 -- United Nations military authorities worked today on modified proposals for the disposition of anti-Communist prisoners after a truce in Korea. The proposals are to be presented at Panmunjom Monday when the plenary sessions of the armistice parleys resume after an eight-day recess.

MILWAUKEE, May 20 -- The Dodgers returned to form in Milwaukee. On their first visit to this new National League town the Brooks made it two straight over the Braves, winning today's game, 7 -- 2, before a crowd of 23,450.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (UP) -- The Eisenhower Administration today cut proposed veteran costs for next year by $279,168,000.

A decline of 1,922,000 barrels last week in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, supples were 155,415,000 barrels, compared with 157,337,000 a week earlier and 122,161,000 a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP) -- Joe Astroth singled home Cass Michaels from third with two out in the ninth tonight to give the Athletics their second straight 2-1 victory over the White Sox in a pitching duel between southpaws Morris Martin of the A's and Billy Pierce.
Net income of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company and subsidiaries dropped more than 26 per cent in the first quarter, compared with the like period last year, the company reported yesterday.

BOSTON, May 20 (UP) -- Del Wilber hit his third pinch home run of the year in the fourteenth inning today to beat the Browns for the Red Sox, 3 -- 2, in the American league's longest game of the season before 4,121 fans at Fenway Park. As a result, Boston vaulted from fourth to second place when the White Sox and Indians lost tonight.

NEW HAVEN, May 20 -- The Yale Daily News, the oldest college daily newspaper in this country, celebrated its seventy-fifth anniversary at a dinner here tonight but unhappily there was a serpent in the ivy.

The six Thursday evening concerts to be given this summer at the Lewisohn Stadium will be broadcast by WQXR, the radio station of THE NEW YORK TIMES. The series will include the annual Gershwin memorial concert July 16.

Saks-34th deserves a round of applause for its excellent showing of summer fashions last night at the Martinique Hotel. Down-to-earth in price and selected to cover almost every need in a summer wardrobe, the presentation ran the gamut from beach to cocktail fashions, including many designs from well known manufacturers.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, announced yesterday the formation of a committee of fifteen industrial and business executives that will seek the financial support of leading corporations for Columbia's projected $22,150,000 Engineering Center.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 20 -- The Government today issued a forced labor decree applicable only to Africans in Kenya colony. It empowers British district commissioners to force native Africans to work for a maximum of ninety days a year with or without pay at the commissioner's discretion.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Angry and apparently puzzled members of the Senate Investigations subcommittee decided today to call upon President Eisenhower for a personal statement of his position and policy on continued and increasing trade with Red China by vessels flying the flags of Allied countries.

Revision of United States Foreign economic policy in the direction of freer trade -- meaning chiefly a willingness to accept more imports from other free nations -- will depend largely on strong and persistent leadership by President Eisenhower and his Administration.

VIENNA, May 20 (AP) -- A prominent British economist told the International Chamber of Commerce today that "a quasi-revolution" in United States commercial policy and administration was needed to help make the pound sterling convertible into dollars.

This is, of course, the season in which to resume that very worthy institution, the picnic. On the hills just now the dogwood is unfolding its welcome to the traveler, and the jack-in-the-pulpit is preaching his sermon to the spring.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 20 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Brooklyn Democrat, called upon his party tonight to fight the "spreading evil" he said was the result of the activities of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.
The city of Dallas, Tex., announced yesterday that it will receive bids on June 22 on bond issues totaling $10,200,000.
BALTIMORE, May 20 (AP) -- "The Gray Horse" tested the Pimlico race track for the first time this morning and the railbird experts unanimously conceded he would win Saturday's Preakness.

LONDON, May 20 (Reuters) -- Kenneth Rive, 36-year-old British film distributor, announced tonight that he would fly to Moscow tomorrow on Russia's invitation to foster an exchange of "non-political" motion pictures between the two countries.

A local reader complains that he lacks choice in the milk he buys, that it is all 3.3 per cent in butter-fat, the minimum set by the New York City Department of Health. He longs for the "milk of the Nineteen Twenties and Thirties that had two to three inches of yellow cream on top -- cream that was hard to pour from the bottle."

VIENNA, May 20 -- President Antonin Zapotocky and Karol Bacilek, Deputy Premier and Security Minister, have conceded during the last few days that the food supply of Czechoslovakia has broken down and that as a result the people are in a state of smoldering discontent.

According to an article which appeared in THE TIMES on May 12, Mrs. Frances L. Spain, a new official at the New York Public Library, was reported to have said that we need not be despondent over the inroads television is making "in children's reading time"; for the problem can be solved by capitalizing "'on the things' in TV * * * that attract children."

BAYONNE, N. J., May 20 -- Up to the present, no item has been too large or too small to upset the calm, unhurried routine of the disposal experts of the Navy supply depot here. They process everything from a 225-ton, 110-foot long surplus barge down to excess pins, thread, needles and shoelaces.

NEW ORLEANS, May 20 (UP) -- A score of flooded rivers and bayous turned southwest Louisiana into a land of muddy, swirling lakes today and at least 17,000 refugees camped on dry ground wherever they could find it. Water ringed half a dozen towns in the Cajun country.

Commodity prices closed irregular yesterday in continued light trading on the New York exchanges. Sugar, hides and zinc were moderately active. Potatoes, coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, zinc and tin were lower. Hides, sugar, cocoa and rubber ended higher and lead and wool closed mixed.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 20 -- The director of the national register being compiled by the Nationalist Government to implement plans for the segregation of all those considered to be nonwhite persons in this country has called on Mrs. N. E. B. Ormonde to prove that she and her baby daughter are white and not of mixed blood.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- In a statement issued this evening the State Department said that it had received "the utmost and speediest cooperation" from the F. B. I. on investigations of Presidential appointees.

Directors of the world's largest corporate enterprise, the $12,000,000,000 American Telephone and Telegraph Company, voted yesterday to continue the communications concern's quarterly dividend of $2.25 a capital share. This marked the declaration of the 129th consecutive quarterly dividend at the rate of $9 a year.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP) -- Benjamin F. Fairless, board chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, called tonight for peace between labor and management "based on mutual confidence, respect and understanding."

GLEN HEAD, L. I., May 20 -- Two public links golfers from Brooklyn, Bruno Serafini and Lou Kaufman, members of the Shore View Club who play at the Dyker Beach course, won the principal prize at the Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day handicap team tournament at the Brookville Country Club today.

Two new films open at first run theatres today. At the Radio City Music Hall is Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Young Bess," starring Jean Simmons, Stewart Granger, Deborah Kerr, Charles Laughton and Kay Walsh. In featured roles are Guy Rolfe, Kathleen Byron and Cecil Kellaway.

If, as Emily Dickinson said, "There is no frigate like a book to take us lands away," then it probably follows that there is no frigate like a book to bring us home again. Either way, books are being sought -- every week, but this week especially -- by the Merchant Marine Library Association, an organization dedicated to establishing libraries on merchant ships and to lending books to merchant sailors for their stays at sea.

Even though the race was in the Widener chute, where it's usually difficult to follow what's going on till the horses run past the stands, it was easy to keep track of the up-front proceedings in the filly division of the National Stallion Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday.

PARIS, May 20 -- At formal signing ceremonies of the revised conventions settling the economic union between France and the Saar, both Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, and Johannes Hoffmann, Saar Premier, stressed today their desire for a European status as the ultimate solution for the territory.
A broad extension of coverages was announced yesterday by Group Health Insurance, Inc., New York's oldest nonprofit health insurance organization, on its fifteenth anniversary.
The importance of black and white as a summer color scheme was strongly reaffirmed yesterday in Bonwit Teller's showing of cabana designs at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
CINCINNATI, May 20 (AP) -- The Redlegs batted Curt Simmons as if he were a practice pitcher today to drive him off the mound and defeat the Phils, 14 to 5.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 20 -- Embarking on its first venture in public education, the Westchester County Board of Supervisors voted this afternoon to operate the Institute of Applied Arts and Sciences here after the state relinquished control Sept. 1.

In the last six months, the airlines that conduct operations at the city's two major airports and at Newark have reduced by more than one-third low flying over the communities surrounding the terminals, it was reported yesterday.

The two-story taxpayer containing eight stores and seven apartments on a plot 125 by 100 feet at the southeast corner of 164th Street and Crocheron Avenue in Flushing, Queens, has been sold by Harry Sadigur to Herbert Lieblein. Thomas G. Sarris was the broker.

Though it has been shown up as the tool of a foreign Government, the Communist party in France succeeded in regaining some lost ground in the recent municipal elections. These local gains do not amount to much of themselves, but they reflect an opposition to the Government which affects the Deputies in the National Assembly and darkens the prospects of the Mayer Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- A crusade to restore in administrative government and in the courts "a procedure that respects the dignity and worth of the individual" was commended to lawyers today by Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court in an address to the American Law Institute.

MEXICO CITY, May 20 -- The Mexican Government moved another step today toward untangling its long standing foreign debt problems by decreeing a new period of registration for owners of government and railroad bonds covered by a previous agreement with the International Committee of Bankers on Mexico.

MOSCOW, Thursday, May 21 (Reuters) -- The only Australian held by the North Koreans -- a priest -- will be released soon and repatriated via Moscow, the Australian Embassy said here today. Father John Crosbie has been a Communist prisoner for almost three years.

After floundering around to even less effect than their hapless opponents for half the contest, the Yankees pulled themselves together and beat the Tigers, 9 -- 8, before 9,013 spectators at the Stadium yesterday.

A book of memoirs by still another of our adversaries in the last war will be added to the growing shelf by Dutton in August. It is "Franz Von Papen -- Memoirs," a 622-page autobiography of the German leader.
Martha Graham, in her season at the Alvin Theatre, last night restored to her repertory "Deaths and Entrances" after an absence of several seasons, and a triumphant restoration it proved to be.

A diamond merchant who hoped to make a sizable sale to a prospective "customer" from Chicago yesterday afternoon wound up being relieved at pistol point of five pieces of jewelry valued at $56,500 by the "customer" and an accomplice.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., May 20 (AP) -- F. W. Woolworth Company hopes to add forty new stores to its chain this year in a move to combat increased competition from chain drug stores and supermarkets, A. L. Cornwell, president and chairman, told the annual meeting here today.

The earnings of the Sinclair Oil Corporation for the rest of this year are likely to compare more favorably with those of 1952 than they did in the first quarter of this year, when they were about $4,300,000 less than in the similar period last year, P. C. Spencer, president, told stockholders at their meeting here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Thousand-mile-an-hour guided missiles will soon he protecting the New York metropolitan area from high-level enemy bombing attacks. This became known today as the Army announced that it intended to retain the six-mile northern New Jersey spit of Sandy Hook for "defenses of the New York City area."

PARIS, May 20 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, Fla., America's No. 1 player, scored a straight-set victory today in his first appearance in the French tennis tournament. Second-ranked Vic Seixas of Philadelphia dropped a set before defeating Rolando Del Bello, an Italian Davis Cup player.

Sixteen hundred of the city's senior residents ranging in age from 60 to 103 years, are taking part in what is probably the most impressive annual hobby show staged under the sponsorship of the city's Welfare and Health Council and fifty-six institutions and social agencies.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 20 -- A 21-year-old Polish Air Force pilot, Lieut. Zdzislaw Jazwenski, landed his MIG-15 jet fighter plane at Roenne on the Danish island of Bornholm in the Baltic early today, making good his escape from Poland.

Mrs. Mildred McAfee Horton said yesterday that the State Department, in a letter to her, had attested there was "no question of my personal loyalty," in its withholding of an appointment it had invited her to take as United States delegate to the United Nations Social Commission. She added that the letter was written before the matter became public.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- President Eisenhower started the action that led to the release of William N. Oatis, imprisoned Associated Press correspondent, in a personal letter sent to President Antonin Zapotocky of Communist Czechoslovakia on March 30. The White House made public tonight an exchange of letters between the two Presidents.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (UP) -- The House Un-American Activities Committee said today it had decided to make no changes in its methods of ferreting out Communists wherever it found them.

Ladies Day Out, a weekly event dedicated to the entertainment, peace of mind and self-improvement of young mothers of the Hudson Guild, has proved so popular that it will become a regular part of the neighborhood house's program when its ten-week trial session ends next week, H. Daniel Carpenter, director of the guild, announced yesterday.

LONDON, May 20 (Reuters) -- The British Government tonight ordered a inquiry into the allegation made in Washington today that two British ships carried Chinese Communist troops along the Chinese coast last year.

This country's merchant marine needs the support of domestic industry and business at a time when only through superior operating skills is it holding its own against foreign competition, Walter E. Maloney, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, said here yesterday.
The adage that lightning never strikes twice in the same place was disproved again yesterday in a shipboard heroin seizure.

The Winston-Salem Journal for May 15 carried an editorial from a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES, telling of the University of North Carolina's new medical center at Chapel Hill. As a citizen of North Carolina I appreciate this tribute to the state and to its justly famous university.

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 20 -- The high cost of mental and emotional disturbance in money and wrecked lives was stressed here today at the annual convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Uncorking their grandest offensive of the year, the Giants brought their first western jaunt of the campaign to a triumphant close today as they crushed the Cubs, 16 to 6, for a sweep of the two-game series.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 20 -- Five hundred eighty-seven members of Princeton University's class of 353 have taken out memorial insurance policies with a total value of $215,208 at maturity, Samuel Y. Gibbon Jr. of Jenkintown, Pa., director of the class memorial fund drive, announced today.
No "climate of fear" exists in the city's public schools and most teachers are not afraid or too timid to take up controversial issues in the classroom, the Board of Education said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message on taxes sent to Congress today:

State Rent Administrator Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday that rent reductions up to 43 per cent and 25 per cent, respectively, had been imposed on two Harlem landlords who failed to show that they were making ordered repairs.

The proclamation by Mayor Impelitteri of May as Cerebral Palsy Month draws attention to the 1953 appeal for funds of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, 47 West Fifty-seventh Street, New York 19. This year the organization must raise $1,000,000 to continue and expand its comprehensive program.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 20 -- Using a new "panoramic floor plan" for a record 114 exhibits of homes and equipment, the tenth anniversary Westchester Better Homes Exposition was opened for preview this evening on three floors of the County Center here.

LOS ANGELES, May 20 -- A Congressional investigating subcommittee was accused by three lawyers today of violating constitutional rights of the bar in serving subpoenas on them as they appeared with clients.
The reductio ad absurdum has now been reached. The entire lunatic fringe of frightened, vacant little minds must be babbling with happiness. And the rest of us must be sickened with shame.

A new collection of simple, sculptured wood serving trays is now available at Bloomingdale's Designed by Joseph Pelkey and Chester Pfeiffer, the items are characterized by forms derived from early American designs.

PARIS, May 20 -- Party meetings and negotiations of party leaders with Premier Rene Mayer failed today to reduce the opposition to the Premier's call for a confidence vote that would give him special powers to effect economies in the deficitary French budget.

BOSTON, May 20 -- Harvard University's decision to retain three faculty members who refused to answer questions about Communist affiliations was criticized today by Samuel P. Sears. president of the Massachusetts Bar Association.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (UP) -- The Department of Defense announced today that United State battle casualties in Korea rose by 197 last week to a new overall total of 135,155.

TOKYO, Thursday, May 21 (UP) -- Allied warships and carrier planes destroyed 200 buildings and shattered Red transport lines in a day-long bombardment Tuesday of the northeast Korean coast by sea and air, Far East Navy headquarters here reported.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Negotiations are under way between the Department of Agriculture and the Maritime Administration for use of twenty-five more ships moored in the Hudson River to store wheat, which threatens to tax department facilities this year.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption in April had averaged 36,687 bales for each working day. This compared with an average of 33,922 bales in the same month a year ago and 38,609 in March this year.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 20 -- A wage increase of five cents an hour has been negotiated for 3,200 production workers at the big gaseous diffusion uranium separation center, the K-25 plant, at Oak Ridge, effective July 25.

After a month of bargaining between the major parties following the national elections, Shigeru Yoshida, an outstanding exponent of close ties between his country and the United States, has again been elected Premier. He is now forming his fifth Cabinet. The votes which elected him in both houses of Parliament showed substantial majorities, but his tenure is none too secure.

A city marshal battered down the door of an apartment in the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's Parkchester housing development in the Bronx yesterday morning to carry out an eviction order against a Negro family.

Communist China has been using the prisoners of war issue in the current truce talks, which have been suspended temporarily until Sunday, in an effort to "horse-trade" her way into the United Nations, Robert Aura Smith, a member of the editorial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- Although sales of materials-handling equipment have soared above $1,000,000,000 annually, the potential market has scarcely been touched, Neil Drake, partner in the New York management consultant firm of Drake, Startzman, Shehan Barclay, declared here tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The President has now made and announced directly to the people a series of broad and vital policy decisions with respect to the economic and military phases of national security, and he will have to fight for them in Congress. The era of Executive and legislative relations during which the President made a practice of deferring to Congressional objections to his ideas seems to be at an end.

THE coastal fishing seems to have reached the phase where it is almost as unpredictable as the trout fishing, with an added complication, for the trout fisherman can be almost certain of finding activity where the flies are hatching.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 20 (AP) -- A Worcester industrialist today reported purchase of the American Woolen Company's Assabet Mills in Maynard for "about half a million dollars."

Botany Mills of Passaic, N. J., has renewed its contract with H. Daroff Sons, Inc., of Philadelphia to supply fabrics for men's suits on an exclusive basis for another five years, it was announced yesterday. The agreement insures continuance of production of the "Botany Brand 500 -- Tailored by Daroff" clothes.
The Delaware River Port Authority made final arrangements yesterday for financing the construction of a seven-lane vehicular suspension bridge to connect Philadelphia with Gloucester City.

Carmine G. DeSapio, the leader of Tammany Hall, said yesterday that enrolled Democrats of New York County would be polled by mail to determine whom they wanted for the Democratic nomination for Mayor. He added that the poll would be supervised by persons other than representatives of the Democratic party.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

Old persons who can make some returns to the community for services they once received become less self-centered and happier, and old- ago clubs should help them to this goal, Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president emeritus of Vassar College, said yesterday.

An unusual amount of equipment is included in a new model house scheduled to be opened to the public Sunday. Situated on Secor Road in Hartsdale, N. Y., the house is the second of a series being arranged throughout the country under the sponsorship of the General Electric Company.
MELBOURNE, May 20 (AP) -- The chief Australian planner for the 1956 Olympic Games resigned tonight -- an act that was called a "national tragedy" by Melbourne's acting Lord Mayor.

Employes of Macy's store in Herald Square donated 288 pints of blood to the Red Cross on Tuesday, the New York chapter of the American Red Cross reported yesterday. The total throughout the city for that day was 1,017 pints.

A new issue of $30,000,000 of long-term bonds of the Philadelphia Electric Company, a public utility credit ranking with the highest in the land, will be placed on the market today at a price to yield 3.73 per cent, following sale of the issue yesterday to underwriters at public sealed bidding.
Four New York professional and trade schools recently have opened exhibits of student work completed during the school year.

IN his rambunctious new novel, "7 1/2 Cents,"* Richard Bissell does for the pajama industry, in a small Iowa town on the Mississippi what Melville did for whaling, what Tolstoy did for war and peace, what Faulkner is doing for Yoknapatawpha County, what Proust did for fin de siecle society in France. The resemblances, I may say, are not otherwise striking.

LONDON, May 20 -- There was a slight improvement in the stock markets today, reflected in a little more buying of selected industrial shares. Nevertheless closing prices showed a preponderance of small falls.

The task of "cleaning up the Bowery" is not an impossible one, speakers at the second meeting of the Committee for the Abolition of Bowery Conditions asserted yesterday. Forty persons attended the gathering at Cooper Union, Fourth Avenue and East Eighth Street.
PUSAN, Korea, May 20 -- This port city, overridden with poverty, sickness and misery, is a symbol of the wretched state to which the war has brought Korea.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Mickey Vernon led a sixteen-hit Washington attack with a double and three singles tonight as the Senators defeated the Indians, 8 -- 3. Spec Shea, who left the game after seven innings because of a stiff shoulder, held the Indians to two of their seven hits to post his third victory without a loss.

Dancing, making music and using paints and clay are as much a form of personal expression as talking, Dr. Katherine D'Evelyn said yesterday. Therefore, she said, parents, who in the interest of a quiet or scrupulously clean home prohibit or rigidly restrict such activities, actually are hampering their youngsters' full development as persons.
Walter C. Boschen, managing editor of the Value Line investment survey, has been elected vice president of Arnold Bernhard Co., Inc., publishers of the survey.

The so-called left-wing faction of the Parent-Teachers Association of Public School 125 at 425 West 123d Street was re-elected last night in an election marked by extended squabbling over voting procedures and whose results were not determined until after the weary parents were rescued from the sidewalk by the police and given a safe haven to count their ballots.

After an ownership of about a month, the dwelling containing four apartments on lot 23 by 103 feet at 117 West Eleventh Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues was resold by Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, to John D. Marks for investment, Mrs. F. Le Grand was the broker.

A weeping, nervous, 24-year-old carnival hula dancer with a record of delinquency was arrested yesterday as the kidnapper of 2-year-old Clifton Bradford and his year-old sister Diane from Washington last Friday.
TOKYO, Thursday, May 21 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,621, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korean time:

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, May 20 -- The Dutch Parliament completed ratification today of constitutional amendments making The Netherlands the first of the Western European nations involved to change its basic law expressly to permit the transfer of national sovereignty to supranational organizations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 20 -- Mrs. Eda Glaser of the Security Council's reference library staff became the first United States employe of the United Nations to be dismissed by the new Secretary General, Dag Hammarskjold, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, estimated today that the Air Force would spend $15,400,000,000 in the fiscal year starting next July 1, out of about $40,200,000,000 it would have available, and that it would spend four times as much for combat aircraft and spare parts as it was spending in the current fiscal year.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 20 -- According to an authorized statement "emigrants who continue to disseminate hate against our country" will not benefit by any Yugoslav regulations permitting the reunion of resident citizens with their families abroad.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 20 -- Rafael Llovera Paez, Venezuelan president of the Grand Colombia shipping concern, arrived here Monday and in an interview in the Tiempo today said that the question of the future of the fleet was in the hands of the Governments of Colombia, Venezuela and Ecuador.

A major step in the development of the technology of economical generation of steam-electric power was announced yesterday by the American Gas and Electric Company. It is a new boiler and turbo-generating unit designed to cross the barrier of the "critical pressure" of steam for the first time in the production of electric power.

Dr. Everett N. Case, president of Colgate University, was named yesterday as chairman of a nine-state committee to study the problems confronting farmers and distributors in the New York milk-shed. Dr. C. J. Blanford, local administrator of Federal and state milk marketing orders, in announcing the committee, outlined the problems as:

Steps toward setting up a new comprehensive master plan for city slum areas designed for future redevelopment for residential purposes were taken yesterday by the City Planning Commission. The commission set June 3 for a public hearing at City Hall on the Manhattan part of the master plan.

PATERSON, N. J., May 20 -- The Most Rev. James A. McNulty, former Auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark, was enthroned today as the third Bishop of the Paterson Diocese. The ceremony took place at the Cathedral of St. John the Baptist here.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor endorsed today President Eisenhower's requested delay in tax cuts, but disagreed with his proposal to postpone a scheduled increase in the Social Security tax.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Republicans, rather than Democrats, are leading the Congressional opposition to the most important legislative recommendations of President Eisenhower's Administration to date.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The farm bloc in the House of Representatives barely won its first major test in the new Congress today as the House voted $712,747,528 for the Department of Agriculture.

DETROIT, May 20 -- The Ford Motor Company started to shut down most of its manufacturing and assembly operations across the country today as the result of a strike in Canton, Ohio, that had pinched off its supply of axles and other forged automobile parts.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Republicans, rather than Democrats, are leading the Congressional opposition to the most important legislative recommendations of President Eisenhower's Administration to date.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The farm bloc in the House of Representatives barely won its first major test in the new Congress today as the House voted $712,747,528 for the Department of Agriculture.

DETROIT, May 20 -- The Ford Motor Company started to shut down most of its manufacturing and assembly operations across the country today as the result of a strike in Canton, Ohio, that had pinched off its supply of axles and other forged automobile parts.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UP) -- William P. Rogers, Deputy Attorney General, urged Congress today to sanction use of present and past wire-tap evidence against spies, conspirators and saboteurs so that the Government could re-examine "certain cases."
Looking back over half a century in the city's school system, Miss Minnie Obermeier, who turned 70 in February, pondered the tremendous changes in education since she qualified as a teacher in 1901.

One of the nation's largest oil and gas companies, the Cities Service Company, made executive changes yesterday. W. Alton Jones, formerly president, was elected chairman and chief executive officer at a meeting of the $1,000,000,000 company's board of directors.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Henri Bonnet, the French Ambassador to the United States, said today that the Western Allies should not let discontent and impatience cause a break in their unity. He spoke at a ceremony commemorating the 119th anniversary of the death of the Marquis de Lafayette, the French general who fought with the Americans in the Revolutionary War.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 20 -- Keyed up by preview reactions to "Julius Caesar," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has decided to have another go at filming "Romeo and Juliet." Dore Schary, studio production chief, revealed today that John Houseman had been busy for some weeks editing Shakespeare's romantic classic into screen play form.

For real drama, a 60-year-old police captain has decided Shakespeare can match his police blotter in Passaic, N. J. Therefore, every weekday at 4 A. M., the captain turns over the desk to his relief, gets a few hours sleep and reports for a full day's workout to the American Academy of Dramatic Arts.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (UP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway was reported by Congressional sources to have fixed 132 divisions as the "minimum" required to halt an initial invasion of western Europe by Russia.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Vice Admiral Charles W. Fox told Congress today that a university hit the military services with a misplaced decimal point and gave them a black eye they did not deserve.

WASHINGTON, May 20 - Thailand has decided to place the issue of the Communist invasion of the Indo-Chinese state of Laos, which borders on Thailand, before the United Nations next week. Pote Sarasin Thai Ambassador, said today that the Bangkok Government would introduce the subject under Article 34 of the United Nations Charter.
Henry, a pigeon that knows what he likes, refused to take off from the deck of the American Export liner Constitution yesterday morning when the ship returned here from a voyage to the Mediterranean.

BONN, Germany, May 20 -- Dr. Karl Gruber, Austrian Foreign Minister, declared today that he did not favor his country's entry into a Western defense community once an agreement had been reached on the Austrian treaty.

BERLIN, May 20 (AP) -- Two United States soldiers whom the Russians tried to lure into communism with promises of a good life and career returned to duty in a military police company today after having been held in the Soviet zone for six months.

The Long Island Commuters, Taxpayers and Businessmen's Association, Inc., in opposing a change in the type of monthly commutation ticket proposed by the Long Island Rail Road, has filed a formal petition with the Public Service Commission for "a suspension of tariffs" on this issue.

CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) -- The Chicago Sun-Times said tonight Lieut. Franciszek Jarecki, who is now in the United States after flying his MIG to freedom, told of knowing Lieutenant Jazwenski. In a copyrighted interview with The Sun-Times in Phoenix, Ariz., Lieutenant Jarecki said "there will be many others" to follow.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Republican leaders in the House of Representatives won the first phase today of their fight for approval of President Eisenhower's request for a six-month extension of the excess profits tax.

The public needs economic understanding if the "recklessly high" claims and awards for personal injuries are to be ended, the American Management Association's national insurance conference at the Statler Hotel was told yesterday by Chase M. Smith, general counsel of the Lumbermen's Mutual Casualty Company of Chicago.
