WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Administration spokesmen voiced their support today for proposed legislation providing for limited participation by this Government in a joint venture with Canada to contruct the St. Lawrence Seaway. The bill in question is a measure introduced by Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, which received unanimous endorsement by the Cabinet on May 8.

LONDON, May 20 -- Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister, rejected today a suggestion that he and President Eisenhower should get together and try to reconcile "the present differences of approach" between the United States and Britain toward pending international issues.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Spokesmen for several canning and food processing associations opposed today before the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee the factory inspection authority asked for the Food and Drug Administration by President Eisenhower in his State of the Union Message.
Futures closed barely steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and final prices were 2 to 9 points net lower than on Tuesday.

CAIRO, May 20 -- With the dispute between Britain and Egypt over control of the Suez Canal zone threatening to erupt in violence, British civilians here have been advised by their embassy to leave Egypt within the next few weeks.

NEW DELHI, India, May 20 -- John Foster Dulles, the United States Secretary of State, and Harold E. Stassen, Mutual Security Director, who arrived from Saudi Arabia this morning, are expected to discuss with Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and other Indian leaders the entire range of relations between India and the United States in the light of Korea and other world problems.
YONKERS, May 20 -- Pfc. Joseph Picerno, a recently liberated prisoner of war, today received control of a royally bred 3-year-old racing filly, Your Time, at a luncheon at Yorkers Raceway.
The Deck Scow Captains Union began a referendum vote of its membership yesterday on a contract offer by the Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York. The voting will close next Wednesday.

LONDON, May 21 -- Prices made small gains on the stock markets today with improvement in sentiment following the rally in Wall Street and the favorable impression made by the full trade figures for April.

Large-scale Western grazing interests have been attempting for years to get firmer control over the privilege they have long exercised of having their herds graze for part of each year in the national forests. They have been, and still are, chafing at the regulations of the Forest Service, whose duty is to administer these lands for the general good and not for the particular advantage of any one of the various conflicting-interest groups.

MARY PORTER, who runs the Empire Theatre, has been bedeviled for months now by nostalgic players and sentimental customers eager to own some part of the theatre when it goes dark at ultimate curtain fall a week from tomorrow night.
Members of the new board of directors of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City held their first meeting yesterday at the council offices, 44 East Twenty-third Street.
Lucky long-chance players in the crowd of 21.268 at Belmont Park yesterday went home with bulging wallets.

Net profits of companies representing the bulk of the steel industry dropped more than 22 per cent last year, and the Federal Government received $823,000,000 less in income taxes from those companies, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
WEST POINT, N. Y., May 21 -- The Corps of Cadets at the United States Military Academy paraded today in honor of the drum major who has led the Academy band for the last thirteen years.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The President of the United States and the Prime Ministers of Britain and France will meet in the British island colony of Bermuda next month to concert their viewpoints so "the cause of peace may be advanced."

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Department store sales in the week ended May 16 were 7 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

Now that it has become a part of a department with a cabinet officer at its head, the Food and Drug Administration may request, or be given other and additional duties, it is pointed out by Di Cyan Brown, consulting chemists, in their latest bulletin. The administration is now part of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, headed by Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby. It previously was part of the Federal Security Agency.

Boxing will return tonight to Madison Square Garden after an absence of seven weeks with Vince Martinez, Paterson (N. J.) welterweight, facing Danny Giovanelli of Brooklyn in the feature attraction of ten rounds. Martinez, 24 years old, was boxing's 1952 "Rookie of the Year."
LONDON, May 21 -- Christmas has its roast goose, Easter has its spring ham and coronation day, Britain's once-a-generation holiday, has its box lunch.

Production of newsprint in North America last month reached the highest for any April on record, with an output of 568,510 tons and shipments of 587,893, according to an announcement yesterday by the Newsprint Service Bureau. This compared with output of 566,002 and shipments of 562,268 tons in April, 1952.
OXFORD, England, May 21 (Reuters) -- Australia's undefeated touring cricket team today beat Oxford University by an innings and 86 runs.

LONDON, May 21 -- Eleven industrialists and trade unionists were named today as members of the Iron and Steel Board, a new body that will supervise the "denationalized" British steel industry. The appointments were announced in the House of Commons by Duncan Sandys, Minister of Supply.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Congress responded with pleasure and restrained hopefulness today to the announcement of the forthcoming meeting of the chiefs of the United States, Britain and France.

Two new books about pirates and piracy will be issued a day apart. On June 1, Norton will publish Patrick Pringle's "Jolly Roger," an account of the age of piracy. Mr. Pringle is the author of "Stand and Deliver," a story of famous highwaymen.
Local 6, New York Typographical Union, recounted yesterday the ballots cast on Wednesday in its biennial election of officers, and faced the possibility of a second recount today or tomorrow.

The purchase of the Downer Towing Corporation by Carroll Towing Company, Inc., of 17 Battery Place was announced yesterday by John A. Carroll, vice president. The transaction joins two of the oldest towboat concerns in the harbor, both of which are presently run by the third generations of their founders.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 21 -- The French delegation is angry at the United States-sponsored decision by Thailand to bring the Laos case before the United Nations but is expected to agree to a limited on-the-spot military observation by a United Nations subcommission.

ROME, May 21 -- Pietro Nenni, leader of the Left-Wing Socialist party, said today he expected Premier Alcide De Gasperi to seek his collaboration in forming a Government after the general elections June 7.

ATHENS, May 21 -- Nicholas Zachariades, secretary general of the Greek Communist party, has been ousted from that post by order of the Kremlin and replaced by Petros Rousos, once his Foreign Minister in the Communist-led "Free Greece" regime of civil war days, according to a source who in the past has proved to have a knowledge of the "Free Greece" affairs.

HAWORTH, N. J., May 21 -- The Ridgewood Country Club regained the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub team championship by defeating rivals from Westchester and Long Island at White Beeches today.

Fred Noeske, who will round out fifty years of service with the New York Public Library on July 1, was honored by eighty of his fellow workers last night with a dinner in the New York Times service dining room. He received a gold pin.

The National Industrial Conference Board, at its thirty-seventh annual meeting yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, elected Cola G. Parker, president of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, as chairman of the board. Mr. Parker succeeds Neal Dow Becker, who became a councilor.

The Department of Commerce will reshape its working policy to become a service organization for business, according to James C. Worthy, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Administration. Changes in the department, he said yesterday, are being made with a view toward making it a representative of the business community in Government.

Continuing the seasonal decline of the last six weeks, business loans from New York banks dropped $50,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday. The reduction, which compares with a decrease of $29,000,000 in the similar week last year, brought the decline since the start of 1953 to $261,000,000, against a contraction of $316,000,000 in the corresponding period a year ago.

Patrolman Meyer E. Rubenstein the first member of the Police Department to face charges of having Communist affiliations, was discharged from the force yesterday by Commissioner George P. Monaghan. The dismissal was effective at 4 P. M.

THE house was called Dhilkusha, which means "to make the heart glad." It stood on a hillside between the mountains and a lake in the Vale of Kashmir and was, in Ayah's opinion, "not a memsahib's house." But it was there that Sophie Barrington Ward was determined to live after she recovered from a dangerous siege of typhoid and pneumonia. What

VIENNA, May 21 -- The earnest and well organized effort of United States business leaders at the congress of the International Chamber of Commerce meeting here to calm the fears of business men from the rest of the world about the trend of United States economic policy, so far, has had only modest results.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 21 -- The 484 state and federally chartered savings and loan and building and loan associations in New Jersey now have assets of more than a billion dollars, it was reported here tonight. Addressing nearly 700 delegates at the opening general session of the forty-fourth annual convention of the New Jersey Savings and Loan League at Haddon Hall Hotel, Warren N. Gaffney of Roselle, State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, declared:

Leaders of four political parties -- Democratic, Republican, Liberal and City Fusion -- agreed last night that a change in the office of Mayor was desirable. They were interviewed on the "Local Scene" program of television Station WABD, broadcast over Channel 5.

NEW DELHI, India, May 21 -- Indian officials in discussions with Harold E. Stassen, United States Mutual Security Director, were said tonight to have expressed a wish that the Eisenhower Administration assume what was described as a "moral commitment" to keep urging Congress in the next three years to underwrite part of India's five-year plan, on which Indians are banking as an antidote to communism.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., May 21 (AP) -- The Navy today announced that the giant aircraft carrier Forrestal would embody the latest ideas in flight deck design -- the angled deck, originated by the Royal British Navy.
NEW ORLEANS, May 21 (UP) Levees broke in Texas and Louisiana under the pounding of record spring floods today and two feet of water sloshed into the Lake Charles, La., Air Force base.
A $27,100,000 financing program for Miami, Fla., was postponed yesterday by the City's Commissioners until June 15. The securities had been scheduled for sale at competitve bidding on May 27.

Another beautiful and poignant play has come from the pen of Robert Howard Lindsay, who certainly now must be ranked among the truly fine writers brought to the fore by television. His latest work is entitled "One Left Over" and was seen on Wednesday evening over the Kraft Television Theatre (N. B. C.).

PITTSBURGH, May 21 (AP) -- The last-place Pirates, scoring all their runs in the-sixth inning, defeated the front-running Phillies, 7 -- 2, tonight. The victory, which snapped a four-game losing streak, was achieved by Murry Dickson, who hurled superlative ball after a shaky start.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 21 -- A small patrol of two white officers and native troops has been in conflict with hundreds of primitive tribesmen in the jungle highlands of New Guinea 300 miles northwest of Port Moresby. The region is largely unexplored and almost inaccessible.

Aluminium Limited of Canada has decided to reserve for independent fabricators in the United States 110,000 tons of aluminum a year for the next several years "to help assure them a more constant supply," it was announced here yesterday.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 21 -- The projected Western Big Three conference here next month caught local officialdom completely by surprise. A Government spokesman said it was impossible to arrange a meeting place and determine other details until sizes of the various parties were known.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., May 21 -- This city and neighboring Teaneck raised additional funds tonight for St. Joseph's Orphanage Home, which recently was destroyed by fire, with the premiere showing of "Destination Gobi," a new Twentieth Century-Fox Technicolor film. Richard Widmark stars in the picture, which is an account of a famous World War II desert battle on camels.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 16 totaled 779,805 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Western "bad men" rode into town today, followed closely by a band of "Vigilantes" bent on keeping the bold Westerners from "stealing public lands."

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- A group of business men, appointed to study the Mutual Security Program, recommended that foreign economic aid be cut "substantially" in the coming year and "generally" ended by June, 1954.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The people of New York State are losing one of their most effective law enforcement bodies through administrative delays and the vacillation of other agencies.

Stuart Denton Morris, general secretary of Great Britain's Peace Pledge Union, who had arrived by air last Friday for an eight-week, nation-wide speaking tour arranged by the American Friends Service Committee and the War Resisters League, was ruled an inadmissible alien yesterday.

The Court of Claims has turned down a request for a judgment of claims brought by the Eastern Steamship Lines against the United States Government for compensation arising from the use of the liner Acadia in war service.

Government and defense lawyers summed up yesterday in the Federal Court perjury trial of William Perl with the one urging the jury to bring in a verdict of guilty on all four counts and the other asserting that such a finding would be incredible.

TRENTON, May 21 -- The New Jersey State Assembly failed again today to act on bingo or any other major legislation awaiting its consideration. The House convened at 2 P. M., and four hours later, after passing thirty minor bills, adjourned until Monday.

ALBANY, May 21 -- Lobbyists spent more than $230,000 during the 1953 session of the New York State Legislature in an effort to win lawmakers' approval for favored bills and to kill measures considered detrimental to the interests of their employers.

MANILA, Friday, May 22 -- The final session of the second Philippine Congress adjourned in a confused flurry of activity last midnight with the approval of the 1954 budget, giving the major part of the expectable national income to army forces and the secondary allotment to public education.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 21 (UP) -- Senator Wallace F. Bennett, Republican of Utah, said today that American business men had their best chance in twenty years "to build and preserve public confidence."

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A new bill combining the views of some Republican Senators on Taft-Hartley Law revision was made public today by Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, chairman of the Labor and Public Welfare Committee.

A pessimistic attitude on the part of business management could talk this country into an unnecessary depression, Arno H. Johnson, vice president and director of research of J. Walter Thompson Company, advertising agency, said yesterday at a meeting of the American Marketing Association at the Belmont Plaza Hotel.

MADRID, May 21 -- Foreign diplomats said today that repercussions of the visit of President Francisco Craveiro Lopes of Portugal to Generalissimo Francisco Franco, Spanish Chief of State, would have some bearing on the future relations between Spain and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization powers, notably the United States.

Moves to effect the State Crime Commission's recommendations concerning the New York waterfront, particularly the proposed licensing of the port's tremendous body of dockside workers, are expected to bring trouble to an area that has had its share of upheavals.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- President Eisenhower today gave his "enthusiastic" support to the establishment of an Air Force Academy on a par with the Navy's at Annapolis and the Army's at West Point.

Garland Milburn has been elected vice president in charge of development and of the Canadian business of the Grand Union Company. William F. Dempsey was elected vice president in charge of store operations.

THE trout fishing prospects for this week-end are the subject of some debate between anglers and the weather man, but the striped bass fisherman should be very happy, for the first run of bull bass has arrived off Sandy Hook and fish up to forty-five pounds are being taken by trollers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read with interest the editorial captioned "Toward Asian Self-Rule" in the May 11 issue of your esteemed paper. In reference to the transfer of sovereignty you state:

TOKYO, Friday, May 22 -- Shigeru Yoshida, 74-year-old leader of Japan's Liberal party was appointed Premier by Emperor Hirohito yesterday. Mr. Yoshida, who had been elected to form another government by the Diet (Parliament) Tuesday thus became the first man in Japan's sixty-eight years of parliamentary history to occupy the top government post five times.

NEWARK, May 21 -- Financial contributions from corporations to educational institutions were characterized as "a solemn duty, as well as a valid right under New Jersey statutes" in a decision today by Judge Alfred A. Stein in Superior Court.

PARIS, May 21 -- Premier Rene Mayer resigned today after the National Assembly had refused him a vote of confidence to enable him to apply cuts to France's budget. His defeat came about through the withdrawal of support by the former followers of Gen. Charles de Gaulle.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 21 -- The Polish Air Force's Soviet-built MIG-15 jet fighter, which was flown to the Danish island of Bornholm yesterday from Poland by a 21-year-old pilot, Lieut. Zdzislaw Jazwenski, may be returned to Poland direct from Ronne, Bornholm's port, according to an unconfirmed report from there.

PRESTATYN, Wales, May 21 (Reuters) -- Tom O'Brien, a Socialist member of Parliament and chairman of the 8,000,000 member British Trades Union Congress, resumed today his attack on "anti-British cliques in the United States." He asked:

GENEVA, May 16 -- The coming into force Saturday of the international convention binding the countries that ratify it to provide equal pay for men and women for work of equal value marks in a special way "the adulthood of women," Miss Mildred Fairchild, chief of the women's and young workers' division of the International Labor Office said in an interview here today.

West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday net income of $4,455,000, equal to $4.64 a common share, for the six months ended on April 30. This compares with $5,535,000, or $5.83, a year ago.

LONDON, May 21 -- The House of Commons seemed inordinately pleased today when the Prime Minister, Sir Winston Churchill, disclosed that he expected to meet President Eisenhower and the French Premier probably about June 15, in Bermuda, to discuss a common approach to the Soviet Union.
Last night's program by Martha Graham and her company at the Alvin Theatre had as its particular novelty the first performance by Yuriko of Miss Graham's role in "Dark Meadow."

FORT WORTH, Tex., May 21 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt, golf's temperamental genius, rolled placidly to a three-under-par 67 today to take the first-round lead by four strokes in the wind-swept $25,000 Colonial national invitation tournament.

PARIS, May 21 -- The overthrow today of the Government of Premier Rene Mayer was accomplished three hours after the National Assembly had heard him announce with great satisfaction the forthcoming meeting of political chiefs of the United States, Britain and France, which M. Mayer seemed to credit his Government with having first proposed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 21 -- R. K. O.-Radio Pictures is quietly making preparations to begin filming this summed on "Pilate's Wife." It was learned today that King Vidor, the director, has been at work for some weeks on the screen play written by Clare Boothe Luce, newly appointed United States Ambassador to Italy.
TOKYO, Friday, May 22 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,622, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korean time:

The Rev. Dr. Carl McIntire, president of the fundamentalist International Council of Christian Churches, said yesterday that he had never questioned the loyalty of Mrs. Mildred McAfee Horton, but believed that her views should bar her from representing the "capitalist" United States on the United Nations Social Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor today rejected the answer of the International Longshoremen's Association to a council order to clean up or face expulsion. President George Meany said the vote was unanimous.

HONG KONG, Thursday, May 21 (AP) -- An official of a British steamship company today denied accusations by a United States Senate Investigations subcommittee that the firm had transported Communist troops.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A delegation of ten Italian officials intent upon studying American methods of controlling exports is due in Washington late this week. The group is expected to confer with officials of the Departments of State and Commerce and to study forms and declarations developed by the Office of International Trade of the Commerce Department in recent years.

Merit awards were presented to nine members of the City College Reserve Officers Training Corps unit at their annual spring review yesterday afternoon in Lewisohn Stadium, 137th Street and Convent Avenue.

BAYONNE, N. J., May 21 -- Experts of the Navy Supply Depot's disposal division, who have tried unsuccessfully to give away four pairs of doors and a single door, taken from Hempstead House, the old Long Island estate of the Guggenheim family, were snowed under today with offers for the doors as the result of newspaper stories.

The surprise announcement that the President, the British Prime Minister and the Premier of France (whoever he may be) will confer together in Bermuda, probably in the latter half of June, is heartening news to all of us who have been troubled by signs of divergent views among them. The initiative for the conference comes from General Eisenhower, and is a wise and well-timed move on his part for a variety of reasons.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- During the week ended May 20, member bank reserves decreased $88,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

William Wyer, trustee of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road, yesterday accused the Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks, A. F. L., of threatening to strike unless the line abandoned its plan to adopt a calendar-month commutation ticket.
A transient non-paying guest at the Edison Hotel was apprehended on the wing in the lobby yesterday afternoon after a two-hour chase.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, May 22 (AP) -- Two United States F-94 Starfire all-weather jet fighters tangled with two Communist jets in the drizzling darkness last night and may have damaged one of them, the Fifth Air Force reported today.

Subway traffic across the Williamsburg Bridge on the Broadway-Jamaica line of the B. M. T. division was halted for two hours and forty-six minutes late yesterday when a coupling broke on a Jamaica-bound train approaching the Marcy Avenue station in Brooklyn.
HANOI, Vietnam, May 21 (UP) -- Vietminh shock troops hurled new attacks today against the French defense line which guards this capital and the Red River rice bowl.

BOSTON, May 21 (AP) -- The Athletics scored five runs in the seventh inning, during which the relief pitcher, Carl Scheib, and Pete Suder lashed bases-loaded singles, while shutting out the Red Sox, 9 -- 0, today. The Red Sox fell from second to third place, behind the White Sox.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- State Department officials said today that the flow of American books to department libraries abroad had slowed to a trickle while they tried to work out a system for barring works by Communist authors.

VIENNA, May 21 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia broadcast today a call for the United States to lift trade and travel restrictions imposed on that Communist - governed country in 1951 for the imprisonment of William N. Oatis, newsman, whom the regime accused as a spy.
A brunet model, an unconcerned camel, two meek Persian lambs and energetic salesmen on roller skates teamed up yesterday to sell a lot of carpets in Madison Square Garden.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 21 -- A number of United States citizens who hold high positions in the United Nations Secretariat have been kept from attending recent overseas meetings by "unusual delays" in issuing their passports. These delays, a high-ranking United Nations official said today,

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Representative Samuel W. Yorty, Democrat of California, quoted the Air Force today as saying President Eisenhower's program for building up the nation's defenses would result in air strength well below "the absolute minimum" for national security.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Senate Government Operations Committee voted today to support President Eisenhower's plan for reorganization of the Department of Agriculture, one of the key farm issues before the new Congress.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 21 -- Fourteen members of the Asian-African group discussed the Korean situation this afternoon but adjourned without taking any decision.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Grain trading quieted down after the expiration of May deliveries. Less selling pressure was indicated but on the other hand no confident buying was in evidence. Wheat showed a small price improvement early but met fairly free selling.
The conclusions and recommendations of the State Crime Commission's report on waterfront conditions in the Port of New York follows:
BUENOS AIRES, May 21 -- Congress was given today a bill inspired by President Juan D. Peron to dissolve the Jockey Club and to put the Government in control of Argentina's two leading race tracks.

The high cost of borrowing money has caused some of the nation's public utilities to take a closer look at their construction and expansion plans. The Public Service Electric and Gas Company disclosed yesterday that it had postponed a sale of $50,000,000 of bonds it had been expected to market sometime next month.
The futures market continued quiet on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices eased 2 to 12 points.

In a blistering criticism of New York officials for "grave mismanagement of the city's affairs," Governor Dewey denied peremptorily last night the appeals of Mayor Impellitteri and Controller Lazarus Joseph that a special session of the Legislature consider changes in the city's financial program.

WHENEVER Lou Gehrig fell into a slump he was in mortal terror that his inability to hit would become permanent, abruptly ending his career. Fortunately for the brooding Iron Horse, though, his slumps were of short duration. They are transitory things anyway and usually end in the same inexplicable fashion with which they begin.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The State Department's Voice of America has inaugurated a series of religious broadcasts to Communist countries in the belief that freedom of religion in this country is a strong link of friendship with millions of people behind the Iron Curtain.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Casey Stengel must be slipping -- or something. Tonight, at Griffith Stadium, the unpredictable skipper of the good ship Yankee, used only nineteen men, while guiding he Bombers to a 6-5 triumph over the Senators for their fourth in a row.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., May 21 -- Lieut. Sheppard Carl Thierman, a medical officer, was identified today at his court-martial as the co-chairman of an American delegation to the World Youth and Student Festival at Budapest, Hungary, in August, 1949, at which United States foreign policy was criticized as "Wall Street's imperial venture."

BATAJNICA, Yugoslavia, May 21 -- Disturbed by inferences to the contrary, President Tito pledged today unswerving loyalty to the West no matter how much Yugoslavia's relations with the Soviet Union might improve. He added that he saw no sign of improvement of relations with Moscow.

Under the laws of Czechoslovakia, as construed when William N. Oatis was a correspondent in Prague for The Associated Press, a man could be convicted of espionage if he so much as sent out a weather report. Or, as Mr. Oatis put it in a statement made public Wednesday night, "some things that generally are considered in Western countries to be normal news-gathering procedure can be construed there to be espionage."

Fordham University will play its home football games at the Polo Grounds during the 1953, 1954 and 1955 seasons. The closing of the terms was reached yesterday by President Horace Stoneham, president of the Giants, and Jack Coffey, Fordham's graduate manager of athletics in Stoneham's Polo Grounds office.

BONN, Germany, May 21 -- West Germany bluntly reminded the United States, Britain and France today that they had promised not to decide anything concerning this country without having consulted its Government.
TULSA, Okla., May 21 (AP) -- Cuba is planning to woo oilmen in effort to build up her petroleum production.

Stocks pushed ahead for an hour or so yesterday but lost their momentum in the noon hour and ended the day with much-reduced gains. Aircrafts continued their Wednesday strength but rails barely held even and steels lost ground.

Mrs. Lee Maggio, the city's "most serious scofflaw," who had been fined $3,500 for seventy traffic violations, admitted yesterday that she was unable to pay a balance of $2,500 due on the fine and was ordered by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh to serve fifty days in the workhouse.

STRATFORD, Conn., May 21 -- Theatre history may have been made here tonight at the world premiere of Amp-o-Vision, the contribution of Stratford-on-Housatonic to the motion-picture industry's three-dimensional merry-go-round.

A slate of candidates that had been accused by its opponents of being "left wing" won a close election for officers last night in the Parent-Teachers Association of Public School 165 in Kew Gardens, Queens.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- A Treasury official frowned today on proposals to finance limited participation by the United States with Canada in construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway through sale of bonds to the public.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- The Liberal party, which has a voting strength of 500,000 in New York City, opened the door today to possible endorsement of Representative Jacob K. Javits, Manhattan Republican, for Mayor in November.

The curtain has rung down on another act in the tragi-comedy that French politicians have been playing while the free world goes its perilous way. Only the French are enjoying this subtle and delicate play, and probably not too many of them, either. For the rest of us it is a disheartening and even frightening performance.

HONG KONG, May 21 -- Li Li-san, Soviet backed chairman of Communist China's All China Federation of Trade Unions, has lost his leadership in the trade union movement, according to press dispatches from Communist China.

The Arlington Construction Company of New York has purchased a plot 200 by 165 feet on North Broadway, about 126 feet north of Fisher Lane in White Plains, N. Y., for a store center which will contain a supermarket, four adjoining stores and parking space.

Francis Poulenc's opera, "Les mamelles de Tiresias," will have its first United States performance at Brandeis University, Waltham, Mass., on Saturday, June 13, as an event of the university's second annual Festival of the Creative Arts.

A temporary lull in vegetable receipts from the South is being reflected here in higher prices on several items. The Florida growing season for these vegetables is about over, and the Carolinas and Georgia have not yet begun to ship in quantity.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The Marine Corps identified today seventy-eight additional officers and men who "may" be prisoners of war in Korea. All are listed among the 570 marines officially reported as missing in action.

Some people swap stamps, and others swap strange seashells. But one of the nation's leading scientific institutions, the American Museum of Natural History, is one of the best dinosaur bone swappers around.
The alternate-side parking system to permit more efficient street cleaning will go into effect on Monday in the section of central Harlem between Fifth and Eighth Avenues and 110th and 129th Streets.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Ellsworth Bunker, former United States Ambassador to Italy, was reported tonight to be under consideration for appointment as a Deputy to Allen W. Dulles, Director of the Central Intelligence Agency.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 21 -- In a country-by-country review of its operations during 1952, the United Nations Technical Assistance Administration emphasized today the gradual emergence of relatively underdeveloped countries as "givers" of skills needed by other nations, rather than exclusively as receivers of such benefits.

Tom Brigance is a fashion designer whose imagination never seems to run dry. In his summer collection for Sportsmaker, shown yesterday by Lord Taylor at the Plaza Hotel, his flair for the gay and amusing sparkled throughout

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The appointment of Associate Justice Robert H. Jackson of the Supreme Court as chairman of a special committee to direct a nation-wide effort to improve the administration of criminal justice was announced today by Robert G. Storey of Dallas, Tex., president of the American Bar Association.

Industrial psychiatry has justified its bid for a place in American industry by helping to forestall or prevent serious mental and emotional disturbances among employes, a New York University Bellevue Medical Center conference was told yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, today directed the legal staff of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee, of which he is chairman, to seek a solution of the problem presented by scores of witnesses who, having taken loyalty oaths to obtain Government employment, now refused to say whether they were Communists at the time they took the oaths.

CLEVELAND, Miss., May 21 -- Ezra Taft Benson, the Secretary of Agriculture, said today he would "faithfully and vigorously execute the price support programs that are the law of the land" even though he personally regarded such programs as an undesirable and inadequate means to promote self-initiative and self-help throughout the farm economy.

The biggest National League crowd of the season, 46,778 paying spectators, was treated to one of the most eventful first innings in many a baseball moon at the Polo Grounds last night as the Giants, winning their fifth straight game, downed the Dodgers, 7 -- 2.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- Sales of heavy and accessory equipment at the Fifth National Materials handling Exposition at Convention Hall were reported this afternoon to have "soared into millions of dollars."

GENEVA, May 21 -- It would be a mistake for European steel producers to rely on a cartel to stabilize the prices of steel products exported to non-European areas, the Secretariat of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe warned in a study released here today.

YONKERS, May 21 (AP) -- Chuck Volo crowned his comeback campaign tonight by scoring a one-length victory in the $12,200 United States Harness Writers Trophy Pace at The Grand Circuit meeting at Yonkers Raceway.

LONDON, May 21 -- Nigeria, the British West African dependency where more than fifty persons died in political riots during the past week, needs a new constitution, Oliver Lyttelton, the Colonial Secretary, said in the House of Commons today.

Creation of a State Division of Port Administration, with almost absolute control over waterfront workers, was proposed by the State Crime Commission in its fourth and final report to Governor Dewey, made public yesterday.
DETROIT, May 21 -- Scattered strikes at supplier plants caused fresh cutbacks in automobile production today as almost 122,000 workers were made idle by parts shortages.
OGDEN, Utah, May 21 (UP) -- The bodies of thirty-seven Korea veterans and three fliers apparently were looted as they lay in the snow-covered wreckage of a C-46 that crashed four months ago.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- Elizabeth Hess, a 13-year-old from Phoenix, Ariz., became the 1953 national spelling champion today by correctly spelling "soubrette" after her last opponent had stumbled over "spermaceti," which is a white waxy solid obtained from the oil of a sperm whale.

The New School for Social Research will keep indefinitely a yellow cotton curtain over the "Revolutionary Violence" section of a mural in the school's cafeteria by the late Mexican artist Jose Clemente Orozco, because the painting "does not express the philosophy of the faculty," Dr. Hans Simons, president of the school, declared yesterday.

An appeal for support of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem was made last night by Prof. Albert Einstein over a telephone-amplifier hook-up from his home in Princeton, N. J., to meetings held in homes and auditoriums throughout the country under the auspices of the American Friends of the Hebrew University, Inc.
New York's World Trade Week will reach its climax today when the city joins with the nation in observing National Maritime Oay.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Secretary George M. Humphrey said today that the Treasury was preparing recommendations for "a brand-new tax law to eliminate many of the most serious inequities in the present revenue system.

Trading on the New York commodity exchanges was light yesterday but lead and potatoes were moderately heavy. Prices closed generally lower with liquidation before close of the May option weakening many of the markets. Lead, potatoes, cocoa, wool, zinc, tin and rubber were lower.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- Arthur S. Flemming, Defense Mobilization Director, warned Congress today that the Government needed machinery to act "promptly and effectively" in ordering price and wage control in the event of a war emergency.

Awards to fifteen artists, authors and composers were announced yesterday by the National Institute of Arts and Letters. Each receives $1,000 in recognition of past work or as encouragement for ability shown. Awards in each class follow:
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Admiral Robert B. Carney to be Chief of Naval Operations, succeeding Admiral William M. Fechteler.

PARIS, May 20 (AP) -- The two defending singles champions and all the American favorites advanced with ease today in the French international tennis championships, played under an unseasonable broiling sun.
Capt. John W. Anderson, master of the liner United States, has been named commodore of the United States Lines fleet of forty-eight ships, it was announced here yesterday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 21 (UP) -- President Carlos Ibanez del Campo accused international communism today of blocking world peace, keeping mankind in a state of permanent tension and forcing it to squander natural and technical resources in rearmament.

The president of City College, Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, has announced the appointment of Dr. Robert Bierstedt as Professor of Sociology and chairman of the college's Department of Sociology and Anthropology. Dr. Bierstedt, who is an associate professor of sociology at the University of Illinois, will take office on Sept. 1.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, May 21 -- With dollar earning capacity gravely hit by United States import restrictions on dairy produce, New Zealand is taking the lead among dairying countries in the fight to have controls eased. Following three official protests in recent months against restrictions on butter and milk powders, Prime Minister Sydney Holland has been pressing his case in Washington this week.

RANGOON, Burma, Friday, May 22 -- The United States, Burma, Thailand and Nationalist China will confer in Bangkok, Thailand, Monday to plan the withdrawal of 12,000 Chinese Nationalist guerrillas from Burma's frontier areas it was announced today.
Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway warned here last night that Moscow's long-range objectives remained unchanged despite its "peace" offensive, and that the peril to the Western world was as great as ever.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- President Eisenhower announced today that he would sign the offshore oil bill tomorrow even as a sharp new battle raged over whether coastal states should share in revenues from the outer continental shelf. The White House ceremony will be witnessed by twelve Senators and thirty-four Representatives from both parties.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The General Services Administration (G. S. A.) today announced the signing of an agreement with the Harvey Machine Company, Inc., Torrance, Calif., for construction of facilities at The Dalles, Oregon, with capacity to produce 54,000 short tons of primary aluminum annually.
During 1952, some of the hardest working members of the Camp Fire Girls were men, according to the organization's annual report issued yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, May 21 (AP) -- The Cardinals, continuing their heavy hitting, overcame deficits of six and three runs tonight to outslug the Redlegs, 11 -- 9, and take third place in the National League, just one game out of the league lead.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- Two-year-old Clifton Bradford Jr. and his 13-month-old sister, Diane, who allegedly were kidnapped and carried off to New York, came back to Washington today. They were taken to the District of Columbia Home for Children while welfare officers investigate their parents and charges that the parents' home is not fit for children.

Cool color schemes keyed to some new Waverly fabrics, have been used in four room settings that go on view today at Macy's. The designs, pale in color and summer-like in motifs, are printed on cotton Glosheen.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The Government called together some of its business men "alumni" today to discuss the kind of industrial records which should be kept in peacetime as a war preparedness measure.

Gov. Johnston Murray of Oklahoma has signed a bill creating the Oklahoma Educational Television Authority, according to an announcement by the National Citizens Committee for Educational Television. The action opens the way for what could be the first state-wide educational television network.

Two new films arrive at first-run theatres today. At the Globe is "Treasure of the Golden Condor," a Twentieth Century-Fox melodrama starring Cornel Wilde, Constance Smith, Finlay Currie and Walter Hampden. In featured roles are Anne Bancroft, George Macready, Fay Wray and Leo G. Carroll. Delmar Daves did the screen play and directed from a novel by Edison Marshall. Jules Buck produced.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., ordered its locals today not to sign any contracts that failed to provide a thirty-five-hour week. The union served notice on employers throughout the country that it was prepared to strike to enforce its mandate.

PARIS, May 21 -- Free Europe, from Oslo, Norway, to Istanbul, Turkey, is bound to be pleased that the chiefs of the three major democratic powers are going to get together to try to thrash out their differences and agree on a common approach to the Soviet Union.

Large cities such as New York and Newark have industries lured away by the low tax rates of nearby small communities and then are called upon to help these small towns put out their fires, fire officers complained yesterday at the twenty-sixth annual conference of the Eastern Association of Fire Chiefs.
Two hold-up men escaped with $10,000 in diamond rings and gems yesterday from the office of the Four Star Jewelry Company, 72 Bowery.

SARNIA, Ont. May 21 -- A rare northern tornado swept across the United States-Canadian border late today and dealt death and severe destruction in the twin cities of Sarnia and Port Huron, Mich., and beyond in southwestern Ontario.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 21 -- An aim toward greater safety -- a prime factor in the matter of sailboat racing -- was accomplished by the Larchmont Yacht Club with the formation of a race committee auxiliary today.

Antique Portuguese furniture, contemporary accessories from that country and a collection of made-in-America textiles inspired by motifs native to Portugal have been assembled in a new series of model rooms. Arranged by William Pahlmann, the settings are on view at his shop, Pahlmann Previews, 231 East Fifty-first Street, where the objects used in these rooms can be purchased.

The six-story building with forty-four apartments at 227 East 203d Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by Phillip P. Zipes, operator, from a client of Abe Rosenbloom, lawyer. It is assessed at $160,000 and was owned by the seller since 1937.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Neither the customs simplification bill nor repeal of the "Buy American" Act, two key steps in liberalizing import trade, appears likely to get attention by Congress before it adjourns or recesses July 1, spokesmen on Capitol Hill conceded today.

LONDON, May 21 (AP) -- Britain ordered a diplomatic trouble-shooter to Egypt today and confirmed that British civilians were being urged to leave that country unless pressing business kept them there.

BALTIMORE, May 21 (AP) They dropped the names of seven cons into the cater box today for the seventy-seventh running of the $100,000-added Preakness Stakes Saturday then continued the argument whether Native Dancer can gain revenge for his defeat by Dark Star in the Kentucky Derby.

DENVER, May 21 -- A new effort to unite the 17,000,000 Baptists in this country under one denominational banner took form here today when the two top-ranking executives of the American Baptist Convention made vigorous pleas for a united church.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 21 -- Italy has begun proceedings in the International Court of Justice against the United States, Britain and France for the return of gold looted by Germany in 1943, the court announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Weather Bureau officials said today many citizens had been asking if the Nevada atomic tests had caused the abnormally wet weather in the East this spring. Their answer is "No."

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Senator Smith suggested today that the Administration defer cuts in defense appropriations until the newly designated Joint Chiefs of Staff had completed their projected review of United States strategy.

The Transit Authority was informed yesterday by its engineering consultants that it would be mechanically possible to put a fare increase into effect by July 30. This is the deadline for making any fare changes this year under the law setting up the authority to take over and operate the deficit-plagued city-owned transit system.

MELBOURNE, May 21 -- The resignation of Arthur William Coles as chairman of the Control Committee for the 1956 Olympics, though based specifically on the Victorian Labor Government's decision not to build the Olympic swimming pool on the site approved by the International Olympic Committee in Fawkner Park, is the culmination of a conflict between amateur sportsmen on the Organizing Committee and business men on the Control Committee, which is a subcommittee or Organizing Committee.
NEWTON GROVE, N. C., May 21 -- This farming village of 400 persons has been split by an order for the consolidation of the Negro and white churches here.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 21 -- Diana Bourne of the home club shot 41, 41 -- 82 to win her second straight low gross prize in the Women's Westchester - Fairfield Golf Association's one-day tournament over the Siwanoy Country Club course today.
The public appeal for $200,000 made by the New York City Center of Music and Drama has brought in $56,000 so far, Newbold Morris, chairman of the board of directors, announced yesterday.

Six big Indian boys of four tribes came to town yesterday, wearing the colorful sort of things effete New Yorkers expect of Westerners and eager to see such novelties as the Atlantic Ocean and the Empire State Building.
The Army accepted yesterday from Lehn Fink, manufacturer of cosmetics and proprietary drugs, the 5,000,000th "cricket"-type anti-tank mine fuse made in its plant at Bloomfield, N. J.
For the first time in its 161-year-history the New York Stock Exchange made ready yesterday to welcome a member corporation.

The New York Stock Exchange is going to try out a new rule designed to improve the auction market and facilitate purchases of large blocks off the market by specialists. The rule, to take effect on June 1, will be tested for six months.

Manhattan gained its first victory in ten Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference games by defeating New York University, 6 -- 5, at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. The loss was the sixth in twelve league tests for the Violet. Bob Grady of Manhattan and Charles Payerle of N. Y. U. each made three hits.

HANOI, Vietnam May 22 (UP) -- Gen. Henri-Eugene Navarre, new French Commander in Indo-China, and his senior staff officers narrowly escaped death today when their plane was damager by Vietminh anti-aircraft fire.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 22 -- At least 100,000 persons -- the majority Africans -- will be uprooted and moved to new areas in the racial relocation of Johannesburg, South Africa's largest city, under a provisional decision of the City Council made under, pressure from the Malan Government.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 22 -- Gov. John Davis Lodge signed into law today a bill authorizing the construction of the Fairfield County Thruway and its extension across eastern Connecticut to the Rhode Island line.

There is a great deal being said and written these days about forming a coalition in the coming Mayoralty election. Your paper has recognized that only a coalition candidate can hope to retrieve the westerly section of City Hall (and the power it wields for good or evil) from its present incompetent and discredited occupant.

The Whitestone Bridge Drive-In Theatre, Bruckner Boulevard and Hutchinson River Parkway, the Bronx, will be the scene this summer of a new venture in Protestant religious circles. Sunday services, starting at 9 A. M., will be conducted there from June 7 through Sept. 6.

THERE are plenty of anglers now putting in their time on the trout stream who will transfer their allegiance once the bass season opens, and those who are too impatient to hang on until July can take advantage of the special fly-fishing-only bass season which opens in Maine on June 1.

NEWARK, May 22 -- A one-day work stoppage by 8,000 brewery workers in this area threatened to become a full-fledged strike when union representatives this afternoon rejected an offer of a wage increase by the New Jersey Brewers Association.

The spring hunt racing season will close this afternoon with the fifteenth annual Adjacent Hunts race meeting, a benefit program, at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club, Purchase, N. Y. The six-race card is for the benefit of the Damon Runyon Cancer Fund.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., May 22 -- An area-wide Council on Educational Television was organized here today to present a one-hour educational program five days a week over General Electric's television station WRGB.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- Long liquidation in grains again rolled into high today, crumbling prices all along the line. Pressure has increased since the expiration of the May deliveries which had an unsettling effect.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 22 -- Alexander Rankovic, Vice President of the Federal Executive Council and former Minister of Interior, today attributed the difficulties between the Yugoslav Government and the Roman Catholic Church, to opposition by the Church to changes initiated by the Communist-led state.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration has notified eighteen airports throughout the country that because of budget reductions it will discontinue operation of con trol towers at those fields. The airports all have relatively light commercial traffic.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- T. Lamar Caudle pictured himself for House investigators today as "overcautious" in handling tax fraud cases before he was dismissed in 1951 as head of the Justice Department's Tax Division.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 22 -- World mine production of tin and concentrates in March was 16,100 long tons, a sharp increase over the 11,900 tons for February, the International Tin Study Group reported here today.

The Department of Justice yesterday offered Stuart Denton Morris, general secretary of Great Britain's Peace Pledge Union, a conditional parole until his exclusion case is heard in Washington Monday or Tuesday, but he turned it down as a matter of principle and preferred to remain on Ellis Island.

A full-rigged Spanish sailiing vessel, the Juan Sebastian de Elcano, is scheduled to arrive here today on the last part of a training cruise. Aboard the 3,400-ton, 25-year-old training vessel are thirty-eight midshipmen and the ship's regular crew of twenty-one officers, thirty petty officers and 274 enlisted men.

VIENNA, May 22 -- The doctrine that sound policies, not new international gadgets, are the businessman's prescription for restoring sanity to international economic relations was elaborated in discussions at the International Chamber of Commerce Congress here today and reduced to specific cases over a wide range of much-debated world economic problems.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The American Federation of Labor urged today that President Eisenhower establish a special study commission to make specific recommendations to assure continuing economic expansion and full employment.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 22 -- Sidewalk critics in Washington Square will determine the final grades of ten Hun School students Sunday, when the boys will take an unusual examination in the art of public speaking.

The New York City Transit Authority passed its second court test yesterday as the Appellate Division upheld unanimously a decision by Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber declar ing the authority constitutional.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, May 22 -- Mrs. Ann Davidson, 38 years of age of Gloucestershire, England, arrived in Nassau this morning after a one-year voyage across the Atlantic. Mrs. Davidson left Plymouth in a 23-foot yacht, the Felicity Ann, in May, 1952.

There are many signs of spring that the winter-weary city-dweller anxiously watched for, some external, some internal. They included the first robin, the first crocus, the emergence of the birdwatchers, the turning of a young man's fancy, a lilt in the morning walk, a sudden smile to a stranger or courtesy on the subway.

NEW LISBON, N. J., May 22 -- A 26-year-old inmate of the state colony for feeble-minded males here lost his life early today reportedly as the result of an attempt by a group of patients to re-enact a television scene.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., May. 22 -- Robert Wilder, 32 years old, member of a prominent Palmer, Mass., family, was killed instantly this afternoon when his new English-built Allard left the road during a practice run for tomorrow's scheduled sports car road races.

With the termination this week of the first major phase of the investment banking anti-trust trial, the courtroom proceedings gave way to an off-the-record epilogue for the exchange of personal amenities and the computation of certain vital statistics affecting the family life of the lawyers since the trial began two and one-half years ago.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 22 -- Those screen tests Peter Lawford made at Columbia have paid off. He will go to work Monday morning opposite Judy Holliday in the comedy "A Name for Herself."

WATERFORD, Conn., May 22 -- The 230 acres of woodlands, meadow, natural beach and formal gardens comprising Harkness Memorial State Park, overlooking Block Island and Long Island Sounds, will be formally opened tomorrow by the Connecticut Park and Forest Commission.

DENVER, May 22 -- Plans for an $8,000,000 church building campaign hit a snag here today at the American Baptist Convention as opponents of the proposal sought iron-bound guarantees that only "immersed believers" would be admitted to membership in the new church.

BOSTON, May 22 (UP) -- Catcher Sammy White slashed a double in the twelfth inning today to complete a Boston sweep of a doubleheader with the Athletics and move the Red Sox into second place in the American League. Boston took both games by scores of 3 -- 2.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use to the homemaker.
Operations of Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., for the three months ended on April 30 resulted in a net profit of $6,585,130, equal to 96 cents a common share, it was announced yesterday.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., May 22 -- Vic Reinemer, associate editor of The Charlotte (N. C.) News, continued today with testimony identifying Lieut. Sheppard Carl Thierman, a medical officer, as an active participant in a World Youth and Student Festival in Budapest, Hungary, in August, 1949.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 22 -- Ch. Williamsdale Rocky, 3 1/2 year-old black and white dog, took best-in-breed honors today in a field of eighty-four at the annual show of the Dalmatian Club of America on the grounds of the National Guard Armory.

MOSCOW, May 22 (AP) -- Nikolai M. Vasiliev, Minister of State Control of the Russian Republic, said today the Soviet Government had punished such guilty officials as Ryumin, former Deputy Minister of State Security who was accused of helping fabricate the "Doctors' plot."

The National Federation of American Shipping has announced its opposition to proposed legislation in Congress that would let the Government revoke, amend or suspend the certificates or permits authorizing maritime companies to engage in coastwise shipping.

The city accepted a settlement yesterday of $8,806,000 in its claims for $13,025,235 in back taxes from the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road and immediately announced it would throw its weight toward acceptance of the Pennsylvania Railroad's plan for reorganization of the Long Island under private operation.

ST. LOUIS, May 22 (AP) -- The Post-Dispatch, in a copyrighted story, today quoted the retiring Air Force Chief of Staff, Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, as saying his views had not been sought and he had not offered them on the decision to cut the defense budget.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Consumers' Price Index rose 0.1 per cent between mid-March and mid-April to 113.7 per cent of the 1947-49 average, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 22 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. has notified the United Nations that all its foreign employes who have permanent immigrant status in the United States must pay income taxes.

Your correspondent John Perlis reports that communism has cost us 135,000 casualties in Korea; "McCarthyism" none. Even a single casualty is a terrible tragedy; but if men wish to be free rather than slaves freedom could require even the risk of total tragedy in total war.

The Brown Shoe Company, Inc., announced in St. Louis, Mo., yesterday that it had reached an agreement with stockholders of the Regal Shoe Company, of Whitman, Mass., to purchase a controlling interest in Regal. Details of the deal will not be announced until the transaction has been completed.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 22 -- Mrs. Lillian B. Robinson, 47-year-old Roslyn, L. I., business woman who admitted having mulcted the Central National Bank of Mineola of $478,000 through the use of fraudulent home-improvement loan notes, was sentenced in Nassau County Court today to a term of six to twelve years in the New York State prison for Women at Bedford Hills.

Trading in metals was active yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange with tin showing the third largest volume of the year. Most, other commodity trading was quiet but cottonseed oil volume was greater than the aggregate for the other four days of the week.

Mount St. Michael captured two of the four events in Class I of the senior group and Poly Prep did likewise in Class II as the annual track and field championships of the Athletic Association of Private Schools of Greater New York started yesterday at Baker Field.
PHILADELPHIA, May 22 -- Princeton's track team defeated Pennsylvania, 82 to 58, on Franklin Field today in a dual meet that saw three records broken and one tied.

BUENOS AIRES,. May 22 -- As the Argentine Senate was devoting forty minutes today to approving a bill to dissolve the seventy-five- year-old Jockey Club and seize the two valuable race tracks it owns, the Ministry of Justice announced that it was taking control of another important organization of Argentina's once dominant wealthy landowners, the Circulo de Armas, which was founded sixty-seven years ago.

Supreme Court Justice James B. M. McNally offered his services to settle the strike of 800 employes of Hearn's department stores after the company's attorney had announced that telegrams had been sent to union officials proposing to resume negotiations.
TOKYO, Saturday, May 23 (UP) -- The Eighth Army took advantage of a lull in the Korean war yesterday to experiment with supplying a 16,000-man front-line division by helicopter.

BALTIMORE, May 22 -- A highly interesting bit of race track business is booked for late tomorrow afternoon at old Pimlico. It's the seventy-seventh running of the Preakness Stakes for 3-year-olds. Victory carries with it a large amount of lovely money and a large amount of horse-park prestige.

By noon yesterday the yard at the City and Country School, 165 West Twelfth Street, was beginning to acquire the color and gaiety of a real country fair. Students 5 to 13 years old, their parents and teachers were hard at work putting the finishing touches on decorations, booths, games and picnic food in anticipation of the sixteenth annual school fair held last night.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Food and Drug Administration today announced that producers of coumarin, widely used in foods as an ingredient of synthetic vanilla flavoring, are voluntarily withdrawing it from sale for all use in foods.

YONKERS, May 22 (AP) -- Meadow Rice's victory streak of twelve ended tonight in the $7,500 free-for-all pace on the Grand Circuit card at Yonkers Raceway as Thomas B. Scott scored a head victory over Hi-Lo's Forbes. Meadow Rice, winner of the Little Brown Jug last year, was third.

Automobile and truck production of General Motors Corporation in the first six months of 1953 should exceed the record established in the corresponding period of 1950, Harlow H. Curtice, president, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting in Wilmington, Del.
BONN, Germany, May 22 -- The Jews of Germany criticized the Federal Government and Parliament today for not enacting federal law providing for restitution for Nazi victims.

DETROIT, May 22 (AP) -- Art Houtteman, reported to be on the Tigers' trading block, made his employers sit up and take notice tonight with a two-hitter that gave Detroit a 7-0 victory over the White Sox.

Western Europe's dependence on food imports may enable the Communist countries to obtain greateh imports of industrial tools and other strategic goods from that area, Allan B. Kline, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation warned yesterday.

GENEVA, May 22 (AP) -- United Nations Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that he would not tolerate any member of the United Nations Secretariat's engaging in political activities in his own country.

Older horses will be in the spotlight at Belmont Park today, where the sixtieth running of the $30,000 Metropolitan Handicap will be the top offering. Nine, including the Greentree Stable's Tom Fool, the likely favorite, and Mrs. Esther du Pont Weir's Royal Vale, were named overnight for the mile fixture.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were quiet yesterday, and closing prices were off 9 points on old July and unchanged to 6 points up on other active months compared with Thursday's prices.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- In a 2-to-1 decision that may affect more than 2,000 companies in the natural gas industry and millions of consumers, the Federal Court of Appeals ruled here today that the Phillips Petroleum Company was a natural gas concern within the meaning of the Natural Gas Act of 1938, and that the Federal Power Commission had authority to fix rates for the company's interstate sales of such gas.
MOSCOW, May 22 -- Wheat flour has been placed on constant daily sale in the Government's stores in Moscow and the other principal Russian cities.

The stage is now set for the Congressional struggle on the method of producing and marketing vast hydroelectric power resources of the Niagara River and Falls. Representative Becker of New York introduced a bill yesterday to authorize the New York State Power Authority to construct the new power plant under license from the Federal Power Commission.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 22 (AP) -- A Nashville newspaper editor was seated on a Federal grand jury today despite his plea that he was being punished for editorials and news stories his paper had published about the court.

A short course in advertising fundamentals, particularly media evaluation, should be made a part of every company's training for field representatives, it was suggested yesterday by Kevin Sweeney, vice president of the Broadcast Advertising Bureau.

Danny Giovanelli, sturdy welter-weight from the Ridgewood section of Brooklyn, registered an upset last night when he defeated Vince Martinez of Paterson (N. J.) at Madison Square Garden. Trading punches with his highly favored opponent through each of the ten rounds, Giovanelli managed to gain the award by a split vote.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- A three-man division of the Interstate Commerce Commission today blocked attempts of railroads operating in states east of the Mississippi River, except New England, to levy a charge of 25 cents on handbags, and 50 cents on trunks for checking and handling such luggage to passenger trains.

Considering the rapidly growing interest in family-life education in schools throughout the country, it has been noted that only one public high school in any of the five boroughs offers a course considered adequate to cover the subject. This is at Walton High School in the Bronx, where there is an enrollment of 3,400 girls.

BUENOS AIRES, May 22 -- President Juan Peron asserted today that the world was "infected with rotten journalism." He made that remark as he told employes of La Prensa that he daily grew prouder of the help he had given in expropriating the newspaper from its former owners and turning it over to the "people."

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Pentagon officials are studying plans that would have the effect of strengthening the military Reserve forces while at the same time reducing the length of time discharged Selective Service veterans would be required to remain in Reserve status.

BERLIN, May 22 -- The post-war economic recovery of West Germany has reached a point where the current average income has substantially exceeded that in 1936, according to the Federal Statistical Bureau.
Import traders were cheered yesterday by word from Washington that the House Ways and Means Committee had scheduled three-day hearings on the Customs Simplification Bill, beginning next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- House of Representatives leaders indicated today that further investigations in the field of obscene literature were unlikely. Bottled up in hte Rules Committee is a bill by Representative Carroll D. Kearns, Republican of Pennsylvania, to renew the inquiry held last year.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- A directive of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation issued recently has been so detrimental to small business that the Small Defense Plants Administration has suspended efforts to process applications "until the policy is modified or withdrawn,"

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Leaders of Americans for Democratic Action opened its sixth annual convention today with appeals to President Eisenhower to reverse "'business as usual' policies" threatening the security of the free world and to join in the attack against "McCarthyism."

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 22 -- Secretary of State Dulles arrived here today from New Delhi on his twenty-day tour of the Near and Middle East and Southeast Asia "to listen and to learn" in a series of conferences with the United States Embassy and Pakistan officials tomorrow and Sunday.

Not one of the headline problems on Page 1 of THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 21 offers by itself any hope of resolution. Anglo-American discord, Laos, Czech press relations, Korean truce talks, British vessels in Communist trade, India's interest in Korea, Poles escaping with MIGs, dismissals of U. N. employes and our domestic farm, tax and civil defense problems -- each one is depressingly hopeless.

The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross reported yesterday that 1,087 pints of blood were collected on Thursday, including respective contributions of 200 and 173 pints from residents of the Queensview housing development at Astoria, Queens, and of Firthcliffe, N. Y.

BONN, Germany, May 22 -- The West German Government is working on a formula for consultation with the Western powers during the forthcoming Bermuda conference of the United States, Britain and France and any subsequent East-West parley.

Those who are planning to close their city homes for the summer or to take up the carpets to give a cool look on hot days might be interested in some advice from various sources on storing and cleaning rugs.

" For More Than Bread," by Clarence E. Pickett, who for twenty-two years was executive secretary of the American Friends Service Committee, will be published June 29 by Little, Brown. The book combines Mr. Picketts autobiography and an informal history of the organization, whose work in relief and rehabilitation won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1947.

A new convenience for open air cookery is an electrically rotated barbecuer with two special attachments, a set of four skewers for shish kebab and a basket grill for steaks, frankfurters, buns and so forth. The Brevel Party-Q set, the parts of which may be purchased separately, fits over any outdoor fireplace or grill.
DETROIT, May 22 -- More than 135,000 automobile workers were idle today as strikes at scattered supplier plants remained unsettled.

PARAMUS, N. J., May 22 -- Ch. Mar-Hawk's Gift to Glenshaw, a 2 1/2-year-old white and red dog owned by Mrs. R. W. Snowdon-of Allison Park, Pa., gained best of breed today in the 120-dog specialty of the Cocker Spaniel Club of Northern New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Some officials were fearful today that the fall of the French Government would force postponement of the Western Big Three meeting tentatively scheduled for next month.

Jim Hearn, who hadn't been able to last the distance in seven preview starts, strong-armed the sizzling Giants to a 5-1 triumph over the Dodgers before 13,267 paying spectators and 3,581 Ladies Day guests at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
Pittsburgh, Pa., has designated June 4 for the sale of $4,600,000 of funding and public improvement bonds dated July 1, 1953, and due July 1, 1954 to 1973.

There is danger that the importance of the coming three-Power meeting will be exaggerated, especially in Britain. This is Apparent in the eager response to President Eisenhower's proposal, and in the evidence that its scope is rather differently viewed in Washington and London. The Times of London says that "no more important conference has been planned since the Western Powers were forced to unite, rearm and resist Communist aggression."
The importance of gaining personal satisfaction from a job often increases as one grows older, a New York University-Bellevue Medical Center conference on medicine in industry was told yesterday.
TOKYO, Saturday, May 23 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,623, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korean time:

PARIS, May 22 (AP) -- America's queen of the courts, Maureen Connolly, made an impressive debut in the French international tennis championships today by defeating Christiane de Mercellis of Belgium, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- A national transfer program that would permit garment workers to move from one city to another without impairing their pension rights was adopted today by the triennial convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 22 -- Miss Dana Hudson, president of the National Organization of Hospital Schools of Nursing, Inc., charged today that "a new order" in nursing was threatening to destroy hospital nursing schools by "social pressure."
AMES, Ia., May 22 (AP) -- Three 1952 Olympians came through with record performances in preliminaries of the Big Seven Conference track and field meet today.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 22 -- Twenty-one winners of 1952 Headliner Achievement Awards for outstanding contributions to the field of journalism were announced today by the judges committee of the National Headliners Club.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee today ordered subpoenas issued directing two New Mexico officials to produce ballots cast in Bernalillo County at last November's Senatorial election in New Mexco.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) -- President Eisenhower gave the Korean clothing fund drive a pair of spiked golf shoes today and they stole the show from a picture-taking ceremony of Mrs. Eisenhower and Mrs. Oscar L. Chapman.

The observance of National Maritime Day took on a grim note here yesterday despite the presence of all the color and festive air that generally accompany the city's annual salute to the nation's merchant fleet.
TOKYO, Saturday, May 23 (AP) -- An unusual degree of secrecy shielding work by the United Nations Command on a revised Korean truce proposal suggested today that a turning point was approaching.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, editor of The Christian Herald and chairman of the All-American Conference to Combat Communism, told the opening session of that conference tonight that any peace in Asia now would be appeasement.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Shangri-la, the name Democrats gave to the Presidential retreat in the near-by Maryland hills, was renamed for a couple of Republicans today. Henceforth it will be known as Camp David.

The heated dispute that arose at Public School 125, 425 West 123d Street, over the re-election of officers of the Parents' Association there Wednesday night continued yesterday. The winning group categorically denied charges made by an opposition faction that irregularities had marked the voting.

A board to insure prompt and impartial investigations of complaints made by civilians against members of the Police Department was established yesterday by Commissioner George P. Monaghan. Heretofore, many complaints have alleged "police brutality" and eight such cases are now pending.

Another Polish airman has flown his MIG to Denmark and claimed refuge in the free world. Western experts will thus have another chance to examine an intact Soviet fighter plane, and if this plane is an improved model, as some reports suggest, they will gain valuable additional knowledge regarding the level of Soviet military technology.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- The State Department's top security officer, Scott McLeod, said today that he had ordered his aides to be completely ruthless in passing on new job applicants.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Representative Samuel W. Yorty, Democrat of California, called for the resignation of Charles E. Wilson as Secretary of Defense today in a speech to the House of Representatives. He termed Mr. Wilson "pennywise" in recommending a cut of $5,000,000,000 in Air Force funds below the total asked by President Truman before he left office.

ST. LOUIS, May 22 (AP) -- Stan Musial drove in two runs with a single and homer tonight as the third-place Cardinals, scoring their fourth consecutive victory, pulled within one-half game of the National League lead by defeating the Redlegs, 4 -- 2.

A farewell salute to the Empire Theatre, New York's oldest playhouse, which is scheduled to be razed this summer, will take place within its confines tomorrow evening when fifty-six leading performers will present scenes from plays that were done there over the last sixty years.

Some authorities have estimated that there were a million or more Indians when the white men first invaded this continent. The number dropped until it seemed as though the native races would eventually disappear. Now the trend has been reversed. There are nearly 400,000 Indians on federal reservations and the excess of births over deaths, though encouraging, also creates a problem.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The highly publicized call on President Eisenhower by the Senate Investigations subcommittee for his personal views on the apparently increasing trade with Red China by vessels flying flags of Allied countries was never delivered to the White House.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. announced today the return of a Federal indictment charging six corporations and four individuals with monopolizing the manufacture of railroad car-coupling devices.
LONDON, May 22 (AP) -- The London stock exchange will be closed Monday May 25 for the Whitsun holidays.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- A State of Washington sheep raiser said today that Western stockmen supporting a bill to regulate grazing on public lands were "hopelessly in the minority."

Park Commissioner Moses and Borough President Baker of Staten Island believe that the city has an unusual opportunity, not likely to occur again, to add to the city's beach front improvements at relatively little cost. They propose that the entire Staten Island beach front for 2.5 miles between Fort Wadsworth and Miller Field along the borough's southeast shore be converted into a resort similar to that at Rockaway Beach in Queens.

Despite favorable news for the stock market yesterday, only a double handful of issues scored sizable gains. The majority of the list remained flaccid. Some of the oils, rail equipments, liquors and airlines showed strength, as did American Telephone and Telegraph. Motors were weak and other soft spots were scattered.
