When a boy in your neighborhood finally becomes a full-fledged doctor or a girl in your block is "capped" as a nurse, you are mighty proud of it and don't mind taking a bit of reflected glory.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Economy lines failed to hold in six of nine tests today as the House of Representatives added $6,534,891 to a bill appropriating funds for the Department of Labor and the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 22 -- With one vote in opposition, Parliament adopted today an agricultural reform bill more drastic in its implications for private landholders than even the reform bill of 1945 when the first great effort was made by the Communist-led Government to smash the peasantry.

ATHENS, May 22 -- The Hellenic Powder and Cartridge Company has just signed two contracts with the United States Army procurement officers for $14,700,000 worth of ammunition. The company is ready to start production at once.

Following the customary practice for end-of-the-season shows, the Perls and Viviano Galleries are having group shows that survey their rosters of artists. Although many of the paintings are familiar from one-man show appearances, many take on new aspects when seen in unexpected juxtapositions.
William Perl, one of the nation's leading experts on jet propulsion, was convicted in Federal court yesterday on two of four counts of perjury.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Those people whose favorite exercise is porch sitting probably will appreciate the rocking chair patented this week by Phillip A. Joncas of Hollywood, Calif. Rocking in his chair, he says, will provide both children and adults with a pleasant means of strenghtening the muscles of their arms and legs.

Brooklyn Bridge, its basic structural beauty and worthiness unimpaired, will mark its seventieth anniversary tomorrow. And some of the workmen now rejuvenating the majestic old span to meet modern traffic needs will be present to participate in a ceremony dedicating a plaque to the Roebling family, "the builders of the bridge."

FORT WORTH, Tex., May 22 (AP) -- Clayton Heafner shot his greatest round in the Colonial national invitation golf tournament today. -- a 4-under-par 66 that was just one stroke over the competitive course record -- to move into first place at the halfway mark with 140 for thirty-six holes.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- With more than forty proponents of the measure present, President Eisenhower today signed the bill granting the states title to offshore lands within their historic boundaries.

PARIS, May 22 -- Initial consultations today between President Vincent Auriol and French party leaders showed that a solution of the crisis caused by the downfall of Premier Rene Mayer would be extremely hard.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 22 -- The first result of the second official visit to Kenya of Oliver Lyttelton, British Colonial Secretary, was the decision announced today by the Colonial Government here to call to arms a part of the Asian population.

Four of the six dogs that competed for best in show a year ago, including the wire-haired fox terrier that achieved it, are among the 2,612 dogs entered in today's Morris and Essex Kennel Club classic.

Directors of the American Car and Foundry Company voted an extra dividend yesterday of $2 a share, besides a 10 per cent stock dividend and four dividends of 75 cents on the common stock, as well as four quarterly dividends on the 7 per cent non cumulative preferred stock.

LAKE CHARLES, La., May 22 (AP) -- Mounting dangers forced hundreds of additional families to flee their homes tonight while state troopers guarded against dynamitings of highways to unleash dammed up flood waters.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The chances are that Irv Noren never hit a ball so hard as he did against Bob Porterfield in the ninth inning of today's getaway game between the Yankees and Senators at Griffith Stadium. It was a low, screaming liner down the middle, but all it got for Noren was recognition for having rammed into the season's first triple play in the major leagues.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 22 -- The recent increase from 4 to 4 1/2 per cent has removed the "marked competitive disadvantage" of veterans home loans to other types of mortgages and investment, the New Jersey Savings and Loan League heard today.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- An organized labor spokesman termed today the draft of a bill drawn up by the Senate staff committee to amend the Taft Hartley Law as "far worse" than the present law, and a Democratic Senator said it seemed to be "a continuation of the Republican giveaway."

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- With the Controlled Materials Plan expiring on June 30, the Office of Defense Mobilization today sought suggestions from industry as to how such a program could be re-established in the least possible time in the event of war.

LONDON, May 22 -- The immigration of Indians into Kenya preceded that of the whites. They began to be imported in 1896 to work on the railway from Mombasa to Lake Victoria. Before the completion of the railway in 1903, the white population of Kenya numbered about 400 traders, officials and missionaries.
AT Monte Carlo in 1931 the little ball busily spinning around a roulette table dropped into a black pocket twenty-six times in succession.

NEW DELHI, India, May 22 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles listed today three steps he thought the Soviet Union could take to break the present "stalemate of distrust." He indicated that unless the Kremlin rulers took these steps, talks with the Soviet Union would be futile.
LONDON, May 22 -- The final source of information on matters pertaining to dress for the coronation ceremony in Westminster Abbey, on June 2, is Bluemantle Pursuivant of Arms.

LONDON, May 22 -- News of the three-power meeting next month stimulated sentiment though not the volume of business on the stock markets today. Although trading was low before the Whitsun weekend holiday, prices gained slightly.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Martin P. Durkin, Secretary of Labor, told a House Judiciary subcommittee today the admission of 240,000 extra immigrants over the next two years, as recommended by President Eisenhower, would add "a trickle of actually less than one-tenth of 1 per cent" to the nation's labor force.

I can certainly agree with the statement of your May 19 editorial that "Yugoslavs were no doubt provoked by the indirect invitation which Dr. De Gasperi extended to Russia in an electoral campaign speech a few weeks ago to join the Western Big Three in supporting the return of the Trieste Free Territory to Italy."

OTIS AIR FORCE BASE, Falmouth, Mass., May 22 -- The most inconspicuous part of the Defense Department's operations protecting New York is the roaring flights made in the metropolitan area by the Air Force's jet interceptors based here on Cape Cod.
Francis G. Barrett was elected president of the New York Typographical Union's Local No. 6, A. F. L., defeating the incumbent, Laurence Victory, by a narrow margin, the union announced last night.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Mr. Flanagan, queried about the letter, said tonight that "Senator McCarthy wants to discuss it further with the subcommittee before it is sent out."

Two Queens radio policemen, who offered to help a motorist load two heavy trunks into his automobile Thursday night, found themselves modest heroes yesterday. The motorist was charged with transporting $25,000 worth of smuggled cameras, binoculars and lenses.

DETROIT, May 22 -- The General Motors Corporation consented today to rewrite the wage provisions of its five-year escalator agreement with the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., although the original contract had two years yet to run.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the atomic spies now under sentence of death in Sing Sing Prison, have been told that any disclosures they might make regarding the nature and extent of espionage in this country would be a factor in any consideration for clemency, a Department of Justice source said today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 23 -- Following a three-week visit to Israel by thirty leading members of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, Dr. Maurice N. Eisendrath, president of the union, said today that he and his group felt "overwhelmed" by the interest in the reform syngagogue movement that they had found in Israel.

HONG KONG, May 23 (UP) -- The embargo on shipments of strategic goods to Communist China has been tightened in the last few months, but trade with the Chinese Reds still continues in some vital goods because of different definitions of the phrase "strategic material," informed shipping sources said today.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Eisenhower will have a chance on Tuesday to get a tasty idea of what the Department of Agriculture does with some of the taxpayers' money.

AFTER stepping our onto my terrace one day last week and noting they numerous chores still to be done, this city gardener despaired. (The feeling hits every city gardener at some time or other.) Fortunately one of the floribunda roses chose that day to open its first flower of the season.

AMOS is a beagle puppy without a name or owners; in the course of this story Amos gets owners, loses them, and finds them again. A dog-meets-owner's sort of story, with much that is true about dogs, and beagles in particular.
PARIS, May 23 -- Felicisimo Ampon of the Philippines scored the first big upset in the French international tennis championships today, crushing Budge Patty of Los Angeles, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4.

In his appeal to the American people for support of his budget and fiscal policies, President Eisenhower said, in seeking what he termed the "middle way" fiscally, we must avoid "any penny-wise, pound-foolish policy that could, through lack of needed strength, cripple the cause of freedom everywhere."
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., May 23 (AP) -- Charley Pratt, a sophomore, provided the spark today as Manhattan's track team routed Penn State, 72 1/2 to 58 1/2.

MANILA, May 23 -- A fight for the Presidency of the Philippines in 1953 -- perhaps even marked by bloodshed -- had long been anticipated here. What was not expected was the struggle that has developed within the ranks of President Elpidio Quirino's own Liberal party.

I WONDER whether there is any segment of the working economy that is so flagrantly discriminated against, as far as compulsory union membership is concerned, as that containing the actor, and especially the singing actor.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- The first year of the Republican Resurgence may turn out to be the most peaceful year and the most successful year on the labor-management front since World War II. The possibility that strikes will drop to a post-war low was fortified by General Motors' voluntary agreement yesterday to grant wage improvements for its 390,000 unionized workers.
Hun School, in Princeton, N. J., was flunked in public speaking yesterday by the New York City Department of Parks. The first lesson in public speaking, the school was told, is: Get a permit.

EL PASO, Tex., May 23 (AP) -- The United States-Mexican border was closed to the importation of Mexican cattle today, less than nine months since it had been reopened, because of an outbreak of dreaded foot and mouth disease. The Bureau of Animal Industry in Washington ordered border inspectors to turn back all Mexican cattle from the border.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., May 23 -- Eleven debutantes of the 1953-54 season will be presented to society, at a ball, the annual benefit party for the Grenville Baker Boys Club of Locust Valley, to be given on June 13 at the home of Mrs. George duPont Pratt on Skunks Misery Road in the Lattingtown Colony.
PARIS, May 23 -- President Vincent Auriol decided tonight to call Guy Mollet, general secretary of the Socialist party, to attempt to form a coalition Cabinet for France.

SOME of Shakespeare's admirers feel that he is a mystical poet who should be brooded upon in the study, but most people are willing to admit that he intended his plays to be acted. A good actor can light up Shakespeare's lines in a way that only the most talented of readers can do for himself, and Mr. Sprague's new book is a record of some of these flashes of illumination.
The Voice of America bade good-by yesterday to listeners from South America to the Malay States as the deadline arrived for substantial cutbacks in the country's radio propaganda effort.

LONDON, May 23 -- Hundreds of thousands of Londoners and visitors to the capital appeared today to have contracted a rare type of spring fever, induced by the advent of the Whitsun week-end holiday and the imminence of the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II.

Two hundred and sixty-seven places will be at stake in the sectional qualifying rounds for the United States Golf Association's open championship. The first of these 36-hole tests begins in Honolulu tomorrow but the other thirty-two, to be held in various parts of the country, will be staged on June 1.

How goes the assault on Everest and what of the men now fighting their way up its ice-clad slopes and crags? Have the men of this latest expedition already triumphed, are they still picking and pitoning their way upward or have the forces of nature once more turned overreachers back?
The Council of the American Meteorological Society has issued a new pronouncement on modifying and controlling the weather.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 23 -- Dr. Solomon Lefschetz, chairman of the Princeton University Department of Mathematics, will retire July 1 and will be succeeded by Dr. Albert W. Tucker.

BUSINESS volume in general is well above last year's levels. The Federal Reserve Bank reports that sales for the latest week are up 7 per cent, and while this gain is not quite as much as the retail sales increase shown the week before, in which Mother's Day occurred, it is indicative of the willingness of consumers to spend their money on sound values.

JERSEY CITY, May 23 -- Cyril R. Deady, 53 years old, of Union City, N. J., and John Greely, 43, of Jersey City, who one year ago were convicted of first degree murder and sentenced to life imprisonment, in a retrial were found not guilty today and freed.

WITH THE COMMONWEALTH DIVISION, Korea, May 23 -- British soldiers have been effectively holding down a considerable section of the Korean battlefront almost continuously since their arrival two months after the Republic of Korea was attacked from the north in June, 1950.

DETROIT -- The automobile industry, which prides itself on anticipating the preferences of car buyers, has been deeply shaken by the swift and unforeseen acceptance of power steering, a device that (according to the advertising copywriters) makes parking a two-ton limousine about as easy as dialing a telephone.

PICASSO once portrayed life as an egg encased within an iceberg. In this strange narrative, Lionel Barrymore addresses himself to a representation of the national state of mind in the United States about midways of the last century.

CENTRAL CITY, Colo. -- The annual necromancy called the Central City Opera Festival is working magic already in this old mining town as the practitioners of festival voodoo shine the glasses and oil the cash registers for the rush starting June 27.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Details of the Army's program to spot guided missile anti-aircraft units around major cities came to light today, including the fact that some batteries would be located underground.

In practically every Presidential campaign since the passage of the income tax amendment to the Constitution in 1913, the outs have promised economy and lower taxes. The ins have promised economy. Their modesty on tax cuts has been described as "the tribute which expediency pays to experience."

The financial world is getting ready again for another big marketing -- the sixth -- of public housing bonds bearing the perfected Federal guarantee furnished by the 1949 amendments to the Housing Act.
MADISON, N. J., May 23 -- The mantle of national prominence was draped around the trim shoulders of an imported Welsh terrier at Giralda Farms today.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin and chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said today the Eisenhower Administration had made a "good case" for its full $5,800,000,000 foreign aid program.

JACOBS PILLOW, Ted Shawn's hideaway near Lee, Mass., in the foothills of the Berkshires, continues to prove the "better mousetrap" theory by having to expand its summer festival each year. This year will be the largest ever, with a ten-week season of fifty-one performances, starting July 3.

"WHOEVER heard of a frightened Indian?" asks Miss Brenner and around a most untypical figure builds a heartening story for children who are ashamed to admit their own fears. This timid Mexican Indian is scared of his shadow, scared of the echo of his own voice, yet in his dunder-headed way he turns out to be a hero in spite of himself.

THE perfection of bloom this year on iris, traditionally the rainbow flower, is well-deserved recompense for the recent and virtually continuous rains. Zenith of bloom is expected today here in the Northeast.

YONKERS, May 23 -- The Dagsworthy Farms' Volto Man. a 5-year-old brown horse driven by Paul Vineyard, won the $5,800 Hudson Class 14 pacing stake by a length from Jimmy Highland before 32,075 at Yonkers Raceway tonight, marking the close of the spring meeting and ending the two-week Grand Circuit program.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A Senate Armed Services subcommittee reported today that "there was a needless loss of American lives" in Korea at unspecified times and places because of shortages of ammunition.

ORANGE, Tex., May 23 (UP) -- Fifteen thousand men, women and children, who slaved so hard they exhausted the city's supply of adhesive tape to cover their blisters, apparently saved Orange from being flooded tonight as their sandbag reinforcements to the city's dikes held firm.

POOLS are one of the easiest ways to garden in the summer -- there is no weeding or very little, and no one minds having his hands in cool water on a hot day. There is no watering to do, except to replenish occasionally that which has evaporated.

WEATHER has as much influence on the upkeep of a garden as it does on its planting. This year rain not only washed out first daffodils, then tulips and lilacs, but forced many of the little chores to be started earlier than usual.

The U. S., Britain and France are the three keystones in the Atlantic arch. United, they command the allegiance of a highly skilled population of 250 million which controls the major share of world industry, capital and transportation. The U. S. is the strongest power in the world.

New York commercial bankers, after successfully resisting savings banks' branch office expansion plans in one of the bitterest legislative fights in banking history, will "get away from it all" this week. For the first time in fourteen years the New York State Bankers Association will hold its annual convention aboard ship, while leisurely crusing to Bermuda and back.

Girl Scouts in neat green uniforms vied with more casually attired Village artists for attention yesterday at the Washington Square Outdoor Art Show. With the help of a sizable display of art work and a small band, they managed to draw one of the biggest crowds of the day to the exhibition on Thompson Street.

DEVON, Pa., May 23 -- Miss Laura Lee Shreve, 16 years old, of Fails Church, Vs., riding her mount, Cheese Cake, won top honors on the opening day of the fifty-seventh annual Devon horse show and country fair by winning the Best Child Rider Challenge Trophy, donated by Mr. and Mrs. Hugh McGinn. This is the first time the trophy has been offered and it must be won three times for permanent possession.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican of Michigan, indicated today that President Eisenhower's military prestige would be invoked in an effort to quell a threatened rebellion in the Senate against proposed cuts in Air Force appropriations.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- Veterans Administration medical experts estimated today that they would have to close six or seven veterans' hospitals as a result of cuts in their budget for the 1954 fiscal year, starting July 1.

About 2,000 physicians and health workers last week attended the annual meeting of the National Tuberculosis Association at Los Angeles. Nearly every social and medical phase of tuberculosis was discussed.
THURMONT, Md., May 23 -- President Eisenhower may have mixed some trout fishing today with his "quiet day of paper work" at this Presidential hideaway in the cool Catoctin Mountains.

Your recent editorial entitled "In the Battle of the Mind" calls attention to two important problems in the struggle in Asia: the need for an adequate response to Communist propaganda and the existence of many anti-Communist Chinese scholars who lack means of taking part in that struggle.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A Senate committee is studying a report that charges that Defense Department buying practices threaten "complete chaos" in war mobilization plans. The report also asserts that the lion's share of military contracts is being siphoned to big corporations.

BOSTON, May 23 -- Harvard University's decision to retain three faculty members whom the corporation had found guilty of misconduct for invoking their constitutional rights against self-incrimination in refusing to answer questions before Congressional investigating committees has met with varied interpretation and reaction.

BRUGES, Belgium -- The tourist in Europe with limited time at his disposal often apportions the time he will spend in each country according to its acreage. Thus Belgium is only allowed a day and a half: one day for Brussels and half a day to visit the battlefield of Waterloo.

MALAY tribesmen, a Malayan Communist, good and evil Americans, a former British war hero who heads Allied agents in Southeast Asia, a former island princess and an Estonian who has survived two concentration camps cross paths, wills and swords in this story of pursuit in the streets of Penang, in Singapore, through the fierce jungles of Borneo.

If monkeys seem so much like humans it is largely because they are so inquisitive. According to Dr. Robert Butler they want to learn all they can about the world around them. Dr. Butler is a psychologist who has been making some interesting experiments in the primate laboratory of the University of Wisconsin.

IN a matter of weeks -- on June 24 to be exact -- New York's moviegoers will be able to see the first big-scale musical in Technicolor to De presented on the Capitol Theatre's new extra-size, wide-screen with the opening of "Melba," starring Patrice Munsel.

OMAHA, May 23 -- A group of Mormon Church officials will take part in the dedication of Mormon Pioneer Memorial Bridge in North Omaha June 1. A special Union Pacific train will bring thirty of the highest authorities of the church, headed by President David O. McKay, and accompanied by their wives.

GROUP exhibitions, some of them introducing work not previously shown and others somewhat retrospective in character, bulked large among the week's attractions as the waning season continued active. Twentieth-century Paris painters are represented in the show at Fine Arts Associates, one of the outstanding pictures being the Derain interior with still-life (reproduced), a canvas of 1914, in which, after his fling at cubism, the artist did some of his most impressive work.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- The convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., called today for a top-level conference of the democratic powers to work out a positive program for world peace. The union, which is headed by David Dubinsky, said the program should be based on "collective security, not collective appeasement."

"THANKS, Junior," said Roy Campanella as he took the bat from the 14-year-old batboy. Even happy-go-lucky Roy felt a bit self-conscious as he hefted the warclub. The batboy was gazing at him with hero-worshiping eyes. Campy patted him on the back.

ALBANY, May 23 -- Public hearings were ordered today by Governor Dewey to be held at the Bar Association Building in New York on June 8 and 9 on the recent recommendations by the State Crime Commission for cleansing the Port of New York of longshore violence, extortion and theft.
VIENNA, May 23 -- Camille Gutt of Belgium was elected president of the International Chamber of Commerce today at the final session of its fourteenth congress in Vienna.

EVERY now and again the Print Room of the New York Public Library exhibits a selection from its seemingly inexhaustible treasures. The present display, ranged none too happily on the walls of a long, dark passage, is entitled "Five Centuries of Wood Engraving," and includes work from the middle of the fifteenth century down to the present day.

Tom Fool, as expected, won the $36,700 Metropolitan Handicap at Belmont yesterday. Installed the favorite at 1 to 2 in the sixtieth running of the mile race, the Greentree Stable's powerful 4-year-old pleased the majority of the crowd of 37,283 by scoring by a half-length over Mrs. Esther du Pont Weir's Royal Vale. Far back, nine lengths off the pace, was the third horse, the Brookfield Farms' Intent.

ROME, May 23 -- One of the famous landmarks in Italy disappeared today when the "needle" rising above the Mole Antonelliana in Turin crashed to the ground during a cloudburst that hit the city this afternoon. The top of the needle rose to a height of 548 feet and this made the Mole Antonelliana the tallest masonry structure in Europe.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., May 23 -- No longer do Westchester County firemen of one district sit stolidly by while a house burns fifty feet away -- in an adjoining district.

Many novelty stores in the city are doing a brisk business in the sale of "identity" cards to youngsters. These cards, some of them closely resembling drivers' licenses or armed forces identity cards, are filled in by the youths with inaccurate birth dates to persuade bartenders to sell them drinks.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 23 -- Marie's Sweetheart, owned by Carolyn Storck of West Orange, captured three events as the two-day Rock Spring horse show opened today.

Dismayed by the way it has fallen behind the banks and insurance companies in attracting funds from the public, the New York Stock Exchange is on the verge of a great merchandising effort to bring out the money that indirectly finances the nation's business growth.

FIVE Latin-American personalities new to philately are portrayed on stamps which have reached New York. The men honored are Rafael-Alvarez and Jose Joaquin Palma of Guatemala, Paul Eugene Magloire of Haiti, Jose Toribio Medina of Chile and Aarao Reis of Brazil.

PARIS, May 23 -- During the past decade necessity has prompted the United States to elaborate foreign policies for the continents of Europe and South America. But it has never yet attempted to devise an over-all policy for Asia. The seeds of such a policy may, it is to be hoped, eventually grow from the current tour of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles.

Cathedral and St. Gabriel captured the team titles yesterday in the second annual track and field championships for metropolitan area girls' high schools at Randall's Island. A total of 1,503 participants from twenty-seven schools competed in the program of twelve events.
DENVER, May 23 -- An $8,000,000 church building campaign was overwhelmingly approved here today by the American Baptist Convention.

THE author of "Fabulous Spain" is at very least a dozen men in one. The painter in him, though he sketches in bold black and white, is everlastingly conscious of every hue the sun shines on. The writer accepts the artist's rainbow vision, while the globe-trotter is ever at his ear, reminding him of comparisons drawn from the far ends of earth.

TRENTON, May 23 -- Despite too much rain last month, New Jersey farmers report their crops are developing normally. The State Department of Agriculture, meanwhile, has revised earlier estimates to include an increase in acreage for some crops.

VIENNA, May 23 -- The release of William N. Oatis, Associated Press bureau manager in Prague, after serving not quite two years of a ten-year sentence for alleged espionage, has been the most important recent development in the checkered story of relations between the United States and Soviet satellites of the East bloc.

William Wyer, trustee of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road, yesterday petitioned Judge Mortimer W. Byers in United States District Court, Brooklyn, for a hearing June 1 on an application for approval of an $8,806,000 settlement of $13,207,057 in taxes owed to the city.

The impending retirement of Prof. Palmer H. Graham, associate dean of the Washington Square College of Arts and Science, and Dr. Henry E. Meleney, Herman M. Biggs, Professor of Preventive Medicine, was announced today at New York University.

THOUGH it is named among cultivated persons with that offhand familiarity suggesting that one learned it at his mother's knee, Goethe's "Faust" is a peculiarly inaccessible work to non-German audiences.

Take the skill of a mechanical engineer turned economist, the teamwork and energy of an ex-football star and the analytical ability of a devoted bridge player and mix them together. What's the result? The answer is John Rigsby White, the new president of Imperial Oil Ltd., the fast-moving Canadian affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

IS there any way of breaking gently to a United States Army sergeant the news that his French wife will not be permitted to enter the United States because the wartime theft of ration coupons for which she was convicted in a German court is classified as a crime involving "moral turpitude" under the immigration law?

"CONCERTINO" will have its first performance of the season by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday, and that will be the only novelty of the week. Jerome Robbins' "Fanfare," which was to have had its premiere on Tuesday, has been postponed for another week.

Liverpool's unbeaten soccer team will be seeking its twenty-fifth successive triumph in the United States and Canada when it plays Nuremberg, seven-time German champion, at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, this afternoon. The kick-off of this international match is scheduled for 3:30 P. M.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 23 (AP) -- Polly Riley knocked in putts from all over the Chattanooga Country Club's bent grass greens today to swamp Bee McWane, 7 and 5, in the final of the Southern Amateur golf tournament.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 23 -- Patriarch Athenagoras, spiritual leader of Orthodox Christendom, disclosed today that the free Orthodox churches would refuse to recognize the action of the Bulgarian Orthodox Church in elevating itself to the status of a patriarchate May 10.
THE spate of non-theatrical, 16 mm. films continues unabated. Herewith are some recent additions to the field, illustrating a professional approach to a variety of subjects.

Psychiatric help should be made available early in the treatment program for persons with cerebral palsy, a research committee at Hunter College has recommended as a result of a recently completed study.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., May 23 -- The sports car road races here today were called off after eight laps of the featured 100-mile event had been run when, in the second of two accidents of the day, four spectators were injured.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Funds budgeted by the Truman Administration for navigation, flood control and other civil functions of the Army were slashed more than 39 per cent today by the Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives.

INGLEWOOD, Calif ., May 23 (AP) -- Mrs. Ada I. Rice's Pet Bully captured the $25,000 Premiere Handicap and Andrew Crevolin's Imbros won the $25,000 Will Rogers Stake stoday at Hollywood Park before 47,768.

Churches and synagogues, as "the repositories of the moral and spiritual heritage of the race, are the armories of our truest security," Rabbi Israel Goldstein said in a sermon yesterday morning at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., May 23 -- The Teen-Age Club of Oyster Bay that set an example for the youth of the nation at Christmastime by taking complete charge of the Yuletide decorations of this 300-year-old community, even to financial responsibility, is now busily preparing Oyster Bay streets, shop windows, front yards and doorways for the visit of President Eisenhower on June 14.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified 110 more Korean war casualties today, including twenty-three killed, seventy-eight wounded, five captured and four injured. The following were listed from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

WHAT is probably the last conventionally powered commercial plane designed for universal use, be- before the United States' entry into the business of flying passengers, mail and cargo in jet-powered airliners, made its maiden flight in California last week.

SID SOROKIN, the hero of Mr. Bissell's second novel, comes from Chicago to be superintendent of the Sleep Tite pajama plant in Junction City. Iowa, which manufactures The Nite Wear for Men of Bedroom Discrimination and markets its product in every state of the union except New York.

NOW that the rage for soil conditioners is subsiding somewhat, the gardener is being beguiled by propaganda advanced for liquid fertilizers. The millions of amateur gardeners in this country constitute a rich market for all such materials.
The conversion of a former Roman Catholic priest to the Protestant Episcopalian faith was announced yesterday by the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Episcopal Bishop of New York.

A special citation for contributions to democracy and human rights in the Americas was presented yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES and to Herbert L. Matthews of THE TIMES editorial board by the Inter-American Association for Democracy and Freedom.

PARNER, India, May 23 -- Hailing a new joint enterprise of big Indian and American business interests, Ambassador George V. Allen opened India's first pharmaceutical factory here today. The only plant of its kind in Asia, it can produce enough aureomycin -- 1,000,000 capsules a day -- to fill all of India's needs of this drug and more.

The immunity bill that Senator McCarran all but succeeded in snapping through the Senate the other day without public hearings and without adequate debate is at last beginning to receive the attention it deserves.

WHAT makes some highways safer than others? This complex problem involves many factors that are now being studied by the United states Bureau of Public Roads. Research data for a comparative analysis was obtained from more than 15,000 accidents on about 5,000 miles of routes in fifteen states.

THOUGH he died in 1908, Machado de Assis is still considered Brazil's leading man of letters. Indeed, his "Epitaph of a Small Winner," first published in 1880 and first translated into English last fall, has been compared favorably with the best works by Hardy, Flaubert, James, Kafka and Proust.

THERE is something about the smell of salt air, mingled with the fragrance of honeysuckle and roses, or the sight of a bed of brilliant geraniums glimpsed against a blue sky and deeper blue sea that remains always. Fortunately, it is relatively easy for anyone who lives at the seashore to have a garden.

ANDOVER, Mass., May 23 -- Murray Peyton paced Exeter today to its first track victory in ten years over its rival, Andover. Taking three firsts, a second and a third, P'eyton coIlected 19 points in the 65-52 triumph. Hunter Cook registered 17 in the boad jump and high jump.

I read with interest and amusement D. W. Brogan's witty article. I was especially intrigued by Mr. Brogan's parenthetical comment concerning the ancient coronation crown: "The crown, as all literate persons know, was recovered, much later, by young Mr. Sherlock Holmes, but he left it with the Musgrave family in that high, extra-legal way of his."

The visits of Secretary Dulles and Mr. Stassen to India and Pakistan should be productive of good results. The idea of the trip was a good one in the first place and thus far it has been working out well. The major purpose, Mr. Dulles has said several times, is simple fact-finding.

ONCE upon a time, many "North Americans" and Latin-Americans believed that the United States pursued an active interest in the progress of democracy in the American hemisphere. "North Americans" as well as Latin-Americans have retreated from this belief since 1945, driven back by the newly heavy emphasis on power politics.

The American "Era of Good Feelings" lasted only about three years (1816- 19), according to the exhaustive history of the period by George Dangerfield which recently won the distinction of a Pulitzer Prize.

MANSFIELD, Ohio -- The Third Annual Mansfield Exhibit of Photography, which opens here today for a week's run, is a heartening demonstration of a successful attempt to promote regional photographic activity. The show of about 120 pictures selected from the 360 entered (an increase of about 200 over last year's total) is being exhibited at the Mansfield-Leland Hotel under the auspices of the Mansfield Advertising Club, the sponsor.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- Leonard W. Hall, Republican National Chairman, today hailed President Eisenhower's signing of the offshore land bill as a states' rights victory -- "the first sharp turn from the drift toward the superstate in America."

A WHITE stone church in downtown Washington at the noon hour is full to overflowing. Outside, people argue softly with the ushers to get in, and, failing, turn away in disappointment. Inside, standees crowd up toward the choir and against exits, the whole of the throng fixed with a hushed attention on a stocky, white-thatched figure speaking from the high, brass-railed pulpit.

FADING tulips are a reminder that something must be planted in the spaces which will appear in the flower beds as soon as the bulb foliage dies down. Shallow-rooted annuals are the logical choice, for they can be set out in close proximity to the bulbs without damaging them in the least.

Year after year we watch the early and middle weeks of spring and think that surely this year the schedule is different. Early or late. The robins came earlier last year, didn't they? We didn't have to mow the lawn so soon before, did we? What happened to the tulips by the stone wall that they are so late?
Dwight Eisenhower has been President 125 days. In this early stage he has scarcely begun to write the record of his Administration.

IN the middle Twenties Igor Stravinsky -- conceived the ambitious idea that was to develop into Oedipus Rex, a condensation of the Sophocles tragedy in a Latin version, set for chorus, soloists, narrator and orchestra. It has had to wait until now for a recording.

Some clue as to the steel industry's attitude toward the wage demands of its workers and its own price structure may turn up this week as 1,200 top executives of the industry gather here for the sixty-first annual meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute, their trade organization.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The resistance of potent Old Guard Republicans to President Eisenhower's tax recommendations gives new emphasis to the President's dependence on Democratic support for enactment of major phases of his legislative program.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Communists and "irresponsible reactionaries who use the clock of anti-communism" both fight for the same objective -- the destruction of freedom, Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, told the Americans for Democratic Action here today.

SOME of the best examples of modern reporting are found in books of facts for children and young people. This one on spies, another in the Real Books series, reveals the reporter's art at work on a befogged and romanticized subject.

NO Emersonian exists now or ever did. One cannot be both a self-reliant man and a follower. On this hundred and fiftieth anniversary of his birth, Ralph Waldo Emerson, who, in Matthew Arnold's opinion, wrote the most important English prose of the nineteenth century, will not be acclaimed by any beating of drums.

Actuarial soundness in pension plans, long a desirable objective of those concerned with promoting retirement programs, is subject to many different interpretations, recent discussions indicate. Everybody favors it, but few agree on what soundness means.

INSECT pests and plant diseases are plaguing gardeners at this time. These outbreaks can be blamed to a great extent on the abnormally wet spring. An inspection trip through most gardens would prove the great need for timely spraying or dusting.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Determined efforts to save the United Nations International Emergency Children's Fund continued today on Capitol Hill.
CHICAGO, May 23 -- The American Medical Association warned last week there still was an acute shortage of nursing and technical personnel for hospital service and other community needs.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 23 (UP) -- The death of Alberto Carnevalli, leader of the Venezuelan opposition Accion Democratica, at San Juan de Los Morros Prison in Caracas was reported yesterday.

SEATTLE -- One of the country's last wilderness areas, densely forested, mountainous Olympic National Park, covers 1,400 square miles of the Olympic Peninsula just west of this city. It is now the center of a controversy between lumber interests and conservationists.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- A witness before the House Un-American Activities Committee has testified that Russia plans an all-out war to take over Europe next year and expects the continental United States to become a battlefield.

WITH the Metropolitan Opera Association again offering the spectacle of the world's most illustrious opera house in the richest city in the world's richest country campaigning for money, the temptation is strong to see in the subsidized theatres of Europe, or at least in their subsidies, the solution not only of the problems of the Met but of the big orchestras, too.

Little wonder that, in our present state of affairs, the former Prime Minister of Great Britain tells Parliament of the puzzle as to where "effective power lies" in American foreign policy. Many thoughtful Americans feel the same concern. We can answer with a citation of the Constitution.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday May 24 (AP) -- One hundred and fifty Chinese Communists smashed against the main Allied lines on Korea's central front today and were hurled back by dug-in South Korean soldiers after hand-to-hand fighting.

Skidmore College will open its nursing course to students who have fin-; ished one or two years at an accredited I college, providing the course require-! ments have been met. The transfers l with one year of college would enter the clinical period for hospital training and return to the campus for their l senior year.

TRENTON, May 23 -- The New Jersey Legislature reconvened here week after a five-week recess, failed to act on any major legislation and adjourned until Monday with the prospect of adjourning then until June 22.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 23 -- The development of a central jury system for all parts of the Supreme, County and Surrogate Courts in Westchester is producing a tax saving of $200,000 a year and smoothing the tempers of talesmen, Jury Commissioner Ralph T. Mumford reported today.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 23 (AP) -- The first test firing of a nuclear shell from the United States' giant atomic cannon is scheduled at the Nevada proving ground here shortly after dawn Monday. It will be a historic shot heard figuratively around the world and is regarded a great military milestone.

Nine Presidents of the United States and eleven Collectors of Customs have taken office since Frank J. Liddy became a Customs clerk in October, 1904, and the ruddy-faced, white-haired veteran decided yesterday that it was about time he looked for greener pastures.
SUMMER Squash can be recommended as an easy-to-grow vegetable as well as one that brings the reward of an abundant crop. These early-maturing kinds, moreover, are a delicacy.

THE United States frigate Constellation, thirty-six guns, was built by an Act of Congress approved by President George Washington, and first touched water at Baltimore in 1797. A speedy vessel under all sail with her kites set, she soon was nicknamed "Yankee Racehorse."
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- France has asked the United States for another small aircraft carrier for use in the Indo-China war, and Washington is considering the request.
Philadelphia continued its domination in the United States Women's Lacrosse Association yesterday when both its teams came through the first day of the annual tournament undefeated.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Time is running out on the reciprocal trade program, as the high-tariff lobby -- better organized than ever and eager for the kill -- brings its heavy artillery into play.

RICHARD BURTON, for all his youthful energy and fondness for fun, is an actor with a serious sense of professional responsibility. Indeed, the man and the actor are quite distinct personalities. That he has been a subject of bafflement since arriving on the Hollywood scene about a year ago is indicated by the respectful joshings he has received from the local wags in describing him as "the poor man's Olivier" and as "Britain's Brando."

THE trend toward tourist-class accommodations aboard trans-Atlantic liners was advanced a bit further last week with the arrival, and departure, on her maiden voyage of the Italian liner Roma. The ship, a 15,000-ton, twenty-knot vessel, carries 100 passengers in first-class accommodations and 700 tourist-class passengers. Each class has its own swimming pool.

WALDO FRANK has always been a serious and (for this reader) a rewarding writer. As a novelist, he has been writing for more than thirty years. His work has ranged from experimental work like "Rahab," to such studies in realism as "City Block" (which is a precursor in form to his newest book) and such variations on the mystery novel as "Chalk Face."

We are grateful for the mention of Moody's Investors Service in Robert Bendiner's "Current Quotations on Stockbrokers" (May 10). At the same time, it would be inaccurate to leave the impression that Moody's is only a disseminator of statistical data and factual information.

With the long controversy over title to offshore oil lands ended last week, when President Eisenhower approved legislation to confirm state title to submerged areas within their historic bound aries, a large new area of potentially rich petroleum deposits has been opened for development by American oil companies.

MOSCOW, Sunday, May 24 (UP) -- The Pravda editorial said world peace prospects would be damaged if "the Western Powers intend to continue to make a deal among themselves at the expense of the Soviet Union" at Bermuda.
NEWARK, May 23 -- The five-member Charter Commission created by referendum May 12 has completed its organization with the appointment this week of Roland J. Delfausse as executive secretary.

"TANGA TIKA," an independently produced feature, which was two years in the making (in color) in Tahiti and other South Sea islands, has just been booked into the Sutton Theatre and thereby hangs a tale as exotic as the locales of the picture.

BROOKLYN BRIDGE, a structure that has excited the imaginations of many millions of people, went into service seventy years ago today. During the decades since it has stood as a world-famous emblem, reproduced on everything from postcards to souvenir oilcloth table covers, of America's mechanical genius.

The weather man was badly fooled yesterday. He predicted it would be cloudy and showery, but the day came up bright and clear and full of spirit. New Yorkers enjoyed one of the most pleasant days of the year.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 23 -- The cadets were prepared to celebrate in a booming manner at Doubleday Field today as Army met Navy in their traditional baseball game. They brought out a miniature cannon with plenty of ammunition and fired a blast each time the Black Knights scored.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., May 23 -- The family of 20-year-old Airman Third Class Barbara York, a dental technician in the Mitchel Hospital here, who went out to mail a letter last Monday night and has not been seen since, were still waiting tonight for word from her.

SO much emphasis has been placed on the political and sanguinary aspects of the Mexican Revolution of 1910 that the average American has a lurid mental picture of it. He sees galloping bandits, desecrated churches, burning haciendas and ruined cities; now and then he has a glimpse, perhaps, through the smoke and confusion of perplexed Indian peons and Mexican laborers, of members of the middle and lower class wondering whether the struggle has accomplished anything.
In the last three decades the Port of New York Authority's promotion activities has brought 800,000 tons of general cargo, valued at nearly $500,000,000, to this foreign commerce gateway.

I GOT a fever from reading this book, but that was all right. It was in the form of a burning desire to go immediately and simultaneously to six different places and eat six different meals -- obviously so impractical that I brought my temperature back to normal by going to the kitchen and cooking a couple of eggs au beurre noir.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 23 (UP) -- The field for the Memorial Day 500-mile auto race was completed today -- save for tomorrow's 'bumping" -- when a record number of cars qualified.

BY a sleeper we don't mean an overnight berth on the Santa Fe either. We mean "Zorba the Greek," by Nikos Kazantzakis, which jumped on the best seller lists right off, ran through a first printing of 7,500 copies and, within the month, a second printing of 10,000. The Book Find Club has found it for its July selection.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Eisenhower Administration was reported tonight to have rejected the no-more-compromise theme of its foreign policy critics and agreed with its Allies on a set of principles and proposals designed to end the fighting in Korea.

THE season for water excursions from piers in the metropolitan area will soon be in full swing. Already the boat rides around Manhattan, which offer New Yorkers a cool way to take out-of-town visitors sight-seeing during the hot summer, are in operation, with daily sailings by the Circle Line and Hudson River Day Line from West Forty-second Street's piers and by the Panorama Sight-seeing Boat from the Battery.

PUSAN, Korea, May 22 -- This week, Koreans of cultural bent in this city wended their way down a muddy back alley called the "Street of Regained Independence" to a bleak four-story warehouse that, after a grant of $200 by the Korean Government for rehabilitation became the Pusan branch of the National Museum.

Department store sales in the week ended May 16 were 7 per cent above the corresponding 1952 period, on the basis of Federal Reserve Board figures. In the preceding week the advance was 9 per cent. In the latest week there were nine increases and two decreases, with one-district, Kansas City, unchanged.

The chances for an early reduction in taxes were dimmed considerably by President Eisenhower's request that Congress continue the present high rates for at least another six months. Although not unexpected, the news proved disappointing to many.

PITTSBURGH, May 23 (AP) -- Julius Boros, the national open golf champion, shot a brilliant two-under-par 70 at the Oakmont Country Club today in his National Golf Day round and predicted the weather would play a dominant part in the national open at this course June 9-13.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 23 -- Fears of a new outbreak of violence by the reorganized anti-British underground movement of the Irish Republican Army grew today with the discovery of six letters containing explosives addressed to leading political personages in Northern Ireland.

THIS is the most serious attempt so far to put the inflation-ridden, bomb-wracked Argentina of Juan Domingo Peron into one book, to explain peronismo and to relate it to the hemisphere policy of the United States, which President Eisenhower has just redefined.

A program designed to develop more profitable purchasing and inventory policies will be taken up at the thirty-eighth annual international convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents which is to open today at the Statler Hotel in Los Angeles.

In our technological age, with skilled men and women at a premium, this country is neglecting its reservoir of potential "brain power." Fewer than half of those capable of acquiring a degree enter college, while 40 per cent of those who do enter drop out along the way.
PARIS, May 23 -- The fall of the Rene Mayer Government has centered attention on the instability of French Cabinets at a moment when France is preparing to join in international policy talks.

OUT of love for the theatre in general, and for the Empire Theatre in particular, a one-night stand has been arranged for this evening that will add at least 2 1/2 hours of theatrical history to more than sixty years of it already played on the same stage.

ROME, May 23 -- With little more than two weeks before the Italian general elections on June 7 and 8, which will determine the political complexion of both the Senate and the Chamber of Deputies for several years, the belief remains widespread that they are far from a sure thing for the coalition of the four Center parties headed by Premier Alcide De Gasperi.
peaceful "spirit of Locarno" to ease world tensions.

IF one fish were to be selected as the species providing the greatest good to the greatest number of salt-water anglers it would not be the weakfish, flounder, striped bass, or even the tuna, but the tough, hard-fighting, fine-eating bluefish, and all omens indicate that this will be an excellent bluefish season.

MOSCOW, May 23 (AP) -- Eugene Varga, Soviet economist, declared today that there were some signs in the United States economy that "overproduction of merchandise is coming to a head." He predicted "aggravated" conflicts between the United States and other capitalist nations.

MELBOURNE, May 23 (UP) -- Australia's Olympic Organizing Committee, which may find the actual games a dull anticlimax to all its trouble, today unanimously chose Percy L. Coleman to succeed Arthur W. Coles as chairman of its control committee for the 1956 meet at Melbourne.

MARTIN ENDERS interviews Dr. Eric Penn, Nobel Prize-winning biologist who heads a secret Army project. Associate editor of a news-magazine, Enders is also working for U. S. Counter-Intelligence. His job: to discover what is going wrong with the project.

FRANK O'CONNOR with his usual brilliance has given us once again in his article "And It's Lonely, Personal Art" a perceptive analysis of the writer's position in relation to society. He sees what is and tells of it with intensity.

Leaders in civic, educational, professional and fraternal organizations will meet at the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow evening to honor Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of New York City Schools, who is beginning his second six-year term as head of the world's largest public school system.

The New York Football Giants will meet the San Francisco Forty-niners at the Polo Grounds on Thursday night, Sept. 17, in a pre-season contest sponsored by The New York Journal-American for the benefit of the Hearst Free Milk Fund for Babies.

LONDON, May 23 -- The surprising thing about the attacks made by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin on Britain this week was the little impact they seemed to make on British public opinion. Except for a few hot retorts in the more excitable newspapers and some fretting in Whitehall, the reaction here seemed to be one of disinterest and disdain.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce said today that Secretary of Labor Martin P. Durkin had recommended to the White House changes in the Taft-Hartley Act that would "wreck" the labor law.

IN order to grow fruit plants satisfactorily in the home garden, it is almost always necessary to use some form of fertilizer each spring. Possibly the only fruit that may not need fertilizer in some springs is the strawberry, particularly in the fruiting year following the year of planting.
The American Cancer Society's national fund drive is running 30 per cent ahead of last year, with $14,813,444 collected to date toward the $18,000,000 goal.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's letter to President Eisenhower asking for a statement on British trade with Red China was withdrawn before it ever reached the President.

FORT WORTH, Tex., May 23 -- Ben Hogan did the unexpected today -- he missed a three-foot putt on the eighteenth green to fall into tie for first place with Clayton Heafner and Jerry Barber at the three-quarter mark of the $25,000 Colonial national golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Eisenhower will shortly ask Congress to revive the moribund Council of Economic Advisers and make it the watchdog over the freer economy to which he is dedicated.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations urged the House of Representatives today to turn down a bill that would change the system under which the Federal Government paid unemployment compensation funds to the states.

PARIS, May 23 -- The Socialist and Catholic railway unions accepted tonight an offer of wage increases of about 5 per cent and apparently were ready to call off the twenty-four-hour strike in the nationalized railroads scheduled for next Wednesday.

WATERTOWN, Conn., May 23 -- The Hotchkiss track team won the fifth annual Pentagonal track meet today with 49 3/4 points, followed by Taft School with 37 3/4, Loomis, 37; Choate, 23 1/4, and Berkshire, 17 1/4.

Preceded by a colorful procession of 3,000 Sunday School children from 150 parishes and missions of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, the traditional annual presentation service of the children's missionary offerings was held yesterday afternoon in the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).

BONN, May 23 -- With the Soviet Union trying hard to carry out the unfamiliar dual role of honest trader and good neighbor, and German industrial and commercial interests considering the effects of closed American markets or a possible general Western economic slump on this country's business boom, the first stirrings toward resumption of Germany's old trade relations with the nations of East and Southeast Europe became evident this week.

By capturing eight of the sixteen events, the Fordham track team won a triangular meet over Villanova and New York University yesterday at Baker Field. The Rams had 68 2-3 points to 63 1/2 for Villanova and 37 5-6 for N. Y. U.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The passenger-carrying airlines handed the Civil Aeronautics Board this week the makings of a hot dispute over what travel agents should be paid for their services.

Corporations have both "a valid right" and "a solemn duty" to make financial contributions to educational institutions, Superior Court Judge Alfred A. Stein of New Jersey has ruled. His ruling came in a case brought by a group of stockholders against a corporate gift to Princeton University, but both the legal and philosophical implications of his opinion extend far beyond the limits of this particular case.
The auction season, although growing late, is still bringing to market many tempting wares for spring refurbishment.

AN ambitious project of interest to scholars and to all concerned with the history of Christian thought has been initiated by Westminster Press in this country and the Student Christian Movement Press in England. In a series of twenty-six volumes, classic writings of the Christian Church, from the first century through the English Reformation, will be presented in new translations with introductory essays, commentary and notes.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 23 -- The violence and bloodshed in Northern Nigeria and the breakdown of the country's modern, made-in-Britain constitution have announced to the world the appearance in black Africa of a smaller version of the "Pakistan problem" in the struggle for Indian independence.

AMONG the national, natural tongues of the world, English is the leading contender for adoption as an international language. Constructed languages like Esperanto and Interlingua are in the running, but they do not enjoy the same widespread popularity and support.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 23 (AP) -- Getting up in the final stride to win in a photo-finish, J. W. Rodgers' Duc de Fer remained undefeated in three starts as he turned back eleven juvenile adversaries today in the $10,0O0-added William Penn Stakes before 33,000 at Garden State Park.

FIVE hundred years ago Mohammed II, "a splendid wild beast." breached the walls of Constantinople with his mines, his battering rams, his great tower "protected by a three-fold covering of bull hide," and his enormous cannon. The men of the steppes then poured into the magnificent 1,000-year-old city.

Vic Raschi, going the distance for the first time this season, pitched the Yankees to a 3-2 decision over the Red Sox yesterday at the Stadium. The Bombers, who came from behind to win, scored all their runs in a sixth-inning attack on Sid Hudson.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced yesterday the arrest of a free-lance wearing apparel salesman in the theft of six bars of gold bullion on May 15 from a hangar at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

PRACTICALLY all writers, whether of advertising copy or of avant-garde fiction, and perhaps a majority of all the rest of us, have at one time or another, tried to write poetry. In self-conscious modesty, we usually referred to it as verse.

BALTIMORE, May 23 -- In a rip-roaring horse race that had the customers howling with excitement, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Native Dancer, bet down to 1 to 5, today won first money of $65,200 in the $113,750 Preakness Stakes at old Pimlico.

IN some novels, events are made to fit people, in others people are bent to fit events The first kind often produces memorable characters; the second, tidy plots. It's usually the first type of novel you remember. To the second order belongs "The Olive Tree," an emotional romance set in Spain and the United States.
MY attention was arrested by a statement quoted by Abram Chasins in his review of "Maurice Ravel" by Victor Seroff: "The 'Bolero' in Ravel's words 'was a joke.'"

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., May 23 -- In a masterly pitching exhibition that saw him facing only twenty-eight batters and permitting only two singles, Southpaw Chuck Heppenstall of Lawrenceville School continued his domination over the Hill School today.

MOSCOW, Sunday, May 24 -- The Soviet Government published a statement in Pravda this morning warning the Western powers that the proposed three-nation Bermuda conference called by President Eisenhower for next month might heighten rather than lessen international tension.

ALTHOUGH Truman Capote's "The Grass Harp" was a notable failure on Broadway last year, it is currently a success at the Circle-in-the-Square in Greenwich Village. In this respect it is repeating the experience of its distinguished predecessor.

EVERYONE agrees that the worst possible contract to double is a slam contract, and that if you are going to double a slam contract the worst excuse you can have is a "probable" trump trick as in Q-10-x-x.

I am a public school teacher and I am much annoyed at the motif of some of the recent contributions to this column on the general subject of retaining Communists on college faculties under the guise of academic freedom.

THE vacation season arrives with the Memorial Day holiday this week. So it is already time to consider ways of shortening work hours spent in preparing meals. The cook, too, deserves a place in the sun.

THE steady stream of LP's devoted to jazz pianists which has poured out in the past few years has reached one foreseeable milestone. It is no longer enough for a pianist to sit down and record numbers sufficient to fill a ten-inch disk.

READERS of "Postcards From Delaplane," by Stanton Delaplane (traveler and columnist for The San Francisco Chronicle) or those who see it on the Best Seller chart might be interested to know that there actually is such a place as Delaplane, and here is a snapshot to prove it.

THE husky little maverick was running the range beside his mother when Shorty first saw and wanted him. Two years later the maverick was a strapping wild stallion and quickly earned his name, Dynamite, when Slim roped him and Jock, the cowhand, tried to tame him with spurs and quirt.
Three frightened teen-age boys were rescued yesterday from a drifting rowboat in Ambrose Channel off Staten Island after they had been sighted by the crew and passengers of a Bermuda-bound steamship.

DETROIT, May 23 (UP) -- The White Sox exploded for three runs with two out in the ninth inning today and snapped a four-game losing streak as they turned back the Tigers, 4 -- 2, before 8,922 at Briggs Stadium.

The skirl of bagpipes and voices singing Irish melodies drew hundreds of persons yesterday to the statue of the Irish poet. Thomas Moore, near the Fifty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue entrance to Central Park. The program, marking the 173d anniversary of the poet's birthday, was presented by the Feis Committee of the United Irish Counties Association of New York.

PARIS, May 23 -- When the heads of the United States, British and French Governments meet in Bermuda in quest of Western diplomatic unity, one problem directly affecting that unity will presumably not be on the agenda. This is the problem that some Frenchmen call the ungovernability of France.

IN a reversal of what has come to be a trend, Fred Coe will produce a new "live" dramatic series entitled "First Person," as the summer replacement for "The Life of Riley," a film series. The show will be seen over N.B.C. television starting Friday, July 3, at 8:30 P. M. "Riley" will return in the Fall.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 23 -- John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, and Harold E. Stassen, Mutual Security Director, met for nine hours today with Mohammed Ali, Pakistani Prime Minister, and several Cabinet members.

THE Art for Hospitals Committee of the United Hospital Fund has been seeking art which will interest patients and contribute to morale and well-being. The originals and reproductions, which the committee receives as gifts, will be distributed to the more than 100 hospitals which share in the program.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet confided to Senators that early last year, while he was vigorously complaining to his superiors about ammunition shortages in Korea, he had told war correspondents that he had plenty of ammunition.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 23 -- The 187th anniversary commencement of Rutgers University will be held in the university stadium on June 3 when 1,700 graduates of eleven colleges and divisions will receive degrees.

VIENNA, May 23 (AP) -- Robert A. Whitney, 40-year-old fast-talking salesman from Buffalo, must be a very puzzling man to the Soviet observers at the congress of the International Chamber of Commerce here.

AREQUIPA, Peru, May 23 -- The Inca highway expedition of the American Geographical Society has reached the Andes at last. Here, under snow-topped El Misti, we are planning our assault on the mountains and our continued search for the royal road of the Incas.

IN Yugoslavia Marshal Tito recently advised composers to write "optimistic" music. Whether this was merely a benevolent suggestion from the country's boss man, who has a background and interest in music, or whether it was meant to have the force of an order, one does not know. But one would guess that the results will be the same -- confusion in the minds of the composers and perhaps dissatisfaction all around.

An eleven-state crack-down on highway speeders will be started June 1 and continued until Sept 1. The program will be carried out under the direction of the Safety Coordinators of the Northeastern States and is prompted by an alarming upswing in traffic accidents attributed to speeding, particularly in rural areas.

THERE is more than planning, planting and picking involved in creating a productive kitchen garden. Maintenance of a vegetable garden is the all-important factor, although this is just a matter of doing routine jobs when they need to be done.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Planned expenditures for new industrial facilities announced during April totaled $7,642,000, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. This was approximately $1,000,000 higher than the March figure, but sharply under the $16,989,000 during April, 1952.

Housewives too busy to saunter out to the stores are making cash registers of companies who sell merchandise from door to door ring merrily to the tune of $1,000,000,000 a year. Last week Edward L. Sard, executive director of the National Association of House to House Installment Companies reported more and more manufacturers are turning out products designed especially and exclusively for house-to-house selling.

Despite a shortage of trained social workers, the Society for Seamen's Children provided 35,837 days of care in foster homes on Staten Island, at the Charles H. Marshall Cottage, in camps and hospitals and special schools, Louise H. Irving, president, noted in the organization's 106th annual report.

AMES, Iowa, May 23 (UP) -- Wes Santee of Kansas raced to a new American college record of 4:06.3 in the mile-today to lead his team to its second straight Big Seven track championship. The Kansans piled up 138 7/20 points, far ahead of second-place Oklahoma, which finished with 83 1/2.

ANNAPOLIS, May 23 -- Navy made a clean sweep in two sports against Army today. The middle lacrosse team knocked the cadets out of the collegiate stick championship, 10 -- 7, and the tennis squad swept the doubles matches to turn back the Black Knights, 6 -- 3.

WITH the publication of a new translation of Moravia's first novel, this unique European writer's work has come full circle. First issued in Italy in 1929, "The Time of Indifference" at once established its author as a chronicler of the footless middle class.

GENEVA, May 23 (AP) -- Communist China's Health Minister, Mrs. Li Teh-chuan, astonished delegates to the executive committee of the League of Red Cross Societies here this week with a glossy ninety-two-page brochure on the life of United Nations prisoners in Communist hands.
CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- The public will get its first glimpse of Rodney Dee Brodie when he appears on a coast-to-coast television program June 4.

WHEN Virginia Cowles told Sir Winston Churchill -- it was before he was knighted -- that she proposed "to write his biography, he growled good-naturedly: 'There's nothing much in that field left unploughed.'"

MARY MARTIN, a recent arrival in this community after a sojourn abroad, now is engaged in an assignment that is certain to arouse covetousness among many of the ladies who hear about it. The star is being fitted by Main Bocher, the couturier, for a series of gowns that she will wear in the forthcoming Norman Krasna comedy, "Kind Sir."

SUMMER lies ahead and with it freedom for school children from some of their chores, a wealth of new experiences and, hopefully, more freedom and relaxation for parents, too. Two publications just issued -- one for parents of pre-schoolers, the other of interest to parents of a somewhat older group -- suggest how some of this time may valuably be spent.

WHEN Jill handed her carefully accumulated fund of forty pounds for a new pony, she acted out of pique rather than enthusiasm. Rapide, sullen and suspicious, was not the second pony she would have truly liked, but time, patience and kindly schooling brought both Rapide and his owner to fresh esteem of one another.

PHOTOGRAPHERS traveling abroad this year will generally find adequate supplies of black-and-white film, but -- aside from France and Switzerland -- very little Kodak color film, Eastman Kodak Company warns. Kodacolor film, for example, is not sold overseas at all.

THE exhibition which opened on Friday at the Kootz Gallery makes one feel good for a variety of reasons. First, it contains several objects of great beauty. Second, it shows how artists working for the second time on a particular architectural project have matured.
OKLAHOMA CITY -- The eighty-eight-mile, $38,000,000 Turner Turnpike between Tulsa and Oklahoma City, four years on the planning boards and two years building, opened to cash customers on May 16.

Life insurance premiums paid by an individual, corporation or partnership on a policy covering the life of an individual, a partner, a corporate officer or employe, or any person having a financial interest in a business, are generally not deductible for income tax purposes under Federal income tax laws.

ITHACA, N. Y., May 23 -- Cornell led Pennsylvania home in both races of their regatta on Cayuga Lake today, the final event on the program of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges prior to the grand finales at New London and Syracuse in June.

MIXING pathos, action and fantasy, Elisabeth Webster has concocted an odd, offbeat little story about a retired sea captain and his favorite walking stick. Adults and practical youngsters will find it hard to ascribe determination, loyalty and a sense of justice to a cane -- even though it is a magic one.

TOKYO, Sunday, May 24 -- Allied truce delegates wind up today a week of staff conferences at United Nations headquarters here and return to Panmunjom tomorrow with new proposals to reach an armistice in the Korean war.

Cardinal Spellman was honored yesterday as "America's Outstanding Citizen" by the National Department of the Catholic War Veterans of the United States. He received the organization's first annual citation, presented in the form of an engrossed scroll at a luncheon in the Park Lane Hotel.

OMAHA, May 23 (AP) -- Senator Wayne Morse, independent of Oregon, said tonight the Republican Administration "does not seem to understand the difference between private monopoly and private enterprise."
Almost 3,000,000 tons of shipping were placed in commission in 1952, swelling the world's merchant fleet to 90,200,000 gross tons, or 30 per cent more than the pre-World War II total.

NEW DELHI, India, May 23 -- A joint communique issued in New Delhi and Karachi today confirmed that Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India and Prime Minister Mohammed Ali of Pakistan would discuss the whole range of Indian-Pakistani relations when they meet in London early next month to attend the Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II.

Obviously, Mr. Brogan enjoyed his rather flippant treatment of the subject, yet a great truth stands out in it: "The English are a religious people, but their religion is England." This is exactly what the history of England shows most convincingly.
HARTFORD, May 23 -- Gov. John Davis Lodge is in a fight with members of his own Republican party in the General Assembly over a tax program to extricate Connecticut from its fiscal crisis.

IN her coronation oath Queen Elizabeth promises "to govern the peoples of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, the Union of South Africa, Pakistan and Ceylon" and of her "possessions and the other territories to any of them belonging or pertaining, according to their respective rights and customs."
WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- President Eisenhower has picked Cyrus S. Ching, chief labor trouble-shooter in the Truman Administration, to referee disputes in the atomic energy field.
Management is training its future leaders in credit departments, it was asserted last week by Morris Volper, executive manager of the Credit Executives Association, Inc.

SANFORD, Me., May 23 -- Leslie Topham, veteran driver at the Sanford Post Office, reckons that he has gone a distance equivalent to six times around the world in the same truck without leaving the city limits. And he wouldn't have "one of those six or eight cylinder jobs" as long as his 1929 model still runs, he said today.

Sir Winston Churchill's reference to the Locarno Pact of 1925 in his House of Commons speech calling for an immediate top-level Big-Power conference suggests, as many commentators have noted, a reapplication of the principle of the "balance of power" as an international modus vivendi.
The 1953 edition of Investment Companies, a reference work on mutual funds and closed-end investment companies, came off the press yesterday with a hypothetical investment situation.

WHEN Sophie Barrington Ward was 35 her husband died, leaving her with two children and almost no money. Sophie, who was always as honest with herself as her understanding permitted her to be, knew that she had not loved her husband particularly.

Don Hanson of the University of California's Institute of Geophysics on the Los Angeles campus thinks he has taken the psychic element out of waterfinding with an electric dowser. He applies ore-prospecting techniques. Two wire coils are used. One induces an electric current in the ground; the other measures differences in the induced current as it flows through the ground.

BOSTON, May 23 (AP) -- Surgeons successfully removed a tumor from the abdomen of a 41-year-old Siamese twin today while her sister, also anesthetized, lay strapped beside her on a tilted extension table.

THESE are days when the Supreme Court is called upon to pass decision on issues which affect the whole fabric of American society. The Founding Fathers intended that the provisions of the Constitution should be flexible and adaptable to changing conditions.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 23 -- As it nears the half-way mark in a $500,000, five-year campaign to attract new business to this industrial city, Birmingham's Committee of 100 reports that already new plant investments of $150,000,000 are annually putting $50,000,000 into pay envelopes.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 23 -- Minnesota Republicans, who surprised the nation last year with their write-in vote for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in the state's Presidential primary, were setting the stage this week for a new project -- the election of a Republican to replace Democratic Senator Hubert H. Humphrey.

MARATHON, Tex. -- Anyone of the 93,000 persons who visited Big Bend National Park last year will find improvements this summer making it easier to view nature's panorama at its best. Settled before the Pilgrim Fathers were even born, Water Street in St. John's, Nfld., was an "illegal" thoroughfare in the days when Britain still regarded the big island as a fishing base conveniently anchored off the New World and forbade her fishing admirals to settle in the "new found land."

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- When President Eisenhower suggested this week that the heads of state of Britain and France get together with him to talk over their troubles, Sir Winston Churchill immediately proposed -- and the others agreed -- that they meet in "the Bermudas."
