WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The White House has shifted much of its own responsibility for political patronage to Leonard W. Hall of New York, the recently elected Republican National Chairman. One result is that the job-placement machinery for loyal party workers is beginning to move more rapidly.
The New York Women's Bar Association installed Miss Norah K. Donovan as president yesterday at a luncheon ceremony held at the Astor Hotel. She succeeds Miss Julia Perles, who became a director.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 23 -- The Connecticut General Assembly has taken two steps toward the redevelopment of eastern Connecticut, which has been in an industrial decline since the textile industry began to fade more than a decade ago.

Higher pay scales for civil service personnel serving aboard the transports and cargo ships operated by the Atlantic Area of the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service were put into effect on May 16, it was announced here yesterday by Rear Admiral John M. Will, commander.
PHILADELPHIA, May 23 (AP) -- George Munger, head football coach at the University of Pennsylvania for fifteen years, said today the 1953 gridiron season would be his last.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Eisenhower this week began to supply that leadership in Government which only the Executive can furnish under our Constitutional system. CLEVELAND, May 23 -- Reaction to President Eisenhower's tax talk was that business in this heavy industrial area would keep rolling close to the pitch it has been holding most of 1953. One possible deterrent might lie in the inability of certain companies tot finance increased facilities.

A RENOWNED physiologist, W. Grey Walter has pioneered many of the advances in the field of electroencephalography (the study of the electrical impulses produced by the brain). A report of his experiences in eighteen years of intensive investigation has been eagerly awaited not only by his professional colleagues but by many who have more than a passing interest in the functional capabilities of the human brain.

The amount of carbon dioxide in the air will double by the year 2080 and raise the temperature an average of at least 4 per cent. The burning of about two billion tons of coal and oil a year keeps the average ground temperature somewhat higher than it would otherwise be.

CLEVELAND, May 23 (UP) -- Three home runs gave the Indians a 5-1 victory over the Browns today as Bob Lemon pulled even at four victories and four defeats for the season.

VANCOUVER, Wash. -- When outdoor men throughout the land sought not long ago for a wooded paradise worthy of the name "Gifford Pinchot National Forest" to honor America's first Chief Forester, the choice fell almost unanimously on a realm of green fir solitudes and glittering glacial peaks in the state of Washington.

Mount St. Michael scored 53 points to win Class I laurels in the thirty-seventh annual track and field championships of the Athletic Association of Private Schools of Greater New York at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, yesterday.

A team of three American medical scientists has abandoned efforts to borrow a giraffe from a zoo in the United States for important medical tests and is planning an expedition to Africa to measure the animal's blood pressure.

PITTSBURGH, May 23 -- The Giants today were guilty of the rather common error of peering too intently into the future when they might better have given heed to what was underfoot. Their eyes peeled on the first division, the Giants tripped right over the lowly Pirates and promptly went sprawling as the Corsairs stalked off with the opener of the three-game series, 8 to 4, amid the gleeful howls of 7,444 onlookers.
The return of sunshine and warmer weather last week enabled clothing retailers to forget about raincoats and concentrate on clearing of stocks of summer-weight suits.

SALZBURG, Austria -- High summer is festival time in Austria. The tourist calendar says festivals begin in April and last well into October, as indeed they do, but only in July and August can the weather be relied upon join whole-heartedly in the fun.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Opposition to the Administration's sharply reduced military budget has bolted into the open from the Pentagon itself. This despite a severe warning issued throughout the military headquarters that the Administration would brook no controversy over the defense budget and that service partisans, civilian or military, risked reprisals should they engage in special pleading.

The Spanish training ship Juan Sebastian Elcano, a sleek, white, four-masted schooner with a complement of 325 officers and men and thirty-eight midshipmen, arrived yesterday for a week's visit here. Adverse winds robbed New Yorkers of the opportunity of greeting the ship under full sail, for the Elcano was forced to come up the Hudson River to Pier 26 under her auxiliary power.
A 5-cent bag of peanuts in a subway candy machine resulted yesterday in a brilliant stiff-upper-lip performance by a 6-year-old boy and a swift wrecking job by a police emergency squad.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 23 -- Eight high school seniors, four from Nassau County and four from Queens, have won Adelphi College scholarships by examination. They will receive aid ranging from full to one-half tuition at Adelphi. The total value of the scholarships is $12.000.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Dr. Maynard Owen Williams, chief of the foreign editorial staff of the National Geographic Society, will retire on June 1 after thirty-four years' service.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Conflicting views on a proposed livestock grazing bill were heard today by an Interior subcommittee of the House of Representatives as it neared the end of hearings on the proposed legislation. Mrs. Oscar A. Ahlgren of Whiting, Ind., made her appeal in a statement on the eve of the sixty-second annual convention of the women's organization.

PITTSBURGH, May 24 -- The steel industry is going to hang up another record for steel output for the month of May. There is an even chance that output will again top 10,000,000 tons -- monthly mark made for the first time in March.

On the issue of electoral reform in Western Germany I find myself in the unwelcome position of sharply disagreeing with Prof. F. A. Hermens, whose eminence in matters electoral I otherwise admire as much as his political judgment. Art events of the week, although somewhat fewer in number, nevertheless include a number of exhibitions of more than passing interest. WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (F. D. I. C.) said today that the 14,617 banks operating in this country at the end of 1952 had record assets of $215,000,000,000, an increase of 5 per cent over the previous year.

Foreign exchange rates fluctuated within a limited range during the past week. British pound sterling turned soft in a market that was fairly active and the Canadian dollar advanced in moderate dealings.

New Yorkers will turn the clock back 150 years tomorrow to an earlier May 26 when Mayor Edward Livingston laid the cornerstone of the city's third and present City Hall on the site it still occupies in City Hall Park.

I read with special interest Mrs. H. Pantaleoni's letter published on May 4 expressing concern for the failure of the United States to support the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund. FORT WORTH, Tex., May 24 (AP) -- Ben Hogan, golf's mighty stretch-runner, methodically posted a 3-under-par 67 final round today to win the $25,000 Colonial national invitation golf tournament for the fourth time in seven years. He had a 72-hole score of 282.

Columbia University announced yesterday it would formally install Dr. Grayson Kirk as its fourteenth president at the regular commencement exercises on June 2. Dr. Kirk has been president since Jan. 19, when the resignation of his predecessor, Dwight D. Eisenhower, became effective.

Total advertising in the newspapers of fifty-two cities at 233,486,529 lines in April was up 6.9 per cent over the linage of April, 1952. For the year to date total linage at 834,040,493 was 5 per cent over the previous year's period.

A 6-year-old boy, two one-armed players and Gen. Omar Bradley were among the 9,972 players who beat the United States open champion, Julius Boros, in National Golf Day rounds Saturday.

This is a critical week for the new Transit Authority. June 1, a week from today, is the last day under the law for the Board of Estimate to enter into agreement for transfer of the city's transit system from the Board of Transportation to the Authority. The penalty for not reaching such agreement is loss of new city taxing powers on real estate, with a ruinous aftermath.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, May 25 (AP) -- A swift United States Navy task force, supported by planes, swept into fire-blackened Wonsan harbor on the North Korean east coast yesterday and battered Communist gun positions, the Navy announced.

Green Giant Company, food packers, reported consolidated gross sales for the year ended March 31 of $46,835,444, against $44,730,059 in the preceding year. Net profits were $1,562,899, or $3.40 a common share after preferred requirements, against $1,734,928 or $3.80 in the preceding year.

TOKYO, Monday, May 25 -- United Nations and Communist truce delegations went into secret sessions at Panmunjom today as the Allied command, it was believed, presented a new modified plan to reach an armistice in the Korean war through the disposal of Chinese and North Korean prisoners of war who refused to return behind the Iron Curtain after a cease-fire.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 24 (UP) -- A nonscheduled DC-3 cargo plane carrying an engine to Oklahoma City crashed in a heavy fog today while trying to land here for fuel. Six persons from the New York area were killed and one was critically injured.

The Medical Society of the County of New York has refused to let State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman speak in person at its annual meeting tonight before it votes on a resolution condemning his plan for a controversial free clinic at the state-aided Carver Houses project.

Increases in narcotics offenses and in the number of women convicted of various crimes were listed by Irving W. Halpern, chief probation officer of the Court of General Sessions, in his 1952 report to the court.

A plan for a retail code of ethics to guide merchants in every phase of store operation is in preparation by a committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, which represents chain, department and specialty stores throughout the country.

Storming back for two goals in the second half after yielding three in the opening session, the Liverpool Football Club of the English League's First Division notched its twenty-fifth straight triumph in three visits to this country and Canada by halting the Nuremberg Football Club of Germany, 4 -- 3, at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.

VIENNA, May 24 -- One rather curious result of the Congress of the International Chamber of Commerce that closed here yesterday is that the immediate prospects for expansion in East-West trade seem considerably better than the immediate prospects for expanding trade within the non-Communist world.

KATMANDU, Nepal, May 24 (UP) -- Four members of a British expedition on Mount Everest were believed to be high on the icy slopes of the world's highest mountain today, and two of them may have reached the summit.

The combination of Larry Adler, harmonica player, and Shoshana Damari, Yemenite folk singer, drew 1,400 persons to Town Hall last night, and the audience warmly applauded both artists throughout a long program of their respective specialties.

In a series of memorial services in metropolitan New York yesterday, tributes were paid to the soldiers and sailors who died in both world wars and in the Korean war. The same theme ran through many of the day's addresses: Let the living cherish the standards and ideals for which the dead fought.

As dramas on television film go -- and most of them cannot hold a candle to the better "live" attractions produced in New York -- the "Four Star Playhouse" has not been too bad, but last Thursday the show had a decidedly off night, even by Hollywood standards.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- The Braves retained a half-game lead in the National League pennant race today by dividing a doubleheader with the Cubs before 21,250 with a 5-4 opening-game victory preceding a 5-2 second-game loss.

LONDON, May 24 -- Pravda's extensive commentary on the prospects of a big-power conference was read with caution and cynicism in London today. Diplomatic observers thought its most conspicuous characteristic was an effort to aggravate and exploit current differences of view between the United States and Britain.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (UP) -- The Department of Justice is investigating "all phases" of the recent testimony of Thad Mason, a self-styled Communist spy.

The Television Writers of America, which is competing with the Authors League of America and the latter's affiliated Screen Writers Guild for jurisdiction over video writers, will hold a meeting at the Astor Hotel tonight at 8:30 o'clock to discuss the coming election under the National Labor Relations Board.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (UP) -- House of Representative investigators plan to wind up their two-year investigation of tax scandals this week with a hearing aimed at showing the "influence" wielded in tax matters by John W. Snyder, former Secretary of the Treasury.
The Zim Israel Navigation Company is completing negotiations to build a 10,000-ton, 500-passenger liner for double duty for regular service in Mediterranean trade and for special cruises.

NOT long ago every school child knew who discovered America. Columbus in 1492 and go to the head of the class. Now we know that numerous Vikings came here some 500 years before Columbus. But, according to Hyatt Verrill and Ruth Verrill in their "America's Ancient Civilizations,"* the Vikings were Johnnies-Come-Lately compared with the true discoverer of America.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- Scores posted in late March by New York's Frank Santore and Cleveland's doubles combine of Eddie Koepp and Joe Kissoff won championships today as the American Bowling Congress tourney ended.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (UP) -Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, sent three representatives to Mexico today to help in dealing with that country's latest outbreak of foot and mouth disease.

Legislation to impose the 3 per cent city sales tax on more than thirty categories of commercial service not now covered by the tax has been prepared by advisers to Mayor Impellitteri for introduction tomorrow at a special meeting of the City Council.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 24 -- Locusts are swarming east across the great Sind Desert of Pakistan to ravage vast areas in a country already fighting famine.
PARIS, May 24 (AP) -- Vic Seixas and Maureen Connolly, two of America's top hopes for titles in the French international tennis tournament, reached the quarter-final rounds today.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Administrator, made public yesterday two revised and two new opinions affecting the use by tenants of window-type air-conditioning units, hotel room occupancy, and reconsideration of certificates of eviction after the circumstances upon which the certificates were based had been changed.

Some days ago you commented editorially on the enforced resignation of Theodore Kaghan from his post with the United States Information Service, as a result of his quarrel with Senator McCarthy. You seemed to think that because he was recognized as an anti-Communist by the head of the Austrian Government and by the Mayor of West Berlin he should have been supported by the State Department against Senator McCarthy.

A crowd of several hundred persons, watching a baseball game in Central Park, was transformed into a vengeful, frenzied mob for a few minutes yesterday afternoon when a man fatally stabbed his estranged common-law wife in full view of the throng.
Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn Good-naturedly claimed the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday for his home borough when a plaque honoring the Roebling family as builders of the span was unveiled.

DETROIT, May 24 (AP) -- A double by Sam Mele and a single by Jim Rivera knocked in two runs in the ninth inning today to give the White Sox a 3-1 victory over the Tigers and send Ted Gray to his sixth defeat. He has yet to win.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- William G. Carr, executive secretary of the National Education Association, today called the "World Conference of Teachers" that will convene in Berlin July 21 to 24 "a thinly disguised effort to propagandize for the Soviet Union."

Ralph Waldo Emerson's contemporaries often thought of him as an idle dreamer with little understanding of the conditions of life about him and less concern than he might have shown in the affairs of that day.

Six teen-agers and two adults strove earnestly yesterday to decide whether peace could be achieved by negotiation and mediation. If they failed to be absolutely sure about it at the close of an hour on television, one of the youngsters had a bit of consolation to offer.
Increasing $3,200,000 last month, drafts owed to United States exporters reached a new high of $208,000,000, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, predicted tonight that Congress would extend the excess profits tax for another six months to the end of the year as President Eisenhower asked.
Frederick C. Rogers, 44-year-01d broker and member of a socially prominent family, plunged to his death yesterday evening from a living room window of his ninth floor apartment on Fifth Avenue.

KANSAS CITY, May 24 (AP) -- One man was killed and twenty-three persons -- including nineteen Kansas City girls returning from a dance at Fort Leavenworth, Kan. -- were injured in the collision of an Army bus and an automobile early today.

The dominant figure at the Yankee Stadium yesterday was Johnny Sain, who has been in organized baseball since 1936 and who'll be 35 years old come September. It was Sain's pitching, following a shaky start, and Sain's hitting that carried the Yanks to an 8-4 victory over the Red Sox before 45,830 fans -- the local season's largest matinee turnout.

ABOARD THE S. S. QUEEN OF BERMUDA. May 24 -- New York's savings banks "are accountable to no one," a leading commercial banker charged today. Attacking savings banks for their "expansionist plans" to establish additional branch offices, he called for "a restatement of the powers and functions of each type of institution, with clear-cut definitions of the activities and services of thrift institutions and commercial banks."

ROME, May 24 -- In a speech that was notable for its restraint and moderation Premier Alcide De Gasperi expressed his belief today that the Trieste problem could still be solved by direct negotiation with Yugoslavia despite the intransigent stand taken by Marshal Tito in a speech last Sunday.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved irregularly last week. Declines more than offset advances, however, with the result that futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange ended with net losses of 7 to 17 points, or 35 to 85 cents a bale.

LONDON, May 24 -- A perspiring policeman looked at the slow-moving mass of British subjects who filled London's triumphal coronation avenue, the Mall, this hot Whitsunday afternoon and said: "They're sheep. One does it and the rest do it.

The hopes that the new post-Stalin rulers in the Kremlin had experienced a change of heart have been dealt a rude blow by the latest major statement of Soviet foreign policy, which covered Pravda's front page yesterday. This statement assailed President Eisenhower's proposal for a meeting in Bermuda next month of the leaders of this country, Britain and France, arguing that the Western Powers should not confer among themselves before a meeting with Soviet leaders.

Hereafter, the experimental offerings of Elinor Morgenthau's New Dramatists Workshop will be presented on the stage of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. Established as a memorial to Mrs. Henry Morgenthau Jr., wife of the former Secretary of the Treasury, the workshop began its activities last year in conjunction with the New Dramatists Committee, an offshoot of the Dramatists Guild, to help aspiring playwrights.

MOSCOW, May 24 -- The Soviet statement asserting that the German unification issue was crucial, decrying the suggestion of a new Locarno treaty and warning of the consequences of the Bermuda conference of the Western Big Three was evaluated today by Western diplomats here as the most important pronouncement by Moscow on foreign affairs since Stalin's death.
Directors of the Timken-Detroit Axle Company and Standard Steel Spring Company have voted to consolidate, it was announced yesterday by Willard F. Rockwell, chairman of both concerns.

SOLOMONS ISLAND, Md., May 24 -- Driving the boat Rhubard, a Class D stock hydroplane, Robert Boercke of Franklin Square, L. I., won the free-for-all race in the fourth annual Patuxent River marathon today. The marathon was sponsored by the Solomons Outboard Club, a unit of the Solomons Yacht Club and was sanctioned by the American Power Boat Association.

Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican chairman, said yesterday that the Republican party was ready and willing to form a coalition with all forces interested in good government for the nomination of a candidate for Mayor.

LONDON, May 24 -- Owing to the proximity of the Whitsun holiday and the Coronation, interest in the stock markets dwindled steadily last week and business turnover contracted to its lowest level since the beginning of the year.

A Senate Armed Services subcommittee has now brought in its report on the question of ammunition shortages in Korea. The majority of the group sustained General Van Fleet in his charges that such shortages had, in fact, existed, and stated that because of this some American lives had been needlessly lost.

MANILA, May 24 -- President Elpidio Quirino won his Liberal party's unanimous endorsement for election today through political maneuvering that resulted in the walkout of Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo's followers from the national convention, leaving Mr. Quirino's candidacy unopposed.

WHEN Indigenes say of the Brooklyn Bridge, which hit three score and ten yesterday, "There's life in the old girl yet," it's literally so. Fourteen bustling industrial concerns pay the city an average of around $27,000 a year for work space and storage space inside the span's landside arches.

WHEN Indigenes say of the Brooklyn Bridge, which hit three score and ten yesterday, "There's life in the old girl yet," it's literally so. Fourteen bustling industrial concerns pay the city an average of around $27,000 a year for work space and storage space inside the span's landside arches.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 24 -- Is there any danger to the public from the Nevada atomic tests?

HANOI, Vietnam, May 24 (UP) -- French and Vietnamese troops inflicted "very high" casualties on four Communist infantry companies in a sharp seven-hour battle south of Hanoi today, the French Command announced.

The Rev. Dr. Theodore F. Savage, stated clerk and executive secretary of the New York Presbytery, returned yesterday to the pulpit of the Church of the Master, Morningside Avenue and 122d Street, to commemorate Anniversary Sunday in the church he helped to dedicate fifteen years ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 24 -- Financial partnership deals by the major companies with film creators willing to forego established salary scales and gamble on their ability to make profitable pictures is advocated by the current issue of the Screen Producers Guild Journal as a way to increase production of movies and cut down studio operating costs.

PITTSBURGH, May 24 -- Back to earth, where they had been summarily dropped by yesterday's surprising Pirate outburst, the Giants today resumed their drive on the first division by soundly thrashing Fred Haney's Corsairs, 11 to 3.
CLEVELAND, May 24 (UP) -- The Indians made it seven straight victories over the Browns this season by sweeping a double-header, 5 -- 1 and 9 -- 8, today and moved from fourth into second place.
Seven new films, including imports from England, Italy and Russia, will arrive at first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

Most of the world's subways operate under financial deficits. But a survey of eighteen cities here and abroad indicated yesterday that the operating deficit on the New York City subways was among the world's highest in proportion to operating cost -- 8.5 per cent for the year ended last June 30, and soaring to 13.9 per cent for the nine months thereafter.

The Labor Committees of the Senate and the House of Representatives are now considering in executive session the testimony of witnesses concerning proposed changes in the Taft-Hartley Act. The record is long and involved and, as might be expected, strongly partisan.

On Jan. 3, Representative Daniel A. Reed of New York, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, introduced the measure which was to be designated "H. R. 1" (House Bill No. 1) and which was to drive a formidable wedge in the ranks of the Administration party.
Five noted milliners have designed especially for Patterns of The Times the hats shown on this page.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 24 -- John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, sounded a call for collective security in Asia today and said the United States had "no disposition to meddle in the affairs of others."

An analytical history of diplomacy during the twenty years between the two World Wars is published today by Princeton University Press, entitled "The Diplomats." The volume, containing contributions by seventeen experts, examines the curious fate of the diplomat, "the honest man sent to lie abroad for the good of his country."

RENO, Nev., May 24 -- A controversy that is shaking Nevada somewhat like its atomic tests will be focused tomorrow on a public hearing amid a flood of telegrams from educators against any "muzzling" of faculty members at he University of Nevada.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- New administrations in Washington inherit almost all the problems of the old, but in grappling with these problems they must also suffer the unique handicaps of their own inexperience.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- Parents of mentally retarded children need help and increased understanding from medical specialists, educators and the community at large if they are to adjust comfortably to their problems, speakers at the annual conference of the child research clinic of the Woods Schools agreed yesterday.

The services of a much-sought-after star, Julie Harris, have been reserved for "Colombe." Already presented in Paris and London, the romantic drama, originally written by Jean Anouilh, is to be adapted from the French by Louis Kronenberger, drama critic of Time magazine, playwright and author.

BONN, Germany, May 24 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer rejects completely the proposal that he unite his Christian Democratic Union with the Social Democrats after this summer's elections and form a grand coalition that would rule West Germany for the next four years.

In bringing out for public a hearings a scheme for designating blighted and slum areas of Manhattan for future redevelopment as residential sections the City Planning Commission is pushing forward one of the tasks with which it is charged in the city's 1938 Charter -- namely, the drafting of the component parts of a master city plan.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., May 24 -- In some sports a black cat, three on a match or walking under a ladder are shunned as jinxes and hexes. Today on a nearly smooth Long Island Sound and under a canopy of sun and blue sky a sailing racer bearing the number 13 on its white main canvas was guided across the finish line leading in the featured International Class.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- Today's game between the Dodgers and the Phillies, which was a close and reasonably normal contest for seven innings, turned into a Walt Disney fantasy in the eighth when the Brooks scored twelve runs before a man was out. They won the game, 16 -- 2.
Roosevelt Raceway's fourteenth harness racing season will get under way tonight, with horsemen shooting for more than $2,000,000 in purse money during the four-month meeting.

Nine composers will be honored with complete programs devoted to their music at Lewisohn Stadium this summer. George Gershwin, Richard Rodgers, Jerome Kern and Gian-Carlo Menotti will be the modern representatives. Mozart, Beethoven, Schumann, Tchaikovsky and Brahms will be those from the past.
ST. LOUIS, May 24 (UP) -- Gerald Staley, holding the Redlegs to five hits, won his sixth straight victory today for the Cardinals, shutting out Cincinnati, 2 -- 0.

With successful completion of its first academic year, an American-staffed advanced school of industrial administration established in Turin, Italy, to train present and future Italian business managers in American methods will continue tuition-free courses for another year.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (UP) -- Connie Marrero registered his third straight pitching victory and his fourth of the season today as the Washington Senators scored all their runs in the first two innings to defeat the Philadelphia Athletics, 6 -- 3.

STATE COLLEGE, Miss., May 25 -- "A strange and alien disease" of suspicion, distrust and hatred in America is turning neighbor against neighbor and causing friend to distrust friend, the graduating class of the Mississippi State College was told here this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- The Senators scored five runs on five walks, two singles and a wild pitch in the first inning tonight and went on to beat the Athletics, 16 -- 1, behind Julio Moreno's six-hit pitching.

There is little likelihood that the Government ever will try William Z. Foster, 72-year-old chairman of the American Communist party, who has been free in $5,000 bail since his indictment in 1948 for conspiracy to teach and advocate violent overthrow of the Government.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 (UP) -- The American Cancer Society announced today that two scientists, working with frog eggs and frog embryonic eggs, have succeeded in transferring living nuclei from one cell to another, an accomplishment many scientists believed impossible.

As of yesterday Tokyo is only thirty- seven flying hours from Oslo by a commercial plane known as the DC-6B Super-Cloudmaster. It is almost Oslo's next-door neighbor. This plane carried forty-one passengers and eleven crew members via the North Pole, making stops at the Thule airport on Greenland, at Anchorage, Alaska, and at Shemya in the Aleutians.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., May 25 -- Dark Star, winner of the 1953 Kentucky Derby, will race no more, according to his owner, Harry F. Guggenheim. The son of Royal Gem II bowed a tendon during the running of the Preakness at Baltimore on Saturday, and the condition forced Guggenheim, whose home is in near-by Sands Point, to announce the 3-year-old's retirement from competition today.

TRENTON, May 25 -- The New Jersey State Senate moved tonight to legalize bingo and other minor forms of gambling through the adoption of a constitutional amendment and also passed by a unanimous vote a new rent-control law that is designed to replace standby legislation.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 26 -- A group of angry Japanese women roughly handled Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt yesterday after the widow of the President had refused to be interviewed by them. Mrs. Roosevelt was pulled from her car as she was leaving the Japanese Labor Ministry on her way from a conference there on Japanese labor problems to a round-table discussion with Japanese and American women at a downtown Tokyo restaurant.

The three-story building containing a store and two apartments at 4918 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by the 323 St. John Place, Inc., to Jennie, Mary and Gloria Iovino. The Colonial Realty Company was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. said after a White House visit this morning that a bill for extending the excess profits tax for six months "was a kind of must."
CLEVELAND, May 25 (AP) -- For the second time in five days, an attack was made here on the homes of Negroes living in neighborhoods where white persons also live.

DENVER, May 25 -- A New York minister told the American Baptist Convention here tonight that he stood before the delegates "smitten with shame" because his all-Negro church in Brooklyn was "less Christian in appearance than the baseball diamond at Ebbets Field."
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- The Northwest Natural Gas Company has, in effect, bowed out as a contender to pipe natural gas to the now unserved areas of Washington and Oregon.

Judge Mortimer W. Byers in Brooklyn Federal Court declined yesterday to go along with the Long Island Transit Authority for an order to restrain Controller Lazarus Joseph from depositing or cashing checks totaling $5,471,574 received by the city last Friday from the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road for back taxes.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The refusal of the Soviet Union to resume conferences in London designed to settle the Austrian treaty question was believed here tonight to have diminished further the prospects for an early meeting of the Big Four to discuss a global settlement of the "cold war."
Fairy-tale settings inspired by the coronation and peopled with tiny dolls authentically dressed are on view at Abraham Straus. The display will continue through June 5.

TRENTON, May 25 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court, in a split decision, upheld the constitutionality today of a 1952 law under which the state guaranteed payment of a $285,000,000 bond issue by its highway authority. The issue was designed to provide funds for the construction of the Garden State Parkway, which will stretch from Bergen County to Cape May County.

MILWAUKEE, May 25 (UP) -- Max Surkont set a modern strikeout record tonight-when he fanned eight straight batters in the second half of a twilight-night double-header as the Braves swept both games with the Redlegs, 5 to 1 and 10 to 3.
Mrs. Eulalia Figuieredo, described by immigration officials as "a prominent Communist in the Boston area," left for Poland yesterday under an order of deportation.
BERLIN, May 25 -- Continued economic expansion and even greater prosperity were forecast in the latest report of the Federal Ministry of Economics here.

Population and family planning are accepted officially today as necessary for family and national welfare in many countries in the Far East, it was reported yesterday at the opening session of the first World Congress on Fertility and Sterility at the Henry Hudson Hotel.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Day care for the children of working mothers has become an important consideration for most industrial communities.

Much of Western Europe's economic difficulties could be eased if business there made greater effort to sell more goods in domestic markets rather than put so much stress on the need to export, the head of National Sales Executives, Inc., trade association, said yesterday.
The proposal for a free clinic at the state-aided Carver Houses project was firmly opposed last night by the Medical Society of the County of New York.

Atlantic and Gulf Coast shipowners rejected yesterday all demands of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., that would increase payments to seagoing personnel. At the same time the owners issued a set of principles on which they expect to base negotiations for a new contract.

The Authors League of America and its affiliated Screen Writers Guild announced yesterday that they had signed contracts with twenty-four independent producers of "live" television programs covering the employment of free-lance writers.

" Truth Is Our Weapon," by Edward W. Barrett, a former Assistant Secretary of State, will be published June 15 by Funk Wagnalls. Mr. Barrett, who is a veteran in the war of ideas, presents an analysis of the United States information and propaganda programs, his views on accomplishments and blunders of the Truman and Eisenhower Administrations and a proposal for America's public relations with countries on both sides of the Iron Curtain.
HARTFORD, May 25 -- The House of Representatives of the General Assembly approved tonight and sent to the Senate a series of bills that would increase Connecticut taxes by about $44,000,000.
The steady decline of orders for new machine tools from defense producers and the Government was reflected yesterday in a report from the toolbuilders showing a sharp drop in new business.

Bombs, searchlights, flares, droning airplanes, a collapsing house and a great deal of histrionics will be combined tonight in one of the noisier and more Barnum-like of the Civil Defense air-raid drills to be held in the metropolitan area.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -- For his actions on the field yesterday, the crowning offense being the tossing of the resin bag high in the air, Russ Meyer has been fined $100 and suspended for three days by Warren Giles, National League president.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A one-man investigation, at private expense, of the United States foreign propaganda set-up brought a series of recommendations to Congress today to help balance the Federal budget by drastic reductions in this field.
Laying of the cornerstone of New York's City Hall 150 years ago today is an event not less worthy of commemoration because the building was not put into active service until 1812.

The Swedish American Line will resume cruise service from New York, a field from which it has been absent since 1939, it announced yesterday. The first trip -- a fifty-five-day cruise around South America by the new luxury liner Kungsholm -- will leave here next Feb. 9.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A floor fight over "supremacy of the United States Constitution" in relation to treaties appeared to be in the making tonight as the General Federation of Women's Clubs opened its Sixty-second annual convention.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 25 -- Thomas Harlan, son of Veit Harlan, the Nazi film producer who made the notorious anti-Semitic film "Jud Suess," has just spent three weeks in Israel preparing a "documentary film," Government press division officials said today.

Within a week of taking office last January Secretary of State Dulles said in a broadcast that Latin America had been neglected by the Truman Administration and pledged himself to correct that state of affairs. The Secretary repeated the promise to the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Senate.

The American Academy of Dramatic Arts, in collaboration with the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Academy, announces a summer session beginning July 6 and terminating Aug. 14, featuring seminars on Shakespeare, stage direction, acting in theatre, television and radio.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 25 -- The four General Zionist members of the Israeli Cabinet resigned this afternoon in protest against the Mapal (Socialist) party's insistence that on May Day and other labor holidays schools in working class districts should have the right to fly the red flag, symbol of socialism, alongside the flag of Israel and to sing the "Internationale" in addition to the Israeli anthem.
The Arkansas-Louisiana Gas Company refused yesterday to accept the best bid submitted at public sealed bidding for an issue of $35,000,000 of first-mortgage twenty-five-year bonds.

In each of the two races that shared top billing at Belmont Park yesterday there was an odds-on favorite. With one of the events attracting five contestants, and the other presenting only three betting interests, the "chalk" fanciers in the crowd of 23,439 figured that it was their day.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Supreme Court ruled today by a vote of 5 to 4 that the advertising sales policy of The New Orleans Times-Picayune Publishing Company did not violate the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A highly authoritative source said today that a call by a Senatorial investigating subcommittee last Wednesday night for President Eisenhower's views on the trading of Allied ships with Red China had reached the White House but had been blocked there from getting into the President's hands.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The prospect that this Administration will have to get votes from the rival party membership in Congress to assure the passage of the important items in its legislative program is not new. Though this forecast has been made recently with an air of unexpected discovery, it describes a political condition that endured throughout the Truman Administration and at times existed under Franklin D. Roosevelt.

The city's starving coffers began to absorb some solid nourishment yesterday as 29,206 motorists fed $206,875 into the treasury in $5 and $10 bills in the first day's sale of 1953-54 automobile use tax stamps. In the first day's sale a year ago 16,716 motorists paid $104,895 for stamps.

Dr. William Jansen, who was recently elected to his second six-year term as Superintendent of Schools, was honored last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Eighteen hundred persons attended the program.
As one who followed your lead in supporting General Eisenhower for the Presidency may I express my appreciation of your independence in dealing with the activities of our new Government.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Leonard W. Hall, Republican National Chairman, announced today that President Eisenhower and Vice President Richard Nixon had endorsed enthusiastically a proposal by Mr. Hall for an intensified campaign to lower the minimum voting age from 21 to 18 years."
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, urged the Senate Banking Committee today to approve his bill to abolish the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
MANILA, Tuesday, May 26 (AP) -- Brag. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo announced today that he would run for President in the Nov. 10 election at the head of a new party.

BASEBALL has been cautiously moving along on an even keel for the past thirty years, very much afraid that someone would rock the boat. The diamond fathers squelched Phil Ball of the St. Louis Browns when he threatened litigation and they appeased Dangerous Danny Gardella much more recently. But they finally have reached a point where they must sink or swim.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 25 -- Yugoslavia has recently renewed informal proposals to leading officials of foreign powers, including presumably the United States, Britain and France, for a compromise solution to the Trieste dispute.

HOYLAKE, England. May 25 (AP) -- A cloudburst, with howling winds and crackling flashes of lightning, struck the British Amateur golf tournament today. The storm, however, failed to keep a trio of top American players from moving into the third round with one-sided victories.

LONDON, May 25 (AP) -- Following is the text of a note from Jacob A. Malik, Russian Ambassador to Britain, rejecting the Allies' proposal for resumption of the meetings of representatives of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union on the question of an Austrian state treaty:

SAN FRANCISCO, May 25 (AP) -- Sam H. Husbands, president of Trans-America Corporation, resigned today because of "continued unhappy association with some of the directors. His resignation followed the election of Frank N. Belgrano Jr. as chairman of the board of the wealthy holding company.

A revised edition of a Turkish recipe booklet mentioned by this department several months ago has just been published by the Turkish Government. It is a masterly work in more ways than one. The recipes, some new, some improved, are presented in professional style.

Women were urged yesterday to support efforts to develop educational television stations and networks. The appeal was made by Miss Frieda B. Hennock, Federal Communications Commissioner, to 1,000 members of the Women's Organization of Yeshiva University at the organization's twenty-fifth anniversary luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy said yesterday that his city agency had had to create 487 new jobs with state approval to take care of various new programs and services in the last three years. Even so, he asserted, the department is operating with fifty-nine fewer employes on its payroll than at the peak of the relief load in June, 1950, when the Korean war started.
A charge account plan for theatregoers was introduced into the legitimate theatre last week in connection with a play subscription program intended for Pittsburgh and Cleveland next season.
LONDON, May 25 -- An invasion of hairy black and red caterpillars along the Sussex coastline between Brighton and Newhaven has become so extensive that villagers are tackling them with flamethrowers.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., May 25 -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, today deplored reports and discussions that created dissension between the United States and Great Britain.

DETROIT, May 25 -- The Ford Motor Company and the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., announced tonight they had reached an accord on revising their five-year contract to meet the terms granted last week by General Motors Corporation plus what is considered the most liberal pension plan in the auto industry.

UNITED NATIONS, N Y., May 25 -- Conflicting trends in the consumer goods and capital goods industries brought limited recovery to the countries of Western Europe during the last half of 1952, modified by indications that a further slackening might be expected in the demand for engineering production, according to the United Nations "Economic Bulletin for Europe," released today.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- The entire future of professional sports rests on the outcome of the eases the Supreme Court accepted today.

NEWARK, May 25 -- Six thousand brewery workers voted today on whether to call a strike in Essex County. The voting began at 1 P. M. at the Newark Labor Lyceum, 704 South Fourteenth Street, after the American Federation of Labor joint executive board had unanimously recommended strike action to three locals involved.

LOS ANGELES, May 25 -- "Take away the productive margin established by the United States and the free world as we know it will join the civilizations of Greece and Rome in the pages of history," Reese Taylor, president of the Union Oil Company, declared today.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- The storm of arguments over a public lands grazing bill died down today, at least temporarily.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., charged today that the Republicans were substituting "government by caddy" for the "government by crony" they complained about during the 1952 Presidential campaign.
LONDON, May 25 -- The Soviet Union rebuffed an opportunity tonight to show by a deed that it really wanted a settlement with the West.

PARIS, May 25 (AP) -- America's top-ranked men's singles player, Gardner Mulloy, was defeated today by Enrique Morea of Argentina, in a quarter-final round match of the French international tennis championships.

Promotion of diversified furs is needed to rescue the "floundering fur trade," according to Nathaniel Berman, executive director of the American Fur Merchants Association. The situation fully warrants an expenditure by the trade of $1,000,000 for promoting furs on a broad basis that will revitalize many types for the average consumer, instead of one or two luxury furs.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower will entertain fifty to seventy-five sports figures at a buffet luncheon at the White House on June 5.

Building the basis for a closer relationship between parents and their physically handicapped children has been one of the aims of a four-week institute conducted for parents who met last night in Brooklyn for the final session at the Jewish Sanitarium and Hospital for Chronic Diseases, sponsor of the program.

ORLEANS, France, May 6 -- The great military supply line across France that the United States started to build two and one-half years ago to safeguard its combat forces in Germany, now is stalled under excessive United States Government regulations, French restrictions, slow French contracting and the resulting apathy of United States troops.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 25 -- An atomic shell was shot from a gun for the first time today. A projectile eleven inches in diameter, touched off electrically by remote control, hurtled seven...

ST. LOUIS, May 25 (AP) -- The bankrupt Missouri Pacific Railroad Company's request for authority to seek approval by the Interstate Commerce Commission of a new reorganization plan was denied today in Federal District Court here.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 25 -- King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia declared in an interview today that his country, wanted to remain inside the French Union even though it insisted on full independence. He said he advocated a French-Cambodian agreement that would give France military bases here under an arrangement similar to that existing between the United States and the Philippines.

Trading was dull on the blew York Commodity Exchange yesterday, with almost of Europe, South America and Australia closed in observance of Whitsuntide. The only item that approached normal volume was cottonseed oil. Prices closed irregular with cocoa, coffee zinc, lead and tin showing gains

Mayor Impellitteri has called a special closed meeting of the Board of Estimate for this afternoon to get a report from Corporation Counsel Denis M. Hurley on the status of negotiations for a lease of the city's transit system to the newly created New York City Transit Authority.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, May 26 (AP) -- Allied air and sea power blasted the Communists on both Korean coasts early today, and United States Sabre jets knocked down five enemy MIG's and damaged a sixth south of the Manchurian border.

ST. LOUIS, May 25 (AP) -- The White Sex toppled Harry Brecheen to his sixth straight loss and the Browns to a 7-5 defeat, their eighth in a row, by coming from behind twice with four-run and two-run rallies tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 25 -- Pvt. Gabremicail Tumebo, an Ethiopian soldier who lost a leg in the battle for "French Hill" in Korea, visited the United Nations today to see the headquarters of the organization under whose flag he fought.
CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- Medallions and plaques honoring distinguished service to journalism in 1952 were presented tonight to fourteen winners of Sigma Delta Chi national awards.

The Ingersoll-Rand Company reported yesterday an estimated net profit of $4,842,759, equal to $2.39 per common share, for the three months ended on March 31. This compares with $4,914,555, or $2.43 per share for the corresponding three months of 1952.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- A $2,750,000 damage suit, naming Bob Hope, comedian, as one of several defendants, was filed today in Federal District Court. The principal defendant is the American Guild of Variety Artists, of which Mr. Hope is president.

VIENNA, May 25 -- Austria will make its first important post-war attempt to finance expansion from private investment tomorrow by opening a hydroelectric power plant development loan. Inducements which would be considered extraordinary in more stable countries will be offered, the reason being that this loan if successful will be a crucial second step toward formation of private capital market.
The Police Department was invited yesterday to search the soul that lies behind the badge and the jacket of blue in quest of the reasons for its sometimes imperfect relations with the public.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was fairly active yesterday and prices were 33 points lower to 5 points higher than on last Friday.

Two of the nation's largest aluminum companies have contracted to buy 786,000 tons of Canadian primary aluminum over the period 1953 through 1958 for sale in the United States, it was announced yesterday in Montreal by Nathaniel V. Davis, president of Aluminium, Ltd.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 25 -- The Kenya-Uganda Railway, the transport backbone of East Africa, announced today that, due to three major train wrecks, the breakdown of locomotives and other difficulties, transport is to be curtailed.
TOKYO, May 25 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,625, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Monday, Korean time:

Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company shut down for one week its axminster carpet mill in Amsterdam, N. Y., yesterday. A spokesman for the company, one of the country's largest carpet producers, said the shutdown was decided upon because of overproduction and a normal seasonal decline in orders from carpet retailers.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 25 -- The forces that advocate employment of private capital for development of Brazil's petroleum resources have gained their first round in the Senate over the opposition.
BOSTON, May 25 -- A scheduled operation on Arthur Godfrey's left hip has been postponed, Massachusetts General Hospital announced today.

With the summer season rapidly approaching, some stock-taking of the political situation seems appropriate in this city election year. This situation is in part, encouraging to those of independent mind who would like to see better management of city government. On the credit side the discussion of possible candidates for Mayor started early and is gaining in breadth and clarity.

PITTSBURGH, May 25 -- Ralph Kiner hit the three-hundredth home run of his major league career today but aside from slashing a comfortable six-run Giant lead in half and depriving Al Corwin of what should have been a comparatively simple mound victory, the shot was purely a personal triumph for the big Pirate slugger.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Eisenhower and Republican Congressional leaders decided today to support legislation to provide 1,000,000 tons of wheat for Pakistan, which has been in the grip of a drought.

Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican of Manhattan, declared last night that the Republican party should nominate a Republican for Mayor unless no Republican was available "who could do the job."
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Inter-union raiding and other forms of labor rivalry are still going on in large volume, a report of the National Labor Relations Board showed today.
LONDON, May 25 -- As the day of the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II approaches, London is en fete as it seldom has been in living memory.

Male lawyers and politicians joined forces last night to tell American women that citizenlike acts would help them more than a proposed Constitutional amendment to achieve full equality of rights with men. And several women attorneys declared emphatically that they supported this view.
CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- Stan Musial and Red Schoendienst supplied the one-two power today as the second place Cardinals routed the Cubs, 14 -- 3, for their sixth victory in the past seven games.

The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation issued a statement yesterday saying that before granting a fellowship to Dr. Felix Browder, son of the former Communist leader Earl Browder, it had ascertained that he was not and never had been a Communist.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that American law did not apply in a suit brought by a Danish seaman who had been compensated under Danish law. It voted, 7 to 1, to set aside a verdict awarded the seaman under American law.

The Federal Trade Commission has received an increasing number of complaints that retailers are advertising garments made from fabrics composed of a blend of fibers by naming only one of the constituent fibers. This is reported by Harvey H. Hannah, chief of the division of wool and fur labeling of the Federal Trade Commission, in a letter to the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The Watkins bill to admit an additional 240,000 immigrants from Europe during the next two years has its faults, but it can be of real help to victims of Communist persecution and to the more overcrowded of our European allies. It represents the minimum that the United States ought to be prepared to do on humanitarian, political and economic grounds, and as a matter of mere self-interest.

The A-bombs that destroyed Hiroshima and Nagasaki were so large that they had to be carried in B-29s. At the time no physicist or ordnance officer dreamed of anything like an atomic shell that could be fired at high velocity and with high accuracy at ground troops fifteen or twenty miles away.

A three-man trial committee of the Board of Higher Education opened yesterday its hearing of charges of neglect of duty and conduct unbecoming a teacher against Nat Holman, City College basketball coach, Harry Sand, assistant coach, and Prof. Frank S. Lloyd of the Department of Hygiene.

" Trieste itself is and always was Italian * * *." Such a statement, appearing in a TIMES editorial of May 19 under the heading "Tito Breathes Fire," betrays either an ignorance of the facts or a desire to project the Italian electoral campaign to the American scene.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- The Supreme Court held, seven to two, today that the Government was not entitled at this time to an injunction barring John M. Hancock, a partner in the New York investment banking house of Lehman Brothers, from being a director of competing corporations.

BALTIMORE, May 25 -- Henry A. Barnes, a Denver, Colo., traffic engineer, was engaged by this city today to take over its growing traffic problem from a retiring traffic commission at a salary of $18,000 a year, the highest in the city government.

NEW HAVEN, May 25 -- Sixty delegates from ten countries met at Yale University today to discuss means of conserving the North Atlantic fish supply, but then discovered that their first problem was understanding one another's languages.

Sixteen trains of the East Side I. R. T., traveling between New Lots Avenue, Brooklyn, and the Woodlawn station in the Bronx, were diverted from 1:30 A. M. to 5:30 A. M. yesterday to the West Side I. R. T. tracks in Brooklyn and by a circuitous route back to the East Side tracks in Manhattan.

Today's new film at a first-run theatre is the Italian - made, "Strange Deception." at the Normandie Theatre. Raf Vallone, Elena Varzi, Alain Cuny and Gino Cervi head the cast that includes Rina Morelli and Anna Maria Ferrero. Curzio Malaparte wrote and directed the drama, which is being presented here by the Casino Film Exchange.

Lamar W. McLeod, vice president and Southwestern district manager of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, predicted yesterday that increased consumption of electricity in 1965 would require doubling the output of electric equipment manufacturers to meet the needs of the utilities.

Marc Blitzstein wrote the text and music for a twenty-minute, one-act opera called "The Harpies" in 1931 and waited until last night to have it performed for the first time. The opera workshop department of the Manhattan School of Music produced the piece after all these years on a bill that included Haydn's rarely heard little work, "The Songster," and Bohuslav Martinu's relatively recent "Comedy on the Bridge."

PARIS, May 25 -- Seventy-six-year-old Paul Reynaud was reported tonight to have been asked by President Vincent Auriol to form a Cabinet to replace the fallen government of Rene Mayer. M. Reynaud, who will see the President tomorrow morning, is expected to agree to try to do so.

CINCINNATI, May 25 (AP) -- Warren Giles, the president of the National League, said that the Supreme Court's ruling today involving baseball's reserve clause was not an agreement to pass on the legality of the clause.

ABOARD S. S. QUEEN OF BERMUDA, May 25 -- Investors in United States Government securities and especially bankers now suffering "book losses" because of the Administration's monetary policy should remember that their sacrifice is small in terms of developing a stable economy, a leading New York banking executive declared today.

RENO, Nev., May 25 -- The administration of the University of Nevada was accused at a public hearing today of seeking ground for the dismissal of Dr. Frank Richardson, chairman of the Biology Department, long after notifying him he was to be discharged.

Copies of election posters that are plastered over all available walls in cities, towns, villages and hamlets of Italy are being flown to New York, where they will be exhibited, beginning next Monday, at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
One of the largest issues of convertible debentures ever offered to company stockholders -- $162,098,500 of 3.7 per cent debentures of the Phillips Petroleum Company -- will become available today.

Behind the effective pitching of Herb Isaacson and Bill Anderson, Brooklyn College defeated Manhattan in a double-header, 3 -- 0, and 5 -- 2, at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. The two victories enabled the Kingsmen to finish second in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture told the House Banking Committee today that so long as farts price support programs were continued the nation's farmers needed protection against imports.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., May 25 -- Pete Cooper of the Century Country Club. Purchase, N. Y., led the qualifiers in the Professional Golfers Association Metropolitan sectional trial at the Sands Point Golf Club today.

The longest nine-inning baseball game ever played -- some might insist it also was the dizziest -- wound up with the Red Sox outlasting the Yankees, 14 -- 10, last night at the Stadium. At 12:23 A. M. (Tuesday) the contest, which had started at 8:31 P. M. (Monday), was concluded before those of an original turnout of 28.371 who had stayed or remained awake until the finish.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 26 -- The Communist command studied today a new United Nations proposal to reach an armistice in the Korean war, while the truce talks at Panmunjom went into another week's recess.

The alternate-side parking system was extended yesterday to central Harlem, and while the residents of the crowded area were praised for their "wholehearted cooperation," the police tagged 144 violators and tow trucks hauled away eighty-four vehicles.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Ezra Taft Benson, the Secretary of Agriculture, promised today to consult Democrats in Congress as well as Republicans on any major changes in the Department of Agriculture.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 25 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, Mutual Security Director Harold E. Stassen and their official party arrived at Istanbul this morning after an overnight air trip from Karachi, Pakistan.

SEOUL, Tuesday, May 26 (AP) -- The Air Force brought a second airman back to this country from the United States yesterday under guard and sought a third still serving in Korea for court-martial on charges of slaying Bang Soon Kil, a South Korean civilian at an air base last September.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The American Federation of Labor said today it would be folly to cripple the Mutual Security Program through "false economy." It urged that funds be authorized on a two-year basis, instead of every year.

When O. Henry wrote his fabulous stories about the masses of New York he called one of his books "The Four Million," a figure in terms of people that awed the nation. Today that figure has doubled, and with the doubling has come a proportionate straining of living facilities in the five boroughs.

HODDING CARTER, editor and publisher of The Greenville (Miss.) Delta Democrat-Times, is one of the best known newspaper men in America. His editorials won him a Pulitzer Prize in 1946. He is the author of six books. He has written hundreds of magazine articles. He has made hundreds of public speeches.

SEOUL, Korea, May 25 -- The strained relationship between the United Nations Command and the Government of the Republic of Korea over the question of a truce agreement took a critical turn this morning when Maj. Gen. Choi Duk Shin, Korean representative on the United Nations truce delegation, absented himself from today's armistice meeting at Panmunjom.
NEWARK, May 25 (AP) -- The New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad, which has been in bankruptcy since 1937, today entered the final stage of its financial reorganization.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 25 -- The New York opening of "Julius Caesar" on Thursday night, June 4, at the Booth Theatre will witness the re-establishment of a showmanship technique --the orchestral overture -- which was a hallmark of sophisticated motion-picture exhibition until the advent of sound films.

The first four weeks of the intensified drive of the Department of Air Pollution Control against excessive smoke have resulted in 532 warning notices to smoke violators, Commissioner Leonard Greenburg announced yesterday. The period covered April 20 to May 15.

Intimate glimpses into the life and work of Ralph Waldo Emerson and of some of his famous contemporaries are afforded in an exhibition on the Concord sage that opened yesterday at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
RYE, N. Y., May 25 -- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association conducted a best-ball tournament today for members of the three teams that will compete for the Griscom Cup.

BONN, Germany, May 25 -- Allied and German experts on Russian policy believe that Soviet tactics are concentrated on splitting the West over the issue of Germany's future and dividing the West Germans on the key problem of their country's reunification.

A part - time furniture worker, who augments his wages by playing a trumpet in a Bronx night club, was brought in yesterday by the police to Manhattan Traffic Court, where Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh sent him to the workhouse for eighty-eight days on his guilty plea to ignoring forty-four traffic tickets.

MEXICO CITY, May 25 -- The slaughter of about 500 cattle infected with foot and mouth disease began today near Gutierrez Zamora, in the state of Veracruz, and the Mexican Ministry of Agriculture said that with this quick measure the outbreak had been "definitely controlled."

Various candidates for the nomination for the office of Mayor have been named. Many of them may have commendable characteristics. However, one, although not an announced candidate, has displayed practically all of the necessary requisites to bring back a period of tranquillity.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Supreme Court set aside today the death sentence conviction of James Avery, a Georgia Negro, who protested that the Jury trying him for rape was picked discriminately by the use of paper tickets of different colors.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 25 -- Philip Bernstein of Forest Hills, Queens, associate director of the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds, was elected president of the National Conference of Jewish Communal Service at the fifty-fourth annual meeting today.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 25 -- A victory by C. O. Fromer's Tyler Hanover in the featured $3,500 pace, a sizable daily double pay-off and a three-horse accident that produced no mishaps provided some of the highlights tonight as the fourteenth successive season of night harness racing started at Roosevelt Raceway.

DETROIT, May 25 (AP) -- The On-again, off-again strike of 8,000 Budd Company workers was called off again late today. As a result Chrysler Corporation issued back-to-work calls for 36,000 of its 40,000 idle employes.

THE week-end did not provide an excess of satisfied anglers, either on fresh or salt water, according to the majority of the reports, but a few who happened to be lucky, skillful and fishing the right place at the right time managed to get a reasonable return for their time and efforts.

Dogs and their masters picketed the Roosevelt Hotel last night in protest against policies of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which held its annual meeting in the grand ballroom of the hotel.

MANDALAY, Burma, May 25 (AP) -- More than 10,000,000 acres of agricultural land will be redistributed among Burmese cultivators, according to a ten-year plan drawn up by the Burmese Land Nationalization Ministry and presented to the all-Burma peasant organization's seventh annual conference held here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Congressional tax investigators put on the record today the story of how a 1950 ruling of the Bureau of Internal Revenue was reversed in favor of a liquor industry executive after John W. Snyder, then Secretary of the Treasury, had taken a personal interest in the case.

" What we must need in architecture now is a philosophy, not an esthetic." This is the theme that Frank Lloyd Wright expanded while he was supervising the installation of a small exhibition of his work at the gallery of the National Institute and the American Academy of Arts and Letters, Broadway and 156th Street.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the majority Supreme Court opinion delivered today by Justice Tom C. Clark holding that the advertising sales arrangements of The New Orleans Times-Picayune did not violate anti-trust laws, and from the dissenting opinion delivered by Justice Harold H. Burton:

Three large power plants now under construction in Greece will double the electric power and energy output in that nation, Admiral John Karavidas, delegated counsel of the board of directors of the Public Power Corporation of Greece, said yesterday.

Hilton Hotels Corporation is inviting holders of common stock in Hotel Waldorf-Astoria Corporation to tender their stock to Hilton for purchase for cash. Hilton, which now owns 312,557 shares, or 85.4 per cent, of the outstanding Waldorf shares, has authorized the purchase of 35,200 shares more at the lowest prices offered.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 25 -- Mrs. Ethel Carhart Jones Taylor, 26-year-old member of a prominent family, was legally insane when she stole $10,000 worth of jewelry from a girlhood friend on March 29, 1951, according to the opinion of two psychiatrists engaged by the Nassau County District Attorney.

The Intercontinental Rubber Company of New York has sent a letter to its stockholders advising them that directors are considering a merger with Texas Instruments, Inc., of Dallas. The next regular board meeting of Intercontinental is set for June 25, but a spokesman for the company indicated yesterday that a special meeting probably will be called before then.

A three-way plan under which West German steel mills and a large Dutch ore and shipping concern may help develop a new iron ore source in Quebec was described here yesterday by Dr. Joseph A. Retty, president of the Fenimore Iron Mines, Ltd., of Toronto.
The Pennsylvania General State Authority announced yesterday that it will receive bids on June 10 on an issue of $20,000,000 of bonds dated July 15 and due from July 15, 1958 to 1982.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 25 -- Continued operation of the control tower at the $10,000,000 Westchester County Airport in Purchase is essential to the armed forces, commercial airlines and operators of private planes, County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach declared this afternoon after conferences with airport officials.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The chances that Congress would revise the Taft-Hartley Act at this session almost vanished today when the Senate Labor Committee failed to get a quorum for its first executive session on the issue and postponed the meeting until June 3.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The question whether professional baseball is monopolistic within the meaning of the Federal anti-trust laws will be considered by the Supreme Court at its new term beginning next Oct. 5.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey made a bid today for $800,000,000 of tax money in advance to help tide the Treasury over the end of this fiscal year, June 30.
CHICAGO, May 25 -- Grain futures were in a semi-demoralized state again today, with demand still too indifferent to permit any substantial recovery.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 25 -- Western delegates said today that they were greatly encouraged by developments in the Korean truce negotiations. Several said they understood that the latest proposal by the Allied Command was in general conformity with the Indian resolution adopted last December by the United Nations General Assembly, and added that the Communists would bear the responsibility if a Korean armistice did not come about now.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Supreme Court refused today for the third time to grant a hearing to Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the convicted atom spies, who have been sentenced to die.

John H. Davis, president of the Commodity Credit Corporation through which the Federal Government lends on farm surpluses, told the co-ordinating committee of the Perishable Food Industries of the Port of New York yesterday that he would be the "happiest man in America" if industry could show how controls and the C. C. C. could be made to "fade out of the picture."

Rails and rail equipment issues did well in a dull stock market yesterday but most industrials, except the oils, floundered and closed somewhat lower. Motors and chemicals were among the soft spots and shares of the larger steel companies lost ground.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Senate refused with finality today to restore Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon to important committee posts that he lost when he bolted the Republican party and became an independent.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- The House of Representatives today cut $10,000,000 from President Eisenhower's request for funds to help states and communities to build hospitals. It tentatively approved a $50,000,000 allotment for hospital grants to states, as recommended by its Appropriations Committee.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 25 (AP) -- A Dutch airliner crashed as it took off for Paris today and killed a woman and a 5-year-old girl who were standing in a road near the airport. The craft broke in two as it crash-landed in a near-by field.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, May 25 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander Europe and the United States Army Chief of Staff-designate, announced tonight that Admiral William M. Fechteler, Chief of Naval Operations in Washington, had been designated Commander in Chief Allied Forces Southern Europe.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -- Dr. Gaylord P. Harnwell, nationally known atomic physicist who has done research work for the nation's armed forces, was chosen today president of the University of Pennsylvania by the board of trustees.

KATMANDU, Nepal, May 25 (UP) -- Teams of British Mount Everest climbers -- racing to scale the world's highest peak to celebrate the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II -- failed in two fries during the week-end, but were ready again today for another assault.

The Society of St. Johnland, a home for children and elderly persons at Kings Park, L. I., will be the beneficiary of the annual summer day fair, to be held on the grounds June 25. The Rev. Lyman C. Bleecker is president of the society, while Mrs. Gertrude H. T. LeBoutillier heads the women's Auxiliary.

LOS ANGELES, May 25 -- The fifteen-year "reform" administration of Mayor Fletcher Bowron, said to be the longest municipal regime in the nation, will be at stake as Los Angeles citizens vote in a nonpartisan election tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -- The three-day battle of Philadelphia ended tonight with an 11-9 triumph for the Dodgers over the Phils in a game that was only a minute short of three hours long. The victory gave the Brooks a sweep of the series and put them in third place ahead of the Phils by 21 percentage points.

Unions are definitely in the realm of "big business." No more dramatic example of this can be found than the current report of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, showing assets of more than $166,000,000 in general and welfare funds.

According to a survey made at Hunter College recently, 91 per cent of the 175 students majoring in home economics are working at a variety of part-time jobs around the city. The findings are reported in the current issue of The Journal of Home Economics by Joan Hain, Geraldine Klvana and Lillian Loris, Hunter home economics students.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 26 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will make Two additional pictures in Cinema-Scope, giving the studio a total of four big-scale productions to utilize the wide-screen photography process recently introduced by Twentieth Century-Fox with the making of "The Robe."
The National Jewish Conference was denounced last night as a "Zionist front" organization at the annual meeting of the New York chapter of the American Council for Judaism at the Plaza Hotel.
Net profits of Servel, Inc., for the six months ended on April 30 were favorably affected by advertising, selling and promotional expenses.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- Chancellor Lawrence A. Kimpton of the University of Chicago announced curriculum changes today that indicated the controversial "Hutchins plan" of speed-up study had not been a complete success.

ROME, May 26 -- Government circles read with great interest today news from Belgrade yesterday that President Tito had renewed proposals through the United States, Britain and France for a solution of the Trieste problem.

The new motorship Maren Maersk arrived here over the week-end on her maiden voyage, and will sail for the Far East tomorrow. Thorkil Host, president of the Moller Steamship Company, general agent for the Maersk Line in New York, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- A consulting engineer testified today that a 365-mile gas pipeline proposed by the Colorado Interstate Gas Company to connect with one planned by the Pacific Northwest Pipeline Company followed the most economically feasible route.
PARIS, May 26 -- Three significant events affecting the strategical position of the Meditterranean area have occurred during the last few days.

Ceramic sculpture dominates the annual spring show of students' work that opens today at the Greenwich House Pottery School, 16 Jones Street, in Greenwich Village. Many of the objects are for sale, as are most of the pieces in an exhibit of work by the school's professional instructors.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission was charged with engaging in a "relentless pursuit" of Otis Co., Cleveland investment house, by Abe Fortas, attorney for the company, here today.

ROME, May 26 -- The campaign of the Christian Democrats, who are the backbone of the coalition Government, which includes Right Wing Socialists, Liberals and Republicans, for the election on June 7 and 8 shifted into high gear today.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The appeals of three foreign-born women delayed consideration of a resolution on naturalization today at the sixty-second convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs. The resolution was sent back to committee to be reconsidered.

Thirty-one member agencies of the Greater New York Fund, which have completed 100 years and more of service in the hospital, health and welfare fields, gave added impetus to the fund campaign at the report luncheon in the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday.

ALBANY, May 26 -- New York State formally approved today a $30,700,000 Federal project for improving the Hudson River between Albany and New York. The program, aimed at meeting modern shipping needs, still must receive approval in Congress.
