The Government's case in a National Labor Relations Board proceeding against the International Longshoremen's Association. A. F. L., was completed yesterday. and the union will begin its defense this afternoon.

When the Brooklyn Hebrew Orphan Asylum was founded seventy-five years ago yesterday such institutions were refuges of last resort. Not all the youngsters who went to live in the big, too often barn-like structures actually had lost both parents.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 26 -- Tension along the Israeli-Jordanian border flared last night into "murderous and coordinated action by armed forces from Jordan" against three villages in the Shephela district, near Lydda, an Israeli Army spokesman announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- A spokesman for the American Bankers Association urged today that Congress take the Government out of the lending business rather than set up any agency for financial aid to smaller companies.

The red and black topped funnels of a French Line passenger vessel appeared in the harbor yesterday for the first time since April 25 as the 45,000-ton Ile de France arrived with 400 passengers from channel ports.
EPSOM, England, May 26 (AP) -- The English Derby shaped up today as a twenty-horse race worth about $50,400 to the winner.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 26 -- Pete Cooper, Century Country Club professional who yesterday led the Metropolitan qualifiers for the National Professional Golfers Association championship, carried off top honors with his partner, Lyman Russell, Westchester Country Club, in the Westchester County Golf Association's pro - amateur best-ball tourney today.

Two hundred city department heads, assembled at City Hall, were urged yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri to cooperate fully with the Municipal Civil Service Commission in its study of a new reclassification and pay plan for city employes.

BONN, Germany, May 26 -- A reorganization by the United States High Commission of its Office of Public Affairs, long the largest and frequently the most controversial division of the American mission in Germany, was announced today.

An account of an international scientific study of the causes of prejudice and intergroup hostilities will be published June 29 by Basic Books, entitled "In the Minds of Men." Written by Gardner Murphy, American psychologist and director of research at the Menninger Foundation, Topeka, Kan., it describes a study carried out in India by teams of psychiatrists, psychologists and sociologists investigating mass tensions and violence.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The Washington Senators were wondering today just what it takes to get into first place.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 26 -- Efforts to mend the Cabinet breach between the ruling Mapai party and the right-of-center General Zionists over the right to display Red flags and sing workers' songs in Government schools on trades union holidays were inconclusive today.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, May 26 -- The United States Government is studying an important French air force proposal that would add 50 per cent to the French frontline airpower assigned to the North Atlantic Treaty air forces by 1956. The plan calls for $1,471,000,000 in additional financing by the United States and would increase the French air force assigned to the Atlantic alliance from about 1,500 to 2,300 planes.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The American Federation of Labor gave its longshoremen's affiliate today a detailed guide for the housecleaning necessary to keep its charter.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Representative Melvin Price, Democrat of Illinois, demanded to know on the floor of the House of Representatives today whether President Eisenhower's defense policies were being formulated by Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, or Joseph M. Dodge, Director of the Budget. Mr. Price is a member of the Armed Services Committee.
The condition of Central Park is a disgrace to the city. Over the many years that I have walked almost daily in the park I have never seen it so dirty and neglected as it is now.

TRENTON, May 26 -- Edmund Palmieri, former New York City magistrate, declared under oath here today that Harold J. Adonis was planning to return to New Jersey next month and might have done so much sooner had it not been for the activities of certain officials of the state.
The Department of Justice's "major project" to crush crime and corruption along New York's sprawling waterfront moved into high gear yesterday.

PARIS, May 26 -- Hastening the regular procedure, Paul Reynard, France's wartime Premier, agreed today to form a Cabinet and asked to go before the National Assembly for endorsement tomorrow afternoon without consulting with the party groups. His aim was to save time but also showed that his intention, if he should become Premier, would be to speed up action and cut down on procedure.

Stressing the need for a quick decision on a slate of responsible and capable candidates in the Mayoralty election next fall, Thomas J. Curran, Manhattan Republican leader, announced yesterday the reactivation of the Inter-County Republican Committee for the Return of Good Government to New York City.
WESTBURY, N. Y., May 26 (AP) -- Nat Hanover slopped through the mud to win the Garden City pace in the rain tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

ALMOST any farmer who likes to eat asparagus will welcome a woodchuck shooter, according to Bart Allen of New York, who has this form of shooting worked out to a "system," in which a gallon jug of very, very hard cider plays an important part.

The New York College of Music last night took a step in a praiseworthy direction. It hired the Hunter College Playhouse and presented its opera workshop and orchestra there in a full-scale mounting of a new opera with an American theme.
LONDON, May. 26 -- The handful of unromantic souls who want to dispense with the monarchy in this ancient kingdom are facing the coronation next Tuesday with steadfast and courageous misanthropy.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- A British electrical manufacturing company today won the first contract awarded by the Army since the rejection last month of a low British bid on a power project in the Pacific Northwest.

There was not much on the racing card at Belmont Park yesterday, and the lack of attraction was reflected in the attendance. A turnout of 16,859, the smallest crowd of the season, watched the program, the highlight of which was the John A. McNulty Classified Handicap.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The State Department issued today its official explanation of why Mrs. Mildred McAfee Horton, wartime head of the Waves, was not named as United States delegate to the United Nations Social Commission.

MERIDIAN, Miss., May 26 (UP) -- Like a ghost out of a colorful past, an old guitar strummed and a plaintive voice entoned the song, "My Old Pal," before a reverent, moist-eyed audience of 100,000 today.
A collection of costumes designed by Norman Hartnell for the British coronation festivities was flown here from England last week-end and was shown yesterday by Bergdorf Goodman.

Dwellings dominated the sales in Long Island areas in transactions reported yesterday. Three of the sales were in Flushing, where William L. Braun conveyed the house at 61-31 Parsons Boulevard to James Smith; Robert S. Ogden sold 59-16 156th Street to Robert Kavanaugh, and Sam Horowitz bought 146-19 Sixty-first Road from Anton Vikete.

The support of sponsors and producers of filmed television programs in connection with six of its public service ad campaigns is now being sought by the Advertising Council, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon in the Brussels Restaurant, 115 East Fifty-fourth Street.

AMHERST, Mass., May 26 -- The Amherst chapter of Phi Delta Theta was suspended from the national fraternity today by that organization's governing board, the General Council. The chapter was not advised of the cause but members assumed the action resulted from a disagreement over the fraternity's stipulations for membership.
Ward B. Arbury, Grand Master of Masons in New York State, appointed district deputy grand masters for the ten Manhattan areas yesterday and filled other high posts in the organization.
SYRACUSE, N. Y, May 26 (AP) -- The Carrier Corporation today reported net profit for the year ended April 30 was $4,827,126, compared to $3,836,820 for the previous year.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Economy forces sustained their sharpest setback of the session today as the House of Representatives passed a bill appropriating $1,980,706,461 for the Department of Labor, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and four small related agencies.

A syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will place on the market today a new issue of $10,000,000 of Potomac Electric Power Company's first mortgage 3 7/8 per cent bonds at 102 to yield 3.77 per cent.

Two simulated bombs exploded 2,500 feet above Queens and Manhattan last night for the benefit of 2,000 Flatbush civil defense workers practicing rescue operations in a drill at the Vanderveer Estates housing development.

Three men said to be members of an international ring of bond thieves were arrested yesterday by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents after an attempt to sell a stolen $100,000 bond at Fifty-eighth Street and Seventh Avenue.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Following is the text of the White House statement defining the United States position on the Korean truce negotiations: ...

SEOUL, Korea, May 26 -- The uneasy tension that now exists between the United Nations Command and the Republic of Korea Government as a result of the new proposal offered to the Communists in Panmunjom was not eased in any way here today.

Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, retired, was appointed vice president in charge of the frozen food products division of Arnold Bakers, Inc., Port Chester, N. Y., yesterday. He will head a world-wide study of the value of frozen foods, high-nutrition bread in particular.

In a reply to Senator Robert A. Taft's speech, Clark Eichelberger, director of the American Association for the United Nations, commented here early this morning that he thought it was "very unwise for the Senator to counsel the United States to abandon working through the United Nations in the Far East."

Opportunities exist to increase sales in the infants-through-'teens departments, Jesse W. Levison, executive vice president of Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office, said yesterday at the company's fall meeting for managers and buyers of children's clothing.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 26 -- The text of the section on international policy in the address by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, read for him at the silver anniversary meeting of the National Conference of Christians and Jews hers tonight, follows:

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Eisenhower Administration feels distracted and hampered by the demands made upon the time of its officials by Congressional committees and has asked for an early adjournment of Congress.
Two Government agencies reported yesterday that wages of workers in this city and state continued their upward trend in 1952.

CINCINNATI, May 26 -- In a speech read for him, Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, majority floor leader, declared here tonight that the United States "might as well forget the United Nations as far as the Korean war is concerned."
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson denied today a request for a further stay of execution for Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the convicted atomic spies.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Senate unanimously approved a bill today to strip top Government officials of the right to collect cash payments instead of vacations and end what Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, denounced as "a racket."

Francis Cardinal Spellman is asking Roman Catholics of the New York Archdiocese to address letters immediately to relatives and friends in Italy urging them to vote against the Communists in the Italian national elections on Sunday, June 7, and to vote for candidates "sworn to uphold Christian democracy," The Associated Press reported yesterday.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 26 -- The police and a unit of the King's African Rifles yesterday killed a well-known terrorist named Simba, or the Lion. He was leading a small band that raided a farm in the north Nyeri district.

When it comes to home furnishings, the homemaker's taste does not differ greatly from that of the professional buyer for a retail store, a recent poll conducted by The Merchandise Mart, Chicago, shows. The poll was taken of visitors to the Good Design exhibit, held under the joint auspices of the Mart and the Museum of Modern Art of New York City.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 26 (UP) -- The thirty-three starters rolled out their machines for a final workout today for Saturday's 500-mile Memorial Day auto race.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 -- Three national insurance companies today asked the United States District Court here to dismiss a petition in which a Philadelphia law firm accused them of attempting to influence prospective jurors through recent magazine advertisements.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- Grain futures generally were stronger today, with free selling on the early bulges followed by recessions. No special change in the character of the news was indicated, but liquidating pressure appeared to be easing, with a modest improvement in investment buying.

Fourteen junior high school students and four adults participated last night in a panel discussion on vandalism at the William Cullen Bryant High School at Thirty-first Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, Astoria, Queens.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Following is the text of the affidavit given by V. C. Georgescu of New York to officials of the State Department concerning the effort of a Rumanian Legation official to barter the release of his two children from Rumania for his "political collaboration" with the Communist regime:

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee was disclosed today to be seeking to prevent a recertification by the National Labor Relations Board of a union that the Congress of Industrial Organizations had expelled on the ground of alleged Communist domination.

LONDON, May 26 -- The securities market here reopened today after the Whitsun holiday in a cheerful mood but business was sparse. Fresh rises in British Government securities were accompanied by renewed, though smaller, gains in industrials.

Once more an attempt is being made to bring Sir Alexander Korda's Irish film, "Saints and Sinners," released here in 1949, to the musical stage. The motivating factor this time is Frederick Loewe, who has established himself as a front-rank composer with the scores of "Brigadoon" and "Paint Your Wagon."

The plan to provide space in the Carver Houses in Harlem for a clinic to be operated by Mount Sinai Hospital will proceed, State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman declared yesterday, despite the opposition of the Medical Society of the County of New York.

LA ROCHELLE, France, May 9 -- After two and one-half years of poor housing, few showers, rudimentary latrines and scarce recreational, athletic or social amenities the vast majority of the 23,000 United States supply troops in France would transfer willingly to duty in occupied Germany if they could.

The participation of Long Island savings banks in a program for retrieving Brooklyn residential areas from continuing depreciation was sought yesterday by Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner.
Mrs. V. C. Georgescu made a personal appeal last night to the mothers of Rumania "to see that my children are spared."
LOS ANGELES, May 26 -- A panel of top economists predicted today that threats to the nation's prosperity may bring on a mild recession, but said the nation can stand it.
Zoological evidence supporting Jimmy Durante's contention that "everybody wants to get into the act" was presented at the Bronx Zoo yesterday.

Acting Postmaster Harold Riegelman predicted yesterday a reduction of $10,000,000 a year in operating costs of the New York Post Office without loss of jobs by any classified civil service postal employes.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, May 27 -- The Ministry of Internal Affairs announced this morning that four spies were parachuted by an American four-motored plane onto Ukrainian territory the night of April 26. The Ministry said the four had been apprehended by Soviet border authorities and after confessing their participation in the plot had been shot.

CAIRO, May 26 -- Egypt's Revolutionary Government today listed major personalities of the once powerful Ward party, including the wife of Mustafa el Nahas, eight times Premier, for trial by a treachery court for alleged misuse of influence during their days of power under the old royal regime.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UP) -- Representative John F. Shelley, Democrat of California, said today the Department of Agriculture sold its West Coast holdings of surplus dried peas last month for $1,600,000 less than it had offered them to other buyers.

William N. Oatis, the Associated Press correspondent who was recently released by the Czech Communist Government after more than two years in a Prague prison on charges of espionage, has made plans to enter a sanitarium for treatment of active tuberculosis.

MILWAUKEE, May 26 (AP) -- Ezzard Charles, the former heavyweight champion, knocked Larry Watson down four times in the fifth round tonight before the Omaha light-heavyweight finally was knocked out at 2 minutes 50 seconds of the round before a slim crowd at the Milwaukee Arena.

Government security prices drifted downward again yesterday in an inactive trading session. Sixteen of the Treasury's thirty-seven issues of bonds and notes touched new low prices for the year, among them the Victory 2 1/2s due in 1972, which closed at 91 3/8 after touching 91 5/16.

ABOARD S. S. QUEEN OF BERMUDA, May 26 -- In view of the continuing strength of the economy, interest rates are certain to advance even further in coming months unless the Administration is willing to "postpone its anti-inflationary tight money policies.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- A Rumanian diplomat was ordered expelled from the United States today after a naturalized American citizen of Rumanian descent had stoutly refused to barter his own "political collaboration" with the Communist regime in return for the promised release within a year of his two 'teen-age sons, held hostage in their native land.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Eisenhower said tonight that a "fair and humane" settlement of the prisoner-of-war issue in Korea must rest on four "basic" principles that are "not subject to change."

Two new films arrive today at first-run theatres. At the Roxy is "Titanic," a drama of the sea, from Twentieth Century-Fox. Heading the cast are Clifton Webb, Barbara Stanwyck, Robert Wagner, Audrey Dalton, Thelma Ritter, Brian Ahern and Richard Basehart. The production was written by Charles Brackett, Walter Reisch and Richard Breen. Jean Negulesco directed and Charles Brackett produced.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The House Ways and Means subcommittee investigating tax scandals established today that interest shown by John W. Snyder, then Secretary of the Treasury, produced a favorable tax ruling within ten days for the General Foods Corporation.

RENO, Nev., May 6 -- Dr. Harold Brown, chairman of the Education Department at the University of Nevada, defended at a Board of Regents hearing today, the right of Dr. Frank Richardson, head of the Biology Department, to circulate among faculty members an article highly critical of colleges of education and professional educators.

Five hundred residents of the Cathedral Heights section urged last night that the City Council and the State Legislature enact laws requiring that attendants be on duty at all times in lobbies of all apartment buildings with self-service elevators.

Dr. George Baehr, president and medical director of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, cited its payroll cost yesterday as a reason for the increase in rates for subscribers set for July 1.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday but prices held steady, rising 8 to 17 points at the close.

Violation of the trade practice rules promulgated by the Federal Trade Commission for the popular-price dress industry is charged in a complaint filed by L'Aiglon Apparel, Inc., against Lana Lobell, Inc., Hanover, Pa. The court action, believed to be the first of its kind in the history of the dress industry, was filed in the United States Disrict Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.

The ubiquitous porgy, available here the year 'round, will be at peak supply this month and next. Now averaging 25 cents a pound, the fish may be bought for as little as 15 cents a pound in some larger markets. At such attractive rates it certainly deserves the attention of the home cook.
NEW ORLEANS, May 26 (AP) -- A group of Marshall, Texas, housewives told three judges today the Government had forced American housewives into slavery by compelling them to be "unpaid tax collectors."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 26 -- Ilya Semenovich Chernyshev, deputy chief of the Soviet news agency Tass was appointed today as Assistant Secretary General in charge of the Department of Security Council Affairs -- one of the United Nations top administrative posts.
TOKYO, Wednesday, May 27 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,627, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Wednesday, Korean time:

Broadcast Music, Inc., music licenser and publisher, has leased the seventh and eighth floors in the sixteen-story and penthouse office building under construction at 589 Fifth Avenue and part of the eighth floor in the twin structure going up at No. 579.

HOYLAKE, England, May 26 (AP) -- The defending champion, Harvie Ward of Atlanta, scored an impressive victory and Frank Stranahan of Toledo an odd one as the second round of the British amateur golf championship -- the first for all practical purposes -- was completed today.
The letter in behalf of tariffs written by Otto W. Heinigke, published in Letters to THE TIMES on May 20, is so plausible and yet so fallacious that an answer seems called for.

The Irving Hotel, a five-story building at 26 Gramercy Park South, running through the block to 133 East Nineteenth Street, has been purchased by a syndicate of investors represented by Benjamin Pulier, attorney, subject to mortgages amounting to $180,000.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 26 -- The Turkish Government was understood to have told United States Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and Mutual Security Director Harold A. Stassen tonight it favored immediate steps by the United States, Britain, France and Turkey to set up a basic Middle East defense organization without further waiting for a sign of a change of heart among Arab states.

MANILA, Wednesday, May 27 -- The new Democratic party launched here yesterday under the leadership of Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo and Vice President Fernando Lopez rejected today repeated offers by the Nacionalista party for a coalition to present a solid front against the Liberal party of President Elpidio Quirino in the Nov. 10 elections.
Sixty-five hundred youths in this city are users of narcotics, Raymond M. Hilliard, executive director of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City, declared yesterday.

The readers of THE TIMES are, in the main, old enough to remember when crime, gambling and corruption was ended completely and forever as a result of the convictions of Luciano and Hines. We are now facing another siege of prosecutions tending to clean up the waterfront situation.

Production of late spring asparagus is running ahead of last year and of the three-year (1949-51) average, with the lion's share coming from New Jersey. More than half of the total late spring harvest is expected there, with the yield estimated at 2,700,000 crates of thirty pounds each.

A simple method that successfully eliminates sterility in 25 to 30 per cent of infertile women was reported yesterday at the first World Congress of Fertility and sterility at the Henry Hudson Hotel by a team of medical investigators from Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

Commodity prices closed higher yesterday on the New York exchanges on continued light activity. Hides were active, as were lead and zinc. Hides, lead, zinc, coffee, wool, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and rubber closed higher. Cocoa and tin were lower and sugar and potatoes ended mixed.

Listing five critical policy decisions and four broad management decisions that must be made by the city government, Harold Riegelman, acting postmaster, declared last night that they required most of all leadership that could command the respect of the public.

ST. LOUIS, May 26 (AP) -- The White Sox handed the Browns their ninth straight loss tonight as southpaw Tommy Byrne gained his second victory of the year. The Sox pounded out fourteen hits to earn an 8-2 decision.
SEOUL, Wednesday, May 27 (AP) -- A flight of small low-flying Communist planes bombed Seoul's Kimpo airfield early today. The Fifth Air Force said damage was minor. No casualties were reported.

The aftermath of the election appears to have created considerable anxiety and nervousness among minority groups in South Africa. Many South African citizens, many of whom are naturalized South African subjects, believe that they will be dealt with on the lines foretold in the book "When Smuts Goes," by Arthur Keppel-Jones. I am a great optimist, and I believe that nothing of this nature will transpire.

Henry J. Simonson Jr., president of the National Securities and Research Corporation, reported yesterday that the sales of the investment funds managed by the corporation were $41,800,000 in the fiscal year ended on April 30, an increase of 46 per cent over those of the preceding fiscal year.

DEVON, Pa., May 26 -- Despite pounding rains that covered the grounds with a sea of mud, the fifty-seventh annual Devon Horse Show and Country Fair for the benefit of the Bryn Mawr Hospital completed the sceond day of its six-day run today.

RYE, N. Y., May 26 -- For the seventh straight year New York won the intercity women's golf team matches over Philadelphia and Boston to retain the Griscom Cup. Intermittent rain hampered play as New York defeated Philadelphia, 18 to 3, and Boston, 18 1/2 to 2 1/2, for 36 1/2 points over the West course of the Westchester Country Club today.
HARLINGEN, Tex., May 26 (AP) -- A native of Illinois arrived here last night with the first bale of 1953 cotton raised in the United States.

America should not "so greatly fear" isms -- communism, socialism, fascism -- because it has been politically experimental and inventive, Mrs. John G. Lee, national president of the League of Women Voters, said yesterday.

Since Frederick S. Allen admits in his letter that he has been traveling, and so out of touch with current American problems, how can the gentleman know what the Senate committee has accomplished? How can anybody judge McCarthy without actually viewing televised investigations?

Representaitve Clifford P. Case of New Jersey has accepted posts as president and a director of the Fund for the Republic, Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of its board, announced yesterday. Mr. Case is expected to resign from Congress and assume his new duties about Sept. 1.

CHICAGO, May 26 (UP) -- The Cubs drove Wilmer Mizell off the mound in the sixth inning today, after he had registered nine strikeouts, to score a 3 -- 2 victory and split a double-header with the Cardinals before 13,075.

The volume of commercial export and import cargoes moving through the New York customs district increased last year, 34,688,150 short tons being received or dispatched as against 34,034,300 short tons in 1951, according to statistics released last week by the Bureau of the Census.

Prospects of amending the Taft-Hartley Act at this session of Congress appear to be diminishing. The Senate Labor Committee, which was expected to begin considering amendments, could not even assemble a quorum for its first closed session. The House Labor Committee has not yet scheduled its first bill-writing conference.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- David Dubinsky, long a prime mover in the fight to rid organized labor of crime, took a pioneering step today in his efforts to keep grafters and racketeers from entrenching themselves in his union, the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Lyall Tracy of Aberdeen, Wash., until recently head of the Chemicals, Rubber and Forest Products Bureau of the National Production Authority, was summoned back to Washington today to become deputy administrator of the authority. Mr. Tracy resigned early in April to return to Rayonier, Inc., of Hoquim, Wash., of which he is an officer.

The eighteen-city survey of subway operations made by Peter Kihss, with the help of TIMES correspondents, and published in our news columns on Monday was interesting on several counts and instructive as New York debates its future transit policy. While most of the world's subways operate under financial deficits, New York was found by the survey to tolerate the largest in relation to operating cost.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The spirit of the Bill of Rights would be violated and free speech denied by the exclusion of Stuart Denton Morris, British pacifist, from the United States, the Board of Immigration Appeals was told here today.

The Soviet Government has declined to participate in the meeting of the deputy foreign ministers originally scheduled for today to resume discussion of the long-delayed Austrian State Treaty, conclusion of which is required if Austria is to regain its sovereignty and be freed of occupation forces.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., May 28 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, emphasized here today that the United States "must prove to the totalitarian world that democracy is a way of life -- an expression of faith."

With Memorial Day only a few days away, various portents prompt a peripatetic pedestrian to note that the day, nationally dedicated to the honored dead of our country's wars, has acquired a new meaning in American culture.

Controller Lazarus Joseph recommended last night that the city study the feasibility of giving financial assistance to religious schools. The aid, he said, would enable the construction of additional parochial schools and would help relieve overcrowding in the public schools.

Fifty-five hundred employes of seven New York breweries will receive wage increases of 7.5 to 17.5 cents an hour under an agreement reached yesterday between the Brewers Board of Trade and the United Brewery Workers, C. I. O.
Within the next few weeks thousands of young hopefuls will graduate from schools, colleges and secretarial institutes -- and many will seek a place as the boss' secretary.

Public and private financing of General Motors Acceptance Corporation this spring will increase the debt of the installment finance company $340,000,000, according to the registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

It was another trying session for the tape watchers yesterday. After a fairly steady opening, stock prices began to ease on small offerings and the list closed generally lower. Chemicals and construction shares were among the easiest spots, but a handful of steel and rail issues resisted the general pressure.
MILWAUKEE, May 26 (AP) -- Warren Spahn, the Braves' ace left-hander who has been idle because of injuries regained top form today in a brilliant four-hit 6-0 shoutout victory over the Redlegs.

CLEVELAND, May 26 (AP) -- Larry Doby's ninth-inning homer gained a 9-8 victory for the Indians tonight over the last-place Tigers. Doby's bases-empty blast followed a five-run Tiger rally in which the tying run scored on an error.

FRIDAY, May 29, will be the 500th anniversary of the fall of Constantinople to the victorious armies of the Turkish sultan Mohammed II. Next Oct. 19 will be the 335th anniversary of the execution of Sir Walter Raleigh. Neither event ranks with those of 1066 and 1492 in the memories of most of us, but both marked important changes in the history of mankind, which are the subjects of two new historical novels.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Atomic Energy Commission proposed to Congress today enactment of legislation that would "create a favorable atmosphere" for the development by private enterprise of nuclear power for industrial uses, and offered a draft of a bill it believed would accomplish this purpose.

The sixth major sale of public housing bonds bearing the guarantee of the Federal Government was accomplished yesterday at an average interest cost of 2.82036 per cent, the highest since the new bond was introduced in the summer of 1951, and nearly 7/8 of 1 per cent above the low average borrowing cost of 1.959 per cent recorded in January, 1951.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (UP) -- The demands of American housewives are forcing some of our old food stand-bys into new forms.

As City Hall girded itself for an expected near storm of protests from a tax-weary public, the administration introduced in the City Council yesterday its bill to impose the 3 per cent city retail sales tax on more than thirty categories of services not now covered.

North American Aviation, Inc., of Los Angeles announced yesterday that it had designed an atomic power generator and was prepared to build a pilot plant for $10,000,000 to demonstrate and study the production of electrical power for industrial and domestic uses.
LONDON, May 26 (Reuters) -- Hampshire today defeated Kent by 47 runs at Southampton to take a 2-point lead in the English county cricket championship standing.

SEOUL, Korea, May 26 -- Although the crisis in the Korean truce talks, now in recess, may impair the future of the Republic of Korea, the morale of the Korean people seems higher than at any time since the war began.
PARIS, May 26 (UP) -- Losing only two sets in four matches, United States women tennis stars established an All-American semi-final in the French International championships today.
HOUSTON, May 26 (AP) -- The nation's first educational television station -- which televises only educational programs on a noncommercial basis -- has made its initial telecast.
The Public Service Commission called a halt yesterday, temporarily at least, to plans of the Long Island Rail Road for changing the form and use of its commutation tickets.

The National Maritime Union, C. I. O., "Will never negotiate backwards," Joseph Curran, president of the 45,000-member organization, declared yesterday in answering a statement by Atlantic and Gulf Coast operators rejecting union demands for a new contract and outlining new principles under which they expect to conduct future negotiations.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Charged with evasion of export control regulations in making shipments of radio tubes, twist drills and other items to Macao, Portuguese possession off the China Coast, and to Hong Kong, a San Francisco exporter has been deprived of all export privileges until May 1, 1955, by the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce.

Traffic congestion has become a definite factor in highway safety through forcing reduction of speeds, thereby decreasing accident potential, Dr. Herbert J. Stack, director of New York University's Center for Safety Education, said yesterday.
HARTFORD, May 26 -- The Connecticut House of Representatives concurred with the State Senate today in approving a general fund budget of $245,383,000 for the biennium beginning July 1.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it would discontinue its radio program to sponsor a new dramatic series on television in the fall. It said that "final negotiations" were in progress for the Theatre Guild to produce the show.

The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago, one of the country's largest operating electric and gas utilities, is planning to sell a new $40,000,000 first-mortgage bond issue through competitive bidding early in July. The proceeds will be used for a continuing expansion program, Willis Gale, chairman, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday in Chicago.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Aaron Copland said he had told Senate investigators today that he was not and never had been a Communist.

ARTHUR MANN has a far deeper knowledge of baseball techniques than the average writer. More inquisitive than most, he first learned from John McGraw and had his education completed when he served as Branch Rickey's assistant on the Dodgers. The Mahatma, of course, has forgotten more baseball than most men know. Hence the following letter from Author (no pun intended) Mann is both provocative and informative. He writes:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 26 -- The Yugoslav State Secretary for Foreign Affairs reiterated today Yugoslavia's willingness to deal directly with Italy on the Trieste dispute at any time. Col. Gen. Koca Popovic in his first press conference here since his appointment last January, named the Trieste suburbs of Chiarbolo and Chiadino [Skedanj and Zavio] as Slovene districts that Yugoslavia would want in return for giving up to Italy Italian-populated towns in the Yugoslav-occupied Zone B.

Municipal and nonprofit hospitals here are in for a further amelioration of that hospital look if they take advantage of a new plan by the United Hospital Fund to bring art to the unbroken plaster wastes of institution walls.

In its special Coronation Night program at the City Center next Tuesday, the New York City Ballet Orchestra, under the direction of Leon Barzin, will play Sir William Walton's "Orb and Sceptre" march, the official coronation music to which Queen Elizabeth II will enter Westminster Abbey.
City departments joined units of the armed services yesterday in a noontime parade and pageant to mark the 150th anniversary of the laying of the City Hall cornerstone.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture has offered growers in eight major producing states payments ranging from 14 to 15 cents a bushel to hold surplus wheat on farms another year.

The United States Court of Appeals decision affirming the Federal Power Commission's authority to regulate rates charged by independent producers of natural gas has awakened echoes of one of the sharpest Congressional battles of the last Administration. Three years ago President Truman vetoed the Kerr bill to exempt from federal control the price (at the source) of a large part of the natural gas sold in this country.

HAVANA, May 26 -- Cuba and the United States signed today their first commercial air transportation agreement at a ceremony held in the Ministry of State. Willard L. Beaulac, United States ambassador, represented the United States Government and Dr. Miguel Angel Campa, Minister of State and Dr. Pablo Carrera Justiz, Minister of State, signed for Cuba.

The machinery was set in motion yesterday to make a record success of the 1953 Mayor's Trophy benefit game between the Yankees and Dodgers at Yankee Stadium on the night of June 29. In its last two presentations, the annual interborough exhibition attracted crowds totalling more than 120,000 and netted $164,769.29 for the promotion of sandlot baseball in the metropolitan area.

DETROIT, Wednesday, May 27 -- The Chrysler Corporation entered negotiations yesterday with the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., on the union's demands for wage and pension improvements to fit the new pattern cut within the last week by General Motors and the Ford Motor Company.

Julius Fleischmann and Carel Goldschmidt have been elected directors of the International Bank, Washington, D. C., it has been announced by T. Reed Vreeland, president. The bank, organized in 1920 by private investors, is engaged principally in financing American foreign trade and assisting American business in expanding overseas operations.

San Marino, Calif., Unified School District sold $2,000,000 of bonds due June 1, 1954 to 1978, to the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association and associates yesterday at a bid of 102.17 for 3 1/4s. Reoffering was at yields ranging from 1.60 to 3.25 per cent.
The Red Cross blood collections for this area for May are 2,153 pints below the quota, it was announced yesterday.

NEWARK, May 26 -- United States Attorney Grover C. Rich man said today he had been directed by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. to cooperate with the New York Southern and Eastern Federal districts in the preparation for the newly ordered Federal grand jury investigation of the New Jersey and New York waterfronts.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (UP) -- The Eisenhower Administration pruned the Federal payroll by about 50,000 persons during its first three months in office, it was disclosed today.

DENVER, May 26 -- The president of the American Baptist Convention called on the Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles today to investigate the intemperate use of alcoholic beverages in United States embassies overseas.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 26 -- A concert by seventy-five members of the symphonic group opened the traditional Talbott Festival tonight at the Westminster Choir College. With Warren Martin and Ralph Burrier conducting, the singers offered Bach's "Magnificat" and Haydn's "Theresa Mass."

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The House of Representatives Judiciary Committee approved today a bill giving political asylum in this country to the young Polish flier who fled his Communist-dominated homeland in a much-prized Communist MIG-15.

The credit man's function will take on added significance in the months immediately ahead with an increase in business competition and the need to maintain and build sales volume, according to J. Wilson Newman, president of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The low bid for converting two oil tankers to bulk carriers was offered yesterday by the Canadian Ship Building and Engineering Company, Ltd. The bid of $1,272,250 on each ship involves work to be performed at Collingswood, Ont., on one vessel and at Port Arthur, Ont., on the other.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today recommended putting Irish potatoes in the same category as other fresh fruits and vegetables for any type of price support assistance.

SEOUL, Korea, may 26 -- United States F-86 Sabre pilots of the Fifth Air Force had another banner day in the skies over North Korea today as they destroyed twelve Communist MIG jet fighters and damaged another.

LONDON, May 26 -- The latest proposals put forward by the United Nations at the Panmunjom negotiations for a Korean truce have the "complete support" of the British Government, Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister, declared in a statement tonight from 10 Downing Street.

The New York Financial Writers Association elected S. Richard Brown of The United Press as president at the annual meeting last night at the Astor Hotel. Jack R. Ryan of THE NEW YORK TIMES was elected vice president, Thomas J. A. Keller of The Wall Street Journal was named treasuer and Robert D. Deasy of The World-Telegram and Sun was elected secretary and assistant treasurer.

Events in Argentina have gone far enough to make it clear that President Peron is embarked on a class revolution of major proportions. He is out to cripple and perhaps to destroy the upper class, which includes landowners, the professional groups, the intelligentsia, the traditional "oligarchy" of the wealthy by inheritance, the aristocracy and in some cases the higher brackets of the armed forces.
Rosalind Russell, star of "Wonderful Town," received the fifteenth annual Barter Theatre Award yesterday for "the best performance given by an American-born actor during the current New York season."

UNTIL word got out that Kremlin doctors had used leeches in a last-minute attempt to save Joseph Stalin, most moderns thought that leechcraft was pretty much an obsolete practice and no part of the Atom Age.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (UP) -- The American Automobile Association tonight awarded the State of Connecticut first prize in its fourteenth Pedestrian Protection Contest.

GENEVA, Switzerland, May 26 (UP) -- Western European exports to the United States reached a record level in the last quarter of 1952, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe has announced. The Commission said Western European imports from the United States had dropped in the third quarter, resulting in an increase of $830,000,000 in United States dollars and gold for West Europe in the last half of 1952.
Rosalind Russell, star of "Wonderful Town," received the fifteenth annual Barter Theatre Award yesterday for "the best performance given by an American-born actor during the current New York season."

UNTIL word got out that Kremlin doctors had used leeches in a last-minute attempt to save Joseph Stalin, most moderns thought that leechcraft was pretty much an obsolete practice and no part of the Atom Age.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (UP) -- The American Automobile Association tonight awarded the State of Connecticut first prize in its fourteenth Pedestrian Protection Contest.

GENEVA, Switzerland, May 26 (UP) -- Western European exports to the United States reached a record level in the last quarter of 1952, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe has announced. The Commission said Western European imports from the United States had dropped in the third quarter, resulting in an increase of $830,000,000 in United States dollars and gold for West Europe in the last half of 1952.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 27 -- The Danes will vote tomorrow on a revised Constitution.
TAEGU, Korea, Thursday, May 28 (AP) -- Toth, a Pittsburgh steel worker, said in an interview here yesterday that he was so shaken by his arrest and sudden removal, "I wasn't sure just what to do."

PITTSBURGH, May 27 (AP) -- Robin Roberts hurled a six-hitter as the Phillies snapped a five-game losing streak by beating the Pirates, 14 -- 2, in the first game of a twilight-night double-header tonight, but the Pirates came roaring back with a six-run eighth inning to take the second contest, 8 -- 6.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 27 (AP) -- April First scored a two-length victory tonight in the Mineola Pace at Roosevelt Raceway. Driven by Paul Vineyard, April First took the lead on the second turn and beat Vonian Chief, with Linda B. third.
CHICAGO, Thursday, May 28 (AP) -- The While Sox and the Tigers battled fifteen innings to a 2-to-2 tie before a crowd of 13,894 tonight before the game was halted because of the 12:50 A. M. curfew.

After a two-year trial, a program of placing Puerto Rican children with foster parents of other cultural backgrounds has been pronounced successful at the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 27 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion asserted today that a distorted significance had been attached abroad to the Cabinet split in which four ministers representing the right-of-center General Zionist party resigned from the Cabinet in protest against the right to display the red flag and sing workers' hymns in state schools on workers' holidays.

Activity improved yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges with zinc showing the third highest volume of the year. Prices closed irregularly lower, influenced by peace talk. Zinc, hides, rubber, cottonseed oil and potatoes were lower. Soybean oil, coffee and cocoa closed higher and wool, sugar, lead and tin ended mixed.

Whatever fatigues Elizabeth II will endure at her coronation, she will not have to go through the ceremony wearing an iron corset as one of her predecessors, Elizabeth I, probably did, judging from another doll exhibit now on view in a window of Lord Taylor.

Thomas J. Curran, Miss Beatrice Cass, Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr. and Mrs. John J. Parsons, the Republican leaders and co-leaders of the First and Ninth Assembly Districts, designated Robert Morris yesterday for the nomination for Municipal Court Justice in the Ninth Manhattan District to succeed Justice Keyes Winter, who will retire on Dec. 31 because of age.

Enormous growth of the frozen food industry was documented yesterday at the Advertising Club, which was host to leaders of the industry at luncheon. E. W. Williams, editor of Quick Frozen Foods, presiding, cited the fact that for the first time frozen peas, ounce for ounce, are selling more cheaply than canned peas.

" Me and Juliet," the new musical comedy written and produced by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, described as the largest and "most spectacular show" in their ten-year career as author-producers, will open tonight at the Majestic Theatre.

DETROIT, May 27 -- The Chrysler Corporation signed tonight a new agreement with the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., giving its 114,000 hourly-rate employes the same wage and pension improvements granted on Monday by the Ford Motor Company.

In a moment of unreason Congress has discontinued the Spanish and Portuguese language programs of the Voice of America, ostensibly in order to save our taxpayers $250,000 a year. Actually, the decision may well be a hysterical reflex resulting from the recent notorious Congressional investigations of the Voice and our information services abroad, and could easily presage similar cuts in other language programs.

CINCINNATI, May 27 (UP) -- The Cardinals knocked out Southpaw Ken Raffensberger with a four-run rally in the first inning tonight and went on to beat the Redlegs. 6 to 3, before a crowd of 5,309 at Crosley Field.

VIENNA, May 26 -- A new home for those who escape from behind the Iron Curtain was opened in Wels, Upper Austria, today by the United States Ambassador, Llewellyn E. Thompson. It represents the best effort the United States has yet made for recent refugees from the "people's democracies," a class for which the former International Refugee Organization was not authorized to provide.
CINCINNATI, May 27 (UP) -- Officials and players of the Cincinnati baseball team today denied a report from Milwaukee that Red-leg players would quit if the club retained Manager Rogers Hornsby.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 27 -- Mobility, Inc., a volunteers organization here for the rehabilitation of physically handicapped persons, told of plans today for a workshop at Elmsford.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- The wheat market went into another dive today after showing early strength, and made new lows for the season before running into support. New lows for the year were also set for rye futures, which developed weakness on stop-loss selling.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 27 (AP) -- Henry H. Fowler, former mobilization chief, said today that the Eisenhower Administration's plan to cut defense spending might be leading this nation into demobilization.

NEWARK, May 27 -- The Central Railroad of New Jersey and the New York and Long Branch Railroad put into effect at midnight tonight increased intrastate commutation fares that were approved last month by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A group of New York motor carriers has asked that the Interstate Commerce Commission require inter-coastal and coastal water carriers serving piers in New York and New Jersey to get rid of the interference of so-called "public loaders."

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission resumed public hearing today into circumstances surrounding the refusal of Otis Co., Cleveland investment house, to go through with a contract to help market a $10,000,000 issue of common stock for the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation in 1948.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The General Federation of Women's Clubs unanimously approved today a resolution calling for a constitutional amendment to stipulate that any provision of a treaty that conflicted with any provision of the Constitution would he invalid.

PARIS, Thursday, May 28 -- After nearly twelve hours of heated negotiation and debate, the French National Assembly in the early hours of this morning rejected a surprise proposition by Paul Reynaud, wartime Premier, to revise the Constitution and put an end to the instability of Cabinets in France. By a vote of 276 to 235, with 89 abstentions, the Assembly refused to invest him with authority as Premier.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins was appointed by President Eisenhower today as the representative of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff in two key agencies of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. He will assume his new duties when his term as Chief of Staff of the Army expires Aug. 15.

Selling pressure increased along with volume in yesterday's stock market, depressing prices to the lowest point since May 14. Rails, which have been showing independent strength of late, gave up early advances in the final minutes of trading, with the result that the market as a whole had the widest loss since April 23. Steels, rails and aircrafts were the weakest sections of the list.

The steel industry is not disposed to raise employe wages and will resist any increases proposed by the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., in the negotiations opened recently. But if the industry cannot avert a pay rise, it will institute higher steel prices immediately.
Jan Oostermeyer, who retires as president of Shell Chemical Corporation on June 1, has been elected a director of the Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation, San Jose, Calif.

A groundbreaking ceremony to mark the entry of the city into the metered parking lot business will be held on Wednesday at the site of the planned 780-car facility at Union Street and Thirty-seventh Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

The remote Beaver Lodge Lake area of northwestern Saskatchewan is experiencing a dramatic revival of uranium prospecting interest, W. J. Bennett, president of the Eldorado Mining and Refining Company, reported last night.

THE TIMES of May 12 quotes Dr. Harry Wexler of the scientific staff of the Weather Bureau as saying: "All available evidence of the effects of atomic weapons, including observations by competent meteorologists of atomic tests at Bikini, indicate that effects, if any, of an A-bomb on weather can only be of a local character."

The appointment of Leon Edel, whose "Henry James: the Untried Years" was published earlier this month, as associate professor of English at New York University's Washington Square College of Arts and Science was announced yesterday by Dean Thomas Clark Pollock.

TORONTO, May 27 -- Canada's booming economy, which last year saw almost twice as many workers absorbed into manufacturing as in the previous peak years of 1948 and 1951, will probably benefit by any cut in defense spending, G. K. Sheils, president, told the Canadian Manufacturers Association as its eighty-second annual meeting opened here today.

LOS ANGELES, May 27 -- The nation's buyers were given an encouraging picture of ample supplies and steady prices in many hard-to-get materials today as the National Association of Purchasing Agents ended its thirty-eighth annual convention.

New York University, as residuary legatee of Dr. Albert A. Berg, who died on July 1, 1950, will receive $1,952,672 to establish an institute for experimental physiology, surgery and pathology, according to an estate tax appraisal yesterday at the State Office Building.

Six hundred persons attended a memorial service last night at the Riverside Synagogue, 310 West 103d Street, in honor of New York policemen and firemen who died in the last year. The service was arranged by Naer Tormid, a Jewish firemen's society.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., May 27 -- Two leaders of B'nai B'rith said here today that "witch hunts" in the nation's schools were resulting in a "crisis of faith" on college campuses throughout the country. Both also asserted that these investigations were endangering our democratic ideals and principles.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- President Eisenhower got two crates of strawberries and an oil painting of a battle scene as gifts today.
Baltimore County, Md., borrowed $23,000,000 in the public market yesterday on various purpose bonds due from 1956 to 1993 at a net interest cost of 2.9827 per cent.

Classroom Ciceros from Hun School took to the soap box in Washington Square Park yesterday evening and learned it takes more than words to stop people. The teen-age orators came to town from Princeton, N. J., as part of their final examination.

Bishop Benjamin M. Washburn of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Newark, chairman of the board of trustees of the General Theological Seminary, Chelsea Square, presented diplomas yesterday to forty-six graduates.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- The book store as a community center providing cultural services of many kinds was envisioned by J. R. Cominsky of New York, publisher of The Saturday Review, in an address at the annual meeting of the American Booksellers Association today.

VIENNA, May 27 -- Hungary's Communist regime has been forcing Hungarians who own property in Austria to instruct Communist lawyers in Vienna to sell it for the benefit of the state, which already has expropriated their holdings in Hungary, it was disclosed today.
MELBOURNE, May 27 -- An American Rugby League team opened its tour of Australia at Canberra today by beating a squad representing New South Wales' south coastal districts, 34 to 25.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Mutual Security Agency advised Congress today to cut President Eisenhower's $5,828,000,000 foreign aid request by at least $354,000,000 to reflect "savings" of that amount in the current year's appropriation. It said another $50,000,000 cut might come later.
NUTLEY, N. J., May 27 -- Stockholders of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation found themselves in clover here today.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower entertained about 1,700 sick and disabled veterans and service men and women this afternoon at the annual veterans' garden party on the White House grounds.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 (AP) -- Commissioner Thomas J. Gibbons said today that the Philadelphia Police Department would not tolerate a recurrence of the "indecent" display by Brooklyn's pitcher, Russ Meyer, in last Sunday's game with the Phillies here.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 27 -- An appeal for funds on behalf of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund was made today to Government leaders in Washington by a private citizens group that is trying to save the fund from a threatened shutdown.
CHICAGO, May 27 (UP) -- Sears, Roebuck Co. said today that a 1953 midsummer sale catalogue being distributed this week, lists more than 3,000 price cuts.

HOYLAKE, England, May 27 (AP) -- Harvie Ward of Atlanta sank eight-foot putt on the eighteenth hole today to defeat Frank Stranahan. 1 up, in the fourth round of the British amateur golf championship.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 27 -- Miss Ann S. Petluck of New York, assistant director of the United Service for New Americans, denounced today as "frightening" the assumption that assimilability and adjustment of immigrants to this country "can be determined by one's birthplace."

Senator Taft is a confusing man. Moreover, he is not always as consistent as he might be, and his sense of timing now and then lacks the touch of the true statesman. The Senator's remarkable speech on world affairs in which he proposed that the United States "forget the United Nations as far as the Korean war is concerned" is what again gives rise to such judgments on his ideas.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., May 27 -- The prosecution in the court-martial proceedings against First Lieut. Sheppard Carl Thierman asked today that the court take judicial notice -- accept as a fact without demanding proof -- of the subversive objectives of the Communist party in the United States.

Your May 21 editorial "The President's Critics" in support of President Eisenhower's plea for continuation of the present high tax level has a note of religious consecration to the Eisenhower phrase --"the balanced budget." Are you not being more emotional and religious about this than logical?

A patrolman accused of brutality toward a traffic offender was brought to departmental trial yesterday before Third Deputy Commissioner Aaron Frank, in the trial room at Brooklyn headquarters. Mr. Frank reserved decision and will report to Commissioner George P. Monaghan on the case, involving Patrolman William V. Scaringe, 37 years old, of 162-24 Seventy-third Avenue, Flushing, Queens.
CHICAGO, May 27 (UP) -- Floods, drought, snowslides and insect swarms plagued various sections of the nation today.

TOKYO, Thursday, May 28 -- The Communists charged yesterday that armed soldiers of the United Nations Command, apparently South Koreans, had entered the neutral zone around the truce conference site at Panmunjom. The enemy lodged a protest with United Nations liaison officers against the alleged violation of the neutrality agreement made when the armistice conferences began.

VERDUN, France, May 12 -- Up to the present, the $500,000,000 strategic supply line being built across France to safeguard United States combat troops in Germany has had virtually none of the inflationary effects originally feared.

Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan turned down yesterday Frank Costello's application for release on a legal technicality from serving the remainder of his eighteen-month sentence for contempt of the United States Senate.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today the State Department had agreed to confirm publicly that it knew British-owned ships had been used as troop carriers for the Chinese Communists during the Korean war.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- A bill aimed at sharp curtailment of radio and television accounts of baseball games cleared its first hurdle in Congress today.
Morris High gained only two first places but captured the Bronx Public Schools Athletic League track and field championship with 39 1/2 points at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

Plans for a $750,000 parochial elementary school and a $500,000 college of pastoral work for graduate training of ministers on ground adjoining St. Luke's Chapel in Greenwich Village were announced yesterday by Dr. John Heuss, rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The State Department dismissed today as Communist fantasy and propaganda the Soviet Union's charge that four spies had parachuted into the Ukraine under instructions of United States intelligence officials.
Futures were moderately active on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and closing prices for active months declined 19 to 34 points.

Changes in the proposed reorganization plan for the Missouri Pacific Railroad, approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission on Dec. 29, 1949, were filed yesterday with the commission by De Lancey C. Smith, chairman of the committee acting for the railroad's 5 1/4 per cent secured serial gold bonds.

Shortly after counsel for Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, condemned atom spies, made two new legal moves yesterday to reduce their death sentences, the Government notified the defense that a new date of execution probably would be fixed tomorrow.

WHILE others are brooding about summer reading Associate Justice William O. Douglas is out creating it. He believes that gathering material for a book adds much to a good vacation. His holidays are spent writing rather than reading. As soon as the Supreme Court adjourns he starts getting notebook, pencil and passport together for his-next Asian safari, tempering justice with authorship.

Events today: Searle Wright, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 12 noon; Manhattan Opera Guild concert, Carl Fischer Sky Room, 8 P. M.; Composers Group of New York City, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Commencement concert, Manhattan School of Music, 238 East 105th Street, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating. Republican of upstate New York, has received an offer of a $23,000 New York State judgeship in a move that would eliminate him from the field of possible Republican aspirants for Governor next year.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 27 -- United States Secretary of State John Foster Dulles left for Greece this morning with Mutual Security Director Harold E. Stassen and other members of his party after assuring the Turks the United States favored integration of Yugoslavia into the European defense system.

A decline of 1,492,000 barrels last week in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 153,923,000 barrels, against 155,415,000 a week earlier and 122,161,000 a year ago.

With the scratching of Greentree's Northern Star from the $23,600 Roseben Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday, the Greentree jockey, Ted Atkinson, was free to accept the mount on Mrs. Jan Burke's Squared Away for the six-furlong run through the Widener chute.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 27 -- The French defense post at Yenvi on the Day River in the southern delta region of North Vietnam has been evacuated and its concrete fortifications have been destroyed, the high command announced today.

A municipal pound for "poodle parkers" was urged yesterday by the Bronx Chamber of Commerce. These are motorists who snap up tidbits of curb space and squeeze in cars, according to Walter J. Holmes, executive vice president of the organization.

The members of Local 791 of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., voted last night ta stage a mass demonstration on June 8 to protest the "outrageous and undemocratic proposals" made by the State Crime Commission to clean up the racket-infested waterfront.

Rudolph Bing, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Company, reiterated in a shipboard interview yesterday that the fall opening of the world-famous institution hinged on whether contract agreements with the major labor unions could be reached.
WEST POINT, N. Y., May 27 (AP) -- For the first time in its century-and-a-half history, the United States Military Academy will graduate a set of twins at exercises Tuesday.

LINDEN, N. J., May 27 -- Earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) for the second quarter will approximate the $126,000,000, or $2.08 each on the 60,571,092 capital shares, earned in the first three months of this year, Eugene Holman, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting held here today in the former boiler room of the company's huge Bay- way refinery. Some 3,000 stockholders attended.

SEOUL, Korea, May 27 -- There was increasing evidence on hand tonight that the Republic of Korea Government of President Syngman Rhee would continue the war here, alone if necessary, to try to unify the country against the Communists, should an armistice agreement be reached along the lines of the present United Nations proposal.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A courteous but resolute Cornell zoologist who admitted freely that he was a Red through the war years and until 1948 continued today to refuse to identify former associates at Harvard University, who, he said, were in a Communist group, despite a threat of a contempt citation by the House of Representatives Committee on Un-American Activities.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -- Representative Charles J. Kersten charged today that a Communist attempt to use a father's love for espionage purposes proved that all Red embassies here were spy centers and "should be closed up kit and kaboodle."
Twin investigations into the adequacy of service and the safety of certain phases of operations of the Long Island Rail Road were ordered yesterday by the Public Service Commission.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 27 -- An original copy of the first illustrated book published in what is now the United States was placed on display today in Princeton University's Harvey S. Firestone Memorial Library.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 27 -- A jury of ten men and two women decided tonight after deliberating more than five hours that Mrs. Ethel Carhart Jones Taylor, a socially prominent resident of North New Hyde Park, was insane in March, 1951, when she stole $10,000 worth of jewelry from a girlhood friend.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Air Force was ordered today to prove in a Federal District Court here that it had a right to arrest Robert W. Toth of Pittsburgh, a former Air Force man, and take him to Korea to stand trial for murder before a military court.

Real progress is being made toward cleaning up waterfront evils exposed by the State Crime Commission and other agencies. Attorney General Brownell has ordered grand juries in this area to sift the accumulated evidence of federal law violations; to the Department of Justice the waterfront inquiry "has become a major project."

CAMDEN, N. J., May 27 (UP) -- The Maine Chance Farm's unbeaten 2-year-old filly, Incidentally, sped to a one-length victory today in the $10,000 added Rancocas Stakes at Garden State Park. Riant was second and Snugger finished third in the field of 11.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 20, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

A full-scale design for a mural, by Herbert Gute of the Art Department of Yale University, which will be executed in marble and enamels and installed in the newly built Cambridge Memorial Chapel in Cambridge Cemetery, England, was exhibited last night at the Grand Central Art Galleries, 15 Vanderbilt Avenue.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 27 -- Under the United Nations Charter, a permanent seat on the Security Council -- which carries with it the right of veto -- was awarded to the Republic of China, along with the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France.

WOODBURY, L. I., May 27 -- The "old" women of Woodbury, a quiet, 175-year-old village of 500 residents that is now growing sixfold in population as housing developments sprout from former potato farms, gave a garden party luncheon party for their new neighbors.

LONDON, May 27 -- Prices made further small gains on the stock markets today despite a low volume of trading. Nearly all sections benefited except South African gold mine shares, in which there were many small falls.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- President Eisenhower has been ordered by the United States Court of Claims to produce a ten-year-old Securities and Exchange Commission secret report on a World War II munitions concern. Apparently, the President does not have to obey the order, and he has not said whether he will.
Although hours of appointment will be limited tomorrow at Red Cross blood donor centers, persons who wish to contribute before leaving for the week-end holiday will be accommodated.
KATMANDU, Nepal, May 27 (Reuters) -- Weather over Mount Everest continued fair today for the British expedition attempting to conquer the 29,002-foot peak.
SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, May 28 (AP) -- More than 4,000 Chinese Communists slammed against South Korean forward positions on the central and east-central fronts last night and early today.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) Lieut. Gen. Glenn O. Barcus, Fifth Air Force commander, who led his fighter pilots into battle against the Communists in Korea, has been assigned to a post in the United States, the Air Force announced today. General Barcus, who will drop to major general, will become deputy chief of the Air Training Command at Scott Air Force Base, Ill., on July 15.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Eleven Democrats lined up with thirty-five Republicans today to win Senate approval of President Eisenhower's plan for reorganization of the Department of Agriculture.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., May 27 -- Billy Brown, a high school senior here, undertook ten months ago on the Voice of America to tell the world about everyday life in this rural town of northern Westchester County. He planned no panoramic view of the wonders of America, but just a simple glimpse in simple language into the soda fountains, the basketball games, the classrooms and the farmhouse kitchens.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 27 -- A small group of young workers from several European countries sat in historic Winants Hall on the Rutgers University campus yesterday and gave their impressions of the United States after a year of working here and living with American families.

The 11,600-gross-ton Japanese freighter Hikawa Maru of the Nippon Yusen Kaisha Line is nearing her homeland for extensive reconditioning as a passenger ship and will be operated in the United States-Japan trade, it was learned yesterday.

A tract of ten acres on the east side of Bayview Avenue, about 498 feet north of Potters Lane, in Kings Point, L. I., has been purchased by Jay Builders, Inc., from Philip and Eleanor Schwartz. The buyer plans to construct houses on plots of one acre or larger.

Roy Campanella's two-on, two-out homer in the ninth inning, the second four-bagger of the contest for the slugging Brooklyn catcher, invalidated a fine pitching performance by Jim Hearn and enabled the Dodgers to gain a 5-3 triumph over the Giants last night.

WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn., May 27 -- Getting a legal limit of shad from the fast-flowing Connecticut at this popular margin of the river is no problem provided you arrive early, get an upstream position, and can bring your fish to net without picking up too many neighboring lines.
PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- Fabrics composed of man-made fibers have given the fashion industry a big lift, Arthur C. Kaufman, executive head of Gimbel Brothers, Philadelphia, said here today.

ST. LOUIS, May 27 (AP) -- The Browns snapped their losing streak at nine straight and ended Cleveland's four-game winning skein as they defeated the Indians, 5 -- 1, tonight. Bob Lemon, who had twice defeated the Brownies this season, was the victim of an eight-hit attack and three Cleveland errors.

The desire of the Eisenhower Administration to get Congress out of its hair -- and out of Washington -- is understandable, but not necessarily in the national interest. It all depends on what the Administration and Congress manage to accomplish in the way of fulfilling campaign pledges and legislative programs between now and the proposed early adjournment in July.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 135,221 today, an increase of sixty-six since last week.

John Romano, serving a life sentence for the fatal shooting seven years ago of Albert Davidoff, a Brownsville prizefighter known as Al (Bummy) Davis, during a tavern hold-up, failed yesterday in an effort to win a new trial.

A proposal by City Council President Rudolph Halley that the city take over the 1,123-unit Manhattan Beach housing project in Brooklyn and eventually replace it with a permanent development was unanimously rejected yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Two White House aides of the Truman Administration plan to purchase The Adirondack Enterprise, a daily newspaper in Saranac Lake, N. Y.
Helped by three home runs and the three-hit pitching of Southpaw Eddie Lopat, the league-leading Yankees defeated the Senators 3 -- 1, at the Stadium yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The suggestion of Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, that the United States "forget the United Nations so far as the Korean war is concerned" stirred profound but, for the most part, hidden repercussions in Washington today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 26 -- David Lee Shillinglaw, a Chicago investment banker with a long career in local Republican politics, said tonight that a hoped-for appointment as a United States delegate to the United Nations probably did not come through because of his activities in the Institute of Pacific Relations.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, said today that Secretary Wilson had offered to answer her questionnaire on Air Force budget cuts at a regular committee hearing, Mrs. Smith asked the Secretary more than sixty written questions on the effect of the cut in new Air Force appropriations. Mr. Wilson visited her this morning.
SEATTLE, May 27 (AP) -- A British concern submitted the low bid for the second time today for ten big power transformers for the Federal Government's Chief Joseph Dam project on the Columbia River.

BIZERTE, Tunisia, May 14 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther's visit to Tunisia last week was not all gold lace and champagne. It also involved a working session with French Vice Admiral Edouard Jozan at the Bizerte naval and air base, a growing bastion of Allied power in the Mediterranean.

The Worthington Corporation, which grew from a small Brooklyn machine shop to a world-wide producer of pumps and industrial equipment, celebrated its 100th anniversary in the export business yesterday.

GEORGE EASTMENT prepared most thoroughly for his job as Manhattan College track coach but he certainly slipped grievously on one count. He neglected to get an M. D. degree. His Jaspers have been far more in need of a doctor than a coach this season, with arnica, adhesive tape and miracle drugs having considerably more to do with their conditioning than wind sprints.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A New York business executive told -- Senate Banking and Currency Committee today that the present country-wide credit situation places small concerns at "a decided competitive disadvantage."
Motorists whose cars break down on the West Side Highway after July 1 would pay fees of $1 to $4 to a private towing operator, under a plan being considered by the city.
TOKYO, Thursday, May 28 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,628, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korean time:

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 22 -- The Burmese town of Monghsat, about sixty miles above the northern border of Thailand, was suggested today as the prospective "truce team" headquarters base for a four-power group that is exploring concrete means for evacuating Gen. Li Mi's Chinese Nationalist guerrillas from Burma's Shan state.

Research services themselves are responsible for much of the lack of coordination in advertising research programs, it was charged last night by Horace S. Schwerin, president of the Schwerin Research Corporation here. He spoke at a dinner meeting of the Chicago Chapter of the American Marketing Association in the Chicago Bar Association Building.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's proposal to admit 240,000 more immigrants from Europe came under fire in a Senate hearing today.

Yellow was featured as a flattering summer color in vacation attire presented yesterday by Arnold Constable at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Pale shades, brilliant golds and light yellow-greens were seen in sportswear, casual dresses and cocktail and evening fashions.

The controversial 10 per cent rate differential proposed by the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference took its first step toward Federal Maritime Board approval yesterday in a favorable report issued by a board trial examiner.

The rose, for many years a favorite motif with designers of decorating materials, is utilized in a group of about twelve Waverly fabric patterns that may be ordered at Altman's. Some are new, while others have been adapted to form smaller designs or are available in new colorings or on new materials.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -- Representatives of major railroads have agreed on a plan to continue railway express service after the present contract with the Railway Express Agency runs out next February, it was announced today.

WESTBURY, L.
