I., May 27 -- A field of sixty-four took part in the annual women's Long Island Golf Association match-play-against-par tournament at The Creek Club today, but a brisk breeze and difficulty with the par-72 course caused forty-one of the number to post no cards as Mrs. James Walker of Meadow Brook won, 1 down.

The recent slum survey conducted by State Housing Commissioner Herman Stichman is a grim reminder of the appalling squalor in which a considerable segment of New York City's population is living. While great strides have been made in the field of slum clearance, high-level spot-checks of the type carried out by the Commissioner are vital if this ubiquitous ugliness is to be banished from our midst.

The 10 per cent inspiration and 90 per cent perspiration that are supposed to total success resulted early yesterday in the arrest of two parolees charged with the theft of $100,000 to $150,000 in jewels, furs and cash.

LOS ANGELES, May 27 (AP) -- United States Representative Norris Poulson was Los Angeles Mayor-designate today as his election victory snapped the record term of Fletcher Bowron, head man for fifteen years.

NEW DELHI, India, May 27 -- On the eve of his departure for London to attend the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II and to deliberate on matters of high policy with other Commonwealth Prime Ministers in austere halls of state, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru went out in the sun and dust among the squalid primitive villages near his own capital today.

The next Philippine Presidential election will not be held until November, but political activity in Manila has already reached a heat that surpasses the tropical summer temperature. The Liberal party's convention, which ultimately nominated President Quirino for re-election, was split wide open by the walk-out of General Romulo and his supporters.

DETROIT, May 27 (AP) -- Johnny Saxton, a punishing body puncher, landed enough blows to the head tonight to preserve his unbeaten record with a nuanimous decision over Joe Miceli at Olympia Stadium. Saxton, a slight favorite, weighed 147 3/4 pounds to Miceli's 147 1/2 in the lively battle between the two New Yorkers.

High school graduates entering business and industry generally have inadequate training in reading, writing, spelling, grammar and arithmetic, according to a report issued yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

CENTRAL VALLEY, N. Y., May 27 (AP) -- Richard J. Bambrick 38 years old, of Ridgewood, N. J., died last night in Cornwall hospital of internal injuries a few hours after his automobile collided with a truck on Route 32 here.
PHILADELPHIA, May 27 (UP) -- Gus Zernial's seventh home run of the season in the eighth inning gave the Athletics a 4-3 victory over the Red Sox tonight at Connie Mack Stadium.

Frank Lloyd Wright, octogenarian architect, put aside yesterday his avowed "honest arrogance" and also a speech prepared for acceptance of a Gold Medal Award from the National Institute of Arts and Letters, to confess that "a shadow falls; I feel coming on me a strange disease -- humility."

TOKYO, May 27 -- Britain's Anglo-Iranian Oil Company today lost the first round of its fight to prevent the Japanese from buying petroleum products from Iran's nationalized oil fields, formerly controlled by the company.

PARIS, May 27 (UP) -- Vic Seixas and Gardnar Mulloy, the United States' two top-ranking singles players, advanced to the men's doubles semi-finals in the French tennis tournament today when they teamed to defeat Enrico Morea of Argentina and Armando Vieira of Brazil, 11 -- 9, 6 -- 2, 1 -- 6, 8 -- 6.

BELEM, Brazil, May 27 (UP) -- A joint United States Brazilian agency drew plans today for a cooperative system of low-cost housing here under which owners would pay for their homes with labor and $10 a month.

Individual citizens and civic agencies must abandon their "laissez-faire" attitude toward public health programs, Dr. Leona Baumgartner, newly appointed executive director of the New York Foundation and a noted authority on child health, said last night.
Douglas Leigh, advertising executive and creator of "spectacular'' Broadway displays, announced yesterday the development of two new filming and projection systems in a wide-screen form.

It was one of the cruelest choices ever imposed upon a father, a torment only the Communists could have devised to get their way. And we shall not soon forget the decision that V. C. Georgescu made, in favor of patriotic loyalty to his adopted country rather than pay the traitorous ransom price of spying for a foreign Power to free his two sons from a detention camp in Rumania.

Dr. Frank S. Lloyd, chairman of the Department of Hygiene at City College from 1944 until his suspension last November, submitted his resignation yesterday in the course of the hearing by a three-man trial committee of the Board of Higher Education of charges against Professor Lloyd, Nat Holman and Harry (Bobby) Sand.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., May 27 -- A threatened clash between New Mexico state officials and the Senate subcommittee investigating last November's contested victory of Senator Dennis Chavez, Democrat, over Maj. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley, retired, was averted today by a compromise.

SHAWNEE - ON - DELAWARE, Pa., May 27 (AP) -- Mrs. George Smith, Plainfield, N. J., and Mrs. A. B. Haser Jr., Glen Ridge, tied with scores of 76 each today in the first round of the women's New Jersey Golf Association handicap tournament.

ABOARD THE S. S. QUEEN OF BERMUDA, May 27 -- New York's commercial bankers, at the closing sessions of their fifty-seventh annual convention aboard this liner, voted today to begin an intensified public relations and information campaign designed to insure full public understanding of their industry's operations.
Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., earmarked $500,000 yesterday to help its Local 100, representing city transit employes, to achieve three long-held objectives:

Record sales of $314,894,718 and a net profit of $11,345,200, or $4.13 each on the 2,448,121 shares of common stock outstanding, were achieved by Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., in the fiscal year ended March 31, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 27 -- Until the last few days it had been taken for granted here that there was nothing wrong with the attitude of Americans to the United Nations that an armistice in Korea wouldn't cure.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Following is the 46-to-29 vote by which the Senate refused today to disapprove President Eisenhower's plan for reorganization of the Agriculture Department. The vote was on a motion of disapproval by Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, with votes of forty-nine Senators required to veto the plan:

The five-man Ways and Means Committee of the National Football Hall of Fame met yesterday at the McGraw-Hill Building and discussed plans to approve a schedule of "Hall of Fame Award" games this fall and to seek other means of fund raising.

George Balanchine's little "Concertino" had its first presentation of the season last night by the New York City Ballet at the City Center. Set to the slight but witty music of Jean Francaix with Nicholas Kopeikine playing the solo piano part delightfully), it is the merest breath of a piece, but it has charm quite out of proportion to both its length and its depth.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee made two major changes today in a bill extending the doctor draft act that was passed by the House of Representatives. The legislation is slated for Senate debate and probable passage tomorrow.

DEVON, Pa., May 27 -- Mahrapo Farms of Mahwah, N. J., retired the challenge trophy for two of the get of the same hackney pony stallion at the fifty-seventh annual Devon Horse Show and Country Fair today. The two ponies, Mahrapo High Fling and Mahrapo King of Magic, were shown by their owner, Stephen Birch Jr.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A drop in the "old series" Consumers' Price index announced today indicated a pay cut of 2 cents an hour for 1,000,000 automobile workers but most of them will miss it because they have switched to the revised index.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations said today it would support the Ives anti-discrimination amendment to the Taft-Hartley Act to the extent that it was a step in the direction of fair employment practices legislation.
The following booklet, published recently, may be of interest to career-minded high school and college students:

" The Flowers of Friendship," a collection of letters written to Gertrude Stein by Ernest Hemingway Sinclair Lewis, Bennett Cerf, Pablo Picasso, W. G. Rogers and others, will be published by Knopf on Aug. 17. The material for the book came from the Gertrude Stein collection at Yale.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- Ben Mandel, former Chicago ticket broker, has on file in Federal District Court here an anti-trust suit seeking $120,000 damages and an injunction restraining another ticket agency and a theatre operating company from stifling the sale of tickets to stage plays.

President Eisenhower's statement of basic principles for settling the prisoner of war issue in Korea keeps along a straight, clear line. It is the same line on which the previous Administration fought and won the United Nations General Assembly battle last autumn.

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer ruled yesterday that a former affiliation with the Communist party that had long been discontinued and reasonably explained was not a bar to employment by the municipal civil service.
ATHENS, May 27 -- Secretary of State Dulles and Mutual Security Director Stassen were greeted at the airport today by their wives and members of the Greek Government.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -- The Budget Bureau has slashed from $19,000,000 to $7,665,000 funds for constructing housing for United States diplomats in Germany.

Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, defined the newspaper's responsibility to the community yesterday as presentation of the news as honestly, fully and intelligently as possible.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The long and growing parade of witnesses before Congressional committees who refuse to give information, pleading the provision in the Fifth Amendment that "no person * * * shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself," has put new life in an effort to expand the law by which immunity from prosecution can be granted in exchange for this kind of information.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 27 -- The letters and papers of Louis Wiley, business manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES for twenty-nine years before his death in 1935 and one of the best-known newspaper executives in the United States, have been presented to the Rush Rhees Library of the University of Rochester by his brothers and sisters.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 27 -- While the making of theatrical motion pictures may be at a low ebb in Hollywood, a big boom in television film production is getting under way here. The results of a survey published today in Daily Variety show that $30,000,000 will be poured into the making of forty eight series of TV movies during the next six months.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 27 (AP) -- The International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., tonight asked Governor Dewey to name an arbitrator to help settle its seven-week-old dispute with the General Electric Company. Officers of Local 320 asked Mr. Dewey, in a telegram, to designate the Right Rev. John Boland of Buffalo, a member of the State Mediation Board.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee voted today to withhold further contributions to the United Nations in the event that Red China should be admitted to the organization and thus become a member of its Security Council.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., May 27 -- Memorial Day remembrances of veterans' organizations here -- a Confederate flag and the Stars and Stripes -- fluttered today over the graves of two brothers who fought on opposite sides in the Civil War and who are buried side by side in the historic First Presbyterian Church cemetery.

HOBOKEN, N. J., May 27 -- That Whitewater, Kan., school bus that was parked high on the banks of the Hudson today was not a wayward bus, nor were the twenty-two seniors who arrived in it playing hookey. They are carrying out a tradition established in 1935 in Whitewater (population 500) by topping off their last high school year with a sightseeing trip.

William C. Chanler, chairman of the Citizens Nonpartisan Committee, hailed yesterday the reactivation of the Inter-County Republican Committee for the Return of Good Government to New York City, announced on Tuesday by Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican Chairman.

Sherbet fits into any summer meal course, we are reminded by the manufacturer of a new quick-mix for that frozen dessert. With a fresh-fruit starter it looks and tastes cool. It is a seasonal accent for a main dish. It puts a refreshing period to dinner.

There seems to be some confusion in many minds here about the geographical setting of the recent riots in Kano, Nigeria. Nothing happened in the native city of Kano, one of the most peaceful communities in the world, with a 100 per cent native population of 100,000.

BAR HARBOR, Me., May 27 -- Thomas K. Finletter, civilian chief of the Air Force during the military build-up after the start of the Korean war, today called attempts to curb the growth of the nation's "air atomic power" a reversion to "ground soldier thinking" and an apparent blindness to the Soviet Union's surge in both air and atomic capability.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Thursday, May 28 -- In the Dutch Municipal elections today, the Socialists bettered their position as the country's largest party, presumably at the expense of the Communist party, which continued its steady post-war decline.

MILWAUKEE, May 27 (AP) -- Four hitless innings of relief pitching by Johnny Antonelli, coupled with a thirteeen-hit attack on three Chicago hurlers, gave Milwaukee a 9-4 victory over the Cubs tonight.

ALBANY, N. Y., May 27 (AP) -- President William White told New York Central Railroad stockholders today the company earned $1.59 a share in the first four months this year and estimated net income for the entire year would be about $5.85 a share.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- President Eisenhower is expected to announce in the near future a plan for the creation of a separate high-level agency to handle all Government international information activities except the educational exchange program.
Because of the holiday week-end, news of good buys in food' is published today instead of Friday, as is customary.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., May 27 (UP) -- The Big Ten will agree tomorrow to renew the Rose Bowl contract with the Pacific Coast Conference for the second time.

New issues of public utility, natural gas and railroad securities totaling more than $44,000,000 will be offered to investors today. Included are debentures of a natural gas system, common stock of an Eastern utility company and equipment trust certificates of two Western railroads. The offerings are as follows:

The New York City Transit Authority agreed yesterday at a three-and-a-half-hour closed meeting with the Board of Estimate in City Hall to give consideration to all objections raised by city officials to a proposed lease that would turn over city-owned transit lines to the authority.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The Treasury and Commerce Departments joined today in urging Congress to pass promptly a bill to streamline customs rules and procedures and thus remove "major obstacles" to foreign trade.

HARTFORD, Conn., Thursday, May 28 -- The Connecticut State Senate early today approved a state corporation tax increase of $9,200,000 for the calendar years of 1953 and 1954 and then began consideration of bills increasing the state sales tax and the unincorporated business tax.

RENO, Nev., May 27 -- Dr. Frank Richardson, University of Nevada biologist, testified today at a Board of Regents hearing that he had been directed by the university president, Dr. Minard W. Stout, "to take my principles to another campus."

MOSCOW, Friday, May 29 -- Senator Taft's declaration has not been published in Moscow thus far, but it was expected that newspapers would soon take note of the latest United States foreign policy developments.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Twenty-four digger merchandising machines, 1,428 rouge boxes, seventy-one pocket knives, 132 cigarette lighters, forty-two pencils, ninety-eight fountain pens, fifty-five compacts, 401 pottery dogs, sixteen metal horses, three comic buttons, nine flashlights, nineteen dice, two bracelets, eleven watches, ten steel tapes, two compasses, one razor, nine jewel boxes and Loyal George Staley petitioned the Supreme Court today to hear their case.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 28 -- Two officials of the conference department of the British Foreign Office, working here since Tuesday, have drawn up plans for approval of the Bermuda and British Governments concerning the Western Big Three conference next month.
TOKYO, Friday, May 29 -- British and Turkish soldiers on the western Korean front last night and early today beat off Chinese Red attacks of 5,000-man strength. The fighting was continuing at noon.

With Manhattan favored to hold the team crown against the challenge of Yale, the seventy-seventh annual outdoor track and field championships of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America will open a two-day stand at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island today.

New issues of public utility, natural gas and railroad securities totaling more than $13,000,000 will be offered to investors today. They include offerings of common stock to finance repayment of bank loans incurred for capital purposes, and an issue of trust certificates to help finance the acquisition of equipment by a western railroad.

The Graham-Paige Corporation, a closed-end investment company, had a net stockholders' equity of $7,636,385 on March 31, based on market values for securities having market quotations and on book values for other investments, as compared with $7,602,952, on the same date last year, according to an announcement made yesterday by Joseph W. Frazer, chairman, and John J. Bergen, president.

The story of the superliner United States -- speed queen of the North Atlantic passenger shipping lanes -- is known throughout this country and the world, and much of the credit for the telling must go to Carla Dietz of the United States Lines, who was honored at a dinner at the Statler Hotel last night marking her retirement.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Evidence that the so-called excess profits tax is blocking expansion plans of young business men trying to get ahead has been unearthed in great detail by a survey conducted for the Young Presidents Organization, a report disclosed today.

Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman will set a new date today for the execution of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, condemned atom spies. This will be the fourth time that the jurist has fixed a date for the execution.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 28 -- A film on the life of Dr. Chaim Weizmann, first President of Israel, will be produced by the British movie team of Emeric Pressburger and Michael Powell, they said here today. The picture will be based on Dr. Weizmann's autobiography "Trial and Error."

This country has lost one of its finest artists and one of its best citizens in the death of Albert Spalding. He retired from the concert field almost three years ago, but he continued to be a vital part of the intellectual and artistic life of his country. He leaves an empty place that will not be easily filled.
TORONTO, May 28 (Canadian Press) -- Brazilian Traction Light and Power Company's net income for the first four months of 1953 was $2,000,000 more than a year ago, Henry Borden, president, said today.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Government today said it has signed a contract with the Banner Mining Co. ,Tucson Ariz., calling for production of 12,960,000 pounds of refined copper over a three-year period from mining properties in Pima County, Ariz.

A new group of custom-made ceramic and tile objects, suggested as gifts for the bride and bridegroom, are on display at Kiln Craft, 201 East Sixty-first Street. All the pieces are hand-made by the owner of the shop, Miss Slyv Smith.

GUATEMALA, May 28 (AP) -Charnaud MacDonald, Interior Minister, is heading a well-organized move aimed at eliminating Communist influence from the parties supporting the Government of this Central American Republic.

Predicting that the steel industry would find itself with too much productive capacity "in a very short time," Benjamin F. Fairless, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said here yesterday that his company planned to have every product "carry a reasonable profit" and that "we're going to be competitive."

BONN, Germany, May 28 (Reuters) -- Nearly 250 members of the United States High Commission gave a farewell party tonight to Theodore Kaghan, senior High Commission official who resigned recently after a hearing before Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's Senate Investigation Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- President Eisenhower said today the necessity for detailed Federal Bureau of Investigation reports on Government employes was slowing the Administration's efforts to change the Government's face.
TOKYO, Friday, May 29 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,629, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korean time:

The apartment and store building at 185 East 163d Street, the Bronx, bought about a month ago by George Goodman, operator, has been resold to a client of the law firm of Hayes, St. John, Abrahamson Schulman, for cash over mortgages of $230,000. Jacob Schulman was the broker, and Zarah Williamson, lawyer, represented the seller.

In an attempt to reach agreement on the method of producing and marketing the hydroelectric power resources of the Niagara River, Senator Herbert H. Lehman and Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. will confer with Governor Dewey this morning at 10 o'clock in the Governor's suite at the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on Saturday were 769,618 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 10,187 cars, or 1.3 per cent, fewer than in the preceding week; 7,913 cars, or 1.0 per cent, more than in the corresponding week last year, and 42,181 cars, or 5.2 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 28 (AP) -- Hedgewood Fingo stepped down the middle of the track to win the Williston Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 28 -- The Rev. Dr. John Alexander Mackay, president of Princeton Theological Seminary since 1936 and one of this country's best-known religious leaders, was elected moderator of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. today on the first ballot.

TUSCALOOSA Ala., May 28 -- Mrs. Aurora Navarro said here today that she had given to Harold J. Adonis, former clerk in the office of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, one-half the money Adonis needed to build a home for his family in Roseland N. J.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Grains had a choppy price trend today, with evidence of more active absorption on the small reactions but no disposition to follow rallies. Wheat and rye futures registered new lows for the crop year and rye was notably weak on scattered liquidation. Recently rye has lost ground in comparison with other grains especially corn.

NEW DELHI, India, May 28 -- The sacred Buddh Gaya temple in Bihar State, where Gautama Buddha was said to have obtained "enlightment" about 2,500 years ago, was transferred from Hindu to Buddhist ownership today by Hindus who have had custody over Buddhism's holiest shine for centuries.

Following a conference in his City Hall office with American-Italian representatives and clergymen, Mayor Impellitteri yesterday called upon all New Yorkers, especially those of Italian origin, to write to relatives and friends in Italy urging them to vote anti-Communist in national elections there June 7 and 8.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., May 28 (AP) -- The Big Ten formally agreed today to renew the Rose Bowl contract with the Pacific Coast Conference for another three years, but wants a free hand to select its team for each post-season game.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 (UP) -- Marion Fricano pitched five-hit ball today as the Athletics defeated the Red Sox, 6 -- 1, to hand an old nemesis, Mel Parnell, his first defeat of the season after he had won six straight.

DEVON, Pa., May 28 (AP) -- Mrs. Carol Durand of Kansas City suffered minor injuries today when the mount she was riding in the Devon horse show and country fair knocked down an obstacle, fell and turned over.

The legend of Cecil Rhodes' life will be told in a new biography by Andre Maurois, which Macmillan will issue June 16 in its Brief Lives series. "Cecil Rhodes" presents the maturing of the "frail, pertinacious child" to the "vigorous, passionate man--'a Roman Emperor with a moustache.'" The work is translated from the French by Rohan Wadham.

A large tract of land in Jackson Heights, Queens, has been purchased for future development by a syndicate of which John M. Kokkins is treasurer. The Citizens Development, Inc., was the seller and Richard K. Gregory was attorney for the buying group. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

FRANKFURT, Germany, May 28 (AP) -- An American business man asked the United States High Commissioner's office tonight to get him out of jail and to set up a system of legal relief for United States citizens held in "illegal detention by German authorities."

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- President Eisenhower gave the nation his personal assurance today that the proposed cut of $5,000,000,000 in budget requests for the Air Force, below the level asked by President Truman, would leave the United States in a reasonable state of defense.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -The Senate gave quick approval today to a bill extending until July 1, 1955, Government authority to draft physicians, dentists and veterinarians into the armed forces.

NEW DELHI, India, May 28 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru left for London today, carrying with him the hopes of many Indians that his talks with Sir Winston Churchill. Britain's Prime Minister, and other Commonwealth prime ministers after the coronation festivities would help advance many Asian and world problems toward a solution.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., May 28 -- Making her first apearance of the season in women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association play, Gail Wild of the Greenwich Country Club, the association titleholder in 1948, triumphed in today's weekly tourney at the Innis Arden Golf Club.

Six million children ride in school buses every week-day Come summer this number shrinks, but up goes the total of youngsters transported in groups by bus from settlement house or city center to open spaces for day camp activities.

The sixth annual concert of the Composers Group of New York, which took place at Carnegie Recital Hall last evening, began with a shocking, outrageous novelty, a quintet for piano and strings by Eldin Burton.

Plans for a twelve-story apartment building on the upper East Side were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase of 11 to 17 East Eighty-seventh Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues, by a syndicate headed by Armino A. Campagna, builder.

When Mr. Rodgers and Mr. Hammerstein make up their minds what they are writing about, "Me and Juliet," which opened at the Majestic last evening, may turn out to be an enjoyable show. This is their Valentine to show business, expressed in the form of a show-within-a-show; and it has just about everything except an intelligible story.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of the President's tenth news conference today, with his remarks in indirect discourse, as required by White House rules:

The Institute for the Crippled and Disabled presented diplomas to forty-four graduates and certificates of achievement to fifty-three others at the annual graduating exercises yesterday in its auditorium at 400 First Avenue. The total who have now graduated during the thirty-five years of its operation is 30,000, Bruce Barton, president, told the class.

Seasonal repayments, principally by food products manufacturers and commodities dealers, were the principal influences in a decline of $62,000,000 in business borrowings from New York banks in the week ended on Wednesday.

Another prospect has just been added to the expanding agenda of Richard Aldrich and Richard Myers. The former confirmed a report yesterday that contracts were being drawn for his firm to acquire the rights to "Day of the Harvest," Helen Upshaw's novel published last month by Bobbs-Merrill.

HONG KONG, May 28 -- Communist newspapers from Shanghai have reported the breaking up of several "espionage organizations'' operating in eastern China and the arrest of "a large number of Nationalist and American agents."

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., May 28 -- Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of Glen Oaks captured the gross honors in a Women's Cross County Golf Association tournament for the second time this season when she scored a 76 today at the North Hempstead Country Club.

Tuesday -- Coronation Day -- will be a holiday for almost all British Commonwealth security and commodity markets. Some will also take Monday as a holiday, among them the London Rubber Exchange, the London Wool Terminal Market, the Singapore Rubber Market and the Johannesburg Stock Exchange.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 28 -- Nassau County Sheriff H. Alfred Volmer today substituted hamburger for turkey on the county jail's dinner menu for next Thanksgiving when the theft of thirty-five 8-week-old turkeys from the jail farm in East Meadow was reported to his office.

MILAN, Italy, May 28 -- Alfred Ildefonso Cardinal Schuster, Archbishop of Milan, joined many other Roman Catholic Church leaders today in urging the Italians to vote "solidly" at the June 7 national elections for Premier Alcide de Gasperi's Christian Democratic party as the best means to defeat the avowed "enemies of the Church" -- the Communist and left-wing Socialist parties.

In an effort to raise morale among the 38,000 postal employes in Manhattan and the Bronx, Acting Postmaster Harold Riegelman announced yesterday he was seeking permission in Washington to reduce the annual hiring of 18,000 to 20,000 temporary Christmas workers to 10,000, so as to provide more overtime during the season for regular employes.

BONN, Germany, May 28 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today described Senator Taft's speech in Cincinnati Tuesday as "a serious warning to Europe" that the Continent must complete its unification in defense as soon as possible or face the prospect of loss of United States support.

The city's 19,000 policemen and 11,000 firemen will be shifted next month from a forty-five-hour work week to a forty-two-hour week under action taken yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The conversion will involve increasing the two forces by 607 policemen and 420 firemen.

The Empire State Highway Transportation Association has asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to require steamship companies to do their share in ridding our port of "public loaders," the origin of considerable racketeering.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee voted unanimously today to recommend confirmation of President Eisenhower's choices for the new Joint Chiefs of Staff. The Senate is expected to confirm the nominations early next week.
If Queen Elizabeth has failed to reserve a hotel room for Mrs. Louise Cochran, British-American relations are in for a new jolt.

Three new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Destination Gobi," a Twentieth Century-Fok adventure in Technicolor, with Richard Widmark, Don Taylor, Casey Adams and Murvyn Vye, is at the Globe. Stanley Rubin produced and Robert Wise directed, from a screen play by Everett Freeman, based on a story by Edmund G. Love.

ST LOUIS, May 28 -- A 1949 Executive order by former President Harry S. Truman, which prohibits aircraft flights over three roadless areas of Superior National Forest in Minnesota, has been upheld by the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth District.

HOYLAKE, England, May 28 (AP) -- Harvie Ward went on another spree of keen golf today, blasting two opponents from the British amateur championship. The Atlantan went into the quarter-final round by lopsided margins to become the only American in the last eight.

Operations of the Truax-Traer Coal Company and subsidiaries for the year ended on April 30 resulted in a consolidated net income of $2,802,377, equal to $2.21 a common share, it was announced yesterday. This compares with $3,346,838, or $2.95 a share, in the previous fiscal year.

Chester Bowles, former United States Ambassador to India and Nepal, told the India League of America last night that to weaken American defenses now would be "the worst kind of folly" and that war with Communist China would be "stupid" and of benefit only to the Soviet Union.

A Jordanian lawyer said yesterday "the Arabs have almost completely lost faith in justice from the West" and asserted communism was spreading rapidly through the Middle East in the wake of "Zionist ambitions" and of the unsettled question of Arab Palestine refugees.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- The International Harvester Company notified its 75,000 employes today that a 2-cent hourly wage reduction would become effective Monday and that the company would not agree to grant interim union contract concessions, as has been done by General Motors, Ford and Chrysler in the automobile industry.

Dr. Leonard Greenburg, Commissioner of Air Pollution Control, announced yesterday the appointment of five prominent engineers to serve his department in an advisory capacity and at the same time the Board of Estimate appropriated funds to augment his staff by nineteen and equip an air pollution laboratory.

CINCINNATI, May 28 (UP) -- A two-run single by Jim Greengrass in the tenth inning tonight gave the seldom-victorious Redlegs a 10-10 tie with St. Louis in a game halted by agreement so the Cardinals could make a train connection.

The Gotham Hosiery Company has leased the second floor in the old Tiffany Building at 401 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of East Thirty-seventh Street, and will move there from 200 Madison Avenue. The lease is for ten years and involves an aggregate rental of about $800,000.
PITTSBURGH, May 28 (AP) -- Jim Konstanty, the Phillies' 36-year-old right-hander, survived three big Pirate uprisings today but managed to wabble to a 9-8 triumph for his fourth victory of the year.

VIENNA, May 28 -- The New Austrian coalition government, like its predecessor, is finding it difficult to reconcile Socialist and conservative differences about economic policy. These differences found expression today in a question addressed to the Government by a number of Socialist members of parliament as to why counterpart funds were not being released to cure unemployment.
Your edition of May 24 carried the news of the death of Alberto Carnevali. This is sad news indeed.

The New York City Transit Authority agreed yesterday to extensive modifications of the terms of a proposed ten-year lease to it of the deficit-ridden city-owned transit system and thereby made probable the approval of the agreement by a majority vote of the Board of Estimate.

The transportation of cargo by air is becoming a major factor in the business of flying planes about the United States and the world, and one of the experts in the industry predicted yesterday that, within the next ten years, the airlines would be earning "at least as much in cargo revenues as they now earn from passenger revenues."

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Department store sales in the week ended May 23 were 8 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 28 -- Mixed reactions from governments of highly developed countries toward a proposal for establishing an international finance corporation to provide long-term aid for underdeveloped areas were described in a report, released today, from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to the Economic and Social Council.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- North American Air Lines announced today the first commercial flight in the United States using passenger seats facing to the rear.

LONDON, May 28 (AP) -- Miss Enid Margaret Cripps, youngest daughter of the late Sir Stafford Cripps, and Joseph Appiah, son of a Gold Coast Negro tribal leader, announced today that they would be married.

Store sales of Frigidaire appliances throughout the country from May 18 through May 23 totaled $24,750,000, Herman F. Lehman, general sales manager of the Frigidaire division, General Motors Corporation, reported yesterday. He said this was the biggest week in history for Frigidaire dealers and that it was marked by a recordbreaking day on May 22 when sales exceeded $9,500,000.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The main points of President Eisenhower's news conference were as follows:

" Your Big Moment" is the title of a new television program enjoying the services of Melvyn Douglas, who should be the last man to dispute the accuracy of the program's identification. It's certainly not his moment.

Edwin C. McDonald has been appointed vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in charge of group insurance activities, effective June 15. He succeeds Alexander C. Campbell who is retiring.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- A physical examination of Henry W. Grunewald, the Washington "mystery man" who has pleaded guilty to contempt of Congress, to determine if imprisonment would endanger his life or health, was ordered today by Judge Alexander Holtzoff in Federal District Court. He will be examined by a heart specialist.

Continued growth by the Roman Catholic Church in many fields of activity in this country and its possessions during the last year was reported in the Official Catholic Directory for 1953, published yesterday by P. J. Kenedy. Sons.

Lulu Perez, 20-year-old Brooklyn featherweight, will make his first main-bout appearance in Madison Square Garden tonight when he opposes Glen Flanagan of St. Paul, Minn., in a scheduled ten-round fight to be broadcast on nation-wide radio and television hook-ups.

The Senate vote approving by a wide margin President Eisenhower's plan for the Department of Agriculture should give the Administration encouragement to come forward with additional badly needed reorganization proposals. Time is now an important factor, for a plan submitted to Congress can only become effective sixty days after its presentation, provided that neither house turns it down and that Congress is still in session at the end of the two-month period.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Christache Zambeti, Rumanian diplomat, today denounced as a "frame-up" his ouster from this country on charges of trying to blackmail a United States citizen into spying for the Communists.

Much greater emphasis is needed in this country on the advantages of private investment over government-to-government aid in strengthening Western Europe economically, it was declared yesterday by Walter Hoving, president of Lord Taylor, on his return from a two-month business trip abroad.

CAPETOWN. South Africa, May 28 -- Some speculation has been aroused here by a sentence in an editorial in Die Burger the Nationalist newspaper which might suggest that Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan may have some constitutional point to put to the Commonwealth Prime Ministers' conference in London next week.

ASHLAND, Va., May 28 -- President J. Earl Moreland, addressing the staff and students of Randolph-Macon College in its new auditorium, said today that man's right to knowledge was confronted by a "two-fold danger": communism from without and another "from within ourselves."

The negotiating committee of the National Maritime Union, C. L. O., walked out of a meeting with Atlantic and Gulf Coast shipowners yesterday, charging that the operators had refused to bargain for a new contract in good faith.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 (AP) -- William M. Leader, president of Branch One American Federation of Hosiery Workers, A. F. L., appealed to President Eisenhower today by letter to save the American hosiery industry from wholesale unemployment and idle mills by restricting importations.

The Real Estate Board of the Bronx announced yesterday that it had sent a resolution to the four Congressmen from that borough and to Senators Herbert H. Lehman and Irving M. Ives expressing opposition to the building of any additional residential units by any city, state or Federal agency.
LONDON, May 28 (AP) -- Experts have decided on the make-up for Queen Elizabeth II on Coronation Day, thus settling a cosmetic problem that got headlines in some newspapers here.
SEOUL, Korea, Friday, May 29 (AP) -- About 11,000 Chinese Red troops were reported engaged in the west-front attack.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Taking their cue from President Eisenhower, United States officials exercised caution today in appraising the Soviet Union's military-to-civilian change-over in East Germany.

The Welfare and Health Council of New York City voted yesterday to admit the Planned Parenthood Committee of Mothers Health Centers as a member in spite of announcements by Roman Catholic agencies that they would resign rather than cooperate with any group advocating birth control.
The hours the Bronx and Brooklyn blood donor centers are open will be reduced during the summer months, the Red Cross announced yesterday. The new schedules become effective on June 1.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active and steady yesterday, closing with gains of 4 to 8 points.

ROME, May 28 -- Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce moved to the center of the political stage today when she warned the Italians by implication that United States aid would be cut off if Italy should become the victim of either Left-wing or Right-wing totalitarianism.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Senator John Sherman Cooper, Republican of Kentucky, a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, today told a luncheon meeting of the General Federation of Women's Clubs that this country "should not allow sudden resentment to turn us against the United Nations."

ALPINE, N. J., May 28 -- The first five-mile section of the $46,000,000 Palisades Interstate Parkway. which has the first intensive application of modern split-level highway design, will be opened on Saturday, Memorial Day.

The Tammany executive committee cut the number of its cumbersome Democratic County Committee members from 11,762 to 3,471 members yesterday, acting four months in advance of the deadline set by a new state law enacted to further election reforms.

THE week-end angling prospects seem very bright at the moment, and even the weather man seems in a pleasant mood, so those planning a venture to the distant trout streams and near-by salt waters may regard the situation with some optimism.

The annual report of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., for 1952, released yesterday, showed a continued growth in the business of its Latin American subsidiaries. Consolidated net income rose to $15,454,755, compared with $14,213,310 in the previous year.

When new ways are found to win ball games, the Dodgers undoubtedly will discover them. Their ninth - inning triumph over the Giants on Wednesday night was dramatic and unexpected enough, but yesterday afternoon in the tenth inning the Brooks scored the winning run on a catcher's error, a wild pitch and a passed ball. The final score of 7 -- 6 sent most of the 17,219 fans (11,219 paid) home happy.

LONDON, May 28 -- The problem of milady's beauty on the morning of June 2 is one that has occupied the minds of many experts for many months. First of all, her hair and complexion must be taken care of before the sun has risen very high in its orbit.

BUENOS AIRES, May 28 -- An amateur boxing team from the United States last night finally injected some goodwill into Argentine-American relations. The United States squad dropped four of five bouts by decisions in its opening encounter against Argentine boxers.

BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, May 28 (Reuters) -- The Rev. Michael Scott, British missionary who has spent a lifetime crusading for "African rights" and who has recently been fighting the proposed Central African Federation. was deported today by colonial authorities.

LONDON, May 28 -- Queen Elizabeth II entertained 7,000 guests today at Buckingham Palace at a pre-coronation garden party where turbaned Oriental Sultans and other satraps of the Empire mingled with men in the uniforms of all the countries of the Commonwealth.

Alfred Kohlberg, national chairman of the American Jewish League Against Communism Inc., took issue yesterday with opinions expressed on Wednesday by Samuel Markle and Rabbi Arthur Lelyveld, both leaders of B'nai B'rith, deploring "witch hunts" in American colleges.
The value of the electronic devices that United States fighter planes are equipped with was praised yesterday by two of the best men qualified to testify on the subject.

ST. LOUIS, May 28 (AP) -- Marty Furgol, a former champion, and Freddie Haas, who plays only the major tournaments these days, toured Bellerive Country's Club's demanding course today with 2-under-par 68's for the first round lead in the fiftieth Western open golf tournament.
ST. LOUIS, May 28 (UP) -- Bob Elliott's grand-slam home run gave the Browns a 7-5 victory over the Indians tonight and a sweep of their two-game series.

Raymond Baudouin, general secretary of the French Wine Academy, who has created some world famous wine cellars, has returned to the United States on his second visit. He gave his views yesterday on vintages, wine-tasting, American gastronomy and allied topics.

Mrs. Else F. Schlemmer has sold the controlling interest in Hammacher, Schlmemer Co., housewares, gift and hardware store at 145 East Fifty-seventh Street, it was announced yesterday. Henry Willard Broido, a merchandise manager of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., has been elected president and a director of the company and will assume his duties as chief executive officer of the store on June 6.

Two years ago this month a newly effective paragraph in the Uniform Code of Military Justice gave the armed services power to arrest and try by courts-martial former members of such services who were charged with an offense against the code "punishable by confinement of five years or more" and who could not "be tried in the courts of the United States or any state or territory thereof."

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The White House announced today the itinerary of a crowded five-day trip starting June 10 that will take President Eisenhower to Minneapolis, the Dakotas, New Hampshire and New York.

QUITO, Ecuador, May 22 -- A little-publicized, hazardous airlift flown by the United States Air Force to combat the ravages of Ecuador's heaviest rains in thirty years has won a reserve of friendship for the United States in this country.

A 28-year-old sales trainee for an underwear manufacturer, who had been president of Brown University's class of '48 was arrested yesterday after an elaborate but unsuccessful attempt to hold up a midtown restaurant on his lunch hour.

IN 1924 I was old enough so that I should have known better than be taken in by the phony dramatics of "Beau Geste," a ludicrously bad novel by Percival Christopher Wren about English gentlemen serving in the French Foreign Legion. But along with several hundred thousand other delighted readers I enjoyed that synthetic tale immensely.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Department of Agriculture was "happy to make the sale" of 80,000 tons of surplus Austrian winter peas at a price $60 below their cost because they were deteriorating and costing the taxpayers $40,000 a month in storage charges, John H. Davis, president of the Commodity Credit Corporation, said today.

The Parker Pen Company is planning a strong back-to-school fall promotion on its new electropolished point fountain pens. The company has developed, by use of chemicals, a smoother point for its pens than was possible under the old method of grinding, it was said yesterday by Dr. D. R. Dayhoff, Eastern sales manager.

PARIS, May 28 -- The first group of the United States Army's new atomic artillery battalions will be sent to Europe for duty with American elements of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces toward the end of this year and in the beginning of next year, it has become known here.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today it had suspe.nded the trading privileges of eleven Chicago livestock dealers for bribing weighmasters to pad weights in 1950.
America's dead of all wars will be honored today and tomorrow with parades, patriotic oratory and prayers for peace in traditional Memorial Day observances.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 28 (AP) -- High company and union officials conferred today on the fifty-two-day-old strike at General Electric Company plants where band music and singing brightened picket lines as salaried employes went to work.
Little Neil, her grandfather and the shop in Charles Dickens novel. "The Old Curiosity Shop," appear in the decoration on pieces in a new dinnerware collection at Altman's.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 28 -- C. S. Brinsfield of Baltimore, chief of the division of food control for Maryland, today was elected president of the Central Atlantic States Association of Food and Drug Officials at its thirty-seventh annual meeting.

WHEN New York's official Father Knickerbocker took on the assignment four years ago this month, he didn't know the work he'd be put to in 1953, the city's 300th anniversary. Having made one of his major appearances this week at the 150th anniversary of the City Hall cornerstone laying, he pantingly looks forward to an imposing schedule that calls for repeated appearances in his Father Knickerbocker outfit.

One robbery, suspect was killed and three others were captured yesterday in a pistol battle during which thirty shots were fired in a three-mile chase through the East Bronx. The suspects allegedly had held up a restaurant owner and had fled with $5,000 in cash.

HARTFORD, Conn, May 28 -- The white man's government and the white man's business may soon be thrown out of much of Africa, acording to Professor William E. Welmers of the Division of Modern Languages of Cornell University. In order to spare Christian teaching from the same fate he urged fuller understanding of African languages on the part of missionaries.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, called today for a Senate investigation of KaiserFrazer's purchase of Willys-Overland Motors. He said the Government "is the loser by several million dollars" in the deal.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 28 -- In a plea for man to gain the same mastery of himself that he has achieved over the natural energies, Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, declared today that too many minds stopped growing in youth.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -President Eisenhower said today he opposed the "Prussian" concept of a single military staff and had no intention of creating one Chief of Staff to head all the armed services.

Whitey Ford, regaining his touch after a couple of fruitless outings, paced the Yankees to a 7-2 victory over the Senators yesterday with a five-hit pitching job, some nimble base-running and a bases-loaded single that was the key blow of the Bombers' decisive five-run rally in the sixth inning.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- A Federal grand jury began questioning witnesses and poring over the payroll accounts of Representative Ernest K. Bramblett today in search of alleged irregularities.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- President Eisenhower differed publicly today with Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio on how to negotiate peace in Korea, but there was no indication that this marked the beginning of a test of strength between the President and his Senate majority leader over the conduct of United States foreign policy.

When George Munger became the Penn football coach in 1938, the alumni watched him with amused interest that occasionally bordered on cynical contempt. They take their football seriously in the vicinity of Franklin Field and Munger gave them a be wildered, frustrated feeling.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Senator Taft, in the hospital at Cincinnati, was quoted by friends today as surprised that his speech on foreign policy to an inter-creed conference on the night of May 26 made so great a stir in Administration circles and in the chancelleries of the world.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- A House Armed Services subcommittee reported today that the Government spent about $2,000,000, yearly testing military tires that had been or could be tested by their manufacturers.

LONDON, May 28 -- A large London audience was introduced tonight by Prince Littler at the Coliseum to a strange assortment of Broadway characters invented by Damon Runyon and brought to life in "Guys and Dolls."

Notwithstanding his eloquent plea that he had failed to answer fifty-four traffic tickets because he was poverty-stricken, Robert S. Rubin, 55 years old, was fined $2,700 yesterday by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh.

NEWARK, May 28 -- Representatives of 6,000 brewery employes in three American Federation of Labor locals requested the New Jersey Brewers Association today to submit for consideration tomorrow a delivery plan for drivers as a key step toward settling a strike that started last Friday.

The proper time to make resolutions, it would seem, is the season when nature is renewing itself -- just about now. Making them at the end of the calendar year, which point is a rather arbitrary demarcation, doesn't appear to be quite in tune with the cosmic order of things.

President Eisenhower said a good word for compromise at his press conference yesterday, but not for the kind of compromise that could reconcile his views on foreign policy with those expressed by Senator Taft at Cincinnati on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Confirmation by the State Department that it had evidence that two vessels owned by British companies had transported Communist troops along the Red China coast in 1951 and 1952 was disclosed today by the Senate Investigating subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- A detailed plan linking Federal and State facilities in a program for the compulsory treatment of narcotic addicts was drafted today by the Narcotic Drug Control Committee of the National Association of Attorneys General meeting here.

News of two Government contracts awarded this week makes heartening reading for those who understand the great importance today of fair trade practice among the nations of the free world. A British electrical manufacturing firm was the low bidder on, and has been awarded the contract for, building transformers for a dam being constructed by our Army engineers in the Pacific Northwest.

SEOUL, Korea, May 28 -- South Korea informed the United Nations truce delegation today that it considered the most recent Allied proposal for a settlement of the prisoner-of-war issue a complete surrender to the Communists on their demand for forced repatriation of all captives.
The letter of Paul Ross in THE TIMES of May 23 made sense until he spoke of "cleansing McCarthyism from the bloodstream of American life and especially from the life of our city."

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York, who has been advising the President on Government organization, received a new opportunity today to show his talents as an administrator. President Eisenhower nominated him to be Under Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Dr. Helen Markham, Harvard Medical School professor, refused to tell Senate investigators today whether she recently had told university authorities that she was not now and never had been a Communist.

PARIS, May 28 (UP) -- Vic Seixas, United States No. 2 ranking player, gained the men's singles final of the French tennis tournament today as Maureen Connolly, San Diego, Calif., and Doris Hart, Coral Gables, Fla., advanced to the women's singles final.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges were irregularly lower yesterday with volume easing from Wednesday's improved activity except in cocoa, world sugar and tin. Tin, zinc, lead, coffee and rubber closed lower. Cocoa closed higher.
LONDON, May 28 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Moscow announcement on East Germany today, as translated from the Russian:
LONDON, May 28 -- The stock markets were cautious today and prices fell following the setback in Wall Street yesterday. British Government securities were an exception and prices continued to rise.

Stuart Denton Morris, British pacifist detained at Ellis Island since May 15 under terms of the McCarran Act, was released yesterday when the Board of Immigration Appeals in Washington overruled a finding that he was an inadmissible alien.
Orleans Parish, La., will open bids on June 23 for $10,000,000 of school bonds dated May 1, 1953, to mature from Nov. 1, 1955 to 1992. Bids are not to exceed 4's.

The fourteenth president of Columbia University, which is soon to confer its 200,000th degree, received yesterday a long-missing psalter used by its first president to solemnize the graduation of the first seven Bachelor's candidates 195 years ago.

PARIS, May 28 -- Pierre Mendes-France a vigorous-minded Radical deputy who is the representative of France on the International Monetary Fund, was called today to try to form a new French Cabinet in the difficult situation caused by the failure early today of Paul Reynaud, wartime Premier.

TRENTON, May 28 -- Harold J. Adonis was quoted here today as denying the bribery charges contained in his indictment and of accusing John J. Dickerson, former New Jersey Republican state chairman of "deliberating fabricating" when he declared that Willie Moretti, slain gambler, had told him that Adonis had been paid $228,000 in protection money by syndicate gamblers.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 28 -- The new Constitution, already approved by Parliament, was ratified today in a plebiscite by a bare 1 per cent above the minimum required for ratification. It won the approval of roughly 46 per cent of the electorate.

The city's 3,000 Turks will toast with "lion's milk" today the memory of Mehmet II, the Turkish Sultan who 500 years ago conquered Constantinople (now Istanbul) and thus ended Rome's domination over the Byzantine Empire.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, said today after a closed meeting with National Labor Relations Board officials that steps had been taken to prevent a "Communist dominated" union from representing New York Western Union workers.

It was encouraging to read in THE NEW YORK TIMES that the debate on the Status of Women at the Women Lawyers Association the other night was good-natured, but it would have been gratifying to have had a more generous sprinkling of logic from the "male lawyers and politicians" who argued that "citizenlike acts" would help more than a constitutional amendment.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- A major overhaul of the Federal Government's far-flung tax collection machinery was announced today by George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, as part of a plan for more vigorous enforcement of internal revenue laws.

BONN, Germany, May 28 -- Vladimir Semyenov was named High Commissioner for East Germany today in a surprising reorganization of the Soviet Union's control structure believed to be tied to Russian moves on Germany's reunification.

Montadet, owned by John M. Schiff and ridden by Flint Schulhofer. was the decisive winner of the Belmont Spring Maiden Steeplechase yesterday. While a crowd of 17,762 looked on at Belmont Park, the 5-year-old gelding fenced competently and moved on the flat with enough speed to capture first place by more than three lengths.

Dr. Oliver C. Carmichael's resignation as president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, to become president of the University of Alabama next fall, means that New York will be losing a highly useful citizen. The loss to the foundation, which he has led since 1946 through numerous studies and activities contributing to educational advance, is evident.

Stock prices broke yesterday for the fifth session in a row, penetrated the May low and closed about where they were on April 27. Volume, however, remained small, only 1,240,000 shares, against 1,330,000 on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- A full-scale investigation of the Securities and Exchange Commission is in prospect as a result of "numerous" complaints both from individuals and corporations about the agency's operations, Representative George H. Bender, Republican of Ohio, said today. Mr. Bender is chairman of the subcommittee on public accounts of the Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee.

The medical prescription for a healthy and happy old age must include a little well-regulated "vice," one doctor reported here yesterday at the opening of the tenth annual meetings of the American Geriatrics Society.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The National Civil Service League submitted to President Eisenhower today recommendations for improving the efficiency and morale of Federal employes.
I refer to the editorial "Niagara Falls Power" which appeared on May 23, and to your opinion stated therein, "that the power should be developed by the New York State Power Authority."

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Representative Daniel A. Reed, chairman of the House Mays and Means Committee, renewed his fight for immediate tax reduction today with a demand for an additional cut of $2,000,000,000 in foreign aid outlays.

NEW DELHI, India, May 28 -- Mount Everest's icy defenses have driven back two more attempts to scale the world's highest peak, according to reports tonight from Nepal, tiny Himalayan kingdom that shares the unconquered 29,002-foot summit with Communist-ruled Tibet.
TRIPOLI, Libya, May 28 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, conferred with Libyan leaders today, winding up his tour of the restless Middle East and South Asia.

SFAX, Tunisia, May 20 -- A new impetus has been given to oil prospecting in Tunisia as a matter of urgent policy for oil is held by many to represent Tunisia's last chance for economic betterment, perhaps even for economic survival.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 28 -- The Connecticut General Assembly, pressing to adjourn tomorrow night, agreed late today on a tax program to avert a fiscal crisis. The legislators approved a series of tax increases to yield about $46,700,000 in additional revenue in the next two years.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- King Paul and Queen Frederika of Greece have been invited to visit the United States this fall, the White House announced today.

I am surprised to read those who believe that the retirement of Senator McCarthy will alter the political picture. His retirement will no more diminish the degree of national hysteria than the death of Stalin diminished the threat of Communist aggression.

Voice of America officials decided yesterday to continue 17- year-old Billy Brown's broadcasts to Pakistan, even though their popularity, does raise financial problems. However, announcement of the decision contained the observation that reductions had been made recently in the Federal funds for Voice operations. It added:

ALBANY, May 28 -- The Court of Appeals upheld today the banning of the French motion picture, "La Ronde," by the State Board Regents on the grounds that the film was "immoral" and "would tend to corrupt morals." Two of the six participating judges dissented.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 28 -- Mario Lanza's movie career, interrupted by a dispute over "The Student Prince" that led to the recent termination of his contract with Metro, may be resumed under the auspices of Columbia Pictures. Preliminary talks between the singer's representatives and Columbia have started, it was learned today, although the studio declined to make any comment.

ST. LOUIS, May 29 (AP) -- The Cardinals climbed to within one-half game of first-place Milwaukee today as they scored ten runs in the fourth inning and then held off a home-run attack of the Braves to win, 11-7. The Red Birds retained a 7-point lead over the Dodgers, who also won.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 -- The administration of Federal justice in this area, especially in connection with tax scandals and their resultant prosecutions, was put under scrutiny today by a House Judiciary subcommittee headed by Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of upstate New York.
Memorial Day The few United States security and commodity markets that ordinarily are open on Saturdays will be closed today for the Memorial Day holiday.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement issued by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles today after he and Mutual Secretary Director Harold E. Stassen reported to President Eisenhower on their trip abroad:

THIS week-end may see the first good striped bass fishing of the season at Cape Cod, and reports just received indicate that large schools of fish have been spotted just off the beach at Race Point and other areas along the Cape.

PARIS, May 29 -- Pierre Mendes- France agreed today to try to form a government to deal with the developing financial crisis that threatens the ability of the French state to meet its foreign and domestic obligations.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) -- The Treasury announced tonight it has borrowed $800,064,000 by letting certain taxpayers -- mostly corporations and banks -- pay their Sept. 15 tax installments in advance at a discount.

DETROIT, May 29 (AP) -- Pinchhitter Dick Kokos and the winning pitcher, Harry Brecheen, two late entries in the game, each slammed two-run singles as the Erowns erupted for six runs in the eleventh inning today to whip the Tigers, 11 -- 5.

The seventy-nine accredited medical schools in this country are in a perilous financial condition. Tuition, already increased 65 per cent over 1940, pays only one-fifth of the cost incurred by the schools. The remainder must come from other sources of revenue, with the result that the expense of medical training represents as much as 40 per cent of university budgets.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 29 -- A record fleet of forty-four cruising yachts headed out from Flat Neck Point, off the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, early this evening, under cloudy skies, as the eighth annual Storm Trysail Club race to Block Island and back to Port Jefferson got under way.

As the Russians no doubt anticipated in planning the move, their decision to substitute nominal civilian for direct military control over the Soviet zone of Germany has stirred much interest and speculation. General Chuikov has been demoted to a purely military capacity as head of Soviet occupation troops, and Vladimir Semyenov, who was the General's political adviser until his recall to Moscow last month, is now the "Supreme Commissar" of East Germany.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 29 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is working on a new approach to the "Grand Hotel" formula, which went over so well at the box office in 1932 with a star-studded cast. This time the studio will do it with music, and the Imperial Hotel in Tokyo will be the scene for a series of comedy situations.

Patrolman Paul Creighton of the Twenty-second Precinct testified yesterday at his departmental tidal that he was innocent of the charge that he had deliberately fired his service revolver at a man during an altercation Aug. 16, 1952. He said that the man, Anthony Arroya of 28 West Ninety-seventh Street, had thrown a piece of wood at him as he (the patrolman) was drawing his pistol and that the wood had struck his arm.

Emil yon Elling, track and field coach at N. Y. U. for the last forty years, last night was honored at a testimonial dinner by the Violet's Spiked Shoe Club at the Prince George Hotel. Past and present athletes under Von Elling joined with sports notables in paying tribute to the "grand old man of track."

ROME, May 29 -- Hard upon the heels of her speech in Milan yesterday Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce delivered another in Genoa today in which she again emphasized the danger of Russian aggression against the free world and broke a lance in favor of lowering trade barriers everywhere but especially in the United States.

The National Committee on Indian Health called yesterday for the transfer of medical services among reservation Indians from the Bureau of Indian Affairs in the Department of the Interior to the United States Public Health Service.
CHICAGO, May 29 (AP) -- Home runs by Dale Mitchell and Al Rosen were enough for Mike Garcia tonight as the Indians' hurler gained a 2-1 victory over the White Sox.

Apparently still suffering from shock in the wake of the horrendous misadventures that befell them in Brooklyn the two previous days, the Giants returned to the Polo Grounds yesterday and forthwith performed like so many men moving in a trance.

SEOUL, Korea, May 29 -- The campaign of the Republic of Korea Government against the United Nations' current proposal for an armistice has reached such an open stage that the coun try's acting Premier, Pyun Yun Tae, outlined today two steps to be taken by his Government if a truce agreement should be reached under the present terms.

DEVON, Pa., May 29 (AP) -- Tanahmerah, owned by Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Charles B. Lyman of West Chester, Pa., today retired the challenge trophy for working hunters and jumpers at the Devon Horse Show and Country Fair.

DENVER, May 29 -- One of fifteen students who criticized the administration of the Military Intelligence School at Lowry Air Force Base here has been recalled to his Marine station, Brig. Gen. John T. Sprague, base commander, said today.

Quality in furnishings and simplicity in their arrangement are the most important factors in decorating a home on a budget, according to Mrs. George Goldstein, an amateur decorator who has just completed furnishing a model home which will be opened to the public on Sunday in Freeport, L. I.

BONN, Germany, May 29 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, on behalf of the West German Government, has decided to warn President Eisenhower that any announcement of a Western Allied meeting with the Soviet Union would seriously impair and might even completely wreck the prospects for the proposed European army.

Joseph J. Whalen has purchased the two-family semi-detached house at 97-34 Sixty-fourth Avenue in Forest Hills, Queens, from John Monaghan. Trylon Realty, broker in this transaction, also reported the sale of the attached house at 67-51 198th Street, Flushing, for Benjamin Laye to Ralph Malisdorf.

The Voice of America warned the Communist government of Rumania yesterday that the fate of two teen-age boys was "the sacred trust of all the people of Rumania." Their father had refused to save them from detention behind the Iron Curtain by spying against the United States.

Years of work by medical scientists attempting to develop a machine to take over the work of the human heart and lungs in emergencies are beginning to pay off, it was suggested here yesterday at the nineteenth annual meeting of the American College of Chest Physicians at the New Yorker Hotel.

MOSCOW, May 29 -- The State of Israel is described in the latest volume of the new Soviet Encyclopedia as a nation dominated by United States and English capitalists and monopolists operating in collusion with "the powerful Zionist bourgeoisie" and which rapidly is becoming America's Middle Eastern arms base.

Plans for erecting four two-family dwellings in the Bronx was announced yesterday in connection with the purchase by the Di Croce Building Corporation of property at the southwest corner of Rosedale Avenue and 172d Street from the Estate of Alex Wein.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Retail sales continued to gain momentum this month and by the end of the third week stood at 7 per cent above the levels prevailing a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today in its monthly summary of business conditions. The improvement was in spite of a leveling off of industrial production noticeable in April and May.

The proposals of Senator Bricker and of the American Bar Association to amend the Constitution of the United States in respect of treaties and Executive agreements raise great questions of constitutional law, and not, as appears to be the thinking of the distinguished Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles, questions of temporary State Department policy.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman and Representative Franklin D. Roosesevelt Jr. had a three-hour conference yesterday with Governor Dewey in his suite in the Roosevelt Hotel on the proposed development of the hydroelectric resources of the Niagara River.
The median salary of the professional engineer in private employment in this city is $9,000 a year. His average age is 45 1/2.

TOKYO, May 24 -- Communist China, after eighteen months of costly warfare in Korea, may be approaching exhaustion of its available military potential, some well-informed Japanese sources are inclined to believe.

JERSEY CITY, May 29 -- Superior Court Judge Joseph L. Smith today threw out a suit by former Representative Elmer Wene, in which Mr. Wene, a defeated candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor in the April 21 primary election, sought to have the nomination of his opponent former State Senator Robert B. Meyner, set aside.
BERLIN, May 29 -- During the last four days the flow of refugees into West Berlin has set an all-time record, doubling the daily influx of recent weeks.

Without the help of a group of enterprising mothers, the formation of an unusual forty-five piece children's orchestra at the Downtown Community School might not have been possible. The orchestra presented its first formal concert Thursday night at the school.

ATLANTIC CITY, May, 29 -- Harry, (Cherry) Haggerty, resort gaming figure and ousted business agent of the local bartenders union, was found dead this afternoon in a car on Highland Boulevard in near-by Absecon.

When the liner Flanore docked Thursday, she had in her cargo seventy-five tons of Roquefort cheese, which, unloaded yesterday, is expected in retail shops next week. The new shipment should do much to overcome the scarcity of the cheese which has existed in varying degree for the last six months.
A 6-year-old boy, bitten by a dog yesterday while his schoolmates were buying candy for his going-away party, faces a painful series of rabies inoculations unless the owner of the dog is found today.
FRANKFURT, Germany, May 29 (AP) -- The highest United States court in Germany ruled today it had no power to intervene when an American was held without bail in a German jail.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., May 29 -- Because of objections made by several unidentified persons to the salty language used in "Mr. Roberts," prize-winning comedy that ran for more than three years on Broadway, the presentation of the play at this base has been canceled.

MASSENA, N. Y., May 29 -- Construction of the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway would more seriously hurt the New York Central Railroad than any other company or any other railroad in the United States, according to William White, president of the Central.

For the fourth time, Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman fixed a date yesterday for the execution of the death sentences of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, condemned atom spies. He set the week of June 15 for them to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing prison.
ATHENS, May 29 -- 1were held throughout Greece today commemorating the fall of Constantinople.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 29 -- Princess Margrethe, 13-year-old heir to Denmark's throne following ratification of the country's revamped constitution which makes female succession possible, got today off from school so she could be with her father, King Frederik, when Premier Erik Eriksen called to tell him the ratification news formally.

LONDON, May 29 -- The stock markets improved slightly today despite further contraction in business. British Government securities continued to improve and some industrial leaders gained one shilling (14 cents) or more.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 29 -- No longer will friends of Ernest H. Watson, past president of the State Bankers Association, be able chide him for being the bank president who cannot get into one of his own banks.

The Senate Appropriations Committee has approved a rider that would, in effect, take the United States out of the United Nations if Red China were taken in. At his press conference on Thursday President Eisenhower, having made it plain that he was firmly opposed to the admission of Red China under existing circumstances, said that the committee's proposal seemed very drastic. This is, if anything, an understatement.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- N. R. Danielian, president of the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Association, asserted today a "definite plot" exists "to delay and if possible prevent" the House from considering a bill to authorize United States participation in the St. Lawrence Seaway.

The opposition to the proposed decision of Traffic Commissioner Wiley to eliminate the present one-hour parking restriction, as presented by John F. McDonald in the Letters to THE TIMES on May 12, is typical of the attitude of part of our citizenry which is primarily the cause of the middle-class exodus from the city.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Bell system telephone companies today filed with the Federal Communications Commission proposals to increase interstate rates for teletypewriter exchange (TWX) service by about $8,000,000 a year and to revise interstate rates for teletypewriter private line services.
TOKYO, Saturday, May 30 (AP) -- Eighth Army communique 1,347, covering Thursday's activities:

Lulu Perez of Brooklyn out-pointed Glen Flanagan, St. Paul campaigner, in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. Although the fight was a close one, the verdict was unanimous, and met with the approval of the 3,171 fans on hand.

Elliott Murphy, who since 1945 has never failed to keep his seasonal franchise on water shows at the amphitheatre in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens, sends along the intelligence that the 1953 edition of his "Aquashow" will open at the site of the former World's Fair on Tuesday evening, June 23.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- A Federal Power Commission hearing on applications to build natural gas pipelines in the Rocky Mountain and Pacific Northwest areas today was recessed until June 8.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 29 -- Donald G. Fuqua, letter winner in football and track during the past three seasons, was honored in absentia at the annual athletic review of the United States Corps of Cadets as June Week activities opened here today. Fuqua's participation in the IC-4-A track at Randall's Island, New York City, with the Army team prevented his attendance at the parade.
CINCINNATI, May 29 (AP) -- Ted Kluszewski's eleventh home run of the season topped a three-run eighth-inning rally today that gave the Redlegs a 6 -- 3 victory over the Cubs and Pitcher Paul Minner.
