New financing rose substantially in May. More than a billion dollars worth of new bonds were offered publicly here and stock flotations were the biggest since March.

CHATTANOOGA, May 29 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority has reported that its research activities in the development of better and cheaper chemical fertilizers had enabled private industry in that field to expand production and distribution facilities greatly.

Once each week the cook winds up and throws herself into a most fantastic ritual. With a pencil stub and a scrap of paper she sets down what she fondly believes will be the list of menus for that week. A glance at her expression proves, as it indeed is meant to prove, that this paper work is not lightly undertaken, that into it go the results of a major concentration.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) -- Representative Daniel A. Reed, Republican of upstate New York, already fighting the Administration's tax and trade policies, said today he was "disappointed" with the way Treasury officials went about reorganizing the Internal Revenue Bureau.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- A three-man Army review board, studying the case of a censor who refused to be censored, confessed itself somewhat confused today by Army censorship rules The board heard arguments for and against an appeal by Lieut. Col. Melvin B. Voorhees, who used to be chief censor for the Eighth Army in Korea, and before that edited The Tacoma Wash., Times.
" This," said a jockey at Belmont Park yesterday, "should be a real horse race."
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Average primary market prices decreased 0.1 per cent to 109.8 in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Today's observation of a national holiday in honor of our war dead has grown from a limited and localized group of ceremonies to a broad institution. Its significance has increased as our war dead have increased. The burden of memory that we bear grows progressively heavier.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 29 (AP) -- Ankaway scored a wire-to-wire victory tonight in the Hempstead Pace, the feature at Roosevelt Raceway. The 7-year-old side-wheeler, owned by Dr. I. Ben Rubin of Charlton, N. Y., was driven by Billy Haughton to a nose triumph over Garrison Hanover, with Scotch Spencer another nose away.

In an effort to aid its depositors to obtain more business the Central National Bank of Yonkers sponsor a series of forums on retail salesmanship next month in the Yonkers Jewish Community Center, 122 South Boardway.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Two Government departments gave dismissal notices to 2,500 employes today.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, has promised complete legal protection for Robert W. Toth, former Air Force sergeant recently returned to Korea for possible trial for murder of a civilian. The promise was in a letter made public today by Senator James H. Duff, Republican of Pennsylvania.

ALBANY, May 29 -- New York City took its challenge of the Transit Authority Law to the state's highest court today, charging that the controversial legislation was "the most drastic invasion of municipal self-government in the long struggle for home rule."

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Secretary of Defense, Charles E. Wilson, and Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, said today local opposition had been a stumbling block to the Portsmouth-Newington, N. H., jet bomber base.
Moderate and uninspired rallies led by the steels in the final thirty minutes of trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday turned a day of moderate declines into one of a small net gain.

MUNSAN, Korea, May 29 (AP) -- A South Korean truce delegate's letter brought to light today several previously undisclosed details of the new United Nations proposal for solving the prisoner deadlock and reaching an armistice in Korea.

MANILA, May 29 -- The new Democratic party of Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo has decided to hold its first national convention June 20 and 21 in Manila to select eight senatorial candidates for the November election and go through the formality of nominating General Romulo for President and Vice President Fernando Lopez as his running mate.

Sermons appropriate to Memorial Day will be preached this morning by many rabbis and tomorrow by many Christian clergymen. A number of Protestant Episcopal congregations will have services tomorrow anticipating the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II on Tuesday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 29 -- Coffee will not be traded in a free exchange market nor will the cruzeiro be devalued, Minister of Finance Horacio Lafer declared today. The minister's statement followed the granting of a temporary injunction asked by Figueiredo Fortes and other Santos coffee shippers who sought the right to trade coffee in a free market exchange.

JACKSON, Miss., May 29 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, leader of the Democratic minority in the Senate, charged tonight that President Eisenhower was being "frustrated" and "obstructed" by the Old Guard wing of the Republican party.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, back from a tour of twelve Near East and South Asian countries, declared this afternoon the twenty-day mission had "laid a new foundation of friendship" with that strategic but troubled area.

The British pacifist Stuart Denton Morris, who was detained at Ellis Island for two weeks while it was decided whether he would endanger the security of the United States, has now been permitted to enter this country and exercise the right of free speech. It is difficult to see how any other conclusion could have been reached within the spirit of American democracy.
PETROPOLIS, Brazil, May 29 (AP) -- Latin America's vast forests may some day help solve the world's newsprint shortage, experts here believe.
A panel of "experts" on vandalism, composed of youngsters who know vandalism at first hand, tackled the problem yesterday and came up with some answers that astounded their elders.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) -- Senator John W. Bricker, Republican of Ohio, said today he would ask the Senate Banking Committee to investigate charges by Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had failed to "protect the Government's interest" in the recent Kaiser-Frazer Corporation merger with the Willys-Overland Company, Inc.

LONDON, May 29 -- The last and most complete dress rehearsal for next Tuesday's coronation of Queen Elizabeth II drew a crowd of 10,000 spectators today at the entrance to Westminster Abbey where fully caparisoned peers, prelates, maids-of-honor and pages arrived before 10 A. M.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, said tonight the Senate Investigations subcommittee had information that about 100 foreign-owned ships, many of them "unhappily" owned by the British, were still supplying Communist troops in Korea with strategic supplies.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- A mechanics' walkout at the Capital Airlines main shops in Washington ended tonight and the company said it expected normal shop operations to be resumed in other cities. It said flight operations had not been affected.

PARIS, May 29 (UP) -- America's hopes of sweeping the five titles in the French international tennis championships were shattered today when its doubles team of Vic Seixas and Gardnar Mulloy was upset by the Australian team of Mervyn Rose and Clive Wilderspin.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 29 -- Turkey celebrated today the 500th anniversary of the conquest of Constantinople (now Istanbul) by Sultan Fatih Mohammed II with colorful ceremonies witnessed by crowds estimated here at 100,000 persons. Nation-wide observances continue for ten days.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 29 -- Lieut. Gen. Sir Alexander Hood, Governor General of Bermuda, confirmed today that the Midocean Club and Castle Harbor Hotel in Bermuda's swank residential area of Tuckerstown had been chosen as the site for the Western Big Three conference to be held "not before June 15."

Economic developments in France appear to be based or achieving long-term success, according to S. S. Wilson, president of Schieffelin Co., drug house and importer of wines and spirits, who has just returned from a business trip in France and the British Isles.
BONN, Germany, May 29 -- A bill nationalizing West Germany's coal, iron and steel industries is being prepared in the event of a Social Democratic victory in the forthcoming general elections.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 29 -- For the first time in history ten nations have agreed to embark on a vast marine research program covering the North Atlantic.
CHICAGO, May 29 -- The Marquette, the first vessel flying the French flag into this city since the French explorer of the same name came here in 1674, arrived in Chicago yesterday.

New Yorkers began to take to the open road yesterday in the annual Memorial Day curtain-raiser to the summer holiday season. The weather man promised that despite considerable cloudiness today the weather would be generally pleasant and warm.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 29 -- After nearly two weeks intensive study, Yugoslav Foreign Office officials have concluded the Soviet Union has embarked on the development of a serious new diplomatic strategy for dealing with the Balkan area.

TOKYO, Saturday, May 30 -- United States and Turkish troops withdrew from two key outposts on the western Korean front last night after engaging the Chinese Communists in what the United Nations Command described as the heaviest fighting since last October.
HANOI, Vietnam, May 29 (UP) -- American built French war planes today bombed the main retreat route of Communist led Vietminh forces withdrawing from Laos.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Cancellation of military aid to Western Europe this fiscal year will account for $317,400,000 of the $354,000,000 of savings reported to Congress by the Director for Mutual Security, a breakdown of the figures showed today.
Comdr. Daniel F. Meehan, a Catholic chaplain in the Navy since 1942, has been assigned as assistant district chaplain, Third Naval District, effective next Wednesday, it was announced here yesterday.

The Federal Weather Bureau's New York office will be forced to slash information and forecast services to the public if the new administration's economy program limits its operations, Ernest J. Christie, meteorologist in charge of the local branch, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The General Federation of Women's Clubs, by a vote of 246 to 242, refused today to recommend to Congress the passage of a pending bill to admit 242,000 European refugees in the next two years.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was slow yesterday, but the undertone was steady and closing prices were 14 to 22 points net higher.

A tall and rugged former tanker captain will be on hand June 19 at the Naval Reserve Training Facility, in Jersey City to watch thirty merchant marine officers graduate from a special training course.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- Arbitrators awarded a basic wage increase of 16 cents an hour today to 14,215 operating and maintenance employes of the Chicago Transit Authority. The increase will come in steps over a period of eighteen months, with the first rise of 8 cents becoming effective Monday.

DALLAS, Tex., May 29 (AP) -- Senator Joseph A. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, whose departure from Washington Wednesday on a ten-day mission for his Senate Investigations subcommittee stirred a flurry of rumors, turned up in Dallas today.

VIENNA, May 29 -- Leaders of Czechoslovak industry were accused today by Karol Bacilek, Czech Minister of Security, of making lying reports of progress and their workers were charged with mass theft of state property.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29 -- Ray Harroun, who won the first 500-mile race in 1911 at an average speed of 74.5 miles per hour, stood near the finish line at the Speedway today and watched the thirty-three qualifiers for tomorrow's race tear around the two-and-a-half mile brick oval in a thirty-minute practice spin.

A one-time Brown University campus leader and honor student, who assertedly attempted but failed in an East Side hold-up on Thursday despite elaborate preparations, received legal assistance yesterday from a former classmate.

ALBANY, May 29 -- The Court of Appeals unanimously reinstated today a perjury indictment against James A. Leary, long-time Republican leader of Saratoga County, in a move that paved the way for the principal trial in the investigation of that county ordered by Governor Dewey two years ago.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm product prices increased about three-fourths of 1 per cent between mid-April and mid-May. This increase partly offset a decline in the previous month.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) Representative Samuel W. Yorty, Democrat of California, said today that proposed cuts in Veterans Administration appropriations for next year would cripple the veterans' medical program.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 29 (AP) -- The executive board of Local 320, International Electrical Workers Union, C. I. O., approved tonight an agreement to end an eight-week strike at two General Electric Company plants.

There are a number of good reasons for welcoming Secretary of State Dulles home from his trip to the Middle East. It was a good idea to make the journey, when one considers how much the area means to the free world these days and what a variety of difficult and delicate problems there are to handle in it.

Your editorial "Battle Over Natural Gas" approves the Court of Appeals decision that natural gas producers, even though they are not engaged in interstate commerce, must be subject to regulation by the Federal Power Commission. The editorial further maintains that legislation similar to the Kerr bill designed to exempt independent gas producers from regulation would not be in the public interest.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 29 -- In the huge dry basin of land kept alive by the waters of the Indus River system, engineers from India and Pakistan are nearing the end of a study of a problem that has made for bitterness and tension between the two countries for five years.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Senate Investigations subcommittee decided today to seek the aid of the Department of Justice in locating Frank Coe, who for six years until last Dec. 3 was secretary of the International Monetary Fund, a United Nations agency dealing with the delicate financial problems of fifty-four nations.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 29 -- Israel proposed today at a special meeting of the Israeli-Jordanian Mixed Armistice Commission in Jerusalem that local commanders along the borders of the two countries should resume meetings as a means of halting the long series of serious border incidents.

At a recent press conference President Eisenhower again stressed his belief in the importance of local influence, authority and direction when it comes to deciding about the construction of dams and the uses to which they should be put. If there ever was a case where this principle should apply, it is the case of the proposed Tuttle Creek Dam, in the Blue River Valley of Kansas.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., May 29 (UP) -- Illinois, the defending champion and favorite to repeat, qualified fourteen men today for the Big Ten track and field finals. Michigan's Wolverines, rated the best chance to halt the Illini bid for a third consecutive outdoor title, qualified twelve.

NEW DELHI, India, May 29 -- Foreign capital was guaranteed a place in India, even in some cases in competition with local enterprises, by T. T. Krishnamachari, Minister for Commerce and Industry, in a significant address to the Central Advisory Council of Industries today.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use to the homemaker:

Following are the texts of two statements issued yesterday in connection with the dispute within the Welfare and Health Council of the City of New York. One was issued jointly by the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York and the Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn.

Carl W. Ackerman, dean of Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism, announced yesterday that three outstanding students had won 1953 Pulitzer Traveling Scholarships. The scholarships, $1,500 grants given annually for study abroad, were awarded to William L. MacDougall, William H. Trombley and Miss Jean M. White.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The armed forces expect to buy about a billion dollars of domestic petroleum products in the year starting July 1, 25 per cent more than for this year.

LONDON, May 29 -- The formation of a separate East Africa Command, directly responsible to the War Office in London, was announced here today. The new command includes Kenya, Uganda and Tanganyika and its first task is to suppress Mau Mau terrorism in Kenya and restore law and order in the colony.

PARIS, May 29 -- A petition signed by 270 of the 350 Moroccan chieftains -- caids and pashas -- asking that the Sultan of Morocco, Sidi Mohammed ben Youssef, be forced to abdicate, has been turned in to the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs by Gen. Augustin Guillaume, Resident General in the French Protectorate, it was learned today.
Announcing its willingness to join a coalition, the Liberal party has named a committee of its officers to confer with other "good government" groups in the selection of a candidate for Mayor.

Coffee prices tumbled yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange in the fourth heaviest trading of the year. A cable from Brazil reported that a coffee export company had received a temporary restraining order to permit the export of coffee on the free market.

Your editorial comment on Senator Taft's speech starts off by calling him a "confusing man." Perhaps so. But who today is not confused about our foreign policy -- if we have one? Mr. Taft may be confused, but he does state facts as they are and not as we would like them to be.

PITTSBURGH, May 29 -- Johnny Lindell of the Pirates walloped his second home run of the season off Russ Meyer today, but that wasn't enough to overcome the hitting of Gil Hodges, whose three safeties and three runs batted in helped the Dodgers mightily toward their sixth straight victory -- their longest winning streak of the campaign.

The Government bond market declined to new lows yesterday as offerings continued to come into the market in moderate volume. The new issue of thirty-year 3 1/4s felt the brunt of the day's selling pressure, declining 3/8 of a point to close the day at 99 3/16 bid, a yield basis of 3.28 per cent.

The endowment of a permanent scholarship at the Juilliard School of Music by Richard Rodgers, the composer, was announced yesterday afternoon by William Schuman, president of the school, at its forty-eighth commencement ceremonies.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 29 -- Central Kenya, including all three Kikuyu tribal reserves, and the Meru and Embu districts to the east were ordered sealed off today from the rest of the country, except for through travel on certain main roads and railroads. No one may enter the area or leave it without special permission of the district commissioners.

HARTFORD, Conn., Saturday, May 30 -- The Connecticut General Assembly adjourned sine die early today after adopting a "baby budget" of $7,776,000 to supplement the biennial general fund budget of $245,383,000 approved earlier in the week.

A new drug, named phenylbutazone, was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Rheumatism Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The drug reportedly gives quick and often lasting relief from the painful symptoms of acute gout, bursitis, sciatica, fibrositis, rheumatism of the spine and other types of painful and crippling rheumatic diseases.
MOSCOW, Saturday, May 20 -- Pravda today described President Eisenhower's press conference reply to questions about Senator Robert A. Taft's declaration on Korea as "evasive" and "indefinite."

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., May 29 (AP) -- Business and professional women were urged today to organize in an effort to persuade the major political parties to nominate women for important posts in Federal and state government.

The property on a plot about 249 by 100 feet at the southwest corner of Second Street and Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn has been sold by the Shaw Truesdell Company to a client of DiLorenzo DiLorenzo, attorneys. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 29 -- Col. Herman Beukema, a West Point classmate of President Eisenhower, disclosed today that the United States Military Academy's medical board almost had rejected, at a candidate for a commission as a second lieutenant, the cadet who was to become a five-star general and the Allied Supreme Commander in Europe in World War II.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- A golf club for players who do not want to wait for the nineteenth hole was patented this week by Emanuel Merahn of Brooklyn. The host pulls out of his golf bag what looks like a driver, but gurgles faintly. He produces a set of small glasses from the club head, uncorks the handle and pours.
BELTSVILLE, Md., May 29 -- President Eisenhower's "tip" to Congress paid off today.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 29 -- Hatred of communism is producing in this country a "new form of idolatry" that regards "passionate and unreflective opposition to the Communist demon as the one and only expression of Americanism and even of Christianity," the Rev. Dr. John Alexander Mackay, newly elected moderator of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A., and president of Princeton Theological Seminary, warned here today.
Herbert Partridge, a historically minded ex-Londoner, found himself the victim of some unfortunate flips of the coin this week.
BRISTOL, England, May 29 (AP) -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley disputed tonight the idea that Britain and the United States could get along without each other in peacetime.

HOYLAKE, England, May 29 (AP) -- Harvie Ward, the defending champion, crushed two opponents today in the quarter and semifinals of the British Amateur Golf championship and made each victory look easy. The 27-year-old Atlantan meets Irishman Joe Carr tomorrow in the thirty-six-hole final.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 29 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, chief Soviet delegate, has made a sudden and unannounced decision to sail for home next Wednesday. On "a family matter," explained the Soviet delegation. "Maybe." said some diplomats.

ST. LOUIS, May 29 (AP) -- Soft-speaking Ed Furgol of St. Louis made the big noise in the second round of the fiftieth Western Open golf tournament today with a two- under-par 68 that gave him 138 and the 36-hole leadership.

DENVER, May 29 -- Police officials of this city today accused the Los Angeles police department of trying to induce young Denver officers to join the Los Angeles force at higher pay and shorter working hours.

Sales and net profit of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company of America (A. P.) for the year ended on Feb. 28 increased 10.7 per cent and 7.5 per cent, respectively, compared with the previous fiscal year, the grocery chain announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury investigation of the office payroll of Representative Ernest K. Bramblett, Republican of California, recessed today after hearing ten witnesses in two days. The United States District Attorney, Leo A. Rover, said the inquiry probably would run all day Thursday and Friday next week and with another session the following week.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in May dropped to the smallest of any month since last September, but was slightly above the corresponding month in 1952.
Dr. Jacob L. Keller has been appointed director of chemical market development of the Norwich Pharmacal Company.

The average market price of all bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange in April fell to the lowest month-end level since Feb. 28, 1942, the Exchange reported yesterday. The April 30 figure was $95.46, against $96.57 at the close of March and $95.13 on the 1942 date.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- Another slump in grain futures prices carried all deliveries of wheat, corn and rye to new crop lows today. And while there was a sharp rally from the low spots, there was still much uncertainty among traders. Many shorts took advantage of the low prices to cover, and there was broadening of investment demand on the theory that prices have discounted about everything of a bearish description.

LONDON, May 29 (AP) -- A leading American business executive warned his British opposite numbers today to stop complaining about United States tariffs and pitch in with aggressive selling to America instead.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 29 -- Forty-nine seniors and twenty-nine graduate students received degrees in music today at the twenty-fourth annual commencement of the Westminster Choir College.

The Board of Estimate formally received yesterday at a special meeting at City Hall the proposed agreement for transfer of the operation of city-owned transit lines from the Board of Transportation to the New York City Transit Authority.

Fifty-three Roman Catholic agencies resigned yesterday from the Welfare and Health Council of New York City because the council granted membership on Thursday to the Planned Parenthood Committee of Mothers Health Centers. The resignation of the Catholic groups and the membership of the Planned Parenthood Committee both will become effective July 1.
WASHINGTON May 29 (UP) -- Johnny Schmitz, 32-year-old pitching cast-off, won in his first start for the Senators tonight when he stopped the Red Sox with eight scattered hits to gain a 4-2 victory.

The muddle created last month, when local scow captains accepted the contract offer of one group of industrial carriers and rejected an identical bid by another, has been cleared up with the belated approval by their union of the second offer.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 29 -- Col. I Fu-teh, the Chinese Nationalist military representative, awaited instruction from his Government today as a four-power military group continued to discuss measures for evacuating Gen. Li Mi's Nationalist Guerrillas from eastern Burma in accordance with an April 22 United Nations resolution.

LUXEMBOURG, May 29 (UP) -- Joseph Barthel of Luxembourg, who set an Olympic 1,500-meter record of 3:45.2 to triumph in the games at Helsinki, today received a Smith-Mundt award to study chemistry at Harvard University.

PARIS, May 29 -- A record non-stop flight for commercial airplanes of 5,905 miles from Los Angeles to Paris [solid black line on map] was completed today by a French-American crew in a four-engined DC-6B airliner. The big plane touched down at Orly Field, southeast of Paris, 20 hours and 31 minutes after leaving the United States West Coast.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 -- Sweet and sour was the order of the day, as the Yankees, once again coming from behind, overwhelmed the Athletics, 12 -- 7, at Connie Mack Stadium today. For after the A's had teed off with a four-run opening attack that chased Vic Raschi in the first inning, in came Ray Scarborough, a pickle salesman from Mount Olive, N. C., and before long Casey Stengel's men were in command.

NEWARK, May 29 -- Clendennin J. Ryan, wealthy political crusader, said today he had rejected "numerous offers of important jobs in Washington, including one of cabinet rank," to withdraw as an independent candidate for Governor of New Jersey.

Gabriela Mistral, Chilean poet, has protested directly to President Juan Peron of Argentina against the imprisonment of Victoria Ocampo, 63, Argentine author and editor, on suspicion of plotting against the Peron dictatorship.

SEOUL, Korea, May 29 -- Following is the text of the letter sent on May 27 to Lieut. Gen. William K. Harrison Jr., senior United Nationals truce delegate, by Maj. Gen. Choi Duk Shin, South Korean armistice representative, on the latest United Nations proposals on the disposition of prisoners in the Korean war:

LONDON, May 29 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan of South Africa, on arriving in Britain today, delivered a long, sharp lecture on interference in South Africa's affairs, denouncing "busybodyism" and writers who "hurry through South Africa" looking for material "to substantiate their ill-conceived prejudices."

FORT DEVENS, Mass., May 29 -- A court martial panel trying First Lieutenant Sheppard C. Thierman was instructed today to accept as a fact that the aims of the Communist party in the United States were subversive.

This relates to your editorial of May 26 entitled "Latin-American Relations." In it you seemingly deprecate the action of Secretary Humphrey in imposing countervailing duties on wool tops to offset the bounty accruing on their export by virtue of the maintenance of multiple rates of exchange in Uruguay.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 29 -- Edward W. Blyden 3d, a Negro scholar and writer from Sierra Leone, said here today the elements of extreme nationalism becoming apparent in central Africa were part of the natural over-all stage of nationalism through which the area was passing. He indicated the West had best learn to accept it.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 29 -- Dr. Daniel F. Malan, South Africa's racialist Prime Minister, who is in London for the Coronation of Queen Elizabeth, has run into an embarrassment in the form of a song, "Don't Malign Malan," sung nightly by an American Negro singer, Marie Bryant, in the London Hippodrome's current revue.

Jim Redmond of Fordham Prep, the defender, vaulted to a record of 12 feet 3 1/2 inches in the senior pole vault as the twenty-seventh annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association track and field championships began with the field events at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday.

Among the physicians gathering for the annual meeting of the American Medical Association next week are 200 women doctors, members of the American Medical Women's Association. This group will convene today and tomorrow at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel.
Paced by Lindy Remigino, its Olympic 100-meter champion, Manhattan yesterday took a firm grasp on the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. outdoor track and field title it won last year.

STANTON, Del., May 29 (AP) -- Delaware's Park's thirty-two-day meeting, richest in the history of the picturesque track, got off to a colorful and exciting start under sunny skies today as Mrs. Alfred Roberts' Eatontown pounded to victory in the $12,725 Wilmington Handicap.
FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., May 29 -- An "electronic bird dog," designed to aid pilots in bad flying weather by reliably indicating a plane's destination, was demonstrated in the air here today.

ELIZABETH, N. J., May 30 -- The announcement this week that Representative Clifford P. Case of near-by Rahway will resign to accept the presidency of the Fund for the Republic, an enterprise financed by the Ford Foundation to promote civil liberties, posed for Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll the question of deciding how the vacancy will be filled and stirred a wave of speculation on possible successors to the House seat.
President Eisenhower was praised by Rabbi William F. Rosenblum yesterday for having opposed Senator Robert A. Taft's "isolationism."

Two factors held business down in the department stores last week and trade observers believe final returns may show a decline of as much as 15 per cent from the comparable 1952 week. One factor was that the weather was cooler than in the week a year before which retarded buying of summer wear.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 30 -- Polish pilot Zdzislaw Jazwinski, who escaped from Poland May 20 and crash-landed his Soviet-built MIG-15A jet fighter on a barrack ground in Roenne, main town on the Danish island of Bornholm, in the Baltic, was recognized today as a political refugee.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 30 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, announced today that George A. Brakeley, vice president and treasurer of the university for the last twelve years, would retire July 1.

HOYLAKE, England, May 30 -- Joe Carr, a 31-year-old Irish woolen salesman from Dublin, won the British amateur golf championship today by defeating Harvie Ward of Atlanta, the defending titleholder, 2 up, in a hard-fought, but poorly played thirty-six-hole final.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The Atomic Energy Commission made available to American industry tonight four detailed expurgated reports by eight large concerns that undertook extensive studies of "the prospect for private industrial participation in joint production of electric energy and fissionable material from reactors."

Among the more than 2,600 students who will be graduated by City College at commencement exercises on June 17 will be 40-year-old Jeremiah Slattery, who served in the medical corps of Ireland's Army from 1939 to 1948. A licensed pharmacist in Great Britain and Ireland, he will receive a Bachelor of Science degree in chemistry.

THE most critical part of an aircraft's flight always has been the landing. In fact, the military services have long said that if a man is good at bringing a plane in they will depend on him to learn, and become adept at, the other phases and responsibilities of flying.

SEOUL, Korea, May 30 (Reuters) -- President Syngman Rhee of the Republic of Korea said today peace must be restored in Korea by the Korean people themselves without any interference from outside nations.
The sixty-seventh running of the Suburban Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday promised to be a great horse race. It was.

HEADQUARTERS, Fifth Air Force in Korea, May 30 -- The aggressive Sabre jet pilots of this United Nations air force have been racking up what is probably the most impressive record ever compiled in the brief history of air-to-air combat.

Max Fromm will be 80 years old tomorrow. But he thinks it more important that the date June 1 is the sixty-fifth anniversary of the certificate granted him in his native Germany "authorizing him to taste wines." Hence he believes that he is not only the dean of American wine tasters but perhaps the oldest authority on wines in the world.

Manhattan College will award bachelor degrees to 425 seniors and two honorary degrees at its 102d commencement exercises on Tuesday, June 9. Commencement week will begin officially this Thursday when the Rev. Alexander Hoffman will conduct a "day of recollection" for the graduating class.

BEFORE Death, or the Iron Curtain of legend, overtakes me, I want to holler in everybody's ear that Yeats wasn't in the least like that. I see the legend growing up under my very eyes; I gape at people who ask me with a knowing smile, "and didn't he once see an apparition at a board meeting?" and wonder what sort of person they are really referring to.

NEW DELHI, May 30 -- India's representation at the Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II will be in a peculiar position. Of the nine Prime Ministers of British Commonwealth countries who will see the ceremonies in Westminster Abbey only Prime Minister Nehru of India will not swear allegiance to Her Majesty, for India alone of these states does not acknowledge the young Queen as its sovereign.

VALHALLA, N. Y., May 30 -- The Westchester County Children's Association, a thirty-nine-year- old philanthropic organization that aids 2,500 boys and girls a year, announced today it would present its first outdoor festival June 13 to finance the rising costs of a guidance center, summer camping trips; foster homes and special work in public schools.

LENOX, Mass. -- Innkeeping has completed the full cycle in Massachusetts where the country's first hotels first flourished as post houses on the post roads. The coffee houses and stagecoach inns gradually developed over the years into lavish citified hotels, and now they are reverting to their prototype with the construction of motels along New England's byways.

IT is not as generally known as it should be that Langston Hughes laughs with, cries with, and speaks for, the Negro (in all classes) more understandingly, perhaps, than any other writer. Harlem is his own habitat, his workshop and his playground, his forte and his dish of tea.

LAURENS VAN DER POST is one of the small group of South African writers who are, or promise to become, novelists to be reckoned with. His first novel, "In the Province," is an immature work written twenty years ago.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (UP) -- President Eisenhower went to a placid hilltop overlooking Arlington National Cemetery today with Mrs. Eisenhower and led the nation in its observance of Memorial Day.

CHESTNUT HILL, Pa., May 30 -- Ben Hogan, three-time winner of the United States Open championship, is seriously considering making a bid for the British Open itle next month. This was learned from an authoritative source today.

IF Queen Elizabeth II had taken the advice of Her Majesty's loyal subject, Sir Alexander Maxwell, and the British Travel Association, which he heads, there would be no Coronation next Tuesday. Instead, the Queen would have been crowned weeks ago, sometime late in April or very early in May.

June is a heady compound of song and fragrance. You waken to the robin and the oriole, celebrating early dawn. The mid-morning song of the meadow-larks is sheer joy of living. At dusk there is the full-rounded call of the wood thrush, one of the finest of all contraltos.

IN the vicinity of New York City peonies step into the limelight today and for the rest of the week. Actually, the first of the garden peonies to open is the old-fashioned "Memorial Day" peony (Paeonia officinalis rubra).

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- This Administration, with quiet determination, is applying every day the apothegm about the virtues of thrift that Mr. Micawber stated so well to David Copperfield but found himself unable to put into practice:

Before the gates of Buckingham Palace on V-J Day in 1945 a Britisher turned to an American Army sergeant who happened to be standing near him in the throng awaiting the appearance of the royal family and said, "I suppose you fellows think this a bit silly, don't you?"

ST. LOUIS, May 30 -- Dutch Harrison, fast becoming a master of Bellerive Country Club's troublesome hills and tight fairways, gained a one-stroke lead in the fiftieth Western open golf tournament with a par 70 in today's third round.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The Democratic National Committee will begin publication in July of a pocket-size monthly magazine to be sold by subscription and on newsstands. The magazine, to be known as The Democratic Digest, will represent the first entry of a major political party into the commercial publishing field.

Manhattan stampeded to the team title, Georgetown's Charley Capozzoli set a meet record of 9:00.2 for two miles and spectacular upset triumphs were registered by Army's Lew Olive, Yale's Mike Stanley and Columbia's one-mile relay team in the concluding session of the seventy-seventh Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships yesterday.

STANTON, Del., May 30 -- It is bit early in the season to judge, but today's $42,010 Delaware Oaks at Delaware Park may have served is a springboard to the 3-year-old silly title for Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Cerise Reine.

A NATIONAL competition for a $400 full-tuition scholarship for 1953 in the Photography Department of the Rochester Institute of Technology is announced by the newly formed scholarship committee of the Photographic Society of America. The school's photography department is headed by C. B. Neblette, internationally noted authority. A similar award will be made in 1954. The committee members are Lloyd E. Varden, chairman; Norman C. Lipton, Joseph Costa, William Robinson Jr. and Jacob Deschin.

LONDON, May 30 -- From the vantage point of London, attired in such gay splendor to honor a young Queen of the world's oldest continuous democracy, the political problems clouding over neighboring free countries on the Continent of Europe assume a contrast, sharp and disturbing.

Enervating summer is hard upon us. Soon it will become clear that a New York business man or a Hoosier farm boy can get just as hot as an Indian Maharajah, a prize race horse in Ceylon or cattle on a Singapore dairy farm.

MARTHA GRAHAM'S recent week of performances, coming with cumulative effect upon the heels of her appearances in the season of "American Dance" last month, was not only a stimulating experience, but also something of a revelation. Miss Graham's appearance of recent seasons have been somewhat rare, and she had not previously given a series with her company since 1950.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 30 -- In an exciting finish Joe Angyal of the home club, winner of many national titles, barely got home first today in the senior quarter-mile dash, feature race of the Memorial Day regatta of the New York Rowing Association.

RYE, N. Y., May 30 -- Although only twenty-nine hardy skippers turned up at the starting line today, the Long Island Sound Y. R. A. regatta staged by the American Yacht Club provided some keen competition.

The "Poor Man's Common Trust Fund," a new proposal in the fiduciary field, is being advanced by New York commercial bankers and the State Banking Department. Legislative endorsement of the proposal, it was learned last week, is largely dependent upon the question of whether individual trustees should be included in the provisions of the new fund.
Unpredicted rain and chilly temperatures spoiled the first half of the Memorial Day week-end yesterday in New York and the surrounding resort areas.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 30 -- Seventy-six choirs participated today in the Talbott massed choir festival, high point of the weeklong program of the Westminster Choir College. The festival, usually held outdoors, took place in the Princeton University Chapel because of the inclement weather.

A revitalized French merchant marine, doubled in size in the past half century, is now the largest fleet the nation has even operated, according to figures presented last month at the fiftieth annual meeting of the Central Committee of French Shipowners. The figures were made available here last week.

GLENWOOD LANDING, L. I., May 30 -- The first attempt to form a centralized school district on Long Island will be decided next Saturday when voters in the school districts of Glenwood Landing, Sea Cliff and Glen Head go to the polls from 2 to 7 P. M.

PITTSBURGH, May 30 -- Six home runs, four in the first game and two of them by Gil Hodges, were enough for the Dodgers to sink the Pirates twice today, 7 -- 4 and 4 -- 1, and run their winning streak to eight games, their longest of the campaign.

Tomorrow at Panmunjom -- late tonight New York time -- the Communist negotiators are to hand over a reply to the U. N. on the question of truce in Korea. Their answer may be a crucial turning point in the world struggle. On it may hinge not only the future of the Korean war but also the course of the whole conflict between the free and Communist nations and the relations among the Western allies.

State Rent Administrator Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday a simplification of procedure for the granting of rent increases to landlords who propose to make a substantial rehabilitation of property or a major capital improvement.

A NEW kind of school has been established by the United Nations on the picturesque lake of Patzcuaro, in Michoacan, and the villages around the lake are its laboratory. It is a teacher-training school, but the subject which the students are learning is unique -- how to convince underdeveloped peoples that they are capable of making a better life for themselves and how to get them started toward that goal.

As Professor Dowling pointed out in "I Stand on the Fifth Amendment" (May 17), the Fifth Amendment is a limitation on the Federal Government only. The State Constitutions, almost all of which contain provisions similar to the Fifth Amendment, are operative only within the states.

A GENERAL survey of motor vehicle improvements adopted during the last few years and forecasts of improvements designed to make cars easier to handle, more comfortable and safer will be presented at the annual summer meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers, opening next Sunday at Atlantic City.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (UP) -- Representative Robert B. Chiperfield, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said today he expected to make "substantial" cuts in the Administration's already trimmed foreign aid request. However, the Illinois Republican, who usually supports moves to reduce foreign aid, said he could not see how the committee could slice off $2,000,000,000 as proposed by Representative Daniel A. Reed, Republican of upstate New York.

With cotton exports this season roughly one-half of those a year earlier, the trade is wondering whether this slump in sales abroad is temporary or whether it represents a fundamental change in the international markets.

THE Baker Street Irregulars had better approach television cautiously. Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson, who had proved durable characters on the radio, made their belated appearance on the home screen last week and they did not seem too happy in the cathode glare. Something was amiss.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin and chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, voiced strong disagreement today with fellow Republicans who have been outspokenly critical of the United States' role in the Korean truce negotiations.

PORTLAND, Me. -- For years travelers have thought of Portland only as a city they must pass through on their way to the lake regions of this state, or as an enforced stop-over between trains en route to visitors' days at children's camps.

IN recent years America has had no German policy. Before 1948 we were guided by our hope for cooperation with Russia, since then by our fear of Russian aggression. The result has been puzzling and contradictory.

As if the Giants already weren't well up to their ears in troubles, the weather took a turn at getting in another resounding whack yesterday when rain washed out the twin bill with the Phillies at the Polo Grounds.

THE irrepressible triplets, Abercrombie, Benjamin and Christopher, are back again, having new fun and creating more confusion than ever. Although they now part their hair differently, it is still impossible to tell them apart and equally impossible to predict their escapades.

ABOUT this time of year newspapers begin to carry ominous stories reporting half a dozen children stricken with polio here, a dozen there. By the dog days of August the numbers may reach several hundred in each of several large cities. The last five years have seen a spate of such frightening reports, for the incidence of polio has risen sharply.

STORM warnings are being raised on consumer credit. The makers of the nation's fiscal policy are apprehensive about the situation, particularly since any move to impose controls aimed at slowing installment purchases is bound to meet with stanch resistance in the Congress.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, got around this week to the inevitable question: "Is this the road to the promised land?"
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., May 30 -- Rolling up 69 1/2 points, the highest point total in nine years, Illinois dominated a meet of upsets today to win its third straight Big Ten outdoor track championship.

ELIZABETH is the Queen, and queens do not choose the post. They are different even from a priesthood which follows a vocation. The Queen is unique, she is born to a duty, a long and difficult service from which there is no escape, a sentence for her whole life.

Labor developments were the focal point of interest in financial markets last week. The quick agreement on contract revisions by several of the major automobile companies ended a tie-up in production and widespread unemployment in the industry.

KING'S POINT, L. I. -- As the United States Merchant Marine sails toward leadership among the merchant navies of the world, the United States Merchant Marine Academy here is busy developing officers who will command our cargo and passenger ships in time of peace as well as in war.

A public opinion poll taken by the Elmo Roper organization at the request of Richard H. Balch, Democratic State Chairman, indicates that many of the voters who supported Mayor Impellitteri as an independent in the 1950 election have turned against him.

ON earth there are three poles. The North and South Poles have long since been conquered and explored. But the third pole has resisted the assaults of man. That pole is the 29,002-foot summit of the world called Everest.

More determined than ever, the Detroit owners of Gold Cup craft are planning, with tactics, strategy and generalship, their campaign to put an end to what they regard as "this Seattle nonsense." They aim to bring the famous Gold Cup bauble back to Michigan.

Plans for New York's biggest test of atom bomb defenses, a September exercise that will send school children to shelters, halt automobiles and some subways, ground airplanes and possibly change the channels of radio stations, were announced last week.
SCHUYLERVILLE, N. Y., May 30 (UP) -- A light plane plunged to the bottom of the Hudson River here tonight after slicing high-voltage power lines and throwing the community into darkness.

The Citizens Union commended yesterday the Tammany executive committee for voluntarily reducing the number of members of the New York County Democratic Committee to be elected at the Sept. 15 primary from 11,761 to 3,471.

WITHIN another month Cape Cod will be bustling with activity. During June, however, the pace is unhurried, and with the village gardens bright with flowers, it is popular with early-season vacationist.

IN this earnest novel. Sara Jenkins depicts the soul-searching of a young pastor, who must decide between his ministry and his love for a divorced woman. Stephen Elliott's conflict is further complicated by the fact that his work binds him firmly to the lives and problems of a company-run Georgia mill town.

WHEN we undertook the filming of Paramount's first three-dimentional film, "Sangaree," we had already been shooting for ten days in the regular two-dimentional process with Technicolor. The urging of Adolph Zukor, chairman of the hoard for Paramount, and our own willingness to tackle the challenge of our time in show business, launched us into re-filming our story in the new medium.

An increasing number of outdoor entrepreneurs, whose profits and customers have been dampened by rain all too often, have been taking cover under a "financial protective umbrella" by contracting for rain insurance.

DETROIT, May 30 (AP) -- Vio Wertz and Les Moss each knocked in three runs as the Browns walloped the last-place Tigers, 13 -- 1, to sweep a double-header before 24,007 fans at Briggs Stadium today. St. Louis won the opener, 5 -- 4, when pinch-hitter Don Lenhardt slashed a two-run single with two out in the ninth inning.

A SYMPHONY orchestra may be the pride and adornment of a community, but it should also be an integral parts of the life that goes on in the area that it serves. The job of management, conductors and players must be not only to fill the announced dates with satisfying performances but to make the orchestra -- and music -- an active force in the community.
In the last three years, the American marine insurance industry, despite currency restrictions abroad, has been expanding gradually into foreign markets traditionally dominated by London.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 30 -- Three years ago the Republican leaders in Westchester would have scoffed at the possibility of such a thing ever happening, but today they were ready to endorse Judge George W. Smyth of the county Children's Court for re-election in November.

THE fourth premiere of the present season of the New York City Ballet will be Jerome Robbins' "Fanfare," to be seen for the first time on the Coronation Night program at the City Center on Tuesday. Its music is Benjamin Britten's "Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra" and heading its cast of thirty-four will be Yvonne Mounsey, Todd Bolender, Frank Hobi, Michael Maule and Roy Tobias.

It will not be long before the word Sanforlan becomes as familiar to the American public as Sanforized, if Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., owner of both trade marks, has its way. Sanfortan denotes wool garments specially preshrunk by a method developed and patented in 1949 by a division of the famous manufacturer of shirts and other articles.
Following the lead of the House of Representatives, the Senate last Thursday voted to extend the "doctor draft" law for another two years.

THERE is abundant evidence that the United States is on the threshold of an operatic culture. One particularly revealing index is the increasing number of opera performances given each summer. They are presented both in regular seasons and in isolated productions, and this summer there will be more than ever of each class.
IT is truly a miracle when the American premiere of an opera is scheduled in 1953 and the opera is the work of an established genius dead since 1791 -- Mozart.

MILAN, Italy, May 30 -- Local leaders of the coalition headed by Premier Alcide De Gasperi's Christian Democratic party said today they were disturbed over the apparent lack of interest of the people of this province in the political campaign for the national elections to be held June 7.

The offshore oil bill was signed by the President on May 22 and is now a law. The proponents of this gigantic give-away no doubt consider the matter settled, but they may well be in for some surprises when the matter is challenged in the courts.

PLANISTS and harpsichordists recently in action on disks have been concentrating on the three B's. Wilhelm Backhaus, for London, continues his survey of the Beethoven sonatas with the Moonlight, the E flat, Op. 27, No. 1 and the pair in G minor and G, Op. 49, Nos. 1 and 2. Backhaus plays these like the well-drilled, experienced exponent of German music that he is.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 30 -- The United Nations Commission on Human Rights concluded today its ninth session in Geneva after adopting a report to its parent body, the Economic and Social Council, and electing members to the subcommittee on the prevention of discrimination and protection of minorities, according to word received here.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- A proposal to abolish the Government-operated Federal National Mortgage Association and to transfer its home mortgage operations to private hands was being drafted today. The National Association of Real Estate Boards said it was preparing the plan, which it said was "now under discussion with Federal officials and financial institutions."

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- The absence of Frank Coe from this country at the time of his reported intervention in Austrian currency negotiations was "not at all pertinent," Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, said today.
MILWAUKEE, May 30 (AP) -- This will be a quieter town for the next few weeks -- the Milwaukee Braves are on the road.
