KANSAS CITY, May 30 (AP) -- His office telephone is Baltimore 6-1560, and it is no private, unlisted number. The door to his three-room office suite on the eleventh floor of the Federal Reserve Bank building is always open -- and there is a constant stream of people in and out.

More than 16,000 physicians from all over the United States are expected to attend the annual meeting of the American Medical Association, which opens here tomorrow for five days. An additional 16,000 guests, including residents, internes, nurses, medical technicians, medical students and others, probably will attend.

Local 968 of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., made public yesterday a memorandum attacking the State Crime Commission's recommendations for state control of dock hiring and registration of pier workers.

NEW DELHI, India, May 30 -- An official Burmese trade delegation will arrive here next week to negotiate a long-range barter deal with India for exchanging Burmese rice for a variety of Indian manufactured goods.

CINCINNATI, May 30 (AP) -- Right-hander Johnny Klippstein won the first game of his career against Cincinnati today, 2 -- 1, to enable the Cubs to divide a double-header. The Redlegs drove fifteen hits to take the opener, 8 -- 6, after halting a ninth-inning Chicago rally.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- President Eisenhower may have to accept a watered down version of an excess profits tax extension, if he gets one at all. Several members of the key House of Representatives Ways and Means Committee stressed this point today in advance of hearings on the controversial issue, starting Monday.
LIEGE, Belgium, May 21 -- A seventeen-foot-high furnace of a new design was lighted last week and has been producing iron at an estimated rate of sixty tons a day by a special process.

BERLIN, May 30 -- Moscow's current emphasis on the Potsdam agreement as the basis for the solution of the German problem does not mean that the Kremlin seeks restoration of strict four-power control in Germany, the Soviet zone's leading Communist newspaper asserted today.

Probably the most painful affliction with which physicians must deal is angina pectoris. The sufferer feels as if a steel band were tightening around his chest. He lives in constant fear of death and wanders from one heart specialist to another only to find that little can be done for him.

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) -- Favored Royal Bay Gem, running in last place for half the race after an out-of-the-gate mix-up, steamed up the back stretch to triumph by a length in the $50,000 added Peabody Memorial Stakes in the Lincoln Fields meeting at Hawthorne today before 31,397 fans.

IN this volume Gilbert Highet, Columbia's erudite and highly articulate professor of classics, has brought together thirty talks about books which he gave on the radio last year. Were these merely book reviews, one might question the need of giving them permanent form, but they are more than reviews; they are causeries after the manner of Sainte-Beuve.

LONDON, May 30 (Reuters) -- Rumania has protested to the United States over the expulsion of Christache Zambeti, first secretary of the Communist country's legation in Washington, Agerpress, the Rumanian news agency, reported today.

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) -- The White Sox bounced back into second place by rallying to beat the Indians, 6 -- 5, after losing the first game of the twin bill, 7 -- 2, before 41,971 at Comiskey Park today.

ALTHOUGH it is normally the seasonal threshold to a spell amid mountain greenery or a place in the sun. May was a month that held no surcease, or a promise of it, for first-run motion picture theatre managements. In fact, the turnover in newcomers was terrific and paid and paying observers cannot recall a fuller month this year.

ENGLEWOOD. N. J., May 30 -- Miss Joan Scholz of 1274 First Avenue. New York City, was married from her hospital bed at Englewood Hospital here this afternoon to Airman 1/c Peter Petrocsko of Irwin, Pa., who leaves for Korea on June 12.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The escalator clause -- a contract device that automatically adjusts wage rates as the cost of living changes -- has passed the peak of its popularity. Many believe that only another spurt of inflation would return it to vogue.

A CHILDREN'S story that ends with reward both deserved and reasonably limited is refreshing in the long parade of happy, happy endings. Tommy was too little, as big brother Benny delighted to point out. He couldn't belong to the 4-H yet; and Little Twin was not even his own calf -- hard to handle, too.
HAMBURG, Germany, May 30 -- A sharp rightward shift in domestic policy was recommended by leaders of the German party, which opened its pre-election convention here today.

ARISTOTLE -- who described tragedy as a catharsis of human emotions through imaginative participation in the sufferings of others -- would have understood this third novel by an Atlanta regional author and newspaper columnist.

WEST NEW PORTLAND, Me. -- Out-of-state motorists touring in this section of Maine are apt to slow down and even stop when they approach the Carrabassett River Bridge on a town road that leads off Route 27 near here.

NOT everyone could make an exhibition which consists primarily of prints of skeletons, muscles and scenes of cadavers being dissected become something visually entertaining, instructive and provocative.

ALTHOUGH the 1952-53 stage season in New York was not without its shortcomings, as statistical intelligence in adjoining columns shows, the period was noteworthy in at least one respect. Since June 1, 1952, there has been unusual interest by motion picture representatives in Broadway scripts.

A member of the first graduating class of Barnard College will participate in the Reunion Day activities Wednesday on the 116th Street campus. Mrs. Sigmund Pollitzer of Manhattan, class of '93, will return to Barnard to celebrate the sixtieth anniversary of her graduation.
TOKYO, Sunday, May 31 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,631, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Sunday, Korean time:

The Department of Communication Arts of Fordham University will offer a workshop course for moderators and editors of college and school newspapers at its Eighth Annual Summer Institute from July 6 to Aug. 14. The Division of Journalism staff will collaborate in presenting the course, which will stress such factors as reporting and news writing techniques, editing, pictorial treatment, typography and business management.
LONDON, May 30 -- Members of Britain's royal family spent today greeting princes and dignitaries who arrived here to represent their countries at the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II on Tuesday.

BERLIN, May 30 (UP) -- Communist authorities, in a move to plug another chink in the Iron Curtain between East and West, barred East German passenger ships today from lakes and rivers in West Berlin. But the flow of refugees from communism continued.

A FURTHER extension of service for one of the best known and fastest streamliners serving New York and the South began recently when important changes were made in the consist of the Southern's Southerner.

ROME, May 30 (AP) -- Italian Government circles said today that Frederick G. Crawford, a Cleveland business man, made only a limited investigation here before recommending that all economic aid to Italy be dropped.

OAKLAND, Calif., May 30 (AP) -- Wisconsin's varsity crew defeated the University of California by four lengths in a three-mile race on Oakland Estuary today. In six races California has won four times and Wisconsin twice.

OTTAWA, May 30 -- Although there are a few in Quebec Province who dream of a "Laurentian Republic" and there are some everywhere who claim to think that Canada should be either a republic on her own or part of the United States, the great majority of Canadians are by reason and sentiment attached to the Crown and the Comomnwealth as the best guarantees of their national unity and their independence.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- An official analysis of President Eisenhower's revised defense budget figures, compiled by the Department of Defense today. showed that the Air Force would receive seventy-five more combat aircraft and 1,150 fewer support aircraft between now and Dec. 31, 1955, than would have been the case under the estimates presented to Congress by President Truman before his retirement.

HONG KONG, May 30 -- The captain of the 3,221 - ton Panamanian ship Perico agreed today with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, that he had worked for the Chinese Communists -- but only after he had been warned "somebody would be shot" if he refused to carry Red troops.

AMONG the seasonal pleasures gourmets count asparagus, strawberries, freshly pulled radishes and, far from last or least, salmon. Izaak Walton called it "the king of fishes." Centuries before he wrote "The Compleat Angler," a Latin poet apotheosized the salmon: "You are a fit dish for feasts where choice is difficult."

IT is quite true that the singing actor, or singer, may have to join as many as five different performers' unions in the course of his expanding career, as John Sheldon Davis points out in his letter, printed on May 24.

NO lover of the theatre can read the annual statistics without a feeling of awful apprehension. Fewer productions every year; frightening costs of production and operation -- these are the facts that consistently eat a little further into the vitality of the theatre.

The saga of Jewish family life, "The Goldbergs," will return to television on a regular basis as the summer replacement for the Dennis Day Show over the National Broadcasting Company's video network, beginning Friday, July 3, from 8 to 8:30 P.M.

A doubling of the fare appears to have caused a 5 per cent drop in Buenos Aires subway passengers, but may have produced a one-third rise in revenue. A 2-cent increase in Stockholm's former 7-cent fare is still leaving the subway and surface system there running at a deficit.

The National Science Foundation has granted $8,900 to the Worcester Foundation for Experimental Biology to support a conference on "Methods of Determination of Steroids of Blood and Urine," May 31 through June 4. The conference will bring together about fifty authorities from the United States and Europe in the field of steroid methodology to discuss latest methods for steroid measurement and analysis.

Frostbite therapy, used on United States marines in Korea to bring about the lowest incidence of major amputation for extensive frostbite that has been reported, was described by a New York physician yesterday at the fifty-fourth annual meeting of the American Therapeutic Society at the Biltmore Hotel.

As of today the Eighty-third Congress, five months less four days in session, has passed and sent to the President for signature forty-one public laws (ranging in import from one vesting title to billions of dollars in offshore oil with the states, to one changing the name of the Roosevelt Memorial Association to the Theodore Roosevelt Association).

The ingeniousness of New York mechanics was shown in stories told at the convention of the National Industrial Service Association at the Statler Hotel last week. Its members do about $500,000,000 annual business in the repair of industrial electrical equipment -- and a lot of it is done in New York.

CHESTNUT HILL, Pa., May 30 -- Louise Suggs, the women's national open champion, moved a step closer to her goal of winning the Weathervane cross-country tournament with a spectacular three-under-par 72 over the rain-soaked Whitemarsh Valley Country Club course today.

LEVITTOWN, L. I., May 30 -- A group of fathers in this community is rallying to the aid of overburdened housewives who are attempting to conduct a successful Girl Scout program for the 4,000 daughters of scouting age in the area.

THE four new titles of the popular Everyday Adventure Stories, a series related to social studies in the elementary schools, have the easy vocabulary, interesting plots and illustrations which have made the earlier books both informative and entertaining.

THE outstanding art event of the week was the annual ceremonial at the American Academy of Arts and Letters on Wednesday. Always a somewhat complicated and highly diverse affair, the event included the official award of the gold medal for architecture of the National Institute of Arts and Letters, presented by the academy, to architect Frank Lloyd Wright and the award of the Medal of Merit of the academy, to sculptor Ivan Mestrovic.

SOMETHING over a century ago (in 1816, to be exact) there was a year which New Englanders called Eighteen-Hundred-and-Froze-to-Death. This bit of laconic humor served to identify a period when there was frost and snow every month of the year in Vermont (and may well have been the origin of another New England statement to the effect that folks down that way know only two seasons: winter and August).

WITH "Julius Caesar," Hollywood hopes its Shakespeare jinx is broken. Through the years the big studios have made some heavily ambitious attempts to bring Shakespeare to life on the screen but almost always their efforts have brought failure.

TOKYO, Sunday, May 31 -- Chinese Communist troops resumed early today their attacks on the central Korean front where last week South Korean outposts had been stormed. But this time the Reds failed to make progress against the United Nations Command defenders.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 30 -- Through proper utilization of soil, water and climatic resources it is technically possible to bring about increases in agricultural production that not only will keep pace with population growth in the world, but also insure a reasonable standard of nutrition for all, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization believes.

TUBA players may believe that the Shubert Theatre is crowded these days because an compah boy is working in the orchestra pit for the first time in years. But everyone else watching "Can-Can" assumes that the main attraction is a redheaded dancer named Gwen Verdon, whose figure and style are the answer to those who wish Stravinsky had more Minsky.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., May 30 -- The importance of a strong citizens military reserve to the defense of the nation was stressed by Lieut. Gen Willis D. Crittenberger, United States Army, retired, in a Memorial Day address here today.

THE moon is the sky's most cooperative object. It never retires like the planets to the far side of the solar system. It always stays near by, posing nude and obliging in all angles of sunlight. Even amateur astronomers with puny telescopes can study its wrinkles and dimples in fine detail.

ALTHOUGH it does not yet loom as an inescapable consequence of the technical "revolution" which has slowed the production of films the chances are better than ever that the double feature will become a thing of the past before too long.

WHEN we read that "Nicholas wasn't one whit repentant about playing truant" the year 1493 does not seem very remote in time. Certain of Nicholas' problems, though, were very different from those of a twentieth-century 15-year-old.

NEWARK, May 30 (AP) -- Joey Giardello, eighth-ranking middleweight from Philadelphia, shook off the effects of cuts over both eyes to score an easy ten-round decision over lanky Hurley Sanders of Newark tonight. Giardello weighed 159, Sanders 158.
PARIS, May 30 -- This republican capital has caught some of the coronation fever of royalist London.

MOONTDOG, a blind street musician who plays in doorways on Sixth Avenue, has just recorded eight of the odd, exotic-sounding tunes which make up his repertoire on a record called Moondog on the Streets of New York (Mars, 45 r. p. m. Extended Play disk).

DEVON, Pa., May 30 -- My Bill, owned by William J. Brewster of Southern Pines, N. C., and ridden by Jack Goodman, won the Edward F. Beale Challenge Trophy in taking the championship at the Devon horse show today.

LIKE most little girls, Rainbow Jumper had a lively interest in clothes. This small Seminole Indian was as handy at running up a thousand-piece skirt as a grown woman and dreamed of a sewing machine of her own. That, she was sure, was the surprise her mother had promised her when the moon was new -- "something you will treasure * * * something to keep your hands busy."

When Robert Smithdas receives his Master of Arts degree at New York University's commencement exercises June 10 he will neither hear nor see the ceremony. The 27-year-old honor student has been blind since 6 and deaf since 10.

Electric light and power officials from all parts of the United States will hold their annual convention this week at Atlantic City. More than 3,000 are scheduled to attend. They are meeting in the midst of a mounting expansion program -- one which has seen the industry climb to a $25,000,000,000 private enterprise under the impetus of increased demand for power from residential, commercial and industrial consumers.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The United States "needs a new foreign trade policy recognizing our role as a creditor nation, and our agricultural trade policy must be in accord with that policy," Ezra Taft Benson, the Secretary of Agriculture, said today.

All the gamma globulin in the country is at the disposal of the Office of Defense Mobilization. Through the United States Public Health Service it will be allocated during the polio season to the state and territorial health officers. Plans for its distribution will be announced by these officers.

BALTIMORE, May 30 (AP) -- In a filly classic which might have belonged to almost anybody, John, John S. Phipps' Spinning Top hurried down the stretch to win the $20,000-added Black-Eyed Susan Stakes at Pimlico today.

Sound waves -- pitched so high that human ears cannot hear them -- now drive a new kind of machine tool that carves fancy shapes, drills holes and does other such work in hard steel, glass, ceramics or even precious stones. The machine was developed in the Raytheon laboratories, Waltham, Mass.

THAT "lean, sad-eyed master of song-craft," as the late Stuart Sherman once described the present poet laureate of England, celebrates his seventy-fifth birthday tomorrow. He richly deserves a toast. The name of John Masefield, I venture to say, will long outlast in English poetry many of those who have overshadowed him during the years of his reputation's decline.

WESTWOOD, Mass., May 30 -- The smooth dachshund, Ch. Hardway Welcome Stranger, owned and handled by Mrs. John W. Cross Jr. of Wilton, Mass., was named best in the Ladies Dog Club show tonight. Mrs. L. W. Bonney of Oyster Bay, L. I., sent the dog to the top.

Beethoven's "Sonata No. 29" will be one of several new recordings to be heard on Wednesday in the noon-to-2 P. M. recorded concert at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Cutner Solomon, one of the recognized Beethoven interpreters, is the pianist in this difficult work.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 30 -- The International Civil Aviation Organization's annual report released today showed that the world's airlines flew more passenger-miles in 1952 than in any previous year, with "the best worldwide safety record in aeronautical history."

Sportswear and separate departments were active in the wholesale market here last week with retail sales expected to be heavy, McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office, reported. Cashmere is expected to be important this fall as a fabric, color tone and fashion type in coats, sportswear, suits and dresses.

Random thoughts inspired by the small exhibition of work by Frank Lloyd Wright being held at the Academy of Arts and Letters galleries, in connection with the architect's receipt of the Institute's gold medal award presented by the Academy:

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 30 -- Joseph Giovanelli, who is blind, is to receive a bachelor degree in psychology from Syracuse University tomorrow and the view on the campus is that he deserves also a "doctorate in recording artistry."

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- It was a somewhat reluctant Congress that imposed an excess profits tax on corporations after the Korean war started in 1950, and it is an even more reluctant one that is now preparing to bow to President Eisenhower's wishes and continue the levy for another six months.

MELBOURNE, May 30 -- It is safe to say that no previous Coronation has evoked such lively, spontaneous interest among all sorts and conditions of Australians or moved them to think so purposefully about the nature and future of the British Commonwealth and the place of the Crown in its constitutional make-up.

One thousand children, their enthusiasm not dampened a whit by the weather, stared in amazement at a magician, swarmed over a New York City fire engine and tugged their parents from one ride to another yesterday at the annual carnival of St. George Protestant Episcopal Church, 207 East Sixteenth Street.

Columbia University will begin to close its 199th academic year today with the traditional baccalaureate service at 4 P. M. in St. Paul's Chapel on the Morningside Heights campus. Candidates for bachelor's degrees from Barnard and Columbia Colleges and other schools are to participate.

THERE is no need to wonder what to do with house plants now, for they can be moved outdoors. There are very few of them that won't grow there in summer. In fact, they'll enjoy a vacation in the great big outdoors.

PANMUNJOM, Sunday, May 31 (AP) -- The Communists today requested an extension in the current recess in the Korean armistice negotiations until Thursday, June 4, and the United Nations Command agreed. The talks had been scheduled to resume tomorrow after a week-long recess.

HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., May 30 -- Peddie School's undefeated track team, scoring 69 7/10 points won the seventh annual New Jersey Headmasters and Coaches Association invitation state track championship on Peddie's Walter H. Annenberg track today.

A SUCCESSFUL teacher (for a quarter of a century at Dartmouth College) is surely entitled to gather up the reflections induced by a study of comparative literature and to indict it as a gentle moral. The moral here is both negative and positive.

LONDON, May 30 -- It is hard for a foreigner to feel or understand the mood that grips the British people as the time time approaches for the Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II. It is a strange and inexplicable combination of religion, patriotism and paganism.

I am Richard Burns. You put my name in your paper which I did not mind. But I wish you would correct that I could not beat up Master de Wilde. All my friends are making fun of me. If you do not will make sure all the children in my class do not buy your paper.

IT is customary to speak of the departure of a distinguished artist and a man of exceptional character as an irreparable loss to his friends and his nation, and this holds true of the death of Albert Spalding, American's first great violinist of international achievement and fame, whose sudden death last Tuesday night was a wholly unexpected catastrophe.

IRIS time is truly one of the most delightful seasons in all the garden year, and in many gardens this week the Bearded group is the highlight. Mature clumps with a wealth of bloom present a fairyland picture of rainbow hues.

HARTFORD, May 30 -- A move for a reorganization of the administration of public education in Connecticut was rejected by the General Assembly, which adjourned early this morning after meeting for five months.

BEGINNING early this year with that phenomenal bestseller, "Desiree," novels centering on Napoleon Bonaparte and various aspects of his reign have been coming off the presses in astonishing numbers. Several have been excellent novelized history (such as "Why Waterloo?" and "The Eagle and the Rock").

OXFORD - educated Frank Moraes, barrister - at - law and editor of The Times of India, flew to Canton last year as a member of a Government of India cultural delegation headed by Nehru's sister, Madame Vijayalakshmi Pandit.
May I be permitted to offer through your columns some thoughts for the special consideration of those of your readers who supported President Eisenhower in the last election.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- President Eisenhower summoned his diplomatic and defense aides to an unusual holiday conference today on the disturbing military and political developments in Korea.

One of the many cults of India practices what is known as Ayurveda. Like many another, this cult has its own ideas about medicine and insists that certain drugs be prescribed in sickness. Not so long ago it was the fashion in the West to sniff and snort at these primitive prescriptions.

An "Art for Humanity" auction sale of nearly 100 donated paintings, sculpture and other works of art will be held at 8:30 P. M., Wednesday, at the Parke-Bernet Galleries. 980 Madison Avenue, by the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York.

IN "Shadows Move Among Them," Edgar Mittelholzer led his eccentric characters about their exotic world with grace and ease. He touched upon such delicate subjects as religion, sex, neurosis and death with subtlety, wit and tact.

LONDON, May 30 -- By coincidence the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II is bringing together in London the Prime Ministers of all the British Commonwealth countries at one of the most crucial moments of the post-war era.

A Navy pilot of World War II and Korea made a successful emergency landing yesterday afternoon in the waters off Atlantic Beach, L. I., after the engine had quit on a plane he was flying from the Naval Air Station at Atlanta, Ga., to Mitchel Air Force Base, L. I.
PALO ALTO, Calif., May 30 (AP) -- Southern California won the Pacific Coast track and field championships today for the thirteenth year in a row.

PETER RANDOLPH wanted to tend his proud Virginia acres, play the spinet and court pink-stockinged Lucy Garnett, his luscious neighbor. Fate, however, intervenes promptly. First the American Revolution breaks in.

TRENTON, May 30 -- The New Jersey Legislature met here last Monday and accomplished more than it had on any previous day in the last four months. At the same time it failed to complete action on or shelve for future consideration important legislation.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., May 30 (UP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman marched today in the front line of the Memorial Day parade from downtown Independence to Woodlawn Cemetery, a burial ground of pioneers.

A field of 129 golfers will participate in the metropolitan qualifying trials for the United States open golf championship at the two courses of the Winged Foot Golf Club, Mamaroneck, N. Y., tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 -- Somewhere today the sun was shining and somewhere baseball fans were shouting but in this City of Brotherly Love there were no sun, no noise and no game. For rain washed away one of the most lucrative dates of the season.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 30 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Fleet Bird came up in the final phases and captured the $50,000 added Argonaut Handicap by a length and a half at Hollywood Park today.
ST. LOUIS, May 30 -- The Braves kept first place in the National League today by taking both ends of a double-header from the Cardinals, 5 -- 2 and 6 -- 4, before a crowd of 30,105 at Busch Stadium.

JUSTICE WILLIAM O. DOUGLAS has long been deeply concerned about the gulf of misconceptions that plague relations between the United States and Asia. For several years he has been trying to do something to bridge this gulf by traveling in different parts of the East and reporting to the American people what he has done, seen and heard and the conclusions he has drawn.

The same techniques that are used by big corporations in selling consumer products are employed by persons soliciting contributions from such companies for various good causes, according to Edward B. Stearns Jr., a professional fund-raiser who in the past eight years has directed the collection of over $11,000,000 for some fifteen organizations.

THE schools are giving increasing attention to the problem of the retarded reader. A just-released report by the Bureau of Educational Research of the New York City Board of Education concerns "The Retarded Reader in the Junior High School,"

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 30 -- For the past few weeks the free world has been so busy arguing about the terms of an armistice in Korea -- and worrying about how to deal with the Far Eastern problems that will demand settlement once the fighting stops -- that the Soviet peace offensive, as such, has received little attention.

BELGRADE, May 30 -- A few weeks ago the window shutters came open on the Bulgarian Embassy building here and a couple of Iron Curtain diplomats applied for membership in the Yugoslav-operated tennis club for foreigners. If times were happier these would have gone unnoticed as simple acts denoting a natural desire for fresh air and exercise.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -- Bill Vukovich of Fresno, Calif., drove Howard Keck's Fuel Injection Special to an almost-all-the-way-in-front victory in the thirty-seventh 500-mile auto race today.

JUST a year ago Anne Frank's "Diary of a Young Girl" was published by Doubleday and enjoyed a solid run on the best-seller lists. Now word has come that the "Diary," an intimate, touching record of her life and her family's while in hiding from the Nazis, is having an even more astonishing success in Japan.

" There never was anything seen like the state of this town * * * the uproar, the confusion * * * carriages squeezed, jammed * * * the pavement blocked with timbers, hammering and knocking * * * the town all mob * * * gaping and gazing at everything * * * the Park one vast encampment, with the banners floating on the tops of tents * * *."

The short statement that Secretary of State Dulles gave out upon his return from a visit to twelve countries is hopeful. It is also crisp and pointed. He has set his finger upon several of the most critical problems in the area of the Near East and South Asia. With equal clarity he has touched upon a basic problem in our own relationships to some of the countries involved.
BODEGA BAY, Calif., May 30 (UP) -- The body of Mike DiMaggio, brother of the former baseball stars, Joe and Dominic DiMaggio, was found floating in Bodega Bay early today.
Racing fans at twelve tracks wagered the second highest Memorial Day total in turf history yesterday as 334,957 poured $18,769,122 through the pari-mutuel machines.

If the Air Force is going to have to cut back its comitments its Air Material Command is going to make every effort to see that the impact does not fall too hard on the 16,000 small business men in forty-five states whom it has induced to get into the production program.

MELBOURNE, May 30 (AP) -- After two weeks of confusion following the resignation of Arthur Coles, Control Committee chairman, and the adverse reaction of the International Olympic Committee, Melbourne once again has settled down to planning the 1956 Olympic Games.

GERANIUMS, full grown and in flower, made their annual debut last week. And each day for a couple of weeks will see more appearing both in window boxes facing city streets and in suburban flower gardens. Furthermore any gardener who has been tending a collection of geraniums indoors all winter probably has been planning to move his plants, however spindling, outdoors this week-end.
Americans and their friends all over the world paused in war, in work and in play yesterday to honor the nation's warrior dead on the eighty-fifth Memorial Day.

Job opportunities in the metropolitan area will increase 3 per cent by August, regardless of whether there is a truce in Korea, according to the managers of 4,400 local concerns employing 250,000 persons, who were questioned in April.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 30 -- A move to revise the Apostles' Creed, one of the most widely used declarations of faith in Christendom, was defeated overwhelmingly today by the 165th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A.

INTERESTING books have been written on the history, geography and scenery of the Mississippi, rolling from Minnesota southward to the Gulf. Nobody has ever written a book explaining how much nobler the river might have been if, by a relatively minor deviation of course at the source, it had rolled due west to engulf the Columbia and empty into the Pacific.

NEW YORK Airways, which is flying mail and air express shipments between the major airports in the New York metropolitan area and up to Bridgeport, Conn., by helicopter, has set Wednesday, July 1, as its target date for the beginning of inter-airport passenger helicopter service.

YOUR reviewer, Caroline Bancroft in her review of "Money Mountain," by Marshall Sprague cites as a fact from the book that the only authentic bullfight held in the United States was at Cripple Creek, Colo.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (UP) -- Jim Piersall dropped a fly ball in short centerfield in the ninth inning today to enable the Senators to gain a 2-1 victory over Boston after the Red Sox had won the opener, 4 -- 3.

TORONTO, May 31 -- With every inch of floor space filled with exhibits, officials of the Sixth International Trade Fair are concentrating on getting out a record number of buyers to make this the biggest and best year in the fair's history.

The development of this country's newest commercial airliner, the Douglas Aircraft Company's DC-7, is aptly shown in the line-up above of four Douglas planes graduated from left to right as to age and size: the two-engine DC-3 (at left); the four-engine DC-4, the comparatively new DC-6, and the new DC-7, just going into production.

VIENNA, May 30 -- The Czechoslovak Communists announced today a drastic revaluation of the Czech crown that combats inflation, hits money hoarders hardest and cuts heavily into bank accounts. It was coupled with an announcement that all state loans and securities issued since 1945 were worthless.

BESIDES being the flowery month of the Gregorian calendar, May also marks the time when the Broadway legitimate season draws to a close. Of the two the latter event, based on the termination of Actors Equity run-of-the-play contracts, which expire today, usually represents the true note of historical interest to the theatre student.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., May 30 -- To what extent may a state countenance violation of its own election laws?

SYDNEY, Australia, May 30 (UP) -- The Los Angeles All-Stars, an American rugby football team, made its official Australian debut today and lost to a special squad of Australian stars, 52 to 25, before 65,000 at the Sydney Cricket Ground.

PARIS, May 30 -- Ken Rosewall, the 18-year-old Australian champion, upset Vic Seixas of Philadelphia today to win the men's singles title in the French international tennis championships as Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., won the women's crown.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Finish sowing seed and transplanting annuals. Thin seedlings when about three inches high, but water the soil first. Regular watering is needed by transplants for at least three weeks and, if they are not moved when it is cloudy or drizzly, shading with burlap, newspaper, or with strawberry baskets, for a day or two.

The Eastern Intercollegiate Ski Association, at its annual meeting held recently in Hanover, N. H., elected Robert Searles, University of Vermont ski coach, the president. He succeeds Edward Blood, New Hampshire, who served the past two years. Ralph Townsend, Williams, was named vice president, and Graham Taylor, Harvard, re-elected secretary-treasurer.

The British have been vainly trying to climb Mount Everest since 1922. Last year two Swiss expeditions had to admit defeat. All told, fifteen climbers have died in attempts to scale the world's highest mountain. Unromantic Gradgrinds grudgingly concede some sense in fighting blizzards and ice floes to reach the poles and in penetrating jungles never before penetrated by white men.

HARLINGEN, Tex., May 30 (AP) -- They're not yet through auctioning Ray Barnick's "first bale." This season's first bale of cotton -- which brought grower Barnick on Friday what is believed a record price of $4,336 -- will be re-auctioned. Proceeds will be split 50-50 between the Waco Tornado Disaster Fund and the National Crippled Children's Society.

PHILADELPHIA is a unique city in that its various districts began as small towns and retain, after all these years, their individual identities and neighborhood characteristics. Albert Idell has written the story of one corner of such a district, using a store on Camac Street as the focus of his story.
LONDON, May 30 -- The Foreign Office announced today that Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden would fly to Boston June 5 for an operation by Dr. Richard Cattell of the Lahey Clinic.

OF the seventy-nine photographers from eleven countries represented in the show. "Post-War European Photography," which opened last week in the Auditorium Gallery of the Museum of Modern Art, only a small handful are known in this country. The pictures, which will hang through Aug. 2, therefore provide the first large group indication of what European photographers have been doing in the last few years.

HARTFORD, May 30 -- The Connecticut General Assembly, which meets every two years, adjourned early today after adopting a general fund budget of $243,383,000, the largest in the state's history, and a supplemental budget of $7,776.000.

THE study plant with round leaves and clusters of double flowers is undeniably a geranium, the old-fashioned kind which has been planted longer than anyone can remember here, there and everywhere across the country. It is, more precisely, a zonal geranium and is only one of several types classified as garden or cultivated geraniums.

" EARTH Dispatcher to Crew! Earth Dispatcher to Crew! Fasten all Space ports! Fasten all Space ports!" David and Jean were off on a rocket trip to the moon as conducted at the Planetarium. They traveled at the speed of their imagination but the voyage was based on careful scientific exploration.

TO those who have the impression that Federal regulation of child labor wages and hours, and government infant and maternity and other child care programs sprang full blown out of a Jovian New Deal, this book should be enlightening.
One of the advantages of excise taxes to the taxing authority is that they are self-assessed by the taxpayer. The taxpayer computes and pays the tax.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 30 -- Steward Lad, owned by the Carolina Stock Farm of Hobbsville, N. C., won the $4,500 Decoration Day Pace, the feature at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. A crowd of 25,074 saw the son of Steward, driven by Jimmy Jordan, move into the lead at the far turn and pull away from his opposition to triumph by two - and - a - quarter lengths.

The commands "full speed ahead" or "full astern" are being instantly carried out by the engineering cadet-midshipmen at the Maritime Service Training Station at Sheepshead Bay, but the young men just aren't getting anywhere despite their use of high-powered marine steam and Diesel engines.

SINGAPORE May 30 (UP) -- Gen. Raoul Salan, former French supreme commander in Indo-China, said today that French Union forces alone should defeat the Communist Vietminh provided Red China does not intervene.

THE recent trans-Atlantic debate on Korea, an East-West conference and the American Constitution emphasized again that the Anglo-American alliance is a process of seeking the same ends by different means.

Davis' short stories -- and the land of the Big Sky, like the author's own sunny prose, has a flavor and a color all its own.

New York Airways, the airline that carries mail, express packages and freight between the major airports of the metropolitan area and to eight communities between New York and Bridgeport, Conn., is converting its helicopters for passenger service and plans to begin flying travelers between New York and New Jersey on July 1.

EVEN the arrogant title. "Best Articles," doesn't spoil the contents. This anthology is enormously good and entertaining reading, and the subject-matter is refreshingly varied. One article spoofs experts on marriage, while another shows how these experts patch things up between husband and wife.

SCHOLARS have maintained that the book usually held by Hamlet in the "To be or not to be" scene is Cardano's "Consolation," a work with which Shakespeare was familiar and which raises perplexing questions about death.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- General Eisenhower returned from Paris just a year ago this weekend to make a political issue of Senator Robert A. Taft's views on foreign policy. Since then he has put on a lot of mileage and scored at least two notable electoral victories, but he was entangled none the less this week with the same gentleman on the same issue.

FERNAND BOURGES, who in collaboration with Anton Bruehl in the early Thirties "did more to bring color photography to the printed page than any other member of the photographic profession," has presented his collection of about 1,500 sets of four-color separation negatives of great paintings to the American Museum of Photography, 338 South Fifteenth Street, Philadelphia.

TRENTON, May 30 -- Under the leadership of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, New Jersey has joined ten other northeastern states in a coordinated traffic safety program designed to reduce substantially highway accidents through a stricter enforcement of traffic laws.

The firing of the first atomic shell from a 280-millimeter gun on the proving ground in Nevada was of historical importance. There is no doubt that the weapon will have some effect on our military policy and that of Soviet Russia, which has the largest standing army in the world.

The Dodgers defeated the Pirates, 7 to 4 and 4 to 1, yesterday to run their winning streak to eight games and move into second place, while the league-leading Braves maintained their half-game edge with 5-2 and 6-4 victories over the Cardinals.
LONDON, May 30 -- This is the time schedule for the Coronation of Queen Elizabeth:
TELEVISION cameras will be present for the first time Tuesday at the crowning of a monarch in Westminster Abbey in London.

IN "Monsieur Paul," the French novelist Henri Calet gives us a close-up of the cycles of rut and travail which are the average man's portion, and he throws in for good measure a glimpse of the bitter revolt each need engenders, revolt which, he implies, most frequently leads nowhere.
SEATTLE, May 30 (AP) -- Robert M. Watkins collapsed and died today while marching at the head of Seattle's Memorial Day parade. His age was 76.
MUNICH, Germany, May 30 (Reuters) -- Twenty transmitters were used by Radio Free Europe today in a "saturation effort" to get a message through to the Georgescus' sons in Rumania.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The United States has lifted two of four principal commercial and diplomatic sanctions that it imposed against the Czechoslovak Government because of the im prisonment two years ago of the Associated Press correspondent, William N. Oatis.

BONN, Germany, May 30 (AP) -- The United States High Commission today denied a charge by the wife of a jailed American business man that High Commissioner Dr. James B. Conant had failed to protect the rights of American citizens in Germany.

THE "pro-schmoe" tournament is an annual event at the Regency Club in New York. Pros are members with life-master ranking in the American Contract Bridge League. Schmoes are members of any lesser rank.

CARVILLE, La., May 30 -- Dr. Frederick A. Johansen will retire Monday as medical officer in charge of the United States Public Health Service Hospital here after twenty-nine years of work and success against Hansen's Disease, or leprosy.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 30 (UP) -- Representative James E. Van Zandt, Republican of Pennsylvania, said today that America's Allies "prefer war profits drenched with the blood of American youth" to peace in Korea.

Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan of South Africa, arriving in Britain for the coronation with messages of goodwill toward all inhabitants of the British Commonwealth whose skins are not too dark to suit him, has encountered a situation with which he finds it difficult to deal.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 30 -- Concrete negotiations for integrating Yugoslavia's armed forces with those of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, in an arrangement short of membership in NATO but including the development of a common strategy, are about to be resumed.

ROME, May 30 -- Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce, Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Defense Minister Randolfo Pacciardi and other United States and Italian notables stood in heavy rain at the military cemetery of Nettuno this morning while Memorial Day services were held at the graves of 8,000 American service men who lost their lives on the Anzio Beachhead in 1944.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 30 (AP) -- Closing with a burst of speed, Companas' Stable's Versify, a long shot, sped to a two-and-one-half-length triumph in the $20,000 added Colonial Handicap today in the rain before a crowd of 38,000.
The National Maritime Union has issued an appeal to its membership to urge speedy Government action to confer unemployment benefits on seamen who last worked on Government - owned ships.
NAIROBI, Kenya, May 30 (Reuters) -- Ten terrorists were killed today as Kenya warmed up for its tough new commander's all-out campaign against the anti-white Mau Mau.

A special meeting of the board of directors of the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., of 26 Broadway, called as a result of the recent death of the company's founder, Hans J. Isbrandtsen, has elected his son, Jakob, as president. Another son, Walter M. Isbrandtsen, was chosen vice president.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 -- McNair Ilgenfritz, a well-to-do though apparently frustrated composer who for twelve years held a box at the Metropolitan Opera, has left the bulk of his estate to the Met -- providing it will produce one of his operas.

Pakistan's Prime Minister, Mohammed Ali, has issued a comprehensive statement of policy on the major problems confronting his country. This statement is worth unusual attention becauses it came shortly before the departure of the Prime Minister for Great Britain, where, after the coronation, he will meet with Prime Minister Nehru of India for a discussion of their problems.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 30 -- A former inmate of Dachau prison, who has been on an eighteen-hour-a-day work and study schedule for the last four and a half years, will be graduated with honors at Rutgers University's 187th commencement here next Wednesday.

The familiar Central Circulation Branch of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street will still be recognizable, but barely so to the thousands of New Yorkers who use it when it reopens at 2 P. M., today.

More housewives abroad -- not necessarily typical or average -- are becoming customers for American products that make the home more pleasant, such as table lamps and electrical appliances. Orlon shirts, made in America, are being bought by men in the Philippines and New Zealand in preference to other kinds.

Brutus Hamilton, coach of the United States Olympic track and field team that competed in Helsinki, Finland, last summer, has been named coach of the United States Maccabiah squad for the fourth World Maccabiah Games at Tel Aviv, Israel, Sept. 20-29.

Leaflets listing simple precautions against polio are being distributed by the Greater New York Chapter of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis to children in public, parochial and private schools over the city.

MOSCOW, May 29 -- Pravda today delivered a sharp rebuke to press propagandists who are concentrating their chief attention on the problem of transition to a system of "product exchange" and declared that the Communist party and Soviet Government "during the coming historical period" would continue the development of Soviet trade based on monetary circulation.

The John Hay Whitney Foundation, in making its fourth annual awards, has granted scholarships valued at $100,000 to fifty-two persons in twenty states and six territories. These grants are designed to provide opportunities for Americans to advance their education and develop special talents so that they may make their maximum contribution to society.

LANCASTER, Pa., May 30 (AP) -- One of the most unusual accidents in railroading occurred here today when the last car of a freight train moving down Water Street jumped the tracks, smashed seventeen parked automobiles, damaged houses, fire escapes and parking meters in a three-block spree and then hopped back on the tracks.

OCEAN CITY, N. J., May 30 -- Repeating the victory of a year ago and under almost the same rigid bad weather conditions, Gene Gatter of Germantown, Pa., in his 27-foot Ventnor-built displacement speed boat Beaver II, today won the annual John E. Fite Memorial forty-three-mile marathon, sponsored by the Ocean City Yacht Club, to usher in the inboard speed-racing season on northern waterways.

OFFICIAL details of Australia's coming series for the sesquicentennial of British colonizing in Tasmania have been received. A large 2-shillings item will offer a view of Sullivan Cove in Hobart, from a painting titled "First Settlement on the Derwent River" in Sydney's Mitchell Library.
HARTFORD, May 30 -- Senator William P. Barber of Putnam charged in the Connecticut Senate early today that someone had detoured or "grabbed" bills en route to the House for action.

MONACO is preparing three stamps -- two, five and fifteen francs -- to commemorate one of medicine's progressive developments, the "Decouverte de l'Anaphylaxie" (Discovery of Anaphylaxis) by two celebrated French scientists, Paul Jules Portier and Charles Robert Richet.

FISHKILL, N. Y., May 30 (AP) -- Johnny Kelley, long-time distance runner from West Acton, Mass., today won the J. Gordon Flannery marathon as he covered the 25-kilometer route through roads of southern Dutchess County in 1 hour 24 minutes 16 seconds.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 -- The role of the grand jury in America's judicial system, and its right to make inquiries without interference of any sort, were highlighted during a Congressional investigation here today.

HYDE PARK, N. Y., May 30 -- The Roosevelt Home Club, an organization formed in 1928 when Franklin Delano Roosevelt went to Albany as Governor of New York, held its annual memorial service at the former President's home here today.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The bipartisan -- but mostly Democratic -- critics of President Eisenhower's defense plans are now preparing to wage with little heart and less hope a campaign to change both these plans and the President's mind.

MEXICO CITY, May 23 -- Nothing much has changed in the tiny Tarascan Indian village of Tarecuato for 400 years. Although only sixteen miles from a main highway, Tarecuato has lived in semi-isolation because there was no road joining the village and the highway.

Mayor Impellitteri will take to television for a series of weekly fifteen-minute programs beginning Tuesday night, June 9, to tell New Yorkers how the city is run. The programs will be presented over Channel 4, Station WNBT, at 7:15 o'clock.

Alex Kellner, burly southpaw of the Athletics, stepped to the mound at the Stadium yesterday with a chance to match a record held by only one player in the history of the American League, namely, the shutting out of the Yankees in three successive starts.

In 1878, Andover and Exeter met in baseball for the first time. On Saturday the arch rivals clashed for the seventy-third time. It was a routine game as the Exonians beat the Royal Blue, 7 -- 5. However, because it marked the attainment of a milestone three-quarters of a century -- the game recalled some early Andover baseball tales collected by Frank L. Quinby, class of '98.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 31 -- The Royal Danish Ballet closed its seven-day festival season here tonight at the Royal Theatre with one of the most brilliant and spirited ballet performances this writer has seen of "The Dream Pictures."

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- On the eve of Congressional hearings, there were strong indications on Capitol Hill tonight that President Eisenhower would not get the six-month extension of the excess-profits tax he wanted unless he rolled up his sleeves and really started working for it.

MILAN, Italy, May 31 -- According to Democratic leaders, Italy's Neo-Fascist and Communist parties have arranged a "marriage of convenience." Both parties, these leaders said, do not want to hurt each other with adverse political propaganda, but use their political ammunition to launch daily attacks from two fronts on Premier De Gasperi's Christian Democratic party, the strongest of the four-party anti-Fascist and anti-Communist coalition running on a joint ticket.

CLEVELAND, May 31 -- Charging that the country's Social Security system, was "a tangle of legalistic snarls and contradictions," Representative Carl T. Curtis, Republican of Nebraska and chairman of the House of Representatives Social Security subcommittee, declared here tonight that searching inquiry into the program was needed.

J., one of the country's best-known speed-boat drivers, collapsed today in the tiny cockpit of his 48-cubic-inch hydroplane Shooting Star while bidding for the lead at nearly a mile-a-minute speed on the second lap of the four-lap initial heat of a race on Lakes Bay.

NEWARK, May 31 (AP) -- Brewery union and management representatives reached agreement today on a few of the issues in a ten-day-old walkout of 6,000 drivers and plant workers.

A 17-year-old engineering student from India, who was a panelist on the New York Times Youth Forum last night, reversed the usual roles and instead of just answering the questions, he asked one.

Cotton futures prices succumbed last week to the growing bearishness in most other markets, and closed the week irregularly lower with active futures contracts down 40 points, or $2 a bale, to up 20 points, or $1 a bale.

SUPERIOR, Mont., May 31 (AP) -- A crack Tacoma-to-Chicago train, carrying 163 passengers, jumped the tracks near here early today and at least three dozen persons were injured as five cars skidded down a bank.

HAMBURG, Germany, May 31 -- The convention of the German party, the right wing of Chancellor Konrad Adenaeur's coalition Government, ended tonight after the delegates adopted a resolution declaring they would never renounce the Sear territory controlled by France and the territories beyond the Oder-Neisse line controlled by Poland.

Despite chilly temperature and threatening clouds, a small, hard group of music lovers assemble on the Mall in Central Park Saturday evening to hear a Memories Day concert by the Naumburg Orchester under the direction of Remus Tzincoca.

SOUTHVILLE, Conn., May 31 -A century ago this was a thriving hamlet with a church and an industry. Today, ignored even by the map makers, it is a place where three old houses survive inconspicuously among the towering elms and maples and the ruins.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, chairman of the Internal Security subcommittee, said today that it was considering legislation to wipe out statutory limitations on prosecution for war-time espionage. Present law bars prosecution after three years from the time of the alleged offense.
BRENTWOOD, L. I, May 31 -Mr. and Mrs. A. H. Merkel's dun gelding Why Daddy, from Brookville, L. I., took the open jumper championship at the Academy of St. Joseph Horse Show today.

VIENNA, May 31 -- The economic differences that caused the dissolution last year of Austria's coalition government formed by the People's and Socialist parties threaten to end the new coalition formed after last February's elections.

The centenary of the establishment of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York was observed yesterday at a pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The summer schedule of the New York Public Library system, which goes into effect today, provides for the closing of some facilities, primarily on week-ends, Ralph A. Beals, the director, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Despite peace moves by the Communists, the cold war dictates an upward revision in United States reserves of basic farm commodities, the agriculture committee of the National Planning Association said today.

A service of music and prayer was held last night in the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine) in honor of the approaching Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II.

PARIS, May 31 (AP) -- Lewis Hoad and Ken Rosewall of Australia today won the men's doubles title in the French international tennis championship and Doris Hart and Shirley Fry of the United States took the women's doubles crown.

LONDON, May 31 (Reuters) -- Prince Charles and Princess Anne appeared in a top-floor window at Buckingham Palace tonight, waving and laughing at 35,000 people massed outside the palace gates in hopes of a pre-coronation glimpse of Queen Elizabeth II.

DETROIT, May 31 (UP) -- Bob Lemon scattered eight hits today as the Indians handed the Tigers their seventh straight setback, 8 to 1, bfore 17,143 fans at Briggs Stadium for Detroit's longest losing streak of the season.

It is getting uncomfortably close to the end of the school year. The student who apparently has been doing nothing at school for months beyond witnessing motion pictures that reconstruct great moments in history, and sewing endlessly on a corduroy jumper in a home economics class when she was not burning biscuits in the ovens there, suddenly becomes extraordinarily busy.
PARIS, May 31 -- President Vincent Auriol was cheered roundly today by a large crowd outside the Elysee Palace, which remained until he came out on a balcony.

Representative Alvin E. O'Konski, Republican of Wisconsin, proposed yesterday that the United States finance and equip an anti-Communist Polish "Freedom Army" in Western Europe to bolster the Atlantic defenses in view of the uncertainty of whether "our allies will fight with us."

The Ford Foundation, completing the second full year of its active program, made grants in 1952 totaling $37,865,235, according to the annual report issued yesterday. Of this amount, $22,065,232, by far the largest appropriation, went to projects undertaken to advance education in America.

It cannot be emphasized too often that the work of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund has just begun. Sixty million children have benefited in the past few years from the food, clothing and maternal welfare programs that the Fund had initiated and induced recipient Governments to carry on and develop.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 31 -- A packet of blueprints related to work on the hydrogen bomb plant being built near Aiken, S. C., was found today in a stolen auto in which six youths were seized.

CHINHAE, Korea, Monday, June 1 (AP) -- A South Korean Government spokesman repeated firmly today -- after an emergency three-and-one-half-hour Cabinet meeting summoned by President Syngman Rhee, that his nation is determined to fight on if the United Nations Command signs an armistice on the basis of its latest proposal. Pyun Yung Tae, acting Premier, said:

LONDON, May 31 -- The dream of Britain, with her mystical belief in the continuity of a great national history, is that Tuesday's ceremonial splendor, when the Queen is crowned, will usher in another Elizabethan era, during which the strengths, glories and prosperity of the past may be resurrected in different form.

Thousands of out-of-town buyers have come into New York to attend openings of women's wear lines which begin this week. The influx which has filled midtown hotels, will continue for the next three weeks.

In a world where totalitarian regimes have trampled on "sacred loyalties" citizens of the United States should repledge allegiance to their country, where loyalty to God, the family and the Government are interwoven and not conflicting, the Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig, minister of the West End Collegiate Church, Seventy-seventh Street, west of Broadway, declared yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 31 (AP) -- Drastic reduction of customs barriers and plans for the free movement of capital between the Arab states were recommended by the Arab League economic congress that ended here today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 31 -- All trains of the Pennsylvania Railroad heading south and west out of New York were delayed considerably tonight by a power failure on the two southbound mainline tracks at Menlo Park, seven miles east of here.

The Board of Estimate will assemble this morning in special session to vote on the question of approving an agreement to turn over operation of the city-owned subway and bus lines to the newly established Transit Authority. It represents a major turning point in city policy, taking the fare-making power out of politics and establishing in law the principle that the transit system must be self-sustaining except as to capital costs.

PARIS, May 31 -- Negotiations are under way here and in Rio de Janeiro to increase trade between France and Brazil. They have been concerned principally with financial questions and the prices of the chief raw materials, such as coffee and cotton, that France imports from Brazil.

A vast expansion program, to cost $100,000,000 and to add classroom facilities for 90,000 children, is planned by the Roman Catholic school system of New York City. Registration in the Catholic schools is now at a record high.

PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., May 31 -- Figaro, a forty-foot yawl owned by William T. Snaith of the Cedar Point Yacht Club, was the over-all victor in the eighth annual Storm Trysail Club race to Block Island and return.

THE New York Football Giants had just beaten the Los Angeles Rams in a preseason exhibition game a few years ago and Stout Steve Owen was understandably elated. Yet a troubled frown persisted in sweeping across his brow.

TOKYO, Monday, June 1 -- Official Peiping sources today dropped what might be a hint that the Communist leaders would insist on acceptance of their own plan for a truce in Korea as a basis for negotiation.

LONDON, May 30 -- The theory that electric currents in the liquid metal core of the earth act like a dynamo and magnetize the whole terrestial sphere has been propounded by Dr. Edward C. Bullard, head of Britain's National Physical Laboratory near London.

In 1952, debt service was paid in full on $3,022,750,310, or 70.36 per cent of the $4,296,010,588 of publicly offered foreign dollar bonds outstanding, according to a study issued by Dean G. Rowland Collins, director, and Dr. Marcus Nadler, research director of the Institute of International Finance of New York University.
With President Eisenhower's discussion of the budget the general lines of Administration policy are emerging. The President's policy trinity is security, solvency and integrity of the dollar.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 31 -An eight-mile east-northeast breeze greeted fifty-one skippers on Long Island Sound, but only twelve of them finished in the New York Yacht Club's regatta today.
The 166 East Ninety-second Street Corporation, represented by Thayer and Gilbert, lawyers, has sold the apartment building at that address, which they acquired from the builder in 1928.

LONDON, May 31 -- After a week of almost hysterical merrymaking and rubbernecking by huge crowds that have kept London's traffic in a state of creeping paralysis, the thoughts of the British people began turning today to the more solemn aspects of the coronation.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Spokesmen for the Defense Department and the American Red Cross gave assurance tonight that every wounded soldier in Korea who needed whole blood would get it, just as he had in the past.

PITTSBURGH, May 31 -- Final figures will probably show that for the second time this year the steel industry has hung up a monthly record of 10,000,000 tons of steel. In March about 10.2 million tons were made. May will show close to that figure. This showing has been made possible by:

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 31 -- President Camille Chamoun's dissolution of the Parliament last night and his call for general elections in mid-July evoked today a predominantly favorable reaction here. The moves are likely to strengthen the moderate revolution that brought M. Chamoun to power last September.

Just sixteen years ago today the Susquehanna Railroad went into the United States District Court in Newark and filed a petition of bankruptcy. It was unable to pay its debts and said it desired to effect a reorganization under Section 77 of the National Bankruptcy Act.

Controller Lazarus Joseph indicated yesterday that he would vote today to turn operation of city-owned transit lines over to the New York City Transit Authority. The city's chief fiscal officer warned, however, that he would insist on a pledge from the authority that any increase in the 10-cent fare would be based solely on financial need.

ALGIERS, Algeria, May 31 -- When 270 pashas and kaids out of 370 sign a petition demanding the removal of their sovereign, Sidi Mohammed, the Sultan of Morocco, many in North Africa sit up and take notice.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 31 -- A highly placed Israeli Government official said today that negotiations between Israel and Jordan through the Mixed Armistice Commission for the resumption of meetings of local commanders along the border, were proceeding "favorably."
Mitchel Fein and associates have resold to the Pleasantville Realty Corporation, for investment, the fifteen-story apartment house on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 37-41 West Sixty-seventh Street.

In the perennial discussion of the Trieste problem everybody seems to have had his say except the Triestinos themselves. As a native of Trieste I may thus perhaps be excused if I want to enter a dissent from some of the opinions expressed by your readers.
The first week of June brings more than a score of new exhibitions into the New York galleries, about equally divided between group and one-man events.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 31 -- Things will begin humming again at Universal-International this week and it looks as if the studio will be turning out pictures at a more or less steady pace for the remainder of the year.

Opposition increased yesterday to the proposed extension of the 3 per cent city sales tax to more than thirty services not now covered by the impost. Several business and civic groups issued statements of dissatisfaction.

Continuing to pound the plaintive Pirates, the Dodgers yesterday beat them for the fifth straight time in three days, ran their winning streak to ten games and moved into first place in the National League. They took the first game, 4 -- 3, and the curtailed nightcap, 4 -- 1.
CHICAGO, May 31 (UP) -- The Browns rebounded, after losing the first game, 7 to 4, and defeated the White Sox by the same score to divide a double-header before 19,448 fans today.
ST. LOUIS, May 31 (UP) -- Harvey Haddix pitched a six-hitter today as the Cardinals beat the Cubs, 6 -- 2, on home runs by Solly Hemus and the league's leading hitter, Red Schoendienst.

Professional cooking in New York today is generally superior to what it was in 1904, when Otto Gentsch came here from Switzerland to begin a long and successful culinary career. The 73-year-old chef made this statement recently when he received the annual Debands Award in recognition of his half-century of service.

TOKYO, Monday, June 1 -- Medics in Korea have almost run out of whole blood to give wounded United Nations soldiers and may not have enough supplies if heavy fighting continues, Army authorities said yesterday.

Mrs. O'Leary's cow, according to legend, burned down Chicago a couple of generations ago. But, according to a proclamation by President Eisenhower, her successors, now largely confined to the farms of the United States, are just as lethal.

I've been watching this year's City Clean-Up Drive attentively. What has changed? If it wasn't my imagination, the Sanitation Department has worked harder than before to make the clean city dream come true. But what have the people done? Nothing. They toss everything away as usual, children drop banana peels and candy wrappers as they used to.

The American Bureau of Shipping, this country's leading ship classification society, which on May 1 was supervising the construction of 3,159,036 gross tons of shipping here and abroad, has decided to establish a number of technical committees abroad.

LONDON, May 31 -- Of the world's three reigning Queens, two will ride in state to Westminster Abbey on Tuesday. They are Elizabeth II of Britain and Salote of Tonga, an island group in the South Pacific. The third, Juliana of the Netherlands, will be represented by her consort, Prince Bernhard.

LONDON, May 31 -- For the first time in the history of the British chivalric orders, a jockey has been knighted. Gordon Richards, known to every British racegoer by his first name, will henceforth be called "Sir Gordon."
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The law of economics stopped today what the Bill of Rights failed to halt -- radio broadcasts on Washington's street cars and buses.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Harold E. Stassen, Director for Mutual Security, declared tonight that trade in non-strategic materials between free countries and those in the Communist bloc should be considered a factor in bringing about world peace.

NEW DELHI, India, May 31 -- Five Indian companies have received a monopoly of the assembly and manufacture of automotive vehicles in India to pave the way for the industry to become self-sufficient, it was officially announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 -- Federal Judge Louis E. Goodman was under subpoena today to appear before a Congressional subcommittee tomorrow at its final session of a three-day inquiry into the Federal administration of justice here.
Stadium Concerts will present a new feature at Lewisohn Stadium on June 25, a "Gala Latin-American Fiesta."
What we need is more humility, the Rev. Dr. Ralph Walker said yesterday in his sermon, "An Hour's Work, A Day's Pay" in the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, at Thirty-first Street.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 31 -- The 165th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. was told here this afternoon that "it is an awful commentary" on American Christianity when the question of civil rights assumed the status of a major issue in this country.

CINCINNATI, May 31 (UP) -- The Redlegs knocked the Braves out of first place today by scoring four runs in the seventh inning to win the opening game of a doubleheader, 8 to 6. The Braves bounced back to win the second game, 8 to 6, with three homers, but are one percentage point behind the Dodgers.

MERRICK, L. I., May 31 -- An hour after Mr. and Mrs. Archie Davis had said good-by to friends who had spent last evening playing canasta at their home at 331 East Smith Street, a fire of undetermined cause had killed the couple and their two small sons, Glen, 6 years old, and Dean, 3.

CHICAGO, May 31 -- Big reductions in the price of wheat and rye were registered last week, with a succession of new lows for the crop. Wheat and rye showed greatest weakness, which tended to undermine confidence in other cereals. Soybeans have resisted selling, many traders hedging their purchases by sales of grain futures.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Douglas William Hartman today was named as the United States representative on the board for the validation of German dollar bonds. The appointment was made by the Department of State, which also announced that Dr. Walter Reusch has been named by the German Government as its representative on the board.

The way in which the Communists have manipulated the whole question of a truce as a bit of tactics in making war is again illustrated in the movement to postpone the discussions. We are obliged always to remember that the genuine desire for peace, for its own sake, is no part of the Communist creed.

LITTLE SILVER, N. J., May 31 -This quiet, Monmouth County community, the home of State Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons, will be the scene tomorrow night of a widely publicized open-air fair that will feature wheels of chance and other fund-raising devices to test the validity of a recent state-wide crack-down on charity gambling.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 31 (UP) -- Two French mobile columns deep into the Communist-controlled parts of the Red River area and killed a total of fifty-two rebels and captured sixty others, the French High Command announced today.
The new Danish motorship Mexican Reefer, air-cooled for cargo and airconditioned for crew, is scheduled to arrive here today, the West Coast Line announced yesterday.

An aspect of physicians' activities not to be found in the American Medical Association sessions now in progress here was brought to New Yorkers' attention yesterday when the American Physicians Art Association opened its fifteenth annual exhibition.
TOKYO, Tuesday, June 2 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,635, for the twenty-four hours leaded at 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

Sales of three dwellings in Mount Vernon, N. Y., were reported by Finnerty's Real Estate, broker. H. R. Emde sold his home at 28 Parkway Circle to George W. Davis Jr.; Martin Dicker bought the house at 21 Sheridan Avenue from the Hagan Estate, and the house at 11 Wales Place was sold by Sam W. Friedman to Asher Schwartz.

Assiduous gave a fine demonstration of persistence in the Buskin at Belmont Park yesterday, and the demonstration paid off in victory. Under the expert guidance of Hedley Woodhouse, Assiduous overtook the Belair Stud's Prince Charlie in the stretch of the mile-and-a-sixteenth race, and finished a neck in front after a stirring contest.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal District Court at Miami, Fla., had jurisdiction to try a libel suit filed by Al Polizzi, a Coral Gables builder, against Cowles Magazines, Inc., an Iowa corporation that publishes Look Magazine.

Dr. Michael J. DiToro, formerly associate director of the Microwave Research Institute of Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute has joined the guided missiles division of Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation at Wyandanch, L. I., to head electronic engineering development.

STANTON, Del., June 1 (AP) -- Delaware Park's meeting, off to a fine start Friday and Saturday despite conflict with Maryland and New Jersey racing those two days and a rainy week-end, continued in high gear today as 13,007 fans saw Atlanta capture the Everget Purse.
LONDON, June 1 -- Under the influence of British Government securities, which rose about one-sixteenth of 1 per cent, most domestic industrials were firm on the stock market here today.

The market for United States Government securities fell sharply again yesterday in light trading. Of the Treasury's thirty-seven issues of bonds and notes, twenty-four fell in price to record low levels. The new 30-year 3 1/4s reached 98 5/8, a loss of 2/16 of a point, and the Victory 2 1/2S of 1972 broke through 90.

Even though it has not received the Production Code Administration's seal of approval, "The Moon Is Blue," the comedy produced and directed by Otto Preminger for United Artists release and adapted by F. Hugh Herbert from his long-run play, has been booked for simultaneous openings at the Victoria and Sutton Theatres the first week in July.

A three-story apartment house accommodating seventeen families on a plot 80 by 110 feet at 234 Walnut Street in Roselle, N. J., has been sold by Howard J. Wenz to Ethel Morrison. The sale was made through J. I. Kislak, Inc., as broker.

William Wyer, trustee of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road, told Judge Mortimer W. Byers of the United States Distinct Court yesterday that the railroad was willing to pay Nassau County $1,689,522 and Suffolk County $453,778 for back real estate and special franchise taxes.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Tuesday, June 2 -- John Cardinal Alton, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Armagh and Primate of all Ireland, surprised Northern Ireland last night with a coronation greeting to Queen Elizabeth II in which he expressed the hope that her reign would bring the unity of Ireland.

The Board of Estimate voted 11 to 5 yesterday to lease the city's $1,700,000,000 transit system to the newly created New York City Transit Authority for a period of ten years, during which the authority will be obligated to raise enough revenue from fares and incidental charges to meet operating costs.

ROME, June 1 -- The number of Communists who in recent months have abandoned their party and embraced democracy has grown so large that the Christian Democratic party inaugurated today a special "course of democratic orientation" for their benefit.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, June 2 -- President Syngman Rhee, who has been personally directing a program of resistance to the Allied truce plan, returned to Seoul late yesterday afternoon from Chinhae, where he had held an emergency session with his Cabinet on the armistice negotiations.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to re-establish the Council of Economic Advisers as a three-man agency but to grant its chairman greater administrative and policy-making authority than his predecessor enjoyed in the Truman Administration.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 1 -- Independent intelligence reports reaching official Asian agencies here concur in the conclusion that not all the regular Vietminh troops that invaded Laos six week ago have been withdrawn from that Buddhist kingdom in Indo-China.
KATMANDU, Nepal, Tuesday, June 2 -- The British expedition has conquered Mount Everest, a radio message flashed from Namche Bazar to the British Embassy here said today.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 1 -- The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. rejected here today an attempt to alter the Lord's Prayer by adopting in place of "forgive us our debts as we forgive our debtors" the phraseology, "forgive us our sins as we forgive those who sin against us."

A Committee for Liberation of Argentine Intellectuals has been formed by writers, artists and others here "in spontaneous reaction to the recent wave of imprisonments of intellectuals in Argentina," according to an announcement yesterday.
TRENTON, June 1 -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation and two German concerns settled an eight-year-old Federal anti-trust case here today when both parties signed a consent decree.
Record sales and increased earnings were reported yesterday by Federated Department Stores, Inc., for the thirteen and fifty-two weeks ended on May 2.

TRENTON, June 1 -- Federal immigration officials moved into New Jersey State Prison here again today to continue their efforts to expedite the deportation of Joseph Doto, alias Joe Adonis. The racketeer and alumnus of Brooklyn's Murder, Inc., is charged by the Government with being an undesirable alien who entered the county illegally.

A former police inspector whose retirement was forced by Police Commissioner Thomas F. Murphy in 1950 as a result of the Harry Gross bookmaking scandal was revealed yesterday to be one of the twenty-three persons indicted several weeks ago in Staten Island for felonies in connection with gambling violations.

TORONTO, June 1 (UP) -- Nineteen 3-year-olds were entered today for the ninety-fourth running of the historic Queen's Plate tomorrow at Woodbine Park, with E. P. Taylor's Canadiana a heavy favorite to win the most coveted prize in Dominion racing.
