WASHINGTON, June 1 (Reuters) -- Five prominent United States citizens, including two women, were on Queen Elizabeth's honors list, the British Embassy announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it was selling more surplus Government-owned food this year than it had in 1953 in an effort to cut storage costs.

Terminating an ownership of about one month, Joseph L. Ennis Co., real estate operators, have resold the apartment property at 230 West Sixteenth Street to Frances A. Engle. Harold M. Silverman was the broker.

Floyd Patterson, 19-year-old Brooklynite who won the Olympic middleweight crown at Helsinki last summer, gained his seventh straight victory as a professional last night when he stopped Gordon Wallace of Brantford, Ont., in the third round of the scheduled eight-round feature bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn.

LONDON, Tuesday. June 2 -- Flowering plants brought to bloom at precisely the right season were being set out today around the grandstands for the coronation spectators in Parliament Square and around the annex erected at Westminster Abbey for Queen Elizabeth and the members of her coronation procession.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 1 -- -- Dr Nathan Marsh Pusey, president of Lawrence College in Appleton, Wis., was elected the twenty-fourth president of Harvard by the Harvard Corporation today.
Following is the text of an address, delivered last night by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, on his recent trip to the Middle East and south Asia, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

LONDON, Tuesday, June 2 -- Men in 500 different uniforms, including such oddities as Nepalese Gurkhas in tartan kilts and Scottish Highlanders with Asian tiger skins on their backs, will march out of Hyde Park this morning to participate in the coronation of their Queen.

The Senate Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce and the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries axe considering identical bills that would abolish certain features of the Merchant Ship Sales Act of 1946 considered discriminatory by shipping companies that purchased war-built tonnage before the enactment of the law.

Canned salmon is fast becoming a luxury item and "is well on the way to being priced out of the mass market," writes Richard Hooker, head grocery buyer of Food Fair Stores, Inc., Philadelphia, in the latest "Weekly Digest" of the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc.

CLEVELAND, June 1 -- Dr. Seymour E. Harris, Professor of Economics at Harvard University, warned today that the country might be confronted with a depression on the scale of that of the Nineteen Thirties if proposed cuts in military spending were not offset by increases in welfare expenditures.
LONDON, June 1 -- Mr. and Mrs. A. C. Gingerich of Wellman, Iowa, are going to see Queen Elizabeth's coronation procession in style.

Because of the high cost of operation, the Howe Plan Fund, Inc., an open-end investment company, plans to sell its assets to the Whitehall Fund, Inc., part of the Tri-Continental Corporation group of investment companies, Lee J. Rusling, president of Howe Plan Fund, announced yesterday.

Sales in twelve New York and Brooklyn department stores in May averaged 5 per cent below those of the corresponding month last year, according to a survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The decline in April was 3 per cent, and May therefore was the second consecutive month in which a loss was shown.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 1 -- Alumni Day featured today the June Week activities at the United States Military Academy. The 1952 class came of age after a year's "subjugation" to the upper classmen and the 510 members of the graduating class paraded on the Plain for the last time this afternoon.

On a busman's holiday from the galleys of the Swedish-American liner Gripsholm, Chef Anders stromblad is "vacationing" as an observer in the St. Regis Hotel's kitchen. We descended recently to that subterranean realm of pots, pans and tantalizing aromas to discuss his suggestion for a new kind of summer lunch or supper.
LONDON, Tuesday, June 2 -- Following is the order of the procession to and from Westminster Abbey of those attending the ceremony of the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II today:

In your issue of May 28 you printed an article reporting that Crete Anderson, chairman of the American Legion's Immigration Committee, objects to President Eisenhower's program to admit 240,000 immigrants from Europe. The basis for this opposition, apparently officially sanctioned by the American Legion, is that "it would mean an addition of 1,250 potential spies and saboteurs to our present 'powder keg' situation."
LONDON, June 1 -- There was a family reunion at Buckingham Palace today, a gathering of the representatives of the family of nations of the British Commonwealth.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 2 -- At 6 o'clock this morning the most distinguished men in Britain began filing past an empty throne. Within a few brief hours, seated upon it and wearing the heavy crown of St. Edward the Confessor, a young Queen will receive their homage.
Traders and vistors thronged the floor of the Commodity Exchange here yesterday as dealings in copper for future delivery were resumed after a lapse of nearly two years.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Internationalist Senators awaited with anxiety today a lead from President Eisenhower as the Senate approached a showdown on a proposed rider that would in effect withdraw the United States from the United Nations if Communist China should be admitted.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Geologists are scouring the country for a new strategic metal -- hard, lustrous, steel-gray niobium. Until recent years it has been little more than a curiosity, of no commercial importance. Now it is vital for the production of high-temperature- resistant alloys for jet engines.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 2 -- This is the day that all London, all Britain, all the Commonwealth and half the world have been awaiting. It is the day on which the crown of her forefathers is placed upon the head of this old country's radiantly lovely young Queen Elizabeth II whose reign, it is hoped, will usher in another golden age.
TORONTO, June 1 -- Canada fired its third friendly salvo of recent weeks at the protectionist policies of the United States as its sixth international trade fair openend here today.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- Following are the texts of messages sent to Congress today by President Eisenhower in support of his reorganization plans: ...

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- President Eisenhower accepted today "with regret" the resignation of Carl R. Gray Jr. as Administrator of Veterans' Affairs. The White House did not make public the exchange of letters between Mr. Gray and the President, but said that Mr. Gray had resigned because of ill health.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 2 -- North Korean troops launched a series of determined attacks against South Korean-defended main line positions on the extreme eastern and east-central sectors of the Korean front last night and this morning. The fighting, which was continuing in some sectors at last report, was described by an Eighth Army spokesman as the heaviest in many months in that area.

SESTO SAN GIOVANNI, Italy, June 1 -- In this industrial suburb of Milan, the Communists and their allies, the Left-Wing Socialists, have given up their strong-arm methods during the present political campaign for the national elections on June 7.

East Baton Rouge, La., Consolidated School District No. 1 sold yesterday $12,500,000 of bonds maturing from 1954 to 1972 to a syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., the only bidder, at an interest cost of 3.35 per cent.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- The grain trade was semi-demoralized at times today, with little demand to cushion further liquidating sales. New crop lows were the order of the day, but there were periods of short profit-taking which tended to steady the markets.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Raymond Henry Fogler, president and director of the W.T. Grant Company, chain store concern, to be Assistant Secretary of the Navy.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 1 -- John Hay Whitney, industrialist and philanthropist, speaking at Fisk University's graduation exercises today, warned against the bigot who was "chained to his fixed idea" and tried to prove his point "not by thought but by insistence."

A "Hymn of Praise," composed by a New York University student especially for the N. Y. U. baccalaureate service, will be sung by a twenty-five-voice choir on Sunday at the Gould Memorial Library on the University Heights campus.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The absenteeism that was responsible for the failure of a quorum of the Senate Judiciary Committee to assemble today may reflect waning interest in favorably reporting at this time the resolution designed to put specific limitations on the treaty-making power of the President and the Senate.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 1 -- "The Covered Wagon," one of the milestones in the development of the Western film, is up for remake at Paramount and, of course, will get the wide-screen and stereophonic sound treatment. Studio officials got to thinking about the 1923 epic of pioneer days in the West when box-office receipts started coming in from the recently released "Shane."

LEICESTER, England, June 1 (UP) -- Spurred on by cheers of "Come on, Sir Gordon," Britain's champion jockey, Sir Gordon Richards, scored his first victory as a knight today at the Leicester Race Course. The crowd gave Richards a tremendous ovation as he won by eight lengths aboard Mirabelle, a 2-to-5 favorite.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., announced yesterday that a new nickel recovery project in the Sudbury District of Ontario had enabled it to sign a contract to supply the United States Government with early delivery of 120,000,000 pounds of metallic nickel and 100,000,000 pounds of electrolytic copper.

The revised section of the Sanitary Code dealing with maternity services, adopted by the Board of Health on April 13, went into effect yesterday at all hospitals in the city offering care to prospective mothers and newborn babies.

Mrs. Jacob Jofen, 29 years old, is the mother of three children, Aron, 8, Fay, 6, and Mordechai, 3. She is also the author of "Synchronic Description and Division of Eastern Yiddish Dialects," a thesis that earned the degree of Doctor of Philosophy that Columbia University will confer upon her today.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 2 -- The most significant of all the gowns to be worn today at the great coronation ceremony in Westminster Abbey will be those designed by Norman Hartnell for Queen Elizabeth II, the Queen Mother, Princess Margaret, the Duchess of Kent, Princess Alexandra and the Queens' six maids of honor.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 1 (AP) -- Gay Abbe, owned by Edward O'Dowd of Pine Brook, N. J., took the lead on the far turn and went on to score a two-length victory tonight in the Hicksville Pace at Roosevelt Raceway. The victory was Gay Abbe's third of the year.

Nearly everybody in these parts has been saying that May was wetter than usual, what with the badly watered-down Memorial Day and the Sundays behind the Shower Curtain. And yesterday the Weather Bureau agreed that it was so.

Betty Field will star in and Elmer Rice will direct her in Mary Drayton's new comedy, "The Peaceable Kingdom," which the Theatre Guild is testing at the Westport (Conn.) Country Playhouse the week of June 22 with a Broadway presentation in mind for next fall.

Our democratic processes of government are sometimes criticized as being slow and cumbersome. No such criticism is applicable to the establishment of the New York City Transit Authority, which becomes a going concern with Board of Estimate approval yesterday of the lease agreement.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Eisenhower Administration was reported today to have had a new request from President Syngman Rhee of South Korea for the pledge of a mutual defense pact and of military and economic help as a basis for the Seoul Government's support of present Allied truce proposals.
Memo to a couple who taught their daughter to be honest:

ARCADE, N. Y., June 1 (UP) -- The Arcade Attica railroad, a two-diesel engine, thirty-mile, all freight operation, today celebrated its thirty-sixth anniversary as a company and its 100th since tracks were laid between the two western New York communities.

IT was summer in the Shenandoah Valley thirty years ago. Tucker English was only 10 years old. School seemed unimaginably far away. His father, who employed so many men on the big family farm, was a dashing, omniscient person. His mother was kind. His grandmother was fascinating with her tales of the heroic deeds of Grandfather McCantland in the Civil War.

Broderick Haskell, a director and a member of the executive committee of Combustion Engineering, Inc., has been elected vice chairman, it was announced yesterday by J. V. Santry, chairman. The resignation of Mr. Haskell as a vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York also was announced.

BONN, Germany, June 1 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Government has embarked on an intensive diplomatic campaign to convince the United States, British and French Governments that Western Europe's political, military, economic integration must be given precedence over all other possible "European solutions" at the forthcoming Bermuda conference of the Western Big Three.

VIENNA, June 1 (AP) -- The Czechoslovak Communist Parliament has decreed that all men less than 60 years of age and women less than 50 can be forced to work unlimited hours for the state or community outside of their regular working time.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 1 -- Victims of continued unrest reported in Israel today were a 16-year-old boy killed and two boys and two girls wounded last night in an ambush south of Meron in Galilee.
WRENTHAM, Mass., June 1 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon asserted tonight that "no man is more effective in Washington in support of the President than Joe Martin."

Ben Hogan, in town before leaving for Oakmont, Pa., announced yesterday that he had filed his entry for the British open golf championship that will be played at Carnoustie, Scotland, starting July 6.

Thirty seniors, constituting 13 per cent of the graduates who will receive degrees from Barnard College this afternoon, are already married, and an additional 15 per cent will be married soon after graduation. The majority of these students plans to pursue a career.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- President Eisenhower today urged a permanent and clear separation between airmail payments to domestic and overseas airlines and the regular subsidies paid to the industry, estimated at $79,326,000 for this fiscal year. Air mail service payments are estimated at $53,477,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 1 -- The nation's fastest-growing industry, the $25,000,000,000 private electric power and light systems, plans to meet all competition from Federal power projects, Walter H. Sammis, president of the Ohio Edison Company, said today. He is slated to be elected president of the Edison Electric Institute on Thursday afternoon before 3,000 delegates attending the power and light industry's annual convention.

First place in the National League pennant chase will be at stake tonight when the Dodgers, showing the way by a half game, tackle the runner-up Braves, in the opener of a three-game series at Ebbets Field.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- George Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, told Congress today that only "full mobilization" would justify tax increases to produce any more revenue than the Administration was now seeking.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Representative Samuel W. Yorty, Democrat of California, declared tonight that about $1,000,000,000 had been restored to the proposed Air Force spending budget for the fiscal year starting July 1. He said that Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, had notified him of the change.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- President Eisenhower was batting 1,000 on reorganization as he sent four more plans for unifying Government operations to Capitol Hill today.

MONTREAL, June 1 (Canadian Press) -- Exiled Cubans, leaders in the fields of politics, labor, youth and professions, met today to attempt to arrive at a common policy in their fight against President Fulgencio Batista.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., June 1 -- Three patrolmen played Horatius today at the site of the proposed third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel, under orders to arrest contractors crews trying to move in equipment as a preliminary to digging the main New Jersey shaft.
The perennial problem of what to do about the Government's overseas information program has received a new answer in the reorganization plan that President Eisenhower has sent to Congress.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- President Eisenhower proposed today to restore the State Department to its traditional pre-war policy-making role and to transfer virtually all its operating functions to new organizations -- the United States Information Agency and the Foreign Operations Administration.

LITTLE SILVER, N. J., June 1 -- This community's volunteer firemen held a widely publicized "test" fair here tonight, with games of chance in full operation, to find out what would happen under a recent state-wide crackdown on charity gambling.

OMAHA, Neb., June 1 -- The Mormon Pioneer Memorial Bridge, just above Omaha, where the Mormons crossed the Missouri by ferry in 1846, was dedicated today, marking the close of two days of ceremonies participated in by the highest authorities of the church.

TRENTON, June 1 -- The Supreme Court of New Jersey upheld unanimously today the conviction of the Western Union Company and one of its managers, who had been accused of transmitting $300,000 in horse race bets annually at Bridgeton, N. J.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and prices closed irregular 9 points lower to 5 points higher than on Friday.

The perjury conviction in 1952 of Joseph C. Workman, 49-year-old retired police captain, was reversed "on the law" yesterday by the Appellate Division, Second Department, in a unanimous decision. The court ordered a new trial.

B. Patrick Abbott of Memphis, a former movie extra and now a golf pro, paced the nation yesterday with a 5-under-par 69, 66 -- 135 at Memphis as 265 amateurs and professionals qualified for the United States Open championship at Oakmont, Pa., June 9-13.
Pressures from the slumping market for Treasury bonds -- down for the seventh trading day in a row -- sent stock prices into a rapid decline yesterday. Losses of 1 to 3 points were the rule.

Troop carrier and transport aircraft, photo-reconnaissance and other specialized types, air defense and aircraft production are among the elements of air power that may be adversely affected by the Administration's sharp cut in the defense budget for the next fiscal year.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 1 -- President Tito abolished today the system of political commissars in the Yugoslav armed forces, asserting that present conditions no longer required them.

An American edition of a long-lost autobiographical novel by Benjamin Constant de Rebecque (1767-1830), French writer, politician and author of the autobiographical-psychological novel, "Adolphe," will be issued June 26 by New Directions. The "lost" novel, titled "Cecile," is believed to have been written in 1811 and laid aside.
HANOI, Vietnam, June 1 (AP) -- A French Army spokesman announced tonight that Vietminh forces were concentrating heavily in the Phoyen sector, about thirty miles north of Hanoi.
Following is a digest of the Agreement of Lease made yesterday between the City of New York and the New York City Transit Authority:

The Richfield Oil Corporation announced yesterday that it had completed arrangements for $65,000,000 of financing. Through Kuhn, Loeb Co., the company sold privately to institutional investors $40,000,000 of thirty-year 3.85 per cent debentures, and has arranged a bank loan of $25,000,000 bearing 3.25 per cent and payable in ten annual instalments to 1963.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 1 -- Brown University awarded baccalaureate degrees to 601 men and women at the 185th commencement today. The university also conferred eight honorary doctoral degrees and awarded the Susan Colver Rosenberger medal to W. Randolph Burgess, of the class of 1912, deputy to the Secretary of the Treasury.

The conquest of Mount Everest, highest charted mountain in the world, has been the burning dream of mountain climbers the world over for more than thirty years. But every previous attempt of men to clamber to its icy summit has been thrown back by the towering giant of the Himalayas.

BOONTON, N. J., June 1 -- Milton (Babe) Lichardus, New Jersey open champion from Baltusrol, and Frank Harned of Rock Spring playing in his first national open qualifying round, led a field of seventy-seven at the Knoll Club today with a thirty-six-hole total of 143.
Defending champion Steve Gottlieb of Fieldston and second-seeded Steve Bank, DeWitt Clinton High, won tennis singles crowns at the River View courts in the Bronx yesterday.

Twenty-seven masters, presidents, vice presidents and acting presidents have presided over what is now Harvard University. The names of three of them -- Charles W. Eliot, A. Lawrence Lowell and James B. Conant -- are familiar to most Americans of this generation.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Representative Clifford R. Hope, Republican of Kansas and chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, announced today that a subcommittee would investigate the sale of 80,000 tons of Government-owned Austrian winter peas to three West Coast feed companies.
Following are short biographies of members of the British Expedition, two of whose members reached the top of Mount Everest: ...

Many years ago a little girl stood at the window of her nursery and looked out on the roofs of London, over which a night thunderstorm was breaking. She made a speech, short but succinct and spoken loudly, for fear, in the heavenly tumult, she might not be heard.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan announced yesterday at a ceremony at Police Headquarters at which 500 men were sworn in as probationary patrolmen that two policemen had been promoted for their part in a successful chase of four robbery suspects in the Bronx on Thursday.

Chase National Bank is distributing to its 9,600 employes a sixty-four-page book outlining an employes' benefit program described by Percy J. Ebbott, president, as "one of the most important accomplishments in the bank's history" and an opportunity for the bank's workers "to participate more directly in the rewards and risks of our economic system."

Plans for a full-scale civic and business onslaught on tile city administration's proposed local law to extend the 3 per cent retail sales tax to more than thirty categories of services not now covered were announced yesterday at a meeting at the Martinique Hotel.

The architects of a house with an open floor plan in which the heating and cooling unit and other utilities are-placed in the center will receive a $5,000 prize for the design at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel today.

Thomas J. Curran, Manhattan Republican leader, denounced yesterday as "political effrontery" and "a campaign stunt" Mayor Impellitteri's plan to make a series of telecasts over station WNBT that will tell New Yorkers how the city is run.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 1 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, the new Supreme Commander of Allied Forces in Europe, is one of ten leaders in government, education, science and the arts who will receive honorary degrees at Rutgers University's 187th commencement on Wednesday, it was announced today by Dr. Lewis W. Jones, university president.

A ban on curb parking of cars to be sold through raffle or lottery procedures in the mid-Manhattan and downtown Broadway areas was urged yesterday. Furthermore, it was charged that rackets were concealed under the guise of charity in some cases.

Under orders from the American Federation of Labor to stop organizing taxicab drivers in this city, Local 102 of the United Automobile Workers, A. F. L., notified its members last night that it was going out of business, effective at once.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (AP) -- Federal Judge Allan K. Grim today said he would have to get a definite point of view from the United States Attorney General before acting on a plea by the National Football League for a delay in the Government's anti - trust suit against the loop.

" Sometimes a typewriter disappears and we have to redeem it at the hockshop," George Goetscius, head worker of the Madison Street Settlement, was saying. "Occasionally our screen projector finds its way into a hockshop and we have to buy it back."

The letter of Marie Duff in THE TIMES of May 27 contains the following questions: "Since Frederick Allen admits in his letter that he has been traveling, and so out of touch with current American problems, how can the gentleman know what the Senate committee has accomplished? How can anybody judge McCarthy without actually viewing the televised investigations?"

THE Giants knocked down the Dodgers and then trampled disdainfully all over them twice in a row a little more than a week ago. Polo Grounds fans were exultant. This was the break they'd been awaiting. The hitters were hitting and the pitchers were -- well, at least they had Hoyt Wilhelm to stifle the opposition in relief.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP) -Four Cabinet officers will join President Eisenhower Wednesday night when he makes an informal television talk to the nation, the White House announced today. They will be Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, and Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 1 -- The pacemaker in the Metropolitan District's qualifying trials for the United States open golf championship at Winged Foot Golf Club today was 29-year-old Michael (Mickey) Homa, playing professional of the Westchester Country Club.
Nobody ever saw a large sow in a prisoner's cell block -- until yesterday.

A public demonstration of subscription television will be conducted at the Belmont-Plaza Hotel, Lexington Avenue and Forty-ninth Street, from June 9 to 17 by the Skiatron Electronics and Television Corporation. Known as subscriber-vision, the system is one of several under development for equipping home receivers with a "box office."

The New York regional Red Cross will seek 20,000 pints of blood from donors during June. T. Morgan Williams, chairman, announced yesterday. This Mr. Morgan said, is the minimum needed to fulfill requests from the armed forces, commitments for gamma globulin to protect children from paralysis from polio, and for local needs.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- President Eisenhower proposed today to put the operation of all foreign aid programs -- military, economic, technical and humanitarian -- under a single Federal agency receiving "policy guidance" from the Secretary of State.

Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, declared at the annual meeting of the American Medical Association, which opened yesterday, that organized medicine must find solutions to the social-economic problems facing medicine today or the solution would be taken out of its hands.
Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman denied yesterday a "transparent" motion by Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, condemned atom spies, to reduce their death sentences to twenty years' imprisonment.

Improved methods for the early detection of cancer of the digestive tract, which is responsible for 41 per cent of the annual cancer deaths in the United States, were demonstrated at the Grand Central Palace yesterday by a University of Chicago research team.
LOS ANGELES, June 1 -- Retailers expect a continued high level of sales and steady prices for dry goods through the rest of the year. But they have their problems.

This newspaper periodically asks its readers to give blood to the Red Cross, so that the needs of the wounded soldiers abroad and the ill or injured here at home may be satisfied. Yesterday on page one we read of the critical shortage of whole blood in the hospitals and front-line medical stations in Korea.

SEOUL, Korea, June 2 -- President Syngman Rhee disclosed today he had received a three-point message from President Eisenhower, and added: "We must accept anything that the United States President wants."

Importers here were mystified yesterday by a week-end report from Washington that the State Department last week had lifted trade curbs imposed two years ago on Czechoslovakia in retaliation for the imprisonment of Associated Press correspondent William N. Oatis.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said tonight that it was the policy of the Eisenhower Administration to develop goodwill among the nations of the Near East and South Asia to thwart the Kremlin's desire to exploit their many differences.

Steel operations this week are scheduled at 100.3 per cent of the industry's theoretical capacity and production is expected to be 2,262,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The industry is thus expected to duplicate last week's actual rate and production.

Brazil is making a special effort to raise production in order to improve the domestic economy and increase exports to the United States, Licurgo Costa, director of the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau in New York, said yesterday. He spoke at a meeting of the Machinery-Metals Export Club in the McGraw-Hill Building, 330 West Forty-second Street.

Methods of trapping drunken drivers by scientific methods were outlined yesterday at the Center for Safety Education, New York University. Thirty-two police and public health officials attended the opening session of a one-week course designed to show how to administer chemical tests for intoxication.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 2 (Reuters) -- Nearly 40,000 bell-ringers will go into action throughout Britain today to herald the crowning of Queen Elizabeth in the greatest peal of bells in the country since V-E Day.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 -- Federal Judge Louis E. Goodman refused today to answer questions put to him by a House Judiciary subcommittee concerning actions of courts in this area on the ground that to do so would "make the Judiciary of the United States subservient to the Legislative Branch of Government."

Tankermen have always had the edge on their dry-cargo ship colleagues in the matter of quarters and recreational facilities, but J. Lauritzen of Copenhagen, Denmark, has added a new wrinkle to superiority in comfort by installing what is believed to be the first permanent swimming pool aboard a tanker.

The preservation of academic freedom against its subversion by disloyal teachers must remain in the hands of "the community of scholars itself," Dean Lawrence H. Chamberlain of Columbia College declared yesterday in a parting word to 400 graduating seniors.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP) -- "Cold war" frictions will be discarded momentarily tomorrow when official Washington joins eight British Commonwealth Embassies in celebrating the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II.

DESPITE the trick played by the weather man in some areas, anglers put in an interesting week-end, with some unusually good fly fishing reported from several streams and good off-shore and surf fishing reports received from scattered points.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 2 -- London's couturiers have had one of their busiest seasons dressing their fashionable clients for the coronation in the Abbey. The gowns will be handsome in the extreme while following the conventions imposed upon the designers. Of brocades, silks, satins and metal cloth, they will shimmer and shine, many of them extravagantly embroidered in brilliants and pearls to add additional sparkle.
Deere Co., farm implement manufacturers, had reduced earnings in the six months ended with April, reflecting lower sales, the consolidated semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 -- The Supreme Court of Pennsylvania in a 4-to-2 decision upheld today the dismissal of a taxpayer's suit that sought to force the trustees of the Barnes Foundation to open to the public its famous art collection in suburban Merion.
LONDON, Tuesday, June 2 (Reuters) -- The Times of London reported the news of the scaling of Mount Everest in a copyrighted message today.

The Lemonade Opera, which enlivened several summers in this town a few years ago, returned to action last night and brought with it the American premiere of a "new" opera by no less a composer than Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.

HONOLULU, June 2 -- Howard K. Hoddick, assistant prosecutor today concluded his final arguments to the jury in the trial of seven Hawaii residents accused of Communist conspiracy by maintaining that the Communist party was a society that taught and advocated the violent overthrow of the Government and that the defendants joined the party knowing that purpose and became leaders in the Hawaii branch.

Some of the confusion in respect to Indo-China has been compounded by the Communist and crypto-Communist line. Ho Chi Minh, leader of the Vietminh rebels, and his followers have repeatedly been characterized as simon-pure "nationalists" engaged in an anti-colonial war against the predatory French.
OTTAWA, June 25 -- Ottawa today led Canada in sincere and proud celebration of the crowning of Queen Elizabeth II. Radio accounts came directly from Westminster Abbey and the London streets.

THERE was more to Mayor Impellitteri's borrowing a pen from his legal aide to sign the transit lease papers last Monday than met the eye. The Mayor, it seems, has a passion for purple ink, just as James A. Farley, another public figure, is devoted to green ink.
BONN, Germany, June 2 -- The West German Statistical Bureau reported today a sharp increase in West German trade with Communist China, the Soviet Union and the satellite states in Eastern Europe.

LONDON, June 2 -- Casaulties to spectators to the coronation totaled nearly 7,000 tonight, but were still 3,000 short of the number finally reported at the coronation of George VI in 1937. Only 313 of those injured were taken to hospitals. The rest received on-the-spot treatment from some of the 8,500 first aid men, doctors and nurses posted on the procession routes.
New York property holders will pay taxes this year on the highest aggregate assessed valuations on record, and at a higher rate than ever before.

The Northwest architecture of Pietro Belluschi, dean of the Department of Architecture and Planning at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is displayed in a small exhibition of photographs at Museum Books, 48 East Forty-third Street, in connection with the recent publication of a book on this work (edited by Jo Stubbletine, F. W. Dodge Corporation).

New accents have been developing over the years in the Hyde Park section of Brooklyn. There, in an unusual foreign language program financed by parents, youngsters of Public School 208 have been learning their three R's trilingually for two decades.

TRENTON, June 2 -- The efforts of Joseph Doto, alias Joe Adonis, the racketeer, to escape deportation received a serious setback here today when the Federal Government produced nine official documents and six witnesses in support of its contention that the alumnus of Murder, Inc., was a native of Italy.

The real objection by the New York County Medical Society to a state-aided medical clinic operated by Mount Sinai Hospital within the subsidized Carver Houses being built in East Harlem is centered on the increasing popularity of clinics in general, State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman charged yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 2 -- In a sweeping indictment of "increasing" threats to freedom, the 165th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. expressed the fear today that guilt by investigation and suspicion, rather than by trial, might become the "future standard of justice" in this country.

The television coverage of the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II made memorable and unforgetable viewing yesterday. The pictures of the pageantry of the procession through the streets of London and the solemnity of the ceremonies in Westminster Abbey were truly history come to life.

Janet Blair, the leading lady of the touring company of "South Pacific" for the last thirty-eight months, has signed to appear in F. Hugh Herbert's new comedy, "A Girl Can Tell," due here on Oct. 29. A screen star before she went into "South Pacific," Miss Blair will be making her first appearance on the Broadway stage.

Voluntary arbitration as an alternative to Government intervention in labor disputes continues to make headway. We note with interest that in its annual report the New York State Board of Mediation announces that during 1952 the process of voluntarily submitting differences to arbitration developed rapidly and that the number of arbitrations for the twelve-month period increased 27 per cent over the previous year.
LONDON, June 2 (Reuters) -- The Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth went to the microphone here tonight to broadcast messages of loyalty and greetings to their newly crowned Queen.

Members of the championship 1950 City College basketball team were told they would be able to "cut up" a $2,500 fund if they participated in a projected but never consummated tour of South America, it was testified yesterday by Harry (Bobby) Sand, suspended assistant coach.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower received today a certificate representing the inscription of her name on the "Wall of Healing" in the Hadassah Medical Center under construction near Jerusalem.

Commodity prices closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee, copper, hides, zinc, rubber and potatoes were lower; cocoa, cottonseed oil and soybean oil were higher, and sugar, wool, lead and tin ended mixed. Volume was moderate to light, but in cocoa there was the most activity since April 13.

Federal Director of Prisons John V. Bennett visited Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, condemned atom spies, in the Sing Sing Prison death house yesterday and asked them to tell what they knew of the wartime Russian espionage ring of which they were members.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 2 (AP) -- One of the outstanding candidates for the Little Brown Jug, the Newport Stock Farm's Newport Chief, turned on the heat in the stretch tonight to win the Freeport Pace at Roosevelt Raceway by a head over Nat Hanover.
The list of general university awards and prizes and medals given in the various colleges and schools, announced at the commencement exercises, follows:
An 85-year-old woman was found dead yesterday morning in her two-room apartment on the lower East Side, where she had lived alone six years.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Frank Coe, who for six years until last Dec. 3 was secretary of the United Nations' multi-billion-dollar International Monetary Fund, was reported at two sources today to be willing to testify before the Senate Investigations subcommittee.
The citations accompanying the honorary degrees conferred yesterday by Columbia University follow:

A recent study in this city, it was reported here yesterday at the scientific sessions of the annual meeting of the American Medical Association, suggests strongly that up to one-fourth of all those disabled by crippling heart afflictions have what is known as iatrogenic heart disease.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Quick Congressional action on a one-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, as requested by President Eisenhower, apparently was assured today as the result of compromise negotiations between key Republicans of the House of Representatives and the White House.

LONDON, June 2 -- The thousands of coronation spectators from every nation seated in the vast grandstand outside the doors of Westminster Abbey today had everything they could desire -- except bright, warm weather.

GENOA, Italy, May 29 -- Any American on a pilgrimage to discover what happened to all those Marshall Plan dollars -- and there seem to be quite a number in Europe with that in mind -- could ease his task considerably by making his first land-fall at Genoa and taking a run up to the far end of the harbor.

KATMANDU, Nepal, June 2 (Reuters) -- Britain's thirteen climbers, relaxing on conquered Mount Everest today, solemnly drank a toast to Queen Elizabeth II while the world outside hailed their feat as the symbol of a new Elizabethan Age.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (UP) -- The Phillies, with Right-hander Robin Roberts pitching seven-hit ball, defeated the Cardinals, 5 -- 0, tonight in a game that saw the starting and losing pitcher, Cliff Chambers, face only two men.

NAPLES, Italy, June 2 -- Italy is approaching the climax of a hotly contested electoral campaign. The blare of loudspeakers echoes in the streets, every available wall is plastered with posters, and the main piazzas of the cities and villages are the scene of nightly political meetings.

THE 1953 waterfowl prospects are bright but not so bright as last year, according to the study made following a survey of the broad Canadian breeding and nesting grounds by representatives of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service in cooperation with Dominion wildlife agents and Ducks Unlimited.
The address by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, at the Columbia commencement exercises and special installation, follows:

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 2 -- Premier Pibul Songgram declared today that Communist military, political and propaganda activities in this area had made the threat of international aggression in Southeast Asia greater than at any time since the end of the Japanese war.
LONDON, June 2 (UP) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill's brief speech introducing Queen Elizabeth II's radio address tonight:
The intemperate editorial of June 2 attacking me for having voted against the Transit Authority should be dissected rather than answered in kind. I will attempt to do so.

LONDON, June 2 -- Elizabeth II was crowned today in Westminster Abbey and then received the homage of millions of her humble rain-drenched subjects as she rode in her gilded coach through five miles of this capital's royal route.

Scoring twice in the thirteenth inning, the Redlegs outlasted the Giants, 4 -- 2, at the Polo Grounds last night. Going the distance in a game that required 3 hours 41 minutes to complete, Clarence (Bud) Podbielan achieved a splendid seven-hit pitching performance for Cincinnati.

This city put out its flags yesterday in honor of the coronation of a queen in its sister metropolis across the Atlantic. On cosmopolitan Fifth Avenue, the Union Jack flew alongside the Stars and Stripes on many buildings, and below, window displays paid tribute to the young Queen Elizabeth and her family.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (UP) -- Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, today asked Defense Secretary Charles E. Wilson to look into a new "cold flow" metal shaping process and "add it to our present defense production program" if it was workable.

MONTREAL, June 2 -- The Gazette will celebrate tomorrow its 175th birthday. Beginning last Saturday and continuing for the next two Saturdays a special page of The Gazette is being devoted to the presentation of the historical background of the paper.

With a becoming sense of international awareness in an organization that is at least nominally quasi-official, the New York City Ballet last night gave a special Coronation Night program at the City Center. The State Standards of Great Britain and the United States were handsomely reproduced at either side of the stage.

The Fund for the Advancement of Education, established by the Ford Foundation, has awarded fellowships totaling $1,500,000 to 290 high school teachers to enable them to forego all regular teaching duties for the coming academic year and devote the time to programs of self-improvement.
PITTSBURGH, June 2 (AP) -- Frank Thomas' home run in the eleventh inning enabled the Pirates to down the Cubs, 4 -- 3, tonight and snap a six-game losing streak.

Common shares of Botany Mills, Inc., held by Charles F. H. Johnson Jr. and members of his family, representing control of the company, have been bought by the Bankers Securities Corporation of Philadelphia and affiliated interests. In announcing the sale, Mr. Johnson made known yesterday his resignation from the Botany board, of which he was chairman.

IN WESTMINSTER ABBEY, London, June 2 -- From my seat in Westminster Abbey it seemed that the most poignant moment of the coronation of Queen Elizabeth was not when the crown was placed upon her head but when the Queen's husband, the Duke of Edinburgh, knelt in homage before her.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 2 -Gen. Lucius D. Clay, retired, told 510 graduates of the United States Military Academy here today that the hope for averting another world war was much brighter than in 1947 when the Western Allies had demobilized to "a dangerous degree."

Enticing beach fashions for children are to be found on all sides now. Terry-cloth, cotton and knits are the leading fabrics for the play and swim clothes that will be worn in the sun by little sandpipers.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 3 -- Counter-attacking South Korean infantry today drove Communist troops from positions the foe captured yesterday near "Luke's Castle" on the eastern Korean front southwest of Kosong. United Nations Command headquarters said the line was restored at 6:30 this morning, when troops of the South Korean Twelfth Division mounted a fourth assault in less than twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today that retail food prices had risen about 0.6 per cent between mid-April and mid-May. This probably means that the General Consumers' Price Index will show a rise, because food is one of its major components.
LONDON, June 2 (AP) -- Following is the text of the broadcast message from Queen Elizabeth II to the Commonwealth and Empire:

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, outgoing Army Chief of Staff, testified to a Senate Appropriations subcommittee today that the manpower cuts in the ground forces envisaged by the revised defense budget President Eisenhower had presented to Congress carried "certain military risks and limitations" that he declined to specify in public.

Many retail workers, especially junior executives, are "quite unhappy" with their jobs. Evening hours for stores would probably "only intensify their dissatisfaction and adversely affect their attitude toward retailing." Younger store officials, both men and women, are "extremely critical of their working conditions" and many have left their positions for that reason.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Interior and Insular Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives today voted, 19 to 4, to report an Alaska statehood bill that seemed destined to gather dust on the shelf at least until next year despite this strong support.
Senator Estes Kefauver urged last night that the United States take the lead in trying to effect a stable peace between Israel and the Arab states.

A serious question was raised yesterday as to whether the New York City Transit Authority could get enough tokens to increase fares by July 30 on the lines it is taking over from the city. The statutory deadline for fare action this year is July 30.

The character of Queen Elizabeth II, the sixth woman to reign in England undisputed and in her own right, was shaped by a warm and loving family life, the reserved and quietly assured traditions of her class and by an education appropriate to her position.

Directors of the Seaboard Air Line Railroad at a meeting here yesterday proposed that the road's common stock be split into two and one-half shares of $40 par value each for each present share of no par value. John W. Smith, president, announced that a special meeting of stockholders had been called for July 21 at Norfolk, Va., to act on the proposal, which would involve amending the company's articles of association.

Three high-speed military planes of two nations, and two more flying craft, including a privately chartered plane and a commercial air liner, were used yesterday to deliver coronation pictures from London to THE NEW YORK TIMES here in eleven hours.

Newspapers are missing a good chance to obtain additional revenue if they do not exploit the tendency of retail stores to use increased mail order and catalogue advertising. This was the theme of a talk yesterday by Howard P. Abrahams, manager of the sales promotion division and visual merchandising group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, at the "Locally Edited Group" Newspaper Advertising Conference, Brown Hotel, Louisville, Ky.

LONDON, June 2 -- In the cold gray dawn of Coronation Day about 2,400 peers and members of Parliament, their wives, friends and children, rode to Westminster Abbey by subway. The men, in gray "toppers," cutaway coats and striped trousers and some of the women in silk and brocaded dresses with veiled tiaras on their heads, probably formed the most unusual group of passengers ever carried on the subway.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 2 -- Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis won low gross honors in a weekly one-day Class A tournament of the Westchester section of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association over the Fenway Golf Club course today.

Governor Dewey laid aside the cares of state for 20 1/2 minutes (exact timing) yesterday to present awards to eleven teen-age winners in the ninth annual American Automobile Association safety poster design contest. He signed autographs and inquired about ages and classroom standing as he congratulated the youngsters on their artistic ability.

MOSCOW, June 2 -- Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov headed a distinguished group of Soviet guests at a brilliant ball given tonight by the British Ambassador, Sir Alvary Gascoigne, and Lady Gascoigne and other Commonwealth diplomatic representatives in honor of Queen Elizabeth's coronation.

ELIZABETH, N. J., June 2 -- The Elizabeth Post Office mailed out hundreds of stamped-addressed envelopes today at the request of philatelists seeking covers bearing the name of England's new queen and her coronation.
The five Queens of England who ruled in their own right before Queen Elizabeth II present a gallery of differing temperaments and accomplishments. Two were outstanding.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- United States offcials are worried about a possible swing to the Right in the forthcoming Italian elections that would unseat the present Center coalition under Premier Alcide De Gaspari and bring a "do-nothing" government into power.

Forty-one policemen, who were honored for deeds of heroism in 1952, were honored yesterday, two of them post-humously, by Mayor Impellitteri and Police Commissioner George P. Monahan in a ceremony in front of City Hall. The men heard the Mayor cite them as proof that brutality, corruption and crime are not rampant here.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The National Association of Manufacturers and the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, at the request of Treasury officials, are reconsidering their opposition to a six-month extension of the excess profits tax.

Home economists at recent meetings have emphasized that homemakers, to conserve energy and add to their efficiency, should try to cut down on physical exertion in doing even the smallest household tasks.

Msgr. John B. Condon, pastor of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Medford, Mass., and Clifford J. Laube, former day national news editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, will receive honorary Doctor of Laws degrees from Manhattan College at its 102d commencement exercises next Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- President Eisenhower and a supporting cast of four Cabinet members rehearsed today the nation-wide telecast they will make at 9:30 P. M., tomorrow.

One hundred and seventy-five years ago today a Montreal printer named Fleury Mesplet started a French newspaper which he called "La Gazette du Commerce et Litteraire." Today we know, enjoy and honor it as The Gazette of Montreal, for it was soon published in English and it became one of the most famous newspapers of the Western Hemisphere.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 2 (AP) -- Gov. Dan McCarty today vetoed a legislative act that would have rotated the choice of mid-winter racing dates among the three horse tracks in the Greater Miami area.

ATHENS, June 2 -- Differences between Greece and Britain over Cyprus appeared forgotten today as Greek Palace and Government officials attended British-sponsored coronation rites in the Athens Stadium. Cypriots, who legally are British subjects, boycotted the ceremony and later expressed their disappointment with the Greek Government for the alleged "betrayal of their cause," which is for the union of Cyprus with Greece.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 2 -- Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, proposed today that one or more of the major cigarette manufacturers est "a few million dollars" of their advertising budgets in research in the relationship between smoking and cancer of the lungs.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (UP) -- The Senate defeated today economy forces led by Senator Paul H. Douglas and approved $11,600,000 that the House of Representatives had cut out of appropriations for the State, Justice and Commerce Departments.
DUBLIN, June 2 -- The only coronation flags flying in Dublin today were the Union Jacks outside the British, Canadian and Australian Embassies.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Actual spending on foreign aid in the fiscal year beginning next month will exceed the current year's expenditures by about half a billion dollars, according to estimates today by the Treasury and Mutual Security Agency.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 2 -- Edward T. McCormick, president of the American Stock Exchange, called today for a complete overhaul of the nation's tax structure in order to encourage the introduction of venture capital for the continued expansion of free enterprise.

Dr. David B. Stelnman, noted bridge builder and Columbia University alumnus, declared yesterday that the bridge builders of the world had broken down the barriers and spanned the rivers and chasms that halted the progress of humanity.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Hundreds of her loyal subjects paid homage to Queen Elizabeth II at religious services and festive gatherings here today honoring her coronation.
Following is a glossary relating to the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II yesterday, as compiled by The Associated Press and Reuters:
WESTERN FRONT, Korea, June 2 (AP) -- British Commonwealth fighting men in Korea saluted Queen Elizabeth II on her coronation today with guns and cheers and parades.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., June 2 -- A pick and shovel army of the Port of New York Authority was repelled today by the Weehawken Township police, under orders to bar digging for the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel until a building permit is obtained.

PARIS, June 2 -- The Sultan of Morocco, Sidi Mohammed Ben Youssef, struck back today at local Moroccan chieftains who have asked that he be ousted by demanding that France, the protecting power, put an end to "organized dissidence."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 2 -- The honor man of the 1953 graduating class at the United States Naval Academy is Carlisle A. Trost, 23 years old, commander of the Brigade of Midshipman, it was announced today. Midshipman Trost, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Trost of Columbia, Ill., finished his four-year course with an average of 93.15.
Business of the Paramount Pictures Corporation in the second half of this year should exceed that of a year ago, Barney Balaban, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
Two Jersey tracts, one in Old Tappan and the other in Rivervale, have been purchased by builders for improvement with dwellings.

The 1953 international lifeboat and tugboat races, to be held on the Hudson River Sept. 12, are expected to be viewed by close to half a million persons, William S. Stuhr, president of the American Seamen's Friend Society, under whose auspices the regatta is held, said yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, June 2 -- Vending machines in department stores will probably never replace salesgirls. Merchants should be vitally concerned with labor legislation. The problem of returned merchandise lies primarily with the stores, not the customers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 2 -- "Fifty per cent" of the craft workers normally employed in film studios are out of work and this once-bustling production center "is fast becoming a ghost town," according to Roy M. Brewer, international representative of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes and president of the Hollywood American Federation of Labor Film Council.
LONDON, June 2 (Reutersr) -- Champion Surrey beat Lancashire by eight wickets at Old Trafford today and went to the top of the county cricket championship table.

Bryan G., the 6-year-old campaigner owned by C. T. Chenery, encountered little trouble winning the nominal feature at Belmont Park yesterday. The race was called the Easthampton, over a mile and a sixteenth, and Bryan G. gave a front-running exhibition to score by three-quarters of a length.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- President Eisenhower ordered today the establishment of an International Organizations Employes Loyalty Board to evaluate as security risks United States citizens employed by, or applying for jobs with, the United Nations.
New issues of more than $50,000,000 of common stock of public utility, natural gas and automobile insurance company stock will be offered to investors today. The offerings are:

Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey has appeared before the House Ways and Means Committee in support of the plea contained in President Eisenhower's radio talk to the nation a fortnight ago that the excess-profits tax be extended another six months.

The five-story house at 130 East Sixty-fifth Street containing a doctor's office and two apartments has been sold by Lester Woods to Mrs. Marcia Harkness, who will occupy a suite with seven rooms red three bathrooms. It has a red brick Colonial facade and was converted from a town house in 1951. William B. May Co. were the brokers in the sale.

In a span of less than twenty-four hours we lived through one of the most remarkable conjunctures of events in all history. Nothing less can characterize that wonderful combination of the conquest of the last unconquered spot on earth and the dawn of a new Elizabethan era.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Senate Republican leaders capitulated to President Eisenhower today and abandoned a Congressional rider that had been intended, in effect, to withdraw the United States from the United Nations if membership should be given to Communist China.
Brooklyn's ten-game winning streak and its grip on first place were simultaneously broken last night by one powerful smash from the bat of an ex-Dodger.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Wednesday, June 3 -- The fourteen-month-old coalition Cabinet of Premier Wilopo tendered its resignation at a session last midnight following strong Nationalist and Communist party pressure against the Government's agrarian reform program in the rich estate belt of the east coast of Sumatra.
TORONTO, June 2 (Canadian Press) -- Business is booming at the sixth Canadian International Trade Fair, officials reported today.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Active absorption of grain futures on an early break today marked the most impressive rally in a long time. Prices opened near the low marks established yesterday, but there was a quick clean-up of the offerings and from then on the markets were strong.
Amos Alonzo Stagg, grand old man of American football, will be honored at a Football Hall of Fame "award" game next season.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 2 -- The fire that destroyed the United States Embassy's plane at Lydda Airport on May 16 was "not the result of an accidental short circuit or of negligence," according to a joint report by a special investigating group of the United States Air Force and Israeli police made public today. The report does not charge sabotage but it points out that the plane had been forcibly entered.

With trade and industrial activity continuing at the high rates of preceding months, economic developments during May gave little indication that tightening credit is beginning to limit either business programs for plant and equipment expenditures or installment purchases of consumer goods.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 2 (UP) -- Tle United States Government has advised Brazil of its desire to dissolve the Brazil-United States Joint-Commission, Foreign Minister Joao Neves da Fontoura said today.
LONDON, June 2 -- The official royal account of Elizabeth's coronation appeared in the Court Circular tonight, as follows:

STANTON, Del., June 2 (UP) -- Tea-Maker won the Coronation Day Purse today at Delaware Park, but most of the excitement occurred earlier in the program when a $279.30 for $2 chance took the third race.

LONDON, June 2 -- Full throated and joyous, the people of Britain and their Commonwealth cousins poured out love, affection and loyalty for their newly crowned Queen in the rainsoaked streets of old London today.

The New York district council of the racket-infested International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., took two major steps last night toward compliance with the clean-up mandate given the waterfront union by the American Federation of Labor executive council.
The State of Tennessee borrowed $17,525,000 in the public market yesterday on bond issues maturing from 1954 to 1964 at interest costs ranging from 1.941 per cent to 2.63 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Assistant Secretary of State John Moors Cabot sharply advised top American labor leaders today that, far from causing hunger to the Bolivian workers by refusing to buy tin, the United States had bought "every pound" of Bolivian tin offered for sale to date.

Today's new film is "South Sea Woman," a Warner Brothers romantic adventure with Burt Lancaster and Virginia Mayo, at the Paramount. Arthur Lubin directed and Sam Bischoff produced, from a screen play by Edwin Blum, as adapted by Earl Baldwin and Stanley Shapiro from a play by William M. Rankin.

Samuel Reshevsky of New York won the first of a series of eighteen games in his return match with Miguel Najdorf, Argentina's international grandmaster at chess, after forty-two moves, in a five-hour session concluded early yesterday morning, according to a report fro Buenos Aires.

JOLLY CHOLLY GRIMM has so much frothy effervescence to him that he bubbles over with good nature even when his ball club is slightly less than impressive. But the impact of his Braves on Milwaukee and Milwaukee on his Braves has left him virtually gasping for breath, a look of wonderment and disbelief still in his eyes.

A messenger entered the offices of the Madison Street Settlement at 226 Madison Street at 12:30 P. M. yesterday and handed an envelope to Miss Rita Smollens, executive secretary. Miss Smollens found in it $64 in bills and this note:

CLEVELAND, June 2 -- Doctors must be on guard against taking out their frustrations on the chronically ill patient who may be the unwitting cause of them, the eightieth annual meeting of the National Conference of Social Work was told here today.

When an anticipated 500 June[ graduates of twenty-one Eastern and Southern women's colleges and universities come to New Yo looking for jobs this month, they will be entitled to make use of an unusual vocational counseling service free of charge.

The proposed broadening of the city's sales tax was doomed yesterday after Controller Lazarus Joseph gave a re-estimate that the 1952-53 cash carryover of the city's general fund would be $12,000,000 higher than he had estimated previously.
Three teen-age essayists, in common with their elders, differed yesterday on how to handle vandalism.

MONTREAL, June 2 (UP) -- Roberto De Vicenzo and Antonio Cerda gave Argentina a one-stroke lead today in the first round of the Canada Cup golf tournament. The United States trailed by 15 strokes in a tie for fifth place.

The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's television network, which had not entered into competition with other chains, was the first on this Continent to receive and present films yesterday of the Coronation in London of Queen Elizabeth II.

One hundred pupils of the Tobe-Coburn School for Fashion Careers received certificates yesterday at a luncheon given by the school at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Executives in the retailing, publishing and advertising fields were present.

IN WESTMINSTER ABBEY, London, June 2 -- Amid ancient ceremony and medieval pomp in this abbey today, the Archbishop of Canterbury placed the heavy crown of Edward the Confessor upon the head of his radiant young sovereign, Elizabeth II.

Asserting that the three paths to wisdom were those of service, of the intelligent and creative use of the mind, and of understanding, Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College, gave her final message to the 285 members of the sixtieth graduating class in a special ceremony yesterday afternoon on the north campus, Broadway and 118th Street.

Holding as I do total confidence in President Eisenhower and his Administration, it is with reluctance that I exercise my rights as a free citizen to oppose one but vital segment of his program as outlined in his recent message to the Congress concerning the reorganization of the military establishment.
WASHINGTON; June 2 -- Michael J. McDermott, a veteran of thirty-three years in the State Department, was sworn in today as United States Ambassador to El Salvador, his first diplomatic assignment.

With the death of Prof. Alexander Vasiliev in his eighty-sixth year the world loses one of its great scholars, the dean of that galaxy of humanists whose formation must be credited to the universities of pre-Revolutionary Russia and whose presence in exile among us over the past generation has enriched the cultural life of our own country and the free world.

May I draw your attention to the way visitors to the United States are treated by the authorities when leaving. Every visitor leaving the United States must produce a sailing permit stating that he earned no income here. But how to get this permit? It is issued only in the last few days of the visitor's stay.

There will be four times as many American homes with year-round air-conditioning by the end of this year than a year ago if a general business recession does not strike. This prediction was made yesterday by Cloud Wampler, president of the Carrier Corporation, at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The market for United States Government securities found its breath yesterday. After an unsure opening following a week of successive price declines, a feeling of reassurance returned to the community of Government bond dealers, and, as a result, prices registered their best advance in nearly a month.
Controller Lazarus Joseph said yesterday that he might run independently for the Democratic nomination for Mayor in the Sept. 15 primary if the county leaders did not give him the designation.

The eighth floor of Hunter College is not usually a duck hatchery, but that is what it became last week when four wild ducks emerged from their shells and, within a few minutes, had drawn dozens of spectators into the usually quiet biology laboratory.

W. R. Grace Co., the big international industrial and trading concern, which last September borrowed $35,000,000 from insurance companies to finance its expansion in the chemical and other fields, announced yesterday completion of negotiations toward the purchase of the Thurston Chemical Company.

Senator Taft wants this nation to go it alone in Korea because the United Nations, he says, has failed as a peacemaker. Actually, I wonder if the opposite reason may not more nearly explain the attacks on the U. N. of Senator Taft and certain lesser Republicans. May it not be the unprecedented success of the U. N., in one aspect of the Korea tragedy, which drives the Senators to their recent reckless outbursts?

The House of Delegates of the American Medical Association, policy-making body of organized medicine in the United States, will act today on resolutions introduced yesterday calling for censure of the American College of Surgeons and of Dr. Paul R. Hawley, its director.

TORONTO, June 2 -- Canada's first determined bid to capture a sizable share of the world's railway equipment market began this week with the unveiling of a new type of Diesel-electric locomotive engineered to fit almost any line.

LONDON, June 2 -- As the final official act of her day of coronation, Queen Elizabeth came before her people as darkness fell tonight. On the balcony of Buckingham Palace, bathed in the glow of floodlights, she pressed a button and sent a wave of electric light shimmering down the Mall as the street lights came on.
A vacant tract of seventeen acres fronting 350 feet on Merrick Bay in Merrick, L. I., has been sold by William F. Purdy to a client of Irving R. Shapiro, attorney. George M. Mayer was the broker.
LONDON, June 2 -- Celebrities of the stage and screen were among hundreds of guests tonight at a gala coronation ball at the Savoy Hotel.

ST. LOUIS, June 2 (AP) -- Not a single passenger lost his life in a train accident in the country last year, the safety section of the Association of American Railroads was told today. Clark Hungerford, president of the Frisco Railway, cited this record as making 1952 the safest year in railroad history.

ROSLYN, L. I., June 2 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of the Cherry Valley Club scored 42, 42 -- 84 and won a drawing for first place to take the low gross prize in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament at the Engineers' Golf Club today.

HARTFORD, June 2 -- The Connecticut League of Women Voters assailed today the action of the General Assembly in permitting two proposed constitutional amendments to suffer a "quiet death" in legislative committee's files.

LONDON, June 2 -- To most of the millions of Britons who sat on the sidewalks or in the luxury grandstands to watch their Queen ride to her coronation it seemed right and natural that there should be rain. Today was England's day and rain is the most English kind of weather.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, June 3 -- The explosive Korean situation clouded today and will not be clarified until the release of a Republic of Korea Government statement now in the process of preparation.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, outgoing Army Chief of Staff, today outlined a new Reserve program which he said would "stimulate enlistments in the National Guard and Organized Reserve."

A one-day conference to explain the McCarran-Walter Immigration and Naturalization Law to those who must work with it will be held by the New York University School of Law and Division of General Education on June 13.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Leaders of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations agreed today on a way to get rid of union raiding.

RYE, N. Y., June 2 -- A par-breaking 71 gave Judd L. Brumley of Greenville, Tenn., a two-stroke lead in the opening round of the forty-ninth annual United States Seniors Golf Association championship at the Apawamis Club today.
TOKYO, Wednesday, June 3 (AP) -- United Nations Command commnique 1,634, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Wednesday, Korean time:

Thomas May, 44-year-old member of Local 856 of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., pleaded guilty in Federal Court yesterday to one count of a seventy - one - count indictment charging him with extortion on the waterfront.

CAIRO, June 2 -- The declaration by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles of the United States intention to assist "in any desired way" in a solution of the British-Egyptian dispute over the Suez Canal zone and other problems in this area has evoked an initial and tentatively favorable response from leaders here.

Three books that analyze Russia's immediate past and its present and future will be published tomorrow by two concerns. Double-day has listed Robert Magidoff's "The Kremlin vs. The People," an appraisal of the problems, mistakes and the reversals of policy that marked Stalin's regime.

INWOOD, L. I., June 2 -- Vic Ghezzi and his amateur partner, Joseph Feldman, both from the host club, topped a field of sixty-five teams with a best-ball of 37, 32 -- 69 to capture the Long Island Golf Association pro-amateur championship at the Inwood Country Club today.
The General Foods Corporation lifted net sales to a new high for the twentieth consecutive year and realized a $4,372,032 increase in net income for the fiscal year ended on March 31.

CLEVELAND, June 2 (UP) -- Al Rosen's eleventh homer of the season with two runners on base in the eighth inning and Mike Garcia's seven-hit pitching carried the Indians to a 7-3 victory over the Red Sox tonight.

Reviewing quotations for some of the low-coupon bond issues brought to market in 1946, one broker yesterday commented "those who bought them at their offering prices and who still hold them, would have done a lot better if they had put the money in the bank and paid themselves the interest directly."

A Public Service Commission inspector testifying at a hearing yesterday on service and safety on the Long Island Rail Road asserted that of 1,314 cars inspected, 242 needed major overhaul, 945 had defects of some sort, and 455 were dirty. In some cases more than one fault was found against a single car.

Consolidation of the enormous and varied foreign aid programs of the United States Government into a single, unified agency is the logical aim of President Eisenhower's Reorganization Plan No. 7. We have all become so accustomed to the idea of direct economic assistance for the nations of the free world that we sometimes forget that American aid is now being extended in manifold forms to more than forty countries around the world.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady but quiet yesterday, and closing prices were 17 points higher to 6 lower than on Monday.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 2 (AP) -- An atomic test was delayed today shortly after an Air Force bomber had left with its nuclear load from a New Mexico air field.

PETWORTH, England, June 2 -- Exactly fifty-five miles southwest of Westminster Abbey the 2,400 inhabitants of this 800-year-old feudal Sussex village of Petworth Cum Tillington celebrated the coronation in a way that was typically rustic and typically British.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 -- Gifts and bequests to Bryn Mawr College during the 1952-53 academic year aggregated more than half a million dollars, Dr. Katharine E. McBride, president of the institution, announced during today's commencement exercises.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Expansion goals for facilities to produce scientific instruments and military photographic equipment were raised sharply by the Office of Defense Mobilization today.

The recipes appearing today give home cooks a chance to taste the interesting dishes served last week to President Eisenhower when he visited the Department of Agriculture's research center in Beltsville, Md. The luncheon he ate after a tour of the center featured new, improved foods and new ways of serving them.

LONDON, June 2 (Reuters) -- Today's rain and cold never raised the possibility of a postponement of Queen Elizabeth's coronation. Only once in Britain's history has a coronation been postponed -- fifty-one years ago, two days before Edward VII was to be crowned.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 2 -- A small Coronation Day parade here in the capital of this somewhat nervous crown colony was not much of a success. Somehow spectators had gathered in one place and the parade was in another.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- John A. McCone, former Under Secretary of the Air Force, asked a Senate Armed Services subcommittee today to correct in the Congressional Record what he called aspersions on his integrity in office cast more than a year ago by Representative Alvin E. O'Konski, Republican of Wisconsin, in a speech from the floor of the House of Representatives.

The State University Maritime College, founded in 1874 and the oldest maritime school in the United States, held its ninety-seventh commencement exercises at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, yesterday afternoon.

SAN PIER D'ARENA, Italy, June 2 -- Depressed anti-Communist labor officials of this town a few miles from the thriving port of Genoa said today that the Communist-controlled Italian General Confederation of Labor had a stronger grip over more than 10,000 workers in the local state-managed Ansaldo shipyards than in 1949, despite five years of Christian Democratic Government.

After a year and a half of debate and deliberation, the City Council passed twenty-two local laws yesterday covering amendments to the city building code designed to encourage the construction of legitimate playhouses on Broadway.
LONDON, June 2 -- It was a busy and exciting day for Prince Charles, 4 1/2-year-old heir apparent to the British throne.
LONDON, June 2 -- Television made Westminster Abbey a shrine today where 30,000,000 British subjects could share in their most sacred national rite -- the coronation of their Queen.

After an initial burst of overnight selling orders, which sent stock prices yesterday to their lowest levels in more than seven months, offerings diminished and prices advanced selectively with the rail issues firmest. THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks, which in early trading plunged to 176.53, its lowest level since last October, at the close was back to 178.55, where it was up 0.63 for the day.

The danger to our liberties comes from those who are repressing their fellow citizens, Elmer Davis, news analyst, said last night at the annual commencement exercises of the New School of Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, who was installed formally as Columbia University's fourteenth president at commencement exercises yesterday, said in an address that universities must be free from outside dictation in their search for the truth.

TORONTO, June 2 (AP) -- Canadiana, the filly owned by E. P. Taylor of Toronto and ridden by Eddie Arcaro, romped to a six-length victory today over Blue Scooter in the ninety-fourth renewal of the Queen's Plate for 3-year-olds at Woodbine Park.

After an initial burst of overnight selling orders, which sent stock prices yesterday to their lowest levels in more than seven months, offerings diminished and prices advanced selectively with the rail issues firmest. THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks, which in early trading plunged to 176.53, its lowest level since last October, at the close was back to 178.55, where it was up 0.63 for the day.

The danger to our liberties comes from those who are repressing their fellow citizens, Elmer Davis, news analyst, said last night at the annual commencement exercises of the New School of Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, who was installed formally as Columbia University's fourteenth president at commencement exercises yesterday, said in an address that universities must be free from outside dictation in their search for the truth.
