TORONTO, June 2 (AP) -- Canadiana, the filly owned by E. P. Taylor of Toronto and ridden by Eddie Arcaro, romped to a six-length victory today over Blue Scooter in the ninety-fourth renewal of the Queen's Plate for 3-year-olds at Woodbine Park.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- House of Representatives subcommittee on Un-American Activities headed by Representative Bernard W. Kearney, Republican of upstate New York, will begin hearings July 13 in Albany, N. Y., to determine the extent of Communist influence in defense industries of the area.

The microfilming of all volumes in the Vatican Library is progressing and will be completed in three and a half years. This was reported yesterday by James W. McCormick, supreme director of the Knights of Columbus, who arrived in New York aboard the liner United States after a visit to Rome.

The market for United States Government securities renewed the price rally which developed Tuesday. The improvement in prices, the best since late in March, had the effect of drying up much of the nervous selling that had been touched off on Monday by a week of falling prices.

New measurements of the flow of blood to and from the brain in healthy human volunteers, reported at the annual meeting of the American Medical Association here yesterday, suggest that most drugs used to protect the brain from the effects of a "stroke" are useless.
TOKYO, Thursday, June 4 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,635, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korean time:

News that four business firms have each agreed to sponsor one of the Stadium Concerts, and that others are likely to follow suit, is heart-warming to those who regard these concerts with affection. For this support will contribute to the economic stability of what is certainly a matchless event in the city's summer life.

HAVANA, June 3 (UP) -- C. M. Q. a Cuban television network, announced today that it had indefinitely suspended a meet-the-press program because the Government charging that the network was partial to opposition politicians had forbidden public officials to appear on it.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Government has given ground on the quantity of aluminum it will require for the nation's stockpile in the third quarter and has postponed a decision on the amount which will be taken in the final quarter of this year.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- A Senate Foreign Relations sub-committee today approved by a 6-0 vote a bill to authorize United States participation in the St. Lawrence Seaway project.

HONG KONG, June 3 (UP) -- The heated arguments over the kind and amount of trade between non-Communist areas and Red China have almost obscured two facts that have governed activities of shippers and shipping agencies in this British colonial outpost on the fringe of Asia.

BONN, Germany, June 3 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Dr. James B. Conant, United States High Commissioner, signed an agreement this evening in Schaumburg Palace reactivating the 1923 treaty of friendship, commerce and consular rights in an amended form.

President Millicent C. McIntosh announced at yesterday's annual Reunion Day for Barnard College alumnae that the Alumnae Association had exceeded its fund-drive quota by 124 per cent, contributing $81,183 in gifts to the college in the last year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 3 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky left the United States today without benefit of the usual flowers and visits from Communist bloc diplomats but indicated that he might be back before long.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 3 -- The United Nations was urged today, on the basis of an inquiry into world press conditions, to help journalists form "watchdog" committees to look into violations of freedom of the press.

CLEVELAND, June 3 -- Arthur J. Altmeyer, former Federal Commissioner of Social Security, was nominated here today president-elect of the National Conference of Social Work, the largest organization in the United States devoted to health and welfare activities. Nomination is tantamount to election, and he will take office as president next year, conference spokesmen said.

A new book by Eleanor Roosevelt, titled "India and the Awakening East," will be issued July 22 by Harper. It is a record of her impressions of her trip last year to Lebanon, Syria, Jordan, Israel, Pakistan, India and Indonesia.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 3 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarksjold will return from Europe June 9 to face a problem brought to the center of the United Nations stage again yesterday by President Eisenhower: the evaluation of the loyalty of United States members of the Secretariat.

PARIS, Thursday, June 4 -- Pierre Mendes-France, who has been chosen to try to form a French Government, told the National Assembly tonight that if he became Premier he would report to the forthcoming Bermuda conference that the war in Indo-China was a "crushing burden" that his country could not support.

The growth of homemaking education programs for adults in this country is described as "phenomenal'' in an article in the June issue of The Journal of Home Economics by Miss Irene Patterson of the faculty of the New York State College of Home Economics at Cornell University.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Representatives of shipping companies operating under Government subsidies denied before a House committee today charges they had failed to resist union demands for higher wages because the Government would meet a large share of the increases.

More than $95,000 has been raised so far to continue the presentations of opera, ballet and drama at the City Center of Music and Drama, Newbold Morris, chairman of the board, announced yesterday after the annual meeting of the nonprofit institution's corporation committee. The drive to obtain $200,000 to stave off a financial crisis began in April.

The Department of Health distributed yesterday its first allotment of gamma globulin, received from the national pool controlled by the Office of Defense Mobilization, to centers in each of the five boroughs where physicians may obtain it to help prevent the spread of poliomyelitis.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 3 (AP) -- Make Way, owned and driven by Jimmy Cruise, rushed to the front at the half mile and went on to win the Great Neck pace by a length tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

JERUSALEM, June 3 -- Israel's political crisis was patched up tonight after a day of acrimonious debate in the Knessett (Parliament). The coalition Government, reconstituted with the return of four ministers of the Right - Wing General Zionist party, won a 72-to-24 vote of confidence.

The New York Stock Exchange will change its name in the fall to "World Stock Exchange," according to Volume XXVII, No. I of the Bawl Street Journal, the financial district's once-a-year-dollar-a-copy satire of itself. The Big Board is also opening an office in Washington, D. C., it was reported.

The strategic views of Admiral Arthur William Radford, the new chairman-designate of the Joint Chiefs of Staff who was confirmed this week by the Senate, are of major significance to future military policies.

Winthrop Rockefeller announced last night through his attorneys. Milbank, Tweed, Hope Hadley, that he had set up a $1,000,000 trust fund for the benefit of his estranged wife, Mrs. Barbara Paul Rockefeller. He added that he hoped she would be willing to let him have the custody of their son.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Inter-party bickering marred today the House of Representatives' vote of approval for President Eisenhower's plan of reorganization for the Department of Agriculture. A roll-call vote of 261 to 128 in effect approved the plan, which becomes effective at 12:01 A. M. tomorrow.

The recent acquisition of the Sloane-Blabon Corporation by Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., floor and wall covering manufacturer, will place the latter company in a much better competitive position, F. J. Andre, Congoleum-Nairn president, told shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

CLEVELAND, June 3 (AP) -- Held to three hits for eight innings, the Red Sox cut loose in the ninth tonight against Cleveland's Early Wynn with a four-hit, three-run rally that beat the Indians, 4 to 3. Al Rosen drove in all three Cleveland runs with a single and his twelfth homer.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UP) -- Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey told Congress today the Government will have to borrow $9,000,000,000 to $12,000,000,000 in cash between now and Dec. 31. He immediately announced plans to borrow $200,000,000 next week by selling more Treasury bills than will fall due then.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Dr. Herbert Blankenhorn, head of the political department of the West German Foreign Office, called on John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, yesterday with personal messages from Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor.
A three-man bench in Special Sessions deliberated ten minutes yesterday and convicted on simple assault charges Jacob Jackson, 32-year-old truckman's helper, and his wife.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation announced yesterday that it would begin immediately to develop as an open pit copper mine an ore body in eastern Nevada known as the Veteran.

OTTAWA, June 3 -- Records that Rear Admiral Robert E. Peary left in a cairn on a mountain peak at Cape Columbia, Ellesmere Island, 400 miles south of the North Pole in 1906, have been recovered by Canadian scientists.

A vacant plot 100 by 108 feet at the northeast side of Flatbush Avenue, 148 feet northwest of Avenue T, Brooklyn, was sold by the Nomlas Realty Corporation to Edward A. Lashins, Inc., reportedly for improvement with a one-story building to be occupied by Rayco auto seat coverings. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

BOLOGNA, Italy, June 3 -- Giacomo Cardinal Lercaro, Archbishop of Bologna, said today that according to reports from the parishes in his ecclesiastical territory, he expected "only a slight decrease" in the regional communist and Left-wing Socialist vote in the elections.

Representative Walter Judd of Minnesota is quoted as saying that S. 1917, the bill to admit 240,000 additional immigrants from Europe, "will do just as much good to our enemies as if it were written in the Kremlin."

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Automobile manufacturers face a highly competitive market for the first time in more than a dozen years, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago said today. The bank warned that unemployment might plague Midwestern auto centers next fall as a result of expected cutbacks in production.

Sheer white marquisette curtains are now made of Saran, a plastic fiber. Curtains made of this yarn remain crisp and fresh looking even in the humidity and salt air of the seashore. Easy to maintain, they may be washed, dried and rehung in a matter of minutes.
A variety of new items to add to the pleasantness of summer living are on view at the Penthouse Gallery, 15 West Fifty-fifth Street.

The President's latest reorganization plan retains the three-man Council of Economic Advisers, but proposes several changes designed to overcome the two chief problems encountered by the C. E. A. under President Truman. These problems were: (1) the divided responsibility within the Council, arising from the fact that the authority of the members was co-equal, and (2) the friction between the Council and the old-line agencies of the Government.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- In an action taken so quietly as to almost pass unnoticed, the Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs of the House of Representatives has set up a watchdog subcommittee to keep a running check on administrative practices in the Department of Interior.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UP) -- Selective Service has ruled that the draft liability of registrants deferred for National Guard Service extends until 35 years of age instead of the usual 26, it was disclosed today.

The fifteenth anniversary of the Moral Re-Armament Movement and the seventy-fifth birthday of its founder, Dr. Frank Nathaniel Daniel Buchman, find both going strong, spokesmen for the movement said yesterday.

A drop last week of 1,488,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 152,435,000 barrels, compared with 153,923,000 a week earlier and 122,161,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Government today revived the Foreign Petroleum Supply Committee and invited fourteen companies with foreign oil interests to participate. The group, which is expected to gather information on foreign oil requirements and supplies, has been inoperative since last January although the Secretaries of Defense and the Interior have called it "vital" to national defense.

Two events occurred on May 29 -- one in Korea and the other in Germany -- which highlight the dangers inherent in a foreign policy shaped less by an appraisal of existing conditions than by the efforts of a new Administration to reconcile the discordant elements within its own party.

LONDON, June 3 -- The stock markets resumed today after the Coronation holiday with business slack and many sections insufficient to provide a real test of prices. British Government securities alone were active, continuing to attract steady support and gaining up to one-quarter of 1 per cent.

SAN FRANCISCO. June. 3 -- The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, unaffiliated, has agreed with the Pacific Maritime Association, representing the West Coast shipowners, to extend their coastwise contract to June 15, 1955, with a wage review on June 15, 1954.

It is common knowledge that science must serve the state in Soviet Russia. But what of medicine? A sick man is a citizen with a legitimate right to medical attention. But the Soviet theory does not work out in this way. It is the state that makes demands on the citizen whether he is sick or not.

STANTON, Del., June 3 (UP) -- By Jeepers, with Sam Boulmetis aboard, handed I Appeal his first defeat by turning back the Brookfield Farm colt by three-quarters of a length today in the $10,000 Dover Stakes at Delaware Park. The two colts turned in a head-and-head duel from the back-stretch to the final furlong.

NORWALK, Conn., June 3 -- A representative of the Norwalk Teachers Association has informed the Board of Education that "television is not used selectively and properly by the children or parents." Alfred Lamarche, principal of the Winnipauk School, made the statement in delivering a report of the committee for research and improvement of instruction, a division of the group goals committee of the Teachers Association.

Doctors' wives attending the annual convention of the Woman's Auxiliary to the American Medical Association were urged yesterday to encourage private support of medical schools to forestall possible Government subsidy.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 3 -- The 165th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. marked the end of its week-long session here this afternoon with a series of actions designed to strengthen and further unity negotiations with two of its sister communions.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, said today the Kaiser-Frazer Company was asking the Air Force for "another $10,000,000" to complete a December, 1950, contract to build C-119 transport airplanes at Willow Run, Mich.

Activity was light yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges, world sugar showing the greatest volume. Prices were irregular with wool, cocoa, soybean oil and copper closing mixed. Cottonseed oil, potatoes, hides and zinc ended lower and sugar, coffee, lead, rubber and tin closed higher.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (UP) -- The Navy plans to cut employment by about 13,000 in eleven of its shipyards by the last quarter of this year.

The United States has slipped from the position it held at the end of 1952 as the leading exporter of cotton textiles, Matthew J. Cuffe, president of the Textile Export Association of the United States, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- V. C. Georgescu, a naturalized United States citizen, who rejected the to blackmail him into becoming a spy, talked with State Department officials today about the prospects of getting his two teen-age sons out of Rumania.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Frank Coe, who for six years until last Dec. 3 was secretary of the multibillion-dollar International Monetary Fund, which deals with sensitive financial problems of fifty-four nations, appeared before the Senate Investigations subcommittee today for questioning in closed session.

ROME, June 3 -- No less than three outspoken articles appeared in the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano this afternoon urging all Italian Catholics to remain united and vote Sunday only for those parties that offered solid guarantees of defending the "rights of religion and of souls." This was another way of saying the Center party coalition, headed by Premier Alcide De Gasperi's Christian Democrats.

MIAMI, Fla., June 3 -- Six men were indicted on charges of perjury in Miami today by the Federal grand jury investigating terrorism and bombings in Florida. They were ordered to surrender in Miami June 19 for arraignment in Federal District Court.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Senator John W. Bricker of Ohio called today for a showdown with Eisenhower Administration leaders on a toned-down version of a proposed constitutional amendment to limit Presidential treaty-making powers.
The cotton futures market continued quiet yesterday and prices moved within a narrow range, closing 5 points higher to 5 points lower than on Tuesday.

NEW DEHLI, June 3 -- With Mount Everest at last conquered, six other great peaks in the Himalayan and Karakoram ranges, ranking close to the world's tallest mountain in height, are the target of expeditions from several countries, including the United States. Five have never been climbed to the top.
It would be difficult to overestimate the importance of President Eisenhower's insistence that the federal budget be brought into balance before existing taxes are repealed or permitted to expire.

Limitation of the amount of Government securities that may be acquired by the Federal Reserve banks is advocated by the New York Clearing House in a special study, "The Federal Reserve Re-examined," issued today. The 165-page report, which includes a variety of recommendations regarding the central banking system, is the first such comprehensive survey undertaken by the clearing house in its 100-year history.

Two five-story buildings with eighty apartments at 927 and 931 Faile Avenue, in the Bronx, have been purchased by Geisinger Rau, operators, from trustees of Bronx Certificated Mortgages. The property is assessed at $230,000 and was bought for cash free and clear of mortgages. Snyder Co., Inc., brokers, negotiated the sale.

" THE PECKING ORDER,"* by Mark Kennedy, is a taut, dramatic novel about a Penrod-aged youngster in a spectacularly un-Tarkingtonian world. Among the sixty or seventy books I've reviewed here since the first of the year, from Toynbee and Salinger to du Maurier and Maugham, this one stands out for a special quality of burning earnestness, an au thor's desire to say far more than he reasonably can in a given form, a given book.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 3 -- Better public relations by the nation's electric power companies were urged today at the annual convention of the Edison Electric Institure. Charles E. Oakes, president of the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company, said that "only a handful of individuals" has been helping the power industry's fight against socialism.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 3 -- Jordan agreed today to the Israeli proposal for a renewal of meetings between local commanders along the armistice lines. The first such meeting will take place Monday, just five months after Israel denounced the previous frontier agreement.

BALBOA, June 3 -- Gov. John S. Seybold, who is also president of the Panama Canal Company, left here by air today to report to Washington on the adverse affects of a proposal by the House Appropriations Committee to reduce pay and increase house rents and cost of medical attention for United States citizens employed in the Canal Zone on operatino and maintenance of the Panama Canal.

Strength in the morning and weakness in the afternoon marked yesterday's stock market trading. The result was a virtual stand-off. THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average dropped slightly, but of the 1,079 issues traded, 403 rose, 372 fell and 304 closed unchanged. Six of the ten most active issues rose, but all gains and losses were held to minor fractions.

Joseph P. Piccirillo, acting Commissioner of Welfare in the absence of Henry L. McCarthy, denied yesterday published reports that the Department of Welfare was squandering $500,000 a year on unnecessary projects.
Victor Andrade, Bolivian Ambassador to the United States, made a strong appeal yesterday for a long-term contract by the United States for the purchase of his country's tin ores.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (AP) -- An eighth-inning triple by Tom Glaviano and a single by Connie Ryan broke a deadlock tonight and gave the Phillies a 6-5 triumph over the Cardinals. The Cards won the twilight game opener, 5 -- 3, on an assortment of extra-base hits and a clutch relief hurling job by Alpha Brazle, who also saw brief action in the night encounter.

Franklin Foulke of Essex, Md., yesterday received the new Palladium Trophy for his victory last December in his Sagana XIII as part of the Miami Orange Bowl week-end. Made of palladium, a metal in the platinum group, the trophy is valued at $7,500 and reputed to be the most costly of any in speed boating.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 27, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

TRENTON, N. J., June 3 (AP) -- New Jersey Treasurer Walter T. Margetts today made the suggestion that the Federal Government issue a new type of bond -- one that could be purchased only by the states.
Prison riots are the result of faulty administration caused by inadequate financial support, political meddling and public indifference, the American Prison Association declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today, the following proceedings were had:

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The visual and vocal reporting that the modern miracles of television and radio have furnished as a supplement to the printed word made it possible for the Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II to be communicated to the people of the world as this stupendous combination of spiritual and temporal splendors has never before been chronicled.

The State of Washington borrowed $20,000,000 yesterday on school construction serial bonds maturing over ten years, at an interest cost of 2.9353 per cent. The issue was sold at competitive bidding to a banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc.; Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and First Boston Corporation at a bid of 100.011 for 3s, 4s and 2 3/4s.

The Vice President of the Republic of India, Dr. Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan, paid a four-hour visit yesterday to Columbia University and its president, Dr. Grayson Kirk, to discuss Indian participation in Columbia's bicentennial celebration next year.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 4 -- The Communists expressed their views at length today on the new United Nations proposal for an armistice in the Korean war and as far as could be learned under the secrecy agreement in force at Panmunjom neither completely accepted nor rejected the Allied "final" offer.
RYE, N. Y., June 3 -- The first half of the big field competing for the United States Seniors Golf Association championship completed play today at the Apawamis Club, with two tied for the lead.

Governor Dewey announced yesterday the appointment of a nine-member Temporary State Commission, headed by Devereux Colt Josephs, president of the New York Life Insurance Company, to study the feasibility of adapting the city manager form of government to New York City's needs.

A Queens construction worker's belief that a bet on Native Dancer to win the Kentucky Derby was a safe investment for a moderate return caused him to be held in $5,000 bail yesterday on a charge of having stolen $13,000 of his mother's money.

Boys High captured its sixth successive Public Schools Athletic League outdoor track and field championship yesterday at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island. It wasn't till the last three races that the victors moved ahead of their Brooklyn rivals, New Utrecht, to win by a score of 32 to 30. Andrew Jackson placed third with 16 points.

The Metropolitan Conference of the National Federation of Temple Brotherhoods has chosen Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president and publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, for its "Man of the Year" award. Mr. Sulzberger will receive the citation next Wednesday at the Delmonico Hotel, Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

LAKE PLACID N. Y., June 3 -- A state health official reported today that an average group of state employes examined for heart disease "is too fat, gets little exercise, smokes too much and relaxes inadequately with cocktails and television."

Bronzini, Ltd., manufacturer and distributor of men's apparel, has leased the fifteenth floor, including terraces and tower space, in the sixteen-story office building under construction on the site of the old Duveen art gallery at 720 Fifth Avenue, northwest corner of West Fifty-sixth Street. Gerald I. Cutler, broker, and Cross Brown Company, agents for the building, negotiated the lease.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 3 -- Mrs. Allan Ryan of The Creek, making one of her few tournament appearances, gained low gross honors in a one-day event of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the Meadow Brook Club today.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, suggested today that the Pentagon leaders suspend all activities in favor of turning out a small dictionary.

The undistributed balance from the last big sale of housing bonds backed by the Federal Government continues to dwindle. At the close yesterday, the remainder was down to $19,708,000, compared with a total of $122,515,000 placed on the market on May 27.

ANDOVER, Mass., June 3 -- Phillips Academy at Andover, oldest boys preparatory school in the United States, will celebrate its 175th anniversary at commencement and subsidiary exercises here this week-end.
The Columbia University squad has arrived at Syracuse for the fifty-first regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association, to be held June 20 on Onondaga Lake.

Daryl Spencer and Davey Williams batted in eight runs between them and Larry Jansen went the route as the Giants reached three pitchers for thirteen hits and an 11-3 victory over the Redlegs at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
EASTON, Pa., June 3 (UP) -- Penn State and Lafayette gained victories today to enter the final of the National Collegiate A. A. District 2 baseball championship.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Proposals for two Administration-backed commission studies, already approved by the Senate, were cleared to the floor of the House of Representatives today and will be brought to a vote tomorrow if time permits.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 3 -- In an authorized statement Yugoslavia asserted today her readiness to cooperate with member states of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization "with the purpose of building up the collective security of the peace-loving world."

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 3 -- The Nairobi City Council has forbidden the construction of houses for white occupants without servants' quarters. The decision has aroused considerable interest here because it is the sort of thing that holds up to society a mirror in which it can see itself.

The Ford Motor Company announced detailed plans yesterday for its special two-hour television program for which it will spend $500,000. Tracing the history of the United States since 1903, the year the company was organized the program will be presented simultaneously over the C. B. S. and N. B. C. networks on Monday, June 15, beginning at 9 P. M.

LONDON, June 3 -- The Prime Ministers and princes of the British Commonwealth and envoys of other powers were guests of the newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II tonight at a state banquet in Buckingham Palace. A second coronation banquet will be held tomorrow night.

LONDON, June 3 -- The powerful voice of The Times of London, "The Thunderer" of Printing House Square, was raised today to call the British people back from the world of make-believe into the world of reality now that the coronation of Elizabeth II is over.

Britain's taxation policy has now been turned from the problem of combating internal inflation to the provision, through tax relief, of a stimulus to production, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York observes in its monthly Review, issued today.

NEW DELHI, India, June 3 (AP) -- A United States embassy spokesman said today twenty-one books by fifteen authors had been removed from library shelves of the United States Information Service here since the State Department issued a weeding out directive March 18.

ROWAYTON, Conn., June 3 -- A small blue yawl slipped its mooring here this afternoon and, with all sails drawing well to a fresh breeze, departed on a 7,000-mile cruise with its next scheduled stop Bergen, Norway.

The House of Delegates of the American Medical Association, policy-making body for the 140,000-member organization, voted yesterday in favor of a report recommending that new legislation limit medical care and hospitalization benefits of veterans with non-service-connected disabilities.

DETROIT, June 3 (UP) -- Gus Zernial cracked out two home runs, his tenth and eleventh of the season, today as he paced the Athletics to a 10-7 victory over the Tigers, who suffered their eighth straight loss.

In its first change of ownership in more than 30 years, the sixteen-story office and showroom building at 1140 Broadway, northeast corner of Twenty-sixth Street, has been sold to the H. J. Block Affiliates Corporation, who built it. Jesse H. Markin was the attorney for the buyers, who insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 3 -- Col. I. Fu-Teh, chief Nationalist delegate, emplaned for Taipei last night to report to the Government of President Chiang Kai-shek on measures being proposed by a four-power military group here for the evacuation of Gen. Li Mi's Nationalist guerrillas from eastern Burma.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 3 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will draw dramatic inspiration from the Bible for a large-scale production to be titled "The Prodigal" and made at one of the studio's four projected pictures utilizing the wide-screen CinemaScope system presented by Twentieth Century-Fox.

LEBANON, June 3 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic .Presidential candidate in 1952, turned aside with a soft answer today the wrath of an Arab refugee spokesman during an inspection of a camp near here.

ST. LOUIS, June 3 (AP) -- Holly Mims of Washington floored Jesse Turner of St. Louis with a right uppercut in the sixth round tonight and went on to punch out a unanimous decision in a ten-round middleweight bout. Mims weighed 155 pounds to Turner's 155 1/2.

OSSINING, N. Y., June 3 -- Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, condemned atom spies, declared today, in a statement issued by their lawyer, that they would not make a "deal" with the Government to save their lives by repudiating "the truth of our innocence."

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., June 3 -- The Van Cortlandt Manor House here, a 288-year-old structure that never failed in its original role as a fortress against warring Indians, but finally had to yield to the ever-mounting pressure of taxes, has been bought by John D. Rockefeller Jr., and presumably will become a shrine.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Mounting concern in the Administration and Congress over lagging prospects for a single European army and a developing strategy for coping with this main threat to continued military and appropriations, were suggested today in a development involving the White House and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Eisenhower starred tonight in the newest television panel show with a homey, chatty approach to some of the Government's most complex problems.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Senate Democrats blocked tonight a move to give the heads of the State, Commerce and Justice Departments broad dismissal powers over about 75,000 of their employes.

THESE mornings do not all conform to the poet's dew-pearled perfection, and the pleasant waters of the Beaverkill may not flow gin-clear, but it has been established beyong all doubt that the Green Drake is emerging from this haunt of the purist in numbers that have been described as abundant.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Grain futures again displayed resistance to selling pressure and good gains were registered in all pits. While there was the usual exploitation of bearish factors, these seemed to have less effect, indicating they have been largely discounted by recent declines.

Mexico City is a heaven for gourmets, Francis Guth told us yesterday. The word of this Andover, Mass., business man, recently returned from one of his frequent visits south of the border, can be taken on such matters, for he is in the upper reaches of epicurism, a kind of gourmet's gourmet.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Eisenhower discussed the security of the nation tonight, internal and external, and promised the American people a sound dollar based on a sound fiscal policy.

Three films arrive at first-run theatres today. "Julius Caesar," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's adaptation of William Shakespeare's drama, opens this evening at 8:45 at the Booth Theatre. Beginning tomorrow the production will be shown on a reserved-seat basis, with performances at 2:45 and 8:45 P. M. Heading the cast are Marlon Brando, James Mason, John Gielgud, Louis Calhern, Edmond O'Brien, Greer Garson and Deborah Kerr. Joseph L. Mankiewicz was the director and John Houseman produced.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- One of the critics of a 1951 order attacked as extending unduly the authority of civilian Government agencies to withhold information from publication says the Eisenhower Administration may modify it.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg told Congress today that the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as recently as last March, had warned Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, that failure to achieve an Air Force of 143 wings soon after 1954 "would increase the risk to national security beyond the dictates of national prudence."

Record sales of $674,975,000 for the six months ended on April 30 enabled the International Harvester Company to increase its net profit to $25,705,000 from the $24,717,000 earned in the same period a year before.
Harmon A. Joseph has retired from The Nestle Company, Inc., after thirty-four years. He was insurance manager of the company and will be succeeded by Robert H. Cronk, his former assistant.

LONDON, June 3 -- Wildly cheered by thousands upon thousands of her loyal cockneys, the newly crowned Queen Elizabeth II drove today through the little streets of the poorer parts of London on the first of her four coronation rides through the capital.

A $87,690,000 treble damage civil anti-trust suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court by the Skouras Theatres Corporation and four affiliates against major motion-picture producing companies and their distributing subsidiaries.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 3 -- The Turkish Government, whose twenty-two combat divisions control the southeastern flank of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, has made it clear to United States diplomats, including John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, that it is highly skeptical, and even apprehensive, concerning the results of the four-power parley proposed by Sir Winston Churchill, British Prime Minister.

The slender yet ample silhouette was emphasized in the collection of fall furs by Ritter Brothers presented yesterday at the Pierre Hotel. Designs that featured the natural beauty of fur had new flattering details that were particularly feminine and graceful.

TORONTO, June 3 -- Ultimate profits of $40,000,000 to $50,000,000 a year from the Yukon metallurgical program of Ventures, Ltd., were predicted today by L. J. Lichty, vice president and general manager of Quebec Metallurgical Industries, Ltd., a subsidiary.

Armed with new powers to serve summonses, a thousand supervisory officers of the Department of Sanitation will start a campaign on Monday against "litterbugs" who violate the Sanitary and Administrative Codes and make extra work for the city's street-cleaning force.

In an unprecedented joint action the Governors of the eleven Northeastern states have taken an important step forward toward highway safety. Their declaration of a unified summer highway "slowdown" campaign should have a beneficial effect in reducing accidents during the peak of vacation travel, which this year is expected to reach a new high.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Senator Homer Capehart, Republican of Indiana, watched the Eisenhower telecast tonight and described it as a "very frank discussion of the issues."

Thirty to 40 per cent of the air pollution here comes from the incomplete burning of the garbage and other refuse of 1,350,000 New Yorkers -- one-sixth of the city's population -- in apartment house incinerators, Dr. Leonard Greenburg, Commissioner of Air Pollution Control, said yesterday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 3 -- Harvard University will confer the Bachelor of Laws degree at year's commencement on eleven women, the first women to receive this degree from the Harvard Law School.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 3 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther expressed confidence today that peace could be preserved in the world through a strong and unified North Atlantic Treaty Organization. But he warned that peace would be endangered if Russia succeeded in destroying the unity of the United States and its Allies.
The colt that finished third in the Kentucky Derby was the one that led 'em home, in the role of favorite and highweight, in the $34,900 Peter Pan Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

Talks have been held among representatives of the city and the Port of New York Authority looking to the construction of a union bus terminal at the Manhattan end of the George Washington Bridge between 178th and 179th Streets.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, June 4 (AP) -- Soldiers of four Republic of Korea Divisions fought desperate hand-to-hand battles early today for seven outpost and mainline positions won by the Communists on the flaming east and east-central front.

Based on average rather than gross spending, advertising agency executives lead all other representatives of industry in entertainment expenditures, according to a study of the Diners' Club. A shade behind are public relations agents, followed by manufacturers' representatives and distributors, theatrical booking agents and wholesalers' representatives, in that order.

A small new collection of furniture, introduced here yesterday by Laverne of 160 East Fifty-seventh Street, continues the slick, structural architectural tradition for which the organization is known. The pieces, available through decorators, are the work of three designers -- William Katavolos, Ross Littell and Douglas Kelley.

Because of a visit of a sixteen-man Swiss soccer team to City Hall yesterday, 120 orphans at the Shield of David Home for Orphan Girls at 1800 Andrews Avenue, the Bronx, received 180 pounds of cheese. The best guess was that the girls would need just about a month to gnaw through the cheese.

Directors of the Detroit Hardware Manufacturing Company voted yesterday to defer action on the second quarterly common dividend. "Due to moving into our new plant," the company said, "it is considered best to conserve our cash position at this time."

THE wheel has spun full cycle for Wee Willie Pep, once one of the most remarkable fighters of this generation. He's just a journeyman performer now, just another hungry boxer looking for a payday. Wee Willie returns to the Madison Square Garden ring tomorrow night, seeking cash rather than glory. It has been twenty months since the one-time featherweight champion of the world has been permitted to operate in New York.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, June 3 -- Four members of a nine-man team of seven Americans, a Pakistani and an Englishman have completed a year's preparation for the assault of Mount Godwin Austen, a Himalayan peak in the glacial wastes north of here.

Insurgent leaders of the much-investigated International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., announced plans yesterday for a port-wide dock strike next Monday to protest the recommendations of the State Crime Commission for ridding the New York piers of violence, extortion and theft.

LONDON, June 3 -- Sir Winston Churchill, the British Prime Minister, found considerable support today among the Prime Ministers of the other Commonwealth countries for his recent proposal that a conference of the leading powers should take place "without long delay."
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Senate approved by a roll-call vote of 76 to 0 today an unqualified declaration of opposition to the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- The Yankees today flashed their heaviest attack of the season, a nineteen-hit offensive that brought them an 18-2 victory over the White Sox. Other teams have collected more hits in a game this year, but no club in either major league has scored so many runs in a contest.

Following is the text of the television broadcast last night by President Eisenhower, Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Welfare and Education; George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury; Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General and Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Sales of household furniture by manufacturers last year reached $1,675,000,000 at factory prices, Seidman Seidman, accountants for many furniture factories, reported yesterday. This was only one-half of 1 per cent below the $1,687,000,000 chalked up in 1950, the industry's best year.

Despite a poor start, Slowest, an outsider, waddled down the stretch to win the Tortoise Handicap at the Bronx Zoo yesterday. Slower, handicapped by 300 pounds, finished second, while Slow, the oddson favorite, never did quite make it.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Top Treasury officials found themselves in deep trouble with the House Ways and Means Committee today as the result of their efforts to dissuade business leaders from opposing a six-month extension of the excess profits tax.

ST. LOUIS, June 3 (AP) -- The Senators scored one run in the tenth inning tonight on a pair of singles and a stolen base to defeat the Browns, 3 -- 2. Satchel Paige, who came on in the tenth, struck out the first two men before yielding the winning run.

The American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations have agreed tentatively on a two-year "no raiding" pact. This means that each organization will recognize the other's claim to its own members once a contract has been made with employers or the unit has been certified by the National Labor Relations Board.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UP) -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the Japanese Government announced today they were opening negotiations on loans for economic development in Japan.

Ralph Marano is one designer who always can be counted upon to produce exciting fashion news with his fur designs. In his fall and winter collection, created for Russeks and shown yesterday at this store, he turned out the "slick and slim" silhouette as his new look for the fall.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The House Banking and Currency Committee followed the Senate's lead today in voting, 15 to 13, to deny to President Eisenhower authority to institute a ninety-day price-and-wage freeze in the event of grave national emergency.

As in the weeks immediately before the first the Tuesday in November, those of early June are the time for oratory. In the first instance, the speakers look forward yearningly to the holding of public office -- a step along in life, whether up or down. In the second, they look forward to entrance upon a wider life, again up or down.

President Eisenhower has just demonstrated his willingness and ability to exercise forthright leadership on Capitol Hill. During his months in office the President has leaned over backward to avoid even the appearance of Executive infringement on the Congressional domain.

The letter of Morris L. Ernst published in your issue of May 27 is an interesting observation on the subject of statism as presented in the state's approach to the New York City waterfront problems involving crime and corruption and presents a good argument in support of the principles of home rule and democracy.

The fact that the United States Government is trying to get rid of millions of pounds of surplus butter, cheese and dried milk has appeared on the front pages of The Times of India May 18. The world is watching this matter. If the material is fed to swine communism will score its greatest victory yet.

The five Republican county leaders of the city, through Thomas J. Curran, New York City Chairman, announced yesterday the appointment of the reactivated Inter-County Republican Committee for the Return of Good Government to New York City.

Attributing a decline in New York City department store sales in part to the drop in the use of the city's transit system that followed the 1948 fare increase, the Retail Dry Goods Association urged the New York City Transit Authority yesterday to consider "the welfare of the whole community" in making any new adjustments.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UP) -- The Department of Defense today announced a new total of 135,362 United States battle casualties in Korea, an increase of 199 over last week's report. The increase actually was only 141 because the report was adjusted to make up for 58 marines erroneously listed as wounded in the past.

A deal is on the verge of being made that will start activity for the importation of the centuries-old Kabuki theatre of Japan. The project, intended to encourage cultural relations between this country and Japan, was conceived several years ago by Joshua Logan, who witnessed Kabuki presentations in Tokyo.

The newer synthetic fibers such as Orlon and Dacron have brought the knitting industry close to its goal of a dimensionally stable fabric that will make up into fully washable garments, Max Thal, president of the Alamac Knitting Mills, Inc., said last night at the monthly meeting of the American Association for Textile Technology, Inc., in the Builders Club.
PALMDALE, Calif., June 3 (AP) -- Jacqueline Cochran, America's only woman jet pilot, has broken two more speed records flying a Sabre-jet, a spokesman announced today.

OXFORD, England, June 3 -- Although it is some time since the jovial Danes ruled England, they took the occasion of Queen Elizabeth's coronation to send a roasting ox to their British friends for cooking and devouring in the manner customary at the time of King Canute.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A civilian committee of scientific and business leaders, in a report placed before the National Security Council, urged today the continued build-up of the United States atomic air striking power and recommended a greatly improved system of air defense.

Milwaukee's marauding Braves, continuing to comport themselves like a team with serious designs on the pennant, yesterday made it two in a row over the Dodgers to increase their first-place lead over the 1952 National League champions to one and a half games.

The time has come for us to reassure President Eisenhower of our over-whelming mandate to him to restore this country to its moral prestige in the eyes of the world. No further compromise is possible in Korea short of appeasement.
Dr. Moses Legis Isaacs has resigned as dean of the college at Yeshiva University, a post he has held for twelve years.

WHEN Mark Twain's Connecticut Yankee invaded King Arthur's Court, he reached the point where he was dubbed Sir Boss. Because this rich and amusing satire was pure fantasy, the incongruity of knighthood being conferred on an outlander was not too difficult to accept.

Out in the marshes, the swamps and lesser pools of stagnant water there is activity these nights. Along about sunset, at that precise moment when the western sky is shedding its last feeble light and when the air chooses to be still, you can see the silhouette.
TOKYO, Friday, June 5 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,636, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korean time:

CHANTILLY, France, June 4 (AP) -- Bing Crosby couldn't draw a crowd and Harvie Ward didn't get to play a shot, but together they led eleven American golfers into the third round of the French amateur championship today.

Protesting the "existence of maritime academies which are putting into the field licensed engineers who are not needed at all," the National Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, C. I. O., has decided to bar any "large influx" of new members. Earl King, business agent of Local 33, said yesterday that the action would become effective July 1.

LONDON, June 4 -- The news that at least one atomic reactor in the United States is operating on the breeding or fuel-conserving principle has been received with reserve at the Harwell Research Station here, where physicists are under a written obligation to say nothing whatever about Britain's "shadow breeding pile" called Zephyr.

The National Council of American Importers voted yesterday to recommend that Congress increase membership of the Federal Tariff Commission from six to twelve, rather than make an increase to seven as provided in a pending bill. The organization met at the Astor Hotel.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., June 4 -- The first international Civil Defense week entered its intensive phase here today, as 200 United States and Canadian officials met have to discuss what would be done in the event of an atomic bomb attack.

It appears as if C. L. Sulzberger has become "a historian over night" to use his own expression, judging from the number of errors in his NEW YORK TIMES release of June 1 ("Birth of New Era Is Britain's Hope").

Averell Harriman called on President Eisenhower last night to follow the bipartisan example of President Harry S. Truman and invite leading Democratic members of Congress into full consultation on key foreign policy measures. He recalled that Mr. Truman, when President, had consulted the late Arthur H. Vandenberg and other Republican members of Congress on foreign policies.

Rebounding vigorously from two straight defeats by Milwaukee, which cost them the National League lead, the Dodgers yesterday pounded the previously unbeaten Max Surkont and three successors for four home runs, three doubles and four singles.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Creation of a single European army and the political federation of the Western nations are "much nearer a reality than most people realize" and are part of a quiet political revolution that nothing can stop, Jean Monnet, head of the European Coal and Steel Authority, said today.

Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were slightly easier yesterday because of peace talk in Korea and weakness in the stock market, final prices of active months being 8 to 13 points net lower on the day.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 4 -- A committee of the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners is studying problems of regulation arising from the participation of the electric power industry in atomic power development.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UP) -Senator Walter F. George, Democrat of Georgia, said today former Civil Service Commissioner Robert Ramspeck had spent many years in public service and "those who know him have never questioned his character or his motives."

The Palestine Economic Corporation and Jacques Torczyner, diamond merchant, have jointly undertaken establishment of the P. E. C. Diamond Corporation, Inc., in an attempt to increase the sale and distribution in the United States of diamonds manufactured in Israel, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UP) -- Harold E. Stassen, Director for Mutual Security, told senators today that the money spent for military aid in the Middle East and India would be wasted unless it was backed up with economic aid.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 4 -Dore Schary has decided to pour star names into Metro's production of Cameron Hawley's best-seller novel, "Executive Suite." Principals who Will be on hand when filming starts in August are William Holden, Deborah Kerr, Walter Pidgeon and Louis Calhern.

BOSTON, June 4 (AP) -- A New York investment specialist said today that for the first time in twenty years the outlook for the seeker of fixed-income is brighter because of the changed yield relationships between various types of securities.

LAREDO, Tex., June 4 (AP) -About 350,000 Texans in the fruit and vegetable croplands of the lower Rio Grande Valley were faced with an acute water shortage today as the Rio Grande ran dry here for the first time in recorded history.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, assured Senator James H. Duff, Republican of Pennsylvania, today that every assistance possible would be given a Pittsburgh lawyer flying to Korea to defend Robert W. Toth, former airman charged with the murder of a South Korean civilian.

Sea Legs had too much endurance for Oedipus in the Meadow Brook Steeplechase Handicap yesterday, and, as a consequence, won the thirty-eighth running of the $11,400 event at Belmont Park. Taking the lead only three jumps from home, Sea Legs finished the course of about two miles and a half five lengths in front of Oedipus.

Prospects appear bright for a one- year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, but the circumstances are not such as to evoke great enthusiasm from those who genuinely believe in encouragement of international commerce. The worst threat, the protectionist Simpson bill, which would have virtually repudiated American liberal trade policies of the past twenty years, has apparently been shelved.

FREEHOLD, N. J., June 4 -- An indictment against the Little Silver Volunteer Fire Company was voted this afternoon by the Monmouth County grand jury on charges that the firemen maintained a gambling place in connection with a charity fair held as a test of the state law last Monday night.

The Mutual Broadcasting System radio network gave assistance to the Du Mont television network last night by broadcasting a Du Mont program in the Washington area when the latter was unable to clear time on its own station there.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 4 (AP) -- Super Chief, owned by the Three P. Farm of Las Vegas, Nev., charged down the stretch to overtake Meadow Abbe and win the Manhasset Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee called on the four chairmen of the Senate and House Judiciary and Labor committees today to expedite legislation under which National Labor Relations Board certification could be withheld from Communist-dominated unions, even though they won elections as collective bargaining representatives.

BOSTON, June 4 -- The Commonwealth of Massachusetts acquired outright title today to a $13,500,000 ocean terminal as Castle Island. South Boston, in an exchange of deeds with Navy officials in Washington.
DETROIT, June 4 (AP) -- Cass Michaels slammed a three-run homer in the tenth inning to give the Athletics a 9-6 victory over the Tigers and a sweep of their doubleheader today.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Our political processes seem to be misunderstood by so many in positions of influence abroad that today's approval of the Bricker resolution by the Senate Judiciary Committee may be estimated as sure presage of an amendment to the Constitution further limiting the President's authority in the conduct of foreign affairs.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 4 -An unusual television program for children will begin a thirteen-week summer series over New Haven's Station WNHC-TV at noon tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, who will retire as Chief of Staff of the Air Force on June 30, asserted today that restrictions imposed by Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, in the last four months had already retarded by six months the development of 143 combat wings for the Air Force.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Grain traders gathered no bullish inspiration from the Administration's statements on grain trade troubles, and the markets were weak in the early trade. Few encouraging reports came from the corn conference yesterday at Des Moines, Iowa.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 4 --The Stockholm Music Festival, the first international music fete Sweden has offered to the world, opened yesterday as one of the leading events of the Swedish National Festival, which this year celebrates the 700th anniversary of the founding of the nation.

Between now and June 15 the National Broadcasting Company will decide whether to continue its lease on the historic Belasco Theatre through July 14, 1954, it was officially acknowledged yesterday. The former legitimate house, owned by the Shuberts, has been under lease to the broadcasting firm since 1949.

Seven hundred persons attended the 315th commencement exercises yesterday of the Collegiate School, oldest private school in the United States, in the West End Collegiate Church, 245 West Seventy-seventh Street.

A consulting engineer for the Public Service Commission criticized yesterday a recent plan of the Long Island Rail Road for purchasing new passenger cars and rehabilitating old ones as containing "shocking" and "absurd" features.

Frank Erickson, the bookmaker, pleaded no defense before Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday to an indictment charging him with cheating the Government out of $75,630 in income taxes for 1945.

Approximately 100 young people from various provinces of Spain gave the first of two performances at Carnegie Hall last night under the name of "Coros y Danzas de Espana," and on this occasion for the benefit of the Damon Runyon Memorial Fund for Cancer Research.

A change in our present philosophy that would re-emphasize the simple, eternal values was urged last night by Dr. Clarence Cook Little, director of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory at Bar Harbor, Me. He spoke at the ninety-fifth commencement of the State University of New York College of Medicine in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
CLEVELAND, June 4 (AP)--Larry Doby, shaking a batting slump, hit a grand-slam home run today as the Indians whipped the Red Sox, 8-1.

The outlook for the pulp, paper and paperboard industries during 1953 is generally favorable, according to a quarterly report issued in Washington yesterday by the National Production Authority, Department of Commerce.

Fifteen youths, arrested Wednesday night by patrolmen and detectives of the Brooklyn East Youth Squad, were held for court action next Monday and Tuesday when they were arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn courts.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, the Republican Senate leader, renewed today his criticism of the United Nations' approach to Korea, and advocated a free-nation military alliance in the Pacific should the Korean truce negotiations fail.

Many sincere supporters of the trade union as a democratic institution have been perplexed over the problem of how to guarantee members protection of their rights. This problem sometimes arises in acute form when a member is placed on trial upon the complaint of other members or union officers.

Speaking for the Republic of Korea, Ambassador Yang has now stated that his Government is ready "to go along with what the United States does" in working for a truce in Korea. This is a wise Statement and comes at a time when it can dispel some of the talk about dissension in the ranks of the free world.

National Phoenix Industries, Inc., a holding company, has announced the election of Prof. Bernard E. Proctor to its board' of directors. He is head of the ood technology department of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

THE sixteen girls who run the eleven high-speed elevators in the twenty-one-story office building at 260 Madison Avenue at Thirty-ninth Street have their hair done on management's time, at management's insistence. They're all redheads now, but when they were screened out of 575 applicants over a year ago, only two had red hair.

READING, Pa., June 4 (AP) -Four strokes in front of the field after the first eighteen holes, Betsy Rawls, defending Eastern open champion, put in a strong bid today for another year's reign at the Berkshire Country Club.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 (AP) -Federal Judge Alan K. Grim ruled today that a Philadelphia law firm must tell how much it was paid for representing a public utility before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The rally in the market for United States Government securities continued yesterday, with prices of long-term 2 1/2 per cent issues rising 1/4 to 7/16 of a point in light trading. The new 3 1/4 per cent issue closed the day at 99 1/8, up 1/16.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 (AP) -Johnny Wyrostek singled home Richie Ashburn with the winning run in the tenth inning tonight as the Phillies downed the Cardinals, 6 -- 5, for the third victory in the four-game series in the battle for third place in the National League.

More than eight years have now gone into history since the collapse of Nazi Germany in May, 1945. Since that time enormous changes have taken place in that land -- economically, politically and socially. Soviet obstruction over this period has prevented the signing of a peace treaty between a unified Germany and the victors of the Second World War.

LONDON, June 4 -- An Oxford zoologist, Dr. William J. L. Sladen, has brought back from the Antarctic evidence that the little bright-eyed Adelie penguins sometimes walk as much as sixty miles to find food for themselves and their young and often fast for forty days in intervals.

Individuals with incomes of less than $10,000 a year are quite as important to the New York Stock Exchange as those in the $10,000to-$25,000 or over $25,000 brackets, Keith Funston, president of that institution, declared yesterday.

The board of trustees of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center has decided to discontinue its affiliation with the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, it was announced here last night.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today proposed a minimum national wheat acreage allotment of 62,000,000 acres for 1954.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 4 -- Part of the address of Gordon Dean, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, before the Edison Electric Institute here today, in which he announced the development of a new atomic reactor, follows:

New Yorkers will get their first glimpse in almost two years of Willie Pep, Hartford, Conn., tonight when the former world feather weight champion squares off with Pat Marcune, hard-punching Coney Island scrapper, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.

TRENTON, June 4 -- An aunt of Joseph Doto, alias Joe Adonis, testified here today that the racketeer, to the best of her knowledge, was a native-born American. The witness, the first called by defense attorney Samuel Paige of New York, appeared at an immigration hearing in State Prison.
The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York started yesterday a "Telephone Month" during which it aims to reach prospective contributors to the 1953 campaign.

Through a $5,000,000 stock transfer, the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company has acquired the American Lava Corporation of Chattanooga, which will become a wholly owned subsidiary. Terms call for American Laba stockholders to trade their common and preferred shares for "3M" common. The transfer is to be completed today.

There has been a steady shift in the migration trend of Puerto Ricans entering the continental United States, and where new arrivals four years ago were still settling almost exclusively in New York recent comers from the Caribbean islands are settling up Puerto Rican communities throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The country's two largest and most influential business organizations rejected today the request of Treasury officials to support the President, or at least take a neutral stand, on extension of the excess profits tax.

PITTSBURGH, June 4 (AP) -- Bob Hall scattered seven hits after a shaky first inning to whip Chicago, 6 -- 1, today for his first major league victory and the third straight for the Pirates over the Cubs.

A niece of the late William G. McAdoo, former Secretary of the Treasury, and forty other persons were named yesterday in fourteen indictments charging conspiracy to defraud the Government of $70,000 in an income tax scheme.
Dr. Ladislav Feierabend, former Czechoslovak Minister of Finance, said yesterday that last week's sweeping monetary reform in his country would turn Czechoslovakia into "one huge concentration camp."

Willard Price, author of a number of books about Japan and other places, has delivered to John Day the manuscript of a new book about Japan that combines "adventurous" narrative and a political report on the country. Mr. Price describes the observations he made on a five months' sojourn in that country in 1952.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 786,755 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

TERBOL Lebanon, June 4 -Mounted sheep and cattle herders in Arab headdress cantered across the green Bekaa Valley plain today to watch President Camille Chamoun and Adlai Stevenson, United States Democratic leader, lay the cornerstone of a dairy barn at what United States Point Four officials say will be the largest most modern livestock experimental and demonstration farm in the Middle East.

GREAT FALLS, Mont., June 4 (AP) -- Rain-fed mountain streams in Northwest Montana forced more residents from their homes today, and disaster officials said the number of families evacuated would run into the hundreds.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan published yesterday a list of disciplinary actions against eighty-six policemen from Jan. 1 through last Sunday. He said almost all the actions had been announced previously, and that the volume of offenses was "average" for the period.
The world's first cobalt 60 rotation therapy unit was unveiled yesterday at the city's Francis Delafield Hospital for cancer research, an affiliate of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 4 -- Although the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration was dissolved in 1948, a report issued here today showed that the agency's work was continuing, at least indirectly, with Austria, Greece, Italy and the Philippines using U. N. R. R. A. funds for economic reconstruction and allied purposes.
The Silex Company, producer of coffee-making equipment, has completed arrangements to finance the purchase of the Chicago Electric Manufacturing Company, maker of electrical appliances.

SEWANEE, Tenn., June 4 -- The board of trustees of the University of the South voted overwhelmingly tonight to instruct its officials to disregard racial considerations in student applications for admission to the School of Theology.
Forty - five individual parades, involving 100,000 children, threaded through Brooklyn and Queens yesterday to mark the 124th anniversary of the first Sunday School marchers on Long Island.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 4 -- A Yugoslav delegation left tonight for Bucharest for a meeting of a special committee of the Danube River Commission that will take up Yugoslav proposals that would weaken the control over commission exercised by the Soviet Union since the founding of the commission in 1948.

From 60 to 70 per cent of the victims of a once-fatal bacterial infection of the lining of the heart now recover from their infection and remain well and without recurrence of symptoms from two to nine years, depending upon the period of follow-up.
The coronation football team from England was honored last night at a dinner given by the Sportsmanship Brotherhood at the Town Hall Club on West Fortythird Street.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 4 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood won low gross in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association New Jersey tournament for Class A and B players over the Upper Montclair course today.

TOKYO, Friday, June 5-- Gen. Mark W. Clark flew to Korea this morning while all top Allied commanders studied a new Communist statement of views on terms for an armistice in Korea, which, some reports indicated might lead to a quick cease-fire in the three-year-old war.

The New York Trucking Authority, made up of four big unions of truck drivers and six employer associations, notified the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., last night that the truckers would take punitive action if insurgent dock workers carried out a threat to strike on Monday in protest against the State Crime Commission's recommendations for cleaning up the racket - ridden waterfront.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department store sales in the week ended May 30 were unchanged from the corresponding week of last year. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

CLEVELAND, June 4 -- Case Institute of Technology conferred the honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters today on Herbert H. Maas, Sr., chairman of the board of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, N. J.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A master plan designed to keep the economy of this country in balance by effective curbs on inflationary, as well as deflationary, movements is being drafted by the Administration at the request of the White House.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 4 -Gifts amounting to $2,992,578 were received by Harvard University in the first three months of this year. The university said today the total for capital was $1,408,756 and for immediate use $1,583,822.

PITTSBURGH, June 4 -- The Chicago Cubs happily obtained Ralph Kiner, the home run king, from the Pittsburgh Pirates today in a spectacular baseball deal involving ten players. Branch Rickey, the Pirates' general manager, gave up Kiner and three others for six players and a bundle of cash. He would not reveal the amount of money but it is reported to be about $100,000.

Hoyt Wilhelm, whose specialty is tossing a knuckleball that baffles batters, catchers and umpires alike, stepped out of character at the Polo Grounds yesterday and forthwith produced a startling effect.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A New York shipping official declared today that in his opinion there would be no time in the forseeable future when Government subsidization of the shipping industry would not be necessary.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 4 -- What probably was the greatest atomic detonation ever unleashed on this continent -- on the order of double the blast that devastated Hiroshima, Japan, in 1945 --
Five principals were elected by the Board of Education yesterday to $13,500-a-year posts as assistant superintendents from an original list of thirty.

Mitchel Fein and others, who recently bought the fourteen-story store and office building at 420 Madison Avenue, between Forty-eighth and Forty-ninth Streets, from John Kramer, have resold it to the Four Twenty Realty Corporation for investment.

William C. Chanler, chairman of the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee, announced yesterday that he had arranged for a meeting with representatives of the Republican and Liberal parties next Wednesday afternoon. Acceptance from the party representatives were received by Mr. Chanler by telephone.

Pork prices continue to climb, with loin chops and bacon reaching a record high. Loin pork roast advanced to the highest cost since last August, while ready-to-eat smoked hams now cost a dime a pound more than they did last year at this time. Lamb costs, too, showed an upward trend.

LONDON, June 4 -- The British post-coronation debate on the profit and loss aspects of the event is expected to continue for a long time because the figures on tangible debits and credits are still far from complete and the intangible elements may never be assessable.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- A top rubber industry official told Congress today that private interests were prepared to pay "full fair value" for the Government's $300,000,000 synthetic rubber industry.

ST. LOUIS, June 4 (AP) -- The onetwo punch of Mickey Vernon and Clyde Vollmer led the way tonight as the Senators backed up the seven-hit pitching of Johnny Dixon with a fifteen-hit attack and a 10-1 decision over the Browns.

PITTSBURGH, June 4 (AP) -The Pirates ordered Greenberg Gardens -- haven for home - run hitters at Forbes Field -- torn down today but National League headquarters asked the Bucs to withhold action until all other clubs in the league could be polled.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The Senate late today voted $1,102,000,000 for the State, Commerce and Justice Departments in the fiscal year to begin July 1.

A one-story industrial' building is planned for a tract of 157,000 square feet at Nineteenth and Twentieth Avenues, between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets, in Astoria, Queens, which has been purchased by Abe Wenig and David Bach from H. A. Weisner.

TOMS RIVER, N. J., June 4 -A sharply worded attack on "taxation for political rather than fiscal purposes" was made today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey. Such a tax -- and he specifically singled out "an excess profits tax on corporations or a consumer sales tax on food" -cannot contribute, he asserted, "either to the well-being of our economy or to the lasting credit of its sponsors."

ALGIERS, Algeria, June 4 -- Roger Leonard, Governor General of Algeria, will go before the Algerian Assembly tomorrow with detailed proposals for economic and social development on a scale hitherto unequaled in this country.

LONDON, June 4 -- British Government securities continued to advance in the stock markets today. Other markets remained firm despite sparseness of business. The strength of British funds was attributed to a further rise in the gold and dollar reserves of last month and prices advanced about one-eighth per cent, closing at their best.
PITTSBURGH, June 4 (UP) -Pittsburgh fans watched the strange sight of their home run slugger Ralph Kiner, playing in a Chicago uniform today at Forbes Field and the majority were dead against it.

The city of Pittsburgh borrowed $4,600,000 yesterday on an issue of funding and general improvement bonds due from 1954 to 1973. The bonds were sold at public bidding to a syndicate headed by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank at a bid of 100.10 for an interest rate of 2.8 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- Curt Simmons, left-handed pitching star of the Phillies, was cut badly on the left foot today by the blade of a rotary power mower while he was mowing grass at his ranchtype home in suburban Meadowbrook.
The Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing presented diplomas and pins yesterday to 100 students at its fifty-ninth commencement exercises held at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

Dr. Frank Nathaniel Daniel Buchman, founder of the worldwide movement called Moral ReArmament, asserted last night that with "absolute honesty, absolute purity, absolute unselfishness and absolute love . . . we have everything . . . a new world spelt out in new men."

TRENTON, June 4 -- State Senator J. Richard Kafe of Mercer County was found guilty in Federal Court here tonight of income tax evasion. The legislator has five days in which to enter a motion for a new trial or file an appeal.

Timed for summer decorating, five new wallpaper collections with airy designs and texture patterns predominating are available at Davis Wallpaper, 193 Madison Avenue. United Wallpaper, Inc., made four of the new groups, two of which have matching fabrics by Spectrum.

The United States Court of Appeals has affirmed a District Court decision of last November dismissing a $250,000 salvage claim filed by an Italian towing company for aid to the Government-owned tanker Signal Hills.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission decided today to hear argument June 15 on a proposal that New York State be licensed to join with Canada in constructing the St. Lawrence River power project.

NAPLES, Italy, June 4 -- With tactics reminiscent of those that led to the establishment of the Mussolini dictatorship, groups of neo-Fascist youngsters tonight attempted to create disturbances as Premier Alcide De Gasperi delivered the last speech on his tour of southern Italy.
ROME, June 4 -- The electoral campaign closes at midnight to morrow to give candidates and the electorate one day's rest before voting begins at 6 o'clock Sunday morning.

American women who played a decisive role in the election of President Eisenhower were called upon yesterday by Mrs. Ivy Baker Priest, Treasurer of the United States, to lend active support to the Administration's policies.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 4 -- Parents who wish to prepare youngsters to meet change with minimum difficulty must come to grips first with whatever feelings of fear or anxiety they themselves have about new situations, a group of mothers concluded here yesterday.
BONN, Germany, June 4 -- The Federal Republic's old and foreign currency holdings on March 31 reached a postwar high of 5,235,300,000 Deutsche marks ($1,246,500,000).

PARIS, June 4 -- France is staying officially aloof from the controversy now raging in her Moroccan protectorate between Sultan Sidi Mohammed Ben Youssef and the local chieftains who oppose him and seek to oust him.

The Boys Soccer Club of Berne, Switzerland, made its debut in the United States last night an impressive one. Paired against an American Soccer League all-star team, the Europeans -- their youngest athlete is 21 years old -- clearly displayed their class as they swept to a 9 -- 0 victory.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved eleven of President Eisenhower's nominations, including that of Dallas S. Townsend of Montclair, N. J., to be an Assistant Attorney General. Mr. Townsend is scheduled to be in charge of alien property, succeeding Harold J. Baynton.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- During the week ended June 3, member bank reserves increased $23,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LONDON, June 4 -- A one sentence communique containing a minimum of information was issued by the Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth today after the second session of their post-coronation conference. It said:

So far a advance prospects were concerned, everything seemed to be clicking at the close yesterday for bond men planning to attend the Bond Club's twenty-ninth annual field day at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club at Scarborough, N. Y. "Fair tonight and tomorrow" said the afternoon newspapers as executives from the investment banking houses took to subways, taxis and ferryboats.

ESSEX FELLS, N. J., June 4 -A pair of former champions, Billy Dear of Morris County and Myron Friedman, Shackamaxon, and Joseph Leiss, Metuchen, tied for the medal honors with par 71's as the New Jersey state amateur tourney started today.
