The House of Delegates of the American Medical Association adjourned here yesterday afternoon after electing Dr. Walter B. Martin of Norfolk, Va., as president-elect. Dr. Martin, who will take office a year from now, will succeed Dr. Edward J. McCormick of Toledo, Ohio, who was inaugurated on Tuesday.
SEOUL, Korea, June 4 -- In recent weeks the war has not been going well for the United Nations.

RYE, N. Y., June 4 -- A starting field of 184 in the second half of the forty-ninth annual United States Seniors Golf Association championship at the Apawamis Club today brought the entry to the record figure of 352.

An hour after drinking nine ounces of 100-proof whisky without chaser, a 192-pound man teetered on the brink of intoxication yesterday in a classroom at the Center for Safety Education, New York University.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -The normally placid job of being Vice President of the United States took a sudden turn for the worse today: Richard M. Nixon walked right into a lion's cage and put his hand on the beast's nose.

Rumors of an early truce in Korea resulted in declines in commodity prices yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume continued light except on the No. 4 sugar contract, which registered the third most active day of the year, and on coffee, which had a normal amount of trading.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 4-Israel is willing to negotiate the joint use of the waters of the Jordan, Yarmuk and Litani Rivers with Jordan, Syria and Lebanon, Israeli officials said today. They declared that Israel was willing to come to terms on this subject in advance of a general peace settlement.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- An Administrationbacked proposal for study of Federal-state relationship and responsibilities won approval in the House of Representatives today after weathering a storm of partisan controversy.

The New York City Transit Authority appointed Sidney H. Bingham, present chairman of the Board of Transportation, as its general manager yesterday, effective on June 15, when the authority takes over operation of the deficit-burdened municipal transit system from the board.

Donors contributed 761 pints of blood in the New York area on Wednesday, the Red Cross reported yesterday. Shipping concerns in lower Manhattan gave 225 pints at the Downtown Athletic Club, 18 West Street, for a total of 589 in a three-day drive.

The Allied Stores Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries increased sales in the quarter ended with April by 4.8 per cent but earnings were only $162,851 higher because of increased taxes and operating costs.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- The "hatred" that Windy City fans have for the Yankees did not diminish today. Rather, it grew stronger as Casey Stengel's athletes completed a sweep of the three-game set with the White Sox.

Stockholders of the National Department Stores Corporation, at the annual meeting held here yesterday, were told by Harry H. Schwartz, president, that sales for the quarter ended last April 30 were slightly below those of the corresponding three months last year.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -Senator Taft said that he still believed an armistice under the final terms offered by the Allies would be "unsatisfactory," but he made it plain he had no intention of balking at United Nations participation in subsequent political conferences.

Always a "big gun" in coffee and tea merchandising, premium promotions probably will be used even more extensively this year. Coffee and tea packers are making premium offers at a higher rate than ever before. At the same time they are moving toward larger premium budgets, both in amount and in proportion of gross sales, according to Coffee and Tea Industries, a trade publication.

Korean truce parley developments yesterday hammered stock prices down to a new low since Oct. 30. The market on the New York Stock Exchange rebounded toward the close by almost a point but ended the day with a net loss of 2.24 points on THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average.

The debut of President Eisenhower's TV panel program led to a realignment of N. B. C.'s schedule on Wednesday night out of which emerged a "sleeper' -- a genuinely amusing video version of the radio show called "My Son Jeep." It was the hit of the evening.

There is a need across the country for an institution between a mental hospital and a penal institution -- call it a "rehabilitation institute" -- for borderline mental cases or so-called psychopaths:

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Plans to summon Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson to Chicago under court order to testify in the du Pont anti-trust trial, a move which harks back for precedents to the famous Aaron Burr treason trial of 1807, were learned today.

DALLAS, Tex., June 4 (AP) -Gay Brewer Jr. of Lexington, Ky., the defending champion, marched through the opening rounds of match play in the Southern amateur golf tournament today, but there were a couple of smashing upsets.

John F. O'Connell, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, announced yesterday that a series of conferences would be held soon with local, state and Federal law enforcement officials to devise plans for coping with a growing traffic in bootleg liquor.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 4 -- The Atomic Energy Commission has developed a new atomic power plant that can produce new fuel "at least" as rapidly as fuel is consumed in operating the plant.
LONDON, June 4 (Reuters) -Canada has sold to Great Britain 545,000 metric tons of wheat under the International Wheat Agreement, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Dr. Herbert Blankenhorn, chief of the Office of Political Affairs in the Foreign Office of the West German Republic, said after a White House visit today that the Bonn Government would be "consulted and informed" about the forthcoming Bermuda conference.

BERLIN, June 4 -- Two leading ballet dancers of the Budapest Opera Company who want to dance as they please, flew from here to West Germany today after escaping May 15, an hour before the curtain call of a gala East Berlin performance.

LONDON, June 4 -- It was the turn of West London today to see the newly crowned Queen Elizabeth II on the second of her four coronation drives through her capital. Again thousands of Londoners gave her an adoring and noisy welcome.

TOKYO, Friday, June 5 -- North Korean Communists and South Korean troops of the United Nations Command fought bitterly today for "Anchor Hill" on the extreme eastern end of the Korean battleline near the Sea of Japan, where a see-saw battle had last night left each side in partial possession of the summit.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -The Department of Commerce said today farm income declined somewhat in April but non-farm income increased, giving a slight rise to total personal income during the month.

More than 1,900 persons paid honor last night to Leon Lowenstein, chairman of the board of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., textile manufacturers, at a dinner in the Astor Hotel to celebrate his seventieth birthday and fifty-fifth year in the textile industry.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A resolution proposing a constitutional amendment to limit the President's treaty-making power, and specifically to forbid any international commitment at variance with the Constitution, was approved today by the Senate Judiciary Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- A Senate inquiry subcommittee called on the Air Force today to explain why it was in "such a vast hurry" to set up the Kaiser-Frazer Company in the production of C-119 Flying Boxcar cargo planes in 1950.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Army announced today plans to tighten some phases of the Reserve Officers Training Corps program at both the senior college and junior college levels.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 4 -- It is generally believed here that the conclusion of a Korean armistice is now a matter of days, and United Nations delegates believe that the General Assembly will reconvene here by the end of June, or early in July, to call the Far Eastern political conference that is to be held within ninety days after the conclusion of the armistice.
OTTAWA, June 4 (Canadian Press) -- American success in "breeding" atomic fuel was hailed today by Canada's atomic leader as "a very significnt" step.
Lucien Diat, chef of the Plaza-Athenee Hotel in Paris, created a new fish dish for the 330th anniversary of the founding of Gloucester, Mass., which was celebrated yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., June 4 -Marriner Eccles, Utah banker and former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said here today that price inflation has pretty well run its course but that he does not expect any appreciable downturn in the economy until after the first of next year.

CLEVELAND, June 4 -- Five hundred correctional institutions and agencies joined forces here today in a permanent organization to combat juvenile delinquency, which was described as having reached "the crisis stage in America.''

ATLANTIC CITY, June 4 -Nearly 300 members of the National Wholesale Jewelers Association were told today by leading industry speakers that "selling is the function which affords the greatest opportunity for improving wholesale distribution."

FAIRFORD AIR BASE, England, June 4 (AP) -- Fifteen United State B-47 strato-jets, called the world's fastest atomic bombers, streaked from the United States to Britain at more than 500 miles an hour today in the first mass jet flight across the North Atlantic.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 4 -- A class of 924 midshipmen, the second largest in the history of the United States Naval Academy, was scheduled for graduation tomorrow. Most of the graduates will be commissioned in the Navy, the Marines or the Air Force at the same time they receive their diplomas.
The Atomic Energy Commission released yesterday this sketch of the atomic power plant at Arco, Idaho, which can produce new fuel as well as electrical energy.
LONDON, June 4 -- The meals served at Buckingham Palace, even at the most important ceremonial dinners, are extremely simple.

Two events of importance in the history of atomic energy's development occurred yesterday. On the Nevada proving grounds a plane dropped the mightiest plutonium bomb ever detonated on this continent, a bomb that flared for about fifteen seconds, a bomb at least twice as powerful as the ones that destroyed Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

Any $12,000,000 increase in the city's 1952-53 general fund receipts, as disclosed in revised estimates by Controller Lazarus Joseph, should be made available for city employe needs, the Government and Civic Employes Organizing Committee, C. I. O., asserted yesterday.

MANY of the Catskill and lower Adirondack streams, as well as those in Connecticut and Eastern Pennsylvania, are described as in "near perfect" condition. The week-end prospects are for unusually fine dry fly fishing, always provided the weather remains reasonably good.
GENEVA, June 4 (AP) -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, was elected president of the thirty-sixth annual conference of the International Labor Organization by acclamation here today.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Henry W. Grunewald, a private investigator who was credited with having great influence in some official circles in Washington, was fined $1,000 and sentenced to ninety days in jail today for contempt of Congress. Federal Judge Alexander Holtzoff, however, suspended the jail sentence and placed Grunewald on probation for one year.

Various statements coming from Paris have led to the assumption that France may be planning to undertake negotiation with Ho Chi Minh and the Vietminh Communists to "settle" the conflict in Indo-China. We believe that the French are much too realistic to put any faith in such a possibility.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Charters of two cargo vessels, owned by the Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., of New York City, were renewed today by the Navy-operated Military Sea Transportation Service of the Department of Defense.
Five winners of the 1953 National Collegiate Playwriting Contest held by Samuel French, play publishers, were announced yesterday.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., June 4 -- In common with the food industry . - I generally the fishing trade m this! old seaport senses a big conumer demand for precooked foods, l Among leading fish packers the l race is on to see which is first to achieve national distribution ofI fried and then frozen cod, haddock, [whiting, and most important of all dollar-wise, ocean perch.

PARIS, June 4 -- Pierre Mendes-France, financial expert of the Radical party, failed tonight to obtain from the French National Assembly the 314 votes required for endorsement as Premier. He failed by thirteen votes.

New borrowings by sales finance companies, the first in four weeks, held the decline in New York bank loans to business to $29,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday. It was the eighth successive week without an increase in business loans and brought the decrease since the start of this year to $352,000,000, against a drop of $385,000,000 in the similar period of 1952.

ST. PAUL, June 4 -- Mrs. Eugenie M. Anderson, former Ambassador to Denmark, is being boomed as a possible Democratic-Farmer Labor candidate for Governor of Minnesota in 1954. Leaders are seeking a suitable gubernatorial running mate for Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, who is up for re-election next year, and have confirmed that Mrs. Anderson is under discussion.

MESSINA, Sicily, Friday, June 5 (AP) -- The United States freighter Exmouth and the Norwegian tanker Pericles smashed into each other in the Strait of Messina early today. Several hours later both ships were reported under tow. All hands were reported safe.
SEOUL, Korea, June 5 -- Whether or not an armistice quickly is signed in Korea one of the biggest problems facing the free world today is the adequate reconstruction of this shattered land.

Walter Hoving, president of Bonwit Teller, Inc., in a letter to Bishop Charles K. Gilbert, president of the City Affairs Committee, resigned yesterday as a director and chairman of the executive committee of the reform group.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- Cornelius Pytsch, 49 year old, won his fight today to remain suburban Northlake. Gov. William G. Stratton notified Gov. Earl Warren of California that he would not extradite Mr. Pytsch, who is wanted in California for a 1936 crime.

Few people would challenge, I believe, the proposition that the unpegging of federal securities, following the accord of March, 1951, between the Treasury and the Federal Reserve System, and subsequent gradual stiffening in interest rates, were necessary and constructive steps toward disinflation.

Thirty-four national and local Jewish organizations yesterday urged the early ratification by the United States of the United Nations Genocide Convention. The action came as a result of the Senate Judiciary Committee's adoption on Thursday of a resolution proposing a constitutional amendment to limit the President's treaty-making power.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 5 -- Fred A. Swindell, domestic sales manager of the Westclox division. General Time Corporation, La Salle, Ill., said here today that wholesale jewelry sales appeared to be declining and retail sales increasing.

GLENWOOD LANDING, L. I., June 5 -- The election scheduled for tomorrow to decide if the Glenwood Landing, Sea Cliff and Glen Head school districts should merge, was canceled today by the State Department of Education. Court action brought by William D. Anderson, president of the Glenwood Board of Education, made the cancellation mandatory.

Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain, addressing 1,000 of his supervisory officers in the Hunter College auditorium yesterday, told them to be courteous and careful in using their new powers to issue summonses for violations of the Sanitary and Administrative Codes.

TEL, AVIV, Israel, June 5 -- The gap of $200,000,000 in the Israeli balance of trade will be reduced to $80,000,000 by 1957 and eliminated entirely in the following two or three years, in the opinion of Hillel Dan, manager of the Government's reparations corporation.

BAYONNE, N. J., June 5 -- Two men held up the clerk of a travel agency here this afternoon and escaped with $3,000 he was bringing from a bank, but they overlooked $7,000 more in their haste to escape.
After thirty-seven years of service under five flags, the 8.010-gross-ton liner Safina-E-Murad is ending her career on the seven seas in a scrap yard at Karachi, Pakistan.

BUENOS AIRES, June 5 -- Removal of all files from the 212 Socialist party headquarters was ordered today by party leaders in anticipation of a Government move to take them over. They ordered that all important files and historical documents be removed to private homes for safe keeping.
Showers and thunderstorms this afternoon or evening were expected to end the heat wave that sent New York temperatures yesterday up to 87.1 degrees, the highest point so far this year.

The troops that embarked for Europe yesterday were different, waterfront observes agreed as they watched a transport move into midstream. Their gay manner contrasted with the somber overtones that have characterized other troop movements in the port.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today asked American tourists not to bring in "fascinating" plants and plant materials from foreign lands lest they add to this country's insect and plant disease problems.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 5 (AP) -- Germany is making a pronounced bid for the Brazilian motor vehicle market, a study just released by the Finance Ministry shows.

LONDON, June 5 -- The Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth took note today, at their third meeting, of the latest developments in the Korean armistice talks, which have been described both here and in Washington as encouraging.

The suggestion that this country should maintain a free hand in foreign affairs was viewed last night as akin to the "sterile concept" of co-existence put forward by the Communists and the "obsolete and always disastrous formula of 'spheres of influence.'"
TOULOUSE, France, June 5 (AP) -- Amid all her other troubles, at home and abroad, France today found herself engaged in a political dispute with Andorra.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 5 -- In a speech to an audience of Dutchmen and Americans, Johan W. Beyen, Netherlands Co-Minister of Foreign Affairs, hit out tonight at the growth of a "new America" with people who "were often guided by prices rather than values."

Commodity prices closed mostly lower on light volume yesterday on the New York exchanges on prospects of peace in Korea. Sugar, potatoes, rubber, tin, lead, zinc and copper were lower; coffee higher, and cottonseed oil, soybean oil, wool, cocoa and hides mixed.
With another travel season in full swing and liners of many flags assigned to the busy trans-Atlantic routes, one-third of this country's passenger tonnage is lying idle in dead storage.

Relations between the United States and other members of the Pan American Union are deteriorating as nationalism and communism rise in the South American republics, Dr. Jose R. Chiriboga, Ambassador of Ecuador to the United States, said yesterday.
TOKYO, Saturday, June 6 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1.637 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korean time.
CHICAGO, June 5 (AP) -- Wayne Terwilliger's grand-slam home run in the second inning got the Senators off to a driving start tonight and they eased to an 8-4 victory over the White Sox.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, head of the Air Force's Strategic Air Command, was reported today as believing that a cut of five of the projected fifty-seven wings of his long-range bombing organization would be an "extension of the calculated risk" to a point no longer acceptable in view of the security of the United States and its Allies.

Common-sense measures that may ameliorate, postpone and even prevent high blood pressure and coronary heart disease, the two major killers of mankind, were outlined yesterday at the closing sessions of the 102d annual meeting of the American Medical Association at the Commodore Hotel.

LONDON, June 5 -- As Queen Elizabeth took leave today of the envoys, princes and deputations that came to London for her Coronation, Westminster Abbey was reopened so the public could view the brilliant setting of the coronation. It had been closed since Jan. 1 to be converted into the vast theatre for last Tuesday's ceremony.

READING, Pa., June 5 (UP) -- Betsy Rawls, Spartansburg, S. C., breaking par for the second straight day, fired a 71 today to take a nine-stroke lead at the half-way mark in the women's eastern open golf tournament with a total of 139.
MILWAUKEE, June 5 (AP) -- In Milwaukee where, the story goes, most of the best beers are brewed, the citizenry is getting a chance to test the rest.

Carl Dudley, president of the Vistarama Corporation, which has introduced a new anamorphic type of wide-screen photography and projection, will arrive here Monday to hold demonstrations of the Vistarama device.

TAIPEI, Formosa, June 5 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, newly designated chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today the United States would continue to support and build up Chinese Nationalist forces even if an armistice is reached in Korea.

BOSTON, June 5 -- New England has $60,000,000 worth of business for the catching in the offshore fishing banks, but the industry was warned today that more vigorous marketing was needed to continue realizing on this bonanza.

A seven-man field that includes Lew Olive of Army, recent winner of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America mile championship, will meet in the eight-furlong race at the annual Spring games of the New York Athletic Club at Travers Island in Pelham Manor, N. Y., today.

DORTMUND, Germany, June 5 (AP) -- Five leading members of a neo-Nazi underground group, "Movement Reich," were sentenced to prison terms ranging from six to fourteen months by a West German criminal court here today.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 5 -- Government forces killed 100 Mau Mau terrorists and captured fifty-four during the last seven days, it was announced today. In addition, the killing of six terrorists was listed in tonight's report.

The Court of Appeals, highest judicial tribunal in the state, upheld yesterday the constitutionality of Governor Dewey's fiscal program for New York City in a six-to-one decision handed down in Albany.

PITTSBURGH, June 5 (AP) -Outfielder Gus Bell, a former Pirate turned on his old team-mates with a vengeance tonight as he hammered two home runs and a double to lead the Redlegs to a 7-4 victory over Pittsburgh.

The Admiral Corporation expects "the biggest and best year in its history." Ross D. Siragusa, president, told a meeting of Eastern distributors at the Plaza Hotel yesterday. He said the company looks ahead to production and sale of over 1,000,000 television receivers before the year is ended.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 5 (AP) -- More than 40,000 pounds of Fourth of July fireworks exploded with horrible fury today, smashing a city block. The police said at least four were killed and seventy-five injured.

TRENTON, June 5 -- An official report prepared at the direction of Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons to justify his dismissal of Nelson F. Stamler was designed to give a completely false picture of the latter's work in Bergen County, a New Jersey state policeman testified today.

There has been a marked reduction over the winter in beach pollution here, but it is not yet sufficient to add any new names to last year's list of beaches approved for bathing, Jerome Trichter, assistant commissioner of the Department of Health, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Representative Donald L. Jackson, Republican of California, renewed today a demand that Methodist Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam appear before the House Un-American Activities Committee and clear up the question whether he was a member or sponsor of Communist-front organizations.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Michael J. McDermott, new Ambassador to El Salvavador, received a "good luck" and an autographed photograph today from President Eisenhower.

Jule Styne, who signed the sister team of Betty and Jane Kean about two months ago with the idea of placing them in a Broadway musical, has come up with the vehicle deemed suitable for their especial talents. It is a musical by Anita Loos called "The Great Caress," based on a soon-to-be-published book of the same name by an Italian artist, Federico Palavacini.

With admiralty law suits keeping pace with the post-war growth of the world merchant fleet, judges and lawyers are finding increasing use for a nautical museum established last year in the United States Courthouse, Foley Square.

FAIRFORD, England, June 5 (AP) -- Three United States B-47 stratojets, designed to carry the atom bomb, today bettered the existing record of 5 hours and 38 minutes for a flight from the United States to Britain. Two made the breakfast-to-lunch crossing in 5 hours and 36 minutes; the other in 5 hours and 37 minutes.

Plans for extensive alterations, including installation of an elevator, have been announced in connection with the sale of the five-story brick front residence at 12 East Sixty-eighth Street by A. Lilue to Lester Woods for occupancy.

PHILADELPHIA, Saturday, June 6 -- Two tankers were ablaze off Reedy Point early this morning after colliding in the Delaware River near the east entrance of the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal. The Coast Guard here said about forty survivors had been picked up by an unidentified tug.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Despite the wearing of crimson hats and bright-colored shirts, hunters keep on shooting one another with deplorable regularity. As a solution to the problem, Nathan Prupis of Seattle patented this week a sportsman's hat with a red blinker light in the dome.

MOSCOW, June 5 (UP) -- The Ukrainian Pravda, official Government organ of The Ukraine, apologized in a front page editorial today for its own "smear" attack on the Ukranian Health Ministry last February.

Edward Cuneo of 104-21 Sixty-eighth Drive, Forest Hills, Queens, and Silas Simmons of 31-30 102d Street, Corona, told the police yesterday that they had been robbed at gunpoint of a $7,587 payroll at Sixty-sixth Avenue and 102d Street, Rego Park, yesterday morning.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 5 -- Dick Emery, Princeton's sophomore pitching ace, today chose an important occasion to account for his best performance of the season. The 185-pounder, who hails from Upper Montclair, N. J., just missed a no-hitter as he gained a 4-0 triumph over Harvard in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game at Yale Field.
PITTSBURGH, June 5 (AP) -President Warren C. Giles of the National League ordered the Pirates today to keep Greenberg Gardens intact for the balance of the 1953 baseball season.

COMPTON, Calif., June 5 (AP) -- Wes Santee of Kansas bettered the American mile record with a time of 4:02.4 in defeating an international field and Southern California's Parry O'Brien again clipped the world shot-put mark with a toss of 59 feet 2 3/8 inches in the Compton invitation track and field meet tonight.

CLEVELAND, June 5 -- America will stand in mortal danger if it follows the advice of the isolationists because there is no effective military defense against mass air attacks, Chester Bowles, former United States Ambassador to India, declared here today at the National Conference of Social Work.
ESSEX FELLS, N. J., June 5 -- The defending champion, Stanley Calder of Montclair, and most of the favorites gained the quarter-finals of the New Jersey amateur golf championship today.

CHICAGO, June 5 (UP) -- Army worms invaded two more states today as scientists of the United States Department of Agriculture rushed experiments on a poison which they hoped would wipe out the crop-devouring insects.

The four-story apartment house accommodating twenty families at 1758 Sterling Place in Brooklyn has been sold by Abraham and Sarah Entlich to Abraham and Ida Sterson. Simon J. Boss was the broker and the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company insured title.

Why such a striking difference of opinion as to the efficiency of our schools? On the one hand the "top brass" of the educational system do not weary of calling attention to the great progress and general excellence of the product of the local classrooms.

Waterfront workers, some of whose leaders plan a mass demonstration on Monday to protest the State Crime Commission's report to Governor Dewey, now seem to be disturbed and confused. It is apparent that the irresponsible leaders pushing the idea of a demonstration as the Governor opens hearings on the commission's report will be unable to bring out on the picket lines the 25,000 workers they claim to control.

Safeway Stores, Inc., one of the country's leading super market chains, doubled net profit on its common stock in the first twenty weeks of this year, Milton L. Selby, secretary and treasurer of the company, announced yesterday.

By the end of this year practically all cotton and wool knitted fabric for children's and women's outerwear and men's sportswear will be fully washable, it was predicted yesterday by Harry Goldman, president of the Allen Knitting Mills, Inc.

Allan Gordon Foster, convicted of aiding Serge M. Rubinstein, international financier, to evade military service, was deported yesterday aboard the Italia of the Home Lines. He is a native of Edinburgh, Scotland.

LONDON, June 5 -- The music of the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II will be sung in the United States by the choir of Saint Paul's Cathedral, which will open a two-month, United States tour Sept. 30 at the New York cathedral (St. John the Divine).

ROME, June 5 -- The election campaign came to an end late tonight and the principal exponents of the three groups of parties vying for victory in the voting Sunday and Monday chose Rome as the forum from which to address their last appeals to the electorate.

Speedometer inaccuracies, often unknown to motorists, that could lead to accidents and infractions of speed laws, were reported yesterday by the United States Bureau of Public Roads. In two cases out of three, speedometers on the cars tested were inaccurate, one way or the other.
Boys High of Brooklyn and DeWitt Clinton of the Bronx yesterday gained the last round in the Public Schools Athletic League city baseball championship with victories in the semi-finals.

Everest has been conquered. The world has been won. Man stands astride the colossus as victor. The last outpost of ice and stone that has for years exerted its magnetic hold over the minds of men has been climbed. Truly, man is now master of this earth if not yet of himself.

Long ago we absolved ourselves in America from all allegiance to the British Crown, but our fathers who brought forth on this continent a new nation neither absolved themselves nor the new nation from allegiance to the moral values of which the British Crown is a symbol to the British people.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Republic Carloading and Distributing Company, Inc., of New York City, a freight forwarder, today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to broaden its authorized operations so that it may arrange for the transportation of all types of commodities between all points in the United States.

CAIRO, June 5 -- Political and military leaders of the Arab states will meet in Cairo probably late this month to bring into being the Arab collective security pact, to which John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, gavs implied encouragement following his recent tour of the Middle East and South Asia.

Authors will read from their own poems, short stories, novels and plays in a new recorded radio program, "Literary Greats," to be presented weekly by the A. B. C. network beginning Tuesday from 8:45 to 9 P. M. Dylan Thomas, Archibald MacLeish and Tennessee Williams will read from their poetry works on the initial broadcast.

TOKYO, Saturday, June 6 -- United Nations and Communist delegates met for nineteen minutes at Panmunjom today amid a belief widely expressed here that a quick agreement now might result for an armistice in the three-year-old war. The delegates then scheduled a new session for 11 A. M. tomorrow [10 P. M. Saturday, Eastern daylight time].
The cotton futures market here was moderately active yesterday and closed steady, up 12 to 17 points from the final prices on Thursday.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- Judge Walter J. LaBuy in Federal District Court today allowed a motion by a General Motors Corporation attorney in the du Pont anti-trust trial for a summons to be issued to Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, directing the Cabinet member to appear in court to testify next Thursday.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -Under Secretary of Agriculture True D. Morse said today the Eisenhower Administration believes the government should ultimately get out of the grain storage business. But, he said, it has no intention now of disposing of its 545,000,000-bushel storage facilities.

The refusal of the National Association of Manufacturers and the Chamber of Commerce of the United States to support the Administration's proposal for a six-month extension of the excess-profits tax betrays disappointing short-sightedness and lack of statesmanship on the part of these two leading business organizations.

ALTHOUGH a lot of anglers will move north for their fishing during the next two months, but just to prove that fishermen refuse to be guided by thermometers, a lot of them will go to the very deep south for the first International Marlin and Sailfish Tournament, to be held in Panama from July 4 to Aug. 4.

LONDON, June 5 -- The development of a new and more sensitive underwater television camera in Britain may solve the perplexing problem of the "phantom layer" or deep scattering zone that has long mystified those who explore the depth of the sea with echo sounders.

Trying to "put the Dead Letter Office out of business," Acting Postmaster Harold Riegelman has enlisted the support of public and parochial high schools in his drive to educate the public in properly addressing mail. Last year, he said, it cost $71,000 to handle dead letters.

TRENTON, June 5 -- The New Jersey Democratic State Committee decided tonight to let the state Democratic organization absorb the National Democratic Club, which was formed to fight the political rule of former Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to create a Small Business Administration to help concerns that are independently owned and operated and are not dominant in their field.

Employes of 900 concerns in the Empire State Building, 350 Fifth Avenue, will start a week-long contribution to the Red Cross blood bank on Monday, the New York chapter headquarters at 315 Lexington Avenue announced yesterday.

City officials interested in smoke control made a tour yesterday of the electric generating station of the Consolidated Edison Company under construction at Twentieth Avenue and the East River in Astoria, Queens.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 5 -- The women's international team match for the Golf Illustrated Trophy among Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey was won by Long Island over the west course of the Winged Foot Club course today.
MEXICO CITY, June 5 -- There were blue skies over northwest and central Mexico again today, but no one was happy about it.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., June 5 -- Vacationers arriving tonight for a visit to the famous scenic attractions here found themselves in the midst of a simulated disaster.

The Public Affairs Committee of the Rockaways announced yesterday that the Jewish Community Center of the Rockaways had canceled a scheduled appearance of Morris Carnovsky, character actor, because of his alleged affiliation with Communist organizations.

MANCHESTER, England, June 5 (AP) -- Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, was beaten in the semi-final of women's singles in the Northern Lawn Tennis tournament today by Helen Fletcher of Great Britain, 10 -- 8, 6 -- 2.

WASHINGTON June 5 (AP) -Private power companies were accused today by Clyde T. Ellis, executive manager of the National Rural Electric Cooperation Association, of leading a fight to eliminate the Southwestern Power Administration's continuing fund.

Religious services will be held in eleven national parks this summer, starting tomorrow in Yellowstone Park, Wyo., where a pilot project was conducted last year. The services will be under the auspices of the Joint Department of Evangelism of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

For some years past one might have read the bulletins of the University of the South at Sewanee, Tenn., without learning that either the university or its related Theological School discriminated against Negro applicants for admission. Indeed, the stated goal of a "human society founded on the Brotherhood of Man and the Fatherhood of God" would seem to rule out this kind of discrimination.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, publicly called upon the State Department today to keep Frank Coe, an American citizen who formerly was secretary of the International Monetary Fund, from leaving the United States.

Aluminum Industries, Inc. of Cincinnati, has announced the election of Randolph J. Roshirt as vice president. He will be responsible for integrating the production and sales operations of the company, in addition to being in charge of new product development.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 5 -- The United Fruit Company's Pacific zone plantations were threatened with a complete work stoppage Monday when Communist-led strikers issued an ultimatum today.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation attempted to charge automobile-building costs at Willow Run, Mich., to the United States Air Force under an airplane contract, a Senate Armed Services subcommittee was told today.

Large areas of exposed wood are designed for comfort in the new "400 collection" by the Valley Upholstery Corporation. The collection is made up of about sixty new sofas, chairs and sectional units, all of which can be adapted to produce about 400 different styles. The pieces were designed by Norman Fox MacGregor and Peter Schladermundt.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The possibility of an early truce in Korea cast new doubt today on prospects for favorable Congressional action on President Eisenhower's request for a six-month extension of the excess profits tax.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 5 (AP) -- Knight Star, one of the top 2-year-old pacers of 1952, made his debut as a 3-year-old tonight and scored an impressive victory at Roosevelt Raceway.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 5 -- Although "The French Line" has been shooting for two weeks, it was not until today that R. K. O. officially recognized its existence with the announcement that Gilbert Roland had been signed for the romantic lead opposite Jane Russell. He will portray a night club singer and dancer and will effect a French accent in romancing a wealthy Texas beauty who travels incognito in pursuit of a mate.

Another week of substantial underwriting commitments is looming for the investment banking fraternity. The biggest transaction will be the offering of $150,000,000 of General Motors Acceptance Corporation short-term debentures slated for Thursday, with a Morgan Stanley Co. syndicate managing the underwriting.

William Perl, 34-year-old aerodynamics expert, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan to a five-year prison term for perjury. Perl was convicted of lying to a Federal grand jury investigating espionage when he denied having known Julius Rosenberg and Morton Sobell, convicted atom spies.

The mulberry tree is in full fruitage again and there is a flurry of excitement. But that is caused by birds, hungry themselves, in search of food for their young. The mulberry tree is their quick-lunch counter.

Joseph P. Ryan, indicted president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., finally got around yesterday to asking leaders of the threatened pier strike on Monday to call off their demonstration, but he was rebuffed for his pains.

RENO, Nev., June 5 -- Walter Van Tilburg Clark, author of "The Ox Bow Incident" and other best sellers, has resigned as lecturer in English at the University of Nevada to protest "autocratic administration" of the institution.

TAMPA, Fla., June 5 -- Benjamin Fine, education editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, received the honorary degree of Doctor of Science here today at the twentieth commencement exercises of the University of Tampa.

A radical approach toward combating the problem of juvenile delinquency in Children's Court was disclosed last night by Justice Justine Wise Polier of the Domestic Relations Court, in the absence of Chief Justice John Warren Hill, who was ill.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP) -- The Sigma Delta Chi journalism fraternity called on Congressional leaders today to help put an end to "secret Government meetings."

EPSOM, England, June 5 (AP) -- Aureole, a speedy chestnut colt owned by Queen Elizabeth II, and Sir Victor Sassoon's Pinza, a brown colt to be ridden by the king of jockeys, Sir Gordon Richards, will go to the post tomorrow co-favorites in the Epsom Derby.

VIENNA, June 5 -- The devaluation of Czechoslovak currency and the abolition of rationing are not popular with the Czech people, including some Communists, according to admissions by the Prague press and radio.

LONDON, June 5 -- General of the Army George C. Marshall, who is obviously troubled by the recent signs of dissension between Britain and the United States, attempted today to correct some of the things that Britons have been thinking about Americans.

HOUSTON, June 5 -- A purchasing contract which will ultimately cover $150,000,000 of hydrocarbon products has been announced here by officials of the Pacific Northwest Pipe Line Corporation and the Specialty Gas Products Company of San Francisco.

A master plan designed to keep the economy of this country in balance by effective curbs on inflation as well as deflation is being drafted by the Administration, according to Washington reports, at the request of the White House.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A tale of a mongrel dog whose beach-combings along the shores of the Patuxent River turned up bales of Department of Justice letters was told today to a House of Representatives Judiciary subcommittee.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 5 -Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, declared in the commencement address at the United States Naval Academy today that this country could not possibly pursue a lone course in world affairs.

CLEVELAND, June 5 (AP) -Pinch-hitter Hank Majeski's fly with the bases filled and none\out in the tenth inning gave the Indians a 3-2 victory over the Athletics tonight. Larry Doby, who opened with a walk against Carl Scheib, scored the winning run.

VERY early in the morning, nine years ago today, Allied troops began to land in Normandy. Another nine years from now, when more of the personal records are in, someone may write a book about that occasion and the campaigns across France and into Germany that followed, with a chapter on each of the outstanding commanders, and call it "Eisenhower and His Generals."

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, June 5 (AP) -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, expressing surprise at controversy over the Administration's military budget cut, said tonight that "funds available to the Air Force are ample to continue a rapid build-up in its effective strength."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 5 -- If United States tin production continues at the rate established during the first three months of this year, production there in 1953 will be the highest since World War II. The projected output of 45,000 tons is double that of last year, the International Tin Study Group reported here today.

PARIS, June 5 -- An angry statement was issued today by the Grand Rabbi of France, Jacob Kaplan, doubting the sincerity of French Roman Catholic leaders who had promised to do everything possible to recover Robert and Gerald Finaly, two Jewish war orphans.
Willie Pep did an "Old Master's" job on Pat Marcune of Coney Island in the main bout scheduled for ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

A period of relatively narrow price movements for natural rubber was forecast by manufacturers at the recent Copenhagen International Rubber Study Group, it was reported yesterday by the Natural Rubber Bureau, a Washington organization representing southeastern Asia growers.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Average primary market prices were unchanged in the week ended on Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, June 5 (UP) -- Edmond P. Hillary, Auckland beekeeper who scaled Mount Everest, will return to the Himalayas next year as the leader of a New Zealand mountain-climbing expedition, the New Zealand Alpine Club announced today.

Thirty-five years ago the people of what is now the Georgian "republic" of the Soviet Union declared the existence of a truly independent republic of Georgia. By this act they sought to regain the independence which they had lost in the eighteenth century when a Georgian King asked the Russian Czar's protection, a step which led to Russian annexation of the tiny state a few decades later.

SEWANEE, Tenn., June 5 -- Officials of the University of the South disclosed today that a Negro clergyman of the Protestant Episcopal Church had applied for admission to the five-week graduate study class of the School of Theology which begins on July 29. Only yesterday the university officials were instructed by resolution of the trustees to disregard racial considerations in connection with applications for admission.
When an American girl marries today, the father seldom provides a dowry. That duty or privilege, it seems, has been taken over by the Government of the United States.

CAMDEN, N. J., June 5 -- A flight engineer was killed and his flying partner was injured seriously today when their single-engined helicopter went out of control at an altitude of 7,000 feet and crashed on a near-by farm. The cause of the accident is undetermined. Both men bailed out of the plane, but the dead man apparently never cleared it.

Three youthful Federal narcotic agents found 150 pounds of marijuana yesterday in an automobile parked in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, about a mile from Brooklyn Police Headquarters. In the retail market the cache would be worth $120,000.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, predicted today that Britain would force the United States to consent to the admission of Communist China as a member of the United Nations.

This month, at groups of the Jewish Association for Neighborhood Centers, discussion programs among husbands and wives on every day problems of family living are drawing to a close. The discussions are part of a cooperative program of group family counseling carried on by the association and the Jewish Family Service, aimed at keeping normal families happy rather than trying to patch up those already in deep difficulties.

HONG KONG, June 5 (AP) -- Three big rivers in China's Kwangtung Province are out of their banks and reports from the Communist mainland indicate the flood-famine crisis in South China may be the worst since 1947.
So the home cook will know definitely what she buys, the American Spice Trade Association is starting an industry-wide drive to standardize the labeling terms for some fifty major spices.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- President Eisenhower, a devotee of the golf ball, ended a day largely devoted to sports matters tonight by tossing out the first ball at the annual baseball game between Republican and Democratic members of Congress. The sixth annual meeting of the teams attracted a crowd that packed the grandstands of Griffith Stadium, creating a large "purse" for The Washington Star's Children's Camp Fund.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 (UP) -Del Crandall, shrugging off the fact that Jack Dittmer had been passed intentionally to get at him, singled past third in the eleventh inning tonight to score Jim Pendleton, with the winning run as the Braves defeated the Phillies, 3 -- 2, to remain in first place in the National League.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- James P. McAluney, a Philadelphia shipping official, told Senators investigating waterfront corruption today that he had lied to them a month ago.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, the Senate Republican leader, declined today with seeming finality to attempt to accommodate his views on Korea and on the United Nations generally to those of the Eisenhower Administration.

The Cubs brought their vaunted 1-2 punch -- Hank Sauer and the newly acquired Ralph Kiner -- to the Polo Grounds last night but even the most sensitive ears in a gathering of 14,515 could scarcely detect a rumble from this quarter.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The White House said today that President Eisenhower was following the Korean truce talks "very closely." Beyond that, official spokesmen would not go.

SCARBOROUGH, N. Y., June 5 -- The twenty-ninth annual field day of the Bond Club of New York was staged here today on the twin golf courses, the outdoor swimming pool and the tennis courts and other recreational facilities of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club.
MOSCOW, Saturday, June 6 -- Pravda reported today that both sides taking part in the truce negotiations in Korea were "extremely close" to signature of an armistice agreement.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 5 -- It is believed in Canberra that in the course of the Prime Ministers' discussions in London Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill will endeavor to obtain from Australia and New Zealand more help in safeguarding British Commonwealth communications and interests in Southeast Asia, particularly in Malaya and in the Indian Ocean.

Dr. Theodor Reik has written a sequel to his "The Secret Self," and Farrar, Straus Young will issue it in October. Entitled "The Haunting Melody: Psychoanalytic Experiences in Life and Music," the volume presents many new anecdotes about Brahms, Gustav Mahler and Johann Strauss, and it includes two of Freud's letters concerning Offenbach and Mahler that have never before been published.

ST. LOUIS, June 5 -- Eight in a row, eighteen out the the last twenty-two and an over-all 31 -- 11 was the record of the Yankees after they downed the Browns, 5 -- 0, at Busch Stadium tonight. Five and a half lengths ahead of the runner-up Indians, the champions are setting the strongest pace (.738) in Casey Stengel's Bronx regime.
PARIS, June 5 -- Symbolism being in the ascendant this week, it has provided a striking and illuminating contrast for the student of politics.

Greentree Stable's One Hitter got the most attention at the mutuel windows, but Cockfield Stable's Arcave got most of the purse money in the $7,500 added handicap that headed yesterday's program at Belmont Park.

ROME, June 5 -- Tonight Italy's electoral campaign ended with two great meetings -- one addressed by the head of the Government, Premier Alcide De Gasperi, the other by the Communist leader, Palmiro Togliatti. Both were ending a fight that took them up and down the length of the peninsula.

A concentrated early attack on Joe Presko and stalwart pitching by Joe Black in relief of Preacher Roe carried the Dodgers to a 5-4 victory over the Cardinals last night before 28,976 paying spectators. The largest crowd of the season at Ebbets Field. However, the second-place Brooks remained a half-game behind the league-leading Braves, who also won.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 5 -- William Tatum (Big Bill) Tilden 2d, former world tennis champion, died late today, apparently of a heart attack, in his Hollywood apartment. He was 60 years old.

MONTREAL, June 5 (AP) -- Pro golfers of the United States broke even with their Canadian counterparts today in three four-ball, best-ball matches which marked the opening of a three-day team match. Each team finished with 4 1/2 points.

In his last major theoretical work, "Economic Problems of Socialism," Joseph Stalin suggested that a major goal of Soviet development must be the elimination of monetary relationships between city and country. What is required, he declared, is a system of "product exchange" in which farmers will eventually be paid for their produce through a barter exchange against manufactured commodities.
BOSTON, June 5 -- Looking tired and drawn, Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, arrived here tonight at 11:40 o'clock at the Logan International Airport after a seventeen-hour flight from London.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Officials here were reluctant to comment tonight on President Rhee's counter-proposal. The statement was being studied carefully and there were indications that nothing would be said pending a full evaluation of the situation.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations said today it would spend a million dollars on an expanded public relations program. Details were not announced except that radio and television would be the principal media. The American Federation of Labor's radio and television programs cost about $700,000 a year.

PARIS, June 5 (UP) -- Heavily favored Harvie Ward of Atlanta was eliminated from the French amateur golf championship today by a 39-year-old United Stages Air Force major who entered the tournament for a lark.

RYE, N. Y., June 5 -- Frank D. Ross of Hartford who won his first major tournament twenty-seven years ago, became the United States Senior Golf Association champion today after scoring one of the low rounds of his career at the Apawamis Club.

A $4,700-a-year accountant in the City Controller's office, who had acquired properties here and upstate valued at almost $75,000, was arrested yesterday with a second accountant in an alleged $600 shakedown of a Columbus Avenue tavern owner.
Trading Also Narrows -- Price Index Up 0.66 as 407 Issues Advance and 393 Fall
The following is a round-up of household hints that may be of interest to the homemaker.

ALBANY, June 5 -- The State Court of Appeals ruled today that landlords, not tenants, were liable for municipal sewer rent charges in cases in which no provision for the charges was made in the lease.

Sears, Roebuck Co., Chicago, spent 81.3 per cent of its total ad budget, or $34,009,500 for newspaper space last year, according to a story in today's issue of Editor Publisher, trade publication. The figure is 7.7 per cent more than that expended for this purpose in 1951.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- Grain futures in all pits, as well as soy beans, moved sharply lower today in the early trade, then there was free selling. Later, for a while, there was good buying and much of the early declines was recovered. but the demand failed to follow the upturns and the market turned weak again. There was a disposition to even up over the week-end in view of the Korean truce outlook.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- Sixteen stock issues will be admitted to unlisted trading privileges at the opening of business Monday on the Midwest Stock Exchange. All will come under the exchange's system of dual trading, covering issues which also are traded on one or the other of the big eastern exchanges.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Republican leaders have agreed to put off any revision of the Taft-Hartley Law until next year.

A Negro family, evicted yesterday from its apartment in Knickerbocker Village, moved in with a family of white friends in the same development and announced it was staying "until a decent solution is reached."

WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP)--Robert W. Dudley, witness before a grand jury investigating Reconstruction Finance Corporation "scandals" in 1951, was acquitted of perjury tonight after a dramatic courtroom speech by his lawyer.

Although the corporate bond market was irregular in selective trading yesterday, United States Government bonds were again in some demand. Treasury securities dealers reported a variety of buyers as gains extended to half a point.

Five properties in Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens and Nassau were sold at auction yesterday for a total of $101,500 at an auction in the McAlpin Hotel conducted by Stephen A. McDonald, vice president of Joseph P. Day, Inc.
AUSTIN, Tex., June 5 -- Gov. Allan Shivers tonight dispatched H. A. Beckwith, chairman of the Texas Board of Water Engineers, to help solve Laredo's water shortage.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, June 6 (AP) -- In furious sky battles over Northwest Korea yesterday, United States F-86 Sabre pilots shot down eight Red MIG's and crowned their thirty-second jet ace of the Korean war. The Sabre pilots reported also that they probably destroyed another MIG and damaged five more of the enemy jet fighters in low-level battles near the Manchurian frontier.

BONN, Germany, June 5 -- Samuel Reber, United States Deputy High Commissioner for Germany, called upon Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today with a cable message from President Eisenhower containing an assurance that no decisions concerning Germany would be taken at the forthcoming Bermuda conference of the President, Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill and the French Premier without full consultation with the Federal Chancellor.

PARIS, June 5 -- President Vincent Auriol today asked Foreign Minister Georges Bidault, leader of the Catholic Popular Republican party to try to form a Cabinet under the difficult circumstances growing from successive rejections by the National Assembly of the Independent party leader, Paul Reynaud, and the Radical, Pierre Mendes-France.

It has often been said that there is no magic in police work. There are, however, magicians in the Police Department. One of them took his second oath last night within a half year His first was as a police sergeant on Jan. 9; his second was as president of New York Ring No. 26, Inc., of the International Brotherhood of Magicians.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, June 6 -- In a last-ditch appeal to President Eisenhower, President Syngman Rhee of the Republic of Korea has asked either that a specific military defense pact be concluded between South Korea and the United States or that South Korean forces be allowed to continue the war against the Communists alone.

CHICAGO June 5 (AP) -- Country supplies ran in 25 per cent more hogs than the trade had prepared for today, and prices fell another 25 cents to $1 from Thursday's lower levels. Cattle and sheep were steady to weak. The new declines placed hops at their lowest levels in more than a week. Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 5 -- Drottningholm Palace with its seventeenth-century architecture, noble parks and great fountains newly restored and playing for the first time in more than 100 years, was the scene this afternoon of two of the most interesting events thus far of the Stockholm Music Festival.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 5 (UP) -- Thomas Aden Johnston, assistant chief of medical services at Lackland Air Force Base, was sent to jail today after the Government learned he lacked a medical degree.
Bexley, Ohio, borrowed $750,000 yesterday on an issue of school bonds due from 1954 to 1973. The bonds were sold to Halsey, Stuart Co. on a bid of 100.18 on 2 3/4's.

LONDON, June 5 -- The stock markets ended the week on a firm note with sentiment further strengthened by enhanced prospects of an early truce in Korea. Prices rose slightly in nearly all markets despite continued quiet trading.
With the score at one point each in the chess match between Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires, the players rested yesterday.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., June 5 (AP) -- The New Bedford Standard-Times said today a compromise had been reached in the three-year litigation over the $1,000,000 estate of Mrs. Mabel H. Green, daughter-in-law of Hetty Green, the eccentric financier of the Nineties.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The State Department disclosed today the lifting of three of the four trade and travel restrictions imposed against Czechoslovakia following the arrest and imprisonment of William N. Oatis.
ALBANY, June 5 (AP) -- The texts of the majority opinion of the Court of Appeals and the dissent by Judge Marvin R. Dye in the New York City Transit Authority

BERLIN, June 5 -- The Soviet Union took a new step today to de-emphasize the military side of its leadership in East Germany by replacing Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov with a little known lower-ranking officer as commander in chief.

A key witness in the Board of Higher Education's trial of Nat Holman and Harry (Bobby) Sand, suspended coach and assistant coach of basketball at City College, testified yesterday that Mr. Sand had been aware of financial arrangements for a proposed South American tour by the 1949-50 championship team that were contrary to the rules governing amateur athletes.

MOSCOW, June 6 -- Soviet trade unions are now being called upon more vigorously to defend and protect the rights of the workers against abuses by the managers of Soviet factories, mines and other economic enterprises.

THE televising of the Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II was a magnificent achievement by the British Broadcasting Corporation. The corporation's impeccable coverage even survived the tasteless embellishments and outrageous behavior of some of the American networks. Tuesday was British television's day, not America's.

EPSOM, England, June 6 (AP) -- Richards' victory aboard Pinza was his first Derby triumph in thirty-three years of racing. His mount out-distanced the royal chestnut in the last two furlongs for his 4,670th success.

THE British wild rose a national emblem and reputed source of the dynastic battles between Lancastrians and Yorkists, has again become the subject of sectarian strife. This time the struggle lies between British botanists who are now engaged on a national wild rose survey in an attempt to settle their highly technical arguments.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 6 -- Fifty-three persons, including a squadron leader of the Royal Thai Air Force, three army men, a navy lieutenant commander and fourteen noncommissioned naval officers are on trial here on treason charges arising from an alleged plot to overthrow Field Marshal Pibul Songgram's Government and establish a "people's republic of Thailand."

AS soon as your DC-3 has left Cairo and is set on its course eastward via the long loop around Israel, the Egyptian merchant in the seat beside you undoes his seat belt and feels free to open up to a stranger. He offers you a cigarette and begins a conversation that, thanks to the noise of the plane engine, he can confine to the two of you.

Horticulturist, Arnold Arboretum PRUNING hedges throughout the spring and summer can be a time - consuming and disagreeable task. Privet and many other shrubs commonly used for hedges require frequent trimming during the growing season in order to maintain a good appearance. However, the intelligent but lazy man can, if he wishes, select some plants which need practically no trimming and still will look neat year after year.

MONTREAL, June 6 (AP) -- The United States' professional golfers scored 12 1/2 points to Canada's 5 1/2 in singles matches today to take an over-all lead of 17 to 10 in their team competition for the Hopkins International Trophy.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower declared the flood-stricken areas of Montana a major disaster area tonight, thus opening the way for the use of Federal disaster funds.

RAMEY was the son of a back-country preacher in an Arkansas hill town, a boy in his early teens who thought his father was just about the finest, wisest man who lived. Reverend Holvak, as Ramey's mother always called him, was a stern but kindly man with simple ideas of faith and virtue, a man who would stand up to anybody, man or devil, for his beliefs.

THE notion of universal catastrophe concerned men ages before the coming of science fiction. People and their prophets have long speculated about the sort of disaster that would destroy life on earth and perhaps the earth itself.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Manufacturing employment in Illinois declined 6,800 persons in the month ended April 15, following the usual seasonal pattern, preliminary estimates show. Last year the decline was 4,600 persons in the same month.

The chemical industry, young but already big, finds itself peculiarly affected by growing pains. It will complete $2,000,000,000 worth of new plant this year. Recent price rises encourage many of its leaders to believe that the new production now going on will be readily absorbed.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations listed today the names of ninety-six ships of British registry and sixty-two flying flags of other friendly countries as participants in trade with Red China from Dec. 29, 1952, to April 20 of this year.

IN his first new novel since "The People From Heaven" was published ten years ago, John Sanford makes a powerful bid for top billing in current fiction. Written in a muscular and economic prose, this is essentially the poetic, tragically intense tale of an army deserter, Steve Pierce, and his headlong odyssey toward self-disintegration, a flight nearly completed before the reader meets him.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee today ordered Harold E. Stassen, Director for Mutual Security, not to start any new aid programs until Congress had provided specific funds for them.

The conquest of Mount Everest shared the front page last week with the Coronation. And deservedly so. Since 1921 more than a dozen expeditions have gasped for breath, when they were not inhaling oxygen, and took steps as deliberate and slow as if they were marching in a funeral procession as they climbed the world's highest mountain.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- A citizens' committee reports that, of seventeen permits granted for educational television channels, one station already is on the air and another will begin operations soon.

AS the beach plum begins to shed its blossoms and the pungent scent of bayberry becomes stronger on the dunes, a familiar figure makes his annual appearance along the coastal beaches, that purist of the saltwater brotherhood -- the surfcaster.

In each of the last three years Alfred E. Lyon, 67-year-old chairman and chief executive officer of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., has had to tell his company's stockholders that "while our revenues reached a new record high" earnings were lower.

New England is concerned -- and rightly so -- with the recent action of the House of Representatives in reducing by 28 per cent the funds requested by the President for "Investigations of Resources" in the Department of the Interior Appropriations Bill, which covers funds for the operation of the Fish and Wildlife Service.

The jawbone of an ass, similar to the weapon that Samson used to slay the Philistines, according to Biblical lore, is one of the myriad relics from the Holy Land to arrive here for the forthcoming exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, "From the Land of the Bible."

The widespread but false notion that there is something shameful about mental illnesses is hampering our progress in combating these disorders, in the view of Walter Maynard, a Wall Street investment broker, for whom psychiatric research has become an abiding interest.

MILWAUKEE, June 6 (AP) -- Marquette won its first Central Collegiate Conference track championship in thirteen years tonight, rolling up 51 3-5 points to take the twenty-eighth running of the Midwest classic in its own stadium.

THERE is a tough, inbred clique among anglers that persists in spreading the twaddle that fly fishing is difficult to learn -- an approach designed to keep the number of fly fishermen at a minimum and our streams an exclusive retreat for the "elite."
RADIO, in a bid to hold its audience, would appear to be leaning more and more heavily on the one field in which it can give television a run for the money -- the presentation of good music

THOMAS HINDE is 25 years old. While earning his keep by tutoring privately, working as a circus hand and as a civil servant, he managed to write "Mr. Nicholas." At the risk of making a remark and not a critical statement, I must immediately point out that without doubt "Mr. Nicholas" is the best first novel to come in many a year from an English writer.

Figures are extremely important in the men's clothing industry, both for construction and production plans. The industry has established patterns to conform with the shape of the average man, but getting data to predict future trends is more difficult and must be repeated before every season.

CAPRI, Italy -- The beeootiful Isle of Capree is truly a mythical place, even aside from the classical background. What other place in the world has squeezed so much fame from about four miles by one mile of ground and a population of about 10,000? It is, in fact, nothing less than the most famous place in the world.

A team effort by scientists at Stanford University and the University of California School of Medicine, San Francisco, has yielded a new approach to the use of ACTH in the treatment of disease. In one phase of the study, Dr. Arthur Rinfret, Stanford biochemist, prepared a new hormone.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The use of Federal tariff and taxing powers as parts of a permanent defense mobilization base was advocated today by Henry H. Fowler, former head of the Office of Defense Mobilization.

THERE is something disarmingly modest about this rich, sprawling panorama of Hungarian-Jewish life in the middle of the last century. It starts with the flight of simple, sternly religious Sholem and his resourceful wife Malkah, protagonists of the novel's first half; it ends with the flight of their daughter Yiteleh and her fearless husband Sroleh around whom the latter chapters are centered.

England's international soccer team will be out to avenge a defeat of nearly three years ago when it meets a picked team of United States players at the Yankee Stadium today. The only other time the English met the United States was in the World Cup competition in Brazil in 1950 and the Americans won, 1 to 0.

RESIDENTS of Wisconsin are not strangers to the phenomenon of business playing the Medician role toward art. Since 1948 they have been treated to art exhibitions, art prizes and art promotion, courtesy of Gimbel Brothers, Milwaukee, or more specifically, courtesy of Charles Zadok, the store's executive head.

In a surprising shake-up in the Giant farm system, Owner Horace Stoneham announced yesterday that Freddy Fitzsimmons, one-time Giant pitching star and coach under Manager Leo Durocher since 1949, would finish the 1953 season as manager of the Minneapolis club.

MANCHESTER, England, June 6 -- Doris Hart, second ranking American player from Coral Gables, Fla., defeated Britain's vastly improved Helen Fletcher, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 1, 7 -- 5, in the final of the Northern Lawn Tennis Tournament today.

The New York Clearing House issued a critical analysis of the Federal Reserve System last week, the first such comprehensive study to be prepared in its century-long history. Issuance of the report, which the Clearing House itself described as "extraordinary," was taken as further evidence that today's events are providing the severest tests of monetary measures since the Federal Reserve System was established in 1913.

For the second day in a row, the temperature reached a new high for the year yesterday. It broke no other records, but was warm enough to make New Yorkers, who have felt they never had a spring in 1953, look with some hope to the prospect of at least having a summer.

SAFER and more enjoyable travel on the highways, a result of the adoption of a new hand signal code in this state on July 1, was forecast by Thomas W. Ryan, director of the New York Division of Safety. These conform with a simple rule of three: left turn, extend arm horizontally; stop, or slow down, extend arm downward; right turn, extend arm upward.

THE pines and the tall-grass country are calling now that summer is near -- and this timely handbook's purpose is to help beginners avoid some of the backaches and blisters of camping. You don't need to be in a national park or forest preserve to sample the joys of a night under the stars.

On May 29 THE NEW YORK TIMES reported the release of Stuart Denton Morris, British pacifist detained in Ellis Island for two weeks. This case is a typical and glaring example of the lack of coordination between the Departments of Justice and State in the administration of the McCarran Act resulting in serious damage to the prestige of the United States.
One hundred days ago this week Joseph Stalin suffered the massive stroke that robbed him first of consciousness, then of life.
TOKYO, Sunday, June 7 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,638, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korean time:

NANTUCKET ISLAND in 1834 was an exciting place for boys, but very dull for a spirited girl like Jeannie Ramsay. Her brothers could sail with their father on his whaler. The Lady Bess, or mingle with the seamen on the wharves: Jeannie must stay at home, stitching her sampler.

A GROUP exhibition of photographic work, partially representative of the broad body of contemporary amateur activity lying between the extremes of the documentary and the pictorial approaches, opened last week at the Little Gallery in the Hudson Park Branch of the New York Public Library at 10 Seventh Avenue South.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations met here on Thursday, but, by a previously announced decision, all news of the board's actions was withheld until Friday. The purpose of this was to avoid hobbling the annual golf party given by George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, for the labor news reporters.

A SUMMER Sunday used to connote the sound of a crank turning in an ice cream freezer. Later the dessert was served in a cut-glass bowl, smooth, full-flavored and well worth, the youngsters thought, the aching arms resulting from its manufacture.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Signs of weakness in the stock and bond markets early this week set off a ripple of anxiety, at least among the amateur viewers-with-alarm, but a check of the "pros" discloses no important basis for concern about the state of the economy.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UP) -- The Secretary of Defense, Charles E. Wilson, was reported today to be ready to tell Congress Monday that, despite the uproar over cuts he ordered, the Air Force budget for fiscal year 1954 still contained a little "fat."

A proclamation by President Eisenhower yesterday opened "Aid to Korea Week," from today to June 14, during which the American-Korean Foundation will start a nation-wide campaign for $5,000,000 in emergency help to the people of the Republic of Korea.

TO the current generation in tune with bop, video and 3-D movies and as cognizant of Douglas Fairbanks Sr. as they are of the Stutz Bearcat, a biography of the acrobatic actor who personified exuberant adventure and escape for their forebears (at popular prices) is a decided service.

FIVE applications of spray materials are the minimum required for a healthy crop of apples in any year. And a season that is wet, humid or otherwise abnormal in weather may mean any number up to twenty-two or more. Apple trees apparently hold the record in frequency of sprays, although peaches, plums, pears and even crabapples may require four or five applications.
PUSAN, Korea, June 6 -- Now that a truce in Korea appears to be drawing near, there is a vast difference in what the prisoners on opposite sides have to look forward to.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UP) -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, appointed a special subcommittee today to study why budget procedures set out by the armed forces unification law for the Defense Department had failed to function.

Many and searching are the questions with which, over ages, the Hebrew Bible has challenged those who think sensitively about life. At the very beginning of its story Cain raises the question of personal social responsibility by cravenly asking, "Am I my brother's keeper?"

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UP) -- The Four Continent Book Corporation, registered distributors in this country of Russian and other foreign Communist publications, did more than $2,000,000 in business in the last five years.

The new headquarters of the Library for the Blind at the Avenue of the Americas and Spring Street, which was completed recently by the city at a cost of $425,000, will open on Thursday. The library will be dedicated on Wednesday.

New York City was the undisputed medical center of the world last week. An estimated 18,000 physicians from all parts of the nation and the world and 24,000 resident physicians, internes, nurses, medical technicians, medical students and guests gathered at the 102d annual meeting of the American Medical Association.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., June 6 -- The 162d anniversary of the birth of John Howard Payne, author of "Home, Sweet Home," will be celebrated on Tuesday afternoon at the cottage that faces East Hampton's Village Green.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 6 -- One of the ironies of our times is the fact that as the Korean war at last appears to be drawing to a close, Americans -- or at least their Senators -- seem to be more concerned about one of the probable by-products of an armistice than they are about the actual terms under which the war is to be stopped.

A review of the work done by City College's Community Service Division with youngsters will be televised tomorrow evening as the last of four programs on the role of New York's city colleges in the community. The telecast will be presented from 7:30 to 8:00 o'clock over WABD, Channel 5.

WILMOT RAGSDALE, reviewing "No Stone Unturned," by Ian Hamilton, about the stealing of The Stone of Scone, mentioned the fact that this is the stone on which British monarchs arc crowned, but did not mention the prophecy connected with it.

ABUNDANT flowering is the theme set for June by roses. Varieties of hybrid teas, polyanthas, floribundas, and hybrid perpetuals have about reached their peak. But more and better bloom will follow during summer if the simple procedure of keeping the bushes neat is carried out.

PHILADELPHIA -- The tens of thousands of tourists, convention delegates and others who visit Philadelphia this summer will find William Penn's "greene countrie towne" of 1682 in the midst of many changes, the foremost being:

AUDUBON, Pa. -- The numerous visitors to Valley Forge may be unaware of another historic shrine just opened to the public at Wetherill Corners, three miles by road from Washington's Headquarters in the national park.

Citizens of Laredo, Tex., looked out of their windows last week and saw only a river bed where the Rio Grande ought to be. Since Laredo gets its drinking water from this stream, the situation was and is serious. Essentially, however, it is not entirely new. The Rio Grande is a stream of great variety and many whims.
BALBOA, C. Z., June 6 -- A situation has developed at the Panama Canal that informed observers regard as threatening to demoralize its force of United States citizen workers.
