WASHINGTON, June 6 -- President Eisenhower and his White House aides have yet to indicate whether they favor the establishment by law of a permanent "bipartisan" Federal Agricultural Advisory Commission with power to review the policies and administration of farm programs.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., June 6 (UP) -- The directors of the Hot Springs Bathers baseball club announced today they probably would make another attempt to play two Negro pitchers following a ruling by George M. Trautman, president of the minor baseball leagues.

AS a photographer "you move about like a blotter and soak up everything that interests you, shaping up your pictures from the unfolding reality," Dan Weiner told the Village Camera Club audience last week during his judging of the club's picture story contest.

NAPLES, Italy, June 6 -- In many southern Italian cities, including Naples, the Monarchists have built a political machine that is far outstripping that of any other party in an all-out attempt to have a voice in the formation of the next Government.

Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, atom spies condemned to die on June 18, petitioned for a new trial yesterday on the ground that David Greenglass, a principal witness against them, had stolen uranium from Los Alamos, N. M.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UP) -- Members of the House Un-American Activities Committee today assured Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of an early hearing to answer charges that he had served the Communist front. They hoped to arrange the session before the end of the month.

FOR its final week at the City Center, the New York City Ballet has added a surprise premiere to the four already presented. This is Lew Christensen's "Con Amore," set to three Rossini overtures, and inspired by nineteenth-century theatrical lithographs.

A dramatic tale of a nine-mile midnight ride in clothing hastily thrown over pajamas, a conspiratorial meeting in a care "at the other end of the bridge" and detailed instructions in the best d'Artagnan tradition emerged yesterday from, of all places, the Small Defense Plants Administration.

EVERYBODY in this citadel of celluloid make-believe is quite tax conscious these days. The big crusade to lift the 20 per cent Federal levy on theatre admissions appears to have faltered in Washington, so the producers and the theatre owners will have to struggle along a little longer before dividing up this desirable melon among themselves.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Representative Daniel A. Reed ended an effective one-man blocking action against extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act today upon receiving assurance of White House opposition to any Senate attempt to tack on a rider continuing the excess profits tax.

SOMEWHERE (I cannot place the reference now) Sir William Temple speaks of "a considerable person in Ireland" informing him that, when wolf-hunts were on and huntsmen sat waiting at night for the wolf to come out of wherever he was, the party was entertained by a storyteller.

UNUSUAL is the word for this new novel by Henry Myers, remembered for "The Utmost Island." A strange story with atavistic stimulation, Victorian drolleries and marvelous glimpses of a possible tomorrow, it will work an ancient mariner's spell on the imaginative mind.

LONG a student of world affairs, Stefan Possony has undertaken a full-length analysis of the Bolshevik concept of world revolution as a strategy of total force. His wide historical perspective and his keen insight into the nature of Soviet strategy and tactics make this a stimulating and useful study.

Cruiser racing in the metropolitan area is headed for its biggest and busiest summer, if the early season experiences of the New York Athletic Club's Yachting Department are any indication. Vice Commodore Vincent P. Cronin, who is chairman of the Block Island Race, has received thirty-four written requests for entry blanks.

The United States Chapter of the Second World War Veterans of the Polish Armed Forces in Exile held an organizational meeting yesterday in the Henry Hudson Hotel. Three hundred persons, representing 2,000 Poles in this country who fought under British command in the last war attended.

American eyes have been focusing anxiously on Korea for many days, now, as reports and rumors of truce negotiation went on. In all of the proposals and in the thinking and writing about them there has always been a general atmosphere of grave uncertainty.

WITH the hope that the motion picture camera will continue to play a significant role in furthering modern medical science, a medical film center was officially opened here last week as testimony that it already has.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 6 -- The main task of Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan, according to Oswald Pirow, former Minster of Defense in South Africa, is to bridge the gulf between the British and the Boers -- a gulf deeper today than at any stage since the Union in 1910. He said today that if Dr. Malan failed in this then his non-white segregation policy was doomed.

THERE is an Italian proverb: "All ships leak" -- and certainly the reader will agree with it if he follows the peregrinations of the broad-beamed, black-hulled ketch Bessie from Appledore on the Bristol Channel to Gibraltar, to Sardinia, to Famagusta on Cyprus.

PARIS, June 6 -- Whenever -- and it happens frequently enough -- a French Cabinet falls and the President of France is seeking to construct another, it is customarily said in the French press and it is repeated abroad that "France is without a Government."

A "Merchants of America-Hall of Fame" to immortalize outstanding American merchants whose contributions to the nation's economy rank with those of leaders in other fields is being established at the Merchandise Mart in Chicago.

IF the graduating college class of 1953 will square their mortar-boards and give me their undivided attention, there is a baccalaureate sermon which I have every good intention of getting off my chest. What am I doing on the rostrum? Well, for one thing, I just happened to be on the campus because this is my Twentieth Reunion. I was a member of the class of 1933.

Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Science degrees were awarded to 228 graduates yesterday afternoon at the sixty-eighth commencement of Wagner Lutheran College on Grymes Hill, S. I., at exercises on the campus.

WHO was killing the deer on Deer Mountain? When Fred and his friend Hank started to build a hut on the old sawmill site at the foot of the mountain, catching poachers was not their purpose. They wanted a hideaway to which they could escape from the village life that cramped their adventurous spirit.

ON these fine hot days Paris is such a spectacle itself that one hardly need visit museums and galleries to see what the French can offer in the way of visual pleasure. Nonetheless, these are crowded, given over to the judging of new names and old reputations; to showing pictures on which the paint is barely dry or Chinese pottery dating from two thousand years before Christ.

LOS ANGELES -- A major center of tourist interest in downtown Los Angeles, recreating on a large scale the picturesque atmosphere of the old Spanish and frontier days, will be developed in a $1,500,000 project which has received final enabling legislation.
Khaki and blue jeans invaded Steeplechase Park at Coney Island yesterday on the twentieth annual Brooklyn Girl Scout "playday."

FROM Havana comes word that, despite protests of transportation companies and travel agents and the openly expressed resentment of some tourists, there seems to be little likelihood that the Cuban Government will modify the $2.50 landing tax recently imposed on travelers arriving in Cuba.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- Florida is going to have a toll turnpike after all, but it will be a bob-tailed affair, running 110 miles from Stuart to Miami, instead of the 315-mile stretch originally proposed, from Jacksonville to Miami with a 128-mile leg from near Daytona Beach to the Tampa Bay area.

THE of wisdom of the prophets Israel is an essential part of three of the world's great monotheistic religions: Judaism, Mohammedanism and Christianity -- approximately one-half the human race. Through these prophets the biblical "God of Israel" was revealed as the God of all men, of all history.
DETROIT, June 6 (UP) -- Willard Nixon and Mel Parnell pitched the distance today as the Red Sox swept a double-header, 6 to 2 and 1 to 0, to extend the Tigers' losing streak to twelve games.

ROME, June 6 -- Pope Pius addressed today an encyclical letter to the Roman Catholic episcopacy throughout the world commemorating the 800th anniversary of the death of St. Bernard of Clairvaux, France. St. Bernard, who is known as "the mellifluous doctor," was the greatest reformer of monastic life in the twelfth century.

THE drama and intrigue, the emotional unrest and political strife that played so large a part in shaping the character and future conduct of England's first Queen Elizabeth have been skillfully captured in this novel by Jennette and Francis Letton.

Three friendly foreign countries -- Great Britain, Japan and Italy -- may learn this week whether their quest for fairly sizable tonnages of United States iron and steel scrap has won the necessary approval of the Department of Commerce.

Professor Pei's article, "Conquest of Babel" (May 24), makes an interesting and creative suggestion. The possibility, however, of setting in motion a mongrel universal language made up of English words clad in the uncouth garment of the Russian alphabet, seems to this correspondent rather chimerical. It would resemble one of those monstrous creations of antiquity, half human, half beast.

" FOR Tahiti . . . Steamer Araby, Captain Jarvis (freight only ) leaves Pier 45 at 3:30 P. M.," read the notice in the San Francisco shipping guide. But hours past her sailing time the old tramp steamer has not put to sea.

THE traveler approaching this surprising oasis in the mountain-ridged Nevada desert is confronted at dusk by a strange mirage that could pass for Broadway. Amid a palpitating sea of electric illumination, a procession of roadside bulletin boards spell out some of the brightest names in show business:

FROM the moment when "Guys and Dolls" became a smash hit on its native Broadway, managers in London have been eyeing it with a calculating and covetous but cautious gaze. "Shall I or shan't I?" they have been saying to themselves; "Will it or won't it?" And now that somebody has taken the plunge and the show is on at the Coliseum, the second problem remains unsolved: "Will it run or won't it?"

One of the colorful events for philanthropy during the coming week is the twenty-first annual Flower Mart for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association to be held Tuesday on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The fete will be opened at 10 A. M. and will continue until 6 P. M.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., June 6 -- Fred Dwyer, Villanova senior, who is the national indoor A. A. U. and I. C. 4-A champion at the mile, created a bit of a surprise this afternoon when he romped to victory in the eight-furlong scratch event that featured the 157th track and field games of the New York Athletic Club held at Travers Island.

Masters, Inc., the city's largest and most aggressive discount house, will carry its legal fight against the General Electric Company to the Supreme Court if necessary. Stephen Masters, president, said last week he would spare no trouble or expenses to affirm his right to sell any merchandise in his establishment at any prices he wished.

THE Ojai Valley, a snug, citrus-girt retreat eighty-five mile north of Los Angeles, recently wound up a spirited four days of playing host to the hundreds of pilgrims from adjacent coastal areas who converged upon it for the seventh annual Ojai Festival.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 5 -- A United States of Pakistan, born of disappointment with Britain's "indifference" to the young dominion's problems, is expected to be announced in August on the sixth anniversary of the country's creation by partition from India.

WE recall a novel that was once influential and that nobody much bothers about any more Huysmans "Against the Grain." Its protagonist was a chap who never went anywhere, vacation or no vacation. What he did was to take imaginary trips in a room tricked up to look like a ship.

SVENDBORG, Denmark -- If American tourists knew about Svendborg no doubt they would soon outnumber the British in this seaside resort, for Svendborg is a bargain town in a bargain country, where dollars stretch and stretch in a way that's been forgotten at home.

BONN, Germany, June 6 -- Eugene R. Black president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, told a press conference in Duesseldorf today that West Germany was sound enough economically to receive a dollar loan.

Leaders of all the major political parties will soon be forced by the timetable set in the election law to choose candidates and sides for New York City's mayoral election this fall. Petitions entering candidates for party nominations in the primary elections may be placed in circulation by June 30 and must be filed no later than Aug. 11.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Harold E. Stassen, Director for Mutual Security, declared tonight that the greatness of the United States would be tested in the next decade. He Said that the nation's strength "will be determined in a measurement of the quality of leadership of the American people as a whole, and of their representatives, in the world situation."
The Cloisters, the picturesque branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on the summit of Fort Tryon Park, will place a new collection of treasures on exhibition Tuesday.

A man with a long criminal record, wanted for feloniously assaulting a 65-year-old woman last month, was captured yesterday at 5:30 P. M. by the police after a Fifth Avenue chase in which two shots were fired by a detective.

LONDON, June 6 -- The latest information is that Prime Minister Churchill, President Eisenhower and the head of the French Government will meet in Bermuda on June 29. The talks among the leaders of the three major Western powers have been deferred until then to give the French time to form a new government.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, June 7 -- President Syngman Rhee called on the South Koreans today to continue the war against communism should the United Nations arrive at an armistice that failed to guarantee the security of the Republic against new aggression.

Summaries of a merchandising study of the securities market by Stewart, Dougall and Associates have been mailed to members of the New York Stock Exchange. The study recommends that the Exchange concentrate on a "market" of 21,000,000 family units as possible future shareholders.

SEVERAL times in "Blue Trout and Black Truffles," which was reviewed here a fortnight ago, Joseph Wechsberg remarks in passing that men of medicine now have stepped between certain foods and their excellent sauces and himself.

WHEN the Festival Theatre gave up the ghost in the summer of 1950, after putting on three of the four repertory plays it had planned, Terese Hayden, co-producer with Sam Wanamaker, did not sit around and sigh. On the contrary, the young Tennesseean, primarily identified with the Equity Library Theatre, rebounded from the Broadway rebuff with stunning self-assurance.
ATHENS, May 28 -- Until recently, most Greek people, small town-dwellers and villagers, had as their main source of enlightenment the self-generating gossip of the cafe and coffee house.

Richard Gaines, an eighth-grade student at St. Augustine's grammar school in the Bronx, broke a 27-year-old broad-jump record at the forty-seventh annual Catholic Schools Athletic League track and field championships at Van Cortlandt Park stadium yesterday.

NEW YORK'S wholesale fashion markets are bustling with activity. Fall openings have brought thousands of buyers to the city, each intent on determining the style trends, and seeking to stretch his available merchandise budgets to purchase the largest possible number of units, but not all at once.

PITTSBURGH, June 6 (AP) -- An eight-run rally in the ninth inning enabled the Redlegs to break a 7-7 tie today and beat the Pirates, 15 -- 7. The Redlegs' surge came after the Pirates had scored six runs in the last of the eighth to tie the score.

PROKOFIEFF'S "War and Peace" has at last had its Western premiere. The world has waited so expectantly for this, partly to see how so gigantic a project as setting the most famous novel in European literature would be realized.

" HE possesses every quality that could be desired to render me perfectly happy. He is so sensible, so kind, and so good and so amiable, too. He has, besides, the most pleasing and delightful exterior and appearance you can possibly see." Those words might have been written by the young Queen Elizabeth II about her consort, Philip, Duke of Edinburgh.

LONDON, June 6 -- It is a cliche for the free world to talk of the sphynx-like and enigmatic secret workings of Soviet policy and that forbidding fortress, the Kremlin. Surely Moscow must have been equally bewildered by events this week in London.

THE vacationing murder-fancier is apt to be especially grateful for the principal current trend in mystery novels -- the tendency of authors to write directly for paperbacks. These pocket editions are more portable and more accessible (when you're away from your rental library) than hard-cover books; and the general average of quality seems to run much the same as that of regular library books.

ROME, June 6 -- A palpable silence settled over Italy today as the torrents and rivers of oratory that had submerged the country for the last month and more were stilled as of midnight yesterday. Tomorrow, 30,413,247 registered voters will be called to the polls to elect a new Senate and Chamber of Deputies, and thus to decide what political parties and tendencies are to form Italian Governments for some years to come.

FRANKIE BAUMHOLTZ figures to age ten years in the next couple of months from the exhausting chores that now confront him. Baumholtz is the center fielder of the Chicago Cubs and the amount of territory he now has to cover would appall Joe DiMaggio in his prime. On one side of him in the Bruin outfield is Hank Sauer and on the other side is his newest team-mate, Ralph Kiner.
ACCORDING to Webster an "arboretum" is a "place where trees and shrubs are cultivated for scientific and educational purposes." The Arnold Arboretum, Jamaica Plain, Mass., is all of that -- and more.

If you want your child to get better marks in school, to behave better and study harder, get him a green chalkboard, a pastel rose wall pattern and a light blue background for his room with the southern exposure. Bright colors and pleasing classroom designs have a definite effect on the way your child behaves at school and the marks he gets, a team of psychologists at Johns Hopkins University announced last week.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 6 -- The Turkish Government has decided to exert strong efforts for the earliest possible integration of Yugoslavia into the European defense system. Leading policy-makers here believe quick action is necessary if the growing whispering campaign in the West against President Tito and a general slackening of Europe's rearmament are not to delay indefinitely a military link with Belgrade.

WHEN your critic writes that "The Grass Harp." "The Climate of Eden" and "Camino Real" are "the plays that are developing a new play form that is exciting in itself," can he have overlooked virtually all of Saroyan's works, including notably "My Heart's in the Highlands" and "The Time of Your Life," as well as Marc Connelly's "The Green Pastures," possibly "Outward Bound" and some others?

FLETCHER HENDERSON, who died last December, was one of the least flamboyant of the major figures in jazz. As arranger, pianist and leader, Henderson was a quiet, conscientious worker who often seemed overshadowed by the more expansive personalities of some of his associates.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., June 6 -- Quick action by Cecil M. Craft, veteran engineer for the Long Island Rail Road, in jamming on the emergency brakes and jumping from the engine last night was credited with saving the life of a 2-year-old boy playing on the tracks.

WHEN Mr. O'Hara, the proprietor of the general store in Hickory Limb, U. S. A., moved over to "hot air corner" behind the pot bellied stove, the boys in town knew he was going to tell a story. His wife, who worried about waiting customers, sometimes looked at him reprovingly but generally relented enough to hand out sweet crackers to his enraptured audience.

ANDOVER, Mass., June 6 -- The 175th anniversary of the founding of Phillips Academy here was celebrated today with an alumni luncheon attened by 1,400 and the announcement of a twenty-fifth year reunion gift of $10,303 from the Class of 1928.

The choice of a name has brought the peoples of the British Commonwealth into a new Elizabethan Age. Some part of the outpouring of emotion in Britain last week was no doubt due to the feeling that somehow, by the very syllables of that name, the charming young wife and mother who now wears the British crown would bring luck.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., June 6 (UP) -- An explosion ripped through an Imperial Fireworks Companyl building near here today, killing the owner and one worker. Another elploye was injurecL The police identified the dead as Albert Ben-I jamin of Schenectady, the omer, and Anthony Sisario of Amster-, darn. The explosion leveled the onestory cement block building and blew out windows in surrounding

SYRACUSE, June 6 -- Carmen Basilio of Canastota, N. Y., won the newly created New York State welterweight championship tonight with an upset twelve-round decision over Billy Graham before a record central New York crowd of 9,244 in Memorial Stadium.

As a great-granddaughter of John A. Roebling, I enjoyed Harry Gilroy's "It's Art, Poetry -- and a Way to Brooklyn" (May 24). I wonder how many other members of the Roebling family will call to your attention the fact that you used a picture of Col. Washington Roebling's second wife, not one of Emily Warren Roebling who "saw the dream through"?

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 6 (AP) -- A British telegraph ship hired by the Swedish State Power Board starts tomorrow laying out the world's longest submarine cable for high voltage transmission between the Swedish mainland and the island of Gotland in the Baltic.

CAIRO, June 6 -- A high Egyptian source predicted today that diplomatic activity seeking resolution of the deadlocked British-Egyptian dispute over the Suez Canal zone would be resumed "within the next few days."

ONE segment of Hollywood that is rubbing its hands with particular relish at the advent of three-dimensional cinematography is a group of specialists whose artifices moviegoers are seldom aware of: the men who make the opening title sections of films.
Last week's meetings at Panmunjom seemed to promise a truce in Korea.

CHOICE seeds and delectable suet during winter, comfortable nesting boxes in spring, delightful bird baths in summer are a few of the attractions offered birds in the hope of keeping them in or around gardens. But having lured birds, some home owners end up seeking advice on legal and humanitarian ways of discouraging the feathered flocks.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Republican Congressional leaders have now developed, five months and three days after the beginning of this session, a system of party leadership that in its technical aspects at least is entitled to the word impressive.
CLEVELAND, June 6 -- Freighters flying the French flag are plying Lake Erie for the first time in more than 100 years, representatives of the Fabre Line disclosed today.

The general elections which take place today and tomorrow in Italy deserve the closest attention from Americans, for they are important to the free world. There seems to be no danger now, as there was at the time of the last general election in April, 1948, of the Reds and fellow-traveling Nenni Socialites obtaining an absolute majority and setting up a Communist Government.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 6 -- Two important additions to the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration will be dedicated here on Friday. They are Aldrich Hall, a new classroom building, and Kresge Hall, a dining hall and student lounge.

Buying increased in the wholesale markets here last week as many buyers arrived to prepare for the fall season, according to Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Values appeared to be better than last year and orders were placed in substantial quantity.

Brooklyn College's twenty-eighth commencement exercises will be conducted next Sunday at 5 P. M. on the college quadrangle. Degrees, diplomas and certificates will be awarded to 1,950 candidates by Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of the college, who will preside.

ONE winter night as I sat planning my trip to Europe and browsing over the map of England, I discovered near the famous city of Salisbury, the name of my own Connecticut town, Wilton. Said I to myself, "Wouldn't it be pleasant to visit Wilton in England! There must be something there besides carpets."

PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., June 6 -- In one of the smoothest starts in the history of the race, thirty-seven craft sailed in the New York Yacht Club's annual two-day test for "bluewater" boats from Mattinicock Point to Port Jefferson today.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 6 -- This city is involved in a controversy over whether to put identifying stamps on public library books written by persons accused of affiliation with subversive organizations.

Several unfavorable factors combined to mar the showing of the district's department stores last week. The weather was not as favorable in the week as a year before; the average was five or six degrees lower, which served to stop buyers of summer and vacation apparel from shopping.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Proponents of reduced costs in Government and a balanced Federal budget demonstrated this week in the Middle West and the areas bordering on the Great Lakes that it is sometimes simpler to advocate economy than to achieve it.

AS an undergraduate student of Russian, I was impressed, on the one hand, by the ease with which the Cyrillic alphabet and its pronunciation were penetrated and, on the other, by the tortuous complexities of Russian grammar.

I HAVE observed * * * that in his attitude toward food the American reveals significant aspects of his character. The endemic waste, the exclusive reliance upon the grocer and the butcher for all his culinary needs, the obliviousness to what grows freely in the environment -- do not these reflect his indifference to frugality as a virtue, and his subservience to what I have called the quantitative fallacy?

May I comment briefly on the statement by the Rev. Edwin T. Dahlberg, recently published in your news columns, to the effect that the Christian foreign mission enterprise is "the greatest peace movement in the world today."

ROBERT ROSSEN, producer-director of the Academy Award - winning "All the King's Men," who recently squared his disputed loyalty status by testifying as a cooperative witness before the House Un-American Activities Committee hearings here, is about to resume independent production with "Fame," a script he has just completed in collaboration with Jerome Weidman, the scenarist-novelist.

CONTROLLING weeds around the home used to mean spending lots of time uprooting them with a knife, hoe or cultivator. Such methods still have a definite place in the home garden, but today there is a host of aids in the form of chemical weedkillers to expedite the job. Their judicious use takes much of the backache out of gardening and leaves more time for leisure.
The dominant question in the minds of golfers almost everywhere this week will be "Can Ben Hogan win the United states open championship again ?"

STAMFORD, Conn., June 6 -- Whenever the fire-fighting equipment raced through his neighborhood, a little boy used to take off after it as fast as his legs could carry him. This proved to be both good and bad -- bad because his mother, Mrs. Veit, whaled him for it, and good because the impulse was natural.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 6 -- The scientific brains of Israel have been mobilized by a $410,000 Ford Foundation grant for the solution of the basic problems of food production in an arid land, of health in the semi-tropics and of the adjustment of immigrants drawn from diverse cultures.

Your editorial on the election of Dr. Rufus E. Clement to public office in the city of Atlanta should recall the memory of Emma Clarissa Clement, mother of Dr. Rufus Clement and of six other children, each of whom is a person of high education and distinction, holding a responsible place in the community.

Police vigilance was credited yesterday with having prevented -- or at least postponed -- two teenage gang skirmishes in Brooklyn and the Bronx. Seventeen youths were arrested and large quantities of home-made ammunition seized.
After the recent foreign policy speech of Sir Winston Churchill the world knows that there is substantial disagreement in the West as to the policy to adopt toward the new Kremlin leadership.

MOSCOW, June 6 -- Western diplomats in Moscow expressed the opinion today that if an armistice were signed in Korea the prospects for a high-level meeting this summer between representatives of East and West would be substantially enhanced.

CLEVELAND, June 6 (UP) -- Mike Garcia hurled his first shut-out of the season today and scored his sixth victory as he downed the Athletics, 2 to 0, for Cleveland's seventh victory in nine games. The start of the contest was delayed forty-five minutes by a cloudburst.

JUNE is traditionally the month of roses. The difficultly is, however, that while "a rose is a rose," there are so many different kinds that the rank amateur is bound to be confused -- if not dismayed.

THE logical commercial airline route between the western part of the United States and Western Europe, in the opinion of men who should know from recent experience, is the Great Circle course that takes planes over the wastes of northern Canada, lower Greenland and the North Atlantic.
BALTIMORE, June 6 (AP) -- The South came within one game of squaring the series with a 12-9 victory today in the twelfth North-South all-star lacrosse game at Homewood Field.

HARDLY anything on earth, it would seem, needs a boost less than the Eiffel Tower -- which hasn't prevented the company which runs it from offering an automobile to its twenty-five millionth visitor since 1889, when it was opened.

Some 16,000 physicians attended last week's annual meeting of the American Medical Association. Ballrooms and other meeting places in seven hotels had to be used for the scientific sessions. It cannot be said that these scientific sessions were invariably distinguished by the presentation of new information.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 6 -- A portrait of Jonathan Belcher, who was largely responsible for making this community the permanent site of Princeton University, was placed on display today in the Harvey S. Firestone Memorial Library.
THE question is, "What are the books to take along, to make the most of a trip somewhere in the United States?"

AS the author reminds us on the first page of this carefully planned and well organized little book, the best way to learn to sail is to go out with someone who knows how, but a practical introduction like this is also helpful to the beginner.

READING, Pa., June 6 (UP) -- Betsy Rawls soared to a five-over-par 77 today, but a backlog of par-busting rounds enabled her to retain leadership in the Eastern women's open golf tournament at the three-quarter mark with an almost insurmountable eight-stroke lead.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., June 6 (AP) -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Democrat of New York, said tonight he had learned that the House Un-American Activities Committee plans to investigate Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, United Nations official and Nobel Peace Prize winner.

With private pension and profit-sharing plans at a record high level, the need for basing policy decisions on sound tax procedures and avoiding tax pitfalls becomes increasingly important, a pension authority advises.

FOR five and a half years a writer named Robert Howard Lindsay has maintained a rigorous schedule in adapting stage plays and making them fit into the hour-long "Kraft Television Theatre" (N. B. C., Wednesdays, 9 P. M.).
The Board of Education is preparing a new program to coordinate all services necessary to educate physically handicapped children. The plan is based on two years of research.

WHILE mountain laurel grows wild from New Brunswick to Florida and as far west as Ohio, it has been officially adopted by Connecticut and Pennsylvania as their state flower. Any autoist who travels routes U. S. 44, 8, 20 or allied byways in lower Connecticut this week will find ample justification for its adoption by that state.

After a two-week vacation, the N. B. C. Summer Symphony returned to the air late yesterday afternoon and resumed its hour-long Saturday broadcasts from the Belasco Theatre. There was a capacity audience in the theatre, and the program was broadcast on a coast-to-coast network.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 6 -- Yale, behind the five-hit pitching of Bob Davis, today defeated Princeton, 2 -- 1, at Yale Field to continue the spurt that has made it one of the most formidable college nines in the East.

ROSES by the score and in infinite variety once again eclipse all other garden flowers in June. The peak in this part of the country is expected during the coming week, and many festivities are planned for the occasion.

COMPTON, Calif., June 6 -- A new world shot-put record and new American and Finnish mile marks were the chief topics in track circles today as a result of the performances of Parry O'Brien, Wes Santee and Denis Johansson in the fourteenth Compton invitation meet.

SUMMIT, N. J., June 6 -- Annie Laurie, a brown mare, was guided by her owner, Miss Nicky Tully of Summit, N. J., to the junior championship of the twenty-seventh annual Watchung Riding and Driving Club today.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 6 -- There was a popular belief after President Eisenhower signed the offshore oil bill last month that there would be a quick acceleration of oil activity in the Gulf of Mexico. The new law gives the states title to submerged lands off their coasts within historic boundaries.

ALICIA MARKOVA added another major conquest to her list last month when she appeared as guest star with the Ballet Theatre in its three-week engagement at the Palais de Chaillot in Paris. She had not been seen there since just before World War II, when the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, which she had newly joined, scuttled out of Europe on the very eve of the conflagration.
